reviews.review: Exquisite!. I loved this museum because of the size and focus of the pieces contained within. Monet's Water Lilies were my main reason for going but the collection downstairs including Picasso, Renoir, Matisse and many others was a delight!
Lovely. Impressionists abound in this museum. Two floors of art makes for a delightful and friendly place to visit.

Small but still amazing!. This museum was surprisingly small but still high quality and definately worth the visit.
The uniquely large and curved Monet paintings make the entire visit worthwhile!

Well worht a visit. If you are looking for a short activity, this is the one. WE loved the building and seeing Monet's works. We found it easy to find using the metro and enjoyed a long walk back to our hotel along the river.

Surprise bonus. What more can be said about Monet's masterpiece in its custom created settings? Glorious! We had a surprise bonus in seeing famous art dealer Guillame's collection of 1870-1930 art AND a French curated display of US Depression Era art- which certainly gave me a fresh viewpoint.
for Monet lovers. Small museum not to be missed if you like impressionist art. The ground level is all Monet watercolors, but be sure and visit the lower level.

Want a quiet spot to meditate?. I always thought the water lilies were light in color and they were much darker than any print I had ever seen. If you need to settle and collect your thoughts or meditate this is the place to come.

The Water Lillies. After a lovely walk through the Jardin du Tulleries we spent some time looking at the lovely Water Lillies of Van Gough - a relaxing place to sit for a moment and enjoy the beautiful colours 💐

Monet under natural lighting. The Orangerie is available as a combined ticket with the Orsay and represents one of two not to be missed museums. Fans of Monet will marvel at the panoramic installation of large panels in two rooms that are viewed under natural light. The detail is stunning.

One of the most lovely galleries ever devised!. The gallery is so beautiful and the Water Lily's are so absolutely breath taking it is easy to overlook the fantastic collection of Impressionist art downstairs. I ran straight up the ramp to the Monet masterpieces, but my tip would be to start downstairs, then go up to the two galleries. We went for a re-visit and sat down with the Lily paintings. It was crowded, but there were moments when the crowds parted and you feel some alone time in both rooms. Monet was lucky he got to design how his masterpieces would be displayed and they look magnificent! Do not miss downstairs though. Talk about right time and place for getting into art dealing.

Not worth the price of admission. The coolest thing to see here at the Waterlilies, spread out across several rooms with perfect lighting. This museum is very small, worth a quick stop of ~1 hour if you have a museum pass but otherwise skip it in favor of larger collections where you get more bang for your buck.
Wonderful. Simply Stunning. Take your time. Read some literature before arriving. Friendly security and cloakroom workers.

Not convinced this is one of the 'greats'. If you are on a brief visit to Paris I think there are better places to visit. The building itself is interesting turning a rectangle into an oval - but personally I was not enraptured by the art. Perhaps we have just been over-exposed to the water lilies? Took a stroll in the Tuileries and an early lunch!

Worthwhile if you have a museum pass. A small but lovely collection. It only required about 30 - 40 minutes to see all of the artwork in the museum. I'd recommend L'Orangerie if you have a museum pass that includes this admission and have the time for a short visit.

Excellent collection. This is a fantastic museum for a couple of hours, meaning that you can fit other activities in your day. Starting from the basement floor, the collection covers a range of artists from the turn of the 20th century, before leading visitors to the iconic water lilies. Delightfully cogent and well curated.

Worthwhile on the Paris museum pass. We did this after the Louvre as it is located at the west end of the Jardin des Tuileries. You can see la Tour Eiffel from the patio of L'orangerie. The museum itself was a former greenhouse. Plan your visits to all major museums so that you don't plan to visit on a day when they are closed. This one is closed on Mondays, January 5, July 14 and December 25. Regular hours are 9h-18h. Métro is Concorde.All bags will be searched. To save yourself trouble, keep the size of the bags small and don't bring any sharp objects.Photos without flash are permitted. Reservations are mandatory for groups.

Very pleasant museum. I did enjoy this museum much more better than Louvre. There were no queues and place was not so overcrowded as Parisian bigger art museums. I would recommend visiting Orangerie in the morning. There is really lot to see - huge Monet "Nymphae" canvas, Renoir, Utrillo, Derain and many more.

Stunning!. I remembered this museum from a trip taken in the 80 s. As a lover of the Impressionists, this is a wonderful museum to vist. The murals done by Monet and placed here by him are bathed in soft diffused light are unlike anything we have here at the Met in NY. Absolutely worth a visit!!

Restful. I came here just to see the large Monet waterlily paintings. There may have been other paintings there, but I did not have the energy to see anything else. Having only finished 6 months of cancer treatment a few weeks prior, I enjoyed the opportunity to just sit and admire the amazing canvases. It wasn't too busy either which was a bonus.
Breathtaking. So glad we went to see this. The Waterlilies alone are worth the price of admission. Paul Guillaume exhibit was the icing on the cake.

Small and Perfect. This is such an easy gallery to relax in, and to enjoy the paintings without the huge crowds at the Louvre. This is so much more peaceful and it's easy to see everything at a lleisurely pace in beautiful surroundings. It was lovely to know that the rooms for Monet's water lilies were constructed exactly as he requested. He was right.
Amazing. Go early and spend some time admiring some of the great impressionist works, particularly Monet's huge canvases. This is a small museum but well worth the effort.

Great special Paul Guillaume exhibit. The Guillaume collection of impressionist artists is totally amazing and not to be missed. To see this great group of famous works in one location is something special. The "Monet " great water lillies is also at this location.

Just fantastic . We bought the two Musee pass for D' Orsay and here for just 4 euro more than D' Orsay alone. What a fantastic place.The magic Monet pieces that fill the walls upstairs are breathtaking and well worth a visit alone.I was further surprised but the other great collections downstairs, mostly of impressionists. The size of the Musee was not large and a perfect compliment to the D'Orsay collection.If you only like art, you will love it after visiting here.Not to be missed

My favorite museum ever. Not only are the Monet Waterlilies breathtakingly lovely and worth sitting and experiencing for quite a while, but also the Water-Guillam collection of Renoir, Cezanne,Rousseau, Modigliani, Picasso etc. absolutely awe inspiring. This is a MUST museum for anyone who like impressionist art. I liked it better than the Louve.

Very nice paintings. There were some very nice paintings which I enjoyed looking at, some werent so nice but thats down to my own preferences. Was a bit pricey to get in considering there wasnt much to see in there.
Very special. It is really a must visit in Paris if you are a Claud Monet fan. The water lilie paintings are just too special to miss
Quietly lovely. It is truly peaceful and breathtaking. Awesome. Make sure you don't miss it. Especially if you love Monet.

The water Lillies are a cultural must. See them! Very special experience. No paintings in the world like that. The rest of the exhibition is also good and contains some of the most important painters.

Beautiful small museum. Loved the museum, although small in comparison the other museums, it was quite busy when we visited. Lots of people visiting Monets Water Lilly panels.The area was designed for people to sit and look at the panels, however with the number of visitors this is not possible as people stand up close to take photos and ignore the people sitting on the seats trying to view the panels. There is a lift to the other floors and collection in the Museum for those with difficulty managing stairs. There is also a cafe and souvenir shop on the lower level. Many beautiful paintings by Renoir, Monet, Picasso and a number of painters are displayed on the lower floor. Nice area with seating,to sit outside the building and have a picnic .

My favorite museum in Paris. I had not been back to this museum since the remodel. It was excellent. I bought tickets on line in advance (Parisinfo.com) and picked them up at Paris Info on Blvd des Pyramides (not far from the Louvre). This gives you priority entry. It did not matter much, I went on a Friday afternoon and just about had the place to myself. This museum was some fabulous Impressionist paintings, without the super crowds of the Musee d'Oursay (yes, I went there too, but the crowds give me a headache). I highly recommend this museum. Since it is small it can be done in a short period of time (or longer if you choose). It is located in the Tulleries so it is a great walk to and from the museum.

So impressive. Although much smaller than the Musee d'Orsay, the Orangerie is a must visit. Just the massive Monet Waterlilies makes it worth it. Peaceful and serene you feel transported to Monet's gardens where they were painted. Also an impressive collection of other Impressionist works.
More like a gallery. For all the musee fobic, the orangerie is a lovely gallery and exhibition of all the most important peinturs of the history art .

Monet's Waterlilies in the setting he designed for them. Fantastic, compact but spectacular museum. Monet's waterlilies upstairs and a dynamite collection of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist and Expressionist art downstairs. Don't miss it.

A chance to see and learn about classic artists without feeling overwhelmed.. Our time in Paris was limited to seven days. We spoke with fellow travellers about what we should see. This was one of the recommendations and it was a good one. We did the audio tour of the paintings and found it to be very informative without being overwhelming. It took us about three hours to see the art and learn more about the artists. Although we were tired when we left, we were glad that we had made this visit a priority. The only downside was the staff letting people take pictures and pose for selfies. Give this place a try. We believe you will be glad you did.

Monet Nympheas. Money's Water Lilies are overwhelming even if you have seen them before, well worth doing before visiting Given if that is on your itinerary. Don't forget the rest of the museum though, it is amazing as well.
Magic!. Monet donated his beautiful tableaus of water lilies to delight everyone. The two rooms are an oasis of beauty within a city filled with such treats.

A walk in the park with culture. Take a lovely stroll through the gardens and see some fantastic art as well. This is one of my favourite places as the gallery is not too large and overwhelming. Grab a baguette for lunch in the gardens afterwards. A great day out.
A MUST for Monet lovers. You must make this part of your visit if you are a Monet fan...just over the top in scale...LOVE the museum!

Worth the short walk over from the Louvre to see the Monets.. It's a very beautiful museum with a contemporary feel, not far from the Louvre. Honestly, I was expecting more. I don't know if they rotate their Monet exhibit/collection, but I was a bit disappointed, if that's even possible, when viewing Monet. I'm glad I went, but not sure I would return.

Visit to see the Monet Waterlillies. This museum is at the edge of the Tuileries gardens near the Place de la Concorde. We purchased a combination ticket online that allowed admission to both the Orsay and Orangerie museums. This museum is rather a small one but the highlight is the huge Monet paintings of his favourite subject, Waterlillies. The large paintings (probably ten to twelve feet wide) are displayed in an two oval rooms, with four paintings in each room forming a virtual panorama of waterlilly paintings in each room.
Beautiful museum. If you love Monet and other impressionists, you will love this museum. Take your time an enjoy all the beautiful art and stop in the very cute gift shop.
Simply Outstanding!!!!. This small Museum was always on our bucket list and it did not disappoint! The Monet collection was truly spectacular to behold! If you've not seen it ... go!!
Small museum but worth a visit. Although this is a small museum it was worth a short visit to see Claude Monet Water Lilies, in the round.

Worth it! . First museum I've seen in Paris, and didn't regret it. Famous paintings from Renoir, Picasso, and more, and the nymphéas from Monet as big and heartbreaking as it supposed to be. The opportunity is there to make peace with the nymphéas and gives it back its meaning lost from the multiples cheezy reproductions you can see everywhere today.
One of my favorite museums. I found this small but impressive collections of fine art to be one of my favorites because I could enjoy each and every one!
Monet anyone???. This is a gorgeous setting to house the famous waterlily paintings. A visit to Paris is not complete without seeing them.

Worth it to see the Water Lillies collection. The Monet Water Lilies collection (which take up two decent size rooms) are definitely worth the price of admission. Do the Louve and the Orsay first and then put this on your list to visit.

Worth a Visit. For the Monet galleries alone, this is worth the visit. These paintings and the rooms in which they're housed are a memorable experience for any art lover.The galleries in the lower part of the museum were less impressive, in that we are accustomed to a more curated style of presentation. The collection felt jumbled together, and we missed some pieces thanks to odd placement on the gallery walls.

Awesome. I loved this museum and was totally blown away by the size of the paintings, totally unexpected, they are huge and beautiful. I thoroughly recommend a visit even for a short time but it's difficult to just look and leave, take time and enjoy the tranquility.

Exquisite. The museum (sadly hard to find the entrance due to Fashion Week) is a repository of great Impressionist art. Outside stands the bronze Rodin's The Kiss. Inside is the art we went to see. Monet's Waterlillies. These huge paintings occupy two roooms designed by Monet especially to house these masterpieces. The experience was literally mind blowing. I have never seen such a collection of genius from one artist in one place. Truly staggering beauty and artistic accomplishment. Suggest seeing Giverny first and the Orangerie second as we did.
A must see. If you are into Monet art, you must go here. The layout of the water lily paintings is really amazing and one that should be seen.

For Monet affionados. The canvases are amazingly large & interesting both up close and viewed from a distance. The collection in the basement is well worth seeing, especially The Renoir paintings made late in his career.
Fabulous . There are 2 rooms that have the Monet's water lilies paintings that take up the whole wall. I've never seen anything like it before. It's worth the price of admission to see that.
Water lilies and much more. A must see every time we visit Paris. Get there early. Crowds not as crazy as at Musee d'Orsay. Bundle tickets with d'Orsay.

The best museum in paris. Much smaller than the Louvre but far more pleasant because the crowds are behaved and do not wield selfie sticks. If you at like Monet, you will be blown away. There is also a wonderful connection of Renoir, Picasso and others.
Sublime. A few words won't prepare you for the wondrous feeling as you walk into the specially designed rooms that feature Monet's Water Lillies. So just go, sit down and marvel.

Best Monet water lily experience. One of my favourite galleries in Paris expecially if you love Monet's water lilies. There are two whole rooms dedicated to Monet's water lillies and you can sit in the middle of the room and feel like you are in his garden in Giverny. It is a rather small gallery and very accessible - definitely worth putting on your Paris itinerary!
this one should be ticked off the list. L'orangerie must be visit . the Monet art lovers will enjoy this visit . Best to be early and avoid the bulk of visitors

More Than Monet. It was a spur of the moment decision to visit the museum as my husband and I strolled along the Seine. There was no line up to speak of and we were able to take our time with the grand Monet canvasses. We sat on the benches in the centre of the room and waited for the moving crowds to allow for the view. My husband takes photos but I do not when viewing art unless it is a piece of art that I would not likely find easily online. I do find the constant picture taking so disturbing to the nature and intent of this art installation. Some of my discontent is likely borne of the approach I take to viewing art but most of the people I saw walked up close and took a photo and walked away. But they paid the same as I did and they can do as they please. I did appreciate when the guards would call for silence but some guards made more of an effort than others to keep the noise level down. The art on the lower floor is a nice bonus and allows for a look at art that is less often seen in an intimate space. But again that same intimacy can cause a problem. There was a tour guide who would take over the space in front of an art work and although she had a microphone and her poor followers had ear pieces she could be heard throughout the room. All well and good if she were any good but I had to bite me tongue not to leap to the defense of an artist when she made grave errors and kept inserting her opinions, which held no merit for me. She must rely on the people who pay for her time not being well versed enough to catch her mistakes and rank her opinions. I did wonder why a museum would allow a tour guide to disrupt the enjoyment of other visitors but she may have been one of their own. While some changes would improve the visitor experience this is a nice small museum for those who are reluctant to invest a long day looking at images until their eyes blur.
Beautiful & peaceful. Really beautiful, definitely if in Paris it has to be on the travel list. Amazing to see the paintings presented together and just beautiful!

Huge waterlily paintings designed for the location. Another nice art museum in Paris! This museum contains these huge paintings of waterlilies by Monet, which were specifically designed and painted in this location. It is a very relaxing place to be. There are other artists in the basement. Definitely a nice place to visit.

Really fab small museum good stuff, wee shop and cafe.. Good museum some great treasures fine for short high quality visit. Not everyone has long attention spans!
Lilies from dawn 'til dusk......

Favorite Paris Museum. You will not believe the peaceful, wondrous way that Monet's water lilies are displayed here. This place is quiet and serene! Then, on the lower level, you will find a thrilling display of the collection of Paul Guillaume, who was very active in the arts scene in Paris in the early 1900s. This, too, is a fabulous, delightfully diverse collection of art... much different from the Monet exhibit, but terrific in a different way. Do not miss this museum.

Monet's Nympheas are unmissable. If you do nothing else in Paris visit the Orangerie to see these wonderful works of art. Only 9 Euros for adults entry. Pleasure tempered only by tourists taking selfies in front of the pictures.
Monet, Monet, Monet!. See the waterlily paintings in the oval room, then travel to Giverney and see the garden in real life!

A small but AMAZING museum. The Musee is quite small, but it is a home of many famous pictures by Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir and of course Monet. For young people it's free so that is another reason to visit the museum.

If it's on your way fine but don't go out to see it. This is not something I would pay to see or go out of the way to see. It is a quick stop at best in your way between things. Far better places to spend your time

If you like Monet, yes! If not, eehhh.... The top floor consists of two rooms with a handful of huge Monet water lily paintings. The downstairs has some nice pieces (non-Monet), but it's a darn small museum. Easy to get in and visit, but you won't spend much time there...

Simply Heavenly!. If you're a lover of the Impressionists, visit the Orangerie and you'll think you've died and woken up in heaven. Go to the lower level, take a deep breath and prepare to be overwhelmed by Monet's Water Lilies. We went on a Saturday morning and the museum was not crowded. Unless you're going to sit and stare at the Water Lilies for a long time, expect to spend 1 1/2 to 2 hours here.

Monet at his finest. Two rooms with 360 degree wall murals of his lovely water lilies. there are benches to sit on in the middle of the room where you can sit, relax and absorb the beauty and genius of this amazing artist.
Monet is lovely. Monet's 8 panal water lilies was much more impressive than any of his smaller works of art. Does not take long but worth the time to see.

Small but you only came here for the water lilies. There is only one reason to come here and it's to see Monet's water lilies (occasional exhibits downstairs can be interesting).
Favorite panel: latter half of the right-side panel (facing in from the entrance) of the first room.

Very Good Art Museum Close to Louvre. This art museum is often overlooked but in plain sight. It has many famous paintings which are the highlights. The Claude Monet paintings are the main features. A very good good museum for true paint art lovers. The cost is minimal wth easy access from the Metro or bus system. This is not a good attraction choice for young or teen aged children who are not indoctrinated to the art world. It is handicap friendly.

Monet Monet!. Impressionism at its finest. If you like Monet, this is a must see museum. Two rooms with four paintings in each. Doesn't sound impressive but those four paintings surround the entire room. You become encircled with Monet! How cool is that? There's a great collection downstairs from a handful of other wonderful impressionist artists with in depth information about each individual as well. This museum is truly a unique experience that I'm so thankful I got the chance to see.

A beautiful small museum. We both loved the Musee de l'Orangerie. They had very nice auxiliary exhibits with many great impressionist paintings in the other rooms. The stars of the show however were the Monet Waterlilies. It's hard to believe he was 80 years old when he did these. They are presented nicely in 2 rooms and you have plenty of time to absorb the beauty of them. After our first visit there I don't believe that any trip to Paris would be complete without another visit there.

Magnifique. This museum is loaded with the work of famous painters, Monet was one of them. The impressionists to name the few.... You must go visit this and I guarantee, you will lost between the beautiful collections!

Best thing to do in Paris. I love Money and these paintings are some of his finest. But theres also some other great impressionist paintings. One can also sit down to contemplate them and can take pictures!
Surprise in small size. A small museum and an amazing experience. Forget Louvre and even Musee d'Orsay this one is pure joy, not trying to fit everything in.

Monet's Waterlily frescoes. If you are not wanting to spend too much time visiting art galleries in Paris, then I highly recommend the Musee de l-Orangerie as it gives you a taste of the impressionists without being overwhelmed. We enjoyed the Monet waterlily frescoes immensely.

Monet Must!. You need to see Water Lilies the way Monet wanted you to see them. Room and rooms full of Monet's masterpiece... Wow! This is a must see. The museum isn't intimidating and can be crossed off the Paris sight seeing list quite quickly. Our kids were impressed!
Small Museum. Quite a small museum which was unexpected but enjoyed the visit. If you are a Monet fan and/or if you have spare few hours left in Paris then it is worth visiting.

In some ways better than the Louvre. I loved this place, the great expanse in the middle, gorgeous building, big time artists. If you want to go upstairs and work your way down come in the front doors and go all the way to the back, there you will find escalators up, otherwise you'll have to walk up 5 flights . D'Orsay closed down 1/2 the museum when I was there without any notice, apology or refund. Go on the rooftop for the million dollar view.

there are water lilies and then there are THESE water lilies. Wow! A life list two-fer on a recent visit to Paris was visiting Monet's Giverny and on another day spending the late afternoon hours at the Musee de l'Orangerie. There you find the creme de la creme of his water lilies series: eight canvases nearly 100 meters in total length and displayed with all the TLC possible for the artist's personal gift to the French nation. Portions of Monet's water lilies series are on display in museums around the world, but this is the Holy Grail.

Monet's Triumph . This is a relatively uncrowned museum across the Seine from the Orsay, accessible by a foot bridge. The main attraction is the Monet water lilies canvases spread over two rooms. See these rooms and then walk downstairs to see more masterpieces. Your visit should take about one hour to complete.
Monet's Water lilies are worth seeing. Monet's masterpieces are displayed in two magnificent oval rooms. Such a great feeling being in the presence of such beautiful artwork!

Small museum big Monet's. If you love Monet this is one museum you must see. Two large rooms filled with giant canvases. You can sit and disappear into the works of art. Downstairs houses some paintings by Auguste Renoir, Paul Cézanne, Paul Gauguin among others. This is a nice sized museum. Not so big that you'll get lost in it. You can easily enjoy all the art and not feel overwhelmed. Great little gift shop too.
Not that great, but the Monet 360 Waterlillies are nice!. Enjoy the 360 degree view in the round room with Monet's waterlillies, but the rest of the museum is not that exciting.

A Monet fan must. One of the most beautiful museums for Claude Monet's water lilies. Stunning infinity design with 17' panels. A must for anyone who likes Monet. There is also a good permanent collection of others artists in the museum as well as temporary exhibits.

If you are at the stage of being over art galleries then this is the gallery for you . Monet's works are displayed in a magnificent light filled room which was purpose built to show his work. It is a Peaceful and reflective room.

Beautiful display. Afternoon crowds definitely take away from the experience, but beautiful nonetheless. Good audio guide. Small but good gift shop. Was definitely great to see the installation before our visit to Giverny, Monet's property.
Surprising Favorite. The Water Lilies are amazing as expected. What wasn't was the depth of the collection downstairs. Monet and Cezanne each represented with dozens of works

Exquisite!. Beautiful exhibit not to be missed if you are a Monet fan, but several artists represented. We were very impressed by the excellent video that described the history of the Water Lily exhibit. Its not highly promoted, so look for the auditorium if you go. We had limited time in Paris and are so glad we prioritized this museum.

A great Find - Amazing!. The rooms designed by Monet for his Water Lily series are breathtaking. The Museum is relatively small which makes it much less overwhelming - you come away feeling very satisfied. Nice terrace with views of the Eiffel tower etc.

If you love Monet. Monet's Water Lilies as you've never seen them. Framed on the circular walls, you are able to see the vision Monet had when he painted these unforgettable panels. Allow yourself some time to just enjoy the colors, the subtle nuances in the paintings.
This is a must. We have visited before but the Monet water lillies always draw us back. However we were really annoyed this time by the number of people taking selfies in front of the paintings.
Yes!. forgot how nice this museum is. if you like impressionistic art at all you will like this. A varied selection and the water lilies rooms are great if you like Monet.

l'Orangerie. We went the day before we traveled to see Monet's estate at Giverny (second time for both). The artwork was incredible, but not as extensive a display of his style of work or of his contemporaries as we would have liked.

Don't miss it!. L'Orangerie is great! This is a museum you can enjoy slowly and peacefully. If you want to see Monet's late work, it is the place to be. Not to mention the superb collection Jean Walter et Paul Guillaume (also known as "Domenica ou la diabolique de l'art" - look for this movie)!

The Monets on the top floor hide the treasure below.. This is a wonderful museum to visit. It is small, but holds so many works by so many famous artists. The Monet murals are fantastic, but there is maybe even more treasure downstairs.

Very Nice. Monet's wall of water lillies is a must see. Along with all the other contributions a very nice museum and glad we got here. A priority line also for paris museum pass holders got you in quicker. e5 for the audio guide was very helpful and informative.

Don't miss it. This is just one persons art collection. Amazing. Loved this small museum. It wasn't too crowded and I was happy to be able to see all the. Works without. Too much hassle . The Monet panels were breathtaking.

Don't skip this!. The Monet and Renoir paintings were worth the plane ride from Chicago, believe me! Only complaint regarding this museum and two others I visited in Paris, there are no drinking fountains. Guess it's a Parisian thing, because didn't see any outside in the parks either! Had to tote water bottles everywhere. No big deal, but kind of a surprise.

Monet's Space. I've seen the Orsay, but really enjoyed this small museum. Main attraction is 2 gorgeous rooms, designed by Monet to let in the light and each room surrounded by his massive garden paintings. Less expensive, less crowded, and that peaceful experience you are looking for when viewing great art.

If you live art this is a must. Not only do you see Monet's large works (full wall length and height), but there also other artists downstairs as well. There is also a coffee shop that actually serve seasonable coffee.

A museum for Monet's water lilies - do not miss!. And there is even more to see than the famous and overwhelming water lilies by Claude Monet. In the lower parts of the museum you will find a vast exhibition of impressionists and the Paris school (Walter/Guillaume collection). Do take the guide and make sure to have time to admire the water lilies and other masterpieces appropriately. Friendly advice: queues are likely - go early in the morning or late in the evening (with min. 2hrs left of opening times). If you happen to wait, have an umbrella / sunhat and something to drink and nibble with you. People with walking disability: have a camping chair with you and make yourself known to the staff for getting downstairs.Must-visit if you love art.

Monet in the Round. Wow. Two rooms of Monet Lillies in the Round. Museum is very small. If you have an hour or less, you could do this. Don't look for a nice cafe here. Maybe twenty seats and VERY limited food items.

Stunning large scale Monet's. Must visit Monet's not far from the Louvre.Back in the space designed for them these room filling works of art showcase Monet at the top of his game, featuring works from his Water garden in Giverney.Beautiful, just beautiful !

Monet, Renoir, Picasso and more.... A great museum, not too overwhelming and doesn't need hours or days to appreciate, it was well worth it. See some wonderful art by very famous painters and enjoy a less crowded, more intimate experience!

Small but magnificient museum. This museum was partially designed by Monet to showcase his massive water lilies paintings. The top floor od the museum is essentially two large oval rooms where the walls are covered by his water lilies paintings. If you appreciate Monet's work, you must add this museum to your Paris list. Monet's large water lilies can only be found in two museums, Musee de l'Orangerie and MOMA in NYC (I assume they are still there as it has been quite a few years since we were last there). The ground floor has a series of rooms showcasing contemporary artists to Monet, which is also well worth the visit.

Stunning. . I'm not an art connoisseur but have developed an interest in impressionism over the last year and in particular Monet.
It's 9 euros to get in to the museam and very easy to find at the top of jardin de touliere. Monets Nympheas are simply breath taking. It's an absolute must do in Paris.

Beautiful lilies ! . A fantastic little museum , showcasing some of Monet's giant canvases of his lilies.
A fabulous setting, and there's more , a lovely gallery underneath of impressionist and post impressionist painters , some Cezanne, and Modligiani and more.
Very tranquil and a must on your list of galleries!

Loved the Monet waterlilies exhibit. Evidently, the Monet waterlilies exhibit was the first art exhibit commissioned for a specific venue in the world. The two rooms which each exhibit 4 very large curved paintings were designed/specified by him to maximize their impact. The rooms have skylights to maximize the quality of light, which of course is what the impressionists were all about. Also, there are other impressionist and post impressionist painters shown downstairs including Van Gogh. Only need an hour or two here to enjoy.
Cool museum- short visit. This museum is cool but is also small so it makes for a nice quick visit if you are looking to fill up some time.

Summer at L'Orangerie. My husband and I visited this in August 2016. It was such a beautiful day inside and out of the museum. We loved the Monet's and the good feeling energy of the art displayed. Crowded but not beyond being able to spend time and absorb all the art.

Monet 360. We booked Eurostar from London and they have a 2 for 1 deal promo for most of the museums!It's an intimate space with a few galleries.The Monet 360 Water Lilies are the grand finale and well worth it, lovely, stunning, and peaceful.

Favourite museum in Paris. . The museum is small in comparison to the others we visited, however, it was the only one whose artwork moved me to tears. Even thinking about entering the rooms with money's on all sides.... It as magnificent.

A must see!. This was truly a wonderful museum to visit. Not as crowded as other museums and Monet's 8 curved panels which are house in two rooms are breathtaking. Stark setting that needs nothing else but these wonderful pieces. The collection downstairs is not to be missed. The Renoir are gorgeous and some great pieces by Cezanma and Picasso. Highly recommend.
stunning. The renovated Orangerie is wonderful. It is a small collection but each piece is special. And the waterlilies are magic
A feast for the eyes. The prominent work of art here – Monet's large water gardens paintings – are stunning. But other works demand attention as well. Worth the short time it takes to enjoy them all.
A must see. There are a lot of Museums in Paris but really do not skip this one. The works are very impressive. Its a nice easy museum and does not have the crowds.

Don;t know why guidebooks pan this museum it was one of my favorites. Round rooms with the water lilies was outstanding. I also liked the bottom floor with descriptions of the Impressionist artists and the story of the relationship of the art gallery owner and the artists

Lovely museum. We,as a family of four, all enjoyed our visit to this museum very much. The Waterlilies were magnificent and uplifting and we were pleasantly surprised by the collection of paintings downstairs. We found the whole collection very impressive and enjoyable.
Monet and more Masters. How we enjoyed seeing Monet's massive paintings of his gardens, also the works of other masters too. A very refreshing and uncrowded museum (at least when we were there). GO!

Incredible. Don't miss this small museum. Monet donated eight huge Water Lily paintings to this museum and told them how to display them. They took his advice, got the paintings, and you can see eight similar paintings in different light.

BEAUTIFUL. This is just a very beautiful and relaxing and easy museum. Claude Monet Water lilies (Les Nympheas) as well as a very interesting collection of paintings from the first half of XX century. (At one point a private collection). Picasso, Cezanne, Modigliani, Utrillo and a few others. I visited this museum twice the same day, and plan to do it again during my stay in Paris. I have also been there several times in the past. I went in the morning and left because I was to meet friends for lunch. I came back in afternoon to finish. I recommend going early. It was not as crowded as in afternoon.

Impressive museum. In a serene atmosphere in this small museum the large paintings of Monet are shown. If you want you can rush through the museum in 15 minutes, but most people take their time and enjoy the pictures longer.

OK if you like impressionist stuff.. Museum is OK if you like this type of art, otherwise you'll not spend much time there. On a positive note, the rooms for the water lily paintings have been custom built over the years to house them for excellent viewing. Unfortunately, if you're there any time after morning opening, you'll spend time looking at tourists blocking your view rather than the paintings. Try to go during off hours.

Great compact museum of many Masters. This museum is mostly know for the Water Lilies by Claude Monet, but it also contains a limited number of works by Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliani, Matisse, Picasso Derain & Soutine. Monet's Water Lilies are uniquely impressive for their detail and expanse. This museum can be viewed in 2 hours.

Small museum, but worth it. I have longed to see Monet's Water Lilies for years and this museum is the perfect setting. They are displayed on two large oval rooms, where you can take your time contemplating them. The day we visited was not busy and we were able to take complete panorama photos of paintings. This museum is very small, and does have a collection of other artists on the floor below, including some Renoir, but it is not on the scale of the Musee d'Orsay. In fact, I prefer the small, intimate feel of the Orangerie.

No queue for this special museum. We walked in without any wait to see Monet's large water lilly paintings. Having seen his garden, the paintings took on even more significance in the quiet setting of the Orangerie.

Love Monet. A nice museum with Monet,s water lily panels but also lots of other good art works. We found it was not overcrowded and we didn't have to queue for ages. A nice setting in the Tuileries jardin
Unusual placement of art. The placement of Monet’s water lilies was superb, allowing the viewer to have a panoramic view of this famous work.

Home of Monet's Water Lilies. The highlight of l'Orangerie is Monet's giant Nymphéas, the Water Lily paintings. The curved walls are covered with the huge mural size paintings. This museum was much less crowded than the others we visited, and these galleries were very peaceful. They also have a small gallery of paintings by other impressionists and post-impressionists. It is a nice collection. I probably wouldn't pay the price for this ticket on it's own, but it is included on the Paris Museum Pass or there are combination tickets with the Musée d'Orsay that make it cheaper.

A must-see for anyone who loves Impressionism. I've been to Musée de l'Orangerie twice, in the middle of the busiest tourist season in July 2007 and again in April 2016 when there are tourists but not so much. In April I went there first thing in the morning on a beautiful spring day and was lucky because it wasn't crowded. I had the chance to sit on the bench in the oval rooms and just let the changing light from the skylight bring the paintings to life. Amazing experience, Impressionism in it's purest form! Don't forget downstairs with painting from Picasso, Renoir, Cézanne, Gauguin etc.

Small wonder. This is probably the most small museum in Paris. But if you like impressionism you just can miss it! Claude Monet offered the huge wonderful paintings to France and to humanity. It is a unique experience of peace, enlightment and joy.

Tranquility in the midst of Paris. Thoroughly enjoyed this oasis of calm the Monets, Renoirs, Picasso, Utrillo and more. Easy to move around and take in the painting, we were there on a Sunday, just lovely.

Interesting smaller museum. Spent a few wonderful hours touring this lovely, smaller museum. Walked to it from over the bridge crossing the Seine with lovely views of the river. Monet's room size paintings of water lilies was stunning.
Water Lillies. Smaller, wonderful museum with enormous Monet water Lilly series as it's centerpiece. Beautiful modern museum-classic impressionist artist works downstairs

Simply wonderful. Allow at least 2 hours to enjoy this fabulous museum. The water lilies take up two huge oval rooms and there is a long bench to sit and admire them from in the middle of the room. Make sure you also go downstairs as there is an excellent display of other paintings as well from a rang of French artists. I can't comment on the audio guide as I didn't use it.
Peaceful and calm setting. Allow time to just sit and enjoy these 8 panels. Afterwards you can go downstairs for a private collection of art that is outstanding and covers many artists.

Ahhhhh, surrounded by Monet. It's unbelievable - I never imaged it would be so beautiful and so big. One is allowed to get fairly close to the works and see the details of Monet's technique. There is manometer gallery of diverse works and also very good. But the Monet's will take your breath away.

Impressive Impressionism. Charming small museum at the end of the Tuileries. Les Nympheas by Claude Monet is a larger then life impressionist experience. Our 6 year old daughter loved it, you can never start to young appreciating Monet.

Monet and a private collection. . Lots of beautiful art especially if you want to see variety as it houses an art collector's collection of many artists. Star of the attraction are Monet's water lilies surrounding two oval rooms that makes you feel like you are in the pond itself. His reason for donating these art to this museum was to allow for stressed out people to enjoy and return to the tranquility of nature and a respite from it all. Museum goers do respect the peace and quiet ambience of the place so it was a great place to be. Not only was it a museum, it's good for the soul. Really good and I wish I could spend more time in the place. Parisians are truly lucky to be living in the same city as the museum.

Undeniably a must-see.. Even more rewarding in a way than the Louvre, the museum displays works of art from the best of the best. More exciting that ever is the huge display of Impressionist Art from everyone that was anyone! Mind-blowing to see first hand what you've studied in text books.

Amazing experience. Loved it!. My husband and I spent a quick 3 days in Paris, and I'd put this museum near the top of the list for best experiences over those 3 days (definitely beating out the Louvre). Monet fans absolutely must add this to their itinerary. As previous reviewers mentioned, the collection is small but powerful. If you prefer an experience that focuses on a single subject deeply then you won't be disappointed. We used the museum pass and went from entrance to standing in front of amazing Monet works within 5 minutes. The experience felt intimate and relaxing due to the lack of crowds and everyone's silent/respectful nature. Loved it!

An improvised visit.. I was surprised there was hardly a line the last time (August, 2016), but all three previous times the line was long, disorganized, and when it's hot or cold, it's very uncomfortable. Once you're in, it's a smooth ride. The ushers didn't use to allow any photography of any kind of Monet's Nymphéas, until my last visit --again, August, 2016--, so I was pleasantly surprised about that. The permanent collection is always a pleasure to look at. There are usually other exhibits (extra cost, not included in the main entrance fee) but none in Aug. It's a good place to escape the heat, for it's one of the few places in Paris with a well-functioning a/c.
Monet Visit. One has to see the special spot that highlights Monet's famous water lilies. It is open in the evening which is a good time to go.

Amazing. I wish I had known about this gem sooner. Any impressionist fan will appreciate this smaller gallery, the exhibit on the lower floor had many excellent paintings, while the star of the show, the water lilies, were spectacular. We didn't wait in a line and the water lily rooms were not crowded. Said to my husband while we were there that it would be a great place to be proposed to :) -- a suggestion to any gentlemen out there looking for a very romantic memorable location!!

Gorgeous museum. After the Musee D'orsay this is probably the next best. Love this smaller cute museum with incredible pieces. so much better than the Louvre frankly. I am such a huge fan of Monet so this is very appropriate for me and my interests. It is closed on Tuesday so be careful of that.

Perfect when a break is needed. This relatively petite museum is a great place to go when the crowds in the Louvre and elsewhere in Paris get overwhelming. It is busy by international standards, but generally the big tour groups don't go there. You will of course see Monet's great masterworks, the waterlily canvases, but on the bottom floor their is the collection of an art dealer from the great age of the Parisian avant-garde, which contains many impressionist, post-impressionist, and modernist works of great interest. It was the perfect place to take my mother when she grew weary of the tourist hoards.

Favorite museum. This museum was recommended as a "must see" by many of my friends and relatives. It is more low-key than the crazy tourist filled Louvre. You walk into the room and feel an immediate sense of tranquility and peace. The artwork is beautiful. This is my all time favorite museum.

Loved by many but I felt it was overrated. Spoilt by too many wonderful sights at the Louvre, I felt a little underwhelmed at what Orangerie had to offer. Despite holding the museum pass, we still had to wait in the rain for a good 30-40minutes in the late afternoon. The murals were lovely but not a lot else to see apart from those. Only if you are a big Monet fan.

A nice visit. Do not miss the painting collection in the lower floor. Good visit, 2 hours maximum, including a lot of sitting to admire Monet. Better to avoid weekends, especially 1st Sunday if the month: free entrance, but too many people.Don't miss the painting collection in the lower floor.

Wonderful small museum. This was on our list for our visit to Paris. We hadn't been to it on previous trips to the city. Our second day was rainy and chilly, so that became the day for our museum visit. It was very nice, lots of Monet plus other artists from that era - Picasso, Chagall, etc. We spent about 2 hours in the museum
Small and lovely. This is such a hidden gem of a museum. The Monet panels are worth the visit themselves. Filled with beauty you don't want to miss and such a bargain .

my favorite museum in Paris. I love this museum. It's small but wonderfully designed.the upstairs is dedicated to Monet and the downstairs has a regular exhibit and rotating exhibitions.I took my 5 year old daughter this year and she loved the oval room dedicated to Monet.A museum employee even offered to take a photo of the two of us when we were seated, discussing the paintings. Simply lovely

Don't miss if you're a Monet fan. Specialy built to his vision for his greatest works, this is the place to see monet and a heap of other amazing impressionist works. Get the audiotour and learn some fascinationg tidbits of art history.

Impressive but expensive. I went with 2 friends - one of whom has an annual pass so that covered two of us, but then the entrance fee is 9€ and the exhibit is very small. Yes, the giant Monet paintings are beautiful but for that much money I would expect more. Also, as I visited on a rainy day, the place was busy so it wasn't the kind of tranquil experience that you might hope for with paintings like that. Apparently it's free the first Sunday of the month so I would go then.

amazing. If you are a fan of Claude Monet, this museum should be at the top of your list. There are two oval-shaped rooms on the top floor that perfectly display Monet's water lillies series in seamless canvases.

Stunning. While this is a small museum with only a limited collection it is absolutely worth visiting. The massive Monet waterlilies were painted for this location and even if there was nothing else here they would more than justify the visit. These are some of the most amazing works I have ever seen. While visiting on one of the free Sundays might be tempting I would be wary of doing so. This place can get very crowded at the best of times
Must see. It comes easily, is easy to find and has priceless works inside. Matisse's works are especially touching.
Beautiful. just stunning works of art....would recommend a museum pass if you are going to Paris.....you can skip the lines....about 100 euros

Gorgeous, gorgeous, gorgeous. This stunning, small museum holds huge and amazing paintings of Monet's 'Water lillies'. They are breath-taking. We toured on the first Sunday of the month, meaning it was free. Some of our group only went in because it was free and were literally dazzled by what they saw.Paris's museums tend to be huge but this small museum is easy to digest and the Monet paintings are stunning.High recommended, even for those not into art galleries and museums.
Paris at its best. A must see if you're visiting Paris. I had no idea the amount of priceless art inside this art museum until I visited. All absolute classics. Don't miss it.

Decent museum. It is in a very central location. If you get off the metro at Concorde. It is just nex to it. I recommend you to go there in the same day you goto d'orsay.(it is just accross the river) It makes more sense in that way and they kind of complete each other) The art work in the museum is really satisfying.

Monet is magic. This place has a wonderful presence to it. I have visited here twice, the first time over 20 years ago and again just recently in August 2016. My main comment would be that, now everyone was using cameras and devices to take photos of these beautiful works, 20 years ago photos were not allowed as far as I know and the rooms had a feeling of peace and serenityou that is now diluted somewhat.

Jump into the lily pond. Monet loved lily ponds and he loved France. After surviving the horrors of war, he dedicated and donated these paintings to France. The rooms are perfectly designed to display these beautiful artworks and I encourage you to just sit and stare at each of them. As you do, and as the light changes with the moving sun overhead, each painting comes to life. They are truly astounding and well worth the visit.The lower floor also houses a collection of art that is worthy in it's own right but for me, the Monets are the draw-card. Just breathtaking!

Pretty Much What I Expected. It was a rainy Monday in Paris so I decided to head over here and see how crowded it was. There were no lines and I arrived around midday. Coat check and ticket lines were short. The main attraction was straight ahead on the main floor, two oval shaped rooms housing the main events, Monet's Waterlilies. I bought the audio guide for that part and it was a waste of Euros. Not necessary as the two rooms house four large pieces each. The free hand out gives a good enough explanation.This exhibit comprises the entire main floor. From there walk downstairs for the rest of the exhibits. Lined up along the walls of a long hallway type room you work your way down and back, passing paintings from artists such as Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse, Laurencin, Modigliani, Rousseau, Derain, Utrillo, Guillaume and Soutine. There's also a small exhibit of miniatures of Guillaume's apartment.Down and back and you're done. In retrospect, I wish I'd gotten the audio guide for the downstairs instead of upstairs as they don't all come together in one purchase. All in all, if you love Monet and have never seen his Waterlilies I'd say it's worth it.If you've seen them before, as I have at MOMA in NYC, and are short on time, you could take a pass. I've seen all these other artists in other museums before.Staff was friendly, building provided filtered natural light from the ceiling which was special. Other than that, nothing particularly exciting about the building's architecture.

Monet's Late Gift to France. The Orangerie can be approached either via the Place de la Concord from the Champs Elysees or Rue de Rivoli, or via the Tuileries Gardens. It is either a haven of peace after all the traffic and people, or the culmination of a calm and contemplative stroll. It's not a large gallery, but it does have an impact. Downstairs at present is an exhibition of art once belonging to one of the great art dealers of the late 19th/early 20th century. You can get close to Picasso, Matisse, Renoir, Cezanne, Gaugin, Modigliani . . . and then upstairs there are the special rooms for Monet's last great Water Lily paintings. 8 curving murals, 22 panels stretching round 300 feet. you can stand or sit and contemplate from the centre of the room; and you can get up close to the mysterious splodges of paint and gouges in the thick surface. The dark colours and indistinct shapes tell you he was old and nearly blind when he made this, but it makes it all the more awe-inspiring. I love the Orangerie!

A family memory to charish!. My son & family arrived at the museum early. We were able to spend quality family time & shared the cultural experience. Everyone loved Monet's Water Lilies! The perfect small size intimate gallery for people of all ages.

Outstanding experience . Nothing can prepare you for the Monet experience of a lifetime. The two special rooms are so perfectly designed to show the Lillies and willow painting at their best. If you see this you you must go to Giverny to see the house and gardens

Small but really unique. There is nothing like admiring a long / really long painting of your favourite artist in a shiny and welcoming hall.
Need to visit and probably, re visit ...

Small but perfect. A beautiful little museum mostly devoted to Monet's vast Nympheas paintings... two circular rooms entirely walled by pond scenes, which really feel like you are swimming or floating on the water. Downstairs is a small cafe and bookshop selling prints and books and postcards etc - I spent 50 Euros in there trying to take it all home... nice to have the option.Downstairs is another gallery with other impressionists I didn't know but there was some beautiful work there too. 9 Euro entry fee and it took me about 45 minutes to see everything, but it felt just about right. Not too expensive or daunting, just a nice afternoon. And it was a lifelong dream to see Nympheas.

Must see!. We almost didn't go see this but upon a friend's recommendation we went and we were so glad we did! Words cannot quite describe it. It was so serene and the eight paintings were amazing. Whether you're a Monet fan or not, you should definitely check this out!

Small, but beautiful museum!. My absolute favorite art display in all of Paris is the two oval rooms in this museum, which are dedicated solely to showcasing Monet's Waterlillies murals. The white walls and natural light flowing from the skylight windows amplify the beautiful scenery portrayed in these massive paintings and allow the viewer to feel completely immersed in Monet's world. Definitely sit on the benches in the middle of the room and take your time to truly enjoy this incredible masterpiece. If possible, go early to avoid crowds, which detract from the experience.There are other impressionist and post-impressionist artworks on display, but the museum is small enough that it won't take more than a couple of hours to see everything.There's a small café next to the gift shop inside and clean toilet facilities as well.

Excellent collection of impressionist art!. Excellent collection of impressionist art including fabulous Monet. Combined this with a visit the next day to Monet's home and gardens in Giverny. Just wonderful.

Monet Heaven for Me. Another not to be missed museum. The lily pads are set up so beautifully. There are 8 huge paintings set up in round rooms. Sit and then view from different angles for the lighting effect. There are also Renoirs, Cezanne, Matisse and Picasso's to name a few.

Whew!!. Ok Monet lovers, this will be your chance to see the 2 large rooms with essentially 360 degrees each of his lily pad paintings. Monet also helped design the building so this is the full Monet experience. The bottom floor is definitely worth seeing also, many Renoir, Toulouse -Latrec, etc.

The actual water lilies. Nestled in a corner of The Tuileries is l'Orangerie, is a small museum dedicated to Impressionism and some post-Impressionism. The highlight is two oval-shaped galleries containing Monet's enormous panels of water lilies. If you are a fan of Monet or Impressionist painters, this is not to be missed. No copies - the real thing. You also get Cezanne, Renior, Matisse, Gauguin, and even a bit of Picasso thrown in. Much more compact than the Orsay, which is certainly worth a visit as well, but it will take you longer. If you are in Paris, or going to be, put l'Orangerie on your itinerary.

It's an OK museum. I came to this museum after the Louvre & Orsay. I'm not sure but I had my hopes set up high for this museum as all the museums in Paris I had been to exceeded my expectations, sadly this one didn't. It is a small museum and the security queue was so long and it was 30c - so it wasn't fun (I understand this isn't their fault). I eventually got into the museum and the art wasn't that great, seemed a little repetitive. I only spent little over an hour here and had lunch here. I'm glad I didn't pay the €13 admission fee (you don't have to pay for museum entry if you're under 26 & an EU citizen in Paris, thankfully!) because it feels like it was too expensive for what it is worth. I wouldn't come back if I had to pay for it, though

Small but good Monet collection. The museum is small, inside the park de tuleries and has a small cafeteria indise. Nothing spectacular. The best part honestly is the Monet collection wich is well preserved and nice. The museum is the first one I came in which didn't have wifi.

Beautiful Monet Collection. The museum houses the most beautiful collection of Monet's water lillies, the sheer size of them is incredible. It is well worth the small fee to take a look at the amazing paintings that take up entire walls. They are so spectacular in person, photographs cannot do them justice. I highly recommend spending a few hours here.
Monet!. This museum was built to house Monet's water-lillies. The other parts of the collection are well worth it as well. And this is nowhere near as crowded as the Orsay or the Louvre

Some superb impressionists paintings. This lovely little museum has a fine collection of impressionists works including Monet's water Lily series. In about an hour and a half you can see everything so it is a nice little way to spend a couple of hours when down in the Tuilleries.

Small but great impressionist collection. The museum has a great collection of massive Monet paintings. Downstairs there are works by many impressionist painters. Included with the museum pass. Highly recommend visiting. Though less than an hour easily.
MONET MONET MONET. If you miss this then redo your bucket list.To see what this great artist, Monet did is just magical

Stare in the lillies. Wonderful museum, especially for impressionism lovers. If you're keen on this style, take couple of hours to walk around, combine it with another museum and perhaps a walk around the gardens, or the design shops in the neighbourhood.

Beautiful yet manageable. The walls of Monet alone are worth a visit, but there are many more fantastic paintings in this centrally-located museum. I prefer this to the Louvre because you can see everything in a relatively short time, and it is not exhausting. It also has a nice café in which to recharge before going on to the next stage of one's day in Paris.

Unexpected Gem in a City of Big Art!. We visited here as it was part of our Paris Pass - and we are big fans of Monet. This museum is for more than just avid Monet fans. Everyone will see the beauty in the paintings displayed here.
Monet's water lilies. This is a very small museum but absolutely worth the visit because of the round room of the Monet's water lilies paintings. The visit is included in the Paris pass.

Skip the Louvre and go here!. This is a brilliant place, Monet's Water Lilies are displayed in all their beauty. This really is worth every penny, and comes with an excellent cafe that is not too expensive.Some of the other exhibits were not to our taste, but spend lots of time in the Monet rooms, as it is not often that we get so close to such magnificent works of art!

Enjoy serenity of Monet's water lilies in the round. The Musee de l'Orangerie can easily be toured in 2-3 hours or less without a guide. Audioguides are available for a small fee and provide excellent commentary and background. Les Nymphaes exhibit is the star attraction with two touching elliptical rooms each having four Monet water lily paintings that form almost a 360 degree surrounding of peaceful pond atmosphere. Sit in the center and enjoy the ambience or look more closely to appreciate the details executed by Claude Monet over 25 years of work. The lower floor includes works by a large number of artists and some exquisitely detailed small dioramas of some period rooms.

Unforgettable "Monet" experience and a beautiful 20th Century avant-gardes Collection. The "nymphées" from Monet only by themselves are worthy the visit. There is a nice Impressionist Art Collection (mainly Renoir), but also some 20th Century avant-gardes masterpieces (Picasso, Soutine, Utrillo, Modigliani etc.). Exhibitions also are usually very interesting.

Small museum, but worth it for the Monet exhibit.. We visited here as part of a combo ticket with the Musee d'Orsay, and didn't have a lot of expectations. It is a nice building with a pretty good collection of impressionists, but the highlight is the water lilies room by Money. Paintings wrap around the room and surround you with the beauty of these magnificent works of art. That alone makes it worth the time to drop in.
Monets Water Lillies. Fabulous ... could have stayed all day! Lovely big rooms to allow you to fully appreciate the paintings and not too crowded.
my favorite. This is my favorite museum. The Water Lilly display is sublime. The collection on the lower level features incredible work. Its my favorite.

Best kept secret in the Touleries. We went to see a Monet exhibit here. The queue was much shorter than D'Orsay and the Louvre.Just the right size for us who don't want to spend an entire day inside an art gallery.It was great.

Most peaceful. Along with the Rodin gardens this is the most peaceful museum in Paris, and a spot to move slowly and watch carefully. The pace of the Louvre is replaced with the peacefulness of lillies at dawn; and one of the cleanest bathrooms in Paris.

Great museum showing the Claude Monet's Water Lillies masterpiece. I visited the Musee de l'Orangerie buying a combined ticket at Musée d'Orsay for 16E. This gallery is currently showcasing Monet's masterpiece Water Lillies so is well worth the extra few euros when buying your ticket at the Orsay. After the Water Lillies, there are still many other amazing artworks on display though the gallery itself will only take about 1-1.5 hours to fully enjoy. Many captions are also in English so unlikely you will need the audio tour. Overall another great French museum and personally a must at some point of your Paris itinerary if you're an art lover.

Beautiful! . Lovely museum with beautiful collection of art. Monet's water lilies are the centre piece and are just incredible. Definitely worth a visit! Like many attractions, free entry for Europeans under 25 with id.

Monet.....WOW. Went to Monet's Garden at Giverny the day before and then continued to de lOrangerie the next day at 8.50am (opens at 9.00am) and was first in queue....if you are a lover of Monet, it's a must see

Go early . We visited mid August, best arrive early to avoid the queues. Amazing building, not enormous so can be easily seen in an hour or 2, and certainly not overwhelming. Entry price was reasonable and really enjoyed it. We were there early so it was really busy so you could sit and enjoy the lily pond pieces in peace and quiet without feeling hurried. Really enjoyed it and even coffee and the coffee shop was lovely too

A romantic trip through time. A romantic trip through time with some of the best known artists (Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliani, Matisse, Picasso, Derain-Soutine and Claude Monet). Monet's Water Lilies are just breath taking. A good hour spent indulging in a haven of magical paintings (Tutelary Figures, Modern Primitives, Modern Classicism, Return to Order and Turmoil / Bursting Exuberance). A must place to visit when on Paris.

Stunning Water Lillies. This museum is not large, but punches way above its weight. It is divided into two parts. The first, and most stunning, are the two oval rooms devoted to Monet's Nymphéas (Water Lillies), eight large canvases that will take your breath away. The remainder of the exhibition space houses the collection of Paul Guillaume, a savvy collector of late 19th century and early 20th century "emerging" (at the time) artists, including Renoir, Picasso, Sisley, Cezanne, Matisse and others. You can take in the whole museum in a couple of hours, and will come away with your soul refreshed.

Go see the water lillies . You need to go see the Monets. They are honestly breathtaking. The two rooms they are in are perfectly constructed for viewing these works of art. Absolutely worth the price of admission. The basement level has some other interesting works as well. You probably won't spend more than an hour at this museum.
Beautiful. Still a treat. Monet rocks. Basement collection of 1900s impressionist masters is second to none. Well worth a visit. Easy to enjoy the entire collection in an hour.

Love this musuem!. This has turned out to be one of my favorite museums. It is small in size but has fantastic collections. I got chills when I walked into the round rooms that house Monet's Water Lillies. It is a beautiful way to see them. The museum also has many other famous french artists.
Don't miss this Museum. We were blown away by the Monets and the display. But its not just Monet. So much more. Not crowded.

My favorite museum in Paris. I am happy this is in top 10. It is my favorite museum in Paris because of so many Renoir and Chaim Soutine paintings. Though I love Monet, I must say that I am not at all impressed by Waterlilies in this museum. I love his paintings but on smaller scale. Besides a big collection of Renoir and Soutine, there are works by Picasso, Matisse, Utrillo, Derain, Cezanne and one Gauguin. If you wanna go to Orsay too, you can buy joint ticket for Orangerie and Orsay - it is 16 euros.
Great collection. If you are a fan of this type of art then this is the museum for you. It is very big and located near the Tulleries.
Much improved since our last visit. Construction now completed and Monet water lily murals back to their sun-lit glory. An absolutely amazing way to display classic art.

Doesn't require a long visit, and some great artwork. The two main rooms, featuring Monet's panoramas, are stunning, but best visited when there are smaller crowds (near opening or closing) to be able to SEE the work. The rest of the gallery is not too large, so the entire place can be visited in 1-2 hours.
A delightful gallery. The Monet rooms are wonderful enough but there is also an intriguing collection of impressionist and post impressionist paintings downstairs

A beautiful Gem. We had "done" the Louvre and seen the Mona Lisa but the place is a zoo full of many tourists so the calm beauty of Musee de l'Orangerie was appreciated. We had to queue for about 10 minutes because they control the number of admissions. Once inside we began with the huge Monet panels in the curved rooms, amazing. In this gallery you have time and space to really look at the artwork without fighting through the crowds. After admiring the Monet pieces we went to the lower floor to view a lovely collection of Impressionist and more modern art. This is a small gallery but well worth the visit.

Cute little collection. We really like Monet and totally enjoyed this little gem of a museum after visiting Monet's gardens at Giverny. It's a really small collection, but in addition to Monet's great wrap around paintings there are gems from his contemporaries such a Renoir too. Worth a look particularly after visiting Giverny.

Once in a lifetime experience to view Monet;s massive water lilies.. If there is one sight we can recommend for someone who has little time in Paris, it would be to visit this small museum. Monet has long been my wife's favourite painter, and to be able to see this massive many-walls-long painting is to stand in the middle of a dream.
A Must See for ANY gardener. If you are a gardener or just enjoy beautiful scenery this is a must! I liked it so much I have planned a trip to Monet's garden in Giverney next month!

Water Lilies, Yes Please. I am so happy that a friend suggested this museum. Breath taking, mesmerized, could have spent all day there.Definitely a must on your list of impressionist art. A remodel of this museum has created to oval rooms, each containing 4 large canvas works by Monet. These water lilies make you feel you are right there in Gevrny.There is much more art then just water lilies. Do Not Miss!
Less hectic and more personal!. Don't miss the amazing Monet murals that are here permanently...he painted them at the end of his life while suffering from cataracts. Gorgeous!

Excellent museum- don't forget to go downstairs!. This gallery is famous for the Monet Waterlillies series and they are indeed very beautiful. Contemplative? Not so much, with so many other visitors and several cameras clicking away, but still a very wonderful experience. Don't forget to go downstairs though, where you will find lots of other wonderful works by other innovative artists. Also, don't leave it until too late in the day- the website says it closes at 5:45pm but we were asked to begin moving out of the Monet rooms by 5:15pm, so worth giving yourself a bit more time if you can.

Very small, quick museum to see Monet large painting in a nice setting. It was a nice little museum, but very small. Just a little stop. It would be good with kids that don't have such a long attention span.

Small Art Museum. It is situated almost in the Place de la Concorde, in the Jardins des Tuileries. It is not a very big museum but it is worth a visit, not only for the Monet murals but for all the other pictures you will see in it.
Mind blowing . Waterlilies were absolutely outstanding and surpass your expectation in terms of size and beauty! Excellent mix of paintings with some interesting work on Picasso also on display.
Small but charming museum.. Right off of Tulliries garden, easy to find. Wonderful two rooms of huge Monet waterlily painting series.

Don't miss it if you enjoy peace and beauty.. Not too large, one level dedicated to just Waterlillies. Take your time and enjoy the serenity of this place at the end of Jardin des Tuilleries, Concorde square and Ferris wheel. Don't just go in to take a few quick shots, see it like it was meant to be seen -as a refuge from everyday life into peace.
Classic. You can't visit Paris and miss this lovely museum. Take your breath away Monet murals. Relatively short time to view but unforgettable.

Mesmerizing. Highly overlooked, this museum has an impressive collection of Impressionist art. The main attraction is the two rooms with the murals made by Monet which is absolutely staggering. Take some time to stay surrounded by this brilliant murals.

Sometimes I just come in and sit and gaze at the waterlilies.. This gem is small but concentrated, upstairs you have Monet's lilies in the rooms that were built to house them and they really are just mind boggling, and doznstairs is the wonderful Walter & Guillaume collection, which has a vast array of painters of the late 19th Century. It's big enough that there's lots to see and it's worth going in, but small enough that you don't come out feeling glazed over and shell shocked.

The Perfect Size Museum. After being overwhelmed on our first visit to Paris by its fine museums, we were determined to enjoy the "sights" this time. We did, however, venture into l'Orangerie and loved it. Monet in a relaxed setting was well worth the visit.
Often overlooked.. Besides Monet's fantastic works there are many other under represented artist, Impressionist to modern.

Beautiful . The best display of Monet's Waterlilies in the world! Two huge oval rooms were especially made to exhibit four huge paintings in each room - truly amazing. You actually are engulf in Monet's artwork, almost surreal!

As always...our favorite museum in Paris!. The The Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection is amazing and the huge Monet Water Lilly panels are just stunning.
Maybe the best Modigliani collection in one place. Same with Chaim Soutine. We go every time we visit Paris.
Their visiting exhibits are ALWAYS fabulous!

I prefer it !. Most of the touristic visits are for Louvre, but if you look for more modern art, Impressionism, unique and in my point of view one of the best in Paris that offers a great variety for art lovers

The Waterlillies were the highlight. I went here to see the Waterlillies, and I was not disappointed. Just sitting and staring at the room with the beautiful brushstrokes was almost meditative. We even picked up a print to remind us of this back at home!

Bite sized delight!. With some museums, they are an endurance contest and you hope you can see your interests before your energy runs out.This museum is beautifully sized for an hour or two. The top floor is dedicated to room filling Monet paintings.The bottom floor is an entire donated collection of modern artists from a contemporary dealer of theirs that exhibited and supported them as emerging artists.The museum did a lovely job telling the story of the collection and the relationship to the dealer.Fantastic!It makes me appreciate the smaller size and more focused collections.

Must see for Monet admirers!. Nice follow up after a visit to the amazing Orsay Museum. Sure the Louvre is great and all but I prefer Impressionism to all the classical paintings. While Orsay gives you a nice intro to all the members of this group, the Orangerie is a must for those who love Monet's water lilies and don't have the time to go visit his Giverny house . The museum is included in the Museum Pass and it was just a short walk from the Louvre.
monet highlight. this is a definite must for all all monet fans. one of my highlights of my holiday, close to speechless upon entering.

Beautiful and inspiring museum. Skip the Louvre - this smaller museum is decked with inspiring collections of nature at its finest. Lines were short to get in, and it was just small enough not to feel overwhelmed.

Incredible small Gem!. Located at the Tulleries Gardens, this small museum holds mostly Impressionism master pieces by the famous painters: Renoir, Manet, and with the outstandingly beautiful Monet's Lilly ponds murals. There was an average line at the entrance that we skip by having my ticket bought before ( at Gare du Nord) . Nice small souvenir shop upstairs with a very small cafeteria. Entrance fee 9€ and free for 19 and under. Closed on Mondays. Very near of the Musee d'Orsay and Musee du Louvre.

A Hidden Gem. This museum is a hidden gem in the Tuilleries Garden in Paris. I am a huge fan of Monet, and the display of Monet's Water Lilies is breathtaking. We had the Paris Museum Pass so there was only a short wait in line. We had a quick lunch in the cafe, which was reasonably priced. The free bathrooms were clean and very nice. The museum is small compared to the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay, but it was one of the highlights of our trip.
WImpressive. We had Museum Passes & were admitted immediately. The Museum was busy but not crowded. The setting for the water lillies was perfect & we loved it. We would visit again.

Temple to Monet's Masterpiece. This little museum is located in the Tuileries Gardens. Expect long lines outside. The Monet masterpieces on display inside are breathtaking, and it's worthwhile to just sit back and "soak in" the colours of the artwork.

The water lilies are impressive. This is a small museum located near the end of the Champs-Elysees or the end of the gardens. So it is easy to make a quick stop in to look at a very impressive collection of paintings. One of my girls, 8, noted it was her favorite museum and I think it was because it was beautiful without being overwhelming.

See all the masters in one place. WHile Monet is the most promoted of the artists at the Musee de l'Orangerie, you can see works by Cezanne, Matisse, Renoir, Rousseau, Picasso. Be warned that the works by Soutine can be seen as a bit gory but his portraits are fantastic.

Worth the trip if you love Monet. The rooms and panels of water lilies is amazing. You can tell this space was designed for these paintings. You can sit and stare at each panel. Don't forget the collection downstairs. It is a nice mix of famous painters that cross technique, style, and topic.

Go, go now. . Beautiful museum. Wonderful two rooms with monet's waterlillies lining the walls! Loved this place, would definitely go again and stay for another few hours. Probably not worth going if you aren't a fan of monet, picasso, matisse, renoir etc. The cafe is good too. Lovely little book store.

If You Like Monet,Go to l'Orangerie. We visited l'Orangerie the day prior to taking the train to Giverny (Vernon Station). It helped. The eight Monet murals are spectacular. You will want to see the Nympheas in person. The rest of the museum has some nice stuff, but Monet is the star. One of our top five spots in Paris.
