A small gem of a museum in the shadow of the Louvre. From the Louvre, walk west through the Jardin des Tuileries (lovely place to sit and rest) to the Musee de l'Orangerie, a museum housing impressionist and post impressionist paintings, the most famous of which is the Nympheas canvases (water lilies) which Monet donated to France.The building was built in 1852 to shelter the orange trees of Jardins des Tuileries and has been used for various purposes since from storage warehouse to soldiers' barracks to exhibition space. In 1921 the building became an annex of the Musee du Lumembourg.This is a beautiful museum in which to spend an hour or two and a mandatory prelude to a visit to Giverny to see the inspiration for much of Monet's work.The No. 1 metro - Concorde stop and the No 72 bus line will deliver you to the museum and the surrounding Place de la Concorde, Jardins des Tuileries.
Monet!. Loved the experience of being surrounded by Monets classic art. Fantastic building as well - set int he middle of the gardens.
A tiny jewel in the park. Make time to see this small but excellent museum in the heart of Paris. If you like Monet, you will love how his work is displayed here.

Compact but beautiful exhibition of impressive works. This museum is tucked away by The Seine within the Gardens of Tuileries but I made sure I popped in to take a look at Monet's famous works. Like many of the museums in Paris, entry for under 26 year olds is free which is fantastic. There was so queue whatsoever even though it was a Sunday lunchtime in the middle of August.The upper floor contains two light and airy spaces perfectly formed to display Monet's Water Lillies with the lower floor containing several gallery spaces including work from Pablo Picasso. This museum is a real treat for any art-lover and definitely not one to walk on by! I just wish it was bigger.

Perfect size. Beautiful gallery. Monet’s waterlilies attract most attention, floating in their quiet, white, oval-shaped rooms. But the small Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume galleries downstairs contain a superb collection of famous and less well known paintings which we loved seeing close up. Not as busy as the Louvre or the Musee d’Orsay, and so much more rewarding as a result. And, of course, a must-see if you intend going to Giverny.

A Complete Surprise for Monet Lovers. We went there after seeing Monet's House/Gardens and this was a true surprise. Had been to see the Monet's in the Orsay but the Monet's here took your breath away. There are 8 of them, but they are huge - very long panels (about 4 paintings put together). It is all about sitting and taking it in, think like being in a library, there is no talking. To me this is the museum to visit. Just wonderful.
Avoid the Crowds. Very nice museum near the Louvre. We enjoyed the modern art, especially Monet's water lilies. There was no line in August.

Small and perfectly formed . To see a short burst of impressive impressionist work in a light modern environment, this is perfect. The Monet collection of Water Lillies is superb. Remember under 26's are free and your EuroStar tickets give you 2 for 1.Middle of August and middle of the day we had no wait.

Small but important museum. Another impressionist and post impressionist gem so close to the Musee d'Orsay you must visit both. Almost worth it just to get close to Monet's huge Water Lilies masterpiece. But there is so much more to explore. Don't rush it just because it's small, allow a couple of hours to take it all in.

Impressive paintings in an impressive building.. We went early in the day and the Musee was not at all crowded. This enabled us to appreciate the scale and complexities of Monet's paintings without interruption.

Fascinating and worth for the Waterlilies alone!. My daughter and I wanted to visit a gallery while in Paris and this was perfect. It isn't too big but had the amazing Waterlilies, multiple canvases extending all round the walls of two rooms. Downstairs there was a fabulous collection themed on a collection from a gallery owner Paul Guillaume who over his lifetime amassed a really significant collection of artists who are now we'll known. The gallery wasn't too crowded on a Sunday morning and made a great bit of culture in our holiday. We also had a drink in the small cafe and used the clean facilities. Well worth a visit.
Monet's water lilies!. This is a small museum. We loved the Monet paintings. It was great to see his work after a visit to Giverny (Monet's house and gardens).

The most special museum in Paris. The two rooms with the water lilies are the highlights here. Stunning. Spend as much time as you can in these two rooms and let the peacefulness of Monet's garden surround you.

Monets Marvel. Free on the first Sunday of each month. I saw them 30 years ago and they still are fantastic, if you are a fan they are not to be missed.
If not don't bother like some of the idiots who walked round filming and taking selfies it ruins it for everyone else.
Loved It. So much to see, not just the Water Lilies. Truly magnificent and it is not as crowded as other Museums.

Better than the Louvre!. We loved this museum! We went for the Monet's, but also enjoyed the Renoir's, Degas, and others. Rich collection of art. Not as crowded as the Louvre. Easier to see and enjoy.

Don't skip the basement!. The water lily rooms are an amazing experience and not to be missed. The basement, though, has some famous works by Renoir and Cezanne. Definitely poke around for a few minutes!

Do not Miss This Museum. I loved this museum! I was so excited to see Monet's Water Lilies and was then treated to fabulous exhibit of Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliani, Matisse, Picasso, and two I had never seen - Derain & Soutine. The Soutine paintings are captivating- I bought the small catalog in the museum store to take home. We had gone through the Louvre prior to l'Orangerie. It made me appreciate the impact of the Musee de 'lOrangerie that much more. Wonderful!!!! Do not miss it- or the beautiful walk along the Seine to get to it!

One of my favorite museums in Paris!. This museum is such a refreshing experience. It has a lot of art, but it doesn't overwhelm you like the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay or other large museums can. The Monet ellipse rooms are breathtaking and definitely the highlight of the museum. Their collection of art ranging from Renoir to Matisse to lesser known artists around the same time is great. It's a less visited museum, so crowds usually aren't as bad as the bigger places. I went during the off-season a couple of times and it was so peaceful. The museum is also in a great location, at the end of the Champs-Elysees, on the other side of the Jardin Tuileries from the Musee du Louvre, and across the river from Musee d'Orsay. If you don't have access to free entry or have the Paris Visite pass, then I would recommend getting the joint entry ticket that also allows you to visit the Musee d'Orsay, that you can easily walk to.

Incredible. The lillies were simply the most incredible art I have seen in person, really peaceful, immersive experience. The scale and technique were amazing. The rest of the collection downstairs had some very nice pieces as well. I would thoroughly recommend and would certainly prioritise this over the Mona Lisa if you are limited for time! We got there about half an hour after opening and there were very few people there. Tuileries nice for a stroll afterwards or walkable over the Seine to the Musee d'Orsay if you have the combined ticket.

Surrounded by exquisite beauty. Descending downstairs and I was in another world, that of Monet. Be sure to acknowledge the code of silence, no photo taking and take a lot of time to sit and stare at these wonderful oversize works of art.
Superb.. Monet's frescoes are spectacular! The permanent exhibition are also very informative on varied important artists like Renoir, Cezzane, Picasso, Matisse, Soutinne.......... Must visit!
Breathtaking. I only came for Monet's waterlilies. Best two hours of my Paris trip. The rooms in which the waterlilies are presented are perfect, so calm and beautiful. A must.
The Monet's are amazing!!. An impressionist overload! Too many beautiful paintings to really appreciate. Not a big museum, but you could easily spend 2-3 hours there. Definitely worth a stop.

Totally Breathtaking. Not much to say except whether or not you are a Monet fan the setting of some of his most famous paintings really does do them justice and the water-lillies really bring home what a genius the man was

Monet's Lillies. A small but memorable museum, its hard to forget such beautiful large paintings such as Monets. The queue for the museum was not long probably because everybody was at the Louvre, it was the first Sunday of the month and entrance was free :)

Monet's Water Lilies are Amazing . If you visit this museum for no other reason than the water lilies you will not be disappointed. Entrance into the museum is free for children and students and was €9 for adults making this a fairly inexpensive stop. Located in a great spot by the Jardin de Tuilieres my daughter and I first rose the Ferris wheel before going to see Monet and Picasso's works here. The two rooms, designed with help from Monet himself to ensure the best experience viewing the Water Lilies, can get crowded. But if you sit on the benches provided and just wait the two rooms do clear out. The only annoying thing were the people doing stupid things to get the best photo possible. It got irritating having people constantly sticking their phones on our faces to take pictures from our perspective. Otherwise. If you have no reason to go to this museum other than the Water Lilies this museum is a must go. There is also some amazing fresh squeezed orange juice for sale in the cafe that my daughter and I loved.
Small but Worth the Time!. My husband and I really love Impressionist paintings, and the collection housed at l'Orangerie is exceptional, particularly the murals by Monet and the Renoirs.

Breathtaking Monets. I wanted to go to this museum because I love Monet. I didn't realize that there were Monets in the D'Orsay museum as well (which we didn't go to), but honestly, going here instead was nice because it is pretty small. With the Louvre to see on this trip also (and beautiful summer weather outside), I didn't want to have another really long museum day, so this was just perfect! The 2 Monet rooms were breathtaking. I love the stark white rooms, with just 4 huge paintings in each. I haven't seen much that I could even try to compare it to. Lovely!

Monet's large scale nympheas but that's not all!. Located at the corner of the Place de la Concorde and the Tuileries Gardens. Most famous for housing the large scale paintings by Monet of the pond and water lines in his garden at Giverny. My 12-year old son really enjoyed seeing them the day after going to Monet's house and garden. Don't overlook (as some appear to do in their reviews) the impressionist and post-impressionist masterpieces on the floor below. Well worth sparing time for them. Free entry on the first Sunday of the month, as is the nearby Musee d'Orsay. A great double header!
Marvellous Monet. Split opinions on this one! Beautifully designed, showcasing Monets water lillies at their best Not a lot else there tho! Was quiet on our visit

Loved this - worth it just for the Monet Nympheas. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Paris. Small, quite museum - no crowd at all. Beautiful Monet rooms and downstairs a whole wall of Renoir (August 2016). All of it was just beautiful and you can do this one quickly. Get the museum pass and visit d'Orsay and this one in the same day.

Stunning. Having wanted to see monet's lily-fields for many years; I was happy not to be disappointed in the experience. The series of paintings are expansive, a precursor and influence on the abstract expressionists. Monet's work is way before and ahead of its time - just stunning!
Monet. A magnificent display of Monet's paintings of "Water Iillies" that is a must see in Paris and located at the end of the Tuilleries Gardens. A lovely area to appreciate Monet's work.

If you love Monet. This is a must see gallery for Monet lovers and There is a lovely collection of Renoir too.
If you don't care for these artists it is a not a particularly large gallery so you could skip this one.
At Musee D'Orsay you can buy a dual ticket for these two museums.

Another Hidden gem. This one is the 'other' museum if you compare it to the musee d'orsay. Its main attraction is the Monet waterlillies which is awesome, but there are the odd pieces here and there. It isn't 100% interesting and there are very little crowds. If you are a huge fan of monet then I suggest you go, if not, then musee d'Orsay for a bit more variety

Lovely collection...small crowds. Monet's Water Lilies are main draw for most at Musee de l'Orangerie, but I thought the collection of 20th century art was fantastic, and truly enjoyed being able to experience the art without a mass of people around every piece of significance. I'd suggest going early when the crowds are truly minimal.

The Monet's real Nympheas are here. When walking in the famour Tuilerie Garden, don't miss a visit there. Fantastic exhibitions always and of course stop to contemplate and dream when watching the famous Canvas by Claude Monnet in a fantastic Set... Very Zen and Inspiring at any time of year...
MONET. this place is all about Monet. There is some other stuff here.... but the waterlillies is the main attraction.

Pricey. For what the collection consists of, not really worth the entrance fee. We had a twin ticket for it and the muse d'Orsay, so it was not quite as expensive. A beautiful Monet collection, but I do not see why it is not integrated into the d'Orsay collection
My favourite Paris Museum. I visit the Orangerie not only for Monet's incredibly beautiful water lilies but also because of the Paul Guillaume collection of fine early 20th century art.

Easy paced , superb collection, crowd minimal. After visiting the Louvre, worth visiting especially if you are an Impressionist lover ,The crowds arent that many , Children and Under 26 yr old EU nationals with proof of identity enter free. I enjoyed the museum and didn't find it challenging rather something I could pace myself through. Toilets also clean

Superb must see Monet collection. Probably my most beloved Paris museum -- developed by Monet and his family to house his spectacular room-sized murals of Giverny at different times of day and year. You will experience joy and serenity that is almost indescribable

Monet fans will love this museum. Lovely museum with smaller crowds.
The beautiful twin oval galleries are a must for fans of Monet.
Tickets purchased on line can save time waiting in line.

Monet's Panoramic Glory. We were running short of time but we just couldn't pass up the opportunity to see Monet's huge paintings. The museum is across the Seine from the D'Orsay, so it made sense to run over before our lunch reservation. Note: you can easily do the Louvre (steps away) and this museum on the same day. As we had our museum pass, we breezed through the line and security (you will have to check your backpacks). Also, afternoons are less crowded than mornings, but they are closed on Tuesdays. If you are short on time, simply take the steps up and you will enter the two round rooms displaying Monet's panoramic paintings of his gardens in Giverny. Simply gorgeous.

What a beautiful and quaint museum.. This was my first time in this museum. I missed this place the first time I was in Paris. This is a hidden gem, as far as I'm concerned. Not large, this museum boasts many artists, with all the paintings to be viewed completely up close. Monet, Picasso, Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse and much, much more. There are two HUGE rooms with Monet's Water Lilly looooooonnnnnnggggg paintings. Just gorgeous and tranquil. A high recommend.

Beautiful Experience. This was one of my favorite museums in Paris. It's small, which means that you can visit the whole thing without getting overwhelmed, and it is the best way to see Monet (exactly as he would have wanted you to!) I didn't have any line to enter, though it was a little busy inside.
A preferred museum visit. A favorite for years. Usually less crowded with tourist hordes and therefore far more pleasant an experience in tourist season than the Musee d'Orsay.
surrounded by colors and light. The current organization of the museum is wonderful, you sit down and are actually "inside" the waterlilies, surrounded by their colors and lights. Do not miss it.

Water Lilies. If you are a Monet fan, this museum is worth a visit based on the water lily paintings alone! We arrived when the museum opened to beat some of the crowds. The water lily rooms are much more enjoyable when you can somewhat see from one side of the room to the other and take in several of the panels at the same time. Of course, the museum is filled with many other fantastic pieces of art, as well.
If you like Monet. Then this is a must. Pieces are huge, beautiful, and the museum was not so crowded. Line was a bit long, but worth it.

A must see!. We couldn't visit Paris and not see Monet's Water Lilies. We used the Paris Museum Pass to get in. There wasn't any line at all. There are basically two exhibits, the Water Lilies upstairs and another exhibit downstairs. Both are worthwhile seeing. We were able to take photos and carry around a backpack. We visited on the same day after visiting the Louvre and de Orsay.

One of the best places to see Monet's water lillies. There are a few museums where you can see Monet's water lillies but this museum was designed for it and first hand directed by the artist himself. Try to be early and beat the queue
Can't be missed. This is a small museum, quiet, airy and houses the most incredible exhibition of Monet's, Renoir's and Cezanne's paintings to name but a few.

Not to be missed!. We were simply astounded by this museum devoted to the best work of the French Impressionists! Anyone who loves this wonderful genre of art must see this museum for a fuller appreciation of the genius of several of the French painters of this era. And, of course, the Monet Water Lilies covering the walls of two rooms are superb! Steve W.

A small jewel of a museum. This museum tour began with viewing the two rooms of Monet's water lilies series. The space is perfect for showing these paintings. Downstairs there were more impressionists and other exhibits. Sitting by the Tuileries Gardens, it is easy to enter. I think the visitor numbers were nothing like we found at the Louvre and D'Orsay. There was a short line going in, but the wait was really not so long. The downstairs exhibits surprised me. I didn't expect to find so much art. This admission is included in the Paris museum pass.

Monet's gift to Paris. I love l'Orangerie, but I have found it rather crowded the last two times we visited. I recommend going early and getting the audio guide unless you are already very expert on the artists. The extra information made a big difference for my spouse.

I could live in one of the Monet rooms. This houses Monet's largest waterlilly paintings, and they're magical. Almost as good is the broad collection bequeathed by the widow of famous art dealer Paul Guillaume. All the great Impressionists are represented, as well as Modigliani and others who followed.
Stunning. See the water lilies as Monet wanted you to. The perfect setting for these masterpieces. Well worth a visit.
Well worth a visit. Only small but a great art gallery and worth it just for the Monet water lily collection alone! We used our Eurostar tickets to get 2 for 1 so was really reasonable.

Monet and more. I went early in the morning and had pretty much exclusive viewing of the Monet Lillies, This is a small gallery and allows you to appreciate the art on show - 2 levels monet on top other impressionist downstairs - went here twice as such a nice place to contemplate the art - Was included in Paris Pass

My favourite museum in Paris!. By far my very favourite museum experience. It is a small gallery but very well laid out and lovely gift shop/cafe with reasonably-priced items. The rooms with the lilies truly has to be seen in person to fully experience the size and beauty! Fantastic! Enjoyed having the audio guides.
Easy museum. really enjoyed our visit to this museum - it is an easy short visit. Really nice to come to from the Tuileries Gardens

Monet's Waterlillies and so much more . We visited the Musee de l'Orangerie on a hot day in Paris and we're delighted to find it was relatively empty. We headed straight for the Waterlillies and had plenty of time to sit and enjoy them. There were only a few other people about and it was a pleasure and a delight not to have to queue and wait to see them (unlike the Mona Lisa at the Louvre). If you have time to fit a visit in its well worth it to escape the crowds and soak up the peace and calm environment.
Monet unbound. This is a total and inspiring must. The curved murals are required education for any Monet admirer. Take your time and look up close and from the center.
Must see for Impressionist/Monet lovers. Oh my the panels of water lilies are so beautiful. We knew we wanted to see them and we were still blown away!!!
Great, small Paris museum. Good collection. You will not tire yourself out visiting this great little museum. Never really crowded.

Small, packs a punch, overlooked but terrifically curated. Worth it for the Monet waterlily rooms alone, but a terrifically curated museum with many greats from the impressionists. Definitely get the audioguide, as probably 70% of the painting have commentaries and they nicely situate the pieces with history, origin stories, and many quotes from the artists, their friends, and contemporary critics. The museum is relatively small, so you can do it well in about an hour and change. And thankfully much less crowded than the D'Orsay or Louvre, so you can actually appreciate the art without a busload of tourists bumping into you to snap a photo.

Late in day entry still charged full price. We got here late in the day (stood in queue for 35mins) so by time we got to security point it was after 5.15pm. Still charged full price to then almost being chased out closer to 6pm. It closes at 6pm but they were trying to herd you to the exit before then. If we had extra days in paris we wouldnt have gone in so late but due to trip constraints we wanted to go in.Feel that perhaps they could offer discount entry after a certain point.
If you like Monet's water lilies, the best ones are here.. Just absorb the Monets, the go downstairs to other great paintings. Return for a memorable gaze at the water lilies.
Loved Monet's work- it is fabulous!. some of the work on the lower level is not worth the rented space they are mounted on but the top and middle level are definitely! I like the audio as well.

A must see for Impressionistas. Not just Money and Cézanne but all the great impressionists and post impressionists. Renoir, Modigliani and others. The rooms are spacious and invite quite reflection. If you arrive at opening time you are assured of less obstructed observations.The museum is in the Tuileries Gardens right by the Place de la Concorde.

Lovely pictures. Really loved seeing the water lilies and the Walter & Guillaume collection.
The upstairs rooms containing the lily pictures were quite busy and the staff seemed intent on trying to get everyone to stay quiet by shushing loudly - which was distracting and didn't really seem to help.
extra with mussee d'orsay. also very open theme and a lot to see , Picaso , Monay, very impressive hidden away from the louvre ,and just as talented
Must-see Museum. A small but wonderful collection featuring Monet, Cezanne, Gaugin and other great French painters. I would recommend you rent an audio guide to get full value from your visit.

Sublime. Avoid the lines at the Louvre and start your day at Musee de l'Orangerie. Biggest take away: Claude Monet's Waterlilies is unimaginably beautiful. Seen in total, displayed the way Monet intended (in an elliptical room) , this is one of the most awe inspiring works of all time. The museum is clean, audio headsets are available (and recommended), not too big to see in a couple of hours, or skip everything else and hang out in the waterlilies rooms all day!

Miss this, miss life!. OMG, if you are in Paris for hours rather than days then grab a taxi to this museum and experience Monet; your life will be all the richer for this experience.His massive works are displayed in all their glory in this beautiful building that many would pass without a second thought. Because of this the museum isn't a crush of people and you can just sit an soak up the brilliance that is Monet.If there's an audio guide, I wasn't aware of it but then seen my review on du Louvre for my experience with them this trip.There's the obligatory gift/souvenir shop but I must say these are much better than the trashy tat you get some places, in fact the three museums, Louvre, Orsay & Orangerie all have a good selection of decent memorabilia. Sure you can get fridge magnets but also fashions, books, CD's/DVD's, mugs etc and some overlap but mostly specific to the venue.Again there's a cafe which is not a bad snack option, you won't nessecarily need a full day at this museum but the Louvre and d'Orsay do require a day each at least so combining this one might be tricky unless you're doing a night visit to one of the latter. I recommend you do this last of the three combined with a special lunch to contemplate all you've seen.

Hidden Gem. Paris is full of Monet and he created these waterlily panels for this museum and for the people of Paris to reflect and relax. You surely will if you go here. The painting downstairs are the collection of a private art dealer and I found it to be one of my favorites.

If you like Impressionism you have to go !!. Some of the best impressionist’s masterpieces are there, specially remarkable are Monet's massive water lilies. Very well exposed, big space with excellent light, you can appreciate the nice details. Take advantage of the combination ticket with the Musee d'Orsay. My wife and I went during the morning to l’Orangeire and then went to d’Orsay avoiding the big queue to get tickets. Remember that l’Orangeire is closed on Tuesdays and d'Orsay on Mondays.

Breathtaking. Visiting Monet's house and gardens had always been on my bucket list. But when I finally decided to go, I had to add the Musee de l'Orangerie to the list. Long time fans of Monet's, this is a definite must see. I visited on Bastille Day and line was very long but well worth it to see these magnificent paintings.
L'Orangerie. Don't miss this magnificent exhibit of some of Monet's best-known works! The Orangerie itself is gorgeous, too.
Les Nympheas. Beautiful presentation of Monet's Water Lillies series from Giverny. Not to be missed by any fan of impressionists.
Love the way the Monet's are displayed. The light, the curvature, the length ... it is all perfect! Definitely worth the combination ticket with the Musee d'Orsay.

Do not walk past this museum..........please!. Situated at the far end of the Tuileries from the Louvre this impressionist gallery contains some of the best works of Monet, Manet, Pissaro and Degas etc and should be on any visitors list of attractions to see in Paris. Go early morning or late afternoon to avoid the crowds heading to see Monet's massive waterlilies canvasses and enjoy the paintings in the lower gallery.

Little but so beautiful. l'Orangerie a tiny museum that has the best collection of Monet's water lilies paintings. Huge pieces and and only four of them fits to one room. You can admire them far as the whole and close the beautiful details. Downstairs you can find many beautiful paintings by Renoir and other famous artists.
Monet's Waterlilies on display. There is more than just 8 panels of Monet's water lilies here, but this is the reason to come to the Orangerie. It is so beautiful and so peaceful to see.
Great Monet Panels. If you like Monet, this is a must see! These beautiful pieces will get you lost in Monet's world. They are unique i their size. No pictures.
Beautiful. Had no idea of the true scale of these beautiful paintings. Stunning presentation, benches to be able to enjoy them too.

Charming museum in the Tuileries. Centrally located in the Tuileries a few minutes walk from the Louvre. Most known for the Waterlilies from Monet, it has an excellent selection of impressionist paintings. Discounted admission if you buy a ticket that combines the Orangerie with the Orsay.

Small museum but it's worth seeing Monet. The only reason I wanted to go here was because of Monet. As always, the entrance was free (if you are under 25 and a citizen of EU). Seeing Monet room was really the highlight. It is so beautiful and absolutely worth seeing.

A Small Yet Wonderful Museum. What a wonderful museum to see how this masterful french impressionist painter's work was creatively displayed, sometimes in a curvilinear frame, that brought our the best of imagery of his masterful work. A relatively small museum, yet such an enriching and enjoyable experience.

Understated & quiet . We popped in here for an hour just to see the water lilies by monet. It was well worth it. There beautiful, full of life and very peaceful. Great use of space in this museum. Not very big so something you could do In between tours maybe. Try and leave extra time to get through security at busy times.

A Must Do Top 10:Musee de l'Orangerie. What a beautiful museum. This a must do Top 10 in Paris with beautiful collections, but every museum we have visited in Paris is special in its own way. Claude Monet's "Water Lilies" alone is worth the price of admission.The Metro has a stop about a block away or you can walk across the Seine River from a Metro stop there.As with almost all the museums, get there at opening if possible and be prepared for a scan. We arrived on a Monday at opening in March and quickly went through the scans and purchased tickets in less than 5 minutes. Plan your visit carefully, we have seen an hour plus line waits when we strolled by.

Entire mural by Claude Monet. Besides Monet there are small collections of Cezanne, Renoir Matisse, Picasso and others. The walk from the Louvre very enjoyable with numerous trees, sculptures, fountains, benches and an outdoor care.Very warm on entry level floor.Best to choose a meeting point like the gift shop which also has counter service for beverage /snack.Be sure to get a Two day Paris museum pass for easy entry!

The Orangeries. The Orangeries was one of our favorite attractions, if you love and appreciate art. The Monet's are absolutely amazing and serene, could spend hours just sitting in those 2 rooms and taking all of his beautiful art in. Line was a bit long to get in, even with museum pass, but worth it!

Always great. This is a must-see for anyone remotely familiar with Monet. One cannot visit Paris without seeing the water lilies. They are simply spectacular, especially when you realize that Monet was nearly blind by the time he finished them.There is also a nice collection that includes Renoir, Matisse, Picasso and others.Do try to book your tickets on line ahead of time.

Awe-inspiring. One of my favorite museums in Paris. We came late in the afternoon and had to speed through the other exhibits, but for me the highlight is always the Monet's Nympheas (Water Lilies). The sheer size and scope of these huge paintings is awe-inspiring, and the fact that they are illuminated only by natural light adds to the thrill. Lovely gift shop, too! I got a combination ticket for L'Orangerie and Musee d''Orsay, which I believe saves a few Euros. Don't miss this gem!

A hidden gem not to be missed!. Courtesy of our Lonely Planet guidebook: “Housed in a 19th century orangery built to shelter the garden’s orange trees in winter . . . you’ll find eight of Monet’s enormous, ethereal Water Lilies canvases bathed in natural light." Less well-known than the Musée d’Orsay, the Musée de L’Orangerie was far less crowded and featured a nice collection of Cézanne, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir, Modigliani, and Soutine.
A well-curated gem. This was my favourite museum in Paris. Although it is small is punches above its weight and is packed full of fantastic and significant pieces of art.

Must do in Paris!. You cannot visit Paris with out a visit to see one of the most amazing collection of paintings in the world. The paintings, the space, the experience is truly moving if you are artistically motivated in any way, you must visit.
love, love, love. I visit almost every time I go to Paris. This was my third visit. And like the first and second, It was breathtaking. I want to live in this museum!

Precious Claude Monet's paintings!. If Impressionism is your thing, you would be impressed with Monet's huge water lilies paintings at Musee de l'Orangerie. There are two round rooms and each displays four water lilies paintings, you could easily spend the afternoon just sitting there and immerse yourself in Monet's works. The rest of the museum isn't so big but this is definitely my favorite in Paris.

Tiny treasure. I arrived when the museum opened at 9am and got in to the famous "Waterlilies" with only a handful of other people! I was initially sceptical, but upon spending a bit of time just staring at them and taking in all the detail and effects used in the paintings, I came away mightily impressed by Monet's masterpiece. They really are quite soothing and very pretty. By 10am there was a crowd and it was impossible to get an unobstructed view of any of the "Waterlilies" anymore - go early or don't go is my tip. The downstairs collection of other paintings from the late 19th/early 20th century was an eclectic mix of good and bad work from various different painters. The Orangerie is easy to add to any Paris itinerary due to its central location and is worth a quick trip.

Use Museum Pass for this. Unless you just love Monet's water lilies, don't pay for price - use it as a quick stop if you have the Museum Pass. In fact, this gallery is exactly why a Museum Pass is the correct way to do Paris. We were at this gallery for 20 minutes: if I had paid full price I would not have been happy. But with the Museum pass, 20 minutes felt just perfect.
Too small. There was really only one gallery besides the Water Lillies rooms. In and out in less than 1 hour. Not worth the price but nice small collection of impressionist art.

Breathtaking!. By far my favourite museum in Paris. I could sit in those rooms housing Monet's full Waterlilies for hours soaking them in. Beyond that group of paintings, there are many other rooms of Impressionism and paintings by Monet's inspirations and friends. This museum is doable in 1-2 hours and will leave you refreshed, not more exhausted.

Still breathtaking 25 years later. First visited L'Orangerie 25 years ago whilst backpacking. Returned this summer with my two teens. The sight of Monet's works, displayed as he intended, still overwhelmed me even though I'd seen it before. The kids both loved it and it re-affirmed for me that this is one of my favourite Paris museums. Can be done quickly, or sit down on a bench and let your soul enjoy the beauty.

A quiet haven. Have always enjoyef cezanne and monet so have been looking forward to visiting. Brought tickets ahead as per my norm as i had heard there have been large queues. As it happened was a quiet saturday and we were able to relax and enjoy the paintings. If you dont have thr energy fir orsay this is a nice smaller scale place.
Nice, compact. Offering a lot of impressionist pictures, this museum is nice, in particular when viewed with the help of the audio guide.

There are better museums.. I love Monet but these were not as impression as I thought they would be. Colors seems faded and washed out. Other paintings were good and I enjoyed the Versailles treaty paintings.

DO NOT MISS. If you are in the area of the Louvre or the Musee d'Orsay, youre already here, so do NOT pass the opportunity to see the Musee de l'Orangerie. Surely you've seen the Monet's in books or postcards or magazines but when you see them in the proper light, in true scale and arranged in the intended relationship to each other that they should be it is truly amazing.

delightful. You go for Waterlilies, but you discover much more. Buy the Paris Museum Pass and skip the longer line for entrance and security. The Waterlilies rooms are enchanting, and even in busy times the crowds are respectful.

Monet, what can I say?. We went solely to see Monet's water lilies. We walked into the first room of them and I welled up with tears. It's such an incredible display. The way the paintings are exhibited is quite perfect. I waited until my 5th time in Paris to visit this museum and now I know I want to go back.

Monet is amazing. My teenage son actually added this museum to our must see list. That doesn't happen often, I am sure. I was taken aback by the sheer size of the water lilies paintings. I never realized how large they were! We spend quite a while just looking and soaking them in. The building was build, I believe to house these paintings. They surrounded us with a garden of water lilies. The lower floor was full of other impressionist art as well

Perfect visit. We arrived just one hour before closing - 5pm on Wednesday. This was an excellent opportunity to see Monet as it is meant to be seen. I also loved showing my daughter other great artists in a relaxed and beautiful setting.

A journey into beauty. Apart from the splendid collections of impressionist paintings, this museum offers you a unique experience. Visiting the two rooms with Monet's Water Lilies (designed after the artist own concept) you are invited to share a man's great love and special kingdom - the "secret garden" of his home. You can sit and dream for hours in front of the large paintings, or walk by the walls, following their slight curvature that gives a graceful perspective and glow to the landscapes. Delicate colors, vaporous atmosphere...you are there, in Monet's garden, diving into beauty!

More art, but some interesting pieces. A small gallery with some distinctive pieces of art from the likes of Picasso (pre cubist) and Cezanne as well as Monet's big water lilies.The Orangery is conveniently located just of the Place de La Concorde and in the Tuileries Gardens next to the Seine.Worth a visit if you are into art.
Love the size!. Great art work well displayed. Went for the Monets but got pulled in by the other artists as well. Good experience.

An oasis in the heart of Paris . If you can only manage one museum in Paris, this is the one, if perhaps a tie with the Rodin museum. On a hot dusty day the magnificent panoramas by Monet refresh exactly as the artist intended. The permanent collection includes fine post impressionists and there was an excellent temporary exhibition on Apollinaire during my visit.

lots of Impressionist paintings. If you love Impressionism, you must go here. It is home to Monet's Water Lilies paintings. They were so much more than I expected. They are housed in two rooms designed in an infinity pattern, as Monet specified, and they consist of almost 100 linear meters of his lily pond. The Orangerie offers much more too. You can get near the original art and really examine it. IT's not a huge museum, but everything in it was awesome. Arrange for a tour, and you won't be sorry. This was the most inspiring museum I visited.

Dive in Monet's garden . We finally had a change to see the amazing nymphaea by Monet. The display of this huge canvases is minimal but aims at accruing the beauty of the paintings. They are divided into two rooms and they are really gigantic. Definitely worth a visit (and the 9€).

Thank you, Claude. One of the greatests gifts from one human to humankind must be Monet's waterlilies. I was lucky to go here and spend a lot of time looking at this incredible series of paintings. Then, when I was nearly overwhelmed, dozens more Picassos, Matisse, Cezanne, Rousseau, Sisley awaited below. Tip: Get a cup of the freshly squeezed orange juice.
Best museum in Paris . Perfect size. It has Monet water Lilly's which are beautiful. And downstairs so fantastic art too. I would say that it was the best museum we visited
Lovely. I did not go here until my 5th or 6th trip to Paris (after all there is just so much to see and do in Paris). What a wonderful surprise. I loved it.

Monet's chapel. This little gem can't be missed if you are a fan of Claude Monet and the French Impressionist painters. The water lily paintings! The line was long though, go early, it's well worth it. You can get a discounted ticket combined with the Musee d'Orsay.
Water lillies. The gallery really only has one painting. But then it is perhaps the greatest painting in the world. Worth the visit. Simply amazing.

tranquil and reflective musee in the heart of Paris. The Musee de l'Orangerie is by far one of the most spectacular places to see Monet's waterlilies. We were mesmerised by the expansive wrap-around canvases that fill the museum. It was quiet and peaceful in the beautifully lit space.

"The water! It dances!". Breathtaking.Soul filling.Magnificent.We spent a few hours here, 2 families with 3 young kids between us. The gallery offers Ipads with special activities to do with the art. Monet's Water lilies was.... everything I hoped it would be. A bastion of calm, serenity and left me with that feeling you get after visiting a forest. A sense of connection and well being. The gallery is perfectly sized for a visit with kids. We visited in April and there was almost no wait to get in. That may be due to the reaction to the Bataclan attacks or a fluke because I get the feeling its usually incredibly busy. But either way it is worth the effort to go. I would make an attempt to get in very early and spend time in Monet's Lilies before it gets crowded.
Monet and Van Gogh!. It was enough for me just to see Monet and Van Gogh's masterpieces. We were just in awe of this place.
I could have stayed here all day. It's not just the scale of the work. It's the mastery of the work. Plan to sit down and take it all in.

Breathtaking!. The Monets are so beautiful and if you grab a seat you can just drink in their colours, or walk up close to see their paintily details, or stand back to take in their scope and enormity! Then there's the gallery of other famous artists, on a different level. This is a nice little bite sized collection - something that can be handled in detail in one visit without being overwhelmed.

Favourite gallerie. Intimate, thoughtful, get there early to avoid cues, this less well known but amazing example of architecture and very considered exhibition of Monet who designed the building and many other expressionists, make sure you see all of the collection including the basement. loved it. Spent more time than we expected as it was so lovely. Would go again.

Do not miss this small Museum of Monet. This is a small museum in the Tuileries Garden. It is a small museum of Monet's beautiful water masterpieces. It also has a small collection of other artists' works in the lower level. One tip: Purchase the combined ticket for the Orangerie and the Musee d'Orsay. Not only does it save you money, when you go to the much larger and more popular d'Orsay, you will not have to wait in line to purchase a ticket there. Very Helpful!!!

Great, smaller museum with a long line. Great art that is not to be missed. Stand in the middle of the Monet water lilies room for a few minutes and take it all in. This is a small museum, so if you are on a sight-seeing time crunch, you can add to the end of the day for one-two hours. Make time for a line if not showing up early. Even with a museum pass, we had to stand in line for about 20 minutes (the shorter line is for people with a reserved pass). The security controls the number of people going into the museum, so that is doesn't get too loud or crowded.

There isn't too much here and it can take a long time to get in. I didn't really know what was here, but I thought i'd go because I had the pass. But there really isn't a lot to see here. I'd pick something else.

Elegant and plentiful and inspiring without being overwhelmed. We were thrilled to see Monet's Water Lilies so beautifully displayed .... Even planned and designed by Monet himself.And on the lower floor is an abundant and wonderful grouping of some of the best impressionists!The museum is simply and thoughtfully organized so that the visitor has time to see and to digest an incredible array of great art... And outside one can enjoy the splendor of the park and gardens, almost as if you are walking out into an extension of the museum itself.

Stunning display of Monet's Water Lily's. You don't need a tour for this small gallery but it is worth buying tickets on line as the queues are long to get in. The number of people allowed in is controlled which means it takes longer to get in but improves the experience once in the gallery. If you plan to visit Musee de l'Orangerie and Musee d'Orsay it is economical to buy a package that gives you entry to both. We also paid for the audio tour, 5 Euros, which we shared and was helpful. The actual display of the Water Lily's is stunning, 4 enormous paintings in each of 2 rooms. This gallery is definitely worth going to.

Do Not Miss this Treasure!. Two rooms devoted to Monet's water lily paintings, plus a gallery of privately collected paintings from an art dealer in the early 20th century...Soutine, Picasso, Matisse...and more. A jewel of a museum that cannot be missed. The Monet waterlilies paintings are absolutely fabulous, capturing the beauty of the light touching nature, whether it is morning, mid day or evening. Breathtaking.

A must for Monet Lovers. Lovely experience to be surrounded by Monet's; great location within Tuileries gardens. We budgeted an hour but were rushed, substantial art collection in lower level;, budget 1.5 hours for a relaxed pace.
My favorite . This is one of my favorite galleries in Paris. The space and lighting were built to perfectly showcase monet's art. It should be on the list of galleries that are a must.

Uplifting. We visited here during a 3 day trip to Paris. Ideal as the museum is not too large - and contains a variety of interesting work aside of Monet's Waterlilies. Worth getting the audio guide and allowing 2 hours.

Special deal with Musee d'Orsay. Great little museum just off the Seine and in the corner of the Tuileries Gardens. Entry is £9 but if you pay £16 you can get a ticket that is good for both the l'Orangerie and the d'Orsay - a great deal! It isn't huge, but between the two rooms of massive Monets and the other collection of paintings, you can easily spend a couple of hours. There's also a little cafe inside, although on a nice day you'd be better off just buying a sandwich from them and going off to eat it in the Tuileries.

Great museum with kids. If you are traveling with teens, this is a perfect museum. It is small, but contains some very well known and amazing pieces of work that your kids have probably heard of. Monet's water Lily's are breathtaking because they span an entire wall. There is also lots of Picasso. It is a perfect museum for families.

Waterlilies . You'll experience a morning and evening view of Claude Monet's pond in Giverny. Eight expansive works, comprising Monet's end of life work, full two rooms in the gallery. One catching the light of day, and one at night. If you are a fan, you must see. Buy a ticket in advance online with admission to Musee D'Orsay.

very impressive!!. this Museum has a very interesting history. The perception of Monet's masterpieces it's impossible to convey just with few words. For all lover of art and not only - it's a right place.
Magical. We were lucky to have a tour guide who stole hours from us as we were transfixed by the wonderful art works!

Breathtaking display of Monet's Waterlilies. Breathtaking to see Monet's work here, you can really just sit and take in the atmosphere and beauty. Recommend you get a Paris Museum pass which gives you access to the Louvre, Versailles etc and of course includes the Musee de l'Orangerie. It means you can skip large cues and end up paying a lot less, especially if you want to visit a few times during your stay.

Went for the Waterlilies but was surprised by the other works!. We went to show our kids the Monet Waterlilies but were amazed by the wealth of other Impressionist works on show, in fact we enjoyed them more (Gaugin, Picasso, etc). It was very busy the day we visited and we spent an hour in the queue, however it was the free Sunday and we could have booked in advance had we been organised.
Stunning . This is. Avery small museum but well worth it! The water lilies are so incredible and it was a great way to start the conversation about Impressionism with our two boys

Perfect Sized Museum. Paris museums can be a bit daunting. They're huge and can take days to see. Unless you're used to it, you tire quickly. Not the Musee de l'Orangee where you'll find six beautiful Monet Water Lillies paintings with another highlighted painter. 45 minutes or so later and you're on to your next attraction. Perfect!

Monet was spectacular. We went with three small children and only visited the Monet water Lillie galleries. The paintings were breathtaking. The security guards are very strict, we weren't allowed to carry our kids on our backs

Lovely!!. This museum is not popular, however it is definitely worthwhile. It is a beautiful, quiet place that I think everyone will love! There are not a lot of exhibits, but what is on display is breathtaking! There are two rooms specifically dedicated to Monet's water lilies. These rooms are spectacular and something you do not want to miss!

A Must for Monet Lovers. View two wonderful displays of Monet's "Waterlilly" series in rooms specifically designed by Monet to house these panels. Don't miss the comprehensive collection in the lower level also. Housed in the original royal orangerie in the Tuileries gardens at the Plac d'Concord entrance.

Good for Monet. If you like Monet then you will be blown away by 4 huge wall murals of his water lillies. Well worth seeing.
We went early and there weren't long queues despite it being high season. Staff were polite and helpful and overall experience was great

Small museum with a stunning collection. On a recent visit to Paris we had been recommended to visit the Musee de l'Orangerie at the same time as the Louvre as they are fairly close together. It was a very good decision as the museum is excellent.To begin, the walk to the museum from the Louvre is to be recommended (except when it's raining) as there are some lovely gardens to walk through.The real selling point of the museum itself are the massive waterlily paintings by Monet that fill the walls of the ground/upper floor of the museum. These are really impressive, and the museum staff do a really good job of keeping the space they are in quiet enough and free of people taking too many photos to really appreciate the works.The basement/lower floor of the museum also houses some amazing pieces of art, but for us it would be worth a trip back just to see the Waterlilies again.

Monet Picasso Renoir what could be bad. I love this museum it is so peaceful to see monets workand the collection of a little of everyones is a delight and takes less than an hour if you are limited in your museum patience...it doable fast and a great little gift shop too

Deserves to be better known. Lovers of art should allow plenty of time to visit this museum. Monet's water lily collection cannot be seen in minutes. Sit and study the nuances of light and dark and the myriad of shades of every colour he used. then be prepared for a treat in the second gallery full of Cezannes, Utrillos, Renoirs, Modiglianis, Matisses, Sisleys and Picasso. They are all represented here - and moreAt least they have had the foresight to provide adequate seating, unlike the Louvre. Much appreciated by us older folk. I've always thought the Musee d'Orsay was the best art gallery in the world. Not so sure now.

Well worth the visit. Beyond the Monet rooms which everyone comes to see, there are a number of other fantastic works by Cezanne, Renoir and Monet of course. This is an underrated museum that deserves a visit.

Beautiful little museum of art. Perfectly located right across the river from Musse d'Orsay, and at the foot of Champs-Élysées, close to the Louvre. The l'Orangerie is small, so won't take much time to see everything. Entrance ticket is included in the Paris Museum Pass, so you should work it into your schedule. Worth the visit.

Don't miss this place!. If impressionist art is what you like, Musse de l'Orangerie is the place you want to go. It's at the end of the Tularies Garden and is not as busy as the other two museums in Paris (Louve and d'Orsey). However, a great exhibit of impressionist art and quick to get through with two teenage boys who are just getting to appreciate great art. This museum has on display Monet's work of art that span huge walls. Must go if you're a fan of impressionistic art.HINT: purchase tickets directly from their website and print out tickets prior to bypass all of the "pass" lines!
Crowded but still wonderful. Well worth the wait to see Monet's magnificent Water Lilies murals. The permanent collection is also worth seeing.
an interesting and quieter alternative. Visit this for some less well-know Impressionists. I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the works I saw here, ones I'd never known about.

Very nice . Small museum that is the home to Monet nympheas and not much more. In and out in one hour. Some people find this museum to be a favorite but I didn't. Stroll through the gardens and hold the hand of your honey and whisper something special.

Good grasp of Vincent Van Gogh's painting in one centralised location. The museum is very near to the Concorde Plaza. The entrance is on top of some stairs. The museum was designed to fit in his lengthly works. Less touristy compared to Louvre or Orsay.

A must-see!. It was my third time in Paris but the first for my husband, so we compromised on visiting the Musee de l'Orangerie for him to see some Impressionist and post-Impressionist (and more!) art and me to avoid to see the Louvre and the Musee D'Orsay again. It was really worth it not just for the Waterlilies but also for the beautiful collection on the bottom floor and the temporary exhibition. Tickets are inexpensive and it won't take up your whole day. I definitely recommend it to those on a budget or a tight schedule.

Monets Waterlillies. Enjoyed visiting the Musee de L'Orangerie to see the stunning Monets Waterlillies Paintings. They are housed in a round room and it is stunning with four paintings in each room. You are allowed to photograph just with no flash. Plenty of other exhibitions to see too. Not massive crowds, which was good.
Delightful Surprise. A friend suggested this little detour as we sat in the adjacent gardens, and I was so glad!!! Can be done in an hour!! Monet's Water Lilies?? Yes please!

Great little spot. Included in the Paris Museum Pass, this shouldn't be missed if passing by. The two Monet rooms are an experience and not very crowded as they seem to control and limit entry (causing z little bit of a line outside). The basement collection is my favorite, dense with great works.

Musee de l'Orangerie. This is my favorite museum in Paris. There are 2 circular rooms with Monet's huge water lilies....so beautiful and peaceful. There are wooden benches in the center of the circular rooms where you can sit to enjoy the paintings. If that isn't enough, there are beautiful paintings in the lower floor organized by artist...loved the Picassos.....as well as an interesting temporary exhibit that wast heresies we were there. This museum is not overwhelming like the Louvre or the Orsay. If you have a chance to go to Giverney to see Monet's Garden, you'll want to come back to see these paintings again after seeing the real thing. Photography was allowed in all areas except for the temporary exhibit. We bought 4 day Museum Passes which included admission to many sites but most importantly, there was a separate line at this museum for Museum Pass holders which is significantly shorter than the regular line. After going they security, there is a complimentary place for large backpacks. They asked into wear smaller backpacks on the front of our bodies. Museum passes can be purchased for 2,4 or 6 consecutive days. The 4 day pass was 62 euros. Children 18 and under are free and are allowed to enter with their museum pass holder family members. There are certain evenings that this museum is open late but we did not find it to be too crowded late in the afternoon when we went. Bathrooms were located on the lower level.
Well worth a visit. Less crowded than some, lovely Monet water Lilies rooms. Lots of interesting paintings. Nice shop and cafe.

Beautiful. Please don't take photos. There are signs asking you not to. It's a quiet space to sit and enjoy the paintings. We had people blocking the view using ipads and cameras to record and photograph. It is so annoying and disrespectful to other visitors.
Beautiful, go early to avoid the queues. Beautiful and intimate, go early to avoid queues and crowds. Such an amazing collection on Renoir & money preparatory paintings. My daughter was in awe.

My new discovery. If you like a combine wonderful paintings and sophisticated architecture, this is a place which you should visit. This is a museum which mainly acts "Water lilies cycles" by Claude Monet. There are really huge paintings but is enough space to admiring.
Some building is in a beautiful garden, Tuilleries. Spend there time after your visit in museum, necessarily.

Large Monets. We were able to browse this small museum just before closing time. We loved the large Monets and the small collection of other artists. Gift shop closed before the museum, so we didn't have a chance to browse it before we left.
Monet's Waterlillies!. A wonderful experience seeing "the Masters" works! Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds / queue and hire the audio guide, it makes the whole experience so worthwhile.

Just Beautiful!. This is my second time here and I was not disappointed! This museum contains masterpieces by Renoir, Monet, Matisse, Picasso, Rousseau, Modigliani, etc.. It is a nice size museum, but not too large to do within an hour or two. Even if you see just the several Monet Water Lily panels, it is well worth the visit. Afterwards enjoy a stroll through Tuileries Park or enjoy the fountains of the Place de la. Concorde.
Water Lilies. the title says it all. This museum houses the huge series of water lilies by Monet. It's quite a sight to see them set up like this, where they were always meant to be.

Much more than Monet's Nymphéas [water lilies]. The gallery itself is a piece of art — serene white spaces a perfect setting for the masterpieces on display. The highlight definitely is Claude Monet's masterpiece — Nymphéas [water lilies] but there's much more. Their installation in two large circular rooms is as stipulated by the artist. At the lower level there's much more to see — Modigliani, Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir.....There's a good gift shop and clean toilets.

A must-see museum if you love impressionist painting. If you love impressionist painting, this is a must-see museum except Museum d'Orsay.And it's less crowded. Don't forget to take advantage of their package/ reduced price: Orange museum + Orsay or Orange +Rodin museum.
Beautiful!. I loved seeing the rooms of "wall-to-wall" Monet's. They were having a special exhibit based on Guillaume Apollinaire's life that was terrific.

Absolutely Beautiful!. This is a small museum and has the lovely Monet water garden paintings. I highly recommend especially if you plan to take a trip to Giverny to visit Monet's home and gardens. We visited this museum prior to going to visit Monet's gardens. It is beautiful!

The Monet Murals are a must see. We didn't purchase tickets ahead of time, which was a mistake. We had to wait in a really long line. Since we got in to the museum around 3:30 (and they close at 5:30), we went directly to the Monet murals. Although there were a lot of people entering the museum, the crowds seemed to disperse, so we were able to take pictures of the murals with only a few people in them. Some even had zero people in them. We were able to see the remainder of the museum before closing time.

Very small and very quaint.. It is a small gallery with a really nice intimate feel. That being said.. Because it is it is better to go when it first opens. It wasn't crowded when we went and that was a good thing. This is going to sound bad but it is the god awful truth.. Chinese and some of the other Asian tourists are the bane of your existence while you are in Paris. I kid you not.. It only takes one or two, they will stand inches from painting and point to every detail for what seems like an eternity, then, on to the next painting to do the same annoying thing. Imagine a tour bus full of them.. That is hell on earth and it ruins any experience you will have. No other tourists I have seen do it. You can have 10+ people look at a painting if you stand back like normal. Nope, you get these Asian idiots who block an entire piece because they hover over it. This is why going early is important. Go late? Good luck seeing and experiencing this gallery. Another thing.. The galleries and museums in Paris are interesting about bringing bags in. A back pack will need to be checked in. A purse or shoulder bag doesn't. I have my travel man purse/shoulder bag and I never had to check it. When I wore my slightly bigger backpack I had to bag check that thing all day long.

Small but Awesome. I rate museums by the concentration of must-see works of art/artists, and l'Orangerie is up there. It is very small, only requires a visit of 30-60 minutes if you want, and it is full of beautiful impressionist art, including Water Lilies. We went at the end of the day (got there at 5:15) and got to be the last and only ones in the Water Lilies rooms at closing - I recommend that.

Pair it with the Musee d'Orsay. This place is actually bigger than it looks! You descend into the basement of the building to see work from many well-known artists. I recommend buying a ticket ahead of time, as these people get into the museum faster. I didn't have a ticket and I waited for half an hour, which still isn't much, but if you can avoid it, why wouldn't you? There is a small snack bar and gift shop here. I would recommend an audioguide if you are interested in the special exhibition, as most of it is in French.

Art Lovers Delight. Visited museum on a Saturday morning about 30 mins after it opened, no queues and not a lot of people in at the time so able to have a good look at the Monet Water Lillies wihtout the hassle, an art lovers delight. Do not rush your visit, sit and enjoy. we spent about 2 hrs in the museum, which was more than enough time to enjoy and appreciate.After seeing the Monets, visit the basement to see an excellent collection of other paintings.

my favorite. This small museum is easy to see and has such a wonderful collection of paintings that we have all heard of. The building is impressive and they do have a lift for handicap access. One cannot get in after 5:15pm

"The Sistine Chapel of Impressionism". A French friend of ours suggested we go to the Musée de l’Orangerie, as she thought that we’d enjoy it. She was right. The Musée de l’Orangerie is near the northwest end of the Tuileries Garden, just before the Place de la Concorde. “The Water Lilies (Nymphéas),” by Claude Monet is a compilation of eight gigantic paintings displayed in the two consecutive oval rooms. The four paintings known as “The Water Lilies: Green Reflections,” “The Water Lilies: Morning,” “The Water Lilies: Clouds,” and “The Water Lilies: Sunset” are in one room, and those known as “The Water Lilies: The Two Willows,” “The Water Lilies: Clear Morning with Willows,” “The Water Lilies: Morning with Weeping Willows,” and “The Water Lilies: Reflections of Trees” are in the second room.Upstairs were works from the personal collection of Paul Guillaume, who was a trend-spotting art dealer in Paris in the 1920s. In that collection, we saw paintings by Pablo Picasso, Auguste Renoir, Alfred Sisley, Amedo Modigliani, André Derain, Henri Matisse, Chaïm Soutine, Paul Cézanne, Paul Gauguin, Henri “Le Douanier (the customs officer)” Rousseau, Marie Laurencin, Kees Van Dongen, and Maurice Utrillo. There was also a temporary exhibition (ending on July 18) entitled “Apollinaire, the Eyes of the Poet” that displayed art created during the period between 1902 and 1918 when Guillaume Apollinaire was active as an art critic. The next temporary exhibition is supposed to be “American Painting in the 1930’s” and is scheduled to run from October 12, 2016, to January 30, 2017.As stated by André Masson in 1952, the Musée de l’Orangerie is “the Sistine Chapel of Impressionism.” That’s a perfect description; if you enjoy modern art, go to Musée de l’Orangerie; you’ll be glad you did.

On the bucket list forever... The Monet Water Lilies were stunning beyond words. There are two rooms of Monet's best work. The lighting in the rooms brings the best of these amazing art installations. It is the first thing we saw when we went to Paris and I would go again. Stunning!

Small beautiful art museum not to be missed in Paris. I have visited this art museum almost each of the 5 times I have been to Paris. It is one of my favorites. From the main floor rooms of water lilies by Monet to the excellent collection in the basement, it is memorable, moving and I never tire of seeing it.

Hidden Gem by the Louvre. Go early or go during the closing hour in order to avoid massive crowds. Though the crowds here are smaller than those of the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay.This gem has walls and walls of art and as well the rooms of Monets--which is why you really go. This gem is easy to miss but once you go, it'll be your favorite stop of the whole trip. Well worth it.
Delightful Museum. Words cannot describe these magnificent murals. It's so peaceful that you can stare at them for hours.

Delightful shorter museum!. This museum is anchored by 8 huge murals by Monet; there are benches in the center of the room so you can sit and find details to intrigue you. It's a fabulous presentation and the other art in the museum is interesting as well. A nicely sized museum to avoid art fatigue!

Wonderful museum. We started our day here and then proceeded to the Louvre which is walking distance away. L'Orangerie is a peaceful and beautiful museum. There are two large rooms dedicated to Monet's water lilies. The lower level includes Cezanne, Picasoo, Matisse and many others. Great museum, great visit. They also have a nice gift shop and snack bar.

Nice small museum. It is one of the lesser known museums in Paris but due to its close proximity to the other well-known museums, you may want to spend a few hours here as well. The wall-long paintings on the first floor are very interesting pieces of art. Downstairs, you have a big collecting of paintings, most of which belong to the Impressionist of the late 19th century France.
Monet, Renoir, Picasso and many more!. Semi-circle murals are breathtaking! It is a great museum, not too large. If you like the work of Monet, it is a must see.

My favorite museum. Much smaller than the major museums and not that interesting if you don't like impressionism but my favorite museum by far. The water lilies are breathtaking. It's an experience. Wonderful.
It's Monet ~ Gotta love it!. Wow! Got to go! See for your self! Beautiful! Unique! I do not want to ruin your experience so I shall not say more than go see this museum!

Go for the Water Lilies, but be sure to enjoy the other art as well. Like most people, we went to the l'Orangerie to see Monet's water lilies. However, the museum also has a nice collection of art by other painters. We were especially grateful to see a dozen or so Renoirs, since all of the d'Orsay's Renoirs were out on loan. The display of the water lilies is so impressive, two large rooms where you are surrounded on all sides by Monet.
if you love monet you have to see this. This museum was so beutiful, It is open and the natural light just makes the monet murals that much more beautiful. Don't miss it.

best museum in Paris. in comparison to the other musems in Paris, perhaps it's a little lacking in variety, as the majority of the collection are Monet's 'Les Nymphéas' (waterlilies). However, the quality of these HUGE artworks, in beautiful airy rooms, are well worth seeing!tucked away at the far end of Tuileries (the garden of the Louvre), right next to Place de la Concorde, it's easily accessible and beautiful. the cafe is actually very well-priced for a Parisian cafe, and it often has great exhibitions on the lower floor.

A UNIQUE MASTERPIECE. Visiting MUSEE DE L´ORANGERIE is one of the most beautiful and interesting things you can do in Paris. I have been several times in Paris and never entered this museum, but a friend of mine told me and insisted that I should visit it. He was totally wright! It is a masterpiece of Monet´s impressionism. The Water Lilies are absolutely marvelous and you may stay there for hours and get lost into the landscape. Whenever I hv the chance to visit Paris again I will go there!!!

Great location for Monet waterlillies. Glad they reopened this museum and they've made the absolutely perfect space for a panoramic view of the lillies- -just large enough to still be intimate but nit crowded. This smallish museum is well located for a quick stop.
better than expected. Musee de l'Orangerie it's a great museum, with really impressive paintings. I did not expect to be so good, so it you should put in on your list.

Fabulous Monet Water Lilies!. The main draw of the Orangerie is the Monet water lilies murals. They are really beautiful and worth seeing if you like Monet. In addition, on the floor below is a nice assortment of art from various artists. This museum is located right across the Seine River from the Musee d'Orsay so you can easily combine stops in the same day. Total time needed here would be no more than one and half hours. Be sure to have your Museum Pass already purchased.

If you love Monet. Do not miss this Museum if you are a fan of Monet. Just sitting in the room an looking at his murals all around you is overwhelming. The you go to the next exhibilition room and see four more murals.
No luggage store. We tried to visit today but found that there is no longer a luggage store there. Understandable, given the present situation so be prepared.

All the big names are here. An entire wall of Renoir paintings. Very impressive. Picasso, Cezanne, Monet, and many other big names are here. It's not a huge museum, easy to see in a couple of hours. The water lilies are the crown jewel. Get there early, the line was long by the time we left. Spring for the audio tour. It's worth it.
a fantastic museum. don't miss this museum, it's really a wonderful experience. see the art the way it was meant to be seen.
Beautiful escape for a rainy day. This museum houses beautiful impressionist paintings, a treat to go through it. Would recommend following it with a walk in the tuileries garden!
Simply gorgeous. Sitting in the L'Orangerie in the middle of the Monet murals on a hot summer day is heaven! If you can't get to the real gardens, this is as good as it gets.
my favorite Parisian museum. smaller impressionist museum with Monet's Water Lilies and plenty of Renoir, Cezanne and also Picasso.

A Must See. Everyone is familiar with Monet, but most people haven't seen one up close. This place is your chance. There are 3 rooms with GIANT Monet paintings of water lilies that you really have to see up close. Be aware that even though the museum says it closes at 6, you will be kicked out at 5:45.

Great museum!. This museum is great to combine with the walk in the Tuileries Garden. It is a wonderfully organized museum and every painting here is a gem. The rooms with Monet Lilies are spectacular. It is really worth spending a few hours in this museum if you like 20th century art.
Add this museum to all of the main ones. It is well worth going to this museum to see the huge water lilies murals done by Claude Monet. The rest of the exhibits are extra treats as well.
Favorite stop on my tour. Outside the Louvre, this was my favorite museum. There is so much to see and the magnitude of the paintings is unbelievable. It was simply enchanting.

My favourite museum & favourite artist!. Being a Monet lover as a child, this was a must-see on my sight-seeing list and I was not disappointed! I luckily used the 2 for 1 voucher on my Eurostar ticket which was a bonus and it wasn't as crowded as the other tourist attractions. This was the first one on the list so we came early which avoided the crowds and it got busier as we were leaving with queues forming. The Monet art was the best part with 2-3 areas, with more to see downstairs for other artists. I would 100% recommend this if you're an art lover.

Wow, best museum in Paris to visit. Hard to say anything bad about this place. It took us about an hour to cover all exhibits, including the temporary. Monet, Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne, Matisse, Guillaume, etc. 8 huge murals of Monet's water lilies, just incredible. Staff is crack. Atmosphere is perfect. Routing fine. Literally the most enjoyable museum in Paris.

A Gem!. Don't miss a this wonderful little museum. The Monet Lillies on the ground floor are breathtaking. The collection downstairs has spectacular paintings. Allow yourself at least 2 hours and buy the combined ticket which allows you for an extra 2 Euros, an entrance to the D''orsay museum.

Must see if you have heard of Monet!!. I would recommend getting the museum pass if you plan to visit here. The line was quite long, and it took about an hour to get in. After visiting, I would wait longer!!! The Monet exhibit was our inspiration, and it did not disappoint. I could spend all day in one room, but there are multiple. I took a million pictures to make sure the memory doesn't fade. There are other items to see as well, but I'll let you find your way...

Museum for a Monet fan.. We visited the Musse de l'Orangerie in June right after the river Seine had crested to its greatest height in Paris in almost 40 years. Because of the flooding the Louvre and Orsay were both closed to safeguard their collections. I mention that to explain that the line to get in was extremely long. We waited patiently and finally made it in. Security is tight and was a major reason for part of the wait. The museum is basically in 2 sections. One highlights Monet's huge murals painted at Giverny and gifted to the museum. They are worth the visit if you are a Monet fan. The museum is located on the Seine and was an easy walk from our hotel on the Champs Elysees. Several nice local places to eat are within easy walking distance. As with most of the museums in Paris, we highly recommend getting tickets in advance of your visit.

Easy to See . Bought a combo ticket to see Musee d'Orsay and L'Orangerie. Visited at 10 am before going to Versailles. Easy access with manageable crowd. Best display of Monet paintings of seasons. Photographs came out great in these two rooms. Compare styles paintings by Picasso, Ganguin, Matisse, Soutine, etc. 30-60 minutes is enough to enjoy this small museum.

Amazing place to see Monet's works!. This museum is so different from others. It has two rooms each devoted to four large, large, large canvasses of Monet's Water Lilies. You actually feel like you are in the impressionist paintings. Downstairs are select works by Utrillo, Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse and Picasso. There were many beautiful paintings but they were displayed in a way that one did not feel overwhelmed. There were walls with paintings but in front of them were blank walls with benches. It all seemed very manageable and we came away feeling like we really knew something about each painter. Incredible place. The staff were very helpful when we needed elevators rather than stairs and were especially helpful at the main entrance where bright sun and our age did not permit us to stand for the time it took for security and to purchase a ticket. There is much respect for the elderly. Don't miss this museum! It's peaceful and beautiful.

Monet magic. This small museum is a nice one to visit if you only have an hour or two. The two oval rooms with the Monet water lilies paintings are so wonderful, what an amazing experience to be surrounded by such beauty. The collection downstairs is an interesting view into one gallery owner's collection, with some fabulous work by the artists of early 1900's Paris.
great experience for a art gallery. Fewer visitors guaranty better visiting experience and quality art appreciation. This is definitely one of "must-go" for Impressionism lovers.

The Lily Ponds. The museum features impressionists but the main reason to go here is to view Monet's paintings of the lily ponds. There are two oval rooms with 2 paintings that reach 40' long by 8' tall.and 2 others that are 20' long. It is amazing that this could be painted in the way it is done.

Lovely collection. This has one of the most impressive collections of impressionists, particularly of Monet. One gets to see his actual work. At his home, nearer the coast, one can only look at copies.We had the booklet that is sold at the airport giving preferred admission to many of the museums in and around Paris. I recommend visitors get one of these AT THE AIRPORT. They give both substantial savings and access to priority lines. However, in this museum, we were subjected to a much more intrusive search than at any other place we visited during the trip.

Amazing Monet exhibition. Two enormous rooms with original Monet water lilies murals just take your breath away. You just don't want to leave. And there is so much more downstairs!A must see. Go early and avoid the queues.

Beautiful Space!. This is a small museum with two large round rooms with enormous panels by Monet - almost like a panoramic view of his work - it's a quick visit that can be completed in an hour or so. Moet dedicated decades of his life to these works and donated them to for the public. Tip - buy the Musee d'Orsay and the Mudee de l'Orangerie tickets at the same time. You will receive a discount, and will not need to wait in line to get into this museum - and you have two days to use the ticket.

Go for the Waterlilies. It is a very small art gallery that you can finish walking through in less than an hour. It is worth going for the waterlily paintings if you are a fan of Monet (which I am). Those paintings, which cover two rooms, are the centrepieces of the gallery. I sat in those rooms and stared at the paintings. I also enjoyed the paintings downstairs, but not as much as the waterlily paintings.
