One of the most beautiful museum in Paris. The best place for Monet's paintings: beautiful and so relaxing. The collection of modern paintings is also very interesting. The museum is quite small and can easily be visited. It's one fo my favourite place in Paris.

Beautiful gallery. This is such a lovely gallery to wander around. The Monet specific galleries are breathtaking with their design reflecting Monet's wishes for his works. Downstairs, were further collections of many more famed impressionists with many well known pieces on display. The included special exhibition rooms are well worth viewing also as they told the story that linked many of the artists to Guillaume Apollinaire, a poet, writer and collector. The gallery was very easy to move around and we were surprised by how few people were there compared to many other galleries in Paris.

Wonderful museum we had never heard of before . . .. The two oval rooms with the enormous panels by Monet are a must-see before or after going to Giverny. The collection downstairs is very interesting. This and the Musee d'Orsay were our best museum experiences while in France.

Favorite!. I had never really heard of this museum, but I had seen pictures of the huge Monet exhibit inside. So glad we found it! Doesn't require a day like other museums, but art is top notch and stunning, nothing like 360 degrees of Monet!

Breathtaking space. If you are a big fan of Monet, even if you are not, this museum is worth visiting. As you enter the room of 'Water lilies', the pictures haunt you. The ceiling is transparent so you can see the different colors of the pictures as the sunlight comes in and out. The Impressionism collection on the lower floor is also great.

Lovely. If you like the Impressionists, you will love this museum. There are two oval rooms with Monet's water lilies. Absolutely gorgeous, The museum contains a large collection of the Impressionists' works. if it's a sunny day, a great place to have lunch after your visit is the Cafe Des Marronniers located right in the center of the park Jardin Tuilleries where you can sit outdoors what did you have. It has an excellent Caesar salad with chicken, one of the best I've ever had.
Don't pass up Monet!. We truly only went to see the Monet's and enjoyed the entire museum. An excellent place to sit and absorb these masterpieces!

Monet's Museum. This was my wife’s favorite museum, only museum we visited twice.It is near Place du Concord and the tall Ferris Wheel. If you like Claude Monet’s work you will enjoy this very much.It is a small museum and does not take long to see the very large paintings of the Lilly Ponds.

In Monet's Garden. Great museum which lived up to expectations. We saw Monet's Water Lilies in the museum designed for them. We saw Lilies we never saw before, not even in pictures. Main floor was very doable and comfortable to walk around. Downstairs with Modern Art was huge. A great museum, especially if you love Monet as we do.
Loved!!. Gorgeous collection. A must visit in Paris. Very interesting story behind the collection. Beautifully laid out collection.

Breathtaking . The Orangerie appears to be a simple unassuming building. The infinity rooms with the Monet paintings are breathtaking. When I walked into the first oval room with the water lilies, I was not prepared for the breathtaking beauty of those paintings. It's good that there was a bench where I could sit and catch my breath, because when you walk into the room it's surreal, like you've opened the gateway to another dimension. Both the oval rooms are fantastic, no description can prepare you for the paintings. I doubt I will experience this feeling ever again. The icing on the cake are the paintings in the lower level, fabulous collection and very well organised. Fascinating, breathtaking, inspiring, humbling. I had not expected the Orangarie to be such a beautiful experience. We visited the Orangerie with our two young children, who were also spellbound by the paintings. A must visit museum - and I would chose it over the Louvre.
Lovely museum. You need to love Impressionism and probably Monet's water lilies to be worth it, but a gorgeous view. Two rooms of 360 Monet paintings. Go at opening hours to avoid the lines.

visit the Tiuleries garden and finish with musee de l'orangerie. In the musée de l' orangerie you will discover MONET flowers painting you will never see in a other place!
after visit the tuilerie garden and have a lunch or a dinner at terasse of saut du loup insde the gazrden!
How did I miss this museum for all these years. Fantastic Monet experience! The waterlilies series of paintings and many other Monet successes were just a pleasure to see. Highly recommended....

Fantastic Monet. This was my first time at the Orangerie despite a dozen previous trips to Paris. It was definitely worth it - the large Waterlily canvases are beyond compare. Take time to sit and let the details sink in. After you've experienced the famous Monet's be sure to go downstairs for more cool art. The museum pass will get you in the shorter line.

Monet Lives On. in these 4 fabulous water lily paintings. Short lines. Long benches in front of each painting allow the viewer to sit and gaze at these master pieces. Allow an hour for this destination.
Excellent Museum. If you don't have time for the Lourve, this was an excellent option. The Water Lillies are phenomenal. They also offer a student discount. It was a great attraction.

Amazing to see.... Monet's Water Lilies... I never knew how huge his paintings were! Two large oval rooms with the walls covered with his paintings. Each was composed of about 3 or 4 canvases seamed together. Each room had 4 huge paintings.
Don't miss it!. My wife and I almost didn't stop in here. Glad we did! Great collection of Renoir, Cezzane and of course Monet.Be sure to get the audio tour for 5 Euro, worth it for all the details.

Wow, what a simple and beautiful presentation.. Open on Monday at 9a allows you to get in and have room to move. Not a large place with the main floor hosting two rooms of large Monet paintings on all four walls. Simply awesome presentation which deserves a seat to take in these classics. Downstairs hosts some fine works and an exhibition room for you to spend as much time as you'd like...if you like art, want to expose yourself and family to a Masters work, or even simply appreciate history, it's worth the visit to decide for yourself what all the fuss is about.
Peaceful Reflection. Whether visiting the actual garden in Giverny or the paintings of water lilies in the Orangerie, I always enjoy the peace of these Monet paintings.

"Went just to see The Water Lilies!" =). Although I only went to see The Water Lilies and, to be honest, that was the only painting I saw, it was brilliant. I stood in the middle of the room to encompass everything. It was great! I stood in both rooms for about 30 minutes. Walked away to exit the museum, but had to have another look. Looked for another 30 minutes......Could have stayed for another hour. =)
lovely atmosphere. This museum of art is sensitively laid out in the best lighting to achieve a calm atmosphere in which one can explore the paintings and then have some refreshments in the bar area.

If Monet is Your Thing, This is a Must. Actually, even if Monet in not your thing, this is something you should see. In addition to Monet's Water Lilies, there is a really fine array of painting by other important artists.Be sure to get a no line ticket. A museum pass works. Or, ask the concierge at your hotel for a no line ticket. There is a small surcharge, but it is well worth it. The regular lines can be over an hour long.

Not much here except the waterlilies. ...and they're awesome. Sitting in the rooms (there are two) with them is peaceful and mellowing. A good alternative to the frenetic activities on the streets. Good idea to go to Giverny first ... and get a better look at Monet at the sister museum, the Musée d'Orsay just across the river. THEN the Orangerie.

Worth the visit!. This small museum has 2 large oval rooms with 3-4 large Monet water lilies panels in each. Although it has other impressionist/post impressionist works, the Monets are what people come to see. You can sit and enjoy the panels for as long as you wish.
Lovely Work. A small museum that is worth the visit. In good walking distance to other museums and small enough to add to the day.

Skipped this my first three times in Paris, Was I ever crazy?. In all our trips to Paris, we had never visited L’Orangerie, so that was our first stop. I had the combination ticket from the Musee D’Orsay the day before, so we did not have to wait to get in. The top floor has nothing but two rooms in an elliptical shape with 360 degree paintings in each of the water lily gardens. We had just seen another such display at the Museum of Modern Art in New York in March, so were not as wowed as we might have been.From 1914 until his death in 1934, Monet's art dealer amassed an extraordinary collection of several hundred paintings, from Impressionism to Modern Art, along with pieces of African art. When he died, at the height of his career, rich and famous throughout Europe and in America, he was planning to found a museum. His widow Domenica, remarried to the architect Jean Walter, transformed and reduced the collection while also making new acquisitions. She wanted to name the collection after both her husbands when the French State acquired it in the late 1950s. From then on, the collection was destined for display at the Musée de l’Orangerie. Currently, it comprises 25 works by Renoir, 15 by Cézanne, 1 each by Gauguin, Monet and Sisley, all from the Impressionist period. From the 20th century, the museum boasts 12 works by Picasso, 10 by Matisse, 5 by Modigliani, 5 by Marie Laurencin, 9 by Douanier Rousseau, 29 by Derain, 10 by Utrillo, 22 by Soutine and 1 by Van Dongen. This was the entire bottom floor and the audioguide was so good that we ended up there for 5 hours.The audio was the best we have ever heard in an art museum anywhere in the world and the museum should not be missed along with the Musee D'Orsay if you have ANY interest in Impresssionism

Fantastic Museum!. Well I certainly enjoyed my planned visit for gazing at the Monet Water Lillies...however, I enjoyed the exhibit of the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Clooection just as much!!! Then to see Apollinaire ...well it was a totally awesome day!!!

Must see. Totally overwhelmed. This is a must-see for fans of French Impressionism and Monet. But even if you are not, you'll find the two halls exhibiting the water lilies very very impressive. They show the depth of Monet's method of capturing light and colour. It's an attempt to capture 3-D by 2-D paintings. Most amazing. The rest of the regular exhibition is equally impressive. Expect to wait and queue. So, work out the logistics and scheduling of your activities while in Paris.

Amazing Monets. We knew we were taking our children to Giverney to see Monet's gardens so we took them to this museum the day before. They loved his paintings and got really excited to see the place he was inspired by so that when they finally got to his house they were over the moon. The wait to get in was long but if you know the day and time you want to go you can buy your tickets in advance and avoid the long lines!

You need to be an art lover to appreciate!. If you love Monet, you will love the l'Orangerie. Did i need to spend the money to go see what I saw? Only if I loved art which I don't. So It was pretty but...

Art. Cafe. Culture. So much beauty. A small cafe adds the opportunity to eat a light lunch in a very pleasant spot alongside the Tuileries. It's not just Monet, but Renoir, Modigliani and more. Small and impressive. J'adore.
Gorgeous waterlilies!. The waterlilies by Monet are truly amazing! You have to come in person to fully appreciate its beauty. No print out can justify it. Definitely worth a visit.

A Must See. I had been waiting for years to see this place and it did not disappoint. It is a special experience to see Monet's Water Lily paintings in a space built to the artist's specifications and it was just as I had hoped it would be. I was not expecting the other floor full of art which I also liked and the museum was not overrun so it was easy to enjoy. As a tip, I recommend visiting this museum before the Musee d'Orsay as you can buy a joint ticket that (a) is cheaper than the sum of the two regular admissions and (b) allows you to avoid the long ticket line at the d'Orsay (the lines at the Orangerie tend to be shorter from what I am told).

Great rainy day activity in Paris. This is a small museum but worth the ticket price to see the 2, yes 2 circular Monet waterlily displays. I didn't realise there were 2 rooms and don't remember reading that anywhere here so if you decide to go, make sure you see both rooms. The rest of the museum has a wide variety of artworks, including more modern pieces. Spent just over one hour here on a cold, rainy day. Had pre-purchased tickets and glad we did because the ticket line was at least 30mins in the cold wind and rain.

A true homage to Monet and his Giverny paradise!. If you are a true admirer of Monet, then le Musée de l'Orangerie is where you must go. Couple this visit either before or after visiting his home and water lily garden in Giverny and you will truly bask in the glory of his inspiration!Monet painted those canvases in Giverny but it was only 20 years after his death that the government of France turned his vision to reality and created this museum in his honour. The rooms containing these precious paintings are curved, as Monet had envisioned it, and perfectly display his canvases. There are comfortable seats located in the center of each room so that admirers may sit and contemplate ... losing themselves in the beauty of representation. Monet captures light, movement, and the pure wonder and love he felt for his peaceful haven. It is truly not to be missed!!
Monet lover's delight!. Must see to believe! Enormous Monet paintings that are impossible to describe. Definitely worth the admission price!

A must-see! . We went to this museum, the Lourve, and Musée D'Orsay, and this was by far our favorite. It was the lease crowded, and the rooms were designed by Monet himself in order to display his lilies the way he thought they should be shown. Exquisite. We also did a guided tour in English for an extra 6 Euros, which I would highly recommend. They don't allow large backpacks into the museum, and instead check them at the front- so try to pack light when you go.

Monet"s Water Lillies in the "round". I had no idea Monet had this "installation" of water lillies in 2 rooms in this museum. you are basically going to this museum to see these 2 rooms and it is so worth it. Included in your museum pass so go there! Sit on the benches and just gaze at these fabulous works- it will lower your blood pressure, guaranteed!
Pleasant . Small, especially in the wake of the Louvre. Remarkably pleasant. Monet Waterlilliy exhibit alone is possibly worth the price of admission.Enjoy the fountain and free seating nearby.
Lovely gallery. Enjoyed this rather quiet gallery near the Tuilierie gardens. Good security. Photo taking allowed without a flash.The Monet room was worth a seat. Lovely time here.

Great museum of well known impressionists. This morning we went to Musee l'Orangerie. They have some amazing paintings of the Impressionists: Monet, Renoir, Vincent Van Gogh, Gauguin, Derain, Delauney, Picasso, Modigliani (2), Chaim Soutine, excellent Cubism paintings etc. This museum is a must for people who love the Impressionists. You can make photos almost everywhere without a flash. YOU ARE NOT ALLOWED TO MAKE PHOTOS IN THE PART APOLLINAIRE (where excellent Cubism paintings are). You will be told off pronto if you do.

see Monet's water lilies. The Orangerie is most notable for its enormous murals of water lilies painted by Monet on the walls of enormous oval rooms downstairs. Amazing art which must be seen. In the Tuileris Gardens in the middle of Paris.

Worth it for Renoir nymphees along. The huge set of eight nymphee paintings by Renoir are simply breathtaking.It's worth sitting down for a while at each and soaking up the atmosphere. The rest of the musee doesn't quite live up but it's still good
Visual Bliss!. Well worth visiting just to absorb the stunning colour variations in this magnificent work of art. Then to study the light effects on the art as the day's lighting changes.

Loved the Water Lilies!!. This is a great museum that although smaller had a great vibe. I could have spent the day just looking at the two Water Lilies paintings. But in addition to those, there are a lot of great paintings hung in a very attractive manner. This is a great museum!!

Best Monet museum anywhere. If you love Money's famous watercolors, this is the museum to see in Paris. The museum was designed for these specific paintings and the outside light illuminates the water lilies perfectly. Downstairs they have additional important paintings from Monet's contemporaries to give you a fuller sense of the impressionist movement.

Dramatic waterlilies. Have always wanted to see Monet's Waterlilies, so bucket list this one's for you. I was surprised at the size of the paintings and their curved display. The paintings had so much depth, like looking at velvet. I can't imagine the genius that it takes to paint such beautiful art and in such a size that you get lost in it. I was very glad I maxed out my museum pass by going to l'Orangerie. I didn't feel the museum had a lot to offer beyond the Monet's (sorry to those who, in their opinion, that love this museum.) If you love Monet, definitely go. Enjoy...have a safe trip.

Lovely - absolutely worth a visit for some wonderful impressionist art.. The Musee de l'Orangerie is my #3 choice of places to return to next time in Paris, after only the Musee d'Orsay and Sainte-Chapelle. As at the Musee d"Orsay the art is wonderful, but here it is less overwhelming, more manageable in a single visit. If you like French impressionist art in general and Monet in particular, you must include the Musee de l'Orangerie in your Paris itinerary. To avoid endless long lines, be sure to have a ticket or museum pass and get there early.

Necessary if you are going to visit Giverny. The museum features the Monet Waterlilies and is a must see if you are going to Monet's home Giverny.The whole museum is not overly large so it doesn't take all day and can be fit in your schedule for a morning or afternoon.

Much more than just Water Lilies. The Orangerie has Monet's Water Lilies exhibit, but do take the time to visit the other artists and any special exhibits. They had a special exhibit dedicated to the poet Guillaume Appollinaire and his circle of friends which was quite interesting.

If you like Monet.... Very nicely laid out museum in a city full of museum.
My wife is a big Monet fan and this Musee de l'Orangerie highlights Monet with some room filling murals.
When we went, it wasn't crowded, so it we could walk around closely and really absorb the beauty that Monet brought to the canvas.
mind-blowing. I'm not a big art fan, it's not that I don't like it it's just that I don't love it. But these works where beautiful. Come early so you can enjoy them without a crowd.

Loved this Impressionist museum. Since the Louvre and the ORSAY were closed from the high waters of the Seine, we decided to visit the L'Orangerie and we were not disappointed. Monet actually designed this building so he could properly displayed his masterpieces of with murals of the water lilies. There other works on famous artists also displayed that made the museum a joy. Great impressionists works were there for you to see and enjoy. I sure did. I am also glad that I did this museum first before we traveled to le Giverny to visit Monet's House and Gardens. The Water Lily Garden across the street by going under a tunnel is like heaven would be like. The ponds with the lilies, the wooden boats, the weeping willows, the bridges. One sees first hand the inspiration for Monet's famous paintings. He taught other artists here too. LE Giverny is a delightful little town where you will meet today's impressionists.
Wish we had been able to stay longer. Monet's Water Lilies are not to be missed. Mesmerizing. Give yourself plenty of time to enjoy. This museum is on the Paris Museum Pass.

Great Museum for Monet and ExcellentExhibits!!!. .Totally loved it!!!!Built in 1852 as a winter shelter for the orange trees that lined the garden of the Tuileries Palace at the request of Emperor Napoleon II. The new structure was built on the garden terrace along the SeineBefore this, the orange trees were housed in the Grande Galerie of the Louvre. The exposition of the Nympheas or Water Lilies, according to Claude Monet’s own suggestion, were set out in the two consecutive oval rooms. These rooms have the advantage of natural light from the roof, and are oriented from west to east, following the course of the sun and one of the main routes through Paris along the SeineMonet greatly increased the dimensions of his initial project of eight compositions, started before 1914. He wanted visitors to be able to immerse themselves completely in the painting and to forget about the outside world The first room brings together four compositions showing the reflections of the sky and the vegetation in the water, from morning to evening The second room contains a group of paintings with contrasts created by the branches of weeping willow around the water’s edge. In addition there are other exhibitionsWe saw APOLLINAIRE , LE REGARD DU POETE which looks at the period between 1902 and 1918 when Guillaume Apollinaire was active as an art critic in the turbulent times of the early 20th century.Poet, critic, friend of artists and one of the first to discover African arts, Apollinaire proved to be a key player in the aesthetic revolution that led to the birth of modern art.The exhibition explores Apollinaire’s universe from Douanie, Rousseau to Matisse, Picasso, Braque and Delaunay, from Cubism to Orphism and Surrealism, from academic sources to modernity, from tribal arts to popular arts.JEAN WALTER - PAUL GUILLAUME COLLECTIONPaul Guillaume's collection sits naturally alongside Apollinaire's exhibition. He was introduced into the avant-garde circles by Apollinaire, who became his adviserThe museum’s garden presents sculptures by Rodin, Claudell and Moore among others..Buy tickets ahead of time online. The lines to get in are LONG!!!!!!

Monet Junkie. My husband and I came to this museum so I could see the Monet paintings specifically. I had seen large lily pictures in San Francisco almost 30 years ago and I had always wanted to see them in this venue. There are was a large array of impressionist inspired art. There was a special exhibit going on about Guillaume Apollinaire. It was very interesting to see the connections that this one man had between Picasso, and among many other of the Literati of the time.

Well worth a visit. This museum is a short distance from the Louvre so is overshadowed somewhat. However, I highly recommend a visit here, even if just for an hour. There is a wide range of paintings on display, generally more modern than those in the Louvre. Tourist highlights being Monet's waterlilies and Picasso. No photos allowed of the exhibits. I had the Paris pass and it made little difference to my queuing time.

Monet and more Monet!. We were mesmerised by the beauty and sheer size of Monet's Waterlilies in this large circular room, but to our surprise found there was a second room with more of the master's work set in the round. Such an awesome display of these magnificent works.
Well worth it. A nice reprieve from the bustle of the city and the long walks of the vast Tuileries. This is where you could relax admiring the vast Monets.
Musee de l'Orangerie. Totally worth seeing. Monet's water lilies are incredible. You can see the place in under an hour. Highly recommend you visit.

Ah, those Monets!. Not having pre-booked, we had to queue for about half an hour on a weekday to get in. There seems to be a separate queue for ticket holders but it didn't seem to make that much difference as to how quickly you got in. I imagine that it certainly does though at a weekend or holiday. The Monets are stunning and uplifting. These are found in two oval rooms on the ground floor. There is also a small permanent collection of various painters in the basement as well as a small café. You can opt to just see the Orangerie for 9 euros per adult or get a combined ticket with the nearby Musee D'Orsay.

Must see!. I love Monet's water lilies at the l'Orangerie. Every time I am so moved by his talent and the beauty he created. There are also many many beautiful paintings downstairs. A nice museum for kids if they can't handle the Louvre or d'Orsay.

even if so much moved to orsay it is still a wow. the Monets themselves would be worth a visit , but there is so much more . not to be missed and so much to enjoy. and when you come out i the tuilieries gardens ,what a spectacle !
Visit this museum after going to Giverny.. If you like Monet, you have to go to this museum as well the Marmottan. But go first to Giverny, you will enjoy the huge paintings of his home garden.

Rude staff. Once again, the French aren't doing anything for their reputation of being rude. I lined up for a ticket while the one and only lady serving had a good chat to another customer obviously trying to sort out a ticketing issue which was fine. However while there was a line of customers passing staff behind the desk didn't even make eye contact with waiting customers, not a smile or a 'won't be a moment'. Once the customer finished it was my turn next and the ticketing lady then decided to have a good chat with her colleague who arrived. She managed to serve me, take my money and give me my ticket without looking at me, talking to me or saying thank you.....all while still talking to her colleague. Her colleague who scanned my ticket was miserable.Best part was the art! Monet was fantastic and worth seeing....especially if you've been to his gardens in Giverny.

Wonderful Museum!. Went in January, 2016 and used our Paris Museum Pass to skip the line. We waited probably 6 minutes to get into the museum, as opposed to who knows how long for the regular line. My wife and i really enjoyed this museum because of its small size, and amazing collection. When we visited the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay we felt overwhelmed! Monet's Water Lilies were spectacular and my wife really enjoyed a temporary exhibit about women photographers (Who's Afraid of Women Photographers? 1839-1919) - it was very interesting. As is the norm these days, numerous people were taking selfies in the Water Lilies gallery - kind of annoying. We were able to see the second part of this temporary exhibition later on at the d'Orsay as well. Overall, we enjoyed the size and scope of this museum and would definitely visit again.

Take your breath awaay. When you first walk into the room with the water lilies, it takes your breath away. Other part of the museum is great also. If you don't have a lot of time to see the Louve, this is the place to go!

Don't miss the Paul Guillaume Collection. Monet's Nymphéas is, of course, quite impressive. But I enjoyed perhaps even more the Jean and Paul Guillaume Collection of post-impressionist works displayed on the lower level of the Museum. The collection include works by Pablo Picasso, Auguste Renoir, Claude Monet, Henri Matisse, Paul Cézanne, Andre Derain, Paul Gauguin, Amedeo Moddigliani, Kees van Dongen, Alfred Sisley, Chaïm SoutineHenri Rousseau, Maurice, Utrillo, and Marie Laurencin. It was quite fascinating.

Wow. A must for Monet lovers!Went on a Thursday in June about 1pm.Easy access from Concorde metro, in corner of beautiful Jardins Tuileries . You can pre book tickets. I didn't. Small queue where ( maybe as it was quiet) both pre booked and non ticket holders queued together. This was to get through security check on bags. Free Cloak room for rucksacks ( not allowed in) . Pre booked tickets then went and scanned tickets and went straight in. There was virtually no queue for buying ticket, 9 euros. Children free and young adults with eu passport ( check website) also free up to about age of 24. You can get audio guides( not sure of fee if any).Small musee. Divided into galleries. The monet waterlilles are huge and blew me away. Also other artists.Nice modern cafe and gift shop.Allow couple of hours maximum in my opinion.Lovely location in park.No access to Seine which runs alongside along with a very busy road.Would return in better weather to explore park, and walk through to Louvre.

Excellent permanent and current exhibition.. Great paintings by Cezanne, Renoir, Soutine and others and of course the Monet two rooms are beautiful. And still the star attraction at the moment is the stunning exhibition of paintings, sculptures, manuscripts and books associated with the poet and critic Apollinaire. Beautiful Picasso, Matisse, Chagall etc works. Great value if you buy the combo ticket d'Orsay/l'Orangerie.

Small but impactful. Walking around the Jardin des Tuileries, we stumbled into this gem. A beautiful collection of works and of course, the piece de resistance by Monet is overwhelming, and something you cannot imagine if you do not know its size. Go see it! It's also a perfect trip before/after going out to Monet's house in Giverny.
A must see.. Such a beautifl place to sit and look at the paintings. Combine this with a visit to the gardens and you will remember them both for ever.

A small gem. If you like the impressionists and especially Monet you will adore this little museum. It has lots of Monet- the famous huge waterlillys also- Renoir, Sisley, Cezanne, Soutine and many others plus interesting temporary exhibitions. You can combine it with a stroll at the Madeleine and the Place de la Concorde witch are at the area.
Excellent. It can get quite busy especially with s hook groups so go early or after 2 pm to have a peaceful visit

Wonderful little gallery. I came here to see the water lilies, but was pleased with the small gallery on the lower floor as well.Definitely buy your tickets ahead online. This allows you to jump to the head of the line and prevents a long wait at the door. There is an audio guide, but I did not use one and did not feel that I was missing out.
Beautiful museum. I loved this museum. It was a breath of fresh air after feeling a bit bogged down at the louvre, this small and manageable museum was just right, and Monet's work is amazing!

Excellent restaurant and not overwhelmingly large like others. While in Paris, we wanted to see some impressionist works, but since we had only two days, didn’t want to spend the entire day at one of the large museums. The Musee de L’Orangerie is impressive, but not overwhelmingly large. Monet’s “Lilies” panoramic paintings take up two rooms in the museum and are phenomenal. The museum wasn’t too crowded, so we were able to view the paintings up close and actually see the brushstrokes. L’Orangerie also has a great private collection of works from other famous impressionist works. Don't miss this one!

My personal fav in Paris. I have been a big fan of Monet and here is a heaven for me. The lighting is perfect for impressionism paintings and you can get the best experience in the oval setting of the hall. The Water lilies are embracing you. Master pieces in a well designed hall.

Small collection in a beautiful setting. Went to this museum for the first time in June 2016 - despite several trips to Paris, it has always been under the radar for me. I'm glad I visited - it's a beautiful space, and the huge rooms with the Monet paintings are breathtaking. Otherwise, a small but well curated collection and very manageable exhibits. A nice break from some of the more overwhelming museums elsewhere in Paris.
Full of delight. My favorite museum in Paris.I love its atmosphere and air.Must visit list is the chamber of Monet.Strongly recommended.

Nice place to spend an hour. Great works by Picasso, Chagall, Monet, Matisse, Modigliani and several other, perhaps lesser known, but very good artists. Easy access off the Jardins de Tuileries, just a ten minute walk from the Louvre.

Peace, tranquility, reflection.. Entering this Museum is like entering a holy place. To be able to stand or sit and reflect on Monet's Water Lily murals is to be held in thrall of this great art. I went twice so that I could more fully enjoy the experience in the early morning with fewer visitors and more quiet in which to meditate on the art.Don't miss the excellent exhibit in the lower level which comprises art from the collection of the great early 20th century dealer Paul Guillaume and Jean Walter: works of Cetane, Matisse, Picasso, Modigliani, Derain, Laurencin, Renoir, Cezanne, Utrillo and Soutine. I especially enjoyed the tiny replica of Paul Guillaume's study.
Lover of Monet. As a lover of Monet's paintings, I was happy to visit this museum. It is not very crowded and can be viewed at your leasure.

Monet's water lillies. So this is a fantastic museum. However, we were very short on time the day we went to visit. As a result, we could only give the time to Monet's water lilies. This amazing installation is peaceful and all encompassing. I would recommend the Paris Museum Pass to take advantage of all the small museums around the city.
The hidden impressionists.... Amazing collection of impressionist paintings, but you have to walk through the cafe to get to the gallery. Took us a little while to find it.
Love Monet. Amazing display of Monet's work.To really experience the works you need time to sit and view the paitings as the light changes.Beautiful

Get past the nasty lines and once you are inside it is all good!. This was one of the worst museums as far as lines go with getting access. The Paris Access Pass that worked so well at other venues did little here. The lines just sat still outside (thank god it was a nice day) and I guess the Pass did give us a little help as our line move a slight bit faster. Once you get in the door they are very strict about the no bags thing. A parent freaked out when he could not bring his baby bag inside! Like they should have told him before he got in line that this was the case or maybe he could read the "no bags" sign. Oh well, all types come here.The building is a great location and has swell lighting to show off the works. It is so funny once you get past the big lines and are inside, it is not crowded at all. Nice seating and you can relax to view the works and move on the see another portion of the painting...don't think I've been in another museum where you look at one part of the work and move on the see another part of the same painting!

Go early to miss the crowds. My daughter and I arrived early Sunday morning and there was hardly anybody around! The gallery was ours so that we could relax and enjoy the Monet masterworks but while these are the feature of this gallery the collections downstairs are also remarkable. Given that our ticket also gave access to the Apollinaire exhibition without extra charge and we obtained a reduced entry cost by combining the Orangerie and Musee D'Orsay ticket, I consider this an absolute bargain experience.
Beautiful!. You do not need too much time at this museum, but it is so worth seeing if you love Monet. Beautiful building and the Rodin sculpture right outside is gorgeous.

If you love monet, you must go. these large scale paintings are some of his best workt and in large format 20m. In what seems as a basement and not very artistic place, these paintings are transformative and emblematic of the best works of monet.

Nymphéas. Total immersion in Monet's Nymphéas - who could ask for more! Visiting the rest of the museum also wonderful and not expensive as bought a joint ticket for Musée de l'Orsay too. If in Paris, a must! :)

Peaceful experience. Monet is one of my favorite impressionist artists & I loved sitting in front of his giant panoramic paintings.
The whole experience was very peaceful.

Enjoyable visit. Nice museum, enjoyed the waterlillies, cafe and bookshop inside. Restrooms upstairs and down, nice and cold A/C and a respite to the heat of summer while viewing some beautiful works of art. Reserve 2-3 hours for your visit.

For painting lovers. I was not very fond of paintings, but this was part of Museum Pass and my wife insisted to see it. With helpful guide, I got to like some of them. And to see Picasso, Renoir and others. The plus is that Pass gives you priority access!

Two rooms dedicated to Monet's Lilly Pond. There are several famous Monet's and other Impressionists artists but nowhere near d'Orsay quantity. At 12 Euros, it was a bit pricey but I guess you have to judge for yourself. Probably a place you should not miss but it is over-priced.

Incredible place. This is a great museum to see a lot of Monet and other impressionism paintings. The huge murals are impressive and while the museum is not very large there are many paintings. This is a must

Escape with wife. Amazing range and scope of artwork, there is so much and something for everyone. Well worth the €10 fee. You do have to que for a while so do prebook if you can. Lovely places to sit and relax outside.
A must see!. By far the most amazing museum! Visited after a day in Giverny so was meaningful to see the water lilies installation and all the other impressionists!

Must see. Really small and manageable in a couple of hours.
What you would expect from a Paris museum. Queues can be long so go in the morning

water lillys. water lillys where great
overall its a nice and small place
not a must but worth it
you'll need only three hours for everything and it close to the Concord and the Luvre
PANORAMIC!!!. Loved Musee de l'Orangerie and Monet is one of my favorite artists. A magnificent location and set up. Don't miss this exhibit. Merci!

One of my Favorites. Because the Louvre and d'Orsay were closed due to flooding, there were long lines since this was one of the few attractions open. We waited in line for an hour to get in, but worth the wait. The last time we were there we just walked right in. The Monet's are just marvelous.

The "Louvre without the Mob". The Musee de l'Orangerie, not only perfect in size but well organized with security not obtrusive. Other than the famous waterlilies by Monet, go to the lower level and find Modigliani, the bizarre works of Soutine and horses rather than ballet dancers by Degas. There are treasures everywhere in this impressive collection and one could spend hours studying the masters. Keep this information to yourself because at this moment there are not hordes of pushing shoving grinning selfi-nuts destroying the atmosphere. My one regret is that there was only one of 4 Modigliani paintings on display when I was there. I would return in a heartbeat, it was that impressive.

Impressive. You have to see these paintings in real life. They are incredible. Just their size alone is amazing. But you can actually see the strokes that he made. It perfectly wonderful just sitting and staring at these works of art.
Intimate and beautiful. The perfect museum for those who are overwhelmed by the Louvre. Monet's waterlilies are like nothing else and absolutely must be seen when visiting paris
Go for the Monet's. A smaller museum with stunning Monet murals. Beautifully hand painted walls by Monet. totally worth it!

Perfect Dose of Monet and More. Come to see Monet's Water Lillies, yes, but take the time to explore the rest of the offerings. What I like best about l'Orangerie is that it is of manageable size. I felt like I could see and appreciate the works here without being overwhelmed or feeling pressure to "see everything." Security was a bit brusque but museum staff were friendly. We arrived just before the museum opened without tickets but only had to wait a short while in a reasonable line. If you like impressionist paintings you will be happy to visit here--we were.

Loved It. I have meant to go there on several occassions and this time I finally did. It was worth it to just see the water lillies and to learn about them. I highly suggest renting headphones in your language as it will give you a very thorough background on the water lillies as well as the other artwork. I spent 2.5 hours in the museum which I thought worked out very nicely. There was also no line when it opened in the morning but when I left there was a long line.

The magic of Monet. If you're an ardent fan of Monet, do not miss the Orangerie. The octagonal rooms with the paintings of the water lilies is just mesmerizing and divine. The size of the museum is also perfect and the comparatively lesser crowds make the museum viewing experience much more pleasurable than the Louvre (stunning in its own right but way too busy and overwhelming). Go early to beat the crowds and enjoy the magic of Monet in comparative solitude. Highly recommended for Monet and impressionist painting fans.
Monet murals . You have to see the murals! Photos are allowed. This is a small museum but lines can be long to enter. Just the right size museum for us.
Water Lillies!. Overwhelmed by the beauty of Monet's masterpiece! The colors changed as we moved around the room! In awe of the emotional impact the images had on me!

Cozy, comfortable museum. A beautiful museum, small enough to do in half a day. No spoilers here. Just an advisory to keep in mind... The museum entrance is very small so even a small queue will line up outside. Pre-book your tickets so have priority on entering. Yes, they also line up outside.I got stuck in the Paris rains and was hammered and there isn't any shelter so the wind whips through there too. But Go!

Right Size For Me. I'm not a museum person, so the fact that this is a smaller museum was good for me. We ordered tickets on Digitick which meant we waited in a much shorter line. This can easily be done on a smartphone and at Digitick you can then download the ticket to your phone and no need to print. A nice collection of impressionist painting. Cool building. We went to nearby Angelina for hot chocolate and tea afterwards. Lovely day.

If you enjoy Monet - you will be here. I was stunned by the Monet wrapping around the wall. I enjoy Monet and was pleased to spend the time with him. The lower floor also has other masters. What can you say except --- Fantastic!!

Interesting if your thing is impressionism.. This was a nice museum that we hadn't intended on visiting. We had planned to go to the D'Orsay, but it was closed the day we went. Unlike the Louvre, photographs are forbidden. I hadn't seen the signs, but toward the end of our visit, one of the security explained it to me in no uncertain terms. The Monet's water lily paintings were very nice, but I had hoped to see the most famous version which I was told was in New York or Chicago. Check out the museums you want to see on line for the artwork they contain and you won't wind up being disappointed. They were equipped with an elevator, though difficult to use and out of the way.

A musee' you can wrap your head around (and not bang your head against the wall). If you only go to one museum in Paris, or if you hate museums, you must go to this one. Small, in a beautiful park-like location, modern, cool, friendly (nobody yells at you for taking a picture). Nobody talks about it. People who go to the Louvre and brag about it, even if they exit with a raging headache, don't go to l'Orangerie. You should go here, and tell everybody that the Louvre is too hoi polloi for your blood.

2nd time is still a jaw dropping experience. This May was my 2nd time visiting this Museum. Monet's Waterlillies still takes my breath away... a MUST SEE when in Paris. This museum also has FEWER people and therefore less of a line-up than other museums.

Never again!!!!. Some years back, due to the popularity of the Monets, hours for this place were changed and the general public could not get in until after morning tour groups got to go through. On our last visit we stood outside 1.5 hours to wait to get in. My husband and I are independent travelers who resent being put behind groups of people who can't travel without their hands held. (I am admittedly biased against tour groups in general.) Once we got in we saw a tourist trying to touch paintings while having her photo taken and the security guard did not do enough to stop it especially since she just kept doing it. She should have been arrested. The works in the lower level by Picaso are a pleasant surprise.

Excellent Collection. The Orangerie museum has a small but significant collection of impressionist painters. Of course Monet's water lilies are the primary attraction and the scale of the paintings and there serene effect are to be experienced and cannot be written about. The Paul Guilliame collection is a good one and spans all the major artists of the era. Do take an audio guide to delve deeper into the paintings. I personally liked Derain and Soutine a lot.

So much to see. We went to the Musee de l'Orangerie twice, both times early to beat the crowds. There is usually a line in front (not if you're on a tour or are a member). It's so worth it, if you like Impressionists (mostly). There was a huge exhibit of Monets, but so many other interesting and beautiful works. We marveled at how many masterpieces were there to be seen up close under one roof. There's a pretty good gift shop with a small walk-up cafe and seats. The building, at the end of the Tuilleries Garden, is new, light and tastefully done.

My favourite Museum in Paris. If like me you are looking for a more intimate museum experience with some classic painters then this is the one for you.After experiencing the warehouse hustle and bustle of the Louvre I stumbled across the Musee de l'Orangerie. It has some Picasso and other notables but most impressive of all are the Monet murals that surround you in two oval shaped rooms.I have visited here twice and on each Occassion there has been an opportunity to sit on the central seating surrounded by Monet's waterlilies and just soak up the beauty. Not too many people, no hustle and bustle, peace, quiet and beauty!! The way it should be in my mind.Don't miss this opportunity!!
You must see. Despite the crowds it's a must to see. Monet's water lillies are so breathtaking! It was a pleasure to sit and admire his panels.

Precious!. Such a precious museum. Absolutely brilliant. All the works displayed were impressive and I feel I learned a lot from it. The first rooms are stunning and definitely a must see in Paris. Don't miss it!It doesn't seemed very friendly for disabled people but maybe I missed those facilities.The shop could be better. It was little and can look crowed with just a few people. It doesn't help the fact that the room is being shared with the cafe.

150 impressionist paintings and Monet's Water Lilies!. Fabulous collection of almost 150 impressionist and post impressionist paintings in addition to Claude Monet's eight huge murals of water lilies make this a gem of Paris museums. Well worth a visit, and much less crowded than the Louvre!

Small but lovely. This museum is best known for the massive Monet paintings, and is worth it for that alone. There are benches in the middle of the room to sit and enjoy the masterpieces. There are, of course, other beautiful pieces downstairs. If you are also doing the Musee D'Orsay, be sure to get the combined ticket - it's much cheaper. And make sure you buy your tickets in advance - the queue is much shorter!
Small gem of a museum. Have lunch at Le First (Westin Paris), walk through the Tullieres garden, then come here. Astonishing story of how the place was built, and the art collected...

Small, but worth it for Monet alone. The get water lillies are awesome and remember if you're under 25 you get in free so you get Money for nothing and your Braques for free! Queues, even with the Louvre closed, not long.

Monet's Water Lilies - Breath Taking. Musee de l'Orangerie is a canvas for Monet. The two rooms that he painted are magnificent. And then you go down stairs and WOW the Impressionists are there in abundance. This is a wonderful museum and really worth the visit. My favorite museum in Paris.

truly remarkable impressionist exhibit. The main floor permanent exhibit, consisting of four panels of Monet's gardens that encircle the entire room may be one of the most impressive exhibitions I have ever seen. It is truly breathtaking. And the rest of the museum is chock full of beautiful works. Because of it's size, it's a very manageable museum and you can take it all in within a short period of time.

water lilies. was told to visit this gallery as the water lilies paintings where here not a great art lover but blown away by the paintings nothing like I expected not too busy and beautifully displayed in purpose built rooms for the paintings loved it

A peaceful sojourn. Monet water lilies are worth the price of admission. You can sit and admire them with a degree of peace settling over you. Just what Monet desired.The crowds are reasonable (on a rainy day in May) and you do not feel rushed to exit.

Worth the visit for Monet's Water Lilies!. Don't miss this one. There are 2 rooms of these magnificent paintings! Just sit there in silence and be mesmerized. Thus museum has only 2 floors. Bought ticket with D'Orsay for 16 Euro.

A true masterpiece. Quite of hidden among the bushes of Tuilerie this small museum keeps perhaps the greatest paintings series of Monet inside Paris. Good for the ones with not a lot of time to spend inside museums and perfect for those who enjoys sitting in front a masterpiece with all the time of the world.

Monet!!!!!!. I could not BELIEVE how enormous Monet's Water Lilies are!!! Make sure to go here, because you will be in awe. The other art here is beautiful, but the Lilies are by far the best. Plus, the museum is in a beautiful part of the gardens.

graet visit before Monet's garden @ Giverney. The huge water lilies painted by Claude Monet as he was losing his eyesight are displayed by themselves in two large oval rooms adjacent to each other, and are powerful indeed.
The lower floor has twenty or thirty Picasso's and other greats, and it's a visit that does not have to take a great deal of time.

Monet water lilies here. Best known as the building that houses Minet's water lilies the museum also has a really diverse collection of late 19th and 20th century paintings including some early Picasso and other less well known but equally interesting artists.
family trip. Just a beautiful museum with a gorgeous display of wonderful artwork (Not just the Monet's). A MUST see if you like Monet though. Note--closed (like many museums on Tuesdays)

Great museum if you're short of time. We visited the Musee de l'Orangerie on a Monday because Musee d'Orsay was closed, and were most impressed. It houses the private collection of Paul Guillaume, but is most famous for Monet's Waterlilies which are exhibited in truly stunning fashion according to Monet's own detailed instructions.The only downside was having to queue for over an hour in the rain to get in - but the exhibits more than made up for this.

Only if you have time to kill. All has been said already, so here are our tips:- Buy your tickets ahead of time... you'll skip the lines to get in.- Start with the Nymphs galleries on the ground floor... then head toward the lower level gallery.- Be there either upon opening or during the Paris lunch hour, from 1200 to 14:00 to avoid the larger crowds - Expect to spend about 1:15 minutes inside.
First time in Paris. Sacred flower experience here. The 2 salles of Monet's Waterlillies were beyond beautiful. For flower lovers, this is Mecca!

Ridiculous Security Procedures. Waited in line in driving rain for 80 minutes just to get to the door for security. Both prepaid and walk up were lined up in the rain. Meanwhile the comfortable and dry ticket sellers and staff had no customers because we were all out in the rain. Fix it, Paris. It's an embarrassment! Once inside, with soaked shoes, socks and trousers and cold wet feet, I was not feeling in the correct mood for contemplation of the treasures. And neither, I suspect, was anyone else.

Nice Monet work, a couple of others - thats it. Of course liked Monet's works - worth the visitA couple of other nice paintingsother than that - i did not enjoy anything elseie - if you like Monet - you will deem the €9 investment worth it. You wont otherwise - in my view

Loved This. Compared to the Louvre this was a small, intimate museum with great works of art. It was wonderful to escape the crowds and see some beautiful pieces without being rushed or feeling claustrophobic. I absolutely loved Monet's water lily exhibit.
Huge Monet's. Huge Monet murals. Also a impressive collection of other artists, tied to their common dealer, Paul Guillaume.

Perfect visit. Since our trip to Paris was only 3 days, we knew we didn't want to spend tons of time standing in lines and fighting crowds at the big museums, but going here was perfect. The Water Lilies paintings are absolutely amazing, and were all the more fantastic to see because we had spent the morning taking the trip out of Paris to Giverny and seeing the actual gardens - doing both of these things on the same day was one of the highlights of our trip!
Monet's water lillies. Do I need to say more? O.K. Well, the museum has round rooms where you are surrounded by these wonderful paintings by Monet. You almost feel like you're immersed in his world.
Good Art Museum. This is a nice Art Museum, Super friendly staff. It was nice to stop by on the rainy day. Good for art lovers.

One of the best. This museum is one of the most beautiful museums in Paris. It is quite small but offers a nice collection of art by classic artists. MAKE SURE TO PRINT TICKETS AT HOME TO AVOID THE LONG LINE AT THE ENTERANCE,

Lasting impressions. The l'Orangerie not only has Monet's Water Lilly series, but also features avant-garde, fashion and experimental photography exhibits. It's located in the Tuileries just steps from the Louvre, but has a completely different vibe. Less crowded and definitely worth a visit. I go back from time to time to see their latest installations, always something out of the ordinary.

A museum worth visiting. We did not buy tickets in advance and just stood in the queue to try luck. The line moved steadily and we were lucky to get in smoothly 2 hrs before the museum was about to close. Besides Monet's huge collections, the museum has a lot more to offer. It is small compared to the other famous museums, so our time was well spent.

A Cathedral Designed for Monet's finest. Not to missed for any art lover. You can contemplate and delight in masterworks by perhaps the greatest French artist in a veritable temple designed to display some his master-works.

So many great artists' work, all hanging under one roof. This museum was a welcomed surprise to me. I went in to see the work of Monet specifically, but left feeling like I had gotten so much more out of the visit. The rest of the museum had works of several other famously known artists, as well as some I had never heard of before, but had become intrigued by during my visit. Also, I'm not sure if it's just for the French students, but if you're studying Art, you get to go in free!

Amazing. After looking at posters of Monet's work, getting to see his most famous was amazing. The main exhibit is not large, but if you are a fan, it is worth the trip. I can sit and stare at these works and not get bored.
Who knew Water Lillies was so large?!?. Buy a museum pass to skip the long ticket line. Still have to wait in a security line, but you will be bumped ahead of everyone who doesn't have a MP.

Small and lovely. I can't remember the exact details, but l'Orangerie came about after the Musee du Jeu du Pomme closed and parts of the Impressionist collection went to the Musee d'Orsay. The exhibits at the L'Orangerie can be separated into two key areas: the temporary exhibits downstairs, and the two rooms of Monet's water lilies upstairs. I'm always mesmerized by this museum, and return each time I'm in Paris. Plan in 1-2 hours, depending on your level of interest in art museums.
Monet Mone Monet. To be surrounded by Monet go to this Museum. It's not as busy as the Louvre or Dorasy and easy to get to.

Monet!. If you like Monet even a little bit, you'll love Musee de l'Orangerie. In addition to several other pieces of interesting art, the museum features two curved galleries designed by the artist himself to showcase the four mural-size paintings in each.

Wall to wall lilies plus more. Not only do you get to see the huge Monet lilies (which are worth the entrance fee on their own) there is also a basement exhibition with some tremendous artwork - and it has a little cafe too

Beautiful bridge. Really beautiful bridge it is definitely worth a trip. It is very close to the musee de l'orangerie, the army museum. It looked like there were a couple of restaurants on barges but we didn't stop to try any

Lovely little museum and it's free. The big draw of this museum is the magnificent “Water Lilies” exhibit by Monet. These huge works are housed in two special rooms with one painting on each wall. I found this exhibit first and tried to take some panoramic shots, but they were so long in width that the images were distorted. This is not to be missed. The museum is fairly small but chocked full of wonderful art works. They are from the collections of a man named Guillame whose widow gave them to the museum. There were rooms filled with many of the impressionists - Monet, Cezanne, Modigliani, Matisse, Picasso, Utrillo, as well as Andre Derain whom I was not familiar with, and some very nice pieces by Marie Laurencin, one of the few women seen in art at this time.

Beautiful Monet murals!. This little museum is worth the time if you love Monet - stunning water lily murals in a very peaceful setting - not to be missed if you visit Paris. We purchased tickets at our hotel - the lines were not long - but I don't know if that holds true during the summer months, so plan accordingly.
Stunning. Worth the visit to see the two 'Water lily' rooms by Monet although there are also plenty of other wow painting by top 19th/20th century artists - get for a wet day.

You'll be in Monet heaven. Be sure to see the entire museum, but the two rooms of Monet murals upstairs are why you came. When I went to leave I had planned to take a stroll before my appointment, but it turned out to be bucketing rain, so I just went back and zoned out looking at water lillies for over an hour until I had to leave. Wonderful.
Adore. Run don't walk to this gem of a museum. The current Apollonaire display marvelous. Can't beat Monet's water lily display either. Walk through the gardens before or after. Treat.
Magnificent Monet. This museum, close to the well known Louvre, is home to a magnificent collection of impressionist art by Claude Monet and other noted artists. Highly recommended.
Monet is amazing. The 360 room of monet's water lily paintings is worth a visit to mussede l'Orangerie. Line wasn't too bad even in the rain and we were able to get in quickly.
visit in heaven. I believe heaven looks like this beautiful gallery. Every time I'm in paris I go there. Last time I went in april 2016 and I had gorgeous time.

Impressive . The fact that Monet designed his pieces specifically for the museum space makes it that much more worth a visit. His works are truly impressive, wrapping around the room, and you can get so close to them to inspect every detail. The other pieces in the museum's collection are also top-notch.

Cute museum. The artwork presented here is very impressive and beautiful. The rooms with Claude Monet's water lilies are very powerful and I loved how the paintings are presented. I felt like the part downstairs should be given more thought about its interior design. It shold be more inspiring and impressive to suit the art that's on the walls. Also, some statues would be a nice addition to the overall atmosphere...
Dreamy. We absolutely loved seeing the Monet Waterlilies. The other works were just a wonderful bonus. Nice flow through the display. Line went fairly quickly.

Amazing Paintings. The museum is amazing. The paintings are beautiful. Especially Claude Monet's Water Lilies.There was double fun for us as it was museum day and its was open till midnight and there was a lovely jazz performance. There was no entry charge (only for the day). Lot of people took advantage of the day and we could lot of them enjoying the paintings as well as the performance.Due to the special occasion, it took us lot of time to get in. If someone is planning it visit it during such occasion and especially wants to enjoy the performance, it is better to aim for the last one as there was very less waiting time to get in.Overall, amazing experience.

Wonderful special exhibit on Guillaume Apollinaire. This is such a great place to spend time in Paris. Not as well known as the Musee d'Orsay or the Louvre, it is a beautiful location for viewing the Monet Waterlilies. Downstairs is a real treat as well. While we were there a special exhibit on Guillaume Apollinaire, a poet and art critic with profound influence on Picasso and many of the post-Impressionists. There is also a large collection of wonderful and important paintings of the 19th and 20th centuries.
My favorite Paris museum. This was my second visit to the Orangerie to see Monet's water lily paintings displayed simply but so dramatically. So beautiful!

Monet's waterlillies are wonderful. Monet's waterlillies are truly captivating. Stand back so you can see the whole length. It's a visual delight and a somewhat sublime experience. There is also a very good collection of impressionist and other paintings downstairs and an exhibition. To avoid very long queues, buy tickets online and print them out in advance.
Gorgeous!. The Monet water lilies are some of the most sublime paintings ever painted. This museum is an all emcompassing experience of Monet's epic work. It should not be missed!

Monet's Gift to Paris. If you appreciate Art but don't have enough time to get around the Louvre, this is an excellent option. Situated at the far end of Jardin des Tuileries as you walk away from the Louvre towards the Eiffel tower, it's easy to work into a weekend visit. Monet designed the two main rooms to offer an escape for busy Parisians. They contain 8 of his famous waterlily works which are really exceptional. Down stairs offered two more collections, both of which I found very interesting and varied.

INCREDIBLE!. We stood in the pouring rain in line today to see Claude Monet's collection of water lilies paintings. It was worth every drop!!!! These HUGE landscapes were remarkable! I love the history of how he built his studio so he could paint these monstrous canvases and how he painted the water lilies at different times of the day so the light, the colors, and contrasts change. Truly enjoyable! We also liked the other art displayed and the special exhibit on Apollopolonaire.

See my review on the Musee d'Orsay. The same review applies, brilliant collection focus in gone Monet's Water Lillies which is badly spoiled by the masses and their mobile phones who have no interest in the art just the selfie of standing in front of a painting they don't even bother looking at. Heartbreaking

Outstanding artistic content and presentation. Never been to an art museum where the entire main floor (of only 2 floors) is entirely devoted to one artist and eight paintings of water lilies and willow trees painted in his backyard at different times of the day at Giverny.Claude Monet did take some 11 years to complete these masterpieces which if lined up end to end would be nearly 300 ft. The basement is not so shabby either with a top notch collection of Picasso, Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse and Modigliani. Compact but powerful art gallery!

Nice surprise. I happened upon the museum while walking on a cold, rainy day. Very glad I visited it! Amazing works of art from Monet, Cezanne, Matisse, Renoir, and Gauguin. I didn't care for the cubism art - just my preference. Monet's famous Nympheas are on display here. Small museum, but worth going. Definitely get the Paris Pass if you plan to see many things. This is included with that pass.

For the Monet lover. Wow. This is a museum where I would love to be alone for a couple of hours. In these paintings Monet shows us his gardens from sunrise to sunset as you slowly move along the panels. We visited l'Organerie before heading to Giverny to see Monet's garden. The paintings capture the same quiet contemplation of beauty as the gardens that inspired them.

Haunting and perfect. The two rooms in figure-eight with the Nymphéas are the perfect setting for this expo. The lighting is ideal, and moving around the rooms highlights different facets of the murals - the lighting changes and our focus changes in course. I couldn't think of a more perfect place to enjoy the eight water lily murals. That said, the downstairs exhibit of Appolinaire was pretty awful. not my cup of tea at all. I should have stayed wuith Monet.

I think every child on the 70s owned the poster. Having been surrounded by the Water Lilies posters through college I did not realize how impressive the original works were. This has been among my favorite stops in Paris.

A good range of art, Smaller lines than most. We didn't have much time in Paris so had to be very selective with what we did and found Musee de l'Orangerie a good small collection of different styles, ages, and artists. If you are short on time and not overly fussed with hour upon hour of art galleries, then this is for you! A good taster with a much shorter queue.
A must see of all the museums!. This quaint museum holds Monet's Water Lily paintings which are breathtaking and it doesn't take long to complete a round.

Monet rocks.. Though everything else sucks big time. Maybe we are not in cubism and late French school. The ground floor is perfect: two rooms - huge 8 paintings. White interior underlines all canvases in a great way. This is a place worth sitting and watching. Minus 1st floor is dedicated for newer art - cubism, early Impressionism and others. And this one sucks. Price wise and time wise it just few things to see. Worth visiting if you are into cubism or into monet and no cues can stop you.

Second visit better than our first!. We were at this museum 4 and 1/2 years ago and it was wonderful. But since that time the entire lower floor of the museum has been completed and there is much more to see there. This is not a large museum so you can still enjoy it in about an hour. If you have not been there in five years however, it is time to go again!
Great Impressionist Paintings. Great collection of impressionist paintings in a quaint building near the Louvre. Less people. Nice vibe. We had a nice lunch in the café downstairs.

Favorite Museum in Paris. This museum is a fraction of the size of the other famous museums, but it more than makes up for it in quality. Almost every piece is recognizable, and the water lilies are just spectacular. You could spend hours in those two rooms alone. Highly recommended.

Don't miss Monet's Lilies in l'Orangerie. Beautiful Lilies in the beautiful l'Orangerie museum with perfect lighting. Don't miss it when in Paris. Take the guided tour at 2:15 pm. Get a combined ticket to Musee D"Orsay and l'Orangerie.

Worth a Visit. I knew I wanted to visit the l'Orangerie Museum to see Monet's Waterlillies and was not disappointed. I didn't realize how small the museum was (not a bad thing) or know that it wouldn't be crowded like the other museums. So I was very pleased that the museum was pretty empty while I was there so I could sit and take in all of the Monet panels. Then I was able to explore the lower level at my own pace. After being at the very crowded D'Orsay, this was a nice treat. The atmosphere at this museum was very serene and peaceful just to take in all the artwork. It was a lovely visit and I highly recommend it. Also you can buy a combined ticket with D"Orsay and skip the line.

Wonderfully planned and executed museum.. We visited this museum as a prelude to the Louvre which we knew would be overwhelming in its vastness. If you like Monet, this is the place for you. His waterlilies are presented just as he had wished, in natural light. And there are examples of other artists here too but the big attraction are the entire walls of water lilies. It is small enough that you can take your time and see it all at your leisure, an excellent experience.
Monet art work in a tranquil setting. great escape from the rain. It doesnt take long to wander round but worth it for the water lillies. Tranquil viewing

Museum lovers don't miss. The two galleries with the large Monet water lilies will capture the heart of the impressionist fan. Plan to spend time just gazing at these masterpieces. Excellent choice for Monday, some other museums are closed. Make the wait time to enter much shorter with the museum pass or buy the combo ticket with the Musee d'orsey and go to the fast line.

Small but Worth It to See Monet's Work. This museum is SO small and has a very small collection but it’s worth a visit just to see the Monet’s. You can easily do this museum in about 30 minutes and feel extremely satisfied.

Yes, but . The Musee is certainly one of the museums one should visit after the d'osay. I particularly liked the Monet Water Lilies panels because they help set the mood for a relaxing visit. I felt that many of the frames took away from the beautiful paintings.

Captivating!. You don't need to be an art fan to appreciate this amazing museum. Just to see the wonderful works of Monet in this setting was a revelation and the bonus was that it is not nearly as crowded as the Louvre and Musee D'Orsay. There was time and space to just sit and be enthralled with the incredible talents of the artists on display. Do not miss!

Serene oasis!. After a day of very crowded attractions, we popped into l'Orangerie to sit a while and contemplate the giant Monet canvases in the setting he intended. What a treat. Everyone there was so in awe it was absolutely quiet! It's so beautiful and should not be missed!

Good for a quick visit. If you like Monet you should definitely go to this museum. His wall-to-wall pond paintings are very cool. Get up close to the paintings and see the brush strokes. Awesome! Downstairs there are a lot of Renoir paintings - the best is "Snowy Landscape." The Picasso pieces are also interesting of course, but the other things are not very impressive unless you're obsessed with modern art. There are some paintings that made me think, "Oh, come on. Any art major at my school could have produced that." But it's worth it to go just for the Monets.

Amazing. Everyone will be impressed with the shear size and impact of these 'Waterlilies' artworks. Take advantage of the seats and take 10 minutes, at least, to really truly appreciate them. Do not forget there are 8 in total. When I visited lost of people just visited the first room and missed the others entirely.

Modern museum featuring French artists. We purchased a combined ticket to the L'Orangerie and D'Orsay museums. The L'Orangerie is a smaller museum that would be a half-day visit. It was not super crowed except for the Monet rooms.

If you want to see Monet's paintings, this is worth the visit!. When we visited this museum, we did not have to wait in a long line. The museum's exhibit is beautifully done. I highly recommend taking the time to walk through the Tuileries to visit this museum.

Excellent, definite must see. Excellent, definitely a must see - A very nice museum, very centric, with a very educationally minded presentation re. the collection and its provenance; wich makes it more interesting, tangible; you can picture and understand the grit and the savviness and foresight of art collectors; inspiring and educational.It is a tad small, and we believe due to occupancy must restrict access - so there is a line outside that grows round about 11:00, better make it earlier or it will be a good 45' wait to get in. Very nice bookstore and café to recharge your museum batt.

Beautiful. Monet's water-lily paintings are just spectacular. There are eight in total, four in each room, displayed as Monet had intended them to be. If you're nearby I highly recommend visiting just for them. The lower level has a selection of artwork comparable to that in the Orsay I would say, I walked through fairly quickly both times, but it's worth a visit for the water lilies alone.

Must-see for Monet lovers. This was my first time here, and I'm glad we came. I like Monet's Water Lilies paintings, but there were other worthwhile attractions as well, like the collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume, and the exhibit on the life and works of Guillaume Apollinaire, the art critic, collector and poet. Smallish as it is, there's plenty to see here, so allow at least two hours.

So peaceful. I can sit and look at Claude Monet's Lily Pond for a very long time and the museum has nice benches to accommodate such pondering. The size of the museum is perfect, you can see it all without breaking your back and it is worth seeing it all. The exhibit in the basement was really well done. They had several pieces by André Derain showing his versatility and virtuosity.
A place to realx and enjoy. After the hectic throngs of Louvre, this is truly relaxing place to sit and view and enjoy the Monet panels. The lower level displays also very well done.

Wanted to see Monet's Waterlillies. Met all my expectations - I've been trying to paint my own mini Monet since I returned! Great museum showing some of the greatest artists work as well as the room that contains the Waterlillies.

If you like Monet. It is a must see. amazing murals by Monet. We sat for hours taking in the surroundings. Not as big or as much to see as d'Orsay or du Louvre but definitely worth it especially if you are a fan of impressionism
Perfection. I never fail to be overwhelmed by the beauty of visiting Monet's panels. Exhibition is a high light of visiting Paris

Monet heaven!. If you are a Monet lover this is the museum for you! I do love Monet but there were so many people it was hard to really enjoy the beauty of his artwork. I wish I could be left alone in there for an hour but to no avail. It still is definitely worth seeing.

Monet's Water lilies are spectactular. We loved the special rooms of Monet's waterlilies. There was also a wonderful exhibition of French art from late 1800s to around 1930 which included Impressionists like Monet but also Picasso and others. Wonderful to see this art.

Water Lilies. We went to see the Water Lilies which we thoroughly enjoyed. To our surprise , and despite our ignorance, we found the l'Orangerie contained so much more. The downstairs gallery was brilliant and would have been worth the visit alone. Added to this was the simple little cafe which served adequate light lunches.
Monet's are amazing. If you love impressionists like we do, this is the place for you. They have a wonderful collection, in addition to the huge Monet panels.
Monet, enough said. This, along with the Rodin, was my favorite museum in Paris. Beyond the stunning Monet's installed in two rooms he himself designed are some other gorgeous paintings.
Monet heaven. This is a must place to visit when in Paris, if you like Monet you will feel like you've died and gone to Monet heaven.

Quaint museum with beautiful art. I've been to Paris numerous times and this was the first time I visited this museum. It is a smaller museum but has many priceless paintings from Monet and other impressionists. Highly recommend!

Prepare yourself for the good and bad!. Two queues: one for visitors who have to buy tickets and another queue for people who has previously bought tickets. But, as there is just one entrance door it takes almost the same time to enter!The paintings are naturally superb. But the constant crowds difficult its Enjoyment.There is no toilet on the entrance floor, so proceed to the -2 floor.The cafe is ridiculous small...and beware of a" surplus" of 1€ if you use a plastic glass. To avoid this payment you should give back your glass(after drinking its content...) together with yourbill to the cashier! Anyway, the paintings deserve this sacrifices!

Beautiful . I missed this last time in Paris, so wanted to make sure I saw it this time. Still queues at 4pm on a Sunday. It is a beautiful space, and of course Monet is the best, astonishing in size and beauty!

Monet lover. This museum is a must for Money lovers... It's relatively small, you don't get "overloaded" with loads of beautiful artwork by different impressionists...(there are other artists works represented) BUT the size is perfect, the Monets are beautiful, it's lovely to sit and reflect with them. The queue in April was small and just being In the gardens where the museum is located is relaxing :)

Another must visit museum in Paris. There was a long queue outside- hmmm must be a good sign. It did not disappoint , they limit the number of visitors do you are able to enjoy the collection with just enough people inside the Museo de Orangerie. The Claude Monet collection is Simply Beautiful, we sat in the first hall way and just enjoyed the painting - such a simple joy. 2 major halls with Claude Monets panoramic paintings !! Up close & personal .
One of the best Monet Museums!. Absolutely gorgeous museum. Definitely worth visiting. It has a wonderful collection of Monet's work. One of my favorite places.

Absolutely Stunning Seeing Monet's Display. An absolute must for any visitor that loves Monet. There are 2 special display rooms for the painting presentation in the round of the water lily murals that Monet made and designed for the rooms. Not to be missed!

Waterlilies, incroyable. We recently returned from Paris where we got a Museum pass and visited several museums, including the Louvre (on a Context tour) and Musee d'Orsay. However, Musee de l'Orangerie was the highlight for us. The two rooms that house Monet's Waterlilies are a peaceful refuge away from the rest of touristy Paris. We could have spent hours there.
Delightful. Easy to navigate and appreciate smaller museum with excellent collection. Many impressionist works and the highlight, the Monet Water Lilly murals were breathtaking,
A must-see!. Walking into the two eliptical rooms with Monets waterlillies feels like diving into the pond they are floating in. Truly impressive!A small, but very well managed museum.

Perfection. The Musee de l' Orangerie is one of Paris's gems. It houses primarily the art made after Impressionism. Lesser known painters like Soutine and Kokoshka can be seen. The main asset is Monet's Water Lily series. These are shown in huge semi-circular canvasses mounted in circular rooms. There are banquettes in the middle of the rooms to allow viewers to sit and take in the masterpieces.
