Of course one should also see the Musee Marmorean, the main Monet museum in Paris, but the Water Lilies is a fabulous entree into Monet's gardens in the village of Giverny.One of the best aspects of the Orangerie from a tourist's viewpoint is that it is small. It doesn't require a whole day (or several) the way the Louvre or the Musee d'Orsay do. One caveat is that it is not included in some of the museum passes, but the entry fee is a small price to pay to maintain these artistic masterpieces. The museum's location at the end of the Tuilerie Gardens near so many landmarks makes it a must-see for that reason too.

The efficient museum visit. If you want to see some original great art without the huge crowds, this is the museum for you. Monet,Renoir, Picasso, etc. paintings are displayed on two floors. For someone who wants to avoid sensory overload and see a few select works in a calmer environment, this museum is for you. Also, the Tuilleries Garden is a nice walk on the way there.

Too small to miss. L'Orangerie is a small museum by any standards, but it packs a huge punch. I was able to see every piece in the collection in less than 2 hours. This is a good activity to do if you have a little bit of time in between more time consuming actives (looking at you Le Louvre). Some of the better known pieces were on loan out to other museums, but that is to be expected with works of this caliber.
Beautiful painting. The paintings are gorgeous, definitely worth a trip just to see the water lilies! Relaxing, and beautiful.
A bonus museum for us. We were on the way from the Louvre through the Tuileries and there it was A beautiful Museum with Impressionist art . Monet's panels are breath taking. So lucky to see this
Recommended time for visit. I am making up an itinerary of things to do in Paris and would like input on about how much time people spend taking in this site, Thank you....

Wonderful Monet. The way Monet paints water lilies is exquisite and to see 7 enormous canvases in one place is mind blowing. The rest of the gallery which features works collected by a woman and her husbands is also excellent. Pity about the man outside controlling the lines who let people without tickets enter more quickly than those who had them. It was not pleasant waiting in the pouring rain! That's why the rating is four!

Waterlilly calm. Beautiful spot to be surrounded by Monet's water Lilly paintings. Walk by, view from afar or sit and imagine you are in the middle of Monet's garden. I had a beautiful time drawing in pastels and being inspired.

Breathtaking..... Breathtaking.... Just sitting there for some time and absorbing the atmosphere of a true Monet garden.The quick stroke of Claude, the impressions of waterlelies... And those blue coulors...

Water lilies - Claude Monet - simply breath-taking. If you are a lover of Claude Monet's work as well the Impressionists in general, this is one museum you do not miss! CM's 8 water lilies are exhibited in 2 oval halls for one to just look, feel and fall in love with. Simply breath-taking. If you plans of visiting CM's home in Giverny, do visit this museum first - you will then understand the close connection between his home, gardens and the paintings.

Check for special shows. The Impressionist art is first rate; you can see Monet's waterlilies in a setting he designed. We really enjoyed the special exhibition about Guillaume Apollinaire, complete with art by his friends notably Picasso.

Not a Poor Cousin to the Musee D'Orsay. It's an overcast and drizzly February day in Paris. In other words, a perfect day for visiting one of Paris' great art museums, but it won't be the Louvre or the Musée D'Orsay. Even at this time of year they will be thronged and the experience would not be a pleasant one. Yes the art will knock your socks off, but the crowds just make it impossible to just stand, stare and appreciate. Instead I want a place where I can contemplate the art at leisure and not try to cram in hundreds of works of art in one sitting, or more accurately, standing. Fortunately, there is just such a place - the Musée de l'Orangerie or Orangerie as most people just call it, has a small, but great collection of impressionist art, highlighted by Monet's huge water lilies canvases. Although the collection is nowhere near as vast as Musee D'Orsay it's good enough that if it were in any city other than Paris it would be considered a must visit gallery.The Orangerie is located at the south-west corner of the Tuileries gardens and even with the mildly inclement weather it's a pleasure walking along the Seine side of the gardens to get there. The building itself was erected to house the orange trees that lined the gardens in summer, but had to be relocated in winter. From the outside it looks nothing like a de facto greenhouse, but inside it is surprisingly naturally bright.In 1922 the great French impressionist Claude Monet donated eight massive waterlily canvasses to the nation and it was determined that they would be housed in the Orangerie. Unlike Van Gogh and many others, Monet was extremely famous during his long life time and the gift became an immediate national treasure. Then in 1959 and 1963 the Orangerie received the collections of the late art dealer Paul Guillaume and industrialist Jean Walter. Both had amassed among the world's best private collections of impressionist and early 20th century artists. There are 146 paintings in those collections and with the Monet's, makes for a very manageable number to digest in one viewing.Just across from the entrance to the Orangerie is a copy of one of Rodin's most famous works, The Kiss.The admission fee is nine euros and another four for the audioguide. The latter is well worth it because almost every painting has an audioguide number on it and each contains a detailed description of what the painting is meant to represent and what was going on in the artist's life at the time. I suspect this will be very useful when we get to the Cubists. The first thing I notice is something that's not here - hordes of tourists. In this place you can actually enjoy the art in relative peace You can also take non-flash photography.There is a wonderful collection of Renoirs, Cezannes, Picassos, Matisses and others as well as the eight huge Monet waterlilies that takes about two hours to see - enough to satisfy, but not enough to cause the eyes to glaze over.Enjoy the pictures!
Must see. The Water Lillies paintings are huge and amazing, the space is bulit just for them, two large oval rooms. Sit and enjoy, it is must see for any impressionist art lover.

Enchanting Water Lilies. We were really enchanted by Monet's water lilies. We spent hours admiring the huge paintings so we unfortunately didn't have time to visit the rest of the museum. If you visit Paris don't miss Musee de l'Orangerie!

Stunning Impressionists Gallery. If you only see one gallery, see this one. A fine selection of impressionist paintings, anchored around Monet's Waterlilies on a scale that can be enjoyed in a couple of hours. Good bookshop and cafe.
Breathtaking. A small museum but one to see after you've been to Musee d'Orsay to complete the Monet story. We loved it.

Charming little museum. This has 8 large Monet Water lily paintings, which are the main attraction. They are beautiful. The collection is not large and shouldn't take more than an hour to go through. You can buy a joint ticket for this and the Orsay which is a better bargain.

A great way to spend a half day.. Smaller museum but has lots to offer including works by Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliani, Matisse and Picasso to mention just a few. Level 0 houses Monet's Infinity vestibule which shows his lifetime's work of Water Lilies which he donated to France.

Monet magic. This museum is a must see for anyone who loves Monet. The two water lilly rooms are breathtaking. If you are short on time skip the Louvre and spend your time here and at the Musee D'Orsay!

Small and specific. If you make a casual visit to the Louvre and have an hour to spare after seeing the highlights, situated in its Tuilleries Gardens outside is the charming Orangerie gallery. It's not going to take all day, and their small collection is era and genre specific (post-impressionism), but there are some big names here: Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir et al. They just mightn't be the masterpieces that are imprinted in your memory. The museum's crowning glory, however, are the oval halls adorned with eight Monet Waterlilies murals. These aren't loans or acquisitions, but constitute the rooms themselves. For a Monet fanatic, this could be the Sistine Chapel of post-impressionism. There's a very pleasant cafe and bookshop, and admission was cheap. A lovely stop between the Louvre and the monumental Place de la Concorde, which is just over the wall.

Great collection of impressionist work. Lovely museum at the end of the Tuileries garden. The lines were not long and moved pretty quickly before lunch on Saturday. Monet's panels are certainly the highlight! But there's more on the bottom floor, Renoir Picasso, Matisse, and others.

Breathtaking elliptical room displays of Monet's Water Lillies!. This Musee has thoughtfully arranged to viewing of Monet's Water Lillies on 8 huge panels hung in two elliptical rooms and the effect is breathtaking! Don't leave Paris with going to the Musee de L'Orangerie. T is wonderful!

I just had to visit the lily pond exhibit a second time.. This is just overwhelming to experience. Monet is my favorite Impressionist painter and he outdid himself on this project. Definitely watch the video offered. Gives great info on this man.

My favorite museum. Even though is a small museum, it's my favorite! Been there a million times. Summertime is not the best because it's always crowded, but occasionally you can have the museum just for you and sit down in front of the murals and just enjoy it! And if you can, watch the video downstairs about how this museum was "created", why this shape, why in the tuilerries, I think after I saw this video it only made me love even more this museum!!

The most unusual museum, with curved walls and Monet. This museum was so unique. I loved walking through this main room of Monet's 'Water Lily'. There were other impressionists as well, but this was where I spent most of my time. His vision was just amazing.

Special collection of impressionist paintings. The Musee de l'Orangerie has one of the world's best collections of impressionist and post impressionist paintings. This is my favourite period of art, so I truly loved this art gallery. Amongst other things, it has Monet's water lilies and a significant collection of van Gogh's paintings. Pity he only sold one painting when he was alive.

Very nice small museum. The Monet large murals are very nice. Plenty of room to sit down and really examine them. There's also plenty of impressionist and post impressionists downstairs. It Is a great place to go to the bathroom before you go to your next stop.The bathrooms are nice and clean and new. Paris is very secure these days - be prepared to have your handbag searched and to be screened before you go in. This is true at All museums and all sites

Billet jumele. It is worth buying a combined ticket when you visit the Musee d'Orsay as for 16 euros you can visit both museums and avoid the longer queues if you visit l'Orangerie second. Not as impressive as the Musee d'Orsay but the permanent exhibition of Monet's Nympheas complements his works displayed in the latter. The current temporary exhibition of Apollinaire is interesting and there are also a range of paintings of other modern painters in the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection.

Musee de Orsay and Musee de l'Orangerie combined ticket recommended.. Go to Musee de Orsay first (it is larger and will TaKe more time) and buy the combined ticket with L'Orangerie. This is more affordable and l'Orangerie is a smaller museum and it flows better after your visit to D'Orsay and you can enter Quicker If you already hake a ticket.

Walls and walls of Monet. There is little to say. The museum is wonderful. The Monet exhibit is designed to allow you to sit in the middle of the big pond and soak it all in. My 7-year old and I studied impressionism and Monet before the trip; he loved seeing teh swirls up close.
half day event. have stood on long line in the psst. this time walked right in. a little crowded but they control the flow of people well. Noisy. Special exhibit done well. monet water lillies

Lovely. This gem of a museum is a brilliant reuse of the palace orange house. Literally, the royals built this stunning place to house their orange trees during cold weather - no surprise that there was a revolution - the benefit to all of us now is a stunning green house has been repurposed into a stunning museum with masterpieces, such as Waterlilies!

Small gallery which makes it not overwhelming, unlike the larger ones.. We visited because Musee Dorsay was closed. We were not disappointed. The Monet waterlilies are amazing and the rest of the exhibition, while small was just enough for a visit. Larger galleries can be overwhelming.
Magnificent Monet. Wonderful Water Lilies and other Impressionists. Historical collections and travelling collections. This museum is a little gem.

A peaceful family morning. We spent a lovely hour or so with our three children here - just pre tween to early teen - just drinking in the beauty of Monet's waterlilies and a fairly brief but enjoyable visit through the balance of the gallery. An oasis of calm in a busy week of touring in and around Paris. Really worthwhile. Ps also a great place to pick up combined tickets with the Musee D'Orsay - without the lines you find over the river.

Monet Water Lillies are Fantastic. Great art in the lower level but that is overshadowed by the two upper level rooms with four Monet water lilly paintings in each. They are huge. You mist sit and enjoy them.

A place where you can actually savor the art. The Monet Waterlilies paintings get the notoriety. And deservedly so -- don't miss them. But be sure to go downstairs to visit their collections. With fewer crowds, you can actually stand and study a painting to your heart's content. If you are going this year, be sure to go through the temporary Apollinaire exhibit - Goes through mid-July 2016.
Small gem. Stumbled upon this small but fascinating museum in Place de Concorde featuring Impressionists artwork Highlight is the rooms built to house Monet's Water Lilly collection

My Favorite Museum n Paris. I could spend hours staring at the Monet water lily paintings. You can see the whole museum in less than an hour but I would highl recommend just sitting and relaxing and love yourself in Monet's world.

Monet museum exudes a peaceful felling. A nearly single artist museum as it is dominated by the multi paneled Monet art masterpiece. It catches light of a peaceful scene and relays the difference that subtly relay the time of say of the art. Come and enjoy the brilliant Monet.

A rather small but nice museum. I visited Musee de l'Orangerie in March 2016 and i found it pretty nice. You can go through it quickly, the works are very nice, primarily from the 19th century and the space is also modern and interesting, especially the large rooms for the Nympheas of Monet.I would recommend it to visitors as you don't need a lot of time to see it exhibits and it is free for citizens of the EU under 26. It is found in a pretty central area of Paris so you may also see the Tuilleries Garden, the Louvre, Concorde and Place Vendome which are located close to it.

Falling in love with Monet all over again!. I've seen enough Monet on this Europe trip to last a lifetime.And I still didn't want to leave this place. Sat and just stared at the colours for the longest time.

Spectacular. An impressionist lover's delight! The large mural- like paintings of Monet are unlike any art you'll see at the other museums, and the large collection downstairs is fantastic as well. Great collection of Soutine. This season there is also an excellent special show on Apollonaire, and his circle.

One of best museums I have ever visited. We had a wonderful morning here recently. The Water Lilies are fantastic but the rest of the paintings were out of this world. It is such an easy museum to get around with plenty of seats . Get an audio guide , it is worth the extra few euros.

Amazing!! . Such an amazing experience to see Monets paintings in real life, and the building was the perfect frame for them. There were plenty of other paintings as well: Picasso, Matisse, Rembrandt.. We visited early, and it was not too crowded. Loved it!
One of my favorite museums in Paris. I've been several times and find this one of the most peaceful museums in Paris. Sitting in those oval rooms, surrounded by Monet's Waterlilies is pure heaven.

Visit here first before Musee D'Orsay. We found out that you could get tickets to this museum AND the Musee D'Orsay which was awesome as the line ups here are very short. The tip is to purchase entrance to both, visit this one and take a short walk to the Musee D'Orsay. With prepaid tickets in hand you can go to the shorter line up at D'Orsay! This exhibit is small for sure but the large Monets are really amazing when you see them in person.
The Waterlillies were only the beginning. Fantastic exhibitions downstairs as well. Not to be missed. So many more works from that era. Renoir's girls at the piano was a highlight.
Small but impressive. This museum is dedicated to Monet's Lilys. It is not a large museum compared to Orsay and Louvre but it is certainly worth the visit.

A small museum not to be missed. Not only the Water Lilies of Monet but the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection on the lower level is also very interesting and shouldn't be missed when you visit Paris!
Amazing!. Monet's water lilies are a superb gift - wonderful setting to drink them in.Excellent design to set off the works and make them accessible.

Monet!. The water lilies series is even more beautiful than what you imagined. The exhibit on Apollinaire was fascinating, and the rest of the permanent collection is arranged by artist, with explanations about each artist and their lives, their relevance to the museum. Very well thought out. I came here at 10am on a Saturday morning and it was very quiet, but when I was leaving it was quite busy. If you get the combined ticket with the musee d'orsay it is 16 euros, which means you only pay 8 euros per museum. Definitely recommend this museum, you won't need more than an hour or so.

good, but not ideally staffed. The highlight is of course the Nymphéas rooms of Monet. It is an experience that can only be understood and enjoyed right there. No medium could replicate being surrounded 360 degrees by this idyllic world, born out of the tragedy of conflict and misery.However, most unexpectedly, the personnel at the door and inside are rude and disinterested. They also do not respect the Paris Museum Pass priority system, giving mendacious excuses in an uncouth demeanor. So different from all my other experiences of a week in Paris, usually in the midst of courteous, helpful and friendly people.So, do go enjoy it, but expect to be treated summarily.

Skip this one. I understand that people just love the Waterlilies exhibit. Personally, I was utterly bored. There was an interesting exhibit about an artist who was friends with Picasso, but I don't remember his name. Outside of that, I found this tiny museum wholly unmemorable.

Visit only if on museum pass or love Monet. While I like this museum, it's very small and is hardly worth the time or the money. The top floor has 2 rooms with 8 Water Lilies painting, the bottom floor is usually some sort of modern art exhibit. Visit if have plenty of time in Paris and a museum pass for free entrance.

Memerising Monet's. This was an extended visit included in price from Musee d'Orsay.Although separated from from the other museum by at least a 5-10 minute walk, you get to see another little bit of Paris on the way.Two floors with the main attraction being the four really large pictures by Monet in one room. MesmerisingIn the basement there was a great exhibition by Paul Guillaume showing his work up to his death from the flu pandemic in 1918

Claude Monet, c'est magnifique!. Probably not the first museum you think of in Paris. The museum was designed around an installation of Monet's water lilies. The design was approved by Monet before his death. Its amazing. The lower level houses another remarkable collection of works by Renoir, Cezanne, Piccasso, Matisse and other impressionist/post impressionists. You can do it in 90/120 minutes.

Exquisite. The opportunity to visit Monet's gift to the people of France - his famous water lilies collection, in oval shaped rooms that he designed to ensure the viewer experiences them with maximum impact - was one of those awe inspiring travel moments.The building itself is delightful, but the art...there are no words to capture the exquisite beauty of these paintings.Up close the way the blobs of paint create texture, and the colour palettes used to provide vivid impressions of water lilies, was a real discovery for this Impressionist aficionado.From the distance, the overall impressions of colour and light dancing on the surface of water brought a smile to a travel weary face.This is one of the smaller museums in Paris, but it's totally worth your time, even if it is crowded with people who are more interested in the perfect selfie than experiencing the wonder of this extraordinary master.

If you love Monet then you have to see it.. I could spend hours just sitting there, probably because I love Monet. This is a very cozy museum, two rooms filled with Monet murals and some special exhibitions in the basement.

If you like Monet you will love this museum. This museum is small, not crowded and the main attraction is Monet's water lilies - they are beautiful and not to be missed. There are other paintings on the lower level and very worthwhile to visit.

Monet at this best. This museum offers a a series of huges paintings by Monet of outstanding color contracts that show the evolution of his gardens during a year. You have the possibility of sitting in the middle of two oval rooms and just admire the painting mounted in a large circle around you. If you love impressionists, this is a must see!

A condensed version of a larger Museum. I love this museum for its edited selection of masters in Impressionism. It's just enough to take in and enjoy. I always enjoy viewing the Monet water lilies in the large oval rooms. It's a quiet space to collect your thoughts and reflect. .

A Must to See Monet's Giant Artworks.. This is a very nice museum. Sitting in front of Monet's enormous pieces of art is so relaxing. For the rest of the museum, I highly recommend getting the self-guided tour. A relatively fast museum to go through.

a small museum chock full of beautiful art. we were travelling with a 3 year old - we wanted to share some art with her, but not make it overwhelming. L'orangerie was the perfect fit. The water lilies were phenomenal - 2 rooms with 8 full wall panels - worth the visit just to see that, but there were 3-4 other rooms with a smattering of other French artists which gave a nice overview without being too overwhelming.The building is interesting - used to be the shelter for the orange trees of the Tuilleries

Wonderful!!. A much smaller museum than the D'Orsay, but the Waterlilies are here in all their glory. And they are glorious! Two rooms, four walls, worth a visit just for that. The "guards" keep the noise down, so you can sit and contemplate. The bottom floor has other Impressionist paintings worth seeing as well, Renoir, Picasso, Manet.

An opportunity not to miss. If you have a little extra time don't miss this small museum. With the Paris Museum Pass you can visit many museums as often and for as long or short a time as you'd like. This museum hosts 8 of Monet's full wall oil paintings of his lily pond in Giverney. The paintings were given to the Parisians shortly after he died to provide them with a place to relax and be surrounded by nature. Spend a minute or two just relaxing there and enjoy the brilliance of Monet.

Don't pass this one up!. The Orangerie has been redone and it is fabulous. The highlight is still the huge waterlilly paintings by Monet. Two giant rooms of them! But there are also coordinating exhibits that are small enough and focused on one area that fatigue does not set in. On a nice day leave and have lunch in the Tuileries Gardens. Those outdoor restaurants have good food and great Paris watching.

Great little building. Great if you just want to visit a small gallery, it has the famous Water Lilies but also quite a few paintings by the great French artists. It has a nice little cafe and is a nice location for a walk in the park and is very near the Louvre. If you go before 11.00 or so there is no queue.
Skip. The 2 rooms that cover the 8 huge Monet's are great. After that you go downstairs .....if you aren't into paintings.....don't waste your time. Spend your time at the musee d'orsay instead.
monet in all the splendour,. if you like waterlilies, this is the place to go, divine place from the best impressionist you can seat in the middle of the room and dream

Breathtaking..... Monet has given us a beautiful the artists view of his work in two circular galleries that contain four paintings that wrap the room in an immersive experience of impressionism that demands that you sit and marvel at the expansive images that comprise the waterlillies painting. The other galliers are no less beautiful filled with Renoir, Picasso as I had. Never seen him or even knee he did, and van Gough. It's not a big museum, but one that is spacious and allows for space to for thoughtful contemplation.

Perfect small museum. Can't handle the size of the Louve and d'Orsy? Go to Musee de l'Orangerie! Spend as much time as you like admiring a small beautiful selection of impressionist art, and the 8 Water Lillies alone are worth the price of admission. No crowds when we visited, and you can get up close to all of the art.

My favorite museum. This museum was recommended by the concierge at our hotel and it was a huge surprise. The best part were the panels of Monets water lilies. The room and the lighting were specifically designed for them and they were incredible. I could have spent the entire day there! Do not miss it!!!

Beautiful.. Well my children may not have appreciated the beauty and sheer scale of these paintings, but I didn't! I really believe in adding art and culture to trips for the kids such as our one to Paris. However I would like to head back for some quieter contemplation without children to worry about.

MONET. If you love Monet, then you should stop here. His murals housed here are ginormous. They take up whole walls. Certainly a site to see. You don't have to stay in here for a long time, but it's definitely a great place for a quick stop.
Great Monet Murals!. After first visiting Giverny we went to this Museum to see the Monet murals. Amazing to see these huge murals of Giverny pond and gardens

Beautiful and very calming.. I had never been here before and visited a year or more ago. I am hoping to go back in the summer. It has a really interesting layout and is well worth the visit. The artwork is displayed in an engaging way. Be sure to add it on to your trip!
Essential for any art lover.. Wonderful display of vast paintings in a specially designed rooms where you feel immersed inside the work rather than a mere spectator.

I've enjoyed other museums more. It wasn't as impressive as I had expected based on other reviews. I guess the waterlilies are just not really my style of paintings.
I enjoyed the first floor more than the oval rooms downstairs. The first floor had quite a lot of interesting paintings by a variety of artists and a nice bookshop.
Stunning collection of lily pads by monet. If you are a Monet fan, do not let yourself miss this spot. Breathtaking. Inspiring and emotional collection to larger than life canvases.

What a gem of a place. Have been to Paris many times and had not been here. I'm so sorry for not visiting earlier. My favourite was the Nymphéas by Claude Monet, large depictions of his flower garden over the walls of two oval rooms dedicated to them. They are very impressive works of art that invite the visitor to sit on the bench to admire. Well worth the visit.

Beautiful and free to EU residents. This was my favourite place I went on my most recent trip to Paris. It was small but had an amazing impressionist collection. The main floor has whole rooms dedicated to huge Monets. I would loved to have spent hours in those rooms they were so calm and beautiful. As well I got in for free as I was living in the UK at the time.

Beautiful to see Monet's Lilly paintings . We went here primarily to see Monet's paintings. They are phenomenal and reason enough to visit the museum. There is an entire second level to the museum as well of paintings from numerous other artists but I wasn't as thrilled by them (but then again I have very specific tastes in art).

Wonderful!. We visited this museum based on recommendations from friends and travel sites. We're not big art fans, but we enjoyed the variety of art shown at the museum, is spaciousness and ability to meander and reflect. I'm not sure of the price, since we had bought the museum pass and this museum was included. The only negative, as with most Paris museums, is they restrict access 1 hour before they close and start closing areas well before closing time. A worthwhile afternoon.

Wonderful!. We visited this museum based on recommendations from friends and travel sites. We're not big art fans, but we enjoyed the variety of art shown at the museum, is spaciousness and ability to meander and reflect. I'm not sure of the price, since we had bought the museum pass and this museum was included. The only negative, as with most Paris museums, is they restrict access 1 hour before they close and start closing areas well before closing time. A worthwhile afternoon.

Water Lilies. The Musée de l'Orangerie turned out to be an art gallery containing an important collection of paintings whose summit appears to be the Nymphéas by Claude Monet, large depictions of his flower garden over the walls of two oval rooms dedicated to them. They are indeed very impressive works of art that invite the visitor to sit on the bench placed in the middle of the room and stare at the water lilies and beyond, into space. In terms of size, you might feel the contrast between the massive collections of other museums in Paris and the compact, corridor-like display of the pieces at the l'Orangerie, which does not in any way diminishes the depth of the experience.

Good introduction museum for younger kids. Well this is not Muse D'Orsay however the Waterlilies by Monet makes it a must see. There are also paintings from early Picasso, Cezanne, Matisse. Even one Rodin. Good size for one hour museum visit with younger kids.

The Waterlillies are amazing. I have always wanted to see Monet's Waterlillies and here they are displayed in the two huge oval rooms they were made for. They surround you along all 4 walls so it feels like you can see the whole scene as it was painted. Definitely a must see if you like this kind of thing, and to be honest even if you don't.

The water lilies make this a must see. With so many museums and usually so little time, this lovely place can be done with a museum pass in 20 minutes if you just pop in for Monet's 8 enormous paintings displayed in two large oval rooms.

Water lilies are beautiful.. Surrounded by monet's water lilies- no sky or banks of the pond, just pure magic. You fall into the paintings and are moved to another place. Not to miss if you are a fan of the impressionist's work.

Perfect clement to Giverny. The Orangerie is often overlooked by tourists but it's especially interesting to those who love Impressionism and/or Claude Monet. If you plan to visit Giverny, Monet's home, I would highly recmmend including The Orangerie as well.

Small but fabulous gallery. I really recommend going to see the Water Lilies as they are lovely to see in person, even if you are not a fan. Be warned this is a spiritual place for many french people so you will get shushed if you or your kids make noise. Due to the museums very small size and heightened security this was the longest queue we had in Paris (even with our fast pass access) but it was worth the wait.
The place to appreciate art.. Relax and appreciate the feeling of almost 'privacy' as you absorb the atmosphere and tranquility of this sometimes overlooked museum in the grounds of the Louvre

Don't miss this jewel of a museum!. We happened on this museum our first day in Paris. Incredible art, not only the Water Lilies, but other fantastic artists. A small museum, but a fantastic experience. We purchased a pass ahead of time, but on the day we visited we didn't find any lines. There is a little cafe that had good sandwiches - not too many restaurants that we could find in this immediate area, so it worked out well. The Monet murals - words can't describe. We had already visited his Giverny home, so this was the icing on the cake. There is an interesting collection of other impressionists. After so many tours and travels, it was nice to visit a smaller museum that was packed with great art.

If your a Monet fan.. If you are a Monet fan this is a must see. If your time is limited in Paris go to the Musée d'Orsay first. The museum is not so big and expensive. For my wife this was a highlight.

Small but quite nice. Was not busy at all on a Monday morning, I'm not a art nut but the water lily room was quite inspiring. Had some big name artists, very much enjoyed this museum we spent about 2 hours and seen it all. Recommend

L'Orangerie Yes. What a great art museum. It's very centrally located, very near Musee du Louvre. It is probably most famous for the very large curved wall Monet paintings featuring lilly pads. These are the same one's that appeared in the movie, Midnight in Paris. Beyond the many Monet's there are many other classic paintings by well known artists. When friends ask about galleries to visit while in Paris, this is always on my list.

Good for Monet, Bad for anything else. There are 8 beautiful Monet water lily paintings. That's on the main floor over 2 rooms. The rooms are curved and there are benches were you can sit and look. Downstairs, there are a couple rooms with paintings of various artists. Not very much to see. The gift shop is small and kind of a joke. Everything at the gift shop you could get at the Orsay or Lourve gift shop. Not the best museum in Paris but if you like Monet I would recommend.
Fantastic place!. A real important part of Musee d'Orsay expositions...Perfect place for those fantastic enormous pictures of water lilies

Monet Fans, Don't Miss Orangerie. If you don't have the time to take a day-trip to the home and gardens of Giverny, where Monet painted many of his masterpieces, then you must come see the works displayed in the Orangerie. Monet himself played a part in the creation of this facility and how his work would be displayed (with natural light coming in from above and his eight canvases hung in two rooms). It's peaceful (despite tourists) and a magical experience. I would also recommend taking a turn downstairs where even more impressionist painters are displayed (including a large collection of Renoir). The cafe downstairs is not a bad stop if you're looking for a croissant and a coffee. Shouldn't need more than an hour or so for this museum, but it's worth it.

Worth the wait on line. Musee do L'Orangerie was worth the long wait on line.Beautiful paintings all around with excellent works from Rembrandt anda unique circular room with works from the great Monet.The works covered the Impressionist period all the way to Modern artHighly recommend a stop to this beautiful museum on your Paris trip

A treasure in the heart of Paris. If you only have time to visit 1 museum whilst in Paris, visit the the Musee de l'Orangerie and go early before the rush. We got there just at it was opening and had almost half an hour to admire the water lillies in the beautifully designed room before anyone else got there and it was almost surreal.

Love this museum. The Monet's water lilies should not be seen anywhere else. The experience is so enchanting and relaxing and you can see what the artist really intended. Take a stroll in the nearby park as well. :)
fav paris museum!. small & perfect size! monet's water lilies in a circular room are gorgeous with another 75 or so paintings downstarirs. at the end of the tuilieres garden across from the d'orsay-

Show me the Monet. Plenty to see here, but the Monet's steal the show and are the big drawcard, at least for me they were......just amazing.....others will find more eloquent ways to express these global treasures but they are stunning. Lots of other classics to whet the artistic appetite Picasso's, Matisse's, Renoirs, Cezannes, Derains, Sisley and a host of others all command your attention, for me the Cezannes are something special but everyone will have their favourites, but in the end you come back to the Monet's .....just stunning pieces.

Musee de l'Orangerie. This museum covers art - mostly painting- from the Impressionist Period to Modern Art. Most of the art here is from a family of art dealers/collectors. The highlight is two very large oval rooms with large panels of Monet's water lilies in different light and seasons. It is incredible and such an experience to sit on the benches in the center and ponder the beauty of nature. Monet painted these panels especially for this museum which used to house an orange tree grove. Definitely get an audioguide.

Very enjoyable space. A small, intimate art gallery highlighting Monet's Water Lilies. This space was well designed to keep noise out of the lily viewing rooms, making it quite lovely to just sit and enjoy the artwork (most unlike the Louvre!). We really enjoyed getting to see the lilies as well as the other work downstairs, but would not have made the effort or expense unless we had the Museum Pass, which includes this. That allowed us the freedom to feel we could just pop in and enjoy whatever we liked as long as we wished then leave without feeling guilty for not spending more time.

Underrated Treasure!. This museum is one of those that often get overlooked by tourists who have had their fill of museums after the tiring visit to the Louvre. But it is a tiny museum that should not be missed! The two oval rooms filled with Monet's lilies are alone enough for the visit. And they are absolutely gorgeous! *_* Also, like most museums in Paris, it is free on first sunday of the month! Leave this for the last as it will require only about 1-1.5 hrs and end your day with the serene lilies! :D

Small museum with Monet's water lilys!. We missed visiting this museum when visiting Paris last year and so this was first on our list.A small museum, which was a delight after visiting the much larger Orsay and Louvre museums. The focus, of course, is the epic water lily garden paintings by Monet.Take the time to savor the moment and enjoy being surrounded by these two peaceful works of art. Very nice.Also ignore the people taking pictures in violation of the many signs saying you shouldn't take pictures.Quite interesting watching the museum proctors scolding people for taking pictures as well. :-)Well worth the visit.I would note that Museum Pass holders don't seem to have much of an advantage getting in quicker, at least during lower visitation periods.Enjoy!

Forget Louvre this and Musee d'Orsay are the best galleries. Wow sums it up. The Monets and then the other amazing paintings, the curators really know how to put on a fabulous display of art that relates to neighbouring works, such as Matisse and Picasso. The Apollinaire exhibition was superb, room 4, what an imaginative and outstanding hang. Thank you.

A beautiful space to admire Monet's Lilies. I got a combined ticket to visit the Musee D'Orsay and the Musee de l'Orangerie. I was not expecting much from a small gallery space, but... I really LOVED seeing Monet's Waterlilies, the space they were displayed was so perfect to really take in the beauty. The rest of the museum was nice, I loved that there was lot of light.

Great museum. Of all the museums in Paris that I've visited, this his is my favorite. Great place if you like art and would like to see the water lilies.The museum gives you a different experience, feeling and atmosphere from Louvre and L'Orangerie.However, if you don't like Monet or paintings then this probably won't be the best place for you.

Water lilies. I'll admit it...we only came and saw the water lily paintings. We were a little pressed on time, and since I had read about them, I had wanted to see them. They are incredibly breathtaking in person. Photos and videos do not do them justice. I hope to visit again to see the rest of the museum.

Intimate Gallery - Better than the Louvre!. Gallery, audio guide, cafe, toilets and shop. This venue is smaller than the much larger museums around it yet has a breathtaking collection on display. The crowds were far less than the Louvre and there was far more space to stand back and view the works. Entry is €9 per adult. We asked about concessions for disabled - it's free for the disabled person and their carer with proof of disability ( a photocopied disabled badge) which we had. There are lifts for wheelchair access to each floor too. The pieces in the lower floor vary depending upon the exhibitions - we saw impressionist, cubism (Matisse, Monet, Renoir, Picasso, plus many others ). Fantastic. We stopped for a cup of tea before moving onto the next floor which I would recommend in order to collect your thoughts and refocus. The upper floor displays the larger Monet canvasses within the two oval rooms. The whole venue is amazing. It's placed next to Place de La Concorde and not too far from the Louvre. Would definitely recommend. I will be back when I'm next in Paris.

What Happened to Silence?. I have been to Paris 6 times and somehow never managed to get to Musee Orangerie. This time it was a priority, I even came to Paris early to make time. Even the guard outside cautioned with the silent motion, but no one else seemed to notice. The were tour guides talking in several languages and young people more interested in taking and sharing their "selfies" with their friends than sitting quietly and enjoying the panels. I went off to enjoy the other works, the museum has a wonderful collection of impressionist works. Later, I returned to enjoy the water lollies in relative silence. Yet another great treasure of Paris.

Perspective explosion! . It's just perfect. It's so manageable on one level; and so surprising and intelligent on another. The lilies need no introduction ... but when you see them in the flesh you are confronted by the limitations of technology in c 1900. A contemporary artist would have fixed the joins. But that makes this the more exciting. Here is an artist rethinking what makes a "visual experience" just using nineteenth century paint and canvas -- and the way you are obliged to think about perspective is as exciting as looking at Picasso.

If you love Monet, you must visit this venue. But don't forget they have a very nice collection of Renoir and other impressionist paintings too. The temporary exhibits are masterfully curated too. You won't leave without learning something interesting. Only need a couple of hours to go through the complete venue.

Worth your time...and manageable. Great museum that you can enjoy in two hours...tops. Wonderful exposure to impressionism. The Monet Water Lilies rooms are worth everything. They are the only things in the room. Monet himself designed it that way to give the people of Paris a place to relax. Café is nothing to speak of, so don't count on it for lunch as you would at the Musee D'Orsay. Line was small
A beautiful museum. The feeling is almost devoted looking at hte beautiful paintings by Monet. Also the exhibition downstairs was most interesting.
Lovely. Perfect plan - visit to Musee de L'Orangerie the day before a visit to Giverny. To see the murals then the actual pond the following day was a treat.

Worth it just for Monet's water Lilly series. A fairly small gallery with a modest collection of impressionist and surrealist artists. Monet's water lilies were the reason for our visit. Tip earlier the better as can get quite busy later in the day.

Wonderfully breathtaking. I only went because a visiting friend wanted to. Oh how glad I am she convinced me. Truly delicious. The walls are just covered in the waterlillies and there is so much to see and get lost in. Fortunately it wasn't too busy when we went; I don't believe we queued much (if at all; whereas there was another exhibition in the gallery for which there was a longer queue) and there are cushioned benches in the room so you can sit and just lose yourself. Would definitely recommend to my next visitors.

One of my favourites. The Orangerie is a small art museum that will only take about an hour to view, but the LIGHT is amazing and that plus the shape of the room allow you to fully appreciate Monet's lilies. A friend traveled with me the last time I visited Paris (Nov 2014) and L'Orangerie was her favorite of everything we saw. Obviously the art is the draw, but there's a feeling of restful calm to the place that I've not experienced at any other museum. The lines can be long, but if you have the Paris Museum Pass (which I highly recommend, just schedule all of your museum visits in those day and you save not only a significant amount of money but ~time~) you can go to the door on the right that's specifically for pass holders and breeze in. The Louvre, D'Orsay, and L'Orangerie are the art museum trifecta (with honourable mention to the Rodin). Don't pass up the Musee de l'Orangerie just because it isn't as famous as the others.

So beautiful, it made me cry!. This museum is unique for the two rooms of wter lilies surrounding in an oval. The paintings are so uniquely featured that it is breathtaking. Again, early in the morning, no tour, and enjoy this one on your own (museum pass). Downstairs is a gallery of impressionist -fun! Really lovely museum
Wow . I did not realize the magnitude of the Monet paintings housed here. There is more to see on the other level but the main room is stunning

Sitting Amid Water Lilies. This is a very doable small museum near the Ferris wheel just off of Place de Concorde. Go late in the day to avoid crowds. You can sit in the Water Lilies room and be surrounded by Monet's Water Lilies. Skip renting the audiophone.

Awesome and light . The one thing that strikes you is how much light is in the space. The main attraction is stunning and the various rooms in the basement are fab. There is an interesting display in the basement of models of the building showing how it evolved over the years.
Don't miss this one. It's a small museum. But...Wow! don't miss it. The Water Lilly's room is something I will not forget for a very very long time.

Best Monet and Picasso's. This is a small museum. I had only 1.5 hours to see it and thought I might just skip it. So glad I decided to go! It was only €9. When I arrived early, there was no line. I just walked passed the line and up to security. I had unobstructed view of the pictures and was even able to take panoramic pictures. The first Monet room stole my breathe away. I was expecting A picture. It's a room full! Then another room full! Perfectly displayed in a serene setting with the best light and benches to sit on to soak it all in. Downstairs is just full of Picasso art. Then there are Renoir's and so many others! There are nice signs in English explaining the history of the relationships between the different artists. It helps you see the impact of the master on the students - who became masters as well. I was really moved on my visit here. This made my weekend! Loved it better than the Louvre.

Iconic impressionist art. There are many worthwhile things to see in this famous, but not overwhelming, museum. The main attractions are Monet's nympheas (water lilies) which are housed in two oval rooms. They are simply exquisite. If you're in the vicinity of Jardin de Tuileries make sure you set aside some time, even if it's only half an hour, to pop into Musee de l'Orangerie - it houses some of the most evocative and iconic art you're ever likely to see.

Definitely worth doing. This is a much smaller museum compared to the others we went to in Paris. The highlights are the 2 rooms with the artwork across entire walls. You can get a self guided tour. We just walked around. Not in season yet, had a 20 minute wait in line to get in. Don't miss the Rodin sculpture outside.

Not a favorite. After having visited the Louvre, Petit Palais, d'Orsay, and many other museums in Paris, l'Orangerie was our least favorite. Unless Monet is your absolute favorite artist, there isn't much else to see. Your time will be much better spent exploring other parts of Paris.

Monet Must See. This museum is great and was designed by Monet himself. When you enter the rooms you will see Monet' seventeen foot water lily paintings on circular walls. They are fabulous. When you take photos the colours seem to come alive with colors you don't notice when you see them. Save your ticket stub as there is a deal to get another museum entrance at a few euro discount if you show it upon purchasing a ticket to say, Musee D'orsay.

Wonderful collection, heavy on impressionists. Somewhat surprised by the long line, even on a chilly spring afternoon. Absolutely worth the visit though, if you stand for a while or go to the second of the two main chambers you'll often find yourself with broad, unobstructed views. The downstairs gallery is also fully worth the visit. Buy tickets in advance if possible (multiple sites), it's worth the time saved for the slight increase in cost.

Water lilies an astounding sight. Beautiful, smaller, therefore calmer museum after the hubbub of the Louvre. The water lilies are in two adjacent rooms and a marvellous experience. But the remaining exhibits are a delight also: a 'who's who' of Impressionism.

Monet.... Lovely gallery located near the Louvre..
I loved the Monet rooms and thought it was a great find when escaping the rain...

You have to be a real art connoisseur to enjoy this. The lineup is huge usually. It will probably take you as much time being in line as it will actually take you to see the whole museum. It is quite small, so the admission is restricted by numbers. However the works of art inside are marvelous. You decide if you want to dedicate a whole day to this museum.
Great little museum. Great museum for those who want to spend just an hour or so. Monet /Matisse/ cezanne /Renoir fan would be pleased.

Monet at its best.. this is the most accessible art in Paris. It is in the round and takes you from dawn to dark in the famous Monet gardens. Lots and lots of bench seating available so that you can sit in front of the painting at every time of day. truly moving experience

Monet, and all other major late nineteeth/early twentieth century French artists. Yes, the Monet paintings are superb and well lit - you will need to sit down for a while if you want to see them beyond the crowds of people taking selfies. Downstairs, however, is another treasure trove of French art - the personal collection mainly of Paul Guillaume, a visionary art dealer who championed the young artists of the time, including Derain, Matisse and Picasso. His wife, Domenica, broadened the collection to include her favourite artists, including Cezanne, Gaughin and Renoir and all of these great artists are on display in abundance. If you have even a passing interest in French art of this period, this museum is a must and the queues are significantly shorter than at either the Louvre or the Musee d'Orsay.

Monet's Nymphéas are housed here . If you're a Monet lover and cannot get yourself to Giverny, which would be a great compliment to visiting this gallery, then do yourself a favor; grab a sit in the oval room, take in the views of Monet's Nymphéas and reflect on the artist's intended vision. I cannot stress enough that purchasing the audio guide is NOT a waste of your money. At only 5-6€ is definitely worth it. The gallery also features a floor down below with more for you to see-make time to see all the post Impressionism housed there. One of my favorite things to do once I leave the l'Orangerie is to grab a seat at the Jardin de Tuileries and reflect upon the beauty that I was privileged enough to witness. With the Paris Museum Pass you can skip the long, long lines which sometimes are a nightmare. This is a Paris 'must do'.
Monet lover come here. Beautiful paint on all the walls! Just do not want to leave. Wish could have more time to stay. Come here and you won't be disappointed!

Monet's Water Lilies are magnificent. Purchase the personal guide, you learn so much more about the art and artist with this devise. The Monet rooms are wonderful. I spent hours standing so close to the masterpieces I had to pinch myself. This is an amazing collection. Take a walk through the park after seeing the paintings, it gives you a fresh perspctive. Include this gallery as a a must see

Magnificent. Monet’s Nymphéas (8 beautiful paintings of this collection) in a 360 degree panoramic display are a breathtaking & intimate experience. I was spellbound by the sheer beauty, calm, size, technique, & Monets passion for this subject.This museum in not just about Monet, there are other works from other notable Impressionists including Renoir, Matisse, Picasso & Sisley (just to name a few). But Monet will always be my favourite.We purchased the 2-museum pass, but this was definitely my favourite.

Water Lilies!. This museum is small in size and crowds, but rich in art. The lower level holds an impressive collection of art by Matisse, Picasso, Soutine, Renoir and others. After appreciating those works, head to the second floor to view the amazing Water Lilies. I could have sat in the middle of each room for hours, just relaxing at total peace.

Monet. if you are a fan of Monet's water lilies, this is the place for you. Two rooms covered with his beautiful water lilies. That alone would make the museum worth it. It is a small space, but worth a visit.
Have to see Monet's Lillies. Lines here (even with Paris Museum Pass) seem to move so slow, as on our first visit we bailed and came back the next day. Once inside though, it is well worth it.

Surprises Galore!. My partner and I wanted to visit this museum and ended up getting a 2-museum pass. It made more sense to do so. There were more galleries than I had expected. Monet's Water Lilies was spectacular, and the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collection was worth viewing too.

Breathtaking Monet. So gorgeous. Two rooms of only Monet. The downstairs had a mix of paintings. I liked how it wasn't too crowded. The millennials taking selfies and posing were a little annoying though.

Uncrowded Delight. This is our favourite Paris Museum because if you get there near opening time (09.30 which is unusually early for Paris)in our experience, there will be very few others there. Further, most other attendees are focussed on the large Monets, which are certainly delightful but for us, the real treasures are downstairs. The portraits by Soutine are simply outstanding. There are also many Renoir pictures on the lower level

Claude Monet at his best!. The 8 panels of Monet's water lilies would be enough of a reason to visit, but the added works of other artists is icing on the cake! We were unable to tour this gallery on our first visit. So glad we made it this time.

Small but perfectly formed museum. Lovely collection of works from other Impressionists as well as the lollies. Not as big as I expected but quality makes up for that! Worth the wait to see the lilies as I honestly think only in person can you realise and appreciate the scale.8

Simply wonderful. Go downstairs first, and then back upstairs to Monet's water lilies. The latter will blow your socks off - you won't want to leave. Amazingly presented, they are just stunning - highly recommended!

No special exhibit = no long line. Fortunately, our most recent visit to the Orangerie coincided with NO special exhibits. Therefore even with the enhanced security we were able to gain immediate access. Monet's water lilies, which encompass two large rooms on the main floor, are the primary attraction at this museum. If you are a fan of Monet, this is a "must see" museum. On the bottom floor are other other Impressionist and modern paintings. There are a fair number of Renoirs, one of my favorites.They recently added a small cafe which reduced the size of the gift shop. The museum is located in the Tuileries Gardens and is open from 9 a.m. until 6 p.m., closed Tuesday. Although there is a separate line for those with the Paris Museum pass, if there is a special exhibit and people have pre-booked tickets, your wait to enter will be considerable.
Beautiful and breathtaking. We've probably all seen a few Monets in our day. But seeing them as displayed in this gem of a museum is special and awe inspiring. Not to be missed!

Monet is not my fav.... still it's great. So Monet is not my favorite. But it is a great collection. And there are always other artists' works displayed. Easy to get to - Place de la Concorde. Don't miss the Marmontan also. Look it up - great Monet's there too. And other wonderful impressionists.

Musee de l'Orangerie. Other than the needless long wait in line in the rain, even with a Museum Pass, the Musee de l'Orangerie was one of the highlights of our trip, mostly because it has one of the best collections of Impressionist works.
Magical!. If you love Monet's paintings this is a must for a visit. Easy to get to and delightful to visit. Don't miss if you are a fan of 'The Impressionists'
Monet Monet Monet. Excellent end of day activity. A visit to see the huge murals of water lilies. A stripped back presentation that allows you to absorb the full impact of these enormous pictures.

Monet's Water Lilies. We ran into the Musee de l'Orangerie about 30 minutes before it closed. We had hoped to spend more time, but we are so glad to have made a little time for this great museum. The Water Lilies are absolutely worthwhile. Spread over a couple rooms, the Water Lilies are amazingly beautiful and provide an opportunity to truly enjoy them. And don't miss the rest of the museum, it is lovely.
Beautiful collection. This museum did not take long to go through, but the collection was beautiful and we enjoyed our time there.

Water Lilies by Monet. The main exhibition is water lilies. Don't need to spend time and money here if you are not really interested in this painting. However, it's still very interesting to see the huge paintings in two rooms.

Monet up close. The Orangerie itself is a lovely building. Add that to a 360 degree viewing of some of Monet's waterlilies and you're in for a beautiful experience. Downstairs, there are more art exhibits to explore.

Exceeded expectations. These beautiful water-lilly paintings are so well known that you might think it is hard to be surprised by them. For the first few minutes I almost felt disappointed - so many people blocking the view and taking selfies and, treacherous thought, the paintings almost seemed a cliché of themselves initially - but just pick a good spot on one of the benches and be prepared to sit it out as the crowds mill around you, allowing yourself to sink into the pools. Gradually, you become immersed in the picture, as though you are part of the shimmering water and blooms. More and more of the light and shade takes form, you sort out the reflections from their originators. A heady experience. Then go and marvel at the amazing brush work close to. and wonder how those vivid, random looking splodges of colour created such a sublime experience. Then, when you can drag yourself away, go downstairs and be dazzled by a tightly packed collection of paintings by many other artists of the same period. Excellent value at around 9Euros and well worth seeing. We queued for about 20 minutes to get in which is not bad for Paris in these security conscious days.

Gorgeous. This is a special experience going into the two oval rooms and looking at Monet's lillies. They are absolutely beautiful. While there are many paintings downstairs, Monet's paintings are by far the main attraction and I would be happy going just to see them. Take some time just to sit and look at Monet's lillies, there is a bench in the centre of the room to sit on and enjoy. You will have to leave your coats and bags at the front of the museum and no photography is allowed in the oval room.
Spectacular Small Museum. Worth it just to see Monet's Water Lily's. Also a small collection of Renoir and other great artists. Really nice.

Sweet museum. Home to the massive Monet waterlily murals. A spectacular, relaxing experience to sit and study these massive paintings in specially designed ovoid rooms. We try to visit every time we are in Paris (at the expense of some very famous museums I still have not visited after 35 years and dozens of trips here). L'Orangerie also has a small gallery with some other impressionist paintings, but it's all about the Monets.

Impressionist Paradise. It was here, during a visit that I realised that Picasso was an excellent Impressionist painter before he invented cubism. There was a painting of each type side by side. The second time, was again different and interesting. The absolute highlight , of course, is the Water Lilies (Les Nympheas). If you have already been to Monet's Garden in Giverny then these will hold even more enjoyment, though it is not essential. Just sit and enjoy.

Fun small museum. The good thing about this museum is that you can experience it up close without 900 million other people. Yes there is a crowd, but it isn't nearly as crowded as others. And yes like any self respecting museum in Paris, they have Renoir Monet and Picasso all in one room.
Go if you love Monet. An interesting setting for Water Lillies and a must see for fans of Monet. Do the combo ticket as this is a quick visit and you'll want to spend more time in the Musee d'Orsay.

WOW WOW WOW!. Just walking in the rooms with the Montes made me smile. Light and airy, with the huge Water Lilies canvases covering the pond-shaped rooms. Spectacular! Not as crowded as the Orsay and much better orgnized for Impressionists. The lower floor has a very organized and informative collection of impressionist, fauvist and cubist works. Pretty expensive though for a museum that has a focused but limited collection.

A real treat to see the Monet works. We finally got a chance to see the famous Monet lilies and it was a real treat. Although we really enjoyed the visit, it does not rank up there with d'Orsay.Other than the lilies, the collection was amazing for an individual, but modest compared to some of the other galleries.Worth a visit, but buy your ticket in advance.

the monet panels bring the artist's intent to fruition. go and luxuriate in the glory of the lily ponds...you cannot appreciate the true mastery, until you have seen them as they were meant to be presented.
Not impressed. Simply didn't feel welcoming and staff is not very friendly many venues were closed at the time and bathrooms are very dirty too.
Excellent. Not as popular as the Louvre (which is very overrated) and the queues are nowhere near as long. A beautifully designed building to display Monet's waterlilies.

Get lost in the Musée de l'Orangerie. Monet's beautiful paintings of water lilies are breathtaking. The rooms are hushed as people settle in to yield to their spell. The huge canvases are calming and transport you to a deeper state of consciousness.

Waterlillies, seen again. It's a long time ago when I last time saw waterlilies, I just love those paintings. I could watch those for ages. As we visited Paris just after Belgium terror attacks security control was very tight. I don´t mind that at all. We were lucky to be that early that the queue was not very long (around 11.00). So I suggest that you go just after when museum opens. Though the security control slows down a bit everything, personnel are patient and friendly. I appreciate very much what they are doing.

Perfect for Monet fans. Standing in the middle of Monet's water lilies in rooms designed by Monet himself was an amazingly wonderful experience. Upon entry, one is encouraged to leave worldly concerns outside, and the setting inspires quiet inspiration. This is a don't miss museum if you are a lover of Impressionism.
Monet heaven. If you are a fan, then this is the place for you... The two oval rooms on the ground floor are amazing. Also many good other collections. Think my favorite was renoir.

Monet!!. I regret not having more time in Paris to just be able to sit in the museums and enjoy the paintings, and Monet's Water Lilies are just for that. I could spend hours in the oval rooms!The museum is small, so I recommend getting a combined pass with other museums, which saves you some money.

Calming space. We arrived on a busy Easter Sunday. The gallery was a lovely calming space and housed a fantastic collection of artwork. As well as the Monet's the collection included some fabulous little surprises. Great value for money though the cafe is expensive.

Stunning, friendly, calm, with good information in English. Beautiful setting for the famous Waterlillies, as well as excellently presented and curated selection of impressionist work. The information panels were well written,k including in English, which made it very engaging for all of us, including our 12 and 14 year old children. Small cafe on site as well.
Don't miss it. The most incredible place if you are a fan of impressionist art. The Monet paintings are amazing and huge.

Best smaller museum in Paris. If you are a Monet fan this is a must see. Located a short walk from the Louvre, this museum has some beautiful works of art. Lovely shop and small cafe to take a break from sightseeing.

So French. Had a simple lunch in the small cafe and then spent a very pleasant, relaxing couple of hours in this museum. It was a great smaller place to see some of the impressionist paintings. Very enjoyable.
If you like Monet, you love this place.. It was easy to get lost in the water lilies, my wife was mesmerized. We also enjoyed the impressionist exhibit in the basement, an bonus surprise.
Impressionism. Good size museum, it's a nice start for appreciating art, viewing first the Monet lilies, then going through a variaty of works from different artists at the collection.

A must see museum!. We were stunned by the 2 oval rooms of Monet's waterlillies. They are presented on long tableaus, each done at different times of day with different light. It's not a big museum, but we were overwhelmed by the beauty. It's at Place Concorde.

Quick stop. We visited this to see the Water Lillies but spent time exploring the rest of the gallery too. Of all the places we visited in Paris, this probably had the shortest queue. We had the Paris Pass and jumped the queue. Great if you have time to kill as it wont take more than an hour or so.

The perfect union of artwork and gallery. Being surrounded by four Monet's is one of the greatest experiences an art-lover can have. I could stand a meter away from one painting seeing how the colours dance and flicker in and out of figuration or I could sit in the middle to witness a full splendid scene. The under-croft also has a great selection of Modern Masters too. Most of my friends who have been to Paris had not even heard of this fine place and regret not having done so after I tell them about it.

Water Lilies like you have never seen them before!. Loved the two rooms of Monet's Water Lilies in the round. We had previously seen panels at MOMA in New York - impressive, but nothing like this! You feel like you are Actually there - in the garden. A must see for any Monet fan - or any art fan! Just beautiful (and included in he Museum Pass).
Monet!!. Lesser known, but awesome. Sit in the room an drink in the beauty! The Monet panels are so calming and lovely.

Timeless Water Lilies. If you're a fan of Monet's water lilies painting, you'll love to just sit at Musee de l'Orangerie for a few hours just looking at Monet's 8 wall of water lilies painting. By the way, worth buying ticket pass that is good for Musee de Orsay and Musee l'Orangerie at 16€ and the ticket is valid for 3 months.

Must See Museum. If you like impressionist painters this museum is a must see. The two Monet rooms are impressive and were specifically designed to immerse you in the Water Lillies. One of a kind exhibit that is worth visiting.

Tranquil.....and open on a Monday!. Go for the Monet by all means, but check out the exhibitions downstairs too. We spent two hours taking in the Walter-Guillaume collection, which is stunning. Don't bother with the cafe though...very functional and even the coffee is below par.
Beautiful and tranquil. Well worth a visit to see the beautiful murals. A lovely place to sit and contemplate the stunning paintings.

Our Favorite Museum In Paris. This is a small museum, but with a very high quality collection and great focus. The main attraction is the eight panels of Monet's Water Lillies, displayed exactly as the artist wanted. The collection of impressionist art on the lower level is wonderful. An hour or two is all that is needed to see this museum, probably not a great value unless you have the two-day museum pass.

20 Minute Museum. This wonderfully sized museum offers the perfect bite sized look at some of the most beautiful paintings in the world. Everything about this place is perfect. The light, the room size, shape and color. There's also a terrific café for breakfast, snacks or lunch! Much better then any of the dreadful food at Orsay.

So beautiful and peaceful !. The museum was made especially for Monet Nymphéas at the requêtes of Georges Clemenceau, and the Nymphéas were painted for the museum. You sit in front of the paintings and serenity wraps you. Those paintings are unique and so beautiful!! I mostly recommed the visit.
One of my favourite museums in Paris.. Just stunning nice little museum not to be missed. Photos do not do it justice. Conveniently located and not overly busy was a great little stop in the day.
Wow!! . This is totally worth seeing for the Monet alone. The additional art collection down stairs is amazing in its own right. Beautiful space and incredible art.

A superb Gallery for Monet paintings. Magnificently situated at the end of the Tuilleries gardens in front of the unique Concorde square, the gallery presents Monet's enormous water lillies : a must in Paris

THE BEST.. Ah Monet. Ah finally some peace and quiet. Ah a layout that doesn't cause epilepsy. It was the best museum experience in Paris, hands down. Despite not having lockers and having to goggle my purse around, I enjoyed it immensely. At the end I recommend the gift shop for the unique magnets and paraphernalia with the water lilies.

Perfect museum!. Any Claude Monet fan needs to come here!!! We happened to go on the one day of the month when it's free, the line was really short, and everyone was quiet and respectful in the museum. You will be able to see that this museum was designed by Monet himself to house this beautiful paintings!!

The Great Monet's are here. Just off the Seine very close to the Place de la Concorde is a smaller museum called Orangerie. It is on 2 levels. The top floor is what most people come for, which is to view the enormous waterlily paintings of Claude Monet. They are in 2 rooms and they are absolutely fabulous. It is fascinating to view these works from afar to have them make sense but it's equally interesting to view them at arm's length (with a brush in hand) to try to imagine how he could have made shapes and colors that made no sense at that depth and yet perfect sense at 20 ft away. They say it was his failing eye sight that allowed for it. Downstairs is a very worthwhile eclectic collection of painting from the 19 and early 20th century that is also very compelling. If you loved the Monets here, make it a point to see the other great collection of Monet's works at the Musee Marmottan in the 16th. It's also quite extraordinary.
Monet magnificent. Just to see the paintings shown in the round, just as Monet wanted was truly amazing. Such wonderful colours and beautiful brush strokes. He was really a great artist.

Monet's water lillies !. The best thing about the Orangerie is the huge painting of water lillies by Monet. They are hung around a large room -- as he directed. They are beautiful. If you only have time to go to one museum and want impressionists, go to the Orsay or the Marmottan. This is a great second choice.

Impressionist Master. This is a must stop if you love Monet and his contemporaries. The rooms are designed specifically to house these masterpieces, but the basement houses a small collection of excellent art as well. This museum is not big, but as my teenagers stated, it's the perfect size!

A must see with little kids. We went with our children 7, 8 and 13. They were impressed by the two rooms with monets water lilies. They spent time here photographing the rooms and liking around. They even went downstairs to see the small selection of Picasso, Renoir and other works.They were at orsay the day before and this was much more their thing. The smaller museum was less overwhelming to them.
Monet Water Lilies. Beautiful museum we heard about from tour guide. Two huge rooms with Monet's water lilies paintings taking up each wall. Each one is different and incredibly beautiful.
Oh Monet!. This is the smallest museum we visited, but one of my favourites, as it houses one of my most favourite painters... Monet <3

Beautiful purpose built art space. As I am visitng Giverny soon I wanted to see the Waterlililes by Monet first, and I was not disappointed.The entry to the museum is not free, the cost was 9euro and the offer a few other museum ticket deals, which make make your euro go further but I have already visited the other museums and was not able to return (they are valid for the day after).The museum did have a queue, but this moved quickly and was only to clear security. The line to buy the tickets was tony.Once inside you will need to check any large bags, such as backpack, so please be aware of this visiting.The area with the Monet paintings is busy, but take your time and enjoy. There is a lot of seating so you can easily sit down and take in his beautiful work.On the lower floor there is a mixture of other artist, including Picasso before his cubism work.There are good facilities on site (toilets and cafe) and there appears to be disabled access.

Monet's fabulous Waterlilies. Small but beautiful museum. You may buy an admissions ticket at Musee d'Orsay for this venue as the two museums are situated across the River Seine from each other. Easy access to metro, stop is Place de la Concorde. Fabulous views across the city. Exhibition well worth the visit.
Use the first Sunday in the month free day!. Lovely little gallery. Not as overpowering as others in Paris, so just about right to see enough amazing art even for non artsie people!

Experience Monet's Waterlilies. l'Orangerie offers a beautifully-designed structure in which to truly experience these paintings, but offers much more as well...other galleries include more impressionistic art, and there is a nice cafe and gift shop.

A beautiful space to view some exquisite paintings. The museum is small but well curated with the beautiful Monet paintings taking center stage in the elliptical room.It is a wonderful space to sit and take them in, but please do that and don't be one of those people that takes pictures and walks away!The exhibition downstairs has some great early works by Picasso, Magret and others with some interesting themes.The only downside is the gallery annotations are completely in French so not super accessible to those that don't speak the language.

Limited collection. If one has a time crunch in Paris, unless you love Monet, I would skip this museum. I had a museum pass so it did not cost me. If one has been to the Barnes Museum in Philadelphia with over 150 Monets I would definitely give this a pass. There are far better museum options in Paris. The collection is really one floor that is like the wing of larger museums. It may be a place to go if there was a special exhibit.

Exceptional, near Louvre and you can use museum pass. Small museum near the louvre.Rooms that perfectly display the Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet. There are works by other great artists to keep you occupied for a while, as well.Take an hour break from the Louvre and stroll down this gem of a museum. Museum pass gets you in.

A Monet Must See!. This small museum will wow you with the two Monet rooms on the ground floor. Monet painted his works for this space, and they are beautifully presented here. Included with the Paris Museum Pass.

Exquisite. We have a unique relationship with Monet, my wife and I. He brought us together, or at least his art did. Our first date, was to a MONET exposition, and this fabulous lady treated me to information and insights not just concerning Monet but all impressionist art, from her studies and her travels. I was bowled over from the start, and have stayed that way. This exquisite, historic building, centrally located, houses the famous Giverny water lilies as well as Renoir, Picasso, Matisse etc, The impact is sublime. We now have one more memory of our soul mate.

If you love Monet it's the place for you. Pleasant enough experience, Monet just doesn't do it for me. Other significant artists represented (Matisse, Derain). My daughter likes Monet so she enjoyed, I got to use the bathroom so that made it worthwhile (even though it was a little disconcerting when a confused Asian tourist walked out of the men's room - in her defense the "men" and "women" signals are not as pronounced here in France as they are in the U.S.).

Breathtaking. I'm not an art person. At all. My favorite museums are about history, like the Museum of the French Resistance, the Holocaust Museum and Invalides. I thought Notre Dame was impressive but boring. I spent an hour in the Louvre, including getting a snack. Not. My. Thing.I LOVED this place. When I walked into the first Water Lilies room, I got goose bumps. It was like being transformed. The rest of the museum was terrific as well. And the gift shop was amazing.It is one of my favorite places in Paris.

Beautiful. I'd heard that Monet painted some massive paintings in his time, but nothing could have prepared me for the great expanse of artwork; whole walls are taken up by his creation. With a spare hour in Paris, make sure that you come here.

Great museum without the crowds. This small museum is often overlooked but we were lucky to have many Parisians suggest going there. No lines and you can sit for hours amongst the Monet Water Lilies...
