Very nice . A small intimate gallery of mostly impressionists and modern painters; very usefully gives a brief life history of the featured artists which I found helpful. When visited had the Monet water lilies display - if it is still on when you visit Paris , you MUST visit this if nothing else: superb and sublime!!
My favorite Paris museum. Loved the building and the art. Monet's Water Lilies are great to see (see both rooms) and the selection of art on the lower level was spectacular.

Beautiful and not overwhelming in size like other museums. This is a great museum to pop into if you have a little time and unlike other (obviously great) museums in Paris, this is a very doable experience- only consists of around 4 rooms and can be accomplished in under an hour. Definitely worth it.

Manageable size. There are intro films in the basement Audiovisual theatre (programs & times posted on the wall adjacent to it), and these are very good intro & overviews.In addition paying for the audio guide was worth it for us. This museum's size is not too large, in addition to Monet's famous wall panel paintings.Small cafe with very limited seating so avoid peak times.

Lovely little museum . Every time I come to Paris I go to this museum. It's a small, but plenty to see. Although at €9 to get in, not cheap, but worth it. I love Monet's paintings, which are the main feature upstairs. They also have more paintings downstairs too that are definitely a look. Such as Renoir and Picasso's. The descriptions are in English as well as French. The paintings are well chosen and are laid out in a manner that really allows you to get an idea of the artist's behind them. It's my favourite museum in Paris.

A MUST visit for any Monet lover. If you love Monet, or french impressionism, or color, or flowers - this is the place for you! It's such a beautiful space, and The Waterlilies are/is presented so well. And this is a place you can go to without committing a whole day or even an afternoon.
A real pleasure. If you like Monet this is the place for you. If you don't know Monet this will give you a great introduction. Many other delights too.

Unique Experience. I got a combined ticket with the excellent Musee d'Orsay which was excellent value. Essentially eight enormous paintings (Nymphéas) by Monet in two beautiful light rooms...great to see the size of these amazing works.Elsewhere there are a number of works by other artists well worth seeing.

Worth it for the Monet's alone. This small but beautiful museum is found adjacent to the Place de la Concorde and / or at the end of the Tuileries Gardens (a beautiful walk from the Louvre). If you love Monet, is an ESSENTIAL visit. This museum is stunning and the art is housed on 2 levels (with a cafe and shop placed on a third level). The rooms created for Monets Water Lillies series are just filled with light and house nothing but these extraordinary paintings. I had no idea they were so big and blew me away.Other than the Monets, it has many works by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau and many others.

Come to see Mont and his garden. Just the two large oval shape rooms with Mont paintings are worth the trip. Other collections are very impressive as well. Perfect size of gallery for people who only stay in Paris for half day.

Monet fans - don't miss this. If you love Monet you have to go to the Orangerie. There are two huge oval rooms each containing 4 paintings of Monet's garden at Giverney. They are stunning and just fabulous to see these artworks close up.The place was not at all crowded and it was relaxed and easy to view the paintings.A very emotional experience for me!
Ok, not the best museum in Paris. Just ok, I wouldn't go back again. There are better museums in Paris. Some interesting works but this place charges for entry and is quite small.
Musee de L'orangerie. if you can't get to Giverny, go here!! very relaxing and spectacular at the same time. Well worth the trip.
Our favorite Museum in Paris. We absolutely love going to the Orangerie. Monet is our favorite artist. The staff is helpful and the cafe is wonderful.

My new favorite flosers. The Waterlilly collection is a long oval. The seating in the center of the room is also that shape so you can sit and just watch and study uninterrupted for hours. The signage outside is small so easy to miss but worth hunting it down!

My favorite spot in Paris - WOW!. Couldn't believe how awesome this place was. Didn't even plan to do it but for about $10 we decided to stop in. I was blown away by the Monet Water Lilies collection - you could easily spend a day here meditating - unfortunately I was one of those rude americans too busy snapping pics to truly appreciate it because my time was limited. In addition to Monet's work (the highlight for me) I discovered a new painter (to me) named Sautine as well as numerous others. Got so many great pics (YES THEY DO LET YOU TAKE PICS) that I can take home and enjoy for years to come. Well worth it!!

What a surprise!!. I went to this museum to see Monet's Water Lillies. I decided to take a guided tour. Francios (sp?) was the tour guide...she is WONDERFUL!! Her passion of this musuem is evident in her presentation. This museum is so much more than Water Lillies!! I didn't expect to fall in love with this place - I tell everyone to visit. This is now my favorite museum in Paris. If you like Impressionist DEFINITELY go here!!

Best Gallery in Paris. After being to the Louvre and d'Orsay, I still love l'Orangerie the most. It is smaller and usually not as busy as the Louvre or d'Orsay. I also love Monet's work and this place holds his life's work which is his very large water lily paintings that are huge panels. It is an amazing place to just go and sit and stare at his work. I've been twice to this museum both trips to Paris. I loved my visits both times. The set up and design of the place really focuses on seeing the art. If I wasn't so busy my second trip I would have gone twice this trip.If you are in Paris, I would recommend this collection of art the most. It also holds other work in the second floor from other impressionists. Not as large as d'Orsay as I said, but if you like Monet, l'Orangerie cannot be beat.

Worth a visit . This is a must for fans of Monet. I could have just sat there for hours looking at the Water Lillies. It was a very peaceful feeling, providing a nice relaxing break in the middle of a jammed packed day.

Extremely beneficial to health!. We are thankful we were able to visit this museum. I think it is extremely beneficial to health. There are benches provided on which we sat to view the Monet paintings. We became very relaxed almost to the point of sleepiness. If you have high blood pressure, I think viewing the Monet paintings will lower it!

Not just Monet. Of course one goes here for the huge Monet water-lilly paintings in the rooms specially designed to house them - and they are simply stunning - especially if, like me, you can't get enough of the gorgeous colours and sensuality of Monet in his later, almost abstract, period.But downstairs the Guillaume collection of 19th and 20th century paintings would make the museum worth a visit in its own right. About 150 paintings from Cezanne to Picasso, chosen by M. Guillaume to emphasise the influence of classical models on "modern" art, make a wonderfully coherent ensemble.

Tranquil break from Paris hustle and bustle. A lovely little gallery with 8 of Monet's gorgeous Waterlily paintings on show. We chose this instead of the Louvre as there was no crowd and I would rather have seen these wonderful pieces than crowding around to see the Mona Lisa.

A quiet museum that packs a punch. Why does the Louvre get all the attention when this is right through the garden? I'll never know. L'Orangerie was quieter, more intimate, and honestly had peices of art that I was more interested in! Waterlilies was stunning and serene in it's own right but that's not all that this little gem has! We actually went twice in our 6 days in Paris (thanks to the Paris museum pass!) because we enjoyed it so thoroughly.

A Must See in Paris. The Water Lilies paintings are amazing and definitely worth the time if you're in Paris. There are 2 rooms with one on each wall and you are surrounded by their overwhelming presence. Crowds were down when we visited and it was a very peaceful and Zen experience. I liked that the venue allowed photos and didn't rush guests. They also had some Renoirs below and Cezannes. The gift shop had some truly unique and lovely items. Recommend!

Breathtaking. This review may be highly biased because I am positively in love with Monet's work. Standing in the middle of the large oval room surrounded by several of his enormous water-lily pieces was an emotional experience. I have no proper words to describe it. If you appreciate Monet, this is a must-see.
Go to the Musee D'Orsay instead. I must have missed something at this site, everyone was so wowed and I thought it was average. Lined up for an hour and honestly, the Musee d'Orsay is better.
Good . This museum is a fantastic for Monet 's art lovers just here you can see his very famous big painting. The museum works on Monday
Hidden Gem. What a lovely surprise. Amazing and very personal collection. The Monet's are lovely.You can wander round without any crowds. The best hour I have spent in Paris.
The place you have to go!. The place where you can find Monet's waterlilies and many more masterpieces. A must see for art lovers.
Amazing place. Went especially to see the Monet "Waterlilies" and found so much more. The Monets were an experience but the other displays were also fascinating
amazing. i was amazed by the venue and teh quality of works contained within. The arts included Picasso and Rembrant amongst others.

Peace and Tranquility at Monet's Musee de l'Orangerie. Most famous for being the permanent home of eight Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet which are housed in a circular vestibule designed by Monet himself. Monet created this space in order to give Parisians a haven of peace to contemplate his works. This is also the perfect way for the time poor Paris visitor to take in other famous impressionist and post-impressionist paintings in one spot.Located in the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde , the museum also contains works by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo, among others.
Great experience. Wonderful place to visit. Quiet and peaceful and great chance to see such a masterpiece. Small museum but well worth the visit.

Breathtaking. The scale of these beautiful paintings has to be seen to be believed. They are beautiful and displayed in a stunning oval space which is calmly lit and has a quiet atmosphere. Definitely worth a visit and if you visit the Musee d'Orsay you can purchase a joint ticket. The Orangerie is just across the river from M d'O.

Beautiful Waterlilies painting. The Location: Metro #1, 8 & 12, "Concorde". About few minutes walk to the museum. The Admission: 9 euro (included in the museum pass)This entirely refurbished museum houses Monet's Waterlilies and over 144 paintings!The Waterlilies has own special viewing room. The painting is just beautiful~ The size of the painting, the detail of the painting.... impressive!!This museum is close to Musse du Louvre and Tuileres Garden. Definitely plan a day in this area.
Home of the Waterlilies!. To see Monet's masterpieces in the environment he designed specifically for them was extraordinary. The other works displayed were wonderful as well.
Beautiful but small. Even tough the collection of the museum were interesting, I found it really small. I wish there was more variety. The waterlilies are definitely a must see.

Water Lilies. I'm a huge fan of this smallish museum located at the end of the Tuilieries on the left side. Use your Paris Pass to get in, otherwise you can buy a combo ticket for this and the d'Orsay. If you're a fan of Monet and his Water Lilies this is a must see. Two rooms house, oval in shape, large is house, hold 8 full panoramic panels of Water Lilies. There are other beautiful pieces of art work in the museum as well. Small, easy to see in an hour and worth the visit.

Beautiful. The Monet's are the reason why you come here and rightly so. But the collection of other Impressionists works is also very good and well worth the visit. In fact, I'd go here and the Musee d'Orsay and bypass the Louvre. While here you are right on the Place du Concord so after you've soaked in Monet stop for a snack and then stroll the Tuilieres. Perfect.

A more intimate experience. With no lines this museum gave opportunity for true appreciation and reflection.Housing more than Monets Water Lillies you can spend a pleasant hour or two.The museum is near the Louvre and can be accessed by strolling through the Toulleries and is on the left hand side of the gardens...good consideration for those with less mobility

Beautiful monet. I visited as one of the first people in the museum and would definitely advise this, as it became rather crowded by the time I left. The giant Monet paintings are wonderful, and there are many other well-known and trendy artists downstairs as well. Close to the louvre and well worth a visit.

The real Waterlilies and more!. Had no idea the waterlily paintings were so huge and varied. Also had no idea that Monet designed the venue to display them perfectly. Easy access from the walk along the Seine River near the Louvre before reaching Ile de France. Don't skip the "basement" where the Renoirs and Cezannes....etc are casually hanging. A must see for art lovers.

more than Monet. this musee is definitely worth a visit. The monets were great.
But at the basement you find alot of other good works including cezanne, rousseau etc. It is a small musee, you can take your time with the audio guide and not worry about having to walk too much!

More than just Monet!. This famous museum is a must for lovers of the Impressionists and Post Impressionists, as well as where to view some of Monet's enormous Nympheas paintings. Well hung, plenty of space, and centrally located just by the Place de la Concorde.

Monet!. While the collection downstairs has a few nice pieces, the major draw is Monet's Water Lilies. Beautiful and unique! It was hard to get a panoramic picture because the security guards do circles around the room, and the lighting is very soft, but they look great in person! The museum won't take very long to explore, but if you like Monet, this should be a place to visit.

Wonderful Water Lilies. This Museum is an absolute delight. The 8 large Monets are wonderful and are really worth the entrance fee on their own. On top of this, on the lower floors is the interesting Paul Guillaume collection including Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse amongst others.On a nice day, leave time also to walk through the "Jardin des Tuiliers" in which the museum is set

awesome monet's. if for anything else (which would be a lie, because they do have a superbe collection of paintings, going from renoir to picasso), for the most impressive insanely huge monet's paintings. when in the room they're located, you're always under the impression you just poped inside those paintings. breathless. that's for sure.

Stunning gallery. A lot of impressionist art - Money and Renoir particularly - has been over-exposed with so many prints and posters and tea trays displaying the famous images. As a result I wasn't all that positive about going to this gallery. However I was completely blown away by the two rooms of Monet's huge paintings. They are really fantastic. There is also some interesting work on display in the lower level gallery.

A Delightful Museum. If seeing the wonderful works of Monet and Renoir, etc., this is the perfect place. Even without a museum pass, we didn't have to wait too long in the line to enter. Once in, we enjoyed spacious rooms of beautiful artwork. It doesn't take very long to see the entire museum and much simpler than the d'Orsay and Louvre.

Unknown treasure. I have been to Paris 3 times and had never been here. So glad we found it. The main part of the museum is Monet and the waterlillies. The presentation is beautiful, just beautiful. It was not especially busy and by spending some time in each room i was possible to get a good long look at the masterpieces. As well as the Monet rooms there is another floor of excellent art by a wide variety of artists.

Stunning art display. We stopped in the Museum de l'Orangerie on a whim and are very glad we did. The oval rooms are a perfect backdrop to the artwork. The history of the building itself is very interesting, too. The museum isn't very big and can be seen in its entirety in an hour or two.

You will be impressed!. Monet's work beutifully presented. It difficult to describe how amazing these paintings are until you see it for yourself.
Below the 2 oval rooms of Monet's Waterlilly's is a collection of works by most of the well known names. Cezanne, Piccaso, Renoir plus loads more. Well worth a visit.

Great museum. If you like impressionists - it's a must see. Absolutely amazing collection of paintings from the greatest masters. And The Water Lillies by Monet - they are just breathtaking. You could sit and watch those huge, panoramic paintings for hours.
Hidden gem. This is a museum is you have an hour or less. The large artwork pieces are mind blowing. It is usually not crowded, and it is easy to get to. Don't miss this museum when you are in Paris!
Water Lillies in person. Smaller, relaxing museum. Not crowded. Took time to look at the full wall scale of Monet's water lillies. Use Museum Pass.

Wonderful smaller museum. The whole first floor of this museum is 2 large oval rooms with Monet's water lilies. This alone makes the trip worth it though the bottom floor doesn't disappoint either. Like all museums in Paris it pays to get there early. Do so here and you'll have it mostly to yourself. This museum is smaller and can be seen in a few hours.

Wow. The two main rooms with the giant paintings by Monet are worth the visit in and of themselves. Add to that a large number of other expressionist paintings (Renoir is my favourite). Not too big, but chock full of lovely art.
Go!. Amazing Monet's and a perfect rainy day activity. We saw art, walked a little ways afterwards, and had hot chocolate from Angelina's! What could be a better combo?!?
One of the best small museums in the world.. The Monet murals are just stunning...and peaceful. The remainder of the museum's impressionist collections are wonderful, too.

Orsay & l'Orangerie are a nice easy museum experience. At either museum you have an option to purchase a pass for the other one -- I recommend them both. Between them is a beautiful walk down a tree-lined path of the Tuilleries.
beautiful. just as wonderful as ever the only draw back are the numbers of others wanting to see the works ... however its worth it

Just amazing. You need to go to just see the water lilies , however, there is also so much other impressionist art. Not a huge gallery but great quality paintings. Amazing building that is light and bright. Buy tickets on line to avoid queues.

a must-see work of lifetime. The museum of Orangerie is relatively small the the size of collections is quite limited. I spent around 45min in the museum and half time in Monet's Waterlilies. It is an absolutely masterpiece and the venue is in an atmosphere of peace and zen despite the crowd of visitors.

Not my cup of tea!. Amazing gallery if you are into modern art - after walking through we decided that it was not for us - can't get my head around how these pictures can be called "art" after seeing what the Louvre had on offer! Still, the paintings of Monet were beautifully displayed and it is worth a visit if you have time.

Small but Impactful. This museum was designed for Monet's Water Lilies, so it is relatively small. The pieces are pretty and there are nice benches for you to sit and study the art. Students from schools in the EU (or studying abroad in the EU) can get free admission if they have an ID and are under 25.

Worth the admission for the Monet only. The breathtaking circular walls with pieces specifically painted for them by Claude Monet is an almost spiritual experience. Sit here and feel all tension dissolve from your body as you get lost in these stunning pieces
Monet heaven. if you love Monet and his waterlily collections, please visit this museum. The layout, ambience, lighting and display is astounding.

My holiday highlight. I have been to Paris before but the Orangerie was always shut. Not this time and it was everything I hoped it would be. Took my breath away. If you have any interest in Impressionism then go here. Loved it.

Wonderful art collection in a beautiful building.. The Monet paintings were well worth the visit. The rest of the gallery was really good too. The space itself is lovely. Modern meets old architecture.

Very special. The serene Monet water lilies in the oval galleries are the main feature of this gallery. The exhibition Who’s Afraid of Women Photographers? showing wonderful photographs from 1918 to 1945 included some arresting images and was an eye opener to talented female photographers, especially Julia Margaret Cameron. It is worth buying the combined ticket for Musée d’Orsay and Tuileries.

Get your Monet fix here. l'Orangerie is the location of the French national treasures "Nympheas" (Water Lillies). These 8 paintings were Monet's gift to the nation (to prevent his being forgotten) and are displayed in two galleries on the ground floor. A gallery below contains a display of the collection of Impressionist paintings of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume, and excellant summary of many masters of impressionist and later art.Well worth the time, espacially if you like Impressionism.
Only photography exhibits. The whoke museum is now dedicated to phtography and video exhibits. A bit dissappointing, although sone may enjoy it.

Monet need I say more. Spectacular and huge Monet paintings that pictures (even panoramic ones on the iPhone just can't do justice to....a small museum and one of my personal favorites in all of Paris

A huge highlight of my visit to Paris. If you like Claude Monet there could hardly be a better gallery to visit. The works on display are stunning! Even if you are not a huge Monet fan the works are still worth seeing. A true artistic genius. And downstairs there are works by various other artists, some wonderful works by Renoir, a few by Picasso and others which are worth seeing. Also a good little shop and a very pleasant cafe

Good Collection of Impressionist Art. The gallery is located in the Jardin des Tuileries and the nearest metro station is Concorde, although I walked through the park from Tuileries station which took 10 minutes.Whilst the rooms containing the huge canvases by Monet are most eye-catching, I preferred the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection, which housed some excellent work by the likes of Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Utrillo and Matisse, but my favourites were the paintings by Chaim Soutine.The gallery is not huge and an hour or so would be enough to see everything. One down side was the large number of people taking photographs and getting in the way of the paintings.Admission cost is EUR 9 and the gallery is closed on Tuesdays.

In the middle of the pond. This is probably one of the best museum in Paris. It's much smaller than other famous museums and it's not too expensive. This is why I enjoyed it so much: I felt free to sit in front of Monet's paintings for all the time I wanted, without the rush to see other hundreds paintings. The most beautiful thing is that when I observed the paintings I could have the feeling to be there, in the middle of the pond, so close to ninphs and water, meanwhile I was inside the museum! I raccomande it if someone is looking for a corner of true peace.
VERY INTERESTING SMALL ART GALLERY.. Despite being fairly small, the collection here was very interesting. It was great to see the Monet waterlilly collection of paintings.

Always a star attraction. Been before, will go again. Not too big but packed with Impressionists and the superb Waterlilies. If you like Monet, go. And as a bonus there are paintings by other artists of the same era.

Must see. Loved this couldn't wait to get to the museum. Monet was amazing to see. Not really sure about some of the other art in the building my partner thought he could do better. We didn't stay long
Amazing. We went there and spend 2.5 hours. Very nice and very recommended. Great pictures. We recommend to take an audio guide as this helps you to get more insights on the paintings.
Go early or late. If you get lucky and go early you can end up in the rooms of Monet all by yourself and that is truely magical.

Just go!. I had several recommendations to come here, and I am so glad that I did. The Monet murals are just amazing. I had the advantage of a tour guide here. I recommend the additional expense. In addition, I discovered a new favorite artist downstairs. Quite an interesting collection and worth a morning. Tip: Go close to opening time.
Monet at its best!. If your a fan of Monet then this is the place for you! Some of the largest works of Art i ever had the pleasure of seeing. Stunning.

A Must see. As an Impressionist fan we've all seen works of Monet. This museum however stuns at the sheer beauty and size of the works.
Huge floor to ceiling murals of Water Lilies that arc gracefully around the curved rotunda of the main room.
Do make this a priority if possible
Weekend in Paris. So much to see in Paris, we had to choose. We were happy to choose this one. The display of Monets Water Lilies is breathtaking. Totally worth it.

Preferred Walter Guillaume collection to the Monets........ This was a return visit for us after nearly 30 years. The big change is the beautifully realised modernisation of the gallery allowing the pictures to be seen in less crowded circumstances than we remembered. (Once again French ambition in architectural matters seems to be limitless.). We preferred the post impressionist paintings from the Walter/Guillaume collection to the water lilies; in particular the Derains and Modiglianis. If you visit just one gallery in Paris to see this type of art make it the Musee d'Orsay.

Monet's Water Lilies compositions. I walked through the two oval rooms in Musée de l’Orangerie, where Monet’s Water Lilies were set out, on a Wednesday afternoon coming from Place de la Concorde. The 8 magnificent compositions in these unique Monet exposition representing a rural landscape with water lilies water, willow branches, tree and cloud reflections, were considered one of the greatest artistic achievements of early twentieth century painting. The paintings dimensions (6-7 m long and 2 m high) and the 200 sqm area covered by the paint evoke the symbol of infinity. I couldn`t leave the museum before taking a look at the remarkable works by Renoir, Cézanne, Gauguin, Picasso, Matisse, Modigliani and Utrillo, displayed at the second floor.
For Impresionnist lovers. If you love the Impresionnists and want to visit one of the most beautiful museums in Paris, do spend an afternoon here.
STUNNING!. We waited years to see the water lilies again. It was thrilling to see them in their new space. Reservations are highly recommended. Admission lines are long in summer months.
A must for Monet lovers.. The Monet rooms are simply fantastic. I could have spent all day staring and analysing every inch of his paintings. If you are a Monet fan and in Paris it's a must see.

Breath taking Claude Monet. A must to see and take it all in. I would recommend watching the video on the basement level at some time to learn the history of the paintings and artist. English subtitled and very informative.

Monets lilies. Lovely museum .
Wonderfully laid out . Quiet and tranquil to sit and ponder on the works of art displayed

Don't miss the panoramas. Monet's panoramas took my breath away. This is a must see if you're in Paris! Take time to see Monet's brush strokes and colors up close and then sit down on the benches to take in the big picture for a while as well. The Musee de l'Orangerie also has great bathrooms!

Underated and Absoultey Fabulous. This is such an interesting space and an amazing setting! Located just inside the Tuileries Gardens, and as the name implies, this space used to be a shelter for orange trees in the Tuileries.It now houses Eight of Monet's large-scale paintings and they are absolutely breathtaking. My husband is not a lover of Monet, but I am and this experience made him appreciate it very much.

Small but Amazing. This two-storey gallery is quite small, and two hours is enough for any visitor to see all stuff on display.The ground floor is all about Monet's water lilies. The two exhibition rooms houses eight huge paintings of water lilies and have comfortable benches in the middle of the rooms. These two rooms are so pleasant and soothing that many visitors stay here for a long time.The lower level displays Jean Walter's collection of paintings, including paintings by Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Derain, etc., many of which look surprisingly nice.

Beautiful in every way!. It has an amazing collection, and it is something to see Monet's nymphs in person. During the day, the nymphs are lit with skylight, and the architecture of this museum is amazing. It also doesn't feel crowded, and you can just view and take in the artwork at your leisure.

It's all about the water lilies. Unless you are desperate to see the water lilies there isn't really any point in going. I purchased the audio guide which didn't really add much to the experience, but a good way of getting the history of the paintings and the building if you haven't already researched this.
delightful. I had no idea that Monet painted on such a large scale. The architecture and natural light perfectly display these amazing works. High marks.
Absolutely mind blowing art!. Went twice, first time absolutely overwhelmed so had to do it again. You will not find another collection like this.

A hidden gen. The water lilies are at ground level and the amazing collection is downstairs. Spacious gallery with amazing masterpieces. A very reasonable cafe offered chairs and refreshments.A must do in Paris.

MONET!!!. If you like Monet, you'll LOVE L'Orangerie. You are literally surrounded by huge murals of waterlilies and you just lose yourself in the colors. Amazing. Then, go to the Musee Marmottan for even more Monet!

another beautiful place to spend part of your day.... We bought a ticket into the Orsay with the option to also enjoy this museum, great call. This is a smaller place, with fewer folks, but killer art, give it a look see. Happy Viewing, Salida1048

Enormous mesmerizing canvasses. The scale of these large Monet Paintings is breath taking, the specially designed rooms to take the canvasses add to their timelessness. Truly beautiful. The whole visit was wonderful.

Monet Monet Monet. I LOVE the intimacy of l'Orangerie. It is my favorite museum in Paris by far. The curators were able to pack in very impactful impressionist pieces. The museum isn't as crowded as the others, and that gives you the opportunity to really soak it in. Additionally you can cover the museum in about 2-3 hours. A great activity to squeeze in when you have the time.

Excellent little museum. If you are tired of the crowds at the Louvre,this is the place for you.Small but very intimate museum.Monet,Picasso,Cezanne to name a few.Great for families with children.A very nice and quiet little museum worth a visit!

Beautiful . This is a peaceful, reflective museum that has four of the most beautiful pieces of art. Monet's work is presented simply and cleanly and covers 4 walls in 2 rooms with internal seats placed so visitors can sit quietly and enjoy the masterpieces. A must for discerning travellers looking for a gem off the beaten track.
Monet Fan. If you love Monet and you can't get to Giverny, visit here. The whole museum is wonderful, but I went for the water lilies and they were well worth the trip.

For Monet and other art lovers its a must. I am a big fan of Monet so this was a must to see the water lilies while in Paris.My husband is not much of a fan but appreciates the arts. He really liked this gallery.We had been to Giverny to Monets house the day before and seen the real lilies. so it was a nice way to round out the experience.There are some other beautiful pieces in the gallery. And some not so nice ones. But as with all art. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, *Dont take big backpacks as they have to be left at the entrance. But if you do make sure it is locked up.*As with all major Paris attractions watch out for the pick pockets and con artists. We actually saw a group running a scam on a guy while we where outside taking photo. *The Musee de l'Orangerie is in the Paris Museum Pass which I highly recommend for anyone going to 2 or more of any of the museums, attractions and city highlights.*Nice clean toilets here too. So if you have the pass and are walking by you can just use the bathrooms if you want. *recommend grabbing lunch in one of the close by gardens little bistros before or after visiting. its a great way to people watch. While it is a bit touristy the prices are not to bad.

Transport yourself into Monet's masterpiece. The water lily rooms are breathtaking, you can feel the quietness and tranquility by sitting and absorbing the atmosphere. There are other artists here too, Renior, Picasso, but Monet is the star of the show
Simply "WOW". Very nice & open feel. Great for taking in the art from many vantage points. Just the feel of the building alone was very comfortable.

Great for a relaxed Sunday afternoon.. The entrance fee is 9euros and you don't really have that much Monet in there. If you love impressionism then Musee d'Orsay would be better value for money. Not a lot of work to be seen, whole tour can be done in 2 hours max.

Must see after Musee dlOrsay. The museum does not take as long but many important works are in this.... Renoir, Monet MAnnet and many others.!focus on the Monet lillies that made my ice better!
Speaker headsets help! Book ticket with Musee D'lorsay, a better deal.
Money's water lilies. Loved this museum, going in January meant I could linger over the stunning water lilies. Downstairs some artists I had never heard of. Altogether a lovely museum.

Small and doable with kids. Small gallery when compared to the Louvre and Musee D'Orsay, so kids will be able to look around without getting bored. Very good collection of masterpieces and interesting temporary photography exhibition. Make sure you get the combined ticket with the Musee D'Orsay and see both on different days.

A must see just for the water lilies. This place is a must visit just to see the water lilies in person. They are simply breath taking. This museum also features other famous work and is a nice hour to hour and a half long visit.

Show your passport at the ticket counter!. At least if you're in your twenies and from EU/EEA - you might get in FREE. They were showing two different prices on the wall, and I was asking if the reduced price was for under 26 EEA citizens (as there often is such a reduced price offerred at museums and sights). The woman at the counter didn't speak much English, so she just asked for my passport and after a quick chat with her collagues she told the museum is free for me. And for the museum: I went at a bad date, as I visited in between two different temporary exhibitions, so there wasn't one. Monet's huge water lily paintings are shown in a circular rooms, and while sitting down you are just surrounded by them. Cool. Downstairs was more diverse: loads of impressionist masters from Cezanne to Matisse and to earlier Picasso, and my forever favourite, Renoir. Included also many painters that I wasn't familiar with, but liked very much. The most interesting painter must have meen André Derain, whose technique is brilliant and his style(s) comes from a large scale. They even showcased next to each other two paintings with one subject that was painted in one in more classical way and second time in purely impressionist style. Information of the painters was provided in English and Spanish too, and different audio guides could be rented for 5e. I wished for more information of the museums history, as Paul Guillaume himself is just as interesting as the artists he was exhibitioning.

breathtaking. You've learned about Monet your whole life, and you've probably had him hanging in your room at some point, but you haven't experience Monet until you come to l'Orangerie The vast immensity of his pieces are truely masterpieces. There are two separate rooms where his work fills the entire room. I love that they reconstructed the museum so the pieces can be viewed the way Monet wanted them, in the natural light. there are large benches in the rooms so you can sit and really find some peace.
A dream!!!. A lifetime experience! don't miss it!Visit early, there will be less crowd... don't miss the explaining at the entrance...

Very interesting museum. A lovely small museum which highlights some interesting and unusual paintings. In a really useful location, as you can easily pop in when walking from one place to another or at the end of the day, Quite good for and hour or two.

A little treasure in a great city. I've been to Paris many times and have always focused my attention on the larger, well known museums. This past trip I finally went to Musee de l'Orangerie and fell in love. I loved the Musee d'Orsay, but this one was every bit as good! Although smaller in size and exhibits, there is plenty to feast your eyes on, especially is you are an Impressionist lover or lover of the late 19th century works of art. Monet's Nymphanies (Water Lilies) was every bit of pleasure that was advertised. I was there in a brilliant day in January, and the diffused light in the two oval rooms was perfect to sit and reflect on Monet's beautiful works of art. I spent 3 hours at the museum and could have spent more!

Overlooked and amazing. A jewel of a museum not to be missed. Particularly because the space truely highlights the art within. Not a big exhibit... in fact just right for some, this is an oft overlooked but gem of a museum
very nice museum. The monet "searoses" is an absolute must when being in paris and also the temorary exhibitions are very nice

Magnificent Monet. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a must-see for those who enjoy Impressionist paintings, particularly those of Claude Monet.Get to the museum as soon as it opens so that you can serenely enjoy (before crowds arrive) the two salons that are the permanent home for eight "Water Lilies" murals by Claude Monet. Since the two galleries are oval-shaped, you sit in the center as if you were in the middle of the pond of water lillies. It's such an amazing and absorbing art experience that before we realized it, we had been there - in just two galleries - for nearly two hours.

(Semi) Alone Time with Monet. We loved the Orangerie! Beginning with the exterior, and the surrounding Jardins des Tuileries, just getting to the museum is a wondrous journey. Additionally, there are far fewer visitors here than at the Louvre and Orsay. This is certainly not a substitute for either of those important museums, but it's a lovely supplement on your exploration of Paris.Crucial detail: You will have the opportunity to comfortably sit and view Monet's Giverny paintings relatively free from crowds (unless the Orangerie is overrun by a tourist group horde during your visit).

Small, moving museum. Among art museums in Paris, Second only to Orsay. Stereotypically long lines but special pass allows you to skip. Small museum relative to Paris' other treasures but worth it to see Monet's Water Lilies as intended.

the best of monet but more to see too. There are good seating space for watching monet's lotus gardens so you can take your time and relax. Loved how they made this museum and prepared, the natural sun light over paintings..respect. And not just monet, but matis, marie laurencin(can't find his work so much in Paris!?), renoir...so much more. The museum size is not as big as Orsay or Lourve so you can spend less time too.

Orangerie- for more than just Monet's waterlillies. The Orangerie is small but has a terrific collection of 19th century European works and is the home to 8 of Monet's Giverny paintings.Very calming and relaxingis included in the Paris Museum pass and definitely worth a visit

Lovely Museum. It was a bit overcast when we visited, so this made for a nice detour inside. This is a pretty fast museum to go through and what everyone comes to see is Claude Monet's Water Lillies. Their breath taking to see in person and realize how large the painting are. We enjoyed the museum and glad we stopped in.
A must!!!. Wow this place is fantastic I could spend a whole week herelovely relaxed art gallery with fantastic art

Monet's work is FABULOUS!!. We bought tickets for the Musee de l'Orangerie with our tickets to Musee d'Orsay. We tried to go Christmas Eve and they were closing early, so we didn't make it. Of course they were closed on Christmas Day and we were leaving Paris on Dec. 26. So, we went as soon as they opened the morning of Dec. 26. It was great because there were no crowds. The water lilies are fantastic. I love that Monet had design plans for this museum just to display his Water Lilies in the perfect way and they are perfection. I just could not get over how beautiful they are. There is other art downstairs in the museum. We walked through and enjoyed it, but nothing compares to the water lilies! Must See!
Monet"s Water Lilies are a must!. Loved the Monets here! The water lilies are incredible. But there is much more here too. This is a manageable museum--not overwhelming like the Louvre.
The Impressionists!. Come and sit in the two round rooms with Monet's waterlilies and relax! It is a lovely small and accessible museum, not too crowded in January.

Come for Monet's Water Lilies. Why you need to go: The walk there is gorgeous, and Monet's large-scale and fabulous painting of the water lilies (the one that even everyone who doesn't know art will find familiar). Enough said.

A must see!. My favorite experience during our week in Paris! The Water Lilies are spectacular and I found the experience very moving. I would love to visit when there aren't any crowds... Beautiful little museum.

Best place to see Claude Monet's work. The essential works with the water lilies is best seen here at Musee de l'Orangerie. The quietness and the curved rooms presents the work so nearly are stepping into the paintings.
One of my favorite spots in Paris .. Claude Monet is definitely one of my favorites . It Is breathtaking to see these huge pieces , just lovely.

Monday Tours in English!!. My wife and I have been to this museum three times prior to this afternoon's visit. Today we signed up for a guided tour of the museum's treasures with an English speaking guide. Annette made the visit so much more meaningful. She knows art history and threw in just enough personal anecdotes of the artists to hold everyone's attention. At 6E a person it was the best bargain we've run into in Paris!! Go and ask for Annette.

Small............. but quality. Located on the banks of the Seine and just inside the Tuileries Gardens. As might be inferred from the name, this building gave winter shelter to the Tuileries orange trees back in 1852. It now houses works from Monet, Cezanne, Picasso, Modigliani, Renoir, Derain, Soutine and Utrillo, to name a few. Definitely a must see

Exquisite gem of a museum. I have always loved Monet's water lilies, but I did not know until recently that they were painted in these huge, curving murals. What a delight! The museum is designed to showcase his water lilies, and it is a perfect blend of form and function.

Monet's Waterlilies. This is a smaller museum but definitely worth the visit. The big ticket here are Monet's huge Water lily paintings. You can see Monet's Water Lily paintings at galleries all over the world as he painted about 250 paintings in the series. But here there are two large oval galleries that have 4 huge panels in each room.
Lovely . This museum had beautiful paintings and statutes. I strolled around and saw many lovely pieces. Much smaller than the Louvre, but it's worth a visit. I visited in winter and spring.

Hidden gem for a small museum. Easy to miss this museum with the L'Ouvre and the Musee D'Orsay nearby. The two oval rooms with panels by Monet are a must se for any impressionist fan. Worth a visit just for those two rooms alone.

Go downstairs. The Monet was really neat...and enjoyed it. But the real treasure of this exhibit is downstairs. Really beautiful art and paintings you will likely recognize. Get the audio tour...worth it. You will learn much more through the audio which accompanies many of the paintings. Simply fabulous. Careful closed Monday's

Monet. 'Nuff said.. Monet's waterlilies artwork was designed specifically for this space, and to see it surrounding you is amazing and a unique experience. For lovers of Monet or impressionist artwork in general, this is a must-see.
The ticket queues can be bypassed with a Paris Museum Pass, which is recommended.
Combine this with a visit to Monet's garden for the full experience.

lovely gallery but too modern for me now. i love looking at the monet pieces, the pissaros the serats and the many other works of the early 20th century, and i love it being part of the tuileries, but to be honest i preferred the old building not the new concrete rennovation.

Monet's masterpiece. This small museum is the location of huge Monet murals. It is astonishingly beautiful and peaceful. No huge crowds of people were there when we went and we spent hours in this museum.

Monet The Artist. If you are an art lover this is the place. Amazing work by Monet. The Waterlilies curve along the wall, the different season's send you day dreaming. The museum was built just for these works too. I enjoyed a 3 hour visit just admiring the amazing impressionist work. Sat outside after and had a coffee and people watched in the park.

Stand in Awe!. I can not put into words what it is like to stand in the 2 rooms filled with the beautiful works of Monet. The colors, the peace, the movement . . it is overwhelming. Take an hour and see at least the two rooms. You will never forget the feeling of the image.

Profound beauty on the top floor.. The two rooms with the water lilies are like a meditation center. I felt immersed in Monet's garden. It is a place of calm and intense beauty. I am in awe of Monet at the end of his life.

My favorite museum. Of our entire trip through Normandy and Paris, this was my favorite museum by far. Monet's Water Lilies are indescribably beautiful and calming - I could look at them for hours. It is entirely wheelchair accessible.One of the guards said that the museum only started allowing photography in the last year. Museum, I beg you to change this policy - do not allow disruptive photographers. Visitors, please actually look at these paintings for more than two minutes. If you want a picture, get a postcard. Don't go just to say you did - go and let your soul be absorbed into eternity.

Very good collection of art. This museum is known for its collection of Monet water lily paintings and a very large scale. So I was quite excited to see it. I must say it is definitely unusual but the scale of the art for me left a lot to be desired. I was expecting spectacular and was disappointed. I honestly think the art collection in the basement which was donated to the museum was wonderful and included a lot of the famous impressionists. I would certainly recommend it to others. I guess I was just expecting too much.

Amazing Monet. The 2 oval shaped room housing the Monets on the curved walls are worth more than the entrance fee. They're almost worth the airfare to Paris. Quite breathtaking.But there's a whole bunch of other french impressionists / post impressionist works on the lower level, including many Picassos.It doesn't take up a day like the Louvre, or an afternoon like the D'Orsay, but is well worth a visit

My favorite Renoir and Monet are here. This museum has unique art - my favorites are the Monet and Renoir paintings. Also, this museum is the "sister" to Musee d'Orsay, so you can come over here first, buy a dual-museum ticket, spend a couple of hours, and then go to the Musee d'Orsay and skip the long lines there. This museum also had a photography exhibition I found very interesting, worth the visit.

A spiritual experience for fans of Monet. I've visited the l'Orangerie several times, but I never tire of standing in the midst of the incredible water lilies and willows painted by Monet in rooms that he designed to show them off the best. They are huge and take my breath away. When I finally pull myself away, there are some wonderful works of art to see downstairs as well. The have some nice impressionistic pieces and some slightly more modern as well. It is a small museum compared to the Louvre or Orsay, which makes it a nice respite from the crowds.
Out of words. This museum, even beeing small, was by far my favorite in paris. It has a great collection of arts and of course the amazing rooms with arts of monet.
Magnificent. The Monet rooms are breathtaking and surprisely calm. Easy to access and close to many other museums, other exhibitions are also amazing.

A great collection of art. This is a comparatively less crowded museum and you would not have to wait for hours. Monet's water lilies are a must see. It truly is a masterpiece and going there just to see it will be totally worth it. There are a few other collections also which are also very good.

A Great Experience in the Monet Lily Rooms. Get there early at opening time if possible and go straight to the Monet rooms with famous lily paintings. It is a very moving experience with a wonderful sense of serenity and peace. Later it gets busy and loses its tranquility.

Small, interesting, a bit "abandoned". I have visited a fair share of museums and this is definitely not an impressive one. The Monet paintings are really beautiful and worth to look but (at the time of my visit) there were many paintings from other artists missing from the walls and some other details that gave me the impression that the museum is a bit "abandoned". I have to say that I liked the exhibition, because it allows you to know a bit of each artist, their style and their history and I did learn a lot, but it is a very small museum for a 7-euro entrance, so I strongly recommend to buy the paired ticket Musée d'Orsay + l'Orangerie (which is 14 euros) and you will save some money (Orsay Museum costs 12 euros). If you want to visit the museums in 2 different days (like I did), you can! Be sure to keep your ticket, because is one ticket for both museums AND you have up to 3 months to use it!! After my visit, I would recommend you that you go to this museum first (remember to ask for the ORSAY+L'Orangerie), since it opens at 9am and 2 hours are more than enough for this, and then spend the rest of the day in the Orsay Museum! I visited in winter, but if you visit in summer you could make a pause in the beautiful gardens that surround the museum (Jardin des Tuileries) before walking to the Orsay Museum (just across de river)

A Great Place to Discover. Today, our last in Paris we visited this little gem. Just to sit and take in Monet's Water Lillies in such grandeur was superb. To view the works up so close along with the amazing work of many other artists was sensational. It is fabulous to observe each of the paint strokes - gives a intimate understanding of the artists thoughts and talent.

Best little museum in Paris. The art here is simply amazing and the whole collection can be viewed in about 90 minutes. Forget the crowds at the Louvre. This is where the life-changing art in Paris exists. Love the Laurencin and Modigliani. The Monet's are incredible too.

Pretty much just one painting. There is essentially only 1 piece of art in this museum, Monet's Water Lilies - which was nice. I'd only go if you had a museum pass as it is not worth the single admission.

Reflective Moments of Beauty. This is a small museum that tops my list of MUSTS for a visit to Paris. Monet s water lilies are presented in two round rooms with bench seating through the middle. This quiet spot is perfect to take some time to reflect and muse on the beauty of the art. On both visits here, there have not been an overwhelming crush of visitors, which makes this attraction a sweet spot away from some of the Paris rush. The longer you view Monet s water lilies, the longer you want to stay. Breathtaking!

Small museum, huge impact. We specifically went here for Monet's large panels. What a unique way to experience his art! Bought tix online, but still had to wait in long line to go in. Well worth that wait! Being so close to this magnificent art is very special.

Great art poor directions. It was hard to find it, should have more directions and not a lot of people know about it.Once inside the directions was an issue for me. I was there to see Monet and they made it to be the last thing you see. I kept searching, craving Monet and not paying too much attention to other painting.

Great alternative to the Musee d'Orsay. We went here because we're not SUPER art enthusiasts, but wanted to see some of the incredible impressionist art offered in Paris. So, we skipped the Orsay line and came here, and I'm glad we did. The museum is quite small, and you really could see everything in a few hours. There are some incredible pieces and artists in the museum. I got the audio guide and it was well worth the 5€. I definitely recommend going here if you can. It was about a 2 minute wait, only 6.50€ for under 25's, and it may have even been free with an EU passport.
Reflective moment. Its always wonderful to see Monet's lily gardens displayed on the Musee de l"Orangerie. I love to just sit on the couches and reflect on the quiet beauty.

Magical. It is a spiritual experience to see Monet's Water Lilies in the way he intended. Rodin's "The Kiss" is right outside the front door as well. There are also many excellent pieces in the lower gallery including some unexpected Picassos. Don't miss this!!!

Don't miss it!. A simply gorgeous museum across the Jardin des Tuileries from the Louvre. Seeing Monet's Water Lilies the way he wanted them to be seen is such a privilege. The sheer size of the canvases is staggering and highlights his achievement.

Great collection . Strictly an art museum with a great collection. Most people who are attracted are coming for the collection of Monet paintings (amazing in scale) but their collection of other artists, most notably nice pieces by Picasso make it worth a couple of hours Tips -at time of visit entry was €7.5-make it a part of a day seeing other wonderful sights in direct vicinity including the concord, the Madalena, champ Elysees etc.

Perfect way to kick off 2016!. Visited first thing on January 1st. The Monet murals are absolutely breathtaking and are worth the price of admission alone. The rest of the collection is outstanding and the special exhibit on women photographers was very well done. A great space and a great visit.
Lovely museum. Worth a visit! Besides the striking Money Water Lilies display, the museum has great works downstairs. We spent hours, without feeling overwhelmed.

A Must on your Museum List if you love Monet!. Each time I come to Paris (yearly), I go here as I love to look at the eight panels of Water Lillies by Claude Monet. These will never leave France due to the agreement when the government was given the panels by Monet. The other sections of the museum are outstanding too - but take the time to see these panels, absolutely beautiful!
Fabulous building and collection. WE all really enjoyed this. The art and the setting were great and the crowds were less than the Louvre. Would be my first choice next time.

A beautiful small museum. I went for the Water Lillies and stayed for the rest of the exhibit. It is a very nice museum. The art was beautiful and very calming in a busy world. Go and enjoy the beauty.
Monet. This museum is worth a visit. 2 rooms of large panels of Monet's water lilies. It is hard to describe but very beautiful.
Great Museum. Wonderful collection - seeing the Monet's in grand scale is just sublime - a great location too and very convenient for walking around Paris seeing sights - a must see

Fantastic!. This museum offers you an experience. The Louvre was more of a mad 4 hour scramble to find your way, push through the crowds and crane your neck to see some spectacular paintings and AMAZING art. The Musee de l'Orangerie is different. It is more peaceful, structured and intentional in the order you views the works of art. Monet designed it to be as such, sequencing each of the tooms as preparation for the next one. Would highly recommend this. Some stunning Art downstairs after the Monet floor!

A great small museum. Don;t miss the Musee de l'Orangerie if for no other reason than to see the two oval rooms devoted to Monet's waterlilies. You can get a combination ticket with the D'Orsey Museum for just lightly more.

Massive queue. Massive queues did put a damper on our visit - we stood for an hour. I have no idea how this would work out on a rainy day or a day in the middle of the summer. I certainly wouldn't have queued. The Monets are very nice to see especially as they were obviously painted in situ. The other exhibitions were about women's photography which I was very interested in and enjoyed very much. The only other negative was the other queue which was for the ladies loos!

Jewel of a museum. The collection of 145 paintings is a remarkable experience of viewing through the lens of one dealer and his exquisite taste in creating a unique collection at the evolution of modern art - Picasso, Modigliani, Matisse and many others are represented. The highlight is the nymphiad rooms of Monets water lilies. Should not be missed

My favorite museum in Paris. This museum is smaller with the focus being on two beautiful rooms with Monet's water lilies on all four walls, so you are surrounded. The lighting was perfect with a sheer white sheet covering the window ceilings. There are long benches in the center so take your time, relax, and enjoy every side of the painting. Make sure to note how each painting has its own name and color scheme. The downstairs exhibit was larger and also very nice. Overall, this museum was so wonderful and refreshing after being overwhelmed by the Lourve and D'Orsay. If you want a calm experience and to actually enjoy the art, come here.

Waterlillies. The waterlillies are breathtaking in person. This is a rather small museum, but is definitely worth a see. It's also included in the museum pass which is nice. We were able to see both this museum as well as the Musee d'Orsay in the same day.

must visit museum!!. i have been to paris multiple times and had always wanted to make it to this museum, but never had... i finally got to go and wow it was so worth it. i would say this is my favorite museum in paris. definitely make this a priority when in paris. such an amazing collection and large monets alone are incredible!

waterlillies!. To see these amazing huge paintings in person...a must for all fans of Impressionism. Small museum, so will not overwhelm like most of the museums in Europe. Gives you the time and space to experience the water lilies at your own pace.

Wonderful!. Visited on 3rd of January.This was my third visit to the museum. It is my favourite museum in Paris. On the ground floor, there are only two rooms and they contain nothing but different versions of Monet's Nyphéas, ideal for dreaming away.In the basement, there is an impressive collection of some great painters: Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, .. and Chaïm Soutine, a lesser known but very good abstract painter who lived in the beginning of last century, whose work I discovered through visiting this nice little gem of a museum.Do not hesitate to visit if you have got an hour or two to spend!

Most beautiful museum in Paris. This Museum is for any MONET lover. Other wonderful masters also portrayed. Easy access. You can go right up to the pieces and have the opportunity to take wonderful photographs (without Flash)
Long queue, good art. I visited in the winter off season and the queue was still horrible. It took us 45 minutes to get to the front. Worth booking a ticket in advance. The art was excellent though

Relatively small, exquisitely curated. If you love Monet, you MUST visit here. I was bummed at how loud the visitors were. It seemed obvious that the Monet rooms should be places of contemplation.I fell in love with some of the works downstairs. Soutine! I don't know why I am so smitten with a painting of a dead chicken - but I LOVE this work.Short line on a Thursday, NO line for Museum Pass holders (technically there was a line,but no one was in it).

Great for the water lilies!. A very small museum by Paris standards - so buy your ticket in advance or plan to wait a l-o-n-g time in line. Note that there are two entrance lines if you've bought your tickets in advance. The water lilies are beautiful, and the art on the lower floor is eclectic. Not my favorite - but worth the trip.

Worst museum in Paris with rude staff and disappointment queue control system . It was a rainy Sunday and we waited for about 1 hour before getting in the entrance. There is no staff or security whatsoever when queuing the help the waiting people. Once we got in the entrance we saw only one security check window and one staff at there checking people's bag and asking them to show cell phones. There were about 5 or 6 securities or staff there but non were doing their job (i.e. Helping people to get in ). When I went through the security check the staff let me in but one female security suddenly approached and said my backpack was too large and wouldn't let me in. I was very surprised as I carried the same backpack to other museum such as the Musee D'Orsay, Louvre, Picasso, etc. By all means I believe my backpack was not a super size, it was merely a 30L backpack which I carried everyday to everywhere during my week-long stay at Paris. I asked the security if there was another way such as storing my backpack. To my surprise they said no and they said I must leave as my backpack was too large. I had a confused look at that time as I hope there's another way as I waited in the rain for 1 hour in order to get in and I did not want to leave just because of such subjective look at my backpack and simply claimed it was too large. But in 2 seconds there were 3 securities forcing me out of the museum.This was outrageous. I saw that right opposite to the security check there was a cloak room for storage. Even if you really couldn't store my backpack, I believed the staff there should at least explain clearly their policy of hand carry ( such as size of backpack) before taking any action. I was totally disguised by what they did and their way of crowd control. I completely lost my faith and good image of the Paris tourism due to this event.For all tourists who do not want to be treated secondarily, AVOID this museum.

Monet's lillies in Paris. The Musee de l'Orangerie was an absolutely sensational museum,central location and easy to find,not too crowded in October what a fantastic way to spend a 60th birthday.We were surprised and delighted to avoid any queues or crowds and enjoyed the wonderful range of impressionist paintings on display.

Lovely collection. My husband and I visited Musee de l'Orangerie on a busy Sunday afternoon. The queue out the door was related to security (entirely understandable) and not tickets so once inside it wasn't long until we were looking at Monet's Water Lillies.I adored the Monet. We really enjoyed the layout of the collection on the lower level. It was easy to meander through, and to go back and spend more time looking at the paintings we liked best. Washrooms were clean enough. I would certainly go back and recommend a visit.
beautiful. Monet's works, so spiritual and phenomenal. Important very important for my studies. Just wonderful and enriching.

Another terrific Impressionist collectoin. In addition to Monet's Water Lillies, this museum offers up great works from many of Monet's contemporaries. It is rather small compared to some of the other museums but it's nice not to be overwhelmed with quantity. The quality is unmatched.

Stunning.. If you only have tin for one museum in Paris, go here and just soak in the beauty and majesty that is the water lilies. For more impact, take a bike tour to Monet's gardens on one day and visit the paintings the next.

One of the best museums in Paris . You will see Monet's nymphaeas here in a beautiful round / oval showroom. It is impressive. There is filtered light with which you will be see the paintings. On the other floor they have cezanne, Picasso, monet and other impressionist artists. It is a small very manageable museum. It is packed with powerful painters. Their permanent collection is worth a visit and their changing expositions are always very well set up and very interesting. Even the bathrooms are very well maintained. Did I mention the beautiful view, the wonderful stroll to take either before or after in the surrounding garden. This is a really great way to pass a couple of hours on Paris. A must.
Breathtaking. Definitely an underrated museum. Monet's Water Lilies were something to stand in awe at, and then you get to see an amazing collection of Impressionist and Post Impressionist art.
Amazing!!. I went to Musee L'Orangerie for the purpose of seeing Monet's works but was pleasantly surprised to see works by Renoir, Gaugin, and Laurencin.
L'Orangerie. Although I love french impressionism, this was too monotonously the same flowers on ponds. I would not stand in line to see it.

Photo exhibit . Wonderful museum and always has unique exhibits
I came here two years ago and would recommend to anyone who enjoys smaller museums

The Most Underrated Museum in Paris. It is obligatory when one visits Paris to see the Louvre, Rodin, D'Orsay, the Eiffel Tower, and other sights. However, Musee de l'Orangerie is a must-see. The massive Nympheas by Monet is spectacular! Small and not overwhelming, this charming museum has a variety of impressionist artists which will delight. Make this is definite stop.

The Monet was to die for!!. Wow, what an experience.
The panoramic Monet's are spread across two oval rooms. We sat for hours looking at each one in detail.
Take the time to ponder over the artists emotions in each section. They are truly incredible!

Gorgeous!. The Monet experience was magical. It is simply impossible to understand this from a postcard or a calendar. :) In addition, there was an extensive Renoir exhibit and a variety of other works that made the visit very worthwhile. Must see.

Monet's Water Lilies rooms are incredible . Went here after a few hours of the Louvre and it was a welcome change of pace. A small museum with collections from many famous artists, the best by far being the circular rooms with Monet's Water Lilies

Definitely check this out. I wasn't going to visit this museum on our trip because I was feeling a little museum-ed out, but a friend wanted to wander in and I tagged along. I ended up enjoying this one more than some of the others. It's a small museum, so doesn't take much time to get through, but you could spend a ton of time staring at the circular Monets on the ground floor. They were absolutely beautiful and worth the trip to the museum.And it's part of the Museum Pass, which I would definitely recommend as it's a huge time saver.

Fantastic. Not to be missed- lines can be long so go before opens or on an evening that opens late- although everyone heads right to the Monet waterlilies, the other impressionist art is also special. The Nymphea however are a not to he missed attraction-

Great little Museum at the Tuileries. This certainly will not be the largest museum you will visit in Paris, but you will be pleasantly surprised by the variety of artists and the quality of the art. The museum is located at the opposite end of the Tuileries gardens from the Louvre art museum. If you have purchased a Paris museum pass, you can use it here.
A favorite and even better. You must visit. Small fantastic and expanded to include other top modern artists. Romantic stroll from the Louvre overlooking the Tower Eiffel.
Monet Fan Must See. This was a charming museum. Some great works, but not quite as many as the other museums, but the Monet lilies are worth it to see!
Two words - water lilies. These are not new paintings. You've seen them reproduced everywhere. However to see them in the space that Claude Monet had designed for them is a must.

20th Century's Greatest Artists. After reading the book "Shocking Paris," I found this to be a more relevant visit. The artworks featured here hail from the 20th century whose artists were part of Paul Guillaume's dealings (thus the wing named as such). You can see works by Amadeo Modigliani (who by the way just had a work sold at auction for nearly 170 million), Chaim Soutine, Henri Matisse, Auguste Renoir, Pablo Picasso and Paul Cezanne. On the main floor there is an exhibit containing Monet's water lilies. The cost to enter is about 9EU and you can pay extra to get the audio guide. I opted to go without it and still enjoyed the visit.

Honestly? Eh. . There are multiple letters of the title of the museum that are missing on the front door. And that's kind of what it felt like... A little run down. The large format Monet's are lovely...but...Eh. If you have time... And a museum pass. Sure. Go. You can walk through this bad boy in less than an hour. First time in Paris? Skip it.
Must see collection. . Designed by Monet himself to feature these amazing works. The private collection below is equally astonishing, containing Cezanne, Renoir and others.
the light is.... with the sun light interacting on the walls, you can experience different perceptions on paitings. also, monet fans will be very touched by visiting

Smaller modern nice museum. Worth a visit, not a massive all day event, shorter lines. After you've walked until blistered and visited some of the massive temples of art Paris has to offer. This museum offers an excellent experinice without wearing you out or taking all day. The water lilies paintings are 2 huge oval room multiple paintings are the stars and worth the visit alone. Other smaller collections.

we were expecting a bit more. We were expecting a bit more. It certainly is nice to go to and see the wonderful large paintings. If you have the Musee pass and the time certainly its worth the stop. However, I would not make a special trip otherwise. Just my view because there are so many other wonderful attractions in Paris.
Beautiful, peaceful. If you are fan of Monet this is the place to visit. After visiting with the water lilies travel downstairs to see more wonderful art. I love this gift shop.

Emm ... Perhaps not the best Paris museum option. Can't argue with other people's aesthetics - but the Monet is quite magnificent. There is little enough else I would rate. Admission protocols are a bit problematic; approach to museum passes seems erratic. Certainly expensive (a typical French issue ...). One thing I find particularly irritating ... as I recall, non-flash photography is permitted. However, the amount of "selfie/famous art work" stuff going on was a pain. One clown asked (demanded) that my wife move aside so he could be photographed with the "famous" artwork as a background. He was most insistent. Probably, when he gets back home, he will never look at the image again. Cameraphones seem like a very good idea for banning photography in museums - flash or not. BTW - staff were a bit unfriendly as well. Wouldn't say you shouldn't visit but, if it is a choice between this and the Museé d'Orsay, head for the latter. Best regards, OMB (JR)

Water lilies never looked so wonderful!. If you are a fan of Monet and in particular his water lilies, then a stop at the Musee de l'Orangerie at Tuileries in Paris is a must see!! Two wonderful ellipitical rooms with massive paintings of the water lilies at different times of day - just sit, relax and enjoy being taken back to Monet's garden in Giverny - so peaceful and beautiful!

Easy to "digest" for all. I would recommend this museum to even those who are generally not great fans of museums. The two oval rooms with the water lilies will appeal to all ages and all kinds of people and the rest of the museum has some beautiful impressionist paintings. I think you can comfortably see the whole museum in 1.5-2 hours, including some "hanging out" on the seats in the water lilly rooms. Admission is free for EU citizens under the age of 25.
Monet's water lilies. We decided to have a look here after visiting the Louvre. The two oval galleries with series of Monet's water lilies are amazing. The other art work is well worth seeing too.
Beautiful museum. Beautiful water lillies a must see for those who love monet. Building is also amazing to see. Get the double entry to musee d'orsay two museums for 14euro.

Best for short trips. I had a one day visit to Paris and this was a great choice! Monet's waterlilies are breathtaking. And the whole exhibition is so good as it shows different styles. The best to visit if you don't want to spend the whole day in a museum. Totally worth the visit.
Worth visiting . I visited this museum with my family and we enjoyed the visit. The impressionist and post-impressionist paintings are incredible and placed in a space that is very adequate.

Les Nymphéas - Water Lilies! Water Lilies!. Having seen some of Monet's Water Lilies panels when they traveled to the Chicago Art Institute in 1995, we wanted to see the complete installation in Musee de l'Orangerie. The remodel of the Orangerie is entirely successful. The installation is awe inspiring. The downstairs gallery containing Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection is also well worth the time. We spent the entire day at the museum. The café is a pleasant break.If you are intending to visit Musee d'Orsay, purchase the combined pass. The line at the Orangerie is much quicker and the pass is good for one visit to each.

Monet's Waterlilies a Delight. When we visited I was impressed by the scale and presentation of the water lily panels. I did not realize the scope of the rest of the museums collection. If I had I would have scheduled more time. Give yourself at least a couple hours to see everything.

Great for an afternoon. Brilliant impressionism on display. When you think of Impressionism, you think of France. This museum and the d'Orsay offer the best collections in the world. Don't miss either. Should take the average traveler about 2 hours to go through. Don't miss the large water lilies panels. An audio tour is a must.

Peace and tranquility. Monet's panoramic water lily paintings are displayed here to great effect. I sat down in each room and enjoyed a little peace and calm in the midst of my day. I come here every time I visit Paris, it is my favorite museum.

My favorite fine art museum. Can be done before or after lunch.. The small size and unique archticture makes this the ideal place to view fine art for a laypoerson such as myself. It is just a half-day space including the short film of how the building as transformed into its current status. Low key atmosphere for some really exquisite high end art. Take it slow, it leaves you wanting just a little bit more...

Brought me to tears. Seriously. I'm not an overly emotional person, but walking into the center, oval shaped room and finding myself surrounded by Monet's Water Lilies brought me to tears. This museum alone made my first trip to Paris worthwhile.
Favorite art museum. This museum has become a favorite as it's small and managable while still offering tons of beautiful and iconic pieces.
Don't miss it!. You can't see Monets Water lilys on a better place than here - and you have to see them! Better you skip the Louvre if you're not staying long enough to see both.

Lots of people I know like this more than the louvre. This museum is very human scale, and has a collection on par with the louvre and most large museums I've visited in the US. Just sitting in the Monet room for a few minutes is almost a religious experience

Has anyone had the Oval Rooms to himself?. I was surprised to be visitor no. 2 on a Friday morning, and to enter the two oval rooms housing Monet's "Water lilies" to find myself alone. It is a very impressive set of paintings - maybe if you also go early, you will be lucky as well. Try. Downstairs there is the collection owned by the art dealier Paul Guilleaume and his wife, Jean Walter (there are a few portraits of his, including a fine Modigliani, but I found only one of hers). It is a manageable-sized crash course in early 20th century French painting (well, if you include Spanish Picasso, Belorussian-Jewish Chaim Soutain, Italian Modigliani, etc.). Great arrangements, fine buliding, and again, I was lucky to be in the company of only a trickle of visitors. Well, sometimes you can be lucky even in Paris...Definitely worth a visit.

Oasis of Impressionist Art and Calm. The museum Orangerie is famous for impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. One can find not merely the famous Nymphéas (Water Lilies) by C. Monet, but also the paintings of H. Matisse, A. Modigliani, P. Picasso, C. Soutine and others. The room with the Nymphéas is a perfect place for meditation, contemplation and gives one a moment to calm down in the middle of Paris. I will definitely come back to this museum and spend more hours there.

Beautiful Water lilies . This houses Monet's stunningly beautiful water lilies painted towards the end of his life, the oval setting is peaceful and beautiful. A short walk from Musee d'Orsay worth combining the visits.

Beautiful building. I'm so glad I was told not to miss this museum. The upstairs exhibits with oval shaped walls and large scale paintings that fit the rooms perfectly plus the lighting is just stunning. Buy ticket in advance as that line moved much more quickly. On the smaller side but one of our favorite museums.

Wonderful presentation of Impressionist Art. The L'Orangerie like much of Paris is under very heavy security, so be prepared to take some time getting in, the airport type scanner is very sensitive. The museum itself is house on two floors. The Monet exhibit is on the top floor, will all the other artists are on the lower level. Really a very well presented collection. Plus a temp display of turn of the century photos all taken by women. Very nice.

Must See Museum. Forget the Louvre. Buy tix in advance and wander over to the far end of the Tuileries to marvel at the extensive collection of Impressionists at the L'Orangerie.
