The museum is comfortable and spacious and the crowds are manageable. The Monet water lilies on the second floor are breathtakingly beautiful and dominate two entire rooms. The cafe is small and not really suitable for anything other than a quick stop for coffee, tea or soft drink.

Impressionist art after the walking tour. We went to Musee de l'Orangerie after we did a walking tour of Montmatre. It made a world of difference in understanding the period, artists and their relationship. The first Sunday of the month museums are FREE so plan your trip and arrival time accordingly.
Great find. Wonderful paintings, such a treat and hidden treasure. A must see. Sit and relax while viewing these beautiful paintings.

More than Monet. We went to this museum to see the panoramic Monet water lilies. These were wonderful as expected, but for me - the Christmas morning surprise was the many Renoirs in the collection. In particular, there was a early piece of two girls playing the piano, which a final version is at another museum. The initial sketch had more movement and appeared more natural. This was not an usual experience for this museum. We visited in December and first thing in the morning, so we had no line. This did allow us to spend a lot of time appreciating both the Monet water lilies as well as the other pieces. Also available on the museum pass that can be bought at airport information at CDG.

Excellent temporary exhibition. A very refreshing exhibition on the first women photographers who managed to express themselves despite all the obstacle they had to fight against, photography being considered a "man" activity.In the permanent colletions: beautiful impressionist paintings and the Nympheas paintings donated by Monet to the French State which allows the visitors to calm down and feel like being in the Giverny gardens.

My Favourite. This is the museum that houses 20th century art in Paris, including Monet's Lilies installed in two oval shaped rooms by the artist himself. Since you can get a paired ticket with the d'Orsay, it is well worth it. It hasn't the quantity of paintings of the d'Orsay or Louvre, but if you like the late impressionists and pre-world-war 2 art of Modigliani, Matisse and Picasso, it is a must see.

A moment of calm and rest whilst enjoying these beautiful paintings. The Musee De L'Orangerie is very easy to find situated near to Concorde and Tulleries. This is a museum for Modern Art with Matisse, Picasso, Renoir and many many other artists. The Monet Water Lilies is thought provoking and a sea of calm in this beautiful but busy city. The Monet Water Lilies vestibule is a place of contemplation and calm and allows you to take a moment to enjoy the beauty of Monet's work. We also were lucky enough to see the exhibition of Female Photographers and the role they played in history in is medium, it was fantastic. There is a coffee shop on site and the exhibitions and events change constantly. An audioguide is available and a clear map to guide you around.

Water lilies galore!. The highlight is the display of Monet's huge water lily canvasses, which take up one floor of the exhibition. The remainder is mainly Impressionist work, which, though ok, pales into insignificance compared to what's on offer at the Musee d'Orsay on the opposite bank of the Seine.
WOW!!. If you LOVE Monet, this gallery is a MUST visit location! The 360 view of Monet's water lilies was tremendous. Pictures do not do them justice. Go see it for yourself.

Perfect for Reflection. Got the combined ticket for d'Orsay and l'Orangerie and were glad we did. The reflective area was so peaceful and was so nice to chill out and bask in the glow of this wonderful art.

Beyond extraordinary. Most tourists to Paris know that Monet's famous Water Lilies are beautifully displayed in this space designed by the artist for that purpose. They do provide a haven of peace, contemplation, and tranquility that Monet must have experienced at Giverny. They are worth the visit by themselves, but when you add the Paul Guillaume collection of impressionists on the lower level - well now you have something beyond extraordinary. Art dealer, collector and gallery owner, Guillaume encouraged and supported artists whose fame was due in part to his assistance. Cezanne, Modigliani, Matisse, Picasso, Utrillo and others are shown here with excellent interpretive signage in English and French. Spending time studying all that is offered here should earn you a degree in Art History. Intelligently and beautifully displayed art in a comfortable, welcoming setting. It is a must see.

Amazing Monet. We visited the museum at Tuesday morning, as soon as they opened, and I'd recommend you to do the same. Monet Nympheas are the reason I went there, and they are an exceptional work of art, something that really blowed me away, like nothing I've seen in museums ever. Since there was no people yet we got the chance to enjoy the rooms and art all by ourselves and the feeling of peace there is indescribable. Other works are also very nice. Definitely the best museum in Paris.

Lovely museum. This is my favorite museum in Paris. We loved it so much we went multiple times. Sitting in the middle of the Monet's was so moving and relaxing. We had our museum pass, so after we went through security, we walked right in. My breath was immediately taken away. Seeing the waterlilies was incredibly moving, but it was also a respite from the large crowds of Paris. We were there at the beginning of March and when the sun came out, so did all of Paris! It was overwhelming, but the museum was a nice place to regroup. I can't wait to go back someday.

Wonderful. Apart from the eight wonderful Monet murals, there are rooms full of Impressionist painting to enjoy. We did not have to queue at all, but it was just two weeks after the terrorist attacks.

If you like Monet. Go here! It's a quick museum stop but worth factoring in to your day. Beautiful! I honestly can't describe what it's like to be surrounded on all sides by water lilies. Great stop on our trip

A Monet lovers must see little known and exceptional museum!!. This spectacular building purchased by Monet has huge masterpieces done by him in the last 5 years of his life designed specifically for this building. Truly a must see for Monet lovers!!

Wonderful, intimate gallery. I would have loved to spend offer here admiring and reflecting upon some of the art ( however family didn't get it ). Two great viewing rooms for the 'Water Lilies'. Additional galleries of works of other impressionists etc also wonderful. Be prepared for a smaller gallery than other Paris institutions.

WATERLILLIES!. The waterlillies in this museum are truly amazing. They were specifically designed for this space. The rest of the museum is just okay, but the waterlillies are definitely worth a visit.
Monet. Several good works here, but the Monet room was the highlight. It shows several of his works on a curved wall.
Monet is Magnificent!. The Monet galleries are incredible. Each painting takes up an entire wall. Best of all, you're able to get close.
Beautiful. The murals at this musee were gorgeous. The other art installations were delightful. There was a hefty line to get in...about a 45 minute wait.
Love love love. Not as crowded as I expected, which made it quite enjoyable. The art selections brought tears to my eyes. Definitely recommend

Must-see for Impressionist art. A relatively small museum, this is a must-see for a Paris agenda. Upstairs are Monet's water lilies (entire rooms dedicated to the paintings). Downstairs is a veritable timeline of impressionism, with works by all the major artists.

Nice museum, in particular water lilies . Very small museum which is great. You can fit it in on a trip to the louvre since they are very close. I thought some parts of the museum were a bit disappointing and the queue was very long. But the waterlillies by Monet were fantastic and flabbergasted me. They curved half the wall and were of grandeur.

A Bite-Size Art Experience. If you are overwhelmed by the breadth of the collections at the Musee d'Orsay or the Louvre, a visit to the Musee d L'Orangerie is perfect for you. You can get a good sampling of some of the major Impressionist artists (as well as a few later ones) in a visit of an hour or two. They usually have wonderful special exhibits -- just recently a lovely exhibit on women photographers.

Monet's wonderful paintings.. Beautiful oval rooms housing Monet's Waterlillies Heavenly ! A fantastic exhibition, arrive there with time to take everything in, full entry fee charged even if it's less than an hour before closing !!!

A Highlight of our trip to Paris. I didn't realize that this musuem existed, and I still didn't understand what I was going to go see...didn't do very much research beforehand. We were WOW'd. My family of 6, 4 kids, walked away saying that this was one of their favorite parts of Paris. It is so serene and amazing. We were there the week or 2 after the terrorist events, so we virtually had it to ourselves, which is why it might have been so amazing. But for anyone I would put this on a MUST SEE list. Combine it with a trip to Orsay, perfect timing to see the two of them. You can buy combo tickets and get a great discount. ENJOY!!

Paintings displayed in their perfect setting. People will probably judge me for this, but I found the Louvre unpleasantly crowded and hectic with no peace and quiet. The Orangerie was the exact opposite of this. For some reason tourists are more solemn here and it is a beautiful space to take in Monet's Waterlilies. The light is perfect as is the curvature of the wall, gives an organic feel to the paintings. A great place to relax and reflect in a bustling area.

Perfect!. There are two reasons why I love this museum. First, I love anything Monet. The two rooms with the Monet panels are great. Second, it's a small museum (as opposed to the big ones that you can't possibly see everything in). It's one that you can see everything in a couple of hours without feeling overwhelmed. Definitely worth a visit.

Not to be missed. Both the permanent exhibit of modern art (impressionists and others) and the temporary exhibits make this a wonderful museum to come to and to return to. On this visit, we came specifically for the exhibit of women photographers which is in two parts (the other is at the Musée d'Orsay). We spent many agreeable and informative hours.
Beautiful!. Really love this small gallery. Easy to see in an hour and the monets are exquisite. Would definitely recommend seeing

A lovely stop in the gardens!. The expectation can never quite prepare you for the reality of the Waterlilies. The curvature of the wall and the time of day creating such lovely diversity in the individual pieces was quite unexpected. For us, there was one that stood out, where the waters seemed quite real, and teeming with life. Excellent reminder of a time before photographs.

Great Pitstop!. This is not only my kids' favorite museum, but it is also a great place to stop and go to the bathroom with your family. You can buy tickets in advance that can be used at any time on any day. So, stop in and enjoy the waterlines, get the kids to the bathroom and get back out onto the street for more fun & people watching.

A Nice Alternative to the Larger Museums. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a beautiful museum and houses, most famously, Monet's epic water lily murals. However, there are also numerous works by artists like Renoir, Cezanne, and Picasso. If you want to visit a smaller, very manageable collection and to avoid the crowds at museums like the d'Orsay and Louvre, you'll enjoy the Orangerie.

Not purely for the Monet Waterlilies. The Waterlilies are the highlight of the museum but downstairs are 146 paintings by Renoir, Cézanne, Gauguin, Monet, Sisley, Picasso and Matisse among others. There is also a temporary exhibition. Well worth a visit especially for impressionist aficionados.

My favourite little museum in Paris. If you want a short and sweet blast of impressionist art, stop by L'Orangerie. It is a lovely gallery that many people don't notice. The Monet galleries are mesmerizing and the collection on the lower level has many of the impressionist greats.

Perfect size; Monet the highlight but much else to impress as well. Loved this museum. I had no idea that Monet's water lily canvasses were so large. They are beautifully presented in peaceful, luminous, beautifully lit rooms. Thoroughly enjoyed the exhibits downstairs too - discovered that I am a fan of Modigliani, and there was a great photography exhibit on as well. The size of this museum means that you can take it all in without getting overwhelmed. Highly recommended. We used the Museum Pass to skip the line-up.
Lovely Modern Museum. A museum devoted to the most loved works of art is a must see for the visitor to Paris. The location is lovely in the Jardin des Tuileries.

Shhhhhh. To sit quietly and be with Monet's Waterlilies is such a gift. To do this on a rainy Paris afternoon warms the soul. Don't miss the Renoirs downstairs as the range of his works is extraordinarily represented.
Amazing Monet experience. Unique assembly of Monet water lily panoramas. Absolutely fabulous. Downstairs collection does make one wonder about just where Renoir's reputation comes from.

expecting more. if you not an art expert, i dont think is that much worth it. We are just art curious, but we were expecting to be amazed, at least a little bit, witch didnt happen. the museum was some massive beautiful paintings in round rooms witch are very enjoyable, but we only spent 20 min in the museum (very small) for half hour queueing. Only visit because of the museum pass.
Monet extravaganza . No visit to Paris is complete without a visit to Musee d l'Orangerie. The Monet panels in this small museum must be seen as often as possible.

some great treasures.. The museum is much smaller than Louvre (which is a true behemoth) comprised of only a few rooms. I took us around 1.5h to go slowly around it all. Most of the time we were stuck at the Monet’s Water Lilies. A group of 8 extremely long paintings are truly astonishing and them alone are well worth the visit.

Quiet and contemplative place to enjoy art. The atmosphere in here is really peaceful and calm, especially if you go early in the morning like we did. You can just sit and gaze at a Monet while sitting on the comfortable benches conveniently placed in the galleries. And it's really necessary to take at least a few minute to take in Monet's enormous paintings.

Wonderful Museum!. We walked by the Louvre and Tuilleries to arrive at the Orangerie! We just adored this museum! Of course, we love Monet and seeing the 'Water Lilies' up close was fantastic, but the museum had other exhibits which we enjoyed as well...I was particularly interested in the Women Photographers (with the rest of the exhibit completed at the Museum D'Orsay) and of course, all the other artists represented here. (I remember the old days of learning about these paintings in Art History class!)Take you time here and enjoy everything!It was so peaceful! The oval rooms of the lilies are so unique.

Wonderful Monet. This museum is small, so I felt like I had plenty of time to view each piece of art. The main exhibit is Monet's Water Lilies, so if you have no interest in seeing that, I'm not sure it's worth the visit. With that being said, the water lilies were incredibly beautiful. The paintings took up two entire oval rooms, so be sure to visit both. Bench space was available to view each of the paintings on the walls. Take some time to look up close at the brush strokes and then view from a distance - I think part of the masterpiece is seeing the blended paint up close turn into a masterpiece with more definition from a distance. The other collection on the lower level is small, but beautiful. Monet and art lovers should visit this museum.

Smaller and Lovely Museum. I am not a huge museum fan but in Paris I would rate this just behind Musee d'Orsay and similar to Rodin Museum in terms of the one I would want to see. If you are in Paris for only 3-4 days, I don't think this is a must see or anything, but for a long trip of a week or more, this would be a good one to add in. The large paintings by Monet take your breath away and impossible to soak in without some element of superb sentiment piercing your soul.

A Must Visit if you Like Monet. Love Monet so this is an ideal way to spend a couple of hours.Water lilies art on show are amazing and the audio guide well worth getting.Brilliant shop as well well stocked with English books and magazines. Can get overcrowded though, easily done for a small gallery so I would try and make sure there are no groups in attendance when you go.
Small but stunning. The Monet water lilies are housed here in stunning simplicity. The collection downstairs has an interesting mix from Renoir to Picasso. Another must do in Paris

The Perfect Museum for Lovers of Monet's Water Lillies. The Orangerie is the place to see Monet's largest canvasses of his beautiful water lilies. There are nice benches to sit on while you contemplate the gorgeous colors and diaphanous forms. In addition to the Monets, there is a small, excellent collection of works by other impressionists. If you find the Louvre overwhelming, this small museum is "just right." For those who want to see much more of Monet's work, plan to take the Metro to the Musee Marmottan-Monet in the 17th. It has an outstanding group of the artist's work, including "Impression: Sunrise" the painting that gave the movement its name.

The Oval Rooms of Monet. I hope many Parisiens have been visiting the haven of peace to be found in this unique museum, especially after the horrific violation of Parisien life which occurred last Friday, 11-13-15. Monet's intention was to create this peaceful island of meditation for the people of France. Two oval rooms show scenes inspired by his water gardens at Giverny at different times of the year. As a lover of painting, I experienced intense pleasure examining his brush strokes and sense of color. If you look at it closely, you lose the image, but are aware of the strokes of his hand. If you stand or sit on the benches in the middle of the room, the image solidifies as the garden images he intended. Don't stop your exploration there. Make sure you visit the other galleries to see the works of Renoir, Cezanne, Rousseau, Modigliani, Laurencin, Matisse, Picasso, Derain, Utrillo and Soutine. There is more - visit the special exhibition. When I was there it was, Who's Afraid of Women Photographers? 1839 - 1919. If you get there soon, you can see the work of Julia Margaret Cameron, an American Photographer who was ahead of her time, fiercely independent. Located on the West Corner of the Tuileries Garden, the museum is easy to find near the middle of Paris.

Waterlilies!. Perfect! This is a wonderful experience! If possible walk here from the Louvre--it's a bit of a walk, but doable--depending how tired you are after touring the Louvre. The waterlilies are enchanting! They cover the walls--it's wonderfully beautiful

Monet at his EPIC best!. A bit small, but Monet makes it worth it! His lily panels were overwhelming. I ended up sitting and staring for quite some time - art has never done that to me before haha! My wife and I bought the combo ticket with the Musee D'Orsay and were glad we did. Definitely recommended, and especially if you're planning to visit his house and gardens in Giverny - made that trip so much more special.

Monet and Femmes photographes all in one.. Wonderful. Free of charge for UE students under 26 and not too expensive for older people and non UE citizens. There are benches and seats where you can stop and enjoy the beauty that Monet's art is. Absolutely worth it.Also, there is currently a great photography exposition about women's photography during war. Don't miss it!

Beautiful paintings by Monet. Not a too big museum if you prefer that. Not only Monet on display but quite a nice collection of impressionists and often a nice spevial exihibition. Rigth now (oct 15) female photographers.
Another treasure. Just past the gardens arriving at this masterpiece is well worth the time. It is one of the smaller muse s, but provides major pieces to experience.

Just Magic. At last I have visited the Musee de l'Orangerie. It was wonderful and magical and calm and soothing. The lower level is just as interesting with more art and a short history of the building. Defiantly worth a visit and I recommend buying the the combo ticket with the Musee D'Orsay.

Wonderful Monet. This is not to be missed particularly before visiting Monet's garden I recommend this museum. Much information, including a film in French but easily understood. Wonderful paintings particularly the 360 degree painting of the pond by Monet. Easily accessible when not all museums were. Not crowded. We were able to have a cheap wholesome lunch.

Home of Monet's Waterlilies. On of my purpose to visit this museum is to see the Monet's Waterlilies. Monet is one of the great painters that I love for his impressionism art. Although there are also many great masterpieces in this museum. I went straight into the Waterlilies exhibition room after buying my ticket. Admission fee is not cheap for this size of museum, but you can't put a price in terms of your interest, it's priceless. Once you entered the oval shape room which house the Waterlilies, you will be surrounded by the painting. The room was lit up by soft, warm sunlight which gives you a very calm feeling. I sit there in the middle of the room for nearly an hour to admire the scale of Monet's work. If you are a fan of impressionism, this is a museum that you shouldn't miss.
Monet. Not just one or two small Monet paintings, but two rooms with each whole wall with Monet paintings!!!! You can practically just stay put for hours staring at these beautiful artwork!

Impressinists on show here. The Musee de l'Orangerie is one of the most fascinating museums in Paris. It is not the largest, but it is full of impressionist and post impressonist paintings. If you like art from this period, you will be stunned and amazed by this ciollection.
Monet. this museum holds Claude Monet's masterworks, the Nymphéas (Water Lilies) in a special oval room. It is worth the visit and entrance fee is include in the musee pass.

Monet and Renoir. Monet's nymph series in 2 oval rooms, many Pierre-Auguste Renoirs, Andre' Derain, Amedeo Modigliani, Rousseau, Matisse, Picasso, Cezanne, and Gauguin... also an exhibit dedicated to women. A wonderful museum that should not be missed. Manageable without being overwhelming.

Impressive Monet Rooms and Outstanding Impressionist Collection. Visited last week on a 4th trip to Paris. Really blown away by the Monet rooms with the oval shape and diffused light. But, the collection of impressionistic art in the lower level is also terrific. We also saw an exhibition on women in photography. Really enjoyed this museum!
Impressed by Monet's water lilies. This museum is smaller than others in Paris but worth a visit especially because of Monet paintings.

How to jump inside the Monet ninpheas lake.... Great experience, thanks to the smart ideas of putting these pictures in a soft light and on round walls... Magic, full of poetry. It is better in the morning: less people and enjoy more!
The perfect combo ticket with the Musee d'Orsay.. The Monet's waterlilies are huge. Very moving to see them in such a lovely setting. See this museum first and the head over to the Musee d'Orsay.

Hidden gem in plain sight. Everyone is so busy trying to jam the familiar landmarks in that I find this museum overlooked as it is hardly noticable located in the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde. What a treasure ~ wonderful when you have had enough of the maddening crowds. It's a respite, and lends to a leisurely pace while enjoying Monet's masterworks, the Nymphéas (Water Lilies), painted in the artist's garden at Giverny. For those that enjoy Monet, this is a must see.
Monet!. The lilies are the draw. Actually done in twilight of his career and quality of the work is variable. But don't miss seeing.

Thanks for the Sky Light. Several years ago, this charming museum was redone and given a natural sky light. This revolutionized the way we can look at Monet's water lilies. So if you have not been there since the new light was opened, do go back. The rest of this charming museum is also very nice. I enjoy it time and time again.

A lovely visit.... Taking the time to visit this little museum is worth it... the two grand rooms housing a number of Monets is something to behold. Limited seating is available and worth waiting for to let the great works soak in.....
Simple, but enjoyable. The museum is small, but enjoyable to visit. Read some of the history of the museum before going, it has a nice story. We went on a short afternoon.

Impressionists in spades. L'Orangerie is not a large museum but a smallish jewel containing a collection of French Impressionist paintings by the likes of Matisse, Monet, Renoir and Cezanne beautifully displayed in a modern spacious gallery. Together with la Musee D'Orsay, it is one the most approachable art museums in the City.

Water lilies. Monet.. Sit on the benches in the two oval rooms and observe the light changes on the water and the lilies. Monet painted these for this installation. Below, enjoy the many beautiful impressionist paintings by Monet's contemporaries. A manageable exhibit with priceless menories.

Wonderful!. Small museum, memorable day! Many of my favorites here.Small wait in the rain (a drizzle, really,) but not too long because we had a Paris Pass. Went straight to cafe. We split a sandwich (pretty good for a museum cafe) and a water to refuel after a busy morning. The Louvre is, of course, unbelievable but this felt like Paris. The Water Lilies alone are worth the trip!

Delightful. Monet's near abstract water lilies painted at the end of his life are a delight but don't miss a wealth of masterpieces downstairs including fine collections of Renoirs, Cezannes, Modiglianis, Laurencins and I particularly loved the Soutines.

Excellent small museum in Paris. I am a huge fan of impressionist paintings so this museum was one of my few must see places in Paris. The two oval Monet galleries are spectacular. The paintings are displayed just at Monet directed, so you truly get the artist's vision for his work. The rest of the museum displays a number of other impressionist works. We bought our museum pass here because this was a smaller museum without much of a line.

Monet. My husband and I visited the Musee de l'Orangerie while on vacation in Paris. The museum is located directly in the Tuileries Gardens. We unfortunately lost one of our Paris Museum Passes on the day that we went there. We did not realize this until we were in line. Once we got to the ticket agent we asked her what we could do. She told us if we had the receipt to get it and when we brought it, she would allow us in. We had to go back to our apartment to get it, so it took us a half hour to do that and when we returned she was at lunch and we were told that was not the case and that we had to buy a ticket. We realize looking the museum pass was not anyones fault but our own, but why were we told otherwise? It wasted our time for absolutely no reason. We were quite upset to say the least. Needless to say, we accepted things as they were and paid for one ticket. Since it was lunch time, we visited the cafe which is downstairs and sort of mixed in with the gift shop. There is not a ton to choose from but enough to at least refuel for the afternoon. Once we were done, we walked around a bit. It is not a huge museum and really the only thing we enjoyed was the Monet Water Lillies room which has always been a favorite of mine. It is a stunning room and that alone is well worth the visit.

Do not miss Les Nympheas. Les Nympheas are Monet's paintings of his water lillies in Giverny. Do not miss these paintings. If you have even the tiniest bit of human spirit in you (or just love art) you must absolutely see these paintings in their resplendent glory. Pay attention. Don't look too hard. Look hard. Walk by them. Sit and stare at them. Do a handstand. Get close. Go far. Just look!I spent an hour looking at the whole series (split into 2 oval rooms.)They're that great.Keep an eye out for the piece with the extremely vivid indigo colors for the sky's reflection. It was (and is) my favorite bit.

The best one hour visit museum. If you don't like to be lost in huge museum and you have 1 spare hour, go to that place. Nympheas from Monet are so impressive In their circular rooms. Don't forget to visit the underground part, many great paintings!
surprise. Excellent sized museum with a good art gallery on the lower ground floor. The oversized Monet canvas in the elliptical shape of the rooms are amazing. Well worth the visit.
Visit before D'Orsay or you'll be disappointed. Great selection of art, but building, variety and sheer impressiveness did not compare to Musee D'Orsay...but location in the park is fabulous
Small and sparsely attended. For a quiet break at the end of the Tuileries gardens, stop at the Musee de l'Orangerie. A one hour stop after a lunch break in the Tuileries. Free restrooms!!!

Calm.... After the craziness of the Louvre or the Musee D'Orsay, it was balm to the spirit to go to this little gem of a museum. Soothing and lovely. The main attraction is the mural sized canvases of the Water Lillies by Monet. However, there is also a lovely permanent exhibit of other Impressionist and Post- Impressionist work. GO!

We organised, beautiful display of Monet's best works. We went to see Monet's pond works of his water lilies and were pleasantly surprised by the extensive collection from other artists. The Monet murals are extremely well presented and one could sit for a very long time enjoying them. The other works in the gallery are extensive and also well presented.
Another Museum. Its another Art Museum if your into art then this is you for you if not stay away, use THE HOP ON HOP OF BUS

Monet treasure. The highlight of this site, the two rooms with Monet's water lilies surrounding the visitor, is not to be missed. It is a restful experience, just as the artist intended. There is a good, brief English language brochure/map and audio guides are available.

If I had to miss a museum in Paris this would not be it!. Fabulous art museum featuring Claude Monet's spectacular waterlilies paintings which stretch completely around two large oval rooms. Massive and oh so beautiful. Downstairs is a fabulous collection of paintings by contemporaries of Monet--Renoir is a true highlight.

Great art. Smaller & comfortable compared to other museums. I would consider this one of the top three museums to visit. It is small and manageable and the Monet WaterLillies are here. You can get a joint ticket with the Musee de O'leans.

One of our favorites in all of Paris.. Easy to navigate and the rooms with the Monet waterlilies can't be passed up. The collection on the lower level is not to be missed either. Late Impressionists to modern. Wheelchairs available and the elevators work.

Must See the Monet Works. My husband and I visited the Musee de l'Orangerie after a city tour and visit to Musee d'Orsay. While much smaller than Musee d'Orsay, the Musee de l'Orangerie contains something very special - 2 unique oval rooms displaying Monet's cycle of water lilies murals. You can sit for hours on benches in the center of each room as you are mesmerized by the change in light as the paintings advance from morning to midday to twilight to night. There are other Impressionist and post Impressionist works in the basement but the highlight of this museum is definitely Monet's Water Lilies.

No better place to study Monet's works. This museum contained 16 huge Monets and other works which were also fascinating. We studied the art for hours and it was a most memorable experience of our Parisian experience. My only concern was the number of visitors in the Museum and how they tend to look at the paintings very closely making it hard for us to sit back and see the works of art. Will definitely return.
Too small. Great place, beautiful things to see but just a little small... Too expensive! Still, fantastic neighborhood with Tuileries garden... You can have a walk around, nice atmosphere!
I love Monet. The nice museum where you can sit and watch the paintings hours and hours. Of course you can see some paintings from Renoir and other artists.
Monet's Glory. One of my favorite museums in Paris. it is so rich yet not overwhelming and Monet's Les Nympheas are a must. There is always an interesting special exhibition on.

Great to see if you have a Paris Pass. The Nympheas are worth a special trip to this place. Line wasn't very long and with the Paris Pass you get to skip the line. No need to get there early. We went late afternoon and it was fine

Great Art Exhibit features Monet's Water Lillies. This is a great museum to see different impressionism. The current exhibits are Walter-Guillaume collection and a collection of female photographers. The Walter-Guillaume collection has paintings from 1900 to 1934 that are exquisite. I had only seen many of them in books. The photographer exhibit was interesting as it showed how female photography has developed. Well worth the price but bring cash as the telezon was not wroking when I went.

Powerhouse museum. Amazing little museum. Make sure to decompress in the white room before entering the Monet exhibits. Too beautiful to share photos. A must see when in Paris. Included in museum pass.

Monet at his best. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a small art museum featuring the enormous "Water Lilies" works of Monet. If you like art, you can't miss this museum. Very inexpensive to visit. Usually not long lines to enter like some of the other museums. A must when in Paris.
For Monet Lovers. The museum is very unique, as it was specially built for Monet's Water Lily Series. We visit the museum at least once a year. Don't miss the exhibition in the lower level.

Not to be missed!. We showed up just before they stopped letting in visitors. It was 17:15 by the time we got through the line, but it was all the time see needed. The Water Lilies are astonishing, and the rest of the collection is impressive, too. By coming so late, we got a discounted admission of €6.50

Small, but a more enjoyable experience over the Louvre!. This museum is much smaller than the Louvre, which makes the experience much more enjoyable and intimate. At the louvre, I felt overwhelmed and so many different artists and paintings fighting for space on the walls, while here, you can appreciate entire rooms just dedicated to a single artist.When I arrived, there was no queue, yet we also had the museum Paris pass, which I would recommend as it allows you to by-pass any line ups and includes the entrance fees.

Difficult to Leave. On my brief visit to Paris (3 days) I came to appreciate those smaller places that are digestible in shorter periods of time. Not only can this whole venue be seen in 90-120 minutes but the experience is remarkable. Monet's works deserve at least a couple of walk throughs and some quiet study. I found it difficult to leave them.

A great small museum. The Orangerie is a smaller museum than the larger busy museums in Paris but worth the trip to see Monet garden drawings. I spend over a hour in each rooms just admiring the colors and the different settings.

Good value but limited. Fantastic to see the Monet and general exhibition, but I'm not sure it was worth the half hour queue to get in. Perhaps the queue was worse because the Musee d'Orsay was on strike, and it was well managed but nevertheless, the Petit Palais outshone it.

USUALLY OVERLOOKED BUT NOT TO BE MISSED. Most visitors beat a path to the Musee d'Orsay for the famed Impressionist collection, and also endure a wait that could stretch into hours. Avoid the crowds for nearly immediate entry into this spectacular showplace of the Impressionist's, especially including Monet's spectacular water lilies, depicting his flower garden at Giverny. Other rooms have even more exceptional works by other Impressionist and post-Impressionist masters.

Visiting Musee de l'Orange, a must visit while in Paris!!. Our visit to the Musee de l’Orange where the Water Lilies by Monet are on display was one of our more enjoyable museum visits on our last visit to Paris. This exhibit is housed in a very beautiful build at the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde in Paris. The building has been renovated several times over the years. During the last renovation the skylight was completed to cover the complete top of the building giving great lighting to this wonderful exhibit hall and Monet’s water lilies. It is hard to describe how beautiful these paintings are by Monet. The beautiful colors and how he blended the blues and greens of the water with the vivid colors of the water lilies themselves. I commend the creators of the galleries and how they designed the exhibit halls themselves to present these beautiful pieces of art. The viewing halls are very quiet and peaceful almost like you at Giverny sitting on the bank of Monet’s water garden, enjoying the water lilies. In each of the large exhibit rooms there are several benches for you to sit on, so you can relax and take your time to enjoy this beautiful art.I do have a couple of suggestions for your visit to Musee de l’Orange. There are other works of art displayed in this museum also, so plan to spend some time to visit the entire art museum. If by chance you are visiting Paris the first Sunday of the month this exhibit is free. The regular hours are 9 to 6 daily, I would suggest to visit early in the morning, it will be quieter, shorter wait lines and more time for you to enjoy the gallery. When you enter the museum you will come up to an area where you will pay to enter the exhibit halls. There are ticket options that are available to you to purchase that you would not be aware of if you had not been there prior. There are 2 options that you might find interesting that will save you some money. One option is a joint ticket that includes this museum and the Musee d’ Orsay wich is located a very short walk from here and should be on your list to visit also while in Paris. The other option includes this museum and the entrance to the Monet gardens in Giverny, this might be of interest to you if you are planning a trip there during your stay in Paris.Hope this has helped your visit to the Musee de l’Orange.Have fun and enjoy the “City Of Lights”Lary1047
Unexpected. This little museum is certainly worth a visit if you are around the area. It was quite a nice surprise.

Breathtaking.. Before our trip, I was so looking forward to visiting l'Orangerie for the Monet paintings. The museum did not disappoint. A few things I liked about it:1. The museum is not overwhelming large like D'Orsay or Louvre, can finish in 1-1.5 hours without feeling super rushed.2. Monet rooms are stunning.3. Great location! Make sure to stop by and visit the Monet paintings, it was a highlight of the trip for me. So beautiful and moving!
Amazing!. This is overwhelming in its scope and beauty. It is calming to just sit in the room and look at the beautiful soft colors.

Small but mighty. It seemed like we would never get to see Monet at the Orangerie - every time we were in Paris it seems to be closed for renovation etc. Finally, this year we managed to visit and the wait is certainly worth it. A stunning display in only 2 rooms that captivated us for over an hour. We were so excited again by Monet after this visit that we also went to visit the Marmottan Museum the next day.

Waterlilies stunning !. I booked a ticket online (August 2015) so only a very short queue and my daughter was under 18 so had free entry. We went there to see the Waterlilies and these are huge paintings in two dedicated elypical shaped rooms. Just beautiful and relaxing to sit and enjoy them. There is a nice collection of some paintings from Renoir and Picasso, but Monet is the highlight. Much more enjoyable than the larger busier museums.

Check this place out if you want to see classic impressionist work. We checked this place out because I love Monet and Renoir's works. The Louvre only had a few pieces. The major highlight of this museum is the massive installation of Monet's waterlilies. There is also a large collection by Renoir and other major impressionists. At the time of our visit, there was only a fantastic exhibition on Women and Photography. I thought it was critical, intelligent,and very neat to see the amazing (and previously hidden) work of influential female photographers.

a little monet goes a long way with me.. perhaps I should say, a lot of Monet goes a long way. We again waited for a long time to enter, and my museum feet got the better of me. I enjoyed touring the various rooms, but after the Orsay, this seemed 2ndary.

Finally. It seemed that it took years for them to redo the Orangerie at least whenever I was in Paris over he last few years it was closed. Finally I got to go and what a joy to be able to see Monet's gift to France. this is an excellent art gallery but my first love is still the Musee D'Orsey
Great Little Museum. This little museum was built to hold Monet's best known masterpieces. It's an easy museum to see in an hour and well worth the detour.

An awesome experience. I always wanted to go here and as it was an hour line-up to get into the Louvre (buy tickets ahead if u can ) on a cold day we purchased a combined ticket for the Orangerie and Quai D' Orsay  Oh I was so glad I went The Water Lilies by Claude Monet will take your breath away and downstairs there are other wonderful treasures---paintings by Andre Derain,Renoir, Cezanne and Modgliani to name just a few Tea room a bit small but perfectly adequate
Monets Waterlillies. Nice place to see Monets works amongst others. Kids under 18 free. Adults around 8 or 9 Euros. The Tuilleries gardens are nice too. Cafe/shop and facilities in here too

Pretty Nice. Definitely not my favorite museum in the city but still has some nice pieces from the Impressionist period The highlight is of course Monet's waterlilies. But I find the interior of the museum to be sterile and unpleasant.

Monet Water Lillys a Must See. In addition to the Monet Water Lillys, this museum has an outstanding collection of Renoir and Cezanne. It is not crowded and allows enjoyment of their collection leisurely

Loved it. We specifically wanted to visit here to see Monet’s water lillies. My husband and I had the Paris museum pass and children are free so we leisurely picked a day to swing by. There was no line, no wait at all to get in. The museum is quite small compared to others, but the Monet pieces made it well worth it. I am not an art expert so I did not realize the size of Monet’s pieces. They were just absolutely gorgeous and you couldn’t help but stand in awe while looking at them. Even other visitors seemed amazed as everyone just stood or sat in silence starring at these paintings, the size and beauty of them. I am happy we decided to visit here.

Always, always. We crossed the Tuileries Garden and entered the magical space that houses Monet’s 8 panels of waterlilies. Our hotel shared a copy of Rick Steves’ Paris with a thorough description of the paintings they Xeroxed for us. That meant we could skip the audio guide and concentrate on the paintings themselves. I took 30 photos which I hope to reproduce with the appropriate text. This was a return visit so we skipped the other offerings of this intimate and quite special museum. It is one I return to each time in Paris.

Loved the WaterLilies. I wanted to see this museum more than the Louvre. It did not disappoint. It was much smaller so you can take in the whole experience and not feel overwhelmed ( like at the Louvre).

Amazing Monet. The chance to sit in a room surrounded by Monet's murals is a breathtaking experience.You will never be able to see these anywhere but at l'Orangerie because they are a part of the building. There are also other great paintings to enjoy here.
Unforgettable. Amazing experience, the building itself was nice to be in and the paintings were something amazing! Nice to visit with family and friends
Beautiful Monet Paintings. Beautiful Monet Paintings and other impressionists and a tasteful gallery, well explained. Take the audio guide (5E)

If you want to see Monet, this is the pace to go.. We went early in the morning, so we had an unobstructed view of these magnificent paintings. You want to be able stand back and take these works in, and enjoy the tranquility that Monet did in his gardens. Where some museums in Paris can be overwhelming, this one is perfect in it's simplicity.
great collection. I was completely blown away by Monet's Water Lillies. There is also a great collection of works on the floor below. Do not miss this museum. No lines to get in and not too crowded.
A wonderful museum to visit while in Paris. We visited the Musee d'Orsay and the Musee de l"Orangerie in one day. Two spectacular and rewarding museum to visit in Paris

Waterlilies!. This museum houses Monet's waterlily murals. It was originally used to shelter the orange trees of the Tulleries-hence the name. The murals are incredibly impressive and accessible. There are works and exhibits of other artists there as well, but Waterlilies are the stars.

See Giverny First. Our visit to de L'Orangie was greatly enhanced by a visit to Giverney a couple days before. To see where Monet painted the water lilies and the gardens that inspired it made seeing it in person a most memorable visit.

For Monet Fans - A Must Stop. If you arrive fairly early it is easy to get in without a long line. This is a must visit museum for those who love Monet's work. We found the balance of the exhibits to be well worth wile also.

A Must For Monet Fans. It is great to get to see the work of a master on display in a building specifically designed to house and display his works. I suggest that you take Rick Steves guide book with you and let his words introduce the works that you are seeing. The main attraction are the massive waterlillies but the basement display is also well worth some time (Picasso, Matisse, Cezanne,Modigliani, etc.). The Paris Museum Card gets you in here and you skip any line.

art and poetry. Small museum but full of art, paintings, photographs and names like Matisse, Monet, Picasso etc...Located in the Tuilleries Gardens, very easy to find your way around especially if you are coming from anywhere close the Place Concorde...Loved the huge Monet paintings that cover those round/oval walls on the first floor...

A great collection of impressionist art in an outstanding building. I loved my visit here. Although I had thought it was mainly about Monet's water lilies, I discovered a wealth of other impressionist art: Renoir, Cézanne, Derain and an unusual Russian painter Chaïm Soutine. And Monet's water lilies, which I left until last were divine.
Loved the amazing French paintings and artwork. Gorgeous paintings by Monet, Renoir, etc, a great relaxing and enjoyable afternoon spent browsing this gallery.

Small museum with the lovely Monet water lilies. This is a rather small museum located in the Jardin de Tuileries. It displays Monet’s large water lilies paintings. It also has a small collection of paintings from the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection. It is well worth a visit.

Wonderful - small but wow. If you are into the waterlines then this is a must visit. To be honest I was a but underwhelmed but this may have been by the number of (Japanese) tourists trying to do movie star poses in front of the amazing art work. The other disappointment is of course all those tourists who think that they have to have the shutter noise on their mobile phones. Go here and get the cheap the cheaper ticket to Musee d'orsay as well and skip the line t the better exhibition.
smaller museum. Bought a duo ticket to visit here. Don't think it's worth seeing alone as its quite expensive to get in.More masterpieces!
Best Pari Museum. This is a great little museum. Not only is it small and manageable the surround sight of Monet's is incredible.

NOT WORTH THE LINE UPS. Obviously this building has a good selection of impressionist masters but the line ups all seem to be unnecessarily long.Line up to buy your tickets then another line up to wait to get into the exhibit. Frankly there are better venues in Paris to spend your time at unless you just have to see the Monet lily`s.
Excellent impressionist museum. There are huge wall murals done by Monet which are well with the admission. Not to be missed when visiting Paris

All the water lillies you could ever want to see. This was a fantastic museum to view Monet's masterpieces. By buying tikets prior to the day we were able to reduce the waiting time and only stood in line for a few minutes. The crowds were very reasonable allowing you to spend a good length of time viewing each work of art.

Waterlilies!!. Although a small collection, waterlilies alone was worth the visit. But the rest of the museum is well worth while.This museum is a must for impressionist lovers. The scale of the waterlilies can be described, but experiencing them is just beyond imagination! There was a good cafe' (fairly priced), and gift shop.

Not to be missed for a Monet fan. The two rooms with Monet's art in the round is an experience for any impressionist lover. We visit every trip to Paris.
Sitting with the beautiful blues all around is a wonderful change from the hustle of other tourist activities.

Water lilies and more. The l'Orangerie was my favorite museum. I visited lots during my recent visit, and went back to see Monet's Water Lilies again. So beautiful. There was also a nice exhibit of early photographs from female photographers that I enjoyed. A must see in Paris.

Water lilies!. Wonderful! Very organized. Spend the extra 5 euro for the audio. And be sure to sit in on the 44min movie in the auditorium as it will give you a deeper appreciation of Monets last years.

A small but impressive collection.... The two rooms of Monet's Water Lilies are the main attraction here and are not to be missed. However, take the time to see the rest on the fairly small but impressive Impressionist and Post-Impressionist collection in this lovely often overlooked museum in the Tuileries Gardens.
Skip the line by getting the Paris Museum Pass.
just for the monet. well worth a visit to this purpose built museum. Bookshop, café and toilets. Able to sit and take in the paintings.

"l'Orangerie" is the New Black. One of our fav PARIS museums. Amazing concentration of Impressionist art. Monet Water Lilies in 4 gigantic panels. Picasso's, Van Goh's, Manets, Renoir,s, Utrillos and on and one.
Lovely way to spend an afternoon:-)

Worth it if you want to see something specific. A far smaller museum than others in Paris, especially the Louvre. We went primarily to see Monet's Waterlillies. We had gone to Giverny the day before to see Monet's gardens and wanted to see the paintings he made specifically for the l'Orangerie - it was wonderful!

Monet and more. There are bigger, better known art museums in Paris, of course, but the Orangerie should be on the must-see list of any art lover. The jewels in its crown are two large, oval-shaped rooms featuring Monet's huge impressionist panels of water lily-filled ponds (definitely come here before visiting Monet's house & garden in Giverny just outside of Paris). But while Monet is this museum's raison d'etre, don't miss the basement with its varied collection of early 20th century art. For me, the works by Marie Laurencin were a highlight: beautiful art featuring a distinctive colour palette and style, and by an all-too-rare woman artist to boot.

Great Art Museum. I went twice to this museum this last trip. Not too many people, I felt I could take my time and really get to know some of the paintings. The story of how the collection was assembled is also fascinating. The Monet room is spectacular even though Monet is not my favorite. Wonderful Renoirs and other artists who don't get as much press.

Amazing Monet water lily paintings.. If you like Impressionist paintings this is worth a visit. There was no lineup and there are comfortable benches so you can sit and absorb the beauty of the paintings.

Disabled access good once you're inside; wonderful Monet.. Our taxi got us as close as it could but for one of us with a walking-stick it was a fair old walk up the slope to approach the Orangerie. Once inside we were looked after very well; a loaned wheel-chair was excellent, with a handy lift to the frst floor.We had come to see the late-period Monet paintings of his beloved water-lilies and the whole experience was unforgettable. There were not too many visitors and it was a pleasure to wander at leisure from painting to painting.The museum's shop has an excellent selection of tasteful souvenirs at reasonable prices.

DO NOT MISS...... This museum was built to house the curved panels of Monet. These panels are large and exquisite! They truly show the artist's genius. Stand back you see the painting as it was meant, move in closer and you can sense the brush strokes!! Don't rush through the rooms .... Sit... Stare... Enjoy!! This museum also holds the private collection of art dealer Paul Guillaume- lots of Renoir, Modigliani , Cezanne, Utrecht and many others. It is a nice space, easy to navigate and not overwhelming!! It is definitely one of the "must see" museums in Paris.

Small must-see gem if you love Monet.. Be transported and try to go when the crowds are less dense. Buy a ticket in advance , the lines can be very long. Beyond the two huge oval rooms, leave time to go to the basement for more modern master works. The cafe is meh, if a coffee will suffice.

construction. Unfortunately for me it was undergoing renovations and was a waste of time. I was looking forward to the Monet gallery so I just skipped going through the rest of it. You can get a dual admission ticket for this and Musee d'Orsey and save some euros but check if it is done with renovations first!!!!!!

I Was Disappointed . I know it's maybe the not popular view, but I really didn't like the collection here. It just didn't seem to work for me. I did so much enjoy the four Modigliani paintings on the lower floor. Love him.

been there for 10 times!. the most magic place i've find ever in the world, i like Claude Monet so much, when I see the lotus painting, my heart is calm and relax, I am thinking about beautiful things, highly recommend this musee and enjoy the lotus

5 stars for the Monet. The water lily rooms were beautiful. Being surrounded on all sides with the calming hues of the room made it so peaceful. I'm not a big artsy type person but I enjoyed the Monets. Downstairs was mediocre. I'd say skip it. Enjoy Musee d'Orsay instead. This is a good option if you have the Museum Pass because it's covered and free. You could do this on your walk before or after the Louve, just a quick 30 minute stop in.

Immersion in Impressionism. I had heard of this small museum but wasn't fully prepared for the beauty and spaciousness of the architecture. Monet's paintings filled the upper space with color, mood, movement, and depth. Entirely enchanting to spend time immersed in his work simply by sitting within the space. The lower space with its collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings was a wonderful surprise and just as deserving of time and exploration. Don't miss this treasure!

Nympheas Beautifully Displayed. The rooms are beautifully designed to display the Nympheas to best advantage, with wonderful lighting. Enjoy an early morning stroll through the Tuileries to reach the museum and arrive as early as possible to avoid the crowds.When we visited, there was also a fascinating exhibition of many works by other artists of Monet's era displayed on the lower level.

Lovely. Modern and innovative. Right in the Jardin des Tuileries (which you also must walk around in). Monet's paintings are the highlight but also many other impressionist paintings downstairs. Got in fairly quick with the museum pass.

A Must-See. Get a Museum Pass so you can breeze right in — the entire collection is top-notch, and small enough so that you can see it all without museum fatigue setting in. Downstairs, the Paul Guillaume collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings is delightful, especially when you realize that they were assembled by one man for his own enjoyment. I'd never much liked Chaim Soutine until I saw his paintings here, and now I've completely changed my mind! But the true glory of the museum is upstairs: the Monet Waterlily paintings. They are like nothing else, and reward both a long view and repeated viewings. I've seen them 4 times, and always come away with a new appreciation of what he accomplished. I'm a painter so maybe I'm biased, but my partner — who is NOT a painter and has a preference for fairly realistic art — was moved to tears by this work. We saw them twice, and he's looking forward to seeing them on our next Paris junket.

Simply lovely!. Of course, Monet's Water Lillies are the main attraction, as they should be for they are spectacular. But the setting/ rooms in which they are displayed add to the enjoyment of these masterpieces- no surprise that Monet himself helped design these galleries. However, the rest of the museum is quite wonderful with works by Picasso, Cézanne, Modigliani, Matisse and Renoir to name a few. The museum is well planned and not overwhelmingly large - it is not to be missed.

A spacious and wonderful place. The Waterlilies was fascinating to see. Situated in a spacious room it's breathtaking. To just sit in the room and immerse yourself is an amazing thing to do. The Orangerie is spacious and a pleasure to walk around. A vast array of artists and I much preferred the less busy atmosphere in the Orangerie, over the Lourve.

This is not the best Monet Museum, though it houses some good impressionist paintings downstairs. Musee de l'Orangerie is best known for the enormous water lilies that Monet painted toward the end of his life (1919-1926) that line two gigantic rooms on the first floor. They are of impressive scale, and if one is a student of Monet, one should definitely go. For the rest of us Monet lovers, the Musee D'Orsay and Musee Marmottan are far better choices. There are three water lilies in each room (or maybe it's just five in total) -- huge and impressive -- but I found Monet's other work more intriguing for me. I may very well be revealing my ignorance - and that's okay -- because most of the people there were shooting multiple photos trying to capture something they likely couldn't appreciate from an art historian's perspective. It's true that photographs ARE permitted at L'Orangerie (they are not at Musee Marmottan). Other than the five or six water lilies, I don't think there are any more Monet's on display (there may be one or two downstairs). The downstairs galleries house a quite nice collection of impressionist artists. Between this and Musee D'Orsay, go to D'Orsay hands down. There is a combination ticket between the two that if purchased upfront will save the patron 4 Euros. I'd recommend that.The nice thing about the Musee L'Orangerie is that I didn't feel compelled to spend so many hours there. Whereas I was at the D'Orsay for over eight hours, I spent maybe two or three here -- and that was unnecessary. The D'Orsay is huge with Monets in multiple sections, so I jaunted among the locations to see how the artist's form had changed and evolved. Not that L'Orangerie isn't big -- it is -- but the galleries are smaller and with the enormous water lilies taking up so much space, the first floor is only that.In my opinion, unless one has the time, the inclination, some specific reason, or is a student of art history, this is one museum that is passable. I'm glad I went, but when I return to Paris, I won't feel the compulsion to necessarily return.
Monet water lilles. A nice afternoon relaxing visit here. There is quite a queue at busy times but worth the wait. An hour or so visit. Fabulous views of the paintings.

Yes, full-size Monet paintings but also, much more. On our recent trip to Paris, my mother demanded we go to this museum just to see the full size Monet paintings (which indeed are breathtaking and a huge draw)...I thought that was all that was there...until...I went to the second level of the museum where it had an incredible gallery of Picasso, Renoir, Van Gogh, Cezanne....and more. I was blown away, plus there was a Photography exhibit that had just opened in another gallery, focusing on women photographers in history. This was an amazing assortment for a (relatively) smaller museum. I could not leave -- so much to see. We ended up staying about 2 hours longer than anticipated! Yes, it is not the size of the Louvre or Musee du Orsay....definitely not as glamorous. But I think you get a PERFECT balance of awe and art in this visit...enough to be incredulous, but you are not overwhelmed. This is my new favorite in Paris.

Lovely small musuem near the Louvre. This was a delightful place, small but memorable. Audio guide was easy and informative. Places to sit and admire the unique French artists' work, including the giant Monet water lilies works.

Yes, yes, yes!. Had been hoping to take my wife here since i saw it solo a few years ago.
What a place. On the Paris must do but get there early. We did a Sunday and just about got it right.
Wonderful pictures and do not miss the other impressionists down below before a coffee in the Tuilleries gardens below
Excellent museum. Go for Monet's water lilies and stick around for the impressionists in the lower gallery. A must visit on any trip to Paris.

Breath-taking. Among all the galleries my wife and I have seen in Italy and France, Musée de l'Orangerie was the best. The paintings exhibited in this musée are among the most famous worldwide which, any person, artist or not, can recognize and enjoy.

Water lilies. Amazing! Although I must say we should have started with an exhibition downstairs, and I suggest watching the video abt history of the waterlilies first. One of the most exquisite pieces of art.

Enchanting, peaceful, unforgettable. The Orangerie, especially the waterlily rooms, is incredible. The peacefulness of those big, beautiful canvases is amazing. We visited at 10:30am in August & there was no line for entry & the galleries were not crowded.

My favourite. When you have a love of art but a short attention span, this is the museum for you.
It has fabulous art, well organised .
Monet's 'Water Lily's' has its own rooms... Stunning

Not my cup of tea. We got this museum recommended by friends in Paris and it was sitting on our to do list already quite a while, so we decided to visit it finally. No long waiting like as with the other (more famous) Musea so that was already a good start. First visit were the two rooms that have wall-to-wall paintings from Claude Monet, famous for his impressions of his flowery garden and ponds. At the end of our visit I have to conclude this was actually the best part of the tour.The main exhibition has paintings from Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Sisley, so pretty great names. But the works that were on display were not as good as I would have expected. Crude even, with sometimes totally wrong dimensions. Like they were made in the time the artists were still educating/training themselves in the fine art of painting.Next time we’ll go to D’Orsay again.

The second must for impressionist lovers. Musee De l'Orangerie is the home to a project that took Monet over 10 years to finish. If you appreciate impressionism- after Musee D'Orsay this place is a must go place. A lot of art students spend hours in this place to study how Monet presented different time of the day in his paintings. More than Monet's painting I enjoyed the Paul Guillaume and Jean Walter collection (2 of the greatest marchant des arts) downstairs

An impressive tribute to Monet and the French government. The experience of this gem of a museum was heightened by a lecture prior to my visit, which highlighted the commissioning of the works of art by the French government following Monet's cataract surgery, which was experimental at the time.

Stunning, Small Museum. For those fans of Monet, this is the place to visit. There is something to be said to being surrounded by the Water Lilies of Claude Monet that cannot be experience any where else. This is a wonderful, small Museum in a city full of wonderful Museums.

Monet!Monet!. Another of the great museums of Paris. Buy your tickets ahead to avoid lines. Once inside, plan which of the world's most interesting murals you want to contemplate. It is worth the trip just to see the 80' garden with lilies.

Musee . L'ORANGEE is Monet's design and houses some of the most beautiful impressionist paintings. The water Lilly gallery really takes you away from the hustle of the city and transports you to calm. The exhibits are awesome and most of all the art is paintings.

Beautiful, soothing space.. This is a small but beautiful, calm and inspiring museum. It is exactly the space that Monet planned for his Nymphéas series of murals still completely relevant and exactly as he wanted today. I feel the spirit of Paul Guillaume everywhere. I'd recommend a visit to this beautiful treasure over the chaos and aggression of Musee du Louvre any day.

A special place. It wasn't too crowded when we went through this delightful spectacle. I was transfixed by the main feature upstairs, but I also enjoyed the exhibits downstairs. But the matching of the works to the artspace is beyond comparison and I recommend a truly unforgettable experience.
Amazing to see first hand. If I only can go to 1 museum in Paris, I'd choose here. It's not too big and you can totally imersed into impressionist.

Beautiful paintings, limited collection.. This is a lovely museum, which features a number of Monet paintings, as well as an interesting collection underneath the main viewing area.
It is lovely, but for the price of admission, I believe that other museums are more worthy.

October Visit. Well worth a visit.last time we went had to queue for about 1 hour but last week in October walked straight in
Only 2 galleries so quite expensive

Monet. If you love Monet this is the museum where you see his Water Lily's. The size of the exhibit allows you to almost feel like you're in Giverny. If you're buying the Museum Pass, you can by a combined entry to L'Orangerie and the Orsay. The combo ticket allows you to visit both within a four day period.
Waterlilies rooms. Waterlilies rooms are overwhelming!. If you have seen these huge pieces in books or online, you will still be overwhelmed when you see them in person
Monet's water lillies!!. A relaxing museum - take time to sit and take in the magnificent Monet water-lilly paintings. Time to chill and just enjoy the beauty.
Monet - awesome. As a long standing admirer of Monet's work, a visit to this place was a dream come true. The waterlillies are spectacular. We got the dual ticket for here ands the D'Orsay.
Miner's Waterlillies. Two peaceful rooms of Monet's (8) huge Waterlilly paintings. Peaceful atmosphere. No queues! If you loved Giverny then you must see these.
Dont forget to go downstairs. The main gallery has the Monets but in the basement there are many more and varied works by other artists that I probably enjoyed as much, if not more

Small Intimate Museum,-but buy a Museum Pass. We waited for nearly an hour in the rain waiting to get into l'Orangerie; do yourself a favor and buy a museum pass to avoid (or at least minimize) the wait. Monet's famous Waterlilly paintings are displayed in two elliptically shaped rooms (seen from above they form the symbol for infinity, not accidentally). The audio guide was a great help in understanding Monet's motivations in creating these masterpieces and the history surrounding how they came to be here. Downstairs are numerous works by the Impressionists in two long rooms. The audio guide had lots of good, sometimes humorous information, such as a quote by Renoir who said, "If it were not for women's breasts I would not have become a painter" His obsession shows in his work.
Money water lilies - amazing . Worth the visit just to see the Monet gallery. Huge oval room with huge canvases - with seating so you can take it all in. We walked here after our visit to the Louvre

Linger over the Monets, enjoy the lower floor. The Monet "Nymphaes" or giant water lily paintings are the main attraction. We were there on a changeable day; take you time to look at the paintings in the changing light - it was magical. The lower floor includes a permanent exhibition of the collection of a gallery owner and was well worth the time. Buy a combo ticket with the Orsay (you have 3 days to use it) and skip the ticket line at one museum or the other.
By far my favorite!. So many beautiful artists and ease of seeing everything within 2 hours. The line wasn't too long and it my 12year old enjoyed it more that the Louvre.

Very difficult to reach if you have mobility problems, but worth it once you are there. This was one of my chosen places to visit this time in Paris. Unfortuantely it is not easy to reach by any means other then on foot and even by taxi there is for me a rather daunting and unfriendly walk to get there. I wish I could have €10 for the number of tourists who completely failed to see my wlaking sticj and either walked backwards into me while using a selfie stick or made me walk around their group because they were totally occupied texting their friends in Japan or Virginia!Onse there however staff were helpful and wheelchairs are available you have to leave your passport as security.I have waited more years than I care to remember to see the waterlillies in their rightful place and I love the clean lines and airy feel of the recently restored setting.You can book in advance but I think charging. far more than the postage, to send you the tickets is naughty especially as there is not a print -off option.Worth the hike though, so glad i finally made it.

Amazing Monet and other Artists. We didn't get to this on our last trip to Paris and we are SO happy we visited this time! We loved this museum. It was a beautiful museum and the art is fantastic. Sitting in the two rooms with Monet's water lillies is really inspiring. Definitely on our must-do list!
Stunning. Monet is my favourite French artist. His works are displayed in all their glory here. Absolutely beautiful

We visited after the Louvre. WE spent 5 hours at the Louvre and then was making the trek up to the Arc de Triomphe and stopped here mainly to see the Monet which I enjoyed seeing. There was a line to get in and overall I felt it was not worth the wait and certainly pales compared to D'Orsay.
Better than the Louvre. Even though we were there when the Monet room was closed, the rest of the collection is well worth a visit. We were particularly impressed by the works of Marie Laurencin.

WOW!!. I loved this gallery. The 2 oval rooms that house Monet's Water Lilies are amazing. It really has to be seen if you are in Paris, even if you are not a museum/art fan. The scale of the work is unbelievable. Well worth a visit!

Waterlilies and women photographers: take your time in this lovely museum. We've been here several times over the years mainly to sit and spend time viewing Monet's magnificent waterlilies. This visit however was to see the current temporary exhibition "Who's Afraid of Women Photographers? 1839-1919". I spent about an hour looking at this exhibition which was stunning. We then spent about 20 minutes with the waterlilies. There was still much more to see, but it was time for lunch. Although it is a smaller museum than some, it wouldn't do it justice to say it can easily be done in one hour. The cafe is OK for a drink and small snack, but is expensive and has limited seating. I wouldn't recommend it for lunch.A note to people arriving with baggage. The museum limits the size of baggage you can leave in the cloakroom and we saw a few people being turned away as they arrived with small wheeled suitcases. This was being adhered to very strictly by the security staff. I imagine there may be information about this on the website.

Intimate encounters with Monet's masterpieces!. Enchanted and personal experience of Monet's water lilies up close and personal way. Surrounded by huge scale of paintings yet in a very intimate setting, you will get to really emerge yourself and appreciate his painting. Wonderful experience, must see in Paris.

Monet at his finest - impressive. If you are in Paris and like art make sure you visit the Orangerie! Monet outdid himself with these murals - its almost hypnotizing! Walk in for at least 10 minutes - the water lillies ( traditional Monet ) came to life for me!

Nice and easy to visit.. A nice short visit to a small art museum. The main draw for me was the Monet waterlillies which are really beautiful. I noticed that they had quite a lot of Reniors and a few Picassos, as well as others. I found their audio guide to be really good with a little more detail than some others about the artists, their lives, the stage within their career that the painting was done ect, this made the visit more interesting for me, and most works had an audio so I felt that this was good value for 5 euro. The security line was short to enter, note that the Paris Museum Pass doesn't allow any que jumping/time saving at this location, however it didn't take long to get in anyways.

home of Monet's big water lily installation. Before heading out to Giverny, be sure to stop at the Musee de l'Orangerie, home of the huge water lily paintings by Monet. There are 8 panels installed in two rooms and they cover the walls. Monet himself designed the installation. Other artists' works are displayed on the lower level.

Small, but very good. Musee de l'Orangerie is small in size, especially when compared to the nearby Louvre, but loaded with masterpieces. The centerpiece of the museum is the oval-shaped room containing Monet's Water Lilies paintings. There are also works by many of the most famous artists, including Renoir and Picasso. This museum is an art lover's paradise.

Do it! . I came here yesterday (Sunday). Surprisingly the queue was really short. The tickets are reasonably priced also (9 Euros per person). You can admire Monet's 'Les Nypmhes' and loads of other paintings from various other painters like Picasso, Roussault, Matisse, Derain, Cezanne. If you don't want to spend an entire day in a museum and/or queuing, I would recommend you come here.
Water Lilies!. Another must see in Paris - Monet's water lilies! It's a smaller museum so visiting won't take all day.

Monet!. If you want to see beautiful Monet lilypad paintings this is the place! They were stunning! Also went to the Emile Bernard exhibition when it was on which was great. Beware of pick pocketers when you leave, my friend nearly got her purse robbed when they were pretending to collect for a charity. This museum was also included in the museum pass.
Best Yet!. A very fine museum, easy to visit with some very fine pictures. If you are an Impressionism fan, don't miss this one. It's a relaxing visit with some of the best.
Beautiful. Beautiful!. Small beuatiful quiet museum. Absolutely loved the monet room. Do not miss this stop. An hour is all you need.

Money's water lilies. The two elliptical rooms with Monet's water lilies are incredible. Fairly crowded on a Sunday afternoon but the space can handle it. Don't miss the other paintings on the lower level.t

Appealing smaller museum.. This was a very appealing smaller museum. I purchased the combo ticket for entry here and the Musee De Orsay. Started here in the morning. They had an excellent and informative section featuring female photography . Of course, the water lilies by Monet were captivating.

Perfect alternative to the Louvre - Small and Doable in 1 Hour. We really wanted to do a museum in Paris but didn't want to have to wait hours in line. We probably waited 30 mins in line for this museum and we finished it in about an hour. It's not overwhelming at all and Monet's waterlilies are just breathtaking. It had all my favorite french impressionist painters as well so it was just *perfect* - highly recommended as an alternative if you're not in Paris for very long.

Breathtaking...You can almost walk into the paintings!!!. You will love this museum whether you are a Monet enthusiast or now..Very spacious and lots of room to contemplate the paintings and imagine yourself in the scenes. Don't rush through - nice to sit, relax and gaze.

Dreamy, magical, stunning. If you love Monet, this is the place to come to see some of his most stunning paints of waterlilies. Set in two large oval rooms, the eight paintings are positively breathtaking in scope, with so much detail and beauty.
Excellent Musee. The Monet Exhibition is excellent is displayed so uniquely.  The temporary photography exhibition is extremely interesting.

My favorite museum in Paris.... I have to admit, tears came to my eyes when I walked into the Monet rooms at the Musee de l'Orangerie. I have always loved Monet's paintings but these were overwhelmingly beautiful. It was a dream come true to see them in person.

Watch out for worker strikes shutting this place down. Was only partially open, but that was more than could be said for the Louvre and Orsay when we visited. Got to see some nice Picassos, Renoirs, and Monet paintings though for a consolation. Worth a visit for sure.

Cone for the Monets, stay for the rest. There are eight incredible Monet garden water lily paintings in the top floor of this gallery which are worth seeing on their own but the lower floor is a who's who of French modern art and a large temporary exhibition space. If you can, get the joint ticket with the Musee D'Orsay which saves 4 euro if you intend to visit both. Which you should.
Breathtaking!!. a must see.. totally life changing to see these works by Monet in person allow about an hour to see them

Absolutely beautiful. Definitely was worth seeing. Monet's paintings were absolutely beautiful to see. There were sitting areas available allowing you to view the paintings. There were several artists on the lower level. The museum did offer a combination ticket to D'orsay.
Impressive. Well worth the effort and cost. Visited with family member who is an artist she was very excited. Inspired to visit Monet house and gardens the next day.

Monet monet . This museum contains large paintings from Monet as well as other inspirational artists. I really liked this museum also because it isn't as big as others and you aren't so tired after visiting it. Still you get to see beautiful art and different artists and styles.
Very Good. Buy the ticket with D'Orsay, because it is cheaper. It is a very beautiful place to visit. A lot of Monet and other famous artists
