Excellent, great Monet collection. If you love Monet, this Musee is a must see! Go early to avoid crowds to get the best possible viewing of the curved displays....

Well worth the visit. Yes, do go see this. The Monets are breathtaking. You have to see them to believe it - how the lighting in the room changes the paintings in a way that cannot be described. Whomever designed this space knew what he was doing. It is just something else. Do not miss this. You will not be sorry.

Make sure to see the Claude Monet paintings!. This is not a large museum, but there are several areas to wander through. The highlight of this museum is the two large oval rooms with the eight large Claude Monet paintings on the walls. Make sure you find these once inside the museum!Tips: The Paris Museum Pass will get you priority access entry at this museum. You will have to pass through airport security style screening just inside the entrance.This museum was also a little on the uncomfortably warm side despite the cooler day outside.The museum is located in the western edge of the Jardin des Tuileries (Tuileries Garden).Check for open/close times and closure days before planning your visit, so you won't arrive to find it closed and be disappointed.

Montes ware lillys. I'm not an artist, saw Monets water lilies, I think my 12 year ol could do it. Not sure why they are so famous , but f near by, stop and see it , so you can say you were there, it only takes 10 minutes
Absolutely beautiful. If you only have time for 1 gallery make it this one - only small but breathtaking . Take a stroll around the jardin and then a walk along the champs élysées
Small but charming. A very small museum that you can get through in an hour - but it's always great to see Monet in large scale!

Being back in Giverny. If you can go to Giverny before seeing the "works", you will recall the feelings of the pond and the water lilies. If you are fortunate enough to go at a time when the crowds are thin, you may take some extra time to appreciate the work. Try to take a camera lens and change the focus. You may enjoy the experience as I did.

An experience you will never forget. We visited the Musee de l'Orangerie using the four day Paris Museum Pass - such great value and it made visiting popular museums a breeze. We walked straight in to the museum about 11am on a Saturday morning. Monet's Waterlillies are spectacular. The space is incredible and so calming. We felt so privileged to be able to sit quietly, so close to the work. It was beautiful. The impressive private collection of works in the downstairs gallery is a real treat with some incredible pieces.
The best museum. It's taken many trips to Paris before I finally got to go to Musee de l'Orangerie, honestly it's fabulous, don't miss it.

the only place to see Monet. The paintings cover the walls and there is seating for you to just enjoy the views of the famous water lilies. The exhibition downstairs changes but the space is well set out and easy to move around. They have bathrooms available
Must love Monet. I thought the Monets looked dull in color--possibly need cleaning. There are other pictures on exhibit--changing ones.
Space to spare.. Monet, Picaso and friends couldn't have asked for a better (or bigger) space. The murals are incredibe!

Wonderful!. A small museum with great art. Loved, loved, loved the water lily paintings by Monet. An emotional experience to see in person. Enjoyed seeing art by Matisse, Gauguin, Cezanne and other greats in a wonderful space. Don't miss if you are in Paris.

Up Close Monet. Lovely museum with Monet's biggest paintings of his water lily pond in Giverny. This museum also has wonderful pairings by Renoir, Picasso, etc. Very doable for a an art museum. Spend a couple of hours here.

Wonderful dispaly of Monet's water lilies. This is a smaller museum that is located away from Louvre and therefore does not seem to attract the huge crowds.The water lily murals are set out beautifully in two oval shaped rooms with four murals in each room.The works themselves are just astounding and the way they have been presented here accentuates their effect and respectes the efforts and tlanets of this amazing painter.

Small but mighty. It wasn't a big museum but has a beautiful series of wall paintings by Monet on the main level. On the lower level there are more impressionists eg: Renoir, Cezanne. It was an enjoyable visit

Only thing I enjoyed were the lilies.. I personally didn't enjoy this museum. The lilies are gorgeous and honestly could draw a crowd themselves. I felt like that's what was happening here. That's not to say this world famous museum doesn't have anything to offer, just not to me. You can not take pictures and you aren't supposed to talk while in this museum. I enjoy talking about the paintings and what we're looking at. It just felt stiff and awkward. Much smaller than the Louvre and d'Orsay, I would only recommend this museum to a friend who wants to see the lilies or who loves any and all art. If you're visiting Paris and going to museums because, well, it's Paris and they're known for their museums, then I would skip this one.

Not as impressive as I expected. I'm a big fan of Monet. The visit was worth it, to see the purpose-built space, but if you can only fit in one gallery while in Paris, I'd suggest you make it the Musee d'Orsay
A MUST SEE. This museum with it's Monet's is a must see. It was one of the highlights of an incredible trip. This is a small museum and highly recommended.

A gem of a museum. The main attraction, of course, is Monet's murals of water lilies. If his work appeals to you then this is a must-see. The selection of works in the lower level by artists such as Picasso, Matisse and Renoir is very satisfying without being overwhelming.

Truly mind blowing. The eight, massive Claude Monet murals of water lilies are quite astounding. If you miss this you will probably never see anything else quiet like it anywhere else.The paintings were housed in two, huge, oval galleries at Monet's own suggestion. You are bound to ask yourself how he kept everything in perspective. How he managed to execute such a huge piece of of work so perfectly. There can be only one reasonable explanation: he was a technical and artistic genius armed with a paintbrush. Go see this, you will not be disappointed.
Don't miss it!. Similar to other reviews - I've missed this in the past. This is a great showcase of some fabulous art - especially the Monet in the circular room. Close to the Louvre.

Go if you like Monet. Smaller museum, enjoyed the rooms with large curved panels, surrounded by water lilies! Went first thing in the morning, no line.Even had a light breakfast in the small cafe with fresh OJ, friendly service. Good ticket pairing with Musee d'Orsay and a nice scenic walk in between.Since we only went to these museums and the Louvre we passed on the museum pass. Good decision.
Amazing. Small museum, but well worth seeing the huge waterlily paintings by Monet. Set at the edge of the Tuileries Gardens it caps off a lovely walk.

Worth visiting. Great idea to exhibit in such a way "The Nympheas"of Manet. Good exhibition in the rest of the museum. It was sad that at the museum shop most of the books wrre in French, (and some in Chinese) BUT not in English

One of the best museums in Paris!. I have been to Paris several times, but didn't make it to the Orangerie until my most recent trip. This is now one of my favorite museums in Paris. It has an excellent display of impressionist art and is small enough that it doesn't feel overwhelming. This is a great pick if you have an hour or two to kill in Paris.
Small but delicate museum. If you love Monet, this is a must-go site. You can feel the calm when you sit in the middle of the chamber exhibiting the most famous "Water Lilies".

Go For The Monet; Enjoy ALL too!. At first glance and deservedly so, the Monet Lilies masterpiece collection is the draw; yet, the other many artists represented in the lower level gallery is ALSO worthy of equal attention-perhaps even more time. For those museum weary or for those with shorter attention span, this museum is for you. It is easily done in 60-90 minutes too. A true treasure and a memorable visit

Monet, Monet, Monet. If you are a Monet lover this is the place for you. His famous waterlilies are huge paintings that take up two complete rooms. Monet supervised the installation of these gigantic paintings in these rooms himself. With the museum pass it is worthwhile.

Its size is an advantage. Le musee de l'Orangerie has beautiful pieces from the World's leading artists of the XX century. The highlight are definitely les Nymphéas from Monet but, I will add to that the art work from Derain, and Modigliani. A must for art lovers. If it happens that you are visiting Paris with people that do not like museums or Art in general, le Musée de l'Orangerie could be a good compromise. Instead of dragging them into the Musée du Louvre or the Orsay and bearing their complains, you could go this museum instead. They could even wait outside if there is a good weather. It took me one hour and half to see the museum entirely but I think is doable in one hour.

Not bad with the museum pass. We got the museum pass which included this museum so we decided to check it out. Of course the main attraction is the water lily paintings and they are great. They are stored in two big rooms separately and the first room seems to be more crowded. Most of the time you will hear the guide asking the visitor to keep it down even though it is not super loud. I have mixed feeling about it since it is quite a distraction and can't really enjoy the papaintings. But I understand that the guide is trying to keep order. Anyway, overall I enjoy the museum but don't know if I want to pay extra money to get in if it was not included in the pass.

Lilies were the highlight . The main highlight of this short tour (you only need an hour at the most if you're running short of time) around the Musee de l'Orangerie is Monet's beautiful lilies. Otherwise, the Musee de Orsay is still a better choice.

Amazing Water Lilies. A small museum bit worth a visit. You will see Monet's 8 panel Water Lilies as they were intended to be seen; a spectacular exhibit of impressionist art. There are further exhibits of other impressionist artists as well as.others. If you have a couple of hours to spare and you are close to Place de la Concorde you should go.

A Monet Must. Among the other Impressionist sites to visit in Paris, the Orangerie is a must see. Monet spent his final years obsessed with this project. The eight canvasses are immense - he was successful in making the viewer totally immersed in the waterlilies. Words cannot express what an amazing experience this is. We appreciated our visit to the Orangerie even more following our visit to Giverny.

Stunning . The rooms filled with the water lily paintings are truly breathtaking. The gallery itself is quiet and bright and when we went wasn't overrun with tourists.Wonderful after a walk through the gardens. Take a seat and drink in the beauty of these paintings

Impressionist Fans' Delight. This relatively small museum is in a building that was originally built to hold the orange trees in the Tuileries garden adjacent to the Louvre over the winter. It has been converted into a beautiful museum that houses many impressionist artists' works. Highly recommended.

Monet!. A smaller museum, two of the exhibition rooms were closed. The Highlight was definitely the Monet Room. Security looked through bags, walked through a metal detector, and waited in line for 15 minutes. Spent about an hour here.

So where are the orange trees?. The Monet's are enormous, fabulous, beautiful, peaceful and gorgeous. Well worth the visit especially if you have also visited his garden in Giverney to see the original water lilies and the pond.
Do not miss if you love Monet. I think the water lilies are the most beautiful painting of all times. Here you can see large beautiful paintings in an oval room.

Monet, Monet and more Monet....... My husband and I have been to Paris too many times to count over a 35 year period, but until this last visit in August, 2015, were unsuccessful in getting into the Musee de l'Orangerie. It had been closed for renovation for too many years to count (and I really hadn't heard of it during the first 20 years that we visited Paris). I finally saw the Monet rooms in a recent Woody Allen film and realized that it must have finally reopened. The two Monet lilly pond rooms, each with four curved walls, covered in varying lilly pond landscapes, are breathtaking. The other impressionist paintings throughout this rather small museum are also magnificent (and some may have been moved to the Orangeries from the Musee d'Orsay since I know that I have seen some of them before).

An essential visit for all fans of impressionism. A wonderful collection which includes the huge Monet water lily panels which are specially housed in 2 rooms. When we visited the photographic collection was closed to the public, but as it was our second time there, it didn't ruin the experience.

Nice.....just nice. If you love Monet this would be great. For us it was pleasant and nice, we went in an eve on a Monday and it was quite busy and was a good queue to get in. Start closing down 30mins before closing time.

A must-see/must-do for the culture seeking traveler.. A must see for the lover of Monet's impressionist interpretation of his gardens. Pair this up with the Musee D'Orsay (tickets are cheaper if you buy them to see both museums).
Incredible art collection.. One of my favourite galleries. Monet's Water Lillies are spectacular and the private art collection downstairs is an absolute joy to walk through.
Must to see!. Great musseum at the Tulleree Gardens. 2 rooms with huge pictures of water lillyes by Monet (very special!) and a lot of paintings from a private collection.

Monet's water lilies are stunning. We tucked into l'Orangerie on a rainy day and the museum did not disappoint. The lower level features a benefactor's extensive private collection but go for the Monet's on the main floor. As we were entering the building, we made the mistake of saying we were part of a group when security only let part of our party of 8 into the museum. This started a 30 minute confusion with numerous staff asking us to fill out special paperwork, etc. We finally realized there was a misunderstanding...we were not a "registered" group, but just a group of friends visiting the museum together. So, if you go with a group of friends and part of you are let inside and the others are left in the rain, DO NOT tell the security guard you are part of a group! Instead just let them know you are visiting the museum together and wait for your friends inside!

EXCELLENT- small and manageable art gallery with some of the greats. Our vist to the musee de l'organgerie was perfect. its a small and compact art gallery, where it is easy to see everything. Monet's lilies are a highlight and a must see- its amazing how they wraps around 3/4s of the building. Under 26s go free- even better and if you enter an hour before closing time the tickets are cheaper for everyone. could not recommend highly enough

Monet Exhibit. Top floor has two oval rooms with Monet's waterlillies. Delightful. Lower floors a combination of late 19th and early 20th century artists. Museum is not huge and you have time to study all paintings for as long as you want.

INCREDIBLE DISPLAY OF MONET'S WATER LILLIES. The line was very long but it was well worth the wait to see the grand water lilies by Monet in 360 degrees in two different huge rooms. There is not much else in the museum but its worth it just to go and see these two pieces.

Come if you like Monet. It's a very small but worthwhile museum to go to if you like Monet. The two oval rooms have giant pieces of water lilies that you can stare at for hours. The downside is that it's always crowded of people walking around.

Not just the Water Lilies. This small museum is best known for Monet's Water Lilies which are displayed perfectly. It is worth seeing just for that. But some guidebooks imply that is all there is, and it would be a mistake to not go to the downstairs galleries and take in the interesting collections there. It does not take a long time to see the whole museum, but it would be a mistake to skip the downstairs.

A little piece of serenity in Paris. I had wanted to visit Giverny and then come to this museum but unfortunately my trip was one day too short. Even though I did not see Giverny, I would imagine the synergy of the two places would be exponential if one visits both places. The museum is still nonetheless great, and you cannot help but admire the water lilies. There is also a downstairs which features pieces from other artists.
Well worth your time.. Claude Monet´s amazing Water Lilies make this museum worth visiting. There is also lots of other beautiful artwork to be seen. A must see while in Paris!

more Impressionism, and new discoveries. The main display in the Orangeries is of huge murals of Monet's waterlily paintings, four in each of two curved rooms. They show a fascinating variety of colours and composition.The collection of 1930s art dealer Guillaume comprises some 150 works, including a large group of Renoirs; plus Matisse, Cézanne, Picasso, Modigliani and Rousseau.Best of all was the discovery of two new (to us) and highly interesting artists: Derain, and Chaim Soutine whose depictions of tortured people, landscapes and houses (e.g. 'Les Maisons') are extraordinary.
Monet fans. The building is no big deal, but I am a big Monet fan, this is where the beautiful Monet water lillies are. Large painting, do not miss

Best Museum We Visited. You know how you feel when you see something that TOTALLY exceeds your expectations? That's how my wife and I felt at Musee de l'Orangerie.The main floor is devoted (2 gigantic oval rooms) to Monet's Water Lilies, and that alone is worth the trip a thousand times over. However, there's MUCH MORE!! The lower floor is a treasure trove of paintings by Monet, Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, and many other renowned artists. The audio tour is a MUST!! I learned so much about late 19th & early 20th century art. We spent 2 hours on the lower floor, and I wish we had spent 2 more there. The place is just astounding, plus THERE'S NOBODY THERE!! Everyone is over at Musee d'Orsay!! (Also fabulous, of course). This place was the highlight of our trip to Paris. I cannot say enough about Musee de l'Orangerie. It is simply sensational!
Monet, Monet, Monet. Entire floor filled with Monet's paintings of his gardens. Be sure to go downstairs as there are other artists displayed along with a film.

Great hidden gem. Fun little gem! Missed this on our first trip to Paris. Hidden in the Jardin des Tuileries, but easy to find. Fabulous wall murals by Monet. Relaxing to take in. Not as crowded as Louvre and Orsay.

Nice Small Museum worth seeing. If you read my Musee d'Orsay review you will know that I figured out I am not much of a museum person, but this is a very small museum and kind of cool with the art they had. It is best known for the Monet Waterlillys. And they are cool.I highly recommend you stop in the auditorium first and hear about the history of the museum and Monet. I think that would help to better appreciate what you are seeing. We say the video after we looked at the art. I would have preferred to watch the video first.
A must. My favorite art museum that we saw. No lines to get and you can buy a ticket for the Orsay as a combo. Loved the Monet works.

Waterlilies are a must see. This is a relatively small museum so it is possible to go through it in a couple of hours. It is easily accessible from the Metro. It is closed on Tuesdays, so plan your trip accordingly.

An almost mystical experience. For any lover of Monet, this museum is an astonishing place. It centers on two huge oval rooms where Monet's great waterlilies sequences are exhibited. They are, of course, breathtaking, and even the inevitable crush of visitors doesn't dull the experience. You can study them close-up, but also pull back to see the sweep. What is important about them, from an aesthetic perspective, is the absence of clear perspective; you are literally immersed in the world of these ponds with their various forms of plants. The remainder of the Orangerie, on the lower floor, is also filled with some fine paintings that are worth spending some time. But the Monet waterlilies are what people come for, and justifiably so.

I love love love this museum.. I love love love this museum.
I think I can't see this drawing another place.
So it's very special experience to me.
And many chairs in front of drawing, so it's very nice to traveler.

A Must for "Monet" Fans. This small gallery tucked away in one corner of the Tuileries, is a definite must for Monet fans, to experience two rooms of 360 degree panoramas of his garden in Giverny is amazing. Viewed from all angles the paintings take on different hues and the more you look the more detail you see. However, the gallery also houses a small but great selection of painting and sculpture by other artists in the lower gallery. If you are in Paris on limited time, this gallery will provide you with a "taste" of the best in French Art, without needing a day to see it all.
Nearly spiritual experience. Nearly spiritual expiirience emmersing yourself in Monet genius water lily creation and good albeit small impressionist collection

Enjoyable museum, don't forget to visit downstairs!. The Musée de l'Orangerie is the home of a collection of Impressionistic artwork, and the Monet's Waterlilies. The Waterlily rooms are located right after the ticket office, on the main floor, so single-minded people tend to head right there and then out again, leaving the rest of the galleries for more thorough art buffs.Painted in sections and then blended together in 8 large canvases, the Waterlilies are mounted in 2 oval rooms, specially designed by Monet himself to heighten the viewing experience. In one room, the scenes flow from early morning to late evening, the light reflecting off the water changing as the sky changes color. In the second room, the seasons change, so the vegetation is seen in different stated of growth and blossom. The only thing that would have made the whole experience more immersing would have been a quiet flowing water soundtrack, to dull the hum of people whispering, coughing and moving through the rooms, boots scuffling along the floor, Otherwise, we really enjoyed wandering about, getting up close to the painting to examine the brush strokes, moving back to appreciate the piece as a whole. Impressive to have that much vision.The rest of the museum is nice, too - not too big to get tiresome quickly, and not so small as we feel we are overpaying for the visit. The rest of the museum spreads out downstairs. There, we find works by Renoir and Cézanne, Matisse and Picasso, and a full exhibit on french artiste Émile Bernard, which closed the same day. All in all, it's a wonderful museum.One thing to note: if you plan on visiting the Musee d'Orsay, get the combined ticket here. You'll save money on the price getting them together than if you were to buy the two tickets separately. Also, the museum is closed on Tuesdays.

Not just the water lilies. In conjunction with the Musee d'Orsay and Musee Marmottan Monet, Paris houses many of the great impressionist and post impressionist works of Monet, Renior, Van Gogh and many others. Although this museum is best known for the 8 large Monet Water Lily paintings, it also has a very nice collection of Reniors (including an alternate take of the two young women at the piano), plus works by many other late 19th and early 20th century artists. You can buy a combo ticket for L'Organgerie and D'Orsay for a discount price, but I think you have to go to both on the same day, too much for me. I recommend getting the audio tour. Adds lots of info to the experience.

Go for the waterlillies, stay for the Guilllame collection. We go to the L'Orangerie every time we are in Paris and never get tired of it. Monet''s waterlillies in their site specific installation are, of course, incredible to see. (My only complaint is that I wish they did not allow photos in there... it is a mosh pit of people photographing and filming.)However, plan on spending significant time downstairs where there is a very impressive and informative impressionist and post-impressionist collection.Also, if you can, take the guided tour. We have done it twice. We learned a lot and each time it was very different.

A true gem - don't miss it!. The line at the Musee d'Orsay was really long at 12:00 on a weekday so we headed across the Seine to check out some other sights. The Musee de l'Orangerie had been on my list, mainly because of Monet's enormous water lillies.As we walked up to the museum, we were amazed to see NO LINE! Monet's murals are indeed wonderful, but the real surprise was the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection of impressionist art on the lower level: Renoir, Picasso, Modigliani and others. A fabulous little collection.

Showcasing Monet's "Waterlilies". Monet's vast canvasses are displayed (as he intended) to their best advantage in this attractive small gallery. There is plenty of seating so visitors can admire these works at their leisure and the remainder of this collection is also interesting. We were unimpressed by the chaotic conditions in the entrance hall where the arrival of a party of students seemed to have halted the whole ticket system. You can buy a double ticket for the Musee D'Orsay as well here.
The Lillies. No trip to Paris is complete without this view of Monet's Lillies. One step into this space takes your breath away.

A must-go museum for all Monet fans. We visited Musee l'Orangerie on Monday afternoon (note that the museum is closed on Tuesdays) and even outside the best/worst tourist season, it was fully packed. If you wish to skip queues, make sure you purchase your ticket beforehand. Monet's Water lilies alone are a good reason to visit this museum, but downstairs they also have a nice selection of artworks from famous artists, such as Renoir. Also a good selection of art books in the museum shop!

Great art display. Pleasent setting. Monet, Renoir and others displayed in a bright an pleasant building. This museum, even though it is next to the Louvre, is usually uncrowded. Well worth the visit. Two hours is plenty to see its exhibits.

Monet Nympheus - do you need any more reason to go?. I have loved the work of Monet since my early teen years. I went to the Monet exhibition in Melbourne a few years ago (I live in Australia) but to see the entire Nympheus is amazing. Joyful. Serene. Calm. Beautiful. Breath taking. We arrived approximately 10am on a Monday morning with Paris Museum Passes and walked straight in - when we left there was a line around the corner of the building. This is a smaller museum which makes it easier to linger and enjoy the artwork. A long wall full of Renoir paintings is wonderful. .. and then there's the other works to see.But really this museum is about Monet. It really made me wish we had time for a trip to see Monet's Garden - maybe next time.

Well curated, beautiful spot. Perfect for a late afternoon in Paris. Once you see the Monet paintings upstairs, be sure to spend plenty of time downstairs. Well curated, beautiful display of some of the finest impressionist paintings. Works by Gaugin, Soutine, and Matisse were among some of my favorites.Smaller than many of the well-known museums and manageable in size, it was a perfect spot to visit late in the afternoon. I can see why many people rate this as one of the best museums in Paris.

Go early and go straight to the oval rooms to see the Monets. These unbelievable inspiring paintings are set up in 2 oval rooms. Go when they open and go straight into the oval rooms and soak up the beauty. They are meant to be an immersive meditative experience. Sit and watch the light change as the clouds pass overhead and marvel at how the paintings change too. Only when you are fully saturated in both rooms would I go downstairs. Then you can get a snack and enjoy the very nice collection of paintings downstairs. My favorite downstairs was Renoir's peaches...one I don't remember ever seeing before.

Unfamiliar wonderful art museum. Certainly not one of the major tourist, don't miss museums but what a great find! The Monet water lilies panoramas alone make the visit amazing. The other works were way beyond expectations. By all means, splurge for the wonderful audio tour which is actually a mini art history course. We thought we would visit for a half hour and ended up staying for 2 hours. Make time to visit this nugget.

Wonderful little museum we almost missed. My daughter and I recently spent some time in Paris on a great trip. We spent our time at various museums and almost missed going to this one. The place is a gem. On the main floor they display some massive Monet water lilies, the main attraction. They were so beautiful. Then we went into the basement for a great collection of Renoir, Gauguin, Picasso and many other more contemporary art legends. Highly recommended.

Free on the first sunday of the month. We wanted to go to Musee d'Orsay but the wait was too long.This museum is in the neighbourhood of Orsay.On the upper floor the Waterlilies of Monet are beautifully displayed. Downstairs are paintings from other painters, Renoir, Picasso.

The essence of French Impressionism. If youare a fan of Claude Monet and other French artists, this is a necessary stop to make your visit to Paris complete. The display of Monet's water lily murals brought me to tears as this was a bucket list check for me during my visit to Paris. Follow up your visit to the museum with a short trip to Monet's home in Giverny -- you will be amazed at how well the murals illustrate the actual water garden from which they were painted.
Stunning!. The large Monet garden paintings in the 2 oval rooms are stunning....took my breath away. One of my favorite things in Paris!

Prelude to visiting Monet's home and gardens in Giverny!. We disliked the fact that groups of tourists "hogged" all the prime seats for viewing. They were literally camped out on the best viewing spots in the gallery. We loved the fact that a few days later we were in Giverney where Monet did so much of his work!
Lean back and enjoy. A wonderful harmony of Monet's masterpiece and the building it harbours. Take your time and check out the intriguing collection minus zero.

A lovely afternoon interlude. This is a lovely 2hr add-on to an afternoon stroll through the Jardin des Tuileries. Spend a while admiring the water lilies in their natural lighting from the comfortable couches at the center of the room, then head down to the next floor for a great collection of impressionism/cubism. There are big names (Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne) but also some delightful ones less likely to be seen in the states (Laurencin, Derain) - and unlike the Louvre, these exhibits are well marked and commented. You'll walk away from this bright space feeling refreshed.

Impressionist Paintings. This was our favorite museum in Paris that we attended on our last day in Paris! A hidden, and highly underrated gem! The museum is home to a large private collection of Impressionist paintings.
A different experience. Nice museum,not big. There are not so many prestigious pieces of art, but the walls on the base floor is beautifully painted.

Another Do Not Miss in Paris. Monet masterpieces perfectly presented. On our second visit to Paris (did not make it here during our first visit), had a lovely morning stroll to this museum from our hotel. Met with very short line upon our arrival. Great English speaking tour well worth the additional cost.

Gorgeous. This is a small gem of museum. Monet's waterlily murals are there in all their quiet beauty, as well as a good selection of other Impressionist paintings. We went at opening time in September and it was not overly crowded- there was a plenty of opportunity to simply sit and gaze.

Awe inspiring. This is one of my favourite places to visit in Paris. Monet's paintings of his garden and water lillies at Giverny draw you in to their cool, calm depths especially if you're lucky enough to visit on a day when there aren't many other visitors and you can sit quietly in one of the two oval rooms and admire their serene beauty. The natural light from above adds to the experience and for a moment you can imagine that you're in Monet's garden instead of the centre of a busy city.

Dissapointed. Made a special visit to Musee de l'Orangarie on Sept. 7 to see Monet's 'Waterlillies' after visiting Monet's Gardens last year. I was extremely disappointed to find that the 'Waterlillies' exhibition was closed for a few days!
I'll go back again and again. There is just something magical about Monet's paintings. My wish would be to sit in the rooms by myself...but others wanted to share in the magic.
Lovely Art but please ban cameras!. A lovely small gallery by Paris standards. Unfortunately my visit was spoilt somewhat by a large group of visitors intent on taking "selfies" at every opportunity!
Must do when in Paris. Beautiful building and stunning Monet. Make sure you get the double pass for this museum and the Musee D'Orsay.
Monet. if you are a Monet fan , you cannot miss this one. The museum was built specially for his paintings. its a nice manageable small museum and the 2 times i have visited has not been crowded.
Small Museum wit h Monumental Works. this museum is tucked in the corner of the Tuillerie gardens and has monumental impressionist works. Monet, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso....what can be bad!
Come for the Monet, stay for the rest.. Monet's wraparound waterlily murals are amazing. I was so moved by his dedication to this subject and this project. Plus it's beatiful.
Musee de l'Orangerie. Very nice art! Picasso, Monet and other big artist. I will recommend anyone to visit the museum. Don't buy your tickets before hand, very closed from Louvre

Well worth it! Beautiful. . I am not a huge art fan, but was in awe of the beautiful wall sized waterlily paintings by Monet. The museum is well laid out, and it's hard to beat sitting down in the middle of these huge works of art and simply taking it all in.

good art in a good sized museum. We enjoyed this museum as it has around 160 peices of art with a great variety of major styles and artists of the impressionist and post impressionist styles. My enjoyment of a museum suffers if there is too much to see and found this museum a good choice due to its size. It has some great pieces of art and this makes the trip enjoyable as well as being able to see it all in a reasonable time. We had the museum pass which makes visitng multiple museums a affordable option as well.
Loved it!. Really impressed! Gorgeous! The Monet's waterlilies were so beautiful but that's not all. There are more amazing paintings in the lower level.

Best little gem in Paris. Would highly suggest you don't miss this unusual collection of Monet's work seen in panorama view. It's not an overly crowded visit, depending on your day and a walk through the beautiful Tullelries Gardens is a must afterwards.

Impressionism - Part 2. If you spend any time in Paris you have no doubts do it online for the Musées D'Orsay. It's that old train station that they have turned into a magnificent museum. It houses most of the French impressionist a collection in the city of Paris.… At least the big names and big pieces. Most people just stop there. But, if you love impressionism make sure that you go to part two. The Orangerie is an often overlooked museum that has additional works by such giants as Monet, Renoir and Gauguin. I went to 10 o'clock in the morning in late September and there was no line. Not only that, but without the crowds you could just stand there and appreciate the beauty of these paintings. You will see lots of familiar prices. If you have a museum pass, this museum is part of the group. If you want the audio guy and it will cost you five euro. I must say that even though the commentary is a bit dry, the audio guide is worthwhile.

Amazing Water Lilies. Loved the Monet galleries, nice to be able to get up close to these amazing panoramic paintings. Minimal queues even in the height of the tourist season. You are required to check in your bag.

A must see for any Monet fan.. I have heard about this museum and the large waterlily paintings by Monet. But I was not prepared for the size and depth of these paintings. The additional wonderful works downstairs just add to the collection.
Must see for fans of Monet!. Definitely worth a short visit (especially if you have the Museum Pass). Seeing Monet's waterlilies displayed so beautifully and effectively is memorable!
Great small museum. The Monet waterlily gallery was closed the day we visited, but we enjoyed the rest of the collection.

Don't miss it. A lovely gem of a small museum on the place de la concord. Spend an hour enjoying monets water lillies. Dont miss the long gallery featuring masterpieces by Monet's contemporaries. Compact modern and very enjoyable. Spend an hour or two and then stroll the tuillerie gardens for a while. The two water lillies rooms are beautifully laid out and have benches to sit a while and enjoy them. Try to go on off hours so that you dont have hoards of tour bus crowds blocking the lillies. We hit it right on a Sunday morning at 10 am. As we left the relatively uncrowded venue at 11:30 the tour buses were just rolling up. Maybe we were just lucky. Late might work too. In any event- don't miss it. Its a great way to spend a charming hour or two with no museum fatigue at the end.

Don't miss this treasure. How many museums can you visit in Paris. ? Well,the more the better is my answer.this is not a large museum but inside you will find such superb artworks that you will keep in your mind forever. A must-see.

A Pleasant Surprise.. We ended our visit of le Jardin des Tuileries by paying a visit to Musee de l'Orangerie. The art work donated by he Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume is outstanding. This is worth the visit.

Beautiful artwork everywhere. This is another museum with the great masters artworks. Each aisle contains beautiful painting one more amazing than the last. The museum also contains a display of waterlillys by Monet that is a reason to visit by itself.

My favourite piece of art!. I have had a cheap IKEA print of Monet's Waterlilies hanging in my bedroom for years. But to see the original work where this print originated was simply breath-taking! 2 rooms with a total of 8 panels! We wandered around in stunned silence taking it all in. We arrived early at around 9:00 am and there was no queue whatever so ever to get in, but by the time we left about an hour and a half later, the line up was out the door and around the building. So arrive early! There are many other works of art housed here besides Monet's masterpiece, and also a cute little gift shop with lots of reasonably priced "non-kitschy" souvenirs.
Water Lilies. The water lilies will take your breath away. Second only to visiting Giverny in person. The lower floor has a nice selection of paintings.

Best to combine with Orsay. This museum is definitely worth visiting, but in my opinion it is overpriced (€ 9) for its size. So if you have not seen Orsay yet, I advise to get a combined ticket for € 16. Visit the Orangerie first, and then you can skip the line at Orsay, as you will already have the ticket. Orangerie holds magnificent canvases of water lillies by Monet and what used to be a private collection of an art dealer (Renoir, Derrain, Picasso, Cezzane, Gaugin etc.).
Monet's paintings.. Outstanding ...The color schemen and the imagery is so real .it seems one is standing in the garden itself.

A building designed around paintings. Les Nymphéas, painted in a life-long work in progress by Claude Monet, are here mounted on two oval rooms, made explicitly for his unconventional curved canvases. This rooms allow an experience of the European Art, that alone is worth traveling to Paris.

Monet. I think we had a combined ticket for here and the Musee D'Orsay. I wanted to visit here to see Monet's water lilies. I was not disappointed. To sit in the middle of the room and marvel at the sheer size and effect of these vast paintings was amazing.

Musee de l'Orangerie is outstanding. Many folks miss this fantastic, little museum but DON"T. I could spend hours looking at The Water Lillies alone, but the rest of the collection and travelling exhibits are outstanding. If you love great art and the Louvre is too busy for you, spend a couple of hours here...you won't be sad.
Lovely . What a beautiful museum! We watched a very informative video which greatly enriched our experience. I did long for the old days when no photography was allowed.
It's the Flowers!. GO, ENJOY and FEEL Monet! You can site in a room and literally be surrounded by his Water Lillies. It is truly wonderful way to spend a few relaxing hours in Paris.

My favorite Paris musee.. Small museum focusing on Monet (8 large Monet panels), but also had a lot of Renoirs and other post Impressionist paintings. English is included in the information plaques. The Monet information only available in French, however.

Emotional. Given that we had just come from touring Italy in all its Renaissance glory, followed closely by the the Louvre, this intimate modern museum was a breath of fresh air. It was an unplanned visit and we managed to walk straight in for a ticket about mid day. Not sure if this was the reason we had a very emotional reaction to Monet's two rooms of magnificent waterlilies in the round but this small, friendly art museum is a 'must see/don't miss!' Equally the other artists were as much of a surprise and pleasure! Especially given that our planned visit to Musee D'Orsay was spoiled by a two day strike! This was an excellent, easily accessed alternative. Do yourself a favour!
Excellent. What can you say with such beautiful art work. Nicely organized, easy to walk thru. Great selection of magnificent art work.

Well worth a visit. The Musee de l"Orangerie is worth visiting just for Monet's Water Lilies (installed by the artist himself to his specifications for best viewing). But I also recommend taking some extra time to see the rest of the museum, particularly the sculpture gallery. There is some gorgeous artwork here. And there's a nice little shop too. The Musee de l'Orangerie is also a short walk to the Musee d'Orsay: I highly recommend starting at the Musee de l'Orangerie (where lines will almost certainly be short), buying the double pass (billet jumele) for both museums, then heading over to the d'Orsay and skipping the line (which will almost certainly be ridiculously long).

Lovely, lovely, lovely - the best in Paris. By far, this was the best museum in Paris. Monet's water lilies are pure heaven for Impression enthusiasts like me and the intimate setting is even better. We bought a skip the line pass, which was worth it and got right in. We also bought audioguides, which tell you all about Monet's masterpieces and everything else in the gallery. Surprisingly, this small museum housed some of the best works I have encountered including Matisse, Soutine, Manet and so much more. My best tip, get the audioguide.

Go see Monet's Water Lilies. This museum houses the very large Water Lilies paintings by Claude Monet. There are two large rooms that house paintings in which Monet shows changes in light to dark and across seasons.
Waterlily bliss. Ah, the waterlilies. Monet's masterpieces created for this museum are the stars here. Wished there were other Monet's in addition to them.

A little known gem of a museum. Most people head for the Louvre or the Musee D'Orsay, but the Musee de l'Orangerie is so lovely. The first two large circular room display Monet's eight Waterlilies paintings, which are simply breathtaking. The rest of the museum has a beautiful collection of Impressionist art. Crowds are very light, and the gift shop is certainly worth browsing in. Located at the end of the Tuilleries Gardens near Place de La Concorde.

Beautiful Museum worth visiting. Fabulous museum!! A must see! Use the museum pass to by-pass the lines. Lovely space, amazing art. The whole thing doesn't take a lot of time though so you can fit in a number of other things. Lots of things to do close by.
Monet et. al.. Great collection of Monet's garden and other impressionist paintings. Not a long line to get in. Unique wall installations of Monet that the artist himself designed. Fabulous.

An enchanting pearl!. Though Paris is filled with museums this is a pearl that should not be missed! I'd even suggest skipping the mega crowded and over-rated Louvre to enjoy the peaceful ambience and the treasures of this tiny museum. Monet's collection of enormous water lilies paintings is housed here. Be sure to read the fascinating story from the museum brochure to learn why Monet decided to offer the paintings to the museum.
A Must See for Monet Fans. If you love Monet, this is a must see. Although it was crowded when we were there, one could still see the paintings close-up and at a distance.

Beautiful way to enjoy Monet's masterpieces.. Be sure to include time for a leisurely visit to L'Orangerie, as the crowds can make it challenging to enjoy Monet's "Waterlilies" as one would prefer to. I was part of a group, visited on an early Saturday morning, and we had a guide who knew her way around the museum's treasures, so we had that advantage. Afterward, my daughter and I strolled around the adjacent Tuileries Garden, which is also a great park for people-observing. Then walked up the Champs-Elysees. Perfect!

Beautiful Water Lilies by Monet. I would like to spend more time in this museum. The highlight is the massive paintings of Water Lilies by Monet, which take up several rooms. They are magnificent, especially after we had the chance to visit Monet's garden and home in Giverny and could see the water lillies and flowers in the garden which served as his inspiration. I wish I could have spent more time with the paintings by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, and Alfred Sisley, This may be my second-favorite museum in Paris (behind the Centre Georges Pompidou, and just above the Musee d'Orsay and the Louvre), especially since it is not as massive as the Orsay, the Louvre, or the Pompidou.
Monet and more. We were here the day after visiting Monet's garden in Giverny and that made it very exciting. The were other displays downstairs that were very well done.

Must go after visiting Giverny!. If you have several days in Paris and vicinity, consider visiting the Musee de'l' Orangerie after visting Monet's House in Giverny. You will have more of a deeper appreciation of the water lily panels that Monet painted at Giverny once you have already seen the water lilies in the Water Garden at his house. Be wary of not having to bring large size backpacks at they are quite strict to enforce you to check in your oversized baggage. Not a problem but can be an inconvenience to some if you are bringing different camera lenses, etc. There are two rooms of Monet's Water Lilies separated by the time of the day that they were drawn. If you have the chance, one should sit quietly at the benches in each room to fully immerse and focus on the changing light effect of the water lilies as they are huge and extends pretty much from one end of the room to the other end. An enjoyable and relaxing place to visit after a Louvre visit in the afternoon

An easy way to add another museum to your viewing list. Add this to your list of things to see along the way. This is an easy museum to get through in 15 - 25 minutes. If you want a break from the crowds, this is it. There is seating to reflect on the paintings. Have a Zen moment.

Wonderful Museum. When you first enter the Water Lilies exhibit is a most memorable experience. Each canvas depicts a different emotion and feeling, really beautiful. Take your time to observe the details, colors, and mood. Explore the other exhibits and experience art through the masterpieces presented at each room. Wonderful!

Never get tired of Monet. Took the kids for their first visit to see Monet's workMonet is covered in my eight year olds curriculum so he was really impressed When the sun comes through the gauze filtered roof it brings the whole work to lifeHighly recommended
Brief but great museum. Get a Museum Pass at airport to avoid ticket lines. The 2 large paintings were at upper floor and more smaller paintings at lower floor.

Monet by Monet.. Two rooms created by Monet for his gift to the world share his vision of beauty and peace by surrounding your vision with his art. Words are poor substitutes for the effect, only that the paintings fill the space completely, truly unique. The remaining collecting is excellent but should be viewed before the Monet.

Exquisite!. I have been to this museum maybe five times over the years, but still as you come into the first room, the sight of these masterpieces can either take your breath away or make you cry, or both. The experience is a bit like seeing the DAVID in Florence: there is nothing else in the world like it! Go there by all means!

Add l'Orangerie first. Buy pass, see art, then D'Orsay and Louvre.. Just the Monet water lilies rooms would be worth the excellent rating. A bonus to see the rest of the exhibit of the collection of the noted Parisian art dealer. Charming redone museum. Easy to buy museum pass here to skip the lines at D'Orsay and Louvre.

My favorite!. This is my favorite museum in Paris, and not just because of the eight enormous canvases of Monet's Waterlilies series, shown as Monet planned. Although that IS the reason to go to this museum. But don't miss the collection of modern art downstairs. It includes some very fine works from Renoir, Cezanne and Picasso that are well worth seeing. What I enjoyed most, though, was the large variety of painting by Andre Derain, which show how many different styles he tried. There's also an excellent collection of Chaim Soutine and five wonderful pieces from Marie Laurencin. I visited this museum twice in six days and loved every minute of it. Do not miss it. Try to go during the week so you are not crowded out of the Waterlilies. Take time to sit and meditate there. It's why Monet painted those painting after all. Very peaceful and well worth the time.If you're going to the Musee d'Orsay, too, (and you should), then buy the combo pass. It will save you a little money and let you go back to both museums more than once.
Monet in the round. The fantastic Monet waterlilies are well worth a visit. You can combine this with a visit to another museum since it doesn't take long to see.
Breathtaking Monets. The opportunity to view these enormous Monets was breathtaking. Go early before the crowds for maximum benefit
breathtaking... If you love Monet, you will love this little museum. I can sit here and just look at the paintings for hours...

You've got to experience it for yourself. The 360 degree visual of Monet's Lilies in two separate rooms is something I've always wanted to see....and I was NOT disappointed. Just fantastic! Beautiful! Don't miss!

Magnificent Collection of Impressionism. I am a huge fan of Impressionism and this museum gave me an education. The collection coming from a single donor is incredible. I was of course familiar with Monet and his huge nymphae collection, but I was even more impressed by the collection. I was of course already familiar with Renoir and Cezanne but there were a number of paintings I had never seen before. I was introduced to Chaim Soutine, Derain, Utrillo, and earlier works by Picasso. An experience not to be missed.

Monet's Water Lilies. Prepared to be blown away by Monet's huge murals featuring his famous water lilies from his garden in Giverny. Buy a dual ticket for the l'Orangerie and the Musee d'Orsay and skip the line-up at the latter. There's no wait at l'Orangerie.

Surprising gem. We only went here becasue we got a joint ticket with the Musee D'Orsay and it was raining but we're very glad we did. The water lilly rooms are fantastic and the rest of the paintings made the visit really worthwhile.

Monet in the Round. Twice!. Having visited Monet's gardens and house in Giverny earlier in the week, we relished the opportunity to see Les Nympheas (Water Lilies) as displayed in two separate elliptical rooms in Musee de l"Orangerie. What an amazing experience. There is a circular bench in the center of each room, where you are encouraged to sit and marvel at the magical presentation of light and color arrayed before you. Take your time, and move around to different sections of the bench to fully appreciate what Monet has done. When you look at the works up close, they appear to be globs of color, but step back, and be entranced by the transformation. This is one of those experiences where you have to be there to appreciate it. The art on the lower floor, the Walter-Guillaume collection, is also very much worth your time. There are works by Picasso, Derain, Renoir, and Cezanne. All are wonderful works. But the Water Lilies are why you are there. See them first. Then, see them again.

Quiet but beautiful. I recommend buying the two-museum pass when visiting d'Orsay, and make a side trip to this little gem when you have a little time afterwards. I visited this museum on the morning of my flight departure and that was enough time. It's a lot quieter than d'Orsay, lot less people, but the collection is very impressive, Monet's lilies in two oval rooms are breathtaking. Given how un-crowded this museum is, you can really sit down and admire those two masterpieces in peace.
Monet madness. Great collection of Monet and especially nice if you have seen where Monet had painted these masterpieces and planned for them to be here

A must see. One of my favorite spots in Paris! The room for Water Lillies is breathtaking, and the museum downstairs is just as enticing. Even the giftshop is great! Don't forget to see the Rodin sculptures outside.

Monet's Murals Are Just Part of the Attraction. A wonderful venue and small enough not to overwhelm visitors. The Monet murals are amazing. Because the museum is off the beaten track, it doesn't have huge crowds. The other art works represented are also worth the visit.

Impressionism Nirvana (almost). Don't go unless you want to be absolutely blown away by overwhelmingly great impressionist painting. I only wish there were a few more van Gogh's. But then, the Musee D'Orsay is just down the street that.

My passion for Monet. If you, like me, just love Monet artwork, this is a must see. It's small and has just a few rooms, most of them showing the gorgeous and eternal giant paintings of Monet and its gardens. I loved it

Monet Surprise! And then some!. We started out the day looking to visit the more famous Musee D'orsay, but after discovering a 2+ hour wait, we found ourselves at the Musee de l'Orangerie. We got right in and not only did we get to see some amazing Monet's we were impressed by a number of legendary artists also on display. A must see.

Water Lillies! That's it?. Monet Water Lillies. That's all worth visiting for. Most visitors will just sit on the oval bench in the centre to make the most out of the ticket price. It's only a snippet of one of Monet's many pieces so although you can marvel at its expanse and Monet's vision, the experience only moves you momentarily, making you ask for more, with answers at Museum Marmottan Monet.

Impressionism!. A must-see for Monet's Water Lilies! Lots of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings. Small museum, easy to do. On the edge of the Tuileries, Place de la Concorde, Seine and across the river from Musee d'Orsay.

Lovely Little Museum. Musee de l'Orangerie is a lovely little museum. It is not crowded at all, like some of the others. We went to this museum to get our Paris Museum Pass. So easy, because we didn't have to wait in line. Because it is not crowded, you can really see and study the artwork--fabulous paintings by Monet, Renoir, Cezanne, Gauguin and many others. One of the nicest parts is that there were short biographies and explanations in both French and English. I would highly recommend getting the Paris Museum Pass at a small museum like this, and then using the pass at the more popular museums to bypass the long lines.

Waterlilies. This museum is a must-see, just for Monet's "Waterlilies". The main attraction are these paintings that span the whole length of several rooms. They are wonderful examples of Impressionist art and are awe-inspiring. This museum was included on Musee Pass on this visit. On a previous trip, we had to pay a separate admission to get into this museum so we were pleasantly surprised this time.

Water Lilies and more. Fortunately, this past Sunday, the museum offered a reduced rate for Heritage Days (les Jours de Patrimoine). Surprisingly, there was a very small line-up and the galleries were not overcrowded. For anyone interested in seeing Monet's work as he wished it to be seen, this gallery is superb. But, besides the very popular Monet murals, there is a large collection of works by Cézanne, Matisse, Modigliani, Picasso, Renoir and others.Also, if you are a lover of Monet, remember to visit the Musée Marmottan Monet, with a much larger collection of his works.
Monet fans only. There are way way way better galleries to visit in Paris. Only go here if its the free Sunday in the month or you are hopelessly devoted to Monet.

Don't miss this!. We had heard that the Monet paintings were closed without explanation during our stay in Paris, and then on that last weekend, those two galleries re-opened. Having just been to Giverny a few days before made the viewing of Monet's large canvases even more meaningful. It was one of the highlights of our entire trip.

Not really worth it unless you love Monet's lilies. I tried really hard to sit peacefully for a while and find the water lilies inspiring,but just they just didn't move me. Perhaps that means I am uncultured, I don't know, but they just didn't do it for me. There were however some very impressive early Picasso works in the other part of this museum that I found to be very impressive. I guess what I am saying is, if you aren't a huge fan of Monet's lilies, and you don't have a ton of time in Paris, I would probably skip this museum. Spend more time at the Louvre instead.

Monet's Waterlilies. This is a great little museum that houses Monet's Waterlilies murals. There are two rooms with eight large murals. They are magnificient. Even though the admission is pricey at 18 euros, don't miss this museum. If you are in Paris for 2-4 days you can buy a museum pass at any of the mussums. It can be used for most of the museums. I paid $64 for my 4 day pass.

Very nice collection. Most noted for the Monet murals that are obviously special, the other collections are most enjoyable. Particularly liked the Renoirs and Utrillos. Get a joint ticket for here and the D'Orsay.

Rainy day getaway. 9 euros for a ticket which is extremely reasonable as the museum is smaller and an hour to two would be sufficient. Monet's artwork is truly breathtaking and the two rooms are worth seeing. It is also interesting to see work of other artists that Monet knew/studied with. The building itself is modern and simple which enhances the experience.

Water Lilies anyone?. I was surprised at the line to get into this place. It's not a huge museum, but what it lacks in size it more than makes up for in quality. Of course 8 of Monet's Water Lilies is the main draw, and has been since 1920.But there is so much more to see.And the cafe isn't that bad (return your plastic cup and get a Euro back).
Monet in the round. If you like Monet this is a must see. The long panels are a sight that cannot be missed if you like Monet.
Small but Amazing. It's a small museum but everything in side is just amazing, the paintings beautiful and you can get bored here if you love art!

Great pieces of artwork on display - smaller museum. Sadly the Waterlillies exhibit was closed when we went so that was a huge disappointment. I believe it opened up again on September 18, however, I was excited to see my first Picasso in person. The museum is quite small though so don't plan to spend too much time here compared to some of the other museums.
Place of Reflection. The place where you can sit and reflect on the world and your views of nature. Generally a place of silence and contemplation.

Loved it. It is a small museum but worth it!. After the long lines and crowds at the Louvre, this was a very pleasant surprise. It was a pleasure to view. There are two rooms of murals by Monet. The water lily's are impressive. When travelling with teens, it was the perfect size and relaxed atmosphere. It wasn't crowded when we visited. You have to check your bags on the way in and you cannot take pictures of Monet's work. They have a very nice gift shop where we all purchased something.

In the middle of Monet's lilly pond. Musee de l'Orangerie is within walking distance of the Louvre and Quai d'Orsay. The Musee's collection is on two floors. The lower floor has painting from the personal collection of Paul Guillaume the first to collect and sell Impressionists' work. There is even a model of his apartment showing where each work hung in his home.But what makes l'Orangerie really extraordinary is the upper floor. It consists of two large oval rooms, designed by Monet, and containing, in each room 4 large, not to say, very large painting of lilies. Benches are provided in the center of the rooms. One can easily sit on a bench fell that one is sitting in the middle of one of Monet's paintings surrounded by his lilies.This museum is a must see when in Paris.

No review as we couldn't get in. We had to queue and they were only letting in visitors with pre purchased tickets. The queue did not move so we had to leave to catch our Eurostar train. Very disappointing.

If you love Monet this is an absolte must. This is two rooms of brilliant murals bt Monet. Don't expect hundreds of paintings, you will be dissapointed. But if you expect 15 Metre murals you will be thrilled. you can get close to them or sit and contemplate them. We were lucky it was pouring rain the day (Wednesday) we went so not so many people, It is not open on Monday or Tuesday and is Euro9.50 per person. There are toilets so you can spend plenty of time there.There are also some Renoir, Picasso anf many other peices downstairs from Monet. There is a lift for the mobility challenged. It is only a short stroll from Concorde Metro station. There is a cafe on site as well as a gift shop.

Beautiful and quick.. Musee de l'Orangerie is a very small and fast museum to view. The crowds aren't crazy (or at least they weren't when we were there). We arrived fairly early and it was our first museum which was good. I would think if you kept it to the end it might be disappointing compared to the other larger musuems.

A great place to know impresionism. We just came for the Nympheas by Monet and was happy to learn a lot more on impresionism with numerous paintings by other artists. The sourvenir shop is fantastic. You also can have a combined ticket with musee D'orsay.
Musee de l'Orangerie. We were so glad that we went to see the Musee de l'Orangerie after having read and heard about if for such a long time.
Amazing . This was an amazing visit. Beautiful . A must see in Paris. A joy for everyone young and old to see .
An audio guided tour. This is magic ! The presentation and organization has no equal. Not too busy and good for a couple of hours .

Don't miss this museum. This was my favorite museum in Paris. It was included on the museum pass and it was so quiet and lovely. After the crowds at the Louvre and D'Orsay, this museum was so refreshing. Just sitting and relaxing with the water lillys.
One word of warning though, there are gypsies outside.
Go to the Orsay. We were disappointed in this museum, I though we would see more impressionist, also the Monet was closed the day we were there.

Monet Magic!. One of the best museums in Paris ... fascinating choice of pictures ... and the Monets really special. If you get one of those tickets that enable you to see several places you can get in without having to join a long queue (if you don't visit this museum first, that is). Another 'must see' when in Paris!

Best of Monet in one short visit.. Very well displayed huge Monet water lilies displayed in two huge oval shaped rooms. Takes your breath away. Just when you think you have seen enough go downstairs to theprivate collection of Reniors, Picassos and many others on display. What a good find!

Waterlilies was closed.... We went and the Waterlilies display was closed. As it was the last day of my museum pass, we were not able to see it. Maybe I will get back to Paris one day and see it. Disappointed that I did not get to see it.

My favorite Paris musuem. If you love Monet don't miss this amazing exhibit. To see his work on the large canvases is a must. It was wonderful to sit on the long benches and just observe. You can get close enough to see every brush stroke and far enough away to be awed by by his beautiful gardens.

Originally built to shelter orange trees, now shelters priceless art.. Two oval shaped rooms on the main floor ar devoted to Monet's Water Lillies. Beautifully presented with impeccable lighting. Bottom floor has extensive collection of Renoir, Matisse, early Picasso, Cezanne, among others. This is a must see.

Extremely rude staff but amazing art!. I personally love this place. I've been here few times but the rudeness of the staff was really shocking this summer. I came with a friend in a Sunday morning, no queues at all, but towards lunch time it started to be full and the staff was shouting and screaming at the people who came "too close" to the paintings. Including at a partially blind lady that was trying to understand what she was seeing. Awful.
Charming. Beautiul paintings in charming place.After seeing collections you can eat and drinc in caffe or buy nice souvenir in museum shop.

Great museum with amazing Monets. We stopped in after the line for the Louvre was insanely long. Glad we did! It's best known for the two oval rooms with Monet's water lilies. Downstairs there are other well known impressionists. A nice, real overly small museum that you can reasonably walk through in a couple of hours. Definitely worth a trip.
Can't miss. This was amazing and if you have Paris Pass short line. It does not take as long as some of the other museums. The bottom floor has other artists
What's not to like about Monsieur Monet?. I thought my heart was going to stop beating when I walked into the room and the walls were covered with Monet's Water Lilies. It was spectacular.

Monet's Water Lilies are on display here. This is a museum that is manageable. The size of the museum is not indicative of the quality of the art collection. The highlight for me was viewing Monet's "Water Lilies" panels, spanning two large rooms. Many Renoir works as well.

Not a top tier museum. The Orangerie has been redesigned in early bomb shelter style, and is one of the ugliest buildings in Paris, once you get inside. The Nympheas actually looks better on the web than it does on the walls, mostly because the pictures are so large that it's difficult to get the overall impression. The other parts of the collection are more interesting, although rather eclectic.
Monet <3. The Monet murals were simply breathtaking. The set was was wonderful for observation and reflection.
Amazing. I cannot wait to go back!! Don't miss the interesting gallery downstairs, and be sure to look up the history of the donors!

Good museum, Lilies is closed until mid September. Disappointed that the Water Lilies exhibit was closed, but we went right before closing on free museum day (first Sunday of each month), so we can't complain much. I really like smaller focused museums like this with a nice selection of Monet and a few Picasso, Matisse, Renoir, and Rosseau paintings. This way you can see and really absorb everything in little more than an hour before you get too tired.

HGuge Monets. We went to see the Monets which were magnificent and worth seeing. The building is beautiful too. Go early as there seems to be always a queue to get in. There are Renoir and other well known artists works on show

A special museum stop. After you have explored Musee d'Orsay, this should be your next stop. Here, we used an audio guide which worked well. Fortunately, we were able to view Monet's water lily panels before this special room was closed for renovation.Great scarves in the gift shop!

Valentines in Paris . I loved, My fiancé loved even more he went back another day.
Buy the musium pass.
Take time to sit and truly see the beauty and granduer.

Somewhat disappointed. It was a let down due to the water lilies exhibition being closed when we went.
However, the other collections were still worth a look if you love impressionist paintings.

Beautiful, peaceful small museum.. Got to see just after the reopening of the Water Lilies. It's spectacular. Beautifully displayed and presented. There is a wonderful collection of Impressionistic paintings in the lower level.
Go here first and buy a combination ticket to the d'Orsay across the river. Then you can walk across the bridge and cut the line since you already have a ticket.

Cutest museum in Paris. It goes without saying that Claude Monet's Les Nymphéas are breathtaking. There are two large rooms to view them. They are larger and more beautiful than any picture. The other artists within the museum (Picasso, Guillame, Walter for a few) have wonderful pieces to view. It's a great size of a museum that you have plenty of time to take it all in as well as take part in other activities in the day.

Beautiful. I had no idea that Monet's Water Lilies painting was actually several painintngs taking up 2 whole rooms. The paintings are massive. They wrap around 2 oval shaped rooms and are nearly the height of the room. You really can't appreciate it unless you see it. This definitely worth a stop on your way to the more famous Louvre.

My favorite museum!. This gem of a museum is not to be missed!if you have any love for Monet you must visit! The lighting is beautiful and really showcases the art. If the benches were more comfortable, I could stay there all day!
Favorite art museum in Paris. Intimate gallery offers a stunning presentation of Monet's water-lilies and other paintings. Not crowded like the Louvre.

I visited to see Matisse!. Everyone comes here to see the Monets. Not me. So I wasn't disappointed when the special Monet rooms were closed for the day, as it made it a very peaceful day to admire the several Matisses they have in the collection. But, the entire collection is lovely. If you are an art lover, it's a must (after Musee D'Orsay, Pompidou -- and, if you feel the need to tackle it, the Louvre.)

Disappointed. We were disappointed in the Musee de l'Orangerie as it had it's Water Lillies collection in renovation while we were there, which was the only reason we were visiting it in the first place.We did go the first Sunday of the month for free and didn't even have to wait in line, which was a perk, so no real loss there.

Perfect Visit. We spent two very enjoyable hours here today (Sept. 12). The Monet water lilies is open. The audio guide provides valuable insight. The museum is small and well laid out. Very glad to discover the Russian artist Soutine whom I was not familiar with. Really enjoyed his work! Also there were no tour groups or guides distracting from the enjoyment! The Musée de l'Orangerie is an art gallery of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings located in the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde in Paris. Most famous for being the permanent home for eight Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet, the museum also contains works by Cézanne, Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Picasso, Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo, among others.

Wonderful smaller museum. We primarily visited the Walter-Guillaume collection, since the large Monet viewing rooms were closed (the sign said they would re-open Sept 12, 2015 -- a definite disappointment for us). However, the impressionist works collected primarily by art dealer Paul Guillaume were impressive. Saw many favorites and enjoyed discovering a few artists who were unknown to us. A far different experience than the Louvre, this museum can be enjoyed at a leisurely pace.The Paris Museum Pass (highly recommended) grants you admission to this museum, and there is a separate line for guests with the pass (or pre-purchased tickets).
Worth the visit. Worth the visit to see the large water lilly paintings. Not a large museum but there is a impressive collection.
Disappointed. The main attraction, Monet's water lilies exibition was closed. Very disappointed. Took all of ten minutes to see.

cool and inviting. Not to be missed, cool an inviting building showcasing some cool and inviting paintings. I was surprised at the size of them. Well worth the visit, but dont neglect the park outside which is also a very pelasant place to be, especially by the lake.

Don't miss the emotional center of Impressionism!. On our first trip to Paris in 2009, we missed this gem. This trip, we visited Giverny on the way into Paris, so we were determined to find the Water Lillies display. The building was built specifically to house Monet's famous paintings, and they are in two very large oval rooms. It is very impressive to stand in the middle of the oval and look at the paintings. I would suggest to go early to the museum, close to opening time, so that you can stand back to appreciate the whole painting without people walking in front.

Not Much When Water Lilly Display Closed. Not Much to see with Water Lilly Display Closed in beginning of Sept 2015. A small sign at the entrance stated the display was closed which explained the lack of a line at the entrance. If we did not have a Paris Museum pass that allowed us a free admission, we would not have entered. The small display in the basement of the building took less than an hour to view all the pieces. Very disappointing.

Most disappointing. We came to see the Monet large water lily paintings. For some unexplained reason, they were not available for viewing for a two week period, Visitors were notified of this with a crudely hand lettered sign on cardboard at the desk. Not exactly what one would expect from a major Paris museum..

Go to see the water-lillies even if you don't like art. Two huge rooms with water lilies are really very impressive.The down stairs rooms of the museum are also full with wonderfull pieces of arts.My favourite museum in Paris.
Museum to visit. Small museum located in the corner of the Japin Des Tuilieries. Worth the visit. Exhibits mainly Paintings fropm the late 19th C.

Lovely Collection that can be viewed in under two hours.. Very interesting and succinct collection. The audio tour was especially enlightening. Monet's Lillies were unavailable but still worth the trip.
Awesome. Awesome Impressionist museum . Must see in Paris, unfortunately the big Water Lilly's paintings were closed. :(

Monet Comes Alive. The panels were breathtaking. Be sure to visit if you love Monet.
This was a surprising treasure and with enough time and patience you could see the lilies and willows.

GREAT, even though The Water Lillies were closed.. Sadly, the Monet Water Lillies were closed when we visited (closed until Sept 12th). However, the rest of the paintings in the museum are outstanding.
We recommend getting the audioguide, it will add greatly to your visit.
Water Lilies!. Like Monet's Water Lilies, which are well presented on huge oval rooms. The museum is a little small but good.

Serenity. Stepping into the first round room was almost a spiritual experience. It's beauty brought tears to my eyes. You can look a square foot at a time and see colors and shades different from your last view. Such a gift to the world.

Take a morning or afternoon. Lots and lots of Monet's water lilies, which are of course gorgeous, but it was the chance to become acquainted with lesser known artists which truly delighted me. The museum is very small, so you have a wonderful opportunity to browse without feeling rushed.

More interesting museums near by.. Unfortunately the Monet gallery was closed so there was little else to see.
Close to Muse D Orcy which is fantastic.
Small but enjoyable. This museum was small but there were many great artists. It took about 1 hour for us to see everything. Unfortunately, the water lily exhibit was closed.

Great place for art lovers!. Once you have been around the gardens, you must go into the Orangerie Museum! Some of the last works by Monet are housed in two purpose built oval rooms - huge murals of his lily ponds and surrounds, donated in memory of WW 1 losses. After that are lots more works of art in the basement, and a good cafe. Buy a combined ticket for Musee d'Orsay at the same time and save money

Monet plus 25 renoirs in a row. we make it a point to go every time we are in Paris and irs wonderful. starts with the famous Monet water lilies then down to a collection of many impressionist. along one wall are 25 Renoirs in a row, eye filling and will fill your craving for his form and color

Water lilly exhibit closed. The water lilly exhibit is currently closed for renovation. There only one other small exhibit at the museum, so it is not worth the entrance fee unless you have the paris museum pass.
Top Paris museum for Impressionsits. sadly the Monet's were not available to view but the rest is really very impressive. Lots of Renoir's and others displayed really well.
Quite and nice musseum. Payed a visit some time ago and enjoyed the exposution. Mysseum is not a very big one though have a nice painting collection. Not crowded, quite silent and relaxing.

Small but beautiful museum. The two oval rooms with Monet's works are jaw dropping. We took our three kids there, and they enjoyed them too. It is easy, quick and beautiful. We went the day before we went to Giverny, but probably better for kids to go afterwards if possible.

Lovely small museum. The highlight of this museum is Monet's enormous waterlilies. Having been to Giverney the day before, we really wanted to see them. The rest of the collection is was a nice surprise. Many artists that I was unfamiliar with and the history of the collection was an interesting story. We had a light breakfast here beforehand. They have fresh squeezed orange juice which was a treat. However the coffee was terrible--tasted like hot water.
Just to kill time. You should visit this museum ONLY if You have the time, if not, be sure You can skip it and nothing will happen.
Beautiful Monet water lillies. Its worth a visit just to see the giant Monet water lillies on the curved walls. Absolutely stunning.
