Absolutely brilliant!. We so loved our time at this museum. The display of Monet's Water Lillies in two rooms in a circular format was spectacular! Nice benches to sit and marvel at Monet's masterpieces also. It was a thoroughly enjoyable visit and if in Paris again would return to this museum...it is one of a kind!Covered under the Paris Museum Pass. Small security line. We had a 15 min wait to enter.
Muse de l'Orangerie. We were thankful to have a guide to give us more depth to our experience. There aren't so many paintings so it is not an overwhelming experience.

l'Orangerie - good impression. The Monet section was closed, unfortunately, but the rows of Renoirs are impressive as are the works of Cezanne, Sisley, Gauguin and an artist I was not familiar with - Chaim Soutine.

Monet exhibit closed. A small museum worth going for the I'm impressionist on display, unfortunately the monet exhibit was closed and of course that is the main reason to go, but was free with our museum pass so still worth the time.

Relaxing art gallery. This is a much smaller art gallery than most but it is very relaxing to walk around. Not as frenetic as some of the others. Don't suffer from art overload. Much more relaxing than the Louvre or D'Orsay.
Small but amazing. Probably the smallest museum in the city but still one of the best. Lots of wonderful artworks can be found here! For free for european under 26.

Monet Water Lillies Closed until Mid-September. Superb museum, but we were saddened when we brought our friends there, only to learn that the Monet galleries were closed for a couple of weeks. Hopefully, this review will spare others the wasted trip.
Incredible. Tiny museum, and huge line (what else did I expect in August) but well worth the wait to see the Water Lilies! Absolutely breathtaking.
No water lilies right now!. The Monet water lilies are under construction so check before you come. Disappointing not to see them
Don't Miss It!. Less crowded than the other museums and the Monet's are a must see. Don't miss this museum on your visit.

Waterlily and others worthy watching. Went there on a rainy day, just watching the waterlily paintings made me calm, in the downstairs area they had a great selection of other paintings also worthy of visiting.

Amazing for Monet's waterlilies alone. For the beautiful Monet waterlily paintings alone this place is worth 5 stars. They are in two, specially designed rooms. You can get right up to close to them and they surround you. Amazing. Downstairs they also have a large collection of various other paintings collected by two local art dealers. Lovely, understated place.

Amazing room filled with Monet's waterlillies and much more.. Huge walls covered with Monet's water lilies (Les Nymphéas)--what more could you ask for? Well, many more Impressionist masters and post-Impressionists including Picasso, Gaugain and Cezanne. A must see.
Don't miss this!. Wouldn't have missed it. Peaceful and relaxing sitting looking at the very long paintings of Monet. Strictly no photo taking allowed. No queues when we visited.
A little disappointing. Worth a visit only after the Louvre and Musee D' Orsay. Monet's lilies and a few other worthwhile pieces.

Monet on a grand scale!. WOW!!! Monet on a grand scale! Two rooms at the top take your breath away and there's even more art to delight on the lower floor. Do not miss this gem hidden away in one corner of the Jardin de Tuileries.

Monet and More. It was a cold, wet late August day that let more like October than summer when we waited patiently to enter L'Orangerie. One cannot appreciate the breadth of vision of Monet until one sees the full dimensions of the water lilly series of paintings he created in Giverny. We had driven right past Giverny the day we arrived on our route to Rouen, but the heavy rain that day deterred us from stopping. So we felt like L'Orangerie was not a bad substitute.

not to be missed. Seeing how we already liked Orsay museum a lot, we wanted to continue our exploration of the impressionism era and this museum was the next logical thing to do. Much smaller but with great art - we liked it a lot.

Unique art exhibits. Great museum that is small and warm. Your museum pass won't buy you a shorter line, but will get you in. Don't forget to go downstairs to see the Renoirs after you marvel at the Monets on the main floor.

Monet center-stage, in a beautiful space. This museum was absolutely fantastic. So I'm perplexed why others here said there wasn't much there. Perhaps they missed the lower level, which has about 250 additional paintings. The museum is located at the south-western end of the Jardin des Tuileries, not too far from the Louvre.The centerpieces for me were the two oval rooms on the first (ground) floor showcasing several of Monet's water lilies. I was surprised to see these so large, wall sized. The presentation in the oval rooms, with an oval sitting couch at the center, lets each painting stretch into your peripheral vision. Sitting quietly, especially if you come early morning before the crowds, you can imagine yourself sitting at a pond with his lilies. The Waterlily exhibits were designed specifically for and by Monet, to show his grandest works. This is how he wanted them seen.And while Impressionism is a highlight here, many other periods and styles are represented too -- from Picasso's cubist and earlier works, to Rembrandt, to lesser known international artists. I enjoyed this museum because of its scale -- not too large, not too small. Art aficionados can see it in about 2 hours, or only 30-minutes for someone wanting an Impressionism fix.Go for the beautiful expressive presentations of Monet's masterpieces. And if you're truly interested in Monet, his last house is in the village of Giverny (town of Vernon) an hour northwest of Paris. It's an easy escape into the countryside of France. The waterlilies pond on his property is absolutely superb -- it really looks like his paintings. Worth a visit if you have half a day (last admission at 5pm). If you plan to go to both, the l'Orangerie offers a discount off both tickets. While his house in Giverny doesn't accept the Paris Museum Pass, the Musee de l'Orangerie does and is definitely worth a stop.OPEN:9am - 5:45pm everyday except Tuesdays (closed 1st-May, 14-Jul, 25-Dec)FEES:Free if you bought the Paris Museum PassFree for children 18 or underFree to everyone the 1st Sunday of each month (but it's more crowded)€10 for adults (note: ages 18-26 can be free or at reduced rate of €6.50)WEBSITE: http://www.musee-orangerie.fr/ (click "English" on top-right)GUIDEBOOK: http://www.musee-orangerie.fr/documents/plan_guide_EN_%20juin14.pdf

Worth a visit for artlovers. Lot of artwork from great painters. You can spend a lot of time here enjoying countless artwork. This is a must see museum for art lovers and you can easily spend at least half a day here. This is part of the great Paris Pass.
For Monet fans. This is a must see for Monet fans. The first time visitor will be awed. On a second visit several years later after having been to Giverny it was enjoyable.
More than Monet. Here you can see Monet's big interpretations of his Giverny garden. There are also many other great paintings on display. Well worth a visit.

Monet's My Favourite. I love Monet's paintings, so this was a real treat, the walls of the two oval rooms in the museum, contain Monets Water Lilies, which were painted for the gallery, each panel has different tones to them, which I was told depicts different times of the day.If you have a chance, go and visit Monets house and gardens at Giverny, which is about an hour out of Paris, it will make you appreciate his talent even more.The museum is not just Monet, but a lot of other artists from the impressionist period.Get a Paris Museum Pass, it saves a lot of time and gets you through a lot of doors.
Big Monet Fan. This is an incredible exhibit - make sure you have plenty of time to sit and enjoy it - buy your tickets online to beat the crowds

Wonderful l'Orangerie Museum. The l'Orangerie Museum is wonderful. The Monet lilies are so impressive. Take time to enjoy all the lilies! Then more enjoyment on the lower level with 25 or more Renoirs and many other paintings to appreciate. This museum is not very large but is so memorable. Enjoy! This museum is on the Paris Museum Pass.
Monet Spectacular. I never knew how big the Monet paintings were until I visited this museum. Beautiful works of art were shown.

The Third Paris Art Museum. Though not quite in the same league as the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay, l'Orangerie is well worth a visit. The building, which once house orange trees during winter, was converted specifically to house several large water lily paintings by Monet. In addition to the Monet paintings, which are surely worth a visit in themselves, there is a nice display of Impressionist paintings; the large group of paintings by Renoir is especially noteworthy.

Disappointing but loved some of the art. Unsure if I was just disappointed because of the wealth of opportunity in Paris but found this gallery very poor. Very small and with little artistic variety it was made worse by a rude person on reception.
Doesn't take long to get through and worth it.. Much easier to see everything and worth it if you are into Impressionism. Mainly Monet, surprise, surprise. But others represented.

Not sure about this one.... I was looking for a short line, inexpensive museum in Paris. This fit the bill, especially since I was interested in seeing the Monet Waterlilies. Unfortunately, we didn't think there was enough other exhibits to make the visit interesting. I'll admit that I'm not a huge art connoisseur, so others may disagree, but as long as you are in Paris, you are much better off with the Louvre, or Orsay.

Immersed in Monet. The pond landscapes by Monet that take up the walls of two large oval rooms on the top floor are spectacular. You feel like you swim in the images. Spectacular. The collections downstairs have a good range of artists and are well chosen to juxtapose the similarities and differences in their styles. At one point it was a wonderful to have very similar landscapes by Monet, Renoir, Sisley and Gaugin all lined up right next to each other to easily compare them.
Well worthwhile. Fantastic museum, highly recommended.For those that love monet and his water lilies and equally for those that have never heard of it.

Water Lily - Monet at his best.. Monet's water lily panels are absolutely amazing. You can sit in the center of the room surrounded by the panels and just take it all in. Very awe inspiring. Museum pass lets you skip the ticket buying line. This is a must if you are a Monet fan.

Stunning museum. Compared to the Musee d'Orsay or the Louvre, this museum is pocket-sized. But what a pocket!. The row of Renoirs are a stand out, as are the Monet water lilies. Cezanne, Sisley, Gauguin and Picasso are well represented here. Many of the paintings have commentaries (if you have hired an audio guide) - many more than other museums I have visited. Stroll around the Tuileries, then visit this museum - it will be an unforgettable experience!

Exceeded my expaectations. Very nice place, surprisingly good! Went there mainly to see Monet's Water Lilies but, going down stairs, I was surprised by an incredible collection of other great impressionist painters. The value is very good considering the collection
Monet at a grand scale. If you like Monet then the orange ride is a must, just to see the scale of the pictures. If you have been to Giverny then this is really worth it

My favourite museum. I absolutely loved this museum. We had purchased the dual tickets for the Musee D'Orsay which saved money. Purchased our tickets from CDG airport travel information bureau which was quick and easy and saved us hours in the queues.
Could not possibly be disappointed.. The first floor of the Monet garden paintings are phenomenal.And, all of the floor below is also a must see.
Orangerie. Orangerie is always great to see. Check for days of free entrance before you go! A beautiful collection of Impressionism!
Worth a visit. We sprinted through most of the museum as it was getting close to closing time, but the two rooms housing the water lilies were great to experience.
Go for the Monet. The large Monet's are beautiful.. but they are really the only "big name" / exciting thing here. If you want a larger overview of Impressionist painting be sure to go to d'Orsay.

Lovely museum. You can seat hear for hours and meditate in front of the amazing painting. The only thing - you can't take pictures of it or of yourself, the guard will immediately ask you to stop because, I don't know why, it's forbidden in oval halls. It the other halls you can photoshoot.

This place necessarily to visit!!. It's really great museum . You should take the audioguide, it will give you a lot of interesting information. I'm sure everyone should visit this place. The paintings of great artists inspired me. To view all work slowly you needed 2-3 hours. Go there and enjoying))

Wonderful Museum. This museum is small in comparison to most museums in Paris, but it is definitely worth the time. Seeing Monet's Water Garden and Water Lilys was the highlight of our trip to Paris. Since it is a smaller museum, you won't need to allocate an entire day to it.
Very relaxing. Nice and cool inside, not to crowded, had free seating outside with lovely view and a nice breeze, great for a nap

Monet's Masterpieces. Walked around the Tuileries then stopped by here to the oval room to see Monet's lily pond. Compared it to his garden in Giverny next day and realized what a genius he is. Breathtaking!

Beautiful but frustrated. We came to enjoy the water lilies and they were beautiful indeed. What was absolutely frustrating were all the people shooting selfies in front of the paintings, and then moving on! Not one or two, but many. They didn't even turn around to take in the beauty and history behind them. They just needed that selfie show their friends they were there. Unfortunately for us, it got under our skin enough that we cut our visit short. We still saw what we came to see. We just didn't enjoy our time as much.
Monet, personally.... When you go downstairs to see Monet's famed murals, you suddenly feel like you are near water: it's nice and cool and so very handsome.

Only if you're interested. Before i start i will just say that i have no interest in art.My wife on the other hand does and she said it was fantastic. she was chuffed to see Monet's,Renoir's and Picasso's.

Beautiful. This is one of my favorite Museum's in Paris. The Waterlilies are displayed as they were meant to be seen. It is awe inspiring to walk into the oval rooms with Monet's work. There is a small private collection downstairs as well. This would be a good museum for kids and for people who have a limited attention span for art. It isn't overly large, but big enough to spend longer in if you desire to sit and admire works. It works well to buy the dual ticket with the Orsay at the Orangerie and visit the Orsay after. The lines to purchase tickets tend to be longer there.

Monet's Water Lilies. Monet's water lilies are huge! Just being there, sitting looking at the water lilies was worth it. It is a get a way from all the crowds at the Louvre. Just a short walk from the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay.
Go If you like the Lilies. Not crowded, short and sweet but go after 5pm, can do it in an hour and it is cheaper unless you have museum pass which is highly recommended.
Must See for Monet Fans. Visited primarily to see Monet's Les Nympheas (sp?) and the Guillaume collections - well worth it to stop by.

Gem in the Tuleries. Some brilliant paintings by various artists as well as the fantastic Monet murals. The paintings are in the building designed and built to display them, and it has been recently modernised and improved. My only negative is that there is very little written information about the paintings in the museum and one is forced to hire an audio guide. That having been said, the audio guide's information on the paintings was very helpful and informative.

Monet Mania. This is a beautifully well laid out space where you can see the large scale works of Monet (The water lilies) in well lit rooms. There are also other sections where you can catch a glimpse of a Modigliani, a Picasso or a Renoir.

More than Manet. Manet's large murals of waterlilies dominate two rooms, but there are many more paintings also worth viewing. A much more intimate gallery than many others. Worth visiting first thing to avoid the crowds.

Emotionally moving. to be in the rooms surrounded by Monet's work was breathtaking and moving. these works are just amazing, and can be absorbed from so many angles. there is no way to encapsulate the genius but instead be encapsulated by it.

Incredible Monet murals and significant French Impressionist collectoon. With only a few hours to spend on our last morning, we decided to visit this museum because they had Monet's Water Lilies. Well it turned out to be so much more than we expected. The museum has 2 galleries that were built specifically for these magnificent murals. The galleries are oval shaped with 4 large walls with each totally covered with a mural. Words and photos cannot describe the beauty. The rest of the museum is loaded with significant French Impressionist work by many artists that you will recognize (Renoir, Cezanne, etc.). Definitely worth a few hours and far less crowded than some of the better know museums that are just walking distance away.
Museum of worth. We visited givereny and then came here. Not many take the time but it has a great selection of 19th 20th century art and is much easier to navigate than the louvre

Great experience . We visited this museum along with the Orsay and the Louvre. This was our favorite. Not being art aficionados, but having an appreciation for it, we really enjoyed the Monet and Renoir paintings. This museum is smaller and easy to navigate. Less crowded, and at the edge of the Tuilerie Gardens. We visited here after a picnic lunch in the Tuileries.Highly recommend.

Wha a great way to get away and enjoy art without the crowds of the Louvre.. If you want to really enjoy a day looking at art this is the place to go. No crowds, no hassle. Only Monet and a few other notables. We were so relieved to be able to get up close to these wonderful works of art. We discovered Wendt and a few other artist that get to shine with out the hustle and bustle of the larger museums. Treat yoursel to a relaxing day at the museum de l'Orangerie.
Water lilies. Monet's water lilies are the star of this museum, encompass entire rooms- worth it for that, alone (but whole place is great).
Small but worth it. Cool small museum ,we went here because the lines at le louvre were too long,totally worth it. Beautiful paintings.

Small, but interesting. Visited this museum yesterday (Fri).10am, no crowds and bought a 2-for-1 ticked (16 Euro) that gets you in here and the (bigger) Musee D'Orsay across the river = good value.Monet's Water Lilies are housed here and they're pretty impressive.They seem to be the main attraction, however, the rest of the museum features many fine painting from The Walter-Guillaume Collection.I'm not a huge art buff, so I'm sure I've overlooked many great features - sorry.For me, this is a much quieter, less overwhelming gallery.

One of my favorites. One of my favorite museums in Paris, truly. Monet didn't want his lilies to be displayed until after his death, and they've done a stellar job of displaying them here at the Orangerie, truly. You can sit for as long as you'd like and take in their magnificence...and then you can go downstairs and enjoy a few hours' worth of more masterpieces! This museum really is a hidden gem of a place and well worth the time. Give it a few hours. You won't regret it.

Lovely environment for viewing Les Nymphéas. Good collection, including a wonderful display of Monet's Les Nymphéas. Much smaller and a little less crowded than the Louvre and d'Orsay. Ok cafe. Pleasant to get to when walking through the park (Jardin des Tuileries) that surrounds it.
A must for Monet Lovers. This is THE place to view Monet's famous water lillies. I could have stayed there for hours just taking in the beautiful paintings.
Musee de l'Orangerie. We went here to see the water lilies panels by Monet, but found so much more fantastic art downstairs.Visit August 2013

Well worth your time!. We purchased the museum pass for Paris upon arrival at the airport in Paris. This time it worked as we were able to quickly get in using the pass. Sadly-this is not a highly visited museum yet the art work is as beautiful as anywhere else. Benches are provided to sit and enjoy the work of Monet and happily here tourists aren't so inclined to muck up the art work with "selfies" The art work is beautiful and the gift shop will gladly relieve you of your money to purchase replicas from calendars to silk scarves.

a real discovery. I do NOT understand why everyone is queuing up for the Louvre whilst having a smaller museum nearby that is as good. I especially enjoyed the impressing paintings of les Nympheas of Monet ....

The Waterlilies are a must see!. An excellent museum to visit, especial if you like Monet and the impressionists. Besides the famous waterlilies, as seen in painted different parts of the day, you have the opportunity to go downstairs and admire selected works from Renoir, Matisse, Picasso, Cezanne and more. The Museum pass works here!

Enjoy Monet. It won't take long to go round- start off with the water lilies and then explore, and revisit the water lilies before you go. A lovely airy museum, with works of most major artisist. It took us about 90 mins to go round.
disappointed but I don't know why. It's really a small and very specialised collection. I expected a greater reward for the queueing and the price.

Especially for Monet lovers and, also, people who are not very interested in art.. Fantastic! If you are the least interested in art, this museum is a very nice experience. Not too large, and with wonderful, big Monet paintings.

Go early and enjoy . What a great museum! We planned ahead and got there before 10am so we got in quickly. We bought the two day museum pass here.
The water lilies are incredible but we were surprised by the number of other artists and pictures on display downstairs. Well worth it.
Lovely museum. It is a lovely museum, not very big but it has a high quality collection of paintings. Beautiful Monet paintings!

Small but packed. As others have said, this is a smaller site visit pending how you move through the museum. It is packed with a lot of quality pieces though. The two upstairs rooms can lead to some great panoramic pictures. We did not do the audiovisual portion so I can not judge that.

Monet's Lilies. Spending time with Monet Lilies is a wonderful way to spend a low impact but high quality afternoon. Simply sit on a bench in an oval shaped room and let you mind take you to the wonders of the waters before you.

I wish I had more stars to give.. I wish there were more than five stars. I love everything about this museum. This is the single best place I went in Paris, hands down. I was able to hit this at a time when it was relatively quiet and I spent my time with the water lilies. The light is spectacular and the room invites you to spend time in quiet contemplation. There is also a wonderful collection of paintings on the lower floor. Really glad I took the time. This is a very intimate museum, and I found the experience remarkable.

Breath taking . Completely worth the visit. If you want to go to musee d'orsay also, buy the combined ticket. Try going early in the morning if you don't want to find a crowd. The Monet's pathings inserted in this rooms are completely breath taking.

Amazing little Museum!! Must visit!. This museum isn't very large at all, and you could easily visit the whole thing in 1-2 hours and see every piece in that time if desired. The Monet pieces are absolutely incredible and worth the price of admission alone. This was my favorite museum of all the ones we went to in Paris. Not that I didn't enjoy the others, but I really enjoyed the layout of this one as it was very spacious and the lines were not long so it just made the whole experience that much more enjoyable. I would definitely visit here again my next time in Paris!
Don't miss this!. Starstruck by the amazing collection. This is a once in a lifetime dream of seeing the greatest paintings and sculptures.

A small museum with plenty of character. Definitely worth a visit, beautiful building and beautiful paintings. Make sure you take the time to visit the auditorium to watch the documentary on Monet's waterlillies, it will make you appreciate his wonderful paintings even more.
Worth a visit. Well worth a visit. Very relaxing and plenty of space to view the variety of art work on offer. There is a good level of information by each artist and work of art.

Beautiful Monets. Because this is such a small museum, we had a long wait to get in as they were regulating the number of visitors. The Monet water lilies are outstanding, but not much else to see. We were in line longer than we were in the museum.

Rare view of great Art.. L'Orangerie is a unique gallery housing art works from the 1920s. A wonderful collection of paintings by Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliani, Matisse, Picasso, and of course, Monet. The museum has an interesting history including the discovery of a Roman structure beneath its walls. Situatied in a corner of the Tulleries it is very convenient to visit.

Not to miss!!. No Paris tour should skip the visit to the water-lilies! Impressive! Best visited listening to some Debussy (I suggest the "reflets sur l'eau") for a truly impressionist experience.
And the permanent collection in the basement is very good as well!
Quite expensive though!

Recommended. A less busy, smaller gallery which is located off the Place de Concorde & on the banks of the Seine. Wonderful Monet canvasses and other art. We used the 4 day Paris Museum Pass for all our gallery visits & found it great value.
Must stop for Monet fans. Incredibly quiet and serene. Monet's works are beyond what I could have imagined. Love this place. Must stop for Monet fans.

More to art then I thought . This display of art was more then I expected. We had done the louvre and although the louvre is magnificent it is so large it is almost to much for someone who is not an art buff. L'Orangerie was the perfect exhibit. I enjoyed every piece in the museum and took my time looking and understanding the brush strokes. Ok so hands down truth, you have to go to the louvre but don't miss this collection. You will enjoy it more if you are not into the art world. Unless of course you critique art then you would enjoy all the museums.

My Dream Museum. When you love impressionist painting, after seeing Musée d'Orsay you must visit this museum. I have visited Maison de Monet in Giverny Vernon France too, so this is the continuation. This museum has all the collection of Monet most famous Nympheas. You will see them in their big wall. They are just sooo amazing. Real painting, so big so you are just like in the garden yourself. What Monet did was just magnificent, you can stay hours to enjoy what he did. Like scratches from close, but something so amazing when you see from far. The other collections in this museum are also very interesting from the famous impressionists painting like Renoir, Cezanne, Sisley, etc. Themuseum is not as big as Musée d'Orsay but the collections are among the best in the world of impressionist and post-impressionist.

If You Love Monet's Water Lilies, This is a Must See!. If you are a Monet art lover, as I am, you do not want to miss Musee de l'Orangerie! It is a small museum, especailly in comparison to the Louvre, but well worth the visit. While it does include art from other masters, the main attraction is the two large, circular rooms that display Monet's most famous paintings of his Water Lilies. To see these larger than life panels surrounding you is surreal. My only negative about the experience is that they seem rather strict about no photography while in the museum. I did not know this at first, and I had taken a picture of these gorgeous panels of the water lilies, when the sound of my camera's shutter had museum employees shouting at me. But other than that, it was a great experience and I would highly reccomend le Musee de l'Orangerie.
Great in conjunction with Musee d'Orsay. We went in conjunction with Musee d'Orsay. Short 1 hour visit, not extremely crowded. Beautiful Monet paintings.
Stimulating, informative visit!. Well worth a visit! Loved Monet's "Waterlilies" paIntings" and now look forward to visiting Monet's gardens at Giverny on our next visit to Paris.

Great Impressionist Gallery. Brilliant display of the Monet water lily paintings - I had not realise their huge size until seeing them here. Downstairs a superb display of Renoirs plus Picasso, Matisse and other artists.
Free under 25's. Good free experience for under 25's. A nice change not having to que for hours. Friendly and helpful staff.

Monet Lives Here. Designed by Monet to display both Waterlilies and Nymphéas, if you love Monet, is a sit to see. Displayed in two rooms, you can see these works up close. Downstairs is an impressive impressionist collection.

Just go and see this museum . We bought the Paris museum pass and this museum is a must to see even just for Monet water Lilies. I would recommend you visit here first then d'Orsay before going to the Louvre (if you have to the Louvre)
Dont miss it. I am reluctant to review this place as no one knows it and it is brilliant. Small and intimate, really not to be missed.

Amazing . Such a beautiful gallery. I went during tourist season so I was expecting to have to wait in the line for ages and it be busy, but luckily that wasn't the case at all. Definitely recommend for art lovers!
Monet. I have visited the museum almost every time I'm in Paris. I love Monet's Nympheas rooms! I'd like to visit there when noone is in the room.

For art lovers. Quiet museum, without big queues. Two rooms with an amazing work from Monett. Where you can seat and look around you and "feel like a frog in the middle of a pond". Exihbitions from other artists.

Paying tribute to the waterlillies. If you love Monet, this is a must visit. It's an intimate space - can be completed in less than an hour. Monet's paintings are housed in two elliptical rooms and showcased in natural light.It's quite awe inspiring!
For a Sunday in Paris. Don't miss the place! Take a guided tour that will explain each room and shows you all the details! We went a Sunday and we don't regret it!

Do the double with Musee Dorsay. A boutique little offering after the splendours of the Musee Dorsay just across the river but well worth the visit. The Monets are breathtaking, not just intrinsically but because of the way the're displayed. The two custom-built rooms show them to perfection. Sit for a while and breather them in. Then have a look at the donated collection in the basement. Ain't philanthropy grand!
Monet. Monet, Monet, Monet!!! Two rooms surrounded by larger than life water lilies. Great works by other impressionists too.

Monet, and more!. Of course the water lilys are here, but there is more! I got the audio guide and spent time learning a great deal about several more artists. There aren't many, but there are a lot of works by each one. Good for a few hours.

Only worth it for Monet. Upstairs is devoted to Monet's les Nympheas a la France. This exhibition is fantastic and you find yourself absorbed in the amazing colour and light. However, downstairs sees a mediocre collection of works by Renoir, Rousseau, Matisse and Picasso. All in all I found the place very overpriced (9 euros per person).

Well worth a one hour visit.. This was our second visit to the small Musee de L'Orangerie and it was still a thrill. In addition to the beautiful large murals painted by Monet, be sure to visit the downstairs gallery to see the small, but excellent collection of other Impressionist painters.

Small and Calm. This museum makes for a nice, calm, not crazy-crowded stop. The Monet rooms are beautiful but there are some other really good pieces to see. I think we were in and out in 50 minutes and it was nice to combine with a day of window shopping and browsing with my 14 year old. She enjoyed it and was thrilled it didn't take 2 or 3+ hours!

Must see. We took a veto taxi from the Musee d'Orsay to the Orangerie because it had already gotten late in the day, and we just made it in before it closes. Monet's water lilies are beautiful and soothing.

Lovely to visit. Monet's waterlilies panels are displayed here in two specially designed rooms. A good selection of other paintings resides here. We arrived at about noon, and there was no line. It is very clean. The visitors were polite and considerate of each other. Lovely visit!

Marvellous collection on impressionist artists. Coupling this museum with the Musee D'Orsay across the Seine provides a cultural smorgasbord of impressionist art which needs at least 4 hours to assimilate. l'Orangerie is the Paul Guilliaume collection of impressionist art while the D'Orsay is a comprehensive collection of Impressionism art covering paintings, sculpture, furniture and murals. Well worth the time for a visit. The entry line can be long so it's worth paying a little extra to save having to stand in the sun.
Les Nympheas. just go and dive into monet's pounds ... admire the sky of Giverny in between the nympheas... observe modern art birth
Probably can be skipped as a museum.. Saw this the day before I took a bus to Monet's garden/house in Giverny. Pretty neat displays, but a bit expensive for what you see (10 euros, I seem to recall).
A delightful small museum. Visited this gallery one afternoon, and was delighted with the display. Few crowds, easy to move around, and of course, Monet's painting.
Swimming among the lilies. I wish!!!!!. This is THE PLACE IN PARIS which I wish I could wrap up and take home or else camp in the Orangerie for the rest of my life.
Monet!. Very good museum but on a smaller scale, I felt you could see the whole thing in about an hour. Nice paintings by Monet!
Pefect Size - More than Monet. It's so much more than the Monet paintings. The museum wasn't too crowded and it has a lovely collection of works.

More than Nympheas. The art gallery is close to the Place de la Concorde in the corner of the Tuileries Garden. Till 1986, it was paired with Jeu de Paume, which collection was then moved to the Musee d’Orsay. The gallery is well known for the collection of eight paintings of water lilies (Nympheas) which are displayed on the ground floor in two oval rooms. But the gallery holds many great works from other painters, and not only from impressionist era. In my humble opinion, this museum is underrated and shouldn’t be missed!
Beautiful Monet Paintings.. The 2 rooms with the large monet paintings are stunning and the gallery downstairs also has some lovely pieces.Worth visiting!
Musee de lOrangeries. There are many beautiful paintings. I am much impressed by the 8 large water lilies paintings by Monet
Good museum. Beautiful museum in a wonderful building. I have loved the art pieces exposed and would recommend this visit to anyone close to Paris...

Sublime Scale. Simply lovely - this all encompassing environment lends itself to the grandeur of Monet's work. L'Orangerie is a place to reflect, relax and marvel at the scale and beauty of his work.
The downstairs gallery is quite engaging, too.
Wall to Wall Monets!. My favorite museum in Paris. Wonderful impressionist paintings and special exhibits. Monet's Les Nympheas will "knock your socks off!"
Great works worth the visit. I was not able to stay long as we got there only 1 hour before the closure, but I would have to go back. It is a beautiful museum, worth visiting.
See the lilies, then go downstairs! . There is a wealth of seriously gorgeous and famous art downstairs. Monet, Renoir, Manet, and many others - pretty amazing.

Outstanding Beauty. Well worth a visit - the water lilies give you chills when you walk in the room. Monet is the main attraction but the featured collector on the lower floor also was very interesting.

Water Lilies by Monet a must see!. Had a museum pass and just went here to see the eight huge Monet Water Lilies murals. Definitely worth the trip in to see these. A 10 minute walk from Museum D'Orsay, so do on the same day.

More than Monet. On top of the 2 most stunning Monets anywhere (go early to avoid the crowds and live the experience), go downstairs and enjoy a ton of fabulous works by Rembrandt, Picasso, Gauguin... This museum is underrated!

beautiful museum. A wonderful museum, there is so much great art to see! I just wish that the visitors would look at the pictures instead of taking pictures of themselves standing in front of the pictures...

Exceeded expectations . First time visiting L'Orangerie: wonderful combination alongside Musee D'Orsay. There was an intensity to the concentration of both the Monet water lilies and all the Renoirs downstairs. Not on the scale of its more famous neighboring museums but well worth it.
Unexpected response.. Very moving to be standing in among Monets last works- The build up of colour in each section a wonder.

Beautiful Monet Paintings. This museum is within walking distance of both the Louvre and Musee de Orsay. There are several very large Monet paintings in rooms with glass ceilings. I would recommend visiting this museum at different times during the day, in order to enjoy the change in lighting.

If you love beauty, go to L'Orangerie. To stand and be surrounded by 360 degrees of Monet water lilies is enough to bring one to tears. His genious pours from the canvases and it's impossible not to feel privileged to be there. And don't miss the exibhits below. Spectacular!

Great display of Monet's work, and more!. Being dragged there by my artist friend, I was thoroughly enjoying the works of art at this museum. At a good price and not too far from the Louvre, our experience was very good!
Lovely museum with a great collection. Great museum and won't take all day. Don't miss the excellent collection downstairs, definitely worth a visit without the crowds.
Relaxing and beautiful. Lovely museum with uniquely beautiful artwork. This is a hidden gem and should be visited by all travelers.
The Water Lillies!. Words can't describe Monet's water lillies. Although crowded, we were able to sit for some time to appreciate all aspects of the artwork.
Stunning Monet's. Small but stunning museum. The large Monet's including the water lilies were a fantastic sight. Easy to walk to from Concorde metro stop. Entrance 9 euros.

Sooo good. Monet's master pieces got their appropriate form of presentation! So powerful. A two-hour tour is enough for this unique museum. Better purchase a combine tkt with Musee d'Orsey, another must-see gem.

Worth visiting to see the water lilies as Monet wanted them to be displayed.. Very nice, small museum. Definitely go to see Monet's masterpieces. Nice to sit on benches in center of gallery and just soak in the work -- amidst several dozen people. :^) Lower floor also has a surprisingly large and interesting collection. Try getting Museum Pass to avoid the queues. We were lucky and walked right in.

Better than we expected. This was pleasantly surprising. We had heard they had special Monety Lilly paintings but these panels were huge and glorious. They also had Money, Matise, Van Gogh, Cezanne, etc.
The museum was well spaced out and had wide halls.

Paris's best kept secret!. Forget the Louvre...even Musee D'Orsay. L'Orangerie (where they kept the orange bushes from the Tuleries gardens during winter) is an artistic & architectural wonder.Upstairs are two oval, skylit rooms displaying Monet's "WaterLilies" ... "The Nymphs". These displays, as suggested by Monet himself, allow you to sit & immerse yourself in the spectacle.Even better, downstairs, is the collection of M. Paul Guilliome, a Parisian art collector & dealer from the 1920's. Here is a snapshot of a possibly opportunistic man who collected artists & promoted & publised their works. He helped put artists like Matisse, Utrillo, Modigliano, Renoir & even Picasso in the eye of the public. His personal collection, on display here, includes menay significant works from these artists. There are paintings of Guilliome himself as well as details of his life & early death. This man helped put modern art on the map 100 years ago

Impressive collection. There is so much more to this collection than just the, admittedly astounding, Water-Lillies. Easy to find. and inexpensive, this is a good gallery in which to while away some time.

Go early to avoid the crowds and take awesome pictures!. This was absolutely breathtaking! If you go early enough you will be able to take photos without the crowds. I was able to get one good shot on the exit wall. 8 of the most beautiful canvas paintings I have ever seen!

Just like being in Giverny!. If you love Monet and his famous waterlily paintings, be prepared to be wowed! The walls of his work are simply breathtaking! We visited this museum two days after visiting Giverny, Monet's home and gardens where this work occurred. Beyond Monet, there were other Impressionists and works to view. We rented the handset, and found that it enhanced our tour.

Go for the Waterlilies but see the rest, too!. Get the combo pass with Musee D'Orsay. Don't miss this gem. It's worth a view just for the room with Monet's Waterlilies but the rest of the museum is amazing as well. It can be a pretty quick visit compared to some of Paris's larger museums so it doesn't have to take too much time. The combo pass makes it easy to do.
Waterlilies all round. Liked this museum. Being surrounded by Monet waterlilies is great. Does tend to get quite busy, security can be rather slow.
Wonderful Nymphéas!. Very small but worth a trip. Monets Nymphéas really make an impression. There is a combi ticket with orsay.
Antithesis of the Louvre. The antithesis of the louvre. Intimate and quaint. One of the highlights of our trip to Paris. Highly recommended
See before you go to Giverny.. We didn't have too much time for this but had to stop in to to see Monet's Water Lily before our visit to Giverny. Well worth the time and easy in and out.

Great museum but terrible stuff. Great museum but terrible stuff- I just wanted to call my family who set in the cafeteria after they finished seeing the museum but was not allowed to ! And was forced to buy a ticket to go on for 9€. Then as they closed it started raining hard all of a sudden and they refused to give people any shelter. Inhuman!
More than I expected. I stopped at Musee de l'Orangerie on a whim and was pleasantly surprised. The Monet's are worth the price of admission alone.

A great pairing with the Musee d'Orsay. This spot is just a short walk from the Musee d'Orsay and lets you continue to enjoy some amazing Monet works along with a variety of other fabulous works. I highly recommend that you add this to your trip!
see the impressionist paintings too!. Been here before to see the Monet hympeae but never visited the superb impressionist collection on the lower floor - amazing collection which given to nation.

A MUST SEE of MONET'S NYMPHEAS. I think your primary visit to this historic museum should be to see Monet's Nympheas. Monet donated eight panels of water lilies to the museum and he worked directly with the Museum to ensure that they would be displayed properly in oval rooms. They were first displayed in 1927 for the public.From 1999 to 2006 the Museum closed for renovations. The Orangerie now houses the panels in the renovated upper floor of the gallery and to view it is simply breathtaking. The panels are huge and the rooms display the work so elegantly. Due to the sparseness of the room, the lighting and the oval shape you are immersed in the art.The Orangeries also houses other fine works. It is definitely a museum not to be missed!

hard to find. If you don't know where to look, this can be a museum that can be over-looked. Ask locals where it is located. Once inside we enjoyed the Monet murals, which are located in 4 oval rooms. One of the highlights of the museum...

Monet and water lilies! A must see.. After spending a day at Giverny a trip to the Musee del'Orangerie is a must. Seeing where Monet painted the water lilly paintings made the museum so much more interesting. Sitting and contemplating his amazing work is such a wonderful experience. After walking miles and miles this was a treat.

In the Louvre complex...home of the Impressionists. Tucked into the Tuileries gardens of the Louvre complex and close to Place de la Concorde it is the small museum packed with Impressionist art...very satisfying.

You will love the. A smaller museum, but central in Paris and also a must-see place. We enjoyed the Monet experience, and his work is displayed very well. Much quieter than the Louvre, this museum is a lovely walk-through and delightful.

Thoroughly Enjoyable. If interested in Claude Monet, Renoir and more then this a musee is a must.I totally recommend to hire the audio so much more enjoyable than just looking and not fully understanding the history. Monet's paintings are breathtaking. Take the time to soak up these masterpieces. We spent 2 hours or so browsing these masterpieces and being educated by the audio. A true gem.

Peaceful museum full of treasures. This museum might be in the shade of the Louvre or Musee d´Orsay but I enjoyed this one most - because it was not crowded with tourists. Usually a place where you don´t bump into 50 Japanese and 70 Russians may not be so interesting, but not in this case! Monet´s Water Lilies accompanied by many other impressionist works... it´s a jewel among galleries.

It is "awe full".... We used to love this museum before it was closed for a 6 year renovation. Thankfully after re-opening in 2006, we are able to revisit the post-Impressionist treasures!The special Monet Gallery is beyond belief and we can only highly recommend a view! You won't regret it! Really!

Small but beautiful. Having limited time in Paris, we gave priority to visit Louvre and Musée d’Orsay first. We weren't sure if we could fit l'Orangerie in our busy schedule. Thanks God we did. It is a small museum if compared with Louvre or d'Orsay. It is much less crowded. We are glad we didn't miss it. Water lilies were definitely worth to see.

Must Visit for Any Art Lover. This is only a short walk from the Louvre, through the park, and while it's a separate admission, it's not much to see some of the most famous paintings in European history. I believe there are a total of eight of the ginormous "water lilies" paintings here, spread out over a few rooms. The rooms are well lit and have good seating for anyone who wants to just hang out and soak up all the images.The museum is two levels, with the paintings on the ground level, and then special exhibits in the lower level. Afterwards, grab some ice cream in the park.
Wonderfull. We were told about this attraction by a person we know and we loved every min. The waterlily,s brought tears to my wife's eyes. Louver tickets are all that is needed.
Slow pace art. This is the place if one wants to really absorb,feel and breathe Monet's water lilies. I have seen a few in NYork at MOMA. These ones are the best.

Beautiful masterpieces by Monet. The best part of this museum is certainly the Monet water lily paintings that encircle two rooms. However, the museum also has another floor of paintings and a good gift shop. If you like Monet, this is a must-see.

How lovely!. I had no idea i would enjoy this museum so very much; to see the variety of Monet Lily paintings was overwhelming. We simply sat and enjoyed ourselves and let the art overtake us.Definitely a "to do " while in Paris--and not while in a hurry. This one is to be enjoyed and savored.

Peaceful Monet haven. This is a small collection of impressionist art well worth a visit. Two light filled glasshouse rooms of Monet's wonderful water lilies. Downstairs has inspiring pieces by Renoir, Modigliani, Matisse etc. Enjoy....

Meditation in Monet. Visiting the Musee de l'Orangerie is a two part experience - on one floor there's a mixed lot of fairly modern art that doesn't really do much for me, but then on the other level there are two oval shaped rooms, each filled with four massive waterlily paintings by Monet. Sitting in these rooms, looking at the paintings is like meditating. It's wonderful, and well worth the entry fee for these two rooms alone.
Great Museum!. Wonderful museum! The two curved rooms which contain Monet's Water Lily paintings are truly stunning. Well worth a visit.
STUNNING!. If you like Claude Monet you have to see what his gift to France looks like in real time. You can spend hours sitting ans staring at the beauty that is this paiting.

Go there now!. A truly wonderful collection of Monet's water lilies and other Impressionist art work. Nice seating area in the middle of the rooms so you're able to take in what you're seeing. The beauty is overwhelming.

Monet's Waterlillies!. This is a lovely art museum in a pretty park setting. It is worth visiting Musee de l'Orangerie if only to see the huge Monet as it was meant to be seen...spread across a large room!
Great Monet & Renoir works!. Wished we had come here sooner than our 4th Paris visit but there is just too much to see in this wonderful city!
favorite museum. This is my favorite museum because it has Monet's Water Lillies paintings. Those paintings are amazing and cover large portions of the walls.

Small museum well worth the time with the museum pass. Almost half of the museum is the Lily room, but they are simply stunning. Standing in the middle of the room and looking for season to season is fantastic. The rest of the museum reads like the B sides of the greatest hits in art history. If you remember the name of an artist and they weren't a Ninja Turtle, odds are they have a painting here. It's just not one you'll remember/recognize.I think I would have been slightly disappointed if I didn't have the museum pass. The museum is so small it takes less than an hour to pass through. But with the museum pass, it was a great stop, and one I'm glad I did.

Impressive, impressive, impressive!. This a almost a hidden gem in Paris. If you like Impressionism then I highly recommend this museum. This is an adorable, small, friendly museum. The lines are not crazy even if you don't have a ticket at your arrival. My 9yr old daughter and I had a wonderful 4 1/2 hour visit. We bought the audio guides at the entrance. She got the children version which is on a tablet with game and awesome child friendly information for children to understand the art pieces. My daughter couldn't get enough of this guide. Touring the museum is easy and everywhere you go you will be surprised and impressed. I say visit the Louvre just because it is only one of the most famous museums in the world but to truly appreciate art, you must visit the L'Orangerie. I aboslutely loved it. My daughter and I plan to visit it every time we are in paris from now on.
Lovely museum/gallery. Have visited this gallery on a few occasions when visiting Paris - it's not too crowded and small enough that you can see everything within an hour.

A must in Paris and walking distance through the lovely Louvre gardens to the Orangerie .. One can only be impressed by this Monet exhibit.The display is worth the trip.The additional works on the lower floor vary from time to time .The Paul Guillaume collection was on display and was outstanding.
If your like Monet its a must.. I have going to Paris for years my first visit but not my last. Small but I love this place and its surroundings. if you like Monet its a must.

Underrated. This place wasn't on my "to do" list.
However, with a bit of spare time, and being close by, in I went.
This smallish museum is well worth the visit. Take time to appreciate the two oval rooms of Monet's water lillies. Some nice other art here too.
Home of Beautiful Monet Waterlilies. If you are a fan of Impressionism - you must visit this wonderful little museum in the Tuileries Garden.

Cool. Very very very small. You do not need more than 2 hours here. The Monet exhibit is the main attraction and I was thrilled to see it. Buy a combined ticket with Musee Orsay and you can go to both in the same day.
Monet!. If you like the impressionist art, this museum is for you! It's indescribeble the felling of being inside the Nympheas room, so peaceful and wonderful...
a must while in Paris. This museum is beautiful there was a line waiting to enter however it was very well organized and the wait was short

Monet eye candy. It is such a wondeful small museum displaying the best of Monet with paintings that stretch an entire wall. So many museums now days prevent you from taking pictures but this one allows you to do what you want. The lines here are not very long which is a bonus and is covered under the museum pass. There is a small cafe that will charge you an arm and a leg at the lowest level. Skip it and find a wonderful relaxing cafe nearby. We were there less than an hour so it is an easy add on to your daily plans. Enjoy

Impressive Impressionists! . Headed out early to avoid the majority of the crowds...worked brilliantly. First in line and had plenty of opportunity to take my panoramic photos of the Claude Monet's magnificent panoramic style "Water Lillies". The museum is small and intimate and has another large downstairs with other well known painters such as Picasso, Rembrandt, Renoir etc.. There is a lift tucked around the corner which was initially hard to find but is required for those with mobility issues as there are two flights of stairs. Would recommend this museum for those who want a taste of art without the swarming crowds of the other museums. It's also situated within the Jardin des Tuileries so it's easy to head out of the museum and wander the gardens. Is close enough to the Louvre if you then want to put your feet to the test!

Definitely worth a visit for the Monet murals. Truthfully we stumbled upon this museum completely by accident. We had the 2 day museum pass and really was trying to see as many museums as possible. On the map, it didn't seem too far away from the Louvre, so we walked over - well it's a long walk, we got there around 5pm (it closes at 6pm). And I was truly surprised by the museum. Beautiful paintings by Monet in 2 giant oval rooms. It's a MUST for Monet waterlilies lovers. There are long benches so you can sit and admire the paintings. And the museum was designed to the specifications requested by Monet. Definitely utilize the panorama setting on the phones to take beautiful photos of it. On the bottom floor, they also had temporary exhibitions that was really excellent as well. We had to hurry and leave the museum at 6pm since they literally started closing down everything, but we were really glad that we got to visit here.

Beautiful!. I only had time to see the two rooms with Monet's Nymphéas. It was breathtaking! My husband who has zero knowledge of Art didn't understand why people love it so much but after he took a photo of me infront of the Art, he fell in love. Among Louvre, Orsay and Orangerie, Orangerie was the best. We visited on a Thursday around 2pm, we waited in line for about 15-20 minutes. The staff welcomed the people in line and was very friendly by saying 'Hi, thank you' in every possible language he could say:)

Small and quiet. I'm not sure I'd pay full price to enter, but with a Paris Museum Pass, this is a brilliant place to spend a couple of hours. Not the biggest museum, but still lots to see (especially the water lillies). Almost in the shadow of the Louvre, but uncrowded even in August.

Underrated gem. I thought Monets Water Lillies would attract a bigger crowd but I suppose we did get there early. It worked out well though as we were able to appreciate them without swarms of people blocking our view. There are lots of artists here who I didn't recognise but take your time, you might find some new favourites - I know I did!

Water Lillies. An interesting alternative to the biggest and most famous museums. It’s a must if you like Monet, as his water lilies murals in the 2 oval rooms are the main attraction. The water lilies are amazing, you should take your time to sit in the middle and just be surrounded by Monet’s garden. The museum is not very big but has a quite complete collection of less famous paintings of well-known impressionist artists. If you buy your ticket together with the Orsay museum you get a discount.

Lovely for impressionist fans. Beautiful to see the water lilies as Monet intended them. Not as extensive a gallery as I'd expected but maybe good for that! Students free entry with proof of age (at least on Sundays)
L'Orangerie. Possibly my favorite museum! Small, intimate with a wonderful selection of works. They also have a fabulous book store with a nice selection of English language options.

Serene. L'Orangerie wasn't originally on our plans, but our cruise director suggested it as an alternative activity for a Monday when other museums are closed. It turned out to be one of the highlights of our visit. The Louvre will wear you out, but L'Orangerie is low-key and restful. You can see most everything in 90 minutes or you can linger for half a day. It is worth the visit just for the "Water Lillies", displayed as Monet intended, but the Walter-Guillaume collection is marvelous too, particularly for fans of Impressionism.
Small but delightful. Beautiful small museum housing Monet's Waterlilies, with a lovely gift shop. Ideal museum if you only have an hour or so.

One of my favorite museums ever - Monet's Water Lillies. I love the Musee de l'Orangerie. It is a small, accessible museum that houses Monet's Water Lillies, two rooms filled and dedicated with room length paintings of his gardens at Giverny. The colors and the flowers are incredibly soothing and beautiful. Every time I visit, I am content to walk around the room, then sit, and contemplate his garden. If you are a fan of Impressionist art, this should be one of your destinations. There are other artists' work in the museum as well, on other floors. A typical stay in the museum is anywhere between 1 and 2 hours, depending on how much you love the art. I highly recommend.

Favorite place in Paris. An uncrowded look at Monet's last works, the Musee de l'Orangerie was a highlight of our trip. The waterlilies are spread between two rooms and the basement had a lovely collection of other Impressionist works.

It gots Magic!. I went there on 7/8/2015 for free because I am student under 26 and I study in the UK. I wasn't have high expectation of this gallery, but I really feel refreshed and surprised after the visit. Monet's painting wasn't new to me and usually people might think it is boring but when you see the real thing, you see the difference. You can still see the stroke of the brushes and see the direction of the colour change. You will be amazed by how big the painting is. The gallery is that big yet they have some exhibition of some private collection, I took around 3 hours to finish the whole visit. The decoration inside the gallery is very simple, but the painting itself gots the magic that makes people want to stay longer.

Don't miss this!. If you want to experience the magnificence that is Monet, you must see this. I have always appreciated Monet, but this made me sincerely a fan. There are not words to express how sitting in this gallery is awe inspiring and humbling. It's a short visit, the gallery is rather small, but one of the best decisions we made! Seriously, take the time to see this.

ALWAYS A TREAT!. This small museum has an abudance of great Impressionist paintings. The Monet waterlilies were painted "for" this museum roughly 100 years ago. The recent renovation work of this building has brought out the beauty of these waterlily paintings.
Beautiful Monet collection. Do not miss this place if you like Monet's work! Gorgeous nymphea work on the curved walls. Museum is quite small. Buy tickets in advance! We did combo with Musee d'Orsay
Underrated museum. Hidden gem among museum. Great museum that deserves to be explored, not overly crowded. The architecture bodes well with the exhibit.

Wonderful waterlillies of Monet - and a bit less wonderful modern art on the side. We specifically visited the Musée de l'Orangerie because we really wanted to see the beautiful Waterlillies of Monet with our own eyes. And what wonderful paintings they proved to be. Also compliments for the Musée de l'Orangerie, their specific design with the oval galleries and soft lighting, really brought out the best in the paintings. Downstairs there was a gallery with temporary exhibitons and more modern art. Also very interesting, but because it was so completely different from what the "purpose" of this museum was (which are the Waterlillies), it kind of felt like the art displayed here did not fit into the original Musée d'Orsay anymore and just put here. And a tip: to avoid spending ages waiting in line in a burning sun, make sure you arrive here early. The museum doesn't take too long to view (about an hour), so it just doesn't add up to wait in line for 2 hours and then be outside again in an hour. Also: for every EU citizen under 26 entrance is free (yay for the cultural encouragement of France)
Prepare to be moved. What and incredible experience to see such massive and beautiful paintings close up. and feel immersed in them in this way. It moved me to tears

Monet's exhibit is Fabulous!!. I have never really enjoyed museums before and I came in and was stunned as I saw the exhibit with the water lily pond. The description said that Monet gifted this to the French government so that anyone else who saw these paintings would sense a feeling of calmness and peace. That is exactly how I felt as I walked through the two rooms. Would recommend this museum for that exhibition if not anything else!

Must See Monet. Had a long hot wait in line to view this exhibition, but well worth it! Lovely, cool white rooms display the eight monumental panels depicting the famous water lilies providing a wonderful space to sit and absorb the colours, light and variety of tones.The remainder of the collections features some wonderful works by Cezanne, Renoir, Rousseau, Picasso etc. Busy but not too crowded to spoil the experience.
A real shock. Get ready for some news. Monet was not only an impressionist. He was a master of impression, leaving you with an imprint that will last a long time.
Skip the lines!. Accessible! Underrated! A hidden gem. Fabulous collection of enormous Monet water lilies and impressionists

L'Orangerie. Outstanding museum. Have been to the Louvre and D'Orsay several times and had no desire to see the Mona Lisa behind glass and the hordes of "photographers" ever again. Did not go to either. Was invited to go to this museum with friends, so took them up on it. Just one more museum not to miss in Paris. Phenomenal collection of art "donated" by widow of art collector, dealer and friend of impressionists and post-impressionists, Paul Guillaume. Outstanding with excellent, thorough "Explications" on artists and their works. A must.
Wonderful museum. This is a wonderful museum. The art is excellent and we enjoyed the lack of crowds. We were able to take our time. In this museum, you are able to get quite close to each painting.

Always an incredible delight!. We have been at the Orangerie many times and it is always a pleasure hard to describe. Just sit, watch and meditate. Let yourself drawn into this incredible beauty. No need to analyze, it is simply pure pleasure for the eyes and the mind. I don't know of any other place where you can understand the word "impressionism" as deeply as at the Orangerie.

Beautiful place, perfect size when you're tired or short on time. Perfect sized museum with some real gems. Lovely building and peaceful gallery spaces--not as busy as the other big museum attractions in August and the queue was only about 30 mins to get in. My seven year old really enjoyed using the audio guide, it really kept her interested in what she was seeing (I liked it too).

An odd, joyous treat: Monet’s late lilies plus Mr and Mrs Paul Guillaume’s small powerful personal collection.. This museum is gold. It is known for Claude Monet’s “Lilies” (Les Nymphéas), but the unquestionable highlight for me is the small permanent collection housed there since 1965 of garage owner Paul Guillaume and his wife Domenica who remarried after her husband’s early death age 43 in 1934. Paul G began by collecting African sculptures which of course became a vital influence on the course of modern art. Through this he met the famous French poet G. Apollonaire who was was a lightning rod in Paris among a small group of now famous modern artists, Picasso et al. His collection, modified by his wife, brings some strong works by famous painters like Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse, also Picasso. But, more interesting perhaps, it brings a punch from the underrated chameleon Andre Derain, and important works by Modigliani (including a fine portrait of PG), the mercurial and inspirational Rousseau and the distinctive Russian expressionist Chaim Soutine. Plus a fine portrait of PG by Kees van Dongen. Throw in a tidy friendly café and we have a top Paris art destination, and more manageable than say Musee d’Orsay.

Beautiful works of Monet without long lines. On a hot July afternoon, we strolled out the end of Tuilerie Gardens and entered the Orangerie. We had no wait at all. We had seen beautiful Monet paintings in the Musee d'Orsay. This sort of prepared us for the "Monet on steroids" that we saw at Musee de l'Orangerie. Two rooms were filled with water lily landscapes, each painted in different lighting giving off a different mood. This was awe-inspiring and emotion-provoking These paintings, alone, were enough to make the museum visit worthwhile. However, there were other nice collections in the museum.Once again, I highly recommend the Paris Museum Pass. It not only saves money (if used regularly) but also saves time in the ticket queue.

Relaxing. I'm not a big museum person . I like art but I have no passion to spend hours looking at a painting. We went here to see the monet paintings. I enjoyed all the art displayed here. It was a cross section. Price is reasonable line up was small.

Monet all around . If you are a Monet fan, this is an amazing place. Two rooms, specifically designed to show off huge water lily landscapes painted at different times of the day and in different lights. Truly showing his genius. In the basement, there are many other artists from some small collections...but these are a side benefit.

Musee de L'Orangerie has more than water lilies!. Monet's gift to his country to help ease the horrors of war with the beauties of life, his water lily murals fill two oval rooms and are spectacular. There's also the private collection of Paul Guillaume in a significant new galley space beneath. He was an early collector, agent and friend to many impressionists; the works he purchased, and the time and place they capture are fascinating and fun. There's also a lovely gift shop and cafe. Go early or bring your museum pass (or both). This is a rewarding and doable museum; we had a teenager with us and it was just the right amount of art viewing and scope.

Still dreaming about the paintings. We did wait about 40 minutes to process thru the entrances and security, but it was really worth it as the masterpieces were excellent and even enthralling. The gift shop had an excellent selection of books a outs various painters and we also enjoyed a bite to eat in their snack shop

Amazing. For any art-lover, this is definitely a must-see, especially if you have the time to watch the videos detailing the artist's lives. The history of the building is also very neat to read, and you gain an appreciation for how much work goes into showing these masterpieces.
Monet's Delight. The Gallery contains Monet's Water Lilies which is a must see if you know of his work. Other then that, theres not much to see.

Monet's Nymphéas are Exquisite!. This small museum was one of the highlights of our trip to Paris. Eight of Monet's water lily paintings are displayed in two oval-shaped rooms. The murals are quite long, and the canvases were apparently glued to the walls during installation. The rooms are lit with skylights, and the natural light enhances the paintings beautifully. There are long benches in the center of the room, so you can sit and gaze at the paintings to your heart's content. The Collection of Jean Walter & Paul Guillaume is also housed in this museum, which features paintings by Renoir, Cézanne, Gaugin, Picasso, Derain, Modigliani, Rousseau, and Matisse, among others. The l'Orangerie also has a very nice gift shop! We visited the museum on an extremely hot day, and were pleasantly surprised to learn that it has excellent air conditioning. There were also fewer crowds at this museum, so we were able to take our time and really enjoy the paintings in peace. So, if you want to avoid large crowds and see some outstanding paintings, l'Orangerie is the place to go!

A don't miss site in Paris. Before you visit the large galleries, visit this one and enjoy art in a smaller setting particularly the room designed just to display Monet's Water Lilies. Centrally located and an easy walk from the d'Orsay and du Louvre this is a delightful gallery that can be viewed in 60-90 minutes. And if you enjoy Monet's work, don't miss the Musee Marmottan, the largest Monet collection in Paris.

Hidden gem in The Tuilerie Garden. We read about this before setting off for Paris and visited on our last afternoon. Amazing collection of Monet's most loved paintings. It's a lovely gallery, particularly if you are not an art buff and just want to admire a few famous works and then drink coffee!

Water Lillies is Magnificent!. Monet's "Water Lillies" is so much more beautiful and much bigger than we expected. Loved it! Due to time restrictions, we did not view any other artwork In this museum.
Monet water lilies. Wonderful water lily murals by Monet. A number of large Monet water lily studies that are stunning. Other good exhibitis also, but it is all about the Monets.

Monet's Water Lilies, bigger than life.... Amazing gallery of Monet's Water Lilies series, and a smaller gallery on the lower floor of other painters... Really, a must-see if you like Monet and Impressionism even a little bit - not a long wait to get in; a very pleasant experience.
Monet's Masterpieces not to be missed.. Beautiful museum. It's a must see if you love Monet...and even if you don't. It's very unique and of Monet's own design. Get the audio tour.
My favorite Paris museum. If you love Claude Monet, you can't miss this museum. He designed it and painted the water lilies just for this space. It's amazingly beautiful. Don't miss it.
buy your tickets in advance to avoid the queue. you really want to stand in these rooms in the quiet on your own; very busy, but you still get the atmosphere of these amazing pictures
Awe-inspiring.. I love Monet so I couldn't pass this up. The rooms have been thoughtfully constructed for optimal viewing. Just beautiful.
Excellent art museum.. This museum is a nice compliment to the Musee d'Orsay. The rooms of Monet's water lilies are truly unusual. A nice hour-long stop while in the Tuileries.

Musee de l'Orangerie. Try to sit still and look at the water lilies then wander round the rest of the gallery. Weekdays are best as there are less crowds after the orangerie stroll round the Tulleries have a cafe see and be seen that's very Frenh.

Don't Miss the Monets!. There are so many sites to see and visit in Paris....this one was almost overlooked. Fortunately, we had a four day museum pass and we chose to stop in here while biking around the city. Boy are we glad we did. I was much more impressed by the spectacular Monets at L'Orangerie than the many impressionists paintings at the d'Orsay Museum. The two rooms housing his giant paintings are not to be missed.

Short and sweet, go early to get more out of it. Monet's murals really are amazing and well worth the effort to see. For the murals alone it would be worth going to this museum however the collection on the lower floor also contains a number of interesting impressionist and post-impressionist works.In order to enjoy it most I would recommend:1) Also going to see Monet's Garden at Giverny2) Getting there early to avoid the maddening crowds3) Taking a decent amount of time to just take in each room of Monet's murals4) Not being "that guy", of which there are sadly too many, who is too busy taking selfies/posed portraits in front of the murals to appreciate the art. Just don't, you will look like a fool, annoy others in the gallery and impress none of your social media followers. Don't.5) Enjoy the beauty!

Start by this small museum. I loved this museum, specially because of the Monet paints. I really do recommend going to this museum BEFORE going to others, because this one is small and has many paintings from important artists: Its a great way of learning about them.

Panoramic water lilies and more. As we are visiting Monet's gardens we decided to pay homage to the artist's dreamily beautiful water lily panels. Absolutely stunning art work within the Musee de la Orangerie. Monet achieved his objective of giving the public respite from the ravages of inhumanity from the First World War. Well worth a visit and not as exhausting as the bigger galleries and museums.
If you like Monet, add this to your list. Some of Monet's larger works are on display here. There was not a line to enter and not so crowded that you couldn't get close to the displays

Beautiful Monets. L'Orangerie is a charming smallish museum at one end of The Tuilleries -- The Louvre is at the other end. It has one floor with 8 VERY large Monets of Giverny as well as other works of art by him at other Impressionists.

Monet's final masterpiece awaits you.. Musee de l'Orangerie should be visited close to the Musee d'Orsay. Here you will find Monet's final masterpiece, Les Nymphees, occupying two huge oval rooms. There are also many other chef d'ouvres from other artists of the period.

Don' Take Your Selfie Sticks Inside, PLEASE. The museums in Paris are my favorite sites to see when I'm in town, so I was surprised when I discovered I'd never been to this one. I hurried across town, and after waiting in a short line, was viewing the collection of Impressionist masterpieces. It's not a large museum by any means, but it is well laid out and does not take long to go through. A few hours at most. Monet's "Water Lillies" are beautiful to see in person, though that experience is a bit marred by all the other tourists taking selfies with their selfie sticks. I just don't understand that fad. Quite a few artists I was unfamiliar with were on display. I had a very enjoyable afternoon. A nice café can be found inside, too.

L'Orangerie. Now this is my favorite museum in Paris. I can spend hours here, each time I visit, and never get bored. It creates a feeling of such peacefulness within that you never want to leave. The walk to/from the museum is also a beautiful beginning to a wonderful viewing.
A must-see impressionist opus!. Breathtaking scope of work. Be sure to immerse yourself in the background history in the making the paintings, you become submerged in the colors and textures.
Small with a big impact . 5minute waiting line, only 9 €. Fabulous Monet lilies panoramic paintings! Plus other fabulous painters , Picasso and Renoir.
Not to be missed. Take your time. Look at the artworks. Sit in the rooms with the Monet panels, this is a not to be missed opportunity.

Highlight. By far a highlight of our trip this time. We were all stunned by the sheer beauty of Monet's work so marvellously displayed across the curved walls. Time did not permit otherwise we would have loved to linger to admire and reflect on the paintings.
Lovely presentation of these large works. This was another of our favorites. We enjoyed resting on the benches in the center of the rooms to take in the enormous works. Lovely to get so close.

Stunning. Go early to see the stunning Monet water lily panoramas displayed in an attractive setting. It is worth noting that unlike many museums this art exhibition is closed on a TUESDAY. When we visited early on Wednesday the queues were very short and we were able to visit the paintings without too many people. Downstairs there is a lovely collection of impressionist paintings all bought by a couple of collectors - we enjoyed seeing a miniature of their apartment showing how the paintings were displayed. They certainly had amazing taste.
Paris Museum. If you like Monet don't miss this museum. The large pieces by Monet surround the room and will take you to the places he painted by pulling you into the paintings. Wonderful.

Monet's most famous paintings. What more can his fans want!. After its closure for update a few years ago I visited The Orangery to see Monet's famous works of waterlilies etc. If you are a follower of his work you must see this. Wall after wall of his well known work without a frame. Even if Monet is not your most favourite Impressionist these works are quite stunning to see. Do not forget he is the artist that earned the name Impressionist as an insult to his work by a critic. Take the time to stroll from The Louvre through Jardin des Tuileries. A lovely park, and at the end of the park just a small gallery but well worth it for an Impressionist fan.

Great museum. We went to this museum to see the Monet's but was very pleasantly surprised with all the other artworks on display. Most impressive and lots of different artists. This museum seems to float under the radar as there was no queues and it was not crowded, allowing fee and easy access to view all the art.
H and P take Paris. This museum is only worth it if you want to see Monet's Waterlilys in the round. Line wasn't too long. An attractive and updated building inside.

Monet's water lilies and one of the best collections of early 20th century art in the world. There is little to dislike in this wonderful space. Okay, the café and bookshop should be accessible to all, without having to pass through the ticket turnstile. Aside from that, nothing but masterpieces from the likes of Picasso, Soutine and Cézanne. Then there are the two elliptical rooms in which you are literally surrounded by Monet's water lily paintings. These paintings are, in fact, the reason this building was renovated and dedicated to fine arts in the first place. Please go first thing in the morning so that you might have the chance to sit and just absorb the experience of these works without the afternoon crowds.

A must for every Monet-Fan. as only here you'll find the special made eight oval pictures "Nympheas" from Claude Monet. The museum offers some other good pictures from impressionists and I would recommend to buy a double entrance for this and the Musée d'Orsay (16 Euro).
