Make sure to come early in the morning to avoid longer waiting lines during vacation season. The audio guide is always nice to have (5 Euro). The walk between the two museums is about 5 minutes over the "lock-bridge".

Beautiful display of Monet as he intended. This is a museum that takes you to Monet's family garden. The circular display is as the artist intended and is part of the experience. After viewing thousands of framed art pieces in magnificent museums, the simplicity and beauty of this setting is refreshing. I don't think this is a must see museum, but it should be high on anyone's list if Monet is a favorite.

What's not to love?! Calm, cool, and plein air!. This is my absolute favorite museum (so far) because of its calm, cool atmosphere punctuated by Monet's famous murals. Visited in 2008 and again this year, a perfect escape from the summer heat. It's a fine spot to visit after the labyrinth of the Louvre because it's offerings are limited. Just continue out of the Louvre since you'll want to stroll the Tuileries anyway! Make sure to get the Museum Pass to use the shorter line, (although the security seemed to hold it up a little).

Nice & Fast to see!. It's nice not as big as the louvre or Orsay but ddefnitely worth visiting. 25 min walking from the Eiffel Tower so you can walk through the beautiful garden of the Eiffel tower enjoying the scene and a eating ice cream. They provide lockers and there is a library and a cafe.

Lovely. Not as crowded as other museums and a definite a must go! Apart from the Water Lilies (which are obviously the main attraction and absolutely beautiful), the rest of the museum is a good size to cover in around an hour to an hour and a half.

Quieter & great contents. I really enjoyed this museum. Great artwork on show. The Monet vestibules are lovely. You can leave you bags - not an orderly area for collecting/leaving them though. It's right at the front of the museum. Small shop & cafe present too.

To really enjoy this get here EARLY. Again, big Monet fan here, so I could see past the crowds, but do yourself a favor and get here before opening to really enjoy these immense canvases the Monet painted specifically for these rooms in the museum. It's divine. AND the very well appointed collection of impressionist art - namely Renoir - loved it just as much as the Orsay.
Small museum but much better than Le Louvre. Much preferred this museum to Le Louvre. Would recommend. Quiet a small museum so you don't need very long to view all of the pieces.

A pleasant surprise if you love impressionist art!!. Went here for the first time after recommendation from tour guide at Monet's House & Gardens. The murals he painted are on display here. 8 of them in total. Stunning!! Also lots of other great works. Small museum , so doesn't take long but worth the visit
Monet!. One of my favorites!! A small museum tucked int he corner of the Tullieries -- has the elliptical shaped room with Monet's water lilies which are beautiful. Easy to go through in and hour!

Awe inspiring Monet!. I adore this museum, it's oval room that displays Monet's Nympheas permanently is such a breathtaking experience! I also like that they have an amazing collection of other impressionist artists, and that it is a doable museum, its not to big and has an impressive selection of paintings on display! It also hosts some amazing temporary exhibits! I also like the fact that it lies on the borders of the Jardin des Tulleries , so after or before the museum visit you can stroll through the park, or take your children to the playground and enjoy the fresh air!

Must go. After reading trip advisor review we decided to visit and were so pleased we did - arrived at 10am - no queue whatsoever - spent an hour and a half in the museum with audioguide - would recommend to someone who wants to see some beautiful and interesting art without the hustle and bustle of the large galleries.
Monet's Nymphae. Don't miss Monet's Nymphae---mind-boggling. Sit down and contemplate...spend a LOT of time in there.

Less crowded than other museums.... I loved L'Orangerie. There is a great deal of impressionist art here. Monet was actually commissioned to paint the walls inside of this museum. The reason it is called Orangerie is because the royals stored their citrus trees inside the building back in the day. Much less crowded than other museums in Paris...and isn't too big and overwhelming. Perfect for an afternoon.

Spectacular Monet Les Nymphs, and more.. Having just spent three days in Giverny and enjoying all things Monet, it was exhilarating to see the two room installation of Les Nymphs. Although we have been to Paris on three previous occasions, this was our first visit to l'Orangerie. I recommend first time visitors try to include it in their itinerary. .
Favourite Museum in Paris. The 2 salons with Monets' large works are stunning. And the lower level is full of incredible artwork. Love this museum, and nowhere near as crowded as the Louvre!

A Small Gallery. This small gallery is worth a visit, but only after visiting others such as Musee du Louvre, Musee d'Orsay and Musee Rodin. The Monet murals are the most significant pieces of art, but there are a number of other pieces of various masters that are also enjoyable to see in an environment that is not nearly as crowded as the others.

Impressive and Comfortable. Low key and air conditioned = ahhhh in the Paris summer heat/tourist season....the "Water Lilies" were spectacular....the special exhibit (a sculptor) and impressionist paintings were well displayed and of course, masterpieces. This was worth the price and the reasonable line.

Small but Perfectly formed. The nymphaeas spead out over 8 panels in two oval rooms are compelling viewing. During our visit, there were not too many people present making the experience more satisfying. A good place for quiet contemplation and reverie.
Gallery worth a visit. Well worth a visit to see Monets Waterlillies..This had been the reason for my sisters visit and it was a very humbling quiet gallery!
Monet, Monet, Monet. the Monet's are really beautiful. take the time to get up close then back up 15-20', wow! such creativity.
Amazing. This is a bit of a hidden treasure. It doesn't take long to breeze through the entire collection and it's worth it just for the Water Lilies.
Do not miss the greatest impressionist paintings. Immerse yourself in the garden of Matisse.Usually there is some special exhibition as well.Highly recommended, in fact essential !

Do this before the Orsay!. We tried to visit the Orsay but the lines were terrible, even first thing in the morning, so we wandered across the Seine to this little wonder. No lines, and if you like Monet, essential. Full curved rooms are given over to his revolutionary art. And the museum is sufficiently small that my three young children were not bored (though we admittedly only spent 2hrs there). Don't miss the basement either, for some beautiful sculpture.

An art lover's dream. I go for Monet's waterlilies. To sit for hours and stare at genius. Many other amazing artists on display so do not be in a rush. Just wish they could do something about silly, photo snapping idiots who spoil the entire experience. Buy a postcard.

My best in Paris. As many have written before this is a must. What I liked about it are three things: very good size in terms you can wrap your hands around it, see all of it in a reasonable amount of time without getting overwhelmed or being jostled around by crowds.Of course the Monet lilies are absolutely breathtaking you can sit and spend hours gazing at them. But there's also Renoir, Picasso, Marie laurencin( I had never seen before), Andre Derain, Maurice Utrillo. I really enjoyed my two hours
A must for Monet lovers. Never realized just how big Monet's art pieces were. This building has curved walls to accentuate the beauty and size of the art.

A beautiful, memorable museum. Not to be missed!. A spectacular collection of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings in a smaller and more accessible setting. The enormous water lily murals by Money are incredible. Such a lovely spot. My favourite activity that day

It's bigger on the inside..... This turned out to be more of a gallery than we expected. Obviously the Monets are lovely, and don't take long to see, but downstairs is a pretty impressive collection that takes a while to do full justice to. With the audioguide you're certainly not going to get around in an hour, as some seem to think. While it's clearly not the Louvre, we should in retrospect have allowed more time to see this.

Monet and More!. If all you do here is spend some quiet time surrounded by Monet's water lilies, you will experience something wonderful. This museum is not nearly as crowded as the others in Paris, but it houses some of the best Impressionist works. Our two teenagers were blown away by the sheer size of the water lily panels. This is a must-see museum!

Monet is simply amazing. Anyone who loves impressionism, or beautiful paintings in general, do make a stop here! Monet's water lilies is simply breathtaking! Although it is quite small, it was very tranquil just sitting on the benches and gazing at one of Monet's masterpiece collections. This museum is covered in the Paris Museum pass and does have another line for pass holders. I would suggest to go in the morning as there are generally less people then. The museum is just by Jardin des Tuileries so after visiting the museum, we walked around the big Jardin before heading to lunch.
Breathtaking!. If you love Monet then you have to see this museum and the room created especially by him to display his "Water Lilies" series.

Another amazing gallery. This gallery offered many of the impressionist artists and was a delight. The large Monets were amazing. The morning we went it was not as crowded as some other museums, which was a bonus as you could actually stand in front of the art work and have an uninterrupted view.

The waterlily rooms...... I could spend a whole day just sitting in one of the Waterlily rooms.... so clam and so serene. Very easily accessible, great amenities, a must see if you are an art lover. Just awesome...
Worth a Visit. Peaceful and small/manageable size. Definitely worth a trip when you're in the area for the bigger, more popular museums.

One of my Favorites.... ... Until we went to the ACTUAL water lilies in Giverny! But it's an easy museum to peruse some of the best paintings and sculptures. Just couldn't get over the 2 rooms of water lily panels. I went through twice. Beautiful.

Small but worth every minute. This small by comparison museum is worth your time, even if you only view Monet's "WaterLilies." But don't stop there. The collection includes works by Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Modigliani and others. They range in style from Impressionist to Cubist and come from two of the most insightful collectors, Paul Guillaume and his wife Domenica. The museum is also a great relief from the shoulder-to-shoulder crowds of the Louvre.

A must see to view the artworks of the masters. Well organised access to the museum. We did not have tickets but having arrived late afternoon, the queue was manageable and moved swiftly along. The artworks exhibited are just incredible...Monet, Picasso and more...

Monet's water lilies, but much more besides. In addition to Monet's water lilies, magnificently displayed, is a remarkable collection of art starting in the late 19th Century. Some wonderful but less-known works make this a very rewarding visit. Note discounted entry price if you buy a combined ticket with the more popular Musée d'Orsay.
For Monet Lovers. Musse de l'Orangerie is at the far end of the Tuilleries and features two rooms with Monet's water lilly murals displayed in the round. Expect to wait to get in.

The Mind of Monet. I go to see the Monets whenever I am in Paris. Since 1927, the Orangerie has dedicated two permanent exhibition spaces to these large (six and a half feet high) water lily studies and they are worth the line to get in. If you skip the Cezannes, Picassos and Matisses, you will still be glad you went. Two peaceful ovoid rooms with diffused natural light take on the contemplative feel of the artist's effort to see the water and plants in different light at dawn and dusk. The eight paintings curve around the walls giving you a feeling that you are enveloped in nature, as Monet was in Giverny where he painted them.

Monet Heaven!. If you go to any museum in Paris make it this one if just for the two oval rooms where Monet's Water Lilies are on display in all of their magnificent size and grandeur! This is included in the Paris Museum Pass but the lines here are said to be normally not long anyway. The two rooms contain the eight huge paintings of the water lilies at his garden in Giverny and they are so beautiful up-close. I sat there with tears in my eyes at the emotion that these paintings evoked in me. Words do not do them justice nor do photographs...go there and sit and wonder and be engulfed in the joy and beauty that he created. DO NOT MISS THIS!

Monet Magic!. The Monet's Water Lilies are the reason to go, but the museum does have works by Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, and Renoir as well. The museum is small, but it a worth the visit. I suggest walking through the Tuileries Gardens on your way.

Lovely small museum of art. We called in as we were walking through the Tuilleries and it was conveniently located. It was quite busy on a Wednesday afternoon and there was a small queue to get in. Like most museums and galleries in Paris you have to be prepared for a security check on entry. The 8 Monet water lilies are certainly spectacular in this setting, only marred by the crowds taking photos and selfies. The gallery downstairs also contains some interesting works of art. There is a small cafe inside which sells drinks and snacks.

Monet's water lilies are not to be missed. Gorgeous experience. Truly extraordinary. The installation is so well done and if you go at the end of the day (you really don't need more than 90 minutes) you will have minimal crowds.

Don't miss if you like Monet.. This museum is Monet's artistic contribution to the people of Paris, after WWI, and is extraordinary. This museum was designed by Monet to hang his panoramic 'Waterlilies'. There are 8 panels depicting water without horizon or banks, representing infinity. This artwork surrounds you with in 2 elliptical rooms built to Monet's specifications. The history behind this display is fascinating. One of the highlights of our trip to Paris museums.
Summer visits are "oh so crowded".. A small intimate Museum which is very very crowded in Summer. Impressionist art works are stunning, good collection.

So much more than water lilies . The big water Lilly pictures were great but make sure you've got time to enjoy the collection downstairs too. Worth getting an audio guide so you know the background of how the collection was built up and info on the pictures. No queue and pretty quiet at 9.30am on a Saturday in July.

Hidden jewel in Paris. Tucked in the Jardin des Tuileries, this lovely museum hosts not only several of Monet's water lilies in the round, but a great collection of other well known artists (Van Gogh, Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse) get the combo ticket for the d'Orsay for good value.
Mixed feelings. I found the layout to be interested here of the large Lily paintings. We really enjoyed the paintings downstairs too. I loved the Renoir's Peaches painting.

Water Lilies. Really like the fat that it was small and was not overly crowded. one room is filled with Monet's water lilies. Lower floors have great sculpture, modern paintings. Easy access on corner of the Tuilleries and Place de la Concorde.

Amazing museum overshadowed by other nearby attractions. This is an amazing museum, which I only visited on my fifth trip to Paris as there are so many attractions in Paris to chose from. If this museum was in any other city, it would attract a much larger crowd but it has competition from the nearby Louvre and Musee d'Orsay. Monet's Water Lilies are here and the main reason to go. These paintings are shown in two connecting rooms. I recommend walking back and forth between the two rooms, as the paintings start to look different the more you see them. The Walter-Guillaume Collection downstairs is also worth seeing but not the highlight of the museum.

Jewel of a museum, always worth a visit!. We discovered l'Orangerie two decades ago on our first trip to Paris. We only had one day, so we didn't want to even try the Louvre, and someone suggested that l'Orangerie would be a great place to visit that would fit well with our limited time frame. We love impressionist painters, which is what this Museum is dedicated to, and is also the home to Monet's famous Water Lilies. This is a wonderful collection of art, which also has some earlier works by Picasso. It's a perfect size if you haven't a great deal of time, or if you don't want to devote a great deal of time to art galleries. This museum is twinned with the much larger and magnificent Musee d'Orsay, so you can see both places for a combined ticket price - very reasonable!! Students 17 and under get in for free, but make sure you bring a piece of identification as proof of age. We thoroughly enjoy l'Orangerie each time we visit!

Great!. My favorite museum in Paris....you can see all of the famous impressionists, without the crowds! Everything about this museum is great...the price, location, lines, paintings, audio tours, etc.
Wonderful. If you are into impressionist art, this is the place for you. Monet's Gardens is wonderful as are the downstairs exhibits.

Monet!. This small museum had the most beautiful Monet paintings. It had no lines, and there was plenty of room to view everything. We picked up museum passes here since it wasn't busy. The two day pass is 42 euro and worth every penny! The café in the museum had delicious offerings and the fresh squeezed oj was great! Beautiful art, good snacks, and no lines make this place a wonderful stop on your tour of Paris!

Again, again and again!. A must see! We were awestruck the first time we visited the Museum to see the series of paintings in their display rooms. Had to revisit this trip and will work in a return trip again. Good to view the paintings before your trip to Giverny. Looking at the painting this time, took us instantly back to the visit to the painter's home.
Small, and underwhelming, but beautiful art. Exactly what is said in the title. Beautiful art, but long lines, and very small museum. But it has full length 50 foot paintings of Monet's waterlilies.
Worth the visit. Go just to see Water Lillies It's a small museum so it won't take that long. It is covered by the museum pass.

l'Oranerie. Monet's "Water Lillies" are on display and magnificent. Also, there is an excellent Renoir exhibit as well as other Impressionists. It should take about an hour or an hour and a half to see all of the works.

Well worth a visit. A good visit here, especially in connection with the Monet theme as Giverny was on the later itinerary. The displays of the broadscape lily paintings are excellent and well situated. A "beat the line" ticket permits you to line up in the tree-shade vs direct sunshine, and reduces but does not eliminate the wait. This is, like many others in Paris, a very popular attraction, and while small can still be quite crowded. Second only to the Musee d'Orsay for me.

worth it for the waterlilies. Monet's waterlilies were surprising. I did not expect them to be so large or on curved walls. I'm not a huge fan of modern art so most of the rest of the collection was lost on me. But there was not much of a line!
Beautiful & cohesive. The Monet rooms are stunning but the lower floors offer a much unexpected surprise. These are donations from a collecton and there are some stunning pieces. Loved this place.

Must go, but don't expect any privacy. If you haven't seen Monet's massive Water Lilly murals, you must. Get the museum pass to avoid the ticket lines, and be prepared for a big crowd in a small space.

Intimate Private Impressionist Collection Is Now Ours. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a perfect complement to the Musee D'Orsay just across the Seine (and about a 5-10 minute walk). It is smaller, but comes from a private collection and the display of Monet paintings in particular is exquisite.What art is on display? Renoir, Rousseau, Modigliani, Matisse, Gauguin, Henry Moore, Picasso, and, of course, Monet. These pieces would be snapped up by any museum in the world that could. To give credit where credit is due, it is the very great gift of Paul Guillaume, an art collector who died in 1934, and his wife. Guillaume rubbed elbows with some of the very painters in the collection, which includes portraits of him. The generosity of donors like them allow all of us to enjoy these wonderful masterpieces.Although there are many paintings by iconic artists, here are the highlights:1. The stars of the show, so to speak, are the enormous Monet waterlily paintings in two large elliptical rooms. They are extremely well presented and you can see that many of the visitors are awed by them with good reason. A large number of the visitors come here primarily to see them. They have benches in the center of the room that invite you to sit back, relax, and enjoy the vast murals.2. The Matisse paintings. Woman with Violin, Woman with Mandolin, the Boudoir, one of his Odalisque paintings. These are Matisse, in my very biased and humble opinion, at his peak.3. Modigliani. The Young Apprentice, plus one of the benefactor, Paul Guillaume himself.4. The Henry Moore sculptures outside. An art expert taught me to walk around Moore's sculptures - I highly recommend it.This museum is part of the Paris museum pass, which we highly recommend if you have several days in Paris and/or intend to visit more than a few arts attractions.This is an excellent collection, made all the more appealing by the realization that they were collected by a couple who knew the artists. We had a 20-minute wait to get in, but it was well worth it. Most come for the Monet displays (which are well worth it), but this museum has a whole lot more.

Our personal favorate in PAris. Our granddaughter agreed that this is a favorite. As it is not the Louvre or the Orsay it is not as crowded. Here are Monet's Water Lilies in the round (two rooms) and a great group of other outstanding art available. Schedule at least a couple of hours or more. Great art in great environment cannot be rushed.

A must if you are a fan Monet . We came here to see Monet's Water Lilies but were presently surprised to find the works of many other great artists such as Pablo Picasso. Top top it off there was no line to get in and hardly anyone there.
If you found my review helpful please let me know by clicking the Yes button.

A Fitting Home for Monet's Water Lily Murals. Monet's Water Lily Murals are so large that Two oval rooms of this museum were designed to showcase them. A must see for lovers of impressionist art. Admission is included with the Museum Pass.

A must for Impressionist aficionados. My wife and I visited the Musee de l'Orangerie primarily to view Monet's murals of water lilies. Those were worth the visit. One thing that made it most enjoyable was the natural lighting from the skylight used for illumination. In addition, we were pleasantly surprised at the works of others here, especially Renoir and Picasso. Yes, the Orsay has greater number of Impressionist works, but for true art lovers and especially aficionados of this genre, do not miss this museum. And to correct some of the uniformed lesser rated reviews, you can take photos as long as no flash is used. Although, I did partake in this amusing activity (MHO), at least half of the visitors did. Finally, the staff was most friendly and helpful.

Anniversay Vacation. Beautiful museum with the major artist of Paris. It was a collection of a major early 19th century art dealer. The influence of Paris and France for that matter could be felt. A must see

Great exhibition of impressionist paintings. Even though l'Orangerie is not a large gallery the number and quality of impressionist paintings is amazing. The panels by Monet are just amazing - have to be seen to be believed. Well worth the visit.

Drown in Monet's water lilies. This should be a "must stop" on everyone's tour of Paris. This intimate space feels more like the home of an art lover than a museum. This place gives you the freedom to sit and be enveloped by Monet's water lilies, and also to get up close and personal with Soutine. Unlike at Musee d'Orsay (which I do also recommend) and the Louvre, you do not have to peer around people 5 deep to get a glance at one of your favorites. Every time I have visited, I have been struck by how uncrowded it is, which I think is more a testament to the crowd control than the to the popularity of the museum, since there is often a line to get in. Holders of the Paris museum pass do get to hop the line, which to me is alone worth the price of the pass.

Great introduction to French painters. Took my 12 year old, who is semi-interested in art, to introduce her to impressionism and it was perfect. Small, great exhibits and so much better than over-crowded Louvre. Beautiful display of the famous Monet water lilies (but we did find them a little dull, and preferred the other exhibits)
Surprised collection. We were surprised to see many collection of impressionists' paints.It is worth to visit there in addition to the Musee d'Orsay.

Exquisite. The most beautiful collection of impressionist paintings can be found in the heart of the Jardins de Tuilleries. Go first thing in the morning at 9am when it opens for a quiet experience. The Monet water lily murals are divine, but don't forget to peruse the rest of their incredible collection.

If only one, then this one.. If you go to Paris and think that you need to do lots of art but kinda fear it, then skip the Louvre. Skip the Orsay. Don't get me wrong - I love these places, but if you want to see one thing that will impress you and that you can look at in quiet, then go to look at the water lillies in this smart museum. And stop fiddling with your camera. Just take it in. And breathe.
Small amazing museum. It's a small museum in Tuileries Gardens. the paintings and sculptures are more contemporary, but they have some monet's collection and renoir which are amazing.

Monet amplified. The museum is a permanent home for eight water lily murals by Monet, and even though I've been to Paris 3 times, this is the first time I visited the museum. It's much more personal than L'ourve, so the whole experience is very enjoyable for me. It was also situated next to Concorde square so quite easy to get to. The queue is long but it moves quite quickly so I wouldn't be too concerned. A must visit for Monet and Renoir fans!

An awesome display of Monet's waterlily paintings. We had no idea that these paintings were so large! The biggest was probably around 40 feet long. They are displayed beautifully in a couple of large, airy, light rooms with curving walls, & seating in the middle of the room. There was only a short queue when we visited in the early afternoon and the rooms weren't crowded. Very highly recommended.

NOSTALGIC FOR THE OLD MUSÉE!. I was a student in Paris in the 1960s and used to visit The Tuileries Gardens, Le Musée de l'Orangerie and Le Musée du Jeu de Paume on a regular basis. I have returned at other times throughout my life. My daughter and I were recently on a trip to Paris and revisited Le Musée de l'Orangerie after a twenty year gap. Monet's Water Lilies are definitely still worth a visit. We found the new museum after its renovation, however, rather disappointing. It had lost some of its old charm and seemed too modern and clinical! I am glad I saw it all those years ago!
Small museum at the park. It was nice to see the impressionist paintings, but I was annoyed that everyone in the galleries was taking a selfie. It was hard to appreciate the paintings.

Nice museum- less crowded than others. If you are looking for a smaller, less crowded museum, the Orangerie might be a good choice. We visited because it is free on the first Sunday of the month. Otherwise, we would have skipped it. The Monet exhibit is obviously the biggest draw for many tourists, but there is a great deal to see downstairs.
Small and classy. A small but classy art collection, including La Nymphaes (Water Lillies) by Monet. A very accessible art museum.

Do Not Miss de l'Orangerie. This is a quick stop. The Monet's are breathtaking (on the main floor) On the lower level, Renoir and Cézanne works are present. We just traveled from the Provence area and much of Cézanne work was done in that area; so it made it even more enjoyable. Note this museum is closed on Tuesday, rather than Monday. Also it open at 9 AM. Very convenient.

Highly touristed but essential cultural touchstone. It would be pathetic to go to Paris and not see the Waterlilies at least once. The two special-built oval upper galleries are a remarkable shrine, and don't miss the fine permanent collection downstairs. Nevertheless, it's slightly silly and amusing to find oneself surrounded by people who are clearly ticking this item off the list of experiences they can boast about to their friends back in Tulsa or China. (But then that's what I'm doing too, isn't it? The act of observing others observing is part of the experience.) Be sure to buy the Paris Museum Pass and plan your time well.
Water lilies. Small, not too crowded, lovely location.No major faults noted. Water lilies are the highlight of the museum

Nice and quick - Monet lillies amazing . This Musee is quite small which was actually nice! There is one level of painting and then of course, the rooms with Monet's Lilies. The Lilies do not disappoint and were a highlight of my museum visits. I just wished the staff would enforce the "silence" rule as it takes away from the brilliant staging of the works. I got the audio guide on the day and it covers almost every painting. So if you wanted an "express" and single museum experience in Paris, this could do it for you. Because I had been do Musee D'Orsay before I was a bit tired so only lasted an hot.

Monet's waterlilies in full scale.. Nice display of the Monet's waterlilies. The full scale of the paintings bring a new level of appreciation. To take in the larger paintings, you really need to stand on the opposite side of the room, but the crowds often force you to see it too close. The circulation in the museum is very awkward, so that bottlenecks are created.
Worth a quick stop. Small, easy to get into museum featuring Monet's large waterlillies. No lines, and neat to see them on such a large canvas. Good bathroom break if needed as well.
Little Gem. This is a wonder little GEM that many might ignore. It is surely worth a visit. Wonderfully laid out. Easy to get to. Friendly and helpful staff.
Magical Monet. Be overwhelmed by Monet's giverny painting in the main room (no photography in that specific area). The rest of the museum is great however probably does not require that much time

Buy ticket ahead as Combo Online with D'Orsay. Can book ahead entry ticket with Musee D'Orsay and avoid standing in long line to buy ticket! Much smaller exhibits - the 2 rooms of the Water Lilies and then another exhibit below. Well done.

Great stop on museum pass. If you have a museum pass, this is a must see. The surround of art is stunning. If you have the time, I would recommend going to Giverny first and seeing the inspiration, then come here on another day and seeing the inspiration, then head over to the Marmottan Monet museum to finish the Monet extravaganza.However, unless you are really into impressionism, the Orsay is a much better value for the price. I rated this an average because for the average tourist, I'm not sure this should be on the top of your list. But if you love the impressionists, for you this should be in the mix of priorities during your Paris stay.
Nice to have seen. Some art works I could enjoy at home some no. I do not enjoy deformed bodies of women. Worth to visit

Nice little museum - if you're at the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay anyway.... The highlight is the set of Monet's "Water lilies" canvases. Truly lovely. There are also paintings by other impressionists and post-impressionists but for me, at least, the rest of the collection is less memorable.

Museum L'Orangerie. A small museum but loaded with fabulous impressionist and post impressionist artists such as the wonderful 8 murals by Monet and many other stunning works by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo, among others. A very comfortable and easy museum to walk around as it is small and therefore not exhausting. Do not miss it!

Visit Giverny First. A visit to Giverny will further enhance his glorious murals. Seeing what inspired his works makes the museum experience even more meaningful.
PS Don't forget to purchase a Museum Pass!

Must see museum for fans of Claude Monet. I visited this museum for the second time in June to check their temporary exhibition as it was quite interesting last time. The oval rooms that house Monet's water lilies paintings was a tad crowded this time round so I didn't hang around as the seats in the middle of the room were mostly taken. Nonetheless, they are quite an experience if you are a first time visitor and it's highly recommended to sit and look at the paintings as it is quite therapeutic. Apart from the paintings , the small shop which is integrated with the cafe, has some unique souvenirs like puzzles and Rubic cubes with Monet's paintings on them and they certainly make great gifts for Rubic cube enthusiasts.

A different experience . This museum helps you relax, it does, the Monet murals are the best if you just need to take a break but continue with your visit to Paris. Take a deep breath and see how you calm down while enjoying the paintings. When I went it was not crowded like other museums which also help to sit down in front of the paintings. That is not the only part of the museum but it is the best
Go to say you've been there.. I think a lot of people go here because you're "supposed" to go here - and it is beautiful, but for me, the Marmottan has more to offer in the 16th.

Loved this. Go if you think you might like it.. Beautiful museum, lovely impressionist art, near the Louvre, easy to get to walking through the gardens outside the Louvre then down the road a little. It was better than I expected and I had high expectations. If you like impressionism i don't think you should miss this or the Orsay. The Marmottan is another excellent impressionist (particularly Monet) museum. Both the Marmottan and the poranegrie offer deals where you can buy tickets for Giverny with your ticket, and if you do this you can then skip the line at Giverny, (you go down a small side path before the main entrance) and the total for both tickets is slightly reduced.

More Monet. The Monet waterlily paintings here are huge and occupy two specially built rooms. These alone are worth a visit, but there's quite a bit more. The main exhibit is based on the collection of a famous dealer named Paul Guillaume. It contains many works by wonderful artists I already knew about like Picasso, Matisse and Cezanne, but I was really struck by the work of a couple of artists I hadn't seen before. I never studied art history, so I didn't know about Marie Laurencin or Chaim Soutine. Both of these artists did some remarkably beautiful things.

The best museum in Paris. Just a few minutes away from the famous Louvre museum, this is probably my favorite museum in Paris. I had very little expectations as it is rather small museum but I was totally blown away!! The 1st floor housing the water lilies series is just incredible, I felt like I can sit there the whole day and admire the paintings.

Fantastic art. Spend an hour or 2 appreciating the incredible collection of impressionist art on display including the beautiful sculptures of Adolfo Wildt. I had not heard of this sculptor before. His work alone is worth a visit to this gallery. No crowds, no lines, and it is mid summer.
The murals were wonderful. We loved the Monet Murals. The laser focus on Monet and Renior is great. It is a quick visit but you get to see some incredible works.
Excellent museum. Very well laid out. You can get through it in no more than two hours and you feel like you saw everything in the museum. The toilettes were extremely clean and accessible.

Monet's Water Lillies in a custom designed setting - very special!. Monet painted his series of Water Lillies works and then designed the layout for the museum - quite extraordinary - will take your breath away. When you buy the tickets make sure you also by for the Musee d'Orsay at the same time - or vice versa - you will make a small saving.

Exquisite Monets,. The exquisite Monet's are the focal point of this smaller museum situated close to the banks of the Seine River. Claude Monet signed a contract donating the Nymphéas series of decorative panels painted on canvas to the French government, to be displayed at the Musee de l'Orangerie. Site-seeing in Paris can be overwhelming at times, but sitting and contemplating the beauty of these incredible works of art was both peaceful and serene.The downstairs of the museum also includes many treasures with paintings by many of the masters including Renoirs, Cezanne’s, Matisse, Picasso. Impressive small museum!!
Monet, Renoir etc. What a huge secret. Value for money, not crowded and reasonably priced. Everything you'd want: Monet, Renoir etc. Good shop. Didn't try the cafe.

The Jardin of Tulleries. Amazing, beautiful gardens just walking distance from the hotel. There was a carnival at the edge of the gardens, so, if you wanted to watch some of those activities you could watch from a distance. There was a shady section where many just sat and relaxed.

Favourite Museum in Paris. Loved all of this museum. From the Nympheas in the oval rooms, to all the other impressionist's works. Tip: I visited Monet's home in Giverny the day before coming to L"Orangerie so looking at those amazing colours and lilies felt extra fulfilling after seeing the Japonese Garden.

Extraordinary impressionism paintings. I was at l'Orangerie twenty years ago and it has changed significantly since then. The main attraction are the water lilies paintings of Monet - huge paintings displayed in an oval room entirely around the walls. Sitting in the center of the room gives one the sense that they are sitting in the middle of Monet's pond in Giverny. Extraordinary! The museum also contains many paintings by well known impressionists - including an excellent large display of Renoir's work. When I was last here twenty or more years ago it seemed that this museum had yet to be discovered bu ttoday the crowds have found it - go early!

Fantastical. Water Lilies everywhere! Just amazing. Maybe a little pricy for such a small location, but it is a little haven, well worth stopping into and imagining what Giverny must have been like when Monet was there. We may have all seen Water Lilies elsewhere but it is quite a different think to enter a room and be surrounded by them.

Bucket List Destination. This museum has always been closed on previous visits to Paris. Fortunately, it was open today. Some the best painting of late 19th-early 20th centuries are on display. It has thebest collection of Soutines in the world. (Better than The Barnes!) The museum is well managed, so you may have to stand in line for a bit. It is well worth it.

Amazing water lilies!!!. Small museum with very nice paintings.We walked from Louvre to this museum. Love Monet's water lillies. Just sit back, relax and enjoy the paintings. Be sure to have a good look at the paintings close and far and see the difference.
Boring. This place was boring for me with weird sculptures and not many paintings. Thankfully the wait to enter was not very long.

My favorite of the museums I visited this trip!. The Monet Nymphias are beautiful but the private collection downstairs is not to be missed. It has more wonderful Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings than Musee Picasso or Musee D'Orsay! There should be more than one person selling tickets though to move the line along.

Simply brilliant!. We went here primarily to see Claude Monet’s Water Lilies (consisting of eight enormous wall panels arranged around two vast elliptical rooms). It was worth the visit simply to see these, but we hadn’t appreciated how amazing the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collection located in the basement of the Orangerie is. The collection consists of 25 Renoirs and 15 Cezanne’s along with many paintings by Matisse, Picasso, Rousseau’s and other contemporary (to them) artists. We had allowed ourselves most of the morning for our visit but it was insufficient time to take in all the paintings and we will have to return. On the occasion we visited, a Thursday morning in July, the gallery was quite quiet for most of the time. We also hired an audio guide whilst we were there and found it to be of excellent quality with just the right amount of information about each painting.
A place to contemplate. A beautiful place to visit to see some of Monets larger works - try and go when it's quieter Like many attractions buying a ticket early gets you in faster
Monet Exhibit 2015. It was nice to visit a smaller less hectic gallery but thought the collection of Monet paintings would be better

A real gem. This small museum at the end of the Tuileries near the Place de la Concorde, houses two impressive collections. On the top floor there are two large rooms specifically constructed for this purpose - each containing water scenes by Monet. Each canvas is large - roughly 10 feet tall and 40 feet long. The bottom floor is just as impressive in another way. The bottom floor contains the art collected by a dealer / artist representative / friend Paul Guillaume. The fact that he collected this body of work is amazing. And the works are normally arranged so that all the work of a particular artist is clustered together. in several cases, there are painting of artists such as Renoir and Cezanne in this collection that are duplicated by essentially identical but larger pieces in d'Orsay. Also, the museum normally has a special show of an artist who is not part of the permanent collection.Because the museum is not crowded, there is far more time that you can spend looking at the works of the collected artists. The one thing the museum could use would be more benches to sit and spend time admiring the wonderful collection.

Small powerful Museum. The oval rooms are amazing, go early avoid the crowds. Take a few moments in each room to appreciate the murals. Avoid the temptation to do grab your phone and do a panorama on a picture you will never look at . Instead appreciate the paintings
Don't miss the Monets. Monets large water lily paintings are wonderful don't miss sitting and contemplating these marvels. It's also a quieter gallery away from the Louvre crowds
Beautiful Collection. This museum is much less crowded than any other in town. It is totally worth the visit. The upstairs Monet exhibit is memorable.

Mesmerising. It is a gem of a museum near popular tourist spots in Paris. You can simply be one and at peace with Monet's Waterlillies. It is a welcome respite from the huge grandeur of the nearby Louvre. Visit this lovely little museum and your trip to Paris will be worth it!

Worth a Visit for its Special Exhibits. This lovely subterranean space almost always hosts a worthwhile temporary exhibit. Most recently, it highlighted contemporary Italian sculpture. L'Orangerie is of a manageable size, scale and scope so that you can spend an hour or two and then walk the Tuilleries.

Go early and it won't take more than an hour to visit. You have to see Monet's circular murals before you leave Paris. There are two, so don't forget to explore beyond the first room.
I only wish there was someone in the first room to stop all of the selfies and amateur photographers!
Go when it opens and there is no line!

Seeing the water lilies in their designed environment. The space in this museum was designed by Monet for the water lily paintings he was working on - the light, shape, size, were all what he wanted. It makes for a great experience to walk into the two rooms and see the paintings just as he envisioned them to be displayed. They are 6 feet tall and fill almost the entire walls of each room, and I really enjoyed the colors and experience of seeing them. I also appreciate that this museum is manageable - really I only need to see the two water lily rooms. There are also more works displayed downstairs, including Renoir and Picasso, which I did enjoy seeing, but the Monets are the main attraction. We spent 30 minutes enjoying the water lilies and another 30 browsing the rest of the museum. You can get free (and faster) entry with the Museum Pass, and the museum is in the middle of the beautiful Tuileries garden, so if you are able to get over there with the Pas it is definitely worth a visit.

Water lilies by Monet. We enjoy impressionists, including Monet, and this was one of the best exhibits either of us has seen. There are Renoit's, and Picasso's here but the main attraction no doubt are Monet's water lilies. Two rooms of white wall wrapped with his water lily paintings. This was so awesome and a must see. Easy to miss but right near the Louvre. We were moved to point we bought a print. Disney effect? No, it was something we wanted in our home.

Waterlilies - the reason to go. This museum is small but it is much more comfortable than the Musee D'Orsay in a way - you are not as overwhelmed by the vast amount of art works! But for me, the only reason to visit this museum is the Waterlilies by Monet. The whole experience is excellent - once you walk into the room, you are in a completely different world. This is a place I would recommend for anyone who has the love for art and in particular Monet.

Not just for Monet fans.. Just a quick walk form the Musee D'Orsay this little museum had a lot to offer. It was quite something to be surrounded by Monet's water lily paintings. The collection of art works downstairs is not to be missed. The only downside was the cafe.
Exquisite!. Not as large as some of the other art museums in Paris, but does not disappoint if you love Monet's work. Worth your time if you have the Paris museum pass!

Amazing hidden gem. Not one of the big names in museums, so it tends to be less crowded, but wow, it does not lack in great art. Yes a much smaller selection, but you aren't fighting the crowd at all times.Best part is the amazing two rooms where the enormous Monet Waterlilies are displayed. They are oval, with a well designed diffused skylight to provide a perfect light and environment to appreciate these masterpieces.

Must see. The whole family had a great time looking at the amazing art in this museum. I highly recommend taking the time to visit. This is one that you are able to get a complete viewing without an overwhelming crowd.
Worth a visit. Monet's paintings are the highlight here. A small museum but worth a visit. It has a cafe where you can take a break if needed.

Only if you love waterlilies. This is a small modern museum with huge paintings by Monet of his waterlilies. It is nicely air-conditioned and has other works by modern artists in the lower level. There is a cafe as well. If you have the museum pass, it is worth a quick run through but otherwise don't go out of your way.

Impressionist art and sculpture exhibition. Excellent sculpture exhibition of Adolfo Wildt and impressionist paintings combined with massive Monet water lilies paintings. Museum is small and intimite with an excellent small cafe and gallery shop. Well worth visiting in contrast to the huge collections in most art museums.

Water Lilies are a must see. I absolutely adore Monet. I loved this museum. It's fairly small, but the 2 rooms with the 360 degree views of Water Lilies are so worth it. I've been to Paris several times and never got around to going. I'm glad I went. If you're a Monet enthusiast, you'll adore it.

Music and art together. A bit hard to find (police we asked didn't even know where it was) but Monet's Waterlilies, with accompanying music composed to complement the paintings, were breathtaking. Other art also interesting. This museum can be seen and still leave you time to do something else. Buy a ticket ahead or a museum pass and skip a long wait in line.

A calming museum with such beauty. I love this museum...use your museum pass, or go late in afternoon to avoid crowds. Very peaceful, and plan to spend a small bit of time to fully enjoy the grandeur of the extraordinary Monet murals. Like no other!
Monet Lilly Pond. This is a quick visit. The Musee is small. The main attraction is the Monet's Water Lilies room. The paintings are so peaceful.

A small museum that packs a big punch. If you like Monet you have to come here. It is a small museum that takes less than an hour to see. The Waterlillies are so magnificent and awe-inspiring. The gallery in the lower level is eclectic and interesting.  The view from the front of the museum is lovely. It is of Place de la Concorde and the Eiffel Tower. Proving once again Paris is the most beautiul city in the world.  The day we came there was no line and it wasn't very crowded.
Monets to sit and stare at.. Small, non-crowded, bright and airy museum to view huge Monet "waterlilies" paintings. One of my favorite museums. Quick in and quick out and major impact.

Water Lilies Galore!. There are more than 200 Water Lily paintings by Claude Monet. But if you want to immerse yourself into them, this is the place. Get up close, back up and take them in from afar. Do it all here. Gorgeous!

I expected more given the reviews and what I heard from friends. I was expecting to be much more impressed with this museum. I heard great things about it from a Colleague and saw that it was highly ranked on tripadvisor. It is worth scoping out if you are in the area around the louvre/Tuilerie gardens. This location is included for free access as part of The Paris pass, there also wasn't much of a line. The main attraction is the large water lily canvas paintings by Monet (these are on the main level). Downstairs are painting by other artists, personally I didn't find them that impressive especially when you consider the quality of musee d'orsay.  The other negative was that since I visited in July the Monet lily rooms were very crowded and you couldn't get a great look at the paintings as many people were posing for selfies and taking pictures. There was one Asian tourist who was literally posing in front of the same painting 20 minutes later with up friend snapping more pictures when I returned back to the room after viewing all 8 of the large scale paintings. It was just a little frustrating that there weren't that many museum employees around to force people to move on. I noticed that at many of the art museums that tourists just go from painting to painting taking picutres rather than actually looking and appreciating the art.  Again worth going to if you're inmate area and have the Paris pass, but I personally wouldn't pay the fee just for this,mothers are much better museums in Paris. If you're that big of a Monet fan go to the musee d'orsay or musee marmotten.

Monet as always, Adolfo Wildt exhibit on now. I personally don't like the "modern" remodeling of the Orangerie, but the exhibit spaces are good. Entire first floor is rightfully devoted to Monet's Water Lily. There is a snack bar which they don't advertise. Looked nice, but we ate in a Tuileries cafe. Incredible collection of Impressionist painting, too many Renoir's unless they are your cup of tea. Wonderful display of little known post-impressionist artists. Get the combo ticket with the D'Orsay.

Paradise for fans of Impressionism. Lovely little museum, a great place to get your fill of French Art if you do not have time to do the Louvre (or you want to try something different). The highlight is the 2 purpose built rooms displaying the iconic Monet's Waterlillies series - 8 enormous paintings. The remainder of the gallery is made up of the other impressionists, all of the big names, along with some of the lesser known artists too. There is also temporary exhibitions which are included in the ticket and well worth a look - we saw Adolfo Wildt's work which made an incredible contrast to the impressionists.

So good I went again.. A must for Monet fans. I just sat there for more than an hour totally absorbed.Down stairs is the Walter-Guillaume collection which contains art by Renoir, Cézanne, Modigliani, Matisse, Picasso, Derain, Soutine and more. Not all of these artists are my cup of tea but they succeed in broadening the appeal of the museum.As a Monet fan this is number one on my list of places to visit in Paris.
Overwhelming. After visiting Giverny where Monet planted his garden and then painted his Water Lillies, it was incredible to then see the end result.

One of Paris's must-see museums. If you're walking around near the Louvre, the Tuileries, Place de la Concorde or Rue de Rivoli, you'll pass pretty close to this small museum dedicated to impressionism. Yet, a lot of people pass it by. That's a shame, because the art inside is exceptional and there is rarely long. This makes it a high payoff for very little effort. If you have the museum pass (shame on you if you don't) this makes a great target of opportunity. You'll see Monet's water lily murals displayed as he intended and a very nice small collection of impressionist art. So many museums in Paris have long lines. This one is a joy to visit. For whatever reason, security is a little more visible in this museum. You'll see more guards. Occasionally you may hear them ask somebody not to stand too close to a painting. Non-flash photography is ok.

Escape to Monet's tranquil garden!. Truly stunning. The display is top notch. We visited on the first Sunday of the month & had free admission. We arrived just as the museum opened and thus avoided long lines. This is one of our favorite Parisian museums and I highly recommend a stop here which is just a short walk from the Musee due Louvre.
l'Orangerie. Water lilies were mind blowing. The facility is well laid out and flow of art lovers does not cause unnecessary congestion.

just amazing. Monet's waterlillies on display in a curved room are just overwhelming upon entry. Two rooms upstairs with 8 large paintings are a must if you like impressionist works. Downstairs are more works by other impressionist painters.

nice quaint little place. i really liked this museum as Monet is my favourite and it is where you can see the lillies. if you go downstairs there are also some very lovely paintings. it's pretty small so we were only there an hour, but its worth paying a little extra to get the pass with Musee d'Orsay so see stuff in a more relaxing environment.

Small gallery, worth the visit. Impressive room of Renoirs! Can be visited in a short time frame. We got around it in an hour. Has regular visiting exhibitions. Oval rooms with Monets Lilly paintings - really worth seeing. Combine with a Musee d'Orsay ticket to get you into both.

Immerse yourself.. First we took our kids to see the "real" garden Monet created in Giverny. Then we came here and our kids were awestruck. Not once did they say it "didn't look real". They "got" it that it was the "feeling" of the garden, but they also still recognized it. Very Cool.

Bowled over. Before my husband and I visted the MO we had been to Monet's house and gardens in Giverny. I had expected to see Monet's paintings of water lilies in frames, so I was unprepared for the huge curved murals in two oval rooms, and I was bowled over. I was glad we'd been to Giverny first and were able to put the paintings in context.

Monet Monet Monet. A highlight of our trip. The lilies are as beautiful as everyone says they are. It's a small museum so you can get through it quickly. You can be in and out in an hour. There is other great art there to see too: Picasso, etc. Go as soon as it opens or later on before closing time. You can't go to Paris without seeing this museum.

Wonderful Impressionist Museum. L'Orangerie is smaller than Le Musee D'Orsay, but it is fantastic too! It is conveniently located in the Tuilleries Gardens and is open on Mondays which is rare for Paris museums.There are 2 large rooms which each house 4 enormous Waterlilies paintings by Monet.Downstairs there is also a wonderful permanent collection of Impressionist paintings.

Just happen to be passing. The Monet exhibition was most excellent. I was never a fan but had only ever seen his work on postcards on fridges. However the full sized work was just amazing. In the Monet exhibition you are free just to amble about take pictures and have a good old look close up of the work. There are guards wh tell you keep behind the rail. Fair enough these are priceless works. We also visited some of the other works in another part of the museum. So you can imagine we were quite shocked to find a strict adherence to a no photo rule in place. As a seasoned photographer I am aware that no flash means just that and with good reason. But here we seem to have gone back to kindergarten. We didn't hang around long as the guards seemed really oppressive. Shame as there are some fantastic pieces hanging there. 4x stars for Monet and none for the other bit.
Worth an hour of your time. Not up to a few other venues, but special because of the huge murals with wonderful color. Easy, comfortable visit.
Orangerie. Boring museumOnly worth a visit to see Monet s nympheasHuge paintings in two separate roomsShould take you 15 minThe rest is not at all worth it

Fabulous. This was the magical surprise of our visit to Paris. The Monets are stunning and the gallery layout is just superb. But it's not just the Monets, there is a fabulous collection of other paintings as well. I discovered some wonderful artists I had not encountered before.

Just for the water lilies and Picasso . Visited this museum just to see the monet water lilies. Not disaapointed. This one is walking distance from muse d orsay and the louvre. We visited this late in the afternoon. There are two queues; one to buy ticket and one for passes and preordered tickets. The guard let both the queues pass equally for the security line. Might as well be one single queue. After the security check don't join the queue again as this is for tickets if you already have a museum pass. This queue is also for audio guide. Go straight ahead for the Monet paintings. Two rooms and 8 paintings wall to wall. Superb experience.Downstairs you have impressionist paintings and Some works by Picasso. You spend around 1 hour not counting the queue time.
I loved it!. Next to the Louvres and the Tuileries Gardens, this museum is famous for the painting "Les Nymphéas" ("Water Lilies") by Claude Monet. This painting is HUGE!

having tried to visit several time at last it was reopened. The newly renovated museum houses the waterlillies by Monet other expos are housed in smaller galleries maybe a little expensive for the content. Its you call here

Treasures of Monet. This is a very good choice if one does not prefer the crowds at the bigger museums. Though I came on a Sunday where admission is free and still had to queue about 1.5 hours before getting in. It's a small museum but the section on Monet is the biggest attraction, it's well worth the time of spending an afternoon there.
Unforgettable experience. If the whole collection is worth seing, the Monet remains one of the most beautiful experiences ever offered bay painting.

Finding Peace. A smaller museum than other institutions in Paris but one you can spend hours in, marvel at Monet's Nymphéas. Do not miss the impressive impressionnist et postimpressionnist collection downstairs, you go from a masterpiece to another (Renoir, Picasso, Braque, Modigliani, Rousseau and much more), priceless

Culture in a nutshell. If you are looking for a small museum to fit in your crowded visit of Paris, this is it. The water-lilies are astonishing. You might have seen many reproductions of it, but once you have seen the real thing you fully understand its popularity. Read also about the history of these paintings and the building, and understand how lucky we are that it is still available for us to enjoy. Note: buy tickets in advance!
Can't miss Monet!. Loved this small museum - it was small enough that you could see everything in an hour or two and really enjoy it. After the craziness of the Louvre, it was a lovely change.
Extraordinary private collection. Crowded but well worth the trip Monet murals and vast collection of impressionists. Cafeteria a very poor choice. Go very early.

What an amazing view of art! Worth the trip.. You can see the main features of this museum in about an hour. Make sure you get there early since the crowds pick up later in the day. Also, unless you buy a Paris museum pass, you will wait in a long line. The museum pass gets you in a LOT of places with no wait, so make the investment. Recommend highly!

My first visit since the restoration in 2006. The huge Monets were magnificent and are displayed to great advantage in these wonderful oval spaces. The subdued light from the central windows somehow emphasises the absence of any horizon in the canvases. The gallery below the Water Lilies was pleasing and whilst not all the exhibits in the Walter-Guillaume collection appealed there were some works by artists, who I admire less than others, which were of a quality to make me quite change my mind about them. A Maurice Utrillo for one. I really enjoyed my visit.

Gem of a Museum. This is an often overlooked but must see museum, especially if you love Monet. The museum is very small, so you can easily do it without a huge time commitment and without the 'museum fatigue' that sometimes happens in massive places like the Louvre. The main attraction here is a circular room, where you are literally surrounded by four GIANT curved paintings of Monet's Waterlilies. It's a stunning and tranquil space, and must be experienced in person.
Monet's Water Lily Garden!. Loved the four large murals that Monet painted of his water lily garden - it is a must see. Then go visit his home in Giverny and see the real thing. Beautiful!

Monet Lovers. If you love Monet this small museum / Gallery is a must. If you buy a museum pass this will be included and after a walk in the Tuilleries it is a must to visit. Monet's waterlilly paintings are spectacular and the museum is set up for the best viewing experience possible.

A Museum Oasis of Calm in A Busy City. I loved this museum...it was calm, quiet, and soothing. Moving through an all white passageway of quiet preperation before experiencing Monet's Water Lillies was unique and almost spiritual. Make sure you see this Paris Gem!

Pretty. One nice thing about this museum is that it's pretty small, so i would say plan on about an hour. As with all museums in Paris buy your tickets ahead and plan on a line. This line isn't too bad compared to the Louvre. I recommend the museum pass. There are lots of young scamming gypsies around this area that travel in small packs with their clipboards asking you to sign for their supposed cause. Don't let them get too close as they will try to pick pocket you.

Simply stunning!. Home to eight of Monet's Water Lilly paintings, this is a must see. Monet himself oversaw the creation of the oval rooms displaying his paintings in natural light. Standing in front of his masterpieces is an experience unlike any other. As a fan of his work, I love this museum. Under normal circumstances, the line isn't too bad. When they have special events, the line to enter can wrap the building. Check it out before visiting.

Water Lilies!. What a pearl...it's a must while in Paris. The huge Water Lilies paintings by Monet are simply breathtaking. I just like to go and sit on the benches and breathe them in. I visit them every few times I'm in Paris, just to reconnect.

A calm, soothing space, just as Monet envisioned it!. Whether one is a fan of Monet or not, I believe the L'Orangerie is a small museum not to be skipped. Monet designed the space to display large paintings of the water lilies at his garden in Giverny. He worked on the paintings for many years before his death. He meant the L'Orangerie to be his gift to Parisians....a space where the busy Parisian can take a short break from hectic city life and be enveloped in calm and soft beauty. The two main rooms achieve exactly what Monet intended. The emotion I felt sitting on the bench in the middle of each room was simultaneously powerful, transcendental, yet tranquil and reverent. It made the visitor not a mere viewer of art, but an active participant. The L'Orangerie made me appreciate Monet in a way that viewing small canvases of his water lilies and other works could not.

Small museum but packs a punch!. This is a great museum to view Monet's water lilies. There are a couple of rooms that they are displayed with seats to rest and enjoy them. We were so grateful this museum was included on our Museum Pass.
Monet fans!. We appreciated that it was much less crowded and hasty than the other major museums. I could sit with the water lilies for hours, if my husband let me...
Nymphaeas!. Loved the beautiful wall-to-wall Monet water lillies. The lillies and gardens are captured in every shade of day light. Spectacular. This is a peaceful little museum.

Loved the guided tour in English - a bargain!. Went here solo and arrived just before the tour in English began that day at 11am. Was initially going to be effectively private, but 2 other families arrived. It did not matter. The tour guide was the best gallery guide I have had..she made both the water lilies and the collection of Paul Guillaume(sp?) live. See if you can find out when these gallery in house tours are and use them.....better than any private guide.....responsive to questions and only 6 euro on top of admission. Best 2 hours I have had in a gallery for a long time.
Excellent small museum. Museum is great if you like Modigliani and Soutine. The minus is very difficult access for people who have problem walking.

Monet is my favorite. This museum is unparalleled. It is the home of the most incredible Monet paintings that are literally wall to wall. My husband, who is not the biggest fan, fell in love with this museum. Absolutely stunning.

worth seeing. we decided to stop at this Museum to see a few more of Monet's paintings and we were not disappointed, they have his later in life, very large canvases available for viewing - 3 to a room. it's worth taking the time to just sit in the middle of the room to really consume these masterpieces. we found having the Paris Passport pass really did work well for quick and easy entry to this and many museums and other attractions..

interesting, worth a visit. worth it to see the Waterlillies in the location they were always intended to occupy. Shame about the number of people taking selfies in front of them! Also other interesting stuff on lower floors - some fauvist and other impressionist works, also temporary exhibitions.
A dream come true. The collection in here is so exciting , it was fabulous to see the Monet's and they were so beautiful.

Thought I'd Fall In Love...But I Didn't!. I expected to absolutely LOVE this museum, but I found it middle of the road. I loved being in the same room with the gargantuan Monet paintings, and loved that you could sit, and experience the natural light change as clouds passed overhead...like you were really in Giverny...but it was crowded, and an over-anxious museum worker actually "Shhhhh"'ed everyone multiple times. I found him really overbearing. I also found a typo in one of the English signs, on the first floor. I enjoyed much of the art in the private collection, but overall, nothing compares to Musee D'Orsay, still my absolute fave.If you have time to spend, this is worth a trip. But I wouldn't make it my only (or my last) museum visit, personally.
Buy tickets in advance. Queued for hours with kids which was big mistake so buy tickets online!Monets were truly amazing and a must see

Worth the effort!. If you want to see Monet's "Water Lilies" this is a "must see." Just see it, quit with the photos already! I was worried that the visitors around me were only there to photograph the work, not see it. Go later (they close at 6:00, supposedly last guests in at 5:15) like 4:00 and the line is shorter. Great collection of modern art downstairs-all with A/C

Small Impressionist Museum. This museum is located inside the Jardin de Tuileries right by the Place de la Concorde. I specifically went to see the giant works by Monet of his waterlilies. We made it to the museum half an hour before they closed so we didn't really have a chance to look at much more than the works by Monet.I prefer the small museums compared to the large ones that require a map and GPS to navigate, so I particularly enjoyed this museum. If you are a fan of impressionism you will probably enjoy this museum.

6 Paintings worth seeing. It will take as long as you want to really enjoy a very small museum with fabulous art. I would not go if you only have few days in Paris. You can always visit on your next trip.

The most wonderful place in Paris!. If you like Monet or impressionist art -- or nature -- go to this museum. It consists primarily of 2 large round rooms filled with huge paintings of Monet's water lilies. You can see the photos but they can't really capture it. Most people just sit in the middle of the room, which is hushed almost like a church, and feel the serenity of the paintings and the fact that the museum was created just to showcase them. It's near the Orsay and the Louvre but much, much, much less crowded.

Beautiful art experience. The l'Orangerie is in its 4th incarnation a fabulous place. A very nice and practical view to the greatest art Paris is famous for. The architecture is also interesting. If you fear daunting walks in big museums, this the place for you.

Not My Paris Highlight. I am a huge Monet fan and had this museum on my list as something to absolutely visit in Paris. The Monets are spectacular and there are some other Impressionistic paintings on the lower level, but if you're in Paris for only a few days, this is one I would probably skip.

Water Lilies!. Small but impressive museum focusing on the impressionists. Well worth the visit. Best known, perhaps, for Monet's water lilies, in two large oval rooms, covering the walls of both. But there's a bunch more great impressionist and post-impressionist works on view.
The best. Our favorite museum in Paris. What a setting and amazing artwork. What a treat and a great little cafe
A great art gallery. What a brilliant art gallery!So many works of impressionist art and in a beautiful setting.Even if you're not a Monet fan, you have to be amazed by the sheer size of them

Small but leaves an "impression". Long queues, in the drizzle, but worth the effort - a Paris Pass does make some difference, so I'd recommend getting one. The Monet waterlilies are, of course, the star attraction, but there is plenty more to see.

Relaxed and cool!. Not crowded, very relaxing environment and well air-conditioned (unlike Louvre which is crowded and hot). You can just sit on a padded bench and admire the beauty of the huge Waterlily paintings which encompass the room.
Well worth a visit. Excellent presentation of the Monet paintings and a very interesting collection of other works as well. Well worth a visit to this little museum. It's included in the Museum Pass.

Fabulous collection in beautiful location. I love the Musee de l'Orangerie, for the collection is small and focussed on impressionist artworks. The two rooms with Monet's Nympheas are fabulous. And this gallery is generally not overcrowded.

of the best museum in paris. this often overlooked museum is so superb. the monet rooms are stunning and even spiritual, and the rest of the collection (from one woman and her husbands collection) is so superbly curated that any lover of impressionist and post impressionist art must must come.

Enjoyable uncrouded experience. We paid a visit to the Museum on a Saturday, there was no waiting, the price was not overly high. We took the English tour at noon and this was very helpful. Th ground floor, of course has the water lillies, while the lower floor hosts a lot of highly interesting impressionist art from Picaso, Renoir, Sotin, etc...We spent some 3 hours which is so much easier than Louvre or Orsay... Highly recommended!!Great value
Away from the crowds. Quieter than the Louvre and more manageable scale. The museum has a fantastic collection of Monets. Soak up those colours.

Gem!. We split off from half our group who was going to the Louvre, and went here based on a review my 10 year old daughter read. We enjoyed the (only) 40 minute line, no crowd, manageable size for kids, and STUNNING waterlilies. Wander through the park on the way there. Best day in Paris!

Very good museum of Monet and other selected works.. This is great spot to fully absorb Monet's work in and environment especially set up for this experience. If you like his art this is a must stop. There are also a number of interesting works downstairs worth a look.

Impressionist Masterwork. If you love Monet (and I do) then do not miss this! The two oval rooms encircled with the Waterlillies is worth the visit alone. But please do not miss going downstairs and seeing the other paintings. This is what I would call a small but mighty experience. If you are going to multiple museums like our group - please get a museum pass - you avoid the lines and have unlimited access to the museums.
Great works in a beautiful set up.. Love Monet so I always visit when in Paris. One truly gets the feeling of his garden. Very dreamy paintings all about feelings and pure color and nature.

One of the most perfect and purest viewing experiences if you love Monet. The small, specialized building was designed to house the late Water Lilies of Claude Monet, who was commissioned to paint them by Clemenceau and to make them work in that space. It is a shrine, with magnificent, oval shaped rooms that surround you and have a naturally lit skylight that brings in filtered sunlight. It is really awe inspiring to sit and take in the work and realize that Monet had a hand in the overall design of this museum.I am a painter and I wanted to take some pictures of the painted surface, since these paintings do not travel and the build up of color and marks --the facture, is amazing in person and a good macro lens will get the whole surface. But no pictures are allowed. Which is probably ok, because it does force you to contemplate with your two eyes, not a lens, and to sit and stare and absorb! Worth multiple visits.  Great location-- walk through the Tuileries--have a coffee and a croissant on the way, and as you leave, end up at Place de la Concorde. Truly picturesque inside and outside.
Not a worth of visit. This just has a different layout a curved one as paintings. It also has some art works by picasso and other great artists

Overwhelmed by Monet. We went close to closing time and beat the crowds. The enormous size of the paintings was amazing. Wish we were allowed to take pictures, but it was a gift we were able to see these works of art.

Lesser Known But Worth The Trip. If you are a fan of Monet, don't miss this museum. He donated his largest lillie studies (Massive canvasses) to the state provided they build a gallery to his specifications and that alone is worth your visit. Other standouts include the Dega and Gaugan exhibits

Monet lovers do not miss. This is a wonderful museum if you love Monet. We did the Louvre for 3 hours in the morning and after lunch decided to walk through the Tuileries Gardens and go the this museum. It is a pretty walk and towards the end head left up the ramp to the museum. With the museum pass we got in right away, a very , very short line and we were in within a couple of minutes. I suggest going on a sunny day so the light will shine in and the colors on the huge water lily canvases will look so radiant. Monet painted the water lilies at many different times of the day,, so it is an interesting study on the way he sees it. This is not a very large museum, but is worth the hour or so it will take you and certainly is very pleasant getting there.. It is very fascinating to look at the lilies up and the far away, as you will see things differently. After Monet there are other Impressionist works here, Renoir, Cezanne, and Matisse to name a few. So if you like this period of painting it is definitely worth it and compliments the Louvre, being short enough to do both in one day.

Don't Just Go to See Waterlilies!. I went to the museum at 4:30, and they close at 6:00. There were still a lot of people, but that is certainly expected, since it is Paris in the summer!! The entrance fee was €9, and the audioguide was €5 (I highly recommend the audioguide!!). When you first walk in, you see Water Lilies. Yes, they are absolutely AMAZING, but they are also insanely crowded. There are so many people walking through there just to take selfies. It is pretty annoying, if you ask me. However, you just can't miss seeing them, so you'll have to put up with the selfie takers!! The rest of the museum is fantastic! So any famous painters have work there. The building alone is worth seeing. I highly recommend seeing Orangerie on your visit to Paris.

Beautiful waterlilies. Perfect size museum. The waterlilies are displayed exactly as Monet wanted them to be thus are quite an impressive sight. The collection is small enough to enjoy without getting tired but diverse and interesting
Nice escape. This museum is wonderful, but was not crowded like others, we were here on a Sunday. We could actually enjoy the art here, unlike others. It helps that I prefer impressionist art
Small but great couple of hours. Many great masterpieces.. We visited after being in the Louvre. Really good selection of fine works, more casual and well worth the visit

Wonderfully restored building. Monets Les Nympheas were hung and displayed wonderfully.. The museum was not busy and light and airy. The cafe was reasonably priced and the sales delicious. Staff helpful and friendly.The downstairs galleries also housed a collection of impressionists. Not as large as Musee d' Orsay but nevertheless well with a visit to get away from the crowds.
the water Lilies is a must!!!. eight panels presenting the passing hours from sunrise to sunsetof light on the water lilies in his water garden in Giverny.So beautiful and inspiring!!!

Come for the Monets -- and Stay for the Renoirs. The newly renovated top floor displays the water lily murals as Monet intended - flooded with natural light. Stay in the center of each room and slowly turn to see the light and the seasons change in what Monet was able to see (and interpret) with his cataract-ridden eyes.
