Just wonderful!But don't stop there! At the bottom of the stairs on the right, you will see a Renoir, then another and another -- 20+ lined down one wall. Breathtaking. Then the adjacent rooms have Cezanne, Modigliani, Matisse... The hits just keep on coming!I went as it opened on a Friday morning, got in with only a few minutes' wait and went straight to the second Monet salon. For a few wonderful moments, I was there almost alone.If you like the Impressionists, this is a small gem that presents works of many in a compact space.
Monet. So happy to have gone here early, and then later to Giverny to see the inspiration for Monet. Wonderful and go to both place.
Water lilies. Such a lovely place. We can enjoy Monet without having long que. It took us two hours to walk around which fit our plan.
Monet what else.... It's worth if only for Monet's Water Lillies. But there's so much to see...Don't miss the Guillaume Collection: Cezanne, Picasso, Modigliani and lots more!

Stunning. This museum is lesser known that many of the major museums. The queues are much shorter. We went specifically to see the Monets and well were bowled over on entering the gallery. The paintings were magnificent. There is also a collection of Renior paintings as well as other artists. Definitely worth a visit.

A Small Gem. L"Orangerie showcases Monet's water lilies in two rooms created to accommodate their serenity. Special exhibits and the lower floor of impressionist masterpieces make this a great intermezzo -

Stunning. Some of my travel books at given this a 1/2 star on a scale of 3 for "must-see's" but I could not disagree with that more. This was one of my favorites places in Paris and absolutely worth a visit on anyone's' trip for the lilies alone.This was not on our original itinerary but we were walking through the Tuileries and realized the museum was on our Paris museum pass and there was no line. Once inside, the first thing you see on the top floor are the lily rooms. I had no idea the true scope of these paintings and I was blown away by how beautifully they were presented. The floor below is a beautiful art museum with works by Monet, Renoir, etc. Look out for a room to the left that does not have any obvious markings - it is a small theater room presenting a history of Money and how his presentation of the Water Lilies came to be. Very glad we stumbled upon this! Overall a fantastic visit!

Benches to view art gave you more time than most places. My sister would give it a 5 but I thought some of the lighting was difficult to really enjoy the art. Still the benches to sit and really look at Monet's work made this truly enjoyable visit.
Monet!. Small but much less crowded than The Louvre. Much smaller collection, but more than adequate. The best Monet you'll ever see!

Great for kids. This museum was great. The natural lighting makes taking pictures a dream. Monet's Water Lily's are the star of this museum and are amazing. The cafe in the basement is a bit overpriced, but still delicious. We really enjoyed our visit here.

All about the Panoramas...sort of...other great artist too. Do a little reading and you realize this museum was renovated to house the MASSIVE Monet paintings. They are incredible, and it is hard to imagine how Monet did what he did on the canvases presented. The other works of art in the museum were also well worth viewing. Be sure to purchase the Paris Museum pass and skip the main line outside.

This well might be installation of the century - last and current. Monet is something of a genius but to see the works in this location takes your breath away. Of course you need the room to fairly empty to enjoy the whole effect.. the tourist bus had yet to arrive and the school groups had just left. Monday morning seems to be a good time. No doubt it would feel quite different on weekend afternoon. The museum holds a fairly large collection of contemporary pieces but two rooms dedicated to the these paintings are well worth the price of admission.

Poor crowd control. More crowded than other museums we visited (skipped to Louvre) and crowd control seemed disorganized. Monet "Waterlillies" obvious draw and probably worth seeing, but I would not waste a lot of time here.
Nice museum. This is a smaller museum dedicated to a few artists. However, it is well worth seeing. If you like impressionists, you will really like this.

Monet at it's best. A feast of Monet's garden with the circular rooms filled with landscapes of his art! Other artists are featured but Monet is the reason I went and I was not disappointed with what was on display. Simply stunning and a visual feast!

Sensitive Place. This musium has just size of space, quantity of pictures and visitors to watch hte pictures slowly to feel hte message of them.
my son (23 years old) said that this is the best of three musiums that are Musee de l'Orangerie, d'Orsay and L'ouvre.

The Red Bull of Paris Museums - Small and powerful. Of all the museums in Paris with masterpieces by the thousands, this museum wins for sheer concentration of fabulousness. Monet's work here is simply stunning, jaw dropping for anyone who has only seen them on posters or the random umbrella print. The sheer size alone is staggering, but the depth, color, detail and beauty is tonic for the soul. DO NOT SKIP THE BASEMENT. Although there is little signage to indicate the treasure trove of Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Mattisse and more.
This is one of the best art museums in Paris. We visited this museum several times in the last 10 years or so. In particular if you love Monet don't miss it

Awesome!. Breathtaking! To just enter the round room so early and after all the anticipation, Monet's water lilies or Nympheus are right there in front of you...As I said, breathtaking! And then you enter the second room....There was a little line when we got there but as we had purchased a dual ticket when at Musée D'orsay we were able skip the line. The building was much less ornate than I expected, probably because I had been to Musée D'orsay and the Louvre previous nights, but I wasn't disappointed, it was more that the art was doing all the talking. The exhibition downstairs is really worth looking at too, love Paris!

Small but Inspiring. It's not very big in terms of size, but if you are prepared to really sit and absorb the energy and emotion of the art, it's so worth it. You might find yourself overcome with emotion...just let it happen :)

If you love Impressionists!. We started our trip in Giverney and saw the gardens that Claude Monet developed that inspired some of his paintings. This museum brought us full circle with his Lily Pad paintings. Breathtaking.
Huge Monet. Small intimate museum with the collection of the huge Monet water lilies. His gift to Paris after WWI in the hopes of no additional wars. Just beautiful.

It does NOT let you down. I am an artist. I am an impressionist so I really needed to see Monet. The "Nympheas of Claude Monet" was a dream come true. The museum is run very well and the installation of 8 giant panels was overwhelming and meditative. The first floor has the Monets and the explanation and tours. The next floor has a little cafe and book store gift shop. The downstairs has amazing pieces as well of other impressionists and a current exhibition. It is a clean lovely museum well worth your time, but as an artist a MUST SEE. It is within walking distance of the Louvre through the central walking path that is lined with gardens and statuary and little carts to buy a coffee of ice cream. Charming and beautiful.
fro. The heart of the museum are eight pannos money's water lilies.you. Should attend mostly if you are impressionist's fun
Monet is amazing.. We wanted to relive the Monet experience after we had actually visited Giverny 2 days before. The painting did not disappoint. Worth the visit.

A must-see if you love Monet. What can I say.. I've been waiting to visit this museum for years and it does not disappoint. It's at end of Jardin Tulleries (near the Louvre) in a small building. We visited just before going to Giverny to Monet's home. Both are breathtaking.

Top 10 list on my bucket list. Great museum. Must see. On par with the Met in New York. Top 10 Museums to see . To much to see in one day. Plan what you want to see before you go. Do your homework. Worth it

Must See for any Monet Fan. You can't call yourself a Monet fan and not go to see 'Les Nymphéas'. Simply breathtaking. There are also works by Matisse, Picasso, Sisley, Renoir... so if your a Impressionism lover than along with Musee d'Orsay this is the Museum for you. It situated perfectly in the Tuileries Jardin and it's also a nice walk from the Champs-Élysées. Most often not crowded and there usually short if no queues at all.

Great surprise!. So this musuem may go unoticed but for me it was a great suprise, i loved every painting. My favorite painting it was "Les Nymphea" by Monet : beautiful and very soothing. It stays half way between Les Champs Elysées and Louvre.

More great Monet works!. Most famous for the two oval rooms of VERY large Monet works - sit and comtemplate is the best way to enjoy. Tickets including Musee d'Orsay can be bought here wich will save time queueing there. Very good works in the basement also by other big name painters.

Monet Monet Monet. We were short on time and only visited the Monet room on the ground floor, but what a treat! The huge painting in the round is amazing! We arrived about 10am on a Wednesday. There was no line to get in but when we left about 40 minutes later there were about 25 people in line. Glad we went.

A Monet Admirer's Dream. This was my favorite museum in Paris. I have loved Monet's works since I was in elementary school, so I very excited to go here and see some of his greatest (certainly largest) works in person. It did not disappoint. There was a short line outside (shaded by the trees) even with the Museum Pass because they don't allow too many people in at once to keep the main room from overcrowding. Aside from the Numpheas, there is a small collection with a variety of artists on the lower level. Compared to Musee d'Orsay and the Louvre, this is a very quick stop, which is nice because it allows you to really stop and enjoy these works without feeling rushed to see everything.

Not to be missed!. Super nice museum at the corner of the Tuileries, right by the Place de la Concorde. Excellent impressionist exhibition, small size and spectacular Claude Monet's "the Nympheas". A must if you are in Paris, not crowded and only 9 Euros.

Monet lovers' den. If you love Monet and love lilies you cannot miss Orangerie. Can spend hours enjoying the lilies. Usually this is not the first destination and for some it does not fit in their plan but not to be missed.

Monet till you drop.. We visited this museum / gallery in combination with a trip to Giverny. A book or anything on the TV will not give you the scale of these phenomenal paintings. They are enormous. If you love the impressionists this is in the top five places to stop. It's a modern airy space with room for everyone, no shoving or impatient visitors - and you can take photos, without a flash.

Monet at his best. WOW, watching the paintings on Monet on the walls is just remarkable. You can not tire of just sitting on one of the benches and enjoying them. I have been here every time I have been to Paris and do not tire of it, then again, Monet is my favorite.

You must see Monet's Water Lilies!. This is a quick stop on a long list of museums. The two rooms of the water lilies are a must see, if you like impressionism. The walk through the gardens was wonderful, I stopped for lunch halfway between this museum and the Louvre. It was a perfect day.
For Monet's Nymphéas. I was there on the museum night. It's free and not too many people. Monet's famous "Nymphéas" is incredible!

Monet's best. This is a small overlooked (in my opinion) museum. This was his last project and he designed the building. It's not big, but there is an overwhelming sense of peace here. Definitely worth a visit.

Take Your Time. In the two large rooms Monet's 'Water Lilies' and in the basement a great collection of paintings from different painters. Plus as a bonus, the current special exhibition of pieces by the Italian sculptor Adolfo Wendt.
An Intimate Encounter with The Impressionists. Love the impressionists? If you do, then Musee de l'Orangerie houses a worthy cleection. It's a must-see haven for the eyes.
Beautiful. I thought this small museum was beautifully designed to showcase the art. My husband was not a fan so we did not stay very long but I could have stayed for awhile.

More than I expected. I knew there were nice water lillies here, and they are wonderful, but there's much more. The Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection is very good with Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse, Picasso - seriously good examples of these artists' work. At the moment there is also an exhibition of Italian sculptor Adolfo Wildt's work. I'd never heard of him, but I was very impressed. I like it that the Paris Museums Pass gets you into all areas at l'Orangerie - not so at all Parisienne musees.

The water lillies will enchant you. The stars of this museum are Monet's water lillies paintings, which are breathtaking giant pieces surrounding you in an oval shaped room. If you like Impressionism, you will think you have died and gone to heaven. If you don't, skip this museum.
Beautiful Museum. This museum not only offers beautiful work by Monet, but many other great artists. It is a place I would definitely go back to. Well worth the time.

Perfect museum size. Enjoyed visiting this museum and seeing the Monet paintings. The museum is the perfect size for us to visit - it took about and hour and half to visit without rushing and without huge crowds...Actually enjoyed this unhurried, relaxed visit more than our visit to the Louvre with its enormous crowds. .

Gorgeous . If you're a fan of Monet's water lilies, you've come to the right place. It's about a 10 minute walk from the d'Orsay and a nice compliment to the Impressionist art there. All of the lily panels are assembled in very long sequential sections, and the museum has a much smaller, more intimate feel - rather like the Jeu de Palme before everything moved to the d'Orsay.

superb!. The best part of my visit was this- I always wanted to see Monet's waterlily paintings in all their glory in situ. This topped it- highly recommended for all people interested in art, the Impressionist and Monet and his magic brush strokes.

I'D GO AGAIN AND AGAIN. Great architecture and interior design. You are not always walking in hallways and huge rooms. The place is huge but you can see 80% of it in a day, one step at a time. There is a lovely cafe so when you get tired there is coffee, soda and decent food available.

Always on my must see ost. Great gallery we always combine with a picnic in the park.Stunning and enormous Monet's displayed superbly.We thoroughly enjoyed the lower floors as well which are filled with wonderful art.In our experience this is word class art without enormous crowds.Did it on the museum pass in early afternoon and had no issues getting in.

Huge Monet Panels Inside. and they alone make this museum. Not well marked as to the entry, which is accessed thru the Tuileries gardens, and still confusing there. Other art on the lower level, but the Monets are why you go there. Been there, saw it, would not go again.

Water Lillies...that's all you need to say. That's all that's about here...which is more than enough. Not as crowded as the other major museums--a blessed fact--and yet right on the Seine. If you've already done the Lourve...make this your next stop.
Incredible artworks.. Monet on a scale that has to been seen to believe! Picassos and other beautiful artwork. I bought the ticket for here plus Musee d'Orsay together. Good value.

midnight in paris. We went with our museum card so we were there when it opened and didn't have a long wait. I saw this museum in the movie so thought we'd take a look. We were fortunate that we had time to sit, and soak up the monet in the curved rooms without crowds of people.
Loved it.

Make sure you are queuing before 9am like me. In fact I was first in the queue. When the doors opened at 9am, I promptly purchased my ticket in cash to avoid delays, made my way briskly to Monet's water lilies and had the entire two rooms all to myself for a few minutes before other people started streaming through. I felt like Gil Pender in 'Midnight in Paris', just drinking in the atmosphere in peace and quiet before the masses arrived to do their selfies and video shots.Do yourself a favour, get the audio guide as the rest of the museum is truly amazing but you learn a lot about the artists and their work if you listen to the guide as you stroll about. Give yourself 2-3 hours. I could have spent more but I left as the big tour groups and their ever loud tour guides started to descend.
Short and Sweet. It's nice, but there is not much here. It took us about an hour to walk through the whole thing. Monet water lilies room is beautiful. Nice if you are looking for something shorter.

Amazing Monet Works. The museum was beautiful and seeing Monet's water lillies in person was breathtaking. The collection of impressionist paintings downstairs was also well worth the time.Be aware that you will be asked to store any bags at the coat check. You are allowed to bring a camera through the museum with you, but flash is not allowed.I highly recommend using the Paris Museum Pass with this attraction. There was a line that stretched the length of the building, but by using the pass we only had to wait for about five minutes. Well worth the cost.

Don't Miss this Charming Museum. I almost passed this wonderful museum by because I had visited the Rodin, the Louvre, and the d'Orsay but I am so happy that we stopped in for a visit. This is a great collection of Impressionism and post Impressionism in a very nice venue. It is also very accessible and well exhibited. Of course the enormous paintings of the water lilies at Giverny completely blew me away! Lovely spot and a true treasure!

Up close with famous artists. Loved it, Monet's Nymphea, lots of Picasso, Renoir and Matisse...no wait, easy friendly and time to consider and appreciate the art...for sure a go, went after the Louvre and enjoyed the slower pace

Small overlooked museum. This museum is small. It only houses about 30 pieces of art. But it is a must see. The most important pieces are Monet's Nymphaes (The Water Lilies). These pieces are made even more amazing considering he painted while being almost blind by cataracts and near his death.I invite everyone to go and sit and get lost in these paintings.
Must see. It's not known as the others museums in Paris but if you like the Impressionism you should definitely visit this musemum with the last masterpieces of Monet.

I preferred it when it was home of the Impressionists. Many years ago, l'Orangerie was the niche of the Impressionists. Now it is just modern art. Maybe I just wasn't lucky, but the exhibitions I saw were not so great. It is a pity because this museum is perfectly located, very close to the Louvre.

Monet's water lillies and more!. Don't miss it. If you love art you will find a fascinating collection here. Also, when we visited - maybe sheer luck but there were very few people around - probably because they were queued up for miles at the Musee D'Orsay!

My pick for the big Museums in Paris. I preferred spending an hour an this place than an hour or two in the Louvre or Musee D'Orsay. I went here for the Monet 360 paintings upstairs but was surprised by the quality of the works downstairs. They had rooms to the cream of modern European painters - Renoir, Picasso, Degas, with few distractions. My tip, go to the Musee D'Orsay first and buy the combined ticket first, which will allow you to skip the line here.

Not my cup of tea. So many people love it...just wasn't what I was looking for. Nice paintings in an interesting space. But just sitting around the Tuileries and people watching was more fun -- and I'm an art junkie!
Great Art Space. The Monet's are beautifully displayed in this space. We also really enjoyed the works of Matisse on display at this museum. Worth the visit.

A special annex to the D'Orsay Museum. I came to the Musee de l'Orangerie right after visiting the D'Orsay. The line up was non existent early afternoon. The Nympheas rooms were crowded though. While I cannot say I particularly loved the Monet collection at the D'Orsay, I am happy to say the double oval rooms of his wall to wall water lilies war was absolutely magnificent. So many painting strokes that if you look up close don't seem to mean much, but from farther back, create such a tapestry of blues, greens, purples and the occasional pinks and whites. A total joy to be around. I'd highly recommend this museum.

Good Museum. Collection not as big as Orsay or Louvre but we enjoyed this museum. It's relatively small so can be seen in a relatively short amount of time. Lines are short, if there are any at all. At the opposite end of Jardins de Tuilleries, so a nice walk from the Louvre.

The Monet Is worth the visit. Smaller museum, not crowded, no lines. Buy your ticket, walk to the first gallery, sit down and unwind. Don't move, don't speak, don't take silly selfies, just sit. Later, there are excellent pieces to see downstairs, but just sit.

WONDERFUL and Manageable Museum in Heart of Paris. This was my favorite museum in Paris (and I went to a LOT). It's a manageable size, and while it's crowded, it's not mobbed like The Louvre. There are the absolutely stunning Monet murals, but there's also some important works by artists like Modigliani and Renoir. We had a wonderful time at this fabulous museum. Highly recommended.

Monet's Water Lillie's are enchanting. Our first view of Monet originals was 30 yrs earlier at an exhibition in San Francisco, since then we are fans of Impressionism art. Monet's Water Lillie's are enchanting. The day was scattered rain so that helped speed things up and we were fortunate to bypass even a small line, so to enter was easy and the cost was worthwhile. The l'Orangee collection is diverse and the ability to view the art was not crowded, even the cafe was pleasant.

Not to be missed!. Anyone who loves the work of Monet must visit l'Orangerie. There are two beautiful and expansive oval rooms which display his huge canvasses to perfection. Seeing his "Nymphees" is an experience never to be forgotten. Allow time also to see the collection of early 20th century art downstairs, including works by Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne, Matisse and many others. Afterwards there is an opportunity to relax under shady trees and enjoy aspects of Paris.

Don't miss this gem. After the exhausting visit to the Louvre, this was a breath of fresh air. A totally manageable museum with such lovely art. The space is stunning. We went at around 1 PM on a Saturday and didn't have a line at all. It was so pleasant not having to deal with crowds. Our friends went on Monday at 12 PM and said that line was huge (not many museums are open on Mondays, so I would avoid this one on that day).

Worth it. It may not seem worth it to go to this relatively small gallery in Paris when there are so many fantastic museums and galleries. But yeah, it's totally worth it. It is bordered by the beautiful Tuileries Gardens and the river so even the location is special. Inside are some nice impressionist paintings and the star is Monet's Water Lilies which sprawls around a circular room. Somehow this transforms into something truly magical. I recommend you buy a combined ticket with Musee d'Orsay but take a break in between.

Like being inside a Monet painting. If you like Monet and impressionism- definitely go. This museum features the first ever art installation- where the Water Lilies cycle by Monet is set into special rooms where the paintings surround and fully immerse you. The rest of the museum features a pretty good collection of various impressionists and is of manageable size to enjoy and not get tired.

If Monet is your man, you must go. This relatively small museum does not hold as many of Monet's works as the Musee Marmottan. However, its presentation of his panoramic garden paintings makes it one of the most breathtaking spectacles in Paris. Two ovule rooms hold the Water Lilies in splendor - different seasons, different hours of the day. Magnificent and mesmerizing immediately come to mind. Besides Monet, there are dozens of Renoirs, Cezannes, Matisse, and Picassos. It's easy to navigate and well worth the price of admission.

A must for life vets of Monet & Impressionist . One of my favorite galleries. Monet's Water Lilies are hung in oval rooms with large benches for you to sit and take it all in. Other impressionists also feature here - a must see if you love Impressionists.
WATER LILIES. The amazing Water Lilies panels make this a must do. We had been to Giverny the previous day, so that made it even more meaningful. It's on the Museum Pass, so skip the line!

Hidden surprise. I was not planning to visit this museum, but a friend we connected with wanted to go see the Monet's. And it was probably the best visit of my entire trip to Paris. The Monet's are so beyond expectations given the books and pictures you see. I never expected them to cover entire walls. And it was practically empty (a rarity for our trip in June). I was able to walk right up to the paintings and really study them, then step away and still be able to see the whole thing. Do not miss this museum

Can spend half day here.... Monet at his best. Arrived early at this smallish museum with fairly level expectation. But the two oval rooms of Monet's water lilies exceeded our expectation far and beyond. Remaining art display were also outstanding, but experiencing the Monet's without much if any crowd - completely satisfying experience. Reluctantly left as museum got more crowded.

Be surrounded by light and beauty,,,Monet's Water Lilies series. There is a not-to-be-missed gem of a museum tucked into the southwest corner of the Tuileries Gardens. Musee de L’Orangerie was built to house Monet’s expansive canvases depicting one of his favorite subjects, the water lilies at his home in Giverny. Painted during various seasons and times of day, the canvases surround you and draw you into his world. The museum offers other works by Monet and other Impressionists and Post-Impressionists including Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Utrillo, and Picasso.

A beautiful Impressionist museum you can fully explore. Don't get me wrong - the Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay are world-class museums, but they are huge. If you have just a few hours to spare, you can't even scratch the surface of what they have to offer. The Orangerie, on the other hand, enables you to enjoy Les Nympheas as well as a phenomenal collection of Impressionist art in a short period of time. In just two hours, you can appreciate the works at your leisure, and leave knowing that you've taken it all in. A Parisian gem not to be missed.
Monet. I love the huge Monets! Earlier in the morning it was quiter and you were able to see the full picture without people standing in front of it.

Great Museum without Being Overwhelming. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a great museum that you can easily see in a couple of hours. The exhibits are more focused and smaller in nature so you don't feel overwhelmed at the end.

A treasure for impressionist lovers. 2 halls of enormous Monet and the ground floor gull of Remoir, Cezanne, Picasso and others
Perfect view to Concorde and Eiffel Tower just from the museum steps

color me breathless!!. I only visited the Monet Water Lilly panels on the day of my visit. There is more art on exhibit downstairs. "Only" is just so totally the wrong word when it comes to anything to do with Monet. These panels really are breath taking. The building/exhibit hall is oval shaped and the different paintings are connected into huge panels. "Sunset" with its unexpected vibrant colors was my favorite. Please go here and spend some wonderful quiet time in Monet's Garden.

Small Gem. Don't leave Paris without spending at least an hour at this small gem of a museum. It contains the eight-walled Monet panels of his garden at Giverny as its main attraction. Lesser known but even more enjoyable (unless you're a Monet fanatic) are the smallerrooms housing Renoirs, Picassos, and other Impressionists. An added attraction during our visit were three rooms filled with modern Italian sculptures. A true must-see.

A small wonderful museum well worth the visit. On the ground floor you'll find Monet's water lilies. Take your time to admire the paintings set in two oval-shaped rooms. On the lower level, there are lots of paintings by Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse and other famous artists. The museum may be relatively small, but there are many wonderful works of art that'll make your visit worthwhile.

So crowded, hard to enjoy. While I'm sure the museum is a wonderful experience for some, I was frustrated by the crowds. The flow of the lower rooms made it especially difficult to really look at the art amid the hordes of people photographing every painting. I was disappointed in the experience.

Stunning and no queues. As a fan of both Monet and Renoir I was overwhelmed with my visit to the Orangerie. The waterlily paintings were beautiful and I was allowed to take photos as long as I didn't use the flash which was a surprise for me. We enjoyed walking through all of the rooms and admiring all of the artworks but we had to go back and look at the waterlilies before leaving. We were also pleasantly surprised that we didn't have to queue before entering. The Orangerie must be a well kept secret.

Great to see. This was an enjoyable art museum to visit. It wasn't as busy as a lot of the other museums and the audio guide was excellent in describing each piece of art and giving some information on the artist. A very relaxing few hours - we were glad to have gone.
Lovely small museum. After the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay this is nice change of pace. Its main attractions are the large oval rooms displaying Monet's water lilies, and they are magnificent.

Lovley quiet museum. If you want to see a bit of art whilst in Paris (or are a huge Monet fan) this is a great museum to visit. It is not nearly as busy as the Louvre and we only waited a few minutes to get in. Lovely small gallery that doesn't take hours to go round. The water lilies are beautiful and so amazing to see up close ( they are huge long curved paintings around an oval room - well actualy 2 rooms). I took my 12-year-old son and he was quite impressed. Despite the signs saying no photos everyone seems to take them as long as there is no flash think they are ok with it.

Quality, not quantity!. Amazing art collection containing true masterpieces. One of best galleries, not only in Paris, but overall. Recommend guided tour, or at least audioguide. Take your time, at least three hours, try to avoid the busiest hours, but make sure that you are there during the day, when there is daylight (bright, sunny day). Not just great collection, but a - must see for every art lover.

Monet's Water Lilies. I recently visited the Musee de l"Orangerie for the 3rd time, just to see Monet's Water Lilies. I went shortly before closing time and it wasn't crowded at all. These huge paintings are lovely and such a sight to behold. If possible, be sure to go to Giverny and see Monet's gardens. Seeing the gardens really makes one enjoy seeing the paintings that much more.

Plan on an hour. Go when they open at 9:00 as they limit the number of visitors. Make sure you have a museum pass. We were there at 9:00 and whisked right in but people wishing to buy tickets were kept outside in a line for I don't know how long. You need an hour, maybe 2 but we found an hour enough. My daughter is a huge Monet fan so we sat for some time surrounded by water lilies. The gallery on the lower level we went through in about half an hour. There were some nice Renoirs and paintings by painters I wasn't familiar with but nothing that really screamed "You must go the Orangerie". The Orangerie is really all about the water lilies and I highly recommend it but you don't need to plan a half day. If you have time for only one, go to the d'Orsay but they are close enough that you could walk from one to the other quite easily.

A museum built for one purpose. This gem of a museum was designed with the main purpose of properly displaying 8 enormous canvases of Claude Monet's water lilies from his 30 years of painting them at Giverny. 4 panels are 50 feet long. 4 panels are 30 feet long. Two of each are displayed in side by side oval rooms. It alone is with the visit. It just so happens there are a dozen Picasso paintings along with Van Gough and other notable impressionist and Nabis painters, such as Soutine in the downstairs space.

Special Exhibit Makes this Worth a Visit. There was an exhibit of the works of Emile Bernard on the lower floor, which we visited first. I was not familiar with his work, but fell in love with it. Then, upstairs in the Monet galleries, it was exquisite to sit and absorb the works.
A great Experience. Magnificent!! I had seen pictures on-line but to sit in the room and see these great paintings was an experience i treasure.

Beautiful art in an easily seen museum. Musee de l'Orangerie is a gem of a museum. It's a not to miss attraction. The art is spectacular- and the museum is small enough to do in just an hour or so. Don't miss the Monet Waterlilies rooms.

Nice way to spend an hour. The Orangerie was included in our museum pass (highly recommended to get that). Our last day in Paris we had a spare hour. We walked to the Picasso Museum only to find it was closed on Mondays. Should have checked that. Anyway, the Orangerie contains Monet's famous landscapes of his garden at Giverny, specifically his water lilies. There is also a worthwhile collection of works by other Impressionist masters. If you are just looking for a quick look at the works, you can do this museum in an hour. There is a separate line for museum pass entrants that will get you in quicker. The two rooms that contain the lilies at various times of the day and year are very busy, but not overwhelming. The works are impressive enough to say that it is worth the diversion to the museum. I would not say this is an all-day destination.
Exquisite!. Little museum with beautiful Monet panels and a wonderful collection. Must see in Paris! Close tp the Tullerie gardens which is also wonderful to walk around.

Monet's Water Lilies. Two circular rooms hold Monet's Water Lilies; masterpieces not to be missed. Go early in the day if you can as it does get busy. Take the time to sit on the benches in the centre of each room. The walk from the Louvre through the Tuileries to reach the Orangerie is very pleasant if the weather is good.

Must.See.Monet's.Water.Lillies. Simply breathtaking. If you can go at a time when the crowds are smaller, do it. Take your time in the two rooms that contain the Nymphéas and soak in the beauty. Then go downstairs to see the rest of the museum and the impressionist works that are there.

Well worth the visit. Much much smaller than the Louvre and a lot fewer visitors which makes it easier the to get around. The quality of the works of art on show are fantastic and well worth looking at - Monet, Picasso etc.

Compact and sweet. This is a great museum that often gets over looked. The building is every bit as historic as the Louvre or d'Orsay and the collection is exceptional. The collection of Renoir is always amazing. Other less well know artists like Derain, Modigliani, and Utrillo are well represented. Picasso is also a big hit. When you're done with the lower level, don't forget to visit the main floor where Monet's massive murals are located. What I like best about this museum, besides the quality of the collection, is the compactness of the museum. You can easily take it all in before nature calls or you get hungry. God bless Paul Guillaume for stocking this place with his brilliant collection; a gift that all the world can share.

Great museum.... If only they could run it well.... I love this museum, Monet's water Lilly's are my favorite...however, today my experience was completely ruined by screaming children ( teenagers). There are staff to tell these people to keep there voices down.... Some of us really do love art....Go on low season and then maybe you can then hear yourself think....
Monet is the Man for me. beautiful museum with spectacular paintings. Many impressionist works of art but the piece de resistance is, of course, the waterlilies! Not to be missed.

Not what I expected, but ok. We missed this last trip, so went this time when Louvre lines were too long. This place still has free Sundays first Sunday of the month. Bottom floor was actually better.Advertised as "more Monets" than anyplace else, I assume they are counting by wall space, not number of pictures.

My Favorite Art Museum in Paris - Don't Skip This One!. Love this Place so much that I've visited it each time I've come to Paris. Most people swarm the Louvre & the Orsay, while the l'Orangerie is left in the dust - mistake indeed! The l'Orangerie is perfect for tourists who appreciate art but perhaps don't want to spend their entire day in an art museum. The Monet rooms are something to be seen and experienced, nothing I say here can accurately describe their beauty. Plus, you can easily visit this lovely site in an hour. Will be back again next time I'm in Paris!

Exceptional Museum--Fabulous Monet Water Lily Ponds. Fifth time in Paris and first time to visit this fabulous museum. Monet water lily room is not to be missed. Just gorgeous--what a life's achievement for an aging man. This museum is nice because only takes about an hour to see amazing art.

A Gem!!!. Don't miss this museum!! It's small but loaded with art including two rooms of Monet's huge water lillies! There were no lines when I got there and it was wonderful viewing works of impressionist's without a crowd.

No space does more justice to the artwork. I've always been a Monet fan and have seen his work in many museums around the world, but seeing the massive water lily paintings in the two large oval rooms was hands down the best. Additionally, the museum's smaller collection is a nice digestible size for those daunted by the Louvre or D'Orsay.

moved to tears. loved this little art museum the best part was the room which held the paintings of the waterlillies by monet. I actually felt really emotional as i caught site of them they are so beautiful! never had a reaction to a painting like that before and hope i dont again as its really embarrassing crying in front of a load of tourists.

The stuff could be more polite,. We visited for Monet's masterworks,but first of all the stuff could be more polite and secondly to learn some english.The fact that they were keep asking for me to cover my belly,and you could see just 3cm of it,when you could see very short skirts and diffrent kind of wearing to other guest it was very unpolite and without reason.And all of in french,a language i don't speak,and i told them that.....they just ignore me and keep saying everything in french and doing some weird faces.TOO MUCH OFFENSIVE!
Great building. Excellent exhibits in lovely building easily accesses - again having a lift makes upper floors accessible to all.

Favorite Museum in Paris. This museum was by far my favorite. It is nowhere near as big as the Orsay or Louvre, but I think it's that quaint size that makes it so enjoyable and unique. We started at the bottom and worked out way up. There was a nice variety of styles and artists. But oh my goodness, the Monet's were AMAZING. Absolutely break taking. Those alone are worth the admission price.

Incredible display of Impressionist works of art. This was a dream come true to be surrounded by some of Monet's amazing Water Lilies. The other Impressionistic art is also very neat. This museum is very manageable in just about an hour's time. Definitely use your Paris Museum Pass to skip the line!

The Best Museum in Paris. Musee de l'Orangerie was our "Ahhh" moment. A 5-minute pause in each Monet room dropped the blood pressure 20 points. The collection on the lower floor was outstanding. Our time spent here was far more beneficial than that spent in the Louvre. Bravo!

Water Lily Heaven and other impressionists too!. Walking into the museum's main floor rooms, where you are surrounded by Monet's masterpieces is a not-to-be missed experience. And then you go downstairs to a well-curated exhibit of Impressionist art. Superb.
Magnificent. Paris is the art repository of the world, and L'Orangerie is a major component. Must see and spend a couple of hours.

A Gem of a Museum. I had looked at this museum's website before going to Paris and really wanted to see the Monet paintings is houses. You have to see them to appreciate how beautiful they are. The Museum has two rooms each with four curved Monet paintings. They are breathtaking. To our delight there was also a special exhibition of sculpture by a little know Italian sculptor, Adolfo Wildt, simply superb. The museum has a lovely café and book shop. A delightful museum the should be on everyone's list to visit.

Monet died in 1926. The Orangerie opened in 1927. During the liberation of Paris in 1944, slight damage was done to the Waterlilies, but it was quickly restored.In 1965 the Paul Gaillaume Art Collection of 19th and 20th art was added to the building.When I read that Monet's eye sight was very poor when he painted this work, it helped explain to me why I thought it to be over colored. As I viewed it I could not help but think that many other painters could have 'done a better job.' However, I did like several of the individual paintings that were hanging on the walls. Isn't it amazing that when it is discovered that, say a Rembrandt - is not a Rembrandt, its price tag drops from 5 million to 200 hundred dollars. It is still the same painting. Judge the painting as a painting.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia

A must-see for impressionist lovers. Some of Monet's Waterlilies are housed here and were actually painted specifically for this exhibition place. This museum is small, but there is so much packed into the space! I think I spent about an hour gazing at the Waterlilies alone, before heading downstairs to take in more wonderful late 19th century art. If you love this era in art, it is a must-see, along with the Musee d'Orsay. And, hold on to your ticket stub, because you can use it for a discounted admission to the Musee d'Orsay and vice versa.

Awe inspiring water lilies. Claude Monet's Nympheas - 6 large mural paintings of water lilies displayed in two rooms that form the murals into the shape of infinity - are truly awe inspiring. Whether viewed from the middle of the room at a distance to take in the capture the Impressionistic genius of light and color of the lilies in the pond or getting lost up close on a particular image this display captures the height and genius of the Impressionistic movement. A must see.

Visit to LOrangerie. I visited Musee deLOrangerie with my cousin. Its a beautiful spot. It was built especially for Monets water lillies. It is spectacular and well worth a visit. U could spend time there admiring the pictures. The building itself is unusual in its design.
Monet, Renoir, Picasso - They're all here. This museum features works of art by Monet, Renoir, and others. It is not a large museum but is quite interesting and is covered by the Paris Museum Pass.

Your Respite from the Insanity of the Louvre. After getting lost three times in the Louvre and swarmed by the horrendous numbers trying to be saved by the Mona Lisa we went to the L'Orangerie as a respite. We had a museum pass so I expected to be able to jump right to the front of the line - but they had two lines - one for museum pass holders and ones who had to buy tickets. Security would let a few dozen pass holders get to the door, close that line and then let a few dozen ticket buyers line-up near the door! If they want to encourage pass purchasing let us all in first and then the ticket holders - the process in place kind of undermines the point of having a pass. If you have a daypack or large bag you must leave it at the counter before you enter. Having just come from the Louvre the silence and contemplative atmosphere immediately strikes you. In the Louvre you run the danger of someone running you through with a Selfie stick - here you have to double check that you are not at a silent religious retreat. Unlike the Louvre there are large benches for viewing the Monet Water Lily paintings. While the Monet curved paintings are interesting and definitely calming the real treat for me were the collections of other notable Impressionist artists in the basement. Even some early Picasso's before he started fracturing everything into jagged pieces. Again here it was very quiet and contemplative. Given how close it is to the Louvre and how refreshing it is to body and spirit after Louvre swarmings it is worth a visit if you plan to attend the Louvre.
Water Lilies. Great little museum, no lines. 8 large Monet's water lilies, plus works by Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso

This museum is a do not miss!. This is, perhaps, my favorite museum in Paris. Monet's Water Lillies are displayed in a room built just for their presentation and they are a work to behold. Even with a lot of visitors, it is easy to appreciate them. Just breath-taking. Many other impressionist works are also in the museum and more than worthy of time and attention as well.

Great smaller scale museum. My favorite museum in Paris is the d'Orsay. However, this museum deserves a lot of consideration, particularly if you have a little less time to devote to seeing the wonderful exhibits. Terrific location; not overwhelming in size; wonderful collection of large scale Monet water lilies; also nice collection of other impressionist/post-impressionist art. Would certainly return in a year to two for a revisit. One caution: as with most everywhere touristy in Paris, there are the seedy pickpockets waiting to steal your money, cameras, computers, phones, etc.. In the case of the one we spotted in the l'Orangerie, he was dressed in sport coat and slacks and almost looked like he belonged; however, with our experience, there was no doubt as what he was up to. We kept him in our sights and let him know by staring that we knew why he was there. He eventually left.
Pleasant couple of hours. monet waterlilies wonderful to see for real one wonders why anyone tries to take photos.-can not capture the reality.

Small but worthwhile. Worth a visit just to see Monet's Les Nympheas! Also a lot of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. Buy your ticket in advance in combination with the Musee d'Orsay to save having to queue.

A must see, try to get a guided tour. We had a guided tour and it was so worth it!! They are free and the hours are listed in the website. Our tour only had 5 people and the guide was phenomenal, made the visit a lot more enjoyable.

Worth it for the Water Lilies alone. The museum is significantly less crowded than some of the bigger ones in the same area. If you get a museum pass or are already planning to go to the D'Orsay, the entrance is included and it's worth it just to see the Monet rooms.

Beautiful jewel of Impressionist art. This is a nicely sized gallery in the Tuileries with an impressive collection of Monet murals as well as a private collection on display. After the enormous and grand Louvre, it was mind respite to focus on Monet's gracious murals and the thoughtful collection of Impressionist art.
solid museum. the staging for the lilypads was fantastic - although I am a little ambivalent about them (that's art). Enjoyed the rest of the exhibit downstairs with other artists (such as Renoir).
If you need more impressionist art after the Musee d'Orsay.. My wife wanted to see more impressionist art. I got enough from the Musee d'Orsay. It's not an overwhelming museum - fairly easy to tour.

Little impressionist gem. Warning: by your ticket in advance, otherwise you can spend an hour to get inside. This is a part of Museé d'Orsay, not by chance have you here the impressionists and Monet water lilies. The temporary exhibitions are first class always.
An Intimate Gem!. Arrived at opening time, after "morning costitutional" walk along the Seine - almost on our own - what an amazing way to see this stunning collection - advice is to go early!

Monet Magnifique!. Loved the Monet rooms. We bought dual tickets at the Musee for the garden in Giverney but then were unable to get there the next day.Suggest unless you are on a tour you do not buy in advance .

Immerse yourself in Monet!. Wonderful experience of Monet.....take time to experience it! A good selection of other works,too.Wonderful location. try breakfast at Angelina's ( hot chocolate and a brioche) before you start.

Beyond all expectations. The two room display of the lily pond was unbelievable. I recommend going straight upstairs when you get there. The museum was recently renovated and seems to be purpose built for this one incredible piece of art.
Wonderful museum. Famous for Monet's huge Nympheus rooms. Dream-like must go!

Nymphaes. You go here for Monet's epic work "Nymphaes"...some 40 years in the making the museum was remade to house it in two elliptical galleries where you are surrounded by the painting...it is epic. Gallery tends to be crowded so be patient. Photos OK but no flash. Downstairs more impressionistic works...very nice.

Overrated. In my eyes, this museum was over-rated. The entire top floor is the water lilies by Monet which is a must see, in fact probably the only reason most people go here (like myself). I was surprised to see that it was so high up on the ratings here. Only 2 floors that I can recall (saw a lot today) and really the other works in the museum were a disappointment. Great to see the Monet Masterpiece, but I would not go out of way to pay into this museum, I got in free with museumPass, which was awesome
Monet at his Best. Finally visited Paris when l'Orangerie wasn't under renovation, so got to see all of Monet's works for the first time. Paris Pass gave quick entry on a Sunday.
Something for Everyone. I went to appease my Daughter and was blown away by the stone sculture exhibit! It was the strongest exhibit I have ever seen. Unbelivable.....

A real surprise. This was a real surprise. Yes, it contains the famous waterlilies but the real reason to go is to see the collection of paintings in the lower level. You will see a bit of everyone who is famous in French art history. The space is manageably small (you won't get exhausted) and the lines to get in are tiny in comparison to big sister down the road. I would almost suggest to skip the Louvre and see the Orangerie instead. Then with your left-over time, have a sit-down in the park and contemplate what you just saw.

Two terrific shows. One exhibit was of photos of women scientists and how they feel about fashion. The other showed embroidery being done in a community in India supported by an organization in Paris.

Great compact collection of the best of the masters. I love this place. They have a Matisse I would like in my living room, they have a few this a few that and it is a great place to give an introduction to a teen, or jolt of joy to a cold an rainy day.

No queue!!. We walked straight in when we arrived at just after 9am. There were only a handful of other visitors so we were able to thoroughly enjoy the water lilies with uninterrupted viewing.The lower floor has an excellent gallery of art donated by one of the major art dealers of the early 20th Century - dozens of paintings by Renior, Monet, Cezanne, Gauguin, Pissarro, Picasso, Sisley etc with almost nobody there. Also a very interesting (temporary?) exhibit of sculpture by a major sculptor of the late 19th/early 20th C.I heartily recommend this museum to anyone who enjoys Impressionist art.

Great art, miserable reception staff!. We decided to squeeze in a visit here in our last few hours in Paris before catching the Eurostar home. Really great to see several of Monet's famous paintings, along with Cezanne, Renoir and Picasso. It's quite a small museum and we saw all we wanted in around an hour. The only low point of the visit was the security/cloakroom rules and the staff manning them - we had backpacks with us (as we were travelling later that day) and were told these had to be handed into the cloakroom facility on the way in (for security apparently, although having visited the Louvre with no such similar policy it seemed a little heavy handed). We had passports and various valuables with us so asked about the security of the cloakroom and were then told we could keep the bags with us. The whole scenario played out with the only real communication consisting of huffs, sighs and annoyed looks from the lady on the cloakroom desk, which we thought particularly rude and unwelcoming!
Excellent. Very much loved this attraction - would highly recommend. It was one of our favorite attractions on the trip.

Orangerie Museum. This is truly one of the jewels of Paris! It is full of early Picasso, and other great friends of his who were artists as well. It takes only about an hour and a half to see the entire Museum, but I sat viewing Monet's "Water Lilies" for well over an hour.If you do one thing unexpected or unmentioned in your planning for a Paris stop, visit this Museum!! You will not be disappointed, believe me!!

Amazing!. Seeing Monet's Waterlilles (Nympheas) in this large format (6.5 feet high and 42-56 feet long) was one of my favorite things on our 8-day trip. Even my 19-year old daughter, who likes art, although impressionism isn't her favorite style, was captivated. The lighting in the rooms (skylights with screens) makes the colors just come alive, and the benches are perfect for allowing visitors to soak in the beauty. Having the Paris Museum Pass allowed us to skip the line for tickets.
What a pleasant experience!. Wonderful art collection! Very comfortable and pleasant to visit. If you like Monet, Renoir, Cezanne.... YOU have to go! ENjoy!

An Impressionist masterpiece. This museum has on the first floor large canvasses- the water lilies- by Monet. There is a bench in this large white room where you can be amazed at these huge mural like paintings. The museum also displays other impressionist works by the other impressionist artists. It is covered by the museum pass . Afterwards, take a nice stroll through the Tuileries Garden which is right behind the museum for a walk to the Louvre or you can stroll down the Champs -Elysees which is in front of the museum as you look from the Place de Concorde.

One of the best no waiting line museum in Paris. We arrived at the museum about 10 a.m. on a Friday thinking we might have to wait in line but one of the Paris guide books had said head to the L'Orangerie and avoid the lines a most of the other museums in that area. We walked right in and were delighted with the exquisite art works by Renoir, Degas, Picasso and many others. In particular the 2 oval rooms featuring Monet's water lilies is exquisite, peaceful, serene, and a not to be missed experience. I'd go back again and again.
Gorgeous Monet. As well as the fabulous Monet water lilies, there were paintings by other impressionists and a lovely space to see them in.

Great little museum. Great place to kill a little time.. After leaving the Louvre, we walked through the gardens and went to the Orangerie. The other art on display didn't interest me at all, but the Monets are something to see!I wouldn't go back, but it's something you should see if you have a little time and are down at that end of the gardens.

Monet's Grand Works will make you dream in pastels. I do love Claude Monet and admire his wonderful work, but was unaware of his large works until I visited this museum. I go back every time I am in Paris. Being in a room where all four walls are covered ceiling to floor by his large panels of water lilies will make you dream in lavender, pink, green and blue. Amazing!!

Monet Must. If you like Monet, you have to see this. The 2 oval rooms where he installed panoramas of the water lilies is amazing. Could spend an hour in there alone. Full breath of the impressionists throughout. Great afternoon stroll through art history

Spectacular and easy to visit. The most impressive paintings I've ever seen! You must see Monet's water lillies that literally wrap around walls in two rooms. Absolutely breathtaking. The tiny museum also has an incredible incredible collection of works from master painters.
For Monet Lover. It's a small museum, and they have high quality of artwork. 8 of the Monet's water lilies murals are absolutely beautiful. It's probably my favorite museum among all.

Love Monet? This is your treat!. The large panel Monet's are simply mesmerizing. There are other artists in this smaller museum - but Monet is by far the key artist.
Remember - this is included on the Paris Museum Pass. Don't bring your backpacks.

Monet's Waterlilies Up Close. A smallish museum featuring Monet's masterpieces in a space specifically designed to house them, with changing natural light. Truly phenomenal. Many of the other great impressionists are featured here as well. Very manageable in size, not terribly crowded, no line to get in. If you don't have the time or patience for the Louvre, try this as an alternative.

Peaceful space in bustling Paris. The Museum is well-known for the Monet's cycle of works which is definitely worth seeing . The halls are really spacious, calming and relaxing. The paintings are extravagant and impossible to imagine. But not many people know that the museum also houses some less known works by Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Modigliani and other renowned painters. It's a must for all fans of Impressionists and for all those who want to experience a museum in a new way.

If you like Impressionism. All lovers of Impressionist painters believe that "the" place for impressionist painting is the Muse d Orsay. Do it but make sure you do Musee de l'Orangeried'Orangerie has one floor devoted to huge canvases of paintings by Monet. If you love Monet, this is the place.After being awed by Moneet you retreat to the lower level where there is what was an incredible private collection of impressionist painters representing as least one of each major painter. Renoir is well represented. This was the collection of one of the first major impressionist art dealers.

Struggled to find the entrance, but worth the stop!. Since this museum is covered by the museum pass, it was an easy choice to pop in and see what it had to offer. Easy choice, not so easy to get in- we missed the ramp up to it (no signs and a bunch of construction) and ended up circling the building. So you can find it- when facing the Louvre the ramp will go up to the right just after you get in the gates from the Concorde Plaza (or if you're facing the obelisk/pillar, go up the ramp to the left, if you go thru the gates you've gone too far). The entrance is on the west side (a small end of the building facing the plaza) but is a level higher than the plaza or the street alongside it. There was a short line just for the security check, but it went pretty quickly. The rooms with the water lilies are awesome- the guide said it was Monet's intention for the rooms to feel peaceful & be a transition from the hurried life outside- they really achieve that goal if you stand there for a few minutes and study them. We arrived about 5pm and had plenty of time to take in the whole museum before closing.

Monet collection. Small museum with an impressive Monet collection, but you have to be a Monet fan, otherwise skip it. Can be done quickly and is located in the Tulleries Garden. Nice museum to add to an afternoon.
Perfect size. I went for the water lilies but loved the entire museum. It is the perfect size for in depth exploration. So many masters in such a well sized space.

Beautiful. Must see if you are a fan of Monet or have been to Giverny. Gorgeous paintings. Definitely recommend a Museum Pass if you want to pop in and out quickly, the line was quite long when we were there. The Museum Pass significantly shortened our wait time.
Wonderful. I hadn't read up about this museum in advance so the sheer scale of the paintings came as a delightful shock. Not as full of tourists as you might expect either.

Monet lovers... rejoice!. I'm not a huge fanatic, but I do enjoy Monet paintings. It was interesting to see the gigantic water lilly paintings that Monet created for this space. The rooms are in the shape of giant ovals and the long paintings that span the length of the room are impressive. If this is your first trip to Paris, I would skip this museum unless you are a fanatical Monet fan. I've been to Paris many times, so it was neat to see a new museum, but I would advise seeing either the Louvre or the Musee D'Orsay if you only have a couple of days in Paris. This is a smaller museum with fewer paintings, although it's certainly a different experience for Monet paintings than you'll find anywhere else in terms of the size of these paintings.

Loved the Monet waterlillies. While we enjoyed the water lillies, which are huge, a bit more research on our part would have established that there are only the eight huge Monet's here. WE visited on a first Sunday, and did not pay a fee, so I am uncertain if there is normally a fee.
Peaceful and Perfrect. Havng visited Monet exhibitions for over 20 years all over the world, this was by far the best. Dont miss it.

Musée de l’Orangerie was a surprise. Musée de l’Orangerie can be found on the Seine River side of the Tuileries Garden. The main entrance to the museum faces Place de la Concorde. This museum is set since 1927 in the former orangery of the Second Empire and fitted out to shelter the Claude Monet's Nymphéas. 144 paintings of the collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume (Cézanne, Renoir, The Customs officer Rousseau, Matisse, Picasso) are exposed there.Métro or Bus stop: Concorde
Monet's grand gift to Paris. Amazing full-room super colourful waterlilly works laid out in a way that let Monet help lift up France out of its post WW1 depression.

So big!!. I love Monet and wanted to go to Musee de l'Orangerie to see the series of paintings that are contained here. We went into the first room I was blown away by the size of the paintings. I had read about how Monet had the rooms in this museum designed to hold these extra large paintings but I was not prepared for the actual size. You can sit on the benches in the center of the room and just take in the paintings. Amazing!! This was what I was looking for in my visit to Paris. French Impressionist art at its best. This museum is not as crowded as other museums in Paris.

Magnificent Monets!. Wonderful museum with huge panoramic painting by Monet.This is a must-visit in Paris.The museum is not generally very busy; we experienced no line-up.Delightfully peaceful museum with wonderful art in a spacious setting.Easy access; near the Louvre.

Small gem!. Absolute must see if you like Monet's water lilies. Entire top floor covered in these wonderful paintings. Great impressionism and post-impressionism paintings in main collection. Visiting exhibit was interesting, but very different from main collection. Easy to fit into your schedule with only 1-2 hours needed to view.

Definitely a must for Monet fans!. I did not realize how many pieces of art by Monet were in this little gem of a museum, I was struck in awe when I entered the large room with the waterlilies all around this magnificent room.
The rest of the museum only took under an hour to see but all worth it.....

So glad we went. Early in our trip we decided we didn't have time to fit in this museum, on the off chance as we were passing by we decided to go in.The queue was quite long but moved very quickly.Was definitely worth the trip and so glad we didn't miss this place.Monet's Les Nympheas (water lilies) are truly breathtaking, the paintings are displayed in two oval rooms, which I could spend a lot of time in viewing these beautiful works.The museum itself is very nicely kept, and the rest of the exhibition is also lovely, although the water lilies are the star of the show.
Amazing. A museum very modern, beautiful, exciting, huge works of course with natural light, very interesting.

One of the top spots for impressionist paintings. A very well organized and annotated presentation of impressionist art, centered around Monet's Water Lilies. Carve out at least a few hours for this show. Admission does NOT include the tour headset, which is an additional 5 euros, but I'd highly recommend it -- the narration is excellent. This is an extremely "accessible" museum both for the art aficionado and the novice.

Outstanding, a must do. Most people know about the Louve, but unless they dig a bit further for great art in Paris they will miss experiencing Monet's Water Lilies. The museum was built to house these awe inspiring iconic works of art. You can never get a true sence of the scope and scale of these paintings without experiencing them. The Water Lilies, are just some of the amazing works of art that just fill your soul at this Museum. Make time to take your time. We went on one of the day's the museum was open late. As a result we were able to fit both this museum and the Musée d'Orsay in the same day. I would recommend coming with the intent of spending at least half the day. If you like to sketch bring a sketch book and pencils with you. Make sure you take time to hang out to just sit, appreciate and reflect on The Water Lilies in both rooms the paintings are in.

A Great Gift to the Parisians post WW1. This is a must visit in Paris. Some can linger for hours while others can pass through in 30 minutes. Its truly a masterpiece and like art the museum means something differently to each viewer. You have to see this and marvel at how Monet captured his images and brings them to life in Paris. It's truly a gift to mankind and this is coming from someone who isn't passionate about art.

Stop in to see the Water Lilies. The museum, which is covered by the Paris Museum Pass, is best known for its incredible exhibition of Monet's Les Nympheas [water lilies]. 8 large oil paintings are displayed in 2 oval shaped rooms dedicated to the exhibit. They are impressive works worth a quick stop. The museum is located in Tuileries Gardens just a short walk from the Louvre. The line was short on a Wedneday afternoon and we got in with just a few minute wait. We visited before a trip to Monet's Gardens in Giverney.

Go late in the afternoon to avoid the crowds. Stunning works in this smallish space which is a pleasant reprieve from the larger time consuming museums in Paris. We went late in the afternoon around 430 and it was quiet .... No queues!!! Good value and kids are free :)

Wonderful and peaceful place to sit with Monets. Wow - what a beautiful way to appreciate Monet's Waterlilies... The two rooms featuring these works are just stunning. Take time to sit and engage with Moent's study of the Waterlilies over different times of the day and study the subtle variations. To be surrounded by them is something I will always remember. The rest of the collection is worth a look, too, of course but I found myself drawn back to the Moent rooms.
Les Nymphéas. On this museum I discovered my fascination for Monet. I love Les Nymphéas. Is a tiny museum but it is worth it. Remeber to use the Paris Museum Pass to save some money

Relaxing, modern, filled with brilliant art. On a very hot day in Paris, I stopped at the musée de l'orangerie and not only did it give me a respite from the heat but also immersed me into beautiful brilliant art. Some artists I knew well others I met for the first time. Terrific venue for viewing art. Also, staff is very lovely and helpful.

Very well curated art gallery. Hadn't been there for many decades and very much enjoyed teh recent refurb. Monet's Water Lilies now have an almost shrine like status. But there's other excellent work as well - Impressionist & post Impressionist. Longish queues when I was there. Best book in advance.

A great setting for Monet's water lilies. Often missed off the list of "must see's" which is a big mistake particularly if you like Monet's water lilies. And you really must then follow this up with a half day visit to Giveney which was the highlight for us
Amaziang. We had a limited time and only visited the Monet water lily paintings which were so impressive. There's nothing like seeing these famous works of art in person.

nice little museum. there is main reason to come here: water lilies. And yes, it is worth the visit. Some may not like this museum due to its small size and limited exhibit compare to Luvre or Orsay, but after visiting so many big museum, I prefer this smaller one, which felt more quiet and personal.

You go for waterlilies and won't be disappointed. Don't miss this one, you go for the waterlilies and the 2 purpose-built rooms to exhibit them are excellent and you will have time and space to spend some time enjoying them. There are also some other paintings to see of course Renoirs, Cezannes, Modiglianis etc., not lots but you came for the Monets. The building is really good and the walk down the Tuileries from the Pyramid to Concorde is interesting, enchanting and historic. So for a leisurely break from the mayhem of Louvre do yourself a favour and enjoy the L'orangerie experience.
Monet. This is a favorite museum of ours. It's so serene. The temporary exhibition was good but I go for the permanent collection.

Took my breath away. This was by far the highlight of my trip to Paris. I didn't want to leave. There are no words or pictures to describe Monets masterpieces. The magnitude and beauty is beyond anything I have ever seen anywhere.

BEST MUSEUM TO VISIT. We went at 9:00 am and walked right in. Crowd was not bad and you can leisurely take in everything. Great collection of Monet, Renoir, Picasso and others. Room with the water lilies is spell binding.

It's the lilies. While there are plenty of nice but second tier Impressionist paintings at the Orangerie (2 of the 3 Modigliani's and some of Soutine's work are exceptions), Monet's lilies in the first oblong chamber are what the museum is all about, and worth the price od admission.

Expected more. Ground floor has Monet's eight large canvas of water lilies--Les Nympheas--displayed to two oval rooms. I really like much of Monet's work but was underwhelmed by these.Some works of other artists (Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso) are displayed on other levels. There was also a temporary sculpture exhibit by Adolfo Wildt.The Musee d' Orangerie is many notches below the Musee d'Orsay and the Louvre.

Wonderful. You are essentially paying and queuing to see Monet's 8 paintings in two rooms but it is well worth both (even in the rain.) The rooms are perfect to house these massive pieces and there is an incredible sense of peace despite the usual frenzy of photography. Choose your favourite and then just sit on a chair in the middle of the room and take it in for a while.

Monet and more. This was certainly one of the highlights of a brief 'city break' - nothing prepares you for seeing the Monets displayed so magnificently. Faster entrance with the museum pass too, so worth bearing in mind if you're visiting several sites.

Wonderful art collection and no crowds. This museum is home to some of Monet's most beautiful work and lots of other gorgeous art. Since most tourists and tour-groups head for the Louvre and d'Orsay, this small museum is quieter and you are able to enjoy the art more. The ticket lines are reasonably short which is a huge plus in Paris.

If you like Impressionists, it is a must see. We bought combined tickets for this museum and Musee d'Orsay. We toured the impressionists on the lower ground first and then made our way to the ground floor and the two oval rooms designed to showcase Monet's water lily paintings. Just wow! The two rooms are set up with ample seating so you can just sit and admire the artwork. It was very peaceful despite the number of other people viewing it at the same time.

Very nice exhibit. This building was primarily designed to display Monet's "water lilies" panels. A very impressive work presented in semicircular galleries. There is a limited collection of some other painters from an individual's private collection. This is a small museum, so you will not be spending many hours there. There may be a line, and the waiting is outside (be prepared if it rains).

Musee de l'Orangerie. It's certainly worth a visit. You've got a room entirely surrounded by Monet's water lilies -- and then, there's quite a bit more impressionism, including some wonderful paintings by Modigliani that I've never seen.

Spectacular art, mainly featuring impressionists. This art museum is a perfect size. It is modern and beautifully laid out. The very large Monet paintings cover the walls from floor to ceiling...transporting the viewer from morning to night at Giverny. We particularly enjoyed the Cezanne and Derain paintings as well. The lighting is spectacular here. The Monet rooms have oval skylights covering most of the ceiling. A special exhibition one must pay to see, but we skipped that, preferring to focus on what we came for. There is a minimalist gift shop in one of the main corridors.

Tres Bien . We were early enough to miss any lines which was a plus. Our family loved this little museum. The Monet works were magnificent and the other collections were just as superb. I thoroughly recommend this gem especially if you have children as it is small enough to hold their interest. You also enjoy wonderful Impressionist art without the crowds of the larger museums.

Monet lovers. Beautiful peaceful experience; two lovely rooms of Monet and downstairs excellent collection of art including Impressionists. Tickets for both this and Musee D'Orsay. Come here first to avoid long lines at ticket counter at Musee D'Orsay.

Water Lilies.... We went first thing in the morning the line was not long but we had purchased tickets in advance in case. I have to say that I am not really a Monet fan but being surrounded by these beautiful canvases in their perfectly designed setting was definitely something I am glad we did not pass on. The center of the 2 rooms have benches, where if it is not too crowded, you can sit and really appreciate the paintings without feeling rushed. There were 3 of us and we all felt that the L'Orangerie was well worth the price of admission.

If you love museums but get tired of them that's the place for you. It's small and if you have tickets in advance the line is really fast. It has great paintings and you feel you can spend time but still see all of it (or most)

Monet's Water Lillies. It was the only place in Paris where I wanted to cry when I entered the galleries. Monet's Water Lillies can't be described in words. You have to go there to experience them. Then, be sure to go downstairs to experience the art of other master's of Impressionism and other art styles. I didn't want to leave the Museum de l'Orangerie.

More smoke, than fire. OK Monet's lilies are great, but the rooms in which they are shown are too small. At present, we see only brush strokes. Another 5 meters in each of the display rooms would certainly have helped.
Monet big paintings. At this museum is a few but huge Claude Monet paintings on the wall. It's very impressive to see all of those paintings in a big, round rooms and enjoy colors, shadows...

Monet's Collection at L'Orangerie. I had been to Paris before and heard about the famed Monet rooms at L’Orangerie. We got there late on a Monday afternoon, and there were fairly long lines wrapped around the side of the museum. Fortunately we had our Museum Pass, and we were able to get in quickly (we still had to wait in line for security, but bypassed the main line). Once inside, you can enter into 2 oval rooms lined with 8 Monet Water Lilies (Les Nympheas) paintings. The rooms themselves are beautiful (white, oval, and minimalist) with seating in the middle of the room. The paintings are grand and classic Monet. My husband was unimpressed, and we didn’t spend too much time there. In the basement, there are a few other rooms with a seemingly “random” collection of artwork. Nothing fantastic after coming straight from the Louvre. In addition, there was an impressive sculpture display that was definitely worth passing through (Adolpho Wildt). Bottom Line: If you are a die-hard Monet fan, than L’Orangerie is a must-see. If you are not, than I would skip the lines at L’Orangerie and head to Musee D’Orsay. The top floor has some of Monet’s most famous pieces, as well as very impressive collection!

Lovely little museum. This museum is very small but it is a lovley location and the water lillies are worth the entry fee alone. The Tuileries gardens are beautiful to stroll around and watch everyone jogging. A lovely wee gem.

Small museum. It is well worth the visit to this small museum just to see the Monet water lily collection. You can stop to admire many other works of art and still complete your visit in an hour, then have an ice cream in the garden when your finished.

Orangerie and Monet. Jardín des Tuileries is the place that holds Orangerie Musee and Monet´s waterlillies that I love. Be early with pre-bought tickets in order to avoid long lines and school groups. If you have time visit Tuileries Garden you will enjoyed it; needles to say to bring walking shoes. In order to complete Monet´s visit buy excursión to Giverny...
Loved!. I liked this small quaint museum better than the Louvre! Very intimate and you really get to enjoy all the artwork inside much better than the huge museums. Absolutely loved!

Water Lilies. Hadn't heard much about this museum and it was such a nice surprise. The Water Lilies are displayed in such a tranquil, peaceful setting that it was easy to imagine the artist's intent--well worth the time!

Worth the short wait. I had a Museum Pass so I got to wait in the short line. Took about 20 minutes to get inside. Monet's waterlillies are breathtaking. Many other fine works to check out. Crowded and VERY warm inside.

An afternoon of restorative calm. Take a moment before you go in to the Orangerie to check out the series of carved hands set on little plinths on the lookout above the Place de la Republique. They were done by the French-American artist Louise Bourgeois when she was 85, and they’re like a tender prelude before the main event (not that they were intended as such). Then spend lots of relaxing and restorative time with Monet’s waterlilies: two large oval rooms, each with four large paintings under diffused natural light. He put them here to bring solace to Parisians, and the rooms are thronged with visitors, but quite hushed. Big benches at the center of the two rooms let you sit and soak in these glorious artworks; people shuffle round and exchange places in a little minuet of unspoken politeness.
