We take a slow stroll through the rest of the museum—long corridors of Matisse and Renoir and particularly Derain, from the collection of the famous dealer Paul Guillaume and his wife—and it’s all so calm and reaffirming that I’m reluctant to check out the associated show by “the last symbolist,” Adolfo Wildt. I’m glad I do. He was an Italian sculptor influenced by Klimt and the Secessionists, and his knack for giving marble an almost translucent look, like flesh almost, invests his yearning, emotional sculptures with a great human tenderness. “I want to sing, not tell;” he said, “to exalt, not describe.” The sense of heroic striving that he gives to the faces and bodies he carves made him very popular; Mussolini’s mistress championed him. This little side show amplifies the dimension of transcendent spirituality that people tend to find in the Monets; in the bustle of Paris, an afternoon of restorative calm.

Odd queuing system and watch out for school parties. The queue for this is very odd. There is two lines, one for pre bought tickets which he let in every now and again. And then one which we joined hoping to get in. This queue hardly moved so after 30 mins of no moving and watching a school group miss both queues we almost decided to give it a miss, and then magically he let us in.Once in they take your bags and go through a security check. This is fine however you still don't know how much the tickets are ( as there is no sign outside). Inside the pictures are stunning, but because the rooms is so small it's probably the noisiest gallery I have been in. The sch party didn't really want to be there and there was nowhere to move them onto. I am glad that I saw them but........

"Boutique Museum". If you would like to paintings of many famous and only famous artists this is the Museum for you. It will not take your whole day nor will it suffocate you with art like the way Louvre does. You will be able see and enjoy a reasonable number of paintings and i honestly think that this is the limit one human being can absorb and actually enjoy in a day without having to give a break.

Iconic. Gotta see!. The museum isn't that big, but you're gonna wanna sit and just take in the beautiful room-filling Monet paintings. If you don't have time in your itinerary its not the end of the world, but it's definitely gorgeous.

Impressionism. Near to the horrifically crowded Louvre, the Musée de l'Orangerie offers works of the impressionists. It is located at one end of the Tuileries Garden. On a fine day, sit in the Garden and rest your feet when finished. Watch the tourists walk by.

Uncrowded gem. Lovely little museum. Terrific Impressionist collection in newly renovated building. Loved the Renoirs. Very uncrowded on the weekend compared to Louvre and Orsay In the park near the Place Concorde. Monet's WaterLilies in separate room.

Had to See the Monets. We had to use our museum pass to see the gigantic sized Monet paintings in two rooms of the museum. How awesome and peaceful! It was a bit hot outside too, so we were enjoying just sitting there looking at the huge paintings and also doing some people watching. We were surprised by the lower floors where they have several Renoir paintings as well as several other well known artists works! Wonderful.

First time visiting after first arriving in Paris more than 30 years ago. I had never been to the Orangerie. I had always thought that I would get there but it has taken a great deal of time. It is a small museum at the western end of the Tuileries Gardens. It is not large and the number of visitors is manageable. The importance of the impressionist is present.
A lesser known gem. As well as Monets water lilies there is a large collection downstairs of lesser known impressionists works from around the world. Fantastic stuff!

A treasure!. I've been here twice. There is a great gallery in the lower level, but the crown jewels are The Nympheas of Claude Monet. Spectacular. Awe-inspiring. Extremely well presented. Quiet. Contemplative. Probably the most beautiful art I've ever experienced. My suggestion: first visit Claude Monet's home and gardens in Giverney -- an hour or so drive west of Paris. There, you can see where he painted and also the studio where the panels for Les Nympheas were painted. That perspective adds much depth to the Orangerie. Admission is included in the Paris Museum Pass.

Monet's Waterlilies In The Round. This is a very small, very nice museum. We went to see Monet's waterlilies, displayed on long, curved walls, to show the different light, from morning to evening. They are beautiful and a unique way to see his work. There are other paintings by Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse. It was not crowded in May and we walked right in. The museum is located on the edge/within the Jardin des Tuileries. It is very easy to find and a great location among many other sites.

Simply the best. My favorite place to visit in Paris.A bit of a hidden gem.Tucked away in the South West corner of Le Tuilliers(Gardens) next to the River Seine is Musee de l'Orangerie. It houses huge art works of Monet and has many works of other 19th C. French artists(Renoir my favorite).You can buy reduced price tickets to this museum and Musee d'Orsay which will give you quicker access as well.

Great museum with a very small crowd. This museum houses a collection of Monet's Water Lilies and many other remarkable works of art. The crowd at this museum is also very light so you have the opportunity to really inspect and enjoy the art.

Absolutely worth it. This is one of my all time favourite art museums. I am a Claude Monet fan, and especially love his waterlilies. Was looking forward to this for years and finally when I did go it was totally worth the wait. If there is any way you can avoid the crowds it would be great - off season maybe. We got lucky. We arrived before the crowds started pouring in, and there were no school groups yet. There are two huge oval rooms where 8 large waterlily paintings by Monet are kept, lit only by natural light. It is simply mindblowing. Try to sit right in the centre of the seats so you can observe the paintings for a while. The best way to enjoy these are to just sit and stare at each of the canvases. Once you finish with the waterlilies, if you think that was all, there is more. There are more impressionist and post impressionist masterpieces waiting for you in the floor below. We bought the Museum Pass from here, as it was relatively less crowded - and in hindsight this was a brilliant idea as most of the other museums have really long queues.

More than water lilies. L'Orangerie is famous for its two rooms surrounded by Mpnet's outstanding murals, but the exhibit of other post-impressionist artists is excellent as well. When we visited it was not as crowded as the Orsay had been, which made our visit much more enjoyable.

Sublime. Luckily not too crowded, so one could just sit and gaze at the wonder that is Monet. So incredibly calming, just as he intended. The galleries downstairs were a great surprise, The Walter-Guillaume Collection. Allow yourself time to immerse yourself in each room of wonderful art. And we also were amazed by the special exhibition of Adolfo Wildt, on until 13 July - incredible artist, and great complementary artworks with Wildt's works.

See before going to Giverny. These paintings, are fabulous. The colors are wonderful and the sheer size is mind boggling. How anyone could paint such huge canvases is beyond my comprehension. A must see if you love Monet!
Monet Nympheas. you can take a view of Monet's Nympheas with different times of the day . you can have Cezanne , Van Gogh in this museum
See the Monet!. This is a very pleasant space with Impressionist art and more. The walls of Monet water lilies were awe-inspiring!!

Reopened. One of my favorite museums. It was closed last trip to Paris, so was top of list this time. It is WONDERFUL The Monets can never travel so you must see them there. They have expanded and done a marvelous job.

Small but Impressive collection of Masters. Used the Paris museum pass for entry. Went in the afternoon and the line was very modest compared to the other attractions. Very enjoyable for a non art buff and a beautiful Monet exhibit. Pleasant visit compared to the chaos of the Louvre Highly recommend..

Early Sunday morning. I could spend hours in the l'Orangerie looking at the water lilies by Claude Monet. The scenes are so tranquil and spiritual. early on Sunday is perfect not many people around and the peace is ahh. If I lived in Paris I would go regularly.

A must see especially if you go to Giverny. The water lilies are really what Monet is know for. And L'Orangerie is THE place to see Monet's water lilies. A must see befor going to Giverny. And the building is very interesting, often showing other excellent exhibits. It's a quick visit.
My favorite museum. The waterlilies are never forgotten. The museum is small enough to enjoy without being boring. The position makes it convenient for a walk by the Seine.

Quiet contemplation. After enduring the hordes at Le Louvre for five hours, l'Orangerie was a much welcome relief. The Monet galleries are everything you've heard: serene, stunning, quiet, just beautiful.

Yet another grey Paris museum. The museums in Paris are reliably outstanding. This is one of them. It houses Monet's famous nymphaides. When we went there was the excellent Paul Guillaume collection (a late 19th-early 20th century art dealer ) with lots of Renoirs, Cezannes, interesting early Picassos , Derains and such...Few of the really fabulously well known paintings but many that give one a real sense of the artists' works and collector's tastes.

Monet. The sheer size of the Water Lilies was amazing. It covers two entire rooms. On this rainy Wednesday morning though, the crowds were too large to fully enjoy the piece. Downstairs is a full sampling of French Impressionist artwork which should not be missed.
Go early in the day!. This is a wonderful exhibit of some of Monet's waterlilies but you need to get there very early before the crowds to fully experience it.

The Water Lillies. My favorite thing to do is stroll through the park from the Louvre to the Museum (about 15 - 20 mins). Then to simply sit in the rooms with these beautiful pieces by Monet is time well spent.

Water Lilies. The backbone of this museum is the Monet Water Lilies but this museum has so many other wonderful paintings to offer. It is a short walk through the Tuilleries Garden or across the street from the Place De La Concorde. If you plan on visiting several museums get a museum pass to skip the lines.

The Monet Water Lillies......swoon !. A really beautiful experience...seeing the Monet waterlilly paintings. The bookstore is excellent . The orange trees were outside this late spring day... I suppose they move them in in the winter..but where ?

Water Lily Pond paintings :). I loved the set up for Monet's Water Lily Pond painting, oval, white, relaxing rooms, where you could sit and just appreciate the beauty of his work. More art work is downstairs, Picasso, Renoir...many more.

Staggering Monet collection- must see. it is unlikely that you will find a Monet collection like this elsewhere. It is also displayed in a way that allows you to just sit and look. Not a massive gallery which is great. You can feel a bit underground but I guess that is to stop light affecting the paintings

Perhaps my favorite in all of Paris. A fabulous museum with the Monet's you can't resist. Sit, relax and wonder at this fabulous space where you can lose your tensions and marvel at the serenity created here. Allow yourself a little extra time ..... you'll want to linger.

Peaceful and small museum. This is one of my favorite museums in Paris. I'm a Monet and impressionist fan so you'll like it if this artist and others resonate with you. It's small enough that it doesn't take hours to see and you can spend the entire day soaking up the art if you'd like. Like the location as well. Stroll through the Tuileries, spend the day, morning or afternoon here and then savor the scenery and people watching out in the gardens. Took my small art journal and pastels and sat on the bench 'sketching inside'.
The giant Monet Water lilles are there. Can you imagine a 360 degree mural of Monet's water lilies? You will fend them there. There is other art, of course, but that's what I came to see.

Monet as he should be seen. The highlight of this gallery has to be the wonderful series of panoramic paintings by Claude Monet, Les Nymphéas (The Waterlilies), displayed as the artist intended, in large oval galleries. There is an interesting collection of other artists' works but it is worth a visit for these alone. Tips: there is no café and buy a pass that also gives you entry to the magnificent Musée D'Orsay as that will save you money and having to join the enormous lines there.

Great little museum. We very much enjoyed this small museum. The Monet's are spectacular, especially when combined to a visit to Giverny a few days earlier. The other exhibits were very interesting, and there was a good variety of artists. My husband, who is not a big art museum fan, said it was by far his favorite in Paris. We received free admittance with our Museum Pass. They were only admitting a few people into the building at a time, so while there was a special line for pass holders, we still had to wait outside for about 20 minutes. But the line for non-pass holders was a lot longer. When we did get in we agreed it was for the best, since it really helped to keep down the crowds, and allowed us to better appreciate the exhibit.

Excellent though I'm biased. I love Monet and that was the only thing I wanted to see while here. Stunning the way Monet wished them to be presented. People move through rather quickly so it's easy to get a seat on the benches in order to take in the paintings. There was a little bit of a line for Museum Pass/advance ticket holders so took a little time to get in. Normally wouldn't have minded except it was windy, cold and raining. We lucked out that the line was under the trees so we were somewhat protected.

Only good for the Monet's. It costs about 9 Euro to get in and takes about 30 minutes to an hour to see everything. The Museum pass doesn't work here. The Monet's are worth seeing for sure! They're beautiful. Other than that, I didn't see anything other than a painting of Coco Chanel that was worth my time. They say no photos, but if you don't use a flash and are discreet, no one cares. Snap away. Go first thing in the morning to avoid the huge line and tons of people inside. To really appreciate the Monet's, you need to see them when the rooms aren't filled with people. I also recommend traveling to Giverny to see Monet's house before you go to this museum, to really appreciate these masterpieces. When they say they close at 6pm, that means the doors close and no one is inside at 6pm. They won't even let you in 30 minutes before they close.

The Best Choice for Short Paris Stay. This was our reason for spending a few days in Paris during our two weeks in Europe. We easily spent five hours examining Claude Monet's eight Water Lily panels in two rooms (four temporal works each). After breathing in his intended peaceful atmospheric presentation, we went downstairs to view paintings by Renoir, Cézanne, Picasso, and other artists in the Jean Walter & Paul Guillaume collection. As wonderful as they are, Monet's aquatic haven called us back for a second look before the museum closed for the day.

DON'T MISS IT!. I didn't expect to be so wowed by this museum, but I was. The space is small and shaped like an egg - so the end result of the Monet waterlilies is personal. Like viewing them in your own studio. They have skylights above and have hung cloth to diffuse the light - it's a beautiful setting for amazing paintings! And the size and scale of them!! Who knew Monet could paint such huge canvases! Don't miss this museum while in Paris.
Beautiful, no photos. The museum is an impressionist (i.e. Monet) art museum. Unfortunately you have to practice stealth to get a photo. :-)

Excelent exhibition on Wildt. Very nice museum. The permanent collection is wonderful. Waterlilies, while busy, is very impressive. Excellent early works from Picasso, and the exhibition on Adolfo Wildt was very fine.
A Must See. A wonderful and moving experience viewing Monet's Water lilies. Don't forget to also view Paul Guillaume's collection as well.
Average if you want Monet. I expected more Monet - we spent under half an hour and I was a little disappont end. Glad to have seen what was there but no where near his best water lily work...

Lovely Museum. I would rank this museum second to the d'Orsay, but it is a lovely museum to visit, primarily for the Water Lilies, but also for its other treasures. With the Museum Pass you can enter through a dedicated line. We visited in the afternoon after visiting the d'Orsay in the morning. There was a wait even in the dedicated line, but nothing like the general admission line.

Small and Wonderful. The louvre overwhelms a visitor and its crowds make it hard to stand and enjoy its wonderful offerings, but l'Orangerie merely offers the visitor wonderful art, collected in small by representative collections, and lots of room to stand and admire the collected works. Most impressive, of course, are the two rooms decorated with Monet's paintings, the painting that were created to be the foundation of this museum. The painting represent Monet's best work and make coming here a must-do for whomever is visiting Paris. In fact, were I to come to Paris a hundred times, I would include a visit to l'Orangerie on every visit.

overwhelming. we went to l'Orangerie after a visit to Giverny. the first floor has two round galleries containing murals painted by Monet.
you really can't describe the size or the aura given off in these rooms. I was actually so taken, that I had to hold back my tears

Enchanted. This is my second visit to this museum. The charm still works on me. I highly recommended it to my husband and my children who had never visited this museum before. As I had expected, once they walked in the oval room, they were captivated by the series of Water Lilies. These monumental panels were actually stipulated by Monet who envisioned the viewers just the way he intended. These two oval rooms alone are well-worth the visit. Other master pieces of Picasso, Renoir and Cezanne are also very much enjoyable. A fan of Monet of not, I highly recommend it to all as it elevates the enjoyment of art and gives one a new level of art appreciation.

Fabulous museum. Each piece a masterpiece. It's famous for the Monet waterlilies, but I found them less interesting than the lower floor of the museum. I think that the signature water lilies would be best appreciated when the museum was not crowded - good luck.

Wondeful exhibition. Always there is Monet's Water Lilies panels. Currently the exhibit halls have a collection of donated Impressionists works including Cezzane, Renoit, Matesse, Picasso and Soutine. Worth the 9 Euro admission

A Treasure. Had not visited this museum on previous trips to Paris but was very glad to find it this time. Monet's huge water lily panels are breathtaking. A small museum at the edge of the Tuileries Gardens; lovely collection.

Water Lilies.. Of course the main attraction is the display of the "Water Lilies" in the oval room.However take the time to see what else this gallery has to offer.It has a very extensive collection of paintings and the building itself is a work of art.

Paris weekend in May. This is such a great little gem at the bottom of the Tuilleries Gardens. Fabulous presentation of Monet's "Water Lilies". One can visit this museum in about an hour especially using "Rick Steve's Paris Guide"
Notre Dame. A beautiful, beautiful structure in the heart of town. We only viewed from the outside, did not want to wait the line.

Good but not great, go to the d'Orsay first. I love Monet and this museum is really all about his whole floor of large art works. I actually much preferred his art works at the d'Orsay to these water lillies paintings. These are much more abstract and the presentation was designed by the artist himself, so I can see where some people would appreciate this one. I prefer his other work more. The lower floor with other impressionist art is also well worth a visit to this museum but only if you have already gone to the d'Orsay first.

Excellent. Part of the Louvre complex near the Gardens but at the opposite end from Concorde and Arc De Triomphe . Beautiful art and not overwhelming like the Louvre can be. Not for kids, but no museum is unless it's Lego or Space

Our Best Stop. The paintings by Monet are displayed so well. This is a must see in Paris. Get a museum pass and you'll get in faster. We waited about 10 minutes to get in. Not a lot of walking inside the museum. Go downstairs and enjoy the exhibit after you've see the Monet Water Lilys.
Little gem. A must to visit, if only to see Monet's Nympheas! Absolutely breathtaking! And it is within the Tuileries so it is quite accessible as well.

Monet at his best. The monet rooms are awsome, better than the ones you see at giverny, the ligthing is spectacular and the two rooms with the large Monet paintings are unique. Worth visiting lLa orangerie just to see them. Some temporary exhibitions are a good complement.

Small and enjoyable. It is a small museum at the end of the Tuillerie (pardon my French typoes). The advertised hilight is Monet's Water Lillies. Certainly large pieces, however, I liked better the other collections.
It is a compact museum, not too many visitors, so nice and easy.

Tranquil and inspiring. On our weekend visit to Paris we decided to visit this museum rather than the larger alternatives. There are several styles of impressionists on display; Sisley, Cezanne, Sautine, Renoir & Picasso to name a few. A real highlight was the two rooms with Monet's water lilies; the 360 panorama makes it an absorbing experience.What we liked about this museum was that it was small, personal and not particularly busy. There was time to sit, observe and enjoy the beauty of the paintings on display. What a delight; take the time to visit.

If you love impressionism and not standing in a line: visit this museum. The oval rooms in the orangerie were designed for the water lelies of Monet which are absolute master pieces. The basement is dedicated to the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection which has a lot of impressionist and post-impressionist works. I really like to see the evolution in the style of painting. The last part of the basement has a Adolfo wildt exposition at the moment. I only gave it a cursory glance to be honest. I took plenty of time for the previous expositions and I wanted to spend some time outside and grab something to eat.

Monet. This little museum is a treasure. The two oval rooms with the massive Monet canvases of his pond in Giverny are breath-taking. Other of his canvases of great beauty and historical significance are here, as well. If you like Monet, it is imperative to see not only this museum, but the Marmotan as well. If you possibly have the time, make the trip to Giverny to see the house and gardens, as well as the famous pond with Japanese bridge, water lillies and other beautiful foliage that inspired so many masterpieces.

Loves this Museum. This was a wonderful museum to visit- not so huge but there's plenty to see. * of Monet's large water lily paintings are here and downstairs is a wonderful collection of many Impressionists works done by various artists.

Don't miss this museum!. The paintings featured at this museum are magnificent. The main feature and attraction are Monet's paintings. There are 2 rooms dedicated to Monet's "Water Lilles". After seeing the paintings, take in the artwork of Matisse, Picasso, Renoir and Rosseau. It is definitely a museum and attraction to add to your list if you have time. It is ideally located within the Jardin des Tuileries.

Incredible. This is one of the best spots is Paris - even if you're a regular visitor. The water lily collection is mind boggling - a few massive paintings in a remarkable space. It's worth the queue! Do take some time to go downstairs; but all in about 1 - 1.5hr visit should suit most visitors.
Lovely Impressionists. And lots of it. A little limited in offering, but the space and what it does offer are excellent. Well worth the visit.

Better than visiting Monet's garden!. Monet worked on the paintings in this space until he died, at which point the museum opened. Two large oval rooms, each with four paintings of waterlilies - one is surrounded. Downstairs is a nice exhibit of other artists, but they are not typical examples; there are enough of each that one can get a more well-rounded sense of the artist than occurs with a couple of representative paintings. I would visit again in a heartbeat.The museum was crowded, but not noisy - try to figure out when it may be less crowded, as craning around the crowds can be frustrating

720 degrees of serenity. There are 2 rooms each with 360 degrees of Monet's water lillies! What a marvellous concept and so well executed. A fantastic legacy to leave for France and a special treat for visitors from around the world. Go there!
Monet's crowning achievement. Water garden (Nympheas) water lilies, special curved canvas made for display in the museum. They are over thirty feet long each.

A museum you can really, truly, enjoy. There are many museums in Paris, but Musee de l'orangerie is by far one of my favorites. Unlike the large/busy/overwhelming museums that are just no fun, this museum is just the right size. Monet's works are wonderful, and the environment is so serene. Also, do *not* miss the downstairs exhibits. They are just as wonderful as the 'main attraction', and often overlooked. See if you can find the spot where they filmed the scene for Midnight in Paris :)
The best museum in Paris. l'Orangerie was an oasis in a busy city the oval room built for Monet's waterlily paintings was just superb

Monet's waterlilies. This was a new museum for me and I was pleasantly surprised at the content and quality of the exhibits. The water lily murals were in 2 large rooms with skylights that changed the lighting in such a delightful way. Many other wonderful paintings were there to enjoy.

A museum not to miss. Great little museum known for being the home of Monet's Water Lillies. These are a series of panels depicting water lilies. The panels are arranged in a arc along 2 walls with seating between them. This way you can sit and simply enjoy the art. Along with Monet there is the art of Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Guillaume and a few others.

Breathtaking Collection in Stunning Location. There are two major collections here. First Monets seminal work of water lilies installed in two stunningly large and beautiful oval rooms. Second a personal collection of Walker and Guilaume which includes the work of many impressionists. If you really love the impressionist or if you have already visited the Musee D Orsay then make a stop here. It was exciting to see the work of Marie Laurencin, which I had not seen elsewhere. Her work is not as appreciated as many other artists of her time.Buy your tickets in advance at an FNAC if you can. You won't have to wait in line.

An excellent collection of impresionism. this is a small museum, but it has a great collection of different very renounced artists. The lilies are impressive to see, in the size, and the super well lit rooms...also an impressive array of artists, Picasso, Mattisse, Cezane, Modigliani, Renoir, Derain... and much more, even though it's limited to a few paintings each, the fact that you can get all those names and see their work of art together for me was the best...also since it's a small museum the price is lower than the other ones, recommendation is to get the pass for Musee d'Orsay as well if you're interested and have the time to go to both, which are within walking distance if you don't mind strolling along the seine river (who would!)

Must see if you love Monet's art. This museum's murals of Nypheas (Lily ponds) were especially spectacular since we just arrived from Claude Monet's home and garden museum in Giverny. It's a good idea to combine Musee d'Orsay and this one as they sell combo tickets and these two are quite close to each other.

Favorite Museum in Paris. This is hands down my favorite museum in Paris. It is small compared to every other site in the city, but i think the smallness give it its charm. The rooms with Monet's water lilies is breathtaking and must be given a good amount of time to enjoy. The other collections in the bottom floor are equally enjoyable and is a nice change to the earlier pieces you find throughout the city. Having the Museum pass can help bypass the line, through it is not very long, just not enjoyable in the rain.

Monet, Monet, Monet. If you love Monet's work this is the place to go. Don't worry about going through security as it is a sign of the times. There were so many other artists' works to see as well. Very centrally located near The Concorde.

Guided Visit. Almost two hours guided tour enhanced our understanding about the making of waterlily and life of monet. Also covered, work of other impressionist artists on the firstf floor. Recommended, instead of just relying on books. Worth the extra 6 Eu/pax on the top of ticket price.

A pleasant surprise. Two rooms in this beautifully illuminated museum were specially constructed to display huge Monet water lilly installations that were created just for this museum. There are many other paintings here from the Guillanes art collections - art dealers who represented masters such as Picasso, Derain & Cesanne.

Beautiful place for quiet reflection. This is a small but unique museum with Monet's water lillies displayed in 2 huge oval rooms. Plenty of seating space to give your weary legs a rest and enjoy the paintings. You don't need a lot of time for this museum. I don't think young kids would particularly enjoy this museum though as it is set up for viewing/sitting in quiet reflection.

Not to miss. We nearly missed this gem. Visited Monet's garden so decided to go to see his water babies. This is a great museum to get a great exposure to some master works in under two hours, Highly recommend.

Transcendent . While my 19 year old nephew was bored, I was in heaven, literally. I am a Monet fan, and loved the Marmatton in 2005 during my first visit to Paris (the Orangerie was closed then), but this trip (summer 2014) I finally made it. The Waterlilies are truly moving...I don't see how anyone can stand in those rooms & not FEEL...my nephew said he didn't but he patiently let me wallow in the pleasure. Truly wonderful moment.

For Monet Lovers...Nympheas. I am a huge Monet fan of his Water Lilies....so I LOVED this museum and could have spend the whole day in two rooms. Just stunning. If you're a Monet fan and love his water lilies....you need to see this and how large the paintings are. Basically, they are housed in two rooms, with four paintings on each wall. You can spend hours looking at each section of each painting. Bring your ipad/tablet to take photos for higher quality.

Great for Monet fans, dull otherwise. We got in for free, which was good because I'd feel a bit annoyed if I'd paid to get in. Just to be clear, the gallery is nicely done and everything is centred around the huge Monet works that were the purpose of the museum's redevelopment some years ago. But... the paintings themselves just don't do anything for me. If you are a Monet fan then I daresay this is your art Nirvana, otherwise there's a good chance you'll end up wondering what all the fuss is about.
Monet's. These wall sized Monet paintings are worth visiting. Beautifully mounted and displayed. Many other good paintings on the ground floor as well. A very easy museum to enjoy.

Monet. If you're a fan of Monet and can't drive to Givenchy, you must visit this museum. Two large rooms with each wall dedicated to one work of art is jaw dropping. The art is comprised of 3 panels put together to form an inspiring display. We were told that Monet was specific in his demands that the walls be curved to showcase his work. In order to secure this collection, the museum designed their rooms around his specifications.Downstairs contains an art collection to rival other museums.Not to be missed.

Monet's best. This is the home of Monet's water lily mural paintings, and they alone would be worth the visit. There are many other things to see in this museum, and in a size that doesn't wear you out some some other venues.

not to be missed. A last minute decision to visit as part of the Petit Palais was closed. So glad we didn't miss this. The 11 euro entry fee was worth it for the Monet Waterlilies alone.....complemented our trip to Giverny a few days before.

A Lasting Impression. Loved the vast array of impressionist paintings on display. The top floor was dedicated to Claude Monet's room of paintings while to lower level contained a large display of Renoir, Picasso, Matisse (and many other artists) paintings.
Excellent. exceeded all expectations - unlike the bigger museums, musee de l'orangerie was less packed with tourists. The display of Monet's water lilies was breathtaking

Waterlilies galore. i have always wanted to see the Monet waterlilies that he painted for the Orangerie and I was not disappointed. The exhibition of paintings and sculptures in the lower floor were very interesting and showed a collection of Impressionist painters. Well worth a visit

my favorite museum in Paris. This is in my opinion the one museum that can never be missed on a trip to Paris. Even if you are not particularly fond of art, you will find Monet's Nymphaea stunningly beautiful. It's actually almost moving to see these gigantic chef d'oeuvres in the exact setting that the artist had thought for them. If you're passionate of paintings, you will also very much appreciate the collection at the ground floor.Seriously, do not miss it.

Definitely the Highlight of My Visit to Paris. Stunning art in a stunning building set in a stunning garden -- it doesn't get any better than that. Though I've been to Paris many times, this exhibit was closed for renovation for years, and WOW was it worth the wait. Monet's Nymphaea series is stunning and expertly presented in a beautiful space with changing natural light. I could sit and absorb the pieces all day, and it looked like quite a few visitors were doing just that. The collection on the lower floor is also superb, and quite extensive without being overwhelming. I particularly enjoyed the Gaugin pieces.
A Must. If you like Monet, you must see the lilies at the Orangeries. The setting is ever changing due to the natural light

A smaller museum but good. The queues here are short, especially early in the morning, and the museum is small. The main feature is the two rooms with enormous Monet water lilies paintings in two oval rooms. The other art works are good, but the Monet is special
Waterlilies. To see the impression work o the masters, was amazing small museum, but the shear scale of the works was impressive.

Beautiful art work. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a small but significant museum particularly for the display of the large paintings by Monet and others in the two main rooms of the museum.
Liked: The main paintings and many of the smaller paintings
Disliked: Some of the smaller paintings

Understated Excellence. Our fourth visit to Paris but first visit to this museum. It's best known feature is the Monet display of the Nymphes or water lillies. The museum is small and less hectic than its sister d'Orsay. We loved it and the two-for ticket you can get for the two. No better deal for lovers of impressionists.

Free on first Sunday of the month. We visited on the first Sunday of the month (April) when many French museums including this one are free to enter. Arrived right at opening time; the queue was quite short and we were inside in probably 10 minutes.The huge Monets are obviously lovely, and we enjoyed comparing the different artists downstairs (including Cezanne, Picasso, Renoir and Matisse).Can be done in an hour if you're pressed for time, or you could spend hours listening to the audio guide if you're keen!

a little world of impressionism. It was my main goal in Paris. Perfect museum with amazing panoramas of Monet and without queue on the enter and crowd inside. The museum consists of two floors: on the one gift-shop and two rooms with eight paintings Water Lilies and on the next paintings different representative of Impressionism. This place deserves a visit. I recommend it.

What a Gem. We loved this museum. Of course the Monet and Cezanne, and all the rest, but the information on each artist was so well done and to see these exquisite works up close and personal was amazing. We were introduced to some artists and especially liked the current exhibition of Adolfo Wildt sculptures and the presentation of his development as an artist -- Fascinating!

Murder Avarice Adultery and Blackmail. Great museum. The best thing to do here is google the museum, and find out where the permanent collection came from. Les Nymphéas of Monet are beautifully exhibited in the`upper rooms that were specifically designed for them. Downstairs there are wonderful temporary exhibition.The best of all is the permanent collection that is also in the basement. The Jean Walter et Paul Guillame Collection.The black widow of the two of them managed to negotiate her freedom with the city of Paris by donating most of Guillame´s collection to the city..

nice smallish museum. Nice massive paintings by Monet (most famous ones are in the Musee D'Orsay however). The building was built to measure for his work. The Museum pass covers it, I walked right past a massive line of people in the middle of the afternoon and walked right in. GET THE MUSEUM PASS!

Our favourite museum in Paris. After an 11 day trip to London and Paris, and many museums, this was our favourite museum. It's very well laid out, and not too large that you feel overwhelmed by it. The audio guides are well done and provided insightful information to the art. Of course the water lilies are impressive, and it would be nice to return at a quieter time of year and really enjoy them.

Beautiful museum and park . It is located at the end of the Tuilleries Garden, which is an amazing park from Louvres museum to Concord place . The museum itself is not that big , but the whole concept and environment is worth seeing.

Good for Monet. If you're a big fan of Monet's waterlilies this is worth a visit- they're impressive and you really have the space to study the works. If you're not, you can probably skip this museum- they form the bulk of the work, along with some smaller Impressionist collections (but the Orsay collections are broader).

Don't miss it.. Just the shear scale of Monet's work of Water Lillies is worth the walk across the Tuilleries Garden. The colors are gorgeous and if you can go there when there are few other visitors it is an experience.
Water Lilies. The Orangerie contains, as Monet specified, two complete installations of water lily paintings in the round. Astounding.

small museum. I visit Musee de l'orangerie to see Monet's room.
Except Monet's room, there's nothing special.
There're not many paintings compared to Musee d'orsay.

Loved it!. Even though I've been to Paris several times, I never visited L'Orangerie. It was incredible to see Les Nympheas, the large Monet water lily murals and get close enough to see the brush strokes. The museum exhibition of Adolfo Wildt was also amazing. His marble sculptures were spectacular.

Breath taking Monet's works. Beautiful museum with the water lily series by Claude Monet. Many other works are included but Monet's painting are just outstanding. We made this visit the day before going to Giverny.

Beautiful Unless You Need the Loo!. The museum itself is gorgeous - the outside is trees and sunshine (well when I went!) and the inside is minimalist and beautifully designed to allow full appreciation of the paintings. The Monet's were of course the statement pieces and absolutely divine. The gift shop was spacious and had lovely prints and souvenirs and the whole museum was quite quiet and not too cramped. Its major downfall was the visit to the toilets. Almost all of the cubicles were out of order and the drains smelt like they had never been working. There was toilet paper all over the floor and the taps didn't work properly either. The floors were grubby looking and many people walked out.It really didn't make my visit end well - but luckily for them the artwork was definitely worth the visit. Go, see the fabulous paintings but maybe avoid the ladies unless you're desperate.

Oui, allez-y!. I highly recommend this museum to any art lover or even to someone who is tepid about art. I visited on one of the many May jours feries here in France, May 8, 2015 so there were a lot of people waiting to get in. The brief wait (10 mins?) was worth it! The two rooms in which Monet's Nympheas or Water Lilies are displayed are peaceful for the most part, designed specifically to showcase these incredible paintings. Signs at the entry to the rooms encourage onlookers to remain quiet, and there are comfortable benches in the middle of both rooms where you can sit and contemplate these beautiful works of art.But don't stop there- there are many delightful impressionist works downstairs, with a nice collection of Picasso paintings as well. There is a special exhibit of works of the Italian sculptor Wildt until July 13th this year. I entered thinking I would simply zoom through it on my way to the museum gift shop, and was pleasantly surprised by his sculptures, some of which were quite large, and most of which had some quizzical feature which caused me to do a double-take. I spent a lovely couple of hours at the Orangerie, and when I left, I headed behind the museum into the Tuileries Garden, and visited the bookstore there. It includes many lovely little offerings, such as a strong collection of children's books in English and in French.NB: You can buy a double entrance ticket good for 3 months that gets you into both the Orangerie and the Musee d'Orsay for 16 Euro-such a deal!

It isn't just the Water Lilies. I have visited the Orangerie before and as it was a Monday when most of the other museums are closed, I decided to return. I was overjoyed to revisit the terrific collection Of Jean Walter & Paul Guillaume. The collection is a great tour ov modern art and a must see. Also there was an exhibit of Wildt, a great sculptor that I had never seen before. The translucence of his marble is beautiful. I liked the way they also included pieces of other artists of the time. Again, a good way to know the period.

A must for anyone. As a big fan of Impressionism, this was a must for me to see. It was a great sight to see Monet's Water Lilies displayed in a perfect setting with viewing of these masterpieces a dream. I would recommend this to anyone to go and see.

Unbelievable panorama mural paintings by Monet of his pond and garden. In two giant oval rooms, 4 mural type paintings creat a panorama of Monet's gardens in Giverny (sp?). Plus large collections of a number of other impressionists and post impressionists.
Breathtaking. The extremely large water lily masterpieces are set in Beautifully designed rooms, creating A calming, relaxing and peaceful place.

Breathtaking!. What a find - a small, almost intimate gallery of Monet`s works, sympathetically and effectively displayed in a romantic, peaceful setting in Passy. Although they are brilliant museums,you can spend a lot of precious time searching the Louvre and Musee d`Orsay - if it`s Monet you`re after, just head straight to Le Marmottan. Then simply relax and soak it all up.

Magical Monet!. The two rooms with the 8 massive Monet paintings were incredible. We didn't even go look at anything else in the museum as they took our breath away. The set up in the two rooms is beautiful--a long row of benches in the middle so people can sit and just take in the art and atmosphere. Even though there was a constant flow of people, it never felt crowded and everyone was considerate to everyone else. This is so worth seeing. A picture just can't capture it. There were no lineups when we went (a Saturday morning at about 11:30 am).
Fabulous Monet. I've been to this museum before. It didn't matter. It's fabulous.If your time is limited forget Eiffel and Mona, go here and Orsay.

A gem especially for Monet fans. This is a gem of a museum whose highlights are the eight large water-lily panels Monet donated to France. Can spend an hour just looking at them. A small, noteworthy collection of other French art. Can do it in less than two hours. If you don't buy a multi-museum pass, save money by buying a combo Musee D'Orsay and L'Orangerie ticket. Also gets you 10% off Paris opera self-guided tour.
Thank You Monet. Monet contributed this frat Art to his country following WWI so people could contemplate it and think of "peace". Thank you, thank you, thank you!

Extremely Biased...but there you go.. Disclaimer: Monet tragic to the extreme here.A friend told me about this just before I headed off on my trip so I inked it in as a "must see".Wow...so glad I did as it was fantastic.I'm a great admirer of the Impressionists but especially Monet so I was really looking forward to visiting here.It was way beyond my expectations and I could have spent the whole day there.I spent ages just admiring each painting.Standing close to check out the brush strokes then backing away to take in the whole work.As someone else said it's a wonderful place to just sit and relax and take it all in.Then if that's not enough wander around the rest of the galleries and view many other great works by so many famous painters.Oh isn't that just typical...now I'm feeling sad I'm not back there now.
Loved it!. If your not crazy about museums, this one is a great size, great works, worth it just to see the Monet.
If you love lilies... Nice collection but go to see the rooms filled wih Monet's lilies. The aura is sacred. If you need to relax after a busy day, sit here for awhile.

MONET. a great collection!
the Museum itself is a must.
and is located in a special place,Tulheries.
Reserve one afternoon just to walk around after going to thus beautiful place.

best museum to see the Nympheas by Monet. My wife and I always vist this extraordinary Museum on account of the 2 oval salons where the gorgeous murals of the Nympheas(Water Lilies) by Claude Monet are exhibited permanently. Once you are inside one of these rooms, one gets enthranced by the beautiful colors and luminosity of Monet's palette. I consider him the predecessor of the Abstract Expressionist movement of the New York School in the 1950's. This is one of my favorite Museums in Paris. A must!

Water lilies. L'Orangerie is the home to many impressionist artists including Modigliani, Picasso, Matisse, Cezanne, Renoir and others but the star is the Nympheas commonly known as the Water Lilies by Monet which are housed in two separate rooms in the museum. It's an exhibit to take your time on since the scale is immense.The paintings are best viewed from a distance to clarify the overall concept.The location is near Place Concorde but you can also stroll through the Tulieries gardens to get there.It's important to pre-book tickets as the line ups are long and slow
Okay to Skip. Small. Not worth spending valuable trip/vacation time. This became very obvious after seeing the Orsay. Available on Museum Pass.
Very nice Musee. Large Monet pieces and a lot of select impressionist paintings. Small space but really sweet musee lover!

Monets Magic. The 8 waterlily paintings surrounding you are just so restful, as they were created to be. Awesome. We did not have enough time to do the rest of it justice, but enjoyed the exhibition downstairs, and will return.

Monet masterpiece is worth the trip. While we went for the Monet so to speak, we were pleasantly surprised by the additional artists (Cezanne, Gauguin and many others) on display. We ended up spending the better part of two hours. While the exhibit is free the first Sunday of each month, the line was prohibitive when we went there so we decided to return the following day and pay the nine euro entry fee - we were not disappointed.

Out and About in Paris. This is a lovely smaller Art Gallery in the corner of the Tuileries Gardens. We were going to Giverny on a day trip and wanted to see Monet's life size water lilies or Nympheas before our trip.We went on a rainy day and had to wait in line late in the day for about 15 minutes. The gallery can easily be seen in under an hour and a half depending on how much time you want to be amazed by the large lily panels on the main level. There is a lovely art gallery in the basement featuring other impressionist paintings.

Amazing Monet!. The museum makes homage to the great impressionist Claude Monet.Two oval halls of huge dimensions display 8 enormous Nimpheas paintings of his from Giverny, leaving one speechless!Besides there are temporary shows, these days the Walter- Guillaume collection containing impressionists like Renoir, Soutin, Cezanne as well as Matisse, Picasso, Modigliani and others. Unfortunately, at the moment Rousseau is on loan and not on display.
simply breathtaking. my wife broke her foot so she was in a wheel chair. the staff was very accomodating, we did not miss a thing. truly a memorable experience
Magical. Worth the trip. Give yourself plenty of time to just sit and take it all in. Buy a museum pass so you can visit again and again.

Peaceful. Musee de l'Orangerie was the last one we visited, just before catching our train back home. After some bad experiences on the previous day, I found this little museum quiet and very organised. As for prices, since we had a Paris Museum Pass, we thought it was reasonable.

Quiet time with Monet. Loved the Orangerie as it was not crowded and you can sit and soak in Monet's lily pad paintings in relative peace (after being at the crowded Louvre). Use a museum pass to get in.

Well worth a visit. This is a lovely little gallery - just big enough for us! The main attraction is Monet's waterlilies which are displayed round the walls of 2 rooms - spectacular. There are other works by Picasso, Renoir and many other artists in the downstairs area. As always, it is better if you have ticket before you arrive, since you then join the "pre-paid" queue and get in earlier. We had to wait! Still, at 3pm the queue wasn't too long and we only waited perhaps 45 minutes.
Monet!!!!. Small, limited, but the gigantic panoramic Monet wrap around paintings are amazing. Other exhibits in the basement level are always surprisingly special.

a museum built around a single painting. If you can get in at a quiet time, this is one of the most fantastic places in Paris, sitting in front of the waterlilies of Claude Monet, suddenly far far away from the noise and agitation of the nearby Place de La Concorde. Alas, it is rarely the case that the museum is not crowded....

This museum is nice but i feel not having any descriptions in English is a little disrespectful.. No English descriptions. Gives the entire history of Paris but no point for an international visitor.There is an English brochure and that's all the description one gets

Best Museum gem in Paris. The Louvre is overwhelmingly fantastic. The d"Orsay is enchantingly confusing. And, the l'Orangerie is just plain delightful. The Monet waterlilies are perhaps the most beautiful and perfect Museum experience there is. They alone are worth the trip from anywhere. And, the rest of the Museum is so accessible and enjoyable -- especially after the vastness of the other museums. This place is like dessert.

Lovely small museum. We went to the museum while strolling through the gardens on a Saturday afternoon in April. We had a museum pass and were able to walk right in, no line at security. The highlight for me was Monet's Les Nympheas. Seeing the colors up close was beautiful.

Monet's water lillies. Which is what you come for, really not too much else. Had an excellent Picasso giantess and two or three other pieces that I really liked but it's about Monet.Staff really nice - we had a baguette preparatory to a lunch in the Tuilleries and the guard joked about not finding it when we'd come to claim our bag. So funny! And my husband had to take a call so he had to leave the museum, and no problem getting back in. And you step outside into one of the nicest views on the Planet Earth; more beautiful, really, than what's inside the Orangerie!

Pair a visit here with a trip to Giverny. For a great "Monet" experience pair a visit to these panels with a trip to Giverny to see the real lily pond! Fantastic. Buy tickets in advance- there were two lines- one for advance tickets and one for those waiting without tickets- both are long but I have to say they really did a good job in balancing both lines. It was raining and they gave us bags for the umbrellas- great idea. There is a very serious security check and I almost had to take EVERYTHING off to get through the detector! The coat check is nice so that you can really view the paintings unencumbered.
Orangerie - worth the wait in line.. The museum was great, as was the Renoir - but we had to stand in line for more than an hour and a half to get it.

Prepared to be bowled over. The recently refurbished l'Orangerie begins rather unassumingly. A modern entrance and two oval rooms housing Monet's Water Lilies. Superlatives exhaust themselves before one is done absorbing this (these) masterpiece(s) of impressionism. (My one cavil is that I wish these rooms, although built to Monet's specifications based on his own studio, had given me just a bit more distance from the work.) As wonderful as Water Lilies is, the real gold in my view lies in the unbelievable collection of impressionist works that comprise the greater part of l'Orangerie's collection. Degas, Van Gogh, Matisse, Utrillo, Derain, Modigliani Manet, Satine and on and on. If one has any interest in the art of this period, one can fill one's self to overflow. A truly magnificent collection, the history of which reveals the genius and hard work of a great patron and promoter of artists and the arts.

Do not miss this one!. This was the third museum we went to on Paris, and the most successful of all three. The paintings are absolutely touching, and the fact that the museum is located right near the gardens adds added value to the effect. The Water Lillies are definitely a must see, and the small size of the museum makes the exerience very appreciated. Feels like every painting was hand picked.

Smaller museum, but worth it with Museum Pass. This is one of many stops where I may have disappointed if I paid for it, but since I had the museum pass, it was worth it to me. I only say that because I'm not a HUGE art person, so while I like to see different pieces and such, I wouldn't spend a lot to do so.But this has Monet's lilypads up on huge walls that encircle the whole room, which was a sight worth seeing.And the rest of the museum has quite a good collection as well. It's one of the quieter museums as well, so lines aren't too long, but still try to get there earlier rather than later!

Beautiful - a must visit to see Monet. The two 360 degree rooms of Monet water lilies paintings are incredible. Well worth the small entry fee alone. Some of the other galleries in Paris can be overwhelming but this is intimate and perfect for a relatively short visit. A great option if you have children, too.

Most Excellent. this is my favorite museum in Paris -- small but manageable. No sensory overload. The Monet waterlilies are amazing in this setting that was built especially to showcase them. The other collections are nicely arranged by artist and easy to view

you can not miss!. you have everything inside petit a class museum, starting with monet paintings in a veru big size, two rooms full of it, marvelous, then just a taste of of the most remarkable impressionist as gauguin, cezanne, van gogh, degas and others... very cosy and easy to see and to remember! finally, the location is perfect: half way from louvre and dorsay.

Highlight of my visit to Paris. What can i say that has not already been expressed by others... This place was the highlight of my visit to Paris and was an unexpected find. After see the Orsay the day before, my wife and I wanted more impressionism art. The first level is devoted to Monet's masterpiece and ... it was with out a doubt the more beautiful and serene place I have been. I was lost in the pond with lilies...The second level was all an experience to remember. It was interesting to see the works of Renoir and their swing from impressionism to a mixed of classical style. The Picasso area was eye opening to see his work prior and after his cubism phase. Cezanne was an experience too, seeing the seeds of Modern art being formed.I would recommend getting the audio guide for 5 euros...well worth it.

Not to Be Missed!. We stood on line for about 1 1/4 hrs. in the rain today to get into the Musée de l'Orangerie. Museums are free the first Sunday of the month in Paris. It was worth it! Then we were in the museum an equal amount of time immersed mostly in Monet's water lilies, Les Nymphéas. I didn't complain once. The only other time we stood in any line this long was to see David in Florence. These paintings, in rooms designed specifically to hold the massive panoramic canvasses, are AWESOME, especially for fans of Impressionism and Monet. Even though we've visited l'Orangerie before, the beauty of Monet's creations continue to be exceptionally moving. On the lower level of the museum, we found a wonderful exhibit of some of Renoir's best portraits. Don't miss this museum if you are in Paris. Because the museum is relatively small, the number of entrants is wisely controlled to prevent overcrowding. You never feel mobbed inside, as is sometimes the case with the Louvre or Musée d'Orsay.
Monet fans must. cool art downstairs too. pretty small but still can have a line. so get advanced tickets or get there early or later.

Lovely Monet. The centerpiece of this museum is two rooms designed by Monet himself to house eight of his pieces. This museum was included as part of the Paris Pass and so we decided to stop by. I enjoyed it and if you are a Monet fan I would defiantly recommend it. Still there is the Louvre and the Orsay so you need to pick where you want to spend your time.
Must-see!!. A definite must on our trips to Paris, the Orangerie and Monet's gigantic paintings are breathtaking every time.

A Must if you love Monet. This a small intimate museum with Monet's wall size Nympheas dominating the walls. You don't have to walk much as the 2 main rooms congaing the bulk of the paintings. This is a great place to come chill and just inhale the colors. It's a shame the Jeu de Paume does not hold the Impressionist paintings since they moved to the huge Gare D'Orsay.

The only museum I would visit over and over again. This museum is absolutely beautiful. It has two 360degree rooms of Monet paintings, 4 in each room. Each painting is of Monet's garden at a different time of the, dawn, dusk, mid-day, etc. I could sit in these rooms for hours. The museum has a cheap entrance fee, and it is worth every penny. Going to the Louvre or the Orsay each time you go to Paris is unlikely, but this museum is worth a visit each and every time you go to Paris, as every time it never ceases to amaze and it is small enough to not be bombarded with too much art. A MUST for all.

Fantastic Monet paintings. This gallery is at the end of the Tuilleries near Concorde Metro. It has some wonderful Impressionist paintings and in particular one large room that contains 4 huge long Monet pictures. They are enormous and absolutely stunning. I can't remember what the entrance fee was now, not much though and well worth the price.

Monet and other Impressionists. This is a refreshing museum visit, in contrast to the overwhelming experience of the Louvre. Focused on Monet and other impressionists (though the current exhibit includes what I suppose is a Furturist) you can enjoy this in an hour or so while walking through the gardens. Charming, and of course the artwork is visually rewarding. A very nice break from the "museum as marathon" experience.

Sublime Monets. Monet painted his series of large paintings of waterlilies from his garden in Giverny to be hung in specially designed oval galleries located in this museum. We were the first people who went in the morning and we got to see these galleries before they became very crowded. It was a truly transcendent art experience. Besides the Monets there is also a very good collection of other impressionist and post-impressionist paintings here.

Impressionism and Monet. fantastic place! Perhaps my 2nd favorite museum after Orsay!Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse, Picass, Monet's Nympheas and Lilies series, it was just fantastic! Such a peaceful place where art lovers can really focus on what they are observing and interpreting

Surprisingly the paintings looked better on pictures that we took there. You can take pictures, many people did, just without lamp. Unless you are big fan of Monet I wouldn't recommend as the queues are just unbelievable!!! To wait over 2 hours outside standing is just crazy!
It is so difficult to plan day in Paris as the recommended visit times don't take the queuing into consideration.
Disappointing. Very mediocre after having queued in the cold and drizzle. Very clinical environment. Staff not over friendly. The Monet's were good to see, but overall not impressed.

Musee de L'Orangerie. Go for the Nymphea alone (water lilies) and you will have achieved much; linger awhile. Watch out, however for the scammers outside...."pardon me, do you speak English?".....move along quickly SVP.

A museum of interest when you only have an hour. We visited it on a rainy Friday morning in February. We took about an hour to see the Water Lilies by Monet and the other paintings of the impressions and expressionists. They have a collection that can be seen in an hour or maybe two. That makes it not so overwhelming as the Louvre or Musee D'Orsay can be. And they have some interesting paintings as well. We saw a painting by Renoir that is like a study of a painting that is in musee D'Orsay. It was nice to be able to compare the two.

An Afternoon in the Garden. Don't rush your visit here. Plan to stay long enough to see the light change in the large oval rooms whose walls are covered with continuous murals of scenes from Monet's garden. The rooms are lit with filtered natural light which changes with time of day and as clouds go by, contributing to the illusion of being in a natural space. It is absolutely unique. A central seating area in each room encourages rest and contemplation. The lower level collection of impressionist painting by variouis artists is also worth a visit.

Monet. The top floor has two large oval rooms with each having four large paintings by Monet. Sitting in the middle of each room is like sitting in Giverny looking at his water lily pond. The lower floor has rotating exhibits of over great masters.
Breathtaking. It was really nice to sit on the bench in the middle of the room and look at the paintings all around us. Definitely worth going

Monet's Waterlilies. Monet donated his Waterlilies to France, his paintings are huge, and the building housing them was built in an oval shape. You can sit in the centre and look at the paintings all around you, each one painted to reflect the changing light at different times of the day from sunrise to sunset. There are eight panels contained with two rooms, and it is really peaceful there.

First visit to Musèe de l'Orangerie. My wife insisted we go here on our first full day in Paris. I thought, "Fine, let's just get it over with." It was late in the day and I was tired. I had no idea what a spectacular present she had given me. Just don't miss it. Go to the first floor first. Then go see the exhibits in the basement. And, then go back to the first floor and just sit in each room for ten to thirty minutes. I think this was the first time I have had an emotional experience in the presence of true artistic genius.

A must if you are a Monet Fan!. If you are under 26 take your passport or ID showing your birth date and your entrance is free. You chance to experience these amazing Monet's masterpieces on a totally immersing scale! Just beautiful!

Really wonderful - not to be missed. These huge canvasses were always intended by Monet to be exhibited in this way, to create a quiet refuge for contemplation, and that has pretty much been achieved. It's a completely different experience from the other museums, and well worth the walk down the length of the Jardin de Tuillerie from the Louvre. And the four outdoor cafes under the trees nearby are a very pleasant place for lunch or a coffee - all recommended.

Absolutely stunning. I have wanted to visit this museum for a long long time. We took a tube to the Place de la Concorde and wandered past the delightful ponds and statues, the queue was reasonably short so not to long to wait to get inside. Your bags will be checked and scanned before you are allowed to enter and bear in mind on rainydays you will have to wait outside. Monet's water lilies are over two rooms, the paintings wrap themselves around the room, it's hard to appreciate the paintings when it's so busy but I would take the advice of others and get there early and just sit in peace and quiet and drink in their magnificence. Most visitors are there to see Monet but don't miss downstairs there is a large interesting display of artists. whne you've finished take a wander around the lovely park, or sit on one of the many free chairs or benches and have a picnic. A lovely destination.

Monet and company. This museum is a treasure. Go early and enjoy the water lilies in relative quiet and privacy. Walk along the paintings in a circle and enjoy Monet's garden during different times of the day. Don't forget downstairs where there is a treasure of Impressionists.

Sublime experience. No line (used Museum Pass to bypass line), no crowds, and complete serenity inside this small museum. What a welcome respite from the more crowded attractions. After an hour or so spent gazing at Monet's masterpieces, I was completed renewed.

A small, not to be missed, Paris Museum. Compared to many the Orangeries is a small museum but it has a really wonderful collection of art. Part of the pleasure is to see Monet's "Water Lilies" in a space specifically designed for them. They are huge canvases, and to be appreciated they need a huge space for viewing. At the Orangeries they are displayed as the artist wished, and the presentation is exceptional. On the floor below, the display of the art dealer Paul Guillaume personal collection is also one not to miss. It is an amazing collection of Impressionist and Post Impressionist works. It is hard to imagine living with these paintings on ones walls, but the dioramas of his office and apartment give some idea of what it was like. With only two floors it is easy to complete a visit in a couple of hours.
Quiet and introspective. No queues and crowds in this small museum which offers breathtaking displays of Monet's water lilies. Adjoining the Jardin des Tuileries, it is well worth a visit!

What the museum pass was made for. The Orangerie is small and easily seen in a couple of hours, but the cycloramas of Monet's lilies will keep you coming back to sit and ponder their beauty. Behind the museum lie the Tuilerie gardens peacefully isolated from the roaring traffic of Place de la Concorde and the quays.

Loved it!. Of course, everyone heads for the two Monet rooms, and they do not disappoint. Get here EARLY!, at opening, to sit and marvel at the wraparound murals that are so brilliantly executed.Then, go downstairs and check out what is a more than creditable collection, some rotating, some permanent. Be surprised by their range and quality. It does not matter what is hanging; you are there for Monet, but the other galleries are a true bonus.
STUNNING. To go in And see Monet paintings in really life was just amazing and I'm not really into art but my husband was like a child in a candy store
Gave Me Chills. I didn't think we could spend an hour in two rooms, looking at 4 paintings each. How wrong I was. We were mesmerized!

Small but nice. Its a small museum and its about a hour worth of your time
Great display of Monet's and how he wanted them displayed.
Lines usually not that long and it goes fast

Be there first in the morning. This is another place you want to arrive first thing in the morning. We got there just under an hour before opening and sipped espresso while waiting for them to open. I think 30 min would have been sufficient. Even with time for coat check we were the first ones in to see water lilies (we went there directly) and had the whole room to ourselves for several minutes to enjoy quietly and take it all in without other people standing in front of it. Highly recommend you bring information with you into the museum (we brought a RS tour book) so that you can understand what you're looking at and enjoy it. We spent a couple hours wandering through the whole museum. It had great bathrooms that were well-kept and uncrowded. Highly recommended for a first museum of the day visit!

A delightful cultural interlude. This is an art gallery of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. Not an overpowering museum but most certainly one of the most delightful if you want a short cultural interlude. You can sit and relax while absorbing the magnificence of eight of the Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet. The museum also contains works by Paul Cézann and other well known impressionists. Situated in the west corner of the Jardin des Tuileries next to the Place de la Concorde means that one can combine a visit here with a pleasant stroll in this well kept garden, a delight in itself.

Monet's Waterlillies and Willdt! Yes.. We went here to see the rooms containing Monet's waterlillies, which were spectacular. Yes, you can take lots of pictures (no flashes), or just sit and admire the rooms. But, don't miss going down the stairs to see the Wildt exihibit. We would have gone just to see this work. Put the two together and for a couple of hours you can immerse yourself in two very distinct types of artists and viewpoints. The museum is not very big, but also contains works from Renoir and other impressionist masters.
Monet and company. The right size museum to enjoy without exhausting and overwhelming the senses. The large rooms of Monets work are unique
Always a pleasure to see Monet paintings. Small enough museum if you do not want to stay all day indoors. Monet´s waterlilies are something everyone visiting Paris should see.
Amazing small museum. Some of the greatest art in the world us here.mthe huge Monets arecjust breathtaking, what an experience to see them.Worth a trip.

Pretty amazing!. Two oval Rooms of Monet. Then just for grins, Renoir , Matisse and much more. Sunday afternoon and not too crowded. Museum pass gave us instant entry and cut the line. Some Musee are too darkly lit and I have a very hard time seeing(particularly the grey on white title descriptors due to my AMD) but the lighting was fine here

Small but important museum. The water lilies are breath taking and to see them under the natural light is a pleasure. its also fun to go at different times to see how the paintings responds to different light.

small hidden gem Museum. wow !!! its a very quick museum to walk thru , to tour prior to the Musee de' Orsay and can be done within 1 hr easily...definitely worth the visit to see best panoramic water lilies paintings ever !!! you'll be awe for sure for these masterpieces ..

Great classic art , compact , a must on Paris . A very interesting museum , not to big with the finest classic art of very famous artists .
On the second floor the nimpheas of Claude Monet remarkably displayed .
Combined ticket available with muses Dorsey .
Don't miss !

Wonderful art museum - historical site. We strolled over from the Latin Quarter after brunch and took time to walk through part of the Tuilleries Gardens and into the Orangerie to see Monet's "Lilies" and other pieces on display. It was very nice and was not crowded full of people. Well worth the time and price.
Big surprice. I live a big surprice in thi little but wonderful museum. Masterpice incredible, Picasso, Modigliani, Monet, ecc dont lost for anything.

Lovely. So much to see, our only problem is we did not allocate enough time spend at the museum. Go early in the day and plan on staying for hours. It is very enjoyable. We used the Paris Pass and got free entry.
Monet's water lily panoramas. What a beautiful little museum and wonderful collection. Waterlillies stunning of course but the associated collection of art from that period was amazing.

Lovely. Lovely little gem of a museum. The combo ticket for the Musee de l'Orangerie and the Musee d'Orsay is a good value. Might want to buy tickets in advance during the busier months. During off season line wasn't too long.
A gem!. Both the Monet rooms as well as the permanent collection are wonderful. The scale of this museum isn't nearly as overwhelming as Musee d'Orsay, and can easily be visited in 2 hours time.

Water lilies. If you like Monet it can be a quick in and out to see the water lilies. They are spectacular. Not much else here at the museum to see. Glad it was part of the Paris museum pass and we did not have to pay a separate entry fee.

Best place to see the Water Lilies by Monet. Stopped here before going to D'orsey. you can buy your tickets here and skip the line when you get to D'orsey. But the stars of this museum are Monet's Water Lilies. This is a must stop, as they also have a wonderful collection of other French artists. This gallery is a great size (not too big) and there were no line ups the morning we visited.

Breath-taking. Known well for its Monet Le Nymphéas - Water Lilies, there is much more to see. L'Orangerie feels intimate. Extremely well done. Tickets can be purchased in advance, or in combination with D'Orsay, and you have no, or much shorter wait. See their online site before you go.

Go for the waterlilies - see a pretty good personal collection. Not a big place - the line can be formidable even with a museum pass. If you can get in without waiting go. Otherwise it could be an unpleasant experience.

How did I not find this place sooner?. I've been to Paris several times and I LOVE Monet, and yet I don't think I knew this place existed until my latest trip. Definitely get the Museum Pass so you don't have to wait in line, as they control the number of people that enter since it's meant to be a relaxing and reflective experience. The Museum Pass holders get to go first, so we only waited about 2 minutes to enter. That makes it much nicer than the craziness of the Louvre and to a lesser extent, d'Orsay which get crowded. The two main rooms each have 4 massive Monet murals of the Japanese gardens, and you just sit there and stare at them and take it in. I highly recommend it, unless you don't like Monet for some reason (like my husband who skipped it).

In the Park. this musee is in Tuileries gardens. You'll see the monumental Water Lilies by C. Monet. You will just sit down and soak it all in. such a magnificant piece of art. The entire museum is wonderful

a special place. Take time to visit this smaller museum esp if you like the Impressionists. It is a real treat. All 8 of Monet's waterlilies are here in 2 rooms as well as numerous lesser known artists.

Wonderful art mueseum. This was built to house 8 large Claude Monet Water Lily paintings he did late in life, and donated to France, to counter the despair of WWI. Those paintings are on the upper level and are the reason most people come to this museum. However, I love the art collection downstairs, donated by the widow of two art collectors. Many impressionist paintings, and many paintings of more modern art schools. I never miss this. Get a Paris museum pass to avoid the mine.

Monet! But not only Monet.. I went for the Water Lilies murals. I left amazed by the Water Lilies murals. But they were not the only work in this museum that hooked me. There is an impressive and varied collection including Renoir, Modigliani, Matisse, and yes, more Monet. We started with this collection, and then worked our way upstairs to the masterpieces that are Monet's "Nymphéas"-the eight Water Lilies murals. I recommend doing it in this order, because, if you're like me, you will hardly be able to pull yourself away from the incredible Water Lilies rooms.

Impressionism At Its Best. The building has been renovated several times, most recently in 2006. It is a modern building, purpose-built to house these connections.Seeing all the Monet Water Lilly paintings the way Monet intended is a real treat. We visited Monet's Home and Gardens a week ago so we recognized Monet's subjects.The rest of the collection plus rotating exhibit is an eclectic wonder. Assembled by an early enthusiast of the Impressionists, collector and later art dealer, the collection includes works by both familiar and in familiar artists, all from before 1934.Took us just over an hour to see everything we cared to see.
Great little art gallery. Worth getting a dual ticket to see here and the Museum D'Orcy. The huge Monets are definitely worth visiting if you've time.
The Monet Mural's place. Airy, light with a feeling of space. Monet's Water Lillies, for which two entire rooms are devoted, are a must see.

Amazing paintings - but they need some explaining. I found these paintings amazing, but lacking the understanding to interpret them or the information panels you get in the d'Orsay, I felt I was missing something.Paintings below are also worth looking at.

Took my breath away.... I did not expect that impact that the 2 rooms of Monet's water lilies would have on me! All I can say is WOW! I felt like I was in Monet's garden. Sublime. I also wasn't expecting all the other amazing pieces of art...can I say WOW again?? Picasso, Matisse, Cezanne, Renior...and more. It's also a great place to take the kids because it's not that big and the water lilies are impressive even to the younger ones.

Awe Inspiring Impressionism. This gallery which is smaller than many in Paris had some outstanding works by Monet and Renoir. The Monet freezes are large pieces which allow you to get a grasp of his work which you don't in most places. The feel of the gallery was less fussy than many and they restrict the flow of visitors to ensure that you get to see what you want to. Would highly recommend.

Musee d l'Orangerie. Special treat is the round room with panoramic Monets. Also great are the Morisot and Soutim collections. Go early in the day to avoid crowds. and get a Museum Pass plus audioguide

DO NOT MISS Monet's Water Lilys! Unforgetable!. Make sure you don't miss on this museum while in Paris!
