Monet's water Lilys actually brought me to tears, it is an unforgatable experience!Rest of the museum is also nice, even though it is mainly about the Lilys... Don't feel bad to see only those and than continue on to other Paris attractions.If you plan on visiting the D'orsay museum as wll (HIGHLY recommende it also) - buy a "discount+skip the line" ticket for bothe museums on the cashier of the first one you visit.
Surrounded by Monet. A nice gallery to take a break from the throngs of the Louvre. Standing in the Monet Room surrounded by the impressive water lilies is a unique and magical experience.
Amazing. Amazing am really gladiator was able to see the monet,s renoirs and gaugains. I had set a goal to see the oval walls. With monetpaintings and was delighted recommend for Monet lovers
Monet, Monet, Monet. The two rooms with wall-to-wall Monet water lilies are a must see. Small museum, but some great art. Get there when it first opens for short lines.

Fantastic musee to see Monet's waterlilies. We bought the passport for Musee de l'Orangerie and Musee d'Orsay for 16 Euros! We didn't have to queue to get in here and Monet's works alone were well worth the visit. Absolutely fabulous!

The best of Monet. Arrive early (10 ish) to get in and avoid the large ques later. Buy a combined passport ticket to also get in the Musee D'Orsay. The panoramic rooms of Monet paintings of Giverny are exquisite.
Monet's Lily mural. If you want to see the Water Lily murals displayed as Monet wanted them, go here. There are 2 complete sets.

What a little gem.. This museum is well worth a visit. Especially if you like waterlilies. It is a little gem with lots to see downstairs and amazing rooms filled with huge canvases that take your breath away.
Small gem. The collection of Impressionist works and the beautiful lighting make this worth a stop even if you're visiting many other art museums in Paris.

What a treat. After a long day of walking around Paris and spending time at the Musee d'Orsay, going to the l'Orangerie is peaceful bliss. Seeing Monet's water lilies as he wanted them displayed is awesome. A fabulous small museum well worth the trip.
Go Early. The crowds were moderate but even then it interfered with the pleasures of seeing the rooms in peace and quiet. Go first thing in the morning to avoid the crowds.

For Monet Lovers!. I spent hours in Musee de l'Orangerie just staring at their waterlilies installation. Words cannot describe the beauty. There are two large oval rooms with huge canvases of the scenes from different light perspectives. There are also of course other artwork which is lovely downstairs but the Monet is the main draw card. Definitely worth it.

Well worth a visit. If you like like Renoir and Monet this is a wonderful destination. A small gallery and quieter than many others in the city, giving you a real opportunity to appreciate the beautiful pictures

The best Musee in Paris. Memorable visit seeing Monet's large paintings hugging the curved walls of this Musee. Two rooms which will never be forgotten. Downstairs we were surprised to find a huge selection of Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso and many others. Talk about value for money! It was a peaceful Musee and by arriving at opening time (9am), we basically had the Musee to ourselves. This Musee is one not to be missed and was a highlight of our recent trip to Paris.

invitation to Giverny. Reasonably priced, no queuing, excellent, quiet exhibition space. Museum plan clear and staff helpful. Liked the Monet paintings so much that we took a trip to Giverny to find out more about him.

Incredible collection. This art house features the most incredible rooms filled with Monets waterlillies, as well as a great collection of modern works. Wedged in between the D'Orsay and Lourve, the museum itself seemed overlooked and was quiet. While smaller it is definitely worth a visit, especially if you have a Paris Pass.

Panoramic Monet Lilly Paintings. This museum is known for their enormous Monet panels. They're neat, but other than that, it's not worth the trip. If you're a big fan of Monet I would go here and absolutely the Orsay Museum.
One of the best impressionist collections in the world. Allow minimum 2-3 hours to enjoy the most amazing art collection in the world. Make sure to take the audio tour.

A long wait but worth it. The Orangerie is one of the places the Museum Pass doesn't allow you to bypass the line (it just puts you in a shorter line). Although you may wait quite a while until departing visitors allow new arrivals to enter, the crowd control ensures that viewers can see the gallery's offerings in relative comfort. The installation of the Guillaume collection with supporting photos and documents is very interesting, with several stand-out paintings, but of course the main attractions are the Monet cycles of water lilies. No matter how you feel about impressionism, these late ensembles of Monet's are literally breathtaking in their restored setting. Truly awe-inspiring, and seen in ideal conditions (especially if you don't think about all those people waiting outside for you to leave so they can come in).

There's more than just the water lillies. I've been here before, but it was interesting to go with a small group and hear her reactions to the magnificent round walls filled with Monet's crowning glory -- Water Lilies. Going down the steps to view some of the impressionist artwork helps you realize that it's not all in the Orsay museum. When you visit Orangerie (the building was originally built to house fruit trees in the winter), you just might be inspired to visit Giverny and walk through the area that Monet used as his backdrop for many of his beautiful paintings.

Breath-taking. This is a small museum that must not be missed. It is so easy to add this to your list because it is right between the Louvre and the Musée d'Orsay. the pièce de résistance here are Monet's Water Lilies. These will take your breath away and may even bring you to tears. Magical.

Yes - do go!. This is my third visit to the Musee de l'Orangerie, and it very disappoints. Monet's water lily paintings are a must see. And it has an impressive and not overwhelming exhibit of other impressionist works downstairs.

Monet's serene Les Nymphéas are the star of the collection. The two rooms housing Les Nymphéas are some of my favourite spaces in Paris and I try to return every time I am in the city. The museum was closed for six years while it's renovation and redevelopment was halted by archaeological discoveries, but reopened to reveal the 8 paintings by Monet now bathed in natural light. The only down side is the popularity of these rooms: I would strongly recommend seeing the works as far outside of the tourist season as you can as in my experience being able to enjoy the paintings in relative peace with only one or two other people is a vastly different to jostling to see them in a crowd. You'll soon see from the length of the queue that can wind it's way out of the museum's front doors what your experience is likely to be.
Peaceful oasis. The waterlilies are beautiful. Get a Paris Pass to jump the queue though, as there isn't at lot else to see there and a long wait without one to get in.
Must see!. I enjoyed the art in this small museum immensely. The two oval rooms containing Monet's Water Lillies are a "must see" in Paris. Admission is free if you have the Paris Museum Pass.

If you love Monet - prioritize 1 hour for this. This is a right-sized museum. The building design encourages quiet study and observation of Monet's giant paintings. Very special experience. Coupled with a visit to Giverny during our trip made it all come together for us

Super sized Monet. Few things can be better than a room that has huge Monet waterlillies and you walk from one to the other, trying to decide which is your favorite. Impossible. Plus, don't miss downstairs which also has a small but wonderful collection.

Beautiful paintings. One of my favourite museums in Paris, this never fails to disapoint! The rooms with Monet's Les Nympheas are calm, tranquil and fascinating - well worth a visit. The permanent collection downstairs is also well worth a visit and the museum is small enough not to be over-whelming, like the larger galleries in Paris. Students from the EU with a student card get in for free!

Breath-taking Monet. Despite the 1 hour queue it was well worth the wait. Nothing can prepare you for the size and the breath-taking beauty of the water lilies. Allow yourself plenty of time to just sit and admire their beauty.

orangerie museum. I never really thought of myself as one to enjoy impressionist paintings but this place is amazing. Monet's Water Lilies, in two circular rooms, showing them painted in different light, different time of day etc. A wonderful day in Paris would be the Louvre in the morning (as early as possible). Then walk through Tuileries Garden, have lunch from one of the stands set up in the Garden, then go to Orangerie which is at the end of the Garden. Louvre at one end, Orangerie at the other.
LOVE. Loved it when I was 16, love it again. It's intimate and not overwhelming. We did not have tickets but did not have to wait long (15 min).
Loved the water lillies!. This is a small but wonderful museum. Seeing Monet's water lillies is a treat beyond compare. Don't miss the gallery on the lower level, too.
Favorite museum in Paris!. Small, exquisite museum in the Tuilleries. Go to experience Monet's Water Lillies and a fabulous collection of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings.

Worth your time and near the Louvre. After visiting the Louvre (which this is within a 5 minute walk from), d'Orsay, Versailles, Pantheon, Invalides, Rodin, etc. This was refreshing! Only two floors which, I thought, allow you to really enjoy a more focused exhibit of impressionist art arranged by Monet, including the famous water lilies exhibit.

Place if ultimate beauty. After crowdy Musee de Louvre that was a real oasis, place if peace and beauty.Vibrating light, amazing colors, delicate nuances and shades. Like a intimate conversation with Mrs Monet.You cant miss to experience this Ultimate Beauty!

You must visit this place!!!. This is my 2nd time in Paris and l'orangerie is still my favourite place in Paris . If you like Monet, and even if you don't , this place is a must . Such an inspiring and relaxing spot with lilies all around you . Fabulous place for all the family

The Two Most Beautiful Rooms in the World. The home of Monet's Nympheas (Water Lillies), you walk into two oval rooms and are surrounded by the glorious depiction. You have an uncrowded opportunity to sit and photograph a remarkable work of art. Located in the gardens off the Place de Concord, you can have a pleasant afternoon sitting around the fountain. Other artists are on display on the ground floor.

Spectacular Water Lilies. Even though we had to queue for just over an hour, it was worth it. (There's a separate queue for Museum Pass holders.)
This compact and well-organised museum houses Monet's spectacular "Water Lilies" as well as works by Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso and Matisse.
A definite must for art lovers visiting Paris.

Perfect gallery with kids. We weren't able to get into the Musee d'Orsay being a Monday when it's closed but this made an excellent substitute. It's a manageable size and you can do the whole thing in just over an hour. It's well laid out taking you through Renoir via Cezanne and Picasso to more modern works. The enormous Monets are incredible too. For only 5 euros you can hire an iPad which gives children running commentary and games around the paintings. Our 10 year olds were captivated and never bored!

Wonderful little museum!. We visited this museum after seeing the MASSIVE queues outside the Musee d'Orsay and deciding to give it a miss! Located in the beautiful Jardin du Tuilleries this little museum is an absolute gem. Unlike the Louvre you can actually get to see everything! No looking over people's heads to get a glimpse, you can actually spend time studying every beautiful painting here. The two rooms dedicated to Monet's waterlilly paintings are magnificent, but there are so many other treasures here by Renoir, Picasso and many others. My favourite museum in Paris and we didn't even have to queue for hours to get in (something of a rarity in Paris). Can't recommend it highly enough!

Small but a must. The two rooms with Monet's paintings are wonderful. I was surprised to see that the blending between panels was not as good as I would have thought, but Monet was nearly blind when he did these so it's understandable.

Pilgrimage to Monet. This art gallery may be hard to fine...tucked away in a corner just off the Place de la Concorde but when you do find it, you will see the great Waterlillies by Monet. Take time to just sit and take in the wonder of this huge painting.

Monet's Water Lilies Murals are amazing. The museum is located on the rotary of the Place de la Concorde. The Murals are gorgeous and how wonderful to see them in 2 curved rooms. Saw a number of Renoir's I had never seen before. Small museum so you can easily fit it into your schedule. I went at the end of the day and had to wait only 10 minutes until the security checkpoint.

Waterlilies and more!. We didn't make it to Giverny, but we loved seeing the large Waterlilies by Monet at this beautiful museum. It is smaller and manageable in 1-2 hours. We got there early around 9:30 before the lines formed.

Gorgeous Monet's! Not to be missed. When you have walked through the Tuileries Gardens, head to your left to visit the L'Orangerie, a small but very precious and very impressive collection of Monet water lilies. The rooms are austere and the walls lined with huge wall size murals of gardens and water lilies. The beauty is extraordinary and fills one with a sense of wonder and a feeling of peace and serenity that is indescribable. Sounds corny in writing but once you experience it, you will surely understand. Not to be missed!

Small but lovely. We really enjoyed this small art gallery. The works were brilliant. We had to queue for quite a while to get in. We didn't book in advance and I would say based only on my observation on the day that those who did didn't gain too much as the two lines were basically the same length and they seemed to be alternating between the two, allowing the same number of people through.

Musée de l'orangerie . You should totally visit the museum if you are a true art lover and if not you should read something about Monet and Impressionism before visiting the museum, it's just two big rooms with Monet's nymphéas, really nice. Downstairs they have small expositions sometimes.It's not free.
Monet. The home of my favourite paintings. Get here early and buy a ticket which includes the Musee d'Orsay, then you can skip the queues.
Impressive on the outside and inside. ITS FREE!! I couldnt believe it. Wasnt vast inside - mainly art, I found the building more interesting. Nice small cafe adj to courtyard

My favorite Museum we visited in Paris.. This was my favorite museum in Paris and I enjoyed it more than the Louvre. Not only did I enjoy the impressionism artists such as Monet and Renior, but the museum itself was small, intimate and quite manageable. The lines are fairly quick, especially if you have a ticket but you will be waiting outside without cover. This isn't nearly as crowded as the other museums but is a must do. The museum pass puts you in a priority line for the wait.

The absolute best.. Don't cheat yourself. Watch the paintings, see them. Don't storm through Monet's galleries snapping pictures. Walk up to them and study them closely. Sit. The gallery was meant for relaxation. The downstairs exibition is great for understanding the painters of the era if you don't know too much already.

Just how many water lilies did he paint?. I understand the brilliance of Monet and the need to display his masterpieces yet feel this is overpowering and provides an excuse for featuring many other paintings by a number of inferior artists.Sorry, rather disappointed and would not consider visiting this gallery again.

A Must-See with Every Paris Visit. Sitting in the circular room with the Monet panel brought tears to my eyes. No matter how many times you visit this room, each visit is unique as there is so much to admire about this work. There are other extraordinary Impressionist pieces by others as well that take your breath away.

Great sized gallery. The rooms were light and airy for displaying art work. Monet's water lillies were everything I expected and more. I was surprised that people were taking photos of the art work, but the staff seemed ok to allow it
Magnificent museum. If you love art this museum is a gem. Not just for Monet but the attached collection. Also the best toilets in Paris. Heated seats and all.

Monet Plus. The Monet that is displayed here is just beautiful, but that's not all. The Chaim Soutine collection is fabulous, and the museum is small enough that one can absorb the works without getting overwhelmed. If it's raining on the day you plan to walk the Tuilleries, step inside this museum. It holds more than three brilliant paintings by Monet.

Fantastic Collection. If you like Cezanne, Rubens, Derain and Picasso then this is the collection for you! I love this museum because it is not too big but has the most fantastic impressionist collection with a few post-modernists thrown in. I would advise that you get your tickets in advance to save from queuing.

Breathtaking!. I had been planning my trip around visiting the Musee de l'Orangerie! I love Monet and couldn't wait to see the water lillies! When you actually see them displayed it was so much better than I imagined! The natural lighting in the museum makes them seem alive and like you are looking out a window! I can't stop raving about my visit, I loved it!

Amazing Monets!. I am a big fan of Monet's waterlilies and this museum has them displayed beautifully. Although there are many people there every day, these paintings are still very impressive and definitely worth seeing. You can get a combo pass for the l'Orangerie and the d'Orsay, which I found to be a great deal.

I cried when I saw Water lillies. After years of studying art history and loving all of the Impressionist I was simply overwhelmed seeing these works in the home that was built for them. You can not believe how huge and enveloping this amazing paintings are until you see them in person. Bucket list...check!
Monet finest on display with special lighting. If you like Monet, this cannot be missed. The special natural lighting and the murals create an environment to be in it to experience it.

Wonderful museum. Just loved it as very fond of impressionist paintings.The sheer size of the Les Nymphéas of Claude Monet baffles me.With a handicapped card, entrance is free for the handicapped and the accompanying person as in most of the museums.It is just near Jardin des Tuilleries which any tourist would visit. So don't miss the chance to visit this museum.

Amazing!. Don't miss this amazing petite musee in Paris. With it's wall length Monet's displayed in rooms built just for them, you will be blown away by their beauty. Add many other fantastic works if art & you get a great visit that can be done in an easy 2 hour stay.

Horrible customer service. We bought tickets ahead of time but had to stand in a lineup for over two hours in the freezing cold while they let more than twice as many non ticket holders into the exhibit we wanted to see. After two hours the majority of our party gave up and left.
If you love Monet...!. If you love Monet's paintings, you must go! It has a relaxing atmosphere, breautiful paintings, and a great view of Paris from the front of the Museum.

beautiful monet murals. A relatively small museum with incredible murals of monet's water lillies. It was much less crowded than the other museums, but it's a nice space to explore and definitely one of my favourite galleries in paris.

Monet's Panels. It was breathtaking to stand before the paintings of Monet - to see up close what I had only seen in books! Then to see the actual water lilies in his garden at Giverny, well, what more can I say!!

Monet!!!. Go here just to bask in Monet's curved paintings! Next best thing to seeing his gardens in person ... In fact might be better because you see them through his eyes. Able to get up close to paintings. Loved this museum and will return.

For fans of Impressionism. This museum is small and tucked back into the Tuileries gardens, but for fans of Impressionist work, this is worth a visit. I would recommend either a combination ticket with the Orsay or else the Paris Museum Pass if other museums and sights are on your list. The large installations of Monet's waterlilies are incredible, and there is additional Impressionist work downstairs. This is a more manageable size than the massive Louvre and can be seen in a couple hours or less.

Large scale Renoir. We visited this Musee to see the Renoir Water Lilies and were not disappointed, however there is a lot more to this establishment than just the Water Lilies, down stairs there are lots more paintings of the impressionist school and just outside there are numerous sculptures including Rodin's The Kiss

Great Monet!. Loved this place. Small but focused exhibition. The Monets were fantastic and the other select works very good representations of various masters. Great to go into a small museum see everything and be out in an hour, not worn out by continued repetitions.

a Monet haven. An artists heaven. it has to be visited by all people who are interested in art. some of the best work of Monet, Renoir, Delacroix are there. unusual work i would say. close to the Louvre and a small cosy museum. good for those who are keen to understand french art.

Small and friendly. We visited this small museum and enjoyed Monet and others.I did not read the "small prints" of the ticket I bought in Musee d'Orsay, so I payed once again, instead of saving some Euros.
A sacred place. There are so many great museums in Paris, but this one is special. You get the feeling that you are in a sacred place, a feeling I've only had a couple time in my life.

Came there for Water Lilies (Les Nymphéas).... ... stayed for everything else as well. It is packed with beautiful paintings from a lot of different painters like Cézanne, Matisse, Modigliani, Picasso, Renoir, Rousseau and Sisley. It looks small from the outside but there is a lot to see inside.The Water Lilies by Monet are stunning though. The two oval rooms have their very own flair and tranquillity.

Kid Friendly. On our visit to l'Orangerie, we had planned on only taking the kids to see Monet's Water Lilies. At the audio tour desk we were offered ipad tours for the kids. It turned out to be a nice way for our tweens to learn about the collection. They watched videos about the different artists, specific pieces of art, and the collector. We did feel a little uneasy about screen time while sitting in rooms with wonderful art, however they learned a lot and the adults could enjoy the museum as well.
A small museum but with fantastic Monets. The Monet paintings are absolutely fantastic and cover all four walls in two rooms. Even the other exhibitions are worth a visit. Loved it.

Interesting Museum. First I want to start by saying that this museum admissions can be bought in combination with the Musee d'Orsay. So I suggest visiting the Orsay first and buy both tickets. The museum was really nice and it had a very unique 360 display of Monet's Water Lillys paintings. Other than that it was a bit of a let-down on quantity of works. We were in and out of there in about 45 minutes.

Dip in each time in Paris. Like the Musee d'Orsay across the river I find you dip into l'Orangerie to add it to the layers of visits you have done in Paris. The secret to Paris is avoiding the lines and here is no exception. Buy passes in an effort to avoid the queues and dip in. Any time spent with Monet's Waterlilies will be worth it.

If you like Monet, this is a must. The museum has a wonderful selection of Monet's work, especially two rooms on the main floor with installation of four panels each of waterlily series. Work by others (contemporaries of Monet) are also found in the museum. The building has great feng shui and the holdings impressive. It is worth the time.There is an option to buy one ticket for l'Orangerie and d'Orsay. This means a reduced rice, but more importantly it allows admission through the ticket holder's door (no wait or line-up). We were advised to buy the ticket at l'Orangerie where lines weren't so bad (we arrived mid-morning and it was quiet … it was crowded when we left several hours later), and we avoided very long lines the next morning a d'Orsay.

Monet's Water Lillies!!!!. Awesome, fantastic. The memory of standing in the Water Lilly gallery will last a lifetime! It was breathtaking! To see the way the dappled light plays on the paintings to create an illusion of movement was incredible. Could have stayed for hours... My daughter and I just stood in awe!!!!, my husband not impressed and bored from our day of art galleries.

No visit to Paris is complete without a visit to l'Orangerie. Every time we visit Paris we go to the Musee de l'Orangerie. There's a gallery of impressionist and post impressionist painters like Renoir Cezanne and Gaugin but the highlight is a series of paintings by Monet that fill the ground floor.Try to visit at a quieter time (early or late in the day) because then you can really appreciate the two roos, each with four gigantic paintings creating an in-the-round picture of the waterlily covered lake of Giverny with you in the middle. It's totally absorbing and relaxing. The sense of escape when viewing these gigantic paintings that Monet created especially for the space is extraordinary. And they're beautifully presented and lit with natural light.

Great display of the Jazz age artists. For admirers of art, this museum displays works of Jazz age artists: Claud Monet, Paul Guillaume, Pablo Picasso, Amadeo Modigliani and Henry Matisse among others. The most overwhelming area is the display of the "Les Nympheas" or the Water Lilles by Monet. Definitely worth visiting!

Nice Museum, but not a must-see. This museum offers a solid collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art. If you love Monet it's worth paying to see the Water Lillies as he intended them to be displayed and the Guillaume collection downstairs is also interesting. The smaller scale of this museum makes it more appealing in some respects than the more overwhelming Louvre or Musée d'Orsay, if you are looking for a break from the crowds for example or if you only have a bit of time. Also nice for when you've just come in on the night flight from the US and want a sightseeing warmup - a small museum and then relax in the Tuileries gardens.

Tranquility defined. I had an hour to myself in Paris and wandered into this unassuming museum. I hadn't researched it so was overjoyed to be sitting bathed in a selection of Money's large canvas water-lilies. An hour can sometime fly by. There's also another 250+ paintings by other masters that are well worth seeing.

A must when you are in Paris. This is probably one of the must sees, Monet, Sisley, etc etc ect. Do yourself a favour, if the line and the Louvre is too long, take a 5 minute walk in the opposite direction and visit this gem!

Terrific hidden gem !. A wonderful museum to see Monet ! A smaller museum that was suggested by our driver to Giverny ! What a treat, not crowded and a wonderful display of Monet. A must see when in Paris !!!
Monet!. It was a very simple gallery, but with a fantastic large painting of the water lilies. You could sit there for hours.
If you like Monet, you will love this museum.. Worth every minute to take in the full selection of Monet's water lillies, one whole room dedicated to this inspirational art is a must when in Paris.

Musee de l'Orangerie. Wonderful, quiet, contemplative place to sit and admire the Water Lilies by Monet. Would highly recommend this museum as a quiet alternative to the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay. The check in was easy and the rates are reasonable. The display of paintings in the lower level was fantastic
Not great value. The ground floor is 2 rooms each containing 4 Monet murals. The basement has about 150 paintings by about another 6 artists. Entrance is 9 euros.

Nice museum, close to Louvre. Located at the end of the Louvre's grounds, on the left...before you reach the square.
The museum has an entire section dedicated to Monet's gigantic paintings...minimum 8 meters long.
Downstairs, is a selection of famous paintings by various artists.
Entrance was approx. 9.50 euro.
A good 1 hr needed to view all artwork

Not much to see besides the Waterlilies. I loved seeing Monet's Waterlilies. I learned a lot about them that I never knew. They are gorgeous! The rest of the museum is very small (only 2 floors and the top floor is only the 3 large rooms with the waterlilies) and it didn't have any other very famous works and we were in and out in under 30 minutes. But they do allow you take photos without a flash which is always a huge plus for me in any museum! If you have the Paris/Museum pass or are a big fan of Monet then go!

My favorite .... I'm an impressionist fan, the Monet walls are amazing! Must see! Great advantage no lines to get in and you can take your time to appreciate the paintings with very few people around.

Small museum with Monet's water lillies. It was a beautiful experience standing in the circular room with the dome roof that let in the natural light to see the four water lily paintings. It is an experience to remember.

Don't miss this museum. It was a wonderful experience and great opportunity to see Monet's largest works. No flash photography, but you can get some great photos. Beautiful lighting. One of our best memories.
Monet Waterlilies- a MUST see. This was my favorite exhibit in Paris. Seeing the Monet Waterlilies in person was incredible. While we didn't see much else of the museum this was A MUST see.
wonderful small museum. go for the water lilies, and just sit and take them in. I had no idea they were so big-and the lighting is just excellent for viewing them, especially on a rainy day...

A must for Monet fans. An excellent capsule museum. The display of Monet's water lilies is absolutely wonderful. As a bonus, downstairs there is a display of a collection of mainly Renoir but also works by several other well known artists. This is a wonderful small museum, without the usual long queues and crowds inside.
Small museum. Who likes impressionism will enjoy in this collection. It is a small museum, not very crowded, perfect to go with your company who maybe does not enjoy art as much you do.

C'est Magnifique!. By far, the best museum of early French Impressionists! We absolutely loved the panorama of the Water Lilies (Les Nymphéas), so much in fact, I bought the prints of all three and have them matted and displayed in my home! A was also extremely impressed by the Walter-Guillaume Collection.To save time, be sure to purchase a Museum Ticket that get you into all the Musee and allows you to skip the local ticket lines!

Water Lilies Are Superb. This museum will not take a whole day, but it is worth the visit as the Monet paintings are wonderful. Then go to Giverny and stroll along the pond where Monet painted the lilies!

Short and sweet - great for our kids. Nice and quiet place to reflect. A small museum housing Monet's Water Lillies in the four seasons. It has long benches to sit on so you can gaze at the paintings. A nice way to relax if it is hectic outside.

Monet's Water Lilies . Lovely museum. Works from Monet, Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso and more. It won't take any longer than an hour and a half, and it's so worth your time and money. (Hint: buy a Museum Pass)
GREAT collection!. Small in size, but beautiful collection that includes 8 Monet waterlilies, Matisse, Renoir, Modigliani, Picasso and more!

Great must see museam. If you have always wanted to see paintings from the worlds best known artists this is a must see.They also have a great souvenir shop and you can get a guided tour or an audio in almost every language.See Monet's famous lily pads close up.

Brilliant gallery. Everyone goes for Monet's Nympheas on the main floor which is equisite. But equally attractive is the exhibit on the lower level of impressionist and post-impressionist artists - Soutine, Modigliani, Matisse, Laurencin and many more.

BEST museum, hands down!. Traveling in March may be perfect because when we arrived there was no line. Looking at the negative reviews of l'Orangerie, that seems to have been the biggest complaint. I thought the Monet Waterlilies were spectacular and so beautifully displayed in peaceful rooms (SO different from the Louvre nearby). The works downstairs were smaller and perhaps less significant but no less beautiful.

This is a must for art lovers. Been to all the famous ones around many times but not this one. Don't know why I did but I would highly recommend this place. Not as crowded as it's famous cousins and much smaller but great highly prized French collection.

One of the best museums to visit in Paris. Love all the exhibitions in the museum. Went there in Feb. and very little tourists which was great. Would recommend anyone visits Paris to spend couple of hours there!

amazing Monets in the middle of Paris. this was quite a surprise. Went her and found Monets and other prominent art work in what from the outside looks quite subtle. Several rooms with wrap around Monet works makes this a must see

Monet's Les Nymphéas (The Water Lilies). My favorite! As a youngster, I saw a traveling exhibit of Monet's Water Lilies at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. I never forgot that installation. At l'Orangerie, there are two rooms filled with panels of Les Nymphéas. Love these spaces. There are different exhibits and special installations (sometimes video) on the bottom floor. But, it is Les Nymphéas that brings me back every time. Get there early. It is a small space, and they will hold off on entries for crowd control.
LOVE MONET. This is one of my favorite museum in Paris. Go in the morning when everyone goes to the Louvre. This is also a great spot to purchase the museum pass as not that busy in am.
My personal favourite museum in Paris. If you pick two museums in Paris then this and the d'Orsay would be my recommendation. Unbeatable works of art in a stunning space.
In love with the monet. Its a small museum next to Jardin de tuilerries, but the collection are amazing, specially the water lily painting from monet

The greatest museum!. This was a wonderful treat to see such a beautiful Impressionist selection. Monet's Water Lilly exhibit is breathtaking. You need time to sit and take it all in. This museum was my favorite because it's small but important.

Our favorite museum. Small, but powerful. Monet and Water Lilies on main floor, soothing and seating to give some time for really seeing it all as it should be seen. Downstairs a fantastic impressionist collection, much of it owned by what may have been one of the greatest art collectors ever, Paul Guillaume.

Amazing and serene. The upper two galleries were custom built to house and showcase Monet's Waterlilies. They are breathtaking and you can spend ages just in splendid contemplation.The second and equally impressive part of the museum is the Paul Guilleme collection in the lower level of the museum. There are too many paintings of import to pick out any specific ones but what stuck me were two things. The breadth and the quality of the collection and a sense of almost jealousy that one individual guided the careers of so many great artists. What a privilege.A great museum worth visiting. Intimate in scale but not in worth.

Beautiful Monet. I knew the Monet water lily pictures were big but they were huge. Both myself and 2 daughters absolutely loved them. It was nice to be able to sit down in relatively peace and quiet (compared to The Louvre) and just take it all in. Downstairs they had a gallery with lots of other well known artists work in and that was also amazing. I think what made it for my kids and me was the sheer size of the Monets and the rooms/ambiance they are housed in.

An intimate experience. Would recommend a visit to see the astonishingly large murals of the Lily ponds by Monet. A calm oasis no matter what it's like outside. Super collection downstairs of other impressionist works. My second time of visiting and I shall return!

Worth it for Monet halls alone. The Monet rooms are stunning and the entrance fee is worth it for these two areas alone. There is plenty of opportunity to sit & absorb yourself into these large Water Lilies pieces of art. We bought the audio aides which I would highly recommend. The other floor of paintings is also well designed with plenty of room to view even with many spectators.

Well worth the time for art lovers. If you enjoy the work of Claude Monet, then this is a must see. His paintings are huge and are all of his famous water lilies. It's a short walk from the d'Orsay and you can buy as a combo ticket. I highly recommend taking the time to see both.
Beautiful Monet's. Loved this museum! The Monet paintings on display are breath-taking. Also, the paintings display on the floors below were beautiful as well. I would recommend everyone go here!

Monet's Nymphéas above all. Imagine an artist being allowed to choose the museum his works will be exhibited in.Well, this is what happened to Claude Monet when the state offered him to choose where to exhibit his Nymphéas, vast paintings of water-lillies done in the inimitable Monet style.The paintings are vast (hard to steal) yet are intimate enough to discern nuances of colour, texture and even movement across the water.Of course you can enjoy more of France's impressionist and postimpressionist painters, but Monet's Nymphéas are the piece de resistance.

Much Improved. When I'd visited this museum some years before it was worthwhile because on the Monet Nympheas, but not much else was on display at that time. They've now moved the Nympheas upstairs, but the downstairs Walter / Guillaume collection downstairs is also excellent, with lots of works from notable artists - including other notable artists from the Impressionist Era that you might expect to need to go to the Musee D'Orsay to view. Given access was so easy, with a very short queue, and the location is ideal - in the place de la Concorde - its a major sight in Paris these days.

Not so well-know museum with a great Impressionist and Post Impressionist Collection. Some friends of mine who oftem go to Paris recommended this museum and I decided to have a look. I was gladly surprised to see some paintings by Monet, Renoir, Matisse, Modligiani, Picasso among others.Not as big nor as comprehensive as DÓrsay but definitely worth a visit! Located at Place de la Concorde near the Ferris Wheel.
Monet water lilies is still great. The new layout for the lilies is perfect. And then 150 feet of Renoir 's and other impressionists is great day

Have a pass or get there early. We visited here in late October 2013. We had wanted to visit the Musee D'Orsay the day before but it was closed due to technical surveillance problems. The Orangerie was not open this day but we decided we would visit it the next day and arrived at 9.15am (open at 9am) to find a really long queue. We think the D'Orsay was still closed which may have resulted in this long queue. We had to wait 2 hours to get into the museum which houses 4 huge paintings by Monet of waterlillies. There was also a temporary collection for viewing and it also houses a permanent collection of Renoir, Cezanne and Guillame paintings which were fabulous to see and could be photographed. The lillies by Monet are housed in 2 rooms where you can sit and look at them or walk around for a closer inspection. No photos can be taken of these.

The Monet vestibules should not be missed. The first floor contains two large rooms which are intended to create a peaceful place to get away from the stress of the city. These rooms are oval shaped and have Monet water lilies around the entire rooms. You can sit as long as you want and relax looking at the magnificent view. The lower floor is filled with magnificent art by Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Derain and others. The museum is not huge but it is a real don't miss it.

Totally in our top 10. What a surprise. The two rooms are built for the paintings. North is north and south is south and as you view these very large paintings it is as though the sun rises and Monet catches every nuance and you finish at dusk..so wonderous. The staff is exceptionally helpful with those patrons with mobility difficulties as well. Thanks to them, very much.

Monet Heaven. Have visited this museum on both of my trips to Paris. And yes, if I go again, I will visit it again. The two Monet rooms are so beautiful. I could sit there for hours. There is lots more to see here. For more info: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musée_de_l%27Orangerie

My favorite museum. This is my favorite art museum in the world. The collection downstairs is amazing and makes the visit worthwhile but I could sit and study the huge Monet Water lillies paintings on the main floor for hours. Truly unique and if you love Monet, a real experience to cherish.
Monet!. Loved the curved rooms with Monets paintings - just awesome! No real queue, which was a nice change from the usual for attractions in Paris!
Sublime. The tranquil environment in this museum befits the artwork. I had no idea these pieces were so huge. The space is devoted to creating a unified presentation. Just beautiful.
Impressionist trove. We went for the Water Lillie's upstairs. Wonderful art from other Impressionists down stairs. Much easier to see and take in than the Louvre.

Monet's Water Lilies are an Inspiration. If you love Monet's or even like them - this is a MUST! The Monet Water Lilies panels in the 2 rooms are exquisite. You could sit there for hours and contemplate life. What masterpieces..... and the rest of the museum was quite interesting. The Jean Walter & Paul Guillaume Collection was lovely - and given to the French state in 1959. Art dealers and collectors, their taste was excellent. Renior, Cezanne, Picasso, Modigliani, Matisse just to name a few. There was a bit of renovation going on and it made shopping in the "gift shop" a bit challenging.

Most manageable major art museum in Paris. I love this museum. The best part about it is that it has a small, well-curated collection of Impressionists that is worth seeing in its entirety. No worrying that you're missing the "good" stuff or just getting plain worn out by feeling obligated to see an entire museum such as the Louvre or the Musee d'Orsay. I also love Impressionist paintings, so that helped! If you don't like that style, skip this museum.We visited on our last day in Paris - our flight actually left in the late afternoon, so we had time to eat breakfast, visit the museum, and still make it back the hotel before checkout. With allowing ample time to view the entire collection, we probably spent 1.5 hours here. It was a good museum to visit with our baby too, since he can handle being inside without being fussy for about that long. The musem also was not crowded at all. I'd read a few reviews that mentioned long lines, but we walked right in. I visited this museum 7 years ago when I was here (in May that time) and also don't remember any lines or crowds. A very nice change of pace from the Louvre and the Orsay.The one thing I didn't like is that the bag/coat check counter is before you have to show your ticket - so if you will need *anything* from your bag - bottle of water, or in our case, diapers, burp cloth, etc - make sure you bring it in with you. Although we did ask if it would be ok to go back out to our diaper bag and bring it back in and they were fine with that.*if you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews love to get them and it motivates us to do more :) *

Small but worth the wait. Went here on the first Sunday of the month when its free to enter museams in Paris, so had about a hour wait to get in. Some wonderful paintings down stairs, with Monet water Lilly's upstairs with you can get up close to.

Beautiful impressionist displays and the Monet panels. No line to get in. I liked the Impressionist display downstairs more than the 2 rooms of large Monet panels upstairs. There were a couple of artists new to me including Marie Laurencin who I very much liked - and who were not presented in the D'Orsay (Mrs CTS, though, didn't like her stuff at all. To each, their own.). Other artists were displayed Argo museums. Display panels discussing works/life of the artists. Not that many paintings on display but still well worth a visit.

If you love Monet.... This is an interesting building, with an interesting history - housing Monet's Water Lilies as he envisioned they would be exhibited. It can get crowded, and the line to get in can be a 30 minute wait, but it is worth the wait. Beneath the Water Lilies is a theater and there are also more paintings are exhibited. Close out your visit with a trip to the gift shop - it is everything Monet.
Lovely lovely lovely. Loved this small beautiful museum... perfect for when you don't have a whole day. Small enough to enjoy in a few hours with amazing variety of artist.

Simply a MUST see!. This gem is really like two museums in one. The first floor of this converted hot house for oranges is the home of the breathtaking Waterlillies by Claude Monet. They were to be a place of peaceful reflection after the horror of World War 1. Words cannot describe the sense of peace as you walk into the first room. Stay here and bask for a while in the bench provided. I went in the late morning on a Thursday in early March so the museum was not crowded at all and I was able to take a seat and move to the different views as I chose. The only real noise in the room at the time was a little art history class being taught to five children about aged 12. The teacher spoke ever so softly. There are no photographs allowed in this section of the museum and nobody tried to take any so I don't know if the personnel on either side of the room would have said anything. I then went to the second room and my brain found it even more peaceful. You can stay in here as long as you would like. I lingered a while and decided to go see the paintings on the second level. I wasn't really expecting much....I was wrong. This collection of paintings is the gift of art dealer Paul Guillaume and his wife Domenica. It is a staggering personal collection of paintings by Renoir, Cezanne, Rousseau, Modigliani, Laurencin, Derain, Picasso, Matisse, Utrillo and Soutine. There are 25 paintings just by Renoir. The museum is much smaller than some of its sibling sites but it is no less impressive and one you should not miss. in this edition of the museum photos may be taken.Some overall advice if you go. First pay the 5€ and get the audio guide. One gets so much more out of the experience if context is given. Many of the paintings have information on the audio guide. If at all possible try to go this museum alone or just with your family or friend. When I went back up to the Waterlillies room after viewing the downstairs collection I sat in a room with probably 15 people in complete silence. We were all silently gazing, occasionally changing seats and enjoying the peace. In came a tour group like a heard of buffalo into a field of little butterflies. They were extremely disruptive in their noise and wandering. They weren't there long but I point this out because I do not see how one could possibly get the depth of this place in a group. As a group this is just one more thing to check off on the list...Arc de Triomphe, check, Mona Lisa, check, Venus de Milo, check, Waterlillies, check. If a group is the only way to see it then so be it but just go knowing you won't experience this place the way it was intended. You won't feel the peace and you won't experience the depth of the commitment to art in the collection.
Worth the walk from the Louvre. Contains works from Monet, Renoir, Matisse and Picasso to name but a few and would recommend to any lover of art.
Had to appreciate the grnd 360 degree vistas. Really enjoyed the vistas and the artworks in the basements.good to see collections so well presented and preserved for all to see.

Don't take photos. If you don't want to be treated like a low level criminal don't take a photo. The signs that say photos are not allowed are tucked away and not very apparent. The very unpleasant guard screamed in my face and continued to shout at me even when I apologised and offered to delete the photo. Learn from my mistake.

Beautiful art in an intimate setting. All the joys of the Musee D'Orsay in a more intimate setting. Musee de l'Orangerie is small but perfectly formed, and especially great when combined with its sister, the D'Orsay across the river.
Musee de l'Orangerie, Paris. An excellent opportunity to see Monet's waterlilies on large paintings that cover whole walls. And hundreds of paintings belonging to the Impressionists
a calming reprive from the more hectic sights. When you're exhausted from too much sight seeing of the major sites go here for a meditative hour surrounded by nothing but serene beauty.

Splendid Monet & Renoir. This is a small but incredible museum. Monet himself supervised the construction to house his magnificent water lily paintings and the two majestic oval rooms are exquisite settings for the work. The wall of Renoirs downstairs is equally incredible.

Water Lilies by Monet. Delightful gallery. The water lilies by Money are exhibited perfectly in their own rooms. A must see. The impressionist displays downstairs are also worth seeing too. Set aside at least an hour for your visit.
Sit for hours. I could sit for hours and just stare at the incredible art in this museum. I didn't want to leave. It is a must for art lovers...you cannot leave Paris without seeing it.

Curved Wall-to-Curved Wall Water Lilies: Love L'Orangerie!. It’s a shame some visitors miss Musée de l'Orangerie, on the edge of the Tuileries at Concorde. This museum re-designed by Claude Monet himself to house his Water Lily masterpieces will leave you happy you got to spend time in the oval room. A bonus is the second floor full of paintings by Picasso, Cézanne, Renoir and my favorite, Modigliani. Take home a memento from the gift shop and you’re out of there in 1 to 2 hours, depending on the pace you want to take.

One of the best Musee I've ever been to!. Well, besides holding the world famous Water Lillies works of Monet, the lower level holds a wonderful collection of Matese, Picasso, Guillmond & other contemporees from the 1910-40 era.Very worth the 9euro admission price.
If you love Monet !. You will see his water lilies in all their magnificent glory. Huge and breathtaking over two halls. Get the double ticket when you go to Musee d'Orsay. Its cheaper.
Small but worth a visit. Beautiful Monnet paintings painted directly to the walls. Small museum but nice, buy tickets in advance from internet and avoid queuing. Small museum shop inside, too.

Museum of Impressionism paintings - worth it. Renoir, Monet, Cézanne : absolutely amazing and very famous French Paintings from the XIXth century.Some very nice paintings from Picasso & MatisseDo not miss it

Wonderful gallery to visit. If you enjoy the Impressionist era don't miss this gallery ,its the most fantastic building holding Monet's waterlilies and other highly regarded and recognisable pieces from Renoir,Cezanne and others.We visited the Musee D'Orsey which was also incredible, do them both as they intertwine and you learn so much about this beautiful era of art.More peaceful ,more to study and simply enjoy and experience.Have never been in such a beautiful room as the two oval rooms housing the vast Waterlilies,illuminated by the natural light above streaming through.

Very good small museum. Monet's Waterlilies are very attractively displayed in the oval rooms. Nice seating to sit and contemplate all the nuances of colour and light.
Excellent exhibition downstairs when we visited, housing many impressionist and later works. Very worth a visit. Our museum pass didn't give us priority entry but there was a small queue so didn't matter.

A piece of Giverny in Paris. An extraordinary collection of Impressionist art, the Orangerie seems to be little-known but an absolute gem. The first few rooms of Monet's Waterlilies are worth taking a good while to sit and soak in, if you can get a seat! Just stunning, even on a day of miserable weather. If you've got a Paris Museum Pass, make sure this is up there on your list - especially if you want a little segue from the Louvre or Musee D'Orsay.

Quiet amazing museum. Claude Monet's water lilies spread over an entire wall--this is a small museum, but the artwork is no less spectacular. This is well worth a visit for anywone who likes the impressionists.
Amazing Monet. great exhibitions, good location and a magnificent building!!!! Visit it if you like impressionism!!!!

Next best thing to Giverny. Even if you hit the peak of your Monet-loving in high school, and are now sort of embarrassed to admit you like waterlilies anymore (guilty!)... go here. It's genuinely lovely. Take a stroll through the Tuileries before or after.After living in Paris for a while, and touring a lot of beloved family and friends through multiple museums, multiple times, I always recommended they skip the Louvre and stick to Musee de l'Orangerie, Musee d'Orsay and Centre Pompidou.
Not what we expected. We should have done more research. We knew it housed Monet's water lilies but not the paintings most of us know. The one with the wooden bridge is actually at the Musee D'Orsay.

Was on my bucket list.. I heard of this place back in high school art class and never thought I would ever be in Paris, let alone going to this museum. We had to wait in line forever in the mud because we didn't buy advanced tickets which was a pain but we were glad that we finally got it. It was beautiful in there. There are two rooms for the water lilies so don't miss them both! I recommend sitting on the benches in the middle and just pretending you are in a boat floating on the lake yourself. It's really amazing to see all the paintings together like that. You are not supposed to take pictures but that clearly doesn't stop anyone, even with a guy who yells out at people every once in awhile.Worth it!

Small, intimate, breathtaking. A fantastic small museum with an impressive collection for certain. Most everyone comes for the Monet Water Lillie's but do not miss the lower floor where there is a very large display of Renoir's as well. Make sure to spend some time sitting and looking at the Water Lillie's, the sheer size of them is amazing.

It makes you believe humanity has a future. It is a small museum, transformed in the beginning of the 20th century to receive the astonishing and breathtaking Monet’s Nymphees. When you read the story of Monet’s donation of his work to the world (to celebrate peace after the first world war), and enter the oval room where the enormous works lay on the walls as if crafted by a magician or God himself, you will feel the breath of peace, magnanimous generosity and love to humankind from one of the greatest artists of all time. It is a must see in Paris. There is also the exhibit of Paul Guillaume’s collection in the underground, with a good sample of European art from the 1910’s to the 1930’s. Don’t miss Soutini in the end of the corridor.

Wow. Really worth a visit for the amazing Monet water lilies. Its just a shame they won't allow photos of this, but downstairs you are able to take photos and the art here all though not as extensive is still amazing.

Immersive, emotional experience. The sheer size of the canvases make exploring the water lilies rooms completely immersive. Circle the rooms and study the mood of each scene, the brush strokes, the unfinished corners. Pick a favorite. Take a seat and inspect from a distance.
This gallery is best experienced sans crowds, so come early for a more subdued visit.

Fantastic!. Oh the joy of seeing these vast Monet canvases in the most perfect setting. An almost greater joy was to come though, the 'not Monet' section of this gallery holds wonderful, wonderful Renoirs, Utrillos and so much more which we weren't expecting.A real plus was a cloakroom for heavy bags and a plastic tube for carrying a dripping umbrella - the dripping coat section of the cloakroom was full when we got there. Despite the cloakroom being full, nowhere else felt full although there must have been a lot of people inside. This is spacious and airy and just too beautiful for words, what a treat.

Monet's are amazing!. The Water Lily's were breathtaking, but those thinking that this is the only reason to visit L'Orangerie are mistaken! The Renoir collection alone is well worth a visit, and the audioguides (at €5 each) are very good value. Will definitely visit again.
Magnificent !. This is my favorite museum by far.....more intimate and the Monet murals are exquisite. A must see for anyone!
Wonderful. Monet...Monet.....Monet...don't miss this museum. We were awed by Monet's paintings of Giverney. A wonderful visit and time well spent.

Uncrowded, sophisticated - you can see Monet's Water Lillies close up. Unlike the Louvre this little gem is easy to access, with no queues and will take less than an hour to see fully. Truly amazing is the 360 degree view of Monet's Water Lillies in a vast room. You can look close up to see the brush strokes or stand back to get the whole 20/30 ft canvas vista.

Don't overlook L'Orangerie. It has been several years since we visited L'Orangerie. The renovation a few years ago improved the museum by a great measure. Most visitors come to see Monet's water lillies. The gallery in the lower level is equally impressive--especially when you consider all the works came from one private collection.

Stunning. I went to this art gallery 20 years ago, and was keen to go back. It did not disappoint - to see the Monet paintings in the truly wonderful oval rooms setting is a lifetime memory. There was no queuing here - not sure if we were lucky! You can buy a ticket for this place and the Musee D'Orsay as a package and save a few euros.

An amazing place. Arrive early would be the best advice I could give. We got there just after 10a.m. on a February weekday and it was relatively quiet. This allowed us to enjoy the serene atmosphere in the three main galleries. The gallery downstairs had some very interesting works of art too. We did hire the audio guide and found it helpful. It was 5 euros. As we came out about 90 minutes later, there were queues to get in.there is no cafe there in case you were expecting one. There is a cloakroom and toilets though. Security is visible and bags are scrutinised.

Amazing display and collection. The best Monet Waterlilies!!! 2 oval rooms of wall to wall waterlilies. This magnificent museum is further complimented down stairs with Paul Guillaume's amazing collection of Manet, Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse. if you combine this museum and D'orsay, you might not like the Louvre anymore, ...maybe once again, magnificent Nymphea!

Review of Musee National de l'Orangerie by John Sanderson. The Orangerie Museum is not the first Museum that most visitors head to but it is certainly worth a visit. A remarkably quiet, relaxing atmosphere in the Museum. There is a collection of paintings from the Impressionist period to the early 20th century, but the highlight is work of Monet, particularly his Water Lilies. There are works of many others, including Cezanne, Renoir and Picasso. Nearest Metro station is Concorde on Lines 1,8 and 12.

Impressionist era. Monet's Nymphea was amazing and it was a nice stroll through Tuillerie gardens before reaching this museum. I prefer this museum over Louvre, it had all the painters I love gathered in one museum. Great collection.

A Monet fan's delight!. A beautiful little gallery largely dedicated to displaying Monet's water lilies, though the downstairs includes work from other modern artists . The gallery is small, but being situated among the Tuileries gardens and it makes a great side trip to a visit to the Louvre/picnic in the gardens.

Monet's Water Lilies. Seeing Monet's giant and beautiful Water Lilies paintings in that large, round room is something you never forget. It's just an awesome experience being able to experience the great Impressionists in one place, one great work after another.

A must for Monet fans!. A tiny museum but a must for all Monet's Water lilies fans. If you do think of going I recommend you buy a combined ticket with the Musee d'Orsay as they are just across the river from each other.

Museum that doesn't take long hours. It's a nice alternative to greater museums like Louvre or D'Orsay. It's impossible to enjoy Louvre in 1 or even 2 days, so it's not worth trying if you are a big art lover and staying in Paris just for several days. Musee de L'Orangerie has some good pieces from impressionists, and it's main attraction - the wall-size Water-Lillies by Monet. You can spend an hour inside, and still have lots of energy to explore other sights. But keep in mind the lines. If there is an exposition going on, you will have to spend some time in lines (which is a usual thing for most of the museums)

Monet!!!. I have been to Paris a number of times but I had never gone to see this museum before. I always wanted to but put other things first. But I have to admit that I loved this museum. The Water Lilies in the round are spectacular and the seasons changing as you rotate are pure genus. I enjoyed the other works in the lower levels as well. Two summers ago we visited Giverny and I became a fan of Monet's on a new level. if you have a love of Monet like I now do you shouldn't miss this small treat. It is the culmination of his studies in light and his beautiful garden. The other works are interesting as well. I saw a number of paintings by other Impressionists that I have seen in books but never laid eyes on. It takes only an hour or so depending on your desires. You could just pop in to see the Water Lilies . This is covered by the Paris Museum Pass,
A wonderful afternoon walk!. L'Orangerie is a place for romance. The most delightfull art is there. Renoir, Monet and others. Go right before the happy hour!

great small museum. this is a great small museum if you only have a little time. the water lily pictures by Monet are wonderful. I like the way several painters are grouped by room. you get to notice their style of painting
Fabulous. Absolutely fantastic museum. Monet's huge works are incredibly well presented and convey a huge sense of tranquility. The collection in the basement is a marvel.

Much more than expected. I had always wanted to see the Monet water lily paintings in the Orangerie, this is a beautiful museum of manageable size on the Tuileries. The great surprise for me was the wonderful collection of impressionist and post-impressionist art on the ground floor-fantastic! I think about two hours would be ideal for this museum, maybe a little less time if you are not an art lover.

If you are a Monet....... lover, then the Orangerie is an out of body experience. It's easy to reach from the Concorde Metro station; and when your stomach begins to rumble I highly recommend the restaurant Lescures on Rue Mondalvi, about 10 minute walk. Or for a light lunch and incomparable hot chocolate/patesseries, there is the ever popular Angelina's, on Rue Rivoli. Be prepared for a crowd, which often spills out onto the sidewalk.
Perfect way to experience the Water Lilies. Such a simple design for this Monet exhibit, yet stunning. The downstairs has a great variety of artists as well; Matisse, Renoir, Gaugin, etc.
Nice Building.. Art was a disapointment. in and out in 15min compared to the day at all the other galleries. a bit pricy for such a small collection.

L'Orangerie features interesting exhibits and fair fees. My partner and I happened to be walking to a nearby Metro station and noticed the museum and its photography exhibit. We returned at a later date, and were quite pleased by both the exhibit and the entrance fee.

Monet and some waterlilies. So if you cant do the mammoth Louvre filled with pictures and random stuff but want some "culture" then this is the place for you. It has that long long long picture of waterlilies by some famous artist which is admittedly quite impressive - a lot better than that picture of a woman that is either smirking or passing wind which makes the Louvre such an attraction. It also has some exhibitions underneath with pictures of fruit and naked people (whom's anatomy sometimes defy gravity). Anyways a good visit and not bad price.

Moving Experience. It was a crowded museum on a very cold day in December. We bought tickets from Ticketmaster France and picked them up at the tourism office. We could walk up to the short line for entry. The audio guide is worth renting. Its only for the permanent collection so you are n your own for the visiting exhibits. The Monet rooms of the L'Orangerie have been on my must see list for years. There is nothing that can prepare you for stepping in to the first 360 degree oval room of water lilies. Talking crowds fall silent as they enter the room. We walked to look up close up first and then sat on the benches to take it all in. Then we entered the second oval room. Viewing both rooms was very emotional for me. Print and film can't do the color justice. The natural filtered light is perfect for viewing these rooms. The lower level of the museum features some impressive impressionist big hitters. More works from Monet are on display. Restrooms are on the lower floor.
Nice gallery. Great location and not too crowded on this February day. Able to linger in Monet room. Beautiful art to see.

Small and easy museum. This was our 3rd trip to Paris, so we had the luxury of visiting some less typical attractions. The Orangerie was top on our list for museums this time, and it did not disappoint. We mostly went to see Monet's water lilies, which are in 2 rooms purpose built to display this art. These are large canvases that must be seen in person to get the full affect. In the basement, there was also a nice collection of impressionist art. We liked the smaller sized museum because it was less intimidating and tiring.
Monet!. Fabulous Birthday treat, after seeing a section of this at MOMA NYC it was a delight to see this work

Love this museum. While the water lilies are amazing - go to the basement and enjoy the other paintings. I actually found my favorite painting and it was a Picasso. This is a treasure trove of some of the best art in the world!
Monet. A lovely gallery, small but perfect. This and the the Marmottan Monet gallery were wonderful. There are some other notable paintings.

Always worth a visit.. Located at the end of the beautiful Tuileries Garden near Place de la Concorde this is probably my favourite Art Gallery. It houses a permanent display of Monets Water Lilies murals which cover two whole oval rooms especially designed in the 1920s to house them. You can sit in the centre and take in the peacefulness. The guards are a bit more overbearing than they were on my previous visit, watching out for cameras. The downstairs area houses Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne, Guillaime and many others. Small but gorgeous gallery. Tickets easily available at the office.

A must see!. A friend and I unknowingly visited this museum back in 2000 and were completely shocked to see Monet's water lilies in a mural form. This has become one of my go-to stops when I am in Paris. I've brought multiple friends here since my 'discovery' and love watching their expression upon seeing the exhibit almost as much I love seeing the exhibit itself.

Into the Water Lilies..... One of my top must see museums in Paris. Here you will find the famous Water Lilies, or also called Les Nymphéas by Monet. For me the experience was also more valuable as I have been to Monet's house in Giverny, Vernon (which is closed in winter). Being in the place that inspired some of his most famous paintings was an increadible experience as you get to understand both, where we took his inspiration from, and also what a genius he was by being able to translate the beauty of his gardens into magnificent paintings.If you are a Monet fan, I also suggest visiting Museé D'Orsay, and if you are going during summer seasons, Giverny.

A place of tranquility and beauty. The setting for displaying Monet's water lillies is almost like entering a church with a small vestibule separating the main corridor from the actual display room. This prepares you for the beauty of the work. The downstairs galleries are fled with gems by Renoir, Utrillo, and others beautifully displayed with pockets of natural light coming through.

Mindblowing. What a beautiful place, go and admire these wonderful water lillies, they are just the most amazing paintings ever. Also if you got pass the water lilly exhibition, there is a vvery impressive collection of paintings, some of them are my favourite ever. It is not a big collectoin so it feels much more special and you can spend enough time on each painting without rushing. What a treat. Also their souvenir shop is my favourite in the city

A new appreciation for Impressionism. There are many beautiful things here, but of course, the main attraction are "Les Nympheas" (Monet's "Water Lilies" in mural form). It's impossible to describe the impact of these enormous murals, and they give the viewer an understanding of the true meaning of Impressionism - a single, snapshot impression of a landscape at one particular moment in time. It's wonderfully serene to just sit and take it all in. I highly recommend a visit to L'Orangerie.

Stunning. This gallery has some of the most famous Monet paintings known. The rooms they are housed in are perfect for viewing and reflection.It is small and doesn't take long to go through, but is worthy of the visit. Go to the Monet first, view the other paintings downstairs and then take another long look at the Monets before leaving - amazing how they improve on second reflection, if that is possible.We had a Paris Museum Pass so we could skip the queue - well worth it as the normal queue was very long.Only one negative comment - I understand the museum was busy but one security guard in particular could take a lesson in friendly customer service - was not rude to us but was particularly mean to a lady in front of us in the queue, unnecessarily in our view but there you go, maybe he had a bad day!!!
Not as crowded as I expected. Art here is better than the Louvre I think- but if you want more Monet - see Musee Marmottan Monet, which is even less crowded.

A Gem. Musee de l'Orangerie is located in the 1st arrondissement, very close to the Place de la Concorde - the museum is in the South-West corner of the Tuileries Gardens. The ground floor is exclusively Monet's water lilies murals. Totally enjoyable, but we were very pleasantly surprised by the collections on the lower level. This is the Walter-Guillaume Collection and includes works by Picasso, Soutine, Derain and Marie Laurencin as well as Renoir and Cézanne. Basic admission is 9 euros/person. I strongly recommend the passport option for 16 euros/person which also gives you admission to the Musee d'Orsay just across the Seine.

wonderful to see the Monet paintings up close. The Musee de l'Orangerie is beautiful - downstairs is a collection of wonderful art that doesn't take long to tour, but the big attraction is upstairs - the two rooms of monet's water lilly paintings were created for the space and surround you in 360 degrees of delight. This is a lovely calm peaceful space in the heart of Paris to escape to - definitely worth a visit.

Never skip it when I'm in Paris. If you love Monet, if you like Renoir's still life paintings and Henri Rousseau's great-great fun paintings, this is a place for you! It's indeed small, as others pointed out, but I always need at least 1.5 hours to go around both floors, even if I only focus on my favourites. Do spend plenty of time on the upper level, sit down and enjoy the large, wall-size Monets! If you want to avoid large crowds, which kind of ruins the Monets, go in January!

Orangerie and Lemons. This gallery in the Tuileries gardens has a superb display of 8 huge Monet murals that he presented to the people of Paris as an antidote to urban life. The two main galleries are quiet and uncrowded.The anti dote works!We were disappointed by the rest of the Impressionist collection - plenty of well known artists but not their best works.

Monet up close and personal. Monet in all of its glory, this is a must see. Really liked the lighting in this building as it showcased such beautiful creativity. I actually followed the rules about pas de photo so include only a shot of the entrance.

So fun for a quick, 20 minute museum. Definitely worth a visit, if you are getting in for free (students with visa!) But, maybe not if you're paying because it is quite small. Monets water lily's are breath taking and massive and amazing and I really enjoyed walking through.
Love this museum. The Parisian equivalent of MOMA, in NYC. Monet to its essence. Small, easy to accommodate another visit on the same day to another awesome museum in Paris.

Beautiful!. Of course, the Monet rooms are breathtaking. (And, knowing the story of how Clemenceau got Monet to do it helps give it a historical context that really brings the whole thing to life!) But, there's more to this place than just Monet! The exhibits (which change) are really pretty neat too! And the permanent collection is nothing to sneeze at either. Perfect spot to begin or end your day at the Tuilleries!
Monet. Best art work we saw. Loved the gallery layout, and the size of the work. Huge.Favorite gallery we visited

Water lilies. Wonderful reflections in the water in a great space. Beautiful colors. I took about an hour to enjoy the scenery of Monet's garden. I was surprised that there was also a lower level with outstanding impressionist pictures. It was an amazing visit.

A gem of a museum. If you have only an hour or so, pick a small museum where you can appreciate what it has and you won't be overwhelmed. And Orangerie is exactly this. It's at the opposite end of the Tuiliers Garden from the Louvre and well worth the visit. The paintings in it are a superb collection, including its fixed display of Monet works.

Beautiful building average service. I have been to many galleries and I found this was average. The wait to get in was long and I felt the service and manner of the guards and attendants was poor. Once inside I enjoyed the building but was a little underwhelmed by the art collection. The toilets were dirty when we visited.
Lovely. One of our favorite places and surprisingly not as crowded as you'd think. You have time to sit and contemplate.

Very fine museum. Most People go there to see the large paintings of the water lilies by Monet on the ground floor (no photos there!). I found the collection Guillaume in the basement much more interesting: beautiful artworks by the most famous painters of the impressionist and post-impressionist period (e.g. Renoir, Gauguin, Sisley, Cezanne, Picasso...). And what a surprise: photogrpahy allowed (without flash of course). Foresee at least an hour for the visit.

Visit Monet's Water Lillies. Who knew that Monet's water lillies was large enough to take up two rooms... what you see on posters/frame work is just a very small piece of the entire work of art? Loved visiting Musee de l"Orangerie. Would have loved the opportunity to take photos to remember the trip; however, they are not allowed in this museum.

Go just for the Water Lillies. What a great museum! I confess I didn't know much about it until the hotel where I was staying recommended it. The Monet Water Lillies murals are going to leave you speechless and the collection of impressionist art downstairs is outstanding. It only takes 1-2 hours to totally take the whole place in. I absolutely recommend it.

Waterlillies in oval rooms. Monet's waterlillies were the promary reason for me to visit it. And they were worth it. The ambiance of the rooms with these huge and majestic painting is imcomparable. You just sit there and contemplate. But the Mudeum has more than that. It also has painting by Cezanne, Matisse, Renoir, Picasso and others. This is a relatively smaller museum and less crowded too. Very enjoyable.
Art paradise!. Simply amazing and you can easily spend an entire day if not longer absorbing the visual feast! Too many people but that's always a sign of the popularity of the place.

Money's Waterlillies are just peacefully awesome. We went down on the lower level first which exhibited a number of works of art by Picasso, Derain, etc - a collection by Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume. However upstairs was a different story. As soon as we entered the first oval room we were blown away by the size and the tranquility that oozed from this paintings, equally by the second room.We were glad we viewed the paintings in that order as after seeing the Waterlillies it is difficult to concentrate on other smaller paintings. Definitely another museum to visit! Plus it is set within the Tuileries Gardens, a great place for a stroll!

Not to be missed. If you don't have that long in Paris do not mistake Musee d'Orangerie as a secondary attraction. I am not a fan of the whole museum however The Waterlilies truely are amazing. While I appreciate art I have never been one to spend hours gazing at a few paintings. The Waterlilies are the exception. With every visit I find them just as intriguing and beautiful. It is well worth the cost for a calming visit to view Monets finest work.

I didn't realize Monet's paintings were so big they couldn't fit in my house!. That was an awesome experience! There's an oval-shaped room that is wrapped in Monet's work and it stretches from wall to wall, floor to ceiling. It was immersive, impressive, awe-inspiring and one of my favourite places in Paris. There's lots more to the museum than that, but the Monets are the best part.This museum is right at the end of the Louvre, too, so it's easy to get to, right on the tourist path.

A WATERLILIES LOVER'S DREAM. Two elliptically shaped rooms house eight huge canvasses, specially painted by Monet for this gallery. Superb!In addition, there are dozens of other works by the likes of Cezanne and Picasso.
Monet heaven. Such a treasure for a Monet fan like me.The whole museum is dedicated to his paintings. You won't want to leave the "lillies" behind

Wonderful Gallery. This gallery is always a joy to visit . The art that it holds demands a visit every time you are in Paris . The gallery is such a fantastic space . Even the views from inside are wonderful .
Must see. Fit this little museum into your schedule. It won't take long or bore the kids too much. Great way to introduce kids to the impressionists without getting sore feet.
