Delightful musée in the heart of a bustling city!. Monet's work is a must see, not to mention the other lovely impressionist paintings in the basement of the museum. It is a small museum compared to the D'orsay or the Louvre, but worth it. I would try to go early morning or late on in the afternoon. I visited at around 2 pm, and granted while it was during early summer, there were so, so many people. While Monet's paintings fill the walls, it is hard to fully appreciate them when there are lots of people milling about and standing right in front of them.
Unexpected. I think this is the second best museum in Paris after Musée d'Orsay. The water lilies Painted by Monet take your breath away.
Great Museum. We love this museum because it is relatively small and easy to navigate. It has wonderful paintings, especially the French Impressionists. It's a really a special venue

Only the Water Lilies. Monet is great. But I find these large canvases set in two 360 degree rooms to be underwhelming.Not worth the extra Euro charge at Gare De Orsay plus hoofing it over there.But many find it enchanting, nonetheless.Your call....

Impressionists Delight. The Louvre is notable for its absence of this genre and is way too large this Musee, a nice walk from the Louvre is much more manageable and if you lke Impressinism a MUST do. If pressed for time, I know it sounds like heresy, but skip the Louver and go here.

One of the most interesting choices. If you want to discover some art gallerie with much culture, then this is an ideal gallery. There are tons of great artists work on exhibition, and information about them, available alson on audio description... Monet has an entire floor for him

Go for the Waterlilies!. To be honest, I'm not sure what the admission for l'Orangerie is (we had the museum pass). Our visit was quick and easy - we just wanted to see Monet's waterliles. And they are IMPRESSIVE. I'm sure the rest of the museum is nice too, but if you have the time, go check out the waterliles exhibit - you won't be disappointed!

More than Monet. This little jewel of a museum is well known for the Waterlillies that Monet painted expressly for this space. However, the Paul Guillaume collection of Post-impressionists works down in the lower level is the other star. It's a small collection that highlights the collecting prowess of this successful Art Dealer.

Intimate art experience. This is a fairly small museum, but it has some really great pieces, including two rooms with Monet's "water lilies" paintings as murals on the walls. Buy a combination ticket for this and the Musee d'Orsay for maximum savings and efficiency (you can go on different days).

Easy to visit. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a quick and easy art escape if you have children or museum fatigue. Monet's works are strikingly laid out and you can walk into the 2 oval rooms and immediately appreciate his works. If you have time the time and inclination, there is plenty to explain the history of the site and how Monet envisaged his art to affect his audience.

Nice small gallery. If you find some art galleries to much but like a little bit of culture, then this is an ideal gallery. There are a lot of well known artists work on display with information both written and on audio (with a fee). The most famous work is Monet's waterlillies, which has the upper floor to themselves. I would advise anyone going here not to take a ruck sac though they make you wear it on your front!

Wow!. I cannot count the number of times I have visited Paris but I had never been to l'Orangerie before. Why not? I fon't know, but I eill be back. We visited with our adult daughters, the younger of whom had free admission as she was under 26 years old. I was overwhelmed by Monet's masterpieces. Having visited Giverney, it made the whole series of waterlily paintings even more personal for me. They are huge in scale and must be amongst the most beautiful paintings I have ever seen. There are many more impressive paintings in the museum but for me it was all about the waterlilies. This visit made my 60th birthday a memorable one and I will never forget the shivers which ran up and down my spine as the first of the paintings came into view. Please don't miss this museum. I'm only sorry I didn't go there msny years ago.
Giverny goes to Paris.... For those who can not go to Giverny is a good opportunity to see Monet's gardens, but in paintings. Buy the combined ticket with the D'Orsay Museum

A rest in the middle of your day!. Go inside and sit and look at the amazing large paintings. It is a relaxing break from your day. Children will like it too. We used the museum pass and just went in for 30 minutes and then moved on. Worth the break!!! Expect a line in the summer.

Small museum with huge Monets. This is where you'll find two very large oval galleries that contain only versions of Monet's huge Waterlilies. The colors and textures are gorgeous and fill your entire peripheral view. It's a great way to "cleanse your palette" before heading back out into the city. Walk through the Tuillaries to get there - it's very pleasant, even in cold, drab weather.
The best of Monet. Come early to avoid the crowds, besides the famous water lilies the exhibit in the basement is not to be missed!

Like visiting a chapel. Think of visiting a chapel more than a museum when you visit the Orangerie. Monet's giant canvasses of water lilies are displayed in rooms that he designed. A respectful silence provides an atmosphere of reflection and is a wonderful antidote to the bustle of the city.

A Fantastic Museum. Despite living in Paris for five months a decade ago, I somewhere never went to this museum. I rectified this error on my recent trip and was happy I did so. Monet's water lilies are worth the price of admission on its own. The downstairs featured other impressionists, Picasso, and a handful of other artists of equal talent. I recommend springing for the audio guide, which provided many interesting backstories on the artists' lives and works.

A special place for art. If you are an admirer of Claude Monet then you will know of this beautiful little museum in the Tuileries Gardens. And if not then it is worth a visit just to look in awe at the huge canvases of water lilies in the specially designed galleries.

A quaint art gallery. This gallery is a little different from the larger galleries. The art is very interesting in that it represents a dealers/agents personal collection from a very important art era.

An Unexpected Surprise. I had been to Paris before, but had not visited this museum. I'm so glad we we went. The Monet installation is just spectacular. It is also one of the less crowded musea as visitors tend to focus on the Louvre and d'Orsay. The temporary exhibit was good, though not outstanding. Still, the Water Lilies more than made up for it.

Unique pieces, sensational collection. Some of the most striking works of art you'll ever have the chance to see -- DO NOT MISS! The Monet pieces grab you and hold you for long minutes of rapt attention and respect for the artist and his vision. Mesmerizing and memorable, and the natural light of the generous space dedicated to these masterpieces is glorious. The thought of leaving such open space to head downstairs to a basement full of "other" art just didn't seem worth it, but boy -- gear yourself up for it, because this collection is equally amazing to behold! Many works by a variety of great artists, from Renoir and Cezanne to Soutine and Picasso, Utrillo and Emile Bernard. Amazing collection, museum beautifully located on the Jardin des Tuileries, metro stop Concorde. Get there early in the day if you can, but get there! This is a MUST-SEE!!
Monet. If you love Monet, this is the place to go and visit. What a great walk! Just a great venue to spend and hour specially if you like Monet.

Worth to go to see Monet. Monet's water lilies are fascinating and what l'Orangeris is most known for. You also find some paintings of Picasso, Renoir and Matisse.You probably won't spend much time there, so if you are looking for an alternative to Louvre to spend a day, Musée d'Orsay is better. But it is worth seeing.

Monet will move and enchant you with his Nympheas. Beautifully displayed as he would have wanted. A space of profound peace, quiet and contemplation. The collection on the lower floor is worth visiting too - but the two main rooms with Monet's Nympheas will remain with you always; sit down and look quietly at all the panels. Let them start to shimmer and move, notice how his brush strokes, up close, are dashes and streaks, yet from a distance, the whole epic, magnificent works simply transport you straight to his beloved lake at Giverny. You will be among the water-lilies and the surrounding trees, at the various times of day that he painted the scenes of this garden that he loved.

Monet will move and enchant you with his Nympheas. Beautifully displayed as he would have wanted. A space of profound peace, quiet and contemplation. The collection on the lower floor is worth visiting too - but the two main rooms with Monet's Nympheas will remain with you always; sit down and look quietly at all the panels. Let them start to shimmer and move, notice how his brush strokes, up close, are dashes and streaks, yet from a distance, the whole epic, magnificent works simply transport you straight to his beloved lake at Giverny. You will be among the water-lilies and the surrounding trees, at the various times of day that he painted the scenes of this garden that he loved.

beautiful and relaxing. Worth going here if you like the impressionists- Monet's water lilies are amazing. It's in a beautiful set up too. Downstairs there is also a large collection of other painters including Picasso, Matisse, Renoir, amongst others. Although I'm not a fan of the more modern artists, the Monet and Renoir paintings made it worth visiting!

water lilies. we waited a very long time in line with our Museum Passes, but it was very nice inside - the Water Lilies (even though the rooms were very crowded) were a very nice experience, and there was a small collection of nice paintings (picasso, gaugin. cezanne etc) in the basement

Monet's Huge Water Lilies. And a great collection from a French art dealer that has all the Impressionists including Monet, Matisse, early Picasso, Renoir, Manet, and many others. Near Concorde and Tuilleries Gardens.

Interesting museum - bad service. We visited this museum in December 2014 and enjoyed it very much except for the extremely slow moving line outside. The wasn't even that long, somewhere between 50 - 70 people were in front of us and we still waited for almost an hour in the freezing cold. The process of getting the guests inside and trough security is simply inefficient, especially when the temperature drops below zero. We would have enjoyed the museum more if we weren't frozen solid.
Noteworthy Collections. Aside from the Louvre, we liked the Musee de l'Orangerie. Unfortunately, photography is not allowed inside so one can only imagine the beautiful Monet's decorative panels.
hands down, my favorite museum in Paris. This is a fantastic museum and a great way to feel as if you knew Monet. It is a small museum, but worth the time to see it.

Monet would weep at the Breathtaking Beauty of his Water Lillies.. This museum has the most breathtaking exhibit of Monet's work that one could ever see. Two oval rooms displaying enormous panels of Monet's famous Water Lillies series. In both, you will be completely surrounded on all sides, and from almost the floor to the ceiling by Water Lillies - one can easily imagine floating in the ponds in Monet's garden at Giverny, placidly watching the sunlight dance across the water. It is Simply Stunnning! One can also see some beautiful works by Matisse, Picasso, Renoir, Rousseau, Cezanne, Sisley etc. While the Louvre is amazing, it can be overwhelming, so if searching for a truly intimate and inspiring experience visit the Musee de l'Orangerie in the beautiful Tuileries Gardens - it is located right next to the Place de la Concorde.
Water lilies - Monet. If you love Monet you must come here. Only a very small museum, easily done in less than an hour but well worth it.Also some Renoirs, Cezannes and other impressionists
Fabulous. Some wonderful impressionist paintings here - well worth your time if you like Van Gogh, Renoir and Monet. There was also a special exhibit that was interesting.

best to view monet in paris. this museum is inside the jardin de tuileries at Concorde, at the right side.this is a small museum, unlike the Louvre.the best thing about this museum is the very big canvasses painted by Monet,famous for the `lilies ` or the Les nympheas.the canvas size is really very big.there are a few such Monet paintings of lilies in ponds, each in different colour and shades. this is outstanding.all other exhibits are dwarfed by these motets.a nice and small museum, very well located and a must visit for Monet lovers.

Gorgeous. We queued for maybe half an hour to get in, with our museum passes (much longer queue for those without tickets).The main focus of this museum is always going to be Monet, whose Nympheas are stunning - you can take your time to look, and look really really closely too. Who knew that these giant paintings were made up of so many colours? From photos on the internet or in books you can only grasp a sense of what these paintings are like. In real life they are truly amazing - flashes of blue, purple, orange or green in the water, which you can only see when you're standing just inches away.I had known that Monet painted these paintings here in situ, but I did not expect to see his brushstrokes where they went out of the painting and hit the frame by accident. After I went home I looked in a book and saw photos of Monet in one of the rooms with a half-finished painting. Just amazing!The gallery downstairs just seemed like an extra addition to the Monets, although it did contain some Renoirs and Picassos. But to be honest nothing compared to seeing those giant Monets.

Excellent collection and a nice variety…. This museum has Claude Monet’s water lilies on display in specially designed oval rooms that use natural diffused sunlight to illuminate the room. If you like art, this is a must see. Additionally, there are other paintings on display by many of the impressionist masters. Give yourself about 1 to 1.5 hours here. Photography is not allowed.
Pequeno e charmoso. The museum is located in the Tuileries garden and is extremely charming. With excelent exhibition comteporanea art
Claude Monet. Cheaper to buy a ticket to visit two museums Orsay and Orangerie. However, it should start with the Orangerie, as Orsay is definitely a lot richer.

Impressionist Heaven and more...... L'Orangerie is a Paris must do for art lovers.Queues tend to be shorter here than at either Musee D'Orsay or the Louvre, but the rewards inside are just as exquisite.Here you will find the Monet Water Lily masterpieces painted by Monet late in his life, specifically to adorn the gallery space as a national homage to his artistic genuis and legacy.You will also find near as extensive a collection of impressionist works as at Musee D'Orsay.Much of the collection is housed in underground galleries carved out to accomodate the collection.There are permanent displays, as well as visiting exhibitions.Put Musee de l'Orangerie up there on the list, alongside the Louvre and Musee D' Orsay as not to be missed!
Water Lillies are incredible.... Just go for the Monet Water Lillies rooms... 100% worth it! The collection is also fascinating, with some excellent pieces.

Get There Early!. So, we loved this small musee. We didn't have advance tickets, which is the best option, but we got there as the doors opened and we were the first in line (for non-ticket holders) so made our way in quickly. The musee is so easy to navigate and the displays of Monet's worth the ticket price alone. I loved this place because it's not overwhelming and paying a little extra for the portable recorder is well worth the money. They have an excellent gift shop as well so I was able to pick up some nice souvenirs to take back. Afterwards you can easily stroll the avenue of Place de la Concorde or take a spin on the ferris wheel and picture options are fantastic...well, it's Paris!
Art. Really enjoyed this. Quiet environment. It was smaller than I thought however did enjoy the facility.

Fabulous collection. All the exhibits within this often forgotten museum are worth a visit. The Monets were wonderful but wander downstairs and view the other exhibits, so many memorable pieces. Having been to Paris many times I am still kicking myself I hadn't come here earlier.
Oh so stunning . Beautiful and stunning reflective space. Have overlooked this museum on previous visits to Paris but I think it will be on my must do list from now on.

Not bad but not that memorable either. After a while all the art starts to be a vague memory. I remember the water lillies, but not much else. I remember outside the Museum better. Near the entrance, there was a set of benches and a statue which seemed nice. The Tuileries garden was a large grassy area with a pond, and very pleasant place to relax for a few minutes. The Place du Concorde had some interesting sculpture. An Obelisk and a fountain worth seeing - be careful crossing the avenue
Always love to come. The other exhibits were worth a view. It is so wonderful tp see these works. This is not to be missed when in Paris.

Go for the jaw-dropping Monets; be surprised by the rest. In many trips to Paris I had somehow missed this placeExcellent location in the Tuillieries Gardens along the Seine; line was longer on a weekday than I would have expected even with the Museum PassThe Monet water lilies were simply breathtaking - almost indescribably beautiful with the placement and light. Just allow yourself to soak it in. Trust me, you can't really get a photo of the room - get a postcard in the shop. But we really enjoyed the lower level exhibit space too. Surprising permanent collection and were were there with a well done special exhibit too. Very do-able in an hour or so if you are pressed for time - you won't feel you have missed anything. Was impressed with the selection of books in the shop too.

A quick walk thru and some wonderful Monet wallscapes.. When you're in Paris for a limited time, your goal is to see as much as you can. For us, lots of this is done walking and by the time we got to the Musee de l'Orangerie, it was was late in the day and we were tired. It's a wonderful little museum and well worth the visit. When next we get to Paris, we will make it a point to extend this visit.
What's not to love. Fantastic smaller museum (small compared to the museum down the way ;) with an excellent selection of modern art. It's open on Mondays as an added bonus.
small and wonderful. It's a museum you can go to and not have to spend all day there. Lovely works of art. Not to be missed.

Monet's Water Lilies are a MUST. Went specifically to see Monet's Water Lillies, and it was awe-inspiring. Absolutely amazing that 8 pieces of work span 2 huge rooms. The impressionist exhibits downstairs were great as well, but I will always come back to see the Lillies.

Monet. Went to this museum to see the water lilies by Monet. Well laid out, clean lines and very importantly appropriate lighting for the masterpieces on view.Fabulous three hours browsing the artwork, impressive gallery of artists and originals. Well worth a visit if in Paris.
Amazing. We waited in a long line, but it was worth it! The paintings were breathtaking and it was worth the wait.

Ultimate experience. Have you ever walked into a museum exhibition room and just felt that nothing can be better than this on that very moment?This is how I felt when I entered to the two exhibition room where the huge Monet paintings are exposed.It is a breath-taking moment when you can just sit and admire those painted gardens. It makes you visit. And re-visit. And re-visit...
If theres no line-up. Beautiful works- including two beautiful rooms of Monets Water Lilys. Downstairs has a small but significant collection. Worth it- if theres no line.

Left feeling a little disappointed. We decided to visit Musee de l'Orangerie as we both love Monet far more than the Mona Lisa (plus the queue was much shorter than for the Louvre!) but we both left feeling a little disappointed. The building is beautiful, the exhibition design is perfect and the collection on display is extensive although the majority are by artists other than Monet but we were just left little blank, although I couldn't really put my finger on why. I think the large Monet freezes are almost a bit of a disappointment compared to the rest of the exhibition areas. Also, I know many will recoil in horror when I say that a cafe would be an excellent addition.
D'Orsays little brother. Water lilies are wonderful, but there's so much more. Worth going, buy a combination ticket with the Musee D'Orsay
Matisse Museum. long lines .. but people who wait to see art are nice folk.The Emile Bernard exhibit was very impressive.

Breathtaking Monet Water Lilies exhibit!. Bought tickets on line to avoid long lines; it worked! Got right in. Other exhibits were good, but the special galleries built to house Monet's magnificent huge "Water Lilies" simply take your breath away!! Wonderful! Don't miss it!

Claude Monet's Water Lilies!. The Orangerie was built in 1852 to shelter the orange trees of the gardens of the Tuileries next to the Place de la Concorde. It became a museum in 1921 and contains work from (post)impressionist painters like Monet, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir, Rousseau, Soutine, Utrillo and Paris born English artist Alfred Sisley. The museum is most famous for housing the eight water lilies murals by Claude Monet. Two galleries were purposely built to display the eight donated water-lily paintings known as the Nymphs (1915-26). Monet created the effects of his masterpiece with many hundred minute brush strokes.Taking photographs isn't allowed and I would recommend buying tickets on line to avoid the long lines.

If you love "Waterlilies", this is a must. Monet's "Waterlilies" is one of my favorite paintings. I sat and savored for a good 10-15 min. My kids (13,12,10, and 7) didn't enjoy it as much, but did like the museum as a whole.
My favorite museum. I know there are bigger museums but l'Orangerie is simply breathtaking. The perfect size and the water lily's in the round are unbeatable!

Buy a museum pass and don't miss the water lillies. We visited Monet's garden and then came to see the finished artwork at l'orangerie. Many people miss this gem as they are busy at D'orsay or the Lourve but if you are on a museum pass, this stop is included and well worth it. Nothing can prepare you for the sheer size of these paintings. It has to be seen to be believed. Make sure you have Amorino gelato from the truck parked outiside after your visit. Enjoy!

An absolute must do if you are a monet fan. I spent hours just admiring monet' s works. Perhaps it is just me but I could sit here all day if I had the time. As usual the queue is horrendous. But I was lucky I suppose since I only waited about 45 minutes. I can't imagine what the peak season would be like but please book. In any case it was all worth while for a museum goer. Again I can't say the same for non museum folks. A museum is what it is after all filled with art works of the masters.

Worth a Visit. Small museum with 2 separate parts. This first contains 8 huge paintings of Monet, and the second rum contains a collection of paintings from various artists. I myself enjoyed the the Monet painting as it was more unique. The visit only takes about 1 hour so if you are in the area you should visit.
Fabulous Museum. This is one of my favorite museums in Paris. Very much inspiring and a must see in the city. Monet's Waterlillies are just amazing and if you miss seeing them be sure you miss a lot.

My favorite museum of all time!. I love the Musee de l'Orangerie. It's a small, manageable museum but with huge star appeal. There is not an insignificant piece in the collection. The rooms with the Water Lilies are amazing, but what really impressed me was all the art on the lower level - Picasso, Renoir, Matisse. Really amazing pieces - most of which I've never even seen prints of before. LOVE LOVE LOVE this place! I will be back!

Small and intimate museum. This is a small and intimate museum with amazing artwork. The Monet exhibit of the Water Lillies is the draw, but they have some beautiful (and some even "works in progress") paintings on the next level. Very intimate museum and much more manageable than the Louvre!

A gem in the shadow of the Louvre. By the Tuileries gardens we came by this gallery almost by chance. It contains a purpose-built gallery displaying Monet's 'Water lilies' in their magnificent glory. These huge works of art can never really be properly represented on a printed page and 'in the flesh' they are beautiful, awe-inspiring and almost overwhelming. A must-see.
All about Monet. If you like Monet you will love this museum. If you don't like Monet, I think you will like him after viewing his wall to wall to wall "Water Lilies".

Musee de l'Orangerie visit. Had a half hour wait in biting cold befroe getting in. The two oval rooms with the Monet Water Lilies were stunning but the numbers were a touch too high for the tranquillity that would be ideal. The Guillard collection was interesting but the large number ofRenoirs were not of his best impressionist era and nor were those of other artists. There were films running continually about individual artists but being detailed and only only in French with no sub-titles were quite hard to follow.

Great world-famous waterlilly paintings. Well worth a visit to see these world famous 200 meter long paintings of water-lilies. The building is in the jardin de Tuileries , and a short walk accross the footbridge takes you near the Musee d'Orsay
interesting. what an interesting building and exhibit...so well done but obviously you have to be a fan of Monet which we are

Can it be larger ?. The Water Lilies murals are quite amazing. The site suffers though from its popularity: It's difficult to get lost in the murals when so many other people swirl around you. The admission fee is steep for its size. It'd probably be less crowded if it were more expensive but then it might lose its hype. The best solution would probably be that it in some way expand...

Interesting small museum. The Musee de l'Orangerie is located on the southwest corner of the Jardin des Tuileries in central Paris. It is also located near the Pont de la Concorde in one direction and directly across from the Place de la Concorde in the other direction. The museum has the famous Water Lilies exhibit upstairs and the Walter-Guillaume Collection in the lower level. All of the works in the lower level once belonged to Paul Guillaume, a Parisian art dealer and friend of many of the Impressionists.I went with my wife on a Wednesday afternoon in late October and really enjoyed touring this interesting small museum. We went primarily to see the Monet Water Lilies but ended up enjoying the Walter-Guillaume Collection more. This amazing collection includes works from Renoir, Cézanne, Matisse, Picasso, Modigliani and others. The Water Lilies are huge and it is impossible to understand how big they really are until you see them in person. The huge paintings are displayed in two oval rooms that make it easier to take them in.The museum was not very crowded but the line to enter was pretty long. You have to be in the museum before 5:15 pm and we got in at about 4:45 (so we were getting a little nervous that we were not going to get in). There are two lines outside the building, one for general admission and the second for Paris Museum Pass holders. They offer an English speaking guided tour but we did not get there in time for that so we just did a self guided tour.Overall I enjoyed this interesting small museum and recommend it. It is an easy museum to visit due to its convenient location and small size. This museum is interesting but I would not put it on your itinerary if you are visiting Paris for the first time (unless you are a huge art lover).

Great gallery that isn't too big!. This is a really nice gallery to spend a couple of hours in and take in all the exhibits. The Monet waterlillies are the obvious highlight and are magnificent. If you're only in Paris for a couple of days or weekend I'd recommend this gallery as a much easier to tackle than the Louvre.
Exquisite. This is the place to really see Monet's water lilies and more. The size of the museum and the quality of the collection make this very people friendly.

A gem; a 'bijou'; loved it as much as beloved Louvre. It was a long walk to L'Orangerie and I only knew that it was small and modern. There was a long queue and it was once inside that we found that this was because it was a Sunday, when entrance is free. So we navigated the many small rooms of 19-20th century paintings by painters with whom we were familiar and felt quickly drawn into the world of the impressionists, of Montmartre, of Paris street scenes of a hundred years ago. After the brilliant but oppressive religious inspirations that dominate much of the Louvre, I think both my son and I found this utterly refreshing.Was this all? Oh, of course, there were Monet's waterlilies. So in we went. Again, I was lost for words; had my breath taken away. I hadn't expected this - a whole room (then another) devoted to this wonderful series of paintings. We sat silently, in awe, trying to take it in; I found myself thinking of MIchelangelo and the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel nearly five hundred years earlier; art critiques and historians might find this laughable but I was equally moved by the beauty, mastery and integrity of these works. A knockout.

One of the best in Paris. Not only does it have rooms full of Monet, the toilets are the best you'll find in Paris, according to my 16 year old son.Walking into the museum is like most others, buy your tickets, check your backpack and then bang you are straight into the first room of Monet's Waterlillies masterpiece or pieces. Seats in the centre allow you to rest your Paris walking legs. People watching in these galleries is nearly as good as the artwork. Boy oh boy some people have themselves on.We had two teenagers and easily sat (moving around the rooms) for 20 minutes in each room. The artwork is special but it is the setting that makes this museum as must see. After being upstairs for a while we headed downstairs to The Walter-Guillaume Collection, a very well set out easy to view collection of paintings.A great sized museum, easy to get around, good gift shop and the toilets have to be used to be believed.

Didn't expected!. Went to this museum only to look at Monet's npmyheans, but was surprised with the quality of the collection they have, it's a small museum, it didn't take much time to do a complete visit.

little gem not too well known. Close to the Louvre and all the other museums is the Orangerie. A one topic museum. It hosts the famous pond paintings by Monet. He painted his pond in the 4 different seasons. These are huge paintings and the visitor feels almost immersed in the pond itself. A wonderful experience, close to the 'panorama' paintings which were popular in that era. A not very crowded museum and coming in from the bright light of the Tuileries garden it is also a cool recluse.Worth a visit and take your time. Let the paintings immerse into their cool water.

Unknown to many yet in plane sight!. Located directly across from the Concorde, this incredible building was originally built as a royal greenhouse for an Orange grove. Later converted into a huge linear exhibition space for Monet's water lilies, the room is alive with history and beauty. Check for open ours as they sometimes close unexpectedly.
A lovely small museum. I enjoyed a relaxing hour here after walking around Jardin de Tuileries. The large curved Monet paintings are extraordinary. The museum also has a nice gift shop.

Magnificent Monet. By chance our river cruise company offered tickets for this fabulous experience the day before our visit to Monet's Garden at Giverny, where we saw the Real Thing! (Still unsure which was better, both out of this world - we were so lucky to have this opportunity). You will be transported to a world of light and shade, beauty, colour, contrast, silence, subtlety and coolness. Sit and watch how the light changes on the paintings, especially when it's sunny outside. The Orangerie is the perfect venue for these Masterpieces. Don't miss it if at all possible.
Paintings and School Groups. Ok if you have the museum pass. Paintings from well known artists, but can afford to give a miss if you have been to the Louvre.

A must, if you visit Paris.. We visited this Musee on a trip to Paris in October, we have been before, but are still transfixed by the beauty and tranquillity.If you love Monet and other impressionist, this is the place to go.Situated at the Place de la Concorde, it is easy to find, you won't be disappointed, there is so much to see.There is also a wonderful cafe there to have lunch, a day well spent.The only thing that spoilt it a bit for us were the people outside controlling the entry, even though we had Museum passes we were forced to wait in a queue for an hour while they let people through who had to buy tickets.Strange, hey!

A real surprise. We visited this museum in December 2014. The trick is to arrive early - around 9.15 am and beat the tourists regardless of the season.A real must and not as busy as other museums in beautiful Paris.

Slightly chaotic ticketing. The day we arrived, the ticketing system had a meltdown which meant that people who had queued for quite a while could not get in. I can't understand why they didn't just say, okay, you can enter for free. Instead there were many cranky and tired visitors who couldn't get in.That aside (and the extreme unhelpfulness of the staff during this period), the work is brilliant. Worth queuing hours for the Waterlilies and the absolutely perfect venue in which they are displayed. The Bernard exhibition was an unexpected wonder. Extremely good wall texts as well.
Great docents - fabulous water lilies!. Be sure to take the English tour to gain the best understanding of the works located here and especially of Monet's work.

Winter Christmas Markets Trip. This was my second visit to the Musee de L'Orangerie and I expect that I will go again when I visit Paris the next time. Although the museum was crowded, you can still see anything you want with patience. I enjoyed seeing school children seating in front of one of Monet's water lily paintings attentively listening to a docent. This is a must visit.

Monet. Terrific, little museum on the edge of the tuileries. While it has showing of other artists (when we were there in December 2014, a showing of Emile Bernard), the main draw are HUGE elliptical water lilies, seasonal expressions, by Monet specifically crafted for the two rooms. Quick little tour will do, but must stop in the area.

Better Late Than Never. If you can, try to get to this jewel of a museum before January 5, 2015 to visit a once in a lifetime exhibit of the works of Emile Bernard, a show which has attracted works from multiple museums as well as private collector here in Paris. Also, by all means get the audio guide to provide a wealth of information about this very talented artist of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. This special exhibit is unlikely to be replicated at any time in the near future. The evolution of Bernard's styles from early impressionism to late classicism is amply illustrated by gorgeous works hung in chronologic order. Get there before it departs.The rest of the collections here are also totally wonderful, well described in other reviews, and well worth a visit.

Might be the best small museum in Paris. L'Orangerie is probably my favorite Paris museum and it may be the best small museum here. It would be enough simply to view the stunning and deeply moving water lily murals by Monet, all 8 of which are displayed in two rooms for which they were specifically painted. What a gift to the people of France Monet gave when presenting these for display. But in addition to the waterlilies, the downstairs of L'Orangerie has an excellent small collection which was the life's work of two different collectors/dealers. Paul Guillaume was a great friend to the impressionists, and there are several portraits of him and of his wife. Perhaps these were gifts in payment for services rendered? Regardless, this is a lovely collection of Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse, Rousseau, Derain, Utrillo, Laurencin, and a sizable collection of works by Chaim Soutine. Currently there is also an exhibit that is a retrospective of all periods of work by Emile Bernard. Do not miss this gem in the heart of Paris on Place de la Concorde.

Tranquill water lilies. The main attraction of this museum is the two circular rooms with 8 panels of Monet's water lily paintings. The rooms are quiet, allowing for a break from the bustle of the city just beyond the walls, and the paintings are breathtaking. I visited the museum just for the water lilies. The remainder of the small museum is filled with paintings by other impressionists and there is a gift shop. The Orangerie is part of the Paris Museum Pass. The only drawback is the fact that photos are not allowed. They wouldn't do the panels justice but it would have been nice to have as a reminder.

Monet's Masterpiece Museum. This is where Monet's Les Nymphéas is displayed and the panels, filling up two rooms, are enormous. Monet specifically painted his masterwork for this museum and they are the centerpiece of the collection, taking up the whole ground level in two rooms. The underground rooms are devoted mostly to the collection of Paul Guillaume and include works by Renoir, Cezanne, Rousseau, and Picasso. Small in size, it can comfortably be done in a couple hours. A big benefit is that it is not crowded, so it is a nice respite after visiting the Louvre. And it's an easy 15 minute walk from the Louvre. There is a free bag check and all bags must be checked.

Monet's Lilies displayed well. Monet had a big part in how these two massive paintings are housed and displayed - so inevitably - they are displayed well (as the artist thought to best effect, and he was correct).I could have walked between the two rooms gazing at them for easily another hour of my time and it would not have been wasted.There is also a small exhibition of some works by Monet's contemporaries downstairs which is interesting - but it is the Lilies that drew us there.The video that plays (in a room opposite the toilets) explains the process of these paintings being completed and displayed; and it does so very well. I am glad we took the time to sit and watch the whole thing.Basically, if you like Monet and/or Giverny then you will love this place. If not, you won't! - it is a haven for Monet lovers.

water lilies. Nothing beats being able to see Monet's water lilies, 8 panels of it. 2 rooms. not allowed to take picture though and they're really strict about it! Also plenty of other impressionist paintings in there too from Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse and more.

Small Impressionist Museum with Big punch. The two rooms of water lillies by Monet are amazing. I had seen these before but was quite happy with the two special exhibits in the lower level. Amazing collections. Great location near many other key spots to visit in Paris.
A must for Monet fans. Central museum just of Place de la Concorde. A very good variety of artists for such a small museum.
Wonderful. A truly wonderful experience to see Monet's Water Lilies. Much quieter than other museums which is good as a visitor but I cannot understand why more people do not visit.

Worth it. Just spending time looking at the Waterlilies would be enough, but there were a number of other artists displayed which was very interesting, some familiar, some not, so a comfortable impressive museum.
Beautiful!. Monet's water lilies are worth seeing in the flesh, with large oval shaped rooms dedicated to showing them off. Very enjoyable.
Do come here.. This is a gem. Quieter than the bigger museums. The Monet water lilly paintings are staggering - so large and serene in the oval room.

Monet's water lilies - do you need more?. If you are in Paris please visit this wonderful museum with it's purpose built display area for Moet's Water Lilies, truly wonderful art. The other exhibits displayed in the lower galleries are well worth seeing too. As with all Paris museums, pre-pay or be prepared to queue for as long as you will go round the gallery. Even the pre-paid queue was 20 minutes in May.
Monet all the way. Great layout for huge water lily canvasses in oval display. But a treat with other Impressionists also. If you can't get enough Monet or Impressionists, definitely worth a visit.

Just right. We usually get overwhelmed by most museums given the vast and diverse collections that you get to see (hello, Louvre!)...this museum is much smaller compared to most and thus enabled is to really appreciate and soak up the beautiful work that is Monet's water lilies. The whole set-up is just impressive where you have the paintibga mounted in a room with sunlight streaming through. I've read that Monet designed the setup himself but didn't live to see it. In any case if in Paris, don't miss this, especially if you have done the smart thing of getting the Paris museum pass. We used the pass and were inside in minutes. Note, bags are checked on entry.

An annex to the Musee d'Orsay?. We remembered the old Orangerie as an "also ran" and didn’t expect much of it now, so it was a lovely surprise. There were two rooms of Monet’s Water Lilies on the ground floor, but when we went to the lower floor, we were stunned -- this was a fantastic collection of the post-impressionists! Rooms of Picassos, Cezannes, Matisses, and a room of the Rousseaus I had missed at the d’Orsay. Had we had more time, we would have returned to revel in the paintings on the lower floor.

Peaceful and Beautiful. Absolutely loved this museum. We used our Paris museum pass for entrance and skip the line access. It is quiet and relaxing, which you don't find in most museums. That may have been due to the time that we went which was about 3:45 pm. The collections of Monet's waterlillies were amazing and so breathtaking. I highly enjoyed all the modern art on display and just taking it all in! A must see in Paris!

Relaxing place. I visited L'Orangerie during my last journey in Paris. It was the first sunday of the month and the museum was free! I love the enormous painting of water lilies by Claude Monet. It was so relaxing insomuch that I was going to sleep on the sofas! Very suggested.. near Tuileries Garden and Louvre

A Small Gem. Designed by Monet to showcase his work, the ground floor is two rooms. Each has four enormous paintings of the lily pond at his home-- creativy unbounded! Definitely one of my top art experiences.To top it off there is wonderful collection of Monet's contemporaries below ground.

I visit every time I'm in Paris. Forget therapy, meditation, medication, drugs, alcohol, whatever your thing is. Just sit here for half an hour and you'll have a new and wonderful view of life.The downstairs exhibit change but have always been wonderful.In short, do not miss this, it is good for the soul.

This has been closed for a long time..now open.. Was looking forward to visiting after such a long period of renovation. Slightly disappointed. Collection only so so. Remembering a time I really liked going there an cannot say what is so different now. I won't go back again. Lovely setting.
Ahhhhh, Monet. What can you say about the magnificent water lilies of Claude Monet? One of the most serene and extraordinary art experiences in the world, not to be missed!

Relatively small museum but still worth the visit. This relatively small museum is nicely tucked within a corner of the Tuileries Gardens (next to Place de la Concorde) but it is no less important compared to the larger museums when it is home to Monet's Les Nymphéas. No pictures of the 8 panels of waterlilies can do this incredible art piece justice. You must see Monet's unbelievable and beautiful work in person; sit down on the chairs provided in the centre of the two oval white walled rooms and just let yourself feel awed. I was lucky enough to go on a day where there were very little people to obstruct my view. The gallery downstairs is also home to many celebrated artists, including Émile Bernaud, Cézanne, Matisse and Renoir and of course, that's a treat too.

Better than ever. We have visited Monet's Lilies often but I think I have studied them enough by now that I'm beginning to understand how he achieved what he did. The atmosphere, with few visitors right now, is very good. And the accompanying exhibition downstairs is fascinating. I knew nothing of Emile Bernard. His work is startling, very fine. May I also say that the staff was kind, and that, seriously, they have Japanese washlets now? I mean, that's cool. Actually, it's warm.

Built in 1852, it's a wonderful museum with Monet's huge waterlily paintings. At Southwest corner of the Tuileries Gardens by the Place de Concorde, is a relatively small museum. In 1922 Claude Monet signed a contract to provide the French with 8 huge panels of Water Lily paintings. The decision was made to build two large oval rooms on the East End of the Orangerie to house these panels. Now these two oval rooms are quiet, simple with some benches in the middle and you are surrounded in each room by the four long canvas panels depicting the water lilies and water gardens. The rooms are very peaceful, and visitors quietly sat or stood and enjoyed the paintings. Of course, on other floors, there are numerous other famous paintings including the entire collection donated from Paul Guillaume which included Renoirs, other Monet's, Picasso's, and many other impressionist and post impressionist paintings. For a Monet or impressionist fan , this is a must-see museum.

Paris' most digestable museum. I recommend this museum above all others in the city. In addition to the ovular rooms dedicated to Monet, the floors below offer a concise, understandable, and unintimidating review of a late Parisian art collector's former collection along side a rotating exhibition. It makes for a perfect afternoon trip.

very nice structure. Went to Orangerie for the first time last month, Really enjoyed the interiors and the oval rooms. I liked the long stretched paintings along the wall, very airy and bright. Easy to stroll around downstairs were we managed to see more impressionists. Recommend the double pass Orsay - Orangerie, I had mine with 3 days validity for 16euros.
Surround your self with water lilies. Apart from the good collection of Monets water lilies there is also much more of worth to see. Nothing to dislike and lots to like

Fantastic gallery - not too big or busy - great exhibitions. I really enjoyed this gallery. It's a manageable size, and not too busy. We went on the first Sunday of the month - which meant there was no entry charge - a saving of €9. Upstairs there are the 8 Monet Water Lilies, whilst downstairs there was an Emile Bernard exhibition - which closes in early January. I was not familiar with this artist (my ignorance) and was pleasantly surprised. There is also the The Walter-Guillaume Collection - various artists. There is a small gift shop, but unfortunately no coffee shop. I'll definitely visit again.

the power of the water lilies. This selective collection is a must see, starting with the rooms housing Monet's water lily paintings. They have the power to transport even a group of 7 and 8 year old students. The balance of the collection is a delight as well and well worth the hour or so to view it.

My Very Favourite!. I would highly recommend this gallery to all visitors to Paris. They have a small, manageable collection containing the most fantastic works of all the artists that we have come to know as being synonymous to the art revolution in Paris. such artists as Renoir, Van Gough, Picasso, Matisse, Cezanne and Monet Well set out, easy to walk around and photograph. Excellent two hours!

Don't overlook it!. Don't overlook this smaller museum in one corner of the Tuileries near Place de la Concorde. The oval rooms dedicated to Monet's water lilies are spectacular. I am a fan of Marie Laurencin's work and there are 5-6 nice pieces along with some other great impressionists here. There is currently a great Emile Bernard exhibit until Jan 2015. I didn't know much about him previously, but I really enjoyed learning about his work and appreciating his talent. I don't think there is a cafe in this museum, so make sure you've eaten. There is a complimentary coat check.

My favorite museum in Paris. This is an incredible little museum, less exhausting than a visit to the major Parisian museums. Tranquil and designed for art lovers--the ban on photography really improves the experience, I think, as it encourages visitors to sit and appreciate Monet's spectacular murals in the moment. The architecture is very interesting and avant garde for its time -- crazy to think that Monet designed the museum for his works during his life. These paintings are a national treasure.

If you only have a day in Paris.... If you only have a day in Paris, visiting this museum is a must. The Monets' are absolutely spectacular. Just as importantly is the fact that the museum is so beautiful in itself. Unlike the other major museums the large Monets dominate such that you can sit in the middle of each room and just enjoy. I would much rather spend a couple of hrs here than in the Louvre.

The Monet Lilies!. Go for the Monet Lilies! Strapped for time I didn't have time for the rest of this small museum but I'm so glad I made time to see the Lilies. 8 massive Monet paintings spanning two spacious oval rooms. It was so beautiful and very peaceful could have sat there all day.

Unforgettable experience.. The whole museum is an exquisite little gem, but those waterlily paintings are like something out of a dream. I remember hearing (perhaps in Moma? or the Tate Modern?) about these big waterlily paintings, and Monet's painting them near the end of his life in the aftermath of WWI. One of his friends was invited into his studio to see them, covering the floors and the walls, he said seeing them was like seeing the world made new. It is not crowded, and is centrally located. You will not regret going.

Easy to miss but don't. This museum is easy to miss, located between the d'Orsay and Louvre but make the effort to see. The Monets are magnificent. Just as importantly is the peace a quiet of this museum. Unlike the other major museums the large Monets dominate such that you can sit in the middle of each room and just enjoy. No rushing not hustle just beautiful art and peace.

Impressionisme in pill form. After a big and long renovation ten years ago this small museum became one of the leading museums in Paris. You cansee a lot of nice paintings from the most famous French period - The Impressionism. I am not very fond of the big Water lilies (6x2m) however since 2006 they are in the direct daylight which desapeared for many years. Easy to go through and small enough for a two hours visit. Of course there is the big Orsay Museum but if you don't have time for this or you saw it already do not hesitate.

a place of quiet and sensual art. Even as it is often over-viewed by many, just for the fact that is placed in a complex of historical buildings that surround the majestic Louvre, this small museum is a a true jewel in a large possibilities of Parisian museums. They have an incredible architecture- a combination of historical value and a modern interpretation, and that is just enough to take a bit of your time during the visit, to hold you for a short while while you enjoy. Monet is the star of their show, his large pallets of water lilies are right here. And that room is timeless, you slip into another dimension. The museum also contains works by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo, among others. Don't mind the long lines, it is worth it.
Lovely. This museum is for the fans of impressionism. Beautiful Claude Monets paintings. There are no crowds - only art. I recommend.
A wonderful museum. A much easier visit than some of the other Parisian museum behemoths! The works are arranged in helpful and logical order.

Easy to overlook, hard to forget. The build in a small classical building across the Seine from from The Orsay Museum. Cross the river on the Pont Alexander and turn left. Walk a ways until you come to a beige stone building and the front is on the east side. The Monet water lily paintings are sublime and there is another museum downstairs with a wonderful selection of impressionist and cubist art. No photos allowed inside but still a wonderful experience.
Amazing Museum. This museum is great because it is small and can be managed in a half day. The paintings are beautifully displayed.

A Must See. The Orangerie houses Monet's later works - large panels that can be viewed in an intimate setting with a 360 degree view. It is not crowded during the week and these works are a marvel - a link between impressionism and abstraction - amazing composition and color with no apparent light source.

A must before going to Givernay. This museum is the permanent home to Claude Monet's very large water lily murals known as the Nympheas. They are in two large oval rooms on the main floor. The water lilies were painted in different times of day and various times of the year to provide a unique perspective. Seeing this exhibit really added to our enjoyment of seeing them at Givernay. This smaller museum also displays the works of other impressionists in the lower level. but for me, Monet's murals were the highlight.

Monet's water lilies are perfectly displayed. Beautiful little gem of a museum just on the edge of the Tuileries gardens. Lovely museum with the whole upper part dedicated to Monet's water lilies. These are massive canvases that are properly displayed in large oblong rooms. There are benches in there and you can happily sit and contemplate Monet's garden for as long as you want. Downstairs is a remarkable collection of impressionist works (especially Renoir!), and there's space for special exhibitions as well. A favorite in Paris

Monet lover's paradise. 2 rooms full of Monet's water lilies. You can sit for hours and imagine yourself in his garden as morning turns to dusk. So many other great impressionists paintings of one collector. If you love the impressionists and you don't have much time this is the place for you.
A must... Magnificent!. What a treat for the spirit and soul! Wonderful to sit and soak in the beauty in both rooms. Truly calming in the middle of Paris's hustle and bustle.

Great little collection. I love small collection that can be enjoyed completely in 2-3 hours (Frick in NY, Phillips in DC, Barnes in Philly, Thyssen-Bornemisza in Madrid.) This is a small collection of high quality pieces. Do what Monet recommended and take a respite from the city in this jewel of a collection.
A beautiful place to visit. Not a large museum, but lovely to spend some time.Walking into the main gallery it seems peaceful, and the water lillies are beautiful

Monet Monet Monet Monet... Monet. To truly appreciate my title, you have to sing it to the tune of the O'Jays "Money money money money... money." Now that we've got that settled, this museum is all about Monet. He painted his last and I think largest, water lilies paintings specifically for this exhibit. It's pretty impressive to see two whole rooms filled entirely with giant Water Lilies by Monet. I think Monet painted like 150 water lilies paintings in his lifetime, but if something's working for you, I say go with it. These are huge and impressive, but they aren't his best water lilies paintings, in my humble opinion. But definitely something you need to see. While the Monets are definitely the main attraction, there is also a nice museum of works by other impressionists downstairs. If this were anywhere besides Paris, this would get five stars easily. Okay, right after I wrote that, I decided that I'd upgrade it to five. So even in Paris it gets five stars. But I had to think about it first.

4-5 stars for Monet lovers....otherwise just lots of paint. The water lilies are ok. It was kind of disappointing. I like his bridge scenes, but none were present. Best part of museum is exhibits in the basement with some Renoir's, Picassos, and Cezanne. Short stop as you walk down Champs-Ellysse, so would still stop just to say you saw it.

Serenaded by waterlillies. This is a gem. I visited it one cloudy, cold morning in November the day after Musee D' Orsay and it was everything the guide said it would be.Easy to reach. The museum is located within the Tuileries Gardens which are really central and can be reached by Metro.Upstairs are masters from late 19 th and early 20 th centuries, Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse, But the piece de resistance are the circular downstairs galleries where Monet has painted waterlillies at different times of day along curved walls. The effect is breathtaking, you are transported to lake Giverny where the artist painted his masterpieces. The guide told us that he painted more than 200 versions of the waterlillies.The museum shop sells posters of quite a few of the murals.Just outside are the food stalls selling hot crepes and waffles. Welcome on a cold day.
A Monet must-see!. Lovely collection, nothing to dislike. Would have liked to have found an English version of the l'Orangerie collection in the book store. If there was one, couldn't find it!
Wow. What a beautiful small museum and what a wonderful collection. The Monet waterlilies were larger than I expected and in a space which did them justice..

Need a fairly quick and hassle-free art museum visit?. This is it. The first time I went years ago, it was to see Monet's Water Lillies. I was totally unaware of the many masterpieces just downstairs. Second time around, we toured the gallery downstairs and loved it. It's small relative to the Orsay, and minuscule compared to the Lovre, but still has enough delightful art on display to make you feel like you've gotten at least some of your requisite culture when in the City Of Light.

Oasis Museum. Such a beautiful museum that allows you to be overcome with the magnificient water lilies by Monet that surround you in two rooms. It is very calming to slowly walk by and examine the paintings and then to sit and absorb an entire section. After that, it also has incredible painting on another level by a strong representation of artists.Truly an oasis for the soul.

Lilies. Money's water lilies are worth the entrance alone but add in the rest of the permanent collection and the temporary Emile Bernard exhibition and it's superb value for anyone who appreciates the art of the period.

Small Gem. Musee de l'Orangerie is a small gem. If you have limited time in Paris, and can only visit one museum, this is the one. Upstairs are Monet's water lilies. Downstairs is a superb collection of French painting of the late 19th and early 20th centuries from Renoir to Picasso. The audio guide is excellent. Almost all the paintings have commentary.

Entranced and Bewitched. Breathtaking. I never hesitate bringing friends here, just seeing that they are as moved by these eight immense paintings of Monet's waterlily filled and willow fringed Giverny lake as I am is wonderful. When you get up close and look at the broad brush strokes you wonder how he could see the wider perspective of his creation. Sitting in front of each one and absorbing it, feels like being absorbed by the lake itself. I could sit and gaze for hours. The gallery of impressionist paintings on the floor below is also worth seeing, with Picasso, Renoir, Cezanne - to name but a few- it is a perfect introduction to the style, just enough and not many. There can be long queues to get in so it pays to buy tickets in advance - but you can be just lucky and stroll right in - we did on our second attempt. Metro Concorde.
Beautiful settings. Not a big gallery, but the quality is excellent: Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse, and especially the Monet murals.

breathtaking. As a hard-core Monet's fan.. this was a must in my list in Paris!! I thought it contained more of Monets paintings.. but i guess the wall-to-wall waterlillies filling huge rooms are worth the visit!! I wished people didn't make such a fuss about taking pictures, since i would have LOVED to have a picture of me with these masterpieces as a background! ;)
Beautiful small Museum. Beautiful small museum with great spaces for sitting and viewing paintings . In the west corner of the Tuilleries difficult to find but well worth the visit

Cosy impressionism vault. Museum created to contain Monet's Water lilies series in a wonderful oval room. Also has a nice collection of impressionists paintings. Possible to buy combined tickets with Musée d'Orsay.

Enjoyed the Emile Bernard exhibition. L'Orangerie is a smaller, contained museum that generally shows one subject in detail. We didn't know much about Emile Bernard, a lesser known impressionist, friend of Van Gogh and Gauguin, and enjoyed being introduced to his works.

A stunning collection. A beautiful collection of art - we went to see the waterlilies but also really enjoyed the collections of Renoir, Picasso and others that I can't now remember! There is an audio visual room where you can watch a documentary (French, English subtitles) on Monet & his works - worth a watch. There is a museum shop, no cafe so really just a nice place for a short visit (plus it's en route to the Louvre and alongside the Tulieries!). There is a bag check and cloakroom at the entrance. We spent about an hour there...

If you have some spare time. This small museum wuold be put on my "if you have a spare hour" list. They have moving exhibits, which may or may not be good, and the art modern collection of Paul Guillaume. I am not a fan of modern art so keep that in mind as you read this. The big claim to fame is the 2 oval rooms that house Monet's Water Lilies. These are 8 panels that form large wall murals, The space was specifically designed for the murals, including input from Monet himself and they are displayed to their absolute best, If you are in the area and have a about an hour to kill it is worth a quick run through with most of your time spent int he 2 oval rooms!

Special. A rare experience, sitting quietly, without the shifting throngs one expects in Parisian museums, contemplating Monet's Water Lilies, hung in the circular gallery he was involved in designing, in the places he chose. Very special.

Wonderful Monet paintings. It is always a joy to visit the Nympheas, the enormous Monet water lily paintings (8 of them filling the walls of two rooms). If you are lucky you will also find an interesting special exhibition in addition to the permanent collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillame. Beware, there is no cafe here so have a drink before you arrive!
Must see. Monet´s Water lilies? They´re all there! In three rooms! It´ s a must see. Located at Jardin de Tuileries.

Enjoyed Monet on level 1. As Monet intended the pieces that are on his level gives everybody the ability to visit and get away from the chaotic Parisian life or touristic frenzy. Comfortable surroundings but heavily busy when I visited. I went there as an alternative to the huge Louvre that I thought I would not be able even have a small snap shot of their collection. Here you are able to just take in 8 pieces of art at a slower pace, indulge yourself in what his intentions were and discover more on your perception of tranquility. I recommend it just as an alternative to some of the larger galleries in the city.

BEAUTIFUL. Oh my word, this was the best little museum. I saw some reviews that said they had to wait in line, we walked right in. We were able to just sit in the room and admire the water lilies. This was one of the most beautiful and calming experience I had in Paris. Me and my son were able to take our time and admire Monet's beautiful painting. We even had one of the security people give us some inside information on the building and Monet. I would go here again before I would spend my money on the Louvre. This was a dream come true for me to sit and look at Monet's artwork. It was amazing how he designed this building to house his painting.

Monet plus others. I usually go to France every year, but not always Paris. However when I am in Paris, I go to the L'Orangerie to sit among Monet's ethereal water lilies. There are two other collectors' paintings there as well. This fall there was an extensive exhibit of Emile Bernard a less known artist.

Small museum with quality art work. We went their in the morning and had absolutely no waiting in line time. I like this museum because it's small and therefore does not overwhelm. I really enjoyed Monet's artwork and recommend finding a suitable time when the upstair rooms are not too full. (Maybe go downstairs first and then go upstairs to see Monet's water lilies.)Just sitting there and let Monet's water lilies sink in was like an art meditation. Definitely worth a visit.

Favorite place to wander. I love this museum because it's small and serene and perfectly located on the grounds of a beautiful garden. It's also a short walk from the Louvre. The oval rooms are calming but I also enjoy the lower level which feature different artists. It's not too crowded which is a huge plus for a city like Paris.

Monet and more. We were in Paris for 24 hours and decided to visit Musee de l'Orangerie and D'Orsay.Musee de l"Orangerie is a very doable museum and far less overwhelming when compared to the Louvre. On the day we visited it wasn't overcrowded and the only groups were university students. The Monet panels are stunning and a visual treat. We then discovered the other exhibits which we thoroughly enjoyed. You can easily enjoy this museum in 1-2 hours.Following Musee de l'Orangerie we enjoyed a nice stroll to the D'Orsay as we had purchased a pass for both museums.

Not the best museum in Paris. We used our Paris Museum Pass to skip the line, but still ended up waiting a while. The Water Lilies were underwhelming for us, perhaps our tastes are changing. We far preferred the Louvre and D'Orsay.

Monet's Water Lilies. Starring at Monet's water lilies took away all my troubles. I arrived at the museum thinking I lived in a depressing world and was truly uplifted after minutes of Monet's Nymph's. There is some good in the world and Monet painted it for all the world to see. Very inspirational. One of my favorite museums in Paris. After the Orangerie visit Giverny and see Monet's water lilies.

Dissapointed. I have been her loads of times, however it's got very expensive E9 then if u go to Musse d'Orsay u can buy a joint ticket for E16 saving E4 but no one at orangerie told us. Again no discretionary, which there definitely were befor, again another book required, disabled access like most of the attractions limited and annoying

Small gallery worth going. This is definitely worth a visit if you are interesting in the Impressionist period. There are many great paintings and a broad representations of the artists in that period. The Gallery is not big and there are not too many people. It is a good way to spend the morning.

One of my favorite places in Paris. I'm a big fan of Claude Monet. From his water lilies to poplars, I can't get enough of his paintings. I first heard of this museum from a Rick Steves video. It was instantly on my list of places to go when I visited Paris. It was hard to find but when I did, I returned three times because I enjoyed it so much. I was with my boyfriend, now husband, and he enjoyed it as much as I did.The large panels of water lilies and the way that it was displayed was just so calming to me. I walked around the rest of the museum but the water lilies are the main attraction. The room can be packed but it doesn't take away the beauty of the art. You can't take pictures and there are people in there to prevent you from doing it. I highly recommend the Paris museum pass. You skip the long lines and get unlimited access to most of the museums in Paris. There are two lines to enter, if you have the pass, you're in the short line and get in in no time at all.

Monet's Nymph's. Easy to go there..just at Tuilerie's corner. Have the amazing works from Monet. Also have many nice works from Impressionist and post-impressionist period such as Renoir, Matisse, Gauguin, Cezanne, Rousseau and Picasso

Enchanting Afternoon with Monet. Be prepared for a wait to get inside, but it's worth it! The Monet paintings are spectacular and beautifully presented in each room. The atmosphere, assuming too many people aren't in the room, is tranquil and soothing. Hang out in the room and see how the light outside changes the way the paintings look. great afternoon after a stroll in the park.

Claude Monet's Water Lilies.... They are what you come here for, especially if you do not plan to visit Giverny (which require a day trip from Paris), where the lily pond still exists in Monet's gardens... The visit to Orangerie is pairing well with visits to many other places: Museum d'Orsay, Jardin des Tuileries, Place de la Concorde, and even with a Avenue des Champs-Elysees stroll all the way up to Arc de Triomphe.

Monet's Water Lilies. The Musée de l'Orangerie is an art gallery of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings located in the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde in Paris.Consist in two gigant ovals with majestic masterpieces done by Claude Monet.A quiet and pretty site, that invites to reflection and admiration!

a lovely gallery. ancient architechture from outside and inside modern architechture make the place surprising and welcomimg. placed on the central Place de la Concorde and next to the Tuileris gardens, you don't have to plan ahead the visit, but spontaneously visit there while enjoying the city. but check the opening hours because there are certain days (Mondays or Tuesdays) that almost all Paris gallaries are closed.

An absolute favorite. If you are in Paris on the first Sunday which is free, go here first. Walk right in and there are few people. they usually have another exhibition going on also. The theater has great cinema about Monet, rebuilding the museum (my favorite) and other topics. Thirty minutes well spent and easy to rest your feet during the visit.

L'Orangerie. The Orangerie has been for donkey's years the home of impressionist artists. Located amidst the Tuileries Gardens, anyone who enjoys paintings by the greatest artist of those times MUST visit...
Great Colllection. Really enjoyed the Monet and Renoir's. Lots of other great artists also. Definitely worth visiting as the collection is really great.

An hours visit...tops.. nip in here if you have just came from Musee D'orsay, you can use the same ticket, and its accross the road in the Tuilries gardens.The staff are strict about not taking photos and will stalk you if they think you are trying too, the layout and artwork is beautiful. but really only for Monet fans (which i am)

Disappointing. My friend and I are art lovers and we felt that the paintings were rather second rate. We couldn't find one which we would have liked to take home. The space and lighting are great so a great pity about the pictures.

See after the D'Orsay to continue your impressionist experience!. Visited 5 years ago, still amazing. Not only the Monet pieces, cannot believe the man could not see well as these are so beautiful. Also the art collection in the lower portion of the building is not to be missed.

Frida & Diego. We actually went in October of 2013 during the Frida Kahlo & Diego Rivera exhibit. The museum is not too large but the line was incredibly long. Not sure if that was because of the exhibit or if that is normal.

Wonderful Museum. Wonderful museum, short lines and well run. The viewing rooms for the water lily painting are very nice with adequate seating. Be sure to spend enough time in each room to see the effects the changing cloud cover has on the paintings. Must check bags and no photos allowed. Clean restrooms.

Monet and friends. The waterlillies are fascinating and beautiful. The exhibits downstairs are really nice because you have 20 to 30 paintings of several well-known artists like Renoir, Monet. etc. and can view them slowly and up close. You have the art of the Lourve without the crowds. Take time to see this!
For Monet fans. We found this by chance and were very impressed. Worth visiting just to see Monet's 8 paintings of water lilies which were done specifically to be shown in this building.

Outstanding Museum. The Orangerie was everything we had expected and more. The Monet Giverny panels of Water Lillies were extremely impressive. The collection of Renoir, Mattisse, Picasso, et al was well presented and manageable.

For painters & art lovers only. This is a smaller museum of paintings featuring Monet and other impressionist artists. I liked the Monet's better at d'Orsay than the wall-sized pieces here. We were in a bit of a rush, but I just didn't feel the same magic, and perhaps it's because I didn't get an audio tour.

Monet's famous Water Lilies. If you want to see something special without spending an entire day finding your way around the Louvre, this is the place. Monet's Water Lilies are wonderful and certainly different.
It's a small museum and very reasonably priced.
You'll learn the stories of several of France best artists. Enjoy

Wow. Monet's Waterlillies are just mind-blowing. They are enormous, they are fantastic. I could all day and stare at their magnificence. If you are and Impressionist fan then this is the place for you.

A treasure chest paintings !!. Sitting nestled in a peaceful corner of Jardin Tuileries Musee de l'Orangerie is a must see Musuem while in Paris ! The 8 panels of Monet's Water Lilies that fills two rooms takes your breath away ! Walk slow... Sit down and savor this stunning masterpiece ! The museum is filled with the works of Renoir , Matisse , Picasso , Utrillo ... To just name a few !

The place to admire Impressionist's works. We had the chance to visit this museum for the first time after numerous visits in Paris, since we found no ques. The dominant part of the museum, situated in the Tuilleries, the gardens of Louvre, is dexucated to Monet's work, the water lillies. 8 huge works inspired by his garden provoke to the admirer a serene feeking while they surround him as they are placed in all the 4 directions of two oval rooms. We have seen these paintings in photos however the originals are breathtaking. Moreover there is a big collection of imoressionists works very well organized and presented.
Monet Waterlillies. The title says it all............. I have always loved the waterlillies and have viewed those at other galleries. The sheer scale of them at the Orangerie is stunning

Smaller than I thought. Good place to visit impressionists, and will not be disappointed. It's just small that I took 1 hour can finish. May arrange between visits to Louvre or d'Orsay since they're all near.
Excellent collection of art. Enjoyed this display. We went to see the water garden paintings, but the other art was terrific. A good place to buy joint tickets for the Musee D'Orsay

Beautiful intimate museum, must see for impressionist lovers. Monet's Waterlilies alone are a mind blow, just exquisite! Plenty more to see there as well, nice collection of Renior's and other Monets as well. It's very uncrowded and so you can really enjoy it. It's walking distance from the De Orsay so you can combine the two for a lovely day!Also both are included on the museum pass which is a really glad deal actually

Nice place. If you like museums you certainly would like this place. Even though its not that big as compared to other museums in paris but its worth watching. So if you have time you should visit it else you can skip.

Quite pricey for its size.. Some beautiful pieces in here, notably the Monet Exhibts which dominates the uppper floor however it is surprisingly small and for its price only really good value if you are a fan of the art held there. Pretty building though.

awe-inspiring. My trips here leave me mystified by its beauty. This intimate museum tucked between Tuileries Gardens and the Place de la Concorde offers a divine collection of impressionists. Here claude Monet's Les Nymphéas (Water Lilies) simply stuned me as my eyes rolled around from color to color. It's my favorite museum in the world.
Awesome. A must see for any visit to Paris, Monet's genius on display. Only dislike were the staff at the entrance who were not helpful or welcoming.

Special exhibit = very long line. We had the Museum Pass which supposedly allows you to skip the queue. However, since there was a special exhibit going on, in which we had no interest in seeing, we had to wait more than a half hour to enter. However, those without the Museum Pass or reservations, had to wait hours. This museum has Monet's water lilies series of paintings. The rooms were designed specifically to accommodate these beautiful paintings. Definitely worth a visit.

Visit in November. The queu on a Tuesday in November was very long and very slow. This was largely because the security arrangements were very slow and the gallery has only two ticket desks, one of which was closed. Leaflets in English for the exhibitions were not available as staff explained that these were 'finished'. Only Japanese was availed in addition to to French. The Monet works are stunning so it is a shame that the organisation of the gallery is poor.
For impresionist lovers. If you love the work of Monet, you should visit this museum in order to see the giant painting he made for this museum specially.

Wonderfully Monet. A smaller museum, the biggest drawcard of Musee de l'Orangerie are Monet's Waterlily panels. And my goodness, they are impressive. Covering the walls of two large, oval rooms, you are surrounded by a master's work. I recommend you not only sit on the provided couches to admire from afar, but also step closer into the middle of an arch panel and 'immerse' yourself in the view. Not taking anything away from the amazing pieces in the galleries on the floor below, this is a museum that is wonderfully Monet.

Stunning. L'Orangerie is wonderful. Standing in the purpose designed rooms viewing Monet's Water lilies is quite moving. Definitely worth doing especially if you buy the combined pass with musee d'orsay (€16ish) which is fantastic value.

Small/Manageable/easy to Navigate. The water lillys are the main attraction here--and alone are worth the visit. A bit disappointed that they had "run out" of maps on our last visit which are very helpful in guiding you through the museum.
