To better understand what we were looking at we had to rent their headphones.
Worth the trip. This museum is a gem. The water lily room is not to be missed. This small, initimate museum that is within walking distance of other major attractions and can be done in an hour.

Try to visit early in the day. If you love Monet, Musee de l'Orangerie is a must. The Les Nympheas are beautiful and if you arrive early in the day you may be lucky enough to view them without hordes of tourists

I cried.... This is the museum that Monet designed himself to house his Waterlillies. There is something quite surreal about the stark whiteness of the rooms and the vibrance of the murals. There are usually no lines, and you can be in and out quickly. Absolutely loved it.

A gem of a museum not far from its more famous sibling, Le Louvre. The Monet-designed rooms showcasing his immense "Nympheas" (Nenuphars) murals are unforgettable, a true zen experience in the heart of Paris.
If you like modern art. Then you should definitely go here if you are in Paris. Not my favorite place, but worth seeing as it is a one of a kind.

Must see if you love Monet.. We had just been to Monet's Gardens at Giverny a few days before, so I was anxious to see the Water Lilies at the L'Orangerie. If you have limited time, it is worth going just to see these 8 magnificent murals. It is a small museum on the edge of Les Tuileries, which is a great spot for a lunch or a glass of wine or an espresso.

Don't forget to "Squeeze" in the Orangarie. Many quick itinerary's leave out the Orangarie, which I think is a mistake, chiefly because it can be appreciated fairly quickly. If you were on a speed date through Paris, you could run into the Orangarie, go straight to Claude Monet's Water Lily's, be blown away, maybe cry a little, and be out in 20 minutes. I realize that it seems like a waste of money to fork out $10 bucks to run in and look at 2 rooms for 20 minute, but to miss these sublime masterpieces would be tragic. If you have time to tack on another 20 minutes you can quickly get yourself through some of the rest of the Orangarie's collection which is really first rate!

monet !!!. Small but with a great collection of impressionist paintings. Dedicate an hour . The Monet paintings are outstanding!!No lines getting in. Near many of the other art museums plan a quick stop from one to the other.

In any other city this would be outstanding..... Musee de l'Orangerie gains from being distinct from both the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay (both closeby). The Monets are clearly the main event but the real interest and attractions are downstairs, with a fascinating collection of C.19th/20th paintings. Well worthwhile.

Beautiful nympheas. This is a MUST SEE. The building is one of two at the edge of the Tuileries gardens overlooking Place de la Concorde. In the basement of that building you will find the series of "Les Nympheas" by Monet painted for the spaces where the paintings are displayed. Go just after lunch, on a sunny day with some clouds, so that the light shimmers and the colors of the paintings dance.
Intimate Museum. Lovely collection housed in the Tuileries. And while many people focus on the two oval rooms of water lilies I was most impressed by their collection of Derains and Rousseaus.

No crowds and relaxed visit!. Visited Musee de l'Orangerie in September 2014 - although we had a 6 day Paris Museum Pass to skip the line, there were no lines and we walked straight in. The Water Lilies (Les Nymphéas) is on the first level- take a pamphlet at the entrance for more detailed information on these Monet's works. One floor down there are beautiful exhibitions that includes Modigliani, Maurice Utrillo, Renoir etc. The Emile Bernard exhibition was not open yet during our visit. One is permitted to take photos (without flash) that was great! Outside the museum there are chairs under the trees to relax and rest your tired feet! Loved the museum - no crowds and relaxed visit is an added bonus!

Go for the Monet Panels..... but if you have time try to visit the Musee Marmottan. L'Orangerie is not that crowded and is definitely a must see for art lovers (especially if your Paris stay is short). But, if you want a variety of Impressionistic art and have the time please visit the Marmottan. The Musee Marmottan has a huge private collection of 100+ masterpieces from Impressionists such as Cezanne, Monet, Sisley, Degas, Renoir, Pissaro and many others. L'Orangerie is on the Paris Museum Pass.

Disappointing after last time. We visited this museum several years ago and were thrilled with the two "infinity" rooms lined with the Monet lily pad paintings and the many Impressionist works in the downstairs gallery. Although the Monets are obviously still there and beautiful, most of the other Impressionist works are now over at the Musee d'Orsay or at the Musee Marmottan Monet. You can buy a joint ticket for the Orangerie and the Musee d'Orsay, which you'll need to do if you want to see the best collection of Impressionists.

Great museum for Monet lovers!. If you want to see the large Water Lilies paintings up close and in person, you MUST visit this museum while you're in Paris! The top floor has multiple rooms with the large paintings covering full walls, and the bottom floor has a gallery with other painters' works (including Picasso and Cezanne, among others).This is included in the Paris Museum Pass, so there's no reason not to stop in if you have it. Be sure to check the opening/closing times and days before planning youre visit. Arriving earlier in the day will help you avoid long lines and having to wait outside.I would definitely recommend this, especially to those who love Monet and the Impressionist Movement. (Add this to the Orsay and a day trip to Giverny for a fuller picture of Monet's artwork, life, and history.)

"Up close with Monet". Admittedly, I was not much of an at art enthusiast until i visited this Museum and seeing the Monet works in the arch room first hand. I was just soo captivated by the amazing colors, the size, the the movement, was just breathtaking. Also loved art works by Renoir, but for me Monet has made appreciate art so much more. Also worth noting is the venue is not so crowded as other exhibitions which allows viewers to truly appreciate the artists works. Highly recommend.
If only for Monet's Les Nympheas, so worth the visit!. Truthfully, Monet's Les Nympheas were my primary reason to visit this gem of a museum. Such a delight!

Wonderful. I thoroughly enjoyed this museum. I found it less crowded than the Louvre and the Musee Orsay. I could take my time with each painting without feeling the need to constantly move on due to imposing groups of people. Renoir, Monet and Picasso can be found here. Along side some other wonderful items the exhibition was truely mesmorising and thought provoking. Again if under 26 and an EU citizen bring your passport and it's free. It also has a cute little shop where you can buy prints and postcards and silk scarves in Monet's prints. We easily spent 2hrs here but could have spent a lot longer due to the relaxed atmosphere.

A must visit for Monet lovers.. If you love Monet, your first stop in Paris should be the top floor of l'orangerie. Followed by d'Orsay and his house in the outskirts of the city (closed during winter months).
AMAZING!!. Houses Monet's Waterlillies. Overwhelming!! Takes up 2 rooms. Sit on the provided benches of each view and take it in. Perfection!

Monets are the stars, but whole collection is very good.. Easy visit since not too large. Basically the two rooms of the Monet paintings of Giverny which essentially fill the walls, and the collection of Paul Guillaume. Really excellent but not overwhelming in size. Very easy stroll from here to the Jeu de Paume and the Louvre. Lovely place to sit outside under the trees and take a break and look at the Place de Concorde with the Tour Eiffel in the background.

A Must See for Impressionist Fans. It's hard to describe the feeling of being completely surrounded by a single Monet masterpiece, but that's the effect at this museum. This place was only opened in the last decade, so if you haven't been to Paris for a while, put this near the top of your places to go.

Greatest impressionist works in the world. Monet has captured light, movement and solitude in these masterpieces created especially for the rooms.the painting collections in the lower gallery were great also.

Miracle ... no queue!. What a surprise - the weekend before All Saint's day - 31st October many French pay their respects and visit the family cemetaries so Paris is very quiet. Noticeably shorter queues! Fabulous! Tranquil setting to view and enjoy magnificent Water Lillies

Stunning display of Monet's water lillies. When I first entered one of the two oval galleries housing Monet's Nympheaus the scale and classic beauty of the room took my breathe away. Both these galleries are bathed in natural light that enters the rooms from the ceiling and brings these symphonies of colour to life.I was really disappointed that no photographs are allowed in these rooms, and also they had run out of english guides when we visited.The gallery on the lower floor contains exhibits from Renoir, Cezanne, Utrillo, Matisse and others that is well worth a visit. This is a lovely size gallery, enough of interest to be worth a visit but not overwhelming.
Manageable Museum. Loved this place, amazing Monet panels, just enough art to swallow at one time. Also, the line went quickly, unlike the Louvre and Sainte Chapelle!

Monet's Waterlilys Worth It. Two large elliptical rooms to view the almost panoramic pastel waterlily panels of Monet from his garden at Giverny. Additional significant Impressionist painting collections on a different floor. If you like Imprssionists, couple it with the larger collection at Musee D'Orsay for sure. Get a Museum Pass for two or four days to visit multiple museums without ticket lines (on-line in advance or from your concierge)

Monet Waterlilies alone worth the visit. This is a great museum with a permanent collection, smaller than the Orsay, special exhibitions and the star attraction, the two oval rooms containing the the huge, beautiful Monet Waterlily works. Monet created these eight paintings specifically for these rooms and the effect is wonderful. They fill the walls of the rooms and as you stand in the middle of either, slowly turning 360 degrees to view all the paintings, you feel almost as if you are in his gardens seeing the ponds and beautiful colors in life. It amazed me how these impressionists works convey that feeling. The museum is well worth the admission price and your ticket can be purchased in combination with one for Musee d'Orsay saving a second wait in line (though the line was not long the morning we visited.) This museum is just across the Seine from the Orsay, an easy walk across the bridge, and just a stroll through the Jardin de les Tuileries from the Louvre.
Monet at his finest. Not only great Monet paintings but great art of his contemporaries too .A lovely place ,without huge crowds .
In the presence of genius and beauty. If you only had time to visit one museum in Paris,choose this one.The waterlillies by Monet are actually breathtaking.As are the other beautiful works.

Fine if you like this form of art. This small museum is pleasant but I personally prefer Renaissance Art and art that looks realistic 'versus modern or impressionist. There were things in there I wouldn't hang in my barn but I was a science major not fine(?) arts. Some of the Renoirs were beautiful. The take home is - know your taste and interest before you spend valuable time and euros entering every museum and that leaves more time for your favorites..
Monet Waterlillies not that exciting.. I was disappointed in Monet's Waterlillies. I've seen other paintings of his waterlillies and they are fabulous. These were dull.
Do visit - exceptionally large paintings by Monet. Could not believe how large the paintings by Monet of the Water lilies were. So impressive and well worth a visit.

Great gallery - not too big, not too small!. If you want to see the large Monet waterlilly paintings and also see a great private collection of impressionist and modern art, yet don't have time to spend in one of the larger Parisian galleries/museums, this is the place to go. The rooms holding the large waterlilly canvases are of course superb, but the bonus is the collection downstairs - the Walter-Guillaume collection which ranges from Renoir to Picasso, plus there is often another temporary changing exhibition as well. You can also buy a combined Musee de l'Orangerie and Musee d'Orsay ticket if you wish - the d'Orsay being just over the river from the l'Orangerie.

Worth a visit. The monets take your breath awayThat's all we went for and found downstairs an excellent array of different artists Renoir, Picasso , the list goes on , hugely enjoyable You feel very privileged just to be there

Fabulous Monet Water Lilies and Other Impressionist Art. The Musée de l'Orangerie is an art gallery of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings by Claude Monet, Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo. It is located in the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde in Paris. The Metro stop closest to this museum is Concorde. It is covered by the Paris Museum Pass. The museum is most famous as the permanent home for eight Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet that are housed on the first floor in two oval rooms. These paintings were painted by Monet late in his life and are amazing. Do take the time to sit down on the benches provided and enjoy them. The other paintings are housed downstairs below the Monet paintings, and are definitely worth the visit.

Small but nice museum. Stopped here while walking to the concorde and Arc de Triumph. The museum is a nice collection of 19th century art, including the famous water lillies by Monet. Worth a short stop if you're in the area, but I wouldn't make a special trip unless your an art person.

Monet's waterlillies and more. You should definitely buy the Paris Museum Pass because you can easily go in an out of about 15 museums without waiting on the long lines to buy tickets. This is a delightful place. Emile Bernard's paintings are marvelous.
You will not believe it until you see it. entire walls of Monet water lilies. you are overwhelmed with it surrounding you everywhere. i love this one second only to musee d'orsay.
Jewel. While I enjoyed the Bernard show currently on view, nothing compares to the L'Orangerie permanent collection of Impressionist paintings.

More than just Monet. If the obvious reason to visit here is to view the magnificent Water Lilies, beautifully restored in their original location, there's more to this not-so-little museum. Downstairs there is a fantastic collection of impressionist art, including Renoir, Picasso, Derain, Sisley, Cézanne, Gaugin... who were all represented by the same dealer (Paul Guillaume) whose collection this represents. Unfortunately there are often long queues to get in, especially during school holidays - but visit on a normal weekday and you get the museum to yourself. Free on first Sunday of the month - which may mean a longer queue, but it moves much more quickly.

Disorganized the day we visited. There were no English maps and no French, just Japanese, and so did not discover until leaving that we missed an entire room of Lily pond paintings. Loved the Emile Bernard show on lower level.

Loved the Monet rooms. As a fan of Monet's Water Lilies, I really enjoyed this small museum. It's different in that you just sit and take in three huge panels of his work in two separate rooms. People are encouraged to be quiet and still, and it's actually a very moving experience. This coming from a person who appreciates good art, but doesn't really like to go to museums for hours. I liked how manageable this one is... esp with the Museum Pass, it's a no brainer! :)

The best art museum for me. After fighting crowds at the Louvre the day before, I found this museum totally delightful. There was so much wonderful art to see and the queue to get in was less than 30 minutes and it is small enough to see everything in a few hours without getting exhausted from dealing with crowds. It has a nice little shop too and the location is beautiful near Concorde and the Tuilerie gardens. My favorite touristy thing by far!

Perfect Setting For Monet's Water Lilies. While not as popular as the other art museums in Paris, l’Orangerie offers Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces with less crowds.Two oval rooms wonderfully display the highlight of the gallery, Claude Monet's Les Nymphéas (Water Lilies). Each room holds four curved canvases, encircling you in Monet's gardens at Giverny. If you can view the works without large crowds, these rooms offer a lovely place to sit, rest and contemplate the beauty around you.While Monet is the headliner, other artists grab your attention in the lower level gallery. Works from Alfred Sisley, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Paul Cézanne, Pablo Picasso, Amedeo Modigliani, Henri Matisse, Maurice Utrillo and André Derain add to the impressiveness of the museum. All of these works once belonged to Paul Guillaume, a Parisian art dealer and friend of many of the Impressionists. Thankfully, the collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume is accessible to the public in this intimate setting.Conveniently located in the Tuileries Garden (beside the Louvre), l’Orangerie originally housed orange trees for King Louis XIV. The structure has been modified many times, with the most recent renovation completed in 2006. The added skylights filter natural light onto Monet’s Water Lilies, emphasizing the beauty of light Monet sought to capture in his works.Photography is not permitted in Les Nymphéas, but is allowed in the other galleries.Admission is included in the Paris Museum Pass, or can be purchased individually for 9 Euro. Note that there are two lines outside the building, one for general admission and the second for Pass holders. The Paris Museum Pass will allow you to bypass the ticket line, but not the line to enter.Musée de l’Orangerie is closed on Tuesdays, and is crowded on Mondays since the Musée d’Orsay is closed.
Monet appreciation. This is a small museum which makes it a great choice - you can walk through it and enjoy all the Monet masterpieces.

Worth a visit. My knowledge of L'orangerie was that it housed Monet's 'Water Lilies' murals, and it does. However it's so much more.On the ground level there are two circular rooms, each with 4 of the murals. These are beautiful. There are no windows into this room so you are totally surrounded by the murals and the atmosphere is very serene. There is seating in the middle of the rooms where you can spend time soaking up the paintings.There is also a basement area to the museum with other impressionist artists. When we visited there was an exhibition of Emile Bernard paintings.L'Orangerie is a little gem of a gallery. Well worth a visit!
Small Colleciton. The collection was small, the people not very friendly and there was no cafe or water fountain which would have been welcome after a long walk along Jardin des Tuileries.

My favorite. The collection and the presentation here are wonderful. Somewhat less crowded than the Louvre or the Orsay. You actually get to view the art here! Get the Paris Museum Pass. It will cut through the lines.

Emotional!. I am not generally into art however visiting the L'Orangerie and seeing the Water Lillies by Monet has to be one of the highlights of my year. The building is very peaceful and calm and is the perfect environment to view these pieces of art. Entrance fee a bargain. I would recommend this for anyone visiting Paris and enjoyed this much more than the Louvre which was also very good.

Monet waterlilies. Great place if you love Monet paintings as much as I do.No big lines like the other museums in Paris. In my opinion is a must-see!And it doesn't take too long to visit the entire place.
Special. Worth the entrance just for the two Monet rooms alone. Went on a Saturday morning so not too crowded.

A small but great museum. The museum is located on the western corner of the Tuileries garden, next to the Place de la Concorde. It is a small museum that is often skipped by the tourists. A series of Claude Monet's water-lily paintings, donated by the artist himself, known as the Les Nymphéas, is on display on the ground floor of the Museum. The eight paintings are exhibited along the walls of two rooms. No photos are allowed in these rooms. The downstairs gallery displays the works of the great artists like Picasso, Renoir, Matisse amongst others. There is a book shop in the museum.
For Monet Lovers et al. Brilliant. A feast for lovers of Monet's Waterlilies. Also the downstairs galleries are wonderful and very easy to negotiate.

Monet Rules Two Rooms. This is a wonderful museum with great exhibitions. The two Monet rooms are beautiful and well lit. This was one of my favorite museums in Paris. You can visit it in a couple of hours and it won't wear you out as much as many of the other museums in town. Very conveniently located, and just out front is an area that provides nice views of many iconic buildings/sites, so we stopped and had our sandwich and snacks we had packed for lunch that day.

Monte fans - don't miss!. While I found the employee service level rather disappointing, the Monet exhibits make up for it. The scope of the exhibits is quite broad and there is something for everyone, but the Monet rooms are not-to-miss!!

Just Fabulous. This was my second visit and I wish I had had more time to spend studying the Monet Lilies. You cannot believe how beautiful the paintings are and how large they are. The museum is modern and functional and had an exhibition on as well as its own collection. This is a hidden treasure though becoming better known. The opening hours are very good and it pays to get there early as there are no queues. Being open on Sunday is a real bonus.

A lovely small museum. This museum is known mainly for Monet’s “Les Nymphéas”, and it is true that the two oval rooms are quite impressive with the sheer size of these 8 water lily murals. The Monet paintings are straight ahead when you walk in, conveniently close to the entry so this could be a time saver if you are in a hurry. I don’t know how so many people have take photos of these Monet paintings based on the previous TripAdvisor reviews. They were just sneaky and/or lucky, because there is a sign saying no photos are allowed and the museum staff was definitely watching during my visit. It is interesting to admire these lovely paintings from afar and then upon closer inspection look at the seemingly mishmash of colors and brush strokes. If you are particularly a Monet lover, then don’t miss the small but wonderful Musée Marmottan Monet in the 16th arrondissement of Paris.You can take photos elsewhere in the museum except at the temporary exhibits and also of the glass ceiling entry area which is interesting architecturally but I was told to stop taking photos in the entry because the architect doesn’t like it?! L’Orangerie was originally built in 1852 but was closed from 1999 – 2006 for renovations. There are many other paintings by great artists such as Picasso, Renoir, Matisse, Soutine, etc. worth admiring in this human-sized museum. These other paintings and temporary exhibits are all downstairs. I saw the Emile Bernard (1868–1941) exhibit, which is running through 5 January and it was very interesting.Of course this museum doesn’t replace going to the Musée D’Orsay, but it is a nice little museum if you have already done the big one, love Impressionist and post Impressionist art and are looking for something else to do. It is conveniently located in the Jardin des Tuileries near the entry next to Place de la Concorde.I went at 11h00 on Saturday, 1 November (French Toussaint holiday) and walked right in, no lines. I think this place gets busy during high tourist season and since it is fairly small they make people line up outside and then only let in so many as others exit. They have a very small bookshop onsite. Depending on your interest and if you use an audio guide, plan to spend 1-2 hours here. Be sur to check out the Rodin sculptures in front of and on the side of L’Orangerie.
Small but Lovely. Walked along after the Louvre through the beautiful gardens to a small but lovely museum. Well worth a visit to experience The Water Lilies oddly peaceful.
Must See. Nice size museum; very enjoyable place; small crowds. Water lilies alone are worth the trip but lots also to see.

Oh those water lily paintings!. The enormous water lily paintings that take up entire walls painted by Claude Monet at the height of his powers in a special studio in Giverny are spectacular. This is enough reason alone to visit the L'Orangerie, but don't miss the excellent collection of paintings by other artists contemporary to Monet that are housed downstairs. This museum was shut for renovations for a number of years and only reopened to the public about six years ago.
Not Impressed. We were expecting more when visiting this museum. My wife loves impressionist paintings and we only spent about 30 minutes here.

A treasure you will delight in forever.... One of the little delights of Paris that is most often overlooked is the Musee de l'Orangerie in the Tuileries Gardens, which offers two of the most prestigious art collections you will ever see.The first is Monet's Water Lilies. Called monumental and intimate at the same time, Water Lilies are the masterpiece of Claude Monet, who diligently worked to explore all the variations of light in his garden at Giverny, not far from Paris and a glorious place to visit in good weather. His paintings are on display in two elliptical rooms, which encourage you to "gaze in endless contemplation". The second group of gems can be found in The Walter-Guillaume Collection; a project of Paris art dealer Paul Guillaume and his wife in the early 20th century. A unique collection illustrating the creative work of early 20th century artists, like Picasso, Soutine, Derain and Marie Laurencin, who Guillaume often supported financially and through shows of their art, as well as two of their predecessors, Renoir and Cézanne. The entire collection was given to the French State in 1960. Some gift! Don't miss it...
such a treat. another small museum but packed with some amazing pieces, especially the two rooms that house Monet's Water Lily masterpieces. Not to be missed!

You have to see Monet.. Here is where you enter a room and suddenly you are surrounded by Monet's gardens. My husband gasped. Further, there will also be a special exhibit and you can see what if you are interested. It's a smaller, less crowded, lovely place.

not open on Tuesdays. This place is i'm sure just insanely beautiful and unique.. but it is closed on Tuesdays. We didn't know that. So here's for everyone else that doesn't know that Tuesday is museum closed day in Paris.
Worth the visit.. I liked being able to sit and move from room to room to look at the work of Claude Monet. The is also another area that you can visit to view other paintings.
Another Wonderful Museum. The very best were the two rooms containing Monet's Water Lilly Murals. Then we went down to the lower level and were awed by the selection of their Impressionist paintings.

Second visit!. First visited three years ago and second time around, Monet's work still takes your breath away when you walk in the oval room even though we knew what to expect! Arrived at the museum at 9.05am with no queue and bought a passport ticket for l'Orangerie and Musee d'Orsay. The first half an hour was very quiet so perfect to sit and study the beauty of the water lillies. We also enjoyed the Emille Bernard temporary exhibition. Do not miss Musee de L'Orangerie.

Glorious museum. L'Orangerie is a fantastic museum built especially for Monet's "Waterlilies" which encompass the entire main floor. Lines can be long so it's best to go early. Easy to find at the end of the Tuileries..

A small gem. This delightful museum which houses mostly Impressionist works was recommended to us and was well worth the visit. It was not overrun with tourists as the larger museums are and we enjoyed a very pleasant time there. The panoramic Monets are unbelievable.

More than water lilies. Having visited Monet's Garden it gave me a greater appreciation of of the water lilies . There is some wonderful impressionist art on display so do allow time to see it.We were in Paris for 2 weeks so time was on our side. We went to the mussee one afternoon on a weekday and joined the non museum pass queue. After waiting almost an hour and only museum pass holders were going in we left. We came back later in the week before noon and walked straight in. Guess museum pass is the way to go but having been to Paris several times previously we were not visiting the major museums.

Monet and more. I visited this museum a day after touring Monet's home and gardens in Giverny. It was such a wonderful follow up to seeing where he lived and worked. My tour guide in Giverny had made the suggestion and I would like to pass this on. Seeing the large works of Monet are just incredible. It brought my interest in Monet to life. This is a smaller museum that is easy to fit in your day while touring Paris. Interesting building also, seeing how it is very modern inside, classic outside.

Wish we had more time. This was kind of a last minute decision to go on our last day so we had some museum fatigue already. Had lots of commentaries on the paintings. Nice that it is not too big so you can cover most of it.

Water lilies!. We had been here before, but decided to make this our last stop during our three nights in Paris. There is a bit of a queue to get in but once in, you can quickly move to see what you need to see, which in our case, was Monet's Water Lilies, large impressionist paintings that are magnificent both in scale and artistry.

Enjoyed 3-4 very nice hours. I enjoyed the Walter-Guillaume Collection very much. It is a medium-sized collection (around 5 rooms) with very nice paintings.After going over the collection twice, I joined the guided tour (around 30min in the water lilies and 45min in the collection) which was also very entertaining.The museum is located in the middle of Paris, walking distance to the Louvre, the Seine, Eiffel, and Shanzelize so it is easy to combine it with other attractions.
Not to miss. If you like Monet, it is a must. I wanted to stay there all day and look at those masterpieces. You feel like you are visiting his garden.
The most special one. Simple, very well organized, beautiful. Perfect. I will visit always I go to Paris. I loved to to see the Monet's Ninfeas!
Ah. Go, sit, and take it all in. The design provides the viewer with a sense of the full view of the works. Each room presents the works in a panoramic style.

enjoyable. The space of this museum if of an odd layout. Slightly difficult to maneuver when people with kids or wheelchairs are in the mix. This museum is a popular ducking area during foul weather so be warned.The collections were representative of the artists featured.

Among the best. The most missed museum among the top tier, this view of some of Monet 's most spectacular pieces is a must for Monet fans. Combine it with a trip to the Marmotten museum (and Giverny in season) and you don't ever need to step inside the Lourve.

Monet Magnificient. The Monet paintings are magnificient. Seating allows you to sit and absorb these masterpieces. I would recommend this Musee as a must visit whilst in Paris. It is just across the river from the Musee d'Orsay. You can purchase a combined ticket for both which is a lot cheaper.

OMG Monets Galore!. The most gorgeous water lilies on exhibit in a museum built to house them! Two oval rooms with four paintings each full of color and light. Just stunning. The rest of the museum is also full of interesting Impressionist and other 20th and late 19th century art.

fabulous gallery. Do not miss this gallery. The Monet exhibition is so beautiful, the way the walls envelop and caress these major works. I had been to Monets garden and to see the Waterlilly paintings was so special. A guide is a great tip here, they will educate you so that you can really see the depth and complexity of these works. The light in these rooms is muted and gentle. Apart from the Waterlilly exhibition these is also an excellent collection of other imoressionist works. This gallery is not as huge snd overwgelming as some of the oers in Psris, but it definitely should be on your "to do " list
Monet's Water Lilies. When you can spend time in an oval room surrounded by Monet's Water Lilies is there anything more beautiful?
Water lilies and more. Monet's water lilies are impressive, but the Orangerie has much more too. It is a good size for a museum so you can see it all without getting too tired.

Perfect afternoon!. We loved the Musee de l'Orangerie. We had the museum almost to ourselves as it was about an hour before closing. We saw Monet exhibit which was breathtaking. Another must while in Paris.

Waterlilies - WOW. If you appreciate Monet's Water Lilies, this is the place to go - 360 degree of beauty! Just breathtaking. Nice gallery downstairs as well, but Monet is the main reason to enjoy this museum.

Monet and More. The museum is famous for its main-floor display of the huge Monet paintings of water lilies each of which covers one of the two walls in two large rooms. But it has much more to offer. The lower level features paintings by Monet contemporaries from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including figures like Picasso and Modigliani. It also houses large temporary exhibitions. For the lovers of impressionist and early modern art, it is not to be missed.

A must see!. My boyfriend and I saw these Monet paintings in the film Midnight in Paris and he immediately said this was something he wanted to see on our trip. Neither of us are are enthusiasts by any means either. It was also included in the Paris Museum pass we purchased so it was a no brainer. It is stunning to be surrounded by these wall sized Monet paintings. There are places to sit in the middle to just admire them. This museum won't take you long at all but definitely worth a visit!
Peacefull. Loved this small museum. Wasnt crowded. Gift shop was great. The monet exhibit was great. Would visit again.

visit Giverny fist. This is a wonderful museum that contains some of Monet's last works of Water lilies. it meant so much more as we had already visited his home in Giverny- which has reproductions of these encircling his studio-now gift shop.

Breathtakingly beautiful water lilies!. We queued for a while to enter this museum. But the wait was really worthwhile once we entered the Monet room with the spectacular wall to wall painting of water lilies. It was so breathtakingly beautiful. Took our time to enjoy them.

Fabulous!. I knew this museum showed some Monet water lily panoramic paintings so had to check them out. Eight are displayed in two beautifully constructed oval shaped gallery rooms with diffused natural lighting and are extraordinary. You can walk right up to them to examine the brush strokes and technique of the artist. I also loved the special exhibition of Emile Bernard paintings on the bottom floor. An overlooked Impressionist artist finally getting his first solo exhibition in a major museum. And I loved seeing the permanent art collection, also on the bottom level. It is the personal art collection of an art collecting couple, he one of the greatest gallery dealers from the early part of the 20th century. 145 works I believe, many by artists that I really wasn't previously familiar with. And all beautifully displayed. We went to this museum one hour before it closed on a Saturday and waited only about 10 minutes to go through security. (We had a Museum Pass.). Of course, I would have liked more than one hour in this premier museum .
How can you miss Monet's Water Lilies?. Small but perfect. Some of the art is not so great, but historically important. You are really going for the two fabulous rooms of Monet's Water Lilies

Come early!. A must-see whilst in Paris for Monet's water lilies - but also a wealth of other art-work in the lower level. Come early to beat the crowds - we arrived almost as it opened and had a few minutes of peace to absorb the tranquil atmosphere before the coach party hordes descended!

Impressionist Heaven. We arrived early which was a good idea so as to avoid too many people viewing at once. This gave us really good viewing of the amazing Monet water lily paintings. They are huge and awe inspiring.What we did not count on was the collection on the lower floor of impressionist art work. Many examples of many artists' work over decades gave us a real insight to their individual styles, how they developed over the years and some similarities. The sheer volume of great works to look at a meter away from one made for a special experience.A must see for anyone with an interest in art.
Worth a trip with a museum pass. Monet's water lilies in their full glory, but not much else. Probably not worth a long line or a separate admission fees. But a great quick trip.

For Monet lovers. Beautiful museum and a must see for fans of Claude Monet. I hired a private guide for my visit, which was wonderful, but also a place where one can sit and mull over Monet's masterpieces. Go early to avoid lines, and get a Paris Museum Pass!

Beautiful display of Monet & others. This was great, even if just for the two rooms of waterlillies paintings. We went about 2:30pm on a Friday, and only waited about 10mins for a ticket. There were large queues when we left about 4:30.The two rooms of Monet's work is stunning. Plenty of space to sit back and admire them. The rooms itself are quite pretty too.The downstairs level had a lot of other good paintings, but even if there wasn't, I think the waterlillies was worth the entrance price.
my favourite museum. The jardin des nympheas is one of the most beautiful pieces of art I've seen in Paris. You will become a huge Monet fan and buy many books at the petit gift shop.

Magnificent. We love Monet but this is amazing. You need to see it up close to appreciate what he did. the brush strokes and colors are amazing in real life. So much better than on the internet or in a book.
Water Lillies are a highlight.. Monet's water Lillie's were my artistic highlight for the trip. Beautifully presented. Don't forget to go through to the second room!

The waterlilies are stunning...... We bought the Museum pass and this was one we could use it on. I wanted just to see the waterlilies....and found out there were 2 rooms of them! We just stayed for 1/2 hr. before heading to the D'orsay, and I'm glad we did. They were stunning.

Horrendous queues. When you eventually get inside this is a lovely gallery, in particular the Monet rooms. However unless you have an advanced ticket you should prepare yourself for very long queues. Having waited outside for almost an hour, I was gob-smacked to see that only one person was selling tickets inside. So it took another half an hour to get from the entrance into the gallery itself. Invest in more staff, please!

Great small collection of Impressionist Art. Parisian museums can get slammed with tourists, the best part of Musee de l'Orangerie is the total experience, especially when it comes to Impressionist art. If you saw Midnight in Paris by Woodie Allen and wondered where they were in the oval room discussing Monet, they were at the l'Orangerie near the Place de Concorde. Go there. Enjoy it.
Nymphéas. A long wait to get in but oh so worth it! You will see the spectacular Nymphéas (Monet), Renoirs, and many others. Next stop...Musée Marmottan for more Monet.

Small museum with beautiful presentation. The central point of the museum is a display of Monet´s water lilies and it is done beautifully in two rooms. The paintings themselves are huge and there are only four to a room.

Amazing Collection at l'Orangerie. Starting with the Monets and descending into the lower reaches of the museum one encounters the wonder of what is largely one man's art collection. The Walter-Guillaume Collection is an intellectual enterprise gathering works of the major artists of the early 20th century. I love this museum with its wide range of artists. Monet at the beginning, but Renoir, Picasso, Utrillo, Modigliani, and many others I was unfamiliar with before visiting. Artists of great impact like Mary Laurencin and Chaim Soutin a great expressionist with impasto and wonderful colors are now on my "art experience" list.

Must see when you are in Paris. Mere words cannot describe how beautiful this museum is, it is a definite must-see while you are in Paris. I had no idea of the amount of time and energy that Monet spent creating these wonderful paintings. They are HUGE! My wife actually started crying when we walked in, really a beautiful and moving experience. This space was actually created by Monet and then donated to France by Monet after the first World War so that the people of France would have a sort of haven to go to for peace and tranquility. It's a really beautiful museum and a wonderful history and story of Monet and the city of Paris. A++

Monet Water Lillies A Must. The Monet Water Lillies room is a must. The other parts of the museum seemed like they would be good, but it was late in the day, we had museum feet at this point, and the galleries were crowded. I gave it five stars for the water lilies room, but I would say the rest of the museum is 3 stars. They don't allow photography in the Water Lillies room, which is a big plus.

Monet's Genius!. The l' Orangerie was an amazing experience. Our guide shared that it was Monet's vision to create the room and the art that is the highlight of this Museum. You enter a sequence of 2 rooms that encircle you with visions of Monet's Water Lilies! Each room is filled with ceiling to floor visions painting of the Genius of Monet! Simply Fabulous!

Our favorite museum. Smaller than most - but the only one with Monet's gigantic Water Lilies ... it is a must if you have never seen them - or a must if you just want to take then in for a second or third time.

A MUSEUM WORTH THE VISIT. The Musée de l'Orangerie is not only worth visiting for its Monet's water-lilies and its permanent collection of Modern paintings but also for its ground-breaking temporary exhibitions - in autumn 2014 for example the wonderful works of Emile Bernard. A good tip is to buy a combined ticket for the Musée d'Orsay - a mere 10 minutes walk away - which allows side-entry avoiding the usual queues.

An Impressionist Dream. I loved this lovely Museum in Paris. We went for one reason and that was to see the incredible murals that Monet painted in his 80's. We were not disappointed. The murals spanned two circular rooms and they were a feast for the eyes. The light of the paintings were luminescent and you felt like you were in Monet's gardens of Giverny, which is also a wonderful attraction in itself. We enjoyed the rest of the museum, but it paled in comparison to these two beautiful rooms.

An impressive panorama in oil paint - in a way far ahead of its time!. Monet had the unique ability to paint the 'stillness' ... He did this for all the different seasons and you can now, over a hundred years later, relive some of his beautiful garden of lilies in the form of gigantic panoramic paintings. This is a perfect place for a moment of meditation (and great admiration for a skilled painter) ... It requires of you as a visitor you to stay a while and take the time to consider the works. You will be richly rewarded (so have I been - every time!) ...

Magnificent Monet Display. We made a short tour of Monet’s beautiful and large impressionist paintings of his water lily gardens at the Orangerie. They are displayed on the walls of two oval shaped rooms. They are the curved walls in effect and reflect what we saw at his gardens in Giverny. The presentation is well worth the visit.

An Outstanding Museum in the Tuileries. Located at the southwest corner of the Tuileries, Musee de l'Orangerie offers a generous selection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art, mostly notably Monet's Les Nymphéas. Located on the upper floor of the museum, these eight vast canvases deserve a visit just to see them. The museum's interior exhibition spaces are well-designed and elegant, and even the walkways just north of the museum contain a series of intriguing Rodin and Henry Moore sculptures.

Hit it on a great day.. We were visitind during a Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibit. We could not have hit it at a better time, the exhibit was amazing. This is also home to Monet's Water Lillies, which are breathtaking. We loved this small museum. Be aware that the lines can be long, we visited off season in early December and still found long lines. We ended up purchasing priority tickets at the Musee D'Orsay and were able to get right in to L'Orangerie the next day with the dual ticket.

Wonderful Paintings. I love the Orangerie. The paintings in there are wonderful. I love all of Renoir and Monet. The rooms of Monet's water lilies are amazing. If you have only about an hour to go to a museum, I would highly recommend this place.

You just indulge in the garden. Visiting l'Orangerie is absolutely an amazing experience, esp after I went to the Monet Garden just the day before. You can totally imagine how Monet felt when he was looking at the garden by looking at the wall paintings. A refreshing experience especially after visiting the larger museums such as Louvre.

Monet Extravaganza. Small museum but excellent quality. Great coverage of the Impressionists capped off with the magnificent Monet water lily murals on the top floor. If you've been to Giverny you will really appreciate this and if you haven't you will still be stunned.
Monet....go go. The building is wonderful.. And the Monets are a Wow!!!!What a peaceful place to spend a few hrs...

One of my favorite. There is something about this museum, invite you to the calm of the contemplation in a good silence, unlike all the museums in Paris, this is a very quiet and tiny one, nothing pretentious , almost secret, sit around Les Nympheas of Claude Monet and is the best therapy you can find for 8 Euros, art is able to open up the most closed and tired, bored of the routine minds, it's a great place with an incredible atmosphere.
Worth a visit!. Monet's Water Lillies in panoramic form are awe-inspiring So glad we stopped in here on a whim. Don't miss this museum!

My Favorite Museum in Paris. This was my fifth time visiting l'Orangerie. It has many of my favorite artists all in a lovely small and manageable museum. The museum is best known for the Monet Water Lillies but there is also a very good collection of Matisse, Picasso and Renoir. The only downside is there is often a long line to get in but a few years ago I did the multi-visit museum pass which moved me up to the front of the line. I highly recommend this museum which is very centrally located right by Concorde.

Monet.Monet.Monet. If you like Monet, there is no better place to see something unique and different from all the regular sized paintings of his. This are huge murals (8) in an oval setting which makes you think you are in the middle of his world.

Spectacular, once you get in.... Despite the poorly staffed intake (and their rudeness too) and long line to enter, the exhibits are amazing. Monet's water lilies flank a round room at 360 degrees; the impressionists are well represented, along with some of Picasso's early works. At the time we visited, there was also a special exhibit of Emile Bernard, whose works were beautiful and wide ranging in style. That exhibit is on until January 5, 2015--a must see!
Great small museum. Went to see the Monet waterlilies, which are very impressive.Also delighted with the Impressionist collection downstairs.

My favorite of the larger Art Museums in Paris. We visited L'Orangerie after Louvre & Orsay and enjoyed it the most. Monet's Water Lily's are not to be missed if you enjoy art at all and visit Paris. The museum is well laid out, organized, easy to visit and not that crowded. The other exhibits were outstanding as well as Monet's.

In love with Monet's Lillies. We had visited Claude Monet's Garden on the way to Paris so decided to pay homage to his paintings of this beautiful garden. This museum has set these paintings out in beautiful rooms with elegance and outstanding lighting. We also visited the galleries permanent exhibitions and its new exhibition which was fantastic. Would come again just to sit and look at the Lillies.

Monet's Grandeur and Beauty. I wanted to see Monet's huge paintings at Musee de l'Orangerie. I had read about the paintings and seen photos but was not prepared for seeing the actual works. They are spectacular. See them on a sunny day if possible as the sunlight plays across the ceiling and changes the feel of each work. 9.00 am is the best time to avoid the crowds but mid to late afternoon gives the best light for viewing. The exhibition and collection downstairs are interesting and worth the visit.

Free first Sunday on the month. I love this Musée. It is small but has a great range of masters represented and of course Monets Waterlillies. We happened to be there on the first Sunday of the month and entry was free. Get there early.

Didn't do it for me. Art is a very subjective and personal thing. While I would never tell someone NOT to visit a gallery or museum, my personal thoughts on this one are that the collection just didn't appeal to my tastes. My suggestion is to take a look at the website and see their current collections as I believe they are changed often. Having said that, there were many, many happy tourists around me. As I said, art is subjective.

Another musuem not to miss. After visiting the Musee d'Orsay we crossed the 'lover's bridge' on our walk to the l'Orangerie. The ticket and security line was short and we had all the time we needed in the museum to see Monet's Water Lily masterpiece as well as other impressionist art in the collection. Renovations were completed a few years ago and there were scale models to show how this building has changed over the years.

So much more than water lilies. Great museum. The history of the museum and it's collections is as interesting as the art within is impressive. The Monet installations are beautiful. The galleries on the lower floor were a very nice surprise. Also nice that the museum isn't overwhelming large.

Five stars for the Monets, 2 to 3 stars for the permanent exhibit,. There are eight enormous Monet water lilies that are breathtaking. The permanent exhibit has some minor works by really great artists, and some major works by some not so great artists. I went because of the special exhibit (Emile Bernard). In my opinion, a good special exhibit make this museum worth three hours. Without a good special exhibit, I would skip this and spend the time in the Marmotton Monet instead.
Long queues. Long queues but worth the wait. The Monet walls are wonderful and there are seats to sit and ponder.

Expected more. I had l'Orangerie on my must-see list for a long time, pushing the actual visit forward at each opportunity. Now I finally had the opportunity to go and it was a bit disappointing. The Nympheas - to be honest the main attraction - are magnificent. Yet, less vibrant and colourful as expected. This may be due to the crowdedness. The rest of collection is good and highly recommended to visit, but do not expect the finest masterpieces that you fall in love with.

Go for the Monet, Stay for the Curating. Monet gave his gigantic Nymphéas ("Water Lilies") to France around 1920 and the Orangerie Museum, right at the edge of Place de la Concord was adjusted to house them. But in the last 10 years, the entire place has been reconstructed. I had not seen it. the main display in two oval rooms is a lesson in contemplation and relaxation (unless you are a painter and figure out you cannot likely equal this). If you only walk into these two rooms and sit and think about life, your trip will have been worth it. But today, we saw the whole show. Downstairs is the permanent exhibit of the 150 pictures gifted by the widow of the leading art dealer and collector Paul Guillaume (who later married well to Mr. Walter, hence the Guillaume-Walter gift). These paintings include a host of Renoir, Picasso, Matisse, Cezanne, Rousseau and others. But on top of that, the museum has space for special exhibits, and currently has the first French exhibit dedicated solely to Emil Bernard, a famous painter and art critic. It is well presented and documented and a fascinating learning experience. Lots of information and a fun couple of hours. It bodes well for future return trips for other work of museum personnel.

Best Bang in Paris. Amazing little museum with amazing collection. CANNOT miss. Also a great place to start a round of museum and site seeing as it has a relatively short line and you can buy your Museum Pass here (which allows you to skip the long lines everywhere and pay a reduced single fee for about 50 attractions and museums in and around Paris).
All the famous artists in one place. If you want to see your favorite artists, then go to the Musee de l'Orangerie. Monet and Manet, Picasso, Van Gogh, etc.
DON'T SKIP. This is one of the greatest exhibits anywhere in the world...not to be missed. The gardens around it are great for people watching

Beautiful, Overlooked Little Museum. Of course a trip to the Louvre is a must, but don't forget Musee de l'Orange, especially if you are a fan of Monet. You will find one room surround by Monet paintings, which he actually painted directly onto the walls. Sit on a bench and just take it all in. You won't be disappointed.

If you like Monet's water lilies, this is a must see.. At the opposite end of Jardin Tuileries stands the Musee de l'Orangerie which houses, amongst other things, Monet's Nympheas. The enormous panels are hung in two oval rooms with excellent natural lighting so they can be enjoyed to full-effect.There are other impressionist works on display, but the Nympheas are what you're here for. It is not a big place and it's nice to be able to take it easy and enjoy the art, not feeling worried that you're not going to get around the whole gallery.
Don't miss it. Closed on Tuesdays.. What's not to like? Sweet location in the Tuileries, the water lilies are a retreat, and we saw a terrific show and the permanent collection is beautiful.

Make it what you want. Everyone visits to see the water lilies. Some are sitting and admiring and relishing the art. Others are able to walk around, see the main attraction and move on. For artist and art enthusiasts it may last a bit longer, but for my family the visit last maybe 20 minutes. We went in the morning as we traversed the Tuileries. The line wasn't long and we were able to zip in with our museum pass. It was nice to say we've been but it didn't seem like there was much to the whole exhibit.

Go on Sunday. We stood in line for a long, long time and did not have to pay to get in. I actually did not mind this experience because the museum is in the Tuileries gardens and I was people watching. Monet's water lily paintings encircle two large rooms, displayed in a way that the artist intended. I must say that I have seen several Monet water lily painting exhibits that included some of his other works also. The water lily wall paintings did not produce the awe in me that other exhibits did. However, there were two other exhibits in this museum that were very interesting to see and made the visit better, one exhibit of Bernard's work and the collection of an Impressionist art dealer. The dealer's collection contained a large variety of works, including some by Matisse and Picasso. The museum was not enormous and that was a plus because, we tend to overdo when seeing museums.

Beautiful museum, loved Monet's waterlilies!. We loved our afternoon at the Musee de l'Orangerie! It is a small, more intimate museum and not overwhelming to view all their art. The highlight for me was Monet's gorgeous (& huge) waterlily paintings. I would recommend visiting the Musee de l'Orangerie!

Beautiful and accessible museum. The Orangerie was quite beautiful and of course Monet's paintings were the highlight, although we quite enjoyed the rest of the exhibition. Well worth a visit when in Paris.

If you love Monet, you must visit the Orangerie. This is where they huge water lily murals are housed. They are exquisite. Its a small museum on the edge of the Tuileries, if you don't have a museum pass, buy the ticket that gets you into both the Orangerie and the Orsay (and skip the lengthy Orsay lines). Lovely place to spend an hour or so.
Not worth your time. I've visited Paris several times and wanted to finally get to this museum. Although it was nice, it certainly was not worth the effort and expense to go.
de l'Orangerie. We walked through the gardens on a warm, fall day and arrived at the museum. Beautiful museum and one not to miss.

astounded. We had never seen the Monet paintings and we were on our wayto Monet's garden when rain caused us to change our plans and we were very glad we had. There was a short queue but we moved quite quickly and when we got inside we were glad it had rained. It was the best exhibition we have ever seen. If you have not been-go. Photos and mobile phones not allowed.

Awesome!. It's a relatively compact museum filled with masterpieces. Easy to see all of them in an hour or two. We saw Claude Monet's large painting which covers the walls of two rooms! We also saw works by Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse, and an exhibit of Emile Bernard. Do not miss this one!

Gorgeous Art. If you like Monet's work, you'll love this place. Absolutely marvelous. And, by the way, the list for date of visit needs to be changed. I did not go in Nov. of 2013, but you don't have enough dates listed.

Worthwhile short diversion. Well, it's got the water lilies, hasn't it? Good as a set but some were really boring. However, there's a great collection of paintings on the lower level, including Renoirs and some fantastic Soutines. Even with a museum pass, you still have to queue for the inefficient and inconsistent security checkpoint (they mainly check bags then send you through an unmonitored metal detector, but if they don't like the look of you, they'll tell you to take out your camera and wallet before going through - they won't check them or stop you if you beep, they just want to slow things up.
Don't miss this museum. you should not miss Monet's water lilies. The permanent collection is also exceptional. The crowds are minimal and the museum modern and comfortable.

Amazing Monet. We went mainly to see the massive Monets and were not disappointed. It was busy the day we went with school groups so we weren't able to sit in the middle of the galleries for too long. The two circular galleries of Monet's paintings are truly the highlight of the Museum. The lower floor had very impressive paintings by various Masters and it was certainly worth the admission.

What a gem!. Visiting Musee d' Orsay made me want to discover more about Monet so I decided to come to this place. Waterlilies paintings by Monet are amazing. For me, it's quite a life-changing experience. I became very interested in his work and impressionist art that everywhere I travel, I will try to visit museum with impressionists collection. This place's made me found my new passion.
Go. Good location; to make a pause when you are walking from Louvre museum to Place de la concorde. Very quiet. Pity it dont have a bar.

Beautiful little Museum. There was hardly a queue to enter, only 9€ and small enough to navigate easily. Monet's Nymphéas is magnificent. Be aware though that no photography is allowed so you'll have to buy a poster or a book instead.

Small and wonderful. What I liked best about this museum is the fact that is not as large and overwhelming as the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay. It is easy to see it all in less then 2 hours and better yet you will not get lost.The museum is famous for the series of Monet water lilies and they are indeed amazing. You are literally surrounded by very large canvases and need to take time to really see it. On the lower level however you will find a private collection of late 19th and early 20th century art that is worth seeing. The museum also has temporary exhibits and we were lucky to have visited it during the retrospective of Emile Bernard. A less known contemporary of Gaugin and Cezanne but in my opinion a marvelous artist. This particular exhibit will be there till January 2015.
Stunning mural. The Monet murals are truly astounding and deserve hours of appreciation. The museum also offers changing exhibits about other artists, often but not always Impresionists.
A pleasant surprise.. My charming wife said 'let's go here'. A great choice.A lot smaller than any other art museum, but allowed for a quieter experience. More introspection.Go early or risk crowds.
Waterlilies!. Fantastic Monets. The rest of the collection is limited, but pretty good too. Magical displays. Bit of a wait to get in, but worth it ... leaves you wanting more!

Monet!. I have not visited the l'Orangerie in a very long time. In fact this was my first visit since the former restoration. This is probably the most peaceful museum to visit early on a Sunday morning. No crowds, and the chance to get so close to the magnificent Monet paintings.

Don't just go for Monet. First visit, impression: the museum rooms that hold his panoramic pieces are well lit, present the canvas in a beautiful setting making it the one and only focal point. There are slim bench style seats in the center of the room, good luck sitting and enjoying, this is a very crowded museum in September and I am sure all through summer. However make it downstairs, see some Picasso, Chagall. I love Monet, I love gardens but I enjoyed seeing Giverny much more, live and in person and the other art downstairs was much more appealing to me but you must appreciate what it took for Monet to paint these pieces in the day and age in which they were created. No pictures and be silent. If chatter gets too loud you will be asked to quiet down. To experience art, it to appreciate it then go out to a local café for food and wine and talk about it.
Sweet, Sweet, Sweet!. What to say but WOW!!!....don't miss this gem of a museum...water lilies everywhere and oh the exquisite colors Monet used!

Monet, Monet, Monet and other masters as well. Monet painted six large--and I mean LARGE-- Water Lily scenes that he gave to the French government as a contribution. The are housed in two rooms in the Orangerie and they are the main attraction. Be sure not to miss the fabulous collection on the lower floor.

Monet says it all. Simply the best single exhibit in Paris, the wonderful, cool and big exhibit of Monet's Water Lilies in the basement. See it to believe it. The oval rooms and the sheer size of the paintings attest to his genius. Impressionism for the masses.

If you can, go to Giverny first and then to l'Orangerie. We were able to first visit Monet's gardens at Giverny (about 45 minute or so ride from Paris). We visited in September so the gardens and lilies were not as much in bloom as depicted by Monet. Nontheless, the following day we went to the Musee de "Orangerie, to view Monet's Waterlilies. The display is magical and the paintings can change, depending on the light. -- not to be missed.
Disappointed we couldn't take pictures. The artwork is absolutely beautiful and worth the visit. They do have a few places to sit down if you get tired of walking.
Wow. Included in the museum pass and well worth a visit. It is quite small but has some fantastic paintings.....especially Monet.

Must see for Monet fans. This was the first gallery we visited in Paris and a really good introduction for our kids aged 10 and 13. Monet's water lilies were amazing but the rest of the gallery contains gems from the impressionists and is worth a leisurely stroll. If you can, I suggest you visit Giverny (Monet's house and garden outside Paris) as this puts his lilies in true perspective.
Monet Nymphs incredible. The Nymphs paintings are huge - and not at all as I expected!Many other beautiful paintings are housed here too! Well worth a visit, and after wander in the Tuillery gardens!

Monet for everyone.. The Musse de L'orangerie is a lovely little museum. I've been there a few times and it is very pleasant with a peaceful atmosphere. It is much much smaller that the Louvre and as a consequence, it's not as intimidating if you're not sure what to look at. The L'orangerie has a beautiful collection of Monet's very late work on Waterlillies. These are huge panoramic paintings. There simply isn't a photo, postcard or book that can do these paintings justice. They simply glow, and give you a sensation of the light in nature rather than an accurate depiction of structure. After the Monet you can wander off downstairs and there are a variety of works by the very famous (Picasso, Renoir, Pissaro) and the temporary exhibition is also included in the entrance fee. A truly lovely little gallery. The first time I went to the Orangerie, was before a night out meeting up with friends! You don't need a whole day for this one, so try to find an hour or so in your day. You won't regret it.

Great presentation of Monet. There isn't much to say other than: Monet. If you like him, go here. If you don't, go here to see why so many do and perhaps you might even come to appreciate his style and ability. There is other art here too but the price you pay is for the waterlilies.

Emotional to visit the oval rooms with the Monet Lilly paintings. It was emotional...you have seen these on the TV but to see them with your own eyes is something else. These were so great that the next day I paid a visit to Monet's house and gardens in Giverny. A hidden gem in a Paris with not too many visitors in September. Don't miss this gallery. It's a real treat for art lovers and all. Also go to Monet's house if you can as it really is like the paintings.

Little museum with big art. My favorite museum of my visit. The two large oval rooms filled with Monet's waterlily paintings are serene and breathtaking. I could literally sit there for hours and get lost in the paintings. If you are visiting The Louvre, just walk to the other end of the Tulleries Garden near the Plaza de Concorde to find this museum tucked away. You will not regret your visit there.

Simply lovely. Excellent collection of impressionist art in addition to Monet's stunning Nympheas. Intimate setting and much less crowded than the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay. Well worth the visit. Be sure to stroll through the tuileries gardens to get there.

Breath taking!. The Waterlilies are just unbelievable. Get a tour guide to explain the painting, and they will come alive for you. It's a very Zen like place, so don't try to rush through, or you will miss the point.

Love this little Art Gallery. This is a great little gallery to get a good hit of Monet's last work....the water lilies.... and some other impressionist painters in the basement. There is also and Emile Bernard Exhibit there right now. I did not know this painter but certainly he was an important one and I found the exhibit interesting and engrossing. If your feet are sore and you want a respite this is a great little museum to go to.

Monet and more!. This was one of my favorite Paris museums on our recent one week trip to Paris. It houses a. Umber of impressionist paintings, including a number by Renoir, on the lower floor. Upstairs, there are two immense oval-shaped rooms which are completely wrapped by floor-to-ceiling murals of Les Nympheas (water lilies), which portray Monet's famed water gardens at different times of the day. I recommend watching the film, shown at various times of the day inside the museum, which describes The development of the paintings and museum. Later in the week, we visited Monet's actual home and gardens and really appreciated the feeling of what tried to accomplish these amazing paintings.
Love It. Quite, not as crowded at the Louvre, if you like Monet, it's a must. 2 rooms surrounded by his water lilies. don't miss the other artwork in the basement.

Water Lilies and More. The Monet water lilies are the draw. The surprise is the additional work downstairs - Renoir, Cézanne, Utrillo, Picasso. We planned to stay about an hour and left after three hours because we were famished! There is much to be absorbed and enjoyed. Make the time.
For Monet Lovers Only. If you love Monet this is a must. 30 metre paintings of Monet's garden at diferent times of the day and night. You could sit for hours and just soak up the beauty of his art

the monet dream. it was a great idea to give Monet`s waterlilies a space where they can really been appreciated.ANd the collection is very important too.It is a very nice museum specially because is is small and one can see it all without getting tired
Eight of Claude Monet's Waterlily Collection. To be able to say you saw eight of Claude Monet's Waterlily Collection was exciting and an experience in itself.
Don't miss this gem in Paris!. Monet's water lilies Les Nympheas. You'll literally gasp when you walk into this room. Then head out to Giverny to see his garden!

Great Collection -. The collection was so great that the big draw (the Monet Water Lilies) seemed almost secondary. Make sure you don't skip the little alcove that shows how many of the painting appeared in the collectors' library and dining room.
Lovely museum, nasty staff. This is a small museum with a lovely collection, but our experience was marred by the inexplicable rudeness of the staff.

Teary-eyed at the end of my visit. This uncrowded museum at one end of Jardin des Tuileries was a must-see on my list. I went there alone and truly enjoyed the display of Claude Monet's water garden in a building built for these paintings and showing them with natural light. It is possible to sit in peace and regard each painting. It is possible to walk right up close and study the master's brush strokes. The display of other impressionists downstairs was an added attraction AND the garden related bookstore nearby was sheer delight. A wonderful morning.

Breathtaking!. We visited the Musee de l'Orangrie as part of our Paris Museum pass. We were mainly interested in seeing Monet's Waterlilies. The paintings are so beautiful. To be able to sit and gaze upon this works in their intended viewing spot was amazing. I was really glad that the museum was part of the Paris Museum pass. The pass has enabled us to see so many places & most importantly avoid any of the lines to get in. The museum is fairly expensive to get into, and if you are not an avid Monet fan I am not sure if it would be worth it to go it considering there isn't a whole lot else to see there.

You haven't seen Monet till you've seen his "Water Lilies" here!. Located in the West corner of the Tuileries Gardens, Musee de l'Orangerie was built in 1852 to shelter the orange trees. In 1927 Monet's monumental panoramic murals, "Water Lilies" ,which he had painted in his garden at Giverny, were installed. It's breathtaking especially if you've been to Giverny. After your tour of the Orangerie, go for a walk in the Tuileries Gardens and savor what you've just seen. Truly inspiring!
Aussie travellers. Such a wonderful surprise to see the Monet murals. We sat in the centre of the room and the changing light over the water and the water lilies was spectacular.

Monet!. Les Nympheas, aka The Water Lilies, by Claude Monet...go see this!
The rest of the art on the bottom floor is forgettable.

A special impressionist exhibit.. It was showing the impressionist collection of a famous collector. Also the first floor is the permanent home of wall-long Monets. Unfortunately they were out of guidebooks in English.

Monet. The Nympheas takes my breath away every time I come.
There is also a great collection of work by other artists like Renoir and Soutine

Amazing space. The oval gallery is just breathtaking.
To be able to just sit and wonder at Monet greatest works.
It must be a must for any art lover.
Expande since last year. Great exhibition of Bonnard as well as a collection of impressionis moved from the D' Orsay. Of course the water lilies are always worth going for

Can't Miss for Monet Lovers. No one prepared me for this. It is the centerpiece of Monet's Water Lilies. Beautiful and breathtaking, the 2 rooms which are the centerpiece of this museum are stunning. You can really appreciate Monet's mastery of color and become totally immersed in his art.

The Monet rooms are worth the visit alone!. This small but mighty gallery will give you a great sense of what Monet was trying to achieve with his water lillies. It has a focused collection that gives viewers a great sense of the stylistic approaches of Picasso, Modigliani, Matisse, Soutine, Cezanne, Renoir, and many more. It is situated in a huge sculpture garden, amidst water features, cafes, and gardens.

Commune with Monet. Beautiful to sit in the rooms with all the water lily paintings. Do, however, arrive well before closing. The times were not the same as the website showed and we were not allowed in the first time we tried to go. The guard was exceedingly rude.

Fabulous exhibits. Leisurely walking through the Tuilleries to get there was as much fun as visiting the museum. The gardens are full of sculptures, a pond, places to sit and observe, eateries and a gelato station. L'Orangerie was full of many masterpieces and a special exhibit by Emile Bernard. Visit their website to take advantage of the English guided tours before visiting: http://www.musee-orangerie.fr/homes/home_id25242_u1l2.htm There were hardly any line and there are English audio guides available as well. Totally enjoyable and worth doing especially if you've been to the L'ouvre already.

The Orange Greenhouse. Must get Cold in winter tyo house orange trees. Anyway great spot for a gallery, full on impressionist stuff. Upstairs some humungous Monet waterlillies (yawn) but downstairs some absoloute Gems, fabulous.use the paris pass meuseum tyicket for line skipping

Intimate look at iconic Monet. L'orangerie is the perfect scale for those with art museum fatigue, not much time, or young children with short attention spans. Minimal, fast moving queues (avoid lunch hour). Ground level showcases Monet's water lilies in the round on a breath taking scale, letting them speak for themselves. Downstairs is the impressive permanent collection (big name artists spotting area) plus a temporary exhibition on Emile Bernard - and the toilets. Most definitely worth a stop

Disappointing art tour. I booked my daughter and her friend an art tour that was supposed to include painting after a stroll through the Tuileries for inspiration.They didn't get to paint. The regular guide was absent but we weren't told until afterwards. Very, very disappointing!
Good Art Museum. I loved how the paintings were laid out. Each painter was in a separate salon, & arranged chronologically.

Monet, Monet, Monet. Loved the Monet masterpieces here, as well as the works of other artists on display on the lower floor. Combine your visit with a trip to the Musee d'Orsay as well for a feast of Impressionists plus other.

Breathtaking. Monet's waterlilies exceeded my expectations. They were breathtaking. I am so glad I came and saw them. I tossed up between the Musee de l'Orangerie and the Louvre and I made the right choice. Not overcrowded and a simple museum that let's Monet and his waterlilies shine.

Wonderful museum in paris. Loved this museum, and it's impressionist collection. The waterlillies by Monet is worth it alone, but the rest of the collection is excellent. Such a nice setting next to Tuileries gardens also, perfect for strolling.
Impressive impressionists. Worth it for monets nympheas aloneA best -of potpourris of french peri - impressionist art in the basementShort but sweet- great with kids/ teenagers
Exceeded expectations. The Monets left me breathless. I'd put this museum right behind the Louvre and the D'Orsay in my must do list.

A good scale to avoid art oversaturation. The Monet water lilies are perfectly showcased in this purpose built museum with natural light and a good seat in the middle of each room to sit and admire the massive paintings. The art collection downstairs includes some lovely Renoir works I really enjoy too.
Beautiful Monet. Really like the Water Lilies by Monet, but was not fond of all the other artwork there. Bit Pricey to get in.

An oasis of beauty. This small museum is primarily dedicated to Monet's large waterlily paintings, but also has some great Renoirs downstairs, and a few other impressionist works. The waterlily works are phenomenal. I'd plan to spend at least an hour or two here overall. The museum is adjacent to the Tulerie Gardens, so you could have a picnic there and then look at the art for a nice afternoon!

If you love Monet --. You will love this place. This museum was built to house Monet's waterlilies. It is quite a site. don't miss the exhibit downstairs with almost 150 paintings by Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse, Picasso, etc.

Monet Nympheas Revealed. Monet painted hundreds in his Giverney water Lilly series , Les Nympheas, BUT he specifically designed only this space to house his large panels. And so, with his oversight and blessing, this museum became the prime venue to see his Water Lillies as he wanted them to be seen!The museum, damaged by WW II bombing in 1944, was finally restored and reimagined in the 1990s to really present these master works in the best possible setting and light. This museum, therefore, is a highlight of Paris art and architecture.To round out the experience, the entire collection of Monet's art dealer Guilliame has been housed here, and this is one of the more elegant collections of impressionists and pre-impressionists who influenced modern painting.Modigliani, Cezanne, Picasso, and other lesser known but significant painters, are well represented and presented here.What we love about this precious place is the smaller size, allowing one to swell and fully enjoy without feeling that one is missing something. The Louvre is overwhelming, the D'Orsay is fabulous but crushingly crowded, but the L'Orangerie is quiet, magnificent, and the most wonderful of museum experiences while in Paris.
Good!. Not really much to see, but it worth visiting. security staff were very friendly. we had a good time there.
Love Monet!. If you love the work of Monet, you must see this museum! The first floor is absolutely breathtaking!

Monet. There is nothing like Monet's Water Lilies anywhere else. The other art is also fabulous in this small Museum. Get the combined Musee D'Orsay/l'Orangerie ticked for better value and easier access
