Wonderful small gallery for Impressionist lovers. I just read about this gallery prior to this trip to Paris & thoroughly enjoyed it. The Monet panoramas alone are well worth the visit - stunning. Also a most enjoyable range of other impessionist paintings, many that I had not seen before.

A Must for Water Lilies Fans. The main attraction here are 2 large rooms dedicated to Monet's Water Lilies. Each room has 4 enormous water lilies canvases. We sat down to just admire and be surrounded by the tranquility of these masterpieces. (We had the Museum Pass and got in pretty quickly in the middle of the afternoon.)
Water lilies are wonderous. This tiny jewel box is worth the stop to see room after room of Monet's water lilies mounted on circular walls.

where two rooms of peace resides. one of the few museums open on Mondays in Paris. Originally wanted to go to Musee d'Orsay, but we only had Monday available to go. So we ended up visiting Musee de l'Orangerie and I personally do not regret a bit. The first floor has two rooms that is holding total of 8 panels of art works by Claude Monet, called Water Lillies. I am very disappointed that they don't let us take pictures of them but I understand them at the same time. You have to go see it to truly understand the art. It is not gigantic and magnificent, but by seeing with you own eyes and trying to understand his motif for the art, you get to truly appreciate his work.The lower floor has gift shop and the basement has assorted art works from various artists. You are allowed to take pictures in the basement.There is 1 Euro discount if you also buy the ticket for d'Orsay.

Just divine!. This is one of those places you don't want to share because it's just a slice of heaven to be able to sit quietly in the large oval room and take in the giant panels of water lilies that surround you. The natural light is slightly muted and the effect is surreal. Like another reviewer said, it's a surprise that the art is so large and that it's displayed so beautifully. Consider this an escape from the race to see as much a possible and rest your tired feet. Save money to buy a book. It's like a mini-vacation to read about Monet's garden and how he loved to paint.

Monet. This is the place to really understand Monet's Waterlilly paintings. Quieter than the Musee D'orsay in terms of visitors, this Musee sits in the Tuillerie Gardens and is a must for any art lover.

Orangerie Was Just OK. The Orangerie is located on the corner of the Tuilleries Garden. The rooms that have the Monets along the walls are ok but you feel that the Gustopo are watching you as you cannot take pictures of these paintings along the walls. You can go downstairs to see some paintings from artists I have never heard of. They do have some very good Renoirs. That is the only redeeming quality of this museum. In my opinion.

Small museum with great art. We only had a couple of days in Paris and didn't want to spend all of them inside in museums, so instead we chose just to do the Orangerie and I'm so happy we did it. It's small and easy to get around in a short amount of time, but it provides a lot of great art and has the Monet water lillies which were really breathtaking.

This was a favorite museum in Europe so far.. We loved this museum! It was spacious, well laid out. We are fans of the impressionism, so this was the place to be.They had a great special on van Gogh while we were there that was spectacular. We walked through 3 times just to see the large selecting of his paintings. Our 10 year old loved his work.Of note- it has a great cafe on top floor and a great restaurant that has reasonable prices and good food. If you want a nice view of Paris, go to the cafe on the top floor and look for the doors leading out the terrace. Great place to have coffee or a glass of wine and relax. There really aren't any restaurants close by, so plan to eat before you come or I would plan on having lunch at the restaurant in the museum as we did.

Small, but EXCELLENT museum!. We really enjoyed visiting this smaller place containing all the great impressionists! The LARGE, oval rooms holding the Water Lilies paintings were great, then you're treated to an impressive collection of paintings by Monet, Picasso, Utrillo and a host of others. Definitely worth a stop!

A place to reflect. The ticketing for l'Orangerie should be procured on line... this saves you from waiting on the horrendously slow moving cue. Once in it is a wonderful place to sit and reflect on the images, the imagery and the artist.

My favorite place in Paris so far!. The two rooms of Monet's water Lillie's are truly amazing. So calm and serene. The additional exhibits on the bottom floor are equally good. Very comfortable chairs outside overlooking the fountains and obelisk for a short break afterwards.

is breathtaking!. is breathtaking! Monet is unique, incomparable, perfect, is light, his paintings not only portray the nuances of brightness but his soul, sensitive to perceptions of beauty of nature; do not let go and if you can, go to Givenchi, feel the atmosphere of the gardens, the flowers, the lake, the house where he lived and portrayed in this beauty!

Monet - the Master. Go simply for the 2 rooms that contain the giant-sized tableaux of Monet's water lilies. They are a feast for the senses! You will sit and look in sheer wonderment at his creations. NOT TO BE MISSED!!

The Magnificence of Monet. The Musee de l'Orangerie is located in a stunning building within the Jardin de Tuilleries. It houses the art collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume which include works by Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir and Modigliani among others. It is most famous for the two galleries which house Monet's les nympheas, the water lilies. Monet supervised the design and construction of the galleries. There is a history of this (in French) as you approach the two galleries.We visited mid-afternoon on a weekday. We purchased a joint ticket, 16 euros, for entrance to the Musee d'Orsay and the Musee de l'Orangerie. The ticket is to be used within four days of purchase. The museum was not crowded at all and is easily seen in two hours depending on your interest in art. There is a nice, but pricey, gift shop yet no cafe.My husband and I spent a good deal of our time in the two water lily salons. They are oval rooms with benches in the middle so that you can take your time and drink in the vision and magnificence of Monet. How did he create these masterpieces? Their brilliance leaves you breathless. The salons are silent places of reflection with no photography allowed. There were many guards on duty, yet one in particular was very vigilant in maintaining silence in the galleries. I appreciated his diligence as it allowed you to be alone with your thoughts and the art work. The galleries are on the main floor with the Walter/Guillaume collection on the bottom floor.While this museum may be overlooked on a trip to Paris, it is a must for admirers of Monet.

Wonderful expo of Monet!. There are very large Monet murals of his beloved lily ponds--so large and so lovely that they take your breath away. This museum is such a delight--it isn't over visited like the Louvre or the Eiffel Tower--of course you must visit those icons if you are in Paris, but don't forget the lesser known attractions like this little gem.

Monet and Fellow Impressionists. If you love the Monet water lillies, you will love this museum. Located at the end of the Tuilleries, this small museum is a delight. We went at the beginning of the day and there was not a crowd.

A must see. I had been to Paris several times before getting here, and regretted immediately all those lost opportunities. Easy to get to, easy to get around, and stocked with such treasures (well, particularly Monet's Nympheas). I would recommend starting with the Louvre, then Musee de l'Orangerie and conclude with Musee D'Orsay for a circuit.
Monet Lovers Delight. I loved the large wall murals by Monet of the Water Lily theme. A small museum but a a very pleasant visit.

If you love Monet, you'll love this. This was a nice walk away from the Arc de Triomphe. We mainly went here to see Monet's water lilies. They are huge, two rooms with the walls covered in the original paintings. You can get so close to them, and they aren't covered in glass, so you can see every tiny or broad brushstroke that he did, as well as the vast range of colours he used.We spoke to a guard there, who was clearly passionate about Monet's work, and he explained that Monet actually designed the gallery, so that his work could be viewed properly any time of the day. A brilliant gallery, in which under 26's get in for free, providing you had suitable ID (driving licence, passport).

Monet's Lillies and not much else. Seemed like a waste of time to line up to get in when effectively there were only 2 galleries depicting Monet's water lillies and not much else. Sure there were a few Renoirs in the basement but I thought the Musee D'Orsay gave a better selection. Go if the line is short and you are wondering what to do with your free time near Place de La Concorde.
Fantastic place to see great artwork. Take the guided tour...it is wonderful!The building is incredible.Eating in the restaurant is wonderful, too!
Loved it. The l'Orangerie was closed when we last visited Paris. I'm glad I finally got to see it. Lines were not so long as I remembered from last time, possibly because of the time of year.

Awesome museum if you like Claude Monet and the Water Lilies. Small and enjoyable. Great location. Next to the metro station. Do not pay extra for "guided" tours or anything like that. The museum has two big chambers with most of the Water Lilies on display. I liked Claude Monet, so I enjoyed this museum, but it is not for everybody. Also, if you like Claude Monet go see the Giverny Gardens. This is where the Monet's house is located and where he painted the Water Lilies.

Great Prelude to Giverny. The morning of a trip to Monet's home and gardens in Giverny we decided would be a great time to visit this museum. Absolutely a great combination! To see how well the paintings were shown and then going to the "source" was a wonderful combination and is a must. The museum is set up and flows so well through these fantastic works of Monet - don't hesitate to do this.
Beautiful Monets. Beautiful gem of a museum. Takes about 2 hours. Monet's work is humbling especially when you consider he did it in his 80's with failing eyesight. Make sure you get there!
We did not like it. After musee d'Orsay it was real disappointment. If you are not great fan of Picasso and cubism do not go there. Water lilas rooms were not so impressive as we thought.

The Orangerie: Unfortunate Identity Crisis. This museum has been on our list for decades. In the past it was our favorite, edging out the Louvre and the D'Orsay. Not so now. The Orangerie seems to be in a state of identity crisis. The Monet rooms retain as much wow factor as any museum in Paris, but the remainder of the museum is basically in disarray. The Orangerie once housed the most impressive collection of Impressionistic art.Shame on whomever changed this!

Amazing. Surround yourself with the beauty and tranquility of Monet's giant water lillies panoramatic panels. Drink in the Renoir,s, Sisley's, Manet's and more in a less crowded environment than the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay. Buy the 2 for one pass at one and enjoy the other.

Unbelievably beautiful waterlilies!. We went late morning/early afternoon and happy to see that there were no lines, even though we had the Museum pass. I was absolutely stunned when we went into the first room of two waterlily rooms the paintings were breathtaking. The second room was just as large with even more waterlilies. These two large rooms are oval shaped with one huge canvas on each wall. I had no idea the display was going to be this big. You sit there for hours just looking at them.The rooms with the smaller canvasses were beautiful too. The entire museum had lots of light and was a very pleasant, relaxing atmosphere. Not too many people either, which made it even more enjoyable.I would definitely add this gallery to your 'things to see' list.
Les Nymphéas is well worth it!. Peaceful and quiet, it was a luxury to be able to enjoy Monet's water lilies in the beautifully designed rooms where no cameras and noise were allowed!

More Monet. Having visited Musee Marmottan, this was a must. Here were some amazing works by Monet. taking up a complete room and more than life-size. The museum is very fresh and modern and has works by other artists too. Worth a visit!
'A Must See' -Enough said. Even if you don't like art, these paintings are fantastic. For photographers, make sure you visit both clocks and the terrace for photo opps.

Finally, I had the chance to visit the Orangerie!. The Orangerie houses 8 of Monet's Waterlily paintings. You will find two large oval rooms with 4 paintings in each. The rooms are painted a soft mellow cream and somehow feel calm. There are long benches in the centre of the room so that you can sit and observe the Waterlilies at your leisure. It is marvellous to see Monet's brush strokes so close and then sit back and appreciate the entire painting. It is possible to see the order in which Monet painted them as his eyesight failed. I had waited for years to finally see the Orangerie (it was closed for years) and I was not disappointed.

Top 3 for sure!. I will make sure to stroll back through every time I go to Paris! This is an experience, not a museum. After visiting Paris 3 times, and hitting the "top 10s" of the major tour books, this spot would make my top 3.

Spend an hour here!. If you can't make Giverny, this is an amazing exhibit of Monet's large works in the round. You won't need more than 2 hours, or even less than that - maybe an hour in this small museum to appreciate several works of great artists including Monet, any many others.

Impressionist Art. If you love the works of Monet then this is the museum for you. This is where the "Water Lillies" is in its own beautiful created space. On my top 5 list for our trip to Paris,it did not fail to amaze me.
Waterlilies and more. I went to see Monet's waterlily murals but found that i like some of the other impressionist paintings much better.
Interesting collection. Well worth a visit if you are in Le Tuilleries Jardin along with Jeu de Paume art Museum. Make sure to visit the Monet collection.

A must see if you love Monet. We had visited Monet's gardens a couple of days before and this was our last museum in Paris before heading off. so glad we fought off 'museum fatigue' and headed over the Sein to the Musee de l'Orangeri. Such delights await in the two oval rooms with wall to wall , ceiling to floor Nymph series. Very moving and very beautiful. Tips: If you have Monet's Garden on the itinery try and do this museum after - it will mean so much more. Book a double ticket with Musee d'Orsay - its cheaper and is easily done on Musee d'Orsay's web site.

Surprised with what we liked. We actually preferred the other artist's works to monet's murals. The murals seemed a bland taste of many of his other works. Go to Giverny and see his home and gardens, that's much more enjoyable!
Monet at his best. Go late afternoon at about 5 as the crowds are thinning and buy your ticket for the Musee d'Orsay for the next day as a dual entry deal.
Beautiful!. A small, intimate museum in the gardens. I could look at the lily pad paintings for hours. A must see when you are in Paris!

Surprisingly good. So if you go there tired after seeing one museum after another, its not wow, but I went there expecting to see the water lilies and was surprised by the good stuff in the basement, Picasso, Modigliani and more.
Wonderful small museum!. This museum is smaller than most, but there is still a lot to see. I loved being surrounded by Monet's water lilies. Then you have other artists such as Renoir.
Wonderful Museum. The size of this museum works for me with just the right number of exhibits so I felt I could enjoy it all and not be brain weary at the end! Money's work is really intriguing!
Water lilies. Monet's water lilies are amazing so big is an amazing room and also wonderful pieces on the bottom floor
Serenity. Remarkable venue to appreciate Monet's artistry, just past Tulieres Garden, venue designed to showcase Monet water lillies

Water lilies.. Stunning museum with a fascinating history as it was purpose built during the artists lifetime to display his paintings and then left to fall into disrepair! Now fully restored it is a lovely accessible gallery, along with the Orsay, if you hate the crowds and are overwhelmed by the Louvre.
All about Monet. Very excited when we learned about this museum. Monet's water lilies are in oval rooms surrounding you. One of the best exhibits in Paris

A BEAUTIFUL IMPRESSIONIST GALLERY IN HEART OF TUILLERIES. This was our first visit to this gorgeous Impressionist gallery. Photos are not allowed, unfortunately. The top floor is a symphony of Monet paintings done from Giverny with the water lilies and pond that he built and so cherished. The lower level has wonderful paintings from the usual suspects from the Impressionist genre. Renoir, Van Gogh and many others. This venue is not to be missed. We have been in Paris on 7 prior occasions and I cannot believe we did not see this museum before!

Stunning. This small but wonderful museum should be as much if a "must see" as d'Orsay, the Monet's are truly stunning and it is often quiet, allowing you to enjoy them in a way you can't in the Lourve at times. Especially great if you have a Pass but worth the fee alone, too.

The best small art museum anywhere. This art museum is not as well know as some of the others, but it really packs a powerful punch. A few paintings by each of the top Impressionists, plus laid out in an easy to follow manner. And then the unbelievable water lilly murals by Monet in the basement, that really tops it off.

Impressionism and beyond. My main reason to go to this museum is to see more Monet. They were beautiful. I loved how they were arranged in the museum. I enjoyed the rest of the museum to after I got my fill of water lilies.
Incredible compact collection. The display in two of the galleries of Monets Water Lilys is mind blowing. Other works by Renoir, Mogdiliani, Picasso amongst other has to be seen. No coffee shop!

A real treat. What a beautiful place - surrounding gardens are a dream and so is this beautiful museum -even the queue was friendly ! Monet's waterlilies were such a feast for the eyes but what I wasn't expecting was the other great paintings downstairs .they were beautifully displayed and it was just all so - manageable - not so overwhelming as other galleries we have visited . I thoroughly recommend a visit to this beautiful art museum

Must see. Saw the (small) painting at Orsay and just had to see the "big" ones. In two rooms we saw "Les Nymphies" (a series of eight murals) all around us. There are benches in the middle and we sat and just let our minds drift ...amazing paintings!
Great museum.. Not a big museum fan, but this was the right size for me. Had Monet, Renoir, and Picasso to name a few artist. First Sunday of every month is free which is why I went initially.

Amazing waterlillies. I have been wanting to come here for years and it was worth the wait. The two rooms with the waterlillies are just amazing. They really are huge and suit the room well. The other paintings on the lower level are a good mix of different artists. I enjoyed the audio guide and the kids were entertained with the ipads - they cost 5 euros but as the kids were free to get in I did not mind paying for the ipads and it meant I could have some peace while I looked at the paintings.

The very best. My favorite museum in Paris. I loved the quiet, calm surrounds in which to enjoy these brilliant works of art. Monet's Nympheas are there to be experienced and not just viewed. and as for the Paul Guillaume collection, one cannot thank the people responsible enough for making this available to the public for viewing. These include works by Cézanne, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir, and Sisley. Absolutely brilliant to see.

Amazing!!. We went to the Museo D'Orsay and had a tour focusing on the emergence of impressionism and then went to this museum. Beautiful!! I have always favored impressionism but to see such a collection. Never mind Monet's larger than life paintings that leave one in awe. Downstairs were so many other amazing peices. I could spend days in this museum and keep seeing something new.

Beautiful Museum. We visited on a rainy day, so be prepared to wait in the rain on the line outside, the Museum Pass gets you on a much shorter line however.Of course Monet's Water Lillies are incredible and we used Rick Steve's guide to walk through and understand the huge pieces a bit more but the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collection on the ground floor is not to be missed. Extraordinary works from Renoir to Picasso to Modigliani all close up and fabulous. We checked our backpack making walking around easier.

Favorite museum in Paris. L'Orangerie is our favorite of the main museums in Paris. It's easy to love the extent of the Louvre, the impressionist collection of D'Orsay, or the history of Notre Dame but the L'Orangerie has a great manageable collection that is topped by Monet's large waterlillies (Nympheas). While certainly the focal point, the Nympheas are not the only thing. The bottom floor has a wonderful collection of Impressionist/post-impressionist paintings with an amazing audioguide. In fact, there were more paintings highlighted on audioguide here than at D'Orsay! We did the whole museum in about 90min at a slow pace taking in almost the entire audioguide (5E - well worth it).L'Orangerie allows you to get away from the masses a little, have a smaller museum to digest, and catch a surprisingly good Impressionist collection in addition to Monet's Nympheas.
A must see. Better than the Louvre. Great pieces and can view them in less than 2 hrs. Monet's paintings "in the round" are spectacular.
Monet water lilies. I was in awe and speechless in the two oblong rooms that house the Monet masterpieces. You are completely immersed in his paintings, just the way he wanted you to be. Incredible!
Must see for Monet. If you love Monet you must go to the Musee de l'Orangerie. Monet's Waterlilies take center stage, but you also won't be disappointed by the other master artworks you'll find.

Must do. If this is not on your must do list it should be. We revised having last been here in 2007. Apart from the permanent collection on the ground floor there is always an excellent exhibition on the lower ground floor. We ended up spending double the time we expected to. We will be back again.
Musee de l'Orangerie. Great little art gallery in the Tuileries. Easy to spend hours gazing Monet's huge water lilly paintings.

Breathtaking!. Our favorite museum in Paris. Monet has prepared an artistic embrace for humanity. Stunning and moving: a beautiful gift. Get the Museum pass http://en.parismuseumpass.com/ and bypass the long lines. Enjoy...
Don't miss it. Monet's water lillies are a must see but there's a good deal more. Paris Museum Pass gets you past the line. Plan on one or two hours.
Under rated Great museum. Lots of good French impressionist painting. No crowds to impede your viewing. It looks like many overlook this small museum for the large tourist museums.

Simply the best. If you like Monet, you will love this. This is the only place to see huge panels of Monet's waterlilies. You are also in for a treat if you venture further into the basement, where an outstanding collection of Renoir, Picasso et al can be found.

Go for the top floor, stay for the lower floor. Most people come here to view Monet's water lilies, but the true highlight of this gallery can be found on the lower floor. A variety of paintings collected by a famous Parisian art dealer are exhibited there. From the widely known to the little know in the art world, at least to the average tourist, they will open your eyes to the world of art as never before. A museum that is truly worth a visit.
If you love Monet.... This is your place. My wife loves his work and she just sat looking at the walls for what seemed like hours! lol I am not a Monet fan but she loved it

For impressionist and post-impressionist art lovers. A small but very impressive collection of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings by French artists. It is an easy walk from the Louvre into the Tuileries Gardens where this modern building housing the collection is located. Huge Monet murals fill space dedicated to his work. Too bad photography isn't permitted.

Like Monet?. Go here for a quick fix of Water Lilies. Huge Monet panorama (Admittedly I'm using the wrong technical words and title for the art, but you can get the meaning). Restful stop and walk around with the real thing on the walls. I believe it still has other exhibits, which are also very interesting and the location is not prominent, meaning you have a good chance to get a non-crowded visit in non-tourist times. Worth the visit.

Stunning small gallery - not to be missed.. This is a beautiful gallery. If you like French paintings don't miss this. The ground floor is a mind blowing wrap around diorama of Monet's lilly ponds - occupying two oval shaped rooms. Underneath is a lovely gallery of a selected set of paintings by Renoir, Cezanne, and others. There is a great concentration of superb paintings in one place. Excellent shop also.

Lovely - almost. We loved the whole experience, with one exception. We had to check our little back-packs - which we found acceptable until we saw many people walking around the gallery with FAR bigger bags than ours. When we went to collect our bags I asked the man behind the desk why he had taken our bags, while far bulkier ones were allowed through. He shrugged his shoulders, but the woman standing behind him, who seemed to be senior to him, muttered something about "best not to engage with difficult people". So although the exhibition is beautiful, maybe they could retrain their staff, both in logical approach and in courtesy.
Great small art gallery. Well worth a visit. Not too much to see, but all of a fantastic quality. Impressionists, inc picasso and monet.

My favorite museum in Paris. I am an art nut. My husband and I got 2 4-day museum passes during our recent several week stay in Paris. On museum pass days we were like kids in a candy store seeing several museums each day. Even though L'orangerie is "small" it has a magnificent collection that we returned to revisit on our last museum pass day. Monet's lilies are worth the visit. Read about them first so you understand what is special about each panel. A little preparation goes a long way in appreciating. The rooms are perfectly designed to enjoy these magnificent works. I remember seeing them before the renovation and can appreciate the job the designers did. The works by the other impressionists are the surprise of this museum. They are many.
Monet Monet. If you like Monet, this is your kind of museum. You can sit and contemplate the waterlilies for hours on end. There are also other works in a section below.
Water lilies. This is a great museum, not overcrowded, no big queue, and accessible art. The water lilies are stunning

Waterlillies a disappointment but not the museum. I always wanted to see Monet's Waterlillies at the l'Orangerie but was disappointed. The smaller paintings have much more detail and impact. However the other paintings here were fantastic. A great selection of impressionist work.

Masterpieces - Period. As I sat gazing at the lilies, I truly felt myself transported to that garden in Giverney. I had been there only days ago. I wished I could have been there alone to simply contemplate the beauty and the genius of these masterpieces...and they are huge. Take the time to sit quietly and gaze into the pond. You will be richly rewarded.

Not just Monet. Of course, Monet's Les Nymphéas (Water Lilies) are what draws the first time visitor, but the permanent collection of l'Orangerie (the Walter-Guillaume collection) is really first rate. Paul Guillaume was an art dealer and collector in the 1920's and early 1930's. He supported many of the great artists of the early 20th century, including Picasso, Soutine, Derain and Marie Laurencin. His collection (with his wife) is a really stunning study in the beginnings of what we think of as modern art (as well as some great impressionist work). It is well worth visiting and revisiting.
Monet en ronde. The 2 rooms with Monet Water Lilies 360 degrees are amazing. This museum gives you great insight into Monet's painting. It is smaller and less crowded than the d'Orsay
Little museum with a lot to see.. If you like Impressionism then you have to see this museum. It's a museum that's small enough that you can easily see everything in a couple of hours.

Must See for Impressionism. I always recommend l'Orangerie as a more "off the beaten track" impressionism destination than the Musee d'Orsay. The collection is incredible and the crowds are much better. Definitely spring for the audio guide on this one.

Water Lilies!. The history behind this building is enough of a reason for a visit but can't say enough about the Monte room, "Water Lilies". To be in a room filled with so many people and everyone being quiet and just taking in the experience is like no other. Make sure to sit in the middle and just absorb the beauty of the magnificent paintings!

An exhibition area in Palais de Luxembourgh. This building which is in the gardens of the Palais de Luxembourgh has contemporary art exhibitions which are open to the public - the current one has paintings as wells as a photo exhibition. it is well worth your time and a peaceful place to spend an hour or two. It is free to anyone.

So much better than expected!!!. Oh, the Monet murals!!!! Truly unbelievable. We went on a day trip tour of Monet's home at Giverny prior to visiting this museum, and walking in here was just like walking in his garden and pond. If you have time, visiting his home will make the artwork at this museum even more special.
Perfect before a visit to Giverny. Lovely to see what Monet painted before going to his home. Beautiful gallery sitting just above the Tuileries gardens
Required Stop. The Monet Water Lilies, of course. Required, or turn in your tourist credentials. Repeat visits encouraged.
Waterlilies are wonderful. Use the Paris museum Pass to skip queues. Two rooms of waterlilies and galleries below. Busy, but not unbearable.
A Magnificent Museum - not to miss. This museum is small but wonderful. It's easy to find in the Tuileries. The Monet paintings are magnificent. Just a real jewel and a pleasure.
Monet. small museum - perfect collection of Monet's waterlilies - located near the Louvre - good collection of Renoir and Cezannes
Water lilies. Fans of Monet's late work will appreciate being surrounded by motifs from his garden at Giverny. Monet planned the oval installation in the 2 rooms but didn't live to see it open.

Not so crowded, restful , in the Tuileries. This lovely museum sits in the delightful Tuileries Gardens, you can walk over from the Metro Palais Royale- Louvre station across the park to Place de Concorde, if the weather is nice.The museum's biggest draw is the Waterlilies by Monet. Set in two oval rooms, the canvases are huge, and the audioguides tell us the history of the paintings, painted as they were when Monet was very old. Nonetheless, they are a wonderful sight.You are not allowed to take photographs in these rooms.The audio guide is, in fact one of the most informative I came across in Paris, and there were numerous paintings with full explanations. This could get quite tiring, so that you might find yourself selecting paintings, rather than ploughing through them one by one. I haven't seen so many Renoirs in one place. I also got to know about a couple of other artists whose work I found fascinating. You also get more of a feel for the time scale of the various "movements" such as Fauvism, and "return to order" - and about the artists who led these groups, tired of them, and moved on. Brilliant and informative. The staff are stern and strict. My husband got told off for getting too close, and he wasn't, really. Then this staff member, she went of to gossip with another "guard" and totally became oblivious to others getting far closer to the works. Good toilet facilities, and lovely chairs outside facing on to the Obelisk and the Arc De Triomphe. Traffic roaring but still a lovely Parisian spot for lots of pics!Use your Museum Pass for this one, and you'll get total value out of using the card during your stay.

Interesting and easily accessible museum. We planned to visit the Sainte Chapelle, but the line was hours long. Instead, we wandered into the Orangerie which is next door. It is a fairly small museum, so it is easy to see the whole thing in an hour. It is strong on the history of the building. You walk away with a real sense what it might be like to be imprisoned there. It is good for children as the story is simple and it does not take long to understand. My daughter especially appreciated the story of Marie Antoinette which has all the tragic romance designed to appeal to a pre-teen girl. Worth a trip!

Good old Monet. No Que and straight through with Paris museum pass, just go to see the water Lilly's, breathtaking. You don't usually see beaming smiles in museums, it was great to watch jaws drop open and the elation on faces in ore. Out of the museum for a nice walk pass through the park to the louve.

Loved this small museum. This museum houses 8 Monet murals displayed in two rooms. If I were a Paris resident, I'd visit once a week simply to enjoy these paintings. The rest of the museum focuses samples of work from some important painters from the 1910s and 1920s. Work is grouped by artist and arranged historically. There is adequate English explanations even without the audio guide, which is not always the case. We were fortunate to arrive upon opening on a rainy morning and managed to avoided much of the crowds.

All of Monet's Water Lily Paintings. I don't think I was expecting such large paintings as those that are displayed here! Monet has shown his water lilies at different times of day and in different seasons and they are hung around the curved walls of two rooms in the orangery. If you like Monet, you'll love this gallery! In the basement is a display of some of the other impressionist's work, some well known and some not so well known outside of France but well worth a visit.
Precious little museum. try to enjoy an early morning arrival at this pleasant little museum boasting a variety of ad hoc exhibitions with material from the Louvre, Musee d'Orsay and others.

Monet on a massive scale. I enjoyed the large Monet 'Les Nympheas' - no photographs though which was disappointing. The room in which the giant panels are displayed is perfect. The rest of the museum was a little disappointing but that is probably just down to artistic taste.
For Monet only!. If you are a lover of the art and of the impressionists, you need to go and see for yourself, it is huge in every sense of the term!
Small, but very nice and well worth it.. This is a smaller museum, but we came to look at some of the larget Monet water lily collections. It is well worth it. So beautiful and serene.

A really nice sized art museum to take a teenager.. We took our teenager here, the first art gallery she has been old enough to appreciate. Not too many paintings or artists. A good intro to Monet and Cezanne.
A sacred space. It hard to explain, but it was a spiritual experience sitting quietly, amidst the hubbub, surrounded, engulfed by and embedded in Monet's liquid, blue-green luminescent images.

Monet at his best. Visited this late on an afternoon and not an 'arty' type was impressed with all the paintings in this museum, however, on it's own this could seem an expensive museum to visit at 9.50 euros, better looking for a deal with the Musee D'Orsay

A special place. If you like Monet, well, this is a small diamond, in the fantastic Paris.
Having it separate from Louvre may seem strange, but it deserve a separate space and a more quiet environment.
I like this place!

Not Very Extensive. If you have a Museum Pass, don't miss this museum. If not, I'm not sure it is worth it, especially given the Impressionist collection as the d'Orsay. However, if you have an hour to spare...
Good collection of Monets and Delacroix. Many paintings I had never seen before of these two masters. It's a bit out of the way, but I will return again on my next Paris visit...
AMAZING. If you like impressionists work this is a MUST SEE. The water lilies rooms are even better than they are in the photos. I could just sit in those rooms all day and I'm not even doing art.

If you like impressionism.... This is a quick 1 hour stop, but completely worth it to see the Monet rooms with his water lillies at different times surrounding you on all sides. Some good selections in the downstairs room as well from other artists.

My Favorite Museum in Paris. The art in this Gallery was stunning. Monet's waterlily paintings in the situation he especially designed for them are a truly sensuous experience. This Art Gallery has fabulous Cezannes, Soutines, some lovely work by Modigliani and many others. There is a lovely intimate scale. It is not too big and that allows you to enjoy the work much more than a day at a vast Museum like the Louvre, which ends up being quite gruelling. You don't have to queue either.
Water lilies a must. The oval rooms here are designed to hold Monet's paintings, and it is a very serene and peaceful experience to visit.
Monet!. We went just to view the Water Lilies again. The other Impressionist paintings were also beautiful, of course. A must! Get the Museum Pass, too.

If you're a Monet fan, you shouldn't miss this one. There are two rooms lined with Monet's Waterlilies, and these are the main event. It's a very relaxing experience being in there. It would be better if people were a little quieter, but what can you do? There is also some other fine art on another floor. This museum is walking distance to the eastern edge of Champs Elysee.

Beautiful and Peaceful. Located at the end of the Tulleries Gardens, a tranquil, small muse containing Monet's water lillies murals in two rooms and a wonderful collection of other impressionists as well. You cannot dislike this gem; what a treasure trove of art is Paris

Come and admire the water lilies of Monet. This small museum houses eight huge paintings of water lilies and pond views from Monet's garden in Giverny. Most impressive. The museum is closed on tuesday. If you don't have a Paris Museum Pass, I would suggest buying a combination ticket that allows you to visit this museum and the Musée d'Orsay in a timespan of four days. It is 4 euros cheaper than buying your tickets for each museum seperatly.

Go for the water lilies. If nothing else, Monet's water lilies are worth going to see. There is a small collection of other notable artists as well, and although this place doesn't have to take a long time it is definitely worth stopping in - also, it's in the Tuileries garden which is a nice place to go unto itself

Wonderful museum -- not to be missed!. While so many people are braving the chaos, lineups and overcrowding of the Louvre and the Musée D'Orsay, there is a quiet gem waiting for you at this museum. Situated in a lovely garden lined by trees, it is a peaceful way to spend some time. Easily accessible and a simple entrance (no crazy crowds!), you will not regret making a visit here. The audio tour is very helpful. Of course, everyone comes to see the famous Water Lillies by Monet (and the architectural design of his display is unforgettable). But we were equally impressed by the lovely collection of Picasso, Rousseau, Modigliani, etc. This museum was less intimidating than some of the others which made it a good choice for us and our teens. We could take our time and didn't feel like sheep being herded along a wall of art! Everyone could relax and take their time.

If you enjoy Monet .... In case you dont know this is the home of the eight largest of Monet's Waterlliy works. The space was specifically designed for these spectacular works.This is a Must See if in Paris.

Expected more Monet. Other than the central room with the panoramic Monet's the rest of the art was from other artists that I didn't particularly enjoy. Had expected to see lots of Monet's work so was a bit disappointed.
Great place to relax. Lovely tree lined grounds with a large pond/lake to sit and relax and watch the ducks and have a coffee. Very close to all the other main attractions.

Small but very interesting. This is one of those places that you could easily skip or miss, but do yourself a favor and go. It is small and doesn't have to take a long time. Great display of Monet water lilies (large format) and a very interesting art collection on display on the lower levels.
Impressionists galore. Loved the lack of crowds and the time explore up close the works of artists such as Monet, Picasso, Renoir, Matisse the list goes on. An overlooked museum.

MONET. I love Monet and the giant water lily paintings here are surreal. went the day after a visit to his gardens in Giverny and it was the perfect complement to see the place then see these paintings. I saw them with new eyes. loved the water lily rooms and could have spent the entire time in them but the special exhibit was worthwhile too!

Monet's water lillies. This musuem is a must visit if you love Monet's work espeically his 'Water Lillies' series. There is two oval rooms which contain 8 of those paintings. Lighting in the room changes from sunrise to sunset so you can see the effect of light on the paintings. AWESOME! You can sit on a bench (if there is room) and watch the subtle changes. One of my favorite museum to visit in Paris. Also the downstairs has some great works of Impressionist art. Get the Museum Pass and your entry here is free with that pass.
Quick visit. Quick visit to less populated but still impressive museum. Monet's are very cool. Plus you can buy one bundled ticket that includes d'Orsay (which avoids the line there).

A Secret Picture Garden. L'Orangerie is a small museum primarily dedicated to Monet and his fellow Impressionist painters of the period. Tucked in a corner of the Tuilleries Garden it is a must not miss for painter fans and garden fans alike because nature, light, and flowers that abound inside and out.Easily can be done in less than 1/2 a day, I think this is also probably one of the most overlooked Museums when discovering Paris. You will find many of the early impressionist works here, Monet's huge Garden inspired triumphs and a few Picasso, Van Gogh, Renoir, and Fauvists works too. A perk in particular is a very nice tribute to the extraordinary art dealer, patron, and collector in Paris of the time of Mr. Paul Guillaume. Many of which his collected works are now in the museum.In tribute there is a exhibit section dedicated to Monsieur Guillaume showing in part his apartments throughout Paris and his collections at the time in petite doll house dia-Rama views that are great and will make you drool with envy at what he had on his walls. The kids think they're cool too!Overall a must for lovers of Impressionism and a small petite "salon" that makes for a lovely, tranquil, morning or afternoon.

Small but good. This is a quick museum to visit. Not far from the Louvre.While it's small it is worth visiting.A nice change from some of the overwhelming large museums you can look at each picture.Monets, Picassos and Renoirs in a smaller setting.Put this on your list.

What a gem. This is not a huge museum, which makes it all the better. Loved sitting in a peaceful room looking at Monet's water lilies. The rest of the collection is also interesting, and not as crowded as other museums. Definitely worth visiting and nice sitting outside in the sun afterwards. We had pre-booked tickets so as not to wait in line, but in fact there was no line!

Monet´s not quite the greatest attraction here. Of course you go to the L´Orangerie to see Monet´s water lillies. But, apart from the place´s architecture (specially designed to receive the laaaarge paintings) and the fact that it was a gift from Monet to the people of France right after the end of WWI, in my view Monet has much better stuff to offer in other places like the MET in NYC or even the d´Orsay or the Marmottan in Paris. But what I really liked about going there today was the Paulo Guillaume collection, ranging from Cezanne to Matisse, and I discovered Soutine, a wonderful expressionist. Another thing that called our attention was the staff - nice and friendly, esp. the audioguide attendant. And... it was not crowded at all!!! What a relief!
Beautiful surroundings. This is a beautiful environment in which to appreciate Monet's work. I would recommend going early before the crowds build up.

A hidden treasure. While this isn't a major museum like the Lourve or d'Orsay, it's worth a visit. Great collection of giant Monet water lilies, and some nice Renoirs and Picassos. It's on the way from d'Orsay to the Champs-Élysées - I'd recommend stopping by.

Great Place. If you like Monet you'll like this sweet museum. Although not a lot to see, what the have us top notch. You can get through this museum quickly and do the D'Orsay the same day or another when you buy a pass for both together.
must go for art lovers. not a big museum, but less crowded still a lot good paintings to see. very impressed by Monet's painting, a masterpiece no one should have missed.

Must see if you like Monet. If you're a fan of Monet you have to see this one. There are two rooms that feature water lillies by Monet, you can sit down in the middle of the room, relax and have a good look. No pictures allowed which I appreciate much. The museum is small so I think around one hour would be enough. Also not so crowded, I went during high season in the morning and there were no lines.

Small museum and near the Louvre.. Before much of the Impressionist art went to the D'Orsey, this was the place. But it still has some fine examples of famous artists, the lines aren't long and you can see it all in an hour.

Should Be on Your Bucket List. Claude Monet's water lilies displayed pretty much as he hoped it would be is worth observing for an hour or more. Sit and look, think and allow the other tourists to fade away.
very interesting Monet exhibit. We enjoyed this museum with its impressionist painters. A good experience if you have already been to the Lourve
Beautiful Monet. Best to visit early in the day to avoid crowds, seeing the large Water Lillies was wonderful, the small size of building makes it a very qiuick visit, but very worthwhile experience.

Truly stunning. I was blown away by the displays, take your time, don't be put off by the crowds. Find somewhere to sit and just absorb yourself in the most amazing and beautiful art that you will ever see. It is absolutely stunning and despite the numbers of people present, very calming. Always worth a visit.

Disappointing. Poor signage to get to this museum.there us a mirror building on the other side. It is towards the river. No crowds but probably a bit expensive for what there is. I found the water lilies underwhelming and why can't you take a photo in the rooms? What a load of rubbish. Copyright? Give me a break. I found them dull and without real colour. The display downstairs is interesting.

Favorite small museum. I still love this place after seeing it for the forts time 25 years ago. Water lilies are phenomenal to see in person. A very doable museum with kids. My boys enjoyed it as we were in and out within an hour.

Overrated. If you have a museum pass it's an okay side trip. Not much there except for the murals. They badly need cleaning and restoration. If you are a huge Monet fan it's good otherwise not worth the price
Great smaller art museum. My wife and I were going to Giverny, so we wanted to go to this museum as well. Just outstanding. The space, artwork itself.....everything. You should go!

An experience to sit and drink in Monet's masterpiece water lilies. It never changes, every time you enter the oval rooms where the Nypheas are you are overtaken with the desire to immerse my ourself in them, to draw and reflect in this wonderful quiet and peaceful ambiance.If you have never been add it to your list. Both rooms are amazing and even better after visiting Giverny, the inspiration pond of water lilies.The rest of the exhibition the Paul Guillaume collection is very impressive too. A must in Paris

Wonderful museum! One of my favorites in Paris!. Loved the Monet water lillies, two rooms of four panels of his renowned paintings. Also enjoyed the other exhibits. Just the right size museum to enjoy and not be overwhelmed. A nice collection of paintings--samplings of various artists' works. Two hours will allow one to enjoy the entire museum. I highly recommend a visit here.

Yes! Yes! Yes!. Be sure to go to the Musee de l'Orangerie. Monets longer than the walls in my house. Truly a spiritual experience. Quiet prevails as observers sit in peace among the genius of Monet. Be sure to go downstairs, too.

Monet, yes, but much more. Two beautiful rooms of full-surround Monet water lilies is enough to get your in the door, but stay for Renior, Cezanne and Modigliani. If you already have the museum pass to enjoy the Louvre and d'Orsay, just pop in for an hour to fill in the nooks and crannies of your post-impressionist experience.
Very enjoyable. A hidden gem. The monet panoramas were amazing and the rest of the museum was very coolly designed. Recommended

A welcome respite amid the bustle of Paris. A small jewel in the midst of major attractions. Filled with the impressionists, this wonderful museum is a place to sit and meditate surrounded by the incomparable works of Claude Monet. Enter the quiet room, sit on a padded seat and immerse totally yourself in this lovely room.The museum is easy to maneuver, lines are not intimidating and the price is reasonable. I highly recommend the Musee de l'Orangerie.

How can you not go?. Beautifully restored, the buildings are worth a visit in themselves. The fabulous Monet vast water lily murals are the big draw...justifiably. And a very easy walk from the Orsay.

Monet Prime. If you have also been to Giverny to see these fantastic gardens in the flesh, these murals will mean even more to you. I love stopping in to the Musee de l'Orangerie since it is fairly unknown and is such a hidden gem off to the side of the Tuileries. Très charmant.
Gorgeous Art. Monet ! and others! What can we say? - in a pleasant setting, easy to get to. If you love Monet, then be sure to, also, go to Giverny.

a charming little museum in the Tuilleries. The best place to see Monet's water lily paintings on large oval walls with lots of light. Paris is very crowded at this time of year but this is a good way to spend an hour without a very long line.

Superb museum with few visitors. On the ground floor, the dazzling Monet water lillies. The lower level's collection is also world class. Delighted. In fact, we visited this museum twice during this trip.

Great museum that can be done in a short period of time. We've been in Paris for 4 days and are pretty tired so headed to Musee de l'Orangerie today which we loved as it could be done in an hour. Some great paintings and a worthwhile experience.
The monet's are fantastic. Very nice museum, but really small. The Monet paintings are fantastic. Then go downstairs for a selection of Renoir and others artists. Small but good
Monet's Lillies. This is also a great museum if you like Monet. It is not a huge museum so it is very manageable. It is a must see if you want to see Monet's Water Lillies.
Little known gem!. If you are intimidated by long queues this is the place to admire true masterpieces in a lovely setting.

Monet!. We loved the waterlillies display. I think you should go down to the audio/video presentation regarding the museum and the paintings first. Or at least after. It helps you understand what Monet was trying to convey with this work. We went back up to look at it again through his eyes and really got it. I am glad we didn't miss it!
Lovely building and lines were not too long. Small and can be done in about an hour! Nice to have some seating outside for people to take a break, Louve should take a lesson on this

Beautiful Impressionist Paintings. This Musee is not as large as others in the vicinity (D'Orsay, Louvre) but has a more relaxed atmosphere with an excellent collection of Impressionist paintings particularly Monet on the ground floor. Also good selection of paintings by Renoir. Highly recommend - plan on spending 2 hours.

Waterlilies are perfection. We dragged our kids to this museum after a morning at the Louvre and some burning off steam in the Tuileries. They complained mightily until they walked into the first Waterlilies gallery, which stunned them into silence. These two galleries - and the paintings in them - are impossibly lovely and moving. Definitely worth a visit, especially with a Museum Pass. When we went, the museum was relatively quiet, and thus provided a nice respite from the chaos of the Louvre.

a little expo worth to see. The gallery is quite small. if you don't consider the -1 floor, there are 10 big pics by monet. They're amazing and impressing, but the full ticket is a bit expensive. During rainy or terribly hot days you can spend some time around the museums: This gallery is not far from the Louvre.
Breath taking!. Fabulous gallery featuring Monet' s Waterlilies which are beautifully displayed in two curved galleries.

Impressionist art. If you enjoy impressionist art, this is the place for you. It had a wonderful mix of impressionists artist--the pieces by Monet were exceptionally thrilling to see in person. I also learned about a few new artists that I am quite excited about.

If you are a Monet fan, this is a 'must do'. The Water Lilies are a sight to behold. I'd been to this gallery decades ago and have tried several times since but each time after the first it was closed for renovations, strikes, etc. This time however it was open. Although it did not seem as utterly breathtaking on this second visit, it was still amazing. If you haven't been to l'Organgerie, you should add it to your next Paris trip itinerary.

If you're into art, add this to your list. After checking in our back packs and paying the €7.50 entrance fee (an extra €5 if you wanted to use the audio set), we entered the Musee de L'Orangerie art gallery where we spent a few minutes in two large oval rooms each housing four very large murals by Monet. All the murals were of the water lily lake in his famous garden and looked very similar. We then took a set of stairs that led downwards to a number of smaller, connected rooms which hosted paintings by a group of artists known as The Macchiaioli. Macchia, meaning "stain" or "blot" was a group of painters which included Signorini, Boldini, Lega, Picasso, Renoir, Degat and Matisse, amongst others. Originally a term of ridicule, it was later adopted by the group to explain their approach and technique which was a break away from the neoclassical and romantic tradition to a new style with a focus on the outdoors and light.Beauty is in the eye of the beholder and this one thoroughly enjoyed viewing the paintings by famous artists despite not knowing a great deal about art.

L'Orangerie...a revelation. I visited L'Orangerie about 30 years ago and enjoyed it greatly. This time, it was a revelation! The Monet Water Lilies murals are obviously a highlight, but the real jewel in the exhibits is downstairs, in the Collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume. This collection of paintings from the last 100+ years or so was nothing short of spectacular. Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne, Sisley, Matisse, Laurencin, Modigliani...the list goes on and on. L'Orangerie is arge enough to give you an amazingly wonderful view of this era of painting, yet small enough so you won't suffer "museum feet." For the next few months, Renoir's final painting is on loan and displayed. You won't regret spending an hour or so here...well worth it!

Waterlilies to sooth your soul. Travelling with two teenagers and a husband who can take or leave (preferably leave) galleries I wanted our week in Paris to include one galler - and choose this as : a) Monet's waterlilies b) small and compact. Everyone loved the waterlilies - they really will take your breath away and small is beautiful!
Wonderful. A small but lovely museum containing Monet's beautiful Waterlilly series. Also on display, a small but very interesting collection of art including Picasso, Rousseau and Renoir.

Small, Gorgeous. We got the package of the l'Orangerie and Musee d'Orsay ticket, and I highly recommend it. The bottom level of this museum is nice, but the main attraction, Monet's lilies, is spectacular. My family felt like this was one of the less crowded places in paris, yet just as worth seeing. The paintings will take your breath away! There's nothing like it...

A pretty little place to spend a couple of hours. The Monet Nymphaea are lovely, but the rest of the museum is very pretty as well. Makes for a beautiful afternoon. The impressionist beauty continues as you walk around the beautiful gardens outside, and stroll along the Champs Elysses.
Just go!. Small and intimate, quiet and cozy. Go early and you may be nearly alone with a circle of water lillies. It's spectacular.

Worth A Visit. This wasn't on our original list of sites to see. We happened to be in Paris on the first Sunday of the month when all museums were free of charge, and ended up in the Tuileries near the museum when it started to rain. When we saw the line was short, we decided to go in. It is small by museum standards but includes 2 rooms of Monet's water lily paintings. It was worth the time.
A must see!. How could you go to Paris and not see the Water Lilies? It may not be huge and full of groups of tourists, but move it up your list. It's almost the essential Paris.

Best small art museum in Paris!. Compared to the Louvre and the D'Orsay, this museum is much smaller and you can actually enjoy every piece of art! While the Louvre and D'Orsay had a few amazing things and a lot of ok things,everything at the Orangerie was excellent. In summary, it's small but everything is great, especially the Monet lily flowers ("Nympheas"). Wonderful! Note: you have to be quiet in the Monet rooms!

Wonderful Museum for Impressionist Lovers. This museum houses the wonderful huge panels of Waterlilies that Monet painted, with sky lighting just as the artist envisioned it. Go on a sunny morning for maximum enjoyment and no line. Downstairs are other impressionist and period paintings well worth the visit on their own. Purchase tickets together with Musee d'Orsay (a short walk across the Seine) at reduced rate. Buy at l'Orangerie, and then skip the lines at d'Orsay--you'll be so glad you didn't stand in long lines there.

Must see the Monet Waterlillies collection.. We enjoyed the museum but the main draw is certainly the Monet Waterlillies collection. Very easy to breeze in and see these as they are on the first floor straight in. If you want to see more I would recommend the Matisse, Cezanne and Picassos.

A Must for Monet Lovers. Spectacular museum. I find it to be so tranquil. Sitting and taking in the permanent exhibit of Monet's Waterlillies is just breathtaking. Make this part of your Paris visit. I always return every time I am in Paris and I am never disappointed.

Monet, and many other people. The Orangerie museum is famous for its Monet paintings and present them in a pleasant atmosphere. However, you don't really get to enjoy it on a normal day since there are just so many visitors.

Monet!!!!. If you love Monet and impressionist art -this is a must see--the way they have Monet's painiting displayed is breathtaking! Also right outside the museum is a wonderful park with a great cafe!
Go and see the Water Lilies Paintings. I didn't know much about this museum before I went to Paris, but it is very serene sitting and looking at the paintings in the two Water Lilies rooms.

Very special. This small and very specialized art museum has been one of our favourites in Paris for a few decades now. Even going in high tourist season couldn't take away from how extraordinary the permanent exhibit of Monet's Waterlilies is and how perfectly the artist chose to have it displayed.

A Gem!. I really enjoyed my visit to Musee de l'Orangerie. It was my first time in Paris and I was only there for two nights. I love art and wanted to visit a museum, but didn't have time to get lost in the Louvre for hours. What I liked the most about this museum is that it is small and very manageable - every piece on display is fantastic, no "filler art" so to speak. It felt like a very fulfilling and efficient place to see great art. Tip: Get a ticket online in advance, the entry line will be much shorter!

I love "Les Nymphéas"!. When I went into the hall on 1st floor and I saw Les Nymphéas, it stunned me!There is a quiet and peaceful place you can walk around or just sit, think and enjoy the painting!Another paintings are good, you must go there and enjoy it!!(if you love "Midnight Paris" you can't miss it!)
Those Monets!!. This museum was almost free when buying a douple ticket to Musee d'Orsay. This museum is worth visiting even you just check out the stunning Monets.

Amazing!. Went on the last day in Paris as it was raining. The water lily paintings were so beautiful, seeing them was better than seeing the pictures. The rest of the collection is well worth a look too. Didn't have to line up for long to get in, only five minutes.
Do not miss!. Monet!!! Have to see place! Two oval rooms designed by Monet, with two four panel paintings in the round. Very close to Orsay.
Monet "Rocks". We loved that this museum was not too crowded so we could get a really good view of the pictures. The room size Monet pictures created a peaceful feeling.

My new favorite museum in Paris!. I LOVED this museum! The artwork is top notch and the crowds are not too heavy. If you like Musee d'Orsay but detest late July crowds, this is a great alternative or addition to your trip. In addition to the impressive wall sized Monet water lilly paintings, the museum has an impressive collection of other impressionist works. The audio guide was fantastic and to see a museum as the artist envisioned is truly a treat. I will return to this museum as it is one of the most peaceful settings one can imagine.

A True Gem!. I couldn't wait to see Monet's Water Lillies, and I cried when I first entered and saw four large canvases encircling the room. There are eight paintings in all and each is breathtaking. It was quite an emotional experience! I learned that Monet never signed his large works. The museum is lovely, housing other wonderful impressionist paintings. There is a feeling of reverence, and the smaller number of visitors makes it very relaxing. Do not miss this!

Don't miss these Monet's. We were blown away by these paintings. Even if your time is limited, you only need a few minutes to stop in and see what I felt was one of the highlights of my trip to Paris. We actually popped in twice (museum pass and we were in walking distance). If you'll be at the Louvre, it's so close. Stop over and you'll be glad you did.
If you like Monet, don't miss this. I adored the upstairs exhibits, which are all Monet's murals of waterlilies.Downstairs is a paradise for art lovers,I loved the Renoirs in particular.

Water Lillies. If you are into this (impressionism) then you mustn't miss it. It was built by Monet himself - he wanted us to experience this. It is a small museum and therefore not to be missed as it is not taxing in any way. Go and see how the seasons and light change.

I cried..... We visited Giverny on a rainy day during our stay and bought the two visit pass for Monet's house and garden and then the museum. I have waited many many years to visit as the Museum as it was under renovation the last few times I have been to Paris. After seeing his home and lily pond to see his painting...the size and breath taking beauty of them...I just sat and cried as they were so magnificent. Truly an amazing sight and I would go back again and again.

My favorite Paris museum. This is a wonderful, smaller museum with rooms built specifically to house Monet's Water Lillies. Those rooms and the paintings in them are an experience not to be missed. The other impressionist works within the museum are also fantastic and can be viewed in a leisurely less crowded atmosphere. Rent the audio guide so that you get a full appreciation of the works and their individual stories. I will say this in every Paris review, but GET THE MUSEUM PASS. The line of people just waiting to buy tickets is ridiculous and those with the pass go through in a much shorter line. Do your research before you leave and buy the pass!
Small gem of a museum. This lovely small museum holds 8 huge water lily paintings by Monet. An ideal stop on your way to the Tuileries or Louvre.

If you need to miss a museum in Paris.... Of course this has fabulous, monstrous Monets and more, but if you can't squeeze this in, it's okay. I enjoyed it, but I was in the city for an extended period. If you have plenty of time, by all means check it out.

worth it for the Monets. A small gallery by comparison with some of its neighbours, but worth visiting if you want to see some of Monet's stunning water lily works. They are vast, and displayed around the walls of two huge rooms.

Best Museum in Paris. If you love monet (as I do) this is the best museum to visit, water lillies fill the oval rooms and you can see every detail and every spec of colour. They also change the exhibitors regularly - Great Gift Shop and Facilities. This is also featured in SATC too
Nice -. This museum visit probably takes and hour - lovely art work nice relaxing stroll through the museum after the morning at Musee d'Orsday.

Monet at his best!!!!. This museum was the product of Monet's donation after the world war for people to come in and sit down and feel relaxed and calm amidst a busy and hectic day. It really does feel that way. The two rooms for his water lilies collection are superb. You can get lost just staring at them. The different color shades were meant to show the lighting over a course of a full day till evening.

Must See for Monet Fans. You must go see this if you love Impressionism and Monet especially. Although I would recommend 2 things. 1.Buy your tickets ahead of time and go early and 2. Don't go during the summer. Paris is already so crowded in the summer. We didn't have a choice with travel dates this year though. The Museum's 2 rooms of the water lillies is pretty amazing. You're in a self guided tour so you can take as long or as little as you like. If you're also interested in the Musee d'Orsay, then buy the combo ticket for 16 Euro. Buy your ticket ahead of time online and you can pick them up at several different tourism office locations throughout the city.
Small museum but lovely artwork. If you are a fan of impressionalist art, you have to visit this small but lovely museum. Just sit and stare at the water lilies for a while, it is worth the trip!
Perfect size. We took the kids here and they enjoyed the experience. Really a nice size for a short visit and Monet is always wonderful to see.

Water lilies. I have always loved Monet and on this trip I went to Monet's Garden and the Marmottan Museum. I almost skipped the L'Orangerie but am so glad I didn't. The Water lilies here are magnificent. Monet painted them to give to the people of Paris with specific directions on how they should be displayed. What a treasure!

Amazing Museum.. We had been to Paris twice before this visit so we were looking for places and things we had not seen on the previous trips. This small museum fit the bill. It costs 9 Euro each. It is located in the Tuileries Garden near Place de la Concorde. The hours are Wed - Mon 9:00 - 18:00, Closed Tues.On the main floor is Monet's Water Lillies displayed in two oval rooms. The skylights flood the room with natural light. There are 8 large curved panels of Monet's garden at Giverny. They feature different parts of the pond at different times of the day from pre-dawn darkness, to morning light, to late afternoon and to sunset. Monet worked on these paintings for 12 years (1914 - 1926). By this time Claude Monet was nearly blind. A successful eye operation in 1923 gave him new energy. He completed all the panels, but did not live to see them installed here. In 1927, the year after his death these rooms were completed and the canvases put in place. In the underground gallery there are works by Utrillo, Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse & Picasso from the personal collection of art dealer Paul Guillaume. His wife, Domenica Guillaume Walter inherited them after his death. There are benches to sit and admire these famous works. I loved this collection. So nice to be so close to these world famous canvases. I really enjoyed this museum.
Nice if you like Monet. A nice place to spend an hour or so. Well presented, interesting. Nice modern building. Not much more.

Monet's water Lillies. A very small art gallery with 2 whole rooms of the wonderful large panels of Monet's Water Lillies. This is sited at the other end of the Tuillerie Gardens which begin in Front of the Louvre buildings, which are well worth a stroll through on the way.

The water lilies are worth the price. This renovated museum in the Tuileries is a gorgeous building by itself, but seeing Monet's Water Lillies in person makes it well worth the price. The size and detail of the art is amazing. And the additional exhibits downstairs were also worth seeing.

One of our favourites in Paris. This museum has a great collection in a smaller building. It is easier to visit than Le Louvre or Musée D'Orsay and very enjoyable. Apart from the Monet Water Lilies (magnificent) you will see a vast collection of impressionist art. Don't miss the Chaim Soutine's paitings, worth a look!
Amazing Monet paintings. A small but very nice museum. The best part being the huge monet paintings on the first floor. We bought a combined ticket to l'orangerie and musee d'orsay.

Small collection, but the Monet's are a must see. The two newer rooms displaying the large Monet paintings are worth the wait. The rest of the collection is small, but worth seeing. Buy the combined ticket with Musee d'Orsay.

Just wonderful. First you enter and enjoy two large rooms, each with 4 huge Monet water lilies paintings. Then see the large number and high quality works of the other Impressionist and post-Impressionist painters. No line to enter, €9 admission , overall a joy.
A visit to Monet & Cezanne. Monet's water lilies, plus works by Utrillo, Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse, and Picasso. We really enjoyed our visit.

A beautiful experience all the way through. If for nothing else, come and see the water lilies and plan time out to get to sit and watch them. My husband and I had a tight schedule and I wish I would have scheduled at least an hour for just the top floor. Downstairs is also amazing- be sure to read up beforehand all about Paul Guillaume, Jean Walter, and Domenica.

Water Lilies - the high definition version. I'm not an art person. But I know what I like, and I like Monet. This exhibit is not just filled with huge panels of water lilies (HUGE), but he also helped design the gallery space. His purpose was, in his words, a place for the working person to come and relax and get away from the world for a little while. And it works. 10 euro gets you in, zero lines (entrance on the west side, away from the Louvre). Plan on spending an hour in the two galleries, for instance when it's hot outside in the afternoon, and just soak them in. The missing star is because i lost an hour of my life to the rest of the museum. Like I said, I'm not an art person. If you are, and the artists listed on the website work for you, please go and enjoy. As for me, uncouth and unwashed, I was unimpressed to the point of irritation. That's art, I guess. Oh, and Rodan's 'The Kiss' is parked out front of the building as well. Bonus.

For lovers of Monet. The two upper galleries with the Monet wall paintings are breath taking. Sit down and enjoy the enchanting water lily paintings.Downstairs gallery has a wonderful collection of late 19th and 20th century paintings with Renoir, Cezanne,Matisse and Picasso well represented. Well worth a visit.
Monet in 360 degrees. Loved the setting for panels of Monet's water lilies. Peaceful and contemplative first floor. Lower floor has hallways and rooms to explore with spectacular paintings.
Monet. Wonderful to visit this beautiful small museum and see Monet's water lilies as he wanted them displayed. Hardly a line at 4 in the afternoon, and we enjoyed the audio guide as well.

Better Than Expected. We loved Musee de l'Orangerie. It was such a refreshing change from the Louvre. The rooms with Monet's lilys were perfect and were great to see before we traveled to Monet's home and gardens in Giverny. The museum was not over-crowded and the art collection was simply beautiful. I think this museum might be a bit overlooked but I think it should not be missed while in Paris. Plus, it has the best bathrooms in Paris!!!!

Best Monet Exhibit Ever!. I've seen some Monet's in Boston and New York, but this museum had the most beautiful Monet's I've ever seen. The waterlilly's were lovely and transported me to Giverny. The museum is small and the line was short. I didn't get run over by thousands of other tourists and actually got to get up close with the paintings. Lovely!

Must See for Monet Lovers. So impressive to see Monet on the walls of the room. There is an excellent collection of artists from the same general time period and it is an enjoyable walk through the museum.

Beautiful. Well with a visit if only for the two round rooms showing Monet's Nymphéas - beautiful! We didn't see half of what there is to see here as we didn't want to spend too long indoors on a beautiful day but this really is a must-see!
Monet.. Had another great day here some loveley paintings to see. No big lines here waiting very quick getting through even with the security.

Wonderful. To me the best museum in Paris.Underground floor shows artists like Monet, Manet, Modigliani, Rousseau, Matisse ... my favourite.In the ground floor you can deep into the lake covered with water lillies Nymphaneum. There are two oval rooms, you can sit in the middle and enjiy the 360degr view to pure beauty.Unfortunatelly photo is not allowed. After visit to this museum I had to go to Giverny to see the pond with waterlillies by myself.

Awe-inspiring setting for amazing art. I had heard that Monet's water lilies were at L'Orangerie, but that was all. I've seen a couple of large paintings at museums elsewhere - in San Francisco at the Palace of the Legion of Honor, in particular - so I wasn't prepared for the canvases he stitched together into huge panoramic views of color. There are water lilies, sure, but mostly there is color - he painted morning light, afternoon light, and dusk, each with its own palette. As remarkable, though, Monet was instrumental in designing the display rooms, which are two large oval rooms with the paintings curving inside the walls, enabling him to position viewers in front of his work and be surrounded by them. It's like surround-sound but with art. There is plenty of bench space, although you might have to wait a moment for a spot to sit and take in the experience. I was expecting other Monet pieces as well, but there are no other pieces (of Monet's) than the large panoramas. On the lower level is a beautiful exhibit of other Impressionist artists - most notably Cezanne, Renoir and Laurencin, among others - as well as an area for traveling exhibits. The gift shop has lots to choose from related to the Impressionists, but does not sell water. The small café in the museum was closed and the drinking fountains were out of order, so I was forced to get water from the bathroom sink using my cupped hand. That was my only objection to this lovely museum. I'll go again next time we're in Paris - sitting in front of the Monet panoramas is both refreshing and inspiring - but I'll bring my own water.
Monet's water lilies. You can soak in the beauty of these huge murals without fighting big crowds. It is conveniently located near the Louvre. It is a nice interlude.
Wonderful!. This is a little slice of heaven, if you only go to one museum make it this one! Air con is also great!

Monet Monet Monet!. Amazing, wall sized, very very famous Monet paintings. Great to see them in the flesh. If you want to see the Musee D'Orsay as well I'd recommend that you get a joint ticket and go to l'Orangerie first as the queue is shortest. This way you can get into d'Orsay quickly and avoid the big queues.

My Favorite Museum in Paris. Musee de l'Orangerie is a fantastic museum for several reasons. It houses Monet's Nympheas (water lilies) the size of which you cannot believe until you see. The best part - it never seems to be as crowded as the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay.

Magnificent!. Monet, Picasso, Modigliani, Renoir.....one of the best museums in Paris for sure if you adore Impressionism. I really don't like people who came to museum and to not appreciating the rules of museum, particularly the rule of being quiet! The staff is really nice, museum is so well settled. I really like it, I would give it 10 stars if it would be possible :)

Not my kind of museum. Art is completely subjective and recognizing this this museum was not my cup of tea. The museum itself is also not a particularly interesting building either which sometimes can add to the experience. Part of the museum pass so entry was easy. If you like contemplating Monet's water Lillys you've come to the right place

Must See Panels. Well, the Monet panels were all I expected and a little more. The rest of the museum was fine as well.....but back to the panels. I felt like I was scuba diving through Monet's ponds. Just go....and live the experience....no descriptions truly suffice.
Amazing!. A small but STUNNING museum. The Monet water lilies are worth the price of admission, but the rest of the collection is breathtaking.

Somewhere different and not too crowded. Despite being close to the Seine and Musee d'Orsay, this less well known art museum is interesting in many ways. The exhibitions are down at basement levels, with the fist level dedicated to Monet's water lily paintings. For me, the lower floor was more interesting, being the personal collection of an art dealer that exhibited various famous early 20th century artists. Overall it might not have the wow factor of Musee d'Orsay or the Louvre, but it is more personal and doesn't take a half day that is the minimum required to do justice to one of the bigger museums.
