Escape in the middle of the city. This place was such a gem and so memorable. Sitting in the two large rooms surrounded by the water lilies was quite an experience! It was lovely and quiet - which is a very different experience to the Louvre or Musee Dorsay. The visitors were almost reverential of the work as well. Lovely place to sit and quietly contemplate for a while. We had the Paris Visitors card and this was included. Make sure you visit the galleries on the lower floor.

Great gallery.. This is always a lovely gallery to visit. You can sit in awe, looking at the water lilies, for as long as you like, and then wander though the downstairs area as well. All in all, it's a nice compact gallery with some great paintings which can be seen in an hour or two - not exhausting at all. My only reservation this visit was that many paintings were out on loan and there were many gaps. But it's still one of my favourite places to visit. And we didn't even have to wait in line this time - amazing!

You can SKIP it. I live Monet but there is such a thing as too many water lilies. This museum has them all. They do not become more attractive because there are more. There is a good collection of Monet's personal collection of other artists in the basement. But you need to compare that collection to the collections of the Louvre and Musée d'Orsay, both 5 minutes away.
Queues. Lovely place to go, not a big gallery but again, get the Paris museum card, such a bonus for the queues

Monet Water Lily Paintings and More. A great small museum. The Monet Water Lily paintings that were created specifically for the rooms on the ground floor are spectacular. (Go to his house and gardens in Giverney the next day to stand where he stood while painting them). An unexpected treat was the small galleries on the lower floor. Good collection of paintings starting with Impressionists and continuing through early Cubism.
Monet. Excellent collection of Monet. A smaller museum which has a slightly earlier opening time, which makes it perfect to squeeze in before a trip to Muess d'Orsay or the Louvre.

Wonderful place to view Monet's Water lilies. This museum is a special place in that it has some of Monet's best examples of his Water lilies studies.Large paintings which are truely wonderful.also a good exhibtion of the works in the Walter -Guillaume collection.Well woth the visit.
Beautiful Monet's. Use the museum pass to get in. Wonderful painting you will only experience properly here. A must see.
unexpected treasure. no lines. walked right in and blown away. facility built to showcase Monet's garden paintings and it works. the rest is icing.

The Monet Murals. l'Orangerie is a small but stylish gallery on the bank of the Seine in the old orangery of the Tuileries Palace on the Place de la Concorde. Beware it has long queues. Luckily we purchased our ticket in advance at the Paris Visitor centre but we still had to wait at the security line.The art gallery has impressionist and post-impressionist paintings, it is most famous for being the permanent home for eight Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet that are the highlight of the gallery. You can sit and admire the paintings for a long time as it has a hypnotic quality.It also has works by Cézanne, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir, Rousseau as well as others but it is the Monet that are the star attraction.
Monet's Waterlilly Murals. The l'Orangerie is a must see for all Monet lovers. There are two rooms of Monet's murals and the lower floor has many other wonderful paintings.
Amazing!. Monet's waterlily paintings never fail to inspire and amaze in their wonderful oval rooms. Enjoyed the galleries downstairs as well. Always worth a visit.

Nice little museum. It took us about an hour to visit this museum with our kids. We really enjoyed the paintings, especially Monet's Nympheas. The kids got a little bored so it was nice that we could tour the museum quickly.The lines weren't too bad - we had a museum pass and were in after about 10 minutes; others seemed to wait longer.We bought a Nympheas print in the gift shop, seemed to be a good value.

Only go if you have an interest. The l'Orangerie houses Monet's famous paintings of the water lilies. There are other impressive names in the museum as well but it is quite small and if you are not in love with the art it holds (and you are crunched for time) then you may want to skip. However, if you are in love with impressionism or even just Monet it is worth the trip (but keep in mind there is also the Musee D'Orsay with a larger collection and more to look at). I went on a day when admission was free and although I love Monet it helped that I hadn't paid to see such a small museum. I would recommend going when its free if you don't mind waiting in a long line (I would plan on about an hour) and some crowds.
Amazing. I could spend days looking at these paintings. A truly great artist doing such insightful work. A place to stop in a busy city and be uplifted.
Great museum. Great collection of impressionists. Go early. The Monet is astounding. We would go again. The art is displayed well with room to see and enjoy each piece.
A gem. Great because it's not so big and not so crowded. Monet's Water Lillies are amazing, but the museum has much more to offer. A "must visit"!

Heaven. As a Monet fan, I adored this museum. The Nympheas (Water Lilies) are heavenly and I could have spent hours losing myself in them (though my companion was not quite that patient). I wish I could live in a room surrounded by those paintings. The rest of the collection was nice, but it was worth it for the Nympheas alone. (used the museum pass so got through quickly)

Swimming amongst the lillies. Visited Giverny the day before to get the full impressionist view and experience of what he was achieving. This museum truly is a must-see for anyone visiting Paris. The size and scope of the lillies in the adjoining rooms is a sight to behold. Museum also offers numerous paintings by various artists as well.

Small But Worth A Visit. The real reason to go to the Orangerie is to see the two Monet galleries. Well worth it just for that. There are other works on exhibit in this small gallery, all interesting, but go just for the Monets. There's usually no lineup.
Reflective. A beautiful gallery well worth a visit. You can lose yourself in the vast canvases. Sit in the middle of the room and immerse yourself in the pictures.

See the Monet master works!. Most of what is in this museum are in two large oval rooms in which hang Monet's huge multipaneled paintings of his little lake with water lilies. It was a treat to sit there with his master work accomplishments and see how the lake was morning, noon and evening.

Nice addition to a visit to Giverny. We had visited Monet’s home in Giverny then followed up by experiencing the water lily paintings spread over two rooms here. Not as crowded as some of the other museums and well worth the visit.
A hidden gem in a city of huge museums. Monet was ahead of his time creating a 3D effect in his water lily painting. If nothing else see the two oval rooms and feel like you are in the water lilies.

We found the Musee de l'Orangerie after a dusty treck!. We finally made it to this unique Musee and we were glad we did! The unique nature of the art displays makes this a vere worthwhile stop in Paris. Make sure you bring some water as there didn't appear to be anything available onsite. The two Monet rooms were the best places to spend time here.

Beautiful small impressionist museum. Having been to all the big crowded museums, i wanted something smaller but great art. The Monet canvases in the 2 rooms designed for them based on monet's specifications were amazing. There is also art from many other well known impressionists. Worth a visit. Close to the louvre. Museum was full but not overly crowded. There wasn't a line when we went in but there was one when we left.
Amazing Monet. A small but amazing museum, well worth visiting. We purchased the Paris Museum Pass which allows you to Skip The Lines, an added bonus!

More than Oranges Here!. Although the Impressionists used a lot of orange in their art, this is named because it was formerly the orangery, as in green hous for the Emperess Josephine, as in Napoleon's wife who was heavily into plants and plant collecting.Originally converted into a museum to house Monet's circular water lillies masterpieces he bequeathed to the state upon his death, L'Orangery has been extended underground to now house a collection that is as engaging and icon laden as Musee D'Orsay!Every moment here was a joy!Inspiring art, inspiringly and innovatively presented!Don't miss it!
Monet paradise. a smallish museum built especially to exhibit some of Monet's waterlily series, a must see if you love Monet
Not just Monet. The Water Lilies are amazing, but the Musee de L'Orangerie has much more to see. Do not miss the lower level exhibitions. Wow!
A surprise. I was stunned to see the Water Lillies in all their grandeur. It is not a long visit but you really appreciate Monet even more after this experience.

My favorite museum in Paris!. My wife and I honeymooned in Paris, and decided to buy a combo ticket for some of the museums. I wrote a review for the other museum we visited (Musee d'Orsay), so feel free to check that out.There were two combo ticket options: the first was to see the Musee d'Orsay and the Musee Rodin on the same day, or see the Musee d'Orsay and the Musee l'Orangerie within four days of each other. We chose the latter of the two so we could enjoy the works of art.The Musee l'Orangerie is much smaller than some of the other museums in Paris, but it was, hands down, my favorite that we visited. The crowds were much smaller than in the others we toured (d'Orsay and Rodin). What was truly remarkable was the collection of water lilies in their own private few rooms. You could view these gigantic (10+ feet long) works of art in whatever order you would like. They represent all the different times of day that they were painted during. I truly appreciated seeing so many works from the masters - Monet, Cezanne, Picasso, Renoir, and so on. We took about two hours to view the Musee l'Orangerie. We didn't feel rushed at all. I do wish that the museum didn't close when it did. We had just sat down in the movie room to watch a short feature based on Monet's Water Lilly collection.

my favorite art museum. Loves this museum. The Water Lillie were lovely and I loved the story of their installation. The other exhibit we say was wonderful, but it might be temporary. It includes descriptions of the artist and then say 8 examples of their work. It was terrific.

Perfect size and not too crowded. Get there early , beat the crowds, and you will be treated to the greatest impressionist collection in Paris. Takes about 60 to 90 minutes which for us was just the right size collection. We loved it here.

Nice, if you like Monet and impressionist painters. My sister in law recommended I visit the Orangerie for the water lilies murals.
Which were lovely, especially after visiting Monet's Gardens in Giverny 2 weeks earlier. It's a small museum, and if you're not into Monet or impressionists, I wouldn't recommend it.

A sleeper that will rouse you. There is a wonderful surprise waiting the visitor after taking in the two rooms of the ultimate Nympheas. And that is the fine collection of other 20th century artists contained in the other galleries.

Breathtaking. We visited this museum at the end of a walk across the Jardin des Tuilleries. The 2 rooms containing Monet's Water Lillies were breathtaking. I had seen small versions of them, but to be surrounded by the entire panels in an all white room was dramatic and lovely. I developed a new appreciation for Monet and Impressionism. We didn't go to any other part of the museum, but this was sufficient.

Perfect museum for my ADD. I am one of those people where after 2 1/2 hours in any museum, my attention span sputters and everything just starts to blend together. Regardless of all of the priceless treasures, I just can't enjoy it any longer. Sure I love art, but I cannot spend an entire day looking at masterpieces. I need a break in between.With that said, this museum is PERFECT because it is a smaller museum and you can enjoy all of said masterpieces and see the entire museum within 2 1/2 hours as well!Not to mention, it is very refreshing to see and enjoy non-religious art, which is what you'll find in a majority of the other museums in this city. I understand that during certain time periods, it was illegal to paint anything other than Jesus and his crew, but if you're not religious like myself, all of those pieces start to look the same to me (regardless of how magnificent a piece may be).We decided to go to this Museum spontaneously on our last day in Paris so we stood in a 40 minute or so queue. Many people purchased their tickets online and we should have done the same. If you do buy your tickets in advance, you will enjoy very little waiting.Some of the pieces in this museum are priceless and this should definitely be on your list. Sure we loved the Musée du Louvre (overwhelming but a must do) & the Musée d'Orsay, but overall I really enjoyed this museum the best (my wife does not agree for the record).

My favorite museum. Although less well known, I think there were more impressive impressionist paintings here than at the d'Orsay. I was mesmorized by Monet's Waterlilies (having just come from Giverny. Unlike the Orsay, every piece of art was had commentary.
impressionists galore. we loved this because it is a smaller museum and more enjoyable and quieterthe art is gorgeoushighly recommended

Wonderful Museum. It was raining cats and dogs when we went to this museum. We had been here before and enjoyed it. We first went to see the two salons where Monet's Water Lilies were and enjoyed seeing them. Then we saw the 144 Post-Impressionist paintings in the collection. There were really few people and we were able to see them without a problem. I took photos of all the ones that I liked.I will return to this museum in the future. I have to mention I bought my tickets ahead of time at FNAC.

A wonderful collection of Art in the centre of Paris.. Such a lovely Museum of Art, and the real treat is the Monet room at the bottom of the museum. Very unique and shows of the Monet paintings well.The collection of Art sways towards the impressionists and they have some wonderful pieces.Not the biggest gallery, but a lovely chance to see these pieces in real life.Nicely place in the Louvre gardens.

Love it or hate it. I don't really do either. Just so you know what you're getting into - the first floor is just two big oval rooms. There are four paintings in each room of Monet's water lilies. I'm not a huge fan, but they were very nice. People say they can stare for hours - I am not one of those people. But the paintings are huge and very nice, especially if you stand back further.Downstairs are more paintings - Renoir and the like. Decent, but I had seen a lot at D'Orsay already so I was good on that. But it was nice. Worth maybe 30-45 minute wait or so? If longer, don't bother unless you really, really like Monet and need to see this.

Must see. I wanted to see Monet's Water lilies and it was amazing!
It is a must see! Monet was a genius!
I liked his pictures before this visit as well, but these pictures are really unbelievable!

Breathtaking Monet. I arrived very early for the museum opening in order to be first in line. With my museum pass, I rushed in when the doors opened and was able to spend time with Monet's waterlillies alone.
It was surreal. Definitely one of the highlights of my life.

Great little museum. Rick Steves suggested we would need only 1 hour, but we wished we had had more. The water lillies alone are 'worth the price of admission', but the rest of the collection is nearly as good. Having just toured the Village of Montmartre that morning, it was great to see some of the lesser known painters, who painted some of the vistas we had seen.

A Monet Tragic's Nivarna. My wife is a Monet tragic and on for some reason which evades us we missed it on three previous trips to Paris. This time around it was given high priority which means if we missed it again my life would not be worth living. With this in mind on the last Sunday in June we were off early for the short walk from our hotel to the Musee de l'Orangerie arriving just after the doors opened. This early start warranted the effort as to fully appreciate Monet's two rooms of his 360 degree Water Lily's Series you really need time and to sit in the room's central seating to view it at it's optimum. The series are Claude Monet's gift to the French Nation for the World War 1 Victory and a testament to what is good in humans. Beside the Monet Rooms there are other galleries which are also well worth viewing and a Gift Shop well stocked with books detailing the collection. Before we left we revisited the rooms but the moment had gone because the rooms were crowded and unable to fully appreciated. The look on my wife's face was testament to her seeing her Monet Nirvana. This is a must see but please visit early to see it as it deserves to be seen.

This is much more than the Water Lillies. This museum is known for the 2 rooms of Monet's Water Lillies. Those 2 rooms are very impressive but you must wander into the basement where you'll be very impressed with an incredible collection of impressionist and post impressionist art. You won't be disappointed at this museum if you love paintings.
Great for Impressionists lovers!. Small but powerful museum. Monet at his best--the full panels of the the Water Lilies. Quite restful after the Louvre.

A Small and Authentic museum. Monet's water lily's series is showcased here with a astonishing 360 degree view of them. It is small, but you will enjoy every inch of it. Other impressionist and modern artists are here as well, but if you are a Monet lover or appreciate his art, this is the place.Tip: you can get a discount admission if you purchase for both Musee d'Orsay & Orangerie museums.

Tranquil water lilies - Monet's masterpieces. We arrived just at opening time to bask in Monet's masterpieces before the crowds arrived. There are two oval rooms with four Monet panels (waterlilies, and willow trees) with natural lighting and benches in the center, so that you can study the lighting and brushstrokes, etc. peacefully. (Warning: no photography allowed, and no talking above a whisper or you will be 'shushed'!) Downstairs featured other Impressionist paintings - overall, a lovely way to spend an hour in a beautiful museum.

Highlight of my trip to paris!. The water lilies took my breath away. Dont talk or think, just sit and breathe and let the emotion and beauty wash over you. If you have small children please dont bring them. It is meant to be enjoyed in silence and talking or screaming children (or adults that act like children) really takes away from the enjoyment of others. I wish the staff would be active in maintaining a tranquil environment, almost took a star off for that, but just cant because everyone must see this!!
Water Lilies. The only reason you'd go here is to see the water lillies, but it was well worth the visit. There are a few other interesting artists displayed, but you can see those elsewhere.

Most pretentious museum. We went to this museum for the Monet waterlilies and other impressionists, but the culture of the museum drove us out within 20 minutes. The person who admitted us frowned at our Paris Museum Pass and acted like we were wasting her time. Someone softly said "it's beautiful" when looking at the water-lilies and was shushed like a child. If you are the type to sit and absorb a painting in complete silence then this is your place.

Great way to see the Monet pieces. Small museum located in Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde. Very easy to visit and in an hour or two. You could easily sit and look at the Monet's Water Lily paintings.

Tranquility and beauty all in one. This might be one of the smaller museums (great as it is not as crowded as the others, so you have more time to spend with every piece) in Paris but it houses 8 large Monet's that are in two large oval rooms that make the shape of infinity. The room prior to entering the first oval is especially designed to be empty and the rooms use only natural light. There is seating in the middle of the ovals so you are able to sit and absorb the beauty of these immense masterpieces. Make sure to get the audio guide as most of the pieces in the museum have an audio description. The museum has a great collection of paintings by Chaim Soutine. This was the first time that I ever came across this artist and I was pleasantly surprised. As you stare at one, intending to move to the next one, you realize that there is a lot more depth than what you first see. The artist uses bold colors, but grabs your attention with the distorted shapes of the people and objects. Soutine' emotions are clearly shown as his paintings often reveal a tormented soul.

Monet wonderland. My wife loves Monet so she says give it an excellent. It certainly was fascinating to see the large displays of lily pads. The art downstairs was interesting. For those lovers of impressionism, you can't go wrong.

Nympheas forever. Don’t miss this true gem in the center of Paris, at the corner of the Tuileries gardens and by the river Seine.The impressionnists’ paintings by Cezanne, Manet, Degas and Utrillo are beautiful, and this is most famously the home to the Nympheas, by Claude Monet. A pure wonder!!!

The water lilies. The reason to come here. Apparently Monet designed these rooms as places of quiet contemplation....you're unlikely to experience that unless you come early & in mid winter. Nonetheless, it is absolutely extraordinary and not to be missed.

Could Improve. I/We visited in the morning, it was busy, on the side of the ramp going up the were explanations of the various pictures and techniques which were almost unreadable because such was the angle of the glass you had the sun reflected in to your eyes. You could tell the majority of the paying customers were not French! So why was no attempt made to have any explanations in languages other than French? When traveling else- where you normally find at least English and one other language, but not here. The main rooms were excellent more the better when you read that they were all done in different light conditions, I found the lower area lest interesting but as a snap shot art gallery it was interesting especially as the crowds were much less intense than all the other main art galleries.

Impressionism and Water Lillies. I am a huge Monet fan, devotee - so for me it was an amazing experience...after walking through the Tuilleries, watching the old men race their yachts on the Bassin, this oval space awaits like a cool oasis. Then there's everyone else - yet another overload of incredible works of art that inspire one to see the world differently, and to smile, and to wonder. For my partner, who is not into impressionism....he enjoyed it very much, but would have preferred less time...but again, you've bought your Museum pass, so time really doesn't matter.
Monet. If you like Monet, you will love being here. Small but gives you a chance to dream. Then walk through the Tulleries.

Small Museum with Many Great Works. Musee de l'Orangerie was a lot smaller than I expected but has Monet's Waterlilies, many Renior's and a good selection of Derain. I arrived at opening time and it wasn't too croweded then. I was able to go directly in as I had a Museum Pass. I would imagine it would get rather crowded later in the day so it would be ideal to go early.The museum has banned photography, which I appreciate as tourists with camera are the most annoying and inconsiderate in galleries.

First time visit. We have been to Paris many times but this was the first time that we visited the de l'Orangerie. What a wonderful surprise. Just go and be inspired by all the great artwork including Monet's full wall garden paintings which take up 2 rooms.

A Highlight. I loved this museum. We got there when it opened at 9A. Hardly anyone was there. We could sit and take in Monet's water lilies framed in two oval rooms. It's beautiful.Downstairs was a surprise. There were several impressionist paintings by famous artists: Renoir, Van Gogh, Picasso, Cezanne, and more. Since there wasn't hardly anyone there, you could really soak all the beautiful art in.When we were leaving (after 1-1.5 hours) there was a line to get in. Don't miss this one....a fraction of the crowds of d'Orsay and very nearby. Easy to find on the west side of Tuillery Gardens.We had the museum pass so we walked right in.

Beautiful collection of Monet's panoramic water lily paintings. If you're a fan of Monet, definitely go the the Musee de L'Orangerie. There are two rooms which house several of his huge paintings of gardens and water lilies, and other rooms downstairs which contain paintings by other impressionist artists like Degas, Renoir etc. You can see the collection in about 2-3 hours.

Monet, Cezannes and Rubins. The Water Lilies are -in my opinion- the best work of art every done. To take them in you need to sit down and just stare at the works for several minutes; only in this way can you take in the detail and colours.And when you consider the best Cezannes and Rubins are also here this is a can't miss.
Wonderful impressionists.. The museum was wonderful. Need to go to the top floor through the coffee shop for the best room. Van Gogh special exhibit was great!

I went for the Monet. I have always been a Monet fan, and wanted to see Les Nympheas in person. It did not disappoint. The day we went was fairly rainy, so I think that helped in that it was not overly busy. We purchased the museum passes (which I highly recommend), so went from museum to museum during our stay in Paris. Of course, there is much more to see than just Monet, and we enjoyed strolling through the galleries and taking in everything. An interesting an varied collection. The Museé d'Orsay is great, but I think I enjoyed L'Orangerie more (the sculpture in d'Orsay should not be missed though).

Monet Masterpieces. Not to be missed if you love Monet, especially his Water Lilies. A spectacular display of his most famous art works, in a gorgeous setting. Won't take long to see it, and you will be glad you did.

Lovely and Small. Tucked into a corner near the Place de la Concorde, l'Orangerie is a small and very manageable experience. Quiet on most days (we lucked into the one "free admission" day a month, so it was very crowded), it is a pleasant way of viewing some early modern works, including those by Modigliani, Picasso and Rousseau. Most lovely are two simple rooms, where you can sit peacefully surrounded by Monet's murals of water lilies.

Nature ..ah. Visited this museum last week . If you Monet you will love the display . The whole area ,the garden and statues there are so beautiful . The grandeur of the place ,makes one experience the openness and aesthetics . . Sunday there is no ticket . It was the highlight of my trip . Just mesmerized by that whole area . Easy to reach by metro . Not to be missed . Enchanting
Fab photography exhibition. Exhibition was blown up black & white photographs from the 1st world war. Photo quality was excellent & the exhibition was extremely interesting -& free

Enough for a non art person. I went here on my holiday and enjoyed it.It took me only about an hour to see it all and there was no waiting to get in.I saw some paintings from famous artists without the crowds of the bigger galleries.I saw enough to make me realize I am not an art lover.
Water lillies. If you're passionate about seeing Monet's 'water lillies' in real life then go, otherwise skip it. I was, however, shocked at how large these murals are!
MONIFICENT. To see the collection of Monet's was a sheer delight. Sit own and take each one in. The visit was unforgettable and a highlight of the trip to Paris.

Small, excellent museum. The museum is accessible and well organized. The Monet water lilies are classics not to be missed. The rest of the museum was also interesting. Entrance lines are (understandably) long.

Beautiful Renoir and Monet pieces. I had not expected to find this museum so delightful. The centrepiece is Monet's waterlillies, of which I had seem numerous examples previously and gotten bored, but these were breathtaking and refreshing. The museum has an extensive collection of little known but exquisite Renoirs, along with many Cezanne pictures, and a variety of other post-Impressionists and beyond (the Utrillos were in particular attractive). Compared to other museums, I will say the audioguides were of less interest than usual. This museum can be done in several hours.
Monet on Steroids. This is a must-see place for Monet fans and art lovers in general. It's right across from Musee D'Orsay and can be visited in a couple of hours vs several days for Le Louvre.
Monet Monet Monet. Not to be missed! This is the most immersive exhibition of Monet's Water Lilly paintings. An absolute MUST!
Monet at his best. This is really Monet at his best, Nice prequel to a Giverny trip! Monet was brilliant, and to think that he painted with cataracts....
Definitely worth a visit!. Really enjoyed viewing the impressionists. I would definitely recommend a visit to the l'Orangerie and D'Orsay museums!
Be Still My Heart. This museum is small enough to walk through leisurely and enjoy it all. It has some of my favorite artists and a peaceful atmosphere to view them in.
The place to see Monet's Water lilies. Lovely small art gallery housing massive Monet paintings, and other impressionist works. Well worth a visit. We bought a joint ticket with The Musee d'Orsay.

This just became my favourite museum. The round white rooms filled with natural light really show off Monet's water lillies - I could have stayed for hours. We came just to see the 2 round rooms, so were really pleasantly surprised at the lower level which we also loved.This museum is small and a beautiful building and that just adds to the charm of it in my opinion. It was great to be able to go to a museum and see everything (and not be so overwhelmed with its size)If you love impressionism and Monet, this museum is a must.

Extra money well spent. When you go to the D'Orsey they have a combination ticket that will get you into the Orangerie, too. It is only a few euros more, but very well worth it. Monet's water lily panels are in there, along with a wonderful collection of drawings and watercolors. Don't miss it.

My favorite art museum in Paris. Yes, the Louvre and Orsay are amazing. However they're also overwhelming. That's why the l'Orangrie appealed to me the most. Just the right amount of art to take in and works from some of my favorite painters. I was in awe by the panels and panels of Monets. I could sit there and look at them for hours. A wonderful experience!

Downstairs is more interesting IMHO.. The LOML - Love Of My Life - really wanted to go here and check out the main attraction. The 8 massive canvases of Monet. They were nice. Call me uncultured, call me unrefined, whatever, I think that art is in et eye of the beholder and while they were nice and pretty spectacular due to their size, I actually found that the other artwork that was downstairs, to be of a greater interest to me. I liked seeing the slightly different styles of the various artists that also seemed to build and reflect off of each other. With the wider variety, of art downstairs, I personally found it to be of a greater interest to me. Go and decide for yourself … If you agree, vote this as helpful :-) LOL.

For Monet lovers. After visiting Monet's Garden at Giverny we had to see the water lilies at Musee L'Orangerie. To sit in silence and look at each panel was relaxing and thought provoking. You could spend lost time just in reflection of the beauty of the paintings in the round.Bonus was the exhibition below the stairs, but really it is all about Monet for us, a peaceful museum that was not packed with tourists like the Louvre. Go early as no queues.

My favorite Museum. While not offering the huge collection as the Louvre, the building is a wonderful piece of art in itself. The collections are very good and the movement from room to room is quite easy. As you enter and look out over the museum floor, the view is wonderful. Obtain a museum pass and you avoid the long lines as you are provided a separate and faster entrance without the wait.

Monet's nympheas ❤️. Those people who love imeressionism and Claude Monet have to go to the l'orangerie museum. There are realy fantastic works from Monet, which are represented on the round white rooms of the museum. I am realy impressed with nympheas

Nothing special. If you are not the fan of Monet's waterlillies, this place is not for you. For impressionists go better to Musee d'Orsay. If you want to visit Orangeri, it's better to start from it, because after Louvre and Orsay it's absolutely unimpressive(

great little museum. After spending time in the Louvre and the Orsay, a stop at this museum is a wonderful break. The size is manageable and the display of the waterlilies extraordinary. Although we cam for them, the downstairs that houses a number of other impressionist paintings was a real bonus.
Beautiful Museum and Water Lillies. Wonderful museum in the Tuilleries Gardens that has the most wonderful collection of Monet's Water Lillies. Beautiful setting

Waterlilies. A place of tranquility, the mammoth Monet's are wonderful.
Other artists displayed on floor below, definitely worth going.

Changing seasons.....the Lillies...as seen by Monet. small wonderful museum ..the private collection is fabulous...you have never seen some of these paintings...easy to manage time wise....do not need to buy tickets in advance EXCEPT on holidays..if it is open....closed Tuesday
Superb, relaxed and you won't get lost. This is a delightful museum which is easy to get around and not too overwhelming - though of course Monet's waterlilies are spectacular.

Worth the visit after Giverny gardens. I recommend to visit the Monet Gardens in Giverny first, then complete it all with a visit to L'Orangerie. Visit the furthermost room through the LEFT door and you will be baffled with the atmosphere and impression instantaneously. Buy your ticket beforehand to skip long queue. Only disadvantage is too many people and noise.
Loose yourself in Monet. This is a must see museum - I was lost just sitting and taking in the beauty of Monet - i felt transported in those amazing paintings

Musée de l'Orangerie. This is the only museum where Monet's waterlilies can be appreciated in their full beauty in the curved versions that adorn the walls. The Nazis looted the Orangerie but most of the paintings have been found and returned.

Water Lilies. I was overwhelmed to see Monet's famous water lilies - it is worth a visit, of coarse there are many other pieces of beautiful artwork. The surrounding Jardin des Tuileries is a great place to relax if you arrive by late morning you won't have a problem finding a chair near the fountain.
Very nice. Not my favourite museum, but great in that it is very quick to cover and then continue on one's way.

Excellent collection very well curated. The renovation of l'Orangerie seems very good and on the day we went it didn't seem crowded although I suspect it was - this is usually a good indication of how well thought out the curation and the building design.The collection was very good and very well curated - it told it's story well. My only slight criticism is that I think it should almost force a start with the overview of Guillaume and how his collection came to pass. It's there but you could easily miss it. And this section should also be in English as well as French as it is key to the whole experience IMO.

Great museum. The bottom floor is fantastic - with the Renoirs and other paintings. The upper floor (water paintings) - the paintings seem a bit dark - as though with soot built up on them. Maybe my expectations were too high...

Monet at his finest. My husband and I had the Paris Pass, so we went to this museum mostly to see the two Monet waterlily rooms. We were not disappointed--the experience was unlike any other I've had at a museum; being completely surrounded on all sides by such beautiful artwork almost made me feel like I was standing in Monet's world.The rest of the museum I could take or leave. There were other impressionist/modern paintings, but they did not rival the artwork in the Musee d'Orsay. I do tend to prefer Classical and Renaissance art, so definitely keep that in mind as you read this review.If you have the Paris Pass, bought a combo ticket with the Orsay, or love Monet, go. Otherwise, I would suggest considering whether the ticket is worth the 9 euro and the long entrance line.
Go for the Monet panels. We stumbled across l'Orangerie as we wandered back to our hotel. Worth a visit to see a Monet in the round.

A hidden treasure. Monet's waterlillies in a peaceful setting was a highlight of my last trip. I had missed it on my other trips and just discovered it this last one. Need relaxation and refreshment after a busy day of sightseeing? It's included on the Pass Musee.

Remodel loses the flavor of the old building. I'm sure that the museum is happy with this modern building and proud of themselves for putting it up but it loses the warmth of the previous building. All the wood and windows made it look like an orangerie.Seating for longer viewing of Monet's light studies not as convenient as before.
Must see!. If you love Monet, you must go to this museum! The museum was in part built around a few very large Monet' of his garden, the water lilies. Beautiful !
Most amazing Monets ever painted!. This is not to be missed if you are an Impressionistic art fan. These Monets were specifically painted just for this building. They are amazing!
What an amazing place!. First of all you can see so many amazing pieces of art in two hours! Love this place! And it is so nice that it is next to the Tuileries gardens!

More than We Expected. We heard about Monet's large format Waterlilies series, and came to see this. They were as wonderful and spectacular as we had hoped, definitely worth a visit. We did not know about the other paintings in the museum, these were fantastic. Under-rated museum, fantastic Impressionist and post-Impressionist collection worth a visit.

Highlight of my trip. This small museum contains the treasures of Monet's waterlily paintings. There are 8 room size paintings and you can see the shifting light and colors he captured in each one. I spent time sitting in each room gazing at the way the colors change and it was a peaceful place to enjoy art. The paintings of Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso are also downstairs. They also had a temporary exhibit downstairs with sketches from many artists. The park outside is a delight and you can enjoy people watching. I brought a picnic lunch.
Heavenly colours and water lilies. I loved Mone's colours, all the various artists works displayed and the fact that it was not so crowded. Very worthwhile to visit.

Short and sweet. We didn't have advance tickets and only had to wait about 20 minutes to get in. It's small and you can see the whole thing in less than an hour. Worth checking out IF you're in the area.

The best. If you are a fan of the Impressionists this museum is a must. The range and quality of its holdings are simply the very best. We made this visit in June and this is not the ideal time to do so since there are simply too many visitors to really appreciate the works presented. Previously we visited in the off season and had a very much better time of it. Our recommendation is avoid June and I guess July visits if at all possible.

Small and Delightful. I'm not an art buff, but I've always felt you did not need to be to really appreciate impressionism - and this museum is chock full of impressionist and near impressionist works! Some pieces are most typical of the style, with shapes drawn together by careful dashes of color, and others are more defined pre-, early, and even some post-impressionist works. I am not sure if this is the case, but I felt like there was some other non-impressionist works there too, which I only note as this museum was presented to me as centered on impressionism.Regardless of the exact taxonomy of the works contained, everything flows terrifically from one to the next in carefully curated rooms. Even though I was tired by the time we got to this museum, I was quite happy to visit each of the show spaces in the museum. In fact, this ability to really control the flow of your visit is an advantage for a small museum like this over a larger one, like the Louvre.Monet's Nymphéas, a two chamber exhibit of eight paintings of water lilies set up to the artist's requirements, is definitely the stand out piece to see. Unfortunately, while these pieces would be spectacular in a moment of quiet contemplation, Paris is one of the busiest tourist sites in the world, and it can be difficult to find the best view for any of one of the paintings. It is a testimony to both Monet and the Musée de l'Orangerie that, despite the hum of the people, Nymphéas still can be an emotionally powerful piece.In general, if you like art or impressionist art specifically, this museum is well worth the price of admission. If you're less arty or but like to see some truly unique displays, checking out the Nymphéas can still make this trip worth it. This museum is pretty much a must see if you have a Paris Museum pass!

Jewel Box of a Museum. Spectacular display of Monet's Waterlillies plus wonderful work by Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, etc. in a manageable space. No one goes berserk in this small and beautiful place. Great place to expose the kids to incredible art without overwhelming them.

A hidden treasure. While the Louvre and Orsay are great, visiting some smaller museums should be on your itenerary. We absolutely loved L'Orangerie. The smaller scope and scale make for a much more relaxing visit. And the prohibition on picture taking makes the crowds flow efficiently. The Waterlillies rooms are absolutely breathtaking. The scale and the beauty of Monet's canvases (which were designed specifically for this building) should not be missed. Admission to L'Orangerie was free with the museum pass.
Do not miss!. Great museum. Beautiful installations. The Monet murals are outstanding. The collection of his contemporaries terrific. Could spend the day there.

Small but good!!!. The Monet's were amazing but remember no photos! There are also some nice Picasso's as well. It's located in a great area, after we left we just sat in the park for a while to rest and people watch.

Great Little Museum. With the museum pass this is free to enter. It's sort of nice to go to a smaller museum after the enormity of the Louvre. Very impressive collection of paintings and to hear the story of the art collector who brought them together.

Nice museum. We came here on a rainy day. Lots to see and we really enjoyed the Van Gogh exhibit they had. Unlike the Louvre, they do not want anyone taking any pictures. I understand no flash, but I do enjoy getting a few pics of the actual interior of the building (it was very pretty).

Great Small Museum. Very close to the Louvre. In the Jardin de Tuileries this is a great museum. There are two rooms with enormous Monet canvases on display in a circular fashion. The museum has other great painting in the basement including a joint exhibit with the Musee d'Orsay. If you have the Paris Museum pass you can skip past the ticket line and enter the museum.

Fantastic.. Go and see this superb Monet exhibition if you're in Paris.There are also wonderful Renoir and other artists in the collection. It was a great value option for seeing art close up and not crowded.
Monet, Monet, Monet. If you like Monet, I would not miss this one. The museum is amazing. We thoroughly enjoyed the water lilies. If you are into Impressionist painters, you will enjoy this one.
exhibit of 1st WW. in this rather empty building they had a great exhibition of items and photograpghs of France and the 1st World war.Worth a visit when in parque Luxembourg anyway

A Must for Monet Fans. We walked through the Tuileries to visit this museum on a beautiful June day in Paris. It was a lovely walk and a nice transition from the hustle-bustle of Paris to the tranquility of the enormous Monet canvases on display. Give yourself time to just sit and absorb the beauty of the works. The museum has other work, of course, but the main attraction are the Monet's. If you have the Paris Museum pass, be sure to use it here and skip past the ticket line.

Ahhhhhh!. If you like water colors, this is the place for you. Just go inside into the first room and sit down and take in the around the whole room layout of Monet's beautiful water colors. There are also many other beautiful paintings around the museum. It's also located right near the Tullierrie's Gardens so it's a nice stop after stopping by the gardens. Enjoy this little oasis of calm from the crazy streets of Paris.

Not value for money. I had never made a visit to this Musee. Having been to all the others more than once I did not require the multiple attraction ticket. The cost of the ticket to visit this Musee alone is 9,00€. It is tiny, and not to take away from Monet's stunning Water Lilies (Les Nymphéas) shown in two oval rooms, just too expensive. There are a couple of nice Renoirs too but that is all. This is a 30 minute attraction. DO NOT get the audio guide (5,00€) - you just don't need it.Recommend including it with a multiple musee ticket.

A marvelous experience.. Briefly viewing a myriad of major works at a large and complex venue, for example the Louvre, is certainly grand. Counterpoint is a few hours with both the intimacy and grace of the Monet lilies at L'Orangerie. The grandeur and scope of these works at an intimate distance is remarkable. Even more transporting is the close experience of the brush strokes, touches of color, and tiny markings of Monet, as though the artist had added a few touches earlier that morning, then stepping back to reverberate with the entirety of the work. Profound and fulfilling experience. Followed by a leisurely walk along the Seine to a bistro to reflect. A perfect Parisian afternoon.

Monet lovers- you have to see this!!!!!!. I suggest that you go to Monet's gardens in Giverny before going to the l'orangerie to see his work. This smaller building next to the Seine was much easier to get in.It is a must-see to enable you to embrace the full perspective of this famous impressionist artist. You won't regret the time you spend here taking away memories that will last your lifetime.

A must see in Paris. We kept missing the Orangerie, either it was closed for refurbishment or we didn't seem to have the time but this time we made sure that it was on our list and we were not disappointed but it can get crowded so you need to get your timing right, which seemed to do, by luck. The Monet's are stunning.
A tranquil museum!. Fantastic and not mobbed with visitors, giving one the chance to contemplate the amazing Monet's in peace.

A gem often overlooked. Many people want to see the Impressionists when they come to Paris and think that they have to head to the Musée d'Orsay (which is excellent but quite large and often with large queues). Take a moment to visit the Orangerie for a more intimate experience with Monet and his "Water Lilies" (among other works). The Orsay it is not, but it is certainly a wonderful museum

Only for art fans. If you are not a Monet fan or a fan of the current temporary exhibit there are many better museums. Yes the Lillies were incredible in such a large format, but this can be skipped if you are short on time.

Can you say Monet???. An outstanding approach to displaying those iconic masterpieces! I had read Tripadvisor reviews so I had expected to see these glorious works showcased so perfectly. Even so, I was still blown away when I actually saw them, bathed in the lovely Parisian light from above. This is a lesser-known venue but certainly deserving of a visit!

If you love Impressionist you must go to the Orangerie. This was a great museum. It was smaller and more intimate than the Louvre and Orsay. Much less crowded so, it was much easier to walk around and view the works.

Must see if you are interested in Impressionism. Monet's Waterlillies in two versions line the walls of the two major rooms of this museum. It is interesting that in the second version you can get a better sense of perspective because the trees are shown. Good collection of impressionist art on the lower floor as well.
2 words: Monet's Nympheaus. If you are a Monet fan, this is a must. A small museum that doesn't require forever to see.. The exhibits in here are awesome. Very beautiful works of art. A must see.

Favorite Museum. Visiting this museum and seeing Monet's Water Lillie's was definitely a highlight of our Paris experience. Housed in two rooms, the paintings should be savored and contemplated for maximum enjoyment. Take your time and marvel at the work of a master nearing the end of his life.
paintings. Painting are well done and well displayed. Less crowded than the other major museums. Next to the Tuileries. Get the Museum Pass, it is worth it.

Didn't make it in..restricted hours beware. We tried twice to see this museum upon a high recommendation from friends who live outside of Paris...but, days closed and short hours didn't permit...BUT!....my consultation came in the form of Rodin sculptures surrounding the grounds!....beautiful, amazing and redemptous!

Wonderful smaller museum!. Wonderful smaller impressionist museum---well known for the large scale Monet water lillies painting! So lovely to be surrounded with this art. The rest of the museum contains small exhibits of other great artists--Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso. The audio guide was superb too.
I highly recommend a visit!

Relaxing experience, if you go at the right time. Monet's artwork is gorgeous, and it is absolutely stunning. I sat in there for almost an hour just looking at how beautiful it all was. The key is to go when there are not too many tourists, and that will make your experience more relaxing.It is possible to buy a combination ticket at Musee D'Orsay which will save you money and time when coming here.

A must visit for art lovers!. This was a terrific museum for anyone interested in art and educational for children as well. it's focus on Impressionest artists and a beautiful design that was easy to navigate,made it especially appealing to us. It was not as overwhelming as the Orsay or the Louvre but plan to spend 1-2 hours here. Very enjoyable!

Charming Little Museum. Overshadowed by much larger museums in Paris, I think this a great little place to go. It features interesting works by artists in the lower level but by far the main attraction are the giant water lillies Monet painted at the end of his artistic efforts specifically for this museum. The works are on circular walls with plenty of seating for you to sit and gaze at them. If you love Monet this is a must see.

If you Love Monet's water lilies, visit here. Absolutely breathtaking to sit in the two oval rooms displaying Monet's water lily murals. This museum is not overly crowed and you can sit and admire these stunning pieces.

Most beautiful art installation. While the Orangerie is smaller than the Orsay, it contains the incredibly lovely offering to peace that Monet gave to France--the eight panel water lilies paintings that he painted as his gift to the nation after the slaughter of WW1. While jabbering tour guides can break the mood, load some running brook sounds on your smartphone, sit and just absorb these 8 panels--different views of Monet's gardens at dawn, midday, afternoon and dusk, lit by the natural light flowing through the ceiling.And then visit the modern art collection of Paul Guillaume. Stunning.

must see although most people don't know about it. what to say, only Monet-haters should not go there. if you like his work you will enjoy his larger-than-life paintings of the pond.take your time and look at them long. you will see more and more details. After a while your feet might even get wet ;)

Monet's waterlily panoramics. As huge of a Monet fan as I am, I don't think this is worth standing in line for more than 1/2 an hour for. The paintings are beautiful and in the perfect setting for them. But sometimes the lines are really long and you could be spending that time at the Orsay.
Waterlilies. Need I say more?. The museum overall is nice, but the waterlilies are beautiful. The shape of the room, the light and the ability to feel yourself at Giverney is worth the trip.

Favorite Museum in Paris. The Paris Museum pass would certainly save you time here, but the line wasn't too long - 1 hour. We loved this museum because it's manageable in its size and you can take your time with all the great works without being too exhausted. The water lily murals are as amazing as everyone tells you - so beautiful! If you love Impressionists, get the combo pass with the Orsay to save time in line there.

Wow, those Monets!. The two Monet rooms are so fabulous, I will never forget the experience. A big plus is that it was not crowded. I counted 50 people (only!) in one of the big Monet rooms. There's a big sofa where many people can sit and look at the paintings in a restful way.

Remarkable!. So many museums are enormous and overwhelming. But that's not the case at L'Orangerie. We attended (no charge on our day to visit-Saturday) L'Orangerie because of the Monet exhibit...our favorite. We quickly observed that numerous other masters were on display, also. You will be thrilled. An entire series of oval rooms were dedicated to Monet. The works were extraordinary. In under 2 hours we had seen everything slowly and methodically. This museum is a nugget of gold, and a must see located in the center near the Place de Concord. Go early when they open..for us about 11 AM. Easy in and out. Remarkable experience.
The place to see Monet's lilies. What a wonderful spot -- one can take pics but not of the lily walls. It's on the museum pass -- so you can bypass any long lines.
My favorite museum in Paris. I enjoyed our visit to l'Orangerie as much as the Louve and D'Orsey! Claude Monet is brilliant. To see his work displayed in a setting he designed is a treat.

Best of the best. The Water Lilies must be experienced in the two wonderful oval galleries conceived by Monet himself. The basement galleries are traditional but completely packed with extraordinary works.The Paris Museum pass will eliminate most waiting.

Need to see...and it won't take much time.. The sweeping oval rooms of Monet, with their sense of the infinite are one of the highlights of Paris. This won't take much of your time, so make it a priority to squeeze it in. Even if you are tired after the L'Ouvre it fits.

Peaceful, as if you are in the gardens of Monet itself.. Walking distance from the Metro station Concorde and the Place de la Concorde (Devil wears prada scene), is the Musee de l'orangerie. It houses Claude Monets infamous waaterlilies painting. With a paris museum pass, you can skip the lines. We went on a early april morning and got seats at the center of the room and had a nice 360 view of the paintings. There is a sense of serenity in the calmness of the painting and the noiseless ambiance of the rooms they were housed in.
small, quaint, and worth your time.. I had never heard of this little museum until i read about it on trip advisor. What a lovely museum to visit. Go early because I think it will get very crowded.
Tiny Museum with Quality. If you like Monet, this is the place for you. In addition there are many other powerful paintings to visit. Compact but very worthwhile. Lots of seating to enjoy paintings.

Not Just For Monet. Our main goal when we decided to visit this museum was to see the Monet's giant work of water lillies. But when we went there, we discovered that there is a lot more to discover in this lovely museum. The Walter-Guillaume collection was as impressive as Monet's water lillies.Though there was a long line at the entrance (not long when compared with that of Louvre or d'Orsay thoug), thanks to our museum pass, we did not wait at all. We did the tour ourselves, we did not even need audio guide. As the crowd was not large, we could spend as much time as we wanted in front of the paintings and other art exhibits. It's not allowed to take pictures inside.In case you have very limited time to spend in Paris and you still want to visit at least one museum, this one will be a great choice.

Peaceful and worth a visit. My #1 tip for this museum: Go during lunch. We have found that there are no lines and the place is nearly empty. This is not like many other museums in Paris in that it is not loaded with a ton of art. But it is great for spending a long time just looking at the wonderful Water Lilies and relaxing.

fun exhibit. This is a museum I could have stayed in all day! I absolutely loved the "Water Lilly" exhibit by Monet. My younger daughters however did not and were bored within a couple of minutes of sitting in the room. We enjoyed the other artist that are on display in other parts of the museum. My daughters were happy to play on the grounds outside of the museum. Again I loved this museum and it was worth making it a part of our trip.
Huge Monet paintings!. You don't need a huge amount of time here. Worth stopping just to see the Monet's. Definately have your museum pass, it could save you some time here.
Well worth visiting. Well displayed and interesting collections. The queues can be long, but the space inside is large and you don't feel over crowded.

Do not miss this!. A smaller museum than most and no lines. Covered with the Paris Museum Pass. This is an amazing museum and the Monet panels were astonishing. I was very suprised and the history of how these were commissioned and painted is well worth reading prior to going. No need for the audio tour. Just get Rick Steve's Paris book which gives you all the info you need.

A musée not to be missed. This is a must see museum if you like Monet's water lilies... They are very large paintings and worth a visit. The rest of the collections are interesting. I am not an art buff but I did enjoy going too this museum. The Paris Pass makes it very easy to go to and skip the lines. Great museum and it does not take a lot of time to go through.
do not miss it. Located in the Tulleries,it is a must see for Monets water lilies.They are so breath taking that they built this museum for these 8 paintings!

Worth to go to see the water lillies. Even though I am not a big Monet fan, I was very impressive by the large water lillie paintings here. The rest of the collection was interesting and worth a visite. They had a exhibition of drawings as well at the time we were there which was really great.

Worth it if you have a museum pass.. I think everyone goes here to see the big Monet's. They were quite beautiful, but the museum seemed to be in a bit of disrepair, compared to other Parisian museums. I'm not a huge art buff, but I know a bit. Like I said, if you have a museum pass and you can skip the line, this is a no brainer as it is a small museum you can get through rather quick and then stroll through the gardens after.

Calm, quiet in the heart of Paris. The main attraction here is Monet's massive canvases of water lilies (Les Nymphéas), but the rest of the museum is a manageable size for a quiet afternoon. We found that the crowds thinned out and everything became quieter after we left Monet's paintings. It seemed that many people came only to see Monet; don't cheat yourself! The rest of the collection is wonderfully rich, with many late 19th-and 20th-century painters well-represented---Renoir, Matisse, and Picasso, among others.

Bite size Impressionists museum. It is a must see for any Impressionists' fan, impressive Monet waterlilies should be seen in person as no photo can do justice to their rich color and massive scale. The rest of the collection is down stairs and what an amazing selection. The temporary collection was fantastic too, sketches and drawings of famous Impressionist like Monet!Tip: Compared to Louvre, it is a nice little museum, which you could visit in couple of hours, maybe add another hour if you're going to see the temporary collection too.ps. I found the audio guide good, but a bit boring wish they added some of the interesting stories the tour guides were telling.
A must for Monet lovers. This is well worth the visit. The paintings of Monet's in the two rooms are moving. It is overwhelming to see them and "soak" them in. Sit and absorb. Wonderful

Best place to enjoy the Waterlilies. The place did not have so much people because it is not very popular even though it is located right in between the Concorde and the Jardin de Tuileries. The room with Monet's Waterlilies was just beautiful, you could sit there all day.

Quaint. Loved to walk around in Le Marais. No other way to do it. Quaint and old world charm with lovely cafes lining the streets. Stop and take in Paris and just let the city sink in. Lovely way to spend an afternoon or evening..

Don't miss Van Gogh / Artaud exhibition. We thoroughly enjoyed this gem of a museum, but were just delighted to be there during a special exhibit entitled Suicided by Society that contains many self portraits of Van Gogh and a interesting thesis on his suicide. The exhibit is included in admission to d'Orsay

It was worth the wait in the line...in the rain. Yes, we stood in a long line, in the rain, but it was worth the wait. Two stunning rooms of Monet's water lilies with more fascinating art downstairs. I highly recommend that you buy the combo ticket for this museum that allows you to visit Monet's Garden in Giverny where you can see the real ponds of water lilies that inspired the artist. Memorable.
Beautiful gallery. Very accessible gallery with lovely selection of art. Well presented exhibition. Beautiful setting for the Lilies.
Amaizing feeling.. Go downstairs and sit on the bunch just facing the round wall with the lilies. Stay there staring to them for 10 minutes. Ok, you may go. You're cured!!!

Monet's Water Lillies. WOW!! I think my wife and I sat in each of the Water Lillies rooms for an hour each at least - it was that amazing. They also had lots of great Impressionist art downstairs with a special exhibition for drawing and sketches.

A lovely small museum. The centerpieces are Manet's large pieces. What I hadn't expected was the large variety of works by other impressionists. The kids found the museum moderately interesting. From there we took them to the Tuilleries to jump on the trampolines.

Interesting interlude. Having missed this Gallery on last trip, it was worthwhile getting in this time. The Water Lilies panorama by Claude Monet is grand and worth contemplating the size and time involved in its creation, however there are better Monet's to be seen. The main collection of art by Paul Guillaume is very good and covers a great range from Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso , Degas, Matisse and some interesting lesser known names. Drawings as well as paintings are featured.

Amazing. I went to Paris to see the exibition "Impressionists en privée" and as i loved decided to see Monet Water Lilies. I have no words!!!! Everybody must to go there. After i went to Giverny to see the real lake... Unreal!!!! Please go.
lovely, small museum; monet!. this is beautiful, small museum of impressionist art, featuring two rooms dedicated to monet's water lily murals. recommended.

Perfectly executed. A recent reviewer titled their review "Manageable and Enjoyable" and I think that sums it up very well. Unlike the amazing, but overwhelming Louvre, this rather small museum was much easier to take in. It was not striving for grandiosity, but it expertly showcased a small slice of incredibly important art in the impressionist era. It is included in the Paris Museum pass, which makes it very affordable. It is close to the Louvre, and on a hot day was a beautiful, peaceful respite from the heat and crowds of that museum. The top floor is all Monet water lilies in two incredibly well designed rooms. It was not overly crowded when we visited, but I can only imagine what it would be like to sit in those rooms all alone. The very large paintings conveyed such a serenity. The lower floor showcased a variety of artists who were part of, or influenced, the impressionist movement. Lots of Matisse, Degas, Cezanne, Picasso, etc. I particularly loved a Picasso still life that presaged his movement towards the development of Cubism.

My New Favorite. I love this small and less crowded museum. Amazing works by Monet. Don't miss it. Small in size, huge in priceless art. You will sit in quiet looking at the splendor of Monet's Murals. Go!

The place to see Monet's waterlilies. This small museum has two rooms on the first floor that contain four only paintings each--enormous water lily canvases.There are additional exhibits and a nice bookstore on the lower floors, but come for the water lily canvases. This is a must-see for any impressionist lover.

Manageable and Enjoyable. Loved this museum. Tip: buy a Paris museum pass from the concierge at your hotel. Best ~40 Euro we spent--this museum had a very long line to get in, and having the pass enabled us to skip the line.Museum is beautiful -- and old building, but a quite modern interior that allows a surprising amount of artwork to be displayed within the space. The Museum was crowded, but did not feel overly so--we were able to see all of the art without fighting through crowds of people.Of course Monet's Water Lillies impressed and inspired--it's very cool that Monet himself designed the space in which they could be displayed. It was a reflective experience, being able to see so many of them displayed together. Their scale is impressive and you really do get a feel for Monet's love of his gardens and how light affected them at various times of day.The museum on the lower level was also excellent -- many artists from the Impressionist period and an accessible, manageable collection. A highlight of our trip to Paris!

Good but not amazing. Expected more. Great view of the water lilies. Expected there would be more here. It's a bit smaller but still has excellent pieces from famous artists to enjoy here. Would recommend it after the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay. Also, get the Paris pass if you are visiting multiple places.

The Master's Masterpiece. I have always considered Monet the epitome of impressionist art. The Bruce Springsteen of Impressionism; Van Gogh was Jimmy Hendricks. This is arguably his most famous/important work; his "Born to Run," to complete the analogy. The gallery setting is absolutely perfect and establishes a calm serene mood and is the perfect blending of gallery and painting into one piece of art. I now know why Monet demanded this building to display this particular art. I know of no other harmonious setup like this anywhere else in the world. I set down for 20 minutes in each room, just to take it all in, which is something I have never done in any art gallery.This display was my favorite of all Paris museums, yes even the BIG ones. Not many people here, quiet and contemplative. This is a must do before any other museum.

Monet's water lilies - Amazing!. After a second failed attempt to visit the Louvre (a delayed opening meant the line was even longer than usual) we made our way to this lovely museum. There were only 10 people in the line so we got straight in. We got audio guides, which gave a lot of interesting history on the different paintings. While it was great to see some Picassos, Renoirs and more, the highlight was Monet's massive water lily canvasses. With two huge oval rooms dedicated just to them, and not many people around, we could stand there and really admire these amazing works of art. We are not normally that into art, but something about Monet's work in general is fascinating, and these paintings are no different. If you cannot stand waiting in line for hours but want to see some lovely pieces of art from some of the world's most renowned artists, head straight for this excellent little museum. You won't be disappointed!
Monet's to LOVE. What a special place to spent time!!! If you are a Monet lover, this is HEAVEN!!! There is also more impressionists art downstairs. It is a small museum which is nice!!!

Abundant Jewel. This smaller museum is a rare Parisian jewel: master works of art in a smaller building, and if you go in the morning, few crowds. I had no idea Monet's water lilies were exhibited in such focused splendor: this was a marvel and incredible experience. Two rooms with curved walls show a number of the water lilies panels in both comparison and as the spotlight. Extravagant and yet simple. Then, in a separate part of the building, less famous but just as spectacular paintings left me entranced. When I return to Paris, I will definitely return to this special spot and hope it remains the forgotten stepchild to the bigger museums.

Now, one of our favorites!. We enjoyed the entire experience. Yes, the Monet exhibit is quite nice, however, we had just come from Giverny. I very much enjoyed the Renoir paintings, and it was a special pleasure to find the Modigliani works. We certainly will go back to this place of such ease, when we return to my favorite city. It is a special place and deserves at least one visit to decide for yourself!

Huge canvases were impressive. We went here to see the huge Monet paintings which each have their own long wall as an exhibit space. They are a bit varied so you can find one to focus on that you particularly like. Seating is provided in the middle of the room so you can extend your viewing time comfortably. Downstairs are more, normal size, paintings by a variety of Impressionists. We saw a special exhibit here that was interesting and I assume either this exhibit or one like it will persist. It is nice to contemplate these amazing works of art in a more personal and less crowded location than the D'Orsay.
Wow. I could just sit here for hours! Especially great on a partly cloudy day, when shifting level of sun recreates the light that Monet was capturing on his canvas

When you don't have time for D'Orsay. A smaller more specialised museum built to house some of Monet's amazing artworks. There's often a temporary exhibition downstairs but the treats are housed in the impressive oval rooms. You can sit for an hour easily and gaze at Monet's largest artworks. A great facility for such impressive pieces. I always stop in when I am in Paris.

Small but charming!. It's a small and quite museum, but very charming. The building itself is already a masterpiece. Just watch the young ladies outside the museum, trying to make a "survey": they are robbers (seriously!).

Monet plus great space. A perfect little museum for those amazing water lilies. Don't miss the downstairs too...Renoir, Cezanne and more. Very short line with the museum pass and great to see before you go to Giverny.

Impressionists.. This was tricky to find ,it is a smallish building but well worth the search. We loved the great range on show , it's lay out was so fresh, relaxing and so French, elegant. Beautiful Monet you feel like you are in his garden.

Water lilies galore. This was my most favorite place. The first two circular rooms with Monet's water lilies at different times of day were breathtaking. I could sit in this room forever. Definitely follow this up with a day trip to Giverny to see Monet's house and visit his gardens and the water lilies.

Impressionist lovers heaven. The lilies are breathtaking and they alone would make the visit worthwhile but there's another few galleries full of impressionists and other artists of the period. All excellent!

Go for the Monet. The 2 rooms containing several of Monet's Water Lilies are magnificent, and are shown and lit as Monet intended. They are worth the price of admission (although, as with any museum that takes it, the Paris Museum Passport is well worth it). The lower galleries have a mixed bag of post-Impressionist artists. If you're a fan of some but not all post-Impressionism, you'll probably find something you like. But I would spend my time with the Monets.

Nice but not as Nice as I expected.. Honestly Monet's water lilies are cool, the rest of the collection is pretty decent. Honestly I find the Philips Collection in Washington D.C. more impressive than this facility and collection. I also take points off for forbidding photography in certain sections. I have never met someone that avoided going to a minor museum b/c they saw a picture on Facebook.I;d give it an hour then enjoy the Tuileries Garden on the way to the Louvre.

Breathtakingly beautiful. This gallery is a MUST SEE on the Paris list. This has to be one of my favourite places in the world and if I lived in Paris I would get frequent visitor points. There was a short queue when we arrived on a sunny Saturday morning but that wasn't a problem. We went straight to see Monet's water lilies. They are just amazing, the light in the rooms is perfect with comfortable seating in the middle where we just sat for ages. A father brought his little girl in while we were there and made her keep her eyes shut until everyone had moved out of the way and then let her open them. She loved the paintings but the look on her dad's face was even better than on hers.The lower gallery has a beautiful collection of paintings and we were fortunate to see an excellent temporary exhibition.Then of course it was back to the water lilies for one last look...until the next time I'm in Paris!
Monet 's Water Lilies are outstanding. This museum is located at the end of the Tuilleries Gardens--near the place de Concorde. Spend at least 1 hour at this museum to view the art.

Paintings vary in quality. Orangerie is one of the lesser quality museums in Paris. The paintings vary widely in their quality. There are quality paintings to be found in this museum, but most of the museum is dedicated to mediocre expressionist paintings and naked women.

A charming museum.. I have visited L'Orangerie several times before and always enjoy it. The downstairs collection of mainly expressionist paintings (Utrillo, Matisse, Renoir, Modigliani, Soutine and Derain), is excellent. It is always breathtaking to go into the galleries which house Monet's massive Waterlillies works which were painted later in life when his eyesight was failing and which he gifted to the nation. The layout of the galleries could be improved by having some sort of one-way system so that one could stand or sit quietly without loads of people walking past on their way out.Get there early or arrive in the rain as I did, to avoid queues and for €16 you can buy a combined "Passeport" giving admission to both the Orangerie and the Musée D'Orsay. That ticket means only one lot of queuing and can be used over a 3 day period.

A Small, Impressive Musuem. The display of Monet's Nympheaus was impressive, but the great surprise was the collection of impressionist works on the lower level. A small museum when compared to Musee d'Orsay or Musee du Lourve, but definitely worth a visit.

Don't miss your chance to see Monet's Water Lilies. I'm not used to loving art exhibited in a gallery setting, but Monet's Water Lilies were glorious, and worth the price of admission on their own... I could have sat there for hours. The colours change before your eyes, and the longer you sit in each room the more you see. Amazing!

Museum visit Paris. This museum sits at the end of the Tuileries Gardens and not far from the Louvre. It's a very beautiful museum featuring Monet's water lilies - 8 large canvases. It's much less crowded than the Louvre and more manageable. I would recommend, though, that you get a museum pass prior to arriving in Paris as it seems each museum has a special fast line for the museums. There is also a multi-day discount card if you plan to visit several museums over a few days.
A must see.. Monet, Monet, Monet. Took my breath away. A lovely space to meditate. All public spaces should be so calming. Don't miss this.

Most intimate place to enjoy expressionism.. First Sunday every month is free, try to avoid it so you can actually enjoy great Monet Nymph, you can seat on the bench and feel every hue, every shadow, every color essence. Check for combination ticket for L'Orangerie and Dorsey to save couple bucks.

Monet's panels. l'Orangerie has an oval room with 4 wall-sized panels painted by Monet - water lilies. They represent various times of the day, and an orientation from north, south, east, and west. Looking closely, you can see where one of the panels was damaged in WWII. I probably would have given this a rating of 5, but a large part of the museum was closed on the day we went - very disappointing.

a little museum with great surprises. this museum is small and the sister museum to D'Orsay. You can purchase a ticket that would include both museums. At this museum, you will see the most incredible paintings by Monet specifically Monet's Lilies. There are 8 room size paintings that you view 360 degrees in 2 rooms. I cried - they are breathtaking. You cannot take photos because you are looking at the raw paintings.

We got our Monet's worth!. Bad puns aside, we visited l'Orangerie the morning after our trip to Giverny, and we stayed for about an hour just in the two Monet rooms. This was the perfect reprise to our visit. Don't rush through merely to check this one off your list. We used our museum pass, and but there was no line as we pretty much got there when it opened on a cloudy Thursday.

Admire the stunning Waterlillies. The gallery itself is not huge, but we still spent a good 1.5 hours here. The star of the show was undoubtedly the two rooms displaying Monet's Waterlillies which are perfectly displayed in two light galleries. That said, we still enjoyed the other artists on display in the downstairs galleries too. I wouldn't miss it. Buy a joint ticket with the Musee D'Orsay (see my review of this for details).

More than just Water Lilies. While the enormous Monet water lilies are worth a visit to this fantastic museum, there are other art treasures on the lower level. Some of the finest Impressionist paintings outside of the Musee d'Orsay are there. Other Monet's, Renoir, Matisse and Cezanne are on display. The lines are usually shorter at this museum, as well. You can buy a Paris Museum Pass at Paris cityVision at 214 rue de Rivoli and skip the lines at all of the major Paris museums. Use the "priority access" line if you buy your pass in advance. This will save you quite a bit of time.
Get there early!. Wonderful permanent display of Monet's nymphs, but get there early, contemplate Paris Passport, get you front of the line privileges.
