Must visit for impressionism lovers. The Monet rooms are stunning. Amazing artworks designed to be viewed in the space they're in is a rare treat and a must see. The collection downstairs is also wonderful if you love impressionists. It's a good size too whereas other museums can be overwhelming.

Worth the Monet. Obviously well worth a visit for the art but lacks some facilities like a cafe, but to be fair it is a relatively small museum. What struck me was the lack of thought to the design with the dead end at the second Monet room resulting in all and sundry filing back across newcomer's view of the paintings. Go first thing as I did to avoid the queue's and the bun fight that I suspect would be the case at a later hour. One final note, if early its entertaining to see the 8 or 9 (I lost count) employees taking forever sorting out a few posts, ropes and signage at the entrance....let's hope they all had proper jobs inside as well!

One of the best in Paris. This museum is small, but it's probably the best small museum I have ever visited. I have this on my short MUST DO list along with Musee D'Orsay and a few other sites. I recommend visiting D'Orsay first, early in the morning to miss the queues, and buy a combination ticket for both museums. Or, just get a Paris Museum Pass, which I highly recommend anyway.

Charming!!!!. The Monet rooms are simply enchanting for everyone, not just for "art fans".THE WHOLE MUSEUM IS EXITING. Very highly recommended,combine with Tullery and the great surroundings. One of the best museums ever. small and pleasant.

A must see. We liked it because of the Monet murals but the downstairs galleries offered a smaller impressionists selection of Renior's and many others without the crowds. We recommend and early visit it opened at 10 am and no queues.

the best of all. I liked this museum the best of the ones I got to. the Monet panels are wonderful. I think I spent about 45 minutes on both rooms. they were a very ambitious project Monet did late in life and gave them to this museum so people in Paris could come to the museum and enjoy them in the midst of the busy city. the rest of the collection was also interesting.
Culture. Tastes differ - one of us preferred upstairs (Monet water lilies), the other downstairs (late nineteenth century art collections) - but we both enjoyed very much.

SO Glad we did this!!. Not just for the Monets (much more enjoyable than the Museè Monet, btw), but best pre, during and post-Impressionist collection I've ever seen in one places - truly astounding, not crowded and worth every moment. Highlight of this trip.

Wonderful museum. I had visited the museum before but always find it stunning. It is a lovely location in the Tuileries. There is a good deal in combination with the Musee d'Orsay but I didn't have time this visit to do both. The Monet walls are overwhelming and it is easy just to sit there and watch. The rest of the museum is also very good.

For the building and the Monets. Intimate yet great. When possible look for a late afternoon or early night openingThe best alternative to Orsay for Monet. See the Nympheas as you would see them in his Giverny garden... Giverny being closed from October to May

A Really Special Place for Art Lovers. The Monet Les Nympheas are so large and the way they surround you creates a meditaive experience. These painting line the walls of two oval rooms with canvasses made to fit that room, they envelope you, priceless. Downstairs were paintings by Cezanne, Utrillo, Soutine, Renoir, and others. Make sure you visit this museum! You can purchase one ticket for this museum and the Musee D'Orsay for a reduced price.

Hidden gem. Happened to visit this museum on a very cold and rainy day. It was worth the wait in the bad weather. Not a large museum but with some of the best impressionist paintings under one roof in the world. Very well laid out and easy to follow signs. After the Louvre and d'Orsay, I would say this is the next best museum in Paris.

My favorite Museum. This was my favorite Museum in Paris. It was so grand like the Louvre or the Orsay, so you could actually take it all in and not have to rush.
The Monet's are stunning and the lower level is filled with famous artwork as well.
Underrated. This is an underrated museum that has some great art and a lot less people than many of the other sights in Paris. It is worth the extra time if you have the chance.
Monet, Monet, Monet. This is one of my favorites if your love Monet. His tirelessness in completing this absolute treasure.

Stunning for Monet fans. We visited a day after visiting Monet's house & gardens so was great to see these amazing pieces, I could have admired for hours. Entrance was quick as we had a museum pass. I found the lower level a little disappointing, too many pieces too close together and crowded but worth going if you love Monet's water lily series
Monet is Spectacular. Worth the view of Monet if not the traveling shows. You can spend 20 minutes upstairs looking at his work.

A Gem in the Tuileries. A must-see for Monet fans, a lovely place for relaxed contemplation of some of his greatest paintings of water lilies. At the risk of being a boor, it would be even better if the explanatory panels at the entrance as to how it was conceived and built were en anglais.
Wife's Bucket List. Went today. Lines manageable. Water lilies beautiful. Lots of other art to see but NOT hours of it. This museum just the right size for me :-). And Bride was ecstatic !

For Monet lovers.... This is a museum to enjoy the Water Lilies of Claude Monet... you'll find more and maybe you'll be surprise by other work, but the main event is Monet. Don't get me wrong, it's worth the line, the cost and and every minute of time you spend there.
Love the Lillys. If you like Impressionism, go see the Water Lilly's at the Musee de l'Orangerie they are breathtaking.
The best of Monet. If you like Monet, you have got to go to this place. It is everything that you can imagine and more. Select the time you go carefully since the lines for entry can be long

Great Museum. Another must see especiallyif you get the 2 day museum pass. This place sits at the corner of the Jardin Vendome. If you get there early then you can have time to visit the d'Orsay thats just sits across the river.
Nice exhibit of Monet's water lilies. Recently renovated museum. For those Monet's fans this museum not to be missed! Near the place de la Concorde and The Avenue des Champs-Élysées.

Meditative art. Went here on a Wednesday after the Rodin. Both were excellent. Monet's waterlilies are breathtaking. Take some time to sit and enjoy all the views. Also 1st floor had many paintings by Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse & Rousseau, in addition to the magnificent Monets. Well worth the visit...made the visit to Monet's Gardens in Giverny even more meaningful.
Waterlilies. Seeing a museum specifically built to house Monet's Waterlillies was amazing. I think I spent more time admiring these paintings than all of The Louvre

I can handle this!. Dont you just hate these huge museums where you spend five hours, and yet you feel that you have barely gone in through the front door. This little gem is just big enough to put in your heart pocket. The permanent collection is superb , always loved the Renoirs and the Waterlillies of Monet. And just when your feet start aching after walking and walking, you can just slip outside and sit by the fountain in your reclining chair in the Tuilerie Garden. Aaaahhhh, can't beat this!

Monet's Water Lilies. Built to house Monet's gift to France after winning the 1st World War, Nymphaea, the Water Lilies. Monet was going blind from cataracts while he was painting these masterpieces, the colors rippled like liquid throughout the painting. I sat in wonder at their beauty, quite mesmerized.

A magnificent Monet experience!. If you're in Paris and you can't make it out to Giverny, you can appreciate the waterlilies - and Monet's incredible talent- at the Musée de l'Orangerie. There are curved rooms awash with waterlilies. the coloors are soothing and thrilling at the same time. Not only are the waterlilies an excellent reason for visiting this museum. The museum also has a lovely collection of Impressionist paintings, so be sure to leave enough time to see them all.Then you can stroll through the Tuileries and have a nice, relaxing lunch! The perfect afternoon in Paris!It IS advisable to get a billet coupe-fille, which helps to get you inside faster, if there is a special exhibit.
Like Monet in IMAX. A truly meditative experience not to be missed. Unlike viewing any other Monet due to the sheer size of the works.The museum is quite small though so it may not be for everyone.

Take Your Time. Sit down, view the Monet Waterlilies and don't rush. To appreciate these masterpieces, you need to be quiet and feel the peace that will overcome you. Then make sure you go to Giverny to see Monet's gardens and then you will have an even greater appreciation.
So Breathtaking. Loved seeing Monet's huge paintings in person! It was beautiful! Also loved the current collection downstairs. Wish they would let you take photos inside!
a small oasis in paris. in the tuilerie garden, it is a really nice and small museum. avoid the Sunday because to busy. The walk in the garden after is just great.

Monet on Sunday.. Small but perfectly sorted museum predominantly for the Monets but there is more. Been twice, over a couple of years. Early Sunday was quietist and you want to be able to just sit and take in the vast pictures.

Monet's large works are here. Monet spent a decade painting huge panels of artwork for two rooms intended for meditation. Other quality works of art are here as well. Near the Louvre. You won't spend all day here, but a good museum to add to your trip if you are an art lover.

Yes!. This was an amazing museum, highly suggest if you are an art lover. Seeing some of Monet's paintings was worth it in itself, but in another area a stunning exhibit of the impressionist painters.They are open every day except Tuesdays, so it is a good place to visit on a Sunday or Monday, when many of the other museums are closed.
Need to go to down stair. A amazing Monet's collection. You can experience to feel four season from the arts. Better to make a reservation through internet, so that you can enter it quickly.

A wonderful museum and an absolute must. Again more queues but only approx. 30 mins - but so worth the wait. The large Monet canvases are beautifully exhibited and it was possible to just sit and completely lose yourself in them. A wonderful contrast to the madness of the Louvre. Of course there is so much more than the famous Monet Nymphaeas and this museum beatifully complements the Musee d' Orsay that is just a few minutes away across the Seine.
Over rated. There are many sights & museums to see in Paris. You remove this from the list as there are very few of Monet's paintings here. Better to focus on Musee D'Orsay

Perfect little museum for a quick visit. I didn't have a lot of time in Paris so the Louvre was out of the question. At the foot of the Louvre plaza is this little gem. It was the perfect size to fit into a compact schedule. Visited on a Sunday and we were able to walk right in, though there was still a lot of people walking around. Such a great collection of impressionist work and the Waterlillies are amazing. Lots of great Cezanne works and he's one of my favorites.

Monet's paintings are a must see. Go simply to see Monet's lovely paintings. I always enjoy this museum! The first time I went, it was an experience. Also, if you have a french visa (work, student), you will be able to get into this museum for free. So bring your passport!

Worth every painting. This small museum of mainly impressionist art is a beautiful gem. It is ideal for someone who wants to appreciate each piece of art. The artists in the museum are Monet, Renoir, Matisse, Picasso, Durain, and several others.

monet and more. As well as the 8 large Monet's which the building was especially constructed to house, there is also a huge collection of other impressionist paintings. There was a queue to get in through the security check and then another queue to pay but it is worth it.

A little museum without the hustle and bustle. There were no queues to this museum and it focussed on just art particularly 8 fabulous works by Monet.
Downstairs there were many other pieces including Renoir and Picasso which just served to demonstrate what a brilliant artist Monet was, these large panels have a 3 dimensional feel to them.
Buy a ticket in advance -wait in line. Bought tickets ahead of time and still waited for 1 1/4 hours. Crowd was overwhelming and too criwded to reall ysee and enjoy.

A little disappointed. I was expecting to see more than I did. Maybe because I had just seen Musee D Orsay You really can't compare the 2. I went to see Water Lilies by Monet they were much larger than I was expecting.
I pressionist haven. If you love degas and monet and the other impressionists, don't miss this one close to place de concorde where supposedly marie antoinette lost her head.

Here is the great Claude MONET. The masterpiece of Claude Monet. His last work.His most ambitious. Above his previous series: cathedrals, poplars and haystacks...Thema is apparently so simple:Variation of colors according to the hours. The very old painter put touches of pure colour on the canvas with a maximum of energy. Check it by yourself. Put your nose on the canvas ! and thenafter make some steps backwards and look again. The magician has operated. The most accessible artpiece you can imagine. For anyone from anywhere in the world, of any age and any culture. A genial creation of the Michelangelo of the painting.After your visit you will never forget The NympheasHave a nice discovery.

For lovers of Monet. With the museum pass, you can skip the long lines and stop by for this amazing water Lillie's painting. I didn't realize the size of the 8 canvases and that the museum was designed to hold this beautiful art work. The colors are amazing considering Monet was nearly blind from cataracts. I could have stayed for hours.

Perfect stop on the way back from Giverny. My boyfriend and I went here after our day touring Monet's house and gardens in Giverny. It was the perfect follow up - to see the giant waterlilies that Monet painted. They were even larger and more beautiful than I had imagined. I just sat on the benches in the middle of the room and took time looking at each one.We went near the end of the day, and the wait to get in was longer than I was expecting - we almost missed the cut off time. We took a brief walk through the other galleries, but the Monet's are really the star attraction here.
Go for the beautiful Monets. A great gallery to visit especially if you are short in time and don't like standing in lines. You can buy a combined ticket that includes Musee D'Orsay

A 'must see' whilst visiting Paris. We had a Paris pass so had the advantage of not having to queue to visit this gallery. Awe inspiring and thought provoking, my husband and I both had different views on the works of art displayed and it gave us plenty to talk about over lunch. You have to visit!

Wonderful little museum, a must if you love impressionist art!. I love Musee de l'Orangerie, it's so nice to sit quietly looking at Monets Waterlilies. Beautiful light coming through the glass ceilings makes it seem a little otherworldly and far away from the hustle bustle of the city streets.Downstairs is also a great collection of impressionist paintings and the size of the museum makes it very manageable without rushing.I have visited here both times I've been to Paris and would find it hard to resist coming back next time. I find it such a wonderful place and would warmly recommend it over anything else I have done in Paris.

A Must See. Out of all the museums I saw in Paris, this was by far one of my favorites. No photos allowed but to walk into the oval rooms with the 8 paintings from Monet, in the environment that he wanted them displayed, was just so peaceful and incredible. The other pieces in the basement were also very interesting. Some of the names are recognizable but others not so much. It really didn't matter, the works of art they have on display are just really cool. Highly recommend this museum. Closest metro station is Concorde. Visit the gardens outside too.

A Must For The Fans of Monet. This is a small museum located by the Tuileries. There are 2 rooms comprising 8 panels of water lilies that evoke the hours between sunrise and sunset. One gets the feeling of being immersed in the pond at Giverny.However, Monet's work is not the only attraction as there is a wonderful display of the Jean Walter & Paul Gullaume art collection which contains many previously unseen works of the likes of Picasso and Soutine. There is usually a line for this attraction and one is well advised to get a ticket prior to visiting the museum as the waits can be very long. I would suggest that you speak with your hotel concierge who can usually provide the ticket or makes arrangements to get one. You will save a lot of time.

Don't miss this museum!. Located on the terrace of the Jardins des Tuleries, this museum is not to be missed if you like impressionist art. Most famously, there are two rooms each with four of Monet's Water Lillies. The rooms are specially designed with natural light. Leave enough time...I found the rooms to be peaceful and could have spent all afternoon just soaking in the Water Lillies.

Breathtaking. This the perfect place for people who love impressionism. Monet's water lilies are just beautiful and I can sit there all day. The lower floor has a nice collection of other impressionist as well.

Center pieces: Nympheas (Water Lilies) and more!. For those that love Monet's art, the two oval rooms with the Nympheas or Water Lilies are must see! The two rooms depict water lilies at different times of the day. It is a 360 view. Also, the ceiling have skylights. At the time we saw the paintings, the lighting went from cloudy to sunny. Therefore, we were able to appreciate the effect of natural lighting on the paintings. It was very neat to see the change. Can sit in the central bench and admire the 360 view. It gives the impression of peacefulness.At the lower level of the museum, we were able to appreciate a small collection of paintings from artists such as Cezanne, Renoir, Monet, Modigliani, Matisse, Rousseau…In addition, there is a special exhibit running until end of June of drawings/sketches from the Musee D'Orsay. We had the museum pass and were able to go to the museum pass line and skip the ticket line. Compared to the Louvre and D'Orsay, this museum is not as crowded and was able to have an enjoyable experience.Afterwards, can enjoy a walk through the Tulleries garden or cross the rive to the Musee d'Orsay.

The waterlilies are incredible. Truth be told my partner and I came here exclusively for Monet's waterlilies and left without seeing anything else. Totally worth it. The paintings envelop you in the oval rooms. There is so much depth to them and the colours are so calming. Seeing them was a highlight of Paris. I wish I could have taken a picture.NB: No photographs are allowed and backpacks need to be checked into the cloakroom. Also the Museum Pass doesn't help to skip lines here.
Excellent Monet Experience. An incredible Monet Experience as you walk through an entire room of Monet's Water Lily's. It's as though you're stepping right into the painting.

Heavenly. Monet's huge waterlily canvases are breathtaking and the main reason to visit this gallery, but there are also some wonderful works by Matisse, Picasso and Modigliani on the lower level of the building. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a pleasant walk through the Jardin de Tuileries from the Musee d'Orsday. Worth the visit.

nympheas. the monet paintings"Les Nymphaeas" in 2 oval rooms are more than paintings. They are an experience. Monet did these in the last 10 years of his life. He was nearly blind at the time and underwent cataract surgery part way through. When completed , he kept the paintings at his home till he died.The paintings are plastered into the wall. I wonder what kept them out of the hands of the Germans during the war.This is one exhibit I wish I had seen with fewer people present. A Paris blog, finding noon, describes that experience. She visited with the friends of musee d"or say and took pictures(not allowed).

Water lilies worth seeing. On a busy tourist Saturday in Spring / Summer, the Orangerie has a shorter queue / is less crowded than the main art galleries. One floor is 2 rooms of the Waterlilies, one floor a collection with half a dozen or so paintings from some of the major painters - Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Monet. Recommended for families where one child is less interested in art - it's some 'Greatest Hits' in one hour!

Monet's Gift. Two large rooms of paintings that wrap around the walls to create complete environments based on the artist's garden at Giverny.While the thundering hordes are squashing each other in the Musee d'Orsay, those in the know are sitting in pools of colour and light, drinking in Monet at his best; this pair of cycles were the artist's last major work, his give to the nation. Don't miss it!

Bring your lunch. This museum is located across from a lovely park. Perfect for enjoying while eating your lunch. You must see the Monet Water Lillies-absolutely breathtaking. He donated them to the state and had them installed here. Wonderful in conjuction with the D'Orsey Monet exhibit. Both are included in a Museum pass, which I highly recommend.
Favorite Museum in Paris. I can spend at least an hour just sitting in the downstairs area where they have the 360 surround Monet Water Lilies painting!!!

Beautiful exhibition. The "Nympheas" exhibit is endlessly fascinating. The 8 canvases are unbelievably complex and rewarding to gaze upon. Many of the paintings in the downstairs collection are also quite interesting, though I was disappointed at the rather thin Cezanne offering. There were a couple of other painters, though, who I had not seen much of before, who were quite fascinating. I wish I could remember the name of the most prolific of them, but the web site doesn't give that detail, and I didn't make a note of it. Very much worth a look, though!

museum trip. Extremely interesting presentation. What was more interesting was the "temporary" exhibition, evidently an over flow from the D'Orsey. Very small pieces from some very interesting artists.

Monet and the Nympheas are waiting for your visit. One of the best museums in Paris, and one of the less visited. You may visit it in a morning, because it's small. The fantastic and huge paintings by Monet show the nympheas of his Giverny Gardens. Don't forget to visit downstairs the collection of Impressionists that once was owned by Paul Guillaume.

Don't Miss the Archives of the Dream (to June 30). While many people appear to visit l'Orangerie for the large scale water lilies by Monet (which are spectacular), I found a temporary exhibit downstairs that was AMAZING! The Musee D'Orsay has an extensive archival collection of drawings and works on paper by various "masters" such as Degas, Cezanne, Rodin, etc. The collection I saw runs through June 30th and I got the feeling another collection will go on view after that as the archives is so expansive. Don't miss!

Monet's Water Lilies - WOW. This museum, private collection, just amazing. In many ways, more special than the "big guys" (Louvre, Pompideau). The two oval rooms built especially to display the Monet water lilies in 360 degree glory alone are worth going for.

Worth the visit. Seeing the six panels of Water Lillies was quite an experience. Plus there are other exhibits that are very worth while. Not as crowded as the Musee d'Orsy, you don't need tickets in advance to go in.
the water lilies are amazing. This is a small museum, so you can see it all in a short time. All Monet fans should put this on their list.

Refreshing. A small museum that you can finish in 2 hours or less. Good even for those having a tight schehule. Definitely worth the visit because of the circular panels of Monet's waterlilies. A refreshing & spectacular experience. it's conveniently located in the Tuileries garden near the Concorde entrance. A must for those who hold the museum pass.
Beautiful Museum. Viewing Monet's Water Lilies in his specially designed display rooms was a highlight of our Paris visit.

Meditation by Monet. The presentation of Monet's Water Lilies murals is in 2 oval-shaped rooms. You are surrounded by sunlight, moonlight, and everything in between, and feel like you're existing in the world he created. Let this beautiful art transport you to another time and place.

Uncrowded. A lovely museum that has a very calm and unfussed feel about it. After enjoying the works of art on display, walk around to the Jardins Tuilleries and have some lunch. A very nice way to spend a day.

A must. If you visit only one museum, this is the one. So intimate and lovely. We are from DC where museums are free so we have museum burn-out but this one is so refreshing w the Monet water lilies in the beginning and then a perfect selection of other impressionists down below.

Superb!. The Orangery is a little gem. While Monet's Water Lilies are the stars of the show, don't miss the Guillaume collection, which contains some wonderful works by Renoir, Cezanne, and Matisse among others. The reception staff are friendly and helpful, although the museum attendants are a little over-zealous in their quest for perfect silence in the galleries! This is a perfect museum for art lovers who want a more intimate experience than can be found in bigger museums like the Louvre or the Musee D'Orsay.
It's on the wall. Long, slow moving queue to get in but once in the Monet's are breathtaking, if you are not into Impressionism then you will not enjoy this museum.

Great museum! Quick Visit!. We basically wanted to see Claude Monet's work and visiting Musee de l'Orangerie was well worth it! It was a quick visit (20 minutes) which was nice! It's part of the Paris museum pass so well worth visiting! Claude Monet water lily panels are beautiful! Take a moment to sit and really look at each aspect! Lovely!

An excellent collection of paintings. Fans of Monet would love the two circular rooms containing his series a water lily paintings done over a 12 year period. But on top of that there are the collections of JeN Walter and Paul Guillaume which house many works by Modigliani, Cezanne, Matisse, Henri Rousseay, Renoir, Picasso, Derain, Utrillo, Soutine and others. A fantastic collection of artists at the end of 19th and beginning of 20th centuries. There was also a temporary exhibition of amazing pencil, pastel and aquarelle works organised thematically. You can buy a combined ticket to Orsay (valid for 4 days) which gives you a reduced price.

Under the Nympheas. We visited the Musee de l'Orangerie to see the Waterlillies. The was short to enter and very little fuss getting in. Monet's Nympheas were breathtaking. Downstairs is the Collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume which includes Cezanne, Renoir, Monet, Picasso, Gaugin, Rousseau, Sisley, Matisse, Utrillo, Van Dongen and Soutine. It is magnificent and recommend highly.
The best musee in Paris. If you love Monet you must visit this awesome musee, it will not disappoint! And the other artwork is pretty spectacular too
Simply Wonderful.. It was April and we arrived just before opening time. There were not many here yet and we were able to sit quietly and "take in" and enjoy Monet's masterpieces. Simply wonderful.

Very special!!!. This is such a lovely museum! There are a few things to call out. This is a small museum - you can finish your visit in less than two hours. The two Monet rooms will take your breath away - there is no other way to describe it. The collection downstairs is also quite nice which completes this lovely visit. Outside of the museum there is a Rodin statue called "The Kiss" which is incredible. Be sure to take some time to observe it. Last but not least if you plan to visit Giverny, Monet's house, be sure to visit this museum first.
For Mone't fans. Great collection of Mone't and others art work. This small and museum delivers a world class artexperience.

Best Museum for "non art types". We prefer smaller collections of art. I could say it is because of the teenage kids but to be honest one of them is happy to spend hours looking at art and historical "stuff". The other would prefer to "do something" so has a rather short attention span for seeing without touching. While a bit better than that I do find massive museum collections overwhelming - my back aches and I get antsy. I start to rush and then feel like I haven't really taken anything in.The Musee de l'Orangerie is perfect for us! The 8 Monet "murals" give you the feeling you are standing among the water lilies I have been to the real thing and it is well worth seeing but if you are short on time, or simply want to appreciate his talent, you can't miss this one. THe rest of the collection is enjoyable too but nothing compares to those 2 rooms..

Wonderful Collection but book online first!. Wanting to see Monet's Waterlilies again after more than a 15 year absence, I remembered this being one of my favourite museums in Paris and it did not disappoint except for one thing: the queue! We must have spent a good part of one hour waiting to be admitted and once through the doors we discovered why, the airport detector/scanner that you had to pass your bags through and empty your pockets repeatedly until the offending item is removed from your body. This issue really needs to be addressed as it spoils an otherwise splendid visit to this enchanting museum. Purposely designed in collaboration with Monet to house his Nymphéas, they envelop and hypnotise with their expressive abstraction and strong colour sense. Downstairs, the permanent collection of Paul Guillaume resides alongside a temporary exhibition: Drawings from the Musée d'Orsay (at the time I visited), which has to be one of the most sumptuous drawing collections ever assembled! An excellent visit which I highly recommend.
Over hyped. Just OK in my opinion. You can see Monet s works in many other museums and this was a bit over hyped in my opinion.

Go here, not the Louvre!. Okay you sort of have to go to the Louvre, but really, it is too big, too crowded, and too overwhelming. This wonderful museum can be managed in a few hours, and the quality of the art is just breathtaking. It's much quieter too. Sit in the specially-created rooms with the vast Monet artworks -- anywhere else and they alone would cause lines round the block. It's wonderful.
Excellent. A sanctuary for lovers of Impressionism. Two special rooms for huge and beatiful water lily paintings from Claude Monet are impressiv. Tha Paul Guillaume collection is amazing. Must see!

Unexpected delight. We had not visited this before and with so little information to go on we assumed it was something to do with plants. No. The two oval rooms with the Monet paintings take your breath away, after that, galleries and galleries. Picasso, Manet, Renoir, Degas... sorry too many to remember right now but please, add it to your list of places to visit.
Loved the Water Lily Murals. You are surrounded by the breathtaking murals of water lillies in soothing cool shades of blue and green. The effect is overwhelming. Do not miss this overlooked jewel!
Wow. Incredible collection of art, and a great little museum. Hey, your in Paris so it's all about the sites, and this is a good one.
A Gem. The Monet water lilies are spectacular and they have some outstanding shows (we saw an exhibition on drawings) in the basement floor.

Water Lilies!!!. Monet's water lilies are even more beautiful than I expected. There are 2 large rooms dedicated solely to these works and they are stunning. The museum is small and easy to stroll through in an hour or so.

The BEST of Monet. The best of Monet to me is his water lilies and these are on display here; they are enormous paintings and for a small museum we were over whelmed with the works on display. The Louve is so large; this place is easy to find and you can see so much is less time. The water lilies are something you keep within your heart forever.

My favorite museum. During our visit to Paris, we hit the Musee d'Orsay, the Louvre, and the Orangerie. Of all of them, this was my favorite. Instead of just checking off bucket list pieces of art to see, visitors are actually able to experience and be moved by the art. It is the perfect size museum, as the visitor can spend time with pieces and still see the entire collection and the special exhibits without getting too worn out.As with other visitors, I was very moved by Monet's Nymphees and hadn't anticipated two whole rooms of them! Then when I read that he had painted them after World War I as a tribute to peace, I cried.The Museum Pass enabled us to skip the line, which was very helpful. If you are at all a fan of Impressionism, this is the perfect corollary to the Musee d'Orsay.

Breath taking!. When you enter the first oval room, you're amazed at the scale of the pieces. But then you enter the second oval room, your soul is touched in a very profound way. Get the Museum Pass. The lines were CRAZY long, and we felt so satisfied skipping to the front!

Lovely smaller art gallery. Enjoyed this art gallery more than the d'Orsay with its unique monet water lily painting in the curved rooms, and the rest of the art in it was well worth seeing and not as overwhelming to see all like in the d'orsay. if visiting both this and the d'orsay on your trip go here first as it seems quieter and buy a joint ticket which will then help you get in the quicker pre booked que at the d'orsay and save you money(C+D entry)

Must Visit in Paris. Musee de l’Orangerie is situated at the corner of Jardin de Tuilieries just before Champ Elysees. It’s a little tiny museum, but very highly rated on travel websites, and deservedly so. It had two rooms dedicated to Monet’s Les Nympheas, four in each room. The Orangerie also had a nice collection of paintings by Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse among others. I think out of all the museums we visited, this one was my favourite. I really enjoyed their collection, and the size of the museum was not at all overwhelming. Just outside the Orangerie, we came across a sculpture of The Kiss by Rodin, so that was a bonus. I really liked that the place was not crowded at all (unlike the Louvre and the Orsay). One of the things I will remember about this museum is their heated toilet seats. This museum is a must see!

Wonderful setting for Monet pictures. Brilliant visit and I really enjoyed seeing the water lily paintings that Monet painted especially for this setting. We spent a long time peacefully taking in these 8 paintings whilst other people seemed to rush around. Take your time! Rest of the art was also worth seeing. Buy a joint ticket to visit D'Orsay museum also and avoid the queues and also save money. Highly recommended.
Lovely smaller art gallery. Lovely smaller art gallery, much less overwhelming than all the others and contains large beautiful Monet paintings. Recommended.

Great Tour. We took the weekly English guided tour and really enjoyed it. The tour guide was knowledgeable, friendly and spoke very good English.As a traveler with a mobility disability (wheelchair user) we were able to enter at the front of the line which we really appreciated.there was also a 'price concession'.Their handicapped accessible washroom was well designed and an adequate size.It was locked and it took us some time to get the key but that is not an unusual occurrence even in Canada and the U.S. It is a great little museum without the crowds.

Go in the morning. Being surrounded by Monet's lily pads in these galleries was a calming experience. It was easy to sit down and simply admire his work from the benches in the middle of the room. The collection on the floor below was interesting as well, but the main attraction is clearly the lily pads. I would advise you to go in the morning. We arrived around the time it opened and pretty much had the galleries to ourselves, but by the time we left there was a substantial line forming. It would have been a different experience with more people crowding the rooms. Regardless, this is a must-see in Paris.

Water lillies have to be seen in person. If you've seen pictures of Monet's water lillies paintings, you probably didn't have any idea of how large these panoramas really are, each filling entire side of a large oval room. Benches in middle of room allow you to just sit and take in the whole.

Blow you away~. Monet has painted beautiful walls in this museum, you will want to sit on the bench in the rooms & reflex, relax & be amazed at his work. There are also rotating exhibits here which are fantastic. We viewed Frieda Kahlo when we went.

It either grabs you or it doesn't. This was my third time going to this museum and each time I come away feeling it is something I "should" like more than I actually do. On an intelleluctual level I appreciate it is quite an accomplishment but I never feel very moved by it. We had a Museum Pass and were able to go to the front of the very long line. I think I would not have gone in if I had to stand in line. Each to their own, I suppose.

Off the Beaten Path-artistically. A wonderful museum to see Soutine, Matisse, and Utrillo, and then immerse yourself in Monet's famous lily ponds...small enough to see it all in one visit....grandiose enough to be overcome with the artistic spirit!

Better than expected. We bought the combination pass at the D'Orsay so we were able to avoid the long, long line to get in. We came to see the famous Monet's water lillies paintings, this small museum's claim to fame. There are eight mammoth scale paintings (4 each in 2 oval shaped rooms) You will see different views of the pond and water lillies captured at various times. Spent some time just sitting quietly here before venturing downstairs to see the rest of the museum. We were pleasantly surprised to see a fabulous collection of works from artists that bridge the Impressionistic and Modernistic art era. Works by Renoir, Cezanne, Utrillo, Matisse and Picasso. Once inside, the museum was not that crowded. Musee de l'Orangerie was well worth the visit.

Great little museum. You need to go to see Monet's water lilies (2 rooms) and other great artists. It is a nice size museum and less busy.. This museum is covered under the museum pass and the line was quick. There is also a different line for those with a museum pass. This was a nice change of pace as we had just come from the Louvre. There were nice areas to sit outside as well.

A must see!. Compact and digestible, this Art Gallery is ideally situated on the edge of the Tuillerie Gardens. It is a 'must see' for lovers of Monet. It provides an introduction to Art if you do not have the stamina or inclination to tackle the Louvre or the Musee D'Orsay.

not all that. To wait 2 or 3 hours in line for the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay is one thing (it's still a lot, but at least you're investing the same amount of time getting there as being there), but to do that for a small space of 2 rooms is a bit much. Impressionists aren't my thing, and Monet's waterlillies are in this genre. They're good, very good for what they are. But couldn't they have been made an extension of the Musee d'Orsay (where there's an agreement with the l'Organgerie) so you only have to wait once?
The little Musee that could. This museum punches above it's weight with Monet's Water Lillies and some great examples from Renoir, Cezanne and Degas just to name a few. We loved this museum
Monet's Water Lilies - so peaceful. Buy the Museum Pass to shorten the time in line. The two rooms of Claude Monet's Water Lilies are gorgeous. Could you just sat in those two rooms for hours.

get lost in the water lilies.... Amazing setting for Monet's water lillies. Between the Musee d'Orsay and l'Orangerie, you'll find some of the finest work of the impressionists. It is far less busy than other large museums, which really gives you the chance to breath in the atmosphere of Monet's garden...
Monet at it's best. Love the Monet in surround. We missed the Frida Kahlo show with much disappointment. Will need to go to Mexico City
Use museum pass. It is too small to wait for long times, but usually you won't have to since people are in/out quickly. Worth seeing if you are nearby (which you will be.)
Wonderful Monet. Monet's Water Lilies are displayed here as you will not see at any other museum. By all means go see them here.

An oasis of calm. This is a relatively small gallery - but with very high quality pictures on show. Downstairs impessionists and post-impressionists, upstairs the star attraction Monet's huge paintings of waterlilies specially painted for this museum.Pictures are not my speciality at all - but the effect of the Monet paintings was astonishing. I have rarely felt pictures so calming - precisely the result at which the painter aimed.The queue was not too long - in this city of queues - and the relatively small number of pictures meant one could give them time to work.Unmissable.
ninfeas - monet. its wonderful to see the paintings of ninfea. its interesting to go to giverny to feel the same as monet felt when was painting the ninfeas.

lovely gallery and if you get time... Just been on a guided tour of the paintings and waterlilies. At 1.5 hours it was perhaps a little long but very interesting.The waterlilies are always a treat to see. And if you visit on a bright day, try and get in to the park outside and visit the little cafe. You can watch the world go by with some basic but tasty food..

Reluctant art lover impressed. Monet's water lilies were larger than expected and left me with a better impression of how an artist interprets the seasons of the year and their affect on his scene. Downstairs I also found myself becoming an art critic and excited by seeing works by Picasso, Renoir and others. The building made this a special place to view art. Well worth a visit. I may even go now and visit more galleries!

Space to appreciate. A well laid out museum , room to wander and enjoy a large number of Impressionists and other styles. Even when busy there is loads of time and space - the outdoor area is well used too.

Only visit with a museum pass. This museum apart from monets water lilies paintings across a large area of the walls there was very little else to see. You could be in and out within thirty minutes like I was and quite disappointedDont waste your money unless you have a museum pass.

Easy to visit with children. This is my absolute favorite museum to visit in Paris. The place is easy to visit with children. It is manageable and you are not overwhelmed. Flow is very good from exhibit to exhibit. Love the large Monet water lilies covering the wall. Easy to see collection. My kids loved it as well.

Must See for the Monet Waterlilies. A small museum at the edge of the Seine, with the largest of Monet's canvasses on the light filled main floor. Downstairs there were collections of many other significant artists. A delightful size for a museum, just the right amount of art to peruse on an afternoon.
Best museum. The combo ticket to this and d'orsay is a must for any impressionist lover. No lines here and the art is as good as d'orsay. Loved it. Photography seriously discouraged

Fantastic visit to Musée de l'Orangerie. The Monet "Water Lilies" would be enough to make this a must visit museum. But that is only the beginning. Level 2 presents a world class collection of the works of famous artists: Cézanne, Renoir, Modigliani, etc.Allow at least two hours for Level 2 viewing.
The Lillies are amazing. This was my second time visiting this museum and it was just as good as I had remembered. I think save the main floor (The Lillies) for last.
Great waterlilies. Get the combo ticket online with Musee d'Orsay for 19€ to skip the lines in both museums.The waterlilies paintings are beautiful and impressive.

Leap Leap Philippe!. For those Monet enthusiasts out there (or for those who as children loved the book Philippe in Monet's Garden (highly recommended)) the Musee de l'Orangerie is a must. Monet's Water Lilies cover the walls of two oval shaped rooms so you have to sit in the center and take a stroll around the outside to fully absorb what's going on in the paintings. A museum pass is recommended to avoid the line in the comparatively small museum.

Superb collection, beautiful location. Monet's vast canvasses, presented in spacious oval rooms, are what draw the crowds, but there is a fantastic collection of post-impressionist painting on show here. Dealer/collector Paul Guillaume was mates with many of the artists he represented and built an unrivalled collection of modern art including Derain, Modigliani, Matisse, Soutine and Utrillo. Forget the cattle market at the d'Orsay down the road, make this your pilgrimage. Tip: buy the Paris Museums pass and saunter past the queue.

What a little Gem!. If you loved Monet's Water Lilies it would be reason enough to come, but the other pieces in the permanent collection is amazing too. The French are so orderly and this museum like the Musee D'Orsay makes total sense. The special exhibit of Drawings was very worthwhile
Relaxing paintings. I really loved this museum, especially the huge pictures in the oval rooms. I think this is one of the best museum in Paris. I can only suggest for everyone.

Great place to absorb Monet water lilies and French Impressionists. You are suppose to see the water lilies moving as you look at the immense paintings. Did not quite see that. Best was the fact that they had a rather larger collection of paintings borrowed from the Orsy Museum while we were there so we were able to skip that museum. Lots of huge paintings by French impressionists such as Cezanne, van Gogh, Picasso, Monet, degas, boudin, Renoir, Gauguin, Seurat, Manet, Matisse, Rosseau, Sisley, Modigliani. The only one I thought terrible was works of art by Picasso but that is my personal taste.

Surprising. I liked it bc there are huge murals by Monet I had never seen. We went at 5pm and they close at 6 so it wasn't super crowded and I am also a huge cezanne fan and there is a whole room of only cezanne. It also is small enough you can do it quickly and not have your eyes glaze over. Not overwhelming or crowded like louvre.

Maybe my favorite Musee in Paris. The building is stunning after being closed the last time we were in Paris. Monet's "Waterlillies" have a wonderful home and are breath taking. If that is not enough downstairs there is a wonderful exhibition. The architect did a stunning job on this building. It was a wonderful experience.

this really is an astounding museum. Words cannot express the deep serenity that comes from viewing Monet's Water Lilies series in person. Barring none, our visit to Musée de l'Orangerie was probably the best experience I had in France.

See the flowing water through his eyes. With a resident permit of EU, I even visited the museum for free. For a long time I'd not been a huge fan of Impressionism (Actually I'm more for modern arts). As I stepped into the great showroom, I was still an outlaw of Monet's art. I took a couple of minutes, just staring at the paintings...then I understood it. I could hear the summer's breeze wrinkling the tranquil pond in his garden. I could see the colorful waterweeds posing with the smoothly surging wave below. On the surface, les Nymphéas sat there gracefully, like ballerinas who were taking a break during the intermezzo of seasons. Masterpiece.
Great art. We did the museum pass so was great to drop in to any of the many museums and just see what we wanted to see.

Monet's Water lily panels!!!. Beautiful to be in the two rooms surrounded by Monet's Water Lily panels, and knowing we would be seeing his home, gardens and pond the next day. Lower floor has excellent collection of art as well.

Include with Musee d'Orsay. An absolute must see if you like impressionist art. Monet's water lilies are amazing and take your breath away. Loads more paintings downstairs, and much less busy than Musee d'Orsay.

Amazing Museum, and not just water lilies. Visited this museum last week while on a short break to Paris and we were absolutely stunned by how good it was. Firstly of course the main reason for visiting the museum is the outstanding water lilies by Monet. There are eight of them arranged around the side of two rooms and they really are very well presented with you being able to easily sit in the centre of each room and admire all four paintings. Then downstairs there is a wonderful collection of paintings by Cezanne, Modigliani etc which rival that of the Musee D'Orsay in quality if not quantity. We entered using the museum pass so didn't pay but I did notice that the entrance fee was quite steep and the audio guide probably isn't worth it; impressionist art is for looking at and interpreting, not being told about. Overall a fantastic museum.

Surrounded by Magnificent Monet Water Lilies. For art lovers, particularly those who like Monet, this is a must see. Within two large rooms, there are about nine 40 to 50 feet wide canvases of water lillies, willow trees and Giverny pond. The whole effect left me feeling very peaceful and tranquil. You can almost hear the birds, feel the breeze, and touch the water. Great to see his technique both upclose and then far. Stupendous.

Skip Musee d'Orsay and go here instead!. Don't tell anyone, but if you are a lover of Impressionists, skip the crowds at the Musee d'Orsay and go here instead! It has a fraction of the crowds, a phenomenal (albeit smaller) collection of Impressionist and other 19th/early 20th century pieces including Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse and others. It's piece de resistence is Monet's water lilies murals. It is included in the Paris Museum Pass and is a much more do-able sized museum to explore if you have young ones with you.

Impressionist Paradise. Amazing paintings of Monet's water lilies in 360 degree displays in two rooms. After a long overnight flight, I sat (yes, there is a big comfortable couch in each room) and soaked in the restorative beauty for a long time. Also enjoyed the paintings downstairs by Renoir, Degas, and Picasso. An Impressionist paradise!

Combine with Musee d'Orsay for a better deal. This is across the river and a few minutes' walk away from the Musee d'Orsay. It is worth seeing for the layout of Monet's water lilies on the ground floor. However there is also a large collection of paintings on the floor below including Picasso, Renoir and Degas, as well as other interesting artists like Chaim Soutaine. I bought a 16 euro ticket that allows entry to this and Musee d'Orsay. Queues were not long (about 15 minutes on an April weekday afternoon).
Breathtaking. Monet's Water Lillies are breathtaking. Great collection of Renoir. Nice museum to walk around for a couple of hours.

Magnificent Monet!. This is an excellent place in which you can immerse yourself in the truly outstanding Monet water lilies 360 degree displays. Quite unique. Went early on a weekday and had barely a 2 minute queue. Not the greatest collection of other painters - including Picasso and Renoir but pleasant enough.

A Must See. This is a must see museum when in Paris. The two oval rooms that house Monet’s Water Lilies are spectacular! You see the perspective of each panel as well as how they all work together from the benches in the center of each room. In the second room, it is interesting to look at the tree trunk/bark and notice that the color brown is not used at all. The basement of the museum houses some more Impressionist work, a special exhibit and the book/museum store. This museum is in a great spot; at the beginning of the Tuileries Garden, half way down the Champs Elysee on your way to the Louvre.

Wow!. Really worth a visit, epically as it is included in the Paris pass which I would also recommend. I am not normally someone who visits art museums, but it was spectacular here. I never released who big some of the paintings were. Really nice way to spend a few hours enjoying classic art.

Good but not great. The two Monet water lilies rooms were excellent. I also enjoyed the drawings in the west side of the building. The paintings were from well known artists such as Renoir, Picasso, and Cezanne. I just did not find the work to be all that pleasing to the eye. While I respect them for their historical value, and wanted to like them, they were underwhelming to be. The venue is also very small. If you have the museum pass, are in the area, it is worth a look. Otherwise, there are better options.

Perfect meditation upon light and/or dark. The two rooms of Monet's studies in light of the lilies are like no other. I love art, museum's not crowds. We went early, and the rooms were not yet full. We found seats, and had time to enjoy. A timeless and priceless moment.
Not a Lot to See but Beautiful. I didn't do my research in advance so I was expecting to see more, but Monet's work made the stop worth it!

Great for Monet fans. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a nice, little museum in comparison to the others in Paris. Large oval rooms with 360 degree paintings from Monet who designed the rooms too. Nice, quieter museum with fewer crowds. It's great to sit in the rooms and see all the different aspects of these large pieces. The museum in in a great location at the Tuileries Garden and you can easily get from here to the Orsay Museum for more great Monet works of art. Both are part of the Museum Pass which I highly recommend to make it easy to skip long ticket lines and encourage you to see some places you may not have normally considered. The drawback is you're not allowed to take photos of the Monet paintings so consider the gift shop for a souvenir postcard or small print.
Favorite museum. We enjoyed the overall small but beautiful exhibit. The Monet lilies should not be missed! In two oval rooms you are transported to the country side.

Great place to relax. In a city were it's easy to get carried away and start hopping from attraction to attraction, this museum and it's wonderful Monet's Nymphéas naturally invited us to sit down, relax and enjoy the place. Definitively worth a visit.

More than Monet's Water Lilies. This museum does not allow express entrance even for museum pass holders. The queue was long but worth it. Monet's water lilies were beautiful and serene. Did not expect it to be so large. Whatever we saw beforehand on prints , is only a small section of the entire painting. There were also delightful collections from Renoir, Picasso and other artists on display. We were very lucky there was a Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition at the same time. It was awe-inspiring.
Beautiful. Really enjoyed the Impressionist art here. The Monet murals were beautiful and great experience viewing them. Unique.

A perfect place to see the large Monet's. I could have spent hours looking at the large Monet's perfectly displayed, brought a combined ticket from Orsay, Orangerie a good addition to the Orsay collection.

A hidden treasure. We'd heard that l'Orangerie had two specially designed rooms to house eight of Claude Monet's Nymphéas, so that was the focus of our visit. The two oval rooms with their vast canvasses are incredible, perfectly arranged and laid out, with seating so that you can appreciate the view.An added surprise was a small but excellent collection of later 19th century and early 20th century works by Matisse, Renoir and even a couple of Picassos. Not to be missed, so make sure you make time to see them even if you're only there for the water-lillies!

Now so much more than just Monet's Water Lillies. Definitely worth seeing if your taste runs more toward post-1850 art. Beautiful display of Monet's famous work, but now includes many other works from artists from the same period.

Great exhibition but where is the cafe?. This is a great art gallery. We spent about 90 minutes here, long enough to see everything but not get too worn out. The water lilies are inspiring and well presented. Despite being a star attraction the galleries were not overcrowded and there is plenty of bench space from which to admire them. The rest of the collection is worth a look, plenty of variety but not daunting for those of us that are not art experts.Being used to London museums I was really surprised that there isn't a cafe. There is a cafe in the Tuilieres gardens but apart from that nothing nearby.

Another must see, if you have time. The lily pond of Monet stretch across an oval room going from morning until evening. This is a lifetime event that takes both money and time to view. There are so many art exhibits to see in Paris that you can't be faulted for not seeing this one, but it's so close to the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay! Get the museum pass and take an hour or two to view the exhibits here.

A Paris Must!. The Musee de l'Orangerie is the perfect complement to a peaceful stroll around Tuileries Garden. You must sit and gaze upon the quiet splendor of Monet’s Water Lillies murals. The Staff is very friendly and many speak English so communication is not an issue.
A wonderful experience. The display of the Monet water lilies is absolutely beautiful. When we visited, the Gallery was free on the first Sunday of the month.

Worth a visit. Loads of paintings to look at. Well laid out. Make sure you buy a joint ticket with the Musee d'Dorsay. If you are in Paris the first Sunday of the month remember entry to both is free! Even if you miss this day still very much worth the entrance fee.
in love with Monet. what a Romantic place!!!!i would love to visit it with a girl and kiss her surronded by the Water Lilies!!!:D

Must not miss. we went on a Sunday so we didn't have to buy tickets. Despite the free entry ,the crowds were not very big perhaps because we went early morning . Monet's water lilies are beautifuly ethereal which goes without saying , but what I really liked was the private collection of Paul Guillaume . The Museum is not very large but it houses paintings of different artists of repute.When in paris I know you must visit the Louvre , but honestly this was my favourite Musee. Must not miss!!

Beautiful and amazing experience. Musee de l'Orangerie is a beautiful experience, and it is one of the best museums in Paris. If you get an audio guide, it tells you all about the art and its collector. There is a number that you can type in to your audio guide next to almost every painting - it is a little hard to keep up with. The room with the Nympheas are extraordinary, and you learn so much about Monet's life. The lower section of the museum is extraordinary as well and I got surprised by the personal lives of some of the artists. The museum is quite small compared to some French museums, but bigger is not always better. There is still so much I have not seen there, and would be pleased to go back.

Arguably the best museum in Paris. my third visit to Paris, yet my first time to Orangerie. It wasn't as popular as Louvre or Orsay which was why I did not visit it in my first 2 visits. BUT, it was AWESOME. I liked it the most out of Orsay - Louvre - Orangerie. It's definitely very small (1-2hours, depending on how long to enjoy each piece), but the pieces was very good and crowd was much more reasonable than the two other museums. Love the water lilies the most!

English Tour on Mondays. We arrived in time for the 2:30 tour with an English speaking guide. She was very knowledgeable about art and the artists. The side exhibit of the collection of Paul Guillaume was actually more interesting to me than Monet's water lllies. Allow at least 2 hours.

Terrific smaller museum. I really enjoyed the waterlilies rooms, but was also pleasantly surprised at the rest of the collection in this museum. I particularly liked seeing a 7-8 Modigliani paintings they have. It's right on Place de la Concorde, a half block from the Metro station, so it's easy to get to.

Our Favourite Paris Museum. The Orangerie is a magical place. The 2 oval waterlilly rooms will take your breath away. There is also an impressive collection of impressionist art in the basement which is very diverse and interesting. The whole museum has a calm and approachability not easily found in Paris - It is a welcome break from the Louvre and the d'Orsay which are fabulous, but overwhelming and exhausting. The museum has a particularly lovely, but small, gift shop featuring an unusually tasteful selection of postcards. books, trinkets, and higher end items.HINTS: 1. Try to visit when the museum opens to have some time with the water lillies alone, or at least in a small group. The experience is more powerful when you can sit on the central benches and look around you seeing the lillies without people in the way. 2. If the first water lilly room is busy, go through to the second room - often it is far less busy than the first and you might get some private time there. 3. The Orangerie is covered by the Museum Pass, or by a combined ticket with the Orsay, as well as its own ticket. If you opt for the combined ticket, you DO NOT have to visit both the same day, you have 4 days to visit the second museum.

360 Les Nympheas..wow. Impressionist art is really my favorite (not an art snob by any means) I came based on a friend's recommendation, buying the combined ticket for this and Musee d'Orsay (I'd recommend if you're doing same day, saved 4 euro I think). I wasn't expecting as much from this one, based on the reputation of Musee d'Orsay, but I ended up spending the most time in any one room in the upstairs Monet Les Nympheas exhibit, as any in Paris. Something about the 360 views...grab a seat and soak it in. Fascinating comparing different vantage points, up close, middle, corner, to really appreciate the art.
Great museum. We went there just to see Monet's water lilies, but found so much more wonderful art on the lower level and stayed much longer than I expected. It's definitely worth a visit.
My FAVORITE MUSEUM. Don't miss Monet's Waterlillies rooms. Then we were blown away by the immense Impressionist collection in the gallery. WOW!

Les Nympheas - Wow!. If you look at nothing else, you must see Les Nympheas - Monet's Water lilies, but I'll come to that in a minute.This museum has a good number of impressionist works on display, by a number of artists. Very interesting to compare styles within the genre. At the time we visited, there was an exhibition of drawings staged, which was fabulous, covering many different styles and a vast array of subject matter. And finally of course, there are Les Nympheas. Simply breath taking - but what I wasn't prepared for was the second oval room, which for me surpassed even the stunning paintings in the first oval room. Having been to Giveny, one could feel the atmosphere beside his lake, under the willows, looking at the water lilies. These works are magical and to spend time sitting with them is a blissful experience.Would say that this museum is a must and also that it is worth a revisit - it's on my list. The only frustration is the queuing system to get to the security and then to the ticket booth, but once past that it's so worth it. Do go.
One of a kind. Monet's water lilies. In a setting designed for the paintings. If you can't make to Givernay be sure to come here. Book for a quiet time and sit and drink in the beauty.

Monet Heaven. I loved this museum. I expected to be blown away by the water lily murals and I was. But the pleasure did not end there. This museum is jam packed with mind blowing impressionist art. It's not huge but it is a place to see al the great French Impressionists n

My favorite in Paris!. Seriously, if you haven't been here, put it at the top of your list - especially if you love Monet. The first time I went I was in one of the rooms by myself and I started to cry. A little dramatic? Maybe, but imagining Monet helping in the design of the building so the light is just right....then imagining him painting on those walls. Pretty incredible. Just go.

So nice. Monet heaven. The oval galleries that display the large Monet's are exquisite. The other galleries are also worth seeing. I have been there twice and want to return. Best Monet's in the world.

Exquisite. We visited the Orangerie to see Monet's waterlilies paintings which were wrapped around the oval shaped walls exquisitely. It was very peaceful and relaxing and there are seats available to allow you to take it all in. My daughter had a notepad and drew her own 'waterlilies' pictures - we would have loved to visit Monet's gardens in Giverny while we were in Paris but didn't get the chance so the Orangerie was the next best thing!

Wow. Housed in a small building a stones throw from the Louvre the Orangerie is a must for any impressionist lover. The immense Monet paintings are the star but down the stairs you will find a huge collection of paintings from other famous names of Monet's era. The place is utterly stunning.

Small but breathtaking. With so many big named museums in Paris it would have been easy to skip the Orangerie, but on my fourth trip to Paris I finally made it, and wow. We had seen reproductions of Monet's water lilies all our lives--but to see them in person, huge, in a room that was designed specifically for them according to Monet's instructions was truly breathtaking. We were there at the end of the day and had the room's practically to ourselves. We will remember that for the rest of our lives.

Well worth it. The monet paintings that make up the main part of the permanent exhibition are great and displayed perfectly to appreciate their size and variety. Rest of the museum was really good- be prepared to queue and - seemingly like everywhere in paris now- bring ID to get the (very good) audio guide.

Best gallery!. The Orangerie is delightful every single time I visit. Monet's waterlillies are incredible, and you could easily spend a long time gazing into the artwork. The huge stretches of canvas fill the walls of two oval shaped rooms - stunning. In the downstairs galleries, there is an impressive collection of artwork by Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Modigliani and more. The museum is a very manageable size for anybody, my boyfriend doesn't normally enjoy art, but absolutely loved this museum and the way it was displayed. It is included in the Paris Museum Pass and is definitely worthwhile. Could recommend to anyone and I have never experienced crowding there like can happen at the Louvre and Musée d'Orsay.

A Memorable Visit. I am a big fan of Monet and have wanted to visit this museum for those water lily paintings for a long time. This visit did not disappoint me. It was simply breath taking and mesmorizing standing in those nicely designed show room and watching the giant paintings. I assume someone can stand there gazing for hours. This museum also provides other nice exhibitions. The size of this museum makes it not too overwhelming as compared to some other museums in Paris, where you need to spend days of exhaustive hours to walk through.

become part of Monet's waterlillies. Small museum but what an amazing display of the Monet waterlilles. There are two rooms of them and you can sit and feel that you get absorbed into them. They are highlighted with natural light from oval windows above. Don't miss this.

One of the best small museums in the world. I revisited the l'Orangerie to see the magnificent display of Monet's water lillies, and they were as fantastic as I remembered; but the richness of the rest of the collection lifts this museum above almost every other in the world. The Monet exhibit is one of the most powerful art displays I've ever seen and to have that complimented by strong collections of Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso and others is really stunning. The museum is small an often not as crowded as some of the other Paris museums, which adds to the power of the experience.

favorite impressionist museum in the world!. housing the finest art by the great impressionists and more.
also, you can get up close to the art and gawk at each piece without horrible crowds.

An Unexpected Find. A wonderful display of Monet's Water Lilies.... Four wall filling paintings wrapping the room in glorious color set in an intimately sized room, alone, with glorious light. There is also a collection of Renoir, Cezanne, and Picasso on the lower levels.
A very manageable size museum for anyone.

Small but extremely valuable . This is a great afternoon museum with Renoir, Monet, Picasso, Matisse, Derain, Cezanne and others. The audio is detailed and affordable. Monet's Water Lilies should not be missed while in Paris.

Wonderful small museum. Spectacular room-sized Monet murals in oval rooms are amazing. Wish we could have taken photos. Don't miss the Renoir's on the lower floor. His paintings of children are so charming. This small museum is a breath of fresh air after being in the overly-crowded Louvre. Don't miss it, especially if you have a museum pass. Doesn't take very long to see the highlights.

Must-see if you like Impressionist art. It was a priority for me to see Monet's Water Lilies while in Paris, and they did not disappoint! There is also a decently-sized collection of Renoir, Cezanne, and Picasso on the lower levels that does not overwhelm. It was definitely my favorite museum experience in Paris!The only thing I didn't love was that you can't take photos, which only seemed odd because I took tons of them with no problem at the Louvre...
Sometimes smaller is better. More memorable to me because it was compact, and easy to see the paintings with fewer crowds. Monet's Water Lilies really shone in this setting.

Great for Monet lovers. During a recent Paris visit, I purchased a Paris Museum pass, which includes most Paris museums. The pass is a good value if you visit more than 5 or 6 museums and it includes Versailles. So we used it to visit this museum. My wife is a fan of Monet and though there are only a few here, they are massive. The museum is a short walk from the Louvre and Musee D'Orsay. There is not a lot of art here compared to the other two, so I doubt I would have spent the extra euros to see this museum if it was not covered by the pass. If you do opt to buy the pass, which I recommend if you plan to visit at least Notre Dame, the Louvre, Musee D'Orsay and Versailles, then this is a great museum to include. We had a 4 day pass and visited ten museums and saved over $105.

Top Impressionist Work in Intimate Setting. This museum is great for seeing top notch Impressionist work in a small setting. Very manageable. Only negative was the audio guide was pretty dumbed down. Would love an option for substantive information.
Water lillys. Oooooooooo, if you love Monet this is museum to go.. if you don't- skip it. The best it has are water lillys, other paintings are not as nearly interesting as them..

Worth it for the waterlillies. My favourite museum exhibit in Paris - the two rooms housing the paintings are stunning in their simplicity and the staff enforce the policy of silence so not to spoil the contemplation.
A great little gallery, with some top notch art work. This is a great art gallery, lots of the famous artists on show. What lets it down is the disgusting toilet facilities.

Beautiful, small collection. This tiny art museum is an experience! It is quite something to experience the splendor of the water lilies in a setting the artist himself envisioned for these 08 murals.The upper floor also has a nice Impressionist collection of a manageable size and appropriate variety which doesn't tire you out like the d'Orsay or Louvre do. The architecture of this small museum is also a treat to behold.The lines for entry were really long when i visited in the late afternoon, took about one hour to get in. I would recommend getting the combined ticket for the Orangerie and the d'Orsay, which will save you time when you go to your next museum (the d'Orsay has huge lines at all times) as well as make a small bargain. If memory serves me right, I think the combined ticket was 16 Euros and lasts for 24 hours, so you can go to the d'Orsay the same day or the next day, like I did.The museum shop is nice to browse and get prints or postcards.

Top 3 in Paris. Thoroughly recommend this bijoux gallery. It's much smaller than the nearby louvre and orsay, so you can get round in an hour or so. The nympheas are of course fantastic and the stars of the show in full 360 degree glory. I had not expected the rest of the collection to be as strong. It's a bit pricy but you can enter on a multi ticket. Personally I would chose this, musee rodin and the pompidou over the louvre. The latter is really just too huge to take in without dedicating a lot of time and the older works are less to my taste.The orangerie is at the far end of the tuilleries on the seine side. Try it, if you like monet you won't be disappointed.

Worth it just to see Monet's most famous pieces. When I visited here I thought it was a very small and simple gallery with a good eclectic mix, but... upon going to the top floor after doing downstairs first, I was blown away by the two rooms up there. Think of two circular rooms, and all around you are the huge Monet masterpieces the "Water Lillis". Believe me they take your breath away, just sit on one of the benches and lose time looking at the majesty of Monet.

Love the water lilies!. This was my favourite museum in Paris because I could focus on what I love - Monet's water lilies.They have some other paintings on display in the basement, but I did not come for those, and spent only a little time there. Still, I enjoyed those as well, but for me - the water lilies is worth the entire museum ticket.

Great Visit!. For me it was a small but lovely museum, specially for its main feature: Monet. But I must say that, in my opinion, it's not worth the entrance fee. I went there the first sunday of March and I'm grateful I didn't have to pay. I wouldn't have if I had to.

Get the twin-pass with the Musee D'Orsay. I think I liked this collection more than the D'Orsay. The museum was quieter and really it only cost a few euros more to get the twin pass and see both places (which is good for 5-7 days after visiting the first museum). They don't allow photos to be taken which is a bit of a shame.

Custom design for Monet's Nymphea Waterlily paintings!. After so many years of renovation, I was thrilled to see Monet's paintings of the waterlilies in the display that was designed specifically for them.(by Monet, himself!) The experience of standing in this quiet and peaceful gallery space is amazing. The changing light as depicted by Monet is fabulous. A small, intimate museum that is so worth seeing when in Paris.
Wonderful water lilies. Well worth a visit, a little tranquil spot compared with the louvre, its a lovely way to spend an hour or so, and has an excellent bookshop!
wonderful waterlilies. The Monets are amazing and the atmosphere is restful we also enjoyed the Utrillos and Cezannes . The waterlilies are spectacular.

Confusing to find. I loved what they had to offer, but it took me a hot minute to figure out where to get into the building. It may have been that I walked there from the Louvre and was trying to follow the signage, that seemed to disappear when i needed it. Pretty crowded for what I thought was not a major attraction. I didn't try the audio guide, but that might be something to try if I go back. Check the tour schedules, I missed the one I was going for by a half hour.

The best museum to visit in Paris if you're short on time!. If you are pressed for time on a trip to Paris, I highly recommend l'Orangerie. Somehow it hadn't made it on my radar until about 3 days before we left for Paris, but I'm so glad it did! Since it was right in our walking path to the other side of the Seine, and also included in our Paris Museum Pass, we decided to hit it first thing on the Saturday morning of Fashion Week (which was a great idea, because it made for terrific people watching in the Tuileries garden that morning!).Words can't really express how amazing the Water Lilies installations are in this space. They are gorgeous, and I could easily sit on the benches here and just gaze at them and daydream away. Stunning. There are two complete rooms, and it seems like most people get hung up in room #1, as room #2 was far less busy (and to me, contained the better paintings).We did go to the Louvre and d'Orsay, but I must admit - I think some of the best paintings were housed in l'Orangerie. This, plus being MUCH less crowded than the other two big art museums, really provided for a perfect start to our musee-filled day! Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse (drool), and oh my word, Soutine.... You can do this museum quickly and feel very fulfilled in terms of seeing some of the greatest art in the world.Note: Of all the museums, I saw the least kids here . Its VERY quiet in this museum and also rather cramped in terms of space, so I'm not sure this is the best place to take a baby/kid while in Paris.
Monet's nymphetes. I don't have words enough to describe what an impression you get of 8 meters of the Great Monet's nymphets on the walls of the museum! It's just unbelievable!
Big things come in small packages. I was amazed at the size of Monet's paintings. There are so many master painting in this small museum.

Exquisite. I've been to Paris many time and this is the first time I visited this Museum. It is probably the most beautiful place in Paris and the paintings are equally on a par with the Louvre. Don't miss it.
Impressionist lovers delight. It's well worth a couple of hours visit with a great impressionist collection and the most wonderful display of Monet's water lilies in 2 oval rooms. Very atmospheric.

Wow. Came here on a busy summer day in August of 2013. Queue wasn't too long, and museum is spectacular. Depending on your interest in art, you could spend an hour to 3 in here. The Monet room is beautiful dome shape room. Huge and once there aren't kids running around being loud, it's very peaceful. Got the audio guide to help translate to English & fully better understand the work. Would also recommend getting the guide.

Just what you need. It was beautiful, not too big to be overwhelmed, but enough to capture the eye and interest. I was particularly pleased to see works by Henri Matisse displayed. If you like art, there's plenty here to entertain you for a while. I thoroughly recommend.
Very interesting museum.. Not far away from the Louvre Museum, Paris. If not in a hurry, try to visit this museum. Many excellent collection inside.

Beautiful. We really enjoyed the beautiful permanent display of Monet's eight water lily murals. They were something to see and experience for sure. We loved the two rooms they are housed in and the atmosphere created in each room. Peaceful. The rest of the museum was well done and we enjoyed the paintings. We had our 9 year old with us, and went through more quickly than we maybe would have without him, however, we saw everything and were in and out in an hour.
