Not a museum you need to budget a lot of time to experience. (No painting explanations in any other language than French.)

Hmm..... I'll start by saying I'm not a huge Monet fan. I appreciate his work but it's not my favorite. We had a museum pass and got in for free but I don't think this museum was worth the full entry price. The water lily rooms were neat and there were a couple interesting rooms down stairs but overall I was underwhelmed.

Wonderful Museum. This is a small, but astonishing museum in the heart of Paris. It's located at the end of Tuillerie garden.The first floor is totally dedicated to Claude Monet, there is some wonderful paintings - Les Nymphéas- that are the most beautiful painting that I ever saw from Monet.The basement is dedicate to Walter-Guillaume collection with paintings of Picasso, Renoir, Cezánne, Sautin, Utrilloand others Masters.It's a must see museum, and depending of your interest in the artists you can visit the museum in one hour or five!

A museum built around paintings.... It was the last day of a four day trip to Paris with three adolescent girls. We weren't sure how much more art they would be willing to take in. So we decided to opt for a small museum... And the visit was perfect. The pieces are absolutely beautiful. And the presentation with natural light is a piece of art in itself. Just sit down and contemplate the marvel, take in the colors, the atmosphere, feel the water, the flowers, the slight breeze... Smell the scents. The explanations of how this was all put together are also most interesting. As is the exhibit of paintings of contemporaries. I liked the shop as well. If you just have another hour of time and/or energy, Musee de l'Orangerie is the perfect visit. And if you have more time to spare, all the better!

A must-see for Monet fans.. My husband and I went mid-morning and the museum wasn't crowded at all, so quite relaxing. Our entry fees were covered with our Paris Passes. The museum is a very manageable size, so a visit can easily be about an hour or two. The Nymphéas paintings are beautiful and a must-see for Monet fans. Photography is also allowed inside. I've recommended this museum to friends who have also loved it.

The water lilies are stunning!. If you like impressionist art, this is the museum for you. Its not as busy as the Louvre and not as big. but there are some big names - Monet, Renoir, Picasso etc. The water lilies are stunning and huge - you are just mesmerized when you go in. Its again included in the museum pass.

not too bad not perfect eitherr. It was worth a short visit since I was nearby (included in the museum pass). The garden outside is really nice, the museum is good but not very special compared to others in the neighborhood.

Sweet Museum, Semi-confusing. Amazing building with the very famous, large paintings that I found much less interesting than the building itself, and the remainder of the collection downstairs. My fault for not knowing French; France's fault for not doing a better job of providing descriptions in ANY other language. I almost missed much of what there was to see because of the odd traffic flow and lack of signage. Could just be me, but two other people I spoke to in Paris had the same issue. The story here is so much more than impressionism - definitely worth the visit
The Best Museum In Paris. This was by far the best museum we went to. It is small and perfect especially coming from the Louvre. Seeing Monet's paintings from wall to wall was just breathtaking!
Its ok. Its only ok use of time, Long waits, the art is great but not much of it. lots of current local stuff.The main attraction is marvelous.
Gorgeous Museum. If you get your Paris museum pass you can do this and some of the other places around the Louvre in one day. The best part is of course the Monets!

worth it. I may be bashing the Louvre a bit, but I believe that the Orangerie museum is good if you want to spend an hour or more. This is unlike other museums which go on for an eternity giving you a headache.
Nice exhibition of Monet. If you like Monet's style, then come the Orangerie. You can purchase a combined ticket with the Musée d'Orsay.

Accidental visit - staple of trips to Paris. When my wife and I first travelled to Paris we came across the musee de l'orange completely by accident while walking. If it hadn't been associated with the musee d'orsay we possibly wouldn't have visited. Thankfully we did and experienced a wonderful 2 hour tour taking in one of the world's most famous collection of paintings namely Monet's waterlilies. Viewing those enormous masterpieces became the highlight of the trip and when in Paris we make it a point to revisit when we can.

The most important museum to see!. I had no idea that Monet had been so instrumental in forming this museum for viewing his works! It was wonderful. The museum was easy to get into and not as overwhelming as the Louvre. This should be first on your list if you are into Impressionism. The bottom floor is full of important works also.

Quick & Easy. We visited the museum on a weekday afternoon and there was only a 2 minute wait for coat check to deal with. Very easy entrance with no wait compared to other museums we visited on this trip. The two Monet rooms were the highlight and should not be missed on a trip to Paris if you are a Monet fan at all. We couldn't have imagined the amount of texture and dimension of these pieces.

Small and can easily visit in 2 hours!. This small museum is only 2 floors. The bottom floor holds Impressionism by Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso and Renoir among others. The were in the private collection of Paul Guillaume, a French art dealer, and his widow Jean Walter. They are well presented by the museum and we enjoyed walking through, with many places to sit and just enjoy. The top floor is, of course, the renowned water lilies exhibition by Monet. If you have the time, it is well worth the 2 hours (of course, you can spend much longer if you listen to the entire audio guide) and the price is reasonable.
Take your time, bring some headphones.. Monet's rooms are supposed to be for quiet contemplation and meditation, but there's too much talking, so bring headphones and gaze away.
Small, but Beautiful!. A smaller, open concept museum in Paris. You can do it in about an hour. It is worth the trip in order to sit and enjoy Les Nymphéas.

Monets stunning panels. Always a favourite of ours and we go to visit Les Nympheas - the immense paintings of Monet's waterlilies - every time we are in Paris – they never cease to be awe inspiring and jaw dropping. Give yourself time to sit and contemplate, and to absorb each of the paintings and dream….We were lucky to be there on the first day of a Freda Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition which was outstanding and an added bonus. To complete the Monet experience, try to get to Monet’s house at Giverney and to Musee Marmottan to see the collection that Monet’s son gave to the nation.
My favorite museum in Paris. The peaceful, bright showrooms and crowd control help make for an amazing art-viewing experience. Monet's painting are jaw-dropping.

Monet! Beautiful!. As Monet is a favorite of mine, I love the upstairs where he is showcased. We are not so much into the rest of the art in this museum, it isn't our taste. But if you love Monet, this a must. Sit for an hour in peace and quiet and soak it in. What a lovely way to spend an afternoon! Reasonably price, too.

Monet's masterpieces. I could have spent hours looking at the large water lilies. If you love painting you will love seeing the details of stroke and color in these works. The Paul Guilliame collection is amazing as well. To see so many of post Impressionism & early modern works in one place was a great experience.

most worthwhile visit to a small art museum in this city. Few places can match this for high intensity of interest.. If you need a reason for getting a college degree in western european art especially French art of the period late 19th century then here it is in abundance. "Water lilies" are the origin of abstract art. If you need a reason to become infatuated with art of the Monet here it is in abundance. If you are a fan of Monet's art and his contribution to western European art to say nothing of French art then you must stay here for at least three hours. Small museum to be sure but this is a required visit. Giverny might be the Sistine chapel of impressionism, but his collection has gems that you can not see elsewhere. If you visit the one place you can not be honest with yourself and think of reasons to avoid seeing the is small museum. If you need a reason to attend college and study art of this period here it is in abundance. Forget about bringing the right lunch. Worrying about that is like checking to see if you like the vending machines outside the door of the Vatican museum. Lighting is wonderful. So is the environment or atmosphere. Pre-eminent Monet collection for sure. I do not know why somebody would miss seeing this collection if they spend three days at the other larger museums in this city or elsewhere. Chartres for sure is here in design. Do not get carried away with photographing the water lilies because you might bump into others. Buy a good reproduction. They did not allow photographs when I was there.

see monet's waterlilies as he wanted them displayed. so many people miss this small but extraordinary museum. don't be one of them!! it is a nice cozy size, therefore, not overwhelming. it is designed to show the waterlily panels in the most perfect way. skylights provide very beautiful lighting and the panels (40 feet?) are one continuous vision of the aqua garden at giverny.don't miss the nice collection of impressionists that is in the basement. there are some very beautiful painting there.
A must if you are Monet fan.. One must visit this museum if you are a Monet fan. Nice seating area in order to soak up Monet's masterpieces.Recommend you give yourself two to three hours.
If you love Monet's work, this is a must see. This is a preeminent Monet presentation as well as other works of the period. The venue is beautiful and to see these Water Lilies, well, wow!!!
Beautiful. Take the time to visit, sit and stare, refresh your eyes then look back again - I promise you will see new colours... just incredible.
Monet lover's. The water Lily murals are like nothing else. Painted just for this museum thry are truly grand in scale. Nice gift shop too.
Great museum. Monets artwork was breath taking and well set out. The two oval rooms have his artwork, waterlillies set around all four walls.

Les Nymphéas is a must see!!!. I like to specially mention the places we think it is worthy to go is the Museum of L'Orangerie where it hosts Monet's greatest masterpiece of Les Nymphéas (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6fHorNn2zqQ). It is absolutely gorgeous and beautiful! Face and stare to these giant painting you feel that intensity of the colors, melting water lilies and lights and it shadows and the shadows of the flowers into the water, everything is in harmony and so tranquil and peaceful. It makes you slipping into deep thinking and mediating...
Fantastic!. Love Monet it's a must see! Went back three times in one day! What more is there to say to fill up 100 characters!!!

Lots of Lillys. there are two huge oval rooms built and designed specifically to appreciate Monet Waters Lilly's. if you are a fan of Monets then this is a must see. if you are unsure then i would recommend the Musee d'Orsay first (as it has a wider range of impressionist paintings)then Musee de l'Orangerie if you have time.

Manageable size. With the huge museums in Paris it was nice to enjoy a small one. Rented the audio guide and that made for a very leisurely stroll through a beautiful space. Monet's "Water Lilies" are just part of a wonderful collection.

Monet is exquisite!. Wonderful relaxing experience to be able to enjoy the mesmerizing beauty of the water lilies quietly and peacefully. We were able to move around the room, from painting to painting, and sit as long as we wanted. Exquisite Monet!
Our Favourite!. We loved our afternoon at the Musee de l"Orangerie! We arrived on a quiet day and had the place to ourselves, very lucky and a day we will never forget!

Don't miss the other part. Monet is one thing, but this museum has a whole separate collection of exquisite art.. A ticket to the Musée d'Orsay can be expanded for an entry here which avoids the line.

Awe-inspiring. Monet's water nymph paintings are exquisite and a must see, but we also were able to see the Frieda Kahlo and Diego Riviera exhibit which was such an incredible opportunity. This is a very beautiful museum.

Worth the trip. I was looking forward to seeing the Waterlillies and they do not let you down. You can just sit in the middle of the room for as long as you want to and just enjoy these very large pieces of art. It was very relaxing just to drift away in front of these.

More than just Monet. This museum has always excellent exhibitions, besides the rooms for the water lilies of Monet. It is worth getting an audio guide. There is also a fine permanent exhibition from Paul Guillaume, the famous art dealer of the 1900s.
waterlillies...what more can you say?. You can't take pictures but if you have a museum pass, it's definitely worth the time to go in and take a peek. It's so quiet and beautiful in this hall.
Combine with a trip to Musee d'Orsay. Really enjoyed our visit. Wee tip - you can buy a joint pass to visit both d'Orsay & de l'Orangerie.

Timeless beauty. A visit to Paris is not complete without a visit to this jewel of a museum. The highlight of course are the massive water lilies paintings that fill the basement level in perpetuity that are the crowning achievement of the impressionist master Claude Monet. Other floors usually have a mix of the permanent collection and outstanding temporary exhibitions. TIP-if you visit the D,orsay you can buy a combination ticket for the l'Orangerie and avoid the long lines!

One man's vision and passion is a timeless gift to all.. This gem doesn't receive the attention given to the Louvre, Musee d'Orsay etc but it certainly deserves it. Monet's monumental "Decorations des Nympheas" will astound you and there are other works by Renoir, Matisse and Cezanne to name a few. The tranquility provided in the viewing areas especially designed by Monet is a breath of fresh air and you can easily believe you are in his famous garden. When you visit, buy the DVD that explains the story behind this great gift that Monet has bequeathed us.

Excellent. Regular river taxis, that pick you up and drop you off at or near most of the sights and they are not expensive, other river trips give you a meal and a running commentary on all the sights as you go up and down the river.

The Clockwork Orangerie. This is the only Paris Museum that, on our 10th or so visit, actually has improved over the years, despite the kind of extensive revisions and renovations that have wrecked the nearby Orsay, or the curatorial arrogance and incompetence that has turned the Pompidou Center into a repository of modern garbage while banishing to the vaults the great masterpieces it used to display. We have to thank, firstly, Claude Monet for foreseeing the future of modern art administration and firmly affixing his masterpieces to the walls where they are immune from further interference. Secondly, the Paul Guillaume bequest probably came with very strict conditions ensuring that his treasures would be made available to the public simply and directly, without the obfuscation that thrives in the administrative offices of so many of this city's museums.The Nympheas series is not unique, since Monet has conjured up much of the same magic at the more distant Marmotton Museum, but the quality of the works, their scale and the way they are displayed, and their very number ----- 8 in all, make this the most completely satisfying expression of his artistic vision that he was able to bequeath to future generations. One then has to descend 2 floors into the bowels of the Tuileries Gardens, where, at one end, an auditorium runs a continuous program of short features on the artists whose work you are about to see, and the rest of the space is devoted to the works themselves. Some of the side rooms feature photos and documents describing Guillaume's fascinating life and his dealings with the artists whose work he sponsored. Chief among them --------- and they all get at least one room to themselves, are Derain, Renoir, Cezanne, Henri Rousseau, Utrillo, Soutine, and Picasso ( this latter room was under reorganization and closed to the public, but a number of gaps in construction enabled a sight of many of the great works residing within). The arrows guide you logically and responsibly through the residues of one of the greatest private collections of all time (photographs show many of the treasures that were once part of it). It is refreshing to be able to enjoy these paintings in a Museum that works ---- like clockwork. Remember, there is a combined ticket for this and the Orsay that will save you money, and it is valid for up to 7 days.

Jewel on the Crown!. We were worried when we only arrived the Museum around 10am, as other reviewers suggested that they had to wait for over 3 hours queuing in the cold in November when they arrived that late. We were sweetly surprised as there were no one at the entrance on a Monday morning in January! The Museum housed the best of Claude Monet's waterlilies kept in 2 oval rooms with natural lights coming from the roof. It was awesome at first sight. We dropped our jaws later, as when we moved around the oval room at different distance and angles to see the pictures we see them very differently. The main tone of the waterlilies was in blue and green, and we were at a loss when there was one picture with patches of yellow in the centre. When we were about to leave and we looked at the same picture at the other end of the room, we then know that he probably wanted to depict the moment of the day, and in this case, the sunset. Nothing so stunning I have ever seen in my life. The collection downstairs are also worth visiting. The pictures by Renoir are exceptional. Do buy the pass for this Museum and Musee D'Orsay when you pay the entrance fee if you are to visit both, so that you can fast track into the other without queuing.

Another unmissable stop whilst in Paris. The Orangerie was originally built in 1852 to shelter the orange trees of the garden of the Tuileries. It has an interesting history and was used by the Third Republic in the nineteenth century as a deposit for goods, an examination room, and place of lodging for mobilised soldiers. Claude Monet was actively involved in redesigning many of the rooms and he donated the Nymphéas series of decorative panels painted on canvas to the French government.After visiting the Tuileries, drop in here and be gobsmacked by the extent of Monet's creativity then another day take the train and travel out to Giverny to visit his home.

LOVED IT!!. Only one thing better than this and that was actually going to Monet's Garden in Giverny. I could have sat and looked at these large canvases for hours...but more sightseeing had to happen.

First museum that I genuinely loved. I've been to number of museums around Europe and the US and have never been really blown away. I am certainly not an art person but enjoy a good museum. L'Orangerie is a truly beautiful museum that is so well thought out. Rather than a place like the Lourve or Rijksmuseum where you just fill a huge space with as much expensive art as you can get your hands on, L'Orangerie has a real unique feel to it, where it is showcasing a limited amount of beautiful art that fits together and works. Soutine, Monet, Picasso, Cezzane, etc. are all beautifully and thoughtfully displayed.
An unusual place. Highly recommend -- a unique place. If you spend time there, you'll feel the atmosphere that all painting together create in this special place.

Nice Museum. We probably would not have gone here without the Paris Museum Pass. Spent a relaxing afternoon here. There were some pretty amazing works in here. Sunday afternoon was BUSY with Parisian locals. Get here early!

Breathtaking. We had none of the crowd or staff issues that others have noted, but we did come mid January.
If you can make it to this museum, do it. It is stunning and amazing to sit and be enveloped by Monet's works.
My favourite Paris gallery. I love this small gallery in Jardin Des Tuileries. An excellent collection of art especially the Monets'.

Gallery of pure contentment.. Until an hour before our visit we weren't really aware of this museum,but we'll never forget it now. The collection is predominantly Monet,and canvasses wrap themselves around the walls thus creating a stunning atmosphere which produced a feeling of pure contentment from our viewing position. Quite simply stunning!

Monet's gift of tranquility. So apparently Monet painted these series of Waterlilies in order to give the workers of Paris a place to go to ease stress at the end of the day. They really are magnificent, the rooms have a real sense of peace about them. Interesting artworks in the lower rooms as well.

Always a treat. Made our way again to le Musée de l'Orangerie to see a special Diego Rivera exhibit... and, of course, Monet. It's a very manageable museum - not too big, but with an excellent collection of work. The special exhibits are beautifully presented w/ clear descriptions of the work and, usually, historical perspectives. The permanent collection is a treat, too!

Monet's Waterlily collection has a surreal effect on me. Loved it purely for Monet. I would say that you MUST visit this museum to see Monet's Waterlily collection. I sat and just absorbed the magnicifence of each individual painting for atleast 15minutes... 2hours staring at Monet is well worth the entry fee. I also enjoyed the rest of the artworks at the museum and the temporary exhibition at the time was well designed. I recommend the museum pass as it will help you beat the queues (I.e. avoid the cold in winter and the huge queues in summer)
Interesting place. This is an intresting modern building. I saw an exhibition here last summer. That was very good - Italian Impressionists. Thank you!

Peace and calm in the centre of the city. The original Orangerie gallery was purpose built to show Monet's extraordinary series of panoramic paintings of his lily pond at Giverny. The two elliptical shaped rooms create curved surfaces so when you view them sitting in the middle of the room they surround you with a wave of colour. The overall effect is one of peace and calm - some would say spiritual. They have since Monet's day extended the galleries underground with major temporary exhibition space. These rooms were the opposite to those above them - full of people jostling to see the paintings with great art but little space for sitting to view the work. This is more the norm in art galleries today especially when it is a block buster show - thus making the space and time allowed to see the Monet's even more memorable. Tip - buy a Museum pass to cut down on queuing time to get in - this is a popular venue at any time of year. Remember it is CLOSED on TUESDAYS.

My wife's favorite!. If you like Monet then you have to come here. This museum was built entirely for his Water Lilies. The entire top floor is dedicated to just those paintings. The natural light from the ceiling is the only way to view the Water Lilies, a print just won't do. There are other pieces of art downstairs but the main focus is on the Water Lilies so you don't need to plan on spending very long there. Buy your tickets ahead of time and skip the one hour wait outside in line!

Other things than the waterlilies. If you visit here make sure you stop to see some of the exquisite Renoir paintings as well as the waterlilies. I was a bit disappointed with the waterlilies but perhaps I am missing something here, but the 2 enormous canvasses are set in 2 huge oval rooms, lit with a dreary cold blue light like a mausoleum. More life and colour to be enjoyed in the other Impressionist paintings; and a very nice little shop.

not what i expected. was not very much excited about this museum. thought to find more smaller work of Monet, rather than the wall-covering large waterlilly-paintings. The building wasn't exciting either.

Water Lily Heaven. This gem of a museum is a must-see in Paris. One entire wing on the ground floor is devoted to Monet's Water Lillies. You walk through two rooms whose walls are covered with these enormous canvases. It is very quiet, no photos allowed, and the light from above is filtered through special material so there is no glare. There are ample benches in the middle so you can just sit and look at the paintings. It's like being in Giverny without leaving Paris.

If you only have time for one Museum..... This is the one I'd recommend as its truly remarkable and memorable for all ages. It isn't too large nor too limited in the Impressionist and post Impressionist art displayed. The highlight for me is a large circular room where there are splendid murals painted by Monet of the Water Lilies of Giverny at different times of the day. Unforgettable!

Wonderful. We queued for 2 hours in the cold but it was so worth it. Really enjoyed Monet's paintings in the oval shaped rooms that he created for somewhere for the people of Paris to go and reflect... just have time out!!!After taking in the beautiful works of Monet, you go downstairs to find paintings by Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse, and there was an exhibition of Frida Kahlo.We really enjoyed the Musee de l'Orangerie.

Whats all the fuss about ?. I guess if you like Monet's work you'll like this place but I found it somewhat boring. A big building with whole walls in rooms with nothing on them. Yes there were many Monet paintings which were very nice but other than that not much of an attraction. There is soooo much more important history to see in Paris that I wouldn't waste my time here. Sorry
Monet. Two galleries with huge paintings by Monet--willows, sunset, etc.--along two long walls and two shorter walls in each gallery. And there's a bench where one can sit to admire them leisurely.

Monet's Water Lilies. Don't miss it! The exhibit of 8 Monet's water lilies was created and designed for the paintings by the artist when he was painting the canvases.Other art work is good including 3-5 Picasso's, 1 (one) Modigliani, some other interesting pieces and a special exhibit area which at the time we were there was Kahlo/Rivera.

Monet. Breathtakinglyjawdroppinglymindblowingly beautiful.. The Musee de l'Orangerie should be towards the top of everyone's list that visits Paris. Located just a short walk down from the Louvre through the wonderful Tuileries garden. The city of lights and love has so many "must see's" it might be hard to fit the gallery in if you only have a day but if you're an art lover then it probably should be penned in right under the Mona Lisa at the Louvre. I actually prefer the Monet. This one painting created a bigger impression on us, in so many ways than most of the art we've seen all over the world. It really is truly inspiring and emotional. Get there a bit earlier than opening and secure the front of the queue, go directly to the murals and walk the infinite loop of Monet's mind. It isn't as crowded early. Then you can sit back on the comfortable benches and soak up just how special this work is. Enjoy.

Love/Hate. First of all, the reason I loved this museum was not because of the permanent collection, which is very impressive and I enjoyed it, but because I just so happened to be in Paris during the Frida Kahlo/Diego Rivera exhibit. Frida Kahlo is my favorite artist and I did not know her work was there until we arrived in Paris so I was basically ecstatic when we showed up around nine in the morning to get in line. And then we stayed in line for three hours in the frigid cold and blustering winds of I'm estimating thirty-five mph. It was actually horrible, not like losing your home cable connection for half a weekend horrible, but truly upsetting. In the end it was worth it for me, but I am almost sure my friend loves me a little less because I made us stay in line and she was hardly enthusiastic about the visit to begin with, regardless of waiting time and weather. Here you will find the giant Monets in the stark white oval room that you see sometimes in films, but if it had not been for the temporary exhibit I would have been mad for waiting so long to get in. But impressionism is not really my thing, so take my opinion with a heaping spoonful of salt. If your apartment is wallpapered with a repetitive waterlilies print then by all means go and see this place, you will cherish it. Whoever you are, just make sure you realize you may be in it for the long haul and bring climate-appropriate attire.
Breathtaking Monet!. The Monet murals took my breath away! Try to go during the off season if possible so you can really take it all in without too many people in the way. Loved it!
Monet. Water lillies is stunning and is presented on eight walls. Line to get in may get long at peak times. We went late afternoon and waited 45 minutes. Book online.
Breathtaking treasure. The beauty of the art and the building is almost overwhelming. Don't try to breeze through this one, as there are so many surprises along the way. Relish your time here.

Money's waterlilies! What an absolutely stunning display. Ok - if I had not had the pleasure of visiting Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia, I would have given it the rating of Good.1st of all, do visit this place - waterlilies and willows paintings will take your breath away. Impressionist collection is very minor - almost tiny.They had special exhibit by Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera, which was amazing - wish I had more time to spend there.I recommend booking tickets in advance. We had to stand in cold for 1 hr as we waited for our turn to enter.

well worth a visit. The museum is on a far corner of the jardin des tuileries. These gardens are beautiful and the space it is in is HUGE. They certainly know how to do things in with great opulence. It exudes $$$$$. No wonder there were revolutions.The Musee de l’orangerie was very simple yet beautiful. I am a big fan of paintings of flowers and gardens. I find them very peaceful. This Museum gave me a good dose of those. After seeing the Monet exhibition in Melbourne I thought that the water lily series would be little meh. They were spectacular , what a skilled man he was.

The oval rooms are beautiful!. We went on the first sunday of the month so we got in for free but had to line up for about an hour. We spent probably an hour and a half there, most of the time sitting in the oval rooms. There were two rooms each with four large pieces by Monet. The best view we found was to stand by the entrance of each room. It was a relaxing experience to sit in the rooms and just admire the paintings.
A wonderful way to spend a rainy day. It is small - but to see Monet's waterlillies is an honor. We stared for 30 minutes - just fantastic!

A must if you love Monet. Musee de l'Orangerie houses 8 of Monet's waterlily paintings, huge works displayed in oval rooms designed by Money to show off his creations to their best advantage. These eight paintings alone are worth the visit. The downstairs gallery offers other beautiful works. A small, high quality collection worth seeing.

Beautiful, Small museum. Loved the small size of this museum. The Monet Waterlillies was breathtaking!! Recommend!! I would suggest buying a Museum Pass to bypass long lines at this and other museums.

Great collection of top painters. The Orangerie is located near the giant wheel. After a short wait in line, even though we had the Museum Pass, we entered this great museum. The two outstanding collections here are the Monet water lilies strips and the Paul Guillaume collection. The latter one includes several rare and unique pieces which even the Louvre cannot surpass. Don't skip this must see attraction.

breathtaking - a must do. A beautiful museum with wonderful Permanent collections. We purchased combined ticket at the D'orsay, so were able to skip the queue for non ticket holders. We still obviously had to go through the security checks, and had to wait for about 20 minutes as I believe they only let a certain number of people in at a time. The waterlilies are magnificent. We were also fortunate enough to see the Frida Khoho exhibition.
Worth finding. For some reason we have trouble actually finding our way into the Museum and it could be because it was raining and hard to see, but once inside totally worth the visit!

My Favourite Museum. My favourite museum I could sit and look at the 8 magnificent Monet's all day. Plus a fine collection of other works which is worth seeing. Plus its beautiful to stroll among the Tuilieries to get there. I have been twice and never seen a queue to get in I must have been very lucky both days, I even had a whole Monet room to myself for 5 minutes it was delighful.

AMAZING. the water lily rooms are absolutely amazing. you see monet's work in a space selected by him. make sure you walk around the room and take in the works from different angles. What I liked most is people are pretty respectful and manage to stay in the center of the room so that everyone can see. I was lucky enough to catch the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition. Once in a lifetime chance to see Frida's most special works. I waited in line 3 hours to get in - its small so be sure to get your tickets in advance!!!!

Great place to see Monet's Water Lilies. Great place to experience Monet's paintings in Paris. After viewing the Musee de l'Orangerie, If you can fit it into your trip I suggest going out to see the beautiful gardens of Impressionist painter Claude Monet in Garverny. His garden in Giverny is actually two separate gardens, one a flower garden, and the other his water garden that he designed in a Japanese style. The water garden is the actually lilly pond that Monet painted in his work at the Musee de l’Orangerie. Visiting both locations make a very special treat.

My Favorite Museum in Paris. I went to L'Orangerie in October 2013 to visit the Frida Kahlo exhibit. I love the scale of the museum as it is not overwhelming. I felt like I could spend time gazing at the art without worry that I needed to move quickly in order to see all of the museum. The Frida Kahlo exhibit was amazing with lots of historical and personal information about Kahlo to add context to her art. I highly recommend renting the audio guides.

Perhaps my favorite museum of the Fab Four!. Considering the Louvre, Orsay, Rodin, and Orangerie museums, I think this may have been my favorite everience. Obviously, the Monet Water Lilies are outstanding, but the Guillaume collection of mostly impressionism works was unexpectedly good. The museum was not as crowded as the others, and it was much easier to brose and enjoy the artwork.

Don't miss the Water Lillie Ponds. With a museum pass move to a special line and you are in within 10 minutes. The show case of this Musee are the Water Lillie canvases by Monet. Two giant rooms and 8 canvases! What you have seen before in small paintings is no measure to this work.

Do not queue, if you need to go - book in advance. The queue was round the corner, for a museum that is no bigger than a mid-sized supermarket. We booked online so skipped the queue and after 35 minutes we had walked around and taken in all the art on offer. Security staff are rude, and the employees didn't really give clear direction upon entering. Give this a miss.

If you love Monet. . .. If you love Monet, you must see his water lilly paintings, housed in two oval rooms designed by Monet himself as a place of quiet reflection in the middle of the city. There is also a very nicely chosen collection of impressionists. This is a relatively small, manageable museum that is well worth a stroll through the Tuilieries and a couple of hours and is a nice respite from the madness that is the Louvre.

How to describe. mamba bamba
reviewed 3 months ago
Orangerie is a fantastic museum. It is good to know that before it was where flowers used to be stored, and now it is open to tourists visiting important art exhibitions. Obviously, the paintings of Monet are breath taking, and you will enjoy loosing yourself in his deep colors.

Definitely not worth the 2.5 hours wait in the line. If you book your tickets online in advance then you don't have to stand in line and you can skip the line. If you have the museum pass then you can go stand in a different line meant for the pass holders which moves very fast as compared to the Non-ticket holders line which doesn't move at all. Even if you get to the end of the line you will have to wait at the entrance for an eternity in the cold especially as the wind blows strongly in that corner. The security who handles the lines is very unfair to the non-ticket holders because he was not alternating between the pass/ticket holder and the non-ticket holders in a fair manner. As soon as one person comes in the ticket or pass holders line he would stop the non-ticket holder line.The water lilies by Monet is good. One good thing was there was a temporary exhibition of paintings by Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera. My wife especially loved the works by Frida Kahlo.

World class collection of impressionist and post-impressionist art work. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a wonderful art museum, located at the Western end of Tuileries Gardens. Entry is steep (€10 for adults) for a relatively small collection. However, what you see is world class, likely one of the finest collections of impressionist and post-impressionist art work anywhere. Musee de l'Orangerie is included in the Paris Museum Pass so if you've bought this pass already, this is a highly recommendable museum to see while in Paris. The highlight of Musee de l'Orangerie is (Les Nymphes) The Water Lilly murals by Cluade Monet, which are kept in oval shaped rooms with a centre seating area. The intention is for this to be an area of reflection and meditation. Unfortunately, some of this is lost with waves of tourists coming and going into the two rooms. However, the concept remains appealing and it is very much worth spending at least 10 minutes in each room focusing on the murals. They do have a calming effect on you, if you allow them to. The museum additionally houses the Walter-Guillaume Collection, which features 144 pieces of early 20th century artwork. Here you can find quite a few works by Renoir, a few pieces by Picasso, works by Cezanne, Rousseau amongst others. There are many outstanding works are to be seen.At present, there is a very good special exhibition, featuring Mexican artists Frida Kahlo and Diego Riveria. This exhibition did a nice job of displaying their works while building up the story of their intwined relationship, passionate and dramatic marriage. You can see the impact this had upon Frida Kahlo's work, particularly. Overall, we very much enjoy Musee de l'Orangerie and recommend it to anyone interested in impressionist and post-impressionist art. You can comfortably visit in 30-45 minutes there or spend a couple hours if you like. Hint: In order to control the crowds, they seem to limit how many people can go into the Musee de l'Orangerie at any given time. This results in some noticeable queues by afternoon, even during afternoon visits in the winter. The queue was well beyond 60 minutes when we visited. If you have the Paris Museum Pass, you are fortunately able to skip this queue and wait much less time to enter the museum.

Spectacular little Museum. The wall paintings by Monet were absolutely beautiful! You can't really appreciate them fully until you are there in person! Definitely one of the highlights of my trip to Paris!

A little museum, but a must for impressionism fans. The museum is small compared to the Louvre, but it has a wonderful collection of impressionist works. My wife is a fan of Monet, so seeing the Waterlillies was a must.

Brilliant Museum in Paris. If you feel overwhelmed by rooms upon rooms of Gallery Pictures and crushed by all of the people crowding around you, go and visit the Musee de l'Orangerie. In 1922, Claude Monet signed a contract with the French government donating his Water lilly panels to be housed under the natural lighting in the two oval rooms of the Orangerie. There are 8 panels altogether and they form a cohesive and contemplative display of impressionistic art from the master. You can walk slowly through the two rooms viewing the waterlilies at different times of the day from dawn until dusk and you can also sit on the large benches in the middle of each room to look at the art. A lovely experience for all ages and energy levels. After leaving the gallery you feel relaxed and not exhausted, as you do when you visit most galleries.

Perfect Monet. There could be no better place to house Monet's water lilies. The rest of the permanent collection is wonderful too. That being said, having seen the Kahlo/Rivera at the High in Atlanta, I was disappointed in L'Orangerie's exhibit. It simply did not do as good a job and was a disjointed mess. We expected to have a wait in line, but the three line merging system was poorly executed. It made for an interesting study in human behavior.

Go see the Frida Kahlo/Diego Rivera Exhibit before it ends. For the first time these two artists/lovers work is available in one exhibit. My husband and I stood in line for 2.5 hours in the cold (buy your tickets in advance so you don't have to do this) and it was absolutely worth it. It's a breathtaking exhibit!

Wonderful. I went to the museum today and it was wonderful! Frieda khalo exhibit plus so much moreMy suggestion is go early! The museum opens at 9:00 am : I got there at 8:30 - the line had already begunTook a good hour to get in but worth it!

Routine. For a large museum, it seemed to be very disorganized. Started to the lines, or lack of indicated lines for each catergory (pre-purchased, controlled and needing to buy). Then the bag check-in and retrieval staff seemed to be overwhelmed and confused. The current pieces in the museum were not worth my time.
A feast of Impressionism!. The huge waterlily mural required time to appreciate it, it grew on you. Downstairs the early PIcassos were fascinating. So much to see!

Disappointing after the hype. Had high expectations of this; perhaps it was the huge number of other tourists (which meant trying to stand back & view Monet's water lilies was impossible) but it did not live up to these. Better on a different day? with fewer people?

Awesome colors. The Orangerie is a small museum but the Nympheas exposition makes it worth the visit. Go early in the morning to avoid the lines. Dont go in a hurry, take in the colors and reflect. The only cons of this exposition was the little chaos in the lobby to check in coats. So if you dont need to check your coat just go in with it and avoid the hazzle.

Don't miss this smaller gem!. Even if all you see here is the incredible Water Lillies, it is well worth it. As many have cautioned, the wait can be long, but don't give up without waiting long enough to see how quickly the line is moving. When we arrived, the wait was estimated at 2 hours, and we almost left. After a few minutes of waiting, it became obvious that the estimate was exaggerated, and we waited much less than an hour. We saw both the Frida Kahlo/Diego Rivera show and, for the second time, the huge Monet Nympheas which are stunning. This is a great museum to see if time and/or energy are limited.

It really is an Oasis. The experience of walking into the Nympheas galleries and being surrounded by Monet's work is incredible. Be sure to check out people's expressions as they walk into the first gallery! Sometimes you can see them give this big sigh and relax. It's a very peaceful and quiet place and the work itself is just stunning. I went on my last day in Paris, when I was a little tired of traveling and fighting crowds and it was nice just to be able to sit in this beautiful quiet space for a while and take a breath.The downstairs exhibit was tiny compared to other museums, but it had some interesting pieces. I also enjoyed their temporary exhibit on Frieda Kahlo and Diego Rivera - well done and one of the few very English-friendly exhibits I encountered (I expected no English at any exhibit, so every time I found it, it was a pleasant surprise).Side story: On my last night in Paris, I ended up meeting a lovely group of American women at the table next to mine and they invited me to join them for a drink (they felt bad that I was alone). They wondered what I did with all my time in Paris by myself, and I told them it was the perfect city for a museum-lover like me to visit solo. It turns out there was one woman in their group who loved museums, but the rest were not interested at all - they had only a short time for their visit and didn't want to spend hours in a museum. This is the museum I told them to go to. It's perfect for groups where some people really want to immerse themselves in a museum exhibit and others aren't into it. You can spend an hour or less here and still fill like you got the full experience.

Beautiful. I love Monet. In particular, the water lilies are my favorite. The L’Orangrie actually used to be part of the Tullieries palace, it was where the plants were wintered during the cold weather. It has now become the beautiful museum that houses the Monets. Monet was commissioned to do these works by the government in 1922. They were given to the museum in 1926 upon his death. Their are 8 canvases located in two oval rooms. They are displayed in diffused light as he originally intended. In 1944, two of the canvases were damaged during the Battle of the Liberation of Paris. They were restored immediately.December 2013 until January 2014 the museum is having a special exhibit, Frieda Kahlo until January. If you are a fan or her and Monet, then I highly recommend that you make a visit.
Monet was a god. What can you say that hasnt been said about the eight circular Monet paintings in the L'Orangerie. They take my breath away. Just stunning.

Must see the Water Lillies. Use your Museum Pass to avoid the lines. Even if you have limited time stop in the L'Orangerie and experience Monet's Water Lillies. The permanent collection downstairs is also worthwhile.

Remodeled and excellent. This museum was wonderful because it wasn't too much to see in one visit. Everything about our visit there was perfect except the 2 hour+ wait in line.Should have bought the museum pass ahead of time. The rotating exhibit was Frieda Kahlo and Diego Rivera. Living in the southwest, I've seen a number of exhibits of the work of those two but this one was the best I've ever seen. I agree with the other reviewers about the beauty of Monet's lily pond works in the setting.

Small but worth it. To see the Monet's work in it full intended glory is spectacular. This is worth the trip alone but there are several other areas that are interesting as well. Definitely, a must see.

The Beauty of Simplicity. Monet's paintings draw most tourists to the Orangerie, and I was absolutely mesmerized. The paintings are presented in a white, circular room with benches in the middle. The simplicity of the presentation is really effective in allowing visitors to sit and meditate. There are no explanations or placards with information, so it might be helpful to buy an audioguide. Downstairs, there are rooms full of paintings by Picasso, Renoir, Cassatt, and more Monet. I highly recommend a visit to this museum, although it can be annoying to wade through all of the tourists. Museums in Paris are free on the first Sunday of each month, but I would advise against visiting then since museums like the Orangerie are very crowded.

Great Collection. L'Orangerie is a truly great find in a city filled with amazing art. The large format Money water lillies on the top floor are cool, but the real secrets are downstairs. While there are some works by some of the most famous artists in history (Renoir, Picasso & Monet), it was great fun to discover paintings by artists that aren't as threaded into the public consciousness.The first time I visited L'Orangerie was 7 years ago and I make a point to return every time I'm in Paris. My first visit introduced me to Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo, Rousseau, Derain and several others. I credit that first experience as opening my eyes to the wonders of the art world that are missed just by focusing on the biggest of names.It's a small gallery, so they control the number of people granted access at any one time, but the Paris Museum Pass will allow you to jump the line.

If you like Monet, you have to visit this museum. This is a museum with something of a split personality, due to its galleries with Monet's water lillies, some other collections and visiting displays. It is smaller and less overwhelming than the Louvre or the d'Orsay, and much more manageable for the time-pressed visitor who feels the need to see some art while in Paris, but can not afford the time required to master some of the larger museums. The "catch" is that because it is smaller, its capacity is also less in terms of visitors that can be accommodated at any one time so there are often long(er) lines of people waiting to get in. It is worth the wait, although depending on the time of year and the season, your patience and determination might be tested. Its best to get there early, or else visit at the end of the day. The adjacent Place du Concord offers a lot of photo opportunities (fountains, surrounding buildings, obelisk, views down the Champs Elysees to the Arch of Triumph and beyond to La Defense). A twin building to the l'Orangerie is across the park, the Jeu de Palme, which offers a different kind of art museum experience to the visitor. The museum is very visible, access is somewhat more difficult if you arrive in a vehicle, its best to walk here (weather permitting). There is a lot of parking underground in the vicinity, pay attention to where you park and which exists you use, or you may have trouble quickly finding your vehicle again.

Monet and more. We wanted to visit Musee de l'orangerie to see the large Monet paintings of the waterlillies, willows etc. And they did not disappoint! Wow!But there is more at this musee, which we also enjoyed. Downstairs was a nice display of paintings by impressionists and contemporaires.The thing to watch out for is the queues. The line gets very long quite early... even in winter when we visited. On our first attempt, the line was estimated at 1.5 - 2 hrs. On our second attempt, we arrived at the musee at opening time on a Sunday morning - there was practically no queue - but within an hour, it started to build again.I noticed that holders of Paris museum passes, seemed to have a shorter, separate queue ... so might be worth a thought.
Fantastic Art Museum. Great museum collection of impressionist art . Small enough not to be exhausting . Well worth a visit

Last days of Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo. Only a few days left to catch this once in a lifetime dual exhibition of two remarkable Mexican artists, a couple whose lives are captured in the drama of their art. A rivetting exhibition, at the heart of the Orangerie's purpose. Not to be missed.

Beautiful Monet works!. Two big rooms of some of Monet's famous water lilies in panorama. Enchanting. However, if you get there a little after opening time, expect to wait at least an hour--outside in the cold (we went in December)--if not more. It seems you are better off going closer to closing time, especially if you don't expect to spend a lot of time there. It's not a big museum, and we found an hour sufficed. There are works of other painters as well, but Monet, of course, was the highlight.

Worth the wait on line. First time we have ever waited on line at this museum...but when we entered we were pleased we waited. The new exhibit on Diego Rivera and Frieda Kahlo was wonderful. We never really think about the talented Mexican artists but this was a real treat. It was nice to be able to see a real exhibit and not just one or two pieces of their work. Really enjoyed it!

Monet for fans and all lovers of beauty. See my review about Musee d'Orsay and consider getting the Musee d'Orsay and Musee de l'Orangerie passport at 16€ for a discount off both the ticket price and waiting time in the very long queue to enter the museum. Don't miss this museum; hearing about Monet's Water Lilies and looking at prints and pictures of them online pale in comparison to quiet contemplation of his gift to France after World War One.

Get immersed in Monet. If you have only ever seen Monet's Waterlilies on calendars and fridge magnets, nothing can prepare you for the feeling of complete immersion you get when you view these eight magnificent canvases in the round (well, oval actually). They were painted on concave canvases and the Orangerie walls were fashioned specifically to accommodate them. Try to pick a quiet time to view them, so that you can sit in the centre of either of the two oval rooms and soak up their beauty.
WOW. The large scale Monets in this museum will take your breath. We were lucky to go on a quiet December morning and got to sit and really enjoy the magnificence of what Monet created just fantastic

Nice, but small museum. A must if you are a fan of Monet. This museum is small, only takes about 40 minutes to see it all. The lines are long, but if you go to the Musee d'Orsay first, you can get a pass for both museums and bypass most of the line to get in. I would definitely recommend that. The rooms with the water lily paintings are very serene and wonderful to just sit and look at the colors and brushstrokes. My boyfriend, isn't much of a fan of Monet's, so he was a little bored, but it's definitely a must see if you are a fan.
Monet, Rivera, and Kahlo. The permanent Monet is always wonderful. I appreciated the chance to see the Diego Rivera - Frieda Kahlo special exhibit.

Monet and them some!. We visited here after reading reviews and wanting to see the fabulous Monets. It did not disappoint. The Monets are fantastic and we were pleasantly surprised to find all the other artwork! Great stuff! Almost nonexistent visitors and this was the hight of tourist season. Got to enjoy everything at a very leisurely pace. The paris museum pass made all our visits very easy. If you go to the popular spots first when they open, this is a great choice for second when the crowds are getting out of control.

Water Lilies a delight. The Monet Water Lilies are fantastic. Highly recommended to add this to your agenda if you buy the Museum Pass. You could spend just 30 minutes here as the Lilies are the main attraction. If you don't have the Museum pass, the ticket price is high. Arrive early in the day to beat crowds, or late for a small discount. The special temporary Frieda Kahlo - Diego Rivera exhibition was extremely well-done.
A place of peaceful surroundings. Monet's 8 panels are worth the visit. He achived his goal of creating increditable surroundings. The other art is also worth seeing.
brilliiant. and of course we had the great fortune of seeing a Freda Kahlo exhibition. Totally disability accessible - thank you for your care.
Buy a ticket before you go. This is a great small museum and is worth a visit. The line is very long, so buy a ticket before you go.

What pleasent surprise!. Most people that visit Paris immediately visit the Louve and then possibly the Musee d'Orsay. Both are excellent museums however if you enjoyed those two, a visit to the less well known Musee de l'Orangerie should be added to your list. Get a museum passport at Musee d'Orsay that includes the Musee de l'Orangerie for 16 euros and pay for the Louve separately. The passport allows you to skip the lines in either of the two museums If those are the three museums you visit, the passport and separate admission to the Louve is still lower cost that the Museum pass. The Musee de l'Orangerie has the ground level floor dedicated to the 8 brilliant huge Monet panels, the Water Lilies (Les Nymphéas) which all play with all the variations of light in his garden at Giverny. In addition, the lower floor has many other Impressionist painting as well as painting from the Post-Impressionist period. Not a big museum but worth a visit especially if you like Monet and his water lily paintings.
Flowers nympheas. A place dedicated to the Nympheas . and others paintings. , in Jardin des Tuilleries. A must to see. You will do 1 hour walk in the park before , look at the pool

Exciting!. The oval rooms are indescribable! A word of advice: If you want to also visit the Musée d'Orsay and you do not have any card, go there first and then with the combined ticket back at the Orangerie and avoid the queues!

Interesting Gallery. The main purpose of visiting is to see Monet's Water Lilies and these did not disappoint. However there are also many more interesting paintings. The downside is the que to get in. Even with a Museum pass we waited outside (in December) for 30 minutes and there was a lengthy security process to go through.

Needs a new crowd management policy. I waited 2 hours 15 minutes outside in Paris winter to get inside this museum. The crowd management system is ridiculous, I was surrounded by angry yelling Parisians which at least helped to pass the time. I cannot fathom what the crowds would be like in peak season. In all I spent about 30 mins inside, after seeing Monet's lilies there's not much else to see except a small collection of impressionist works down in the dungeon. I was so disappointed to have waited so long just to spend half an hour inside. What a let down.

Breathtaking!. So, so beautiful. I've never seen paintings displayed like this. It was perfect. And the quiet and peaceful atmosphere they have created really compliments the paintings. So sorry I am missing the Frida Kahlo exhibition they have on at the moment.

Good collection of impressionist works. Enjoy Monet's "Water Lilies" at your desired pace (you can sit and ponder, walk around the room, or do both) and marvel at the collection of impressionist paintings. If you'll be in Paris in the next two months, take advantage of the temporary exhibit of Frida Kahlo's and Diego Rivera's works (saves you a trip to Mexico!). If you know in advance that you'll be visiting the museum, try to book your tickets online to avoid an extra queue to the ticket booth.After your trip to the museum, walk along the Jardin des Tuileries for some fresh air, people watching and sculpture appreciation.

Home to some of my favourite artists. I was very excited to see so many works by Modigliani, Picasso, Cezanne, Renior and Matisse all under the one roof, and of course the beautiful round rooms walled with giant Monets, which was an eerily tranquil space. The Louvre is wonderful but tends to be overcrowded. Musee de l'Orangerie is a must.

Wonderful experience for art lovers. It is a must for any one going to Paris to visit Musee de l' Orangerie. The quality of the art is above the rest. Think of getting the Museum Pass to avoid the long lines. Also, consider going early in the day to really enjoy it and not be tired.

Worth seeing Monet. Smaller museum. Start in the basement and spend some time seeing the other works. Then go upstairs to see Monet's Water Lilies - amazing! They take up 2 large rooms and you can just sit in the middle of each room and absorb them. Beautiful!

A beautiful experience in the round. I cannot really describe how these enormous Monet murals of water lilies draw you in. Just take time to sit and reflect on the paintings. This is not a gallery to rush round (well what gallery is?) but the longer you study the canvases the more you see and a calm relaxation comes over one. On first glance they seem very abstract because they are so big, I think this is why one needs to take plenty of time.Downstairs there are paintings by other artists which are interesting, but the star is obviously the two oval rooms with the Water lily canvases.

My new Favorite museum in Paris. Loved loved loved the 2 large oval rooms with Claude Monet's water lilies all around you. So amazing. The museum is small but significant. You can see it all in an hour but leave time to enjoy the Salle 1 and 2 with the Monet murials!!!

Monet's Water Lillies are NOT to be missed !. The Orangerie is fabulous ! This museum is a treasure. It was worth the long,long wait for it to be redone. When one enters the room with the waterlillies by Claude Monet . They absolutely take your breath away !! Do NOT miss visiting the Orangerie. I have been there several times and never miss going there every time that I am in Paris.

Monet's Lilies. Simply worth the 20min wait for queuing for safety check. Wonderful Monet!Also the other works by Picasso, Gauguin, Cèzanne were worth seeing.I'm not a fan of Frida Kalho and Diego Riviera, but ...

Loved it. I'm not a fan of art galleries, but I really enjoyed this one.We only saw Monet's paintings upstairs, and it was great to be able to experience these paintings first hand, be able to see them up close and from afar. Despite the queue to get in there seemed to be relatively few people inside, which was as a bonus.We we able to skip the queues with our Paris Museum Pass, which was even better :)

My Favorite Museum in Paris. There is nothing quite like sitting in l'Orangerie and taking in Monet's masterpiece. Paris can feel quite overwhelming at times, but there is a serenity found at l'Orangerie that fortifies you. I could spend hours there.

Monet and so much more!. I was under the impression that this museum only showed the Monet Nympheas but I was so wrong! While the Monet's are wonderful and worth the trip alone, I thoroughly enjoyed the permanent collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume! Wow! The collection starts off with about 15 Renoirs and moves immediately into approx 10 Cezannes! Where else do you get to see something like that?! There was a wonderful little alcove that showed Paul Guillaume's apartment and how his personal collection must have looked like in the early 1900's. Imagine having Picassos and Modiglianis in your own home.There was also a Frida Kahlo-Diego Rivera special exhibition but it was crazy-crowded. I had to pass on that (but that's just me).

Breathtaking. The Monet exhibit is beautiful beyond belief and the special of Friday Khalo truly mesmerizing. I must say that even without a pass the waiting wasn't that bad either and worth every minute. Great time to visit

A little gem.. I visited this museum in November 2013 using a 4 day museum pass and was utterly enchanted. There were two huge oval rooms at the rear of the upper floor specifically designed to display Manet's huge panoramic works with water-lilies and the setting was totally magical. I spent 20 minutes in there enjoying the view and enjoying the quiet, being as the majority of the noisy school parties went straight downstairs to the main area. I followed them down and was surprised by the quality of the modern art on display. The best part was the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera temporary exhibition (there until 13th January 2014 so if you get the chance go now) which was spectacular. A nice little museum, and, especially if you have a museum pass or similar, worth the small queue outside. Being as it is so close to the Louvre, it would be a good experience directly before or after that massive undertaking. Worth it.

Lovely museum. Monet's water lilies paintings are absolutely breathtaking! I've never spent so much time admiring a painting, going back and forth. I also enjoyed Frida and Diego exibition. It was very crowdy, but definitely worth a visit. To conclude, some amazing Renoir's...

Worth visiting to see Monet's Water Lilly panels!. Home to at least 6 huge Water Lilly panels by Monet, the L'Orangerie provides a breathtaking setting to see these unique creations as Monet designed them to be seen. In 2 large oval galleries, you are surrounded by these unique compositions of his garden with some as wide as over 30 ft. One only need look up to imagine the coy swimming above you. What an amazing gallery!!

Wonderful! A real gem.. Monet's lilies are beautiful. The lighting is excellent and paintings cover the whole oval shaped walls in four corners and in two rooms. Could use a bit more distance to view them from even more afar. We were very lucky to be there when the special exhibit was Frida Khalo and Diego Rivera. It was one of the best mixes of their works and explanations, and I've been to his house in Guanajuato. Perfect sized museum, not too big to get worn out or lost. If you like modern art, this is a gem. We were there on a late Sunday afternoon and the line for tickets stretched to about a 2 hr wait and the exhibit was closing. People who had pre-paid tickets from online do not have to wait. We returned to about half hour after it opened on a Monday and were able to get in with minimal wait, although behind us, the line rapidly got to over the one hour mark behind. So go early when there's a special exhibit that is popular.

Monet Paintings are so worth it. This was a small museum, but what it lacked in size, it makes up for in beautiful impressionist art! They have six LARGE Monet paintings that take up entire lengths of walls. They were the main reason I went to the Museum and they were well worth the price of admission, even if that's all there was to see. Beautiful paintings, you won't be disappointed!

Water lilies the way they were meant!. This is a small museum, off the Tuileries. I strongly recommend getting the Paris Museum Pass to bypass the long lines. The main exhibit is Monet's Nymphéas, or Water Lilies. You've probably seen smaller pieces by Monet, but these are the huge panels he painted, displayed in large oval rooms designed specifically for them. You are surrounded by the garden, and it truly feels as though you are there. Although I appreciate art and enjoy museums, I'm not one to sit for long periods of time and ponder. This museum was different! I sat for a while to take in the whole experience, and then I made my way systematically around both rooms to look at the details. I was captivated. There is also an explanation (French only) of the history of the works and Monet's life in Giverny, which was enlightening. The lower level of the museum has other impressionist and post-impressionist works as well as traveling exhibits. We did not take in the Frida Kahlo exhibit due to long lines, but the other permanent collection is quite nice. L'Orangerie is small, and if you don't care for the Monet, skip it. But if you want to see Monet the way he meant it, this is a must-do.

Worth the wait!. Finally, an opportunity to see this gallery - has always been under refurbishment when I have visited, and I was not disappointed. Two separate rooms will give you an almost 360 degree view of Monet. Downstairs there is a collection of Renior, Picasso, so a few hours could be spent. Go around lunchtime as the crowds will be less. Baggage and coats can be checked.

You might skip this.. This building houses Manet's huge water lily paintings. The lilies are displayed in rooms like cycloramas. It is just possible that you might think there are more water lillies than you need to see. We did. In the basement is a collection of Picasso Renoir, Cezanne, and other contemporaries. Some paintings are good, but the two museums next door (the Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay) have much better collections. We were disappointed in the time we spent in this museum. Unless you have a burning desire to see Gargantuan water lillies, there is no reason to go here. By the way, if you're willing to travel about 20 minutes, there is a private museum called Musée Marmottan Monet, that has a huge collection of Monet paintings.
Beautiful. The Monet installations in the first two rooms are worth the price of admission! We were fortunate enough to be there for the Frida Kahlo exhibit! Don't miss it!

not meeting the expected. I especially went to this museum to see the nympheas of Monet. Although the 2 oval rooms containing 8 paintings along the entire wall where nice, I did expect something more. There are a lot of other pictures on display.

Pretty; but crowded. The serenity of the rooms was challenged by the hordes of tourists. Water lily series are fantastic.The Frida exhibition is definitely worth a look; but be prepared for some push & shove to get close to the works. Also:The queue inside the gallery was worse than outside.Beware: one of the cloak room attendants is just plain rude & clearly doesn't enjoy her job.

A refuge of beauty from the mega museums of Paris. Musee de l'Orangerie is a beautiful and understated museum. Its focus is, of course, the two oval rooms displaying Monet's water lilies, but in a form and context unique to the museum. There was much more to see other than Monet, and all up it made for a wonderful visit. We didn't need more than an hour and a half take it all in, but this was after an hour outside waiting- book your tickets in advance and avoid the wait. There was a temporary exhibit as well, Freda Kahlo, but there was a line for it as well so we passed on her. A previous review commented that it was expensive wallpaper. This is like saying that Michelangelo's David is just a big lump of stone.

The Gem. This small museum was purpose built to house some great pieces from Monet's later life. And the two rooms on the main floor that house those pieces are a must. Because you can see in the works not only Monet's genius, but also the impacts of later life on his eyesight. You will find these pieces to be far more abstract than earlier works you will find in d'Orsay.Just as important as these pieces and rooms is the lower level. It is essentially a collection of the works of one person from his home. This gentleman was mentor, friend, confidant, supporter of most of the great impressionists and they rewarded his kindnesses with wonderful works of art.Also, there is an area devoted to traveling exhibits. When we were there, they were part way into the set up for a Diego Rivera Frida Kahlo exhibit. Again, with the museum pass, you can go to the right hand door and avoid the long line to enter. Take the ten minute walk from d'Orsay to get here. You will find it is well worth you effort.

Art great- gallery less so. As under 26 EU resident entry was free- so I don't want to complain too much, but the cues and crowds here were frustrating. Cued for nearly an hour to get into the gallery, hardly the tranquility Monet was designing. Water lilies were stunning, panoramic experience is a great way to experience these. Frida & Diego temporary exhibit down stairs was really interesting too. The content was thorough and fascinating, but it was so frustrated to be in such a crowd of people. Hardly able to stop and enjoy the art, or get near enough to read labels, watch videos etc. A real shame.

Fantastic. This is a major stop for Monet fans, perhaps less so for those who think that certain aspects of Impressionism were triumphs of marketing more than art. Even if you count yourself among the latter group, you still might want to catch the Guillaume collection, which counts a number of fine works. There is invariably a special exhibit attached to the museum as well, and these are oftentimes worth catching. Ultimately, your estimation of this museum will rise or fall on how much you love the art it contains. Or how much you've been told you should love it.Keep in mind the museum doesn't seem to have a café, so fill the tank before going, especially if you plan to be there for awhile. There are allegedly plenty of (no doubt pricey) cafés in the Jardin de Tuileries, but few seem to be greatly beloved by Tripadvisor readers.
waterlilies to die for. long queues to get in but for the remarkable rooms of the waterlily paintings it would not be worthwhile but but you must go.
Monet Panels. I have always loved Monet and we came to the Musee del'Orangerie to see the Monet panels. Truly a moving experience!

Always an eye opener. I always love Monet's Waterlilies and the children found them amazing. Even the size is impressive. The rest of the gallery is a mixture of amazement and shock - depending on the art style you are looking at. Beware of the queues - go early. We didn't and had to wait a while despite having line saver tickets.

A gem of a museum. Just what I like in a museum - small, easy to navigate, with a perfectly curated collection. The showpiece are the two oval rooms which each display four huge panels of Monet's water lilies in natural light, just as Monet wished them to be shown. A lovely space.

One of my favorite treasures of Paris!. Who knew? A little solarium built by Queen ???. As she strolled in her garden, still living in what we know as the Louvre, she wanted a place to be alone. Fast forward 700+ years, here is L'Orangerie. Lovely house exhibit and grand exhibitions. The winner, of course, is the first floor, the two oval rooms that the magnificent Monet visited ... oh my god, I cannot walk through them with anyone, has to be solo, shut up!, as I absorb the utterly transcendent beauty of Monet's ponds. Will never, ever tire of it; toujours a jamais, mon coeur casse quand je visite

Monet lovers must visit. it was great it's worth waiting in line for 2 hours in the rain. love the water lilies of Monet and now there was an exhibition for frida kohla so try to visit it if you're near by.

Worth the wait in line. In addition to the wonderful permanent collection of Impressionist art, there are temporary exhibitions that are always carefully curated and displayed. If you know when you want to go, it's worth buying your tickets online or buying a Paris Museum Pass (also available online) that gives you entry to nearly every worthy museum in the city. Either advance ticketing option means you won't have to stand in line to gain entry - the walkup line can often stretch to one hour or longer (sometimes much longer) and that's no fun in Paris's autumn and winter. Pass holders and advance ticket purchasers usually won't have to wait more than a few minutes for entry. Inside, visitors pass through a security checkpoint. The museum can often be crowded and warm - the ticket line is rationed, but they still allow a lot of people in at any given time. The museum shop is very good and there are audio tours available in a dozen languages.

Mesmerizing. Needless to say, Monet's two "oval murals" are amazing. It's like spending a day in his garden in Giverny. As I had a lot of time, I decided to see just how long it would take standing in the regular line. Answer - 3 1/2 hours!!! Those with a Museum Pass - approximately 1/2 hour or less. You decide. However, the wait was worthwhile! The addition special exhibition was excellent, but the main reason for visiting l'Orangerie is the incredible Monet murals.
on a par with the orsay. the monet murals are worth the trip...also they had a frida and diego rivera special show....lines are long, avoid with the pass
Make this a quick stop. It was worth a short visit to see these gigantic Monet paintings. Small amount of other artwork was nice too.

Wow!. Just happened to be there for a special joint exhibition of works by Frida Kahlo and Diego Reviera. Absolutely marvellous! Frida is such a fascinating painter and really bares her soul in her art work. I was blown away. Buy a Museum Pass to jump the queue. It was 2 hours long but I had a pass and walked straight in.

A must for art lovers. The Musée de l'Orangerie is a most-amazing art gallery of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. Walk through the incredible Tuileries Gardens, right next to the Place de la Concorde. It is difficult to imagine the beauty of Monet's water lily painting, until you see them in person. And then, it's still difficult to imagine him painting them as he was going blind. You can see the progression of early morning to evening. If you go to the Musee before January 13th of 2014, you will get to enjoy the Frida Kahlo exhibit, too. Much more to see than Monet and Kaho - GO. Buy your tickets there or online.

Impressionist beauty. If you love Monet's art, this is a must-see. So many museums can be overwhelming but l'Orangerie is a comprehensible and easily appreciated museum. It is located in the center of touristic Paris, near La Place de la Concorde. Do not miss it!

Closed on Tues. We first attempted to visit on a Tues and had to come back again the next day, and I was so glad we did. We thoroughly enjoyed Monet's waterlilies and loved how the museum was strict on keeping everyone quiet in the two rooms to allow one to appreciate the original intention of Monet - " After the horror of the First World War, Monet wanted his work to take on this aesthetic and poetic dimension, and provide a haven for peaceful meditation."

Wonderful. So we arrived late at the Louvre, the lines were horrendous, so we strolled down the Tuilerie gardens and went to the Orangerie. My wife is a big Monet fan. She was very quiet during the visit, overwhelmed by the two room of huge waterlily paintings. There was also a side show downstairs of some excellent minor impressionists. Highly recommended.
Great Small museum. The Monet paintings are the attraction normally, but there was a special exhibit of Kahlo and Rivera. Very good exhibit

Unbelievable crowds. We had a museum pass so didn't have to wait in terribly long lines, but it was still a fair wait to get in. The lines for people without advance tickets/passes extended for 2 1/2 to 3 hours. There were little mile posts saying what the expected wait time was from various places in the line. Monet's water lilies are great, but not worth that kind of wait. I suppose much of the interest was the special Frida Kahlo/Diego Rivera exhibit. It's a nice little museum but one has to be nuts to endure that kind of crowd.

Couldn’t tear myself away … in absolute awe. I was in absolute awe upon seeing the Nympheas by Monet. There was so much detail to these paintings and I didn’t want to leave (my boyfriend had to take my hand and lead me away… ha ha ha.)When we visited, all the other galleries were temporaily closed for a few days; therefore, admission was 5 Euro to see the Nympheas.I would love to visit Giverny and Monet’s garden where he got his source of inspiration.

My favorite in Paris. I know everyone is supposed to like the Louvre the best. However, if you like impressionism go to this museum. They had quite the collection of Monet including Water Lilies and Weeping Willows. We also saw Renoir, Delacroix, and MoDigliani. There were also Picassos, which honestly are not my favorite. The area around it is a park which was a nice walk.

Monet Plus. Two rooms are dedicated to Monet's masterwork oversized water lilies paintings, which by themselves would be reason enough to visit this museum. A good portion of the permanent collection was closed off when we were there, but a very well done temporary exhibit on Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo's work more than made up for that.
