Luckily there was a Frida's collection. First of all, if you don't have the museum pass, try to buy the tickets in advance. The queue line can take up to 2 hours! And check by the entrance the museum pass line.The main attraction here are the Van Gogh's water lilies rooms, but we were presented by Frida Kahlo's exposition at the time and it was great. There was not only her works, pictures, etc., but also Rivera's works and both history.

Small museum but beautiful art. I went at the end of the day (4:30 pm) since I bought a combo ticket with muse d'orsay. Husband had enough art for one day so he waited outside while I breezed in and out, in about 30-45 mins. After 5pm I believe, the price is reduced too, so one could see all of it easily for less. Monet's Water lilies on one floor and viewed the private collection on the other. Beautiful pieces not found at the d'orsay. Photos were permitted. Went to see Monet's house and garden so it was nice to see the finished product and then the inspiration.

Monet Fans. If you like impressionism you should check out this museum destined to the waterlilies of Monet.You will also find here works from Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo.

Best to pre book. We arrived about 20 minutes before opening. There was a bit of a queue but despite the rain everything seemed orderly. Then after the due opening time a most officious official came out and started giving the most irrational directions so that the queuing system could be erected. Chaos rained but eventually we got in and it was well worth it. Would suggest that prebooking or maybe getting a joint ticket with Musee D'Orsay is the go.The Water Lillees are fantastic and really complemented our subsequent trip to. Monet's Garden. The other works are also very good.

Only just worth the wait !. The most ridiculous queuing system ever , arrived 30 minutes before opening to a relatively ( compared to Disney ) small queue . Thought we were onto a winner , however , museum opened 15 minutes late and then we were still queuing 90 mins later ! It was totally bizarre and had the Monet paintings not been so fab I seriously wanted to tell everyone in the queue on the way out to go home ! By the time we had seen Monet we had no enthusiasm to see anything else and whizzed through the rest desperate to move onto our next attraction . Unnecessary queuing ruined what should have been a fantastic morning .

Crowd control works!. L'Orangerie is a small museum that is well managed. They only let in a certain number of people at a time so that the rooms are not overcrowded. Given that, buy your ticket ahead of time instead of waiting until you get there. When we left, people without tickets were waiting in line for 2 hours. You will still have to wait in a security line with a ticket, but the wait is short. Inside, security was on the ball the whole time. When parents were not watching their children and they misbehaved, security was quick to step in. In my opinion, that type of management makes the experience more enjoyable for art lovers. Monet's Water Lilies were impressive as was the rest of the exhibition from Renoir, Cezanne, Rousseau, Modigliani, Matisse and Picasso and a temporary exhibit of Rivera and Kahlo.

Too long a queue. This was one of museums that I really wanted to see in Paris.We arrived at 10 am on a Thursday in late October, and the queue was already over well over the spot where a sign shows it was going to be a two hour wait. We could not wait that long with our two young children.I would suggest trying to get in line well before the 9am opening time.

The "four seasons" room was great. The "four seasons" room, where Monet painted murals on all four walls, was wonderful. Rest of the collection was okay. Worth the visit if you have the Museum Pass or are a huge Monet fan.

Nice painting Monet, can we go now?. My wife & I are 62 and had a museum pass. We were at the end of our day and were close so we decided to walk in and see Monet's masterpiece. Even with the pass, we waited 30 minutes and suffered heavy security screening. Why do people like to make jokes during security screens to people who have no sense of humor? I digress. Once inside, it was a short walk to both rooms. Amazing really. To be able to paint something like this with failing eyesight is something to see, don't pass it up. That said, so many people would sit and stare and stare and fawn. OK, I get it, it is wonderful.. really. We are just not the people to sit and wonder nor do we take hundreds of photos. We spent 30 to get in and 10 inside.We have also been fortunate enough to have already been through the hermitage, Uffize, Vatican Museum and the Acadamia (all on various other trips) so seeing so much amazing art gets you jaded I guess.

A great small museum. L'Orangerie is a very nice museum, situated in the Tuileries Garden, in the heart of Paris. The permanent collection is amazing. Starting by "Les Nymphéas" of Monet, that are wonderful. The permanent collection counts with a spectacular Walter-Guillaume Collection, with Picassos, Cezannes, Renoirs, Derains, among others. Definitively, it worths a visit. I had the opportunity to see also a special temporary exhibition of Frida Kahlo and Diogo Rivera that will be there until January, 13th of 2014. Very nice too. If you visit Paris, you should be there. A practice tip: the metro station closer there is not Tuileries, but the Concord station. Have a nice time..

awesome. We had a super visit, with our museum pass, Still had to some queuing and saw some wonderful stuff. Saw the fabulous temporary exhibit of Diego Rivera & Frida Kahlo, absolutely stunning exhibition, highlight of the trip in fact, also the Monet waterlily's in their special rooms was really wonderful.
Fabulous!. It's not large, but it's one that will leave a lasting impression on you. Monet's Water Lillies are spellbinding! HINT: Get a Paris Museum Pass so you can skip the line!

A must see when in Paris. This was a highlight of my visit to Paris. You only need about an hour if you only want to see the Monet panels. You can walk there from the Louvre through the Tuilerie Gardens. The Monet panels are spectacular, loved every moment.

A cold and wet wait. We didn't pre book but even if you had, the wait was almost as long - not to mention cold and wet. We should have realised the long wait though as L'Orangerie is one of the few museums which are open on a Monday in Paris. There was a Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition on at the time and although I wasn't expecting to be all that interested in either of these artists it was riveting and quite sad. I don't know why Frida bothered with him as he was quite unattractive and fat, not to mention a womaniser, even with her own sister. The rooms with the curved Monet waterlily paintings weren't as spectacular as I expected though but it was worth a visit although definitely not in that long, wet wait in the queue. There were some lovely Renoirs there in the permanent exhibition. Pick a fine day for a visit.

Again and Again. I have been to Paris twice with many years inbetween visits. This gallery space has been renovated since I last visited and I must say that it is even better now. It always leaves a lasting impression and is truly emotionally uplifting. Impressionist painter Monet painted a series of Waterlillies that lines two round rooms of this space. He made this as a place for people to come and meditate quietly. You can choose any canvas to focus on. Natural light is filtered through into this space to add to the tranquility you will experience here. There is also a great collection of other works of Modern Art here including a number by Renoir and Cezanne. A must see when in Paris.
If you love Monet. I went here on my own and sat on the white marble benches just admiring the amazing Monets. Well worth a visit - not as busy as Musee de Orsay

Avoid on a wet day. Their queue management was terrible. They have 3 lines annual pass, prepaid ticket, and no ticket. It was impossible to know which line was which. Furthermore some people were kept outside in the rain on a "slow" day for over an hour. When we got inside the museum was not busy at all but there was only one person handling security which really slowed things down. Even as late as 3pm people were lined up. We went for the Frieda exhibition which really was not special.
Long Line but worth it. Could not believe the 2 hour line, but the Kahlo- Rivera special showing along with the wonderful Monet's Water Lilies made it worthwhile.

A piece of Monet Heaven. I love Monet's work and seeing these large format paintings is so amazing. I didn't have any lines to wait in when I was there on a Saturday. There are benches in the middle of the rooms underneath skylights; mainly people just sat there and absorbed the beauty in near silence. I was in awe. The Musee Marmottan has more of Monet's work so if you can get there, it's well worth the time. But the paintings at L'Orangerie are stunning. You can take photos if you don't use flash. I bought a Museum Pass as I had Friday evening and all day Saturday in Paris. I visited in September 2009.

Impressionist heaven. This small gallery has an impressive permanent collection of impressionist art, in addition to special exhibitions. If you like impressionist art, don't miss it. Also, I cannot stress enough the value of the pars museum card. Even if you don't save a great deal of money (we did, but we went on a museum blitz while we had it), being able to skip the line, here in particular, made it very worthwhile.
Nice but small. The museum is very nice, However, I wish the collection was bigger. The shop is nice and you can buy good things from there.

Closed on Tuesdays. We planned a lot of our week in Paris around getting to l'Orangerie on Tuesday afternoon. Very disappointed to find that it was closed. We did look at their website before going but only saw "ouvert Tous les jours" whereas it now seems to say "except Tuesday".

Small high quality museum. Great Monet collection of his large murals, the main purpose of the museum. However, they have a very nice Impressionist collection on the lower level, too. We also got to see an excellent Diego Rivera/Fraida Kahlo temporary exhibit there. Very pleased we went.

The wait was worth the experience. I disliked the long wait to get in but that would have changed had I booked tickets in advance. The Museum display of art is excellent and certainly worth the wait. The selection of Impressionist Artists is impressive.

peace in the city. This is a small but beautiful collection with Monet's waterlillies being the jewel in the crown. When you enter room 1 you immediately feel the stresses of the city lifting and are drawn to the seating in the centre of the room where you can sit and stare at Monet's greatest works. We went here at about 10am and the queue was already 4 hours long. However there are actually 4 separate queues 1 for those without tickets, 1 for those with the musee pass or other such pass, 1 for those who purchased tickets in advance and 1 for those who hold annual passes. We had the musee pass but his queue was still about 2 hours long so we decided to come back in the afternoon and when we returned about 3.30pm we were second in the line for the musee pass which left us with a total wait time of about 30 minutes! This is a small boutique style musee but the art and atmosphere here was most certainly my favourite.
Couldn't get in the door!. They don't have a skip the line facility through Paris Pass so I tried twice but the wait was 2 hours - 2 hours too long to waste in a queue in Paris

Monet's Water Lillies - Stunning. The gallery is worth visiting just to see the two rooms devoted to Monet's water lillies. Having visited Monet's house and gardens at Giverny, we could see the magnitude of these works.

Charming little surprise. I knew that museum had Monet water lily paintings in the round on the walls but I didn't know that several other artists are also on display in this small museum. It's very calming to sit an look at the large water lily painting here. You cannot take photographs which is a drag because I don't have any pictures or mementos from this museum.

Masterpieces in Natural Light!. If you love Claude Monet's work, it is definitely worth your time to go to the Musee de L'Orangerie in Paris. The Waterlillies, displayed in two specially designed rooms which capture natural lighting, are breath taking. I felt I could sit there for hours! There are other impressionist and post-impressionist works displayed in other areas of the museum, but the waterlillies are the highlight and alone are worth the visit. We had to wait in line for 1hour and 45 minutes, so if you can get a ticket in advance, that would save you time.

very good. Loved the huge Monet paintings, I could have sat and looked at them for hours. The Musee was light and airy making the visit very comfortable. It could have benefited from maybe a small cafe to sit in between paintings, but other than that, I enjoyed it immensely.

Worth a short visit. If you have the museum pass, it is worth a short visit. Really, all you need to see is Monet's Waterlillies. That was definitely a highlight of our trip to Paris, the layout of those rooms really surrounds you in the artwork. The rest of the collection downstairs isn't really worth seeing in our opinion. But this is an example of why you should get the museum pass. You get to skip the lines and visit smaller attractions you otherwise might not want to pay for.

The Monet Water Lilies will take your breath away!. The museum is small enough that you have the luxury of just lingering in front of your favorite paintings. The Water Lilies are in a room by themselves, they are just HUGE, maybe 30 feet long and 8 feet high. They have 3 or 4 of them in the room with benches in the center where you can just be absorbed into Monet's world. It is true that the line was a couple hours long and that might dissuade some people, but it sure is worth it when you get inside!

Monet's Masterpieces in a great space. The l'Orangerie is a small museum near the Place de la Concorde at the far end of the Tuillery Gardens away from the Louvre Palace. With a Museum Pass, you can beat some of the crowds, but it's still a wait to get in....well worth it, however! The space is amazing and illuminates Monet's very large paintings in a beautiful way.

waited in line in the rain but worth it. After visiting Giverny the day before, it was a memorable experience to see Monet's water lillies at L'Orangerie. We got in line in a misting rain and waited about 1 and 1/2 hrs. as we had not purchased tickets earlier. There was another waiting line for those who had pre-purchased tickets or had some museum pass.They weren't too happy. Don't know how to avoid the long lines except to get there very early in the am.Security had to chase off some scammers/possible pickpockets who wanted to take a survey with clipboards so beware. We also saw another scammer who was very nicely dressed but was selling tickets while you waited (no she wasn't). Just use your good sense and get inside and see some wonderful art.

Not worth the wait. The Monet water lilies are impressive, but we had to wait at least an hour to get inside. Even people with museum passes were forced to wait. Before going one should find out the best time to go.

don't miss this. Although the Louvre and the d'Orsay are more well known (and more crowded) this was my absolute favorite of all three. We bought a Museum Pass at the train station when we first arrived in Paris. Not only can you skip the lines (except for Notre Dame belltower) but it's easier than scrambling for cash at all the entrances. If you plan to hit the major museums and attractions, it's worth it. Anyway, I was excited to see Monet's water lilies exhibited the way the artist envisioned it to be displayed. I wasn't disappointed. When you walk into both rooms, you are overpowered by the size and the layout. The light streaming in, the stark white floors and the surrounding canvases make you actually feel as if you are in the middle of the landscape.We thought that this was all the museum had to offer. We were wrong.downstairs, we stumbled upon the most incredible collection of artwork, from the personal collection of Paul Guillaume. He was a friend to many artists before they became famous for their works and as a dealer he amassed a personal collection that is astonishing. The fact that these works once hung in his home blows me away.If you want to see the Renoir painting instantly recognizable whose image is mass reproduced all over the world, go to the Orsay. If you want to see the alternate version of that same painting by Renoir, since he painted multiple different versions, go to the Orangerie.The audio guide is worth the money as it gives you not only background on each painting but clips from the painters themselves describing what you are seeing. So many masters hung side by side in such a small space in comparison to the Louvre. Thought we were hopping in for a half hour and after nearly 2 hours, we didn't want to leave.

More than just Water Lilies. Yes, you will see Monet's Water Lilies here, but there is so much more to the l'Orangerie. I suggest going when it opens because the security line can become quite long. If you need handicap access, there is only one elevator and it is off out of service so you would need to use the stairs-two flights. Bring some water with you for before and after because it is quite dry in the building to keep down the humidity.

Beautiful museum. This was by far the most beautiful museum in Paris. Monets paintings are breathtaking. Would highly recommend a visit but ensure you have a ticket or paris pass as the queue without was over 2 hours and they close the queue at 5pm even if you have been there hours!!

Amazing. Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera was showing maybe that was why the lines were crazy. We came around 9. on a Monday and stood in line where the sign said 1 hour. I was with my 10 year old daughter and out of the blue an employee came and spoke to us in french (not very polite) and I understood NOTHING. She gestured that I should follow and it turned out that she was actually being polite and saved us from the at least 1 hour line and send us straight into the museum. I assume it was becuase I had a child with me and must admit we hardly saw others in the museum. But what a nice surprise. However I noticed that people who had preordered their tickets on the internet were in the same line as people without a ticket! The Monets paintings were absolutely stunning. and the exhibition with Kahlo and Rivera was really neat. Not a hole lot of Frida Kahlo paintings but very much about their life and marriage. When we left around 11 AM the line was even longer.

W.O.W.. ok, so we had a joint ticket from d'orsay and l'orangerie. thank god. it helped only a little. we were in "line 2" which was for those tickets. still waited in line for well over an hour. well over. lost track of time. the other line, line 3, was paris museum pass, and it didnt move any more quickly. line 1, poor souls. they're probably still in line. def get a ticket ahead. you'll still wait a long time, but it's a shorter line. all those people and they have only 1 person doing admissions to the museum. it's a small museum, so maybe it works out, but man, it's not easy. so the museum. it wasn't open when i was last in paris 12 years ago, so i've been chomping at the bit to go. love the waterlillies and they are stunning there in their natural habitat. just go. buy tickets ahead. and go.

A bit disappointed. Finally got into this place when it wasn't undergoing remodel or rennovation. Was disappointed in that we could "only" see Monet's four panels, the rest of the museum was CLOSED due to work being done on the basement level where the other works of art were on display....I have found this place to be exasperating only because of the constant work they are doing to it, this is my fourth trip to view it but only the first time I was actually able to go inside. So my suggestion is to check what is going on there before you visit.

Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera plus Monet's water lillies!!!. This was the BEST exhibit in Paris. The Kahlo work is brilliant and the exhibition is well curated to weave the interaction between these two great artists as they influenced each other's work and lives. Exceptional. And then to see those magnificent panels of Monet's works in the perfect venue was pure heaven.

Wonderful paintings by Monnet. Seems costly but worth place to visit. Huge paintings of Monnet makes it nicer! There is beautiful bronze statue just outside the museum. Place also hosts few paintings of Picasso. If you get time,visit the small village Giverny around 80km away where Monnet spent his life.You can see those gardens & flowers in real.

Extremely bad behavior of staff throwing out visitors at 5:20pm!. Yesterday I wanted to have a short visit at the Musée de l'Orangerie Paris at 5:20pm. Closing time was 6:00pm. There was a notice telling that the museum was starting emptying at 5:35pm. When I reached the entrance there was a lady member of staff shouting at the visitors expecting to enter and 2 other guys of the staff insulting and blocking the entrance to the late visitors! Their behavior was really shocking!

Unexpected long line and wait for admission. We had the Museum Pass which is supposed to allow you to enter most museums and attractions without having to wait in line. Unfortunately, we visited shortly after a special exhibit of Frida Kaklo and Diego Rivera opened. People with time slotted reservations were admitted before those with Museum Passes. We waited more than 1/2 hour to get it, but the people at the end of the general admission line had over a 2 hour wait - so the placard said at the end of the line.The main attraction at this museum are Monet's water lilly painings which cover the walls of 2 rooms. They are spectacular and are well worth the price of admission alone.

Concise Beauty. One of my favorite museums in Paris - doesn't seem to be a wasted painting. Some of the top impressionist paintings in the world, but not overwhelming. Pricey admission for the quantity of paintings is only downside, but Museum Pass was what we had.
Frida Kahlo Exibition. Lovely, small Museum with perfect installed collection of Impressionism.From October 2014 to January 2014 there is an rare exibition of Frida Kahlo.

stunning Monets. Could take as long as wanted when finally got in but you have to be patient and queue for an hour even with a pre-bought ticket. Booking a set time via the internet is no guarantee you'll get in at that time.

Monet's museum. This museum has gone through 4 renovations since it was build. The last being to house Monet's Water Lilly panels. There are 2 rooms specific for this art and it does not disappoint. Downstairs is the temporary collection and other pieces of art. Get in line early and get your ticket ahead of time if you can. You can also get this with a Musee d'Orsay combination which is good over a 3 day period.

Monet in all his glory.......Not to be missed. A must see if you enjoy monet's art. Water lilies in their original format, simply stunning. Have been in both march and October so have never had to queue to get in and have had the paintings almost to ourselves. Just sit and take it all in. C'est formidable!!

Be prepared to queue. So you're going to l'Orangerie to see 8 paintings by Monet? Be prepared to queue for hours!When we arrived at 11:00am there were three queues. The shortest queue is for those with exclusive passes, the second queue is for those with pre-paid tickets (including the Paris museum pass and the museum passport) - this queue was well past the 1 hour board.Then the third queue is for those who need to but a ticket. This was way way past the 2 hour board. The queues make very slow progress as entrance numbers seem to be strictly regulated, and priority is continually given to those in the first queue.So get there early or be prepared to wait in line for around 4 hours.

A must see. Its not a large museum, but its worth waiting for. Again use the Museum Pass to skip to a shorter line, but its worth seeing the Water Lillies. They are amazing. To me it was one of the highlights of my trip to Paris

My favourite Paris museum. If you're a lover of impressionist art and Monet in particular, this is a museum not to be missed. The tranquility of the 2 oval rooms covered in floor to ceiling paintings makes me want to spend my day there. This museum is second really only to Giverny itself.

OMG. This museum right off the Tullierie Gardens is well worth the wait. The works by Monet are awesome - I was moved to tears they are so beautiful. Don't miss the family's private collection downstairs - some gorgeous significant works by Renoir and others.
Wonderful Monet exhibit. This musee can be completely visited without rushing using audio guide in half a day. The Monet water lily rooms are spectacular. Definitely worth a visit.

Get away from the crowds!. This was probably my favorite museum in Paris. It's a great location and has wonderful art. It's much smaller than the Orsay and others so very few people when we went. It's a part of the museum pass so if you buy that, don't miss it!

Might not be worth the long wait. We waited well over 2 hours in line on a cool morning. The system did not appear to be fair with 3 purported separate lines depending on whether people had advance tickets or passes. The attendants seemed to exercise favoritism to some people as the lines were not clearly defined.The Diego Rivera/Frida Kahlo exhibit seemed to be the main draw but is fairly small. If you plan to go definitely would recommend buying tickets ahead but people with those also waited for about an hour.

Nice Content, but not much of it.. The museum is pretty small and the lines are horribly long. I would not suggest going without having advance tickets of some sort. They had the Frida exhibition going, which actually had more Diego paintings then Frida, but it was nice, and the Monet Water Lilly paintings are awesome.

Monet lovers, rejoice. The rooms with the water lilies alone are worth the visit. A wonderful place to sit and reflect. If you get a pass before you travel, you won't have to stand in line to get in. This museum is not large, but it has many treasures in it, and the gardens outside are lovely.
Monet magic. Despite whatever you think you know or have read - you must visit L'Orangerie. Monet's huge canvasses are almost overwhelming. Take time to sit and enjoy these.
Long line. I saw the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition. It was pretty good but the line was way too long. It took over an hour to get in and it was pretty crowded inside.

Monet´s lilies are a balm for troubled spirits. The Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition was superb, an excellent introduction to the life and work of these outstanding Mexican artists for those unfamiliar with their story. Shame about the long queues, even with the Paris museum pass. And Monet´s lilies are a truly welcome respite from the bustle of the city.

Beautiful. If you love Monet then this place is a must! I could of sat in the oval rooms for hours starring at every detail of the water lilies. Loved it. Line was way way less than at the louvre or musee d'orsay and i enjoyed it more.

A must to see. Compared to the other museums this is much smaller and can easily be seen in an hour or a little longer. There is a wonderful exhibit of Impressionism on the lower level not to be missed. While directly ahead upon entering the museum are the two large oval rooms containing the 8 Monet water lily paintings. What a relaxing and peaceful way to unwind at the end of a busy day. You can sit and just feel the stress roll off. Do not miss this charming museum.

Was there during Frida Kahlo exhibit. Get the paris pass! Lets you skip the ticket line, well worth it. Monet exhibits were excellent. The museum is inside the Tuileries and you'll see it once you enter from Place de la Concorde.

Wonderful Exhibit. Lucky me. This is the second time I have been here. So lucky me got to see a Frieda Kahlo and Juan Rivera exhibit. Fantastic,we waited in the cold and rain for 2 hours but worth the Waite ..The French Woman a head of me shared the umbrella,so nice of them. I must admit this was splendid.

Frida and Diego and Monet!. What a great exhibit and of course Monet's work. Very easy to visit. Located in the Tuilieres bought our ticket's at the Orsay the day before. Didn't have to wait in line. So lucky to have been able to see the the Frida and Diego exhibit.

Great Monets, horrible queue management. Getting through security is a nightmare. Perhaps the worst part is the random queue management. It was like a club where the bouncers decide who waits and who gets in. We waited over an hour while lots of groups and individuals skipped to the front. It was like a Monty Python skit mocking the French. There were people that waited several hours to get in.

A must for the Monet fan. Great museum and a nice surprise! It's all impressionist art and worth the visit. Some of the art was off the walls to be sent to other museums. The two rooms of Nymphae by Monet were quite moving. Even if you aren't a fan, the paintings are breathtaking.

Meditate on the waterlilies. Visited the gallery to see the Diego Rivera and Frieda Kahlo exhibition. An very well curated exhibition: cross section of commentary, film, pencil sketches; reproductions of some Rivera murals (the history of Mexico); and the deeply troubling very captivating art produced by Frieda Kahlo.The joy of the visit was reserved for the two semi-circular rooms dedicated to Monet's waterlilies. The colours are still vivid and the pictures exude a quiet energy which should be savoured.Buy a two museum visit-card at the Musee D'Orsay (valid for 1,2 or more days). It enables you to reach almost the head of the queue; an important consideration on a rainy Sunday afternoon.
Nice Surprise. This was our fifth visit to Paris, but, the first to Musee de l'Orangerie. Worth the visit to see the wall size Monet paintings.

Unmissable. I am a big fan of Claude Monet, but finally decided to go and visit this museum since the Frida Kahlo exhibition is on. It was a long wait but it was worth it. I can imagine it might be nicer to be in the rooms with the paintings when there were a few less people around.

The worst experience. I wasn't able to visit this place due to their security controls.I had a museum pass and thought I could go in quicker, however a guard just showed up and showed all of us people with passes and tickets to the end of the long queue without an explanation, so I just decided to leave without visiting. Maybe next time.
A lovely small museum. Located in the Tuileries, this museum focuses on Monet's Water Lillies. If you get to Giverney, it is an added plus to see the original location of these paintings.

Nice art; pity about shambolic queue and museum entry system. Museum has some great and interesting art but unless you book ticket in advance it can be a long wait to gain access to this small easy to view museum; which itself has a fascinating history. We thought the complex queue system might have to do with limiting the number of visitors in the museum but once inside it was far from crowded. The reason for the delay was down to nothing more than a single security scanner manned by one person to screen all visitors! Absolutely hopeless! So make sure to book ticket in advance to ensure waiting time does not detract from the museum experience.

Great Impressionist Art. I had visited this museum many years ago and was blown away by Monet's Nympheas. Unfortunately, the previous times I was in Paris, this museum was closed. This time, I was able to take my wife, who is a huge fan of Monet to see these incredible paintings for herself. In addition to these works, there are many other works by Monet's contemporaries that are also interesting to see. In particular, the works of Laurencin I find very beautiful. The collection of art in this gallery is not as large as some other Paris museums, but for me is a place I hold special because of the Nympheas.

If you love the impressionists...that is the place. This small museum L´Orangerie is one of my favorites in Paris.It has a good collection of the main names of impressionism and contemporary art, such as: Gauguin, Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso... but the most amazing is Claude Monet´s work. The museum has the Nympheas, a series of paintings of Monet´s water lilies, each paint of the size of a big wall, donated by the artist to the French state. Actually they are placed on the wall directly and occupy 2 big, impressive rooms. Luckily escape from major damage during the World War II.A must see museum in Paris.
Water lily heaven. You have got to see Monet's water lilies just as he had intended them to be seen....its truly surreal. Also other amazing works by talented artists...a small museum.

The right time. Even though it is a very small museum in compare with the others but I loved the Frida and Diego exhibit they had.It was well organised and if you didn't know who are they, the story is written beside every picture and painting.I really enjoyed my time there.

an interesting museum with a diffference.. I accidently stumbled over this museum. Unusual exhibitions, in a beautiful building. I ended up spending some time, just wandering around, enjoying the exhibits and the atmosphere

Pure Tranquillity. Two large oval rooms were purpose built for Monet to render the murals entitled "Water Lilies" The rooms are spacious and quiet - with attendants quick to subdue any sort of disturbance. A visit to Monet's garden is an essential sequel (or prequel).
There are additional galleries with extensive displays of the works of other artists.

Monet's Master Works. Monet agreed to paint these panoramic scenes of his water lily ponds on the condition that the museum not be opened until after his death. Viewing this prior to visiting Monet's home and gardens in Giverny was a real plus. The museum also has several great Renoir, Matisse, Picasso, and other paintings. Don't miss this special treat.

small. Monet's Nympheas is the reason to come here and it was nice to see it. I was however disappointed that the rest of the collection is quite limited. There was one special exhibition and for the rest the permanent collection is almost non existent.

Another wonderful museum on the banks of the Seine and universal samples.. Lilies and time ... Now I was fortunate: Frida and Diego with a comprehensive selection of his works. The Casa Azul, and works of Dolores Olmedo,one of the best collector of Diego Rivera, offer viewers a panorama of color and proportions. It is a pleasure in this museum overlooking the Seine.

Amazing. On a recent trip to Paris, we visited the Musee de l'Orangerie and enjoyed the beauty of the Impressionist works on the lower level. However, what we saw in the main gallery inspired visual memories we will never forget. The two Monet rooms are surrounded with huge panels of glorious art created by this master. One is immersed in color and feels like a part of the scene. We have toured Monet's Garden in Giverny and were visually transported there by these paintings. The same feelings of calm and connection with nature were around us. We were fortunate one of our friends suggested this gallery as it is not as familiar as some in Paris. You will not regret a visit to this amazing venue.
Sunday morning at L'Orangerie. Beautiful relaxing gallery. Great to visit on a sunny Sunday morning. Jumped the queue with a Paris Pass!

Not to be Missed. If you lover Impressionism, then this is a must. My jaw dropped when I entered into the main room. Monets on such a scale will leave you breathless. Loads of people coming through, but you still felt like you could sit and take the time to take it all in. Truly masterpieces, everyone of them.

Delightful Hidden Paris Gallery. If you like impressionist art then you must see this gallery/museum. For such a well located Paris gallery/museum, it seems relatively unknown. It is a delightful and not large museum. The best part is clearly the two Monet rooms - that is to say two rooms that are nothing but two 360 degree paintings of Monet's gardens in Giverny. They are a a stunning display of his painting prowess. The two paintings are not just excellent, they can stir feelings that are hard to forget. The paintings were done for these rooms. Particularly if they are not crowded and can therefore give a peaceful opportunity to sit and view them, they are wonderful.The other unusual aspect of this gallery is the way in which an intense series of paintings by the same artist can be shown at the same time. This time the Renoir, Pissarro and Cezanne displays were very powerful. The Cezanne showing was better than I have seen in a number of Provence galleries. A couple of the featured artists this time were dark and somewhat disturbing compared to my prior visits. In addition, although I have been there three times, you have to recognise that the paintings on view change and you can miss some fantastic examples particularly of Impressionist art if they are on loan to other galleries.

Water Lilies. You will inevitably pass close by to this museum on your trip to Paris because of it's central location by the Louvre and Jardin de Tuileries. Definitely go check it out. The rooms filled with water lilies are a once in a lifetime experience and you can be in an out of the museum in less than an hour or you can sit in front of the paintings and enjoy.

Hidden gem. We had a museum pass and would not have found this museum by ourselves. It is in the Tuilleries gardens and does not standout as a place to visit. The museum contained many paintings by well known artists and of course Monets garden murals. Although a small gallery it is well worth visiting.

Loved It. A fabulous collection of impressionist paintings. Small by most museum standards. It was my second time there and there was no line to get in. We purchased a combo ticket to the Musee d'Orsay so were able to skip the long line there and see both museums the same day. Monet's Water Lillies are truly amazing. Even if you are not a huge fan of museums this one is small enough to hold your interest throughout your visit and still have you come away feeling you saw something very special.

Delight!. After seeing all the 'big' sites, finding this little gem was enjoyable. Small lines, inexpensive, well located, perfect after lunch viewing, not a lot to see but Monet's water lilies are worth it!
Small but memorable. The Monet exhibit was a bit too crowded but the gallery downstairs was enjoyable. Used the audioguide but felt that the descriptions were a bit too long.

Unexpectedly surprised. Monet's Les Nympheas (known as the Water Lilies) are the centerpiece of this small museum. I say "small" only because compared to the Louvre or the Orsay this place is tiny. Monet could be considered the founding father of impressionist painting and, indeed, the water lilies are thought by many to be his crowning master piece. Aside from the size of this work if could be considered an exercise in nuance and subtlety. It is a sumptuous experience to sit on one of the two large benches in the center of either of the large oval rooms that house these works and meditate on this elegant painting. Downstairs are a number of rooms that house works by a variety of impressionist painters. One room contained a number of works by Soutine, an artist who I knew little about. To come away from a museum excited about an artist who has had little exposure in the other museums I have visited made this a significant experience. I prefer museums that provide an intimate experience and this one fell in that category. It lived up to its billing.

Great Art. Best display of impressionist painting and art work that I have ever experienced. The main is to see Monets Waterlillies. Sitting in front of this display is a great feeling. Welll worth the visit and located in a great location surrounded by other Museums and sights

Wow. If you like Monet's water lilies from seeing them scattered around the world's museums, be prepared to be impressed with the huge masterpieces housed here.Keep in mind downstairs, the remaining permanent exhibits are fantastic pieces you won't see in person anywhere else (except on a tour.)It is a quick visit compared to the big museums.We've never had long wait getting in/buying tickets, but I could imagine a long queue during the height of season since it is so small.

My favorite art museum in Paris. This museum has a wonderful collection of paintings. It is also a small museum, which I like a lot. In that sense it is similar to the Kimbell museum in Fort Worth, TX. A truly great small museum.

SO worth it!. We were lucky to have gone early in the day and while parts of the museum was crowded...it was still enjoyable. The Monets in the major salons were fabulous but so large it was almost difficult to grasp. What I found even more intriguing were the other galleries on the lower floor. Fabulous! Give yourself plenty of time, don't rush thru. Seeing some of these grand, famous pictures makes you want to pinch yourself just to insure you are really seeing these Masterpices.

Take the time to really see Monet at his best. Sit on the benches in the middle of each gallery and just look...and look...and look. You'll see the beginnings of modern art. If you are at all interested in painting or art, this should be on your list.
Monet and company. Beautiful, intimate museum showcasing Monet's waterlilies. If you cannot get to Monet's home at Giverny, at least see his mural here.

If you're pressed for time, this is it!. We visited the best 6 or 7 museums in Paris, but if I could only visit one, this would be it. Compared to the other museums, this collection of impressionist paintings is modest in volume, but that is part of the charm--in an hour (more or less, depending on interest level), you will have viewed representative paintings from all the greats: Monet, Manat, Renoir, and so on. But, of course, Monet's water lily paintings (10' high by 60' wide) are the stars of the show and MUST be seen in person to be appreciated.If you're deep into art appreciation, you can't leave Paris without seeing the water lilies--the calming, peaceful feeling will stay with you for a long time. Conversely, if you're traveling with someone who can't stand museums, I promise they won't mind visiting the Orangerie. There's something for everyone, but not too much of it!
Nice muesum. Very huge Monet display. I wish there were more Matisse. Not only is there art but also how the history of how the art was promoted.

A hidden jewel. Hard to believe, but it almost seems as if the public has forgotten this small museum at the corner of the Tuileries that is the home of Monet's incredible Waterlilies murals, as well as a beautifully curated small collection of top notch Impressionist paintings. We went midday and found it blessedly uncrowded. Highly recommended.

Long wait in line. Even with a museum pass, the wait was well over three hours just to get in the door. This was mid afternoon with little chance to get inside. Go early??? I enjoyed the gardens and Rodin's "kiss" sculpture anyway.

Open after renovations. Took a few years to break it down block by block but it's renovated and open for viewing again. I rather enjoyed the "old" warmth rather than the new updated interior but it's the artwork inside you ultimately go to see! Small but very nice. I would rate this 4 behind the Louvre, d'Orsay and Musee Rodin. If you have the time, it's worth stopping to see. Don't miss Monet's Water Lillys on the two oval rooms on the ground floor: they take up the whole wall(s) of both rooms!

Small collection. With all the other museums in Paris this isn't at the top unless you have time and want to see the current special exhibit. They do have a room of Monet's water paintings and its a 360 view of 4 paintings. That was beautiful.

Beautiful Waterlilies. I went on the first Sunday of the month (when museums are free) and the queue was actually pretty short in the afternoon, we waited just about 15 minutes. Absolutely breathtaking. If you like Monet or impressionism, I cannot imagine a better presentation. I could have sat for hours...how appealing to the senses...

Lovely place. The display of the water lillies was magical. I loved the uncrowded atmosphere in the room and the rest of this very special small museum. Very glad we visited after a hectic day at the Louvre.

An airy ambiance. This wonderful museum has a room with only Monet's waterlilles and benches where one can sit and meditate. The rest of the museum has impressionist art tastefully displayed. There is a gift shop where a variety of items are sold with art from the collections as their decor. The setting for the museum is spacious with greenery and statuary surrounding it. It is easy to find and near both metros and busses.

Wonderful. I had never heard of this museum. It is much smaller than most but very enjoyable. The Monet's are beautifully displayed and the lower floor has a wonderful collection of modern art. This would be a great museum for children who are overwhelmed by the larger museums. Wonderful for anyone.
For the Monet lovers!. The museum is really small, and it´s major feature are the Nympheas, by Monet. You should go only if you´re a big fan of him, as me. Otherwise, there´s nothing else too see.

Over rated. Again, with friends, I visited this attraction. First off, get tickets from the Concierge or online in advance so you skip the queues for this exhibit. The main purpose of a visit to this Museum is of course to see Monets Waterlillies. We were fortunate enough to visit when there was a special exhibition of the works of Freda Kahlo and Diego Rivera, which was a good thing because with out their art for all to see I would have felt a little cheated. If you have the chance, and are so inclined definitely visit to see Fredas work as they are unusual and special, especially if you appreciate the works for people like Dali and the like. Unless you are a specific Monet fan and must see Les Nympheas I really would not take the time, go to Musee Rodin or one of the other smaller attractions and feel like you achieved something to remember. Dont take children here, they have a quiet policy and all feels a little like a doctors waiting room.

Breathtaking. One of the most stunning displays of impressionist paintings. Very well worth the visit.To sit in front of the water lilies completely filling your field of vision is an astonishing experience.Best if you're completely unhurried and relaxed.

LOVED this museum!. Best museum ever. It's small, but stunning. I was so awed by the two rooms (that's it) upstairs with Monet's that must have been 20 to 50 feet each. Four gorgeous pieces in each room for 8 paintings. Unlike other museums, where I get stimulus overload, I will remember each and every one of those paintings forever.

Nice, easy to do. Sometimes big cities are just too exhausting, so a visit to the Orangerie was suggested as an easy option and as we had recently been Monet's gardens at Giverny we were looking forward to seeing the murals.We arrived about an hour before closing so there was only a tiny queue, and as they were setting up for the new Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera exhibition the rest of the museum was closed.so, just the two rooms of murals, and the history of the gallery/building at a slightly reduced entrance fee. The murals are spectacular, immense and perfectly suited to the space. However, the best way to see them is with no-one else there. When we were the last to leave was the best experience.....and for a moment we were able to appreciate Monet's gift of a place of quiet contemplation in the middle of the bustling city.Thrown back out into Paris, it's a great walk through the Tuileries to catch our bus home.
Impressionism at its finest!. If you're a fan of Impressionism and especially Monet, this is NOT to be missed! His Waterlillies are STUNNING!

Musée de l'Orangerie. Your Paris Pass or Museum Pass will get you to the front of the line. If you like Monet, this is your place, as there are two huge round rooms of nothing but water lilies. In other parts of the museum, you'll see many other works by Renoir and sculpture by Rodin. Smaller museum, not so easy to find. Even though we knew we were within yards, we had to ask directions from a policeman!

More an experience than a museum. Loved seeing Les Nympheas -- Monet's Water Lilies masterpieces. It was a real experience to sit in the middle of each of the two rooms and take in the surrounding murals. Because this museum is not a huge attraction like the Orsay or Louvre, it wasn't too crowded.
This was a wonderful surprise. The enormous Monet murals are spectacular. The museum was not crowded, and a lovely walk along the Seine and through the Tuileries to get there.

A Have-to for any Monet lover.. This was like a dream come true for me, a devoted Monet follower since I was 14. To be literally surrounded by Monet's beautiful artwork was beyond anything I could have imagined. And then add to that an amazing collection of Renoir and Matisse, what could be better?
Monet at his Best. Take time to sit in the Monet room and just relax. the light and calm is just wonderful. they don't allow pictures even without flash.

A must see. If you are at all a fan of Monet's water lily paintings then you must make time to see this museum. Just a short walk from the Louvre, the L'Orangerie is a smaller more intimate setting and usually less crowded. There is a fine collection but it is the Monet installation that is amazing. You have two rooms with four paintings in each that take up 1/4 of the wall, giving you the opportunity to really enter the painting. As with all museums in Paris, including the Louvre purchasing a museum pass is a must. No waiting in line, just present your pass and walk in.
very nice. Nice museum in a nice garden in which you can wander around. Beautiful collection to be seen. Go there!

Interesting contrasts. Monet's Waterlilies are the main attraction - 2 rooms with huge canvases - and they left us cold, though most other visitors raved about them. Downstairs, there was a good display of other typical French painters - many of them better, in our view, than the Monet. Be prepared to queue to get in. Worth the wait.

Best museum in Paris. Smaller venue but amazing works of art. Very quiet and tranquil. We took a self-guided audio tour and it was certainly worth the extra 5 bucks. The museum has many, many works by Renoir and Monet. The tour provided much history and insight into each piece. We went in the morning when it first opened and it wasn't overly crowded. I felt that I saw a good 80% of the art featured and stayed about 3 hours. I enjoyed this much more than the huge, overly crowded Louvre.

Worth it for the Monet... As always a queue to get in (but that seems to be the case with all museums in Paris). However the eight amazing Monet are fantastic with beautiful lighting. Could sit and look at them for hours on end! The rest of the collection downstairs was interesting including some amazing Rodin.

An Uncrowded Museum of Impressionist and Post Impressionist Art. The Musée de l'Orangerie is a museum of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings located in the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde. The museum is home to eight Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet, that completely occupy 2 rooms. The museum also contains works by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo, among others. The museum wasn't crowded when I went.
L'Orangerie. I was not too impressed with this museum. Too modern, too cramped inside the rooms, they were renovating and quite expensive entrance fee too. Sorry.
Must visit!. If you're an art lover this place is heaven! It may be a small museum but getting to see the huge Monet's Water lillies is an unforgettable experience, can't wait to visit again.

Monet on Amazing Display. The full, wall sized Monet's are amazing. I wasn't aware that they even existed until I read Trip Adviser reviews and then I added this to our itinerary. I am so glad that I did.

Excellent Impressionists Excellent Setting.... ..in an almost petite chateau! The walls are hung with instantly recognisable artists (Monet, Manet) and some not so. The setting - fully furnished period rooms - made the lesser known artists all the more attractive as their paintings seemed to fit their station so well, and so kept the attention of the viewer. The major-league Impressionists are well-represented, and Monet's work stands out - several water-lily paintings, a haystack or two? An excellent hour was spent here.

Love the Monet rooms. This is an interesting museum with a few serene rooms built specifically for the water lily paintings. I enjoyed the museum because it felt very intimate and not overwhelming. There are some wonderful paintings in it.

Great smaller museum. Saw the Frida Kahlo/Diego Rivera exhibit, which was informative, but the real treat are the 2 rooms reserved for Monet's water lillies. One of them arcs around one end of the room, and I highly recommend that you stand at the end of the carpeting so that your peripheral vision catches only the painting. You will find that you are in effect immersed in the painting -amazing! There are other impressive works to see.

Monet's Water Lillies are a must see. This is a small, manageable aart museum that has 8 spectaclular pieces of art- Monet's water lillies. They are housed in two rooms on the top floor of the museam - the museum was redone at some point to put these huge paintings in natural light. Downstairs is a very good impressionist collection, but the primary draw are the water lilly p[aintings. You can do the museum in under an hour if you ae rushed, focusing on the top floor, but I suggest 1 to 2 hours. A museum pass is essential, becuase the line can be very long - museum pass holders skip the line. Ir works well with children because it can be done quickly and the water lillies are so colorful and massive that they are of interest to children - at least for some limited amount of time. I cannot imagine visiting Paris without a stop at the Musee de l'Orangerie.

A pleasant surprise. When I thought of the museums of Paris, I'd think only of the Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay. So the Musee de l'Orangerie was a lovely surprise when we visited (covered under the Paris Museum Pass). It's a smaller museum, so it's easy to navigate and the works are captivating, naturally beginning with Monet's Water Lilies. I had no idea how large these pieces were, so walking into the rooms where they lived was an experience. We opted for the guided audio tour, which I highly recommend to get the most out of your visit. Hearing about the Guillaume collection was so very interesting, especially Madame Guillaume's commitment to continuing her husband's art collection after his death. We visited on a weekday and arrived as the doors opened that day, which is best if you're trying to avoid the crowd, especially if you'd like to sit on the benches in the Water Lilies room to "soak it all in." Overall, this a museum that I'd recommend to anyone visiting Paris--and don't forget your camera to capture the view of the Eiffel Tower and Place de la Concorde before you head to the Tuileries.
Fabulous museum. This was such a wonderful surprise. Such a becutiful space. The staff was friendly and courteous.Monet was a joy!!!

A nice little museum. For various reasons, I've never been in Paris when the l'Orangerie was open, and I missed the Kahlo/Rivera exhibit in San Francisco. It all came together in Paris.This is a good little museum with a great permanent collection, and the Monet murals are a wonderful bonus.The Kahlo/Rivera exhibit is small, but nicely curated. Most of it is Kahlo's work and photos of the two artists. Frescoes don't travel we'll.Not a great museum, but a good temporary exhibit. Probably worth a visit if you're in the area.

Monet, Monet, Monet. On our visit the Monet Nymphéas rooms were the only ones open. Brilliant all the same and a reduced entry fee of 5 Euros as a result. The other rooms were closed for the installation of a Freda Kahlo exhibit which I was sorry to have missed. Another reason to go back later in the year then.....
One of The Best in Paris. This is one of the best smaller museums in Paris. Definitely worth a few hours. Do not miss this museum.

a must-see. wonderful collection of paintings on the lower level of the museum but the star of the show is the collection of water lilies paintings by Monet - you walk into the rooms where they are displayed and are surrounded by them - magical...
quiet gem. this was almost empty - stunning and evocative paintings by Monet, and a surprisingly good exhibition of Italian impressionism. Good audio guide.

Water Lilly Rooms. This is the home of Monet's water lilies. The two rooms housing the enormous works were designed specifically for Monet's end of life masterpieces and to get away from busy Paris. The ground floor is packed with impressionist and post-impressionist art. Great little museum - a must stop in Paris!

my favourite place. The highlight of a visit to this small museum is Monet's 'Waterlillies' (Les Nympheas). They take your breath away and if you get the chance to visit his house and garden in Giverny, then it all makes sense! I cannot go to Paris without a visit to the l'Orangerie. There are also exquisite works by other famous and maybe not so famous Impressionist masters. Great views form the gardens outside over Place de la Concorde out to the Eiffel Tower too.

Easy to find, no queue and spacious interior to enjoy the art. Home to the famed waterlily scenes by Monet, this was a nice visit following a trip to the real Monet's garden. We were pleasantly surprised to find no queues and it was an easy walk to reach the entrance inside the Tuileries garden. Inside, you're at leisure to spend as long as you want in front of Monet's room-sized paintings. Further to this, there's more art work to enjoy downstairs and it's quite spacious with no crowds so pushing a pram and walking with little people was pleasant. It's a smallish museum and you can save a few euro by buying a combined ticket with the Musee d'Orsay. Afterwards, enjoy the Tuileries.
Even if you only look at Monet's water lilies ..... .... It is till worth it. Just delightful. Had to queue for 45 minutes but the four huge panels on the basement and wonderful.
Just beautiful. It was wonderful to just sit and appreciate the art, we got there later in the day and it was fairly quiet. we all enjoyed this experience including my teenage daughter.

Small but worth seeing. This museum is small but is famous for Monet's and other Impressionist works. The museum is designed as a haven of sorts, away from the busyness of Paris. And it certainly serves that purpose, in the same way Monet wished for his Water Lilies to bring some peace to people's minds and hearts.Do not expect too much of this museum given its size, but Monet's Water Lilies are definitely the main reasons for visiting this museum.

Monets artwork stunning. Half the gallery was closed so we missed out on quite a bit .I did love the way Monets water lilies were displayed and it was extra special as we had been to see his garden at Giverny the previous day

Lovely little museum- go for more than the Monets. The huge Monet room here must be the ultimate pinnacle of the Monet-experience for fans of his work. It leaves me mostly cold. Instead, I really enjoy all the other artwork tucked in long hallways downstairs. Its a strange museum in more ways than one, but I enjoy it every time. A nice one hour break as you are walking from one part of Paris to the next....

Monet paintings. This small museum, located in the Tuileries just off the Place de la Concorde, has the most beautiful, very large water lilies paintings by Monet. Sit for a while and it's easy to imagine you are there in his garden at Giverny. Even if you only have 30 minutes to spare, it's well worth the visit.

Slightly underwhelmed. Monet is a favorite artist and I greatly admire his work, but I was a bit disappointed by there works, the panels did not marry up properly and this spoilt the effect for me, not Moments best work, if anyone else had done it I doubt it would have been exhibited in this way, however you probably need to see it for yourself.
The only place to see Monets water Lilly's. A must see. Buy your ticket at the hotel before going and save your self an hour wait. These painting must be experienced.

A worthwhile experience. Musee de l'Orangerie is a worthwhile and under-rated experience. It is a smaller museum than some of the more popular ones, but this is part of the appeal. Situated at the entrance of the very beautiful Jardin des Tuilleries, the aesthetic experience starts even prior to reaching the entrance of the museum. The building is modern with clean lines and open spaces. Monet's giant water lilies, housed in two rooms specially designed (by Monet) for the purpose of relaxation and tranquility, are magnificent. While this is what l'Orangerie is mostly associated with, do not underestimate the rest of the modern art collection, which is simply excellent. Afterwards take a stroll through the gardens to complete the experience. You won't be disappointed (or exhausted from overstimulation).

A little gem in the Tulleries gardens!. This museum is definitely worth a visit especially if you want to see art without the usual crowds and have the opportunity to take your time viewing without feeling the need to move on! It has so many beautiful artworks and of course the water lilies are just worth going for! But make a day of it by strolling through the gardens and stopping of at the end. You won't regret it. You can get a joint ticket with the musee d'orsay which is worth it.

Monet's Water Lilies. What more can be said. If you enjoy French Impressionists, this museum is a must! The room that exhibits the paintings was designed specifically by Monet to exhibit his series of paintings. They also have a small but excellent selection of other French Impressionists.

If you only had an hour to visit ONE musee in Paris (this is it!). Even if you only had 30 minutes, this is the place to visit. I love the Musee de l'Orangerie. It's a happy space and quite easy to navigate. It's a must see for anyone coming to Paris. For those who say, I don't want to spend an entire day indoors, waiting in line, with tourists, etc. THIS is the place for you. If you love the impressionists but can't afford a day at the D'Orsay, this is your musee. The l'Orangerie, was built to house the most amazing water lily paintings by Monet. His canvases grace the curved walls of two rooms. After you discover the masterpieces, wander downstairs to find see the permanent collection or an exhibition which might be on display. Again, you can make your visit last 30 minutes or two hours, the choice is yours. It's also part of the Musee Pass, which means you can zip past all the lines! The lines are short and move fast. The space is bright and the best part of all, depart the l'Orangerie and spend the afternoon in the Tuileries wandering among the floral jardins, eating gelato and finding the GIANT hidden tree sculpture by the famous Italian artist Giuseppe Penone

A trifle disappointing. The only part open was the first floor with the murals of the lily ponds. No special exhibits, no second floor, and no warning until you had paid for tickets that the museum was 3/4 closed. Only 5 euros, but not too exciting. Watch out for the gypsies on the bridges around there. They have some scams going.

Another great paris Museum. Had a great tour and it was well displayed and a beautiful building. The building is not far from the Museum D' Orsay and across the Seine. The pieces are really special, vut the audio tour was a little boring. Still a good visit.

A wonderful surprise!. We had not planned on visiting this museum, but it was on our Museum Pass and we were near the area and stopped by. It was one of our favorite museums, small with the most wonderful Monet paintings I have ever seen!

More than just the Lilies!. The lilies are worth it, and they were painted expressly for this site, but don't stop there. Often less crowded than the Musée d'Orsay and, a nice bonus, you can buy a companion ticket here that will gain you entrance to the Musée d'Orsay without waiting in the ticket line.

Can bring tears to your eyes!!!. Just perfect!!! Not to be missed!!! Monet's masterpieces in a perfect setting. Walk in the first room and your jaw will drop and then into the next room and you'll be amazed!!!

Tranquility in the heart of Paris. Worth a visit to see Monet's waterlilly murals displayed in their oval rooms. Really quite breathtaking. The diffuse natural light gives it a lovely peaceful feeling. People were respectfully quiet and moved about slowly - it is a little oasis of tranquility in the heart of Paris. Will stay with me for a long time.There was no queue when we visited mid-day but I understand you can skip the lines on a museum or Orsay pass. Downstairs there is a small collection of Impressionist paintings but we didn't enjoy these as much as the collection at the Orsay.

A great experience. This small but architecturally creative museum has as its main attraction eight beautiful Monet renditions of his famous water garden at Giverny. They are displayed in two wonderful oval rooms with natural light and benches from which to study them. This museum, off Place de la Concorde in a corner of the Tuileries, was blessedly quiet and not overwhelmed with the tourists that jam Musee D'Orsay and the Louvre. If you like impressionists, the Monets are spectacular, and the small collection of contemporaneous Parisian artists was most interesting.

Excellent. My friend and I visited in the afternoon. We arrived just a few minutes before the English language tour at 2:30 p.m. not knowing before hand that one was available. The tour was 6 euros and included the audio headphones which were excellent. Thus, it was our good fortune that such tour was available and given by a young woman with the last name of Bouvier. She was excellent. There were only 4 of us on the tour of the museum first and ending at Monet's paintings. The tour definitely heightened the museum experience. I recommend taking the tour as part of your museum experience.
Don't miss this. The Monel water lillies panels in two rooms are the most moving works of art I have seen. Extraordinary. Do not miss this.

More than just Monet. We returned to the Orangerie after 20 years. It is much better - the water lily panels are stunning. There is great collection of other Impressionist art there too which should not be missed.

Impressive collection. My wife and I visited the l'Orangerie mainly, as many others, to see Monet's Waterlillies. We did enjoy Monet but we were also very impressed with the other artists in the museum. We are not world travelers but the collection of Renoir was the largest that we've seen in one place. Some travel books downplay this museum but we thought it was definitely worth visiting.

The Paul Guillaume collection!. I came here for Monet's Water Lilies and I ended up starring at Soutine's amazing paintings! This is actually the largest collection of Soutine's paintings in Europe. If you like Soutine, you'll love this Museum. The Paul Guillaume collection contents also masterpieces by Cézanne, Matisse, Modigliani, Picasso, Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Sisley, Marie Laurencin, and Utrillo, among others. The location of the Museum, just in the Tuileries Garden, near the Place de la Concorde is also a great plus.
A Hidden Treasure. The Monet murals shown in natural light are extraordinary. Don't miss a visit here. It is unique and beautiful.

wonderful gem in the tuileries gardens. For Monet fans this is an absolute must. Contains 8 large water lilies murals representing dawn to dusk and displayed as Monet directed. Also contains an impressive collection of other works including those by Cezanne, Picasso, Renoir, Sisley and Matisse. The museum is smaller than D'orsay and has a peaceful, tranquil feel about it. People were respectfully quiet. We arrived at opening time, 9 am, and there was no line... it seemed we had the place to ourselves for awhile. We took the opportunity to purchase our tickets to the D'Orsay at the same time and avoided a huge line there later in the day.

Wonderful Monets. The Monet salon is very impressive. The selection of paintings in the museum is small but it is worth the price of admission if you buy your tcket as part of the of cost to the D'Orsay.
unique impressionism experience. The earlier you come - the better will be experience. Best views are from the corners of the rooms towards the other side.

Monet Water Lilies...indescribable!!. This intimate space showcases Monet's Waterlilies on the walls of an oval shaped room. Could sit and admire for hours with beautiful natural light coming through. Busy but not touristy....went and visited Giverny the next day...Photos don't do it justice and no one can compare with Monet.
Beautiful!. If you like Impressionist painting this is the place for you. Eight of Monet's water lily paintings in the setting designed by the artist.

Beautiful art museum. Everyone talks about the breathtaking surround-experience of Monet's waterlilies. These are breathtaking. I was surprised at - and had to go back the next day to see more - the huge collection of wonderful art by artists. A roomful of Uterillo, a room full of Chaim soutine etc. What a find.

Nice small museum. Yes, the Monet waterlillies are impressive but I'm not actually a big Monet fan. I enjoyed the collection on the lower level much more. This is a relatively small museum and not overwhelming. Definitely worth and hour or two if you are in the area. Again, book tickets in advance online and skip the line outside (I believe you can get a combination ticket online with the Musee d'Orsay at a good price).
Small impressionist museum. A very manageable museum with excellent audio guide that wasn't crowed when we went. It was impressive to see the water lilies painting presented like Monet wanted.

What a nice surprise. Having been to Paris many times we never visited the l'Orangerie until now. If you love the impressionists you should not miss this small but lovely museum. Monet left the world a beautiful treat in his garden panels.
Monet on a grand scale. Dont miss the magnificent display of wall sized Monet in natural light. It was designed by Monet to display his work from dawn to dusk.

Beautiful and peaceful. A gorgeous museum - small and tranquil compared with bigger siblings. The lower floor's exhibition of Monet's water lilies in the isolated gallery is exquisite. A truly peaceful place to contemplate.

Now I Get It!. I have to admit, I never really understood what all the fuss was about Monet. I'm not a big fan of the Impressionist movement, even though I am an art lover. I visited this museum recently and the Monet exhibit took my breath away. The presentation of Waterlillies in the dual oval spaces is just flawless. Being in that space really allows you to experience his work. Now I fully realize what all the fuss was about!

Reflect and admire. I loved the feel of this museum and there is nothing to compare to seeing the Monet's water lilies surrounding you on the walls. Take a walk through the Tuilleries first and arrive at the museum in the right frame of mind!

Not bad for an art museum. We like art, just not art museums. We stayed in Paris for 15 days and never even thought about setting foot in the Louvre (that ever happened before?) Anyway, as I said we do appreciate art, just not long lines and crowds. Musee de l'Orangerie was the perfect solution for us. It has all the masters you could want: Picasso, Monet, Renoir, Modigliani, Cezanne, etc, plus awesome lesser knowns like Maurice Utrillo and Andre Derain. Very impressive stuff. And not so big you get lost or bored. Just big enough to keep your interest for a little over an hour, then you're done. Also not crowded. Lineup only took about 15 minutes to get through. There was a fat bearded guy making out with his girlfriend as we were trying to enjoy Monet's Waterlilies, but other than that we have no complaints. Highly recommend this museum. Really glad we went.

Incredible Collection. The stars of the collection where the water lilies paintings, incredibly displayed. Downstairs are also great representatives of Picasso, Gauguin, Renoir, etc. It is a smaller collection than other museums in Paris but, in my opinion, full of the best of the best.
A good find. If you like Monet this is the one for you Great not so busy and quick to get around Nowhere to eat or drink though!
Small but pleasant. Very nice building, a great Monet experience, worth a visit. Unfortunately the other half of the museum was closed the day we went
Monet's waterlillies beautiful. This is a very small museum but well worth the visit to just sit and study the two oval rooms with Monet's panels of waterlillies.
Breathtaking. Seeing Monet's Water Lilies and Willows in person is a breathtaking experience. You simply can't get a feel for the work without seeing it in person.

Monet's refuge. Monet's donated water lilly paintings are worth sitting and contemplating as a welcome respite from the strains that can exist in any city. They're simply breathtaking when you first enter

If Monet is one of your favorite impressionists don't pass this museum. Monet himself designed the display of the famous waterlillies murals. They are shown with natural lighting only. They are done in two rooms with these enormous paintings. You can sit for a long time and appreciate what he has accomplished. If you have been to Giverny, you will greatly admire his accomplishment. We visited his home a few days later, and we could begin to understand what he was trying to show us.
Monet's water lilies in a perfect setting. This is a very small museum that is so worth a visit just to see Monet's murals in the two oval rooms. So beautiful!

Quick, Easy and Awesome Museum. I went for the Monet Water Lilies exhibit and fell in love with the ease of this museum. It was a place you could see in less than 2 hours. Sometimes you cannot spend a half day in a museum and if you have limited time, this is definitely one for you. The exhibit was absolutely breathtaking.As an added benefit, when you are going to the museum, you see the Tuilerie Gardens and the Louvre. It's beautiful and the grounds are a pure delight.

Great museum. I didn't even know this existed until I saw it listed under a "Best of Paris" guide. I'm so happy we went. It's the perfect size for a museum. I never liked the vastness of the Louvre, I've always found it much too overwhelming to fully appreciate. That said, I think I could have sat for hours in either of the two rooms of Monet's masterpieces. The museum is easily found and reasonably priced. It's worth a visit.

Monet's works of art!. Definitely make a stop here if you want to see the water lilies. I never realized that they were such large panels of canvas. Amazing, truly. Almost 2000 sq feet of canvas depicted in two separate rooms. Fantastic. Other works in this museum include Renoir, Picasso, Rousseau, Cezanne... EtcDefinitely worth a visit if you have the time to pop on by, covered by museum pass so it lets you skip the queue (which wasn't too bad on a Friday afternoon).

Another Must See in Paris, France. This is another Must See in Paris, France - especially if one has any sort of classical education. The large paintings of the waterlilies are amazing. As well, there is an impressive display of impressionist and modern paintings at a lower level. Picasso as well as Renoir, and many others.
To get to know another culture. i had so much fun there and the place is outstanding the culture are so beautiful. Stunning graphics

Loveley small museum, watch out for the gypsies outside. This museum is a must do with the two rooms of large water Lillie's. if you love Monet as we do, you'll find the presentation in this beautiful museum awesome, Took a break just outside while husband walked away to get some sandwiches. Here came a gypsy, stooped down in front of me and picked up a gold ring he "found" and tried to get me to take it. I didn't and am not sure what his next move would have been if I did. I had to get up and move on to get him to leave. When my husband came back with the sandwiches, we were approached two more times with the same scam. Were they going to team up once we were distracted or demand money after we'd taken the ring? Don't know but Paris has a real problem we are noticing that we didn't experience twenty years ago. Hotel said they will try to steal from you. Used the metro on the way over and someone tried to pick the strapped fanny pack I was wearing.. Too bad.

Stunning Monet's. If you want to attend a smaller gallery in Paris and see a great range of art work then this is the place for you. There are several very large Monet's on display plus many other masterpieces. Really good value.
MONET. I like large paintings so seeing two huge rooms of Monets work was incredible. It is like you are walking into his pond, Normandy steps away from the Seine.

Don't miss it!. We nearly didn't bother going but just happened to call in whilst strolling by. Great little but varied collection of works on the lower floor from an array of the most famous artists and the water lilies on the upper floor. A real gem.

INCREDIBLE!. Small amazing museum and cannot be missed! Materpieces of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings, including Monet's series of 8 murals of the Water Lilies. Located in the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens.

Small and Worthwhile. It's easy to add this museum to your list because it's small, and won't take the kind of time that the Musee d'Orsay or the Louvre will. A nice collection of impressionist art, and, of course, Monet's Water Lily's are the center of the collection and well worth seeing while you are in Paris.

Beautiful. After the overwhelming scale of the Louvre, this is a beautiful, peaceful breath of fresh air. The 2 oval rooms that each contain large scale, curving Monet water lilies are breathtaking. It is worth the museum entry price just to spend time in these rooms. The museum also contains a relatively small but interesting collection of Impressionist and post impressionist art, including several early works by Picasso as well as works by Matisse, Renior, Rousseau and Cezanne among others. When I visited, it was not particularly crowded, which was also a welcome change.The museum is at the edge of the Tuileries opposite the Place de la Concorde, so it is easy to slot into your visit to major attractions.
