Love, love, love!. Such a treat to sit and view the "Water Lilies" in this beautiful museum. We could have sat there for hours. Wish the staff would enforce the "quiet zone" a bit more as many people don't understand you shouldn't be talking in loud voices in these rooms! Some docents were "sshhing" people but the people seemed annoyed by being asked to be quiet! The incredible art in the rooms requires reflection not discussion in loud tones. When it was quiet, it was magical!!! This museum is a must if you like Monet!

My new favorite museum in Paris!. This is my third trip to Paris and the first time I have been to the Musee de l'Orangerie. On both previous trips the museum was closed for renovations. This time time I finally get to see the beautiful Monet wall mural size paintings. Located in two oval shaped rooms, the murals are amazing. You can easily spend an hour or more just in these two rooms. The museum isn't crowded so it's very enjoyable and easy to view everything. This is covered by the Paris Museum Pass. Located at the Tuilleries Garden, after the museum take a walk through the gardens and have a picnic lunch.
Do not miss the room of Monet murals of Giverny. The Monet murals of Giverny are spectacular in their own gallery. The treatment of the large size affords a view that is remarkable.

wonderful.... Lots of great Monet paintings...great to see so many in one place...Nice areas...close to other good sites...must see when in Paris if you are into art..Giverny is not far from city to make it a Monet day!

Absolutely a "must see" for Monet. When we suggest this museum to people, they usually don't know about it and then thank us profusely. If you know about Monet, you will be so happy you took the time to see this fantastic place where the walls are all about lily pads.

Don't miss. This small museum is worth it just to see the Monet's. They are well presented in light-filled rooms. I could have stayed in there forever enjoying these paintings. You can make a short stop here and walk through the beautiful Tuileries Gardens on your way to the Louvre.

A perfect setting for Monet's waterlilies. A small museum with an impressive collection of Impressionist art. You can visit it in less than an hour, but you'll want to linger in one of the two oval rooms showcasing Monet's famous waterlilies. Absolutely perfect.
Take your time. It's amazing!. One of the best collection of paintings. Check out Claude Monet's "Nympheas" on display at this museum

If only we had more time.... Allow time to appreciate the Monets and cater for extra time to visit the other parts of the gallery which houses very good works by other artists as well. It was a pity that we only got there an hour before the museum closed.

Small museum but Quality. Was able to walk in straight away without queuing perhaps it was because it was September. The museum was quite small but I found it quite breathtaking. I have a large copy of a section of the scenes hanging in a frame in my home so it was particularly pleasing to see the real thing. We ended up walking around twice as we enjoyed it so much. They even let you photograph in here
Monet's famous waterlily paintings. The 2 rooms with Monet's waterlily paintings running around the walls of a circular room.You felt like you were floating in the middle of a beautiful pond

Jardin de Tuilerie & L'orangerie. After Musée de Louvre and before Place de la Concorde you'll find a classical garden "Jardin de Tuilerie". Here you can have a rest from all the walking a talking. Sit down in a comfortable chair around the fountain and just calm down. Or have a meal in one of the two outdoor restaurants surrounded by well kept trees and flowerbeds. And before you leave, don't miss the Musée L'orangerie. Smaller than Musée D'orsay, but ever so elegant and easily overcome. I was particularly fond of the big collection of Pierre - Auguste Renoir impressionist paintings. :)
Giant Canvases. Unbelievable display of Monet. Colors, shapes, you're enveloped by these paintings as they are part of the wall displayed under natural light.
A tad small for the price. Some interesting art, but not enough on show to justify the entry fee. Only worth a visit if you like the style of work on show.

Don't miss it if you have a Museum Pass!. I'm not an art junkie, but I went to this museum to see Monet's "Les Nymphéas" (Water lilies), I admit it. You can also admire works of Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse or Picasso. The place is obviously worth a visit. I had a lovely experience also because it wasn't as crowded as I had expected it to be in mid-July. Tip for journalists: My husband entered free of charge by providing his press card.
Il mio museo preferito a Parigi simply the most charming museum in Paris. What to add at the beauty of the Nymphéas paintings of Monet?... Straordinario, da vedere sicuramente.

Wow.... As a dummy in all sorts of art, I confess I am not a big fan of Monet, though his water lilies are always appealing to laymen. I therefore did not expect too much apart from a few masterpieces. However, this Musee turns to be truly exceptional in that its clever use of daylight has widened any layman's horizon of art appreciation. I visited on a day when Paris was mostly sunny, with a few clouds. At the oval hall, I witnessed the change of colour of the paintings, hence impression, due to the change of light (when the clouds overcast). Excuse my ignorance that's perhaps why this is Impressionist.Strongly recommended - if you have had enough of d'Orsay and Louvre (and their associated crowds).

Tranquility in the midst of the city. Monet's Water Lilies are indescribably beautiful. This is a place to sit quietly for a while and simply immerse yourself in tranquillity. The rest of the collection downstairs is also worth a visit with many fine and lesser known works by impressionists.
Small but great. If you like Monet it's a great little museum to visit. We arrived on the first Sunday of the month so it was free.

Highly Recommended. We walked through the Tuileries and stopped by here. The Museum Pass let us walk straight in. The Monet rooms were marvelous, and the museum is suprisingly big and has a great collection. The space itself is very soothing and not too crowded despite it being a high tourist season.
Small and special. The collection is special. It's a smaller museum but very special! It's everything you've read here and more!1

Perfect string for the collection.. Everything is right. Convenience lighting and proportion. Being able to stand back, see the full lengths and all in every proportion was a delight. I shall come back and back.

Monet and More. The Monet pieces here are unique to L'Orangerie and you have likely never seen them. They are in two large oval rooms with paintings Monet created specifically for these spaces so Parisians could escape the city and enjoy the respite of the gardens at Giverny. The lower level has Renoir, Cezzane and others you will enjoy as a break from the craziness of Place de la Concorde.
A LOVELY MUSEUM. This is a museum that I had not visited before and was amazed at the outstanding collection of art.I would highly recommend this museum.The magnitude of the Monet works are fabulous.

Good to visit as a part of the Galleries of Paris. Some excellent works to see and enjoy.Not as busy and near other attractions.Loved the Modiglianis.Easy to access in the area of many other sights on any day in Paris centrum .It is well worth the effort.
Wonderful. This was one of our highlights, only a small gallery but Monet Waterlillies were just wonderful quite overwhelming. We pre booked a joint ticket with the D'Orsay

An artistic "pit stop". When you get to the Orangerie, after a long day criss-crossing Paris, spend half an hour sunbathing in front of the museum, admiring Place de la Concorde and just watching people. Then, get inside and admire the masterpieces on display, not too many to overwhelm but just enough to be memorable. A must see.

Worth a quick look to see Monet's Waterlilies. There's really not a whole lot here, but there are two big rooms of Monet's Waterlilies to sit and look at. Worth seeing just to say you have. Especially if you have the Museum Pass, anyway. There are a few other rooms of paintings that I walked quickly through.

A slice of Givenchy in Paris.. If you like Monet, you must go to this lovely museum - especially if you are unable to go to Givenchy. This small building is a hidden gem. You go into a round room surrounded by Monet murals. Sit there and absorb the beauty.
Boring. Didn't find this museum all that interesting-- maybe I was tired, but wasn't worth the stop to see! Sorry!!!

Monet's Vision. The musee de l' orangerie is set in the Tuileries and features eight of Monet's huge water lily canvases. It is a lovely museum, quiet and not too many tourists. I thoroughly recommend a stroll through the Tuileries and then an hour or so spent in the Musee. Entry costs 7.50 euro. In addition the Walter Guillaume collection also has paintings by Matisse, Picasso and other artists from 1870 to 1930. You won't be sorry visiting this special place designed by Monet himself.

Worth it for the Monets. Overall a small museum, the rest of the art work does not measure up to what you can find at the louvre and musee d'Orsay, but it's worth it just to sit in the room with Monet's waterlillies

A masterpiece in centre of Paris. After visiting almost all the museums in Paris, Orangerie stays my favorite. This is a magnificent place in Paris and even with crazy amount of tourist it stays calm and quiet. The museum has an amazing collection,from my point of view, which is not too big and not too small, has great impressionism masterpieces and very optimistic in time. If you have a choice to go to only one museum in Paris, I would definitely recommend you this one, even though Louvre is much more famous.

Monet superb. This is another great gallery, the Monet rooms I went through 3 times, to be surrounded by these incredible paintings, the entire collection at this gallery was wonderful. I will visit again before I leave
Must see the collection downstairs. Monet's painting is great, but the real treat is downstairs. Great collection of masters (Renoir, Picasso, etc.)
Overwhelmingly beautiful if you like Monet. These panels are just beautiful reflections of the water lilly pond through the artist's eye. A smaller sized museum focused on these works.

A real jewel. This museum has a unique in the round display by Monet along with works by other impressionists. It is small,very compact and at the north end of the Tuileries Gardens, which is a bonus at the end of the day of museum visiting. You can grab drink at one of the park eateries and watch the people.
if you have the time. Small and interesting. Not a must do. Like the size and the art of good, but there is more to see in Paris

A good collection and the line was not long. Amazing to see how one person was able to collect so many pieces of art. Not a big musee, but still worth the trip as you're walking through the Tuileries. Also near the Luxor Obelisk and Place de la Concorde.

Monet's waterlilies never looked so good.... If you are interested in Monet or the impressionist artists, this is a must. Situated near the Louvre, it is a wonderful place to visit. Quiet and peaceful after the crowds of the Louvre, there is almost no-one here. Rodin's Kiss greets you as you approach the building and then once through the entrance, you go into the waterlily galleries. There are 2 galleries with giant sized paintings of his waterlilies on the walls. There are 4 in each curved room, with a bench in the middle, to sit and enjoy. They all show the same view, from different times of day, seasons, and conditions. Absolutely stunning. Downstairs there are more impressionist paintings to view. A small but wonderful museum. Monet painted these to be placed in this building, it is a special place to visit.

For lovers of Monet. After the overwhelming size and massive crowds at the Louvre, this museum is a welcome change. The queues are short, it is quiet and small. For lovers of Monet it is a real treat with the ground floor devoted to his Water Lilies. There is time and space to sit and appreciate the art. The museum also contains paintings from Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse and many others.Highly recommended.
Mussee. Great museum. Especially for the exhibition of Monet water lilies and also the architecture of the place. The museum is open daily.I Love Paris!

Perfect 15-minute museum. I am not one to linger in museums - especially when visiting a beautiful city on a beautiful day.This museum is perfect for that quick museum visit.Coming to this museum was the perfect end to our day.We visited Monet's gardens in Giverny first, then came to see the 7 huge Monet paintings in l'Orangerie.

Wonderful Impressionists Museum. If you like Impressionists and don't have a ton of time, this museum is for you. It is quite lovely and not very large. We spent about an hour and half and that seemed more than enough time to see everything. Lots of beautiful works of art that can't be seen at the Louvre.

For Monet Lovers. Seeing the waterlilies in the round (there are two rooms representing the change of colors through an entire day) was something I have wanted to experience since about eighth grade, so for me this museum was amazing. My husband, not a big fan of impressionists found this museum to be less than thrilling.

Monet. Such an exhilarating experience to stand where Monet stood and feel/see what he wanted you to see...you have to do this if nothing else in Paris. Hard to explain the peace of his art/ lilies. But go early/late as it is noisy otherwise and hard to pull into a quiet place to meditate on his work. Pics are not allowed unfortunately.

Great for visiting a museum in under an hour. Yes, it can be done! This is a lovely treasure of a museum and can be seen in its entirety in under an hour. We thoroughly enjoyed seeing Claude Monet's Water Lilies. The other works were a bonus and included Guillaume, Renoir, Cézanne, and Picasso amongst others. Museums can be a challenge especially when the beautiful weather calls to be outdoors. However this museum is a must see and can fit easily into a sunny or rainy day.
Well worth your time in Paris. Every piece of art was beautiful! This museum is a manageable size - not overwhelming like the Louvre - and you will want to see everything in it.
Great, but too crowded. Coach tours dump masses of tourists off here. Go early if you don't want to engulfed by masses of people.
My what big lilies you have. Go here to see Monet's lilies, stay to see a surprisingly large range of wonderful paintings on the lower floor.

Amazing Monet. This is a museum you need to visit if you like the Impressionists as the paintings by Monet will not travel to other museums. They were designed specifically for the building and are exquisite.

The Monet is out of this world. The waterlillies was something I can't describe. IF you are short of time, give the Lourve a miss but definitely go the Musse de'l Orangerie....more value for money and just as impressive if not more.

Phénoménal. Looking at the Monet waterlilies was sublime. Amazing what the man could do with color and brush strokes. The sheer size of the paintings is something you must experience. The feeling of serenity was unsurpassed.
Très Joli!. My wife and I were blown away by Monet's Water Lillies!! A must see.....just walk through the Jardin des Tuileries (turn left coming off the Rue de Rivoli)
monet 360. A wonderful museum!Easy to navigategreat impressionist paintings & of course Monet's 360 waterlillies!get combined pass with musee d'orsay & SKIP the Louvre
a gorgeous gem in the tuileries. Amazing waterlillies by Monet - also great collection of Renoir and Cezanne paintings on display at the moment

A private collection that illustrates the best of an era. We had seen Monet's water lilies before on were were impressed with the new lighting. But we missed before the Paul Guillaume collection - an excellent selection of an epoch.

The home of Monet's eight "Water Lilies" murals and other Impressionist and post-Impressioninst works. Musee de l'Orangerie is well-known as the home of Claude Monet's eight "Water Lilies" murals which he presented to the city, but it is also home to works of other Impressionist and post-Impressionist artists such as Modigliani, Matisse, Cezanne, Picasso, and others.The rooms where the Monet murals are displayed are lighted by natural, filtered daylight and feature benches in the center of the room so that visitors can view the works from different angles and in a peaceful setting where light, a Monet inspiration, plays a major role. Another not-to-be-missed art museum for art connoisseurs and people just beginning to learn about Impressionists, alike.

A Must See in Paris. Although small, this place is so worth the visit. It is the only place you get to see Monet's panoramic water lilies. Plan to spend a little more time to sit in front of each painting to appreciate more. If you also plan to visit Musee d'Orsay, you can get the combined ticket here for both places - which we did not see offered at d'Orsay. What you pay for the combined ticket is equivalent to what you would pay for d'Orsay alone.
Monet Water Lillies. Monet's Water Lillies are a must see when in Paris. Remaining items in collection are interesting as well. Close to Louvre and not as overwhelming as Louvre.

Another Paris gem. Love their collection of Soutine and Utrillo . The paintingsnare displayed in small, manageable spaces which allow one to focus on the art more than it is possible in a vast museum space.

Lovely. This is a great break after the Louve. Primarily 2 big circular rooms with 4 Monet paintings 50' wide in each. Each a different view of his gardens, showing different times of the day. full of color and so refreshing and enjoyable. Monet made specifically for this museum but unfortunately died before he could see in completed.

unexpected and hidden. It is small; there is a small downstairs gallery that is worth a quick visit; but the real reason for going there are the water lilliesTwo oval shaped rooms with benches in the middle; the only view is the panorama of the water lillies. And they are gorgeous; .so simple yet refined; I am no art critic, but these are beautiful.The place is quiet and awesome (in the good sense);Hidden away in a corner of the Jardins Tuilleries close to the Place de la Concorde; in is truly a secret gem of Paris museums.Well worth the time

Wonderful Monet, but not much variety.. Lovely museum right in the corner of the Tuileries Gardens. Full if large Monet works done at his home over the seasons of his ponds and Lilly pads. Really pretty and less crowded than other museums.

Charming museum with extraordinary Monets!. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a must for anybody that has an interest in impressionistic art. What I liked about this museum is that it is small and it actually wasn't too busy the early afternoon we were there.The museum is best known for housing eight of Monet's larger water lilly paintings and upon seeing them in person, they leave you, well, speechless.The lower floor of the museum has an excellent collection of paintings by Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Sisley, Soutine, and Utrillo, and even a couple of Picassos too!They also allow you to take photos of the paintings (at least the paintings on the lower level) as long as you do not use a flash. This is the only museum we encountered in Paris that permitted this.If you have the opportunity to visit this museum, please do so, you will not be disappointed!

Claude Monet's paintings. If you love Claude Monet's paintings, you need to come here to see a few of his paintings. My 2 favorites are Green Reflections and The Two Willows. Hard to describe, you'll have to go to appreciate his talent and the details that went into his paintings. They are huge!

Only worth it if using Museum Pass. If you're using the Museum Pass and in the area, then stop by to see the Water Lilies. The other works of art on the lower floor were not impressive nor worth seeing in my opinion. I would not have been happy paying 7.5 Euros for admission to this museum. The Musée d'Orsay is a better value. We were in and out in less than 10 minutes.

The best. Do not miss this little museum at the far end of the Louvre. It houses original paintings of Monet's Water Lilies and also Picaso, and other famous artists that were NOT in the Louve. Very impressed with the price, and quality of how everything was presented. Would go back again and again if I could. Monet helped design the layout. We waited about 1 hour to get in. No pictures of the Monet paintings, security guards watch to make sure.

Wonderful Monet Water Lilies (Nymphéas). If you love Monet (and I certainly do), then this little gem of a museum is a must in Paris. The main room has gigantic murals of water lilies done by Monet and it has been renovated in the last decade or so so it looks fresh and clean. If all you want to do is take a quick look, you can be in and out in under 15 minute. But you can easily spend an hour in the room taking in the beauty of the two huge murals, on opposite walls. The museum is rarely crowded (from my experience at least) and is a wonderful peaceful setting to sit and take in the art. Of course, then you have to take a day trip (at least) to Giverny to see the actual water lilies in the pond in Monet's back yard. A warning, though: if you don't really like Monet and his water lilies paintings, skip this place. You'll be doing both yourself and those who are want to see it a favor.
Best for Sutin and Renuar. Love this museum , go back every time.Its not as popular as the Louvre but has art will not find ay oyher place .

Must see Monet. For such a small building I was surprised by how pleasantly uncrowded it was. There was plenty of room to enjoy the art from different perspectives and at your own pace. I could have spent hours in the oval rooms surrounded by Monet. A very moving experience. That being said, if one was wanting to fit something into their day that could take up 2 hours of time, this would also fit the bill.

Nice mini-daytrip when you're kind of tired!. My daughter (age 17) and I recently spent a week in Paris, and on our last day, we were pretty tired after all our activities (jet-lag, a day at Versailles, another day at Fountainbleu, half a day at the Marche aux Puces (Flea Market), the Latin Quarter & Notre Dame, the Rodin Museum, etc) that we decided to take it easy and go here. It was easy to access via the Metro and a short walk from the Louvre, or a longer walk from the Arc de Triomphe. It's a very manageable museum, meaning that you can see EVERYTHING in an hour or two (unlike the Louvre, where you could spend your whole life and not see everything!). The "piece de resistance" is, of course, the top floor, where 8 long panels of Monet's paintings cover the walls (2 separate rooms, 4 panels per room). We tried to pick our favorite panel (The Two Willows, Clear Morning with Willows, Morning w/Weeping Willows, Reflections of Trees, Green Reflections, Morning, Clouds, & Sunset), but it was impossible. Downstairs was more art, by Renoir, Cezanne, Rousseau, Modigliani, Laurencin, Matisse, Picasso, Derain, Utrillo, & Guillaume. We appreciated seeing it all, and also realized that, masterpieces that they may be, we don't necessarily LIKE all of them, which is just fine! Afterwards, we had lunch at one of the outdoor cafes in Les Tuileries, then fed the pigeons w/left-over baguettes from the previous day, and walked along the Seine. Beautiful Day!

Love for Monet. If you are fond of Monet's work his museum is a must. There are two beautiful rooms with large scale Monet paintings circling the room. It is a very peaceful museum not overly crowed as some of the other museums in Paris.

Can not get enough of Monet!!!!!. Very small exhibit of some wonderful impressionist .!!!!! Monet's water Lillie's and his private room of his works are to me to die for!!! I am a art history buff, and just being here was wonderful!!! Renoir, Cezanne, wonderful works. The only down side is that Monet's Hay stacks only one painting was on exhibit!!!! I was fortunate to see the other 4 that are still on display in Las Vegas, Nevada at the Billagio! I was hoping to have my husband be able to see the display of light that Monet is soooo noted for.
Must see if you love Monet's work. The design and layout. It also is not as big as the Louvre or D'Orsay...so that made it a perfect morning excursion on my travels.

Oh, this is a good one!. Such a small quaint museum. Easy to get through, and see all there is to see. The biggest treat of all is to see Monet's garden covering the entire walls in an oval room. The four stars is because the staff is not the friendliest to the customers.

Tranquility in Paris. Monet's goal was to provide a peaceful spot for Parisians and he absolutely succeeded. Even with a long line of tourists waiting to get in, the main rooms were an oasis of calm, letting you just sit and absorb the beauty of the paintings.

Be in the pond!. Having been a fan of Monet's water lilies since I first saw one as a teen, it was great to be able to have an immersion experience with these 8 paintings in such a perfectly designed setting.

No lines and fabulous art. While quite small compared with its Paris contemporaries (Louvre and Musee D'Orsay, the Musee de l'Orangerie is still chockablock with treasures. For those with small children or restless teens, this would be a perfect outing -- you can see a treasure house of art in a short period of time.

Do not miss this if you love Monet!. It would be so easy to miss this small museum at the far end of the Jardin de Tuileries after exiting the Louvre, but that would be a tragedy if you are a fan of Monet's Waterlilies paintings. They are displayed here in two oval rooms in a way that makes them even more breathtaking than you could imagine. Seeing them literally brought tears to my eyes. The museum has other works worth seeing as well, but this is the highlight by far. I had the Paris Museum Pass, but my understanding is that admission is included here if you buy a ticket to the Musee D'Orsay, just across the Seine.

Sublime. What an amazing sight, had not really anticipated such a massive work of art even though I had read the reviews.The works in this museum are well worth a good look, a lovely sized gallery, not over whelming, you cant get lost in here as I did many times in the louvre!

If you love Monet - you need to go here. I really loved this musee as I love impressionist art - and the Monet here is sublime. If you are a more old school art fan like my father is - you might be better off visiting the Lourve.

Monet's labour of love. First time visiting the Musee de l'Orangerie. If you want to bypass the queue at the main entrance, then buy yourself a Paris Museum Pass online or at the Paris Tourist Centre. It gives you fast tracked access.The overall gallery is not that large but it holds a very well curated collection in several rooms downstairs. The main attraction of course are the two rooms that contain Monet's largest compositions of waterlillies. To see them in person is really a moving experience - I highly recommend making time to simply stand in the rooms and slowly absorb the sheer scale of this masterpiece. It will take your breathe away. What a wondeful legacy to leave for the country.
If you love Monet.... Head to Le Musee de L'Orangerie to see Monet's paintings as he developed through his life. You can even be surrounded by his water lilies in a circular room! Awesome!

The great paintings. We went in June 2012. The highlight of the museum is the oblong shaped room in which you experience the Water Lilies by Monet. He painted them to help people heal from World War I. Very cool. Worth your visit because the arrangement is unique. Maybe other museums have one little painting. But this is the real experience. Go there.

One of the bucket lists. I was surprised by how much more is received from an actual visit to Orangerie for Monet's paintings.This museum was built to display waterlillies and is one of the great series of art works that should not be missed.

totally worth the wait. queued for about half hour but so worth it. Nymphéas (aka Water Lilies) are beautiful and totally worth it, the way it is set up with the room bathed in natural light makes it a great experience

A small museum jewel. a must see for the wonderful Monet Waterlilies.
well worth a trip and then off to the Champs Elysees.

beautiful feeling!!. This experience was great. The feeling when you see this paintings is great. The water lillies are amaizing and like Monet thought we could appreciated best, this is a great display.

Finally!. We've been waiting for years to visit this museum, which was closed for rennovations for many years. It doesn't disappoint! Stunning Monets, of course, but the collection on the lower level is eclectic and very interesting. A highlight of our brief stop in Paris.

The art will take your breath away. There are many museums in Paris but if there is one you should not miss is the Musee L'Orangerie. Monet's Water Lillies will take your breath away...litterally. Words cannot describe the visual beauty of the paintings and what your body will experience physiolgoically speaking. The second floor holds other great works of impressionist art as well.
Well worth it!

Lost in Paris. If you like Monet and his "nymphéas" you simply must visit this rather small museum. After a walk in the Jardins du Luxembourg
this is the place to get some rest and quietness. Just sit and watch.
In the round exhibition rooms these huge paintings are exposed in a magnificent way.

Value for Monet. This museum is worth the money (€7.50) just to see 'Les Nympheas', Monet's last great work, displayed as he intended, in the round and naturally lit from above. Sit and drink in the colours, the atmosphere, you can almost see the water rippling.The bonus is downstairs - the Walter-Guillaume collection of Impressionist and early 20thC works by Renior, Cezanne, Gaugin, Picasso, Soutine and Derain, all for the same entry fee.The audio guide is an extra €5, but is very comprehensive and worth it for the background on some of the lesser-known artists.Easiest way to arrive is by Metro at the Concorde stop. Then perhaps a stroll in the adjacent Tuileries Gardens and an ice-cream to finish a delightful afternoon.

the best small museum of Paris. Totaly renovated, a visit to this monument of impressionist painters of the French school of the years 19xx,is a must for all Paris visitors withe a taste of beaty and art.

Genuine Beauty!. We went to the l'Orangerie to see Monet's Water Lillies, which were breathtaking in their presentation. What came as a surprise was the lower gallery that had a fantastic private collection on display! Renoir was the featured artist and a delight to discover!

If you can't get to Giverny. While you are in France, if you cant travel outside of Paris, at eat go see the room Monet designed for his spectacular rendition of a section of his gardens. Mesmerizing in its' scope and sequencing of the changing light of day, the memory will stay with you. I developed new respect for finite detail
Be surrounded by water lillies. Monet's Water Lillies will surround you in two oval rooms of subtle color. Visitors were transfixed by their magnificence.
les nympheas. i was disappointed that there only was to rooms with huge paintings, i had expected more. we then went downstairs to the other exhibitions and then left.

Just for Monet!. The water lillies! Worth the price of admission. Displayed as Monet intended, this is definitely the pinnacle. But the other artists displayed in this easy, simple museum are also noteworthy. Picasso works on display. Just wonderful.
A must in the Tulleries. A series of Monet Murals attached to the walls of the old Orange Tree Green House. Outstanding collection of Monets and other painters. Conveniently located. Do not miss.

Surreal. Surprisingly there were few people at the museum. Monet's works are amazing and the rooms really allow you to take it all in. Take a seat and lose yourself in the paintings. Downstairs is a private collection. It's nice, but can be skipped if you are pressed for time.

Small, and focused on Monet.. If you love Monet, you should stop here. If you don't don't bother.
My favorite pic from this museum is of the rules on the entrance wall. Think Willy Wonka fine print. and no pics allowed.

Hidden little gem. Beautiful small museum that you have to visit, especially if you like impressionist art. All the most famous paintings of Monet are in this collection. You can get a pass for both Musee D'Orsay and Musee de l'orangerie and this will save you money and you will not need to stand in the line. The location of the museum is perfect. It's right in Tuileries gardens.

Monet's magnificence. Very nice museum without the crowds located in a nice park. If you have the Museum Pass (which I highly recommend) be sure you are in the right line! We saved a ton of time once we realized there were three lines (one for Museum Pass, one for handicap, and one for everyone else). It's not roped so go up to the front of the line to make sure you're in the right one! Museum was nice and calm and Monet's work was wonderful. So very grand in size and achievement. Definitely recommend.

More than Just Water Lilies. The major attraction here is a magnificent painting of the water lilies at Giverny, and the best way to do justice to the room-sized painting is to sit and absorb it. A little advance reading about the creation of the painting and its perspective is also helpful. But the museum has expanded its collection to include a large number of works by painters who lived and worked during the same period. It's very interesting to see all of these pieces exhibited together.
Water Lilly Extravaganza. If you love Monet, then the Musee de l'Orangerie is were you want to visit. Two circular rooms dedicated to his Water Lily work. You will be in awe.

Amazing Collection of Monet. This little museum has an amazing collection of Monet water lily paintings! They are exceptional and it is definitely worth going to! It is on the other side of the Tullieries from the Louvre. Also, note, if you dont get the museum pass, you can go to the l'orangerie and the D'Orsay in the same day at a discounted price ;)
Hidden gem!!. The Water Lilies were beautiful, but we almost missed the great artwork downstairs. If we had not needed the bathroom we wouldn't have even found the best part of the museum.

As important as Musee d'Orsay. Has one of the best Monet collections in the world. Also some nice pieces by other Impressionist artist. You will love the 8 shaped "infinity" rooms designed by Monet himself. They are truly beautiful. It gets pretty crowded in the afternoon I suppose so it might be better to go in the morning to immerse yourself in the huge Monet paintings :) Do not miss this museum if you like Impressionism.

Don't miss this!. This tiny art museum contains works of Monet that are absolutely amazing. The museum was build just for these 8 works. Be sure to look at the difference in the paintings when you stand close and then when you look from the other end of the room. It's baffling how Monet could get the perspective he did.

Small but without the crowds. Very underrated... The experience of walking around inside the work of Monet is amazing. The atmosphere was not claustrophobic and the extra artworks on the lower floor are even better. Attendants were a little heavy handed in not letting strollers in, but it was worth the effort.

Paris visitors to art Galleries. There is so much I could say about Paris, this was my second visit and this time I was travelling by myself. I must say everyone I met were wonderful from the cab driver who picked me up at the Train station and who would not let me tip him, and told me he would pick me up again from the hotel in a weeks time to take me to the Airport. to the small hotel young owners. to people who just offered information when they spotted me looking at a map. I would go back in a minute and hope that I will.Now about l Orangerie it is a must see if you are a fan of the Impressionists painters and will love the continuous painting of the lilypads by Monet. Dont miss it. Of course all the National Galleries are fantastic, not only the art work but also the architecture.

The place to go to see Monet but don't miss the other works. This is a small museum but I highly recommend you see it. Of course, it is the home to Monet's eight Water Lilies murals but it also contains other facinating works by Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso and Renoir. I absolutly LOVED this museum. It will be on my 'don't miss list" for future trips to Paris.

Sublime. In this beautiful museum you can admire the masterpieces of Claude Monet: The Nympheas, or huge canvases painted by the genius when he was already quite aged and nearly blind. Flashes are forbidden (of course !) and - this I really liked: - one is expected to keep quiet during the visist. That is, Monsieur, no conversation, please, especially all of you "papas' talking and explaining things to your dear "kids" who understand nothing... No one must disturb the acquatic wonders created by Monet.The place is magical. The room where the exhibition is located is oval and has this especial kind of diffuse white light from above. The museum is small. Like a most precious jewell, unique in the world I only hope the arabs never buy it !!! As an artist ( that I am), it is also a little more: I think of it as a temple, a sacred precint.
Monet and more. Showed up late afternoon and got in for 5 Euro. The Monet display is breath taking. Various Modigliani pieces worth seeing as well. I'll be back...

My New Favorite. If you love art and/or Monet, you HAVE to visit l'Orangerie. It is really different from many other museums, it is really neat to see rooms organized by artist to really get a sense of their style and development. I love Monet, and seeing the two rooms with the paintings at Giverny made me emotional it was so breathtakingly beautiful. If you plan to visit the Orsay, buy the pass that covers both, you have 4 days.

Monet lovers would feel like Nymp in this musee!. lovly space for Monet lover only as if you are a guy who love collage football and don't know who Monet is! you probably wonder why you are stuck in this ever ending water lilies painting! but for those who love Monet go see this muse but get a Paris Musee pass as I don't think this muse worth 7 Euro to get in.
it's all new!. the renovations are complete and the space does what it intends, welcomes you to fabulous circular water lily paintings in amazing natural light. A good visit before going to Giverny.
Simply amazing. A small boutique museum with big Art ,great collection of Monet and other great Parisienne Artists beautifully designed in the Tuilliries Garden

Monet to the max. This is in the gardens of the Louvre, it is very well presented. the queuing system was great and they look after your bags for free. the Monet works are just amazing, but the intire display is really worth going to see.

Another item on my bucket list ticked off. Thrilled to see the water Lilly paintings for real at last...having been a fan since Athena sold millions of prints back in the 80's when I was a teenager and had them pinned all over my room!
Excellent. Do not miss it! Loved the actual museum, and the Monet! Be sure to walk thru the gardens too. No line, and if you don't have a museum pass, can buy a D'Orsay and this one together.
Monet in a Semi-Circle. Striking building and exhibition rooms with painted Monet semi-circular walls. Not to be missed when in Paris.

Thank You, Monet!. Always wanted to see the oval rooms with the water lilies, and they were even better than I imagined. I could have sat there for hours. Also they have a wonderful collection of Renoir.

Water Lillies. Nuff said. You have to go here to see Monet's Water Lillies. Don't leave Paris without them. The rest of the museum has been upgraded and is a very pleasant, manageable museum experience. Go.
Lovely small museum. If you are tired of the huge museums of Paris or just have a short time and want to view some great masterpieces this is the place.

beautiful museum. I enjoyed a short visit to this museum. It is a small museum but precious pieces of art, specially the waterlilies. (Include a visit to the Jardin des Tuileries, specially in summertime.)

Chillin. Monet's water Lillies, really neat setting in 2 large oval rooms, (again no photo's in the 2 Monet rooms, photos ok in the rest of the museum).Easy to walk thru and see most if not all in about an hours time, well worth the trip.Line was not that long, but the Paris Musuem pass does save some time.(The water faucet turns on by stepping on a pedal on the floor in the mens restroom)

Waterlilies are a dream. Monets waterlilies are indeed a dream but you must take time and sit and admire them for some time to get a glimpse of the escape from normal hectic life Monet intended to give as well as a glimpse of infinity.
Sit down and let Monet's gardens come alive. Monet's room-sized water lily canvases are displayed in natural light in two perspective-filling oval rooms. Other works also impress.

Don't miss this one. I finally made it to this museum this summer after several failing to do so on previous visits. Wow! Have I been missing out. Beautiful artwork that is beautifully displayed. The entire museum has a wonderful serene feel to it.
Amazing seeing Monet's famous works. Well worth the visit but try to buy your tickets at information booths....it really saves on queuing.

Extraordinary. I loved this gallery. Really for me it was about the two beautiful halls with Monet's water lilies. It's worth the €6 to just sit and take in the magnificent paintings. Take time to watch the effect of the changes of the natural light on the paintings. There are lesser known Cezzane's Renoir's and Picasso's.

So glad I visited this little gem. Loved this museum. I missed out on visiting the past few years and it was first on my list this visit.I arrived around 10.30 on Friday morning and walked right in. No queues. It was air conditioned inside, which was very welcoming given it was 30c outside. It wasn't very crowded and you had plenty of room to see everything.Oh those water lilies. Walking in and seeing these murals stopped me in my tracks. Unbelievable!! Then to see the other four was equally as amazing. I sat on the bench for a while just staring. It was quiet and you were able to take it all in.You must go downstairs to see the gallery of paintings. I was pleasantly surprised. Plenty of Picasso. The gift shop is quite lovely with some tat but also some good quality gifts/souvenirs.Lovely and not overpowering or overcrowded like the Louvre. A definite must see.

Small museum, but still a joy to see.. The main focus of the Musee de l'Orangerie are Monet's Les Nymphéas, but there is also a small gallery in the lower level. The water lilies are a must see, and the museum is smaller and not as overwhelming as the Orsay or Louvre.

La creme de la creme. We arrived at the musee late in the afternoon and were surprised to get in straight away. It is of course absolutely awesome. It closes at 5.45 so if you arrive late you need to move quickly, but in addition to the definitive Monet there is an absolutely brilliant exhibition of other impressionist paintings in the ground/basement area. We loved it. Very light but a very profound experience. If you are going anywhere in Paris, go here.
Inspiring. The museum holds some of the finest "modern" works in the world. They are easy to observe and the atmosphere is perfect for the serious art-minded tourist.

Stunning. A surprisingly quiet museum (even in late June). The temporary exhibition as well as the permanent exhibition and Monet rooms were all outstanding. Don't miss it if you enjoy Impressionist painting.
Water Lillies!. A small museum but worth the trip. As with any other museum in Paris, try to get there when in opens. The Water Lillies should not be missed!

Worth seeing. The water lilies look very different installed as Monet wanted. No reproductions do them justice. It is not a large museum and was rather crowded, but then, it was the height of summer when we were there.

Fun for Monet Fans. Monet's famous water lily paintings are definitely the star attraction at this small museum in the Jardin des Tuileries. The long canvases are mounted on special frames that wrap around a circular room, making for a unique art-viewing experience. There are also some paintings by Monet's contemporaries and later artists in the basement, although we didn't stay to see them. This is overall a nice museum to visit, especially for Monet fans.

Everything Musee D'Orsay is not. The art is beautifully displayed in rooms that feel spacious even when crowded. Full of Impressionist masterpieces, including a grand salle for Monet's water lilies. Don't miss this museum.

Wonderful Museum. We loved this museum. The two Monet rooms are spectacular. We could have stayed there for hours. It is the perfect size for a museum - enough variety but not overwelming. It is great to go there with kids as your stay can be about one hour and then you are off to other activities.

Well worth a visit. I can't believe that anyone would rate this attraction as terrible but hey everyone's entitled to their opinion! We did this almost by accident walking from the louvre to the champs élysées and are glad we did. The monet exhibition is fantastic but the current exhibition is out of this world IMO. Not too crowded bust we got there quite early (around 10am) but we noticed that the queue was out the door when we left so a tip wold be to get there early. It is August after all so to be expected no doubt. The exhibitions are wel laid out and they offer a self tour with headset for 5 euro. You can also combine your ticket with the musee d orsay to save money.

Beautiful Small Museum. This is a beautiful, small museum with two rooms with Monet's Water Lilies. After having done the Louvre the day before, it was refreshing to enjoy the small collection of Impressionist art without the large crowds that are at all of the larger museums in Paris during August.

Monet's Nympheas. Beautiful building, in the Jardin Tuillieries. Contains a special gallery with Monet's series of enormous paintings of the water lilies, known as Nympheas. These are displayed according to the conditions specified by Claude Monet, in particular the lighting.

Waterlillies. This was the one museum my wife didn't get to see on our first trip to Paris, so we made it a priority this time. I'm glad we did. I was blown away. I was not really expecting to enjoy it, but what a pleasant surprise!

great small museum. This museum is very doable, in that you only need 1-2 hours to see all the exhibits. It has an excellent collection of the impressionists, and the Monet's are displayed in a cool and unique fashion

Recommended for 19th Century Impressionist Art. Best collection of impressionists and Utrillo's work. Very pleasanty laid out and well organized. Tends to be much less crowed than many of the other major museums which is obviously another plus!
Wonderful Culture. Kids loved it and seemed really good value for money. very clean well kept and tidy.Would return and learn more.

Worth a walk to end of jardin for quick visit!. After the Louvre we wandered the length of the Tuileries gardens and were surprised at how small it actually is, but still had a good half an hour of browsing and the layout of the Monet lilies was definitely worth coming to see in their 2 rooms. Definitely worth a look in with it being so small.
My favorite in Paris. Spent my last day, a rainy one, pondering two rooms of Monet's Water Lilies, but found the other paintings were amazing. No crowds, easy to get to, visited twice.
Not worth a visit. Definitelly not what we had expected. Based on previous rewievs and tourist guides we hoped for a great experience, but it was not.

Visit Monet's beautiful water lilies. Stunning Monet paintings, the scale of which were staggering. This small museum was a nice contrast to the massive scale of the Louvre, it is light and airy and situated in the Jardin au Tuileries.

Great Little Museum. I went in with no queue in a late August afternoon. The two Monet 'Ovals' were worth the price of admission alone. I think they are one of the most underrated landmarks in Paris, unless you don't like Monet. The surprise was a beautiful collection of Renoir (about a dozen) at the basement that you can get close and personal with. You can't say that with most museums in Paris.

A wonderful time manageable museum. Easy to get to. Easy to walk through. Huge oval rooms with Water Lilies by Claude Monet. Many other early 20th century artists as well. Right at the Tuileries Gardens right in the middle of Paris!

Classy and gorgeous!. I went to this the first time the day after a visit to Giverny and again this year, where, upon reflection, the two rooms with the Monet Water Lily paintings are amazing! The collection in the basement, Margaret Laurentin, Picasso, Cezanne, etc. is marvelous as well. This has one of the best gift shops in Paris, too!

Bite size art. The water lilies are breath taking, but do go down to the small gallery downstairs. It has some very beautiful impressionist pieces and is less daunting for some than the sheer scale of the Louvre etc.

Go for the Waterlilies. We may not have gone to the museum if it wasn't for the fact that it was on the museum pass - allowing us to skip the lines and hop in for a quick stop to see the Waterlilies. Monet did not disappoint. The colours were beautiful and it was worth it alone for these beautiful paintings. I wasn't super excited by the works downstairs, but that was okay, because the Waterlilies were the show I came for. Right outside the Place de Concorde, the nearby water fountain, Gelato stand, Tuleries and views of the Eiffel tower are equally enjoyable. Worth the stop.

Musee de l"Orangerie. his is a small but special museum where many of Monet's paintings are displayed under a diffused, natural light that changes throughout the day. They are hung n long panels circumferentially around the perimeter of the room and so seem to merge with one another.The lighting s soft and really impact full. It can be appreciate as you walk around or spend time sitting n benched provided. It was a ver calm place. There are also some Renoir and Cezanne's downstairs to appreciate. Entrance to this museum s free with the Paris Art Pass--so worth it!

Beautiful Small collection. On a rainy day in Paris we stopped in here and was pleasantly surprised by the small but impressive collection. The main attraction is the two rooms with the Monet masterpieces. There were no long lines unlike the other attractions ( Museum de Orsay and the Lourve) . They have a nice collection of French artists as well. Buy a museum pass which is well worth it.
Beautiful.. .Just off main Place de Concorde. Very beautiful. 7Euro entrance. Well worth it to see amazing paintings.

Not the best art. I am pretty sure that Monet should of stopped while he was on top. The only great thing about this venue is the room. I think that the ordinary art work in the two oval rooms does a great dis service to the building. Other art work below is fine

Waterlilies. You must go to see the Monet waterlily exhibits, but don't miss out on the wonderful collection of art downstairs. Several beautiful pieces by Renoir and Cezanne along with some of Picasso's earlier work. I would recommend using the audio guide in this museum.

Monet's Waterlillies. Eight huge paintings of Monet's waterlillies are displayed here in two oval rooms. The gallery is fairly small and not very crowded. Located near the Jardin des Tuileries, not far from Place de la Concorde. Well worth visiting. Other works also exhibited by 19th and 20th century artists.
A Fav!. If you love Monet this is a must. Much less crowded than the other galleries and the huge Monet canvasses were spectacular!

Concentration of masterpieces. This renovated museum has a concentration of masterpieces providing a unique insight into modern art with Monet, Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso...too many to list, all surperb and in a peaceful setting. The Water Lillies are the pièce de résistance, the oval rooms were built specifically for these paintings, as a permanent home for eight murals he did for the people of France. Very nice, expecially after having been to his house in Giverny and seen the gardens, his inspiration, very meaningful visit.

Aaaah, Monet!. A small gem of a museum. The main floor is devoted solely to Monet's studies of water lilies (he calls them "nymphaes, their latin name). Two oval rooms with diffused light provide a place to view absolutely huge masterpieces by this master of Impressionism. The lower level has many paintings by other "unknowns", such as Renoir, Modigliani, Degas.This is a small museum but an absolute gem -- and located in the Tuileries near the Louvre.Not to be missed!!

Don't miss if you love Monet. Monet's waterlilies are amazing! Painted just for this viewing experience. You could sit there forever. Nice collection of Renoirs on the lower level too. This museum is off to the side before the Louvre - a must see!
Excellent, small museum. Do not miss this. Monet's own design to house his large water lily painting. Great lesser known art downstairs. Staff less than friendly.
disappointed. small collection compared to others and yet still the typical inflated price to see it. you can do this one fast and combine with another in a day. not for children

So many pictures in one place. Two parts - a pavilion for Monet water lily "walls" and another - one collection of Renoirs, Modiglianis, Utrillos, Soutines etc etc - all photographable (sans flash - but brightly lit). Very likeable
Monet, Monet, Monet. Highlights are Les Nympheas. It is like being immersed in an Impressionist painting. In the lower level, there is a broad representation of impressionist painting.
Monet's Water Lillies. Located close to the Lourve and the Place de Concorde, this museum offered room sized famous paintings by Monet.

Monet. Awesome it's like walking into his garden. Make sure you go on a sunny day. Don't miss the Renoir's on the lower floor. And the bronze casting of the kiss is easier to see than the copies in other mediums in other locations.

Can't miss this if you love Monet!. A relatively, small, manageable museum in a great location - the Tuilleries Gardens. An entire gallery is devoted to the original Monet Waterlily panels, lit with skylights.

Magnificent Monet and More!!. We could not have been more surprised at how much we love the Musee de l'Orangerie!! The Monet waterlilies are superb and certainly fill the fill if you cannot travel to Giverny. There are also many of our favorites widely represented...Picasso, Modigliani, Renoir, etc., etc.

Just not our type of art. Thank goodness we had the Museum Pass as I would have hated to pay to get into this museum. it was very small and the art was just not what we are in to. Would not go to this museum again.

Fabulous place!. Our family of four (2 adults, 2 kids ages 8 and 10) got a combined Musee d'Orsay and L'Orangerie ticket and had a terrific experience. First, young kids get in for free (I'm not sure what the age limit is, but they did not charge a ticket for either of our kids).This museum has the huge and stunning Monet paintings spanning two very large rooms. The idea is to sit in the middle of the room and take it all in by turning your head (and body) to get the feeling of being inside the environment that Monet was painting.We also caught a small movie on Monet and the circumstances in which he painted the items described above. The movie is included in the price of admission and is well worth catching.Downstairs are another set of magnificent paintings by varied artists including Modigliani, Rousseau, Matisse, Picasso, and many others.Though we had young kids, they were enthralled [no complaints, lots of questions, general good humor] for about 90 minutes. It was well worth it. Afterwards, we took a walk in the Jardin d'Tuileries - the museum is located within the garden. We found a boulangerie after a 10 minute walk and got some delicious sandwiches and drinks for an on the spot picnic. If you go in the summer, they may have the "Fete d'Tuileries" which is a temporarily built amusement park for kids with all kinds of rides. We went there after lunch and a good time was had by all.Highly recommended.

Monet's water lilies in all their glory. Nestled in one corner of the ever popular Jardin des Tuileries, this Museum is a hidden gem. The museum houses two rooms of Monet's beautiful water lily paintings. The paintings (huge canvas which cover entire walls) are breathtaking. They show the artist's beloved pond in his Giverny home during different months and times of day.

A must do. This is a must do, the eight canvases that make up Monet's Waterlillies are truly spectacular. In fact the colours can be overwhelming. Put aside an hour to do this gallery, at least. The top floor is Waterlillies and the lower floor impressionists and post impressionists making a stunning collection, I could have wandered around for hours. We went on a Sunday afternoon and it was not too crowded.

Just wonderful. We got in in no time at 10am and got a combined Orangerie/Orsay ticket. Those amazing, panoramic Monet waterlily paintings that were at the Marmotin for many years are back at the Orangerie and are as awe-inspiring as ever, perfectly lit and not too busy. You can't take photos of them but you can of the interesting collection of paintings downstairs. We thought this our best museum visit in Paris - a compact but stunning collection of paintings.
A great find!. This small museum is a real find! The collection is magnificent and well worth a visit. Make sure you get there. You won't be disappointed.
Prepare to be wowed!. Prepare to be wowed by the 4 huge Monets and then continue on to the lower floor for even more great impressionism -- Renoir, Manet, Monet, etc. Worth the visit.

Some decent pieces on the basement level. The curved Monet art is wonderful but is it worth the price of admission? If this is included on your museum pass I'd suggest you stop for 20 minutes of Monet. For our family of 4 it was a very expensive half hour. If you pay for entrance, plan for time in the lower level which has some surprisingly good collections. Better yet, save your time, money, and museum energy for the Musee d'Orsay across the river which is much bigger and thorough in quality.
My favorite museum in all of Paris. If you didn't love Monet's art before, you certainly will after you see this exhibit. Dont miss it and use your museum pass to get to the front of the line.
Simply Stunning!. Simply Stunning! I've never seen such beautiful creations in my life. The Lilly's were of course the show stopper.
Excellent musee. If you're a fan of Monet's Water Lillies, this is the place for you. I didn't realise how large his works were.

A must-see while in Paris. This small museum was designed for Monet's paintings, and the experience of viewing them in the oval rooms is not to be missed. There are also many other artists' works on display, and we thoroughly enjoyed the opportunity to see so many masterpieces in such a pleasant and relaxing setting. Highly recommended!
Contemplate the Monet murals. After the Louvre, take a walk through the Tuileries. Smaller collections, but the vast Monet murals make it worth the visit.

Water Lilie's set apart from the hustle and bustle. Take a seat in this Monet filled treasure, relax and soak in the two giant rooms surrounded by his two water Lily masterpieces. The walls are curved into ovals as the themes envelope you with their calming, yet sometimes troubling, mood. Walk around the room looking both at the close ups of paint splotches that should not work, but when you walk away become perfect flowers or trees. Look at them from afar as you circle the rooms and they change with perspective. The test of the museum has a nice collection but you go and stay for the lilies.

Favorite Little Museum in Paris!. The show stopper here are the water lillies in the round...and yes..they are amazing! We went here 2 days before going to Monet's home in Giverny to see the actual gardens that inspired him to paint the water gardens...it was a highlight of our trip! This museum is never very crowded so it is nice to be able to sit on the center sofas and reflect on the artwork without huge amounts of people getting in your way. If you are interested in Monet and Impressionist painting..you will like L'Orangerie..there is also a small gallery of other works there as well.

Small but perfectly formed. Wonderful little Musee, and it's never been too crowded. We have visited several times and always enjoy Monet's water lilies wrapping around the walls. You can enter the Musee just off the Gardens of the Tulleries. Small entrance fee.
Les Nympheas. I personally didn't enjoy the paints. There are huges paints called Les Nympheas, or water lilies. Then no restaurant or cafe. I would rather recommend muse d'Orsay instead.
Beautiful Paintings. Not too crowded that is a plus and many beautiful paintings. Many famous artists well presented. drop by when you have time it is located next to the Louvre

Totally worth it. It is a very small museum, but "Les Nymphéas" REALLY worth the visit. They're huge and displayed in a sort of round room, so you can feel like you're in the middle of that beautiful setting, in the very way Monet wanted those paintings to be admired.

Water lilies Amazing, the rest "meh". The setting and display on Monet's water lilies is worth the admission and effort alone. There are many other works some of which are wonderful the for the majority were the 2nd and 3rd bests by great artists. Really that is interesting to see as well. Never thought I would look at a Renoir and say yuck.

Monet Mecca!. If you are suffering from a bit of museum overload--tired of long lines, huge crowds, and wing after wing of masterpieces--head to the Musee de l'Orangerie. The line is usually short (a museum pass will speed things immeasurably), and the building is small by Parisian standards. There are several galleries of wonderful paintings, but the reason to come here is to see the gigantic Monets. Two impressive oval rooms are wall-to-wall Monet lily ponds. The pieces depict the same scene at different times of day, and during different seasons. Breathtaking! Thankfully, the rooms are large enough to accommodate the people without obstructing one's view. This is a must see for anyone who appreciates Monet!

i always come home to the queens.. My goal is to write conversations with the queens of france, to get to know them better, to find out why they were chosen. i have gone to the church in st. denis where many are buried. still not enough. i guess i will just have to keep coming back.
Loved the Museum!. Monet is one of my favorites. Panoramic beautiful view of water lillies. Walk through the gardens on the way to the museum.

Delightful. We visited Musee de l'Orangerie because the queue for Louvre was simply far too long ..... I am sooooo glad that we did. I love Monet, I had never realised how enormous his famous Waterlilies is. Truly amazing.It's a small museum, very manageable and one of the quieter places in Paris.If you are planning a visit to Musse d'Orsay, get yourself a joint ticket and save a few euro.
Top 3 in Paris. Just amazing. One of the museums in Paris that is actually human scale and you can take in all the beauty of the art without the crazy crowds.

Depends on the lines. The Museum is in the gardens and is often crowded because it houses the famous Water Lilies. It is fairly new and is a nice experience .. the collection is worth a visit but depending on your length of stay in Paris you may not want to leave the streets and spend every day in a museum unless you are plagued by bad weather.

Fine small museum easy to visit. Beautiful setting in the middle of the gardens across the river from d"orsay. We liked this museum very much, although it is small. Small made it less crowded, easy to see the art, and after an hour we were able to go out and stroll the gardens.

Wonderful museum!. We went to this museum with our 2 day Paris museum pass. This is a great museum if you also plan to visit Giverny. We went here the day after our visit to Giverny. As we viewed Monet's paintings we felt lucky to have seen the inspiration for these paintings the day before. His water lily murals are in several rooms. They are so beautiful! This museum also has paintings from Picasso, Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse.

A very meditative place, away from the hustle bustle city.. You feel a deep sense of tranquility and peacefulness upon entering the Monet waterlillies room. It is a MUST to see them. As for the rest of the museum, there are a wide variety of paintings from Renoir to soutine. Even if you're not interested in art, it's nice to see the amusing Rousseau paintings.

A little peice of heaven. If you are a Monet fan you must visit. Not a Monet fan then go anyway and become one.
Closed Tuesday, queues were short and free if you have a museum card.

A MUST SEE!. The most stunning rooms of oversized Monet water lilies. Two oval rooms on the first floor are each encompassed by 4 over-sized paintings.
The museum is small and will not take a long time to get thru - if you want to see Monet, this is the best place. It's adorably tucked into the trees of the Jardin des Tuileries.

Worth it if you can fit it in. This museum is on the smaller side so you don't have to spend a whole day there. I suggest going before 11am and joining up with a guided tour. Otherwise you can get nice audio guided tour for 5eruo. You can see some timeless masterpieces and be out of there in 2 hours.
Impressionists. Just love these large paintings that look realistiic till you approach to much. Worth the visite, but not very large.
Time for a Rest. This small museum is a perfect place to relax in the Tuileries Gardens. The Monet water lilies upstairs are spectacular and calming. The artwork downstairs is surprising.

Small museum loaded with Water Lillies. This museum was designed by Monet himself to showcase eight very large paintings of his famous water lily pond. There are a few other collections, but the real draw are the Nympheas, as Money called them. Make no mistake, you are paying for the Water Lillies, if you want other art go to Musee d'Orsay.

Hands down favorite museum in Paris. I was not expecting this to be my favorite museum in paris - but it was.The museum is included with the Paris Museum Pass, so it's is worth an intended visit. The museum is set in the Tuileries Garden, along the Seine River. It is in the old Orangerie of the park, but the interior of the museum is modern and minimalist which allows the impressionist pieces to speak without interuption.The museum has a perfect amount of paintings: split into two levels, the bottom floor has a comfortable number of impressionist pieces from several artists. The volume of paintings allows you to easily visit and absorb each piece at a reasonable pace. The second floor (the floor you enter l'Orangerie on) is dedicated to Monet's waterlilies in (2) oval studios - just as he intended them to be viewed. The oval rooms are a pure creamy white, which allows the enormous paintings to encompass you entirely, without interruption or distraction. The crowds are extremely manageable (museum closed on Tuesdays), the volume of pieces allows you to view every piece, and the progression from bottom to top is perfectly moderated. Highly recommended.

Monet and much more. This great museum is located in the west corner of the Tuileries Garden. The Monet Water Lillies are a sight to behold. There are many other great painting there as well. Entry was included in the Paris Pass. Take the metro to the Concorde. Afterwards take a stroll through the beautiful garden.

A great improvement. I saw the museum in the mid 80s and paid a return visit in July 2013. The building was rebuilt around 2006 and is completely different from my first visit. It now has the second best impressionist collection after the D'Orsay. Well worth a revisit or a first visit.
Best kept secret!. We loved this museum, not so much for the Monet water lilies, but more for the impressive collection of paintings by Manet, Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne as well as others
Wonderful small museum with interesting collection and not crowded at all. Good place to catch a glimpse of impressionists works with no crowd amidst busy touristic season in heart ofParis

Monet paintings. Very easy to find it, as it's located next to the Tulleries Garden (beautiful), I went there to see the famous, gigantic Monet painting (Nynpheas). The rest of the collection is ok, but not as good as the ones of bigger and more famous museums. Go if you're a big Monet fan.

Manageable size with kids. The kids enjoyed this museum, because it wasn't overwhelming compared to the nearby Louvre, just 2 floors. We really enjoyed Monet's large Water Lilies. What a treat! We also admired the works of Rousseau, Picasso, Renoir and Cézanne. Everyone had their favourites. The entire museum can easily be done with kids in about an hour. We got in faster with our Paris Pass, though the queue didn't seem too bad. Highly recommended!
Unforgettable Water Lillies. Wonderful display of Monet's Water Lillies. Excellent collection of Impressionist art. Bright and airy exhibition space, not too crowded when we visited (mid-morning).
Water lilies. Went out of our way to see Monet's water lilies as he intended. Just by themselves, completely worth the trip. Also covered by Paris Museum Pass.

Niche and small, but what a niche!. Well located, this museum has one floor dedicated to Monet's "Waterlilies". This single piece alone is worth the cost of the ticket - you can sit in quiet contemplation with the painting surrounding you in its time-spanning depiction of light on a water lilly pond, but in the lower floor are collections which include Picasso, Modigliani and Renoir as well.

Sit awhile. It always amazes me when you have the chance to be up close and personal with Monet, and folks keep walking by, as if in a cafeteria line! There are comfy places to sit and take it all in. Its a must to truly appreciate your experience. Dont miss Rodins "kiss" outstide the entrance.
I like Monet, but..... Well, if you like Monet, go to the Louvre or to Jacquemart-Andre house. Well, I think L'Orangerie was free on Sunday evening.
Worth the Wait. Monet's water lillies in surround. Just sit and enjoy, nothing quite like it Pleasant museum, easy access.

Just lovely. A treat- and surrounded by beautiful landscapes, gardens and architecture. Just so wonderful to explore and walk through all these Parisian places of art. So easy to get to. Great cafes nearby.

If you love Monet, you have to go here. After having been closed since 2002 this was the first time I was able to see it and I enjoyed it. The Monet rooms are quite an experience and there is a range of other Modern art too. Worth a visit
Go early to avoid lines.. Quiet oasis of impressionism, great way to start a day in quiet contemplation in this little jewel of an exhibit.

A vibe of it's own. After visiting several major art galleries in Paris, my family and I were very happy with our lower stress, and lower key visit to l'Orangerie. One can sit and look at the Monet panels and just chill, rather than feel go-go-go like some of the other museums in town. Sometimes quality trumps quantity.

Water Lilies are beautiful. Small art gallery near the Tuileries. Highlight is Monet's water lily mural exhibit.
If you desire to actually go to Monet's estate in Giverny on your trip, do that first before you see this exhibit. We did and Monet perfectly captured the beauty of his pools.
Not to miss. Monet's Les Nymphaes are unparalleled. If you are in Paris they are not to be missed, though you will need more than a couple of hours to study them. The form and colors are stunning.

Museum closed all week. Call ahead. We went to L'Orangerie only to find it was closed and had been closed for days Such a disappointment. Apparently it was due to a power outtage - be sure to call ahead!

Must for Monet lovers. The first time I came here they were playing classical music and everyone was sat in silence admiring the beautiful works. It was one of the most relaxing and peaceful experiences I've ever had. The second time, they unfortunately weren't playing any music and people were much loader, but even then you couldn't help but be awed by the wonderful 'Nympheas'. A must visit every time I'm in Paris. Also, free for EU citizens below 26.
Monet works. Loved seeing Monet's work here. Great location in the gardens. Small museum but I would recommend it
Enlightening. Whilst the Monet was outstanding, it was the exhibition of Italian impressionists I found most engaging!

Relaxing. We had purchased the museum pass at the airport, from the tourist information counter, so we didn't have to queue and could just walk in. We were hot and tired as we had spent the day wondering and enjoying Paris on a very hot July day. This was just perfect we sat in a white relaxing room gazing at the huge Monet pictures it was a lovely moment.

Small But Check It Out. The main attraction here of course is Monet's Water Lillies and I have to say they are impressive. I've seen them in art books but had no idea the paintings were so large. It would have been nice to sit down and take them in, but too many people were using the seats in each gallery as a rest stop. There's a lot more to see downstairs. I particularly liked the Soutine paintings. I was not familiar with this artist before visiting, but I was impressed with the work. It's not a big museum, you can easily have a decent visit in 1-1.5 hours. If you have a Paris Museum Pass you can get right in. If not, you may wait outside. I visited around Noon on a Monday and waited about 30 minutes to purchase a ticket.

Excellent smaller museum. Stunning home fo Monet's waterlilies paintings, with excellent collection of other works (impressionist and not), covered by a thoughtful audio guide. Glad we made time for this one in our busy itinerary.

Next to baguette.....this is my favorite museum. The l'Orangerie is one of my constants in visiting Paris. Its not far from the Louvre,on place de la Concorde. This fabulous edifice is a Tuileries garden gem,with an outstanding collection of art,especially Monet's exquisite 'Nympheas'. The experience is both monumental and intimate,housing the mighty eight murals in which water-lilies float on the canvas. Monet's prized water lilies which he conceived for this former palace greenhouse,wrap around two skylit oval rooms,under direct diffused light. Absolute magic!! the collection exhibits impressionism and classisism in the subterranean section housing the magic formulae of Cezanne,Mattise,Rousseau,as well as, Picasso,Utrillo,Soutine and Derain. As much as this is a delight for first-timers,the l'Orangerie is addictive for repeat offenders.. The gallerie's appeal lies in part, to its pleasing sense of scale and when not crowded,to its calming and exciting effect. Mull the experience further as you amble through your garden walk.

Paul Guillaume was visionary. This collection of Monet murals was amazing - followed by an equally impressive collection of Impressionist / Post-Impressionist artwork was inspiring .... And his efforts to support the artists during their early years was remarkable)

not of the caliber of what you find at the Orsay. The hallmark displays in this gallery are the two rooms with Monet's water lilies from Giverny. These alone make a visit to this museum well worthwhile. The rest of the exhbiits are slightly interesting, though not of the caliber of what you find at the Orsay.
Waterlillies worth a look. Stunning way to view all 8 of the Waterlillie series. Available on the museum Paris pass, so not expensive.

Exquisite Collection. Be sure to visit this wonderful, small gem of a museum when visiting Paris. Monet himself designed the vestibules in which his magnificent canvases are displayed. Take time to just sit with these glorious works of art and you will feel any tension melt away. You will also find here a wonderful collection of Renoir, Matisse, Modigliani, etc. Located in the Jardin des Tuileries you can also enjoy a stroll through the garden either before or after your visit.
Small but worth it. This museum is a small but still worth visiting you can also take photos in some of the areas of the museum which I appreciated as it will help with the memories.
Wonderful, nice and small.. Kids loved the Monet exhibit, got the audio which is worth it. Good museum for kids, the only one I would recommend for kids under 12. Very manageable.
Excellent art hour. This is a small museum easily walked through in 1-1.5 hours. My teenaged sons enjoyed it the most of the 3 main art museums located near by.

Monet. The only museum I spent a great deal of time in. The water lilies were mesmerizing. I sat on the provided couches and looked my fill. There was a very special feeling in this room, many people dashed in and out, but I was there for over an hour.

Amazing experience. One of my favorite museums in Paris, 'Les Nymphéas' by Claude Monet are a must-see, the works are hung all over the walls of a circular room creating a magical atmosphere, if you like Impressionism you'll be more than pleased. The museum also houses many masterworks by: Renoir, Matisse among many others in a calm and soothing setting. When done with your visit you can take a walk in the Jardin des Tuileries (The museum is located in the park) or visit the impressive place de la Concorde located just a few steps away.
Monet homage. Adore Monet's Les Nympheas so much. They're magnificent, made you feel wonder in admiration and grateful. There were queues but not unbearable and worth the wait!
Awesome art & audio guide. We really enjoyed the museum and their collections were amazing.It's a small museum, but the art is fantastic.
not good at all. I am very disappointed with this museum as it takes to queue for an hour and al inside there are few painting, the air conditioning did not work very well, go to the Museum of Orsay
A Monet lovers heaven. The two rooms of specially painted water lilies make any trip to Paris worthwhile. A very special place.
Water lillies at their best. One can sit there on the banquette for hours and not get bored viewing the water lillies in a room designed by Monet for just that purpose.

Another winner for Impressionism.. loved seeing the paintings and sculptures. Crowded in July and I'm sure in August too. Wear comfortable clothing and get a Paris Museum Pass to avoid the long lines.

Monet, the Impressionists and more. The Nymphéas murals by Monet are indeed the featured highlight of this great museum.
