We were there in mid-July when the crowds got in the way of absorbing the Giverny ambience of these monumental works. Even so, the quietness and contemplation within this space is still evident. The Walter-Guillaume collection of the Orangerie includes much more than works of Monet. We equally enjoyed the many works by all the great Impressionists...Renoir, Sisley, Utrillo, Matisse, etc. The Derains, Picassos and Soutines were also favorites of Paul Guillaume who collected these astonishishing works before their time.The Paris Museum Pass gets you in through a much shorter lineup.
Monet, need I say more. The round rooms with Monet's mural paintings make this museum worth the time! You could spend a long time just looking at these murals from every angle, just beautiful.

Breath taking. As a life long Monet fan seeing the waterlillies literally brought tears to my eyes. The rooms are perfectly designed and are light filled and trainquil. Having a museum pass and being there before opening time I was the first in and literally had the waterlillies to myself for a few minutes.

Monet panoramas!. Monet panoramas are outstanding and will take your imagination into Monet's inspiration at Giverny. Come for the Monet panoramas but don't miss the rest of the incredible art work at this easy to get to musee. The Tuileries Gardens are right next door, my favorite place to walk past the colorful gardens, and sit by the round ponds in the sun.

Calm and tranquil. A welcome chance to rest feet in the cool, contemplating the extensive water lilies gallery. Included works from the series using different colour ranges, and weeping willow trees. Most galleries will only have one Watellilly painting, fantastic to see such a number to get her for comparison.Lower floor gallery was an unexpected bonus. Included in Paris museum pass, with priority entrance.

Stress Relief. This should be on your must see list for Paris. Even though you have seen many copies of the Water Lilies, the impact of the full size in the round is stunning. Sit in the middle, pick a spot in the picture to focus on. It will draw you in and you will feel the stress leave your body. I would make this a regular stop on any trip toParis.
Water Lily Heaven. Main floor devoted to Monet's lillies - fabulous.The floor below was a more conventional layout and showed Renoirs, Cezannes amongst others.Overall, a very worthwhile visit.

Will never forget the Musee de l'Orangerie. It's pretty much impossible to pick just one thing which was the highlight of my time in Paris - but if I was forced to do that, it would be this beautiful museum and the Monet exhibit. July in Paris is a very busy time, but the Orangerie was calm, peaceful and we were able to spend all the time we wanted in order to take in the incredible Water Lilies in both rooms. Make sure you have time to sit and take them in.

Wonderful!. Wonderful to see the paintings from such masters. Best to buy tickets before you get there or have a museum pass as you'll get through the express line and get in faster. Still well worth the wait though!

Beautiful!. small, but beautiful art displayed nicely. a bit hard to locate it is in the gardens near roundabout, head up ramp to overlook of champs eleysee.take minimsl bags as there is a bag screening.....

Fantastic.. We stopped in here to escape the heat today (as well as see some fantastic Monets) but were surprised by the depth in the downstairs exhibits as well. Overall, it's got a nice escape from your usual museum experience with the Monet panoramas upstairs, but a huge cache of interesting and beautiful art (picasso, matisse, utrillo, etc.) downstairs. It's also not overwhelming (comme le Louvre) if you only want to spend an hour or so in a museum one day. Grab the audio guide if you don't speak French so you don't miss out!

Flavour of Monet. This is a much easier cultural visit than the Louvre - two gallery areas - one dedicated solely to the Water Lily murals of Monet - great light conditions and a chance to sit and soak up the art. €7.50 quiet expensive for a the size of the museum but quality impressionist art worthy of a visit.

Outstanding. Depth, colours, light...
And size...and curved walls...
And downstairs so dense and informative. Don't miss the audio visual story of the artist and his visionary fight.

Great gallery, great experience. L'Orangerie provides a great gallery experience and with the exception of the Monet "Waterlilies' allows you to take photographs. The range of art was extensive and compared to the d'Orsay across the river was not crammed in giving a better viewing experience. Having a Paris Museum Pass allowed one to bypass the queue and probably saved an hour overall - without it we would not have had the time to go in given our schedule. This to me was better experience than the art overall in the d'Orsay or the Louvre. While the others have more of reputation this gallery has more ambiance and less crowding.

Not a Picasso Fan, but the water lilies were great. We enjoyed this museum, there was an amazing water lily display. I can pass on Picasso, but enjoyed this as an add on after our second trip to the Louvre.
Monet Monet Monet. Monet's water lilies. Even more overwhelming in real life, breathtaking really. A definite must! Take your time wondering between the two rooms.

Wonderful Museum. If you love Monet this is the BEST place to enjoy his works. Also has many other noteworthy artists and works. In my opinion take the time you would have spent at the Louvre and visit L'Orangerie and the Musee D'Orsay instead. You will not be disapointed.

Just the right size and scope. Small collection near place de la Concorde, known for featuring Monet's 4 large mural panels of waterlilies. Seeing these alone is worth the trip, but there are many other impressionist paintings that you will recognize by Renior, Matisse, Picasso, Modigliani and others. Just outside are the Tuileries Garden where you can stroll, rest in the shade, eat lunch in one of two cafes or get some ice cream/gelato to take a break. Highly recommend this lesser known gem of an art museum. Included on Paris Museum pass.

More than just Monet. While I went for the waterlilies, the rest of the museum and gallery were great too. Lots of paintings in a variety of styles. The little bookshop was also very good - lots of excellent children's books too.
Impressive. Monet's water lilies were so impressive, beautiful, worth the visit. Take your time to sit down and admire them.

Elegant and wonderful. A beautifully constructed museum, especially the oval rooms for Monet's "Waterlilies"; calming, serene, quiet, elegant and understated. The lower level also does not disappoint with fascinating works by several well known artists including Modigliani, Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne. And much less crowded than the Louvre or Musee Dorsay. Highly recommended.

Small museum, big crowds. We waited in line for about half an hour to get in here, and when we finally did, it was pretty crowded. The museum is pretty small, with two large custom-designed galleries devoted to Monet's enormous waterlilies canvases upstairs, and several smaller rooms downstairs filled with other French contemporaries. Most of the downstairs galleries are actually the collections of two private collectors, so you'll see a lot of portraits of those guys and their wives. It's a great collection which I enjoyed immensely (especially the Laurencin paintings), but don't expect a huge, all day event for your €8.50. This is more like a 2 hour visit.

Perfect for Monet lovers. One of my favorite museums in the world. I wasn't a Monet fan when I was younger. After seeing Water Lilies here I've become a Monet lover for good. I have no words to describe how magnificent these paintings are.If I would have to choose one museum in the whole Paris, I would choose this one.Absolut perfection. Tip: Go early during the weekdays to avoid the crowds.
Not very inspiring. Not the best art gallery we have visited. We liked the building but not the paintings which was probably just personal taste.

A feast of impressionism. The museum is a wonderful feast of Impressionism which I had missed on prior visits to Paris. The setting of the Water Lillies canvases was perfect. The audioguide commentary helped me focus on the paintings and the wide galleries allowed good visuals of the art despite crowds which weren't nearly as bad as those at the D'Orsay. Worth the half-hour wait on line.

worth the effort. A special treat for those who love Monet's water lilly series and the expressionist period. Arrive early to avoid queuing and be mindful that the general area is awash with skillful pickpockets and scammers despite the best efforts of a vigilant security.

A peaceful place to enjoy Monet and other impressionist artist's work. The huge Monet canvas displayed in white rooms with diffused lighting are something very special and unique. There is a feeling of peace sitting there for a few moments no matter how hectic your day has been!The lower floor has several other artists, and you will not be disappointed. The gift shop is one of my favorites, with lots of things to take home.. books, posters, videos etcThis museum is NOT to be missed!

Monet's that rival his gardens in Giverney!. I was thoroughly impressed with the works & how they were displayed with natural filtered light. Seeing these in Novembre & then seeing Monet's gardens in Giverny the following summer... Absolutely stunning & breath taking.There are other art peices of the similar time period on the lower level, which are also another most see!and of course, the rodin's "the kiss" out front!visited in novembre 2008, not august 2012

moved to tears by the waterlilies exhibit. It doesn't matter how many posters you see. It does't matter how many art classes you take nor how many coffee table books you have. This is something to experience. As a gift of solace to the people of France, it's hard to believe these incredible works were basically ignored for so long. In the renovated Musee, they can be fully appreciated. The atmosphere is wonderful and you'll find yourself there longer than planned.

go for the Monets. After millions of euros and years of restoration, l'Orangerie has returned to the visitor the viewing experience designed by Monet for his famous water lily paintings. 'Transcendental' is how I describe my first visit to the 2 rooms where these paintings are exhibited. Take the time to sit down and 'watch' them as they seem to change before your eyes.
Water lilies. Wonderful ways to see Monet's water lilies paintings......peaceful, relaxing way to spend some time unlike mmost other museums.....very quite, reflective atmosphere
Ah - Art in Paris. Always nice to see what is on exhibit. Well presented and interesting. If a Paris regular visitor must stop in.

Just a dream away. This is my wife's favorite museum in the world. It's the only place on earth where you can become enmeshed by Monet's Water Lillies. There's lot more to the museum, and its collections of modern art are worth the trip, but Water Lillies is what this museum is all about. I hope my wife knows I was kidding when I saw we were going to buy Water Lillies and put it around the pool.

The perfect museum if you do not have the time or inclination to go to the Louvre or Musee d"orsay. In addition to the breathtaking Monet water lilly panels, this museum has an outstanding collection of impressionist art and you can view it all without the crowds you find at the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay
Ahhh Claude Monet. Get museum pass skip the line! Incredible Monet!! Sadly no photos allowed of the art work.So much more beautiful in person than in any art book!

Relax with Monet. Musee de l'Orangerie is best known for its two room-sized paintings in Monet's garden series. He donated these mural-like paintings to the city of Paris after WWI, so that the citizens could take a break from the stress of their working lives and refresh with a "virtual visit" (no, he didn't use those words, but that's what he meant) to his beloved Givenchy gardens. Some may quibble at the admissions price, but if you are a fan of Monet, or just in need of some peace, it is more than worth it. There are other galleries here, which included an excellent exhibition of Italian impressionists when I was there, but really, Monet is the draw. Do yourself a favor and settle down on one of the benches in the "garden" rooms and open yourself to the essence of the Givenchy gardens, which these paintings convey more effectively than you can imagine.

Water lilies. This is the home of Monet famous wall sized water lilies. Stunning yet sublime. On the lower level was the art collection of Jean Walter et Paul Guillaume. So many wonderful pieces including many Renoir's
Superb. The scale of the work here is astounding. To be viewed up close and from the other side of the room. Monet is a genius.
A nice little gem in the middle of Paris. I must say I was quite surprised by the intimacy of this museum, great place to be mesmerized by Monet. The continuos canvas is just amazing. A must see !!!

Relaxing, great collection. We were very frustrated with the crowds at Louvre and were pleasantly surprised at how relaxing this museum was. It is a bit out of the way, but we were glad we made the trip. We enjoyed Monet’s Waterlilies and the large collection of impressionist paintings. This is included in our museum pass. It’s a smaller museum so there is no café inside. We had to find lunch in the park nearby. The security was also a bit more picky about the size of backpacks allowed in. Our small Camel backpack had to be checked in, even when other museums did not require it. Still, would highly recommend this museum.

Lovely little gem. Small museum housing fine paintings in lower level and eight large scale Monet water lily paintings in two rooms on the entry level. Not too busy, well worth a visit. Purchased a combination ticket to allow expedited entry later to Musee d'Orsay.

Monet water lilies . . .. Nice calm and cool break from the crazy pace of Paris, especially when it's 33 degres Celsius outside!. Paris pass gets you in without additional fees. Monet water lilies canvases are beautiful and much bigger then expected.

The Monets are big, but Oh the Renoirs.. Two rooms of huge "Water Lilies" on the main floor. The basement has a fantastic collection of Renoirs - proving the Mr Barnes of Philadelphia didn't corner the entire market.

If you love Monet this is not to be missed!. The museum has two large rooms designed just to display Monet's large canvases. What a well designed treat! We love to sit in one if the two rooms with the Monets and just enjoy. The lower floor has a smaller collection of permanent exhibits and an exhibit that changes. The museum pass holders have a separate short line here, another reason to get it!

Do not stick to the proposed way of visit !!!. I am from Paris, I have been visiting this place once a decade (at least).And the new proposal to visit with : 1 Monet's Nympheas2 other paintingsis stupid.Choose : first the other paintings (less beautiful) then Monet' ones. You will be in peace for hours.Take care of pickpokets while queueing outside the museum
Great museum. We enjoyed seeing the paintings in this pretty little museum. The size is nice-- not at all overwhelming, and they had beautiful impressionist art as well as other very nice exhibits.

Water Lilies by Claude Monet. Monet's Water Lilies is magnificent. What a brilliant idea to engulfthe viewer with a continuos canvas. The effect is magical. I felt as if I was there with Monet on location as he painted.I was awe-stuck by the scale. I lingered as long as I could afford to to take in every brush stroke.I just wish photography is permitted. No postcards or prints could doMonet's water Lilies justice. Bravo to a legendary genius.I also enjoyed Andre Derian's Arlequin et Pierrot 1923.There were some pieces of Picasso too.

An absolute must-see in Paris!. An awesome little museum tucked away in the Tuileries Gardens! Very quiet and not crowded - the perfect way to view (actually be surrounded by) Monet's Waterlilies - you can actually sit and stare at them for hours if you like!

Monet. IT is a very small museum but it is worth the visit. Buy the museum pass that is a great deal if you plan to visit a lot of the PAris Atraction. I really saved money with it. I recommend doing a big atraction with a small one in the same day and one day for the palaces.

Don't miss Musee de l'Orangerie. This is one of the best museums in Paris! It is easy to get into and the art is spectacular! Everyone thinks it is only Monet's Lillies - which are fabulous, but there are many many other paintings downstairs!

Beware closed on Tuesdays. We only ended up here because he Muse D'Orsay was closed on Mondays. This world treasure closes on Tuesdays. This place is very cool it has a wonderful contemporary entrance of which I took a photo. For committing this crime I was nearly thrown out, the humourless security guard forcing me to delete the photo. I'm not sure what secret I might have revealed with my photo but never the less this got the show off to a bad start. The paintings are of course amazing and a must for anyone to go and see who visitis Paris. All signs are in French when most visitors speak English. Still if you can stomach the over zealous guards, the signs in a language no-one can read ( I can ), the Tuesday closing it's worth the trip.

Wonderful Little Musee. The Orangerie is noted for Monet's "Waterlilies" and they are indeed impressive as hung in specifically designed rooms. However the Museum has a lot more to offer. Downstairs there are impressionist works hung along a long, attractive corridor and side rooms. Really, the Orangerie is a beautiful building and never seems crowded. Another advantage is if you are also planning to visit the d'Orsay you can buy the package entrance ticket here without the long line-ups at the more famous, larger museum.

Monet over the top. Beautiful paintings and the building i lovely.
The murals on the top floor are great.
The special showings were unbelievable.

A Must for Monet Lovers. I've loved this place ever since my first visit as a teenager, and would never hesitate to go back. A rare museum that was actually designed with the paintings it would showcase already in mind, it beautifully presents Monet's waterlilies in circular fashion, surrounding the viewer. I could easily sit and stare at these paintings for hours, the environment and feelings they evoke is so peaceful.I wouldn't recommend it for people not into Impressionism, as it is not a very big museum, but for those who are it's a very special place.

Great if you love Monet. It felt like that the museum was built with Monet's water lilies in mind, featuring on the main floor. Then the rest of the artwork were really a mishmash of great and no-so-great painters and were not very impressive.I did find Monet's works mesmerizing but the rest, not so much. My Paris Museum Pass covered it so it was still a good way to spend 10-15 minutes. Otherwise, there might be other places that are more suitable for you.
This is a gem. You can look at Monet.s art in a quiet setting, without the crowds, as he intended. The museum is a pleasant respite from the craziness of the Louvre.

This is where you go to see Monet's Water Lillies. This is a must-see attraction in Paris if you like Impressionist paintings. Bring your earplugs, though, it's loud and echoing in the Water Lillies rooms, and people very rudely chatter while you're trying to take it all in.

My favourite. Loved this!!!!! We went primarily to see Monet's water lilies, which were stunning, especially as we had been to Giverny a few days prior. But the delight of seeing the rest of the collection here.... Easily laid out, understandable, gave you a great understanding of the development of the art..We were fortunate to also take in an Italian Impressionist temporary exhibition, and this was so interesting.Loved it.

Finally some Impressionist Art. Since the Louvre is nearly devoid of impressionism, this is the place to get your fix. That said, the museum is rather small. It's a far cry from the ginormous Louvre. That's a plus as there were fewer crowds, more room to walk, and time to enjoy the art. It's well worth the price of admission.

Nymphéas!. A must see if you are interested in see Monet’s famous Water Lily panels. Other than that not too much to offer but if you are a Monet fan like myself this is a must-see! You can get a deal to the museum if you purchase a ticket to the d’Orsay. Look for the Musée d'Orsay /Musée de l'Orangerie Passport for 16 Euros.

small enough not to get overwhelmed. Im not an art follower, but even I recognized some of the pieces there. And its not so overcrowded that it makes it frustrating to walk around and admire the artwork.
Monet's are grand. The two oval rooms are a must see...just a beautiful presentation of the Monet's but the rest of the collection is lacking spunk

Not to be missed!. This museum is a treasure: small, elegant, restrained in design, it is a perfect setting for the stunningly displayed series of Monet's Water Lilies paintings. There are two rooms of these magnificent works, displayed in a circular pattern that makes the viewer feel surrounded by their color and beauty. There are other Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works in the gallery as well. Not to be missed!
Monet!. I could sit in the Waterlily galleries all day, every day. If you like Monet, this museum is for you!
Not much there. Overall unimpressed with the quantity and expense of this establishment. We paid a pretty decent amount to get in and then we basically just ended up walking out.

Must see for Water Lilies only. We went to this tiny art museum, as it was listed on the Paris Museum Pass. I wanted to go only to see Monet's Water Lilies, which are a work of art and amazing to see all in one room as they were meant to be displayed. There were other lesser known (at least to me) artists' pieces worthwhile to view, but we really just went to see the Water Lilies. My husband would rather have skipped it, but if you're in the Tuileries Gardens area with the Museum Pass, stop in. I don't think I would have paid the 7.50 euro entrance fee just to see Monet's Water Lilies, but that's me.
Amazing Monet paintings. This really is a must see - particularly the huge circular paintings of the Monet Water Lilies. Unforgettable. And much of interest to see in the basement as well.

Monet water lilies and more!. This small museum is located at the far end of the Tuileries Garden. It has Monet's largest and final water lily paintings (2 round rooms). The rooms were designs by Claude Monet specifically for these huge paintings. Use your Paris Pass (most museums in Paris) and skip the long line. Definitely worth the money getting a Pass Paris. I highly recommend this museum...but they are strict on their no photo policy, so beware.

Good little secret. If you can buy a ticket to Musée d'Orsay try to get this musée as a package (it's technically part of d'Orsay). It has the eight wonderful large waterlily paintings of Monet one, dedicated floor. And, the lower floor has a pretty great collection of other artists. It's worth a visit if you're on Paris to see art.

Water lilies!. A must see museum for Monet fans. These Monet water lilies and weeping willows are unique. We visited the museum in the late afternoon, about an hour before closing. There were no lines to enter and no crowds inside. The downside of this timing was cutting our visit short at the closing time.Don't forget to spend a few hours in the Touilerie Gardens. The museum is located right there. Relax by the Octogonal Basin lounging in the comfortable chairs and eating Amorino ice cream.

love the little galleries. We got a reduced ticket as we purchased it together with our D'orsay ticket - we didn't get a pass this year, and to be honest it worked out just fine. I love the little galleries in Paris, the l'Orangerie, the Rodin, the Marmottan ( although didn't go this year as most of the exhibit is travelling) The feel of this space is so light and wonderful, just as Monet had wanted. The downstairs has a nice display of other impressionists, some of my favourite Renoirs are here. It isn't crowd crushing, it is lovely and centrally located in teh Tuillerie gardens. So enjoyable.

Amazing - love Monet. Love Monet and we were treated to a private tour by an international artist. This made our visit really special and we learned so much about that period in art history. Loved the feel of the space. Highly recommend a visit.
fantastic. awe inspiring exhibition of some amazingly HUGE Monet paintings... just wonderful! You will sit in the round shaped rooms for a very long time just in wonder at what lies before you.
Great little gem of Paris. Absolutely loved seeing Monet's water lilies, and the few pieces by Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, and Modigliani. A must see!
Wonderful !. To see the oval rooms of Monets Les Nympheas will make you never appreciate a Monet calendar, picture book, or print again. The glory of these colors in the flesh is astounding.

Perfect museum. From the size to its exhibitions this museum is a must! Not too many people and quick line to go in. Also very easy to find since it is located in jardin de tuileries. The oval shape water lilly rooms are breath taking and I wish pictures would be allowed. This museum certainly convinced me to go visit Monet's garden at Giverny later!

Wonderful Museum. The large panels of Monet's water lilies and other fabulous art such as Van Gogh and Mogliadini. Definitely worth visiting. Just the right size after a long walking tour in the morning.
Crowded but worth it.. Of course the Monet's are wonderful. I haven't been since the remodel and it's fantastic. The permanent collection of Renior's and Cezanne's should't be missed.

I'm only writing about the set up and queue .... Just a brief note to tell you that photos are not permitted and you have to check your bags into a locker... I waited in a queue for 45 mins and had to leave as I had limited time but as I had my passport in my bag and no pockets, I didn't want my documents left in a locker. I hear its beautiful but I would have liked to have known about the excessive security measures before I left my hotel.

Small but Charming. I was mesmerized by the two rooms of Monet waterlillies on the upper floor. Lower floor had a variety of paintings by other artists. Photography (without flash) allowed. Staff was very helpful in allowing us to use the service elevator since the handicapped elevator was not working. Clean bathrooms on lower floor. Museum is accessed by entering the Tuileries Gardens on the West side (adjacent to Place de la Concorde).
How I do miss the previous version... Yes, beautiful Monet's water lilies etc.. Lovely Picasso's figurative paintings and more. Nevertheless, the unique charm isn't there anymore.

Worth the visit for Monet's water lillies. Get the audio guide for 5 Euros - made the experience so much deeper. The highlight is, of course, the two oval water lilly rooms. If you have visited prior to 2006, a repeat is necessary to see them in their newly renovated space with diffuse, natural light. Loved seeing the alternate version of a famous Renoir that we saw in the Musee d'Orsay.

If you are going to Giverny, go here first!. We visited the Musee de l'Orangerie, the day before visiting Monet's Gardens with Fat Tire Bike Tours. Seeing Monet's masterpieces displayed in such grandeur was magical. The l'Orangerie is a perfect sized museum for older children. Not too big where you lose their attention. We did the audio tour, which was certainly worth the same extra fee.

If the queue at the musée d'Orsay is too long, go here!. Great museum, really manageable size. Obviously the jewel(s) in the crown are Monet's waterlilies, but there are some other good pieces downstairs. I came here on the 1st Sunday on the month which is usually packed but it was still ok - didn't have to queue more than two minutes to get in. Probably spent between an hour and an hour and a half here. Great location in the middle of the jardin des tuileries!
Small but lovely. Very small museum but quaint and full of hidden treasures. Plus if you take your passport it's free!
Water LIllies. Breathtaking display of Monet's Water Lillies. I fell in love the moment I walked into the room. I wish I could have stayed all day to just soak it all in!
Gorgeous. A wonderful little museum. It is a perfect size for people like me that want to be able to enjoy without being overwhelmed.
A must. You must see this museum before leaving Paris. They have the must beautiful Picasso early year painting and offcause Monets waterlilly pictures, are not to bee mist.
Visit before 11.30am. Beautiful museum and less busy if you visit prior to 11,30am, buy joint ticket for Musee D'Orsy and have lunch there. Enjoy

Long lines just to say you saw the water lillies.... Huge lines for this museum. If you do not have a Museum Pass you may reconsider waiting in these lines unless you are a huge Monet fan and cannot leave Paris without seeing the water lilies. It is a very small museum and essentially the two rooms of water lilies are all if there really is to see.

Must See. this is an often overlooked museum that is close to the Louvre. It is filled with mind blowing Monet canvases. Incredible... breathtaking... I return to this museum almost everytime I come to Paris (which is frequently) for the visual delight and the peacefulness of the monet galleries.

The House Monet Built. Waterlilies! If you are a fan of Monet this museum is a "don't miss". The rooms where the Waterlily paints are displayed were constructed just to show off the works as Monet planned. There are also many more painting on the lower level which frankly are over shadowed my Monet's work upstairs. Buy the Paris museum pass and skip the lines that are always there!

Delightful. The museum was small and could be enjoyed for an hour or 2 without taking up an entire day.
I would have enjoyed it more if more of the explanations were in English. The english pamphlets were unavailable.

Sheer perfection. Monet was involved with the planning of the three rooms on the main floor and painted eight canvases for two of those rooms. I sat and stared in awe of the beauty and perfection that these paintings are and was grateful that he spent the last 12 years of his life working on this project for the public. Don't miss this gem of a museum!

Perfect Size. This "small" museum of course showcases the Monet's so perfectly displayed, but the collection downstairs is amazing, too. The special exhibit, The Italian Impressionists, was a nice bonus.I purchased tickets on line that included both the D'Orsay and the l'Orangerie and skipped the lines.

Charming museum with much more on offer than the waterlilies.. Make sure to get your ticket or museum pass beforehand to beat the lines. After admiring the two halls with Monet's magnificent waterlilies there's so much more when you go down. Right now there's an expo on Italian impressionists which was well worth it. Also many works from Picasso, Renoir etc.If you are visiting with kids, go to the museum shop first to buy one of the books explaining the mayor art works to kids, it'll make the visit so much more interesting for them.

One and only. Your place to see Monet's Water Lilies in the perfect setting. The number of Renoir downstairs is a pleasant surprise.While a smaller museum, it is well worth a visit. Get the joint ticket for that and the Musee D'Orsay.

Stunning Water Lillies - Claude Monet. This museum displays an incredible collection of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. from the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collections. It is the permanent home for eight Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet which are set within two oval rooms designed for this piece. The museum also includes works by Cezanne, Matisse, Modigliani, Picasso, Renoir, Rousseau and others. Not to be missed. Allow 1 hour inside. Free admission with Paris Museum Pass so skip the line for tickets and walk right in.

Enchanted by waterlilies. An abundance collection of impressionists' works, which are interesting comparison with those in Musée d'Orsay and other major museums. To me the Oval room where Monet's waterlilies are presented tops it all.

Water lilies. In front of the museum there is always a queue of visitors waiting to see Monet's Water Lilies. It really depends on whether you like such impressionist art. Although I am an idiot in art, I like looking at the painting as I felt relieved and comfortable compared to those historic and religious ones at Louvre. Also, I had a Museum Pass so entrance is free.

Huge Monets. After wandering through the amazing gardens we visited this lovely museum to see the collection of Monet's larger works. We arrived around lunchtime to a small queue. The paintings are gorgeous and it is very relaxing to sit on the large benches in the beautiful room surrounded by the huge paintings. Recommended for Monet lovers and introducing children to art.
There is much more here than Monet.. Be sure to go downstairs and see the rest of the collection by other artists. A museum pass is essential to beat the lines.
Nice place. It's just beside Concorde square. Very convenience location. The collection inside are great, although not a big place. It's for sure better than Petit palais.

If you like Musee d'Orsay you are going to love this museum. This museum takes over where the Musee d'Orsay stops in terms of impressionist works. It is much smaller than d'Orsay but you have the opportunity to see so much and very up close. You will be able to take photos in this museum. There is a great garden across from the museum. You can then walk the gardens. Very impressed with Orangerie. Will return.

Quaint and equally impressive. The Waterlillies are one of the French Impressionist movement's most stunning and impressive works. The museum is relatively small and a great experience if you like impressionist art.

Must see for Monet fans. If you love Monet don't miss l'Orangerie. Here you will be surrounded by Monet's final paintings of waterlilies that wrap the walls of two large oval rooms. There is also a nice collection of Impressionist work.
Go see Monet. We didn't spend a long time in this museum. Had to see the water lilies though! There was a line out front that moved fairly quickly.

Waterlillies and impressionists. Any fan of Monet should visit this small gallery - entry is included in the Paris Museum Pass and it's close to the Louvre and Musee D'Orsay. While in Paris I also visited Monet's beautiful garden in Giverny where he painted these works. As well as the beautifully displayed waterlillies room there is a lovely gallery downstairs which includes an exhibition of other famous impressionists. When I visited there was also an interesting temporary exhibition of Italian painters.

A must. Be prepared to queue, but once inside the tranquillity of the museum is so worth it. The Monet's are stunning and peaceful and my wife, who'd never seen them before, was absolutely blown away by them. Spend a couple of hours just gazing then sit in the Tuilleries Gardens and relax before going off to eat. Lovely.
Would have loved to see it. We went by 3 different times and days and it was closed due to electrical issues :(. We had pre purchased tickets. The gardens surrounding the museum were beautiful.
Don't miss the other paintings. Everyone goes to see Monet's Water Lilies, but do NOT miss the galleries downstairs! This is a museum that is often missed--do not make that mistake.
Unexpected thrill. Never realized waterlilies would impress me so much. Worthwhile visit that doesn't take long. Was great to see in person. Definite must stop

This is not overrated.. The wee (by Parisian standards) l'Orangerie is tucked in a corner of the Tuileries opposite the Louvre and across the Seine from d'Orsay. It exists primarily because of the work of Monet.While many might revile Monet and his peers for producing consumable, safe art that people actually found pleasing, the l'Orangerie is truly a testimony to the actual depth and breadth of the Impressionists and their heirs. Yes, the waterlillies are pretty to look at, and you can see versions of them around the world, but when you see the eight giant canvases displayed in a space designed for them, in a space where you can appreciate not only the sweeping scale and beauty of these masterpieces but the intricate detail of both the art and the artist, only in this place have I found myself truly "getting it." If nothing else, to imagine what it took for an aging artist to create these while suffering near-debilitating cataracts, and indeed undergoing the pain of surgery to improve his sight to finish these works, belies that this was not (as some would decry it) safe art for the masses. Monet had a vision, and no place I've seen captures it as perfectly as l'Orangerie.The added bonus is the lower level. While d'Orsay presented a world-class set of selections from the Montmartre crowd, l'Orangerie places these next to (well, below) Monet's great works in a manner that greatly illumines the complexity of the whole Impressionist (and post-Impressionist) movement in Paris and environs. Go. Please.
Another great museum not to miss. This is a short walk from the Louvre. It has some of the most beautiful and largest Monet paintings. It is a great little treasure.

Monet's water lillies a must see. The murals of Monet, filling the round walls are grand and spectacular. The museuem is small but has quite a few high end pieces that are worth the trip. It is close to its big brother d'Orsey so you can do both in on outing.

The Monet is the only reason we went. Monet's water-lillies are spectacular and the manner in which they are displayed is perfect. Very peaceful and it transports you to Giverny (the location where Claude Monet painted it). The other presentations downstairs pales in comparison to Musee d'Orsay.
Water lilies galore.. Incredible collection of Monet's water lily paintings, in a pleasant setting, with a decent collection of other Impressionist works.
Paris in the rain. Astounding works of art. We visited Monet's garden prior to visiting Musee de l'Orangerie. I could feel the expression in his paintings.

A little gem. If you love Monet then a visit to this place is a must! They are just spectacular . Rooms with walls covered with his water lily paintings. We go every year and just sit and stare at their beauty!

Monet!!!!. This little museum was on my must do list and we loved it. We went specifically to see the gorgeous Monet paintings is the purpose built rooms (love the white gauzy fabric which filters the light from above) and they were even more beautiful than anticipated. We sat and gazed at them for awhile and then decided to take a peek downstairs. Wow! So many absolutely gorgeous paintings from so many masters. I was in art history heaven!

An excellent little museum. The first Sunday of the month the museums are free in Paris. We went and the queue was very short just waited 5minutes. Monet's water lillies were great, but downstairs there was a display of Italian painters as well as impressionist painters Monet, Manet, Renoir etc as well as works by Picasso, Matisse Etc. It is a lovely small museum and after visiting Monet's garden in Giverney seeing the water lilies completed the experience.

What a gem!. Small quiet museum in the Tuileries gardens. What a nice break from the much bigger and more famous and more crowded museum at the other end of the park, whose name begins with "L" and ends with "vre." The Orangerie is a beautiful small space, where the featured stars are the giant Monet water lilies paintings. It was a simple and beautiful space that invites quiet reflection and contemplation, just as Monet intended. Downstairs is a little more like a traditional museum, but also great collections of Picassos, Soutines, Renoirs, Modiglianis, etc. This is a small museum, so you can easily do it justice in an hour or two. Definitely worth the trip. Note, they have a combined ticket that also gets you into the Musee d'Orsay, another beauty worth visiting. We didn't know that in advance, but something to keep in mind if you're planning to do both.
Small and quaint. The Musee de l'Orangerie is much smaller and more intimate than the Louve or d'Orsay. Well worth the visit to see the water lilies.

Much more than water lillies. I skipped the queue because of my Museum Pass, and within a few seconds was sitting before one of the most famous paintings in the world. 4 water lilly paintings in one room, then 4 in the other. I sat on the centre oval seat, shoulder to shoulder of course. I dunno much about art so I didn't stay as long as others. The story behind why Mr Monet did this is interesting.I could have spent hours in the downstairs gallery - there must be hundreds of paintings, with Cezanne Renoir Modigliani and lots of other guys. Fascinating. They could do with some more seating, because I found many of these just entrancing, they just call out to you :Hey, take a closer look, come and enjoy this one too".If I am ever in Paris again even for one day, I will go back to Musee d l'Orangerie. On this trip we resisted the temptation of buying a book about every attraction, but I bought this one.Unfortunately, the more time you spend in there, the less time you have for Place de la Concorde just outside (that is where my taxi dropped me off), or for the picnic or stroll through Jardin Tuileries (I strolled on back through the gardens, through the fantastic Louvre courtyards, back to our aprtment by Pont Neuf).A great afternoon in Paris.

amazing gem. So enjoyed the little side trip to this museum. Didn't expect the awesome Monet Water Lily tina - gorgeous.and the rest of the exhibits were veto nice as well.included in museum pass.no lines.
Another small jewel. Large museums with large crowds can be distracting. This museum is small enough that it isn't as crowded. What a perfect way to see Monet's work in an intimate way.
The waterlilies aren't the only thing!. The downstairs exhibits are wonderful too! And if you have a chance to see the show of Italian painters, don't miss it.

Way Better than the Louve/ Impressionist art amazing.. After the mobs at the Louvre, this was so nice. Wonderful art and laid out nicely in a spacious atmosphere. Wonderful impressionist art from Monet and Renoir. Don't miss.
Superb collection.. We really enjoyed this collection, especially the Monets.Good idea to have the Paris MUseum pass as the queue was huge, and we just walked right in with our pass!

Loved it!. This is a small museum, with two levels. On the ground level, there are two enormous rooms with 4 paintings each. These are Monet's water lilies. They are displayed in these large rooms filled with natural light. Totally amazing! On the lower level, there are several rooms with works by Matisse, Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Derain, Modigliani, among others. What I most appreciated about the collection was the quality of the paintings chosen. I highly recommend going!

More than expected. We bought a dual ticket for this museum and the Musee D'Orsay. I expected to spend a few minutes viewing the Money Waterlilly paintings (which are lovely) but was surprised to find a very large display of Italian impressionist paintings on the lower level (basement). My teenage children and I spent about 2 hours here total and really enjoyed it.

Peaceful. After visiting Monet's house/gardens in Giverny, his painting in this museum captures the feeling of peace and serenity of his home. Joy of nature come to life. Please visit and you will say, Merci Monet!

Don't miss Monet's waterlilies. The star of the show is Monet's waterlilies, although they have a nice little collection of Impressionist art. It is worth it just to go and sit in front of the waterlilies paintings for a time, to contemplate the master colorist.
Underwhelming. I like impressionist paintings. I went to Musee de l'Orangerie to see the large Monet waterlily murals. I was underwhelmed. There is little else here of interest. Give it a miss.

Don't miss this. Monet's waterlilies are magnificent. Small museum can be handled in a few hours at the most. Skip the long line by buying a Museum Pass at the airport at one of the information desks. That pass will save you from hours of standing in lines. Look ahead at the start of the lines for the symbol of the pass and walk on in. After seeing this museum walk in the jardin de tuileries and enjoy a cafe.

Monet dominates. The Orangerie is dominated by the vast Monet waterlily paintings. They may seem unimpressive at first, but you will gradually find yourself immersed in them. The rest of the collection feels rather second-rate by comparison and is housed in rather cramped basement galleries, but is still well worth a look.

Wonderful surprise. I was actually a little disappointed by the Monets, mainly because they were so hyped. That being said, the way they are presented is gorgeous. What I was not expecting was their wonderful collection downstairs. It is not large, but a lot of gems down there, so be sure not to miss it. It is right next to the Tuileries, so you can visit the Louvre, stroll down the Tuileries, then visit this great little museum.

Small but lovely. Easy to get to. The gardens and Place de Concorde are beautiful spots to just walk on a nice day. The museum itself is small and that is one of the things that makes it so enjoyable. You don't have to rush around to see everything. Of course the highlight for me was the exhibit of Monet's water lily panels. They are in 2 rooms upstairs and it is a very peaceful place to just sit and enjoy.

must visit. Beautiful little museum in a beautiful setting in the Tuillerie gardens behind the Louvre. Not as intimidatingly large as the Louvre, but the paintings are breathtaking and encourage lingering.
show me the monet. Exquisite work in a tranquil atmosphere. Additional exhibits on lower level also worth a gander. Not open on Tuesdays, so plan accordingly.

The best of Impressionism. This museum requires very little in explanation. People who love impressionist painting know that there is more and better impressionist work in this museum than in any other museum in the world.You can go to most museums of quality in large cities around the world and see a certain amount of Impressionist work but there is no place to see the quantity and quality that you can see here.The only suggestion to be made is that you try to go to time when it will not be filled with schoolchildren or tourists. This would suggest around opening time and certainly in times of the year such as the late fall, winter or early spring when then maybe fewer tourists around. If you can manage this you'll be able to wander through the museum without having to struggle to see all of the paintings.If this is not possible it is worth going anyway as we did because what is there not be found anyplace else.

The place for the impressionist in Paris plus a nice garden. When to see the Macchiaiolis, the italian impresionnist. Nice dsiplay.The regular exposition is full of the master of the impressionnist.Of course you have the masterpiece of Nymheas of Monet. Two full rooms.

Another great museum for younger patrons. This was my 9 year old daughter's favourite museum as Monet's waterlilies were just incredible. It was here that my girl starting really viewing the paintings, both close up and far away with different perspectives. The stunning layout of the museum makes it easy to appreciate these incredible works. The temporary exhibition was great also as it gave a whole different aspect to the genre of art. Well worth a visit for younger art lovers.

How Monet intended. Seeing Monet's waterlilies wrapped around the circular rooms as he intended was absolutely breathtaking. Middle of the day during a weekday was great for much smaller crowds than usual.

Good museum. It had great paintings and explanations. Monet's Water Lilies was a historic example of Paris's artistic charm and had its own section. Learn more about this before you go, you'll be more impressed.

A Small but Bright Gem!. We went on a rainy Sunday last month (after being in the Orsay for a few hours) specifically to see Monet's lilies. Moved right to the front of the line with our Museum Pass (well worth it!) and within minutes were inside. It is a smaller museum, which the feet appreciated. The two rooms dedicated to the murals of water lilies were both serene and breathtaking. Not sure why we couldn't take pictures (non-flash of course) though when you could take them in other parts of the museum. We were through there in about 1.5 hours, with half that time just looking at the lilies.
Les Nymphéas!!!. Just dropped in for the Monet's Les Nymphéas and it was beautiful. I highly suggest purchasing a museum pass so you can cut the queues.

Les Nympheas surpass all expectations. The total collection at L'Orangerie is amazing including extensive works by Modigliani Cezene Renoir Matisse Picasso & others but the two purpose built oval rooms that exhibit Monet's Les Nympheas is the absolute highlight. This is my second visit & they were as breathtaking as remembered. They inspire awe - the reaction is generally an immediate hush as they overwhelm most who are enveloped by their beauty. If you can go when it isn't crowded the experience is almost spiritual. If 'crowded' is all you can do it is still an unbelievable experience. Don't miss it!

Favorite Museum in Paris. This place is quieter, less crowded and much more enjoyable than the large museums in Paris. Monet's water lilies are spectacular when viewed in the oblong rooms with soft lighting.

The museum to see!. While all of the other museums have so much to see, this one has several nice pieces of art, Monet as the centerpiece, without the crowds and size of the Louvre and Orsay. Take time in the oval rooms dedicated to Monet's water lilies. The downstairs exhibits has plenty of Cezanne, Picasso, and Renoir. An enjoyable experience.

Monets World. After seeing the Home of Claude Monet , the next step is to glance at the wonderful result of his beautiful gardens at Giverney. The vast canvas painting of his impressions of his waterlily gardens is something to see. The canvas of them takes up the expanse of 2 large sunlit galleries. The paintings curve around the gallery itself and seem to engulf you on center- not the same as experiencing them live- but pretty darn close! The only minus really is the policy of most of the museum entrances to have only one line and one cashier for entrances which if you do not arrive early will take up a bit of time. The location is at the end of the museum plaza , if you have a problem locating it up on a hill- there is an information kiosk directly below . Just ask there and the guards will direct you. This is located in a beautiful garden area- combine the two on a beautiful day!

wonderful spot. This museum is small, charming and a nice break from the crowds!(however go when it opens for being small can get busy) Full of Monet..take a minute to sit down & enjoy(possibly to also rest your feet!) in the basements there are so many beautiful paintings , can't remember all the names however some beautiful "Renoir's". There is also a small gift shop. A must see while in Paris
Unbelievable Monet Room Sized Lily Ponds!. Soooo worth it! The Lily Pond galleries are ephemeral and serene. The "basement" is full of Impressionist and contemporary works! Not to be missed!

Monet, Monet, Monet. The house of Monet's Nymphéas. I can stay in the room for hours as the paintings are displayed the same way Monet intended too. Before I went to l'Orangerie the first time, I've been fascinated by them, but only when you get into the room, the emotions from the paintings intensify, and they are breath taking.
small museum great for younger children.. This museum is small enough for younger children who can't handle large spaces nor shouldn't be overwhelmed. The museum covers a nice variety of painters.

Waterlilies. This is a small museum but a must see for anyone who loves Monet's water lilies. The highlight of the museum is the 8 large murals of waterlilies displayed in 2 rooms. It can get crowded so go early to get the best views. Also worth seeing is the Paul Guillame collection of early 20th century art.The small gift shop is also worth a visit.

It's worth it for just the Monet water lily murals. Two oval rooms each have 4 large curved water lily paintings. It is a sublime experience to sit and gaze upon them, and marvel at Monet's persistence and vision. Downstairs were a number of Renoir and Cezanne paintings, and others. The temporary exhibition was a bonus. "Les Macchiaioli 1850-1874. Des impressionnistes italiens ?" Showed paintings from the groups of rebel Italian painters who painted outdoors, capturing marvelous effects of light and contrast. These were beautiful.

Culture without exhaustion. This is a treasure and a museum where your feet will not protest as there is not a lot to see - just quality Monet and Renoir and special shows - and you don't have to walk forever or generally, fight huge crowds. Many other Paris attractions are overwhelming and one has to be selective but no so here. So, if you like Monet and Renoir and are put off by the scale and challenge of the Musée d'Orsay, try this. It is worth it and all you need to enjoy it is an hour or so.
Charming and surprising. A charming, small and must visit museum - sit down, relax and enjoy the enormous paintings by Monet. It's absolutely worth it!

A Solid Stop For 1-2 hours. Easy to visit and convenient near the Place de Concorde, this is an easy visit for all with a Museum Pass. The Water Lily panels are breath-taking, but the other permanent displays are excellent, too, and make the visit a must for the impressionist art fan.
It has the BIG Monet water lillies... ...And that was spectacular. 8 probably 10 X40 paintings of his water garden. very small museum otherwise.

Perfect for weary travelers. We visited this museum after several days in Paris. We'd seen the Louvre and Versailles, which were amazing but overwhelming both in size and crowds.This charming museum was just the ticket we needed! Covered by the museum pass, it only takes about an hour to go through. It is beautiful, and the Monet paintings fill two large circular rooms filled with light - beautiful! As a bonus, the museum had a fantastic gift shop!

Great Museum. Great paintings, Monet's water lilies, not crowded, small. If you only have an hour or two to visit a museum, or if you've already seen the Orsay and Louvre, this is a must visit. Current Italian art exhibit is impressive.

Surrounded by water lilies. The Musee de l'Orangerie has two oval rooms with four of Monet's mammoth water lily paintings encircling each room. There is a bench in the center of each room which gives the viewer a great opportunity to sit and enjoy the experience of being surrounded by his magnificent paintings. This is breathtaking. Sadly, we could not take photos.

Monet!!!! Renoir!!! And More!!!!. If you plan to do a number of Museums get the Paris Museum Pass - it is amazing how much time you save avoiding line-ups. The paintings in this this Museum are wonderful. It was probably our favourite - but we love Monet and Renoir. There are 2 rooms of 'huge' Monet waterlily paintings - each in different seasons and different tones, there is seating in the centre so you can spend a few minutes (or longer) just viewing/comparing the paintings. The lower floor is many galleries of wonderful work. There is a large collections of Renoir - he is a master of the portrait - it is the most Renoir's we had seen together - we loved it. The paintings are well presented with space between so that you can really look at the paintings. It as not as crowded as some of the other museums.

A manageable museum. Okay, now that you've walked a mile in the Louvre and gotten lost you're ready to admit that you want to see great art without breathing hard! The l'Orangerie is that museum. You go for Monet's most iconic work - the water lilies, you sit in peace in the open space that must be what heaven looks like. Then you realize there is a downstairs where you can see a revolving collection of great work. While we were there we saw a delightful retrospective on early photographic nudes and Plein Air painters from Italy and France. Modigliani's, Picasso's, DeRain's...they're just icing on the cake!
Worth the Time. The Monet murals are worth the trip to this small museum. Beautiful walk through Tuileries Garden to get there. Entry price covered with the Paris Museum Pass.

Okay. Not a lot to see compared to some of the museums. We started here and that was good as we weren't overwhelmed. On the other hand, you have to go there to see Monet's work BEFORE going to Giverny and seeing the gardens in the flesh.

The Mecca for lovers of Claude Monet's art. This smaller museum was, in a previous incarnation, literally a building to shelter the orange trees of the adjacent Tuileries gardens. The focus is on Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art, but the major attraction is the works of Claude Monet. These include his famous Water Lilies murals, which are displayed in a sympathetically designed separate gallery which includes carefully positioned seating and this allows these extensive works to be viewed at length in comfort. Other works of art include paintings by Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso and Renoir. The museum is well set out and the paintings are arranged in a logical sequence. One of the very good Paris museums.

Awesome museum. This museum allows the viewer to become one with the painting. You enter a room and are surrounded by Monet. There is ample room to sit and study his work. Signage was clear, the audio tour was informative and interesting.

Museum made for Impressionist lovers. This museum is the home of the beautiful waterlilies series from Monet, he personally designed the layout of the gallery that would show the large canvases with one of the most beautiful pieces of art I have ever seen the amount of natural light filtering just makes his work magical.

More Water Lilies than you ever imagined!. This museum houses Monet's Water Lilies and if you have never seen them in their natural setting, prepare to be amazed. They are so much more stupendous in their "home" setting, and the museum was redesigned to showcase these treasures. There is plenty of space to move around the art and take your time seeing the light play off the different panels. The Water Lilies occupy both spaces on the first floor of the museum; the lower level houses other, changing exhibits. It won't take you long to go through this museum, so it's definitely a morning or afternoon visit, not a whole day, but it's a wonderful respite from the larger, more crowded museums nearby. Also, take advantage of the "combined" tickets; purchase entry here at l'Orangerie and use your ticket for entry at your choice of a couple other area museums within the next four days. Definitely a MUST SEE on any trip to Paris.

The ultimate for the Monet fan. Nothing can match the experience of standing in one of the 2 oval rooms of Monet's waterlilies in the soft light of the Orangerie's skylights, filtered by a fabric screen.

Monet and more.. The museum is dominated by the huge monet paintings, truly a magnificent sight to behold. The lower levels of the building are packed with interesting impressionist paintings, even if you are not an art lover i would be very surprised if you couldn't find something of interest there.

Stunning. Standing in front of the works of masters. Amazing architecture. Not too crowded at the end of May visit. I was put off by the museum worker who loudly and openly scolded a visitor from across the room for taking pictures, and then kicked her out. Even if she was breaking the rules, this was very unprofessional and it disturbed other visitors.

Monet larger than life. I never liked Monet until I saw the 8 panels at Musee de l'Orangerie, which highlight them in a beautiful space that allows distance and up close viewing. The rest of the collection is good to see too, but not the best representations of Picasso and Matisse. I would go back just to see the Monet paintings again.

So much more than just the home of Monet's Les Nymphéas!. Certainly, the perfect setting for Les Nymphéas, but more than that, a lovely museum showcasing some magnificent Impressionists works ... and few crowds!
Monet's in the round. Don't miss the Orangerie and it's amazing Monet's that surround you with Monet's work that he hoped would bring the country to city-bound Parisians.

It has much more than Monet's water lilies. We were glad we went into the Orangerie. The Monet waterlilies are impressive both because of the unique appearance and the size and shape of the canvases. But we were also glad we went because of what is in the lower basement level- many more paintings from the impressionists.They are not all in the d'Orsay and I saw some works by Utrillo (one of my favorites), especially scenes in Montmartre, who was not in the d'Orsay at all. The Orangerie is at the west end of the Tuileries Garden, close to the river and almost right across the river from the d'Orsay. Like the Louvre it is closed on Tuesdays and has a late opening night on Fridays.

Shrine to Monet's Water Lillies. Watching the crowds hushed reverence in the rooms where Monet's large water lillies paintings was truly memorable. Museum also features other noteworthy impressionist works.

A surprising delight!. This was not on our original itinerary but the Musee d'Orsey was closed. The Monet exhibit was devine. Was also excited to see many works by other famous artist like Picasso, Renoir, Matisse and many more. In addition the history of the building is quite an intersting story. Personally I liked it better than the Louvre.
Go for the Monet. If you love the water lilies, this is the one. The other paintings are very good as well, but a small collection. The temprary exhibits are better than the permanent collection.

A real treat. We went quite early in the morning before it got too crowded and so were able to sit and admire Monet's water lilies in peace. The exhibition downstairs was fantastic, such a wonderful collection of impressionist work
Great for Monet fans. The Monet water lilies are spectacular of course but the rest of the gallery was not very inspiring.

Reason alone to visit Paris. Many travelers skip this museum and its too bad. Monet's Water Lily Panels surround in a way no other piece of work can. There is also a wonderful collection of other famous painters as well. Go early. Nice gift shop open spaces very enjoyable visit.
A manageable museum to visit. Small enough to see without crowds of people. A cycle of Monet's water-lily paintings is worth the price of admission.

Must see!. After visiting Monet's house and garden this is a definite 'must see'. Breathtaking on entering the first room and seeing the lily pond shown in such a spectacular way, then a second room! As if this wasn't enough there are many other works of art on display.
Waterlilies. Monet's huge waterlily canvases are not to be missed. It is nice that they put a bench in the middle of the room to sit and stare at them for awhile.
Pleasant experience!. We only went to see the Monet Water Lilies but that alone made the visit worthwhile! Defintely recommend the museum pass.

My favorite museum in Paris. This is a small museum near the Louvre. The giant Monet paintings are awe-inspiring. The smaller Matisse and Renoir paintings were also lovely. No crowds, just amazing art.

Not our Favorite. Full disclosure to start, I don't know much about art. This museum did not do much for me. Using the museum pass we were glad we stopped by but to our family this did not rate as highly as shown on Tripadvisor. Unless you are really into Monet or using the pass I would spend more time at the Louvre or Orsay.

Circular vision of Monets!. The Musee de l'Orangerie, set at one end the Tuileries Gardens on the Right Bank of the river Seine, is spectacular. When visiting the museum, make sure you purchase the Paris Museum Pass to bypass the line. When you walk into the museum, you proceed to 2 oval rooms that immerse you in Monet's water lilies paintings. Sit and take it all in. A must!
I wouldn't go another time.... Monet in his late days (already almoust blind), some Picassos, some Cezannes some Renoirs ... nothing really good

Requires little time. This is a quick stop while you visit the Tuileries Garden but if you are a Monet fan it's a must. It's the only place you'll see the Water Lilly collection the way it was intended. This museum is included in the Museum Pass and you need less than an hour at this stop. We never made it to Giverny, due to a poor touring company, but I still recommend it if you have the time as it is the inspiration for the paintings.
First visit. I really do not know how I have missed in the past. Very interesting and very worthwhile. A little hard to find!
So glad to get here at last.. Last visit to Paris this was still under construction. We were delighted with the excellent permanent exhibition hall and really super temporary exhibition June 2013.

Monet's dream realized. This is a lovely place, worth more time than we had to give to it - don't go after 4 PM, guards start shooing you out of the galleries at 4:45. Monet planned this place to install his last monumental murals of his water lilies; and downstairs there is the fine Paul Guillaume collection of post-impressionist paintings - Rousseau, Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse, and many others There are a few imposing Rodin sculptures outside the museum - but the major setting attraction is its location in the Tuileries Gardens, worth a visit by themselves. This is the 300th anniversary of the birth of the landscape architect Andre LeNotre, who planned this garden for Louis XIV, and the flower display is just lovely. Sit here for a while and watch Parisians having fun - and don't miss having ice cream from the "petal cone" cart - there are a couple dozen exotic and exquisite flavors, and you decide what size cone you want and what flavors you want them to add as the "petals" - YUM! Why don't we have one of these in Central Park? - they'd make a mint, and I'd go there all the time!

Wonderful small museum. The water lillies were wonderful and I loved the benches where you could sit and take it all in.Don't miss the basement level galleries because they are terrific, too. Plus this museum wasn't as crowded as the Louvre or d"Orsay and much more enjoyable.

Beautiful. Worth a visit especially as part of the Paris museum pass. The highlight was the purpose built room for the Water Lillies. The model near the gift shop explaining the history of the building fascinated the kids (as well as explaining the name)
Wonderful paintings by Monet. I went here just to see Monet's famous water lily paintings which I'd heard so much about, and I wasn't disappointed - they are fantastic!

Lovely small museum. This museum was a joy to visit. We went in the morning about 10am and walked straight in and bought tickets. The Monet paintings in the circular rooms are wonderful, if your a fan of Monet I would recommend this museum. There were lots of other paintings displayed by many other artists as well, a very good museum.

Water Lilies. After visiting so many museums in only a few days' time, I went to the Orangerie expecting to be bored of most of the paintings. I wasn't, though because there are great paintings by impressionists like Renoir and Monet - I would definitely say that Monet's water lilies were the highlight of the museum. They were so beautiful. The museum is relatively small so it's easy to cover in less than an hour, maybe an hour and a half if you want to stand in front of each one. Unlike the Louvre on Sundays, it's not extremely crowded.

Our Favourite. Loved this gallery. We had a Paris pass so got to jump the cue, best purchase if you are on a tight schedule.
After checking our bags we did the bottom level fairly quickly, the went to see the water Lilly's. they are huge and I must say I was shocked at the emotion they envoked in me, beautiful.

Worth a visit, although Paris has better museums.. Visited with children because read in a guide that it was child-friendly, but that was not our experience. The Monets are really outstanding, so the museum is worth a visit just for them. The rest was not to our taste. Layout initially confusing.

Unmissable. After Louvre, Orsay (& the list goes on) we felt we had no appetite for another museum. Although we crossed Jardin Tuileries several times we always skipped Musee de I'Orangerie, but we are sure glad we did manage to visit it finally. What is great about this museum & what worked for us:1. It has the most magnificent art display: Monet's wall to wall water lilies. Scale of the display is just stunning. It runs from one room to another & is unlike any other art you would have experienced. The water lilies are a reason enough to visit this museum.2. Relatively small museum limited to Monet & impressionists(downstairs). It doesn't overwhelm, much lesser crowd factor.3. We had the museum pass & got in quickly without having to wait in a queue.I do feel the visits to smaller museums ( Rodin is another example) turned out more fun in terms of overall experience, also appreciating & recalling what we saw.

If you love Monet, come to this museum. There are two or three circular rooms with 3 canvases each of Monet's Water Lillies scenes. Each canvas is from a different time of day. I believe all of the canvases were produced in his later years. The museum was constructed to house these paintings, hence the circular room shape. There are some other paintings within the museum, but the Monet Water Lillies are the hi-lite.

small musee, excellent collection. beauty....and not mobbed. we were on our way there walking in the tulleries when it started to pour rain. It was relatively uncrowded. Later there was a crowd. So go early or in the rain.

a sea of tranquility. This is a must in Paris. If you get there fairly early the line ups aren't bad. The best part is the Monets' which are to large for the hordes to charge up to and photograph. As a result you are obliged to sit and actually observe You can slowly work your way through the paintings and really see them. In the chaos of tour bus people this is a bit of peace
The Monets!. The Monets here are a marvel, even after seeing Monets at many other museums, we were stunned by their beauty and presentation. To go to Paris and miss this sight is a mistake.

Water Lilies Reign Here. We were a bit "Museum-ed Out" by the time we visited l'Orangerie, but I'm so glad we did not miss Monet's wall-to-wall waterlilies murals. Stunning! Strolling along the promenade beneath the beautifully scented orange blossoms was an added bonus.

Beautiful Monets. Had to queue for an hour to get in on a Monday afternoon ;-( Get a fast track pass for museums if you want to avoid standing in line. But the 8 huge Monet's in the oval rooms are amazing

Small but worth a visit. A relatively small but nice selection. Obviously no comparison with the much larger museeum of Orsay but we still enjoyed our visit. The rooms housing the Monet murals really suit the works. Not too crowded though there was a 20 min queue to get in.

Perfect scale for viewing art. Compared to the Louvre and the Orsay, we found the Orangerie a perfect size: after the amazing Monets, we enjoyed the Impressionists downstairs at a leisurely pace without being overwhelmed. Also, a current exhibition of Italian paintings introduced us to something new, and we left invigorated instead of exhausted.

Amazing. I was blown away by this place. Everything was well displayed and well lit. I loved it. Especially the Italian expressionist?. We spent more thime there than we expected. Brillaint. Don't miss it.

Lovely and Quick. If you have a museum pass, pop in here to view the huge, room-filling Monets. If not too crowded, it can be very refreshing. Plan on fifteen minutes or so - more if it is quiet and you want to stay and soak it in.

A must for Art fans. the museum houses the famous Monet paintings - I had seen them many, many years ago but the same precious feelings came back on the second viewing and made me realise what a fabulous man Claude Monet was - one of the most popular exhibits in the museum, but that said it was not over crowded and has benches so you can sit back and enjoy.

Great Museum for when you don't have a lot of time. Great small Museum with beautiful Monets. Check out the rest of the museum as well. We saw Renoirs and Picassos. We were able to see everything in an hour

Beautiful. For me this is a nice to see, not a must see for Paris. If you only have a few days there are other attractions to hit but if you have the time this Museum is small but a gem. The paintings by Monet are the centerpiece and are beautiful. There is something so soothing about sitting and staring at the water paintings. On a day spent running around to see the sights this is a cool and relaxing break.

Small but wonderful!. Visited L'Orangerie to see Degas paintings and was pleasantly pleased to see works by other major artists in a wonderful setting. With our Paris Museum Pass admission was free and we were in and out quickly. A gem in the Tuillerie Gardens!

More lillies. After a half day at Giverny exploring the Monet home and gardens, we had to see the massive murals of the lillies Monet did as a commission here. An easy side trip to the Tuileries Garden. The other collections were enjoyable, as well.
Small, intimate and beautifully lighting. Monet's waterlilies are here in a room lit by natural sunlight. Plenty of seating to sit and view them. Don't forget to cut the line with your museum pass!
Italian Impressionists. For those who want just a little art, this is the place for you. The temporary exhibits are really well done. And, oh, those water lillies!
Monet. Great monet exhibition and many other examples of the modernist style.Far less crowded the many other museums

An unexpected delight!. We went here to specifically to see Monet's water lilies. We didn't quite expect them to be on such a large scale, it was fascinating to sit in the centre of the room and gaze at these masterpieces, then to go close to the canvas as see the technique. We used our museum pass and bypassed the queues. Much quieter than the Louvre which is close by.

Don't Miss this Jewel!. The Louvre at the other end of the Tuileries Gardens takes the spotlight and most people never make it here to see the large scale Water Lilies by Monet. They are unforgettable and there are other lovely paintings here also.

Growth experience. We were so taken by the presentation of Monet's paintings in the oval rooms with overhead lighting. Having visited many, many museums before, this was a unique experience. The only drawback was having the guard hushing the room when no one was being loud at all. Buy the museum pass; it's well worth it.
Monet's Water Lilies!. Must see if you are a fan of Monet! The water lilies painting are huge and are in an oval-shaped room.

Invites quiet contemplation. This small museum houses Monet's Waterlilies. The paintings are displayed in a surround format with subdued natural lighting that invites quiet contemplation and appreciation of his works. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a good place to start your Paris museum tours and to purchase your Paris Museum Pass (short lines at the ticket counter).
The Monet paintings are stunning. The main purpose of the visit was to see Monet paintings which are stunning. The setting is very calm and one can appreciate the paintings very well.
Wow!. If you like the art, go there!Warm recommendation for booking the tickets to avoid standing in the line. Audio guide recommended.I hope I can visit it again soon!

Stare at the lillies forever!. Lovely place in the tuileries- you can stare at the monet lillies forever! also some other collection also not too bad :P, but if you are a fan of monet, this is a must place!
Monet's magnifique - hidden jewel at the Tuileries. Don't miss this little museum nestled between Tuileries park and Place de la Concorde. I've been 4 times I love it so much.
Monet!. Water Lilly's on massive canvases. Loved it. Sit and absorb the beauty of monets garden and the changing water Lilly's
Magnificent Monet. The room with walls covered with Monet's waterlilly garden was unbelievable. I sat there for a long while moving from time to see what Monet saw in the different light.

Lovely surprise. If you like Monet you must go to this museum. Beautifully located in thevJardins Tuilleries, this museum has Monet's Nympheas, which are spectacular. I was not familiar with these previously so did not know what to expect and I was awestruck by the colors and beauty (and size) of the paintings. The other exhibits seem to change but if you happen to like it that is a nice bonus. It can be visited in under an hour so is an easy museum to fit into the day when near the Tuillaries or Place de Concorde. Definitely worth it.

Nice surprise!. This was my first time at the Musee de l'Orangerie and I was pleasantly surprised. It is very small so it was perfect for the afternoon we arrived in Paris. Monet's "Water Lillies" was beautiful.

Great building. Was very excited about going to this gallery and to see the famous works of Monet. The building transformation is superb and if you love a lot a beautiful old paintings then you must go - a few Picassos to keep me interested but was a little bit underwhelmed and left without that buzz I usually get from seeing masters. I can see lots of people love it and I can see why - but just not as exceptional as d'orsay or the Louvre. I love Monet's work but not so much this muddier series of transitions from dawn to dusk.

short but sweet. didn't spend a lot of time here, a bit of adhd kicks in looking at paintings, but, it's worth the trip. the room with large impressionist paintings all around is a great place to sit and consider.

Small museum but fantastic. I highly recommend viewing the two rooms of the water lilies and just sit and stair at the different paintings until they start to come to life. I now understand impressionism. The lower museum area is also good.

A wonderful place for Impressionist art. In addition to the two large rooms of beautiful Monet Waterlilies on the top floor, there is a wonderful collection of Impressionist paintings on the lower level. For people who find stairs difficult, there is an elevator whose hidden location can be found on the free map of the interior of the museum. The area around Place de la Concorde can be confusing. The museum is across from the southeast corner of the Place at the top of a dirt and gravel walkway. If you want to find a taxi after leaving it, look on the cut-though at the northeast corner and eventually you will be able to flag one down, although that is not the usual way to get a taxi in Paris. I did not see a taxi rank nearby.At the Orangerie you can buy a combination ticket which include priority entry to the Musee d'Orsay within four days.
