This is probably the easiest and least expensive way to buy a priority ticket for the Orsay.If you need to ask directions, the museum is pronounced "orange-rie" with the accent on the last syllable.

Waterlilies Meditation. Cycle of Waterlilies is simply divine - do take a moment to just sit there and watch, enjoy and relax. The selection of paintings downstairs is great as well with a few works by Modigliani which I loved the most.

Monet murals of the Water Lillie Ponds in his gardens.. Having previously visited Monet's home and gardens in Giverny we wanted to see the large murals in the Musee Orangerie. We had Paris museum passes so skipped the lines and went right in. On the first level there are two nice size oval rooms with the very large Monet murals of the Water Lillie Ponds in his gardens. They are beautiful and worth the time to enjoy. But please don't miss the exhibits on the lower level of Monet, Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliano, Picasso and others. If you have the time we highly recommend this museum either before or after strolling the Tuileries.

Lovely and approachable. We went to this museum after a half day tour of Monet's garden. This is a small museum, easy to get around and with enough room to take a minute to appreciate the wall-sized murals. The Louvre offers art upon art along with throngs of people while this is a quiet museum where you can breathe. Added bonus, if you have the museum pass you can breeze past the line.

Do Musee D'Orsay first. If you do D'Orsay first your ticket will cover both. Then you can skip the queue at L'Orange. The Monet's are the size of a cricket pitch and if you have been to Giveny, they will mean twice as much.
Gem of a museum. If you time it right ie not when there are masses of other tourists there, this is a little oasis of calm.The water lily rooms are beautiful

Finally got to see this museum.. On all previous visits to Paris the Orangerie was closed for renovations. We got to visit this time and it was very good. There are the great Monet paintings of water lilies in two galleries and these alone make the visit worthwhile. The other exhibitions include a great selection of Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliano, Picasso etc.The staff were very helpful in accommodating little children and a pram. The pram was swapped for a smaller stroller that was better for the gallery space - no charge and smiles. Costs were reasonable when you match it against similar museums and the waiting time was short at 3.00 pm. on Thursday.Put this on the "must see" list.

Monet's Dream Murals. Having been told about this attraction by some fellow travellers we put it on our visit list and were not sorry.The elongated oval rooms of the upper two levels of the building are a haven of quiet and retrospection as visitors sit back to back on the long seats straddling the centre of each of the two rooms. Once settled, with one's mind cleared, one is only aware of being surrounded by the garden of Monet throughout the seasons of the year. On a warm day in Spring it was an absolute gift to sit and be serene, then walk through the Tuileries to the Carousel below the Louvre and stroll through the shops. Wonderful Paris. It has many secrets but we are slowly uncovering some previously unknown pleasures.

Monet Water Lilies. I had the fortune to go to Giverny to Monet's home the day before I went to the Orangerie. The two rooms of Monet's water lilies were spectacular. Until I saw them I did not realize they were life size paintings! It is worth it to go just to see these paintings, but there are other galleries, too, that are wonderful. It's never been crowded when I was there.

Monet the only way to see it. If you think you like Monet's water lilies but have not been here, boy are you in for a pleasant surprise. This is one of the experiences of a lifetime. It will put you in a state of peace.
The greatest. There is nothing like seeing Monet's water lilies here -- people think they've seen it all at the d'Orsay or Marmottan, but this is spectacular.

Monet opus - Nympheas. If you are a Monet fan you must see this. Just for the history alone. It is chilling to realize 5 shells landed in this building during the 1944 French Liberation. This building recently endured 6 year renovation reopening in 2006.The 2 oval rooms have wall murals by Monet done late in his life. Personally I don’t feel they are his best works – a bit dark. But they are classic Monet images. I thought the Picassos, Renoirs and other impressionists in the basement galley were even more impressive. I was surprised - a nice collection of Renoirs.

Monet and Renoir. Before visiting, read up on the history of the Monet works which are displayed there, then go and experience them in all their glory. I purchased my museum pass here, which also admitted me to Musee d'Orsay.
Amazing murals. Claude Monet's murals - a total of 8 - take up two full oval walls in the museum. Impressive. I love seeing his work on a grander scale.

Soul relief. An oasis of peace and relaxation in Paris. In this magnificent city even a museum visit could be really stressfull, but not here. Your eyes and soul will thank you. The Monet rooms are simply wonderful. Take the combined ticket with Orsay Museum here and avoid the long queue there.

Very Interesting. The Monet murals were amazing and the temporary collection very interesting. Artists I was unfamiliar with. Not a big museum, but right next to the Louvre and definaitely worth the visit.
Monet and more.... Fun, smaller museum with famous paintings by Picasso, Matisse, & Modigliani, the famous Water Lillies by Monet, and lots more. I discovered I really like Soutine.

magical. We really wanted to visit this museum to see Monet's famous waterlillies. Totally wonderfull , the rest of the museum downstairs offerred really fantastic works by Renoir and others. Be prepaed to be blown away by artists you have never heard off as well.It was a bit of a walk but please do not let this put you off as the paintings are truly amazing.

A must for those who love the Impressionists. This is the home of Monet's gigantic tableau Nympheas. It is worth while even if you only visit the top floor to see these paintings. On the lower level, there are more impressionist paintings, well organized so that you get a sense of evolution of their work. The museum is a modest size so is not daunting to visit (like the musee d'orsay or the Louvre can be). Combine it with a visit to the gardens of the Tuileries. When we were there, iris were blooming in profusion!

French Impresionism that makes an impression. If you already know Impressionism...I need say no more. But for those of you that don't prepare yourself to fall in love with an art movement that shaped Parisian cultural during the late 19th & early 20th centuries. Come to this intimate & relatively un-crowded museum (you can easily budget just a couple of hours here) for Monet's Les Nympheas but stay for the art collection of a 1920's art dealer, Paul Guillaume, that resides here. It is amazing and includes important works from Monet, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir & others. View up close and then slowly move farther & farther back - the paintings are genius. Until July 22 of 2013 the museum has a large borrowed collection of Italian Impressionists "The Macchiaioli". While very different in style from the French, gorgeous works of art that depict impressions of life. I highly recommend the audio guide as the history of the movement & the artists will give you a new perspective. Not a huge museum so it won't day you hours & hours to navigate. If you are also going to the d'Orsay you can buy a combo pass (only good for 4 days I think) for the 2 museums and save a little money.
360 degrees of Monet. Wonderful. A bit of a walk but worth every step. You are immersed in the paintings, they surround you.

Better than expected. We really wanted to visit this museum to see Monet's famous waterlillies. Not only were these amazing to view on such scale and from a distance, but the rest of the museum downstairs also offerred some fantastic works by Renoir and others. I particularly loved the paintings by Chaim Soutine, an artist I did not know of before but now intend to read up on. My sister and cousin didn't really enjoy the museum that much, and I think it's quite an intense one if you bore easily of paintings (i.e. the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay have a mix of other sorts of things). But in my opinion it was a brilliant museum and the best I visited in Paris.

Went because of Museum Pass. This was my fourth trip to Paris, so I was looking for museums and sites that I had not previously visited. Honestly, the main reason I went was because it was included in the Paris museum pass (which I also recommend). I really enjoyed this museum, especially the main floor with the impressionist paintings. I was a little less chaotic then some of the other major museums, so it was really nice to be able to sit, relax, and enjoy these masterpieces. I'm really glad I decided to visit Musee de l'Orangerie.

Magnificent!. I had not visited l"Orangerie in many years because it was closed for renovations the last few times I was in Paris. The Monet murals are breath taking and the entire museum is so easy to navigate and beautifully arranged so that you can actually go as close to the paintings as you like and see the details. It does not take all day to see this fabulous art exhibit and children like coming here because they can see the paintings easily. It is one of my favorite places to visit in Paris.

I Love Monet's Water Lilies. Don't miss this museum if you are a Monet fan. There are 2 rooms completely filled with panels of water lilies. They are permanently mounted to the walls, so this is the only place you will see them.

An Oasis designed by Monet. Everyone wants to see the Monet Waterlilies, but not many think of the reason why. The paintings are the reason you go to Paris. The inspiration for the museum is thought provoking. Monet wanted to give Paris a symbol of peace after the Great War (WWI) and designed it to provide a restful serene oasis in the middle of Paris. Walk into the tiny white oval entry and pause to take a deep breath and relax before entering the Monet galleries. The busy world slips away and you are submersed in Monet's gardens. No sound, no traffic, few crowds; everyone seems to respect the experience.The remaining galleries are interesting, get the audio tour if you are not an art history major.

Go for the waterlilies. This is a very small museum, which can be easily visited in about 1.5 hours. Worth it to see Monet's gorgeous water lilies, which literally brought tears to my eyes, and which take up the entire first floor. The floor below has a small collection of nice works. Unlike any other museum we visited in Paris, this one is treated with extreme reverence for some reason - no talking allowed or you will be loudly "shushed". Visit knowing you are expected to behave as if you are in a library!

Wow. When I go back to Paris, if I have to choose between this or the Louvre this would win every time. Of course it is much smaller than the Louvre but the collection is brilliant and the crowds aren't quite as enormous. I would go back just to visit the Waterlilies alone. Remember if you're under 25 and from the EU, take your passport and get free entry!

Worth seeing Monet's massive water lilies. The hallmark displays in this gallery are the two rooms with Monet's water lilies from Giverny. These alone make a visit to this museum well worthwhile. The rest of the exhbiits are slightly interesting, though not of the caliber of what you find at the Orsay. Budget one hour minimum, two hours max for this museum. It's included in your Paris Museum pass and is close to both the Louvre and the Orsay, though generally I like to do only one art museum a day.
Beautiful open airy museum. The title says it all really. Monet's waterlillys are phenomenal and in a perfect open bright room. The modern artists downstairs are very good.
A Gem. This is a small museum at the edge of the Tuilleries. There are some wonderful paintings in addition to Monet's Water Lillies. Worth the trip.
Surprisingly good value. The were no queues when we went on a Wednesday morning, but it is closed on a Tuesday...we discovered rather belatedly.
Awesome private collection. Plan to spend time below the Monet murals, especially if you like Modigliani, Renoir and Pissaro. Get the museum pass and get there just before lunch to avoid the crowds

Why won't people shut up.. This has currently a gorgeous collection of Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso etc down stairs but the crowning jewel are the Nympheas or Waterlilies. Try and go when it is not crowded. The people are just too noisy and the guards do nothing to stop them. And these people were certainly not looking at the pictures, it was like they were at a local starbucks, maybe the museum could get a barista, it was truly appalling. I wanted to shush them or maybe start talking loudly to myself but I am not fond of jail

Less hectic than the Louvre!. A small gallery-style with great paintings The Monet rooms were amazing - just sit and take in the magnificence of the Water Lilies - go late in the day to enjoy without too much interruption from fellow travellers
A DELIGHT!. HAving visited Monet's House and Gardens at Giverny, the display at the Orangerie was doubly impressive because we could more easily identify with what we were looking at.
impressionist heaven. Looking for Gaugin, Renoir, Matisse, Picasso, Cezanne, etc, etc? All here in spades with wonderful audioguide (5euros)

Monet Water Lillies. Only thing worth seeing is the Monet Water Lilies. Glad we saw it but not worth it after the Musee d'Orsay which had other Monet work. Luckily it wasn't too far a walk from Musee d'Orsay.

Spectacular array of masters in a beautiful building. We went there today on a wet and cool Paris Spring day. We have been trying to visit for many years but for various reasons like closed for renovations or the only day we had it was closed. Today it was open and for 7.5 Euros I saw a beautiful collection of Monet, Renoir, Cezanne and a number of other Masters. It was easy to find, well run and lovely balanced lighting so the vigour of colours and brush strokes stood out. A stunning experience.

Like Monet? You'll love this place. Strangely enough, we had watched "Midnight in Paris" (for about the 10th time) just before we left on our trip. There is a scene shot in the room with the enormous Monet water lily exhibition. When I walked in, I was overwhelmed with the power and beauty of it. Also loved the entire wall of Renoirs downstairs.

Another good option. Just a notch below Orsay and the Louvre, this is a lovely and simple art museum and a must-see for Monet lovers. The water lillies "installation" is unique and worth a nice, long and quiet look. Since it is open on the day Musee d'Orsay is closed, one never needs to go without a nice taste of Impressionism on any day in Paris.
Monet. Small art museum with Monet water lillies and other artists.Quiet setting. Not much time required to view entire collection.

Surrounded by water lillies. The centre pieces of this lovely gallery are the Monet murals of the water lillies theme. There is much more with a further collection of the impressionists which is excellent. The gallery's setting in the Jardin des Tuilleries is most appropriate.
Musee de l'Orangerie. Loved this museum mainly because there are 2 very large rooms in which Monet's famous pond/garden paintings surround you....just beautiful.

Great museum experience. The Orangerie, in the Tulleries garden, has a very modest collection of impressionist works...except, the two absolutely spectacular rooms featuring huge, oval paintings by Monet of the water lilies at his home in Giverny. These make a visit more than worthwhile.

Monet's Water Lilies. This is a great little museum, with Monet's fabulous murals as the star. Lots of other good paintings. This is easy to get to after you have toured the Orsay, as you just go across the pedestrian bridge and go about a block to the Orengerie.

Love Monet; must see. The line was way out to the ramp from Tuileries Gardens, but I really wanted to see the Monet waterlilies. The line went pretty quick even though it was the first Sunday of the month (free Sundays).The murals are just gorgeous and you can get right up close and personal. If you're a fan of Monet, you should make time for this museum.Downstairs there was some other art that was not too exciting for me.Take your time upstairs -- no photos allowed. This is a very small museum, so once you're inside it's only an hour at most.

i love monet!. i did it just after the musee orsey because i loved the monet painting, do it if you like the best art of monet because its mostly waterlilies, monet paint a lot of that and i didnt know, thats really cool museum, you need to do it if you love monet like me!Juan
Monet is highlight. We stopped in to buy our museum pass but then decided to take a walk-through. Glad we did...the Monet artwork is spectacular!
A Must for Monet. A must if you are a fan of Monet's Water Lilies. A purpose-built museum to display those canvases to advantage. Exhibits downstairs were also good.

A must see despite the queues. Go to this museum in the Tuileries and buy a 4 day joint ticket with the Musee d'Orsay thereby avoiding the long queues that are always the case at the latter museum. The Monets are spectacular and the current exhibition of Italian paintings during the Risorgimento is interesting.

Go!. Take a moment to register the absolute lack of decor as you enter into the Monets. Then take off your tour headphones (quite worth 5e), queue up a little Debussy on your iPod and spend a little time with these beautiful paintings. Currently the Guillame Collection quite worth seeing as well.

Wonderfule museum. Monet's water lilies in the center oval are spectacular. We went early on Sunday morning as it opened at 9am. It was the free Sunday for the first of the month and not crowded yet. The also have a great temporary exhibit by some Italian painters.

A must-see for any Monet fans!. I did not know this place was here until my son informed me, I am so glad I did not leave Paris without seeing it. If you love Monet's paintings, you must experience the water lily paintings in the museum designed for them. Stunning!

A true gem!. This small museum houses a very special cycle of Monet paitings, the Nymphéas, and part of the great collection that belonged to french art-dealer Paul Guillaume. It can be visited in one hour and it is definately worth it!

wonderful Renoirs. The collection of Renoir paintings is worth the price of admission. They are hung so that you can photograph them with great close-up shots. La Niege was my favorite. the is a great Sisley landscape hung with the Renoirs. Monet's Water Lilies are enormous , but they are not S wonderful as the Renoirs, in my opinion.
Museums. Loved the Monet display, well worth a visit with paintings from Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso and Sutine.

Quick trip to Giverny. This museum is the small sister museum of D'Orsay and has a lovely display of Monet's large seasonal murals of his garden at Giverny. Buy the combined museum ticket to see both.

Mix of famuse drawing!!. The museum is near concord square ,smal but has many diffrent painting! The ticket is 7.5 euro p/p for adult ,and child is free ,same more museum in paris. The bad news is information write in french, (same another museum in paris).and english brushure was finished ???I think it is plan to push you to rent a electronic gide device!Now the exhebition of italian painters are done in museum that is so exiting , The painting is so amazing . And it is good chice to spending time ,don t miss it
Small but worth it for Monet's Water Lilies!. You do not need much time for this museum but I recommend that you do not pass it up simply for Monet's water lilies alone - the Nymphéas.

Marvellous Monet. Busy little museum with 8 super large Monets. Lots of romantic Renoir. We had paid for the passport for this and the Musee d'Orsay, but it was free on the day we went! Definitely worth a look. No queues for us.

Not just Monet!. The newly-remodeled Musee is somwhat tucked away in the SW corner of the Tuileries next to Place Concorde, but well worth finding. It offers two attractions: First, two rooms encircled by Monet's massive Water Lilies. Tip: They will mean much more if you bring an explanation - Rick Steves has a good one in his Paris book. Second, the Musee has a fine and manageable exhibit sampling the history of Impressionism from Renoir forward. Even your non-aficianado friend will not get painting-viewing fatigue. Free admission first Sunday of the month - go late.for less crowding.

Small Gem of a Museum. This museum was included with our Paris Museum Pass, but we still had to wait for a bit to get through the security line. When we were there the regular line didn't seem to be moving forward at all, so we were very glad we had gotten passes. I think I got more out of this museum than I did from the others we visited. It is a much smaller museum and so had a much more focused collection. Waterlillies was, of course, breathtaking, but many of the works downstairs were also quite famous and gorgeous. Also, this museum allowed photos (without flash) in most of its galleries (no photos of Waterlillies though).

Expected more. We thought there'd be more Monet paintings. Really, there were just 8. These huge paintings of water lilies were arranged as 4 in each of 2 rooms and although impressive, we expected some of Monet's other paintings too.
Downstairs there are many more paintings devoted to other impressionistic painters.

Monet!. We bypassed the lines to The Louvre (which were at least 4 hours of wait) and were into L'Orangerie in 20 minutes. We bought a combined ticket that included the Musee d'Orsay - I highly recommend. If you like Monet the upstairs is a spectacular delight. A wonderful museum and pocket size by museum standards, which is great!

be engulfed by Monet's garden. This one will not take you long, but you can choose how long it will take you. There are 2 massive rooms that house his enormous water lilies. But go downstairs and you'll find some other very special artwork too. You could do this in 15mins or a good 1.5hrs, but the Paris card will get you in here too so why not?
Worth the trip. We went to see Monet's water lilies, but the impressionist collection downstairs was equally good. This museum is absolutely worth the time and admission price.
Love Monet!. The paintings were spectacular! They were larger and more impressive than I expected! Loved the little shop too!

A Shrine to Monet. An extraordinary experience. You could hear a pin drop in the two oval galleries dedicated to eight of Monet's giant water lily paintings. I've heard more noise in church than I heard on our visit to these galleries. A worshipful experience.

Floating with Monet's Lilies. Attention span too short for the Louvre? Try Orangerie. Lovely big Monet paintings all round that make you feel like you're on a lake island. Realist and abstract art in other rooms for philistines and intellectuals respectively.

The Most Beautiful Renoirs!. Lovely beautiful & manageable museum in the corner area of the Tuilerie Garden at the opposite end of the Louvre. Yes, the room of the Monet Murals is beautiful, but seeing the Renoir paintings downstairs made the trip really worth while. My only complaint is that are no place to sit outside the exhibits if you are waiting for someone except for one small bench at the foot of the steps, where people literally wait against the wall for someone to get up. And while there is an entrance floor where the Monet murals are, a floor that has the museum store and the bottom floor that has the exhibits, the only restrooms were on the bottom floor. The lack of stalls for the ladies restroom was inexcusable and made for a VERY long wait.

Beautiful introduction to Paris. When you just arrive, sleep deprived but thrilled to be in the most beautiful city in the world, get on the enclosed, all glass Batobus, and ride up and down the Seine. You stop at Notre Dame, la Tour Eiffel, le Musee d'Orsay, and 5 other stops. You can make the entire circuit, take some great photos, and be dry, if it's a rainy day. Or you can get on and off as many times as you like. You can also get a pass for several days, using this as a bus.

Small museum highlighting Monet. This is a very small museum found at the opposite end of the Tuileries from the Louvre. The highlight is Monet's 'Water Lilies" rooms created as a tranquil place after WWI. Get the combo pass for both this museum and Musee D'Orsay and save a few euros.
small museum with impressionist. nice small museum - lovely renoirs etc and the big waterlilly paitings by monet. Does not take long to go through the museum

Nice, but not worth the cost. This is a great little museum that is famous for its six Monet waterlilies paintings. They are beautiful, but it's not worth it for the price. I went on the first Sunday of the month, when all the museums are free, and only then would I recommend it.

Second visit just as good as the first. We went to see the painting again as we were going to visit his house and garden the next day. It was great to see the paintings and then visit his house and garden made it all very special.

Think "Musée d'Orsay" on a smaller scale.. This is one of 2 other Impressionist museums in Paris, beside the Musée d'Orsay, that has a substantial collection, the other being the Marmottan in the 16th Arrondissement. There are a significant number of Renoir works and a fair number of Monet and others. Well worth the visit!

Very Good. More art works than expected. We visited to see the Monet which was magnificent but we were surprised that there was an exhibition plus other permanent art on display. Allow time to appreciate it all.
Superb collection. Although every one goes for the Monet Waterlilies, the collection, particularly the Renoir's on the lower floor, is sensational.
Glad I saw it. Not a big place and some odd paintings but it was worth it to see the Monet walls which were impressive. Glad we used the museum pass to get in because I wasn't overwhelmed by it.
Great Museum. It is another classic museum of Paris and one you should not miss. I can spend several hours walking and absorbing the history!

Monet's work well worth a second visit. Love the renovation and art work displays. Glad I could join the shorter entry line with the museum pass at this venue. Not happy visitors are unable to take digital photos without flash.

Amazing Beauty, if you like Monet. Who doesn't like Monet, and his fellow impressionists? On our recent (May 2013) visit the special exhibit on the lower level was a delight of impressionistic art unsurpassed anywhere. The standard display of the Water Lillies always delights, but it is the smaller, more accessible pieces that make the visit truly exceptional. Use a museum pass to skip the lines and enjoy.

A "must" for later Monet lovers, a "maybe" for rest of us. Although they didn't light my fire, I guess it's worth seeing the water-lily mega -paintings, and there is plenty of other stuff too. But if time is precious or it's not raining, you'd do better at Musee D'Orsay!

One of my favorite museums in Paris. Musée de l'Orangerie is a small museum dedicated to huge paintings by Monet. I prefer these small, dedicated museums than huge, overcrowded museums like the Louvre.

Difficult to stand up the the Louvre and the Musee D'orsey. This master work donated by Monet to the city of Paris is almost in a setting too small to appreciate. It is a great place to sit and take in the beautiful colors and try to wrap you head around his "giving up"of the horizon line. The rest of the museum consists of personal collections donated by a couple of people, definitely not up to the standards of the other great museums a short walk away.

Meditation in Blue. Located in Tuileries gardens near Concorde square this is a unique museum (I would call it a Temple) to experience peace and tranquility through paintings of Claude Monet. In two oval rooms there are wall to wall paintings of Monet depicting water lilies (Nympheas) in blue water. The paintings are divine. They are soothing and mystic to take you to a different world. Like sufi music, Monet's nympheas paintings are to be enjoyed in silence and in lonely mood. Lower floors in the museum display masterpieces from the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collection which include works of Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Rousseau, Matisse, Derain, Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo and Laurencin. I recommend that the visit should start from the lower level.

In the backyard... I haven't entered the museum, but I was at a Honda event just outside it. Gorgeous place. Easy to find. I will definitely come back to see the art inside.. I was so riveted by the flora and fauna outside! If you're looking to book an event, as well, please consider doing it here.

Well worth a visit.. We visited this museum by accident. We were checking out the Tuileries garden and realised this museum was included on the musuem pass. We don't know a lot about art but its definitely worth a visit. Our favourite part was actually an exhibition of Italian artworks that is currently visiting on the lower level. The other good thing about this place was that there was no line when we arrived at 4pm in the afternoon.

monet!!!!!. oMG this museum is AMAZING! a must see if you love Monet!!! they have a Wonderful collection of large scale landscape water lillies in two rooms, and the room is sooo calming. its not overcrowded like lourve either, a nice small museum to relax in!
You can do this museum in an hour.. Monet's Water Lilies is a must see and there is seating so you can linger. The rest you can do fairly quickly. Not crowded and not confusing to navigate.

Renoir, Monet, Picasso etc. I great collection of famous artists, with some very large Monet's that are absolutely stunning in a room where the light changes with each passing cloud and the pictures look alive.

Small, but good. The Monet's in the Orangerie are such huge canvases in perfectly designed rooms, give you the illusion of being within the painting. That's just the top floor! The lower floor has some very nice pieces (think Modigliani) that are great to see.

boring, no fun. i got dragged along here by the mrs and wished i had succeded in refusing to come, lots of stuffy old stuff to look at, no interest for me at all, next time i'll stay in the hotel and watch the footie

Not to missed for Impressionist art lovers. The small museum is tucked in a corner of the Tuileries gardens towards Place de la Concorde. Entrance fee is covered by the museum pass. You have to get your large bags (or coats) stored in the cloak room. I highly recommend getting the audio guide, though this will add time to your visit.The gigantic waterlilies in two huge, oval rooms on the same floor as the entrance. Visit these first. There are sofas available for you to sit and just marvel at the artworks. Photography was not permitted, but I should have asked nonetheless. The other paintings are exhibited in the basement. Allow ample time for them. There is also a gift shop.
Ah... Monet!. Prepare to be awed. Standing in either of the rooms containing Monet's "Water Lilies" is not unlike a religious experience.
Surrounded by Monet!. Imagine being in a large room surrounded by Monet waterlilles, with a comfy bench in the middle so you can sit and enjoy the beauty. That's why you should visit this museum.
Manet and others.. Very nice museum to visit. No lines at all. Manet, Soutine, Picasso, and a Special exhibit of Italian impressionists. All outstanding

recent visit. Seeing large versions of Monet's water lillies was a surprise, I thought these would be other artists work, but were actually done by the man himself to give local Parisians a place to relax and enjoy. Yes it was relaxing. Visited using a 4 day museum pass.
Do a double with the d'Orsay. You can save a few Euros by buying a combined d'Orsay/Orangerie ticket that gives you four days in which to visit the latter. One of the better deals in Paris.

Lovely little museum. Orangerie is a must-see if you enjoy Monet and Impressionism. The Water Lilies rooms alone are worth the price of admission, but the rest of the museum's collection is very good, as well. The special exhibit when we visited was "Les Macchiaioli: Des impressionnistes italiens ?", included with the regular admission fee, was fascinating. We probably spent around 90 minutes at this museum. There was no real queue to get in on a rainy May day. If you're already in the area - and especially if you have one of the Paris passes - there is no reason not to check it out!

Monet Lovers will Love it.. You have to love very large impressionist paintings to love the l'Orangerie.( I keep wanting to bring them into focus.) But downstairs is a trove of modern art treasures on a more traditional scale. Many will disagree with me, but art is always a matter of taste. Don;t miss the downstairs galleries.
a let down. Lovely building just off the place de la concorde. Not my favorite monet period but well presented. Not a patch on Musee d'orsay.

Went on a whim -- want to go back. I didn't exactly know what I was going to find but this is one of the most beautifully laid out museums I have been to. It is serene, calm and I will defiintely go back as soon as possible.

Hidden secret. A pretty little gem of a museum that is never crowded (compared to the d'Orsay or the Louvre) that nonetheless has a great collection in a beautiful setting -- both the building and the Jardin.

Terrific little museum. We love Monet anyway, so were eager to see this museum. The water lilies were fabulous, and we were surprised by the extent of the other art in the museum. Very worthwhile. Be sure to get a Paris Museum Pass -- it's well worth the cost to avoid the horrendous lines to buy tickets at the museums; at most places we walked right in, past tremendous lines of those without passes.
Fantastic Orangerie. It is lovely, very peaceful, great value for money, the Monet room is amazing to sit in, you could actually feel that you are on a lily pad, wonderful experience.
Monet's water lilies. A dream come true - to see Monet's gift to the Parisians "in the flesh". It is a different kind of oasis ...

Best way to see Monet's waterlillies. We went on a rainy free late night opening in May and queued for 40 mins. However the 2 large oval exhibition spaces with huge water lily panels are marvellous. The rest of museum pictures also worth seeing.

Oh what joy. No queue when arriving at 12:30pmI make my way down to the lower ground floor and are greeted by a wall of 21 paintings by my favourite artist Pierre-Auguste Renoir. A great feeling of happiness and calm - it puts my world back in balance.The Marie Laurencin room, with 5 paintings was lovely.Amedeo Modigliani was interesting (visited his grave this week at Pere-lachaise cemetery).I never used to 'get' Henri Rousseau and after looking at a further handful of his paintings I still don't!.The 'Classical' section of paintings by Picasso and Matisse were interesting although a couple of paintings for each were away on touring exhibitions. The two Monet Waterlillies Oval rooms were very crowded, which did detract somewhat, however they are still very special.Allow a couple of hours to visit to enjoy the paintings to their full extent.
Lovely. Much quieter than most other Paris attractions. Beautiful works of art and the Monet paintings are truly magnificent.

Small museum you can see in less than 2 hours. We really enjoyed the art here. Good place to spend a couple of hours. if you are a Claude Monet fan then this should be one of your stops. Not as over whelming as other museums.

Gorgeous and underappreciated. Though I have been to Paris, I had never been to the Orangerie - It is lovely - not just the beautiful Monet's that you can practically walk up to - but it is not on most people's "A list", so it is far less crowded than other museums.Definitely worth a visit.
Always lovely. Bright and beautiful. Monet's Waterlilies are always magnificent to see. Lots of other great art, and a special exhibition to boot!

Third visit. Still the best museum in Paris. Their collection is my very favorite in Paris.
Monet's huge Water Lillies and plenty of Modigliani's, Picasso's and Soutine's make this our fave Paris museum!
They always have a great visiting collection! A MUST SEE!
Forget The Louvre. the REAL art is here!

An unusual museum.. You have to see this unusual museum. The Monets are huge, much bigger than I have every seen, and wonderful! They give you such an appreciation for Monet's skills in the last decades of his life.

Even better on Free Museum Night!. We went in during free museum night and it was great! It was so beautiful seeing the Water Lilies the way Monet wanted them to be seen. It was a great trip just before going to Giverny the next day.

Monet's Wonderful Gift to Paris. Of course I had heard of this museum, but it far exceeded my expectations. There was almost a church-like atmosphere in the 2 'Waterlilies' rooms as people quietly contemplated Claude Monet's grand works. While initially disappointed that there was no photographs allowed, I quickly understood how photographers might have spoiled the experience for others (and for me). After feasting on Monet's works, be sure to continue your visit downstairs for the stunning Jean Walter and Paul Guilaume Collection - it too is spectacular!

Beware of pickpockets. Musee de L'Orangerie is a world class museum. There is currently (until mid July 2013, I believe) a special showing of Italian impressionists. Every piece is exquisite. The exhibition is very crowded. I was there in the afternoon. I am usually very careful and carry my purse under my jacket or clasp it in front of me. I am afraid that in my enthusiasm for the great art, I let my guard down and the very deft pickpocket opened THREE zippers to get at my euros. He/she/it got just a few since I don't carry much. Please beware in this and in other museums in Europe... or in any crowded exhibit where people stand or sit very close to you.

Surreal. Small delightful museum on the Champs Elysees - the large, panoramic Monet Waterlilies are just amazing - peaceful and enchanting. Additional exhibits also worth a view - no lines no hassle. A museum visit that was a real joy!
Almost like being at Giverney. Monet's water lillies are better than the real thing - or at least you've never seen them in such a perfect light.

Amazing. If you do one gallery in Paris, do this one. You don't have to be a avid art lover to enjoy the water lilys or the other paintings as there are so many that you will recognise. The audio guide gives you just enough information about key paintings so worth the additional 5 euros. We had a 10-15 minute queue but it wasnt too bad. Loved it.

fantastic museum of art. We had been unable to get into the Louvre (too many people already inside) so we went to this Museum. It was wonderful! Monet's Nympheaus was absolutely amazing. There were also paintings by early 20th century artists. We decided that this museum was one of the best in Paris.

Not to be missed. The Monet waters lilies / waterscapes are almost worth a trip to Paris. The building provides a beautiful setting for these fantastic works of art. In addition to Monet's masterpieces, downstairs there is an excellent collection of other works assembled by Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume. Photography not permitted (previously it was). Well worth a visit!

Marvelous Monet. A must for all lovers of Monet, beautifully displayed in a circular room, with the art "bent" around the walls and the effect creates a special image of his great paintings from the ponds in his house at Giverny

More than just water lillies. My wife and I visited on a Sunday morning. Before we reached the famous Manet rooms, we enjoyed a fascinating exhibition on early Italian Impressionists. The collection of Renoir and Rousseau is particularly good. The 5-euro audio guides let you spend so much time with so many works of art, you'll have to make choices of how long to stay. I'd give it at least 3 hours, and not miss it if at all possible.

A Must for Monet Lovers. This is not one of the typical "must see" museums, but if you are a fan of Monet, it's an absolute must. There are several rooms dedicated to the water lilies and the down stairs galleries have more than I expected.

the best little museum in Paris. This museum is affordable and there is hardly every a line, but that said, it has some of the most outstanding works (by Monet and other artists) in Paris! If you decide to go to the Musee D'Orsay as well, it's worth it to get the joint ticket for the two museums.

Don't leave Paris without going inside. A stunning setting for Monet's waterlilly series - like you've never seen before. I won't spoil it for you. But walking into the purpose built gallery for the first time renders most people speechless. Serene, uplifting, stunning. No photography allowed at all these days - thank heavens. Downstairs an eclectic collection from post-impressionism to mid-20th century, worth a visit in its own right. The Orangerie is at the end of the Tuileries gardens just near the Place de la Concorde. Combine a wonderful walk, or sitting watching Paris out for a walk, in the gardens and then nip into the gallery for mental rejuvenation and visual delight.

another favorite. After visiting the Musee d'Orsay & proclaiming it our new favorite museum, this is a completely different, yet wonderful experience...& now another favorite. The 2 oval rooms 'wrapped' with the gorgeous Monet's are simultaneously calming & exhilarating. Whatever Impressionist paintings that are not at d'Orsay, are here. The private collection on display took our breath away. It's a small & very manageable museum to visit. If it were possible, we'd be there every week!

Another great museum not to miss. Small but dear. Has some great paintings by Renoir Two Sisters and more. Also very very interesting collection and presentation of Italian artist that came to Paris to learn 'the French' way of painting. Very very nice.

Monet!!!. The water lilies of Monet are amazing and worth visiting. These are found on the ground floor. They also host many other interesting paintings including Picasso. It is a small museum and one can visit all the sections in 2 hours. Because of its size I think it is also good for children.

Orangerie, art gallery of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. Beside the two galleries hosting the AMAIZING 'Les Nymphéas' is the downstairs collection displaying Sisley, Renoire, Cezanne, Picasso, Gauguin and until July 22, 2013 'Les Macchiaioli', group of 19th-century Florentine and Neopolitan painters who looked to nature for instruction (1850-1874) such as Florentine Giovanni Fattori, Telemaco Signorini, Silvestro Lega, Raffaello Sernesi and Giuseppe Abbati.I do not recommend it for 'seen it' checked from the list of Paris attractions.We visited twice during the two weeks trip.

giant Monet paintings. If you like Monet just a bit, you need to go! It was in the same park as the Louvre. I actually liked it better than the Louvre. I'm not a big museum person. This was a short & sweet tour. Again, beautiful Monet :)

A beautiful surprise. We wanted to revisit musee D'orsay but that was closed so we went here. A really awesome, breathtaking collection, full of wonderful surprises. Monet is great but the museum offers so very much more. If without a guide, rent one of the iPods, cuts you off from the rest of the public and makes it easier to enjoy.
Impressionists. I am a watercolor artist and admire the expressionists sytle. It was a wonderful experience to be surounded by the soft colors and interesting themes.

made a great impression!!. loved Monet's waterlillies' rooms.
Extra show on currently is well woth a visit.
Skip queues by buying Paris Museum Pass. You can go over bridge to Museum D'Orsay with this pass too.
Great museum. This is a wonderful museum, not to be missed. Monet's water lilies are spectacular, and the venue displays these paintings in a light, attractive setting.

A little cosy but "mustsee" museum. This little museum nicely placed in the Tuileries gardens I probably loved the most among other museums of Paris, even Louvre and Orsay. It is divided in two parts: the upper floor is intended for beutiful and huge masterpice of Claude Monet "Nympheas". The lower floor keeps works of Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Modigliani and his "École de Paris" folks like Soutine or Utrillo and others. It doesn't take too much time to walk around whole museum but it's worth every second.

Small Gallery showcasing Monet's Waterlilies. We visited this gallery on a spur of the moment decision & were not disappointed. Entry was quick as we had not pre purchased tickets. Monet's water lilies paintings were awesome. They are displayed around the walls of the rooms.Two rooms were dedicated to his works & the lower floor had numerous artworks from other well known impressionist artists. No photography was allowed at the gallery.

My favorite small museum in Paris. I have visited the Orangerie many times and it never fails to impress. It is nice a small so there's time to really look at the works without getting overwhelmed. Of course les Nympheas is the big attraction and it is worth the ticket to Paris! I never tire of contemplating the eight mammoth paintings. But I also really enjoy the collection downstairs from the Nympheas. When we visited, there was a very good exhibition of Italian impressionists - beautifully hung and with interesting commentary (in English which was nice!).Highly recommended!

Great finish (or start) to a walk in the Tuileries. We were lucky to have a beautiful sunny day to walk through the Tuileries gardens and end up at this gem of a museum in natures jewel box setting. Just one of the many charms of the thoughtfulness of beauty in Paris.

I macchiaioli. Till September 2013, the exhibit of Italian macchiaioli is not to miss. Splendide, along with the private collections exhibited in the under ground. But, of course, l'Orangerie is Monet.

Only if you really love art.. Don't know what to say without pissing off the art freaks, but honestly, I entered here for rain shelter along with my wife and we both got sleepy... it's painting over painting to the point that the Average Joe who doesn't know much of art (guilty here) ends up seeing the same over and over...
A small but lovelly space. Great to see Monet's Water Lily panels. The line to the entrance was not bad, about 20 minutes to get in. The collections were easy to tour. Not overwheming.

After Musee d'Orsay, the best of all. After you are totally frazzeled by being knocked around by tourists and pickpockets at the Louvre, escape to Musee de l'Orangerie at the other end of the Tuileries Gardens. It is a small museum holding the best of Monet's waterlilies. Get headphones for information on the fabulous exhibit downstairs. You will have few crowds, and lots of time to view and hear about some of the best art in Paris. Just when you think your body has been imprints by the hands of every tourist in the western world, the Musee de l'Orangerie redeems you visit and gives you a new appreciation of Paris' vast collections of great art.

My favorite in Paris.. Go to this after a visit to Giverny. It is amazing and you will have an orientation of having seen the water lilies and the ponds. I was not expecting the wealth of Renoirs and Cezannes and others in the downstairs part. Lovely!

Monet's canvasses as they should be seen. A beautiful gallery that has been sensitively adapted for the 21st century. The art is sensational and this IS the place to see Monet's water lilies as they should be seen. Situated by the lovely Tuilerie gardens, this is a treat to visit.
Tranquil oasis. Lovely gallery showcasing Monet't stunning Waterlily paintings.We spent about 40 minutes here after walking through the Tuillerie gardens. It was lovely and well worth visiting.

Monet's Waterlilies. Not to be missed if you love Monet's Waterlilies! This museum is very doable since it's small but the presentation of the Waterlilies is worth it. They are housed in 2 large oval rooms where you can really appreciate them. There is also a small collection in the other floor, when we were there, there were a couple of Picassos. You can complete your visit here in a couple of hours. It's located at the other end of Tulieries Garden, it you're coming from the Louvre, just walk ahead and it will be on your left, Seine River side.

Second best museum, after the Musee d'Orsay. Smaller museum that had some very beautiful pieces from Renoir. Monet's lilies were beautiful - for those of you that wear glasses for distance, take them off when you look at the lilies. Amazing!

Magnificent Monet and More. This is a must-see experience for anyone interested in the impressionists and Monet in particular. We heeded others’ advice on trip advisor and arrived at the opening time. The opportunity to enjoy the two remarkable Monet rooms in relative silence was truly profound. We then enjoyed a special exhibit of Italian revolutionaries which was well organized and very interesting. The permanent collection is also very worthwhile and would compare with most major U.S museums on its own merit even though it is small in scale when compared to the D’Orsay or Barnes. By the time we left 2 hours later, the place was packed and reinforced our decision to make this our first venture of the day. BTW, ALWAYS purchase a Paris museum pass if you’re serious about managing your experience in Paris.
Perfect. Right sized museum with Monet + other masters. Our first visit this morning and walked right in. Included with Paris Museum Pass.

Outing On A Wet Day. As with the previous reviews, this is the perfect spot to run to if you're caught in the rain, since it's the nearest thing with a shelter while you're at the Tuileries Gardens. This museum is famous for Monet's Water Lilies, which probably covers almost one half of the wall. There are a mixture of famous painters such as Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse plus another handful of which i have never heard of. Pretty shameful, if you were once my history teacher.

Nice but small collection. It is really beautiful this huge Monet painttings, but the the collection itself is limited to a few rooms. I do recommend a visit, but only if you have plenty of time in Paris!

Transport yourselves to Monet's gardens. The building is beautiful, the Monet galleries peaceful and transformative, the basement exhibits packed with varied, interesting works by other artists. The perfect antidote to the grand, massive but crowded Louvre.

Wettest day for 28 years!. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a 'must visit' housing a spectacular range of art from the Walter/Guillaume Collection as well as the Monet Water Lilies set-pieces. A beautifully kept gallery. But....having stood outside 'in-line' for 90 minutes in cold, windy conditions during the wettest Paris day for 28 years our good-will on entry was almost exhausted. True, we should have pre-booked tickets and learned a lesson as countless coach parties were herded in ahead of us. Nevertheless the existence of only two booking desks has to be challenged and there was a definite sense that the external security staff were doing us a good turn by allowing us access. There must be a better way of treating guests especially given that many [including ourselves] were plainly of advancing years and suffering in the conditions. I recognise that there would be a reluctance to overcrowd the gallery but on this occasion common-sense via some management leadership would have been in order.

One of my favourite Galleries in Paris!. I ran inside the Musee de L'Orangerie when the weather turned on me during my meander through the Tuileries. I had always planned to visit the Musee to pay homage to some of my favourites: Monet (of course!) Soutine, Cezanne.Renoir, Matisse and Modigliani. I found myself particularly romanced by the works by Marie Laurencin- What a pleasant surprise! I love the light and airy feel of the Musee, it is a perfect home for Water Lillies. Lovers of Monet will feel their chest squeeze with adoration when staring infront of the moving murals. What a gem, I truly love this place- And the staff are really friendly as well, added bonus!

Best to see impressionist painters and not overwhelming like the L'ouvre. This is a beautiful building as well as a beautiful museum. Long lines to enter - so go early and expect to spend a day if you want to thoroughly go through the museum. Paris is great for students since many sites have free entrance for students though the university.
A hidden gem in Tuilleries. So many times in Paris and I've never written a review about this gem. The Monet's ninpheas show to you that Paris is always worth!

Giverny and The Orangerie. Hop on the train to Vernon. Get on the waiting bus and take it to Giverny.n. From there walk in to Monet's Gardens, the gorgeous inspiration for his gorgeous series on Waterlillies. The next day, wake up, first thing in the morning, ahead of the crowds, cappuccino in hand, take the Metro to the Orangerie. In front of Monet's panoramic Water Lillies, sit on the nicely cushioned couches, and let the colors soak in, as if your bathing in Giverny's waters.

really special if you visit Giverny first. Monet is losing his sight and diminishing in power when he paints these great paintings but they capture something magical.Don't expect to get a cup of coffee or lunch here - no facilities except toilets and no paper in them! Head off to 36 rue du mont and visit Le Souffle - book first -

If you love Monet.... If you love Monet you can't go past visiting the Musee de l'Orangerie. There were no queues and you could spend as much time as you like just sitting looking at this amazing artwork. Absolutely fantastic with artwork from a whole host of fantastic artists. I could visit there again and again.
Monet's Waterlilies. We went there specifically to see Monet's Waterlilies which were just beautiful.You need to sit quietly and enjoy them. Wonderful seeing the real thing.

Water lilies!. Just for the water lilies alone, this museum is worth the ticket price. If you have the Paris museum pass, then it's even a better deal. There are also some beautiful works of art on the lower level. The crowning glory, however, is upstairs!

Monet's Water Lilies. We recently vacationed in Paris and one of our first stops was the Musee de l'Orangerie to see Monet's waterlilies. The murals of the waterlilies are truly impressive. The museum houses many othe famous artists and is worth seeing. Later in our trip, we visited Giverny Village where Claude Monet lived and had lovely gardens and where he painted the waterlilies.

Make your visit to Musee de l'Orangerie REALLY memorable!. If it is spring or summer, do one thing BEFORE visiting the Musee de l'Orangerie: take the short train ride from Paris to Giverny, Money's home and more especially his garden, where he painted all of the wonderful murals you will see at the Musee de l"Orangerie. There you can wander through the extensive garden, have a light lunch outdoors, and a scenic train ride to and from Paris. Then, when you visit the museum, you will immediately recognize the site of each of the murals and appreciate Monet's art even more than would otherwise be possible. These murals were his gift to his nation, and they are indeed wonderful.

A Must See for Impressionist Fans. If at all possible, arrange to go to Giverny before or after seeing these beauties. It will knock your socks right off. My sensitive husband walked into the Orangerie after going to the gardens and was in tears, saying, "Now I get what he was seeing!" It's the reflections and Monet's failing eyesight that are captured so movingly.

Small and perfectly formed!. This is a small gallery I go back to every time I am in Paris. It is never a crowded as the biggies and has large Monet panels of water lilies - worth seeing in their own right but are complimented by the small but worthwhile collection of other artists. If you are a Renoir fan you will enjoy the collection here. This is a peaceful gallery.

Great smaller museum. Buy tickets ahead at FNAC store- they have a ticket for both d,Orsay and de l'Organgerie. Or get the "Museum Pass" for multiple museums. If you have your ticket you can skip the line and go right in.
Simple and beautiful. We went there about 10:00 AM on Wednesday and it was still really quiet. There was no line and no stress. We could enjoy the works in a relaxing atmosphere.
Spectacular. When you see the size and canvases and the impact they have when you are basically surrounded by endless water lillies it is time to sit and reflect.

Wonderful treat after stroll through gardens. I must admit, this was not a planned stop. My husband and I had walked through Jardin des Tuileries and were in need of a bathroom break. We didn't want to use the public restroom so we stopped here on the way to Champs Elysee. WOW what a surprise. Musee de l'Orangerie displays beautiful works of art. You could spend hours here exploring and analyzing the beautiful works of art.
Small but worth it. The best part are the oval rooms with Monet murals. Nice little museum at the west end of Jardin Tuilleries.

Less is More. This is my favourite museum as there are no entrance line ups and you can view the paintings without fighiting the crowds. I love viewing the two circular rooms of Monet paintings. The lower level has many famous artists like Renoir, Cezanne, Sisley, etc. There are no crowds so this is my favourite museum in Paris. Please note: I am not an art critique.

Monet's Water Lilies. This is a great museum in Paris, but it is easy to miss even though you will probably walk right past it. It is located in the Jardin des Tuileries which are the gardens in front of the Louvre. Compared to most museums in Paris the l'Orangerie is small and easily accessible. There are two rooms designed specifically to display Monet's water lilies. The size of the paintings are incredible and allow you to be immersed in the works. There are more impressionist works on the lower level that are worth seeing, but Monet's paintings are the star attractions. Highly recommended considering how quickly you can tour this museum and the significance of the collection. This museum is part of the Paris Museum pass.
Monet and more. Do not miss visiting this musee. It is small, quiet and exhibits some remarkable art. We went twice!!

These waterlilies need to be seen "in the flesh". Monet's waterliles in the Orangerie can't begin to be appreciated in reproduction. You need to experience the real thing. See the paint up close. Sit on the benches and take in the calm beauty. You will come out refreshed and convinced of Monet's genius. Downstairs there was an exhibition of others in the Impressionist circle such as Renior, Cezanne, Marie Laurencin. It's worth seeing but the heart of this museum is the Nympheas.

Another great impressionism museum in Paris. I've been to Musee de l'Orangerie a couple of times. The main exhibit here is of course the water lilies by Monet. They are definitely worth a visit even if there is nothing else here. I've seen thousands of impressionism paintings but never in this grand scale and in this quality. On top of water lilies, there are always some other exhibitions at l'Orangerie. Last time I was there, saw a lot of unfamiliar impressionist, post impressionist paintings and it was quite an eye opener for me. So you really can't go wrong by coming here.

Monet as should be. The collection is very small and the showpieces are the canvases that form Claude Monet's Waterlillies, but you knew that! There are sure to be crowds, but you know that as well. This mustn't discourage a visit to these magnificent works. Admittedly, for me, the remainder of the collection was not nearly so memorable, but I do feel that it will be because the Waterlilies are so spectacular! I found that, strangly enough I was able to step back enough to view the canvasses individually and as a set. I'm not quite sure how the crowds managed to part, but I suppose this is just a way of saying that the number of people were not a hindrance to enjoyment.Stop in even if just for a quick look, and stay longer if the spirit moves.

Great alternative to crowds at Louvre.. We went here as an alternative to the long lines at The Louvre. Short lines. An amazing exhibit of Italian Impressionists! Went back to Louvre afterwards but Musée de l'Orangerie was most impressive.
Worth one hour. Good art. Worth one hour. Take pictures of outside traffic. They will empty the galleries 15 min before closing.

laney48. You should not miss this museum. Use your Paris Museum Pass and enter a museum with fewer people than d'Orssay but plenty of Impressionist masterpieces. The rooms with the Monets are amazing. Then later in the day watch "Midnight in Paris" and you can say "I was there"! Also there are comfortable chairs for a bit of a rest in the gardens on all sides of the museum.

Railings for stairways are appreciated. Too many marble stairs.
There is no self help assistance; small spaces to wait in long lines at rest rooms are difficult for many.
Breathtaking. The Monet rooms took my breath away. The rooms were not crowded so you could sit and enjoy the glory. Worth a trip to Paris

Monet's water lillies. If you are a Monet fan, you must visit the Musee de l'Orangerie! The Monet water lilies are just stunning to see in person. They are breathtakingly beautiful! If I come back to Paris, I will definitely come back to this museum! Even if you are not a big Monet fan, I think you will be impressed by these paintings.
Water lilies!. A small museum but with the Water Lilies it is a real find. Many fine paintings and artwork - would recommend and take a walk in the Tuilleries gardens after your visit.

Don't overlook this one. With D'Orsay right across the river it maybe be tempting to bypass this spot. But it was one of our favorites and a nice small size that you don't get overwhelmed by all the art. We would not have gone here unless we had the museum pass. I'm glad we did it was great.
Excellent. The Monet Nympheas were stunning and much larger than I imagined, well worth a visit. We had a wheelchair but this did not prove an issue and the staff were helpful

Wonderful in Ile St Louis. Last minute reservations could not have turned out better. Ordered from 3 course menu and was not dissapointed. Salmon was delicious. Micheal and staff were so incredibly accomondating and helpful with the english menu translations.

Monet water lilies. I knew about Monet water lilies but everyone should see these painings for real. The place, made for those paintings, makes them even more impressive. Fell in love with the colors and the ambience of this 2 rooms. Without naming the famous other impressionistes paintings in the other rooms. I really enjoyed my time in this museum, for free cause i'm under 26, (really nice to be able to visit any museum here for free, hurry up, my 26th birthday comes soon!!) what should i complain about? ;)
Great Museum.. The Monets are great and the other works as also well worth the trip. Great little museum and just big enough to take an hour or two to visit.

Gorgeous!. This was a lovely museum to visit! When we visited to see Monet's work it was quiet and we didn't need to line up for tickets. It is such a peaceful museum. You can sit on long benches and just take in the paintings. A highlight of our trip to Paris.

Gem of a Museum near the Louvre. After battling the crowds at the Louvre all morning, we took refuge in this exquisite little museum in the Tuilieries Garden. There was no line whatsoever at around 3 pm, and we were able to enjoy the two spectacular galleries in which Monet's Waterlilly murals are installed without having to deal with crowds and tour groups. The Monets are worth the price of admission, but there are also lovely galleries downstairs with a wonderful selection of Impressionists and Post-Impressionists. Big thumbs up.

Stunning collection. A truly amazing gallery. Two rooms with Monet's classic waterlilies laid out dominate the musee but worth taking the time to explore downstairs. Try and get there early to avoid the queues or pre book tickets from hotel or online as there is never a queue if you have tickets and save yourself a wasted hour standing inline outside.

no fruit, water-lilies instead. Don't expect to see any plants here, this is another art museum. You can see Monet's large scale water-lilies series on display (two rooms, six LARGE paintings) and quite a lotof other works in the basement (surrealism, some impressionists, picasso). I was there on the Museum Night, there was a jazz band playing, this really made the visit worth.

Monet murals are amazing but there isn't much else. I recently visited the Musee de l'Orangerie on a Monday afternoon around noon. There was about a 10 minute wait to purchase tickets when I arrived, but the line moved relatively quickly.The Monet murals are housed upstairs in three different rooms. They were magnificant and truly beautiful. There was also a downstairs area with various paintings, but I didn't find them overly interesting.It is worth dropping into this museum if you appreciate Monet paintings.. It is conveniently located in the Jardin Tuileries near Place de la Concorde. Please note that there is no restaurant or facilities for other food in this museum, so eat before you go!
Monet Waterliles and More. The giant Monet canvases are displayed beautifully in 2 large oval rooms. Downstairs there are more paintings by other artists.

Amazing!. I had never heard of the Orangerie art gallery though I had heard of Monet's Water Lilies. But I didn't know where or even what they were. I saw one large water lily canvas in Musee d'Orsay and thought that was it. So I was surprised when a friend suggested I visit l'Orangerie to see the Water Lilies. And then I was absolutely astonished to see what a large and magnificent display it is. I had never imagined anything so spectacular. Like everything in Paris, it was very crowded but the wait to get in was not long and it was well worth it. And then I was doubly amazed to find a large collection of more French Impressionists (and even some Italian ones) in the basement. Wow!
Monet!. Worth a visit to see Monet's spectacular painting! Also, the museum is close to the Jardin Tuilleries, Louve, and famous bridges where you place locks!

If you like Monet, you must come here. One of the biggest collections of Monet paintings reside here. So if you like any of this work - this place is a definite must-visit if you're in Paris. There are several paintings stretching across several meters, not like anything I've ever seen in other museums with Monet paintings. I loved just sitting on the bench and letting the paintings take me away to another time.

A gem. Great gallery. To see how Monet stretched the painting was remarkable. The collections of the other lesser known Impressionists in the lower level was a joy to behold. At 7.50e for admission, this one of the best deals in Paris. Don't miss it. Sit outside after and view the Place de la Concorde from the raised level outside the museum. Really a treat!

ART LOVER BUCKET LIST!. Lovers of Monet must come to l'Orangerie! Don't miss their other collection found on the floor below the Water Lilies....Matisse, Gaugain, Renoir...spent hours here. Then enjoy a lovely stroll in the Tuileries that has its own art collection with the likes of Henry Moore!Know that in buying the pass that includes the D'Orsay as well you have up to 4 days to use...you can not do justice to the two on the same day.
Monet!. If you have any plans of going out to Monet's home in Giverny, you must visit the Musee de l'Orangerie. Exquisite!

Very small Museum (relatively speaking). This museum is dwarfed by the Louvre which is not far away. Very pleasant location in the Tuillerie Gardens. Permanent Collection is less eclectic than others. Best to view special exhibitions here that tickle your fancy
Monet's water lilies. Monet's water lilies - highlight of the museum. Small musuem, easily covered under 2 hours or less. Very peaceful. Not to be missed if you are a Monet lover!

Ahhh - the Water Lilies. I had no idea something as lovely as the Water Lilies was available at this lovely, smaller museum. You can buy a double pass here - for the Orangerie and the Orsay - plan ahead as both on the same day is quite a feat of walking, reading and absorbing the incredible works in both places. There are VERY interesting exhibits in the lower floor of the Orangerie - do go.
It's a really nice museum to avoid the crowd.. My wife and I really enjoyed this museum since it's not so crowded.Half day should be enough to visit it.

Good small museum to visit even with a child. This is a lovely place to start with children as it is not so big and demanding. My 12 years old granddaughter even loved it. I normally visit this almost every time in Paris as the location too is beautiful.

One of the best little galleries in Paris. It's easy to get overwhelmed by the scale of galleries like the Louvre, but the petit Musee de l'Orangerie is just... sensational. If you like Monet, or don't know anything about impressionist art at all, this gallery is the best way possible to experience and immerse yourself in the best of the best. Two 360 degree rooms put you in the middle of Monets water lilly filled imagination and a visit to the gallery can be as quick as 15 minutes, or as long and thoughtful as you like. This place is a treasure, don't miss it.
Just amazing. If the waterlillies weren't enough the standing exhibitions should make this a must see. Add in the temporary exhibitions and this is a not to be missed visit

If you love Monet. After a relaxing stroll through the Jardin des Tuileries make your way to the Musee de l'Orangerie. You will be glad that you did. This is where you will find Monet's Waterlilly panels which he gifted to the French Government with the proviso that they never left France. These were painted in his garden at Giverny, at different times of day. Showing the different shades of light. The Orangerie has been renovated several times over the years. The last time was for six years and it reopened again in 2006. This gives the best possible light for the panels. It is possible to just sit in quiet contemplation on a long seat down the middle of the two oval rooms. If there are not too many people around it is possible to get "lost into the panels" completely. Downstairs is a collection of several Masterpieces that were donated by Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume, which are absolutely marvellous.

Wow!. The main reason I came here was to see Monet's Water Lilies because I have always wanted to see it and Wow! I didn't realize what I was about to see... it was so big and a lot of detail to take in on each wall, absolutely beautiful! You must take time to view each panel and its detail, he was such a wonderful artist. I also enjoyed the rest of the museum, we didn't have a lot of time before it was closed so we didn't get to see everything but I will definitely visit again.

A nice surprise. I knew about Monet's Water Lilies but the other art in the museum is just wonderful. I recommend getting the audio guide to enhance the experience. This was high quality art by less famous artists and I needed more info about them and the pieces.

A must See in Paris for Monet's Waterlillies. You will never see these 8 panels of Monet's waterlillies outside of this musuem. Claude Monet donated these panels to the government with the stipulation that they are put in a special musuem and that they never leave France. They are amazing and just wonderful to sit and reflect on what an amazing artist he was.

Amazing!. Following a tip from a friend, we visited this museum first and bought the combined ticket for the Musee D'Orsay as well to save the long queue there and we were so glad that we did! In a lovely setting, the museum has a wonderful collection of paintings but the Monet Waterlilies are the main things to see. Visit the oval rooms where they are displayed and sit quietly and look at them for a while - beautiful!

Home for Monet's Water Lillies. This is the home of Monet's most famous paintings of water lillies. They are in two oval shaped rooms and the pictures and the serenity of the setting make for an almost religious experience. The museum's lower level presents a fine collection of impressionist and post-impressionist French art.
great find. If you love Monet then this is a the gallery for you. Lot's of his work plus a few Picasso's and some works by Matisse too.
Excellent. Allow plenty of time to just sit and admire the wonderful water lily paintings. Go early to avoid too many people
Cool Art. The Monet was outstanding. Well worth the experience. The rest of the art was okay. It was a good value for the price.

Excellent museum - love the Monet paintings!. This is a wonderful museum off the beaten path in Paris. Worth a stop in to see the Monet paintings and special oval room. Other artists shown in this museum are wonderful, as well. Highly recommend while you are in Paris.

Good follow-up to Giverny. Whether you see the museum first or go to Giverny first, seeing both gives you a greater appreciation of the paintings.If you have the museum pass, this will help you get your money's worth out of your pass.

Water Lilies for the win. I really enjoyed seeing Monet's Water Lilies in their full glory, they really were breathtaking. Sadly, they were the only thing that Orangerie had to offer that I really liked. Either way, it was worth it.

Small but choice museum. The Monets are the stars of the museum of course but downstairs are some other paintings well worth looking at. We went on a free day and the line was not too bad and the crowd was OK, in contrast to the Musee d Orsay which was mobbed.

If you love waterlillies. If you love Monet's waterlillies this is the place. There are rooms with nothing but waterlillies. The rest of the museum is very nice. It is not large and the crowds are smalls so you can easily visit everything in a hour or so.

A Gem in the Tulleries. This is a gem of a museum, located at the edge of the Jardin des Tulleries adjacent to the Place de la Concorde. Monet's Water Lillies would justify the visit by themselves. The museum display of these masterpieces is truly wonderful (probably because the artist designed it). Downstairs there is a nice collection of other art, including impressionists. The building is architecturally interesting, too.But those Water Lillies!
Musse de l'Orangerie. Its simply breath taking. I love the curved rooms and Monet. I like that there is no talking and you can let Monet's paintings sink in.

monetmagic. were really glad we went here. It was wonderful to see the large waterlily pictures in their special gallery. They had a fairly large seat in each room where you could sit to study the canvasses.

Well worth a look. Great gallery. I love the large Monets, but the selection of art works downstairs are also well worth seeing. Much smaller than the more famous Musee d'Orsay, it means the queue to get in is short and it is much easier to move around. Highly recommended.
Very good museum. Nice and small but with some very good paintings. Totally worth it if you have the museum pass and are near the tulleries.
Monet Must!. Do not miss the two rooms of Claude Monet's water lilies. Unbelievable! Try to go when the crowds are small so that you can actually sit and absorb the beauty.
Modern art at its best. Reasonably priced to enter. Lots of paintings by well known artist on view. No cafe on site though - use the ones in the garden before you go in.
Quaint but enough to fill the senses. Great venue for the "nymphs" as we'll as all the other great impressionist masters that I was surprised to see. A must go!

Great if art floats your boat. Free on first Sunday of the month. Expect a 30 minute queue on Sundays. Money not Monet does it for me, however my wife did like the Monet and most of the other exhibits. Wide variety of artists. All exhibits are underground - such a pity the building is called the Orangery! I spent about 2 hours following my wife around.
Small and wonderful. Well worth a visit if you want to see Monet but dont want to walk around the larger museums. Paintings were beautifully displayed took my breath away.

Get the package deal with Musee d'Orsay. I was happy to see the "Waterlilies" since the trip was wrapped up in the package ticket. This was a good deal. I was happy that the Orangerie had more to offer then the Waterlilies the post impressionist in the basement floor were worth the trip as well. Great smaller museum!

Go for Monet's Water Lillies. We came here just for the Monet Water Lillies rooms. I love how uncrowded this museum is. The Water Lillies rooms were just stunning - my jaw literally dropped when I saw them. I could sit there and stare at them for hours. I didn't know if I should sit and stare, or get up close and look at his brush strokes. Highly recommend this museum - can be visited in less than an hour. I only saw Monet. Oh - and I used their toilets - which were VERY clean!

Extra-special Museum: Intimate galleries, Outstanding Artworks. The Musee de l'Orangerie is one of the most unique museums in Paris. Two oval rooms with natural lighting present large-scale Waterlily paintings (one on each of four walls) for your contemplation, meditation and review. Centered seating areas allow you to absorb the beauty and scale of the artworks at your leisure. So much of visiting Paris museums involves a rush, crowds, expenses of energy - the Musee de l'Orangerie forces you to slow down, breathe and admire the expert work of Monet's large-scale paintings. Downstairs there are additional galleries, and a gift shop. Entry is usually quick, with included entry at no additional charge if you have a Museum pass (highly recommended). Similar to "boutique" hotels that offer a special and singular experience, this is a "boutique" museum - Highest recommendation.

Beautiful little museum. The circular rooms displaying Monet's waterlilies in a panorama are a must-see. I was incredibly impressed with the current special exhibition, from April 10 to July 22, 2013: "The Macchiaioli 1850-1874. Italian Impressionists?" The permanent collection is also definitely worth viewing.

Monet's garden murals. I was very moved by the 4 giant paintings that were a gift from Monet to the people of Paris. There were many people in this very large room with seating in the middle of the room Everyone was quiet and inspired by the paintings to meditate and slow down, rest and contemplate. It is one of my favorite museums now. Definitely worth a visit.We went after we visited the Louve in the morning.
Pretty much just the Waterlillies. This is a quick stop while you're in the Tuilleries on your way to the Louvre. Don't go here unless you've already got the Museum Pass so it doesn't cost anything.
