Priceless. View eight of Monet's Water Lily panels in rooms designed by Monet to display the panels under natural-diffused lights. Truly awesome\!

Breathtaking Experience. I was so bowled over by the Orangerie and the Monet's Waterlilies that I had to put a review on Trip Advisor! Whatever you do, do not leave Paris without visiting this museum - it's wonderful just to sit in the middle of the room gazing at these paintings!

Monet's Waterlilies!. Small uncrowded museum with plenty of eye candy. Monet's Waterlilies are displayed in two rotundas, designed by the artist for the purpose of viewing the art. We so enjoyed the quiet space for contemplation. The museum has its own fine collection of art on permanent display, and during our visit there was an exquisite collection of Italian Impressionists display downstairs. The museum is on the Paris Pass. Do not miss this special treat..
If you have to pick one museum this is it.. The Monet waterlillies are not to be missed, and there are a lot of other wonderful paintings to be seen. The temporary exhibits are good as well.
Wonderful exhibitions beautifully hung and lit.. No queue, and galleries not packed with people so time and space to enjoy pictures at ones own pace.

Monet!. I would visit this just to see Monet's work in the oval room and paintings by Renoire. Absolutely captivating. Their selection isn't as huge as d'Orsay or the Lourve. But quantity shouldn't be taken as quality.

Monet's waterlilies are superb.... ... but if time is at a premium, avoid the downstairs collection as there is far better in the city. Take some time to 'drink' in the waterlilies and find out all about them as they exude a meditative calm. The 2 rooms of Monet are easily 5 star - the toilets let it down - no toilet paper or hand towels and a huge queue.
The wonder of Monet. If you love the artist, Monet, you will never be the same after witnessing his works in this museum. The extraordinary lily pad paintings of Giverny are spectacular.

Renoir and Monet - a pleasure. We visited this museum because it was a rainy Monday and most of the museums were closed. It's small, but has some wonderful Renoirs and Monet's huge panels of water lillies. If you are tired of the large crowds in the Louvre, head here.

Monet waterflowers in a museum. Small intimate museum- after our visit to Giverny this was a treat to see the waterflower paintings displayed to great effect. As opposed to the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay, not crowded and plenty of time to sit and enjoy the artwork.

Water lilies!. We went after going to Giverny to see Monet's Gardens. The museum was not crowded compared to the Louvre and Orsay. The museum pass is accepted. Don't stand inline, push your way to front and show them the pass, you go right in. Lovely museum. And there is a wonderful temporary exhibit downstairs of the Italian Impressionists, beautifully lit.
Unexpected delight. I did not know much about this museum and found it to be an unexpected delight. Many wonderful impressionist painting were so nice to view.
Great Monet Murals. Well if you like water lillies as seen by Monet the enormous canvasses here are absolutely worthwhile. It takes less than 1 hour to see and its great.

Musée L'Orangerie. Always one of my favorites, this museum boasts not only the 8 water lily murals but an excellent representation of Cezannes, Renoirs & Laurencins to boot. Givre yourself a good two hours to see & appreciate it thoroughly!

Monet is always inspiring. This relatively friendly priced museum gives a brief overview of impressionists, with the number #1 highlight being the Nympheas of Claude Monet. They are wonderful, inspiring and perfectly lit by daylight. Definitely worth a visit.
Water lillies are stunning. The water lillies exhibit was breathtaking. Also, a great place to buy your Paris museum pass so you can skip the forever long lines at the Louvre.

magnificent. After bursting out in tears of happiness when I first time viewed a painting of the litlle Giverny Japanese Bridge by Claude Monet in the musee d'Orsay, After being touched by the Nymphea painting at the MoMA in N.Y. and crying of exaltation when I visited the Giverny gardens, now it was the muss de l'Orangerie's turn to make me grab my handkechief. When you know what Monet's quest was, not painting the objects (anyone can paint a pink dot and say it's an waterlilly) but trying to paint the sprakling reflections of light, capturing the moment and show on his canvas the matter in between his eye and the object, then anyone that sees this paintings will be emontionally grabbed by this work of art. Don't watch to close, just sit on the bench and let the paintings impress you'll be hooked forever. You'll notice that after seeing the four paintings in the second hall and return to the first, it seems like the first four paintings have changed, due to the fact that you perception has changed. The other works of the collection are nice but nothing can impress you after seeing the eight Monet's. Therefore I advise to see the collection in the basement first and after that as an apotheosis visit the eight Monet's.The estimated time a visit takes you is difficult to say. We've stayed over three hours. This time took us to see the Monet's twice and get the full impression to realize what an effort it took and what an achievement it was to create this paintings. If you're not so much of an art-lover and don't want to study Monet's work and life, it probably takes you less then an hour.
Too pack. It's a small museum and it was packed when I visited today. I couldn't stay long as I felt warm and hard to breath. Too many people walking and noisy hardly can sit and admire the painting.
Perfect afternoon stop. It wasn't crowded at all, and you don't need to spend much time there to see Monet's famous paintings of his garden.

One of the main places to visit in Paris. What a wonderful place ! We've visited Paris many times in the last 25 years but this was our first time at L'Orangerie. So peaceful and calm. Really worth seeing.

Great but not very mobility - customer-friendly. My 85 yeqr old Mother and I went to visit L`Orangerie which was the one place she really wanted to visit in Paris. However no lift (acenseur) or escalator (escalier roulant) was evident and there are a lot of stairs to go down to the second gallery. By the time we had looked at Monet on the ground-level floor and seen part of the floor below, she was exhausted. I asked for the use of a wheelchair, which they had, but because I did not have photo ID with me (passport in hotel, other ID stolen in Nice), they just would not allow us to use one. I offered to leave my watch and camera as security, but no. Even though to exit we had to go right past the desk where this discussion was held. This meant we could not see the whole museum which was so disappointing. Shame on you, L`Orangerie. Otherwise I would definitely encourage a visit. Small but full of magificent art. Entry is 7.50 Euros.

Very enjoyable. The main attraction of this museum -- the Water Lilies -- was a bit underwhelming. Maybe it's because the rooms were so crowded and noisy. But the rest of the collection of Impressionist paintings was fabulous. The size of the collection is very manageable, so you can see and enjoy it all in a couple hours. There was an excellent special exhibition as well. If you are short on time and you want to see a good Impressionist collection, go here! The line was much shorter than at d'Orsay. If you want to see both, go to de l'Orangerie first and buy a passport ticket for both museums, so you can skip the ridiculous line at d'Orsay.

Monet's paintings are not to be missed. This is always one of the highlights of my trip to Paris. I could sit in front of The Water Lillies for an hour and not tire of them. I saw the studio where Monet painted them and the gardens which inspired him in Giverny, in the Northwest of France which makes the appreciation of these paintings deeper.

Ahh water lilies. A wonderful experience to just sit in the two big rooms of Monet's water lilies ... so peaceful. Then on the lower level a lovely collection of Renoirs, Cezannes, Picassos, and other impressionists. A wonderful small museum.

Don't forget the audio guide. An amazing museum. Most breathtaking rooms with the water lollies paintings. The audio guides are most informative. Please make some time to enjoy the paintings with the explanations. Superb museum.

Go early, sit and watch the paintings shimmer. We have been to Paris several times but for some reason have not been here. Suggest you go early and spend 1/2 an hour or so in each of the two Monet rooms looking at the 4 huge paintings in each room. They change with the external light and sitting down and contemplating them is worth it. It was not very busy early. If crowded, the experience would be significantly diluted. The rest of the collection has some interest but the Monets are the stars for their size and quality.

A museum designed to display Monet. This is a must visit. The museum has been remodeled numerous times but always has been a place to spotlight the Monet water lilies. Two exhibition rooms surround you with the series of water lily paintings. The rooms are large enough to get a panoramic view of the murals, yet you can get within arm's reach and be amazed at how the artist could possibly see the big picture as he was painting so close.Downstairs is a wonderful exhibit of impressionist paintings. They also have periodic special exhibits.

An overlooked museum. This is a great little museum just across the River Seine from Le Musée d'Orsay. I've gone there on each of my last three visits to Paris, and have not had to line up for more than 15 minutes. The first section, on the main floor, is composed of two oval rooms, the walls of which feature Monet's water garden. It's a gentle reflective space. Downstairs the collection of Impressionist Paintings is surprisingly large -- the museum seems quite small from the outside. It's well worth a visit, and gives you a nice bite-sized portion of world-class art.
Amazing. Great museum for a few hours away from the hustle and bustle of the louvre. Great art. Make sure to visit the circular room with Monet's lillypad painting. Simply wonderful!

Be literally surrounded by Monet's waterlillies. The highlight of this museum is the large, central exhibition room which surrounds you with 4 very large paintings of Monet's waterlillies. It's almost a spiritual experience. The museum also has a permanent collection of impressionist paintings (especially Renoirs) and has traveling shows. The one that I saw (Italian impressionists) was amazing. A nice museum to visit if you are already at the Tuileries or the Louvre, and worth making a special visit even if you weren't going to visit the Tuileries or the Louvre.
Stunning. The highlight is the two round rooms each simply painted white and each containing 4 different panoramic Monel water lily paintings. Stunning.

A Wonderful Presentation of the Masters. Monet, Cezanne, Gaguin, Picasso and many more, they are all here and beautifully displayed .The layout is great and viewing easy and comfortable. A Paris must see!

Favorite place in Paris. This little musee is an absolute gem! We went there after spending the morning fighting crowds at the Louvre. It is an easy walk from the pyramid through Jardin du Tuilliers to amazing views of place du concorde and hidden amount these sights is musee de L'Orangerie. Monet's Les Nymphs is breathtaking and as a lifelong Monet enthusiast it brought me to tears to behold it in person. A must see!

Frustrating. Too much waiting, too much people inside, too little works on Monet. We had a high expectations to see that museum but it's popularity turned to chagrin. The great master pieces of Monet were almost invisible behind of human wall. If you see long queue, go to some another time... Otherwise I loved another paintings in that museum but the purpose of the visit was to see Monet.
Great Monet Waterlilies Murals.. The exhibits were excellent. Best and Largest collection of Monet's waterlillies. Mural size. Museum is a little hard to find but worth it if you are a Monet fan.

Compact treasure. The works of Claude Monet (Water Lillies) is breathtaking.It is a small beautiful collection that includes other impressionists. It is small enough that it does not overwhelm you with the size of the collection. Near the Plac d'Concorde for great views and a rest.

Worth a look. Musée de l'Orangerie is definitely worth seeing if you are a Monet fan or if you are looking for something that is not terribly crowded and doesn't take too long. It's a particularly good way to follow up a visit to Giverny, as you can visualize the gardens as you sit in the oval rooms that house the impressive Water Lilies displays. It's easy to get to, nestled in the Tuileries at Place de la Concorde, I would recommend it.

Spectacular museum. If you like Monet, this is an absolute must!! We spent over an hour just in the two rooms with the large paintings. It is so serene. Enjoy a busy day in Paris and then come here to relax and enjoy.

Go here before you go to Giverny. Good compact museum near the Gardens Tuileries. Takes about an hour but, the real reason to come is the Monet Garden Curved panels on the top floor. It is exciting to see the painting and then visit the inspiration in Giverny .

Italian Impressionists. As well as the Monet's and the rest of the wonderful permanent exhibition, there was a special exhibition of "Italian Impressionists". Quite wonderful, and a terrific insight into the visual art aspects of The Risorgimento

Delightful!. Top Tip - visit this museum before you go to the D'Orsay and buy a joint ticket for both museums, it means you do not have to join the large queues at D'Orsay - the entrance to the right there is for you! Orangerie is a small museum but very delightful. The Monet display is very relaxing and the main feature but there are plenty Renoirs, Cizannes, etc to see also. An easy art museum.

So glad to have discovered this. We have been to Paris a number of times and thought we had already seen all the usual tourist spots. When we go these days it is usually for a specific purpose like business or to attend a concert. So, it was extremely pleasing that we came upon the Musee de l'Orangerie during a leisurely afteroon stroll. The gigantic multi-panelled Waterlilies of Monet was so stunning and the other exhibitions were all impressive as well. Nowadays I go to this Musee and the Musee d'Orsay whenever I can just to see again these fantastic masterpieces.

waterlillies. just a small wait to get in. Paintings fab. My kids are not great at massive galleries that take weeks to get round. This was perfect, in and out in an hour, without painting overload for them.

Great audio tour for my 11 year old. She was mesmerized by the paintings. And the special audio tour for her age really engaged her! The Monets are dazzling, and you will have trouble remembering what time it is. Fortunately, your child can't go anywhere. And will come away in a different "state of mind."

Concentrated for your enjoyment. Musee de l'Orangerie is a small museum at the edge of the Tuleries Gardens. It houses the large water lilies panoramic panels by Monet. They are mounted directly to the wall in an oval room with natural light. Monet actually donated the painting to the museum himself and was part of the design team that designed the room that they sit in today. I got the feeling that I was sitting in a room with not only the artists work, but the artist himself. It was a sureal feeling. I only wish I could sit in the middle of this room by myself. I think about the people that work there and envy the semi private time they may get with the paintings and I wonder if they appreciate that privledge. There are many other great impressionist artists displayed here and very much worth the trip. You can do this museum and the gardens and Rodin all in the same day. This museum is also included on the museum pass. Take it in and enjoy these paintings but you cannot take photo's of the lilies, so make sure you burn the images into you brain to recall later. There are plenty of other artists as well such as Renoir, Cezanne and my personal favorite, Matisse.

Monets lilies. I enjoyed Monet's Waterlilies displayed as he had intended them, but the rest of the museum was a miss in my book. Thank goodness I did not have to stand in line because I had the Paris Museum Pass.

"Très Relaxant !". I have to admit that before being taken to this gallery by my girlfriend that I had never heard of it before. Yet, during our four day visit to Paris we ended up visiting twice! I was so taken in by the relaxing atmosphere and beauty of 'Les Nymphéas'. These masterpieces of Claude Monet are something to both admire and behold, which allow you to escape to hustle and bustle of the metropolis around you.Overall, I would encourage everyone who visits Paris to visit this attraction at least once.
Small museum - great modern art. So worth going. From Monets water lily murals to other significant modern artists showcased pieces. Small but breath taking.Highly recommend

Worth a visit. A must for Monet fans who want to see the rooms designed to house his water lily paintings. You are not allowed to photograph these, but photography is allowed in most other places as long as flash is not used. The other paintings are interesting and well lit. The whole place is a pleasure to visit.

Less famous than the Louvre, but well worth seeing. Visited this because it was highlighted by a tour guide - and glad we did. Amazing, huge waterlilies by Monet - two whole rooms of them. Just sit down and drink them in!
Brilliant. Great. A worth while visit if only for a short time. The Claude Monet water lilies were a highlight. Definitely recommend

Monet water lilies and more. The Orangerie, situated on the edge of the Tuilleries, was built originally to house a number of very large water lily paintings by Claude Monet. They cover the walks of two rooms and are truly a delight to view. As if that weren't enough, the museum also has a modest sized collection of other impressionists that are well worth the trip all by themselves.
Good Italian Impressionist exhibit. very good collection of Italian Impressionist paintings. Doesn't take too long to get through the exhibit.

Worthwhile museum. I live in Paris and feel that this museum is worth a visit for any tourist or resident. The paintings from Monet's "Water Lilies" collection are the key attraction of the museum, however it has an interesting collections of other works as well. The museum is in the Tuillieries gardens and next to Concorde so easily accessible. A worthwhile museum visit

Small - but perfect - big hitting!. Visited this museum as had been to other larger galleries in Paris previously. Found it to be very good, both for art lovers and those with a casual interest. Was €7.50 adult entrance. Lover floors had lots of mini exhibitions and a number of works by Picasso and Renoir but the icing on the cake was seeing Monet's water lilies! Spread over 2 huge rooms were 8 huge paintings - never seen any painting so big - so impressive! Worth the entrance alone. Museum was small but great not to get lost in loads and loads of irrelevant works - this was efficient and very enjoyable.

Wow, How did I miss this on earlier visits?. This was tagged on to my obligatory visit to Musee d'Orsay right across the River Seine. It's a jewel! All that's said about Monet's Water Lillies below holds, only better in real life. Great lighting! The additional impressionist painters adds well to those across the river, almost on the same scale. From April 10-July 22, 2013, don't miss the special exhibit of "The Macchiaioli 1850-1874 Italian Impressionists." They are good counterpoints to the French Impressionists. You may like them and you may not. You can spend between an hour or two here comfortably.

Amazing Panels. This is were you see Monet's water lillies and they are impressive. We used our museum pass again and were equally delighted to see the art in the lower level after viewing the master's great works in several room on the main floor. Contemporary structure and another terrific place to go.

Peaceful experience in awe of masterpieces. We lined up early to ensure we were at the front of the line, we entered quickly and went straight to the water lilies.....how incredible they are and we were fortunate to have them to ourselves for a good few minutes.Having grown up with Monet paintings as prints, it was incredible to enjoy these paintings and the sheer size of them, honestly reviewing them doesn't do them justice - just go and see them!The gift shop has gorgeous prints, some of which I hadn't seen available elsewhere.From here your not far from Angelina's (tea rooms) so pop across the road and indulge in a hot chocolate it die for!

One of the best museum experiences ever!. Impressionists and post impressionists represented in a beautiful setting. I fell I'm love with Renoir again. The museum is very comfortable and allows you to view at your own pace.
My most enjoyable museum experience in Paris. Breathtaking Monets stretch accross entire oval walls of the exhibit. The museum was built for the art, which I thought was unique and beautiful.

Unimpressed. The water lilies didn't do it for me though I admit they are displayed exceptionally well in natural light, perhaps it was because it was a dull day, perhaps they had been over hyped for us or perhaps it was because it was quite crowded who knows. Maybe I'm just a Philistine! Would have thought it a waste of money if we hadn't had the Museum Pass.

Not only Monet Water Lilies but other Works of Art. Water Lilies is the main draw at the Orangerie but there is also a nice collection by classic and primitive artists including Matisse, Picasso, Renoir, Cezanne, Utrillo, Rosseau, Modigliani and Signorini (wonderful!). The Museum is located on the edge of Tuileries Garden where you can walk the park grounds and may want to stop in at one of the cafes or the ice cream stand nearest the Museum (all flavors and they design the ice cream to look like a flower sitting in the cone).

Very good for Expressionism lovers. The Orangery is a special museum, with a lovely display of the most known expressionist painters from France and western europe. The building inside is divided into 2 main sections - the famous "Water lilies" section, and general section. The painting everywhere are special and breathtaking. Included in the Paris museum pass.

Another favourite and must see if you like Monet. This is another of my favourite museums in Paris, probably #3 after Musee Rodin and Musee D'Orsay.The star of this museum is the 2 oval rooms of Monet's waterlilies on the wall. Monet gifted the panels to the people of France before he died. If you look carefully you can see the joins of the different panels. This is a must see if you like Monet since the impact of being surrounded by waterlilies is fantastic.This is on the edge of Jardin des Tuileries and next to Place de Concorde. Spend a little time in the Jardin after.

A favorite!. Just might be my favorite art museum in Paris. Besides the large Monet water lilly murals, there are many Renoirs , Picassos, Cezannes and so many other must see paintings in this very cool space.

Claude Monet's Waterlillies. This is my second visit to this Museum and just as I expected I had the same reaction. The size of these paintings are amazing and the colors are vibrant and cool at the same time. The rooms they are displayed in are a perfect setting to sit and admire these paintings. I love the Impressionists and Claude Monet is my favorite. They also have other Impressionist paintings displayed downstairs.

Don't miss this museum. The Orangerie still houses the Nympheas by Claude Monet, but they are now on the main floor level and the light coming into the room is brighter than when they were downstairs There was a very good special show on downstairs when I went. In addition, the Paul Guillaumin collection is now housed there, and it's a large collection of turn-off-the -Century art work by the likes of Picasso, Matisse, Soutine, Modigliani, Caillebotte, Renoir, and several others. This work was in a private collection until recently and it's a very good record of that era of painting.it's a small enough gallery to comfortably see all the exhibitions in one visit.Take note that it is difficult to find a good place to have either lunch or coffee in the surrounding area. All cafes and restaurants are quite distant from it.

Small but worthwhile. Great little museum tucked right near the Orsay. Nice collection of impressionist works, and enjoyed a temporary exhibition of Italian art. Well worth combining with a picnic in the Tuileries.

Lovers of Monet. Seeing the museum in 1970, again in 2013 and it holds the impact of the beauty of Monet. Very impressive size paintings and the impact is unforgettable. Wheelchair accessible is helpful.

Busy but peaceful to sit amongst the lilies!. This is a small museum so it doesn't take long to go around. It's a must to see the Monet's famous series of paintings in the oval shaped rooms designed for them. Great location too. Over the river from the Orsay.

Magic and a real treat. Having been to the Musee D'orsay the previous day, we wanted more and to see the large Monet water lily paintings . These large canvases were beautifully displayed in two large oval rooms and are well lit, demanding time to sit and view. Overall, a must see for me when in Paris.

Worth a quick visit. At only 7.5 euro I'd say this is worth the trip, but how much you get out of it probably depends on what you think of the giant Monet murals that make this place famous. For me, seeing them in person was nowhere near as impressive as his other (smaller) works. There are some beautiful Renoir's though on the lower level. The line is usually short or non-existant, and this is still a nice 45 minute detour while strolling through the Tulleries.

A must for Monet fans. Loved the rooms purpose built to display Monet's water lilies. Captivating!
Check out the gardens, on a clear day lunch at the cafe in the park is divine and it is fun for people watching too. :)

Breathtaking. A must see!
The Monet painted oval rooms were spectacular.
I did have to queue outside in the rain for 30 minutes to get in, but once I was in I forgot about the annoying weather.
Really enjoyed the galleries downstairs too.

Monet and others. Monet's water lilies wonderfully presented. Also good selection of other artists downstairs. Well worth it and don't miss the Rodin outside! 7E50 or joint ticket with Musée d'Orsay 16E ( cheaper separate if you use Eurostar offer of 2 for 1 at Orsay assuming still available)
Wonderful. Just give yourself enough time to absorb the Monets as they are in my mind the most precious pices of art in Paris!

My favorite. Nothing comes close to the Orangerie. From the fabulous water lillies presented in an ideal setting, to the breathtaking permanent collection downstairs, this is my favorite museum in the world.

Monet Murals = Lovely!. Every time I go to Paris, I need to visit this place. The Monet murals are just stunning and you could admire them for hours I am sure. I love how light this place feels and despite it being free to enter on this particular visit (first Sunday of the month!), it was not overly full of tourists. In addition to Monet's Water Lilies, there is a fantastic collection of works by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo. Well worth a visit!

Don't miss! Well-curated so magnificent. The Monet room recharges and refreshes.. WOW! It is a wonderful collection by French artisits, starting from the room where the Monet works are placed. I could stay there for at least 15 minutes, possibly more, just absorbing, taking all the beauty in. I have been here three times- and will not pass up a chance to see it again. With the bigger museums, after about two hours or so, art-fatigue or visual fatigue sets in.With the collections here, you just have enough- it is so well-curated. Do not miss!

Wonderful Monet landscapes. This is a small museum near the Lourve close to the Place du Concorde at the end of the Tulleries. It has a great two room Monet that covers the large oval shaped rooms walls.
Observe the Monet!. Not as good as the Orsay, however worth it for the Monet Lily's. Allow an hour, no queues when we were there.

Monet,Renoir and Cezanne. A gem of a collection, wonderfully presented and not too many to fit in on one visit. Vast Monets displayed in two oval rooms, downstairs Renoirs, Cezannes and many more modern French artists. Very friendly and helpful staff politely keeping order! Queues on entry were not long and moved quickly.
Lovely museum. Great exhibition. Great selection of art. Centrally located. Good gift shop as well. Do not miss! Should be part of everyone's tour of Paris.

A beautiful space...and not overwhelming.. If you haven't been, you must go. It's a little heaven after the over crowded Lourve. The space is tranquil and absolutely wonderful. You can be in and out in 15 or stay for a couple of hours, depending on your mood. If you aren't much of a museum person, go to this. It won't kill you.

inspiring Monets .... a compact well-designed (modern) museum housing 8 inspiring Monets (giant-sized) which alone warrant the price of admission, not to mention the great number of Renoirs, Matisses and more ...
For the quality of art, quite worthwhile to visit ..
A must for Monet Fans. Excellent museum and not as many crowds as the other more well known. Lillies by Monet just amazing and the perfect setting he created, magnificent.
Small but spectacular. What a great museum, right in the heart of Paris. Very small, but the two rooms with Monet pictures are outstanding. A nice respite from the crowds at the Louvre.

Excellent - I could go again and again. This was one of my favorite museum/art places. What a magnificent display of Monet's Nympheaus. I would highly recommend the Musee de l'Orangerie. It is a beautiful little gallery minus the throngs that queue at the Louvre.
Absolutely stunning.

Monet's Massive Murals are Here!. Probably the main reason to visit L'Orangerie is to see the massive Monet Murals but it's not the only reason. The lower exhibition spaces feature other fabulous french artists. For a low impact museum visit L'Orangerie is the ticket. It's nice without being overwhelming.

Too noisy with school tours. It was difficult to enjoy the Monet rooms with 30-40 teens conversing with their friends..not sure what the best time to avoid them..I was there 4pm -6pm.
Though you will not see this presentation of lilies anywhere else!
Surrounded by water lillies. Go if only to sit in an oval round with the 4 paintings of Monet's gardens. The fact that the museum is in the Tulleries Garden only adds to the experience.

A short, magical visit. There aren't too many pieces on exhibit there, but everything that's there is truly a gem.
And the two halls dedicated to Monet's water lilies are like a magical portal, traveling into his dreamy world.

A great surprise. We visited this gallery just for when we had a short time to kill. Will defiantly visit again as there is so much to see. We thought it was only Monet but in the lower level there is a treasure trove of art.
A must visit when in Paris.

Fantastic. Small but perfectly formed - this is a wonderful space in which to admire some truly outstanding art. The relatively small size of the gallery makes it easy to take everything in, which makes it more suitable for children than some bigger collections.

Excellent. Wonderful small museum, with superb paintings without the crowds and queues. If you don't want to overload on art then this is the museum for you. The highlight of the museum is a series of large Monet paintings housed in there own rooms.
Not to be missed

Orangerie Museum. The museum is located close to Louvre.
it's better to buy tickets in advance, expecially during holiday time, to avoid the queue. At the desk you can find guys that don't speak english. So prepare to speak in frech. No baggage inside, backpack on the front (not on the back).
Price 7 euro on march 2013

Magnificent Water (Lilies) Feature.... Being in proximity to such other amazing venues, Musée de l'Orangerie seems to be on the "if we have time" list for many visitors and that is a shame, as the main oval galleries are stunning spaces displaying Monet's Nympéas in the manner he intended. If it was in just about any other city, it would take pride of place.SURPRISING: The paintings are apparently glued to the walls to achieve the curvature. This explains why they were not in a vault during WW2 when the Musée was hit by shelling. One of the canvas sports a large (well disguised) patch - keep children occupied by challenging them to spot it.ADVICE:1) The galleries downstairs are not very well signed, don't miss them.2) EU citizens 25 years old and under- You can get into the Musée free if you have photo ID with your age on.3) Entry is free to all on the first Sunday of each month.4) The security will let you through carrying an umbrella, but not mention you should then leave it at the cloakroom. Museum staff will escort you from the premises with much Gallic arm waiving and excitement, if you are found in the galleries with one (as my dear wife will attest).

Go early. We went early and were able to see the pieces with only a handful of people in the space, by the time we left only 2 hours after opening the place had a pretty long line and several school trips.

Loved the Water Lilies!. Very small museum. The Water Lilies took my breath away. We went with our children (ages 7 and 10). I could have sat there for a long time but the kids whisked me away. The display is amazing.

Enjoyed our time at Musee de l'Orangerie. We always enjoy the beautiful, huge Monet Water Lily paintings, but we also love the other paintings. There were several Renoirs, as I recall. Musee de l'Orangerie is a wonderful stop after a trip to Giverny. In addition to the wonderful museum, they have a very nice gift shop where I bought several small gifts to take home, as well as a scarf for myself. It's much nicer than some of the gift shops in museums. I also love the setting, in the Tuileries.
Monet at its best. the best two hours you can have- Monet water lillies and a side exhibet wit Renoir and Cezanne. Great value, great art, great natural light.

Wonderful Monet. This is a small art gallery with impressionists and others. Upstairs, two large oval rooms house Monet's beautiful water lilies murals and it was worth the visit just to see these. i also enjoyed the Renoir paintings in the basement gallery and there were others in various styles.

Magnifique!. Delightful day with an unexpected bonus viewing of many of the master painters ever born, not just Monet, such as Renoir, Matisse, Soutine, Gauguin.....unbelievable. So worth it and get the museum pass, super easy access!

Stunning. The highlight from an art point of view of my visit to Paris. We went on free Sunday so added bonus. You might think 8 paintings from one artist is not worth making an effort to go and see but they are so beautiful and displayed in such a way that it gives the feeling of being underwater - the colours are vibrant and soft at the same time. Fantasies are made of this.

L'Orangerie. D'Orsay on a smaller scale. Only one or two examples of the best of impressionist art instead of ten to twenty. Still the Monets are worth the visit. And, afterword you can stroll the Tuileries. Perfect as an adjunct to the d'Orsay.

A cute little museum, with the gorgeous Water lillies. Seeing the Water lillies by Monet and knowing that he gave them to the city of Paris to promote peace. The museum is not large compared to Orsay and Louvre and we spent about 1 hour here. it is close by transport and you can get crepes from the nearby stands just outside the gardens. I love the gardens too, and you can easily combine the Louvre, Tuilleries gardens and the L'Orangerie in one session or day.

Been to d'Orsay, then cross the Seine to double your pleasure!. Having spent several hours with the Impressionists in the Musee d'Orsay you must not miss the opportunity to double your pleasure, by visiting Monet's Water Lilies, et al.

Nice Museum but Unfriendly Security. The museum itself was great - some wonderful impressionist finds downstairs and of course those gorgeous Waterlillies upstairs. But the security desk ruined our visit. My husband and I both had backpacks and coats. We were checking everything and the coat check lady was confirming that we were not leaving cash, passports, mobile phones or cameras. We said no. Then my husband mentioned that there was a laptop in the smaller bag. She absolutely went livid. She made us take it out of the relatively small backpack. I asked her what I was supposed to do with it. A skinny little Mac! She said I had to take it with me. So I asked for the backpack to carry it in. She said no. It told her it was ridiculous so she became angry and sent me to security. He said I had to carry the laptop because no bags are allowed in the museum. I gave up and carried my laptop around with us. However, there were many people with many sizes of bags in the museum, so why I had to walk around carrying a laptop I could never figure out. As nice as the museum was, this incident soured it for us.
Small but Nice Art. A small gallery with some excellent artwork. Museum shop is small too - mostly just books on sale. Children were free.
Beautiful. Not to be missed! It was busy but very peaceful. A place to sit and contemplate the art. To see Monet's waterlilies so close up was amazing

Well worth a visit. If you have a limited time in Paris and don't want to spend a hour upon hour trudging around the Louvre, but still want to see some great art, then l'Orangerie is the place for you.Included in the museum pass, we were able to beat the crowds and walk straight into the exhibition. The two main rooms on the ground floor each house four wall-size Monet waterlillies paintings - even the children were impressed!Don't bother with the collections down-stairs, unless you really are an aficionado of early 20th century art.

The waterlillies. It was wonderful to experience this first hand. On the day we were there it was the 1st Sunday of the month and this is the day that many museums are free so the area was crowded. It would be nice to have the oval rooms to yourself to experience these wonderful pieces but i guess that is unlikely to happen. However everyone in the rooms was very respectful of each others experience.

Monet Waterlillies & More. I recently vacationed in Paris with my daughter & spent about an hour at this museum. The waterlilly paintings by Monet are spectacular & worth the price of admission alone. But you also have many more paintings in the lower level that are truly beautiful. Highly recommend.

Perfect sized art museum. One of my favorite museums in Paris. Come here early to admire Monet's Water Lilies that occupy two rooms, one signifying dawn and the other dusk. I bought my admission with a group ticket with the Musee D'Orsay, which allowed me to skip the admissions lines and go straight to the security line. Its other permanent works are wonderful as well. Metro is nearby and you can walk across the Tuileries to Angelina's for hot chocolate or lunch!

My favorite Museum!. We didn't plan to go to this museum but it was on our museum pass. What a wonderful surprise. Compared to many of the other museums we went to it was not crowded and we did not have to wait in line. The two rooms that each held four wall size Monet waterlily pond paintings were amazing. The light in this museum really enhances the experience. Should not be missed!

Slightly less wonderful than Museum D'Orsay, but still wonderful. This museum is near Musee D'Orsay and contains fewer paintings, but some truly magnificent ones. Also, it is less crowded than some other museums.

A modern art treasure. Impossible not to remain in awe of Monet's Nympheas, located in a circular room designed as Monet himself had intended for his paintings: try to arrive early and avoid summer months, sit on the benches in the middle of the room and take it all in, the filtered light from the open ceiling above makes the paintings come alive: there is truly noything like it elsewhere.

Love Monet. Second visit loved it even more this time. Wait of less than 30 mins to get in. Wonderful building light & spacious & elegant. My teen daughter loved it also we are not arty but the Monets are just superb. we paid extra for the audio guide which was worth it for the extra info on the excellent collection on display. we spent 3 hrs there & really could have stayed longer, wonderful to walk in the gardens afterwards.
Monet!. What a delight to sit on a bench and lose yourself in these timeless bits of loveliness. There is an impressive collection of other works downstairs as well that should not be missed.

Beautiful Monet!. Two rooms with immense Monet waterlilly paintings makes this a real must-do if you are in Paris. Right by Place de la Concorde, this museum isn't nearly as crowded as the others, but it still has some wonderful artworks, particularly Renoirs and some avant-garde artists, along with special exhibitions that are included in the ticket price. Great place to visit!

Picture Perfect. Why fight the lines and crowds of the huge museums, when this little gem has the same big names and more! I ahve been to Paris nearly 2-dozen times and I never miss this museum. The little Marie Laurencin "corner" with my favorite Chanel portrait is amazing. After the museum you can take a walk in the Tuileries Gardens.

What a wonderful gem. We were told about this by a couple we met at a street cafe and what a wonderful tip it was. This museum is quiet and completely underrated. The space is incredible and the art work awe-inspiring. A must if you love Monet.
Attractive scale.... This is the size of collection which you do not have to spend several days to take in. Attractive presentation in an attractive building.
My favorite space in Paris!. It's built as a reflective space, so it's quiet, and all about the Monet murals. Plenty of space to sit and admire his last gift to Paris.

waterlilies is worth a visit. the waterlilies exhibits are unique - nothing quite like it anywhere in the world. although, there were too many people in there to view comfortably, on a monday in april, mostly school kids. the paintings are not protected in any way, only a matter of time before a kid brings down a priceless painting.
Great!. To the lovers of impressionism and great painters, such as Renoir, Monet and Picasso, it's a great option for an after-lunch walk, considering its calm and usually not crowded environment!!

Love it!. The staffs were keeping the place quite so we could view the artwork in a good surrounding. The gift shop was a bit pricey and not the best quality. Would recommend anyone who loves Monet's Waterlilies. It's worth a visit.
Great paintings to view. This is Gallery was very reasonably priced, and you could take you time looking at the paintings. You could sit and take in the lovely surroundings.
Lovely. Nice little museum with no queues which is something in Paris. Not too big to be daunting. The Monet rooms were wonderful to sit and enjoy.

Immersion in Monet's Water Lilies. If you are a fan of Claude Monet, do not miss Musee de l'Orangerie. Sitting on a bench in two different galleries, surrounded by four enormous curving Waterlily canvases is truly unparalleled. For those who are overwhelmed by Musee du Louvre or even Musee d'Orsay, you will appreciate the smaller, more intimate setting of l'Orangerie. It has other works by Renoir, Picasso, Modiglian and additional masters from 1870-1930. My daughters and I had long dreamed of seeing these larger than life paintings by Monet and so it was truly a special to treat to sit surrounded by his masterpieces. Photos do not do it justice. Take a break from walking, rest your feet and enjoy the beauty in this gem of a museum just off the Tuileries gardens.
Paris. small but a must to see if you like Monet. It won't take long to go thru and if you don't get the museum pass I believe that you can combine this with the Musee d'Orsay
Monet for everyone. It was amazing to step "inside" some of Monet's water lillies. A small, well-curated museum. Worth the visit, especially if Monet rings your bells.

Small but lovely. If you like Monet, or if you don't know much about his work, this is a great place to start. The museum doesn't require a lot of time and is well situated in the Tuileries. Lots to see in the area.

Two jewels, Monet above and post/impresssionist below. I was expecting the amazing Monet exhibition, and the opportunity to view the lilies at their best (there are today around 275 "lilies" around the world, but none so stunningly presented). But finding out that there was an amazing personal collection of post/impressionist art on the lower floor was just the icing on the cake. Take advantage of coming in at the last hour: numbers drop off, and so does the price. Alternately, buy the two-fer ticket shared with de Orsai Museum.
A must see. One of the smaller museums we visited, we quite liked the collection and recommend a stop here. Again, go early and avoid the crowds.

If you appreciate Monet, you must visit.. Monet's water lilies around the oval circumference of a hall on two levels... if that does not intrigue you, this may not be for you (but I would encourage you see it anyway).I love Monet so this was a must see -and I was awestruck. The detail on such scale is so impressive and even if you just sit on the bench and contemplate one of the more beautiful scenery paintings you are likely to see on a life size scale. We went as par of our museum pass but I think it was about 7Euro anyway - there are other exhibits and a gift shop that was very well priced with interesting items I did not even see at the Louvre - it seemed to have a lot appropriate for children.This is unlikely to take more than 2 hours of your time.

Why is this my favourite gallery in Paris?. Every time I go to Paris, I cannot miss this gallery. Can't imagine not going to sit and gaze at Monet's Waterlilies. They are set, in two enormous rooms, in the round. So you sit, surrounded by all this impossible beauty, and you feel ... calm. There is a real sense of hush in the room. Even children tend to quieten down when they are there. If you have any sense of romance, or nostalgia, then Renoir's works will enchant you. Perhaps you remember his painting of two angelic looking girls sitting at the piano from your own youth. He captures a time, and a place, so beautifully. Yes, this is a Romantic Gallery, capturing that moment, that split moment in time before the world erupted into the chaos that was the early twentieth century. This gallery would transport even the hardiest of souls. That is why I keep on returning.

Beautiful!. Not too expensive, and no lines! Monet's Water Lilies are so calming, and the history of the museum collections is quite fascinating. Tip: Buy tickets to the l'Orangerie and d'Orsay together, and buy them at the Musee l'Orangerie! No (or very short) line at l'Orangerie, and you can then skip the long line at Orsay!

A nice relaxing museum to visit. This museum is quite small compared with the Louvre, but that is part of what makes it so nice. It has the beautiful Monet pieces, but it also have a nice collection of other artists. It is well located and worth a quick visit. I only wish that the museum had more information about the original purpose of the building to house the orange trees of the royalty.

Small but certainly worth a visit. This isn't a large museum but for me that is a positive thing as it allows you to fully appreciate the excellent quality of art on show without getting 'art overload' as can happen in the larger museums. The basement floor of the museum contains a significant number of works from impressionists such as Monet, Cezanne, Picasso and Matisse to name a few. The entrance level contains Monet's famous Water Lillies. A couple of hours will provide a good amount of time to spend without rushing.

Spectacular Monet.. This has to be my most favorite museum I think on my recent visit. It was not crowded. Not a lot of walking but I could have sat and looked on Monet's painting all day. The whole museum gave me a sense of peace and I truly enjoyed each and every painting. Well worth the visit - a must see on your visit.
A LOVELY MORNING. No lines made this morning event even better. We had all the time we wanted/needed to spend in the galleries mesmerized by the artwork. What a lovely museum!
Lovely museum. Lovely Museum I loved the artists on display it is a pretty small collection great time filler between events. I really enjoyed the sculptures outside.
Great for Monet lovers. Small but well worth the visit in a good location near the Place de la Concorde. Small queues, titles in French, seating area good to absorb the paintings

Excellent Small Museum. This was a great place to visit. It is small and easy to get around in. The paintings were Monet, Renoir and a few more. Lovely. The gift shop had great items. The restrooms were sparkling. There were no crowds. It is located at the end of the Jardin du Tuileries, right before the Place de la Concorde, on the left hand side as you face the place. I think the fee was 7.5 e per person. The staff was very nice to us.
peace and tranquillity. Worth a visit just to experience the peace and calm created by the huge, stunning waterlily paintings, incredible.

One of the most ignored museum gem in Paris. If you like small, not crowded museums devoted to Impressionism, you will love this place. The Monet murals are enhanced by the new natural light, it is simply amazing. The only downside would be the museum shop, but you can find similar articles in any good library.Don t forget to enjoy the Tuilleries gardens.
Bijou. Don't raise your expectation too high, but great if you want a glimpse of the Impressionists to fill the odd half hour.

Stunning. Brilliant collection of art, with the highlight being Monet's amazing work. I was familiar with them but to see them for real was a highlight of our trip to Paris. Take time to sit and marvel at Monet's works but also explore the lower floor where there is a collection of other classics.

Wonderful art. We visited this museum and were blown away by the wonderful art we saw, especially Monet's Water Lilies. We did not have the time or the energy to do the larger museums and this was perfect - enough to see and enjoy, but not too exhausting.

a small restful museum. This was my favorite museum in Paris. Who could not be awed by 8 huge Monet canvases in two oval rooms, with comfortable seating in the middle. The downstairs museum has a nice blend of other works. There are clean bathroom facilities. Overall a very refreshing stop.
Museum terrific. Museum shop awful. The artwork itself is terrific. We particularly liked the Monet murals. The shop is a ripoff--identical books can be had for far less elsewhere.

A Gem of a Museum. I've always loved Monet's Waterlilies, but when I found out that there is a museum dedicated to them I just HAD to go! There is something breathtaking and stunning about the presentation. I could have sat for hours and stared at these murals. If you are a fan of Monet or the Impressionism period, you absolutely must visit this one! Plus it's right by the Louvre so you really have no excuse.
Great Visit. Beautiful rooms with the wall sized Rodins. Wished we could have taken photos. Wasn't too crowded when we were there.

Don't miss the downstairs galleries. The Monet water lilies are beautiful, but it's more of a place of worship than a gallery. I actually preferred the collection downstairs. And the museum building itself is just amazing.

A gem if you like impressionists. We were overwhelmed by the beauty of the waterlilies by monet. The lower level had more incredible impressionist art work. I would always visit this museum when in Paris

Great paintings but small musuem. I enjoyed the museum, but I didn't think it lived up to the hype. The museum is very small and depending on your interest you can see the whole museum in 60 mins. If you are a Monet fan ( i am actually), and have the museum passes then consider it. Otherwise there are many other sights to see in Paris.

L'Orangerie is amazing!. First of all, before or after, check out the tiny ice cream stand near the musee de l'Orangerie(jardin Tuileries). The ice cream is shaped like a flower!! No lines outside and the paintings and sculptures are AMAZING! Great place to check out art with your family and friends! Also, if your interested in the musee d'Orsay, get a double pass when you buy your ticket. That way you don't have to wait in a big of a line.
My favorite musee in Paris!. It is a must-see if you love French Impressionism, again and again and again! The paintings are beautiful and inspiring.

Quick visit.. It was hard to spend a lot of time here; very small. Beautiful Monet paintings for sure. It was funny the way the security guard SHHUSHED everyone when the talking got too loud! Very pretty but 30 minutes was all we needed upstairs; easy to spend more time downstairs and in the gift shop.

A gem. The Monet Water Lilies were breathtaking and the Paul Guillaume collection was awe inspiring in its depth of French Impressionists and Post Impressionist. A MUst.Ps. Get the combined ticket that gives you entrance to the Musee D'Orsay as well. Not only is it good value, it saves you queueing at the Musee.
Terrific museum, but can get crowded. Very peaceful showing of Monet's water lily murals. Lots of other impressionists, too. Right at Tuileries Gardens.

One of the best kept museum secrets in Paris. This is a great little museum. Monet's Water Lilies here and presented beautifully. Other artists include: Modigliani, Renoir, Matisse. This museum doesn't have the crowds that the Louvre or d'Orsay have. Very accessible and can be seen in 1-2 hours, which is great if you have kids in tow, who may have only a passing interest in art.
Monet Everywhere!. The musuem is small and only takes about 1-2 hours to go through. Great collection of Monet and wonderful exhibits of Renoir, Picasso, and other similar time period artists.
Don't miss this impressionist gem. the monet waterlilies, done in two oval rooms, is worth the price of admission alone. the extensive lower galleries are full of gorgeous work. indulge your senses!

Beautiful, thoughtfully presented art. My last visit to l'Orangerie was a number of years ago, prior to its complete renovation. It was enjoyable then, but what a complete pleasure it is now!Monet's "Nympheas" (water lilies) now reside on the ground level, with well thought out natural light showing them off to advantage. There is plenty of room to sit and ponder or walk along right next to the paintings to see the technical details of Impressionism up close and personal. During my visit, French elementary children were sitting on the floor of one hall creating their own masterpieces with crayons, while an English-only tour was on in the second hall. There was still plenty of room to enjoy these amazing works completed by a true master at the very end of his life.The Paul Guillaume collection downstairs is also well presented, again with enough room to enjoy the many paintings by Renoir, Modigliani, Derain, Picasso, Cezanne, Utrillo and Soutine (if anyone can call looking at Soutine's work "enjoyable"!). A few nice Matisses, and lots of Rousseau, filled out the well-known artists represented. I was particularly taken with the work of Marie Laurencin, whose subjects included combinations of women, music and dogs (since I am a woman musician who likes dogs, this struck a chord!)There are in-house tours in English, children's programs, and audio guides, making this small gem of a museum very user friendly. It is also included on the Paris Carte Musee pass, as well as pairing up with the Musee d'Orsay for a "two-fer" reduction.The location of the Musee de l'Orangerie makes it great for combining with a visit to any number of other attractions/activities, from the Tuileries Gardens to Angelina Cafe for hot chocolate. Highly recommended!

A who's who of painters. Forget the louvre and just come here. Monet, Matisse, Cezanne, Picasso all in one place and without the crowds. Just sit and enjoy the Nymphaes (water lillies) in peace and quiet.

A less crowded alternative.. We loved the impressionist art at the d'Orsay but it was very crowded. L'Orangerie has great art in a quiet location, including Monet's huge water lily canvases. Bonus - the Museum Pass works here.

Love the impressionists.... Athough very small, we felt like we could spend far more time here, than we did at the Louvre. Loved sitting in the Claude Monet rooms, absolutely breathtaking. Well worth the visit!

Beautiful museum. This museum is small and easy to manage. All of the art is beautiful. Especially Monet's Water Lilies. I recommend going early when it's not crowded to view and appreciate water lilies.

Overpowering Monet and other abundances. The two oval rooms dedicated to and displaying Monet's monumental Nymphéas (water lilies), one on each wall, it's almost too much too take in. It could be advisable to visit during the period when the sun is high as the natural light floods in from the well-designed oval, light-filtered roof windows. A tip to get the best effect is to stand by one of the entry/exit points and scan the room from here. If you are lucky you can sit on the central bench and get a visitor-uninterrupted panorama, for a few seconds at least.The rest of the museum is also a delight, particularly strong in Renoirs. Also some nice Modigliani ( a great portrait of the collection's patron Paul Guillaume), Derain and Cezanne
Awesome!. Great museum ! -Especially, the gallery with the big paintings.And also the movie (Midnight in Paris) was filmed there :-p

Small museum. Beautiful rooms with Monet's waterlilies. This is great to visit after Musée d'Orsay as it is a few minutes walk. It only takes about an hour and it is really enjoyable to see the large Monet waterlilies in two large oval rooms.

Wonderful. Obviously the big draw here is the Monet, paintings which literally take up the whole of the top floor of this museum. Try to go when the museum is quiet to truly benefit and appreciate these amazing paintings. Sit down and just relax, taking in the view encircling you. You do need to be a fan of Monet, for me these works of art are magical and the space in which they are displayed is perfect.

Lovely collection. They fast tracked me through the massive queue because a security guard spotted I was heavily pregnant which was a nice touch. I actually preferred the collection on the ground floor to water lilies. Although they were beautiful the amount of people in the room meant looking at them wasn't particularly serene. Go early to avoid this. Good value.
Did not live up to the hype. The water lily paintings are obviously very good works of Monet, but I guess we were underwhelmed because of the packed crowd and ambiance of the venue.

The best place to visit in Paris ever. Wow. Amazing. Gob stopping. Go go go go. The wrap around Monets are amazing, then downstairs you can see Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso and all the other major hitters. It is a truly amazing place to visit, the best in Paris. Enjoy!

Small enough not to be tiring. Small enough museum not to be tiring. Situated in the park of Louvre. Likable paintings by Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso,Rousseau, Matisse, Derain, Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo and Laurencin and of course the Nymphéas by Monet!
Nice museum. We were there last November for a Soutine exhibition which was quite nice. The surrounding gardens are beautiful,

not to be missed!. If you only have a day or two in Paris, and a fan of Monet, definitely pay your visit!! The centre piece is Monet's water lillies...amazing!! They also have audio guide available! Love it!
Impressionism!. Let not my three stars deter you, if you are a fan of Monet. His eight water lilies paintings are the centerpieces of the Orangerie. To me, they were ... "fine!"

Monet and Renoir Galore. This gallery is a must for fans of Monet, his colossal Nymphéas are not to be missed and are well worth takiing some real time to contemplate. Downstairs is the Jean Walter and PaulGuillaume Collection containing Renoir, Cezanne, and Picasso amongst others, these are well worth viewing but I think there are better examples in the Musee d'Orsay across the river.

Small powerhouse. I've been to Paris several times, but this was the first time visiting this museum. It's small, and so easy to navigate, but packs a punch, with Monet's nympheas (waterlilys) in panorama, plus works by many other masters, including renoir, cezanne, picasso, and others. Most of the works are also on audioguide, so you can learn a lot about the art and the artists. I enjoyed this much more than going to the Louvre again, which killed my feet the day before.

Amazing works. The large scale water lily paintings by Monet are a absolute must see. They also have quite a good collection of other paintings, in a more intimate and pleasant setting than some of the other, larger museums.
Another wonderful museum. It is well worth the time and in our case the wait to get in. Again as with much in Paris it is well worth it to get here early

short and sweet. I got the double ticket (good for d'Orsay also) and was happy I did. Where I spent three hours at the d'Orsay and knew I could have spent much more time, one hour at the l'Orangerie was fine. I know that sounds crass, but after seeing du Louvre and d'Orsay, I was burnt out as there was so much to take in. It was nice to spend a relaxed time looking at the Monet water lilly paintings. At other museums I kind of rushed myself -- not so at l'Orangerie. Was a very nice hour spent and also after the museum getting the view down the Champs de Elysee was very nice.

Still a gem!. Love this museum. Small enough to feel personal, large enough to cope with the crowds drawn to its many famous paintings. The Monet Lilies are viewed with what seems to be unusual respect - not mirrored in the Louvre, for example!

Amazing place to see Monet's paintings and more. This is one of my favorites museums in Paris. It's small enough to stay focused and admire all the collection. Monet's paintings are exceptionally breathtaking.
Perfect for Impressionism lovers. The work of Monet gets his highest level at this small but amazing museum. Don't miss even if you have only two or three days.

Beautiful exhibits, easy to navigate. Being a Monet fan, I had to visit this museum. My friend and I really enjoyed the paintings. It is not a large museum, by museum standards, but what it is missing in size is more than made up by exhibits!

All about the Waterlilies. The two rooms of waterlily paintings are wonderful. The comparison of paintings from different artists by theme is also very effective. The museum has very few works on display, however, so it is all about the water lilies.

Another must see. Go if you have time - if only to see Monet's Water Lilies in their defined setting. The remainder of the collection is pretty awe inspiring as well - Modigliani, Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse etc.

You are strongly urged to check Monet's waterlillies. Enlarged since our last visit which was at least 10 years ago. A light and airy lower floor shows works from the collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume in series of themed rooms: Tutelary figures (Renoir/Cezanne), The Modern Primitives (Rousseau, Modigliani (one of the highlights for me), Laurencin), Modern Classicism (Matisse/Picasso), The Return to Order (PIcasso/Derain) and Turmoil and Bursting Experience (Utrillo (my second highlight) and Soutine). The upper floor was designed by Monet himself to display at best advantage 8 of his monumental studies of water-lillies. They are stunning and are arranged to give the feel of the passage of a day from sunrise to sunset.
Breathtaking Monet paintings!. Amazing, great small gallery to wonder around in an hour. Monet's waterlily paintings were wonderful to see.

A must for Impressionist fans. Made a return vist recently. The Monets never fail to impress and the setting is perfect. The exhibition downstairs comprising works by Renoir, Cezanne, Sisley, Picasso, Derain, Degas is equally impressive. A nice smallish gallery that doesn't tire you out

Wow!. The huge paintings are beautifully displayed on the curves inside the Orangerie. This gallery only takes a short time to visit so if you family are 'allergi' to art galleries' you can probably get away with this one!
Wonderful museum. Don't miss the Musee de l'Orangerie when you go to Paris!! The Monet's are spectacular and the space is lovely.

Monet Murals are Beautiful. The set up is very nice in this museum. The two rooms for the monet water lilies are wonderful. The downstairs was laid out nicely, but I really didn't care for Guillaume's collection on the whole.

A small gem. The Orangerie is a small museum, on a corner of the Jardins des Tuileries across from the Place de Concorde. Its main attraction is Monet's huge canvases of Water Lilies. The panels are displayed in two rooms, each with four panels streching around the oval room (pre-Disney 360 degree theatre). It's a stunning experience. Below is a collection of a variety of Impressionist and early modern masterworks. A visit can be brief, yet will be rewarding. Get the Paris Museum pass if you're going to do several museums there -- you'll avoid the lines and save some Euros.

Monet Waterlillies a must see!. Imagine two rooms specifically built in a museum to house the Monet Waterlillies paintings. The experience was truly overwhelming for my wife. I took several pictures of her looking at the paintings, since she was so in awe of them. The viewing of these paintings was a must see on our Paris visit and they didn't disappoint. There are low benches in the middle of the rooms so you can sit and soak them in. Plan your visit so you have time to sit a spell and take in the beauty.

Monet at his best. Really the only reason to come here is the Monet display. The 8 canvases displayed in their own rooms are amazing. Amazing! They do have some other works downstairs but it really only took an hour to get trough the place.

Favourite museum in Paris. If you like Impressionism, you'll love the Musee de l'Orangerie. It's significantly smaller than the Louvre or the Orsay, so it's not nearly as exhausting. Monet's water lillies are wonderful, but the downstairs paintings are also incredible.
Simply beautiful. Not huge but not a problem. Its a true art experience. You cant appreciate this from a book or online. This is what art is about- truly moving and not to be missed
Wealth of art. Very helpful staff especially at audio guide desk advised us we would only need one guide which saved us money, well worth having very informative. Monet rooms are just breath taking

Water lilies by Claude Monet.... ...Are the main attraction to this little gem of a museum. Paul Guillaume was a French art dealer....specializing in Soutine and Modiglianii, Matisse, Picasso to name a few....his personal story is fascinating. It is a gallery of impressionists and post impressions and known mainly for the eight water lily murals by Claude Monet.

When you're too tired for a big museum.... The Orangerie is the perfect place to go when you're too tired or short on time for a big museum. There are two large oval rooms covered in Monet's larger-than-life waterlily paintings (8 total), plus a downstairs exhibit hall with a nice collection ranging from Renoir to Picasso. It's quiet and restful, and borders the Tuileries, a great park for all ages. Allow an hour, or if you love the quiet peace of the waterlily rooms, maybe longer.Arty kids will like the un-rushed pace of the place, especially since there's not too much walking. There's an excellent playground (really great for big kids, like 6-12 years) in the Tuileries if they need to burn some energy off first.

Awe-inspiring art, beautifully displayed. This gallery is the perfect size for the quality of its collection. The works are displayed extremely well. You can appreciate the art in a calm environment, rather than in the frenzy that some of the larger museums suffer from.
water lilies and so much more. THe presentation of Monet's masterpiece is in itself a masterfiece. Do not miss the tour de force of paintings of the period on the LOWER floor.
Beautiful. Monet's iconic masterpieces. Much larger than I had thought! Not too crowded with visitors and so plenty of room to just sit and enjoy these most beautiful of paintings.
If you have an hour to spare this is well worth a visit. Interesting Monet exhibition but downstairs there is a space for different exhibitions. We had an hour to kill and this was perfect for that.

I love this place. It's small but every piece of art is amazing. It is easy to navigate and the audio tour is great. I learned so much here and found an entirely new group of people to read about. I am not a huge museum fan so it really is amazing that I enjoyed it as much as I did.
Monet,Monet. From outside a ver unassuming building,very modern entree,then you go thro a small entry and it hits you .....a oval room with Monet water lilies all along the oval walls,amazing

Monet's best art. Monet's finest art is here. At total, that's eight of his water lilies from all his life periods, before the beggining of his blindness and close to it's end. I believe these are his biggest portraits.

Wonderful - don't miss it. This is a beautiful gallery - a good size, not daunting like some of the larger galleries. The highlight, of course, are the Waterlilies which are hypnotising. It was quite quiet when we were there so it was easy to find a seat so we could see them properly. The downstairs galleries are also fantastic - Matisse, Derain, Cezanne, Renoir....

very impressive. it was my first visit to the museum, and i did not expect such a great impression after visiting. this museum is well known because of Monet, which is really very good, but:there is also the simply amazing collection on the first floor. the only recommendation is to go there in the early morning to enjoy it.you can find there the pictures from Utrillo, Sutin,Renoir.... simply the great pleasure!
Expected more. Personally, I didn't think the Monet works on show are the best of his works, a bit disappointed, but I suppose it's a matter of personal taste!
Beautiful water lilies. The water lily rooms are absolutely stunning. A small museum, but nonetheless, very interesting works available for viewing.
Worth a look. A rare opportunity to discover "live" 22 paintings executed by Chaïm Soutine a Russian Artist (1893-1943)

Small Museum but worth visiting. The superstars are The Nympheas but the Renoir Collection and other impressionists worth the visit. You can buy a Passeport Orangerie-Orsay for 16 Euros and you visit both permanent collections within 3 days. They are very serious about the prohibition of photographs at The Nympheas room, but you can you your camera everywhere else.

Monet's vision. Most of the big museums are so full of magnificent art that it becomes overwhelming at some point. The beauty of this small museum is in the vision Monet had to display his thirty-year work. His design of the interior had only one purpose in mind and that was to showcase his masterwork in the best possible way. Mission accomplished!With only a few other distractions in the lower gallery ( worthwhile ones,of course) you can fully focus on his waterlilies and not feel you have to rush off to see anything else. Sit. Absorb. Lose yourself in the immenseness.Or scrutinize the details. Take the time to let it all sink in before stepping back out into the" big world "outside.
Impressionist Heaven. If you like Monet, this is a MUST; Excellent flow and plainly great space. Better if you are in a "quiet" mood and want a museum that will not overwhelm you
OMG!!!. The the the best gallery we went to. 5m paintings of Monet that you could just sit and look at. loved loved loved. Make time for this little gem.
Monet! Monet!! Monet!!!. Besides the magnificent Monets, do not miss the exhibition of the Collection Jean Water & Paul Guillaume. Particularly impressive the room with the paintings by Soutine!

A must see in Paris!. It took three trips to Paris to finally visit the Musee de l'Orangerie, and I should have gone every time. The Monet's are amazing. What a beautiful gift he gave Paris. It is a small museum that you can visit between your visits to the Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay.

Breathtaking setting for Manet's Water Lilies. A fantastic setting for Monet's work and a lot of other painters in the new extension downstairs. Get a joint ticket with the Musee d'Orsay to save queuing (can be used on two different days). If you get a chance go and see the film about Monet's work in the auditorium in the basement - enlightening and gives the whole wonderful story behind the work.

A digestable museum for a day. I have an apartment in Paris, and have wanted to go back to this, as I hadn't bee since I was a kid. The renovation closed itr down for many years. It is absolutely beautiful, and the oval rooms filled with Monet's water lilies need to be seen. The other arrt is very impressive. There is not a lot to the museum, but after a Louvre or a d'Orsay, that is a welcome relief. It is the perfect place to relax, and spend an hour or two. It is so well situated in the corner of the Tuileries gardens by the Louvre, and the Place de la Concorde. If you love Monet, GO!!!!!!

Compared to the National Gallery in Washington DC, this is probably the best impressionist collection. The museum is simple but art is well displayed. There is no coffee shop or cafeteria inside the musum. Admission charges inflexible

Just the right size!. A perfect museum. Relax before and after outside in the gardens. Just the right number of artwork so as not to be overwhelming. You can get a ticket for this impressionist gallery on a double ticket when you go to the d'Orsay. Very cheap and beautiful renovation.
A Gem. Beautiful paintings make this worth a visit. It is lovely and memorable and you float along in a dreamlike state... Monet, Renoir, Matisse, Picasso...

lovely. A lovely place to visit. I had been here before so knew how great it is, this visit I didn't go until 5pm and was pleasantly surprised to find out it is only 5 euros after 5pm (closes at 6pm but still plenty of time as quite a small exhibit)
submerge yourself. Possibly the only place in Paris where you can sit and travel thru time, color and space. A must for anyone who wants to get inside the impressionists vision of the beyond.
Monet - Water Lillie's. Monet murals abound. Very beautiful museum. Great that they will let u take pictures. I used the Paris Museum Pass - a must for your stay in Paris.

Underwhelming and rude staff. Monet's water lilies were the highlight of this visit. The staff was rude and kept ushering us out of spaces as they prepared for closing. They were completely out of any english pamphlets. The audio tour is okay, but not very exciting. If you go, go on the first Sunday of the month as it is free.

Monet - surrounded by water lilies. There are two rooms devoted to Monet's Water Lily paintings which he painted with the public in mind to be able to sit in the middle of each room surrounded on 4 sides by his atmospheric canvasses stretching around the room
It's been expanded!. More showing areas have been added in the lower level with some great Impressionist painters! Do not miss this place.

Small but focussed - great for when you only have 1 hour. This is a focused little museum at the Chanps Elysee end of the Tulleries. Of course the main attraction are Monet's HUGE watery paintings of waterlilles - and they are huge and splendid.Downstairs has a nice but limited selection of mostly impressionist paintings. If you are in Paris with only an hour or so to kill, spent it here - you will feel revived.

so interesting. wonderful museum near the Place des Vosges, so much to see , it wasn't crowded when we went even though it was raining!Lovely just to saunter through the rooms and enjoy the contents.AND IT'S FREE!!!!!amazing. Lovely shops and places to eat in the area too.Highly recommended.
Must see. Lovely small museum with fantastic art, don,t miss it!Purchase a combined ticket for the musee D,Orsay and you won,t have to que up later.

Fantastique!!!. In the middle of a very cold, grey, blustery day in Paris, what a wonderful time in the Orangerie. The last time I was in Paris quite a few years back, it hadn't opened yet in it's present form and had been top of my 'to-do' list ever since. Absolutely worth the wait! I have seen many versions of the 'Waterlilies' in numerous museums across the world, but nothing prepared me for the breathtaking sight of entire walls of them! And to think that Monet had planned the display as well, such that they are now being seen exactly where and how the painter wanted them to be.Just a small problem - all the descriptions, titles, writing everywhere, is in French only. Also a lovely little collection by Guillaume on the floor below, including Picassos, Renoirs, Cezzannes,Matisses etc.

Ifvyou like the Impressionists-visit this museum.... This lovely museum is definitely well worth a visit,especially if you've already 'done' the larger museums.I did not realise that Monet's magnificent Nympheas would cover several rooms. The light here is excellent,which adds to the experience. There are also examples of other paintings of the same era.When we visited-February- there was no queue-an added bonus when the weather is chilly! The price is reasonable and my daughter -who is under 25-paid less.I would recommend this gem of a museum-and a stroll around the Tuilerie Gardens afterwards.

Small, but amazing for Claude Monet fans. The two Monet rooms were fabulous, although very crowded. I love Monet and was able to sit for quite awhile and enjoy the walls as they were intended. A must if you are a Monet admirer.

Take your camera. What a lovely surprise - we intended to go up the Arc de Triumph but as it was foggy we discovered this wonderful collection of paintings. We were allowed to photograph them all, except the Monet waterlillies!

Small, manageable, beautiful. The perfect museum when you don't have the energy for the Louvre or the Orsay. Amazing Monets, where you could just sit and stare for an hour. A great low stress museum that holds some real classic works.
a great museum. so much here to see and you dont get the feeling you missed something like you do at the big museums and best of all NO LINE to get in
Buy a Passeport ticket. The Orangerie is worth a trip in itself, but the Passeport ticket gives discounted entry into the Musee d'Orsay as well, and lets you queue jump.
