Visit this small museum first if you plan to see Musee D'Orsey. Beautiful collection, beautiful Monet. Very small museum in comparison. No huge lines. You must check your bags. Discount for students, but not for seniors. Any written content on signs or display cases was in French only. If you do not speak French, there is no Spanish, English, Japanese, Chinese, etc. For an additional 5 Euros, you can get an audio guided tour. Brochures in English had run out.If you have time for only one or two museums, would recommend the Musee D'Orsey or Louvre before this one.

Nice and peaceful. I can't believe Orangerie doesn't only received 5***** reviews! Who are you to judge Monet and the others! This intimate muséum not only displays the waterlilies by the master of impressionism but a beautiful collection offered to the Frencf by an art dealer of the first half of the XXth century. On top if you hear about the life of his adventurous wife, you think that the thomas crown affair is a bad soap opera! Must see and a good cutting lne to Orsay Museum with combined ticket.

Have coffee here!. It is worth visiting for the building alone. Not too big and there are some very beautiful cafes well worth having a break inside the museum. The kids discovered "the Mr Bean painting " which was very amusing!!! No photos allowed!
Beautiful Monet waterlillies and other Masters of Art. Nothing here to dislike...worth a visit before or after the Louvre...the amount of art here is staggering and the quality amazing

Simple, Reflective Museum. The les Nympheas (Monet"s Water Lillies) showcased in the two rooms is amazing. I witnessed a few people emotionally overcome by the sight and shedding a few tears. A small amount of other impressionist paintings and some of Picasso's early years make this museum wonderful. It is fairly small however. I would recommend for Monet fans especially. A good "add-on" museum if you have the museum pass. It is located in the gardens of the Tuilleries across from The Louvre. Also, an easy walk to the Orsay. We took the metro here and started here then had a nice walk over to the Orsay.

Just OK. I really only went to this museum to see the Monet paintings (which were incredible), but that was all there really was to see. The museum is small, you can't take your bag in with you, and no pictures (which isn't a huge deal).There was no line up and it wasn't hugely expensive so I was happy to have seen the Water Lilies (they are spectacular) but this isn't a museum that would be at the top of my list. If you have time it is nice to see, but I wouldn't cram it into my visit.

Nice collection, no queues to get in. No queues to get in, like when you go to Musee d'Orsay or Louvre. We loved it because it the collection is not too big. First of all there are the nympheas by Monet in nicely lit oval rooms.On the other hand there a very nice paintings by Renoir, Monet, Picasso, Modigliani,...The building has been beautifully renovated.
Beautiful, worth a visit. The Monet watercolours were a highlight and if you're between 18-25 you get in free so well worth it!

Impressive collection. The crowds are much smaller than at the Louvre or d'Orsay. I wasn't schooled in art appreciation but I'm certain it's definitely a place to visit for those who are. There are lots of famous pieces that even a philistine like myself could identify. A good way to pass an hour or two in Paris.

Plenty to see but not too big. We like to quality of the paintings (Monet, Picasso...) and the way that is displayed: you can feel more than some bigger museums the period and the life of the artists that produced these masterpieces.

To all the fans of impressionism this is the place to be. If you like impressionist paintings don't hesitate a second, this is the place to be. Monet masterpiece the Nympheas is something you need to see in your life.

Too much of a good thing.. Yes, Water Lillies is a beautiful painting. If you are into art you could stand there all day watching the light change on the lilies and the water. Otherwise, walk slowly around the room, figure our which section is dawn, storm, afternoon, etc. Try to imagine who someone with cataracts could paint such delicate colors and then move on.
Wow! My favourite art museum in Paris. This is a wondrous collection of Monet's obsession with water lilies. You need to time to get lost in the amazing colours and ambience of Monet's garden.

Fab - u - lus. The Monet Lillies were great, but for me the impressionist paintings in the private collection were the highlight. All the famous names.
We visited on the first Sunday of the month when the entry is free. Go early in the morning or the crowds will be there and it will be too busy.
Get up and visit its FAB.

Heaven. Simply my favourite place ever...I've been 2 days in a row...tranquil, amazing, awe-inspiring!
The audio guide isn't really worth 5 euro in my opinion. Just sit and enjoy. The second room is by far the best for me.
Monet Marvelous. The Water Lilies took my breath away. Really. The presentation couldn't have been better. I could have stayed there for hours.

Monet.... This is one of my favorite art museums in Paris. Of course, Impressionism is my favorite period. The museum is not very large but it does contain quite a few pieces. The main attraction- Monet's Water Lilies. He designed 2 rooms to showcase the panels specifically! They are really great and if you like Impressionism at all, you should visit.
Took the English tour, excellent. Outstanding displays of Monet's Waterlillys in this purpose built gallery! Wonderful Impressionist works!

Very good!. When you go in, you think: "this museum is too small, I will waste my prescious time in Paris". But then you see the Nympheas and all those great paintings from Renoir, Monet, Gaughin, Matisse...
I was very happy to go there and will definetly go back, if I can!

Monet was beautiful. A must see, the presentation of the the monet is amazing and the gift shop has some really nice money prints to take home. I was not interested in the rest of the gallery but there is also art from picasso and many others I was not interested in seeing.

Don't miss this small museum!. No, it's not as big as the Louvre or Orsay, but it is a beautiful space for experiencing art. If you're a Monet fan, you must go. Two rooms of his vast waterlilies paintings (similar to the one that have at the MoMA in NYC, but they have 8 in this little museum). If you are a fan of beautiful spaces, you must go.

A museum...not well organized. The museum is marvellous, but the problem seems to be the actuall management!! The visitors hasn't information enought at the welcome and the wost management in the room is all concentrated in this museum: during the trip there sere a lot of people talking and nobody arrest the noisy this people create. Monet is marvellous, but it requires silnce and quiet.I invited the management in the room to be more proactive in this way...but they we re talking too!!!!!!Museum suggestive, but not the best choice during the week end!!!

a lovely museum!. This museum is a little gem. It is a beautiful building which houses many wonderful works.....two huge galleries of Monet which literally surround you and make you feel like you are in another world, hushed and rich with color. The downstairs galleries have numerous Renoir, Derain, Modigliani, Picasso, Cezanne, Utrillo. This museum is a perfect alternative to the crazy crowds at Musee D'Orsay though there is no sculpture. The entrance fee is 7.50 euros and children are free. I recommend this museum for it's excellent collection, its soothing atmosphere.

Monet as he wanted to be seen. Seeing the water lily paintings in just the manner Monet planned them to be viewed was magical. The collection of Renoir Manet and Monet paintings were set out in a very well lit and managable size space, A real treat. Take the audio tour as it really adds to the enjoyment of the paintings. Sadly no cafe inside which is a shame.

Yet another must see in Paris. This was my second visit in 12 months. Would I go back? Definitely yes. I spent almost an hour looking at the water lilies. I blocked out comments from other viewers eg "how vibrant" "masterful brush strokes" etc and imagined myself at the waters edge listening to the water, magical. Then downstairs to explore the Guillaume collection. I prefer this museum to the Louvre, you can actually see the exhibits and take photographs of the collection.

Must see museum. There is more than the two magnificent rooms displaying the stunning Monet water lilies. The Guillaime and Walter collection of Renoir's and Cezanne's is the unparalleled. Stroll the Tulieres and spend an hour to visit this gem.
If you are a Monet fan!. Great place if you're a Monet fan, to see the pictures that have been on most walls through 90th A good atmosphere and a great light.

surprisingly small collection. I have had l'orangie on my list for years and was excited to see the water lilies. They are stunning and perfectly displayed in two rooms with nothing else.However, the ticket is 7.50 euro and the rest of the collection is tiny, so I was a little disappointed that my whole visit was less than an hour.It's probably nicer in the warm weather when you can enjoy the walk through the gardens on the way there from the Louvre, or D'Orsey.

Show Me the Monet! Beautiful and Wonderful. Monet had produced 8 large mural like paintings especially for display in this building, a former royal orange tree greenhouse. Four paintings wrapped within the walls of each of two oval shaped chambers. These initially seemed rather bland large paintings. *However standing and viewing them from a distance I really appreciated the ethereal beauty and perspective created by Claude Monet's masterful brushstrokes. The surface of the pond appeared to reflect the clouds above whilst the water lilies floated on its surface. I have to say I felt a calm peacefulness standing in the room and could have sat there for a long time (but moved on with the family). Unfortunately there were no English brochures left and we had no ID to use an iPad interactive guide. We couldnt take photos inside either. Subsequent reading has further fascinated me as Monet painted these aged 80 when he'd experienced several losses such as his wife and son. It was just after the First World War, and his eyesight was failing because of cataracts. He painted these to capture the beauty of his lily ponds at home.

Favourite museum in Paris!. Musee de l'Orangerie is smaller than the Louvre and d'Orsay, but I liked it better because of its understated elegance. Monet's waterlillies are so beautiful and for me, had so much more impact than some of the stuffy, over complicated artwork of the Louvre.

See Monet's water lillys like never before. Monet's water lilys are displayed in two elliptical rooms in panoramic view. Absolutely brilliant! You just need to spend time looking and conteplating the magnficence. Monet spent some 30 years paintng the wate lillys in his garden. How about that for attempting perfection and for sheer persistence. The end result needs not to be hurried.Downstairs is a wonderful exhibition of some of the most famous painters works, seen close up. Once again, take the time to slow down, contemplate and absorb the beauty and the painstaking efforts at creating these masterpieces

Wow! Lovely gallery. We have visited Paris many times which means that we have the luxury of just "mooching" around. We wandered through the gardens Tuileries and sort of came upon the Musee de l'Orangerie. It was fab, can't describe the emotions of seeing those huge fantastic Monet paintings, the colours are unbelievable. The variety of the other paintings were also quite breathtaking. I always like a Renoir but add that to Picasso, Modigliani, Dali's etc etc. I see some people have complained about the price but frankly 7.5 euros I think was fantastic value. Oh and no queues :)

Not as much to see but worth it for the Monet. Main exhibit was the Waterlillies. If I had to cut one of the big muesums out of the trip, this would be it. Still very worth going and you should make time for it.

Musee de l'Orangerie. A must for lovers of impressionist art.There is much more to see on separate floors but if you dedicate sufficient time to the art then you may be in need of respite from culture.
Peaceful and beautiful. The two Monet rooms are so peaceful and beautiful. A snip at around 7 euros. Well worth popping in especially after exhausting hours spent in the Louvre!
Monet Water Lilies in Panorama. Two large oval rooms with floor to ceiling Monet's Water Lilies all around you. A must for all Impressionist fans.
Ridiculously beautiful monets. Do not miss this. Absolutely breathtaking beautiful panitings - one for the bucket list! And Rodins 'the kiss' outside oo, an extra treat for art lovers!

A Paris Gem. After going to Paris every year for over a decade we finally visited the Musee de l'Orangerie and wondered why it had taken us so long to get there. It is a lovely museum with many treasures beyond the Monet's . Not to be missed. And, get the combo ticket with the d'Orsay to save some money.

Huge beautiful Monets!. This museum is located in the corner of Tuilleries and was superb. It had 2 huge rooms with massive Monet waterlillies all around which were helped by the spacious natural lighting. Downstairs there were more excellent impressionist paintings including Henri Rousseau, Matisse, Picasso, and other French painters. This was better than Musee D'Orsay and much less crowded.
Nice museum. Nice Monet panels on main floor, excellent impressionist collection on downstairs floor. Refreshing to tour a museum in an hour, unlike exhausting Louvre experience.

beautiful art but rude staff. some male staff are quite rude and racist they have bad expression if you are not white which is very bad
the monet and guillaume art collection are sublime
and lot of gypsies outside the museum begging and maybe stealing money

Sublime. Although I have seen many Monets, nothing prepares you to this amazing experience. Pictures never do art justice. This is particularly true of Les Nympheas. Allow yourself some time to appreciate it, and don't forget to go downstairs.

Well worth a visit. I have always wanted to see the two 360 degree water lillies' artworks by Monet, and was not disappointed, despite the lengthy queue to enter (be warned!) The exhibition of 19th Century French artists in the lower galleries is also interesting, though one suspects it is there to pad out the experience and justify the entrance fee!
Beautiful museum!. I have been here several times and love this museum. It is just the right size and the Monets are never boring!

Maybe I'm just ignorant. I had no idea that the Musee de l'Orangerie existed... On a weekend trip to Paris, my partner and I decided to give it a try... it was amazing. Apart from the glory of the Monet Water Lillies rooms (where I would quite gladly spend half a day, just sitting there and drinking in the amazing pictures!), the downstairs features an amazing collection. Definitely one I will be coming back to!

Monet rooms!!. There is nothing quite like experiencing the Monet Water Lillies rooms. They are truly a tranquil experience. They envelop the senses with beauty in the midst of a crowded city. This is a must-see!

Great Museum but be wary of pickpockets outside museum. We were at the museum today, the museum is great but before I explain further let me warn you of the pickpockets outside the museum.There is a couple trying to fool people with the old "lost ring" scam. I almost fell for it going in, my husband knew right away. After leaving the museum a lady tried to pull it on me again, I kept walking and warned another tourist almost about to fall for it. The lady cursed at me and even tried to spit me (well at least from far away, i was many feet away from her)Now on to the museum. The museum is great. The Nymphs exhibition is excellently arranged. You can really tell that Monet really studied and planned this murals for a long time. The exhibition is even cardinal direction accurate (eg, the sunset mural is placed on the west). It's incredible to think how Monet maintained the scale and the visual effect for the observer while still working on an impressionist piece. The curvatures make the effect complete. The rest of the museum contain great impressionist pieces from a Parisian collector. There are early Picasso's, Renoirs, and Modiglianis.

A different central Paris art visit. Wow. In four trips to Paris previously, I had not yet been to this beautifully designed small gallery by the river, close to Place de la Concorde. Few queues, and wonderful to see the Monets, with an interesting contemporanious collection below. It's no Musèe d'Orsay in terms of big pieces, but the plus is you can go round in an hour or so. Only reason for not giving 5* is that the price (?7.50) is high, when compared with ?11 at the Louvre. Go though!

Disappointing. We are lovers of art but found this museum disappointing. Whilst Monet's waterlilies are interesting, there are few other paintings that we enjoyed - Renoir's girls were good. But that is not enough to justify the price and time taken to reach the Orangerie. If you are short of time, see some of the Louvre, or better yet save enough time to explore its vast collections.

Small museum. This is a good museum to do if you don't have a lot of time, but would still like to see some artwork while in Paris. There are a lot of pieces by Monet here, so if you're a fan of his, check it out.
Great value!. As you walk to the end of Jardins Tuilleries... a chance to see Monet's waterlilies and other wonders!

A gem. We found this intimate museum amazing. Take the recorded tour.I was fascinated to learn about some of the collectors, who helped to support the starving artists, who would become more famous than the collectors.

A dream come true. This is possibly one the best attractions in Paris. The museum, which holds the impressive Water Lilies collection by Monet, is breathtaking. The rooms that display the lilies evoke such calm and peace and you can spend hours just soaking in the gorgeous paintings.Downstairs, there is an amazing collection of Impressionist paintings and a theatre. We were able to see a film about the design and story behind the paintings (subtitled in English) which made them even more breathtaking.We were there as a couple but next time will take our kids. A small, intimate museum and a haven from the bustle of Paris.
Beautiful waterlilies. Breathtaking atmosphere. Standing with Monet's waterliles all around you are transported into a dream
Upstairs/Downstairs. The main floor presents Monet's mesmerizing water lilies, downstairs is quite lively with impressionistic works and Barnes diorama. A wonderful escape from the Louvre.

quiet reflective place. Monet's Waterlilies in their original setting will take your breath away. Sit down in the quiet room (they request that you keep it that way) and meditate on the works for an hour or so. No lineups and well worth the small admission price.

Perfect size for a short visit and lovers of Monet and impressionist art. If you are short on time and only have a few hours this is the perfect. It is famed for its custom built oval rooms to house 8 (?) large Monet panels. These two rooms were designed to create the perfect light and atmosphere to appreciate Monet's paintings. The rest of the gallery had a good selection of impressionist and post.impressionist art. You can hire audio guide which may be a good idea considering all the information boards are in french. Overall a perfectly sized museum especiall if you have smaller children who would not tolerate being dragged through a larger place like Louvre or D'Orsay. The museum is ideally located near the Tuileries and easily accessed from the Concorde metro station.

Monet!. If you love Monet - this is the place for you. You need only a few hours to soak in the full experience. Lots to do nearby - go to Angelique's for a hot cocoa and macaron afterwards - it is close by.

Too small for a museum. It could be reported as a room. In fact it is a room for monet and some other artists. The enormous Ninpheas are pure perfection and the galley exibits great artists with remarkable paintings.

Absolutely beautiful. My second favourite gallery in Paris behind the D'Orsay. It is not anywhere near as big as Louvre or even D'Orsay but what it is contained inside is beautiful. Worth seeing just for the amazing Monet watercolours which are beautifully presented.
Always a favorite. This museum is sometimes not as well-known, but its collection never disappoints. It has some of the best art in Paris! It is completely worth the visit.

Water lillies and more. The presentation of Monet's water lillies is fantastic. Downstairs, beneath these is a good compact collection of impressionist art works that make a good quick companion visit to other galleries close by such as Musee D'Orsay or the Louvre. Allow approx one and a half hours to see everything. Admission included in the Paris Museum Pass, or a double ticket including Musee D'Orsay admission may be bought.

Waterlilies.........!. The museum is wonderful but the piece de resistance is Monet's series of waterliles - huge and unbelievably moving. Housed in their own 2 rooms and they surround you like water. If you love Monet, you cannot miss this.

What a Museum!!!!. This place was amazing! I highly recomend it. It is much smaller than the Louvre but what a fsntastic collection of art. The audio tour was worth the price and was very happy to see a large number of the works had audio info. I would make this a must see. Not open on Tuesdays

Favorite Museum in Paris. Forget the overwhelming crowds and paralying magnitude of art at the Louvre and the Orsay. This quite museum has an amazing collection of some of my favorite impressionist paintings. You know all the ones you studied in college. You can get up close and personal with Picasso, Renoir, Monet, Manet, and Degas without having to navigate your way through the mob. We were blown away by the collection and the Water Lilly halls were unforgetable. You must put this on your short list!
a must for Monet fans. great collection of various artists. massive impression of Monet's Nympheas , go for that if you don't want to spend the whole day in Louvre ................

Well Worth a Visit. We're visited Paris several times, but this was our first visit to the Orangerie. It is housed in a small and unassuming building in a corner of the Tuileries Gardens.If you're planning a visit to Paris and plan to visit any of the museums, I'd highly recommend the Paris Museum Pass. This will not only save money, it also permits access through special permit points in various museums to save waiting in line. We found this particularly helpful at the Louvre and Versailles. That being said, one of the pleasure of this museum was the lack of crowds and relative calm.As others have noted, the Monet Water Lilies are not to be missed. There are two rooms containing these works, and the eye level positioning allows a unique perspective when viewing. The day following our visit, we traveled out to Giverny to see the actual subject of these masterpieces. I'd highly recommend such an itinerary if your time permits.

Best staged exhibition I have seen. Although we have been to Paris many times this was our first time at this museum and we came due to a recommendation from the staff at the Eurostar desk in St Pancras. The waterlillies are absolutely stunning in this setting and it would be worth the visit for them alone. However, it was the Paul Gulliame collection which was really superb - the use of the space means the paintings can be seen at very close quarters and in exceptionally good light. What is particularly good about the exhibition is the flow of the works and how this supports the viewer to really understand and recognise the relationship between the various artists and the evolution of the styles presented. Cannot recommend it highly enough.
The best gallery in Paris. The Water Lilies are stunning but the Paul Guillaume collection downstairs was a real fins and surprise

Small but a must!. This is a small museum but not to be missed if you like art! The way the water lily paintings on the street level were hung was fantastic and almost breath taking, it really gives you a chance to truly appreciate them. On the bottom floor, there are more paintings by other impressionist artists, but none of them are as impressive as the water lilies.

Good, but small.. I got in for free with my student visa, and my friend had already purchased a museum pass, so for all intents and purposes she'd already paid to go. The museum is nice, but rather tiny. The entire upper floor is very, very large works by Monet. Two rooms, 8 paintings, 4 in each. You aren't supposed to take pictures of these, and they are nice, but I feel like it's not nearly enough to be the entirety of one half of the museum, and I love impressionists and Monet in general. The second (lower) floor had more to it, and I rather liked it. There were a few works by Picasso, some Renoirs, etc and while also rather small, was still quite nice. There were other works too of course.It's a nice visit, it's just down the street from d'Orsay and we made it a dual-trip to both museums, but this museum alone isn't worth one special trip (in my opinion).
Monet. Great how visitors here had to adhere to rules of no photography and being quiet. disappointed that there were no map/information leaflets in French or English

Gorgeous art. Beautifully presented art in egg shaped rooms. Monets waterlilies hug the walls in splendor. It is worth considering purchasing the Orsay and Orangerie passport to save some time and money. Make note of opening days is my other tip. Also these museums will take your backpack and coat for free. You can walk between the Orsay, this museum and the Louvre.

Small but Lovely. I've been to Paris many times but never had the pleasure of visiting the Orangerie. A small museum has many virtues and this is one of the best. Don't miss the two rooms of Matisse Waterlilies, built just for these paintings.

Worth the visit!!. It was really cold - snowing and we had to wait outside in line.....the guard said: its going to close in 40 min...you wont have time to spend there..... anyway we waited and it worth the visit!!! just to see the two big rooms with Monet paintings....amazing!

One of my 2 favorites. Perfect museum for the lover of Monet and more. I've sat mesmerized gazing into the water lilies for nearly an hour, more than once, and wandering through the wonderful works in the lower level as well. Would be on the top of the list in my book!

Small is beautiful!. So glad we visited this museum - Monet's water lilies were our main attraction but the rest of the collections are well worth a viewing. Because the museum is smaller than most, it is very easily navigated and can be done comfortably in a few hours.
Winter Vacation. The Monet's are wonderful, the museum is smallish so easily enjoyed without the massiveness of the Louvre or even the crowds of the Orsay

waterlilies. Great to see Manet's waterlilies in space designed for them and also downstairs collection. First time I had encountered ban on picture taking in Paris, so embarrassed when guard nicely told me not to so as to not disturb other patrons. No ban downstairs and took pics profusely of collections.

Perfectly sized gallery with quality in abundance. If like me you find the Louvre or the Musee d'orsay a little challenging because of the volume of works on view the the orangerie is for you. Wonderful paintings by Renoir, Monet and Picasso amongst others, yet in numbers that allow you to spend appropriate time on each one. And the delight of seeing the water lilies as they were intended to be viewed is the icing on the cake.

Really good environment. This museum is incredibly good. The Nympheas are really well presented and the circular form of the rooms helps having a feeling of water that is relaxing and enjoyable. This attraction can be really crowded and in this case you may not enjoy as you deserve, so if you can I suggest you to avoid very crowded days there. I really think this is an attraction that you shouldn't miss in your first (or next) trip to Paris

Totally worth the visit, even after Louvre!. I was very impressed by the wide artworks of Monet. Having seen pictures of them, I really wanted to see them myself, and it was nothing less than I expected. The rooms that are surrounded by Monet's art are simply impressive. Unfortunately, you are not allowed to take pictures there (you can take pictures in some other parts of exhibitions). The sitting area in the middle of the room is a good spot to take in the art, if there is space to sit. The other exhibitions were good, too, but I wasn't as interested in them as I was about this. Be prepared for a security check when you enter the building. The security staff were super-nice!

A gem and open on Mondays. if you love Monet, you will love this visit. Two amazing rooms with enormous Monet paintings that circle the walls. After this you must also go to the Monet gardens at Giverney. The downstairs galleries are also good but not exceptional, but the big plus when you have visitors is that the museum is open on Mondays.

Enjoyable. Really enjoyed seeing the waterlilies and the Renoir paintings. It was free for me as I am under 25 and from the EU, but I paid for an audio guide, which was worth getting, even if you don't listen to every track.
The new building work is wonderful.. Guillaume collection is fabulous and the new building displays it wonderfully. January is a good time for Paris museums - no queues.
Les Nymphéas - overrated. But I enjoyed the rest of the works. Picasso, Derain and Modigliani are particularly well represented,

Could spend hours in the oval room. A small art museum but one that is not to be missed on a trip to Paris. There are various works of art however the highlight is the oval room where the walls are covered with eight Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet. There is a row of benches in the middle of the room and my husband and I could have just sat for hours staring at the stunning paintings. I must admit I don't remember much else about the museum (they do have lots of other artworks!). Well worth a visit just for the Lilies

All about Monet. We went here because our hosts at the B&B recommended it since they knew that I love Monet's paintings. The rooms where the water lillies paintings are on display was very impressive and beyond my expectation. A must visit if you love Monet.
Beautiful gallery. Lovely little gallery in the Tulleries. Three rooms dedicated solely to Monet's lillies - absolutely beautiful.

Don't miss this.. Lovely setting at end of Tuileries Gardens. Lovely Renoirs. And of course Monet's Nympheas, which you need to take time over; fortunately, unlike so many Paris galleries, this one has a reasonable allowance of benches to sit down on. In this case the setting is part of the work, and you have no idea what these pictures are like until you are sitting in the middle of them, almost immersed in fact. While you are at that end of the Tuileries, the Tuileries bookshop might repay a visit - books about horticulture and historic gardens in several languages, as well as other bits and pieces.
Amazing works of Art. While is museum is small, you can probably cover it in 2 hours. The Monet pond painting are absolutely breathtaking and a must see. The rest of the museum is great as well.
The Musee de l'Orangerie--what else is there to say?. Go in January, in bad weather, as we did. We didn't have the museum to ourselves, but pretty close. A day to remember.

Magical. I came here mainly to see the two Monet rooms and they did not disappoint. I actually almost missed the museum because it was smaller than I thought it'd be. If you see a small beige building and you think it's much too small to be a museum, then you've found it. I was lucky enough to come on a cold winter day so it was empty and got a chance to really sit and stare at each corner of the room fairly undisturbed.
Monet magic. Emotional viewing of masterpieces, so amazing. The rooms hold these paintings perfectly. Go early on free Sunday and have them all to yourselves

Nice manageable sized Gallery/Museum. The specially designed display area for the waterlilies does work well and add to their value.The rest of the museum had a nice flow to it and a good selection of artists well laid out.The size is a good start for someone new to art or daunted by the scale of the Louvre... you wont get lost!

wonderful. it feel like a oasis of tranquillity: standing in a large white room, admiring Monet's lilies! The collection is superb! And every time we've visited l'Orangerie it was never crowded - unlike Louvre when it gets noisy and you cannot actually enjoy the silence.

beautiful escape. To see the waterlillies of monet was an amazing experience. it was an experience that left me both in a tranquil and excited state of mind. One can spend hours just watching and dreaming...

Brief but worth a visit. Quite brief - this museum only has a few exhibits in the basement, but the main attraction is the 8 enormous tableaux of Monet's waterlillies on the ground floor. Takes about 30 minutes.

Just go!. This is the perfect bite sized awesome Paris Museum experience. Go, drink in the beauty and the story it tells. Wonderful for a lazy rainy day. The paintings are magnificent and to see the way they constructed the building specially for the paintings is a once in a lifetime experience.

A less visited gem. We were treated to a special exhibition of Chaim Soutine, which was marvelous. But if nothing else, come for the Monet water lily murals which he created specifically for this site.
Amazing. Amazing huge Monets. Well worth a visit. Small in size but full of wonderful large painting. Located at the at the start of the Tuileries (Sculptor Gardens that lead to the Louver).

Monet Waterlilies. This has always been on my list of great galleries and I was so happy that I was finally able to visit Musee de l'Orangerie. It's small but well worth the trip. The Musée de l'Orangerie is an art gallery of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings located in the west corner of the Tuileries Gardens next to the Place de la Concorde in Paris. Though most famous for being the permanent home for eight Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet, the museum also contains works by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo, among others.
Monet's Water Lilies. Truly remarkable experience being able to see Monet's water lily paintings up close. Beautiful museum with wonderful art. The gift shop was awesome as well.

Wonderful Collection. Well laid out. Gallery of course houses Monet's famous Water Lily paintings but also a wonderful collection of impressionist and post impressionist works as well as traveling exhibitions. Don't forget the Rodin sculptures in the grounds which are free to view if you can't afford admission.

The Nymfeas wonderful as ever - and great works by Chaim Soutine. I had seen a side of beef and three herrings on a plate by Soutine and always thought it was not a painter for me. What a lovely surprise to discover that the ongoing exhibition shows a dynamic, colourful, nervy artist with a deep feeling for people and landscapes. The museum is on a small and human scale, and of course it always has the jewel in the crown on display: 8 of Monets waterlilies paintings, to meditate on and feel better for the experience.I`ll always come back here when in Paris. Even in the snow.

So that's how big water lilies are? not poster size?. Airy and light, natural light really shows off the work well. Don't forget to wander downstairs for the other galleries, There were some Russian paintings there that were fantastic when I visited.

Giant Monet Waterlillies. Essential Paris Museum.. Paris and London are probably the best museum cities in the world and with the hugely famous Louvre and other popular museum destinations such as The D'Orsay and the Pompidou, it would be easy to miss the L'Orangerie. Don't. The lower floor gallery is a good survey of impressionist pieces but the real heart of the place are the two upper floor galleries which were constructed exclusively to house Monet's giant waterlilly panels. There is nothing that screams the essential French art experience better than staring at these.The L'Orangerie is easy to do in an hour or so, so easy to fit into a schedule.You should definitely try to get the museum pass or advance purchase tickets as you'll save a good chunk of time in line.Don't miss the Musee de L'Orangerie.
Monet's paintings. I just love sitting in this museum, gazing at the huge paintings. Have been twice and still want to go again!
Tiny but amazing. You just need 20 minutes in there but you can as well stay revere for many hours and just stare at the work of a genious.
Small and awesome! Monet!. If you are a fan of Monet's water Lillie's, you MUST go. There are 2 oval rooms with 4 walls of water lillies. Simple breathtaking.
Waterlilly Wonder. Enjoyed marvelling in the rooms designed to showcase Claude Monet's masterpiece Nympheas. Buy a museum pass and remove most of the line stress.
Not just the Nymphéas. The Monet Water Lilies are extraordinary, and the rest of the collection, especially the outstanding Soutines, are wonderful too.

great collection and great tour. If you love Monet and Picasso paintings and spirit - this is the way to go! They also have a well put in place schedule and various events. Get in the mood for embracing art and you will find this museum incredible!

Great if You Love Monet. Smaller museum near the Louvre with huge Monet murals. Be careful of the people trying to scam you outside the museum by pretending that you dropped a gold ring, then asking for money for it.

Much more than home of "Les Nymphéas". This museum is famous for Claude Monet's masterpiece, "Les Nymphéas", Well, and what about Matisse,Picasso, Cézanne, Modigliani, Renoir, Utrillo, Rousseau, Sisley, and last but not list my beloved Chaim Soutine (twenty two paintings, one of the largest collections in the world). During my last trip to Paris I was fortunate to visit Sutin's exhibition "Order and Chaos" in de l'Orangeree (around sixty paintings, almost "All Sutin": landscapes, portraits, and still lifes with carcasses).

Worth a visit. Very nice museum, with a wonderful collection of water lilies, but there is not much more than that. The lower level includes some wonderful paintings and moving exhibits. Worth a visit, but quite expensive. Buy a museum pass!
Monet. Not so over whelming. Easy to navigate. If you are a Monet fan, you must go for the water lily panels.
Small, but important.. Not much thing to see, but some important contributions of Monet and even one Picasso and some expressionists. Cannot be compared to Musee d'Orsay, much bigger and better.

Monet's Waterlillies are just beautiful!. Worth the visit! Great if you have a museum pass as there is a quick entry! Monet's work is a must to see! The museum was built specifically to house his work!
Must see. Small and perfectly formed! Will only take a few hours to get around. It has the oval rooms that house Monet's Waterlillies, which are breath taking.

Monets finest. A must on every trip to Paris. I waited 13 years for it to open and was not disappointed. Amazing museum beautifully display of the water lilies is the highlight, however don't miss the other galleries.
Monet. A must for any Monet fan. A whole room of very large paintings in the round. Museum is small and will only take an hour or so
Brilliant. Wow - fantastic wonderful and gorgeous staff. Easy to negotiate in a wheelchair and brilliant informaton

Monet and Lilies. Liked - the Monet room. To sit in the middle even for a few minutes and soak up the beauty of the Water Lilies is a pleasure. And then to go and enjoy some of the great works of other artists ... Also enjoyed the exhibition of Chaim Soutine, someone about whom I knew nothing.

Best museum in Paris ... when we were there. The Orangerie has a wonderful standing exhibit of impressionist masters - far more accessible than those at the Musee d'Orsay - and the great Monet Nympheas are worth a trip in themselves. The travelling exhibits will obviously vary in quality. Nonetheless, this museum is halfway between the Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay and much friendlier than either of its famous neighbors.

Museum ia amazing. Glass pyramid and fountain and great monalisa painting is great. there is cost associated to enter inside the museum worth it! must see..outside it is windy and cold in dec 2012 , advice to carry lot of warm clothes and umbrella for sure.
Do not miss. Monet's lilly's amazing. Not to miss. Get tickets a head of time or get the museum pass - the extra money is worth not standing in line.
A must see for Monet art lovers. The two rooms devoted to Monet's Nympheaus were outstanding. We sat on the benches in the center of each room and were able to really enjoy these works.
Great Monet. A must see if you admire Monet's work. A limited collection, but lovely. Not as crowded as d'Orsay. There was a combo ticket available for a good price.

Monet ... Magnifique!. I had not realised how impressive the Monet watercolours were, and how the building was designed to showcase them. I went back to the 'quiet space', the vestibule and re-entered the room, so I could experience the break from the busyness of the city, as Monet intended.

Monet Paintings you've always wanted to see!. You know all those museum note cards with the famous Monet paintings- well this is the museum where you will be able to see those paintings close-up. (Also, if you've seen the movie "Midnight in Paris," which I highly recommend- Owen Wilson is in that museum.) This is an unforgettable experience. I was there in late September so it was not crowded at all. You should include this on your "Have to do List" while in Paris. Even if you only go to a few museums other than the Louvre while in Paris- include this one and the Musee d'Orsay. Plan to stay for a while - sit and relax, really look at the paintings and enjoy. (P.S. - we found it difficult to make the Museum Pass worth the money- AND- VERY IMPORTANT- most museums are free certain days of the month- so when planning your itinerary- check out the web sites for free and closed days.)
Fabulous. Went to see the Monets and caught a wonderful special exhibition as well. Loved the 2006 refurb of the building.

If you only visit one gallery in Paris, make it this one.. It's a gorgeous gallery containing some truly breath-taking pieces of impressionist art. I could spend all day gazing at Monet's water lilies.

Mone water lily – very recommended!. Quite a small museum and very nice! No queues)) Very recommended if you are the art fan or you just what to visit some museum on your walk from the Tuileries garden)Mone water lilies are amazing! But try to look from the distance.
my favorite museum in paris. love the layout of this museum and its story! this is really a must see for the water lilies... if you have never seen them in person you are in for a treat!

Monet in all his glory. My absolute favorite museum! I never miss a chance to visit it. Yes, the paintings in the two main rooms don't change, but they don't need to. I could sit and look at them for a very long time, and over and over again, and always see something different.I recommend looking at the panels from close up, as well as from a distance.The basement also has amazing art, and I assume those change from time to time. I also like that you don't need tons of time to visit this museum. I never feel like I get my money's worth at the Louvre because it is so huge, and I can realistically only spend so much time there. Warning - someone tried to pull the "did you drop your gold ring" scam on me right outside of the Orangerie.

Delightful, smaller museum. I was so lucky to see a special Chaim Soutine exhibit while there. It's a smaller museum so it's not overwhelming. Very well located with a nice variety of art (all paintings).

Must See!. This is a great (and quick) visit. Get there early when it opens, as the two rooms with Monet's Water Lilys get crowded. (Not Louvre crowded, but still not empty). The arrangement of the huge canvases in oval shaped sky-lighted rooms is perfect. The exhibits downstairs in the basement are also good. I hate to say it, but it was just as enjoyable as the d'Orsay, and much more pleasant due to the fewer crowds.

Just Superb!. We visited this place first time and liked it very much. The collection of paintings is perfect. Museum is not big and it's easy to see everything even if you're not a big "paintings fun".))) Monet's water lilies on the second floor are just glorious and absolutely must see!! A small useful hint if you're in Paris for several days . They have special tickets valid for two museums - L'Orangerie and d'Orsay. It's reasonable to buy it here. Using this ticket you can visit l'Orangerie the same day when you bought it and d'Orsay within next four days. And you don't have to stay in huge queue to enter d'Orsay!!!

Breath taking!. This was the one museum I wanted to see while in Paris and it did not disappoint. I am a huge fan of the impressionists and Claude Monet is of course, the grandfather of the movement. To see the two rooms designed by Monet for his water lily paintings was breathtaking. It is a MUST for art lovers!
Worth the trip. If you like impressionism, seeing the 8 Monet Water Lilies murals is breathtaking. Other impressionist paintings there too

Fantastic Monet. Doesn't get modern art.. We visited Musee de l'Orangerie for the Monet's Water Lillies which was quite breathtaking. It was amazing to see his work presented in exactly the way he imagined. However, not being "artsy people", we didn't really take to the rest of the more modern and new age paintings in the gallery so we thought 8 Euros each was a bit steep -although we did spend a long time looking at the Water Lillies.
The best. A sometimes forgotten gallery but my absolute favourite. Tranquil and just perfect. Could sit for hours with the waterlillies and not feel like i had wasted any time at all.

Wonderful private collection. Part of the Paris Museum Pass (highly recommended as you can the skip the lines) - it was pretty amazing to see Monet's paintings in person and to realize how large they were and to think about the process of creating each one. This museum showcases the personal holdings of one art collector - interesting to learn about him and his passion for Impressionist painting. Personally I think it's great that cameras are not allowed. Experience and appreciate the art. If you want a picture of a particular piece then by a postcard in the gift shop.

Both beautiful and odd paintings, but selection a bit small. I really liked the Impressionist paintings because they were really beautiful. There was an exhibition that had some grotesque art so I didn't like that much. We can't take photos in that exhibition or of Monet's Water Lily paintings, which kind of sucks. Also, there aren't as many selections as in Musee d'Orsay, so if you had to choose between this and Orsay, definitely go to Orsay.

I hear it's amazing, but we couldn't get in!. My friend suggested that we go to this museum and that it was the best in Paris. We arrived at 5:45 and thought it closed at 7, but it actually closed at 6 and they wouldn't let us in. We had a Paris museum pass, so we technically already had our tickets, but he wouldn't let me take a quick peek. I begged and he still said no. It was really a shame, I was dying to see the water lilies. Luckily I've seen some at MoMA, but I am sure this would have been even more breathtaking. The guy standing at the door said "Maybe next time..." but of course I'm an American that doesn't get to Paris often. Next time I will know to arrive early despite the hours on their official website!

Don't miss museum. This place was really enjoyable. The museum is beautiful and not overly crowded. The art is spectacular - love the Renoir and Monet collections. The water lilies are breathtaking. Don't miss this in Paris. With the museum pass you can basically walk right in.

Claude Monet what a artist.. Take our time and really look at the 8 panels that Claude Monet created is a life changing event. An afternoon here and you will want to go to Giverny, France to see where you painted this and got his insperation. And don't miss the rest of the art that is at this Paris top 10 place.

Monet - dreamy paintings. Absolutely have to go again. Beautiful and unique display. If you are familiar with Monet or not, get the guide (electronic) and sit and listen. I did not want to leave and feel the exhibitions below that I visited afterwards go a bad deal.

Not impressed. If I could compare l'Orangerie with Orsay: first one is too small and too little things to see, the second is too big and you will always have the feeling you missed something. The good thing though: with 14 euro I could enter both l'Orangerie and Orsay and because i had the ticket from l'Orangerie, I only had to wait on a very short queue at Orsay. For Paris museums that is something rare.
Monet lovers must see. Loved it all, not too crowded the day we went either. The paintings are amazing and the gallery is quaint and well done. Lighting was perfect also.

I visited twice on one Paris trip. Can't believe I waited so long to visit the Musee de l'Orangerie. the Musee specially built to house Monet's water lilies offers much more than just the experience of being surrounded by the beautiful Monet's. The Walter-Guillaume collection contains some interesting art--my favourite Renoir's Bouquet dans une loge. A bouquet of white roses in a chair. Had to go back for another look before heading home.

Small but beautiful. This museum is near Louvre so you can easily walk in the Tuileries Garden and enjoy beautiful paintings specially the Claude Monet's panoramas. The rooms with this paintings are very quiet and let you enjoy this amazing paintings.
Small but great art. If you like Picasso, and Monets "water lilies" this is a great place to go. We had the paris museum pass and bypassed a 1/4 mile line.

Don't miss the water lillies!. I wouldn't pay to go to this museum alone, but it's worth the trip to see the Monet paintings. The rest of the art work wasn't bad, but nothing I particularly remember. The Paris Pass is a great deal and definitely worth the money. I can't stand being in one museum for too long especially when it's crowded so it was nice to be able to get in and out of the museums as often as we wanted. Also, we used the metro passes everyday.

Experience spoilt by over zealous rude security. Astonishing conflict with extremely unpleasant security team because we leant over the barrier by about a millimetre whilst explaining Impressionism to a child who behaved impeccably throughout the visit. We were then 'shadowed' every step of the way around the museum by security staff in every room, making for a very unrelaxed experience. They refused a refund. What a shame - this was the only thing that spoiled an otherwise great trip to Paris where without exception we found everyone to be friendly and helpful. I see on their website they are looking for a head and deputy head for their customer service & security department - what a surprise!

Worth it for water lilies. Claude Monet's water lilies are breathtaking, the museum is small but definitely worth a look. Paris pass allowed us to queue jump which was worthwhile as the queue was looooooooooong!

Serene museum. This is my favorite museum in Paris because it felt like a museum. There are fewer visitors here and it is situated in a very picturesque park -- not to mention the fantastic display of Monet's Water Lilies! It's unfortunate that I couldn't take any photos while inside, but it's more than made up for by the collection of great contemporary art. A must visit after dropping by by Orsay.

Monet in a perfect setting. You could not find a more appropriate place to view the huge works of Monet displaced in such a fantastic setting . The round room filled with the massive works of Monet is the place where I spent most of my time . Downstairs there is also different exhibitions and other works from notable artists . A fairly small gallery and even just visiting the Monet section is well worth the entry fee

I was not disappointed!!. For years I wanted to see Monet's 'Les Nympheas' and it was bigger, brighter and more stunning than I had imagined. Lovely building and setting and so much more to see in this outstanding gallery. Not to be missed!!

Small, easy to walk around but popular. Go early. Lovely setting on the bank of the seine next to the Tuileries Gardens. Opens early so get there asap to avoid the queues. Even with pre-booked tickets we still had to wait to pass through security/search. Check the opening days as most closed on a Monday. Note most museums are free to enter on the first Sunday of the month.

I love Monet. This was a great place to sit and reflect on the large monet masterpieces, the best art gallery we've been to. There was no queue which was great and plenty of room to sit down and look at the artwork.

L'Orangerie is most certainly not a Lemon. This must truly be the most beautiful gallery on a smaller scale, in Paris, and to house the most superb Monet's spanning the whole width of the walls.. What a Great Gallery decision to mount these as such-A sight that had you enraptured,and floating- I will never forget this.Don't miss it !
Monet's water lilies are not to be missed. This is by far my Favorite museum in Paris. And the water lilies are impressive. Plus there are not the lines of Louvre or Musee D'Orsay.
Magnificent Monet. The infinity rooms with the Monet paintings were truly inspiring- a must see and my favorite museum experience while in Paris.

A Sacred Place. Of all the art, all the buildings I saw in Paris, l'Orangerie was the place that moved me most. The clarity of the space dedicated only to the water lillies paintings was inspired. The art... well... words can't describe the impact of these amazing works. One of my bucket list items now complete
Never miss de l'Orangerie. This small museum is outstanding for the quality of the art. The arrangement is outstanding and well arranged. Viewing the Monet murals is always rewarding.

Monet gives us a treat. Well worth a visit, Monet's water lilies and willow trees provide one with a tranquil place to escape the city for a little while. The museum has been newly refurbished and also offers a collection of other famous paintings.
An eclectic collection. This is far more than the exquisite set of eight huge works bu Monet, but covers a very interesting mix of the genre.

A museum built for Monet's Water Lilies!!!!. Saw several different exhibits there before we made it up to the Monet rooms. Once there -WOW!!!!!!!!Seeing the panels linked together in a long oblong circle was breath taking. Chairs are provided so that you can sit and study sections of the water lilies and then move on,Being able to see other numerous actual works by other painters linked together on one wall --wonderful.For us it was also a delight as we have several needlepoints and posters in our home of famous French Art, and seeing the originals was amazing.The audio head sets are a must!!!!The information and commentary provides an indepth understanding not only of the pieces themselves, but also of the background as to what was going on when the paintings were created. So much information. So nicely done, Really made a difference us us

Smaller version of Musee D'Orsay. Situated right in the middle of Tuileries Gardens, so after walking through the museum you can walk through the gardens then down Champs Élysées for a spot of shopping all in the same afternoon.

Monet's Water Lilies. With the museum pass, we basically walked right in past the long line of people waiting to get it. We just went to see Monet's water lily and willow room. It was well worth going - a calm in our day and a place to sit and reflect for a while. The 2 rooms with the paintings are a must see for anyone who appreciates nature.

Great place to spend a couple of hours. Wonderful intimate museum, beautiful building packed with great art works. Arrive early and experience the peace and tranquility. A must see for all art lovers!

Monet's Waterlilies are just incredible!. They have other Impressionist work here, but the two rooms of waterlilies are really the centerpiece and well worth seeing. (You can get a combined ticket for here and the d'Orsay, which was 14 euro when I was there.)

Quiet and Relaxing. Before meeting our family at the Louvre, we stopped by the l'Orangerie because we've heard so many good things from fellow travelers. Seeing the panoramic water lilies in a quiet space was relaxing and energizing. The museum is a great stop and very close to the Louvre. Going in the morning is best because it's not very crowded and you have time to really sit and look at everything.
A must see in Paris!. Lovely small museum with a few very interesting masterpieces. If you are interested in art or art history this museum is not to be missed!

An absolute must for anyone who has ever liked Monet's Waterlilies.. A superb gallery in the middle of Tuilieries - a beautiful light, bright gallery displays some of Monet's extraordinarily large paintings of his waterlilies - simply breathtaking!Don't forget to go downstairs and see the amazing Guillaume collection, where you can wander amongst masterpieces by Picasso, Renoir, Matisse, Cezanne, Modigliani and others.We were lucky enough to visit 2 years in a row, and it did not disappoint a second time.When you leave the Gallery, you can take a stroll through the beautiful Tuilieries Garden, and maybe even stop for a ride on the Carousel!

Small museum but powerful display of impressionists. The small museum on the Place de la Concorde side of the Tuileries gardens features impressionists and post-impressionists. The impressionist displays are moving and powerful, letting the art speak for itself. In late December we saw a special featured showing of the work of expressionist +Chaim Soutine called "Order out of Chaos." But the main attraction is the collection of the great impressionists. This is one of my favorite museums.

Beautiful museum, wonderfully done - must-see for Monet fans. The mural-style Monet exhibit is a huge treat - laid out simply and deliberately as Monet specified, benches in the middle surrounded by 4 paintings, and two rooms. The problem is when more than 10 people are in the room at a time, it's hard to get the whole experience - we went when they first opened, which was the right call. The other exhibits were beautiful as well, though a bit wordy. Highly recommended!

Wonderful Museum for Monet Fans. The display of Monet's 8 water lillies is so simple and perfect - 4 tapestries in each of two oval rooms, not too bad of a line to get in, get there early, and I'd recommend getting the Paris Museum Pass, saved us a lot of money and time visiting a number of attractions. Also a very nicely laid out exhibit of other Impressionist paintings, you can easily go through the museum in less than 2 hours and is well worth the time if you love art. Just a short walk from the Louvre through the Tuilleries and then a short hop to the Champs Elyees from there. No photos allowed in the museum and there is a very nice bookstore.
fantastic. Of the many museum that we visited this was definitely my favourite. If you love Monet, this is the place to go.
Stunning rotundas. We were shocked at the size and number of gorgeous paintings in the Waterlillies series. Well worth the side visit for an hour's reflection in Monet's garden.

Absolutely Wonderful!. Intimate and amazing museum of Monet's waterlily murals and a collection of impressionist works that should not be missed. I arrived just after 9 am on Sunday morning and there were just a handful of visitors making for a beautiful and peaceful experience at this museum.

Small but excellent. I enjoyed seeing Monet's water lilies! The rooms are exquisite for sitting and taking in the large panels; there are other artists' works as well, a good museum shop and clean bathrooms.
great. This new museum is great!!! ?Very well done. You have got to see it!! Spend some time there upstairs and then go down stairs and see the great collection.

Second time was even better than the first. We visited on a Sunday afternoon, planning to just spend a half-hour revisiting the Monet works. Our first trip there was so amazing we all teared up, but did not expect to find it so emotional the second time around. Ha! We had spent the morning in the Musee Marmottan so the Orangerie was just to be a whistle stop. Two hours later we were still in the first room. Once you figure out elements of the style, composition and technique you begin to discover new facets of the paintings.What can I say about this place, it holds a fascination for us beyond the artwork. The atmosphere, the design, the space...There are great restrooms, lifts but no refreshments. The shop is simply amazing and you can seriously hurt your wallet if you stay too long. Look for the photographic documentation along the entry walkway. But most importantly, dont plan to leave after just a brief glance. Walk back and forth, stand close, stand far away, sit a while. Breath slowly and relax. I cant wait for the third visit to my second most favorite gallery.By the way, there are some other paintings in the building, but who cares, this is a monument to one man.

Amazing art in a beautiful venue. I was there early before it opened and was able to be in the Monet rooms practically alone. One incredible experience. The paintings are so beautiful and tranquil. Worth the entry fee just to see them. Also loved the Cezanne and Renoir exhibitions. it is not too large so you do not feel overwhelmed. When I left at 11 there was still no queue to speak of compared to the afternoon the day before. Therefore would recommend an early morning visit to avoid the crowds and the scammers.

beautiful artwork to be found here. This was the first museum I visited in paris and was one of my favorite. The artwork housed here is beautiful. Its not a huge msusem so it is easy to work into your schedule. there was a little something for everyone, so if you are finding that you are same of the repetitive art you may find elsewhere you wont be disapointed here. One thing i will say though, and this is no fault of the museum, know the local scams before heading to this area. due to its location its a prime spot for the scam artists of paris. we were outside for no more than 30 seconds before someone "found a ring on the ground". things like that can really make a great experience less fun. also we bought our MUSEUM PASS here. the line wasnt long to get in which makes it an ideal place to buy the pass.

An artistic gem. The museum is small and can be covered quickly. The large panoramic paintings by Monet are gorgeous. We also saw a special exhibition of Chaim Sutin, which is wonderful. If you find yourself by the Place de la Concord, do not forget to stop by and visit it.
Very beautiful. A wonderful museum with a fantastic collection of impressionist paintings. An easy walk from the Louvre or the Musee D'Orsay. Not to miss!
Water Lillies - say no more!. Go early and avoid weekend! But definitely worth seeing the Lillies. They are bigger than you think!

The Nympheas rooms did not disappoint.. I loved, loved, loved the rooms that housed the nympheas. The rest of the artwork on display was just a bonus. Small, quaint and reasonably priced. Less crowded too!

Excellent Refurbishments. The last time in Paris the MO was closed for renovations. The building is now very modern, light and perfect to showcase Monet's water lilies - really enjoyed experiencing this museum.
Monet. The Waterlilies were beautiful and well worth the visit! The Willows were a surprise. The museum houses other displays that are interesting for the time period.

A Magnificent Experience. After visiting the Louvre we walked through the Tuileries Gardens to the Musee de l'Orangerie. We had heard of it in advance so we knew what to expect. This didn't really prepare us, though, for the stunning size and beauty of Monet's Water Lilly panels and the classy way in which the paintings have been presented in the two rooms. It wasn't busy when we visited (in contrast to the Louvre which we had just left) and the viewing benefited from this. The serenity and beauty were uplifting. A visit downstairs to view the Renoirs which were part of the Paul Guillaume collection was an added bonus. Do take the time to visit l'Orangerie in the Tuilereries Gardens. You won't be disappointed. Obtaining a Museum Pass in advance will get you in without having to queue.

A must when in Paris. Some of the best impressionist and other French paintings are tastefully presented along with two halls of the large Monet's Lillies, usually with a great side-exhibit (the last one was of Soutine)

Great Add on to a visit to the Louvre. After 6 hours at the Louvre we were ready for some Impressionist and post impressionist art and l'Orangerie was perfect - Monet's water lillies, a nice collection of Renoir's and early Picasso. Small enough to see on under 2 hours.

My new favorite. I've been to Paris many times before and had never done the Orangerie Museum. On my past trip, I decided to give it a go. It did not disappoint! It's small, which means it doesn't take hours (like the Louvre) and you can actually appreciate most of the art on display. Of course the highlight was Monet's amazing waterlillies which are worst the price by itself!! I'll definitely be coming back!

Monet will drive you wild, but don't skip the Paul Guillaume collection. The newly re-opened museum has done a beautiful job putting the staggeringly amazing Monet murals in optimal lighting. This was my first time to the museum, and I spent hours just watching the murals, which is a 19th/20th century version of IMAXX. But don't miss the amazing Paul Guillaume (he was an early 20th century art dealer who launched the careers of many of the artists in the museum. My favorite were the Henri Rousseau primitives, which were the immediate precursors to absurdism.

Breathtaking Impressionists. How can you resist 10x40 foot Monet water lilies showing the light in Giverny at misty dawn, sparkling day, and evening golden glory. Also many other wonderful impressionists, and friendly staff. Just remember you'll need to check your backpack or camera with the attendants (no charge).

Musee l'Orangerie a must. This is a most delightful and spacious showing of more fine art. You wander through here thinking Paris must be afloat in impreeionist art.I almost didn't go and I am very pleased I did.No need for pre-booking.Actually there is usually a free pass givne with the d'Orsay ticket

l'Orangerie plus Orsay a great museum combo. Monet created 2 rooms and the giant paintings to fit specially in the space. That plus the remarkable late 19th c paintings make this one of our favourite places to visit when in Paris. This plus the Orsay can be seen with a 'passport'. A lovely treat for Impressionist painting lovers

Sweet Waterlilies May Transform You!. The L’Orangerie is a must-see museum for the Monet Waterlilies, alone. They are serene and inspirational at the same time. My mom did not understand the power of art until she strolled through the Waterlilies galleries—an event that transformed her outlook on art, culture, and beauty. Please visit. I hope you have a similar sense of enlightenment and wonder.The rest of the museum is very small and easy to view quickly. This is a relaxing and gently-paced museum--especially compared to the overwhelming Louvre.TIP: Cameras and cell phones are no longer allowed in the Waterlilies galleries. Keep them safely stowed away or a guard will boot you out.

Unique, smaller Paris Museum...A must!. Have visited many museums in Paris and other European cities, and the L'Orangerie is a smaller, more intimate museum which houses some pretty spectacular large Monet pieces. If you're looking for a smaller museum with allot of wow- don't miss this one. Sometimes it's nice not to be overwhelmed by the size and immensity of The Louvre or the d'Orsay . A real treasure!

A must see. We'd been here before and were surprised you could no longer take photos. The renovations to the front of the building make it easier to get inside, but we still had to queue outside in the mud. This is still my favourite gallery.

Magnificently small. Totally superb because it is small enough to be welcoming and comprehensive enough to house the most unexpectedly incredible range of late nineteenth, early twentieth century artwork.
Must see. The Monet rooms are absolutely fantastic. Also good to know that if you're an EU citizen under 25, you get free admission!

Go for Monet's water lilies. After being blown away by the impressionist collection at Musee d'Orsay, we went to see Monet's two rooms of large scale water lilies. Two oval rooms house the panels and even with a moderate crowd, they were lovely and worth seeing. Our tour guide at the d'Orsay suggested going early in the morning right when they open as sometimes you are the only one there (we visited off season). Given our schedule, we were not able to do this but I can imagine the sublime light and the sense of peace that experience would bring. Had we time, we would have explored the entirety of the museum so I can't comment on the rest of the collection, only Monet's water lilies.

bautiful display of Monet's waterlilies. If you like Monet, visit this museum. It's not that big, but I could stay just in the room with the waterlilies forever. If you like impressionism, you can buy combined ticket for musee D'Orsey and l'Orangery for 14 euro. The ticket will be valid for the second museum for 4 days. You also will get a discount to visit the Opera Garnier for 6 euro instead of 9 if you present the ticket at the entrance.

Quick stop before the Louvre. For anyone who appreciates the impressionist movement, this museum is a must see. It's small and relatively empty and easily accessible before heading for a day at the Louvre. Don't miss Rodin's 'The Kiss' outside.

Enjoyed it. . . Perfect size. .. The museum was great. . .it was not overwhelming and you actually where able to see everything in a couple of hours. . Feeling a sense of accomplishment. We visited the Louvre 4 times and still did not see everything. Totally recommend it

Never boring even if all day. One of the most famous museums in Paris.There are world-famous masterpieces like Monet’s or Renoir’s and also many of not famous but wonderful pieces.It’s as great as it made me wanna go again even though I spent whole day here.
Impressionist wow. Have seen the Monet's in reproductions our whole lives and had no idea how big the water lilies were.so beautiful .

Exceptional. This museum feels a lot more low key than Le Louvre, but it's amazing. Monet's water lilies and the way the paintings are displayed are just lovely. Then there's Picasso, Matisse and Renoir, to name but a few........

Combine it with the D'orsay. The Orangerie has been re done since we last visited. The Monet water lilly series are now on the upper level and the permanent collection downstairs. The museum is a very agreeable addition to a visit to the D'orsay, as they are almost opposite each other on the Seine. Although you may at first not think that you saw much, I can almost guarantee that some of the paintings from the lower level(Guillaume collection) will imprint themselves in your mind forever (Soutine, for me), let alone just the thought of Monet painting those mammoth water lilies.To avoid long line ups, try to buy a two day pass at a lesser attraction in Paris. We stay close to the Cluny, which seems to never have a line up. Buy your tickets at a similar place if you can, that way you can avoid the long line of ticket buyers at the big attractions.After your visit to both of these museums head into the Jardins de Tuileres for a glass of wine and a look at Paris at rest.

My favorite Paris museum. I really love this museum, and I can't understand why is it always nearly empty. They house a beautiful impressionist collection, and my personal favorites, Monet's famous' Water Lilies. I absolutely recommend this museum to everyone that finds the Orsay and the Louvre intimidating and overwhelming.
Monet.... Wow... You will never forget visiting the Orangerie! The Monets are worth going, but you will love the other lesser known artists (as well as many other big names) that yu will see.

Right around the corner form Notre Dame. Marie Antoinette was held here after the revolution and this ancient building is now a museum. I found the list of people who were guillotined to be very moving, in a similar way to the list of names on the Vietnam Memorial in WDC.

An anti-climax to the Musee d'orsay. Lovely round rooms filled with Monets water lilies but we visited after the Musee d'orsay which meant we were a little underwhelmed by the place. Once we saw the water lilies there wasn't much else in there that interested our taste.

A bit of a mixture!. We had to wait over 15 minutes to get into the museuma nd once inside it is a bit of a mixture. One floor is completely given over to huge Monet pictures and takes quite short time to view (especially if you have seen Monet pictures before). Downstairs is full of surprises, but a bit muddly to follow round. Worth a visit if you have nothing else to do.

One of Paris's Better Small Museums. This is an agreeable and civilised museum, with a good permanent collection and sometimes interesting temporary exhibitions. As with other Paris art establishments, be wary of when you visit, as security queues at busy weekend times are formidable. There are no refreshment facilities. This is not a particularly serious issue, as the museum is small enough to get through within a couple of hours.Be aware that you can get a combined ticket for l'Orangerie and the Orsay at quite an economical price.

Make sure you go downstairs!. The lillies are really amazing but try and go first thing in the morning, before the crowds, so that you can sit in some peace and quiet and just enjoy them. When you're done, head back to the lobby and make sure you go downstairs to what is arguably the best bit... trust me, you'll be astounded by the sheer size and content of what was one man's private collection of art.
not just the waterlilies.. downstairs, the guillaume collection outshines the waterlilies, in my opinion. it's just awesome that one man and his wife honoring his memory could collect such wonders.
Great visit!. I liked the fact that this museum was small enough to feel like you really saw everything and beautiful location.

Dull!. Visited long before the restoration & much preferred it. Fantastic to see the Water lilies in own space, but everything else seemed drab & squashed into too small spaces. Remembering impact of many Impressionist canvases in series the new seemed poorer and disjointed. No feeling of wanting to linger here.
YOu must see!. A great experience, seeing such large works by Monet. It's such a hidden jewel of a museum. Centrally located and very close to The Louvre.
marvellous space. This museum has been remodelled and updated and presents some marvelous exhibits of modern artists. Soutine exhibit was superb.

Fantastic museum and fascinating 2012-2013 exhibit : Soutine.. The exhibit is not very very big, but very intense.
This paintor has a whole universe that is really worth discovering.

Fantastic experience. Was disappointed by Monet's water lilies-- a case of too much and too late.But the impressionist exhibit was wonderful! I thought the 5 Euro audio-guide was money well spent. Lots on Renoir, and I loved learning about Rousseau and Derain, who were unfamiliar to me. Then topped off with less familiar Matisse, Cezanne, Sisley, and Gauguin....what more can you want for?Tip: Free on first Sunday of the month but go at opening time or lines are VERY long!

Nice break after the Louvre. After a 5 hour visit of the Louvre we walked through Tuileries Gardens to this wonderful, quiet museum. After the hectic atmosphere of the Louvre, we found the calm atmoshphere and limited scope of the museum a welcome change. The couches available in the Monet Water Lillies rooms invite you to stop and take it all in, which the paintings really require to fully appreciate. The other artist exhibitions were both entertaining and informative, as some of it was new to us. Highly recommended.

Fabuous Soutine exhibit right now. You will never see so many Soutine paintings together anyplace else. Also, of course the Monet waterlillies are so special. Giverny is closed for the winter so good to see them here.

Admirable place. Great place. Small museum which has good collection of paintings, including works of Renoir and Monet. You will not spend much time there but will have chance to see Monet's wonderful Nympheas. This is something you will definately need to see.

My favorite museum in Paris!. If you love impressionist art and only have time for one museum in Paris, go here! See the beautiful Monet lily pad paintings and then go downstairs for a huge selection of Renoir, Monet, etc. The museum is small, easy to see everything in less than 90 minutes, and generally less crowded than the d'Orsay or Louvre.
Never been in such awe of a museum. I have never like a museum as much as I liked this one maybe it's because of the fact that I am obsessed with Monet and his water lily's are there

Monet, Monet Monet!. The museum is rather small compared to its mammoth neighbor, but that is what makes it so charming and lends a lasting impression. The galleries that house Monet's Waterlilies are perfection. The light plays across the pieces artfully, lending different accents and emotions as it changes. A must see even if for just a quick stroll.
A must for art lovers. If you love Claude Monet as well as impressionist and post-impressionist painters, then you MUST go to this museum.
Peaceful. The Water Lillies was the highlight for my cousin! She could have easily stayed there til closing time. For me - yes they were soothing - peaceful and calming.

An immersive experience. So wonderful to see Monet's Water Lillies in the space he planned for them. I also liked that the guards periodically asked for quiet in those rooms. The Soutine special exhibit was lovely.

Nicely done. The museum isn't very big but full of surprizes and gems. The round room display of Monet's waterlillies gives one an impression of almost stepping back in time. Surprized to see so many pics here as they aren't allowed, we were often finger wagged at but hard to resist. The Klimt pieces are especially lovely and we spent a lovely, rainy afternoon surrounded by beauty here. Recommend this one for sure.
