Not what I thought. I expected a lot more Monet paintings. Instead, you see a room with admittedly lovely Monet murals, stunning.But it is a very small museum. Given how we had to trek it out from our location, in the rain, I wouldn't do it again.

A nice surprise. This is one of the lesser known galleries in Paris and is often overlooked. The star of the place is the rooms with large murals of Monet's waterlillies. These rooms are meant to be an oasis of calm and beauty and they certainly live up to their intention. The lower levels contain a very nice cross section of paintings which are nicely laid out in smaller rooms... a very pleasant antidote to the sometimes overwhelming Louvre.

Perfect for weekend-visitors. My favourite museum in Paris!. If you want to visit one museum in Paris - this is the one! It's so calm and bright in there. The paintings are huge and you really get the felling that you're in Monet's garden. I highly recommend this museum, it's my favourite museum in Paris. The museum itself is not very big, which is why it's perfect for those who go to Paris over the weekend and don't want to spend an entire day at Musée du Louvre.

great idea. Third time was the charm. Each time we have been to Paris, Musée de L'Orangerie has been closed but this time we were able to visit the new building and see all of the magnificent artwork it has to show off. I am a fan of Monet and other than Musée Marmontann, L'Orangerie has the best display. Then you start adding the Renoir's and Picasso's and Matisse and....well, you get the idea. A must visit if you are in town.

A real gem!. I love the manageable size of Musee de l'Orangerie and spent lots of time absorbing the art without feeling rushed. Monet's very large lilies paintings on circular walls are meant to be the show pieces. They definitely amaze, but also I loved discovering someone new, Soutine's art and life still has me thinking. This museum is a gem.

Monet's Water Lilies - a special treat!. Visiting L'Orangerie to see Monet's large scale waterlily paintings is a memorable experience. The paintings are displayed in two large oval rooms - the paintings curve around the walls and are just mesmerizing! What a treat to be able to visit this beautiful, museum to see these paintings so exquisitely displayed. Do not miss this if you have any opportunity at all to go! We visited it after having enjoyed the very fine impressionist exhibit at the D'Orsay where a few of Monet's smaller waterlily paintings are exhibited and where we learned a good deal about these paintings and Monet's great fondness for them. Stroll through the tuilleries gardens after your visit and think about the magic of Monet's waterlily paintings and the wonderful L'Orangerie!

It's not just about the waterlillies. Strongly recommended if you enjoy impressionist art. The waterlillies have the expected wow factor, but you can easily spend a few hours in the gallery below. I recommend paying the 4 or 5 euros for the audio guide. I have never done that before in a gallery and felt it really added to the experience. You can pick and choose which paintings you want to hear more about, and there is an accessible version aimed at children. I watched one little boy of about 6 who seemed fascinated by the whole thing! Magical way to spend a rainy afternoon.

A Small but Outstanding Art Museum. This museum has a relatively small collection of mostly impressionist works. It is most noted, however, for its display of Claude Monet's massive water lily paintings. Unlike the Orsay, photos are prohibited, even without flash.

Relaxing small museum.. Worth a visit for Monet's Water Lillies series alone and a stroll through the Tullerie Gardens after. Admission available with a combination ticket with the Musee D'Orsay and reduce price.
fab Soutine expo. We thought the Soutine exhibition was great. Signs for getting there from Concorde Metro could have been better.

Open at last. I have visited Paris four times and L'Orangerie was closed each time. At last I was able to see Monet's waterlies in thier circular gallery.
I had not expected to find an amazing impressionist gallery as well.

Monet and More. If you like Monet, be sure to stop in. It's a nice couple-hour stop, and does not require the commitment of the Louvre ... or even the Orsay. Consider a trip to Giverny to see Monet's lillies in person. It will be a trip you never foget.
Don't miss it. It wasn't busy so I felt I had it to myself on a Monday morning. Magical. Sit, think big important thoughts and just take a breather from the hustle and bustle.

Small museum, Monets and others. I loved seeing the Monets on display, as well as the other art. It is a small museum between the Tuileries Garden and the Champs Elysee and takes only about an hour. We used the Paris Museum Pass to cover our entry fee to this and many other museums during our stay.

Beautiful collection. We loved this small gallery. The rooms featuring Monet's water lillies are unique and wonderful to walk through. There was an exhibition from Chaim Soutine which was wonderful and showed the transition in the artist's life and the impact on his work very clearly. A very enjoyable visit

a must for monet lovers. to see the 8 huge water lily canvasses in rooms built to show them propoerly is a great experience. you can get right up to them to see the brushstrokes and thick paint in areas plus also see them from afar. make sure you look at them from right acros the room, not just the seating in the middle - the further back you get the better the perspective. there is also more art in the museum well worth a visit.
l'Orangerie. Full of amazing artwork! Inexpensive and amongst the beautiful grounds of the Tuilleries. If you have an extra hour or so to spend you should definitely check it out.
Monet!!!!. What an amazing museum, the best of painters in the world are in this museum and its right by the Tuileries Garden!!!
Oustanding!. From the architecture to the outstanding art work, this museum is fabulous in every way! Take a tour, well worth it!

if you like Monet.... there were about 5-6 paintings on exhibit, Monets. they are incredible - stunning and beautiful. The Orangerie is an easy walk from the hotel, dodging gypsies in the Tuilleries Jardin; and the Museum Pass worked. Very neat modern-style building - a change from the heavy Victorian ornate architecture everuwhere else.
Wasn't what we expected. On the upside it's close to everything and part of the museum pass. On the downside, it was very underwhelming. Maybe seeing it just after the Louvre didn't do it any favors.

Monet's Garden. We only had two hours and we spent it in Monet's garden. A wonderful display of impressionist art including many works by the famous Monet. You will love his garden. Go and take a look. It never rains on this garden party.
Go for the water lilies.. its all about the Money water lilies presented in a beautiful setting. Really exceptional. the rest of the museum is nice if unexceptional.
small. i was disappointed in the water lily display, very muddy. nice building, the area is too crowded near the champs elysee.

If you are a Monet fan. Just on one side of the Tuileries. The Louvre had a serpentine line on one of the free days so we enjoyed the architecture and outer facades and walked till the Orangerie. Previously used to house orange trees from being destroyed in winter it had a sliding roof which is now replaced and what a masterpiece.Enjoy the sublime water lilies of Monet in a special room with natural light being diffused into the hall. Paintings of Sautine and Utrillo were interesting.The art collecter Paul Guilliame's rooms are replicated in miniature form studded in the walls. Make sure you buy the combo pass when you visit Museum D'Orsay so you can walk in straight into the Orangerie without standing in lines.

amazing. The whole museum is a tribute to Monet works. The oval room, is superbe, the paint are fantastic and also well maintaned. It is a good feeling sit there and look around at the very small particulars on the paints. VERY very nice. My money to buy the musee ticket.. was the best spent in paris!

Monet To The Max. We loved the display of Monet's paintings in the two featured rooms. We've seen his works in N.Y. but nothing compares to seeing the full length paintings at the Orangerie. This is one of the experiences that will bring me back to Paris.

Monet and more. This museum is tucked away in a large set of gardens (Jardin des Tuileries), very close to Place de la Concorde (with the Roue de Paris -- the big ferris wheel) and the Champs Elysees. The museum itself shows two galleries of Monet's water lily paintings in natural light. The galleries are oval, and the massive paintings curve around the walls to let you immerse yourself in them. It's a very special installation, well worth seeing.Downstairs there are more galleries with an amazing collection of works by other painters, including Renoir, Rousseau, Picasso, and more. Definitely get the audiotour for the downstairs galleries -- it really helps provide context for what's a pretty amazing collection.

Go early in the day. I was here at opening and used my museum pass to get in. (stay to the right at the entrance) There were only 15 people or so there at the time. It was wonderful to sit and enjoy the waterlilies without people being in the way. Everyone was very respectful about noise and trying to not obstruct views. The audioguide isn't really necessary, the brochure has enough information in it. The collection on the lower level is quite small so it won't take much time unless you are really into these artists.The whole visit was about 45 minutes.
Monet's best. Smaller than the Orsay but has the best display of Monet. The display of the lilies is second to none. You must see this if you are a Monet fan.

Oustanding small museum; brilliantly executed.. I hadn't heard of this museum with its restful oval rooms surrounded by huge Monet canvases but as impressionist lovers my wife and I found this oustanding. The rest of the gallery is of the same quality - worth the queue and the price.

A whole Day with the Lillies. A real stunner, was the impression that Monet's Lillies were displayed one reflecting the Morning light and another with the setting Sun. This is a marvelous gallery with still paintings from Cezanne and Picasso - we loved the fruity Apple and Biscuits displayed in the long room on level 1. Take time out of your Paris tour and spend a couple of hours here, the memories will stay with you for years. We used the Paris Pass to by pass the queue, again bags must be left with the porters allow 10 mins for this.

Love the Monet water lilies. I came to see Monet's water lilies. you can't see the grand scale on a book. when you are in the room, instantly you can appreciate and enjoy the great art. Please stand back and view the work at different angle.
stunning. This museum is really worth the visit. It is small, however the two oval room with paintings by Monet are amazing, a must see

Relaxing and calming.. The images of the Monet panaromics fill your vision and the two rooms have a calming ambience, making it a lovely place to relax and meditate.Downstairs the Renoirs were good, but I wasn't a fan of the rest of the art. The rooms downstairs were also quite claustrophic, with more people and didn't quite have the same space as upstairs. Def worth a view for the Monets.

In the Tuleries near Orsay and Louvre. If you are a fan of Monet this is a must see. On display are the largest Monet's I have ever seen.They displayed in several rooms that have natural light to show them as the artist intended.While not at as expansive as the Orsay this museum is well worth a visit .Can be see using a combo pass.

Little gem of a museum. Tiny museum tucked away in the corner of the Tuilieries Gardens. The 2 circular rooms with 4 Monet water lilies each are the key attractions. Very moving. But the other paintings by Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso, etc were the unexpected find that turned a 45-mins scheduled stopover, into a 2.5 hours discovery tour.Go mid-week (Wed, Thu) where there tends to be less of a crowd. If you have a Paris Museum Pass, you can skip to the front of the line.

Surprise!. I almost skipped this museum because I didn't see the shortcut for museum passholders and I thought it's main feature was the large format Water Lilies series by Monet. That would have been a shame. Here are all of the classic Impressionists that I missed at the Orsay, as well as an excellent special exhibit of works by Chaim Soutine.

Monet was a genius with his brushes and dots .... Monet immortalized in eight huge panels of your wonderful Garden Giverny and this museum received the deserved attention. Besides his works are also exposed other works of famous painters of his time.

Monet's Water Lilies extraordinaire!. I finally made it to this wonderful museum on my third trip to Paris! Monet's Water Lily paintings are outstanding. I also discovered another favorite artist, Chaim Soutine. L'Orangerie has a great Soutine collection.

May be a better choice than Musee D'Orsay. The Impressionist collection here is really good, more restricted than at the Musee d'Orsay, to be sure, but if you don't want to spend a very long time waiting in a line to get in there, the Orangerie is a very good second choice. And Monet's 8 huge water lily paintings make up for a lot if you're feeling you may have missed too much Impressionist splendor.

Small place big impact. This museum is in a corner of the Tuileries Garden. It's closed Tuesdays, which clearly suprized a few tourists walking around the building trying to figure out how to get in because the hours were not posted. It was well worth the trip back on Wednesday. The main attraction, for me, were the 2 white rooms dedicated to eight of Monet's Water Lilies. The other exhibits were also spectacular. This is a very small museum but certainly a favourite and not to be missed.

Well worth the Monet !. Visited here on a joint ticket with the Musee d'Orsay and therefore avoided the queue waiting to get in. The Monet murals in the upstairs section are everything they are cracked up to be - and more. The experience is awesome. You definitely need to sit down on the benches in the middle of the halls to take the whole thing in. In the basement there are a series of rooms containing the work of various other post-impressionists - some well known , others less so. It's not too clear why these works are here - perhaps just overspill from the Musee d'Orsay - but still worth seeing.
Beautiful L'Orangerie. I loved the Monet Waterlily painting..the huge ones that took 4 huge walls. Plus the painting by Cezanne and Gauguin,Degas etc.

inspiring museum. The Monet exhibit is well worth the brief wait in line for this museum. Standing in either of two rooms which enclose 360 degree Monet paintings is beautiful. The montage depicting the constuction of the exhibit and Monet's inspiration for it is fascinating as well. There are more Impressionist paintings on the lower level as well but it was the Monet rooms that held our interest. This is a small museum but worth seeing.

Monet's Waterlilies. Although there are a lot of fabulous paintings here, the dominate presentation is the 6 huge (~8' x ~30') panels of his paintings of waterlilies. Most of the panels have hues of blue, green, purple & white but one panel had bold reds & oranges!

more than just the waterlilies. monet's waterlilies are, of course, breathtaking. but also visit the lower level, there are some beautiful pieces here also. again, don't try and rush through in a short time. we also visited monet's garden which i would thoroughly recommend if you enjoy this museum

Don't miss this. This is a wonderful gallery and is staffed by helpful and knowledgeable personnel. Buy a ticket combination with Musee D'Orsay which can be used over a period of 4 days. Essential if you are feeling " galleried out" by the whole Paris experience.

Wonderful museum. If you like impressionism, this is the place to be. Good exhibits in the lower level which change relatively frequently for repeat vistors. Main installation on the main floor is great - take a seat and soak it in for awhile.Crowds are much more manageable than the mega-museums close by. Skip the line (if there is one) if you have museum pass.

if you like Monet - this is place to go - for an hr. Small museum but if you have an hour to spare great place to see full waterlilies by Monet on main floor.. Downstairs are a variety of his contemporaries.. nice selection, easy and fun..

Great to pair with Giverny visit - don't forget the downstairs exhibits!. Visited the Orangerie after seeing the gardens at Giverny. Standing in the rooms with Monet's water lily paintings at the Orangerie made me feel like we were back in the gardens themselves. It was incredible to pair the two visits together. We also really enjoyed the exhibits downstairs and found ourselves exposed to new impressionist artists I had never heard of before. Recommend going on the museum pass or a combination ticket with the D'Orsay museum as this one would be a bit pricey on its own.
More than Monet. the water lilies are grand but the entire museum is a wonderful way to spend an hour or so. Tour the Tuilleries before or after.

Great Museum!. Musee del'Orangerie is in my top two favorite Museums in Paris! It is located at the far end of the Jardin des Tuileries. It is a nice change from the large museums like the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay. It was not crowded at all when we went for our visit, so we had no wait to get in. But the Paris Museum Pass is accepted here. Monet's Waterlillys are displayed in two rooms on the first floor. They are absolutely beauiftul. The ground floor has a numerous rooms filled with beautiful art from Picasso, Monet, Renoir, etc! You can easily get through this museum in under 1.5 hours. I highly recommend a visit!

Favorite Museum in Paris. I could sit and look at the Waterlilly canvases all day long, not to mention the remainder of the collection is fabulous and the restoration of the building itself is just beautiful. It is a perfect jewel located in the Jardin de Tuileries. An absolute must see, we went twice in one week!

monet canvasses- fab!. There's not loads to see in this art gallery but that suited us pretty well to be honest as we'd already been to the d'orsay that day and looked at hundreds of pictures! The creme de la creme of this museum is the huge monet canvasses which are an image which will stay with me. Im not a huge art fan and still loved it so for an art lover or monet fan, I imagine it must be even more spectacular! Be warned though- no talking allowed in the room where the canvasses are. The gallery staff are very strict on this!

Small museum it to be overlooked. We visited this museum as a fill in for a few hours and we are so glad that we did. It is marvelous. The huge murals took 4 years to paint and are magnificant. We visit Giverney on the next day. It is a wonderful museum. We did it wait for ticketsonaSaturday. I think many people view thebigssites first but this is unique museum.

Revelations at L'Orangerie. We went to the L'Orangerie because the lines were so long at the D'Orsay, even though we had a pass. The L'Orangerie is magnificent. I thought I had seen enough Monet water lillies in one lifetime before I saw them in these special rooms with natural light. It was storming outside, and the paintings came alive: the water seemed to be moving. A wonderful Chaim Soutine show was there too. Rich permanent collection. Wonderful.
Wonderful, a piece of calm and culture! . We just went to the gardens for 1e which is amazing value. It's so calm and moving, and lovely if the weather is dry!
Another great museum in Paris. loved the exhibition of Chaim Soutin, it is currently on, also some great paintings of Derrain and Renoir.
Follow-on to Giverny. After visiting Giverny to then see Les Nympheas at l'Orangerie was the icing on the cake. Available audios added to the experience.

Wife's 60th Birthday. This is one of our favourite places in Paris, to see Monet's water lillies in such a setting is breathtaking.
Also the impressionist paintings in the other section are outstanding workds of art

Small museum but wonderful exhibits. The water lilies by Monet alone make this museum worth the visit. They are exhibited in two round rooms, so you are surrounded by their beauty. I'd recommend getting the audio tour because the commentary adds incite to the exhibits.

If it's free and/or there's no line, definitely go.. I really liked the Monet rooms, and stupidly never went downstairs (which I've heard was a mistake on my part!). I disliked the line out front and the cost for a small museum, but circumvented both with my getting a Paris Museum Pass, which I really recommend. You may not recoup the cost in terms of entrance fees, but you don't waste half of your vacation standing on lines.

Lovely gallery of impressionist art. Take the guided tour, it runs for 1 hour 15 min and is informative and includes some interesting stories about the artists. There is a double gallery ticket available which is good value.

Monet takes center stage here. While I loved the water lily and the two rooms devoted to it upstairs, the downstairs exhibits were wonderful for those loving impressionists. One could spend as little or as much time as you needed and it was never crowded when we visited. Again the museum pass allows frequent visits and the ability to avoid lines.

More Than Just Water Lilies. As a Monet fan who was last in Paris when the museum was closed for renovation, we were not going to miss it again. Monet's water lily murals are massive and perfectly set in two circular rooms with 4 murals in each. It is a must for a Monet fan, but to our pleasant surprise, there is also an excellent collection of impressionist and other works in the basement.
Excellent. Absolutely great. Not crowded, very pleasant to walk about andMonet's waterlilies spectacular. A comprehensive collection of artwork. Enjoyed it very much.

Finally open after more than 10 years visiting Paris. Well esigned museum. Tremendous focus on Monet, which is a favorite of our family. Special rooms were created just to show the Water Lilies murals just as Monet wished for them to be viewed. The docent tour was clear and concise. We will visit this museum again

Small and worth every minute. This is one of my favorite museums in Paris. It has a small yet wonderful collection of Impressionist art, and all of Monet's water lilies are in the basement. I've never encountered lines here, and love the collections.

Monets, Renoirs and Picassos, oh my!. This was a great museum experience on our last morning in Paris! We saw the Guiomme (sp?) collection exhibition which is currently featured here. Be sure to get the audio tour, so you get all of the background on the period of the late 1800s and early 20th century. Viewing the paintings and hearing the narrative of the times in which the artists lived and worked, it was easy to drift back to those times. Many great works of art here, minus the crowds!

Must visit. There's no other exhibition like it, just sit back and appreciate the whole expansive wall of waterlilies. The rest of the museum has a unique collection. One of our favourite museums, so much so that we actually spent money at the gift store afterwards!The only annoying thing was the constant click of cameras, even though the tourists were warned many times to not take any photos.

Small but very enjoyable museum. Upstairs, there are two large rooms with Monet's Water Lilies. Very peaceful and serene. Impressive, also, when you observe the size of the paintings. Downstairs, there are permanent exhibits of many of the famous Impressionist artists -- so many famous, amazing artists all in one place. There was also a temporary exhibit but we did not visit. This museum is relatively small (tiny compared to the Louvre). But the size makes the experience very enjoyable (not as overwhelming as visiting the Louvre, for example).Right outside the Musee d'Orsay, there is a small garden with large, life-size Rodin statutes. It is a quiet, reflective place. It's a nice place to take a seat in one of the green wooden recliner chairs & relax.

World Class. This museum is located at the south western end of the Tuilleries Gardens and the walk from the Louvre though the garden is delightful. L'Orangerie was renovated in 2006 and successfully so. Monet's huge waterlilies are rolled out in two well lighted galleries and easily studied, even when there are crowds filling the rooms. In the lower level is the collection of Paul Guillaume, the most important art dealer in Paris during the early 20th century. Picasso's blue period and rose period are represented by important works. Renoirs line the walls, paintings that are so famous that you surely saw reproductions in your grand parents house. Cezanne, Matisse, Gauguin, Rousseau and others are represented. During our visit a comprehensive exhibit of paintings by Soutine was on display. Next year Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera paintings will be exhibited. Musee de l'Orangerie is a world class museum of art and it should be included in any visit to Paris lasting more than three days.
little museum, with a lot of atraction. I loved the museum it is a jewel, very modern with Monet paintings inside, i recommend if you go to Paris, you should not miss it

Small Museum, but worth it if you love Monet. This museum was wonderful because it has 2 rooms of gorgeous Monet Waterlilies paintings. There are also exhibits below where you can see a few paintings by Picasso, Rembrandt, and a few other incredible artists. I would recommend this museum if you are in the area, a fan of Monet, and are short on time. The museum only takes around an hour to see, an hour and a half maximum. But is a beautiful museum, and in my opinion, totally worth it. Happy Travels, Casey
Expensive. This place is a little weird-an exhibiton of mainly nudes downstairs and Manet's paintings upstairs. Military type assistants shout 'silence'a lot!Beware of the gold ring scam outside
Don't miss it!. It's incredible to see Monet's waterlilies in these rooms, designed for them. There are lots of places to see impressionist art in Paris, but don't miss this one. It's incredible.

Bargain visit. We visited at 5 p.m. so got in cheaper. The Monets are gorgeous and the collection downstairs was great - included works by Picasso, Derain, Matisse. Excellent value and a lovely, small gallery.

Monets Masterpieces. This is a nice little museum set at the end of the Tuilleries Gardens adjacent to the Place de la Concorde. It contains some wonderful impresionists work and some great full mural work by Monet. It is a funny style of museum, nothing like the palace style like Louvre or D'Órsay but if you like the likes of Monet, Lautrec et al this is the best display in Paris. There are a lot better galleries if you haven't got much time. Very well located.

Not to be missed. Brilliant tribute to Monet. If you only visit one museum in Paris, go for this. There are several 'dioramas' of Monet's Water Lilies. There is also an exhibition of a collection of fine art of the same period.
Water lillies and more. Nice range of impressionist art as well as the Manet waterlillies which was huge. Particularly liked the art by Utrillo and Cezanne

Best Museum in the World. Well, I havent been to every museum in the world, but I've been to maybe hundreds. This place hit me as perfect. My attention span is fairly short, maybe 50 minutes. Every piece is special, and in an hour you can see it all. Actually, if I had a choice, I'd skip the Louvre and do this place - wonderful.
Water lilies are beautiful!. Definitely recommend that you go and see the water lilies! So beautiful! Stunning art museum as well.

Stunning Monets and a private collection of photos and art. Well worth a visit for the two first rooms alone of wall to wall Mpnet Lilly's the way he intended. Then an interesting collection of more modern paintings, Nadar photos. Well worth the visit of you like this era of art.

Fantastic building and art. If you are a fan of Monet and his group of artists you cannot miss this gallery.It is set in the most beautiful park in Paris,with plenty of coffee places for you to visit. The highlight however is the water lily paintings housed in its own 2 rooms.be prepaired to spend some time in here as the longer you look the better they get!!

Really just for the water lollies. Very nice museum.we had to queue at this for the longest out of all attractions we went to in Paris.very small museum and best bit is the two water lily rooms obviously.toilets were disgusting.urinals taped off and only one male cubicle in use but got ushered into disabled toilet to use their sink as ours also not in use!

A gem of a museum!. This is where Monet's lovely Water Lily paintings are housed as well as other beautiful Impressionistic paintings. There's always an interesting special exhibit. A smaller, more managable museum than the Louvre or d'Orsay.
Nympheas!. This museum has one of the most fantastic basements that a person could ever spend time in. I could spend all day with Monet's waterlilies. Don't miss it.
Monet at his finest. This was an amazing Musee. Viewing the Monet paintings in the round after seeing the live view in Giverny was a moving experience.
Musee de l'Orangerie. I loved this museum. Very small and doesn't take very long to go through. Pretty crowded on free days

A true gem. This museum is a little treasure; easy to see and enjoy all the art work, plenty of resting space and a treasure trove of 19th C art work all from one man's collection. Amazing! This is the arat museum to visit for those who really don't like art museums.

Another museum you can't miss!. Museum de L'Orangerie is located in Jardin des Tuilleries, so it's a perfect opportunity to rest your feet and delight your sight.This museum has two magnificent white walled oval rooms where the Nymphéas of Monet will make you feel like you've just entered the most peaceful place ever, where dreams are suddenly easier to achieve.The lower floors have Impressionism and Expressionism paintings.Just like I wrote in Musée D'Orsay, don't be frightened by the queue: it goes really fast!Don't miss this museum in Paris, it's wonderful!

a little jewel. The first and second rooms with huge paintings of Monet are just so relaxing and beautiful, this is a must. The museum is also much less crowded than the Orsay museum, the queues are not that long and it is ideally situated, just at the jardin des tuileries and the concorde.
A Gem in the Park. Don't walk thru the Jardin de Tulleries without stopping by the Musee de L'Orangerie. Its a great museum and only takes an hour to wolk through. Well worth your time.

Monet was great. Loved the Monet on the first floor hence the very good rating, the exhibitions down stairs were ok, I don't like expressionists. A very small gallery, no restaurant or coffee area, worth a visit if you have an hour to spare and a Paris pass, not sure I would have paid to get in.

Monet, water lilies and friends. This is a beautiful museum. The top floor has the two oval rooms containing the 360 degree paintings of the water Lillies by Monet. The lower floor had many paintings by Gaugin, Rousea, Monet and Cezan. The whole tour takes around two hours and you can rent an audio guide that is preloaded on an iPod touch. You definitely enjoy this one.

Lovely "bite" of French art. Went to the Musee de l'Orangerie on first Sunday. Line was (unsurprisingly) quite long, but a guard let in groups of visitors a few at a time and we were in within 10-15 minutes. Beautiful views of the Eiffel Tower, obelisk and Champs Élysées as we waited, even if it was raining. Went straight to Monet's piece and it was everything I hoped it would be: grand, inspiring, peaceful. Went downstairs to see the rotating collection and a Soutine exhibit, which was quite nice and a good juxtaposition in comparison to Monet and the other pieces on display at the time. Best of all, it's a small museum, so it is not a huge time commitment or extensive entree of art, for those who would like to see other sites in Paris or, like my companions, those with a short attention span. Please, please visit!

An island of peace and calm.... ....just like Monet wanted it to be. Ideally placed between the Musee d'Orsay and the Louvre, overlooking the Concorde, this is the perfect place to chill out, rest, reflect, ... The Nymphéas rooms is something to remember!
LOVE CLAUDE.. Perfect if you don't want to get too caught up in the rush of the Louvre, and if you're more interested in post 1850 impressionism. The Waterlillies are phenomenal.

Unmissable. In that you can't miss it. If you are doing any walking in Paris you will likely go right by it. And it has Waterlilies, so what are you going to do?
Buy your (undated) tickets online and keep them with you. Then when it's a nice day and you are doing that walk, pop in.
Nice size-beautiful collection. Smaller museum of beautiful impressionist and modernista painters. Perfect size for "museum weary" tourists.

Home to Monet's most spectacular achievement. Now fully restored to Monet's original design, it's not an installation to be rushed through. Take your time to sit and contemplate what it must have taken for an 80-year-old artist to have conceived, designed, painted and installed this enormous gift to the French nation. Be sure to get the audio tour so you can listen to the commentary a few times.

Small but well worth it.. The main visitor attraction is the massive Monet Water lilies in 2 circular adjoining rooms. These are the star of the show, however, while we were there, there was also a very impressive exhibition downstairs of works by Soutine which we also really enjoyed.
Monet paintings...Wow!. Its worth every cent just to see Monet's water-lily paintings. They curve around the circular rooms, filling the walls. Simply amazing!
Monet. Great if you like Monet - buy a multi ticket for here and Musee d'Orsay - also great location to sit and watch the Effel Tower light up as it gets dark.

My favority museum in Paris - I am a Monet fan!. If you like Monet, there is no other place to go but L'Orangerie!I remember a few years ago, I visited Musee Marmottan and saw his famous Nympheas. The space was tight and they had to show the individual panels separately. I was thinking, are you kidding me? I can't believe these made Monet famous.Well, a few years later l'Orangerie reopened after the renovation and I visited it to see his Nympheas. I was totally taken by it. They were so mesmerizing!!! Especially, after you read the story behind how Monet was going blind when he painted them! Thereafter, every time I visited Paris, I will definitely visit l'Orangerie even I skipped the Louve or musee d'Orsay. I took some pictures a few years ago, but unfortunately, this time they won't allow any photographing at all! Here are some pictures I told a few years ago.

Excellent presentation of Monet masterworks. The presentation of Monet's masterworks are worth the trip here. Its a good place to sit down in front of these massive canvases and get lost in the fusion of color and light.There are some interesting works on the lower levels, but people come here for Monet. Definitely worth a stop if you are using a Museum Pass.

Monet Heaven. What can I say other than sitting in the rooms with the Monet painting was otherworldly! Give yourself time to just sit and appreciate! Go early as it gets quite busy mid-day. Highly recommended!
Small but worth the time. A private, personal collection with some very distinct pieces. Worth a visit. Check on their current exhibit...we saw a very fascinating special show.
Home for Monet. I will always remember the fantastic display of Monets paintings. Never realized the size and scope of his work. The lower level houses great works as well.

An unforgettable experience. To see Monet's Waterlillies in such a beautiful and purposeful built place was a wonderful and moving experience. However, the waterlillies are not all that there is to l'Orangerie. The exhibition downstairs is very absorbing and houses work from famous artists, a definite must see. When we arrived we bought a passport ticket that also allowed us to go to Musee d'orsay, good value for money.

A place of peace in the Tuilleries. Easily accessible in the corner of the gardens. We spent quite a while simply sitting in the centre of the room looking at Monet's giant canvasses a reminder of our visit to his actual garden at Giverny which inspired him to create these paintings That was also a wonderful experience and a good lunch with a very friendly host across the road near the bus stop.
If you like Monet .... visit this museum. Worth a visit to see the Monet paintings, but this place will seem tiny in comparison to The Louvre, so go here first!

The experience of seeing Monet's water lillies as long as you want is unforgetable. The light is fantastic.I wouldn't tour the Walter collection after Monet's water lillies,if you want to see all leave Monet to the end to soak on the colours shadows and all
Good for Monet. I just went to see the Monet water lily murals as I was going to Giverny the next day. They were specatcular. Nice, airy, open display.

Gem inside tulleries. This museum is a breath of fresh air in comparison with D'Orsay and Louvre. It is set in an old greenhouse at the tulleries and has a wonderful collection of giant monet Nympheas with natural lighting. It is stunning. Normally lots of paintings from the D'Orsay are there, so there is always wonderful artists to watch. You can also buy a ticket with L'orangerie and d'orsay combined which saves a few bucks. And right outside the museum is a beautiful rodin sculpture. Only in Paris.
Another Impressionist gem. The highlight here is two large circular rooms where Monet's waterlilies surround you in shades of purple, pink, blue and green.

If you love Monet's Water Lillies, go here.. A building and exhibit area, designed by Monet, built specifically to house his giant canvasses in an elliptical fashion, so that you feel that you are in his garden. What can be better than that? Again we had the museum pass, and went as soon as it opened to avoid the lines and be first in. There is an audio tour, for the permanent collection which again I recommend you purchase.

Gem of an art museum. The museum has a permanent exhibit of Monet's paintings of his garden (Giverney) that were given to Paris as a gift after WW1. The museum also has visiting exhibits. It is a small art museum that is not overwhelming and can be enjoyed in about an hour.

Monet .... and then some. again...an amazing building built to showcase an amazing artist
the rooms dedicated for the lilies are outstanding...they take ones breath away
an enjoyable walk takes you thru some special exhibits
loved this place and went more than once
:)

Fabulous!. Loved the works of Soutine and visited this exhibition a few times during our visit to the gallery. The Monet water lilies were amazing too - the sheer scale of them is spectacular! This formed the afternoon of a day out, having been to Musee de l'Orsay in the morning. Worth buying the ticket to cover both exhibitions.

Mesmerized....!. I never imagined that a sculpture-freak like me would get so lost in paintings...!The stunning waterlilies are just too good - and after staring at them for a few minutes, it's virtually impossible to tear yourself away. At one point, I felt the urge to 'jump in' and take a dip.A very small museum that strongly brings home the old adage - good things come in small packages.
Amazing. i cannot begin to describe the wow factor when you walk in and see Monet's spectacular works for art - this is an absolute MUST if you like impressionist art. Be prepared for the wow factor
A Waterlillies Experience - but don't miss downstairs. Monet's Waterlillies are what brings the crowd, but don't miss the outstanding collection downstairs. There are also changing featured artists.

Wondrous place. We visited this museum/gallery on Sunday morning in October, the sun had come out and the locality cam to life. The presentation of Monet's water lilies is breathtaking, they are in two beautiful white oval rooms, quiet, even when full of people. There is plenty of space to stare and reflect on a life's work. It was truly a privilege to see them. It is not sensible to visit Paris and not see this amazing place.

wonderful small museum with great works. one has to see the 2 oval rooms - which are impressing enough but to my surprise there is a pretty big exhibition downstairs with many famous works including a pretty astonishing Russian artist next to the french classics, the building is located at the fare end of the Tuileries Park (other end from Louvre).
Monet at his best!. We also loved the special exhibit, Soutine. Displays are well done and it is a great space. I would recommend a weekday visit when the crowds are less.
Information. Good for Monet, but very small. It takes you 20 minutes to walk it completely if you are not a very fan of arts, otherwise 1hour

Didn't love it. There are many wonderful museums in Paris filled with amazingly beautiful works. This one just didn't do it for me. The museum is really just devoted to several works of art by Monet. I've been to Giverney and love Monet, but just didn't connect with these pieces. Desolee Claude!

Impressed by this small museum. This was a first visit to this museum, even though I have been to Paris more than 30 times. The Monet Water Lillies was truly the highlight, However, the museum also has the art Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, and Renoir, only to name a few. This truly was a worthwhile visit.
Monet. We loved the fact we were able to enjoy Monet's Water Lillie paintings and other master paintings as well but to be able see Monet's painting was a magic moment and to be remember forever

If you love Monet...this museum is a MUST!. We loved everything about this museum...the huge Monet panels, the museum architecture, the additional impressionist art painting collection on the bottom floor...what a great way to spend the afternoon!!! If you are using the Paris Museum pass, you don't have to stand in the long line to enter :>)

monet treat. if you like Monet and impressionist paintings, this museum and the Musee Marmotten Monet up in the 16th, are the place to go, these are smaller Monet museums without the lines and crowds. We saw both and were not disappointed. Bought the admission ticket to Giverny here as well which made my trip very memorable. No photos allowed inside.
Don't miss!. Don't breeze past this little musee. It only takes about 1.5-2hrs to see every thing in here and its worth it. See Monet's waterlillies as he wanted them to be displayed!

Monet heaven!. For a mere €7.50, you can see this magnificent display of Monet's water lilies series. Housed in two purpose built oval shaped rooms you can sit without large crowds and just immerse yourself in this beautiful paintings. There is also a wonderful collection of Renoirs, Picassos, a stunning Gaugin, multiple Cezannes and more. Fabulous!

Wow - very impressive. This is a great museum - very different to others and very impressive, especially if you like impressionism. Easy to get in if you go first thing in the morning - there were no queues at all...I would go back again next time I'm in Paris!

Not to be missed. Thirteen years ago when were last in Paris this was the only gallery open on Whitmonday and the queue was so long that we couldn't get in. Well, since then the great renovation has taken place! What a beautiful gallery! So much space, so clean and light, and the art so well displayed! And what a relief not to have to crane one's neck as one does in so many galleries around the world, where pictures are hung one above the other instead of only at eye-level. It's amazing how just one painting can take one's breath away; a Gauguin did that for me - painted just 2 years before he died - a man and two children in a field, two bright green trees, nothing special you might say but it blew me away.And then the principal exhibit, those two connecting elliptical rooms with the most amazing Monet lilies. Having visited Giverny all those years ago, my wife and I enjoyed both the 8 panels of the painting and the flood of memories which they evoked. This is surely, in a city that houses so many great and beautiful works of art, a national treasure, so it is great to learn that it survived the wartime bombings and the (to us incomprehensible) years of dismissive neglect.

The best museum in Paris. So beautiful, and not overwhelming. The people there are there to see the art, not standing in fron of a painting for a photograph to be taken! We went back twice, because we loved it so.

Monet without the crowds of the Orsay. Beautifully renovated art museum with the chance to see Monet's exquisite water lilies series hanging in the octagonal rooms for which they were painted. No crowds and lots of time and space to reflect on the art.

Unless you admire the Art don't go.. My wife loved this but I found it simply: two big rooms with a beautiful pictures that after 2 minutes I was bored. No I know some will say "I am uncultured" but sometime you have to be honest, if you don't find the art inside awe-inspiring you are going to be bored. The smaller gallery and AV display below and the building itself, was much more interesting but not enough for me to justify spending my limited time in Paris on. We went via Paris Pass so no money lost.

It's everything they say it is!. Take plenty of time and get the audioguide. This is not only Monet's waterlilies series wrapped around the two oval rooms, but galleries of Renoir, Rousseu, Derain, Picasso etc. Just fantastic!

Surprise!!. Went to the Musee De Orsay and it was raining and everyone was trying to get in so we desided to go check out the Orangerie.Line not bad and the Lillies were amazing. Also by the passport which got us in to the Orsay the next day past all the lines was great.

Monet Lover's Dream. This hidden museum is a MUST see for any one that love's Monet. The panoramic water lilies installed in two natural light lit rooms is a place to sit and take in how brilliant of an artist he was. The museum also houses an amazing collection of Cezanne, Picasso, Renoir, Matisse, Gauguin and the list goes on. Take the time to visit this one!
too small. Recommend to buy combined tickets with Musee d'Orsay. You will save 6 Euro. NOT recommended for non-qualified people.
Soutine exhibit. We had little time here and stuck to the current exhibition of Chaim Soutine. It was excellent and much enjoyed. Wish we'd had more time to walk around and see the collections.

Yes - see this Museum. Loved this museum in the Tuileries. Monet's water lilies are displayed in two oval rooms and (with less people there) you can sit and absorb and feel like you are almost in the painting. The collection downstairs is great and you can take in the museum easily without too much time consumption and art overload and then stroll the Tuileries apres!

Gem of a museum. So peaceful, so serene, so compact and so utterly beautiful. This gem of a museum is never crowded, so you can sit and relax (just like Monet intended) and take in the astounding colors of his water lilies, oblivious to the swirl and whirl of Paris outside. Particularly good deal if you combine with the Orsay (which is deservedly the #1 site in this list). We loved it.

New Soutine exhibit until January quite good.. Of course, seeing Monet's vision come to life with his large canvases is spectacular and not be missed.But, until January 2013, the museum has a new Soutine exhibit which collects several of his works in themes. It's a great way to get the sense and depth of this tortured artist whom Guilliame supported as a patron and summer guest. It's worthwhile getting the Orsay/Organerie pass for only 14 euros. Easily done together.

My favorite museum in Paris.. If you are a Monet lover, this is your place. The huge waterlilly murals displayed in the oval room were magnificent. And the lower level contained the works of several major artists and was entirely manageable. We were there for about 2 hours on a "free" Sunday. Stood in line for about 25 minutes but it was so worth it.

Best afternoon in Paris. We took the guided tour and our guide was brilliant! she was professional and funny. She took her time with the group and was so passionate about the collection that you couldn't help to fall in love with the place! Can't wait to come back!

Must see for Monet enthusiasts. This museum houses the most wonderful collection of Monet's Water-lilies (Nympheas) paintings.The two oval rooms on the first floor were designed with Monet's specifications so that the viewer can appreciate the works. This is definitely the highlight of the museum.The lower floor houses other paintings from other impressionist/post-impressionist artists such as Cezanne, Matisse, and Paul Gauguin.Admissions is approximately 7-8 Euros. It is covered by the Museum Pass.This might not be the best attraction for children. But right outside the museum is the Tuileries Garden which is also very beautiful.

Showcases a unique collection looking closely at the early 20th century. A little hard to find inside of the Tuilliaries park, but a grand view of Place de la Concorde next door. Collection of Paul Guilliame, an art dealer of the early 20th century who died in 1934. His wife went on to tweak the collection until her death in the 1970's. It is an extraordinary and personal look at a time of intense creativity in the Parisian art scene. Budget more than an hour or two to enjoy what this museum has to offer. Get the audiotape -- it is the best we found, concise, informative and closely tied to each work of art.

One of my favorite. The collection at L'Orangerie is not as extensive as that in several other Parisian museums, but I particularly like the curating, especially of the special exhibits. The order in which the paintings are exhibited and the written information provided with the exhibits truly lead to better understanding of the artist and her/his works. Fair warning: although brochures for the special exhibits are available in English, additional information throughout the exhibits is in French only.As for the Monet murals, if a viewer sits quietly, s/he can, in a sense, become immersed in Monet's garden rather than being a mere observer of paintings. This works better when the museum isn't crowded, i.e. very early in the morning or just before closing. If you have a museum pass, insist that the guards show you the correct line. It is much shorter than the line for purchasing tickets.

Most Amazing Display of Monet's. It has two large rooms that are oval in shape which have Monet's water lillies completely covering the walls. You'll never see anything like it anywhere else in the world. Had a great exhibit of Soutines works. Also has a fairly good collection of Renoir's, but not as good as the Barnes in Philadelphia, PA.
Impressionests. this Museum has Monet's Water Lillies and other great paintings. You can use your museum pass and it is a short walk from the Dorsay and the Louvre

A Must-See in Paris. Since a lot of people reviewing mentioned Monet, I wouldn't repeat here. Instead, I have 2 recommendations for you. First, be sure to buy ticket for Orsay and Orangerie. That way, you can enter Orsay Meseum later without the hassle of waiting in a long queue to buy a ticket. Second, either after or before you go to Orangerie, visit Monet's house and garden in Giverny. That completes the journey to Monet's beautiful paintings.
A Must for Monet. A must for anyone visiting Paris. Its not a large museum so you won't need much time but its definitely worth it.Its nice to just sit and look at the giant Monet waterlilies.
Breathtaking Art. Monet Water Lilies and much much more. Huge assortment of A-list artists, much more than I expected. Renovations are spectacular.

A must see Museum in a city of Amazing Museums.. Do not miss this museum !!! Its small, and can be done quickly if pressed for time. The Monet Waterlillies are here, but downstairs there are many wonderful Renoirs & special guest exhibitions.The Monet waterlillies, seen as the artist intended, two rooms were all walls are covered in large mural sized panels, to create a chill spot away from the bustle and problems of life, for war torn Parisians, equally in need in today's modern stressful environment .There are so many Renoirs, and Picasso's spanning the early and late careers of these artist, you can see the evolution of their style. Never seen a non-cubic painting by Picasso, let alone one as he is developing the style he was famous for.Big surprise, well worth the vist.

Monet...sigh.... This is a hidden gem. If you like Monet you must go here. He designed two rooms to showcase his Water Lilies paintings as a respite from the chaos of the city as gift to Paris. The rooms are indescribably beautiful.
A must see. If you love Monet, this is a must! Evenif your not a follower, it's worth going because of the beautiful men paintings and the amazing architecture of the museum.
A must go. We were travelling on to Givernay to Monets gardens so walking into this gallery and viewing the fabulous Monet paintings was a real bonus starter. The gallery is all well worth a visit.
Minute museum. You come herre for the waterlilies all the rest is just more art to look at. Small but quaint little place at the end of the Tuileries
One of my favorites. Do not miss this museum!! The Monet Waterlillies are here but also go downstairs where there are many wonderful Renoirs and others. Great bookstore as well.

Finally!. After trying to visit this museum on several visits, we finally were able to be in Paris when it as open instead of being under renovation. The Money exhibit is truly wonderful. It is too bad Monet died before seeing his work installed in the museum.

Just Popped In. In a recent June 2012 visit to Paris I had planned a visit to this museum but it was far down the priority list of places to see. My wife and I just happened to end up at this end of the Tuileries Gardens with some extra time on our hands and decided to pop if for a look-see. Since we had previously purchased the Paris Museum Pass, we had no entrance cost.I give this Museum a mid-rating. There is some good art but, in my opinion, it doesn't deserve more than a 30 minute stay. The central piece of art is certainly the Monet Water-Lilies panels displayed in the basement in oval rooms. There are other pieces of Impressionist art that appealed to us but there's not enough to spend a great deal of time viewing. If you are really interesed in seeing a comprehensive collection of Monet Art and a representation of Impressionart art from Monet's contemporaries, I strongly suggest a visit to the Marmottan Museum in the 16th arrondisement. A few stops on the Metro land you a short walk to this Museum. It's well worth the effort to get there and is worthy of a few hours taking in all this magnificent art. If you love Monet, don't pass on the Marmottan.
Fantastic. I never thought I would be so blown away by how amazing Monet's Water lillies were but it is the type of place you could spend hours just sitting and looking at them. A Paris must.
Monet's masterpiece. One of my favourite places in Paris. The two rooms filled with Monet's huge waterlilies paintings are quite amazing.
Calm and peaceful. Whoever loves Monet's nymphea ponds must come here! I visited the museum on 1st Sunday of the month which is free. Arrive there in an early morning to avoid a long queue.

Unexpected gem. We didn't know what to expect with this museum that is situated in the Tuileries. There was an exhibit by an artist names Chaim Soutine, who I was unfamiliar with. It was like discovering a great and wondering why you hadn't heard of him. The other collection is great too, especially for lovers of impressionism and post-impressionism.

Wonderful Monet. My wife and I are not exactly culture vultures but this small gallery is wonderful for a quick hour or so. The Monet rooms are well worth the entry price. Buy a ticket online before though if you can.

Go for the Monet Water Lillies, Linger for the rest of the collection. Great place to sit and relax to look at the Water Lillies. Don't miss the rest of the impressionist collection in the basement. Really nice museum. Not crowded like the Lourve.

My favorite museum!. I love this museum. It's rarely crowded and has the most wonderful Monet paintings. When you walk in it is truely breathtaking! Also downstairs there are some great Reniors and other important artists. It is not overwhelming like some musuems.

great place inside and outside. perfect exhibition area, beautiful inside and outside. A must for every visitor in Paris. Manets waterlilies from wall to wall. Beautiful light and lovely shaped building. Large rooms easy access, lovely park outside. Just perfect for any art lover.

Do not miss Monet's waterlilies!. Seeing this exhibit was perhaps the best art experience I've had. Awesome, inspiring, and moving. The rest of the museum was interesting, including the architecture, but it's worth the price of admission just to see the murals.
love of musiums. I did get a Paris musium pass and this is one in it. I love everything and Claud Monet collection of water lilies asxwell as other works.
Monet in the round. If you can make it in the off season, prepare to spend quality time with Monet's Water Lilies here. Book ahead to save waiting in long lines.
So Beautiful!. To sit in the Musee de L'Orangerie and let Monet's beautiful paintings touch your heart is sheer joy. What a pleasure to be able to see and enjoy the work of this great Master.

Tiny museum with Grand collection. This tiny museum which holds the wonderful gigantic waterlillies by Monet and a small collection of other Impressionist works was a wonderful break from the other large major sites. A peaceful respite in the middle of Paris just as Monet hoped it would be.

Another favorite!. Many of our favorite painters are represented here and it is of manageable size so you can remember what you have seen. We had advanced tickets so there was no waiting in very long lines.

Art afternoon. we were lucky that the day we were there there was a special display with free admission, lots of people , it took about half hour to get to the front entrance but was very worth wile. there was one room with the very large "water lily paintings" by Monet. A very nice walk through the park leading up to the L'O rangerie .

Don't miss one of the best Museums in Paris.. Go for Monet's gorgeously displayed "Lillies", it's a stunning awe inspiring gallery, especially if you have visited Giverny first. See the gardens through Monet's vision. It's much quieter than the D'Orsay or Le Louvre.
Must see. It doesn't take long to view the water lilies. A must see in Paris. Don't forget there are two rooms of 360 degree water lilies.

They refuse entry 40 minutes before closing!!!. This was terrible, we arrived 38 minutes before closing and were not allowed entry. We wanted to see one thing, the Water Lillies and it would have taken 5 minutes, but we were not allowed in!!! Terrible service to customers.

Easy to like. We came here right after visiting Monet's house and gardens in Giverny (thus seeing the famed water-lily pond scene first, and the famous set of paintings, called the Nympheas, of that pond second). Combining these in the same day enhanced our appreciation of both. Monet's house is interesting for its historical significance in Impressionist art, while the panoramic paintings in the Orangerie have a calming quality, a sense of the infinite, that go well beyond real life. For us, then, the visit to Giverny was more of an intellectual exercise, while sitting in the Orangerie to soak in the Nympheas was more of an emotional, even a spiritual experience. Whether or not you have the time to go to Giverny, and even if you know nothing about Art, invest the brief time it takes to visit the Orangerie. One week after their visit to Paris, few non-artsy people will be able to remember a single particular painting in the more famous Musee d'Orsay. But no one will ever forget Monet's water-lilies.
Wonderful Setting. This is my favourite Parisian museum. Monets Nympheas displayed as the artist intended breathtaking - arrive early to avoid the queues and be prepared to be impressed

really wonderful. Not a big collection but definitely worth the visit, after rubbing shoulders with the tall models of the Paris Fashion week in the beautiful Tuileries ;P i spent about 2 hours feeding my eyes with Monet, Renoir and even some picasso.. c'est bon!

Beautiful. It was amazing to see Monet's huge masterpieces at L'Orangerie. Also, there's a famous Rodin sculpture out front. Lines aren't as long as D'Orsay and the Louvre and there's a cheap 2-day ticket that gets you into both L'Orangerie and D'Orsay. If you buy it here, you won't have to deal with the long lines at D'Orsay.
Small, bite-sized gallery. Much more manageable than bigger gallieries. Only requires one to two hours to see some amazing (and famous) pieces of art. Recommend getting the audioguide.

Monet's Waterlillies. Reading Monet's intent with these paintings being for a respite from all of the chaos of city life outside its walls, I really did feel like this place executed his vision perfectly. Peaceful and surrounded by his visions of Giverny, you do tend to melt away into the paintings that almost encircle you. Worth a visit.

Go there just for Monet water lilies!. While this is not my favorite museum in Paris, you have to stop there just for Monet water lilies. The other exhibits are usually more modern oriented and can be easily skipped especially if you only have a week or 10 days in Paris.But the water lilies, no matter how many times you have seen them in picture, HAVE to be seen.... even if you are not an impressionist fan. And even if you think that it's just a big blob when you enter the room, back away to the other side of the room and look at them again and suddenly a whole new world will open to you!

Maybe just not my cup of tea. If you’re in love with this style of art then you will love this museum too. I was far less impressed with it than I expected to be but my wife seemed to enjoy it. The building isn’t very large and was clearly designed to present this particular style of art. While the locals seem to have no trouble giving you directions to the other attractions in the area, several people we asked about this museum acted as if they had never heard of it, which seemed really surprising. While I’d have no problem revisiting many of the sights we saw in this trip on a future trip to Paris, this wouldn’t be one of them.
Thanks. On a rainy day this is a great place to visit. Wonderful exhibits. Wish they had a coffee shop in the restauant.

Great water lilies. Fun to see beautiful and famous Monet water lilly murals along with other significant Impressionist art. Grateful for the small size of this museum, which makes it manageable to do on same day as another Paris must-see spot.
A must if you love Monet. I like everything about this musee because it's Monet. God location in the Tuilerie Garden and a nice walk to the Louve.
c'est manifique!. I really enjoy Monet's paintings. The gallery was laid out in a great ellipsis with calm white walls. Not too many crowds. A visit is manageable in an hour or two.

Great for sitting and contemplating. After traipsing through all the various galleries, this is a place to sit and drink in the lovely colors and brush strokes of these well known works.Teen gypsies were hanging around the area when I was there and the seemed to be setting people up to be pick pocketed.... Be aware when you wander out of the gallery blessed out by the art.
Have time to sit and absorb. Monet's famous room size paintings are worth time to absorb. Also has a range of other paintings, but the reason to go is the water lillies it was built to house.
A special place to see Monet. Not nearly as crowded as better known art museums and as most know, l'Orangerie displays some of Monet's grand paintings. Reasonably priced and well managed.
Outstanding. Thrilling to see Monet's extraordinary lily canvas. A beautiful and peaceful scene. A must see in Paris.

Beautiful Monet Rooms. We had only been at the Musee d'Orsay before but went to this museum instead this time. We only went to see the Monet rooms and they were both beautiful. This was a great place to introduce children to this great artist because the pictures were so large you could walk along the length of both rooms and just talk about colors and feelings.

Must see. This museum is not to be missed because the painting viewing experience in this museum is unlike any where else. The 'Water Lilies' paintings and the natural lighting of the painting will make you a fan of Monet. It also houses other post-impressionist paintings and the visit will not feel overwhelming like some of the other museums might do. This museum is covered in the Museum pass.
Outstanding museum.. Here you will see the Monet waterlily murals that take up 2 oval shaped rooms as well as many Impressionistic paintings as well as the early moderns.

Beautiful. Seeing the huge murals of Monet's Nymphéas in the unusual oval galleries were one of the unexpected highlights of our Paris trip. For one, the works presented in diffused natural light, supposedly as how Monet wanted them to be, are gorgeous. Also, it was a quiet respite from the crazy crowds in most of the major Parisian museums.

Magnificent. IF you love Monet, this is a no miss. You must see his paintings here, they are magnificent. there is one whole room with wall sized paintings and in the rest of the Musee, there are different displays of many artists.

A gem. This museum at the end of the Tuileries is a gem. We were fortunate enough to catch the Chaim Soutine exhibit which was amazing . The permanent collection is also noteworthy for the variety of modern (mostly post impressionist) works. Unlike the d'Orsay, which has a large number of several artists but not a huge variety ) works of many artists. It is no an exhausting experience but an exhilarating one.

My favourite Gallery in Paris. Musee de l'Orangerie is my favourite gallery in France. I never walk by it without going in, (one of the advantages of having a Paris Pass). The experience is a moving meditation that soothes away all the bustle of the outside world around it.

Monet and more. I greatly enjoyed this small but excellent musuem featuring impressionist art, including the amazing water lilly wall murals created by Monet towards the end of his career. You can also get a combination ticket which allows you to visit l'Orangerie and Orsay at a discounted rate.
Small but wonderful. This is a gem of museum with a fine collection of impressionist art, including four water lilly murals created by Monet near the end of his career. Outstanding.
A must for fans of impressionist paintings. A small museum in the tuileries gardens which is near louvre. The sights of Claude Monet's display of eight water lilies murals is simply astounding.

Small Art House......... This small art museum sits near the parkland at the end of where the Louvre is located, it could be easily missed if you did not know where to look. Unlike the major exhibitions, this museum has a cross section of artists from the late 1800s and 1900s including works from Monet, Renoir, Picasso, Rousseau and others from that period.Because of its size, people were admitted on a slow drip basis so as not to clog it up which resulted in a fairly lengthy wait. The displays and the audio tour were quite good and you obtained an understanding of the background and the progression of the artists as they matured over the years. You could see the changes in their works as they undertook different styles and embarked on different periods of their professional lives.Overall, a good display of artworks well laid out in a smallest building, just be prepared to line up or buy the tickets in advance and go to the head of the queue.
Monet's worth a look. Various works by monet displayed in oval shaped rooms are well worth checking out - worth the admission price

Go if you're an art lover. We visited this museum mainly because we had a Paris museum pass and also wanted to see the Tuileries Gardens. I personally wouldn't have paid a separate admission fee nor gone out of my way to visit this museum. if you're an avid art lover however, you may have a different view. It was interesting but not outstanding in my opinion.

Wow!. A visit here would have been worth it just to see the two huge oval rooms with 6 huge works by Monet. However, the works of Renoir, Rousseau and so many other great artists kept us enthralled for many hours. The audio guide was done very well.
If you like Monet this is the place. You must visit this museum if you love Monet. I could spend hours looking at the water lillies. The rest of the collection is also very good.

Marvellous Monet. To see the large Monets in this setting is a very special experience. Take time to sit and enjoy in peace and quiet. The only disappointing aspect to this visit was the state of the ladies toilets. Absolutely no excuse for this.

Lovely Musee. Not as crowded as the Louvre and won't take you long to see some great art - if you think you have seen Monets Waterlilies you haven't until you have seen them here. You can take a lovely walk in the park and hit this museum for a nice relaxed afternoon.

A true gem - a must if you don't hate art.. Monet's two oval, large paintings - covering the entire walls of the two rooms. Aditionall, there where many othe very interesting painter represented - not only the (fantastic) french impressionists.
Crowded but worth the visit.. Even with all the crowd (went on Sunday when admission was free) the art was worth all the extra effort.
lovely, with crabby guards. Monet fans must visit (also Giverny). Besides the stunning oval mural rooms, they have a "just the right size" collection of beauty.

My new favorite museum. Monet's Water Lilies are the undisputed star of this small museum and rightfully so. Two oval rooms, each encircled by these magnificent paintings are breathtaking. The downstairs collection is also lovely, with works from Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Modigliani, Guilliame and others. I went on a Wednesday morning in October and there was no line. Admission is covered by the Museum Pass.

Small museum in Jardin des Tuileries. Place for orange trees, warehouse, examination room.... and finally a museum where you can see Claude Monet art (Nympheas), Paul Guillaume... It known many changes before to become this such small exposition hall in this beautiful garden of Tuilerie!Go visit it if you are gleaning in the garden!!.

Worth a visit!. We mainly stayed upstairs but there appeared to be some beautiful pieces downstairs as well. It was cloudy when we got there and saw the main Monet rooms, then the clouds broke and the sun came through, changing all the paintings entirely. It was like getting two museums for the price of one. A very calm, soothing space to really enjoy these masterpieces.
Ahhhh Monet. It doesn't matter what special exhibit the museum is hosting as you are primarily here for Monet so anything else is just icing on the cake. Sit down, relax and soak it in.

A tribute to Monet. The main floor of l'Orangerie is devoted to the Water Lilies by Monet, and the way they sweep around the space is amazing. The bonus is the excellent collection of impressionists and post-impressionists on the lower floor. The building itself is a beautiful pice of architecture, just off Place de la Concorde at the west end of the Tuilleries. So it fits into any walking tour of the Louvre and the right bank.

wonderful museum. the water lilies in the round are amazing as are the willows. the permanent collection is so worthwhile. the museum is a very manageable size. you can see many incredible works of art and not totally wear yourself out!

A must stop if you treasure Monet's paintings.. Nice collection of impressionist and post-impressionist art on the lower floor, but the highlight are Monet's massive Water Lilies treatments of similar subjects at different times of day and under different weather conditions. Definitely worth an hour or more of your time.
Home of Monet's Water Lilies. A superb building and location to host Monet's masterpiece. The introductory panels tell the story of this exquisite gift to France by Monet
Monet. Two rooms showing Monet's water lilies is a gem. Unique experience. Peace in the world of chaos. The work and space are unique.

Always a highlight. This is a more intimate experience than the Musee d'Orsay, yet the Paul Guillaume collection gives the visitor a wonderful taste of impressionist and post-impressionist masterpieces. Of course, Monet's awe-inspiring Nymphéas are a highlight, perfectly displayed in the oval rooms designed specifically for these iconic murals, with input from Monet himself.

Must See!. Museum pass, museum pass, museum pass! Bypass all the lines at most of the major museums.
Just the Monet displays are worth the visit alone. Fantastic.

Wonderful waterlily rooms!. The rooms designed especially for Monet's waterlilies are divine. There are also other beautiful impressionist works. One of the top museums in Paris after the Louvre and the d'Orsay.
No photos allowed ... my dislike.

Do Not Miss. Ended up at this charming small Museum in the heart of Paris only because our first destination, the Rodin Museum is closed Monday's. So we simply walked to the river and crossed the bridge near the Champs Elyssee and waited on line for about ten minutes and walked into this quite lovely small museum. While the main attraction is Monet's "water lilly's" there is a great deal more to see including some wonderful Degas and very interesting early Picasso's. It is a great collection without the massive crowds of tourists or the overwhelming enormity of the Louvre. A great place to visit.

Breathtaking - Great Museum. After a week and a half of giant museums like the Vatican, The Uffizi and the Louvre, the Musee de l'Orangerie was a welcome change of pace. A small gallery that will take an hour at the most to observe. With impressionist paintings. The Waterlillies are utterly amazing! Just sit on the benches and take it in. But then make sure to get up close to see the colors and strokes. Just beautful! It was the last museum of our trip and we loved it.

Monet Monet. Not to miss if you love the work of this great Impressionist. The Orangerie's greatest asset is its monumental works of the water lilies. It is really spectacular. The other exhibits are also quite good if you like the artists from this period. Worth a visit. And located close to the Jardins de Tuileries too.

Beautiful museum that is a great size for kids!. Whilst travelling with our three children my husband and I wanted to experience at least one Musee in Paris. Musee d l'Orangerie allows one the opportunity to really take the time to enjoy amazing masterpieces and not bore the children for too long - that is perfect in my book! Worth the trip alone to see Monet's amazing water lilies. Highly recommend!
not a big museum lover. but the layout of the place was easy to navigate and clean and tidy .free entry for EU youths 18-26

Overwhelming Monet garden pieces. The museum was nicely laid out--last time I went it was closed for renovation. Very nice gift shop and toilets. Peaceful and easy to enjoy the entire museum in a short amount of time.

More artists than I remembered - a minature D'Orsay. I definitely remembered the Monet installation. It is still stunning, and I used the Rick Steves audio guide while I was there which was even more helpful. I did not remember the second floor with additional artists and that was a true delight. I came to the de l'Orangerie because the D'Orsay was closed that day. Definitely a nice unplanned stop.

Magnificent!. Go for the Waterlillies...but do not miss the exhibits on the lower level. Had relatively manageable crowds during our visit, but the Musee Pass is highly recommended to enjoy the express entrance.

Must see!. A must see if you enjoy Monet. For the best value, get a multi day museum pass for your stay in Paris. At minimum, get the two museum pass for the Musee d'Orsay with the the Musee de l'Orangierie.

Orangerie should be a highlight yet somehow it isn't. The thought of experiencing the best of Monet filled us with excitement.Maybe we were expecting too much having just visited Musee d'Orsay.I am unhappy to report that the Orangerie is a disappointment. Yes, there is the room where you are surrounded by Monet's waterlilies which filled us with awe but there is not much more.This should be Monet's 'shrine' so where were all the works - on loan? We didn't see many vacant spots where normally there is a note saying that the painting is on loan.However, it is still well worth the visit although the entrance fee seems high. If you have a Museum pass (highly recommended), you don't care!To get there take the Metro to Concorde - it is just a short walk into the Tuileries to the front entrance.

Lovely small Musee worth finding. Not as crowded as the Louvre and won't take you long to see some great art - if you think you have seen Monets Waterlilies (I had seen them in Chicago)you haven't until you have seen them here. You can take a lovely walk in the park and hit this museum for a nice relaxed afternoon - go sit by the little lake in the middle of the park if it's a nice day - great people watching

A museum that is not overpowering. Small and compact, the Museum is located in an old organgerie, in the tuileries gardens, near the banks of the River Seine It is home to Monet's water lilies and a group of other impressionist painters.
Monet's Treasurers. An absoluter "wow" moment when you walk into the room where Monet's Water Lilies are displayed. Don't miss the downstairs exhibits - they change regularly.

Monet must. Often overlooked but a must see for Monet fans who will be overwhelmed by the permanent collection of Monet's lilies on the main floor. Imposing in size, attractive setting, sit down and appreciate the beauty of Monet's most well known pieces.
monet heaven. The most astounding monets . Huge . Beautiful. Not crowded like the Louvre and under 25 free. Even if you dont like Art pop in and see these!
Beautiful. A special museum to enjoy Monet-- worth the trip. The other artists are wonderful too and the natural light allows viewing pleasure.

Don't miss this one. A lovely viewing of the waterlilies. Be sure to cleans your eyes with the white room before entering the first gallery. Also, don't miss the permanent collection on the ground floor. There are some spectacular pieces.

An absolute must on your Paris check-list. Somehow overlooked by tourist crowds and overshadowed by a more imposing and definitely more well-known Orsay, Musee de l'Orangerie offers an amazing and extensive collection of the cult art dealer and art collector Paul Guillaume, the collection successfully continued after the death of the latter by Guillaume's wife's new husband, the architect Jean Walter.
