In our opinion Orangerie is undoubtedly a more attractive and interesting destination that the Marmottan museum, let alone boasting a more central location compared to the Marmottan (Orangerie is located by the western exit of the Tuileries gardens overlooking the Place de la Concorde). The spherical halls of Claude Monet's Lillies are impressive, but the various variants of the same theme are widely represented in many world museums. This is not the case with the unique works by Modigliani, Rousseau, Soutine, Utrillo, Gauguin, Sisley, Cézanne, Marie Laurencin, Derain, Matisse, Picasso, Renoir, and Van Dongen. There museum also features a comprehensive exhibition dedicated to Paul Guillaume, his collection, his Paris addresses, the controversy surrounding his wife Domenica, etc. One can purchase the tickets on-line well in advance (we did), which offers an increased convenience when planning your visit.
Must see for Monet fans. Amazing Monet and Renoir paintings. Much smaller and more limited collection, compared to the Louvre and the Orsay. But worth a visit if you like Monet
Impressionist heaven. Such a small jewel. Everyone was walking around with smiles on their faces. You won't find a better group of impressionism paintings. Wonderful lighting.
ok museum. aside from the Monet panels in the 2 rooms on the 1st floor, don't bother to see the rest of the collections. We went because it was free and a rainy day.
Semi worth it.. I'm a big fan of Monet, so the water lilies room was worth the trip. Past that, there's not much else. So unless your looking for some specific, this one is an easy skip.
must see while in Paris. Must see for all art lovers while in Paris. Excellent display of Monet's most famous works. Easy acces and no queues.
It's magic. What I love about the Orangerie is its peace. Compared to the Orsay or the Louvre, here you have a smaller gallery and not a profusion of people. Monets lilies are divine.
Fantastic. Up close and personal with Picasso and Modigliani, Renoir etc etc all in a modern building featuring preform concrete

Monet is so worth it. It's a quick visit but boy, is it worth it! Going down from the entrance you'll find an amazing collection of impressionist art, rivalling Musee D'Orsay and gets you the right context for the waterlilies on the upper floor. Don't miss it.

Loved the Monet exhibit. Loved the Monet exhibit and the structure of the museum. Fascinating that Monet had museum designed to display his art. Used 2 day Museum pass. After viewing exhibits we sat out in sun in comfortable chairs on the grounds.
Waterlilies the way Monet intended. Being able to view Monet's Waterlilies in the setting he selected and designed was a highlight of our trip. A must see if you are a Monet fan.
Great Addition to D'Orsay Visit. Monet works were striking and other works quite interesting. Nice size and good addition to seeing Musee D'Orsay if you like Impressionism.

First time there.... It was my first time visiting the Orangerie and I cannot imagine why I waited so long. The Monet waterlilly murals are simply a must when visiting Paris. The location in the Tuilleries is wonderful. The museum is light and airy and is the most perfect setting for these wonderful paintings. Go there

Perfect in every way. This little museum in the grounds of the Jardin Des Tuileries is a little Gem! Blessed with the spectacular Monet's waterlilies paintings in panorama this museum will delight even non art lovers. Conveniently located nearby to the Seine and easy walking distance across to the Musee D'Orssay. Highly recommended!

Something to see. Cool experience but I wouldn't dedicate a ton of time. We went late in the day just before close so we avoided long lines. We probably had less than an hour which felt rushed. Monet's works are neatly displayed and it is cool how the rooms change with the clouds rolling overhead. The other works on display are quite an impressive collection.

Nice Small Museum in Paris. We paid for a combo ticket to the Musee d'Orsay and the Musee de l'Orangerie. We went to the d'Orsay first and loved it. However, it was larger than I expected and we felt a little overwhelmed by art near the end. We went to this museum on our second day and it was much easier to go through. We sat and looked at Monet's waterlilies for a while. It is nice that they have a large seating area for visitors and it really provides the best viewpoint to take it all in.

Sleepy guard!. Monet's huge Water Lily paintings are a completely spiritual and tranquil experience but we were amused by one of the guards who was so tranquillised he kept nodding off to sleep. The other paintings in the gallery are worth spending time with too and it is less crowded than the bigger art museums.

Fabulous Monet. If you are a fan of Monet or just seeing his work for the first time you must visit the Musee de l'Orangerie. The careful detail he specified for displaying his work truly captures the beauty of what he created. To see the Water Lillies in the environment it was meant to be seen in is breathtaking. Take a few minutes to visit this Musee, you will be rewarded.
An unknown gem. Go to the museum the day before you go to Monet's home. Great back ground for the trip to Givercy. Monet was the one who got the museum started.
Monet by the yard. Beautiful. The two rooms of Lilies were amazing. They are naturally lit so the museim is only open until 4:30.
Beautiful and Serene. This is an amazing museum. No photo can do justice to Monet's magnificent waterlilly paintings. You may have to queue for a bit to get in, but it is definitely not to be missed!

Small Museum With HUGE Money Murals!. This is a relatively small museum and has an interesting and varied collection downstairs. But the main reason to visit here is to see the two large oval rooms, each of which house 4 huge Monet murals of his Water Garden in Giverny. The eight murals each convey a different impression or season or time of day. It's great to get up close and try and figure out how he applied all that paint, then step back and take in the whole scene. We can sit there for hours!

Wonderful. It is a shame that these reviews have to be more than 25 words long because nothing I say is going to add to the title. If you like Monet's Water Lilies you will think you have died and gone to heaven coming here. The rooms where they are displayed in all their glory are superb and the other paintings downstairs are excellent too. An absolute bargain - wonderful!

A gem. Although not one of the heralded museums in the tour books, visiting this small museum off of the Tuillerie Gardens was a wonderful experience. The feature of this musuem are Monet's water lily paintings displayed on two rooms with curved walls. The museum also featured an excellent collection of other works including many by Picasso, Renoir and others. If you have a Museum Pass, you should make time to see this museum.

Monet's garden. I enjoyed walking through Monet's garden - the paintings are huge and are well presented. The collection presented in the basement while not large is also well worth seeing. We did not spend a lot of time here but were happy we went. The park outside is also very nice.

Ah, the water lilies. We visited this smaller museum our first day in Paris after a long and sleepless flight. We felt it would be easier to manage in our jet lagged state than some of the larger museums, and were very happy with our decision. With both its location at the edge of the Tuilleries, and content, it was an immersion back into Paris life after an absence of several years. It was our first time to see this museum, as it had been closed previously for renovation during our visits. The stars of course are Monet's two rooms of huge water lily panels. You can just sit and enjoy from room to room then back again. This museum lacks some of the frantic crowds which can detract from other museums. The panels of course are magnificent. I witnessed one woman burst into tears upon walking into the room. The museum is a delight, low key, and as we thought, a perfect first day visit for jet lagged souls!

It's so serene in here. The museum really puts you in the mood for Monet. There's a stillness inside, even with all the tourists. The curved walls featuring the giant paints are truly spectacular, and the lighting is so perfect. Make sure you visit the rest of the gallery, which is very nice as well.

Great Monet Paintings. This museum contains Monet's super large painting of gis Giverny lilly ponds. Ther are a must see when visiting in Paris. There are also a number of other impressionist painting in the smaller museum. Not as crowded as other more well known museums.
Monet at its pinnacle. If you are a fan of Impressionism , this is a must see. Monet personally selected the old building to house last great masterpiece that everyone should travel to see.
Breathtaking. Could have sat with the monets for hours? The colours are so beautiful - been before. Think it's a must do for every Paris trip. The chance to be inspired all over again

a real treat. The Monet paintings are the highlight of this museum. You are able to sit and just enjoy the experience. Then visit the lower level and see the surprises there. I advise 2 hours at least for this museum.

My favorite art museum. I found out early on that a lot of art that hangs in museums holds no attraction for me. I tend to enjoy Monet and Renoir more than Picasso and Soutine. The Monet water lily murals here are worth the trip.

An Overlooked gem. By the lack of crowds, you would think that the greatest Monet paintings of all time are of little interest. The museum was laid out according to the preferences of Monet. It is a museum not to be missed and is an easy walk to the end of the Jardin des Tuileries

Beautiful museum, without being overwhelmed!. Go to the Orangerie of course to see Monet's waterlilies. They are beautiful; the history of the display is interesting in and of itself. The other late 19th & 20th century contemporary artists' works were also interesting. Enough for an engaging afternoon without feeling overwhelmed or like you've missed something.

Nice experience. During our visit we viewed the Monet murals-very varied exhibition.
Downside was that they had run out of English language guides,which considering their market is poor.
Monet !!. The l'Orangerie is a small museum with spectacular Monet murials. A definite must see if you are a Monet fan.

More amazing that I was expecting. I wasn't expecting to be underwhelmed exactly, but as most people hardly mention L'Orangerie when they mention D'orsay, I thought it would be less impressive. I was so awesome, and you could take the time to sit on the benches and soak all the paintings in. The main galleries with the massive Monet works were not too crowded either, and so my visit was relaxing and I lingered comfortably without crowds. I will make a return visit on next trip to Paris for sure.
A very rewarding, quick museum stop. A small and intimate museum with impressive Monet water-lily panels. An easy addition to your sightseeing itinerary.

Loved it. I can't believe I never heard of this museum before I got here. In addition to the eight massive waterlily paintings donated by Monet, the downstairs has a collection of Dérain, Renoir, Cezanne, Laurencin, and Picasso (plus a few others). If the crowded, human-humidity condition of the Louvre left a bad taste in your mouth, this museum will be a breath of fresh air. Only €7,50 for a full-priced ticket; part of the museum pass.

Life Changing. The museum was closed for several years due to renovation/refurbishment. Finally got to tour it in August 2011, and loved it so much returned in May 2012. If possible, try to co-ordinate your visit with one of the two English speaking tours scheduled - The one we took was very interesting with an adorable local guide. This museum is very French language focused so ticketing, etc., is not the easiest for those who do not know French well - Prepare to be patient. Fortunately, the beauty of the paintings explode beyound language. This is not a large museum - The first floor contains two rooms of Monet's water lilies, and the basement/lower floor has a wing for special exhibits and another for a permanent collect of Impressionist era art. The size does not diminish the power of the works included, it just means (unlike the larger Parisian museums) a visit can easily be completed in 1 to 3 hours depending on one's level of art interest. Plus the location is city central, just across from the Place Concorde and Egyption Obelisk. Words cannot convey the depth of beauty painted by Monet in these water lily paintings - Each different but equally mesmerizing. Truely moving.

Must see if you love Monet!. We visited this museum on the first day of our second trip to Paris. Don't know how we missed it the first time? The huge murals of Monet's water lilies are breathtaking! So glad we saw them before our trip to Giverny.
Magnificent!. Go see the water lilies! And other great impressionist pieces in a pleasantly uncrowded and lovely setting!

Wonderful. At my childrens school they have an artist of the term, Monet was that artist in the term before our visit my girls were dumb struck by monets paintings, just wish you could photograph in there as I would of loved to have captured their awe struck faces
Great low key gallery. Easy way to see some great pieces, without the queue. Handy free guide to exhibits. No crowds, unlike other galleries.

Tranquil!. All, I can say is wow! When you walk into the white room, there is a sense of peace and calm that you feel. I could spend hours just sitting in that room staring at the most famous painting in the world. A sense of awe came over me when I think about the the complexity of the painting. This is a must see.

Loved it!. I really enjoyed this little museum. I'm not a super art buff by any means so I found that this museum was just the right amount of art to be able to enjoy comfortably. The 8 Monet paintings in the upstairs rooms were beautiful and made the entire trip worthwhile. The staff were also most welcoming and helpful as well.

Monet extravaganza. As always there is something spiritual about the huge monet water lilly paintings and the fabulous way they are displayed. I never tire of seeing this extraordinary gift to France and the world.

Art lovers find!. This museum is at the end of the Tuileries but not too many people go. Not sure why as it is an excellent museum and small enough to really enjoy in less than 2 hours. The Monet water lilies may be the big draw, but I liked the downstairs collection even more. Have never seen so many soutines together. Very enjoyable!

Small museum, but excellent.. Although the museum is small it is well worth the visit. In fact, purchase a ticket which includes the Musee D'Orsay. The collection of Monet's Water Lilies is breathtaking!

Immersion in Monet. One major reason for visiting l'Orangerie. The display "in the round" of Monet's Water Lilies series - as he wanted them displayed. Take your time here and just look (in these two rooms, everyone is silent, just attending to the art). You will experience something if you just immerse yourself - easy enough to do because of how these are shown.

Beautiful collection of impressionists work. If you like Monet, Cezanne, Picasso -- check it out. Get the audio guide/ipod if you don't know French. there are no signs in english. Easily seen in 90 minutes. It's the anti-Louvre fast and easy
Fantastic!. I have waited a couple of years to visit - and it did not disappoint! Check out the collection downstairs as well - simply stunning. Do not miss if you are in Paris.

After the water lilies go downstairs. After the two round rooms go downstairs to an amazing collection of paintingsThat is where this museums real gems are.Taxi drivers may not know where this museum is since some taxi drivers are not from ParisIt is at one end of the Jardin des TuileriesIt is a long long walk if you are dropped off at the wrong end.Taxi stand is a distance away (ask at the Museum desk)It is against the law in Paris for a taxi to pick up someone on the street if it is within a 100 meters of a taxi stand.So unfortunately the street in front of the museum one usually can not flag down a taxi.
Go to d'Orsay or Giverny. The main attraction is the Nympheas but, frankly, go to Giverny and see it live. I assure, is much better.

Monet the star of this museum.. This was a smaller venue, but very beautiful large panels of Monet's "Water Lilies " in different seasons and light. The other collections shown by other artists are beautifully displayed.Highly recommend this venue.
Outstanding Monets. A beautiful not-to-be missed experience. Don't miss the collection of contemporary art on the lower level.

Good museum with late 19th century art. If you are in Paris and under time pressure, then this museum is a good choice, as you can tick the culture box, without feeling that you have queued or spent lots of money (or battled with the crowds to see the paintings)! You could see the whole collection in about an hour, without feeling you have rushed.The museum has a very good selection of late 19th century art. It is reasonably priced (7 Euros) and rarely has the queues or crowds of the much bigger Musee D'Orsay. It is free on the first Sunday of each month.The museum holds the grand water lilly paintings by Monet (he painted them to be specifically displayed in this gallery); and the basement holds the remaining collection by a variety of artists.

Magnificent. The Nympheas are splendidly displayed - what a pleasure to be able to sit and drink them in! However, running out of both English and French Brochures is inexcusable for a museum of this calibre. The ticket price is high, and one has to rely on one's memory of the history of Monet's masterpiece which is displayed just outside the display room.

Waterlily Rooms are breathtaking. I'm not particularly a fan of Monet but when I walked into the two Waterlily rooms, I was so moved I started to tear up. It is something to be experienced in person as an installation, photos or pictures will not remotely show you how it feels to be in that space. The museum was not very crowded so it was overall a rather relaxing experience instead of being overwhelming.

Beautiful!. Visited this gallery the day after visiting the Pompidou centre. This I much preferred partly because it is small. In a big gallery there is the temptation to try to do too much. The Monets are stunning and makes me wish I could visit Giverney with no-one else there - vain hope! Thoroughly enjoyed the lower galleries but you do need to collect an English pamphlet to make sure you get the most from your visit as if like me your French is on the poor side there are no descriptions/explanations in English.

Small, but worth the trip. They have a nice little collection of Monet, Renoir and others on the bottom floor, and two rooms on the upper floor which are wrap-around Monet paintings. Those rooms were stunning, and it really surprised me how small the crowds were. I guess this one isn't as well known as the other museums in Paris, but it is definitely worth an hour or two of your time.

Monet in dreamy colors. The two elliptical rooms with the huge Monet panels of waterlily ponds are enchanting and rich in beautiful hues of blue, mauve, etc. . Great for getting away from the busy streets of Paris to lose yourself in their dreamy colors.....

Not very large. But I did enjoy the giant murals by Monet. Easy to do in an hour. I didn't much enjoy the displays downstairs, but I am also NOT an art lover. Worth a trip - especially if you have the Museum Pass.

Fantastic museum. I'm not big museum fan so what is great about the Orangerie is that it's not very big! The upstairs houses the Monet lilies which are brilliantly displayed and then downstairs a surprising number of well known impressionists. We spent about an hour in there, perfect on a beautiful sunny day in Paris to then walk the Tuileries gardens and down to the Lourve. Would thoroughly recommend.
Just amazing. Monets paintings of the water Lilly's. Pay $5 for the guide it is well worth it. Get there early to avoid the masses.
Monets & Renoirs. Monet's water lily series is spectacular! Loved all the great Renoirs as well. This is a comparatively small museum but holds the best treasures.

A Long awaited visit.. I was determined to visit Giverny before visiting here, and eventually on our third trip to Paris I managed both. I have seen these works so many times, but seeing them in reality is far better than any of the reproduced images. I would still visit Giverny first though. If you are visiting both there is a reduced price combined ticket for the Museums.

More Water Lillies. Monet is one of our favorite artists. But he sometimes got carried away with waterlillie's and haystacks. This museum is nothing but waterlillies . A little too much....visit D'Orsay/Louvre instead. You will see better examples of Monet's work.
Don't miss this museum. We went to the Orsay Museum, Louvre, Pompidou, and Rodin Gardens, and enjoyed them all. But this was probably our favorite museum. It's not too big, and the art is wonderful.

Musee de l'Orangerie. This would be my number one pick of art gallery to visit in Paris if you only had time for one - it is lovely and serene with beautiful paintings of course. And right in the middle of the Tuileries Gardens and next door to the Seine. Fabulous
The Paris museum pass will get you in here.

Such a treat. If you love Monet and see no other museum this is the one to go for. It is riveting, with beautiful paintings, but the best, of course are the two rooms of splendid Monet's in the round. They are breathtaking.

Impressionante. Vale, principalmente, pelas impressionantes salas ovais com as Nynphéas de Claude Monet.
Attention to the impressive oval rooms with the Nymphéas painted by Claude Monet.
Tiny musee next to Louvre. Come in for the surprise of the Water Lily masterpiece of Claude Monet. If have time, attend the movie to know the history behind it in order to appreciate the art more.

interesting history. We were lucky to have a guided tour of this museum. The history of it and Monet's story are half the experience. I never imagined the waterlilies were so big and meant to be seen in a 360 atmosphere. Try to take a good guide book to understand what you are seeing.

LOVE LOVE - this is a must see. Monet's "Waterlillies" will take your breath away. This is a must see in Paris. Downstairs is forgettable, upstairs (ground floor) is unforgettable. There is also an adorable park outside that was fun to walk through. Warning - if it rains too much the museum will be closed!
Love it. I will always love the waterlilies at the Orangerie. We got there early and it was not crowded and just sat and soaked it in.
Monet's Waterlilies. Very impressed with the Waterlilies and then seeing Monet's Garden at Giverney was a treat. We enjoyed the smallness of the musee and it was easy to find by Metro.

A must see. Monets series of Water Lillies, from his garden pond viewed in different lights and at different times is mesmorising His vision for a peaceful place to contemplate has been achieved. As a bonus the additonal works of art from various known painters only adds to the experience.

Mainly peaceful gallery of treats!. A fab museum. Monet's waterlilies were our reason to visit. Breathtaking. Set out well in the different White walled rooms. Only real down side was other tourists talking, you almost need complete silence to be able to sit, look and lose yourself in the art. Nevertheless, well worth a visit and our comments are purely personal. The gallery downstairs was also very interesting and full of gems.
Musee de l'Orangerie. Toured it on our own. Fabulous! Since a stop on our Rick Steves tour was to be Giverny, we wanted to experience it. It made Giverny so much more relatable!
A great museum that is manageable and free. A must if you love Monet and especially the waterlilies. Don't be put off by long line...it moves quickly!

Monet, Monet, Monet!. Imagine being surrounded in a sunny room with paintings that Monet has created! This museum is a must see!!!!
Absolutely amazing!

A must for any art lover. Truly delightful museum close to Orsay and other attractions as well. If you at a Monet fan you cannot miss this - get the audio guide and sit in the waterlilly halls and just try and soak it in...

Very impressive murals by Claude Monet. This museum in the old orangery of the Tuileries Palace is located on the edge of the Tuieries Garden. In addition to the 8 large murals by Monet there are other paintings by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau, Alfred Sisley, Chaim Soutine, and Maurice Utrillo, among others. Our one big complaint was that all of the written materials about the exhibit in English were gone. (a problem we found in a number of locations around Paris)
Wonderful gallery. Well worth a visit! Found it full of the great impressionists works, not just Monets waterlillies.better than the larger mused de or say.

So much more than Waterlillies. I have always wanted to go to the Orangerie but until my last trip to Paris was never able, mostly due to the lengthy period it was closed for renovation. It was worth the wait and so much more than I expected. Quite honestly I went to see the Waterlillies, which are awe inspiring to see. While they are practically ubiquitous because of their cultural popularity, nothing compares or can prepare you to see them as Monet envisioned, two elliptical rooms (representing infinity) with four giant friezes encircling the walls. You feel literally immersed in them. I'd put this on par with seeing the David for the first time in Florence.But what I wasn't expecting was the Jean Walter and Pierre Guillaume collection - an expansive and impressive collection of modern art with Cezanne and Renior prominently featured. Pierre Guillaume was an important early 20th century Parisian art dealer who bequeathed his collection to the city, and is a fascinating character. As all of the descriptions are in French, the English audio guide was very helpful and provided lots of interesting information about the art, the artists and art history. It's small enough also to not be overwhelming and just spend a couple hours.

Art for the non-arty!. Exhibition was titled "De ma fenetre", the artist Ahae spent a few years taking photos from his room in South Korea. He captured all the seasons beautifully. Free and worth a visit.
Non-art lover. Modern, well displayed. Can't say I fell in love with impressionist art, but the display was extensive and informative.

Be inspired and fall in love again. Another place I always try to make a point to visit on my trips to Paris. This museum proudly displays the largest collection of Claude Monets Waterlillies, gently lit with natural skylight and curved along the oval walls of this museum.It's very calming and certainly VERY beautiful. Such a treasure

Spectacular. The Monet's are absolutely spectacular. If you are in Paris to see Impressionist art, then this is a must see. Wonderful setting in the museum takes advantage of natural light, passing clouds and changes in outside light impact the paintings.
Small but worth it. Very small museum. Nice selection of paintings. We had a museum pass, so cost wasn't an issue. We did this museum in about an hour.

My Favorite Museum In Paris. Don't pay attention to those who say this Museum is a disappointment. There are more great works per lineal foot of walking than anywhere else. And if you a a fan of the impressionists and post impressionists, this is an absolute must see. There is a large collection of Renoir, including some of my favorites (Two Girls At The Piano and a couple wonderful paintings of the artist's son Claude.). There are also a number of paintings from Picasso, Matisse, Modiglianni, Roussou, Soutine, Cezanne, Laurencin, Utrillo, and Derain, not to mention Picasso - and that is all without mentioning the water lilies.Those who pan this museum either don't appreciate good art, or don't like the impressionists and post impressionists. In my opinion, this is a must see in Paris, and one of the best places to spend limited time.

Small but Memorable Museum Buoyed By Monet's Waterlillies. While not a must-do for the time-poor traveller, Musee de l'Orangerie is certainly a charming gallery, and indeed a beautiful space to view art. We went here on A Sunday morning because the lines for the Louvre were ridiculously long, and I'm glad we did. There were no queues and Monet's waterlillies were particularly beautiful.

Not worth it unless included in Museum Pass. I was curious to see what all the hype was about the water lilies, but was very disappointed. Yes, the murals are large and cover more than one wall, but apart from this most famous work, there are very few other paintings or displays of worth here. We spent less than 1 hour in the museum, but it was included in the price of the Museum Pass.
value for money. No queues! Good priced ticket considering that it's in Paris. Staff speaks English well. Nice pictures, and you can take photos of most of the pics, although not of the Waterlilies).

A nice surprise. What a great experience to walk into a more "human" scale museum without the crowds and terrible touristy gift shops selling all kind of @@@ and still see some great artists and masterpieces without the hustle and bustle of thousands of people. Monet's Waterlillies with their specially constructed display halls, Some of Van Gogh and Rodin's best works as well as several turn of the previous century artists makes this an easy ,enjoyable and relaxing experience. Just one tip - definetely make use of the audioguides - it makes the place come alive!

A Beautifully Renovated Building With Monet's Waterlillies. Located near the Tuilerie Gardens, beside the Seine, this building, which was once the storage place for the exoctic fruit trees for the Louvre, has been given a beautiful, sensitive renovation, keeping the best of the old and enhanceing its purpose for now displaying art. It helps if you have visited Giverny, Monet's beautiful garden outside of Paris, but one can nonetheless enjoy the massive, colourful paintings he painted, that are displayed here. He was going blind when he painted them apparently, and they have a fussy yet beautiful quality. There was an secondary exhibition downstairs, one man's collection full of Renoirs, Monets, and many other extraordinary French artists. Definitely worth a visit. We had a museum pass, and were glad of this, as we had preference to get in. I felt sorry for those who did not, and where standing out in the hot afternoon sun! This is great art, but more of a worth seeing rather than a must see.
Monet is not all you'll see. The collection of art dealer Paul Guillame is also a treat. Includes works by Modigliani, Picasso, Renoir to just name a few.

Beautiful little museum with giant waterlily paintings--worth a visit. Great museum--so different from the Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay because it's small and doesn't feel so overwhelming. You can easily see it in an hour. We went initially because it was included in the museum pass and we were planning a visit to Monet's house in Giverny two days later. There was a long line to get in and to buy tickets, but we were able to bypass both lines with the museum pass. The Monet waterlilies are very impressive and perfectly presented as the artist intended. The museum provides benches in the middle of the room to just sit and take it all in. We also enjoyed the rest of the exhibition. The whole museum looks very clean and bright, just a pleasant place to enjoy amazing art works. Checking your backpack is mandatory though and we were asked to take out our camera and wallet before leaving the bag. My only complaint about this museum was that the ladies working at the bag check were hands down the rudest people we met in 3 weeks in France.

Monet's water lillies. Only went to see the Monets, worth it.
The paintings look stunning and lit by natural light from above.
No queue (we went Sunday late morning) which made it even better!
No photos allowed

The ultimate Monet masterpiece. It's worth it to go just to see the Water Lilies. There are other Impressionist works there too. Get the museum pass and listen to Rick Steves free mp3 audio explaining this famous work of art.

Claude Monet's Water Lilies. I could have sat and soaked in the wonder of Claude Monet's Water Lilies for hours. The rest of the museum is great, but really I just went to see some of the most impressive impressionist paintings I have ever seen.
Inspiring. This is a must see museum if you are an aficionado or appreciative of impresionist art. The Monet exhibit is breathtaking. No lines, minimal crowd, easy to view.

Go see!!. Only went because we had the museum pass and it was covered, but so glad we did. Monet's waterlillies were so neat to see in the large rooms, as were the other artists. For someone who doesn't know too much about art but still enjoys it, this is a great place to start. Don't miss out!

Very accessible and beautifully lit. Tis was a very enjoyable visit. It was a short visit but a delightful one. Naturally the large Monet exhibit is the star, what with him painting these panels with the specific intent that they be shown this way. Crudely put, it's imax for impressionists. But there's much more to be enjoyed downstairs (esp. Renoir). Compared to the chaos of the Louvre, it's more accessible and quieter.
A Must for Fans of Monet's Water Lillies. The Orangerie is a fantastic collection of Monet's water lillies paintings. The main room is a knock out and worth the price alone. A must for any fan.

A Must See When visiting Paris. We heard about this great museum and it was well worth the visit. If you are an art lover especially of Claude Monet, this is not to be missed. You will see 2 rooms with his large waterlily paintings. We sat and looked at them,soaking in the beauty of his work . We looked closely at the art and felt inspired by the colors that were so soothing. There are other rooms to visit in the museum which are all worth while, but seeing this was just breathtaking. Make the time to see this because , its worth it!

Visited after the Musee d'orsay!. The Monet Murals were what brought us into the museum but we went to see all of the exhibits and they were amazing. The Modigliani's were exceptional. After the Musee d'orsay it was nice going to a smaller, less crowded space. The only problem was they were out of English guides.
Better than expected!. we really enjoyed this museum as much for the Monet Lillies as for the amazing works in the lower level! Calm and less crowded than other Paris sights.

Wonderful little museum. To be honest, I only went to see the two rooms of Monet's waterlilies. And it was as amazing as I had hoped. I have loved these paintings for a long time - two of them adorned my room in college 25 years ago. It was incredibly moving to see them the way Monet wanted them to be seen. We also really enjoyed the Rodin sculptures outside.
breath taking. i could have spent days here just looking at the water lillies, monet was brilliant. the more you look the more detail you see, you'll see water in a whole new light after this.
A little gem of a museum. Don't miss this - near the Orsay and the Louvre. The main draw is Monet's two rooms of waterlillies, but the rest of the small collection is also excellent.
awe inspiring. A small art gallery that houses Monets water lilies in all their glory. A delightful place to visit for an hour.
The most beautiful rooms in the world?. If you want to spend some quiet moments to marvel at and reflect on the beauty of nature and art, come here.

A lovely collection. This museum is one of my favourites in Paris. It is small enough to be relaxing and not at all intimidating, and the art has been thoughtfully laid out. A lovely place to spend a couple of hours

Very nice modern compact museum. Very good compacy Museum, located in the Tuileries gardens between l'arc De Triomph & The Louvres. Easy to view in 1-2 hours, the monet collection is fantastic but i even preffered the lower floor with Picasso, Matisse,Renoir,Monet & Verdain.Get the pass that can combine the Dorsay & the De L'Orangerie

My favourite of the art museums! Beautiful. The monet paintings were beautiful and there were also works by Picasso and other famous French painters. I thought it was beautiful. Arrive with at least an hour before closure because we arrived too late (can't remember exactly how late) and they refused to give us audioguides.

Across the road from Musee d'Orsay.. Super little museum displaying some of Monet's Water Lilies series in a couple of circular rooms. A good display of other impressionist and post impressionist work also on display. Well worth a visit and included on the Paris Museum Pass - 2/4/6 day pass providing free entry and special access reducing waiting time - well worth purchasing in advance if you are going to visit many museums.

Huge Monet murals are the draw. This is right next to the Louvre and much more digestible. It is worth the stroll through the Tuileries garden to see this small gem. The Monets are wonderful but I thought the rest of the collection was usual museum fare.

Beautiful Monets. We visited this museum as we couldn't handle the queue at the Louvre. We both love the impressionists and thought this was a real find as although small there was an amazing collection and the display of Monet's water lilies really shouldn't be missed.

Smaller than expected, but worth the trip on museum pass. I purchased a 3 day museum pass right in the Musee de l'Orangerie. Monet's paintings were certainly a sight to behold, but the museum was smaller than expected. Downstairs had an additional Debussy exhibit as well which was also interesting. If you have the time, definitely add it to your list, but you don't need to dedicate too much time to the visit. 1-1.5 hours is more than enough, unless you are really passionate about the works on display. The nice thing is it is located next to several other museums so we did this first thing in the morning, and had a lovely stroll over to the Louvre directly after. With the museum pass, it was definitely worth it.
Very pleasant surprise. I went to see the Monet's but the other works of art on display were excellent. A little bit expensive and the staff were quite unfriendly but still worthwhile

Wonderful experience. The joy of seeing Monet's masterpieces (including the building) for the first time is hard to describe. A wonderful experience and a truly remarkable showcase for this man's work.
Small but worth it. See Monet's water lilies in two circular rooms. They also had an amazing collection of Renois, Cezanne, and other masters.

Much more manageable the the Louvre. We were recommended to see the Monet at this museum, after the Louvre and Versailles this was calm and you could up close. Great space and highly recommended. You can get very close to the work.
Miraculous Monet. This is my favorite museum in the world. Seven years of restoration have resulted in the museum being restored to its original manifestation. It is more like a chapel than a museum.

Small, Incredible and a must see. Monet's famous water lilies are here. He created these for this museum and they should not be missed. This is a small museum with many famous names (Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Monet, Soutine etc.). It is very easy to see in under an hour. Often we do the Louvre in the morning, have lunch at the food court or at Paul outside in the Tuilleries, walk through Tuilleries gardens toward Concord and then duck in to the Orangerie for a quick visit.

A must see for Monet lovers. This museum is small but quite impressive with HUGE panels of Money water lillies upstairs and other famous collections dowstairs. The light is great, seating is provided, great gift shop, convenient location. Any art lover should go here, Monet lovers will be wowed.

Monet's Waterlilies. There are two galleries inside the Musee d l'Orangerie where you are surrounded by Monet's paintings. It's almost like being at Giverny. The rooms are sort of an oval shape. We were disappointed this trip that photography is no longer allowed (it was 3 years ago).

A must see :). I have always wanted to see Monet "The Lillies" , it is simply breathtaking, I sat in front on the bench for about 15 minutes just looking at it. Not the biggest of museum but ideal for Monet enthusiasts. The other masters are amazing to views as well, staff there are very strict on noise levels and frequently "SHHHHHHH " people loudly if they talked. be prepared for that. Would certainly go again :)

A Must For Monet Fans. The small Musee de l'Orangerie is worth it just for the two large oval rooms designed by Claude Monet to house a number of his large Water Lillies paintings. The rest of the museum, however, is also worthwhile, housing a somewhat quirky, though extensive, collection of impressionist art.
Small but perfect. After walking for miles around the Louvre this little gem is perfect. Small but very high quality impressionist painting at its best. Must see!

Beautifully impressive, a masterpiece gallery.. Monet's work blew me away! What a display. The lilies are just spectacular, it was treasure to see and experience. Of course, Renoir, Matisse, and Picasso did not disappoint as well. The museum isn't large, so we got to see it all in under 2 hours and were not worn out! It was great and slightly relieving after experiencing the massive Louvre. Although it was very busy it was still a place of quiet contemplation. Wonderful and relaxing in the centre of Paris.

it was ok. not the best museum i visited it was small but not so many tourist so you have more time to look at the paintings we came there late 2 hours before closing time they had ok selection of arts

Eh....you might as well.. I had always wanted to go here, but never made it. Last trip I went as it was right by my hotel, Le Crillon and I'm glad I can cross it off my list of things to do, but at the same time, it was kind of boring. Not a whole lot of art, and after seeing so many paintings of water lillies I start to not give.

Must be into Watercolors. The Musee de l'Orangerie is near by the Louvre, however it's far apart in comparison. The main exhibit was largely watercolors which don't have great appeal to me, the museum did attract a large number of visitors and most seemed pleased with the art including my wife, however I lost interest and was ready to leave after about 30 minutes. Downstairs there was a number of other types of paintings that I enjoyed much more. The building is beautiful and had the most attraction for me.

Sit and absord the lillies. This was a rather unexpectedly impressive gallery, Quality rather than quantity, it took us 2 hours and, again used our 2-day pass, so economical if you plan to visit more than 4-5 museums, mind blowing pieces on show at this gallery - no photo though ;), though an awful lot of ppl were playing the "I didn't realise" card (there were camera signs with red crosses on everywhere!).

A must see for a Monet fan. I love Monet water Lily paintings. This is THE PLACE to go to. Best to go in early morning so that you can sit and view the long panorama Monet painting quietly with no one bothering you. It can get very crowded with all the tourists even during weekdays.
Great museum.. This place is a wonderful but small museum. Not too crowded unlike the Louvre. A great environment for looking at great art.
Monet!. This little museum is home to the two rooms of Monet's waterlilies painted on the walls. A definite must-see. A museum that won't wear you out!
Worth the visit!. A beautiful museum if you are looking for excellent impressionists without the crazy crowds. The infinity rooms with Monet paintings was fantastic. The audio guide was worth doing.
Monet exhibit is AWESOME. Never realized how large some of Monet's beautiful were until this visit. They are beautifully displayed at the L'Orangerie.
Very nice. Small quaint museum with lovely paintings and a second floor of decent stuff. Prefer this to the hustle and bustle of the Louvre.
museums. the impressionists painters especially Bonnard and Van Gogh and the Rodin sculptures and just the general atmosphere
A must see museum. A defenitely must go in Paris, small museum but very impressive. The Monets are Amazing and it is for sure one of my favourite museums in Paris!

Get Lost in the Beautiful Art At Musee de l'Orangerie! C'est tres magnifique!. I have loved Monet for most of my life now, and if you have similar feelings of fondest for one of the greatest Impressionist painters of all time, then the Musee de l'Orangerie is a must. Two large oval shaped rooms on the top floor are completely covered on all four sides by some of Monet's last works, Les Nymphéas. Those two rooms alone were absolutely stunning. But downstairs, there are even more brilliant paintings of some of the greatest artists of all time: Renoir, Monet, Cézanne, Rousseau, Matisse, Modigliani, Soutine, Laurencin, Utrillo, Derain, and Picasso. As far as Parisian art museums, this is definitely one of the smallest, but it was my favorite. If you have any interest in Monet or you adore one of the other artists, I highly recommend this museum to you! =] Bring an open mind and some leisure time, because this a place where you want to be free to wander around for a while. You aren't allowed to take pictures, so give yourself some extra time to commit these beautiful works of art to memory. Also, if you have a moment, they have a great gift shop to check out in between sections!For those of you in a huge hurry, you probably only need an hour or two tops to zip through. But trust me, once you step inside, you'll practically have to tear yourself away. Because this museum is just that fantastic. Just sit back and enjoy it, all you beautiful people! And have a wonderful day.

Lovely water lilies!. This was not our first time in Paris but neither my wife or I had gone to this museum. It has a breathtaking set of Monet's water lillies, they're in natural light and it's presented in a way that really brings out the best in these masterpieces. If you are a fan of impressionist and post-impressionits painting this is a MUST. If not, don't bother, the paintings aren't as famous as Orsay.Lovely colletion almost entirely from a single donor's private collection, impressive.Great to do on a Monday since Orsay is closed.
Special. Sit a spell and take in the magic of Monet's Water Lilies then enjoy the Impressionist collection - incl. some lesser known artists. Loved the peaceful atmosphere of l'Orangerie.
beautiful works of Monet. this is a little museum, but there are beautiful works of Monet! The study of The Nympheas is the main.

Loved Musee de L'Orangerie. We came across this gallery quite by chance having purchased the Paris Pass, and finding out about it from that. The entry costs 14 euro without the entry pass. The gallery contains a breathtaking display of Monet Waterlilies paintings in two large oval rooms. No photography permitted (but lots of pictures taken by people on their mobile phones!!) Downstairs there was a large gallery of Cezanne, Picasso, Manet, Renior, Matisse to name but a few .. however there were also a large number of plates where the original was on loan to another gallery. The gallery itself was well laid out, beautifully lit and the staff were polite, helpful and courteous. Well worth a visit.

A must if you are a Monet fan. Short queues, lovely art! If the queues at the Louvre are too long, take a walk through the gardens to the museum which at the opposite end of the gardens on the left. Not as big as the other museums but def worth a visit.
Monet Monet Monet. I could sit in the "Monet" room all day...so if you love Monet as I do..it is a must. The rest of the museum is IMO ordinary but the MONETS.....OMG

Don't miss this museum. We have vistied the Louvre and the Orsay on previous trips to Paris so we chose the Orangerie for this visit. It is within easy walking distance of our hotel at the Concorde. We arrived early and there were no lines.What a pleasant surprise to find the works of so many of the world's finest artists in this relatively small museum. Renior, Picasso, Cezanne, Matisse and more.The Monet canvases surround you and you could spend hours viewing them from different benches and standing.While I know relatively little about art, my husband studied at the Museum school in Boston and he really appreciated the Orangerie.This is a great museum to visit, especially if you have limited time and want to avoid the long lines at the Lovre and Orsay.
Waterlilies. This is a place to visit totally Small museum compare to the rest in Paris but a great site with the Monet's Waterlilies
A meditation. Agghh Monet. Timeless vision. Get up close and stand far back. Comprehend the change of seasons. Be amazed and wonder how he manages to reveal more reflection than direct visions.

Another Paris Gem- the Orangerie Museum. Now fully renovated, here are Monet's Water Lilies gift to to France and the world at the end of WW1-but another jewel awaits in the basement where a whole treasury of impressionist and leading French artists works are on display.

Great museum. A huge and very impressive museum with some of the most incredible paintings in the world. I know very little about art and my appreciation of great masterpieces is crude - mainly along the lines of "that's really pretty" and "I love the colours there" - but even I recognized a number of the most famous artists that can be found here.
worth it. Very cool to see the biggest painting that Monet did. They are really larger than life. Best to stand back in order to take it all in.

Monet on a grand scale. Monet's magnificent, sweeping canvases of water lillies are the main attraction. Exhibited under filtered daylight, which makes viewing conditions ideal. There are benches so one can be seated and contemplate these paintings in awe.

The most incredible gallery. I went back twice! This was a dream come true to see such amazing art all under one roof. We went early before the crowds, had a museum pass - brilliant so skipped the queue then (having studied the map before) rushed up to the top floor - think it was the 5th floor) to view all the impressionists work whilst still relatively quiet. Get a audio guide - really makes the trip more worthwhile. To top it off they had a special Degas exhibition on - what a treat!
A must go to!!. Awesome paintings - just take your breath away. The sheer size of the vision and execution of the paintings and the upgraded gallery makes for a wonderful couple of hours.
OMG. an exceeelnt small museum in the tulleries garden. less crowed than the louvre and the orsay but a must see. the water lilies rooms are awe inspiring. you can sit for hours looking at them.

Monet. The main reason I went to this museum was to see Monet's work. We went late right before the museum closed. There were very few people there at that time. We had to check our bags and photography wasn't allowed. There's a gift shop downstairs. The museum pass=no line. We walked right in. Monet's work was breathtaking and worth visiting this museum. We also went downstairs and were surprised to find Picasso, Renoir, and Matisse. If the museum isn't busy then all you really need is 30 minutes here.
Monets masterpiece.. Don't be put off by the lines. It is worth the wait. If you have a Paris Pass, I believe you can jump the line. I love Monet and I was not disappointed.
Awesome!. I've always liked Monet's work but to be up close to soak it in it brought me to tears of joy! Soooo beautiful! Plenty of artwork to discover.
Amazing. The Monets are outstanding. It is worth sitting and watching the faces of the people as they walk into the room.
Monet's Waterlilies took my breath away.. The whole museum was wonderful, but Monet's Waterlilies made the visit. I could have sat there for hours. If you are a Monet fan, you must go.

Perfectly proportioned. The two salons featuring 8 of Monet's magnificent depictions of Giverny are well-sized, although they can get a bit crowded which definitely hinders the viewing experienced. The additional showings throughout the rest of the museum are excellent representative selections. Definitely a must-see.

Small but amazing. Small but amazing. There was no line, the museum was cool which was much appreciated on a hot day and there was not a large crowd so you could actually enjoy the art. Oh and the Monet rooms are to die for!

Pretty museum with Renoirs, Monets,Picassos,Cezannes and many others.. Enjoyed walking through the Tuillerie Gardens to get to this museum.Monets' water lilies are spectacular,I loved the huge paintings.
Small Could Skip If You Have a Packed Schedule. Loved the room with water Lilies...the rest was ok but nothing compared to the Louvre or the D'Orsay.

Monet's Masterpieces. Small, perfect. Had Paris museum pass (buy yours at the Paris airports). Hence, no waiting in line. Didn't see beyond the waterlilys we were tired from walkin from arc de trio one to place de la Madeleine to l'orangerie..

Monets. the monets were very large and the layout of the museum was designed to highlight them. the staff made sure the rooms were clean & quiet. more beautiful and we had imagined. very cool. must see.

Disappointing. The entree fee was expensive and the exhibition not as impressive as anticipated. One has to stand in line if you haven't bought tickets in advance, took only 20 minutes on a hot day and could have been worse.
That looks huge. Huge Monets on the wall. At the end of the park for the Louvre. Take Batabus and walk to it. Museum pass

Monet and more. Monet made his water lily paintings for the two oval rooms here. The scale and the detail are impressive. Modigliani, Laurenchin, Soutine, Picasso, and more. Unlike the Louvre, you can get very close to the paintings because there are far fewer visitors to this smaller museum. Near the Jardin Tulieres, so be sure to go for a walk after! Highly recommend a visit.

Went to see the Monet paintings and found so much more. As we were going out to Monet's Gardens, I had to go and see these amazing canvases before we went out to his inspiration. We thought we'd just pop in and out. Well we didn't, we stayed much longer as it is a lovely gallery. The Monet paintings are splendid of course, but even if you aren't a fan there is plenty to look at. Getting in is quick and easy and there aren't lots of people so walking around is very pleasant. Even the walk to the gallery is nice.

Must see for Monet admirers. Very nice small art Museum showcasing Monet's Water Lilly panoramas. The paintings are displayed ceiling to floor on curved walls. It's definitely worth the visit. I believe they are closed on Tuesday. We trudged through the winter cold once on Tuesday to see the exhibit only to find that it is closed on Tuesday.

If you like Monet - this is a must. Quiet and serene ambience that allows you to view and enjoy the world of Monet. The perspective is incredible. It is small but if you enjoy Monet - this is a great experience.

Only if you have extra time!. I had wanted to see this for several years because each time I was in Paris, it was closed for some reason. So this trip, I finally saw the museum. It was just not that impressive compared to other art museums in Paris. Musee Cognacq-Jay is much better and you get to see a gorgeous old hotel.

You have to like or be willing to acquire a liking for Monet. The Musee D'Orsay is far more expansive in its approach to early modrn art and design, but Musee de l'Orangerie is a must stop for any admirer of Monet. I became one visiting here, and I am glad we took the time to visit. It was very helpful to have wandered through some of the beautiful gardens and parks of Paris before viewing the art of Monet and the other early moderns held here.
Great museum; wonderful Monet's!!!. My family thoroughly enjoyed this museum. Our second fav during the trip!! The staff were very welcoming & the museum bright & delightful.

Musee de l'Orangerie. This is by far my favorite art museum ever. It's so small that it doesn't feel overwhelming like bigger art museums. Monet's water lily paintings are in a custom made room that makes them even more beautiful. Don't miss this if you're in Paris!

A quiet respite in Paris. I have been to Paris many times and never managed to get to the Musee de l'Orangerie until this year. In the last weekend of July, I went first thing in the morning and found absolutely no line...walked right in. I had purchased a combo ticket on-line for both l'Orangerie and D'Orsay. That was a big mistake. Even though I purchased it right from the museum website, It turns out you have to go pick it up somewhere else. You cannot "redeem" your receipt from the on-line purchase at either museum. Very frustrating! The staff tried really hard to help me, but in the end it meant walking many more blocks and back, so instead I just purchased another ticket on site...my knees thanked me! OK, back to the art...the Monet waterlilies are simply amazing...Monet created them especially for this building and location and the connecting oval rooms invite a reciprocal experience with the paintings that is hard to describe. This quiet moment of sitting and taking in the beauty should not be missed. Be sure to watch the video on Monet downstairs that is shown in English at several times during the day.

Water Lillies. A must see simply for the room designed by Monet to exhibit his signature work. The exhibitions can range from very good to ho hum but, because of the water lillies this is a must stop en route to Louvre or across the Seine to the Orsay.

Fantastic. Great little brother to the bigger Musee's in Paris who packs a punch. Waterlillies...enough said. Other impressionists were great too. Not much of a line. Not crowded. Beautiful Rodin on grounds as well.

Wonderful gallery. Absolutely stunning works of art presented in equally beautiful surrounds-Monet's Nypheas collection causes the viewer to sit in awed silence and take in the breathtaking 360 view of the watercolour painitngs. The rest of the collection is also a delight; the Degas' and Renoir's in particular.

AHAE photos were amazing. The photographer, AHAE spent three years sitting in front of a large window in his house taking tons of photos. They are absolutely incredible. I would highly recommend this exhibit to anyone.
Monet the master.... Loved the gallery. The simple white rooms that house Monet's water lilies are a perfect meditative space for appreciating these stunning works of art.
Breathtaking. If you like Impressionist art, you must go. The salons with the water lillies are breathtaking. This is a lovely museum.
Not that impressed.. Wasn't that impressed with 'Waterlilies'. There are better options in Paris. The other exhibition was very busy and there were no English guide books.

Disappointing. Upper floor has 2 rooms with each 3 large wall art in them, looks like it eefinitely took time to do but not what i was hopeing for. Downstairs there were more impressives works from more well known artists but overall it seemed like most of the museum was empty and they had put up pieces to fill in the space. Probably better when there is more doing on and less art work on loan to other museums.

For the lover of impressionism. This quite discreet museum presents some beautiful impressionists et postimpressionists artworks. The light is awesome and natural in this awesome place, may one of the reason for Claude Monet to settle there its cycle of water-lily paintings, known as the Nymphéas, that was arranged on the ground floor of the Orangerie in 1927. 60 of the 250 Monet paintings are presented there.
Enjoyed Monet's Water Lilies!. The Monet paintings were the best part of the museum for me. It's a small museum, easy to see the whole museum in 1-2 hours.

A beautiful yet small museum. As a lover of impressionist paintings, I was told that I just HAD to go to L'Orangerie. The inside of the museum is circular with a large skylight which lets in natural light helping you to see the paintings (or rahter murals) as they were meant to be seen.. They are really beautiful. However, there are only a few paintings there, and if you keep that in mind when you visit, you won't be disappointed!

Don't go during tourist season. I love this museum, have visited twice now, but this last visit was during tourist season and it was jam-packed with people. I loved contemplating the Monet but with so many people in the room there was nowhere to sit and it became uncomfortable quickly. I would recommend arriving very early or very late to avoid most of the crowds and have an opportunity to appreciate the fantastic art this museum has on display.

Small Museum but big sites to see!. While the Musee de l'Orangerie is small in comparison to the Louvre, the painters from the 18 and 1900s are not to be missed including Picasso, Monet, Cezanne, Renoir, and many more. Take in the waterlilies exhibit upstairs first, it is in two rooms and breathtaking. Everything else is downstairs. Not overly crowded but I do recommend getting a Paris Museum Pass, we went around one or two and the line was very long and we just skipped it completely. Your stay in the museum isn't long but there are some beautiful works inside!

quick and small. If you are sick of the large crowds this is a nice little museum near the gardens where you can have a nice lunch then mosey over, not as many things on dispaly as I hoped but a few nice little suprises and yes the big monets were lovely, plus a fiew picassos thrown in for good measure. Also they let you take photos or the guards just looked the other way.

Impressionist heaven. This small intimate museum ended up being one of our favorites. It wasn't crowded--top floor had all Monet in a building conceptualized by Monet himself to showcase some of his paintings. Floor below had many famous impressionist paintings--without the crowds of the Orsay. Museum is small and can be done in 30 minutes but you should definitely take longer to let the art really sink in.

Worthwhile, less crowded. The queue is much shorter to enter, yet the masterpieces are very worthwhile to appreciate. There are 4 models outside the nice bookshop showing different stages of development of the museum...so nice!

Awe Inspiring Monet Paintings. A lovely smaller museum with the treasured Monet water lillies on curved walls. Look at them up close and just looks like brush strokes, but stand back in awe at what Monet painted. Truly amazing!

Nice exhibit, bizarre staff. Monet's watercolor murals of Water Lilies were remarkable. Early works of Picasso were impressive and shows his early skills which differed greatly from his later works. There were many other wonderful works worth seeing. The museum is relatively small and a nice stop from the Place du Concorde on the way to or from the Louvre.The museum guard's loud and extremely rude "shushing" every minute or so was so awful and disruptive, we felt like we were in the midst of a Monty Python skit. In no other museum in Paris did we encounter this and the other visitors in the rooms were not at all noisy or loud. This behavior by museum staff is totally unwarranted. Tres Bizarre!The museum gets a 5 for its' works. The staff gets a 1.

A nice sized art gallery. The Orangerie is especially remodelled for the massive Monet waterlily pictures. However there is also a small (by Parisian standards) collection of mostly impressionist pictures. I found this a manageable size for my 7 year old granddaughter. Enough to see, but not so much she was overwhelmed.

Monet and more. This was at the very top of my "must - see" list in Paris, and I was not disappointed! Even on a relatively busy day, the stress of the world just seemed to melt away while sitting there, surrounded by Monet's magnificent Water Lilies. They are remarkable. I would have been content with having seen only the Monet's, but there were many other works by Matisse, Renoir, Picasso and many other artists. Although, if you are looking for the Picasso from Midnight in Paris, alas, it is not there. :)

a must if you are a Monet lover. After a visit to Orsay, cross the Seine, enjoy a walk through the Tuilleries and visit l'Orangerie. It is definitely worth it, mostly for MOnet's massive paintings of the Nympheas (waterlillies) decorating two rooms, but also for the collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume, protectors of most impressionists.
Incredible!. The panoramic Monets are incredible. This is my favorite museum in Paris. It is a small museum which lends you to spend a lot more time with each painting.

Monet's Water Lilies on the curved walls - amazing!. The way the exhibit as conceived to show these masterpieces is ideal. He of course designed the display himself. Though he painted literally hundreds of water lily canvases, this is hands down the best place to see his work. Also wonderful are Paul Guillaume's collection of artwork including Matisse, Soutine, Picasso, Modigliani, and others.

Not quite I was expected. The building itself is interesting but the collections and exhibits are few. During our visit some of the important paintings were on different exhibitions around the globe.We visited this museum on the first Sunday of the month when a number of the French museums are free of charge to visit so I guess I do not regret it so much. Otherwise, I would have regretted to pay the 7-8 euro for it.So if you don’t mind the fee just go and see it, you’ll be out in max 15-20 minutes but you can say that you’ve checked that on your journey.

More than just the large rooms of Monet's. I enjoyed all of the art displayed in the downstairs as well. This is a lovely museum. Try to sit still, take in the panoramic paintings, and then go downstairs to see much more!

Monet's Waterlillies. This used to be my favorite museum until it was remodeled and made to look modern. It houses some great Renoirs and Monets. Avoid long lines by using a museum card. It doesn't take long to see the exhibits.
A wonderful find. If you plan to got to Giverny Go here first. The Monets are outstanding. The whole museum is beautiful and amazingly not crowded.
Great afternoon out. Wonderful pictures, a great combination of older and more modern painting. Easy to find as part of a walk along the Champs or Tuilleries

My favourite. We visited the Louvre, Musee d'Orsay and the Marmottan as well, but the Orangerie was my favourite by far. The water lillies should not be missed. Definitely a smaller exhibition, but you can buy a combo ticket with the Musee d'Orsay for just a few more euros. We got there first thing in the morning- it opens a half hour before Musee d'Orsay. It was pretty quiet. You can use the combo ticket on different days so you don't have to get museumed-out all in one day.

Always worth a repeated visit!. When I was here many years ago, the museum was in an Orangerie. Now it's in a building, but it never stops to impress and to give a lot of joy. The very nice collection of the impressionists will surely make your heart sing, if you are a fan of that period. An absolute must, if this is your first time in Paris. But you will enjoy it every time.

Beautiful Impression Artworks. Beautiful artwork but no photographer was allowed (they have guards all over to make sure you do not). It is a large museum. We looked quickly through the museum, and it still took us about 3 hours to see it all.

Refresh. It was not so crowded. I had a seat and enjoyed looking at the Waterlily as much as I wanted. I bought the joint ticket with the Orsay Museum. I didn't have to wait in line to get the ticket at the Orsay which was always crowded.
a must see if you love Monet. you can make it a quick visit but a must see, the two rooms with Monets are breathtaking..... and conveniently located off place de la concorde
Well Worth It. The Monets are worth the admission on its own, no queues unlike the more popular museums, and the Jardin Les Tuilleries are a nice place to relax after the visit.

Fabulous art. We were delighted that we had picked Musee de l'Orangerie to visit on our short visit to Paris. We had a pre paid Paris Museum pass so were able to walk straight through the entry and bypass the queue for tickets - which was definitely not long by Paris standards. The Monets are absolutely stunning and it really made it memorable to see them displayed as murals on the curved walls. Also nice that you could sit down in the centre of each room and take in the beauty of the paintings. It was not crowded so that made the experience all the more pleasant and enjoyable. We enjoyed all of the other beautiful paintings displayed and there was enough to see to whet our appetite, without being too much of a good thing.The location at the Jardin des Tuileries is lovely as you can then walk around the gardens, browse the shops or eat at the nearby cafes.
fabulous waterlilies. there are two rooms that were designed to display claude monet's waterlilies murals. this is a must stop for monet lovers.
Only for the water lilies. Very small museum...not much to see aside from Monet's water lilies, but definitely worth seeing those.
Water lillies and More. Unlike many other examples of architecture, this building does justice to the art works on display, particularly the water lillies.

Monet murals are stunning. We visited Musee de l'Orangerie is the morning of the same day we visited Giverny in the afternoon. The eight murals are gorgeous and then to see the water lily pond in the afternoon was wonderful because we could see what Monet was painting. (We took a minivan tour with ParisVision, which was very convenient - pickup at 1:00 at hotel and drop-off at hotel at about 7:00; with two hours to walk around the pond and grounds and home.)

My favourite museum in Paris. I am in love with the simple beauty of this museum, its location and the unforgettable experience you live walking in the two oval rooms. I don't want to tell you more, just follow this advice: do not miss it!
Impressionista plus. Monet, Rodin, and more. Day before yesterday visited Giverny and the works displayed capture the gardens sans Japanese bridge.

A Relaxing Afternoon. I just happened on this museum while searching for another and was pleasantly surprised-there was not a long wait in line even at mid-day-once inside it was amazing-and just as Monet designed it-a place to escape all of the madness and noise of the city-a small taste of larger collections.I spent awhile relaxing in the 2 rooms with Monets paintings-it was breathtaking and I felt compelled to linger there.The peaceful calm was just what I needed after a whirlwind trip through Italy and only 3 days to see the sights of Paris. I would highly recommend that you take the time to enjoy it.

Monet's Waterlilies. Located in the Tuileries, this little building has two oval rooms with Monet's waterlilies installed. You can get a 360 degree view of these fabulous paintings. But, there are other impressionists ob display as well. Be sure to take some time to visit this treasure.
Excellent. Fantastic place. If you like impressionist you cannot miss it. Monet painting are awesome and there is a great number of other masterpieces.

Best place to view a Monet. The cooled oval rooms as you walk into the gallery host the 8 Nymphéas (water lillies) murals which are fantastic to sit and look at. You get lost in them because they are just so big and as you are unable to understand scale (because there is few comparable items to compare to) you spend your time figuring out if you are looking at a true image of a reflection in the water.Once out of these rooms you get to see the rest of the Paul Guillaume collections which mainly centre around Cezanne, Renoir, Rousseau (who I just don't get I might add....) and Derain.The prices are ok but as usual the audio guides are essential if you have anything less than a deep knowledge of art history. This pretty much doubles the cost of the trip.Its worth a trip but I dont think it holds enough for me to return on my next trip to Paris.

Special experience to view Monet. Monet's waterlilies are displayed in two oval rooms. When you enter each room, you are surrounded by walls covered by various views of the waterlilies painted by Monet during different times of the day. There is a large oval bench in the center of the room so you can sit and reflect on the wonder of the genius.
Wonderful - if you are a Monet fan. Very well worth a visit if you like Monet - a small museum dedicated to his 'waterlilly paintings - not crowded.

Waterlilies at their best. The best part of the museaum are the two rooms with enormous monet waterlilies. The remaining galleries are not very inspiring. There are some nice works and our daughter enjoyed the audioguide but the lighting downstairs is marginal and it is not equipped to handle crowds. The groups taking photos at every famous picture were obtrusive and ther was no way to avoid them. No ropes by the painings meant these people prevented you from really enjoying what was there.
Amazing Monet. This place has a fantastic impressionist collection and gives a great insight into the differences between key impressionist artists' styles. Well worth a visit
Really fantastic.. It's small, but well worth the visit. It can get crowded, and the line long, so get a museum pass to make your life easier!

Relaxed atmosphere to Enjoy Monet's Incredible Water Lilies. We bought the combined ticket for the d'Orsay and l'Orangerie. Although they both feature the same era of art, they provide totally opposite experiences. The d'Orsay is of course much more spectacular with more art and an incredible building, but l'Orangerie has some interesting pieces and has something the d'Orsay doesn't--the long panels of Monet's waterlilies. I can't emphasize enough how fabulous it was to sit on the benches in the two rooms that feature these masterpieces and just stare at the paintings in the cool atmosphere where people aren't jostling you and you don't feel like you have to rush from painting to painting in order to see it all. I visited in the late afternoon, and I doubt this museum is ever very busy. It did get busy when I was there with people taking refuge from a rainstorm, but luckily we were finished by then. I can't explain how breathtaking the water lily panels are--way beyond my expectations and even more compelling to us because we had visited Giverny two days before. I can't recommend this museum enough especially for people who only have a couple of days in Paris and not enough time to see the d'Orsay or for people who like to sit and relax and really enjoy Monet.

A tranquil retreat. The Orangerie is a tranquil retreat after the hustle and bustle of the Louvre. Situated at the end of the Jardin desTuileries, there are minimal queues to enter this peaceful space. Upstairs are the spectacular Monet waterlillies - you can almost imagine you are at Giverney. Downstairs is a series of intimate galleries also worth visiting. This is a museum where you leave feeling rested.
Water Lilies. The main attraction of this museum was the Monet Water Lilies collection. They have six massive water lilies. I sat there for over an hour just looking at just those six paintings.

Moments to remember. Seeing the first room of murals was amazing. I was lost and happy to remain so. To my delight, a second room of equal splendour was next in line. Do not miss this. Monet really got it right, and so did this exhibit.

OH...MONET's lilies. Well, this is the musuem where the large painting of Monet's Water Lilies are displayed. They are in a room to itself and it is breath taking. A must see in Paris. There are other impressionists in this museum but they are known for Monet's Water Lilies. You can also take photos here.
Monet's Water Lillies. This is my favorite museum in Paris. This is what 'beauty' is. To be surrounded by these paintings is a very 'moving' experience. a MUST see for all with a heart.

Nice as part of the overall constellation of museums. It was a great place to see the Monet lilypad murals in an oval and other works in the rest of the exhibit space. Not a destination but an intimate setting after the Louvre.

A peaceful Gallery ..... From the trendy dressed staff, request for quiet, no flashing camreras, get your museum pass to avoid the ques, and go inside this beautifully modern interior to view Monets giant Water Lillies and some beautiful paintings below.... I am quite shocked I hadn't been in the 28 yes I 've been visiting Paris ....do it!

A quiet oasis during high season.. The Orangerie is home to Monet's Water Lilies. The museum has been renovated a number of times and the most recent renovation has resulted in a tranquil oasis in the Tuleries. While the line up to get into the Louvre is very long, there was virtually no line up for the Musee de l'Orangerie.

small and lovely. This is a very small museum, the upstairs is exclusively Monet's waterlilies, downstairs is a great mix of art and artists, a few Picassos, some Cezannes, as well as many lovely works by artists I didn't know well. This is a very small collection, well curated and put together, the models of the building and its architectural past, found outside the shop are very interesting, showing the progression through time.

Fantastic collection in a beautiful location. See Monet's final masterpieces as he wanted them to be viewed. Then go downstairs for a wonderful collection of many other impressionist and a few post-impressionist works. A wonderful little museum that too many people overlook.

There is much more than the Monet murals. I really wasn't that blown away by the murals because it wasn't Monet at his prime and it is hard to see the genius of his work in that setting. But the other works at the museum there are definitely worth seeing. This was also the only museum that had problems at the front with managing their lines. I had a pass and it was still a problem having to cue up.

This was one of my favorite sites. If you love Monet, it is a must-see. I bought this ticket as an add-on to the Musee d'orsay ticket, though I did not know much about it. We had done the Louvre before and were looking for something different.The Orangerie experience is simply amazing. The building was designed by the artist to display his paintings (Les Nymphéas) in the way he wanted you to view them. There is a documentary about the making of Orangerie that I highly recommend seeing before going in to see the artwork. It is really beautiful and we are still talking about how much we enjoyed it. Along with Monet, there are many other fabulous works of art.

A must if your a Claude Monet fan. Definitely a must see. We had the Paris Pass and we got right without a wait. We went in the morning and there wasn't that many people in each of the main rooms, and it was easy to take picture (no flash) of the artwork. The size of the painting as it wrapped around a half oval wall was spectacular. We had three kids between 10 & 17 and they were fine going through the museum as the museum is way smaller than the other notable museum in Paris.
