My wife is a huge Monet fan and she was enthralled with it.
Stunning. Adore this small but impressive museum - Les Nymphes was very moving.
Small museum but worth the stop. Amazing pictures and what a different feeling from any other Museum you've visited. Don't miss the video showing downstairs!
Another fine museum!. Definitely worth visiting! Excellent! The exhibits and artwork were beyond compare!

Massive water lillies galleries. The gallery was small, so you could do it in an hour, but everything was interesting. I preferred this over the larger museums that take forever and are monotonous. The Monet water lillies were amazing.

I would Rank This Low Compared to Other Paris Art Museums. The Museum is Small. At the time it was overcrowed, but did not have any thing that was special.
Definitely not worth the entrance fee.
A must if a Monet fan!. The ultimate to see the Monet water lilies. Go to Giveny first if you can - makes more sense. Can be crowded. Don't forget downstairs galleries - can surprise you. Enjoy!

Waterlilies by Monet. Spectacular work of art. But I found Orsay and Louvre better. If you have explored the other two and want another museum, check out the l'Orangerie.
Lots of security guards who will take away your umbrella on a rainy Paris day. You have to also check in your backpacks.
really. 10 years and 28 million?. the water lillys are still great but basicaly not enhance at all buy this highly overrated renovation.

Monet's Water Lillies! Incredible!. This is a wonderful little museum with very few crowds. Buy a Paris Museum Pass to skip any potential lines and save time.
The museum is located in what used to be a greenhouse for French royalty. Hence the Orangerie.
Monet's masterpieces are displayed as he intended, using only natural light. Wonderful!

Very very good but let it be the last one!. Is very very good but only for these specific paintings of Monet!If this is your first time in Paris, leave it for another time!I have seen it the 3rd time I went!

Must See. Beautiful museum, The Water Lilies are what draw everyone, but the collections downstairs are phenominal. Renoirs, Derains, Cezannes, Picassos, and more, Paul Guillaume's collection. Smaller museum, very enjoyable.

Monet's lilies. Wonderful presentation of Monet's massive water lily works. Presentation makes the most of these works which were meant to be on a curved wall, and with natural light (skylights) and electric lighting when it is overcast.

Gem of a Museum. It is a must-see destination for Monet lovers. The two halls of wrapraround waterlily paintings are stunning. It also has an amazing collection of modern art, with many other impressionist works as well.
Very small but nice. Enjoyable museum. Monet's water Lillie's were beautiful.
If you like Monet.... very beautiful musuem- 2 huge rooms dedicated to Monet's water lillies murals. I love the huge collection of Renoir and Cezanna... Another great parisian museum

Wow - what a collection!. Monet's water lillies were amazing and also we couldn't believe the other major artists there from Renoir to Picasso to Matisse. Such a big and impressive collection and well laid out. Not to be missed...right off the Jardin de Tuilleries.

A little gem. This gallery is not one that MOST tourists go to, they prefer the Louvre on the other end of the garden. Take this tip....walk down to the bottome of the gardn and on your left is this wonderful gallery. It houses Monet's large scale waterlillies and provides a tranquil refuge from the hustle and bustle of Parisian everyday life. The cool interieor and spacious exhibition spaces privide a wonderful , intimate experience for the art lover. It houses art from Impressionists, post Impressionsists, Cubists and Expressionsists. Also has a great museum shop.
Breathtaking. Great display of Monet's lillies in large stark white rooms with ample seating to just sit and enjoy. Other exhibits on the floor below worth visiting.
First Visit. After Giverney we looked forward to Monets Lilys. Did not enjoy all of the artists but museum was beautiful!

Go for the Water Lillies, but be sure to see the collection on the lower level as well. One of the best in Paris.. The Water Lilly murals are amazing. Simply nothing else like them in the world and worth the trip just for them. But don't leave without visiting the Guilliam collection on the lower level. Many beautiful Monets, Renoirs, Picassos and other masterpieces. A small gem of a museum tucked in the heart of Paris. Tie this in with d'Orsay and you will have a wonderful day.

Dream museum for Impressionist lover. You can't miss this museum, which is very small, if you love Monet and impressionist art. Museum pass gets you in right away and you can see it all in an hour or two.

Beautiful waterlilies. I loved this museum. Unlike the Louvre, it is not overwhelming. Monet's large paintings of waterlilies are beautifully displayed with natural light coming through the roof. The 2 rooms housing the 8 paintings are serene. Other paintings featuring different artists, such as Cezanne, Picasso, Renoir and Matisse, are downstairs.
A must if you like Monet. Huge paintings of Monet's water lilies surround you in two oval shaped rooms. Works by Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne and other artists were also featured downstairs.
Great large Monet's. Musee de l'Organerie is well designed to house the large scale Monet paintings of Giverny. It is a beatiful space to see these works
Great collection of pictures beyond the Monet waterlilies. Water lilies might be boring,, the other collection was marvellous

Only if you have time. I won't name it in the top three must-sees in Paris, but I enjoyed the atmosphere and the way the exposition was organised.
The lines are not that big, but probably you'll have to wait for around 20 minutes. Take your cance to sit on the bench next to the museum and make panoramic pictures of the Square.
Musee de L'Orangerie. This is a great gallery well worth a visit. It is also small enough to gently introduce children to the world of impressionist art.

Time-out with the waterlilies. A visit to the L'Orangerie is one of the primary experiences everyone should have in their lifetime.The two oval rooms of Claude Monet's absolutely exquisite murals make this one of the most relaxing museums in the world. You could sit for hours moving around on the oval seating to linger over the various views in changing light and season. If you are finding your visit to Paris is becoming exhausting (as it often does!) you should give yourself a break in this wonderful oasis.On a lower level of the museum is the Walter-Guillaume Collection of avant-garde works from the late 19th and early 20th Century - Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliani, Rousseau, Laurencin, Picasso, Matisse, Derain, Utrillo and Soutine. If you fell asleep among the waterlilies, these will wake you up!

A haven of beauty. Do not miss the water lilies series if you have an hour to spend. Easily reached from the Louvre if you feel up to it! Or as a stand-alone nod to culture if you are in the Jardin de Tuilleries. Also get the combined ticket if yiu're planning to go to the Musee d"Orsay as yiu'll miss the queues.

If you like Monet.... We visited here on the day after going to Monet's gardens in Giverny. What a treat to his works, including the oval room with the lily pads. The museum has a manageable size without the crowds that some museums have. It was a family favorite (two teenage daughters).
Slightly off the idiot path. One could slow down and enjoy the paintings at this museum, unlike at the stronger Orsay collection.

The best way to view. L'Orangerie offers one the opportunity to explore the modern art of such renown artists as Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Rousseau, Matisse, Derain, Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo and Laurencin. For me however, it is the Monet Nymphéas that makes this a must see. Seeing these works of art in the way that Monet wanted us to view them makes for a very special experience.
Beautiful. Well worth it! Take the time. Monet's Water Lillies are beyond beautiful.

MONET ALL THE WAY !!!. Absolutely superb.... Monet and a load of others like Dali and Ruben this is one little place you must see. a very nice collection and a cute little gift shop....closed on a Tuesday!!! linked to the Musee d'orsay by the tullieries gardens.NO PHOTOGRAPHY ALLOWED INSIDE.
Good if you like Monet. Excellent to see the Monet water lilies but after that not much there. A bit of a queue but not too bad.
Get a Museum pass. Museum built for one exhibit, the waterlillys. With a museum pass we walked in, saw it and were out of there

beauty near the Tuilieries. I visited here on a Saturday afternoon after strolling around the Tuileries. Even without a reservation, the line was not too long. Gorgeous selection of 19th century paintings and a well-stocked gift shop.

The Finest Attraction in Paris. Do not walk. RUN to see this. You will not be sorry. It is amazing. Do some reading about the paintings first; it will greatly expand your experience.I sat in the first room one day and the sun went behind a cloud; the entire thing changed. It is an extraordinary place to spend time.

Favorite museum in Paris. This museum's size is one of the reasons I loved it so much. I visited late in the day and there was almost no one there. I was able to sit on the bench and marvel at the beauty of Monet's Waterlilies. They are truly spectacular. The lower floor houses the collection of Paul Guillaume, a Parisian art dealer from the twenties. It is an excellent collection and well worth the visit
Great little museum. The museum is located in a park and was built for Monet's Giverny pond paintings. It was lovely.
Loved it!. Sweet, small museum - very intimate and great art!

Not worth paying to see. We went on the first Sunday of the month, so we had free entry. I really enjoy impressionistic art and have visited Giverny, but really, for the few painting that are in the museum...well, you decide. You won't need more than 45 minutes for the visit.

A little gem!. A must see if you like to enjoy Art. After the" zoo "at Orsay the day before ,(huge lines up and unruly tourists)L'orangerie was the prefect place to enjoy "the Water Lillies by Monet .There is a movie downstair explaining Monet' s work (see times) it is in French with English subtitles. The oval room where the paintings are displayed has a peaceful atmosphere where we can really understand what the painter wanted us to feel.Very zen.

Very unique space. Loved this museum and the Monet scenes painted within. It's always full of people, but that didn't detract from the experience of seeing the very famous works within. What I liked most is that the entire museum can be experienced in two hours or so, which can't be said for others like the Louvre and Musee d'Orsay. It's well worth a visit, even if, like me, you're not super knowledgable about art.

Awesome if you are a fan of Monet. Very unique museum. The big round rooms housing Monet's Water Lilies are absolutely beautiful and truly unique. Not the first museum in Paris I would see, but definitely put it on your list! The location is also very nice for a walk through the Tuileries Garden between this museum and the Louvre.
Monet and more. This was not on the top of our list, but we enjoyed this museum just as much as Orsay. Don't miss the amazing Monets. A nice bookstore for gifts too.

Disappointed. I'm probably the only one out here that ranked L'Orangerie so poorly. It's only because we tried to see the museum on Tuesday...when, of course, the museum is closed! Oh, yeah, that's right Tuesday is when this museum is closed. Go figure. Monday I would understand. But Tuesday? Huh? Really?We ended up walking a bit around the Tuileries Gardens which was wonderful especially the lavender which I would give 5 stars to :)

Great surprise. I had somehow never heard of the Orangerie museum, but because the lines at Musee D'Orsay were out of control, we ended up here. Lovely, small museum with some interesting permanent pieces, but what we really enjoyed most was the temporary Debussy exhibit, which I would imagine would appeal to many different people.
Magical Monet!. A real treat to see his gorgeous paintings in uncrowded surroundings.

Priceless Water Lilies. You do not have to be an art connoisseur to have seen beautiful water lilies painted by Monet.You enter the gallery and you are surrounded by genius and peacefulness.There is only one thing to look at in this museum and it is pure heaven!

If you like Monet you will love this. Home to Monet's massive water lily paintings, travel the figure 8 and immerse yourself in the hypnotic blue waters. Many more impressionist paintings in the basement, I vastly prefer l'Orangerie to the very busy and crowded Musee D'Orsay. Check the hours before you go, it operates on a different schedule from most Paris art museums.
Nice option to the huge Louvre. Some nice paintings by popular artists. A good alternative if you do not wish to line up for the Louvre.
matisse in larg scale!. Don't miss this small museum in the luxemburg gardens. Although a bit expensive to get in, it's breathtaking to see the matisse paitings in such a large scale...
Monet, up close. Quite an amazing museum in the way the Monet's are displayed. No where else will you get a sense of the master's work as you will here. The scale of the paintings are amazing.

A breathtaking view of Monet. If you only see the two rooms of the Monet works, it is defiantly worth visiting. You immerse yourself in the art as you walk around the two rooms of the Monet art. Even though there were a lot of people there, it didn’t seem crowded.
Beautiful Monet exhibit. We loved the round room with the water lilies. It is very peaceful.

Fabulous. The Monet exhibition was a highlight of my trip. It was very serene and relaxing with the staff ensuring that the experience was not ruined by noisy visitors. Please note: This museum is closed on Tuesdays - we had a wasted journey on our first attempt to visit. Visitor guides were provided in a number of languages but unfortunately, they has run out of English ones.
Think you know Monet?. This musuem was part of a combo ticket purchased at d'Orsay & I was stunned to see the Water Lillies in this format. I'll never forget it.
giverny comes to paris. monet....monet....more monet...2 rooms with wall to wall water lilies...for those old enough u'll stare like cameron in 'ferris bueller"

Highlight of my trip...being a Monet lover!. There's nothing like feeling the presence of a Master. That's exactly how I felt browsing, sitting, and getting close-up views to these masterful wall-sized paintings. If you love Monet's Nympheas (water lilies) this is a "must-see". The line wasn't too long, and there is seating in the center of each room to sit and admire Monet's great works. Top it off with a trip to Giverny...which we did.
Small but worth it. Even without the paintings in the downstairs gallery the eight huge Monet's make this museum worth a stop.
Beautiful!. All you have to see are Monet's water lilies. The span two rooms and you can just sit on the centrally placed benches and take it all in.
Overwhelming.. Monets water lilies will just blow you away. They are unbelievably beautiful.
nenufares. If you like impressionists especially Monet you must be there.

Exquisite. The renovation of the Orangerie was extraordinarily well done. Although I enjoy Monet's smaller works much more, the aquatic panels are mind-boggling in their scale, and a pleasant brief diversion after the Louvre or Quai d'Orsay.
Size does matter. No queue but fierce warden meant no phone or chatting!

Monet's Waterlillies, a must see.. The display of Monet's Waterlillies is amazing as you are actually sitting in the middle of a 360 degree display. Breathtaking. You can spend a day or days being overwhelmed at the Louvre or take an afternoon and spend it gazing at the tranquility of Monet's Waterlillies. You will not be disappointed by this charming and manageable museum found at the end of the Tuilieries.

A classic don't miss it!. What can I say this is one of the most stunning sights I've ever seen. We did the self guided tour guided tours times and days are limited so pay attention to that if you are planning your trip.
Wow. A ton of the greatest hits of impressionism in a small museum; you can be through it in a couple of hours and your feet will thank you.

Heaven for Monet lovers. It's small but packed full of absolutely amazing art. Monet's Nympheas are just stunning and so beautifully displayed.It's also a great place if you're into Renoir, Picasso, Cezanne, Gaugain... just to name a few.It's a wonderful place to visit and it's in a great location too, very easy to get too.

Dont miss this little gem. I love the l'Orangerie museum because it is small, compact, but the art works her are wonderful. You can get through the museum in a couple of hours without feeling overwhelmed and walk out being absolutely amazed by the mural panels done by Monet- Which everyone needs to see.
A museum as Monet designed and planned for his waterlillies. a respite from the heat of the surrounding garden. A wonderful view of the waterlilies and other great works. great museum architecture.

MONET ON DISPLAY. If you are an impressionist fan and love Monet, do not miss Musee de l'Orangerie. Monet's "Water Lillies" exhibit is breathtaking. You feel like you're sitting in a fishbowl looking out. Quite an experience.
Monet's Water Lilies. You can't miss the beautiful Water Lilies. You can walk in the Tuileries Garden after visiting the museum.

Antidote to the Louvre. If you think the Louve is overwhelming and overcrowded I recommend you go to this museum. There are two rooms filled with huge painting of Monet's waterlillys which are spectacular and peaceful.

Monet's water lilies. The main attraction of this small museum is the display of Monet's gigantic water lily paintings from the latter years of his life. Downstairs there are small paintings by Cézanne, Matisse, Picasso, and several lesser-known artists. If you love art, go to the Orangerie to supplement your visits to the larger museums.

Nice glimpse of artwork. If you want to breeze through a museum in less than an hour but take in a few paintings by Monet or Renoir, then this is worth a visit. If you are visiting one of the larger museums in Paris, this could be skipped. Look for the free entrance day (first Sunday of the month when we were visiting).

Great little museum!!. The two large circular rooms with Monet's paintings are well worth the admission fee. The lower level has several rooms with a various displays. You can easily see everything in an hour or so. It is not overwhelming, just very enjoyable.
Monet's Waterlilies. Don't miss this one. Small, but worth a visit. It's tucked away in the Tuileries, and usually very uncrowded.
excellent collection. Not only Monet, you can also find an extensive precious collection downstairs. Book online and save time, queues are always long
Are these water lilies over-rated?. This is a nice gallery, with some interesting paintings on the lower-ground floor. But I do wonder if Monet's Nympheas aren't a bit over-hyped.

Intimate Museum - Pleasant Experience. I liked that it wasn't so crowded! The staff were friendly and helpful. No cafe inside, grab something in the park just outside. Nice compact collection of impressionist paintings on the lower level, and two rooms of huge Water Lily mural-size paintings done by Monet specifically for this museum. Easy to get to at Place de Concorde, hang and people watch in the park before and/or after. Good bistro in the park just beyond the foundtain by the L'Orangerie. A very pleasant experience overall.
Never knew Monet's "Water Lilies" were that big!!. Lots of Monet but little else. I was suprised how small this meseum was

Gotta love those Monet Water Lillies. The big attraction here is a series of Water Lilly paintings by Monet done near the end of his life when he was nearly blind. There are other high quality impressionist artworks here as well. Be sure to get your tickets in advance online or you will wait, as we did, in the rain, on a long line. They sell a discounted combination ticket paired with the Musee d'Orsay which is very worthwhile.

Small museum - worth seeing for the famous water lilies. I really recommend that people get the Paris Museum Pass while they're in Paris. It allows them to just pop into some of the smaller museums and see some of the most famous artwork in the world. We probably would have missed the l'Orangerie if not for the Museum Pass because we were only in Paris for a week and there is just so much to see.Monet specifically had two rooms displayed in such a way to display his 8 panels of water lilies paintings and they are amazing. Photography is not allowed, and it is worth coming to this museum just to see them. Also, as other reviewers have mentioned, the bathroom downstairs is useful if you are walking in or through the Tuilleries and the museum pass gains admission to a free bathroom and allows you to see and maybe appreciate world famous artwork that you never expected to. I know I did.

Hidden Gem in the Tuileries. I lived in Paris for almost a year before I realized this lovely museum was hidden in the corner of the Tuileries. It's free on the first Sunday of the month, but worth a trip anytime just to see those Monets. Don't miss the rest of the museum, though, it's fantastic as well!
so beautiful. Both the water lilies and the art in the lower portion of this little museum where wonderful

Peaceful oasis. This is a wonderful small museum which is especially worthwhile if you have the Museum Pass. The size of the museum is extremely manageable even for a short visit and the Monet murals in the oval rooms are breathtaking. Sit on the benches, relax, and lose yourself in these paintings.
Monet, Monet, Monet. More than worth visiting for the two rooms dedicated solely to Monet. Truly as if you are in his gardens.

Monet's Giant Waterlilies and More!. We bought the tickets from FNAC, and walked right in about 2 hours before closing. There was a line that we skipped ahead of since we had the tickets. The Monet's in the two large upstairs galleries were fabulous. They were done close to the end of his life, and he really was bordering on abstraction, but they are definitely recognizable and just stunning. The way he captures twilight and the reflection of the clouds in the water is magical. Make sure you head down to the basement to see all the rest of the artist's including Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso,Rousseau, Matisse, Derain, Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo and Laurencin, it's definitely worthwhile.
Monet classics. This smaller museum not far from the Louvre was interesting but it is more for the art lover. The classic huge Monet water lillies are there for your study and enjoyment.

Don't skip this museum!. Make sure to get the museum pass so that you sail past the lines. The Monet water lilies displayed in the rooms Monet designed just for them are remarkable. Get the audio guide, a plus for both the upstairs and downstairs. And do not skip the downstairs. We hadn't been aware of the variety and excellence of the collection.
A little gem.. Buy the combined ticket with the D'Orsay. Great value.

Great small size museum to see with kids. The larger more common museums such as the louvre and Musee d'orsay can be too much for small kids as they don't have the patience. The Musee de l'orangerie is a perfect size to ensure the kids dont get bored. The adults also really enjoyed the spectacular paintings by Monet and others. You also avoid the queues that Cohen with the larger museums. Highly recommended for the whole family.

beautiful. if you are in the area - you must stop just to see the Monet waterlily murals. The air conditioning helps to give you a break from all that walking. Stop and spend 20-30 minutes relaxing. Don't miss Rodin's Kiss sculpture just outside the entrance.
Great. Enjoyed it and liked that it was a little less busy than other Paris museums.
Must see Monet. Monet's waterlillies along with other fascinating artists. What more can I say? Make sure to get the audio guide (nothing is in English) and the dual ticket for the Musee d'Orsay.

Small but very impressive. l'Orangeri was very small. First it was builded for Monet and there are two rooms for him. There are for paintings in each room and they was very big. In other floor there is a collection of a dealer.
Serenity and calm oasis. Breath- taking murals of Monet's waterlilies. A calm oasis to enjoy Monet in the middle of Paris.

Go early. We were waiting in line when the doors opened (at 5 minutes after 9), so we were able to view Monet's water lilies in comparative peace and quiet. A beautiful experience. There was another exhibition from a private collection of Impressionists, lovely to view without the usual crowds.
Small, but wonderful. A museum that can be casually visited and enjoyed without the hustle and bustle of its neighbor (the Louvre)
Renoirs. Went here for the Monet rooms, but what a great surprise with all the RenoirsWent they had, and many others. A great fine and easy to maneuver
A must visit. The paintings are truly magnificent. If yu don't know about this place then just find out and then go!
Ethereal. Hands down my favorite art museum anywhere! The natural lighting and artwork combine to make a truly magical experience.

The BIG Waterlillies are here.. If you enjoy Monet at all, this is a must. here is where the huge water lilly paintings are displayed. Make reservations ahead or get a City Pass so you can avoid standing in line.
Favorite museum in Paris. We love this museum and we plan to go there at least twice during any Paris visit. The Monet's call for at least an hour of watching and dreaming.

Go when it's quiet. It's wonderful. I highly recommend it but I didn't get all the feelings other reviewers talked about because it was so packed! I really recommend trying to find a quiet time to do. A good thing was that despite it being a free day (on the first Sunday of the month, all public museums are free) the queue was only a couple of minutes long so totally manageable with two small kids. When we walked over to the d'Orsay the queue took up the whole plaza and never seemed to move. We were soooo disappointed.

My favorite art museum. If you like Impressionism and post-Impressionism you will find yourself in heaven here. It is redesigned and contains many of the works of the old Jeu du Paume. We liked the sweep of genres and places to sit and reflect.
breathtaking. see Monet's waterlilies from close, and understand these are some of the greatest art pieces ever made.

An oasis of tranquility. Visiting the Musee de l'Orangerie for the first time, after glimpsing it in the movie Midnight in Paris, I found taking the time to view the Monet Nymphea masterpieces in their panoramic splendour (as the master intended) very moving. Monet gave instructions in the immediate post WW1 period that the paintings of the waterlillies from his Giverny pond were to be displayed in their full glory, including with the white ante-chamber to gain the necessary frame of mind to fully appreciate the healing properties of the works. Despite there being quite a few other viewers, I found that the atmosphere in the two salles was calm, reverential and the hushed surroundings enabled me to see the full scope of these truly great panorama paintings. Definitely a fine opportunity to shed the last vestiges of work-stress, and start enjoying the holiday. Next time I visit Paris, I think I will come here first!Th lower floor also has many fine art works of the impressionist and later periods.
doable in an hour. If you're into Impressionist Art and don't have the time to do the Musee D'Orsay (or have a special love of Monet's Water Lillies, this museum is cute and compact

A lovely little gallery that can fill in a spare hour or two.. There is more on display than just Monet’s water lilies but this is the place to see these magnificent murals!
I suggest that you combine the ticket with the Musée d’Orsay as you can easily cover both in half a day (if you don’t need to stop in front of every painting on every level at the larger Musée).
Unforgetable. Wonderful impressionist works, including Monet's Water Lillies. Fewer people than other museums.
If you are a Monet fan, Musee de l'Orangerie is a must!. The huge paintings of Monet's waterlily are breath taking!
Go here then visit Giverny. Great examples of Monet's water lilies in natural light
Great for a quick trip. There are so many museums in Paris it can get overwhelming. I liked this one because it's short and sweet and the art is absolutely stunning!
Great little yet mesmorizing collection. Amazing artwork by Monet. Refreshing and well-organized. It's a much smaller museum than louvre and Orsay but they have a wonderful collection.

Don't miss this. In my opinion, this gallery rivals Musee d'Orsay for the quality and display of its art. It was closed for many years, and we never visit Paris without coming here, now that it's back open.
Monet's Water lilies. Spectacular presentation in two rooms with a new lighting that shows his greatness in a very casual setting. Not crowded very relaxing

l'Orangerie - A Sleeper. Just across the river from the d'Orsay is the Musee de l'Orangerie. Just happened to see something about it before leaving home and thought it looked interesting. Well, this relative small collection has some real gems of Renoir and Cezanne but the real thrill of this museum is experiencing the giant canvases of Monet's Waterlillies collection. Over 8 walls in 2 rooms are spread some of the largest canvases you'll likely encounter. What amazed and puzzled me is that a distance, you "Get the Picture" but at an arm's length (the distance that Monet would be standing to paint, nothing makes sense - it seems like chaos. Sitting back on the benches taking in these beautiful images, is a perfect counterbalance to the sensual overload that you get in the d'Orsay. I recommend them back to back, with perhaps a little lunch in between. What a great experience!
Worth visiting. Nice walking around in this museum, spacious, mostly Monet

Silence Please. Mini Art Gallery if you can't cope with the size of the Louvre or the queue at the Musee D'Orsay. Lovely water lilies, but wish that fellow visitors would note the calm reflective mood of the rooms, and keep the chat down.

Nice little museum off the Tulieries. This is a nice change from the larger, more popular museums in Paris. The water lilies are overrated, but should be seen once. The other exhibits downstairs are very interesting. If you like impressionist art and Monet in particular, you should spend an hour in this museum.
Mesmerizing. The Waterlilies (Monet) rooms in the basement are worth the trip all by themselves.
A privilege to visit. Sensational collection of art! We were bowled over. I will never feel the same about art galleries at home again.

First time here and very impressed. The Lilly rooms are great, though the Paul Guillaume collection is really my favorite part of this museum. Chaim Soutine's work is a highlight for me here as well as Andre Derain's depiction of the Commedia dell'arte characters - Harlequin and Pierrot. The museum is short and sweet and makes a lasting impression.
Beautiful quiet retreat. While there isn't as much art as the other famous museums, this little gem has Monet's water lilies and is a lovely air conditioned retreat from the heat outside.

Monet paradise. If you love Monet then you will love de l'Orangerie. There are 2 circular rooms with 4 original Monet's that cover the surface of each wall in both rooms. Downstairs there is also a very large display of original work by other well known artists of the past.
different view. insteresting to see, complete different that most museum in Paris, quiet museum and paintings were very colorful and vivid.

Quick Visit But Worth It. During my last trip to Paris, I was able to visit the L'Orangerie. Well worth the visit! The museum has a good sampling of Impressionist masterpieces including Monet's water lily room.

worth the visit. The rooms with the Waterlilies was fantastic. You walk into the 2 rooms and are surrounded by Monet's paintings. There are couches where you are able to sit and stare. You can see how the paintings change through the Monet's day. It also wasn't very crowded.

Beautiful small museum. Worth a short visit!
Showing the works of prominent artists: Monet that his famous water lilies decorate the walls of one of the floors, Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse and others.

Worth visiting, particularly if you want to see a smaller museum with plenty of beautiful art. I was pleased to finally have a chance to visit this museum as it was closed for renovation for several years, including when I last visited Paris. The main attractions are the Monet Waterlilly paintings, which are in two rooms specifically built to showcase these magnificent works. The surprise is the collection downstairs - I was impressed by the number of paintings by Renoir and Cezanne included in the collection in addition to a few works by Modigliani and Picasso. Because the museum isn't too large, it is possible to see everything within a couple hours.

I got the Impression..... After a few days in Paris we decided to fill an afternoon with some museum time. By museum standards it is QUITE small but packed with pieces the most impressive being the Monet oval room. It was quite a site.In all we spent about 90 minutes inside and had time to comfortably view everything, some things twice. Security was a little tight (no backpacks or large purses) but the line moved very quickly.worth the price of admission if you enjoy impressionist works.

Monet's waterlilies.. I was in heaven here! I arrived early, didn't have to queue, and could sit quietly and take in the glorious Monet murals without looking over shoulders! This is the most beautiful little gallery in Paris.
Beautiful Setting. It's a wonderful building and tends to be less crowded than many museums in peak months.
Highlight of the trip. Excellent museum - wide selections of artist and artworks. Not as crowded as the Louvre.

Small but beautiful. Home to Monet’s nympheas/ water lilies. The museums was beautifully redesigned and reopened in 2012 and the new look showcases the art in this small museum very well. The space is fresh and open with lots of natural light. The line to enter is never very long. Make sure to visit the Jardin des Tuileries, where the museum is located, after you visit the museum.
Finally. Went to Paris a lot in the last 90s and early 00s... this was closed. Glad I got to finally see it. The oval rooms are amazing. Spend some time there.

Very well done. This museum is put together in a very interesting way: Monet's famous paintings are displayed on the ground level in a very white, open and airy space, with Debussy playing in the halls that they are shown. It gives you a multi-media experience of both the painter and the composer. On the lower level are rooms and rooms full of other impressionist and surrealist paintings, including those painted by big names such as Renoir and Picasso. Although there is sometimes a bit of a line simply because security measures take time, this museum is definitely worth a visit.

Just for Monet - Go and see. This is the most memorial place for me. Just because of the paintings of Monet. I recommend anyone to visit this small museum. We also bought some posters at reasonable price.

Nice museum but far from Paris' best.... The Musee de l'Orangerie is located right inside the Tuileries Gardens and is the home for Monet's impressive Water Lilies. It's a pretty museum designed with beautiful natural lighting which highlight Monet's monumental work. Now while I love Monet, his "Nympheas" aren't my favorites of his but it's impossible to not be impressed when seeing them up close and in that setting,There is also a so-so shop and a decent collection of other paintings. Just pay attention, we never saw much in terms of directions and noticed several people who left right after seeing the water lilies. While this wasn't my favorite museum, it's still nice to visit, especially for those anxious to see Monet's most famous works. Oh, and the Museum Pass works here.
Monet's waterlilies. Simply sit and look at Monet's paintings. They look fantastic up close, then back away to see them look totally different!

Monet at his best!. No lines and Monet water lilies to the max! Two oval rooms with the best of his work. Also has a nice collection of Renoir on the lower level. This is a museum not to be missed if you like Impressionist painters.

Midnight in Paris -. Seeing the water lilly's of Monet is like drinking water.... you must do this! we walked from the Musee de O'say thru the gardens and then visited the Musse de l'orangerie.... a wonderful museam ,
Nymphéas. Absolutely worth the trouble to spend some time in the two oval rooms with the famous Nymphéas. It 's really a unique and inimitable.

Charming little museum. It has many masterpices that I love and is peaceful! A museum pass is recommended, the line was huge. It definitely is worth a visit, but after visiting D'Orsay it is as jaw-dropping as the latter.And yes, the 360º rooms for the Monet's water lillies are amazing.

Monet, Monet, Monet.. The exhibits on the lower floor of the Orangerie are fantastic. But the real drawing card here is the main floor exhibit of Monet's Nympheas (water lilies). It is ethereal and spiritual. Be prepared to experience it from the inside out. It goes beyond a beautiful painting!

A must see for impressionist fans. Being the museum literally designed to house Monet's "masterpiece" waterlily murals, the l'Orangerie doesn't disappoint. I would skip the audio guide and buy a cocktail with the 8 euro as you probably know the story: Giverny, waterlilies, blah blah blah.

A favourite!. This is one of my favourite galleries in Paris. The waterlillies are amazing and the rest of the gallery is also great with beautiful art and intimate atmosphere. Good shop too! There was a fantastic exhibition of Spanish artists when we were there. We bought a joint entry for Orangerie and Musee d'Orsay, just across the bridge, and this meant we didn't have to queue for Orsay, and as we didn't need to fit our visit with a timetable, then this joint ticket was great.

Worth it for the Water Lilies alone. Thank you to the musee directors for making the decision to return this musee to the original state that Monet had envisioned for the epitome of his lifetime's work. Incredible. The bonus was that I discovered a new artist that I loved!!! (and I'm no art snob!!)

well-worth a visit. A small museum packed with fabulous paintings by the great impressionalists, highlighted by Monet's "Water Lillies". Unlike the Orsay museum, the Orangerie doesn't have long queues and long waits to get in - so a quick visit is possible.

One of my Favorites. Please don't miss this wonderful small art museum located in the west corner of the Tuilleries Garden. It is filled with amazing art by Monet, Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse, etc. Due to the small size of its collection you will not need hours to visit!

Dreamy!. When life is too hectic and Paris is bustling and crazy - pop into l'Orangerie and sit for a while and gaze at Monet's waterlillies. There is no more perfect way to while away a rainy afternoon in Paris.
Enjoy!

Loved this Museum. This was the most delightful surprise. I knew what was inside but was still taken by surprise by the reality of what I was seeing. Pictures do not do justice to any of the treasures.

In a beautiful location, Monet water-lillies not to be missed.. This museum is located at the tip of the Tuleries gardens bordering the Seine and the Place de la Concorde. It's a gorgeous setting in any time of year. I went in both February and June this year-- gorgeous. The museum has a lovely small collection, but the true star here is the Nymphaes-- the super sized water lilies paintings by Monet that are a must-see.

A wonderful surprise. Having visited Paris a number of times I did not think to check Trip Advisor for things to do until I had a free moment and found the very high rating for the Musee de L'Orangerie. Since it was just a few minutes from our hotel we decided to visit and were richly rewarded. 2 rooms designed by Monet to house the waterlillies, compete with natural light and seating that encouraged you to bask in the wonder and accomplishment of this artist. And as others have said, relatively few people. Take the time to visit and immerse yourself in Monet's great work.And then downstairs there is a range of works by Matisse, Picasso, Gaugin, Cezanne, etc
Oragngeries. An overwhelming experience of Monet's panoramic water lillies in two circular rooms.
Monet Heaven. Walked here after a morning in the Louvre. Beautiful walk through the gardens, stop and have a coffee on the way then enjoy this beautifully serene gallery.
Art Galore. Enjoyed the Monet, of course. In summer, it can be a bit noisy. But the staff tries really hard to keep it down and condusive for quiet appreciation. Well done!
Great Impressionists collection. Yes, Monet is lionized, but the permanent collection has gems from Renoir and Utrillo, among others. Well worth the price of admission.
Mon musee favorite a Paris. This is a lovely small museum with an impressive collection. It is not as overwhelming as the Louvre or Orsay. I never miss a visit when in Paris.

One of my favoritre places. Arrive early, Purchase a museum pass, and if possible, pay a private guide to give you a two hour tour. You can go online and find one. This is the best way to see the museum. Do not miss this place.
Serene. If you love Monet, this is a small but peaceful oasis.

Great artwork and Monet's masterpiece. The Orangerie is located in the Tuileries Gardens near the Place de la Concorde and houses some important artworks of masters such as Monet, Rousseau, Picasso, Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse. You will also find taking up a whole room, Monet's masterpiece Les Nympheas.PROS- reasonably small entrance fee. Free with the Paris Museum and Monuments Pass.- lots of interesting and colourful and varied artwork to see- for photographers, non-flash photography is allowed in the main collection. Be careful setting white balance however to get accurate colours.CONS- no photography is allowed in Nympheas- no tripods are allowed at allWell worth the visit. I would suggest that you visit the website. It will give you an indication of the artwork on display, as well as prices and information about getting there.http://www.musee-orangerie.fr/
INTERESTING ART. I am not a fan of Impressionist Art, however, this was a fairly pleasent way to spend som time in Paris
Small Intimate Museum. Lovely quick museum after the massive Louvre. Monet's water lilies are spectacular.
Lillies and more lillies. In fact not one but two rooms of Monet's grand garden of lillies. There are others, Renoir, Cezanne, a Picaso, etc., worth a stroll on a cloudy/rainy day.
Great collection. Excellent collection of impressionist and post-impressionist painters, great display of Monet's water lillies.

Beautiful. I chose to visit this gallery over the d'orsay and the louvre, and while it was still crowded it was a wonderful experience and being much smaller than the others (which I visited many years ago) it is manageable in about an hour so it doesnt consume a whole afternoon :-)Although I could easily gaze at the waterlillies for hours! Go and enjoy... You will not be disappointed
Lovely little museum. Beautiful museum (although my husband, who is color blind, thinks Monet's "Water Lilies" is a hoax).

Calm amidst tourists. This wonderfully small museum is so refreshing when one gets overwhelmed by too many paintings and too many people at the Louvre. Sitting surrounded by Monet's waterlilies truly is refreshing, just as he intended.

Absolutely breathe Taking. We visited this museum during a quick get away. This was a fantastic place to enjoy some of Monet's most beautiful art works. The funny thing is that the Museum does not allow photography. They had employees keeping a close eye on the visitors to make sure they were not taking photos. This place was very reasonable especially with the purchase of a museum pass.

The best. This was my third trip to the l'Orangerie and still I can sit and look at the Monet's water lilies for hours....not as crowded as the Louvre or Versailles and much easier to enjoy due to it's smaller size
water lilies. if you like monet, the way these water lilies surround you is amazing. worth the trip, just for them.

An unexpected pleasure. We went to see Les Nympheas by Monet at the Orangerie which is a spectacle in itself. It's where Monet has "sort of" tried to bring the visual best from his garden Givernay and "plonk" it down in the centre of Paris. It's a stunning spectacle and shouldn't be missed, especially if you can't get out to his fabulous garden - although you've "gotta" experience that before you die and see it all again in heaven!But for me, it was the rest of the gallery which was so well laid out with the collections of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume: so cool, calm and what a great collection!
Monet Exhibition was superb. Range of artists work on display including Debussy and Picasso.Had to queeg for entry over one hour!
one for Monet fans. If you have some time to spare and you are at the Louvre, go the extra mile and see the Musee de l'Orangerie. It's expecially interesting for Monet fans.
A must for Monet fans. Be sure to budget some time to just sit and take in the water lilies.

Great and easy. A great chance to see monet without the crowds of some of the other galleries. This was the highlight of my Paris trip as this gallery is small enough for you to enjoy with out feeling over whelmed by the art.

Relaxing museum. Home to Monet's Water Lilies series. The huge paintings are arranged in two oval rooms, taking the shape of an infinity symbol. Yes, it can occasionally get a bit crowded, but still worth it to see. Trust me, your college dorm poster did not even come close to getting across the beauty of this series :) There are a variety of other works on the lower level and usually a special exhibit as well, which are also interesting.
Monet's Nymph's. It was a wonderful opportunity to see Monet's Nymphs and to view the collection of permanent works there too.
Monet Magic. Monets Lily Pond is magical even if you aren't and art buff you have too see this. Other artwork on display is stunning, get there early and have crowd free viewing.

a Monet must see. This museum was designed by Monet to exhibit his huge water lily paintings and contains a white room between the lobby area and the artwork intended to help one decompress and calm down before viewing the paintings. Interesting concept! The water lily exhibition space contains long benches to encourage people to sit and study the paintings, rather than rushing through the space, and the skylights over the paintings were recently (2011) cleaned, providing more natural lighting in the space. The museum exhibits work by artists other than Monet, but it is small and doesn't take long to tour.
Great for seeing the Impressionists. Small museum with a lovely collection of Monet's water lillies lit naturally lit and a small-ish collection of other impressionist paintings. Very good!
Monet Monet Monet. Lovely museum with the light perfect to see Monet's work.Well worth a visit.

Outstanding. Great collection of Monet murals - some of his last work. I loved this museum in the city of so many outstanding museums. It's spacious, quiet, has great art and big enough that you don't run into other people so much. Lots of school and tour groups here so go early. Outside there is a nice sculpture garden as well. Don't miss it.

Underrated. You don't hear many visitors talking about the Orangerie, but it's worth a visit. Monet's lilies are very well-presented, in their own rooms, encircling you. You can get up close to check them out, or retreat to be surrounded by them. And an added bonus: The fantastic art collection downstairs.

Go for the Monet Lilies Check out the rest of it. The Orangerie is more than just water lilies - they are fantastic to be sure - rooms built just to hold the wonderful paintings -- but the museum also has other exhibits that typically complement or contrast with the Monet period, The location is off the Place Concord - so its 'on the way' to or from the Louvre and generally is not to crowded - the facility provides a bit of an oasis in the cycle of 'uber' museums much as Monet intended his room with the water lilies to be.

Essential for Monet Fans, Watch out for Food Stand!. The upstairs is devoted to huge Monet Lily paintings - 60 to 80 feet wide, 10 to 15 feet high. For we Impressionist Fans, it is a feast, such grandeur, such a great opportunity to look closely at brush strokes, then stand back and see the result in disbelief.There are more exhibits downstairs, but Monet was our focus.A bonus here is the grounds, and pond, where you can eat your lunch by the water, and relax in the sunshine.There is a foodstand nearby, where you can buy pop, crepes and sandwiches, which we did. Big mistake - got a major "tourista" attack that I thought was an exclusive of Mexico. I would not recommend buying food here!!
Worth a short visit. This museum is an easy walk from the Louvre and it houses Monet's Water Lilly paintings. If you have a museum pass, you can bypass the line and enter easily.

If you love Monet its a must !. I go there everytime I'm in Paris and I never tire of this museum. It houses Monet's Nympheas which are amazing ! A trip to Giverny would definately complement this visit !

You can stay for just 30 minutes, or half a day.... I always like small museums where you can take the kids with you. I love Monet, and the paintings are well presented. On the other floors some exhibitions (Debussy in May) that I found very interesting.The architecture is interesting, very modern and fresh, on a sunny day it is great, if it rains, it might be a bit sad... Not everything is written in english, sometimes it is frustrating. I am french but I always think about other tourists who might need more information.The gift shop is worth a visit: DVD's music, gifts for kids, very rich in ideas to please loved ones.The people at the ticket counter are of course very unpleasant. I am in those occasions very ashamed to be french...Yes; museums are not cheap; too bad!

Sit - Look - Dream. Musee de l'Orangerie (named because this was once an orange orchard) is on one edge of the Tuilleries gardens on the far side from the Louvre. Go as early as possible. Check the opening hours and be there then. The Louvre & to a lesser extent the Musee D'orsay get the early busloads of tourists. You may find yourself, as I did, sitting alone in one of the rooms dedicated to Monets waterlillies. It is an incredible experience and one which I will never forget. If you get a chance, you should also try to get to Monets actual gardens at Giverney. Be warned however that the crowds are large. It will give you a better much insight to the man and his works than can be gained by reading a book. Enjoy! I have mentioned in other reviews that you should buy a museum pass if you plan to spend several days in Paris. This place, early, is the best place to get one.

Ah Monet! Breathtaking. Beautifully housed, the oval room with seats in the middle allows one to contemplate the beaty of the art-work with its enormity in an atmosphere of reverential and near-silence as you can move so close to see the brush strokes and then look round and back at the amazing size of the painting which I never appreciated before. Long queues and tough security to get in but worth it. We bought a Museum Pass for this and the Musee d'Orsay which meant no queuing outside the second museum and slipped in very quickly. Well worth planning in advance and buying the pass. I wish I'd explored that before.
really good. Yet another great art museum. Visit the Monets here. They are really special

See the paintings, visit the gardens. They spent years redoing the L'Orangerie to accommodate Monet's paintings and it was well worth the effort. His enormous masterpieces open up to you like magnificent vistas, and when you get close you feel you are surrounded by Monet's real gardens. This is a sight you shouldn't miss when you visit Paris, and if you've got time to take the train to Giverny to see the gardens that inspired Monet, do so! It's one thing to see the art, another to view the gardens in their splendor. There are always interesting displays on the lower level of this museum with artists like Picasso, Renoir and others of that era.

Well worth the visit. It's not huge, and right off the Jardin du Tuileries and Place de la Concorde, therefore it won't take very long to see. It's well worth the visit to see Monet's water lillies alone!

The Jewel in the Crown of Paris Museums. Is it art or music that tames the beast? To drop your blood pressure by 20 points, just sit in front of one of the six water lily paintings and quietly contemplate it.

Sit and see Monet!. The large scale Monet paintings are best viewed sitting on the couches provided. I love to compare the way he painted the same picture at different times of the year. We even ran into some people we knew there! l'Orangerie is a favorite place.
Excellent. Wonderful art experience especially if you like Monet and the Impressionists. Get there early to avoid lines.
All about Monet. The museum focus is Monet's study of the effects of changing light in his garden. The wall-sized impressionistic paintings are displayed in the dramatic building.
You have to like more modern art. Doesn't hold a candle to Muree d'Orsay, in my opinion, but that is my personal preference in art.

Incredible. Loved the 360 degree Monet Nymphaea works. Artwork was terrific and beautifully presented. Wish I'd known more about this Museum before our trip. We would have allotted more than the 15 minute mad dash we had.
Lovely paintings. Beautiful paintings, especially the two Monet rooms. Buy a combined ticket with Musee d'Orsay and go here first! You'll get into the Musee d'Orsay without queueing.

If you love Monet. It is a must if you are a Monet fan. The 7 huge nympheas paintings are awe inspiring. The lower portion of the museum provides additional painters, sculptors and photographs. It is in the Jardin des Tuileries, so easily accessible when you stroll down the gardens.

Monet, Monet, Monet. This museum houses Monet's "Water Lilies." The exhibit is set up in two large oval rooms; the panels envelope you as you circle around. Take some time to sit and enjoy. This is a must see. We were surprised that there was no line to get in. We visited Monet's house and garden at Giverny 2 days later which made this museum more meaningful.

Some very nice impressionist paintings. A relatively small - and therefore manageable - museum. Queue wasn't long although foul weather forced a few more people inside when we went. Some lovely Renoirs & Cezannes in the gallery; the large Monets which were the centrepiece didn't actually do much for me.
Monet - water lilies.... And not only! Visit downstairs exhibition. Not o crowded like other museums.
Brilliant. A must see in Paris. The Monet rooms are breathtaking. Luckily other works of art on display which was a massive bonus. Didn't have to queue too long either.
Not a lot to see but well laid out. Seemed like a lot of moneyt to pay for what took less than an hour to look round.

Best museum in the city. After visiting the Louvre, whcih was a disappointment, this museum was a breath of fresh air. Monet's water lilies are of ,the highlight, but the special exhibit was perfect and there were no crowds. Since it's included with the museum pass, it was easy to just pop in. Loved it.
Loved it.. Loved the Orangerie - beautiful collection of well-known works. Beautiful temporary exhibition celebrating Debussy's life and works when we visited.

Good Museum if you have the Paris Museum Pass. I very much enjoyed relaxing on the benches that are provided and letting my mind wander into Monet's Water Lilies. The scale of the paintings are really amazing. The photography exhibit that was there was not my taste, but the fact that with the Paris Museum Pass you walk to the front of the line means I didn't spend hours waiting to see essentially just the Water Lilies. (Through there are some other exceptional painting on display.) I wouldn't choose this small museum over the Louvre or the Musée d'Orsay, but it is worth stopping in if you have the Paris Museum Pass.
A little gem. small and charming, massive Monet's. This is the polar opposive of the Louvre and in my view all the better for it
Monet!. This small museum has the most amazing very large Monet's! The rest of the collection is very nice too. It was also the least crowded museum we visited.

The perfect setting for Monet's mammoth works!. It's impossible to put into words the experience of seeing Monet's large-scale paintings on display in the curved rooms of l'Orangerie. A must-see in Paris.
Monet. Loved the painting and that was the best bit of the musee. The other paintings were good too but I could easily sit in the room with Monet's painting and absorb it for hours.
excellent Debussy exhibition. Get the audioguide and you'll enjoy this art-music exhibition.
Monet. If you love impressionist paintings and you don't stop here, shame on you!!! You would miss the most amazing display of Monet on the face of the earth!
this above all else forms my memory of Paris. the perfect gallery & the best way to see Monet's lilies in captivity
Few pictures to see but a lovely small museum. Loved the wall-high water lilies. You can get lost in the paintins and it was not very crowded.
lovely museum. really enjoyed seeing the monet pieces. loved the calm vibe at this museum
Don't expect the Lourve.. Not a scratch on the Lourve or the Orsay but interesting if you are into the specific artists featured. Small museum in comparison.

Lillies plus surprises. We'd been meaning for a lomng toime to look at the waterlillies and free Sunday provided just the stimulus. What really blew us away were the pictures downstairs - Renoir nudes and a beautiful double portrait of piano players, lots of Derain and lots of Utrillo. Definitely worth seeing.
Kind of boring. If you are picking museums to visit, put this one last on your list unless you want to see Rodin's The Kiss.

Brilliant! The best little museum in Paris.. Just wandered in as we were walking through the Tuileries, and were blown away by the Monets. Had no idea of their size and beauty in real life.
Don't miss this.

Monet's masterpieces. Monet worked for the final 12 years of his life on these 8 magnificent paintings, now displayed in two restored rooms, open to the sky's light, as designed by Monet himself. They are worth seeing before you visit Giverny and see the lily ponds for yourself. Even if Giverny doesn't fit into your schedule, these paintings are well worth a visit. Allow extra time, as you will want to look longer at them than you might expect. Afterwards, there are some nice other nice Impressionist paintings by Monet and his contemporaries downstairs.

Back for a second time. I remember visiting this museum the first time a few years ago and being blown away by the size of Monet's water lilies. I had no idea they were so large; they scan the length of the walls. Just beautiful. The first time we visited, I somehow managed to snap some photos, which I have attached to this review.Don't forget to pop downstairs to see works by Picasso and Renoir, as well as others.Being on the Paris Museum pass, it was a no-brainer decision for us to visit this museum again to see these magnificent works of art. Skipping the long lines was a plus too! Buy the pass! A great help.
Disappointing. Was expecting more from this museum. While the Monet Water lilly murals were special, that was about it. Glad I didn't pay extra (this was part of the Museum Pass).

Musee de l'Orangerie. You cant leave Paris without visiting this museum, even if the queues are long. The museum was renovated and reopened in 2006 making the cycle of Monet's water-lily paintings, known as the Nymphéas, even more beautiful to see. There are other artist works the museum also contains works by Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Amedeo Modigliani, Alfred Sisley among others. Well worth a visit

A gem. You might easily miss this museum if you didn't know to try it out. It's very small, across the river from Musee d'Orsay. The Monet murals are fabulous, and the collection on the bottom floor is also very nice. I really liked that the museum was focused, rather than trying to do everything. The building is also very pretty, with an interesting history. I ended up at the museum after a nice walk through the Tuileries. Highly recommended!
short and sweet. This is a small gallery where it is easy to see the exhibits and not feel completely exhausted at the end!
Go here before Giverny. Wonderful place to go prior to visiting Giverny, the home of Claude Monet. His painting are prominently featured at l'Orangerie
Take time. Take time to see the Monet's here, so peacefull the painting come to life.
Well worth it. We almost didn't see this wonderful small museum but glad we did. the mural size paintings of Monet's water lilly's were breathtaking. Don't miss it!
Great Monet's. Ever since this open I have wanted to see this place. We caught this on the Sunday when the museums were free and this was one were the queues were ok. Awesome Monet's!

Breathtaking Monet's. It's free on teh 1st Sunday of the month so be prepared to queue - we only had to for about 15 minutes though. Also large bags, coats, backpacks are taken off you at the door & securely stored until you leave.The Monet's were worth the queue!
Monet's Water Lillies and More. Not too far from the Louvre. Significantly less crowded. Loved the opportunity to sit and enjoy the water lilly paintings and other impressionists.
A very fine museum that can be appreciated in a shorter visit.. It's a very manageable size museum that will not require a full day (or days) for the general visitor.

Great viewing rooms and downstairs gems. The water lilies were beautifully displayed and museum goers were quiet and respectful. The downstairs is also filled with gems like Renoir, Gaugin, Matisse, etc. The current Debussy exhibit was also a nice surprise.

Monet Water Lilies. This museum is a must just for the two rooms of Monet water lilies. Each room has four huge painting, each painted in different lighting. The rest of the museum is fine, but does not compare with the impressionist collection at the Orsay. Smaller museum and not crowded. Allow an hour at most.

More than I expected. Of course the two rooms of lilies were wonderful, but the Debussy exhibition was unexpected... Spent more time In there. Went at about 4.45pm on free Sunday.... No queue, but quite a few people inside.

Waterlily feast!. I'll admit that I love Monet's Waterlily series. Something about them captivates me. So of course, a museum that has large murals of his Waterlilies hung in two large oval rooms - how can I resist? In addition to the Waterlilies (which are reason enough to go), this museum also has a wonderful collection of Masters and Impressionists and a wide range of gorgeous art. I think this museum is often overlooked but it's really a jewel
a Small Gem. Easy, dont plan on more than an hour and a half. The upper floors are amazing.....Monet and more! The downstairs just delightful.
Monet!. Go for the Monet water lilies but you'll also find some great works by Cezanne, among others
A week in Paris. Monet masterpieces--not to be missed.Close to the Tuilrties gardens

A Monet must. This was a repeat trip to Paris since you need more than one visit. We focused on Monet this trip, particularly since we were going to Giverny. This is a must see if you are a Monet fan. The wonderful thing about smaller museums is they don't wear you out and overwhelm you. Seeing the 2 elliptical rooms of Monet's water lilies is a great experience and great preparation for what you feel later when seeing the gardens where he painted them. Another plus of the Orangerie is the exceptional collection of paintings from the collection of Paul Guillaume, including several Renoirs (one of my favorites, the famous 2 Young Women at the Piano, which I did not know was in this collection).

If you like Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Modigliani..... Beutifully renovated, with an impressive Impressionist collection. Plus, if your planning is good, you get to walk through the Tuileries to get there.
Water Lillies. Long line to get in, but displaying Monet's Water Lillies in the original oval room format is eye opening - a must see while in Paris. The museum can easily be toured in a few hours.

Two rooms were totally unexpected. I sort of knew what to expect because I had researched what I wanted to see in Paris. Think I would have been totally stunned if I had no idea it surrounded the whole room. But then I walked through to the second room and it continued even more beautiful. I came for the waterlillies and just had a quick browse at the restOnly thumbs down, What a pity no photo's allowed
Great day trip!. Fabulous art displays, reasonably priced, teens were admitted free!

Monet Makes This Museum. In general the museum is good but what really makes the visit are the two rooms with the wall-to-wall Monet murals. They are simply exceptional and make the visit truly worthwhile. The rest of the museum is perfectly fine and they have a good gift shop.
Good display arrangement. Quiet and nice. Collection of my most favourite works of Monet.
Great Monets. The water lilies are unbelievable. Much bigger than we expected

Water Lily Showcase. The first time I saw one of these magnificent paintings was in Chicago IL at special Monet Exhibit. The first time I visited Paris this museum was at the top of the list to see "all" of these treasured paintings.

An incomparable Impressionist extravaganza. The Orangerie is the original home that Monet always intended for his matchless canvases of water lilies, painted at Giverny at the end of his life. The museum has been remodeled to display them as Monet intended, but with improved natural light. Downstairs, the museum displays the renowned collection of Walter Guillaume, a dealer and collector of Impressionist masterworks at the turn of the 20th century. Security is tight here (as at all major Paris museums), but not a huge inconvenience. If you like the Impressionists, especially Monet; or would love to learn more about them; the Orangerie is the place to be, for a full day or even just an afternoon. The museum bookstore is just so-so, but the paintings themselves are displayed with good multilingual commentary on the artists' methods and styles.

Museum pass works here. The museum pass allowed us to skip the long line. Went downstairs fist (where the bathroom is) and walked through the special exhibit (de Bussay) signs for the exhibit were throughout the train stations so we felt obligated to duck in and see the work. We really went for the Monet water Lillie's ... While some of his work is at musee de orsay, what drew me to this museum was that Monet also had a say in the lighting of the Lillie's. The result was breathtaking and stirs the soul.

Monet's Water Lillies are stunning. If you are a fan of Claude Monet's work, you must see his Water Lillies on display here in two beautiful rooms.Other exhibits and pieces in this museum are beautiful, but Monet's work is the jewel in the crown of this museum.
Monet's Water Lillies. Monet's Water Lillies were the highlight of my visit to this museum.

Stunning Waterlilies. Although I had not originally planned to visit this museum, it was highly recommended by my tour guide when I was at the Musee D'Orsay. I am so very glad that I took her advice and stopped in! The display of Monet's Nympheas here is amazing--the panels are extremely large and stunning in their beauty. Entrance lines were long on the day I visited, however, with a museum pass, I only had to wait a few minutes. The Monet rooms were crowded, but not nearly as much as other Paris art museums. (It would be amazing to see the waterlilies when the gallery was empty!) Although you can examine the works up close, the seating in the center of the rooms lets you appreciate them on a grand scale. These spectacular paintings make a visit to the Orangerie well worth the time. Highly Recommended.
MONET!!. The building was especially designed to display the Monet waterlilies, much like MOMA but better.
Monet Magic. Wow, I waited 5 years for the renos to be finished and finally get to see the Monets. Then the other art works as a bonus. A highlight of my trip.

absolutely wonderful. Beautiful museum space with an interesting story, not as slammed with tourists as other museums in Paris. Manageable size and quite a few gems in the collection. One useful tip: you can buy an Orangerie-Orsay passport here that saves some money AND saves you from waiting in the really long line at the Musee D'Orsay (you can buy the same passport at Orsay, but there's the long line...).

A "WOW" moment!. We went to this museum AFTER being in Giverny the day before. We saw all of Monet's inspiration spread out in these magnificiant pictures flooded in the sunlight of Paris from the windows above.
do this first. much shorter lines than Louve, and a great little gallery of Picasso, Matise, Monet, etc.

Amazing Monet. Visited this amazing museum in the Tuileries Gardens in May and it was well worth it. If you're a Monet lover, you'll love it for sure. His waterlilies are breath-taking and cover entire walls inside. It's a beautiful space and has become my favorite museum in Paris! It's also quite small and only takes an hour or so. A true must-do!

Just lovely!. This museum was not on my itinerary on my 1st, 2nd, 3rd or 4th visit to Paris, but I finally made it on my 5th. And then wondered what took me so long. The Monet panels are just so lovely! A museum built for them. Such zen spaces they are, and the rest of the collection on the lower level is very nice as well. For art lovers, do stop by and don't wait as long as I did.

Much easier to absorb and appreciate the art than a large museum. I loved the size of this museum, as well as the collection of impressionist art. It was very manageable, and you could appreciate each piece and not feel "sensory overload" as you would feel in the Louvre.
Nice museum, depending on the exhibit.. I liked this museum. Unfortunately, the Debussy exhibit wasn't that great.

Up Close and Personal. Want to see Monet's lillies? This is where you can see the murals up close and personal. This gallery is often overlooked because of the Orsay and the Louvre. But... this one is small enough... with a concentration of powerful art... and just a few folks to share it with.

Monet!. If you are a fan of Claude Monet's waterlilies, you will love this museum. There are 2 large oval rooms with giant paintings of his waterlilies series on 4 sides. There is a large bench in the middle which you can just sit down and soak it all in. Absolutely stunning.

Well done!. This is a very fine remodel. It houses the large water lily paintings by Monet ( which are very well displayed) and the lower-level is filled with beautiful paintings and rotating exhibits. Monet fans will enjoy this new look to some of his largest works. Take the elevator if needed. The steps are a little steep.
Fantastic museum. Do not overlook this museum - it's one of the best museums even beyond Monet's water lilies. Make it a stop on your trip for sure.

Monet and the Rest. Monet's water lilies are definitely the major attraction here, therefore expect crowds in two wings of Monet's paintings. The rest of the exhibition did not interest me too much except for Debussy one. It's a nice gallery to visit if you've been to Paris more than once and you like to enjoy a little stroll in Jardin Tuileries.
Perfect setting for the Monet Water Lilies. Just sit on the central benches and drink in the beauty.

Great small museum. Lovely museum with famous waterlillies of Monet, but with very interesting exposition in the basement. Not too big, so you won't get the "museum overload" that you might get in museums like the Louvre. Located inside the Tuileries garden. Closed on tuesday (like almost all museums in Paris).
Don't miss it. The best museum to see in Paris. Monet's "Lilies in the Pond" are awesome among the other exhibits. Very small crowds versus the Louvre.

Worth it just for the water lilies. Be sure to allow for a few minutes just to sit in front of Monet's water lilies canvases and take them in. And consider getting the audio tour! They have one in English and it really adds to the experience.

Exquisite. Get here early and bask in salles 1 et 2 before they get crowded. Fabulously airy presentation of generally romantic art, loved the audio guide which was informative without being overwhelming (unlike the ag for musees d'orsay and marmotan which were overly academic and heavy). Debussy exhibit this summer to boot. Fabulous, Merci!!!
Worth it just for the 2 Monet rooms. This small museum near the louvre has two oval rooms that each house four massive monets showcasing the lilly pond... truly spectacular!

Waterlilies are AMAZING!. Get the Paris Museum pass (this would be a good place to purchase the pass, short lines here to start).
Don't miss Monet's Waterlilies. An awe inspiring experience. My favorite place in Paris!!

Unexpectedly loved!. Truthfully I only went here to see the big Monet's that were in Midnight in Paris...They were spectacular! I could stay in those 2 rooms forever! The other part of the museum was quite lovely also. Some of the best Impressionist work is at the l'Orangerie. Its intimate setting makes it my favorite over the Orsay! If you're in Paris for a couple of days get the Paris Museum Pass and see a few of the sites. The l'Orangerie is among the long list of sites included on the pass.
Lovely. Lovely museum. Monet's water lillies in 2 oval rooms plus other rooms with very good impressionist works.

No English guide?. I came on Sunday at 11am and there was already a line outside of the museum! Luckily the line for museum pass holders was quick and i got in within minutes. Like another reviewer has mentioned, there was no English guide when I was there too... Hmmm the audio guide was 5 euro and i decided to go in and checked out the museum first. I was glad I didn't pay the 5 euro because the museum is quite small. Given the volume of the works and the price, I don't quite understand the amount they charge for the audio guide. I visited d'Orsay before coming here so it was tough for me not to make the comparison of the value of the audio guide relative to the information I get. This is a quick visit if you are near Tulleries and I won't line up for this for more than half an hour.

Beautiful Waterlillies, can see it all in an hour. The waterlillies are worth seeing! It only took us an hour to explore the gallery - worth the time if you have a lot of time in Paris (skip it if you are short on time).
SSShhhhh!!!. Great building, great art. Prepare to be rudely shushed by the ruder shushers who shush the visitors to this great museum while they view the great art.

annoying closures. visited on VE day and Ascension day very important in France but nowhere else?So could not get in as closures not given on their website.Only upside it's on Place Concorde a fascinating area, but do watch for the traffic.
An ultimate relaxing place. I adore this kind of museums that doesn't bore you at all. The oval Monet's rooms are fantastic, calming and inspiring.

Love the Water Lilies. This is a great small museum that is easy to go thru in 1-1.5 hours. The water lilies are amazing, and the permanent exhibits are very pleasant too. Would recommend for people that don't want to spend all day in a museum.
One of the best little museums. I like museums in small doses and this one is perfect. The very best part are the two special rooms housing eight "Water Lily" murals by Claude Monet. Beautiful!

stunning displays of very famous paintings. Lay out and scale...I never realised the paintings were that large in scale. The colours are so beautiful.. The layout was very impressive and modest entry price.
Make sure you walk through the Tuillerie gardens first...

Monets water lillies. This museum is worth a visit to see the huge canvases that Monet produced of the water lillies in his garden. The museum dispalys them in an oval room to good effect. You can see all the details and brush strokes close up. There are other exhibits on at the same time. Vist on the first Sunday of the month to get free access.

Monet's Water Lilies live here. The museum was very easy to get to. Excellent access from Metro and the bus.It was smaller than I had expected but this exhibit was well worth it. There were little couches in the galleries so you could sit and just marvel at the beauty. This museum was in the top 4 attractions in Paris for me.
Monet monet monet. The Orangerie is not very popular, but it's raison d'etre and the reason to visit are the monumental Monet canvases depicting his gardens in Giverny. Don't miss it.

A Pleasing Collection in an Ultra-Modern Space. The juxtaposition of these priceless paintings set in ornate gold frames, hung on stark concrete walls added to the feeling I was viewing precious relics from a by-gone day.I particularly liked being shown a wider selection of artists from the impressionist era. I met a couple new arts who affected me - Marie Laurencin and Chiam Soutine.

Not just Les Nympheas. Monet's eight large water lilies panels (Les Nympheas) are beautifully displayed in two purpose built rooms. The museum also has some other wonderful art works and changing exhibitions. The museum holds some fine works by Renoir,Monet, Cezanne, Sisley, Picasso, Matisse, Modigliani, Utrillo and Rousseau.In 2009 photos were allowed in the museum but not so in May 2012 (a policy which has also been adopted by the Musee d'Orsay but not yet by the Louvre)
great. enjoy the museum, then exit & enjoy Place de la Concorde, then walk along the river to Pont Alexandre - great views.
For any Monet fan. If you plan to visit Giverney the Orangerie is a great preview of what you will see.

Water Lillies and more. Not only do you get Monet's Nympheas (Water Lilies), but there is a fabulous art collection there as well. The Water Lilies are an incredible work of art and are displayed as Monet wanted them to be. An escape from the outside world.
See the Lillies. I really liked this compact museum. Monet's Lilies are great and the place can be seen in an hour. It is so close to the Louvre that you should see them both.
beautiful. An amazing collection of mostly 19th century paintings.

Simple, elegant, beautiful. But go early.. Monet's waterlilies are displayed in a way that allows one to be surrounded by the paintings. It is absolutely breathtaking.All signage is in French with no English translation - I highly recommend getting the audio tour.
