Also, there is a free 45 minute film (in French with English sub-titles) that helps put the whole thing into perspective. Highly recommended!One last tip - this museum was not horribly crowded early in the morning (as the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay). We purchased a pass that was good both at l'Orangerie and d'Orsay for 14 euros which enabled us to skip the monstrous line at d'Orsay.

A Must See while in Paris!. Take a moment from a busy sight-seeing day and stop in to see Monet's water lilies. That was his intention ... to create a calm place to retreat to from a beautiful and exciting but hectic city.

one of my favorite experiences. I remembered being in Paris 20 years ago when I went to the quaint little art museum called Jeu de Pomme and was thrilled to see it's art had been moved to a new building. I got there at 9 am to open the museum and was lucky to be one of 5 people sitting in the gallery viewing the wall murals of Monet's water lillies. This was a very small collection and not crowded so able to tour entire gallery without feeling overwhelmed ( ie Louvre-not). If you love art this is a must see museum that can easily be done in an hour

Impressionist heaven - without the queues!. Having almost been trampled to death in the Musee d'Orsay, this little gem of a museum comes as a welcome surprise! No queues, manageable crowds, but above all stunningly beautiful art.Museum falls into three main areas:1) The Monet murals2) A Debussy themed exhibition3) A collection of impressionist / post-impressionist paintingsThe museum as a whole package is excellent, and really does make it the "must-see" museum.
Giverny - No Need to Go. We were thinking of a trip to Giverny, but coming here saved us the time. Eight wonderful panels by Monet.
"Big" on Monet. I went mainly to view the very large paintings by Claude Monet. This museum is located at one of the entrances to Le Jardin Tulleries, very close to the Concorde round about.

If you like Monnet, you must come here. This museum presents the giant wall size paintings by the master. The sheer size of these paintings put one right in the scenes. Take a photo (no flash) of yourself in the picture and you fit right in.

Wonderful small museum. I very much enjoyed this museum - wanted to see some impressionist paintings without the long lines. This museum had virtually no line, and each room had perhaps 10 - 15 people in it. Allowed me to relax and really soak up the beautiful works showcased.

Amazing Monet. This is a must-visit for the Monet murals. There are no pictures allowed and they let very few people in at a time but the atmosphere inside the oval rooms is unlike anything I've ever seen before. Extremely extremely quiet and the murals are just massive.

Ugly museum for nice art. I have been here several times and always feel they should rethink the way the art is displayed. Some beautiful objects had no lighting at all. Inexpensive coffee shop for a quick snack.
The impressionists on the top floor are world class
Definitely worth a visit!. Wonderful pictures! The impressionists are truly worth seeing and the second floor is spectacular, you have to love Monet!

One of the worst collections of "art" I have ever seen - could have done better myself. Felt like a total philistine here. Not sure why the French rave about Monet's lilies (or most of the other paintings) and really didn't get why people were queueing to get in. Would rather stick pins in my eyes than visit again.

Beautiful. I am a Monet convert.. This gallery was empty (to my astonishment!) the day I visited. I am so glad that I went, the waterlily paintings were so beautiful. For somebody who claimed previously to be unimpressed by Monet, This gallery completely changed my view.

Nympheas and late impressionism. An excellent choice to go to after the Louvre and d'Orsay but before the Pompidou if you want to view art in a linear way. Not the best Monet water lilies- those are in Chicago, but an impressive room
magnificent. a little confusing to find the entrance but it is magnificent!
blue, blue, blue.. flowers and water and a feel of a summer-evening ven when it is cold and winter i presume.. You can lose youself in the endless paintings on the wall, sitting on the bench.

Gorgeous Monet. Since we had a Musee Pass, we decided to make the most of it and added Musee de l'orangerie on our last day of usage. Well what a great decision, we thoroughly enjoyed this museum. The size of this museum I would consider compact and beautiful. The atmosphere was tranquil and light, just like the paintings of Monet and other great artists. What a little gem, we did not regretmaking time to visit.
Art Lovers. Glorious Monet water lilies and a private collection of Renoirs and more

Envelope yourself in a Monet. We were not here long, due to traveling with young children, but we made it through the Monet rooms. These are later examples of his work and they are stunning. They are mounted directly on the curved walls, drowning you in the water lilies themselves. This alone is worth the visit(although I am not sure about the price, we had museum passes)
Claude Monet giant masterpiece. If you like French impressionist art...visit this museum. A former Orange tree hothouse now holds some of the most famous Monet paintings. A must see

BLUE. This is an intimate museum. Not so large it takes away the breath. IF this is your favorite artist, it is a forever memorable journey. The location crowns the tuileries, so make sure you find time to stroll through this fabulous garden.
Favorites. Loved this Museum! It was my favorite of all that we visited! I loved Monet's Waterlilies.

Waterlilies!. An absolute must if you love the French Impressionists. When we visited there was a "Debussy and the Impressionists" exhibit on, with the original manuscript of Prélude à l'après-midi d'un faune on display. Of course you spend most of your time gawking at Monets superb waterlilies.
ONe of the BEST. breathtaking...a great spot to take in monet and destress from anything
Great museum and no lines!. Was great to see Monet's water lillies and not have to wait in any lines to get in!
One of the nicest smaller museums. If the Louvre is too big, this is just a perfect size, wonderful artwork displayed, you can see it all in around a couple of hours
Culture. A delightful museum is the Louvre gardens, well worth a visit, beautiful art work

I went here twice during the trip!!. The display of Monet's waterlilies is NOT to be missed. Just sit there and take it in. I bought the 2 day museum pass and stopped here twice. PS You can also see another display of this at MOMA in NYC.

intimate museum. i'm not going to lie: i went there for the waterliliesi went straight to the waterlily rooms, found a spot on the benches and sat in the middle of the room and tried to imagine that the paintings were the real thing. it's like remembering a dream where the light makes your vision blurry and all you see are colors. one wall was bright with the noon sun, one was of a cool morning and one seemed to be painted at dusk. even the shadows were painted with different colors.wonderful.
great collection. The permanent collection alone makes this a must. It augments the D'Orsay, but also has temporary shows that are worth while.
Water Lilies!. Monet's water lilies are the reason for the museum, and they are spectacular.
Fantastic collection and building. Take enough time to soak up Monet's Les Nymphéas, then go downstairs to view the collection.
Even better than expected. I adore Monet and this was a dream come true to sit and admire and adore up close and personal. Simply Superb
Monet. Housing Monet's major work. It is a must see!! The audio guides are a must to give one an explanation of the museum.

This museum is built around Monet's water lilies painting.. Since the last time I was here they have stopped allowing the taking of pictures of the Monet water lilies painting. The painting is amazing if not just due to the massive size. There are also Renoir's and Picasso's. Not being huge art fans we spent about 30 minutes in this museum. We enjoyed it and it was amazing to see these famous artists paintings.
pales in comparison to the Musee d'Orsay. Some nice works in this gallery but a lot of unused wall space and a disappointment in comparison to the nearby Musee d'Orsay.
Don't miss!!. Monet works not to be missed! Breathtaking water lilies and then more to take in downstairs with many painting by other Impressionist artists
Wonderful Monet. Do visit this gallery, amazing experience, use the audio guide 5e but well worth the money.

Love Monet, shame about the museum.. I was starting to appreciate art until I saw the collection in L'Orange. Monet's wife must have refused to let him buy more paint until he used up all the off tint, lifeless colors left. Of the other art, if someone stole 98% of it, it wouldn't be missed. I,ve seen better on display in the national gallery in Canberra. By the way, no English guides left the day we went. Not a world class attraction by any means. The Basilica on the other hand, oh la la.
I'm floating in wonderful recollections. I was surprised by the art on exhibit in addition to Monet's Water Lilies which defy description. Enjoyed every minute there.

Moments of tranquiliity. I am usually of the opinion that once you've been to one art gallery, there's nothing to add to that experience. I quite like Monet's work and was amazed to see it on such a large scale. I truly felt like one of the original Parisians who had been working all day and sat in the orangerie to escape the hassles of the day and appreciate the beauty of nature.
Excellent museum; careful about the crowds!. Great Debussy and his era show; very good general collection. Mobbed by noon.
If you love Monet. Excellent Monet gallery including the circular Nympheas rooms. We had been to Giverny the day before, so this was a real treat.

A Gem in the Ruff. This museum has been in my face for several years before I was aware of what is inside. It has been over looked by many for other museums in the city. I will go back to these monet's.

Small and focused can be more satisfying to visit than the Louvre. If you prefer impressionist painting and in particular Monet, this is a great place to start. It's small and the number of paintings are limited but the Monet room alone is worth the price of admission. Quibble: Huge line-ups for the women's washrooms which were not clean nor well maintained. Two stalls out of the five available were "out of order" and there was no toilet paper in the other stalls. So come prepared! There did not seem to be anywhere to have a light snack or coffee on the premises.
new but old. Its a great piece of heaven for people who love impressionism. very close to subway beautiful gardens around it... must visit

Lots of Monet. The Debussy exhibition that is currently showing in interesting but my favourite part of this museum is the two Monet rooms. Make sure you block out some time just to sit and stare at them if you like Monet.
My favorite museum.. The contemplative Monet room. All of the impressionist paintings.
Once in a lifetime..... Just sit and absorb the gorgeous full panels of Monet's water lilies.....it was quiet, not very crowded, and makes a beautiful starting point for a stroll up the Tuilleries.

Average, not great. Been waiting several years for renovation to be completed and see this museum's Monet paintings. Maybe expectations were too high. Two oval rooms with four paintings each arrayed around the walls. Only one painting wow-ed us. The Marmatan we thought was better. In basement is a decent additional collection of art. Now we can say we have been there, but I'd do this as a "what else is there to do," not a primary "must see" item.

Big reward from small museum. All I can say is wow! Despite being small in size this museum contains more quality pieces than pretty much any art museum I've been to. I was never much of a Monet fan but standing in front of his massive water Lillie's was simply awe inspiring. This little museum is well worth every penny or in this case Euro cent.

Water Lillies. The whole Museum is fabulous, but just sitting in the Water Lillies Rooms makes a trip to L'Orangerie completely worthwhile -- you can just sit and take them all in in their full beauty. Don't miss it!

Good and disappointing at the same time. The Monet here are not as good as it should be (with maybe the Water Lilies being the exception), as too many good ones are spread all over the world. My emotion-stirring discovery is the Starry Night Over the Rhone from Van Gogh. It is not the Starry Starry Night in the Museum of Modern Art in New York, but nonetheless magnificent for the depiction of the night lights traipsing over the Rhone River. The l'Orangerie should be the counterpoint visit after a day at the Louvre, separated by a walk through the Jardin du Tuileries.

Don't miss Monet's lillies.. One of my favorite museums in the world. Every time we go to Paris, this stop is on the schedule. It is very close to Musse d'Orsay and the Louve but it is hard to see all in one day.

Just as good second time around. This is one of the best museums in Paris. Small in size, but 'huge' in terms of the quality of the impressionist masters on display. Even if you are not an 'art buff' this is a gallery you would enjoy.
First Time There. This is the most wonderful art musem for Monet, "the lillies" have to be seen to be believed. 8 panels in 2 oval rooms, it's all encompassing and words fail me.

Amazing Impressionist Art Museum. We love this museum. It's been renovated recently and is totally different than the cozy, home like setting we remember but the artwork is still just as amazing. It was renovated to bring Monet's Water Lilies upstairs to be viewed in filtered natural light.
Worth seeing. Personally like Musee d'Orsay better for Impressionism, but you should see this one too, with Monet's huge water lilies, at least once.
Peaceful museum. Having just been to the hustle and bustle of the Louvre, this was a real treat. The Monet waterlilies are stunning and the Debussy exhibition was beautiful and all very relaxed!

Monet waterlillies displayed the way intended.. This museum is specially designed to house the waterlilly panoramas Monet painted in his later years. It is a must see for any Monet follower.A memorable experience.

Huge Monets impressively displayed. Permanent collection includes 8 large canvases (6 ft high by 25 or more feet long) done of Monet's Giverny garden. The display is breath-taking. There is also a worthy collection downstairs of other Impressionists. Well worth a visit.

Monet's palace. Lorangerie is always with big lines, so the best way to arrive and enter is to get the Paris Museun Pass, you dont have any lines and get access to Lorangerie super fast. You must go to these museun, huge Monet paintings, the light is something special too. Picasso and many others to see.
Unmissable Monet. You just can get enough of Monet! The museum is the perfect size and if you book in advance you jump the queues.

A Must see. My husband did not want to see many indoor attractions during our visit so I picked this as my one art musee. It was well worth it and loved everything. You can't imagine the feeling of seeing the water lilies inches from your eyes, then sitting on the benches and taking it all in. There were no lines.
Waterlillies. Their are two oval rooms where the walls are covered by waterlilly scenes by Monet
bite size pleasure. The museum pass (e.g., two days = €40) lets you skip most of the ticket lines and makes it worth stopping at the small museums, which are much less crowded.
little gem. It's small but has beautiful Monets. It's setting in right in the Tulleries. We were there on election day and saw Place de la Concorde being set up for citizens to mass.

Monet's Water Lilies. If your visit to Paris is short, as our recent trip was, skip the Louvre and see Monet's Water Lilies at Musee de l'Orangerie instead. They are simply spectacular. The painting and museum were literally made for each other so the paintings surround you in two rooms which let you immerse yourself in Monet's vision. Though busy, the crowds were not bad on the blustery April day we visited. Whether you love impressionism or not, don't miss this. They also have a lovely collection of the other period artists in the lower rooms of the museum.

Words don't express. Another review that I am having to pad out to keep the moronic Tripadvisor system happy. This is another Paris attraction that defies words - the Monet mroals take ypur breath away. But do note that you can get a combined ticket for this gallerie and the Gare D'Orsay across the footbridge on the other bank of the Seine.

Small But Amazing. When we entered the gallery we didn't realize how many treasures it contained. The Monet murals are sensational, as are the rest of the paintings. Not too many people, very relaxing experience.
Waterlillies. The 2 oval waterlily rooms are awesome. One can sit for hours just watching the colors change as the sunlight shifts. Jut beautiful
A Lovely Site. This is a small gallery which has an exhibition that catches you by surprise. I won't mention it because it will ruin the pleasure. It is a nice place to visit.

Monet Water Lillys and so much more. Its very hard to put words down on paper to convey the experience of seeing Monet's Water Lilly's in full wall size. For me, the words great and wonderful somehow diminish the experience. Those alone would be worth going for but they have works from so many of the great artists like Renoir, Degas, Picasso, Gaugin and on and on. It's an ideal way to spend the day and it's just off the Concorde Metro stop near Tuilleries and The Louvre.

Love Monet?. This Museum is located on the other side of the Tuillieries gardens near the Place de la Concorde. Like the Musee D'Orsay, it houses a wonderful collection including some huge Monet pieces (water lilies) and is not "overwhelming" like the Louvre. Check for free days (but beware of more people on those days)

Interesting collection - Can't miss the Water Lilies. Even though the collection is small, I loved this museum. Monet's large water lilies were breathtaking. I also loved the collection of impressionist and modern works of Monet's contemporaries. It's great for a short afternoon visit.

Not to be missed if you like Monet. Could have spent a few days here - LOVED the "surround sound" water lilies..But do leave time to see lower levels as there are some incredible pieces there as well.
Nice. Defintely worth a visit for one of your many return trips to Paris
Specially laid out to display Monet's water lillies. Top floor is all water lillies, 360 degrees, lower level is a very impression collectiion of modern artists

One of the best. How can you resist Monet's Waterlillies? In a city filled with large museums like the Louve l'Orangerie is a gem. In a "bitesize" space it has amazing art. Because it isn't a large museum you can leave feeling satisfied that you saw everything in a decent amount of time. Well worth a visit.

Kingdown of peace in busy Paris, complement of Giverny.. This museum located in Jardin des Tuileries, just next to the Place de la Concarde, is the perfect complement to Monet gardens visit in Giverny. This place holds Monet's Nympheas masterpiece artwork in two dedicated white round vast rooms. The place has been designed as a peace haven (after the horror of WW1) and the objective is over exceeded. Still works nowadays in busy and crowded Paris. If you want to feel out of time, to have a quiet pause in your Paris tour, try and enjoy this zen experience.
A little gem!. Don't miss the museum if you want to see a spectacular 360 degree Monets Water Lillies, plus an impressive collection of famous artists. I wish I had allowed more time here!

great hidden secret of Paris. Go downstairs in this museum and see the original water lilies by Claude Monet. There is very little waiting to get inside and the lighting is perfect forviewing impressionist works, just as the artists would have loved it. It is located on the Concord Square
wonderful. This was my favorite museum. I could have spent hours staring at Monet's water Lilly's.

Simply breathtaking.... I went to catch the Debussy La Musique et Les Arts exhibition at the Musee de l'Orangerie, but unfortunately, I missed the actual musical concerts. However, it was simply breathtaking to see Monet's Nymphéas - the scale of the paintings lends to them an additional air of grandeur, and you feel truly fortunate to enjoy such beauty. I sat in the salle for quite some time, just taking in the paintings, my eyes picking up something new every second.Art aside, this is a lovely, very peaceful space, lots of light and height, so one doesn't feel claustrophobic even when there are lots of people around. Accessible for wheelchair users, which is great, and the facilities are also pretty good. Had a laugh with the security guards over the fact that I had my iPad in my bag - staff are friendly too!This is a do-not-miss if you are in Paris.

Popular museum though you can do a lot better in Paris. L'orangerie holds Monets famous giant paintings of water lilies which is in it self fantastic. If you are a Monet admirer it is a must see and if you are for art in general you will spend your time much better in other arts museums in Paris.In the basement there is a great collection of other impressionist paintings which in my humble opinion is much more interesting.

Not customer oriented.. The water lilies were ok, and just ok. Monet’s best work came earlier in his life. They were big, but size has nothing to do with quality. Don’t bother with the audio device they have at this museum, it is not worth the five Euros they want for it. In addition, they want another five Euros for the audio for the special exhibition. This is a total rip off. Don’t pay for either. There were no printed English instructions or guide available. All other languages were available, just not English. The staff at the desk where they had all other instructions did not apologize for the absence of the English version; they seemed bothered by the fact that we wanted them. They are definitely NOT concerned about English customers or their needs. I observed this both coming into the museum and leaving and different personnel were manning the desk.

Wonderful, peaceful. What else can you say about this remarkable display of Monet's art, along with that of a few others on the second level. Brilliant! Check the schedule though! I think it is closed on Mondays, which is the day we tried to go the first time - of course!

Happy and sad to have gone here. This was my Mona Lisa. The one thing to see. Monet's water lillies in a room designed by the master himself to best show his work. While I could still marvel at his brilliance it didn't really live up to expectations as the panels appear quite faded and the down stairs gallery was overheated to the point of uncomfortable.

Perfect Alternative to Long Lines and Crowded Larger Museums. We tried to go on Monday, but got there towards the end of the day and the line was too long. Tried again on Wednesday, almost no line to speak of in middle of the afternoon.Found this place just perfectly sized and just the right amount of beautiful artwork to take in. It is not just Monet although that is of course the highlight. Downstairs you will find the collection of Guillarme a prolific collector of artwork in the late 1800's/early 1900's. Although his wife got rid of a lot of his collection upon his death, the collection is really a staggering amount of Renoir, Picasso, Matisse, and introduces us to other important lesser known today artists of that time and is really quite remarkable. I highly recommend getting the headphones for the tour of the permanent collection, it really brings this amazing collection to life and gives it context.I would say you can easily see most of the works in a good two hours or so.

use a museum pass and avoid the lines. One of the best galleries to visit in Paris with the wall sized Monet paintings. Get a museum pass to avoid the lines. Located in the Tuilleries gardens. Better than the Louve, and without the crowds.
Precious Museum Gem. We spent a couple of hours meditating on the eight unbelieveable Monet water lily paintings.

Monet heaven. The Water Lillies are worth the price of admission. The Paul Guilliame collection gives a great view into the changing art scene in his time. The scale of this museum is very manageable as were the crowds on a week day.

Serene. I love how Musee de l'Orangerie is a more manageable museum compared to the Louvre (stressful). It's a small, intimate museum with a lovely collection of Impressionist art. Of course, the highlight is Monet's water lilies -- two circular rooms covered inch to inch with the most overwhelmingly beautiful lilies. We loved it! The location of the museum in the Tuileries Gardens is also a plus and it overlooks Place de la Concorde. Plan to see these two famous sights as well when you go. One tip is to buy a double pass for both Orangerie and Musee d'Orsay. You save money and get to experience two great museums! Go to both within four days of when you bought the first ticket.
Musee de l'Orangerie is second only to d'Orsay. Musee de l'Orangerie is much smaller than the d'Orsay but the quality of the works housed there is really hard to beat.

Underrated!. The magnificence of l’Orangerie is so underrated! The two circular rooms with wall-to-wall “Nymphéas” painted by Monet are spectacular! You can sit in the middle of the rooms and just study the paintings. Beyond these rooms, you can study other paintings of Monet, Manet, Renoir – just beautiful!

Visit in partly cloudy weather. The nicest museum in Paris. It is relatively small, with two big oval rooms dedicated to Monet waterlilies, and a few rooms with impressionist paintings. The roof is transparent, and in sunny weather the pictures look really alive. But the best option is to visit this museum when there is sun and clouds, and the light changes and plays on the paintings. Very tranquil and restful place.

Monet rooms are worth the trip. The two oval rooms in which the Monet waterlily canvases have been displayed are breathtaking and worth the price of admission. But get a 1+ day museum pass and see this along with the Musee D'Orsay, and other favorites and you can sometimes avoid the long lines. Many favorites are included in the pass so check it out.
great exhibitions. RecommendedVery good and interesting exhibitions.Situated in an area that is worth visiting.Avoid the crowd!( Preferable not in August)
A jewel box. Wonderful Impressionist art. The Monel water lilies are gorgeous.

You are immersed in Monet's Water Lilies. I didn't expect to be in a peaceful oval room surrounded by Monet's garden of water lilies--which are 4 long panels. Not like the crowded Louvre or d'Orsay. It was like being in a church: the reverence, the calm, the joy. Go downstairs for the regular art gallery, which has some nice Renoirs and notable French painters. The Debussy (temporary) exhibition was really well-done, with English, French and Italian(?) explanations for each stage, no need for the audioguide. You can come in for free on first Sundays of the month. You can also bypass the queue if you have the museum pass, are pregnant, or elderly with a cane. BUT children in strollers don't get you in faster (unlike at d'Orsay!). If you come with young kids, they must be quiet, which may be hard with bouncy, young toddlers.

A must for Monet fans. A nice small museum, the highlight being Monet's huge water lily paintings, but there are plenty of other things to see downstairs. About an hour and a half you can see verything.
So Beautiful!. Finally, it is re-opened! If you haven't been here do not miss it, especially if you are a Monet fan. It is such a beautiful space. Also loved the exhibit in the gallery downstairs.
Art. Smaller exhibition that I expected but good all the same.
A small interesting museum. Very good to avoy the crowds!! Perfectly located to walk by the Tuilleries Garden.
Little jewel. After 5 times to Paris, finally made it to this nice museum. The oval rooms are interesting. The museum building as well.
Beautiful and not too big museum. The oval rooms with Monet's painting where stunning.
If you like impressionist this is the place!. Starting from Monet you can see the best paintings and impressionism atmosphere there. If you are in Paris is one place to visit!
Water lilies. We made a quick trip inside to see the two rooms with Claude Monet's paintings while visiting the gardens. Well worth it!

One of Monet's best work. you can see the lilies in this museum, so that makes it worth it, they are way more impressive than what you expect, besides that I didn't love the collection, but the museum is located in the centre so it's really easy to get there, I recommend going here, besides if you are a student under 26 the entrance is for free
Monet and more. As well as the water lillies there is an extensive gallery of exciting art downstairs. Get an Orange Pass to combine with Musee D'Orsay within 4 days and save queuing.
A gem of a museum. While a small museum, especially compared to the Louvre or d'Orsay, but the Claude Monet works are worth it! If you have an extra hour, put it on your list!
beautiful and calm space to relax. great antidote to the louvre and its craziness. Very calming and beautiful space to view the art.

My favourite museum in Paris for Monet and others. Of course the water lillies are the stars, but don't miss going downstairs to see the other great artists and their works. Their special exhibitions are fantastic.

Overlooked but shouldn't be. Monet's are amazing.. Everyone goes to the Louvre then the D’Orsay. The Musee de l’Orangerie is rarely mentioned. I would go to the other two of course, but if had time would go to l’Orangerie, especially if you like Monet. While there are works from many of the impressionists and post-impressionists the most amazing part is the Monet Collection called Nympheas. It is a collection of 8 huge paintings of waterlillies. They are arranged in two oval rooms with natural, though diffused, lighting from the skylights. These paintings are not just impressive by their size (I’d guess four are 8ft high by 30ft wide and the other four are 8ft high by 15ft wide) but their imagery. I’m not an artist or art historian (or really much of an enthusiast) but was amazed by the display. (If you’re planning on going to the D’Orsay you can get a combination ticket for both museums and save a few Euros)

Must see. We went to Giverny to experience Monet's garden the day before which was amazing. Then going to l'Orangerie and feeling like you were there again was truly incredible. Definitely a must see if you are in Paris.
perfect. Display of Monet water Lilies. Go, and if Orsay too crowded a pleasant less croded substitute.
Impressive!. The works by Impressionist, Salvador Dali....Worth to visit!

Worth going to see Monet's Water Lilies. We visited the Musee de l'Orangerie the day after visiting Monet's house and gardens in Giverny. We went specifically to see Monet's Water Lilies paintings. They were displayed in two large oval shaped rooms, and very stunning. We quickly walked through the rest of the museum, but the highlight were the Monet's.

Exquisite paintings. Spend a few minutes first in the all-white decompression room, to calmly breathe and de-stress, as this will prepare you for your entry into the next room, where you first set eyes on Monet's gorgeous Water Lilies. I was with an impatient 15 y/o with no appreciation or interest in paintings, and even she was blown away by the beauty before her. She found them 'very soothing.' The temporary Debussy exhibit downstairs is also worth a visit.
Monet Waterlilies. If you love Monet this museum is an absolute must - what's nice is that they don't allow everyone and their broth to take pictures. Easy to walk around and laid out nice.

Monet. fantastic in the round experience...water lilies
small and in the Tuileries
Great place to go after the Louvre or Tuileries. Fascinating gallery in a very interesting space in one corner of the Tuileries gardens. They consistenly have top-notch shows.
A cloud of sensation. The huge pictures of Monet's water lilies in the specially designed building are just indescribable - they are so beautiful.

A must see for Monet's fans. A real treasure. The room of Monet's waterlily canvases is just wonderful. You can spend hours just sitting and taking in the beauty of it all. Also enjoy works by Renoir, Picasso, Modigliani and other modern masters. This Musee is not to be missed. The museum is located in the Jardin des Tuileries, a most beautiful walk about. From the Musee de l'Orangerie to the Musee du Louvre you will have a time of your life. People watching, bird watching, and enjoying plantings. You may also enjoy a wonderful lunch in the middle of the Tuileries at La Terrasse De Pomone on your walk about, an outdoor eaterie that offers salads, soups, mains and desserts. Do not miss this experience. This is a memory that I will have for my lifetime.
The Nympheas : a must see. A circular room with the famous Monet paintings all around.

Must love Water Lilies. Monet's Water Lilies -- that is the reason to go. If you love those paintings you will love it. If not, it is not worth the stop given the abundance of other things to see in Paris.
Superb paintings. Well worth a visit - most unsual setting which does the paintings justice.

If you love Monet, this is the second-best museum in Paris. In two, large, sparse, white-walled, oval rooms, Monet's grand Les Nymphéas are the star in this museum. Here you can effortlessly immerse yourself into the several intersecting planes of delightful reality within the tranquil waterlily ponds. It is worth the trip. However, the best place to see Monet is in the private Musée Marmottan-Monet.

Lovely Museum.... I highly recommend the Orangérie, which has an impressive installation of Monet's final "Water Lillies" paintings as well as a nice selection of paintings by other late 19th- and early 20th-century artists. The space is also very nice: the "Water Lillies" in particular are well complemented by their surroundings, and the rest of the galleries also were set up nicely for viewing the collections. I visited on a Friday afternoon in late April, and the museum was not overly crowded. Visiting was a pleasurable experience.The museum also offers additional programming that is advertised on their website and at the museum. I did the "Monet to Picasso" lecture tour (in French, though it is sometimes offered in English) and I found the guide to be very engaging and informative. The lecture was well worth the 6 euro charge.
A Must See for Any Monet Fan. If you like Monet's work then this museum is a "must see." Two circular rooms in the museum house his Water Lily panoramics.
Very unhelpful staff. The museum was well-organised and we wnjoyed the exhibits but did not like the very unfriendly and unhelpful staff. They actually made it very unpleasant.

The best museum in Paris. The Monet water lilies and the Paul Guilliam collection are not to be missed. I love Monet and these were his last works given to the nation and done with the brushes strapped to wrists as he was crippled with arthritis. They fill two oval rooms at the lower lever of the museum.
small & superb. Loved the smaller size and collections at this museum. Just walk through the Jardin des Tuileries and you are there!
Monet's triumph. The clean and tranquil atmosphere so that it seemed like you were in his paintings.

impressionist epics. there is plenty to see here, but it does feel like no matter how much you dwell on the art downstairs the stars of the show are monets flowers, displayed on long curving walls. they are something to behold, but the musee d'orsay holds a far greater appeal generally and is in sight on the other bank of the river.

Monet Heaven. I did not give it excellent because I think if you bought the ticket independently (7.50 euros, plus extra if you want the audioguide) compared to the 10 euros for the Louvre for the permanent collections, you would feel a bit cheated. The museum is small and can be done in less than 2 hours if you are not the type to meditate in the room with the large Nympheas. But, having said that, this is the one to go to in order to pay homage to Monet and his famous Nympheas. They are absolutely breathtaking and if you are an artist you either want to quit or go home and create so more until you get it right.Get the Paris Museum Pass so that you can see the Louvre, the Orsay and many, many other sights and this will be worth it. On a nice day, you stroll through the Tuileries Gardens either to or from the Louvre. After the mass crowds at the Louvre and Orsay, this is a nice quiet time.
Lots of waterlilies. Good stop off out of the rain, but a few too many waterlilies for my liking. The other paintings downstairs were good though.
Just okay. If you're into more late-year impressionist stuff, its worthwhile.

If you are into waterlillies, go visit.... 1. floor is two rooms with Monets waterlillies. Gets boring rather quickly. The basement however, holds a very nice collection. Definately worth a visit. But if you are short of time, Museu d'Orsay should be the first choice.
Monet - who else ?. This is he place to see the HUGE water lilly paintings. Take some time and sit in awe.

Exciting as Always. I never tire of this museum. This time with granchildren who have never before seen such wonderful paintings. Tie the entry to the Musee d'Orsay ticket purchase and avoid the entry charge. The only disappointment was that there was strictly no photos, even without flash. This is a must see museum that has some of the best paintings of Monet etc that you ever see.
Monet!. Huge Monet water lily paintings dominate the main floor. Don't skip the lower levels with special exhibits.

More than I expected--and bigger too. Only got to see the Monet part of this museum as we arrived with only 30 min. left of opening time. But the Water Lilies display was totally worth it--the canvases are much bigger than I imagined and more awe-inspiring in person, especially with the natural light. Discover the 'infinite' connection when you see them in situ.

Exciting Musee de l'Orangerie. If you can squeeze this museum in between visits to the Louvre and D'Orsay, you will be in for a treat. The building was designed to display Monet's large water lily paintings in a setting designed to replicate his water lily pond at his home in Giverny and it's dreamlike and beautiful. The permanent collection also includes works by many other Impressionists, as well as Picasso, Modigliani and others. When we visited there was a wonderful exhibit "Debussy Music and the Arts", which continues through early June.

Lucky to be there during the Debussi exhibit.. If you know about the Barnes' collection in Philadelphia this museum houses the legacy of the dealer that introduced the American to a number of the impressionist that make the bulk of the Barnes'. There is quite a spicy story surrounding this particular collection. It must be read!
Fantastic. Beautiful museum, and a must stop in your way to the Louvre. Monet, Monet, Monet.
Wonderful display of Monet.. Don't miss this one. A small gallery by Paris standards but well worth the visit. Beautifully presented display of Monet and many other artists of similar period.

A magnificent place. For years visiting Paris, we checked every time on the progress toward opening of this museum which had been closed ever since we first visited!And then it was open!!! And now it is a must-go-to every time. If you love Monet (as we do) this place is a dream come true..and it is a wonderful destination in its own right for other artists too and the roman ruins that they discovered ...and which held up the renovations!The Monets and the way they are able to be displayed are breathtaking.Go here! Stand in line if you have to! You will be glad you did.

The Best Museum in Paris. Small, intimate, and modern the Orangerie has the hard-hitting Monet "Waterliles" that you remember from your art history class. The art is well-presented and, therefore, well-appreicated by the much, much, much smaller crowd than that of the Louvre or the Orsay. Use the Museum Pass to skip the line!
Must see Musee. For anyone who loves Monet, it is obligatory to sit and be awed by the surrounding paintings. You see that it is not about waterlilies, it is the light and water that transfixes you.

Breathtaking. After spending much of the morning in the park, we drifted in (with our Paris Museum Passes!) to this gem of a museum. It is small, but it is right at the top of my favorite museums in Paris. The lighting and conditions are kept ideal for the artwork and it was not packed in with people when we went. Just seeing the immensity of the Water Lillies paintings and the way they have chosen to display them - Lovely.
Dreaming Monet´s way. Feel inmerse in Monet´s dreams. Enter this museum and sit for a while to experience the paysages this Master Painter created. Leave with your spirit enrichened!
wow. You just have to sit on the seats to understand what Monet was trying to convey about light. The person at the desk was typical French would it hurt to smile and be nice to the tourist?
Put this on your list of must do's. The Water Lillies in the round are like visiting Monet's garden in Giverny. Small museum, but a definite must.

Musee de l'Orangerie. Monet's massive paintings of lilies are awe inspiring as are the collection of other paintings like Woman with Velvet Ribbon by Amedeo Modigliani. Less crowded than the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay.
Short but sweet. Very small but stunning Monet pieces...go on the way to Louvre.

Fabulous museum. I have wanted to visit this museum to see Monet's Waterlillies for years, the last time I was in Paris the museum was closed for renovation. It lived up to my expectations, the paintings are just beautiful, go early to avoid the crowds.

Amazing Monet murals. This is a very small museum, so maybe to you that's good or bad. Good because you can easily add it to your trip. Still a good value despite the size since the artists in this museum are well known and it is exciting to see their works first hand. My teenager recognized a lot of them just from her history/Humanities classes. .

one of the best museums in Paris. The big draw here is the Monet water lilies panels - they are shone beautifully, in rooms with lots of light and lots of center seating to take it all in if you wish. Their collection is very impressive - and we were particularly taken with their special exhibit on Debussy and the artists that influenced his music. Quite imaginative and well-done. Of course, you must go to the Louvre, but make this the second museum on your visit.

Seeing Monet on a grand scale. Great museum, line wasn't too long. There aren't rooms and rooms of exhibits. The emphasis in is on Monet's huge paintings of the lilys in his home in Giverny. Even our teenager found it beautiful.
nice. a smaller scale museum great for our 8 year old. Enjoyed the special exhibit. Nice to have a smaller museum that you can take an hour to go see and not 1/2 a day...

elegantly presented small museum. This small museum was a high point on a Paris trip in April. It's "modern" in an old building near Concorde. The downstairs exhibit of Debussy-connected painting was elegant and thoughtful; and the extensive 2-room exhibit of Monet's water lilies was exotic and puzzling. We took close to 2 hrs examining and enjoying it and found it a pleasant change from the train-station atmosphere of much of the Louvre.

J'aime bien Nymphea!. For fans of Monet, this is an absolute do-not-miss. The two large oval rooms containing Monet's large Water Lillies (Nymphea) canvases. One is completely enveloped by these works; it is astonishing. There are other wonderful pieces in this small museum as well.
jewel in the crown. don't leave Paris without seeing this, prepare to be transported to Giverney

A Must for any Monet Fan. If you enjoy the paintings of Monet or other impressionist painters, you MUST go here. You don't realize how big the "Water Lily" paintings are until you see them in person. (They're as big as the entire room). The "Water Lilies" alone are worth the price of admission and seeing some other impressionist art is just an added bonus.

Pleasant and manageable. Good variety of French artists and the Monets are amazing. Easy to get round. Buy the 14 euro four day ticket to go here and Musee D'Orsay and save money and beat the queues thereafter.

The Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet and that's that.. Take your time to marvel at the Water Lilies by Claude Monet. They are superb and their presentation in the two elliptical rooms is top notch. Other than that (and the excellent little shop) the museum offers quite a lot but much less interesting works.

Lovely small museum. This museum was a breath of fresh air. Compared to the Louvre and the Orsay, it was much easier to view the art. The crowds at the two others were overwhelming. The works are interesting and Monet's water lily works were stunning. An absolutely lovely small museum.

Rare opportunity to see Monet's Water Lilies. We loved the floor-to-ceiling Monet paintings, all wrapped around us! This is the only place were one can see these magnificent paintings that are permanently installed into the walls of Musee de l'Orangerie. One can also enjoy paintings from many other artists.
Good. You are really going here for 2 rooms, but it is worth it. We used the museum pass and it turned out to be a good deal.
Small and compact museum. Much smaller and more compact than the Louvre, especially if you like pictures of water lillies.

Like no other. Probably the worlds greatest museum it lived up to the reputation. I won't go into descriptions of the works , they speak for themselves. Only regret was not having more time, one could spend days there. Fantastic ...the French outdid themselves here.
if you like Monet. If you like Monet, especially WATER LILLIES, then you must go to Musee de l'Orangerie. Near the Louvre and the Seine. Another got to do it if you are in Paris.
slightly disapppointing. not as much there as expected. wouldnt go back. quite small and you have to be silent the whole time
A wonderful exhibit that is just right. The Monet lilies and the private collection of impressionists is just right and not overwhelming. A bit of a line up but nothing extraordinary.
small and interesting. monet's nimpheas deserve more than "jeter a coup d'oeil"!!!
wow. an enchanting space where one may go to have a moment out of the crowd and have a meditation while watching the enchanting Nimpheas in a unique setting

Favorite museum in Paris. This is a wonderful "small" museum with a fantastic impressionist collection as well as the famed waterlillies. The museum is great for kids as it is not overwhelming like the Louvre. I loved the art and found the experience there fantastic. Highly recommended.

Small, fast, and fun!. This museum is worth an hour of your time...Paris Museum Pass = no line! The building is beautiful and historic, and the collection is stunning...small, but beautiful! The displays of Monet's paintings are beautifully designed to highlight with natural light and the additional artworks are interesting and well laid-out.
Big Monets. Large scale Monets - exceptional to view. Small museum - excellent to do in conjunction with Musee d'Orsay

Nice work of Monet. Beutiful art works, however; we were with our 22 m old and the don't allow strollers inside the museum - it is kind of small. The ambience is "quiet', more serious - different of the Louvre and D'Orsay for example, so my husband and I had to take turns to walk through the museums because of our child. Not child friendle, but gret!
Nice quiet museum with wonderful paintings. The quiet solitude of the Monet Water Lily paintings is just what you need after a busy day sightseeing in Paris!

Wonderful. I don't know how we got here, but the rooms with the Monet murals cannot be missed! No other museum had anything like it. On top of that, there were paintings of all the wonderful impressionists that you would see in other museums, but l'Orangerie was smaller and much less crowded.

A must-see for lovers of French Impressionism. This museum is like few others in the world, dedicated to impressionist art, and the showcase for Monet's water lily paintings, his gift to the French people. Other beautiful and distinguished works are also displayed in other areas of the museum, but the Monet galleries are breathtaking. Give yourself enough time to sit and enjoy them. No time to visit, or want a preview? Use the virtual gallery on the Orangerie website: http://www.musee-orangerie.fr/homes/home_id24799_u1l2.htm

Simply beautiful. I have been to Paris almost a dozen times and have visited all the major museums many times. I have been meaning to see the L'Orangerie but honestly did not know much about it. One day in the afternoon my husband and I decided to go in. No crowd, nor a long line. The museum is just beautiful. The Monet rooms are stunning, you can just sit on the bench and stare for hours. The walls were filled with beautiful works by Matisse, Picasso, Derain, Modigliani, Renoir and Soutine. Yes, there are other places in Paris with amazing works of art but this one really got to me. It was simple, easy and beautiful. Do not miss it.

Do not miss..... Just a short stroll over the bridge from our hotel, Bourgogne and Montana, this small gallery/ museum is beautifully set out - Tranquil and relaxing in a fascinating building just by La place de la Concorde and on the edge of the Tivoli gradens

A place for lovers of Impressionism. For a number of years I'd been meaning to go to the Orangerie Musée at the Place de la Concorde end of the Jardin du Tuileries. I’d heard about their Impressionists collection it was pretty amazing. There are two oval shaped rooms on the ground floor where the entire walls are Monet paintings, mostly his garden scenes. It was overwhelming. Downstairs is devoted to Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Rousseau, Matisse, Derain, Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo and Laurencin. This is a very accessible and quite contained little gallery which should please lovers of gentle, soothing art.
SUCH BEAUTY. This was our favorite museum that we visited in Paris. If you go to the d'Orsay, buy the paired ticket with the l'Orangerie. Put aside two hours and soak it all in. The audio is helpful.
Amazing museum.. Monet's paintings were fabulous. Lots of Renoir's and other greats as well.
Monet. Wow. A simply display of Monet's largest paintings - 4 per room, 2 rooms, then leading on a lower floor to a more traditional gallery and museum. Worth seeing this!

It's a must while in Paris. It's one of my favorites in Paris. I've visit there a few times and keep coming back each time I visit Paris. The reason is the 2 oval rooms with Monet's nymphaeas.I could seat and watch it for a very long time and it's always a great pleasure.If you love Monet's creations you should absolutely visit here and also visit the Marmotan museum which is dedicated to his creations. Having said that - if you don't have enough time to travel & visit the Marmotan don't miss this charming small museum - the nympheaes are ravishing!
Disappointment. Except for the painting by Monet I would not recommend spending much time here.

Impressive small museum. Monet's waterlilies paintings are beautifully displayed. It's like a shrine. Fascinating exhibit on Debussy and his relationship to French art. Only problem for this small museum is no cafeteria.
my fave place. visited Giverny the prior day so this was icing on the cake to see la Nymphees and the other impressionist paintings.

Very nice.. This is a very nice place to visit if you like Monet and impressionist art. It makes a very nice combination with Musee d'Orsay. I recommend getting the passport ticket which includes both. Come here first and then you can skip the longer lines at Musee d'Orsay. I would also highly recommend trying to catch a showing of the documentary Le dessein des Nymphéas (with English subtitles) which captures Monet's vision and work behind the Water Lilies.

monet and soutine. Wonderful small museum, famous for the Monet panels and they alone are well worth the visit, but the collection of Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume is also excellent - I especially enjoyed the works by Soutine; the entire thing can be savored in under 2 hours, followed by a relaxing walk through the Tuileries. The temporary installation on the influence of art on Debussy was excellent too. We were glad we had the Museum Card to skip the line.
wow. I could have sat and looked at Monet's waterlilies all day long!
Superb Monet. A tribute to Monet, both artistically and personally, with much else to see. Totally absorbing.

Small but excellent. This is a small museum with an excellent collection overall. Of particular note are the Monet rooms, where we spent over an hour just sitting and taking it in.I wish the "white room" was shut off from the outside and the inner rooms and had chairs in it; I think 5 minutes in this room would more likely have the effect Monet had hoped for (you'll see when you get there). No lingerie here (just a little joke, the first time I heard of it was verbal and I imagined a lingerie museum).

You can't miss it!. Even if you're not a museum lover, you musto go to L'Orangerie and see "Les Nympheas" de Claude Monet, it will take less than an hour but you will remind for the rest of your life how beautiful and impressive they are.

one of the best art musems in paris. who didn't hear about Monet Water Lilies? well here you can visit them in their full splendor. also there are a lot of other things to see, a cinema, a shop to take something with you from this beautiful place.

Monet's Waterlilies. A peaceful and beautiful , light -filled respite from all the other museums. It used to be Napoleon's "juice house" so he could get fresh -squeezed OJ from the orange grove but what a lovely building it is now. One of my absolute favorites. If time permits, go to Giverny to Monet's home to see the inspiration of his paintings which makes his works of art so much more meaningful.
Outstanding Monet panels. There are two rooms designed for very large panels of Monet's water liliy paintings painted at different times of the day and year. Beautiful!!

"Paris Visite" Pass beats the queue. Too much to see in a 3-day visit to Paris, but of course we jostled with crowds in Room No.6 to see the Mona Lisa. Impressive glass pyramid covering the underground visitor centre.
Monet's Water Lillys. Two rooms filled with Monet's famous Water Lilys surrounding you. Magical.

Breath Taking Monet Water Lilies. This museum is a short walk from the Louvre, after going through the gardens. You are able to sit and experience HUGE Monet paintings, that take up the entire wall. There are two rooms with natural light. It is awesome. There are Renoir's and other French painters as well. Covered by the Museum Pass.
Lovely museum. A nice smallish museum (Get the Museum pass to avoid lines)
My favorite paintings!. A whole room full of Monet's water lillies in a wrap around display. The colors of the paintings change with the light of the day.
Nypheas are the draw. The rest of the museum is excellent as well, impressionists and up thru late 20th century. Picassos were awesome.
We loved the Waterlillies. We didn't care for the other paintings but the rooms with Monet's Waterlilies were spectacular. The park around the museum is lovey too.
well worth it !!. the most amazing and beautiful place to house Monet's Waterlilies exhibit. This is a great place to see after a trip to Giverny which connects the inspiration with the art .

Nice museum but you need to appreciate art!. Had we had to have paid the entrance fee I think we would have felt like the money wasn't worth it but thanks to the great under 26 free entry ticket, it was nice to see the Monet paintings but I think you need to have quite an interest in art to appreciate this museum to its fullest. Also a shame that they don't allow you to take photos at all, most places just ask you to refrain from using flash which I can understand.
Nice break. Lovely extension to the Orsay. One of the few museums that is relaxing. I guess that was Monet's intent. He did it well.

Nice refreshing walk!. L'Orangerie is a special place, where one can enjoy the peace and tranquility of a walk on the alleys between orange trees, after a day rushing from one museum to another! Great view and big slice of past French life. A must see!
Good smaller museum with famous art.. Not as good at D'orsay but worthwhile visit in a beautiful location (Tuleries). Mainly impressionist art with Monet's water lillies.
This museum is a gem!. Visited Paris during the crowded Easter week. Loved getting away from the crowds a bit (especially with the museum pass) at L'orangerie.
Monet in the round. Wonderful way to experience Monet's work. The light enhances the paintings and there is usually another special exhibit or two to give even more pleasure to the visit.
Much more than Monet.. Enjoyed the Waterlilies but there were also Picassos and other great paintings too.
April in Paris. This is a hidden gem in Paris, opposite the Louvre on the Garden walkway. It is a small but lovely museum. Not to be missed.

A place to unwind. As Monet designed, it is a great experience and fantastic place to unwind from the busy Parisian holiday, the ques move fast enough and once you are inside the oval rooms the experience is incredible.
Monets water lilies. The museum was closed first time I went to Paris was thrilled to be able to see the room where money's water lilies surrounded us.
Beautiful. Lovely musuem, not too big, seeing the water lilies was lovely and they are soooooooo huge!
Intimate and serene. The water lillies are great but also the picassos and cezannes. Decompressed. Loved it
Only one word: Monet!. Small museum, you can see it in an hour at a slow pace - and Monet's Nymphéas are among the most beautiful works of art you can see in Paris!
Not just Monet's Giant Water Lilies, but. When the light changes (from the skylight above) as you are looking at the water lilies, you will gasp. Stunning.
MUST VISIT. Excellent museum of Monet's famous water lillies, this museum is by far my favorite in Paris because of its intimate settings and escape into the world of the Impressionists.
Immersed in water lilies. Looking at a single Monet in a museum is nothing compared to the experience of Monet's creation here. water lilies on every wall, in natural light.
A museum where you could breathe!. We enjoyed the art and also the fact that this was a small musuem not totally overrun with rude tourists.
If you LOVE Monet.... ...This is a must see! It was one of my fave sights in Paris.
Spectacular little gem. Small museum but wonderful collection, beautifully housed, the Monet's are unmissable
Lovely Monets. 8 huge and beautiful Monets plus a collection of other impressionist art
Monet at his best!. If you are into Monet this is the gallery for you. His 'Lillies' paintings are huge!

Monet Water Lillies - plus the Collection of Jean Walter et Paul Guillaum and special exhibits. Amazing and very large water lilly paintings by Monet.
plus downstairs has modern art masterpieces from the Guillaume Collection, featuring Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Rousseau, Matisse, Derain, Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo and Laurencin. Also often has very interesting special exhibits.

Small but perfectly formed. Loved this gallery not too big and overwhelming like the other big ones. I really liked the oval room with the beautiful Monets but my favourite bit was the permanent exhibit with it's range of superb impressionist paintings. I will definitely return here as it was quiet and you could actually stand back to admire the paintings - no crowds on the day I went. I loved this place and only wish that I had gone sooner - I had been meaning to for years! Well worth the money
What a surprise! Wonderful!. This museum was a true surprise. What an incredible collection of impressionist art. I highly recommend a visit.
great place for temporary exhibitions. Looks great, exhibitions are first class, location is superb ...

Must See. Don't visit Paris museums without going to the Musee de l'Orangerie. There is absolutely nothing like standing in front of Monet's murals. The museum is small, with the focus on pretty paintings.
Loved this museum. This is a great alternative to the larger museums. The art is wonderful and in a managable space. My 18 year old daughter and really enjoyed this museum.
A Favorite. This relatively small museum on the corner of the Tuilerie Gardens, that also run up to the Louvre at the opposite end, was a very nice visit. Warning -- closed on Tuesdays.
Monet's water lillies. The two rooms of Monet water Lilly paintings were absolutely beautiful

Small, but perfect. We fitted in Musee de l'Orangerie after the Louvre on a free Sunday (1st Sunday of the month) Just the right size for an afternoon wander. The Monet panels are well displayed and everyone was happy to view them in silence and engage in a little personal reflection.Downstairs, in addition to the permanent Collection of Jean Walter & Paul Guillaume, was a temporary exposition, 'Debussy, la musique et les arts', running until 11th June 2012 - well executed and interesting.It's a bite-sized gallery, easily digested and not at all overwhelming.
Waterlillies Galore. Monet's giant waterlillies. You have to see how big these paintings are.

Lovely!. I don't know why I've been to Paris four times before & have never been to this museum. Unlike the "must-see" Louvre, it's completely do-able, and every room possesses pieces of beauty & value. Additionally, Monet's Water Lilies (8 of them?) are on display in enormous rooms of their own (which, if I'm not mistaken, he designed specifically for them?), & they are lovely. Even if you aren't specifically a Monet fan or if you've "seen them", I still really recommend going! I wouldn't go to Paris again & not visit this museum.
Unexpected delight. Loved this museum--of course the Monets that are showcased here are fabulous, but I also loved the surprise of seeing gorgeous Renoirs in this charming museum.
Great smaller museum. This is much 'less-travelled' museum at the far end of the Tulleries. Lots of work by big name artists and less of the fluffy stuff. Gotta see it to believe it.

Monet's Water Lilies are the Show. It is amazing to see Monet's water lilies in a room he designed just for that purpose. The museum is across the river from D'Orsey and although the rest of museum was interesting it was a long day of art after touring D'Orsey.

More here than meets the eye.. WE first saw the Monet murals in the movie Midnight in Paris. What we did not know is that in addition to these stunningly large pieces, there is a basement full of Renoirs, Picassos, etc. Great day!
Think you've seen Monet?. You haven't seen Monet until you've visited the l'Orangerie. It will blow you away! We visit here every time we come to Paris.
near louve. go only if have paris museum pass, near lourve, interesting gems on view,

Worth a quick trip if nearby or a Monet lover. Our only interests were Monet's water lillies in the round, and they, by themselves, were worth the walk. They are massive and interesting.The museum is in the most southwest building of the Tuileries Gardens, with the entrance facing the Place de la Concorde. It's not hard to find. Get there more than 30 minutes before closing time. They won't let you in, otherwise.

Brilliant late Monets and lots more!. At the Place de Concorde end of the Tuileries is this excellent recently refurbished museum. On the ground floor are the astonishing Nympheas (water lily) paintings done by Monet at Giverney in two large oval rooms. Wonderful light and when we were there a Debussy soundtrack was played as downstairs was a temporary exhibition about Debussy. Also downstairs is a fantastic collection of Renoir, Degas, Rousseau and Picasso paintings in a much quieter space than the Musee Orsay...well worth a visit. No cafe surprisingly.
beautiful paintings. A very good collection of painting from the last part of 1800 to the first part of 1900.Perfectly sized museum - not too big
Monet Delight. Cant miss those Water Lilies., and the special exhibitions here are worth seeing.
Great museum!. This is a great smaller art museum with some amazing pieces! It is not overwhelming, it was not super crowded and it was beautiful!

MONET. I had been to Paris twice before, and not seen the 'water lilies' in person. that's pretty lame for a person who claims a great love for the works of Monet. In fact the building had been closed for both my prior trips, and my exposure to my favorite artist work had been limited to the Orsay, and a few private collections.The effect of these grand works of Monet, to me are overwhelming. I can look at them for any long period of time. Their beauty is beyond me, and thinking about them, the effort, the madness, and love it took to create them.. it brings tears to my eyes. by far the most amazing works of art I have ever seen.

Monet!. The Monet murals are truly inspiring. Go and sit for a while. You will not be disappointed. Then walk across the Seine to the Musse d'Orsay and see the smaller versions of the Water Lilies. You'll be so glad to have seen both.
The place for Impressionism. If you like impressionism (Monet, Renoir,etc), this is the place for you. You could sit there all day and admire the genius. Very impressive and a definite must.

Gem of a museum in a city with so much choice. We went to Musee de l'Orangerie on the basis of reviews on trip advisor & were very glad we did. There were no queues and the entrance price was very reasonable. It's a smaller alternative to Musee d'Orsay where you can still get pleasure of great art. I've been to quite a few museums in Paris & found Musee de l'Orangerie to be a very pleasant experience indeed. Would highly recommend it!

All about Monet. Loved the tranquility of the Monet rooms. Lots of classics. Lovely mix of art and artists who are connected to each other....and even better you can pre purchase tickets from the tobacco store at the Louvre and save yourself waiting in line.
Nice smaller museum. Go there after seeing Louvre and d'Orsay, much smaller scale but the art work are very interesting and must see The Water Lilies.
Great Museum. Monet's Water Lillies are not to be missed. Don't miss this museum!

Hard to Find, but GIANT Monets. If you are into Monet, make sure to visit the Orangerie. I visited with a Parisian and it still took us 2 hours to find the museum in the first place. We asked numerous other Parisians and no one seemed to have a clue where the museum was located, so I would actually advise having GPS on your phone. The Monets here were HUGE and inspiring, but there was not much else to see. If anything, plan on time to wander the jardins and take in the Parisian life instead of searching for this tiny museum.
We really enjoyed our visit.. My husband and I really enjoyed our visit to the l'Orangerie Musee. They have a large exhibit and it is very beautiful.

Monet Fans-this is the place!. With the museum pass we visited here twice during our trip to Paris. The entire walled rooms of Monet's water lily canvases is simply outstanding. Not nearly as crowded as the other museums in Paris, but also much smaller.

Monet waterlillies. There are four painings of Monet's water lillies. The painter painted all four at different times of the day. They are displayed in an oval room with classical music playing. View each one from a distance and enjoy the changes reflected by the change of day and the colors on the water.
lovely gallery. we had a paris pass so didn't have to queue. Monet lillies was amazing

Best museum. After a visit in the louvre, which is very loaded with different exhibitions, the l'Orangerie is a wonderful break. The 2 halls with monet are outstanding. You sit watch the paintings and feel the experience the artist had when he drew them. This is my favorite in Paris.
Worth a stop. Loved seeing Les Nympheas as they were meant to be displayed- simpy stunning.

Pack a picnic lunch for after your visit. Monet's Waterlilies is a must see room. The lower levels have an incredible collection of masterpieces. Must easier to see them here than to navigate through the Louvre. After visiting the musee, use the toilets and then enjoy the gardens outside. Sit on a bench and enjoy a picnic lunch before heading over to the Louvre.
Wonderful!!. Excellent little museum with a wonderful (mostly) impressionist collection. Not NEARLY as crowded as the other museums and sights so far more enjoyable.

Maybe I don't get it. This art gallery was fine, just nothing spectacular. The lady we spoke to prior to entering the "musee" told us she had cried it was so wonderful. Maybe I just don't appreciate fine art. You will find Monet's masterpiece (huge paintings of water lilies that surround you in a circular room) there and many others of this same genre. Sadly, for me....most of these of these pieces were "I could see where he was coming from" at best and "did a 4 year old draw that" at worst. I honestly don't believe that many of the famous paintings we think of today are famous because they are beautiful....but rather because of the story that goes along with them. I perhaps viewed 5 painting in this museum that had me impressed.

Favorite Museum in Paris. With the museum pass, we visited a large number of museums during our stay in Paris, and Musee de l'Orangerie was by far my favorite. Less crowded than the majority of other museums, l'Orangerie allowed us to truly enjoy the museum's extensive collection of Renoir, Monet, and other renowned artists of the impressionist era. Two rooms, designed by Monet himself, are completely devoted to some of Monet's most well known paintings, his water lilies.
Spectacular-a must see. The museum is manageable in size, and designed specifically to display Monet's massive waterlillies. Downstairs are other impressionist works-don't miss it.
Amazing!. Do not miss this when you visit Paris. The museum is small but definitely worth the stop.

Love, love, loved it!. Monet's waterlilies at their very best! I would return to Paris just to see these works again. However, the remainder of the work in this gallery was worth a visit, even if you don't like Monet's work. Its a fairly small gallery in comparison to the Louvre or D'Orsay but that just makes it a more intimate experience.

For Impressionist Paintings fans!. It's a small musuem, nice and clean. If you like impressionist paintings you will love this place! Plus, they have Monet's Water Lily painting which we adored. If you love Monet's paintings this is a place to see!
Worht a visit. We had done the Musee D'Orsay on previous visits so this was a nice alternative
Waterlillies!!. I was spellbound by the splendor of these immense pieces. Sat for an hour drinking them in, and could have spent even more time there. So peaceful.
Amazing!. Monet is my favourite artist and to see his water lillies up close was amazing, truly beautiful.
Monet exhibit. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a small museum and doesn't take long to visit. We enjoyed the Monet exhibit.
A great Art Experience. A delighful airy museum with a good cinema for special interest items. The art collection is well displayed and easy to walk round. Monet's work "Water Lillies" is amazing

Monet's Water Lilies. The title says it all. If you are interested in Monet, impressionism, or just grand art, Monet's Water Lilies are a must see. Go for the Monet's, but don't miss the rest of the art, including Cézanne, Renoir, and Picasso.
Serenity Among the Waterlilies. Beautiful display of Monet's waterlilies in large oval galleries. Additional impressionist works by Renoir, Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso
Impresive Monet. When I arrived to the museum I was in shock because of the size of Monet paintings!!! Arrive early so you can See the paintings without nobody crossing your way

A treat for Monet devotees. Musée de l'Orangerie never seems as crowded as the larger, more well-known art museums in Paris, but it houses many delights and is the perfect experience for the art-lover and uninitiated alike. The collection is not large, but the quality of works by well-known artists such as Renoir and Degas is high, and the best treat of all are the two large circular rooms which house Monet's incredible 'Nymphéas' (waterlilies) paintings. Completed in his later years, specifically for this space, the paintings are large semi-abstract interpretations of Monet's water-lily pond at Giverny (a highly-recommended day trip from Paris) The paintings surround you, and it's a wonderfully calming experience to spend some time on the comfortable chairs in the centre of the room, breathing in the sense of peace and harmony with nature that Monet has lovingly created. Visit Giverny first if you can, where you will see photos of the paintings at different stages of execution. ( If your thirst for Monet's work remains unquenched, and you've already been to the top floor of the Musée d'Orsay, you could also try the Musée Marmottan.)
Another brilliant venue for Impressionism!. A smaller museum but held some beautiful works among which were the exquisite Monets!
Monet Heaven. This was a nice way to spend the afternoon looking at a fabulous collection on Monet paintings in a modern and serene setting

Relaxing retreat in a museum. After braving the crowds at the Lourve and some other museums, it was such a pleasure to enter the l'Orangerie. Uncrowded, peaceful and soothing with the unbelievable Monet murals and lots of comfy seats from which to appreciate them. The museum is small enough to fit in before or after your trip to Angelina's (very close) and our entire group decided that it was one of the best in Paris.

I must for Impressionistic lovers.. This peaceful, smaller museum contains some of the beautiful Impressionistic works, including several Monet waterlilies. The ticket can be purchased in combination with other museums (The Louvre which it is a part of, and also Musee D'Orsay). This is a good option, if looking to see both and save a couple bucks.

brilliant smaller gallery close to the louvre. really lovely gallery in the tuillerie garden close to the louvre. although much smaller i found it charming for its smaller size than it's more famous neighbour. a must see

Not Worth Going Too Far Out of Your Way to Visit. If you are visiting the Musee d'Orsay, a quick trip across the pedestrian bridge over the Seine will get you to l'Orangerie. I wasn't impressed with the two huge rooms devoted to Monet's water lilllies, but others seemed to be enthralled. The art in the basement is better--some of it quite interesting. Figure about an hour to tour the whole thing.
A wonderful art gallery. The current show about Debussey and his artist friends was great and not too crowded

My new favorite museum in Paris. Musee Rodin used to be my favorite museum in Paris, because of their large collection of impressionist work (my favorite!)Well, it has been moved over in favor of L'Orangerie. On the top floor of this gorgeous museum are 2 oval room with natural lighting that display huge canvasses of Monet's water lilies. It is amazing. I could have sat in those rooms all afternoon - if I lived in Paris, this would be my happy place. Downstairs, there was a very impressive private collection of Impressionist work - it almost rivaled the Rodin. I enjoyed it even more because it is a very manageable size, and I didn't get that feeling after a while that everything was starting to look the same.Love Love Love. It is located in the Tuileries.
Peaceful. I found the l'Orangerie a peaceful museum experience (in contrast to the Louvre!). The room full of waterlilies where you begin sets the pace for a relaxing adventure.

We love Monet!!!. Anyone who love's Monet's water lillies, this is a must go and see. I was in "AWE" when I first walked into the large water lilly room. The natural lighting in the room gave the very large paintings such a beautiful look to the them. Magnificent!!! I probably could have spent most of the afternoon just looking at them. It's an amazing story about the paintings. Took 12 years, over 80 years old with cataracts!!! While we were waiting in line for tickets, there was a security issue. We all had to evacuate. We waited for about 15 minutes outside in the cold. It was a mess getting back in but when I got to the ticket line it was a breeze. I recommend buying the pass that includes the D'Orsay only 14 Eu pp.
If you love Monet this is a must. Unbelievable!!! You will be taken back for sure. One tip, read the brochure prior to entering - this way you know about the white room.

Read about Monet's nympheas then go. a treat,I visited the musee de l'Orangerie with an an artist painter friend, so I had the oppurtunity to feel the paintings as I should and to compare and scrutinize the evolution of his style.

Monet's water lilies are the highlight here. This museum houses Monet's famous waterlily paintings in a beautiful setting. It is worth it to see these alone! The light in the setting is fabulous. In addition, we enjoyed the permanent collection housed downstairs. This isn't a huge museum, like the Louvre, but there is a lot to enjoy here. There is less bustle here, it is a nice place to just immerse yourself in the art. There were lineups outside that looked rather long, but we got in within 20 minutes.
so many paintings. Fascinating paintings and the hand held audio equipment made them more interesting

Wonderful setting that Monet chose himself!. It is a rare treat to visit a museum that an artist chose for his/her works, and that is what you get at the Musee de l'Orangerie. Monet chose this museum to showcase his Water Lilies paintings, and the setting is perfect for viewing these masterpieces. He designed an entrance room of all white, a means of cleansing one's visual palette before taking in the paintings. Brilliant! Although Monet is the featured artist, this museum includes the works of many other impressionist artists and offers an unhurried pace and space from which to view them.

love the waterlillies. Love the setting of how the water lilly paintings of Monet's are presented in this museum. They are presented in the "round" and have there are four panels in each room, the natural light streams in from above and showcases these beautiful paintings. I like to just sit on the benches and take in the 360 view. There are other paintings down on the first floor, which I have gone to see both times I have visitied this museum, but the largest draw is Monet's water lillies.

Beautiful. Some of Monet's les nympheas which are beautifully housed in the orangerie. I loved the silence of the place which along with the beautiful paintings created an atmosphere of calm. If you want a peaceful respite for an hour this is the place to go.

hhhhmmmmm!. I was very excited to see the Water Lillies, but if I'm honest I was slightly disappointed.
