They weren't quite what I was expecting but atleast I can say I've seen them.One of the most annoying parts was the museum lady ssshhhh'ing people loudly. Apparently you can't make noise whilst looking at art!!The rest of the museum was excellent and I fully recommend the audio tour. For 5euro it give you the story behind the art. Well worth it.I recommend the Paris tourist pass that means that you jump ques. Only fills half a day but good if the weather is not so great
Wonderful Museum. Have tried to see this museum on 4 previous trips. As is common in Paris, it was always closed for rennovation. It was well worth the wait!

Moved to Tears. One of the most magical moments of our Paris trip. It was like stepping into a Monet painting. Something about the hushed quiet, the lighting,and the vast beauty of those paintings ... took my breath away. We went early so the Monet rooms were nearly empty and we got the combo ticket for the D'Orsay also, which allowed us to then go over to that museum and bypass the ticket line.

Blissed out and almost abstract. Paris is full of art. The Louvre alone deserves a week of visits everyday. To see art in a short visit Paris can be overwhelming. I have seen the Louvre a few times before so decided, for a single hit of tranquility, to see Monet's lilie pool paintings at L'orangerie. Some of them are almost abstract. There are 2 devoted rooms each with only four large paintings one on each wall. These are paintings to sit and feel and be in. The Monet's are worth visiting in their own right. Downstairs there is a good but small permanent collection of the usual impressionist and early modernist masters and usually a temporary curated themed exhibition. It has one of the best Renoir collections.If have already seen the Louvre and you do not feel like a big full-on day in a large gallery/museum L'Orangerie is a very satisfying an uplifting option. You can also walk along the river or across the park from The Louvre to get there.

Orangerie. Definitely worth a visit. There are two terrific rooms that contain large panaramas of Monet's waterlilies, and the musuem has many other significant pieces. The musuem is small and manageable- a nice change from the Louvre!
OK. Not much in the Orangerie but it was nice enough. We were rushing round though and probably didn't appreciate what was in there.

Monet Rooms are breathtaking. The amazing Water Lilly Rooms are so very special and after drinking that in there are other wonderful art works to see, plus the location in the Tuillerie Gardens is so lovely, be sure to sit by the fountain outside and watch the passing parade
Loved the Monets. This is a must see if you like Monet. Two oval rooms covered with water lilies. Fabulous!

excellent permanent collection and interesting exhibitions. The permanent collection has an amazing number of Renoirs, Cezannes, Picsssos, and Soutines tucked away in the new galleries. And of course the famous Monet 'water lilies' which is all that many visitors go to see.We went to see the Debussy exhibition (which was excellent) but couldn't resist a look at the rest of the gallery.

An Absolute Must if you go to Paris!. On a whim on our last day after seeing the eiffel, arc de triomphe, shopping, eating, Louvre, catacombs... etc, We decided to go to this smaller museum and I am so glad I did. The water lily exhibit took our breath away. Words can not describe how wonderful this museum is!
Small but perfectly formed. The exhibits are superb - there was an exhibition on of wich we were unaware so glad we arrived at 10.00 a.m. there was a queue when we left a couleo f hours later.

Happy to visit after the extended renovations. During several years of working in Paris, I always wanted to visit, but was unable to, due to its closure for renovations. On a recent trip with my wife, we were pleased to find the museum finally open.The collection is small, but charming and easily accessible. The Monets are quite wonderful in two special viewing rooms. There was a special temporary exhibition related to Debussy, but I found the proposed connection between the visual art and the music to be tenuous for the majority of what was presented.If you're on the hunt for more Monets, make sure to consider the Musee Marmottan Monet in the 16th. Michel Monet bequeathed quite a few of his father's large format water lily paintings to that museum and they're breathtaking in a specially designed room.

Excellent small collection of paintings. An excellent but small collection of paintings from 19th-20th century artists, including of course, Monet's water lilies which is given its own room. Visit this along with the Orsay museum and marvel at the painted legacies of France.
A don't miss. Art collection was amazing. The size makes it very navigable

Go for the waterlilies, but there is a lot more.. The two rooms with Monet's waterlilies are wonderful, but there is a fine collection of Impressionist paintings downstairs. When we were there, there was also a wonderful temporary exhibition of paintings illustrating aspects of the music of Debussy. A fine museum!

Monet and his waterlillies. We always stop here for a few hours. Plus the balance of the collection is worth the time.. Easy to access, doesn't seem to have the big crowds as at the Louvre or the D'Orsay.

Monet!. The rooms of panels are breathtaking. Go and pick your favorites. Sit and absorb their beauty.The other desplays of art are worth viewing, too, but the Monet rooms are the reason to go.Finding the entrance to the building was a little tricky, but it was worth it. There will usually be others to follow!
quiant. located on the far end of the Tuiliers, it is nice, quiet and not crowded.
Monet heaven. What is this world if full of care we have no time to stop and stare - do it here.
Impressionists in Monet's specially designed space. a good collections of Impressionists and others-at the moment, there is an very good exhibition about Debussy and his links with the arts
Terrific stop!. We loved the tranquility of Monet's water lillies upstairs and the diverse offerings below. It is a fraction of the size of the Louvre but definitely worth the price of admission.
Beautiful Art. We liked everything about this small museum, especially its highlight, two rooms of Monet's water lilies. Just stunning!
Monets water lilies. 2 oval rooms lit with natural light and the most amazing floor to ceiling paintings of Monets water lilies. Very peaceful.

Water lilies. Astounding exhibition of Monet's paintings. The two room with wall sized murals will keep you captivated for hours if you like Monet. The downstairs has a superb collection of 19th century art.

Monet's Water Lilies as he meant them to be seen. I got goosebumps the first time I entered the rooms with Monet's huge canvases, and every time since then, too. A recent remodel has only enhanced the giant canvases. The diffuse light allows the viewer to see every nuance of the scenes. A quiet and calm stop for a hurried sightseer.The current special exhibit on Debussey and Art is extremely well curated. It put his music in context to the arts of the time.
Worth a visit. A quick trip between the Louvre & d'Orsay - viewing Monet's panels was almost overwhelming
Well. It is nice - but further than that I have nothing more to say - been and done it, perhaps

Viewing These Paintings Will Change Your Life. This museum houses some of Monet's long rectangular paintings of water lillies that he completed near the end of his life. The museum is small and this small size allows you to get up close to the paintings and really see the small areas of colors and the texture of the brush strokes. The colors are so subtle and beautiful and peaceful, thatafter seeing these paintings you will want to run out and invest in painting supplies and learn to paint.

A Mesmerizing Experience. This was a surprise gem. For many years of visits to Paris I have missed the Orangerie. I was never quite sure of the purpose or need. After all, with the Louvre, Orsay and so many other experiences, why visit another museum of art? What a mistake. I finally visited the Orangerie and what a wonderful place! The highlight were the two rooms of Claude Monet's "Water Lilies." I must have spent an hour just mesmerized by the work. It has a way of soothing, relaxing and stimulating the mind and soul. Hard to say more. It is something to be experienced. The underground floor with many paintings predominantly of the Impressionists was outstanding. There was a special exhibit linking music and art that focused on Claude De Bussy. The time at the Orangerie was wonderful. Very focused, easy to take in, and absorbing.

My favorite Paris Museum!. I didn't know what to expect when entering this museum, and I was totally blown away. It housed the floor to ceiling Monet Water Lillies, which I had never seen. It was a moving experience, and I was basically enchanted. The rest of the works were great too, and were definitely worth going back for.
Monet lovers, do not miss!. If you cannot get enough of Monet's water lilies, you must see this museum. Great little impressionist collection downstairs
hidden gem, sort of. great layout, great location, incredible works of art.
Worth a visit. In a city with tons of museums, I think this is a must visit. The two huge rooms with Monet's water lilies are just stunning. Plus, downstairs you get to see a good many other masters.

Don't Miss It..... This is a fascinating, beautiful museum--best seen on a day when you can also see the Jeu de Paume on the other side of the park, since they seem to close on different days--and well worth the visit. The gorgeous Monet panels made even more famous in "Midnight in Paris" are star attractions, but there are other exhibits as well. This is a place well worth seeing and then seeing again.

Sit down and take it in. The main content consists of works of Monet, so large that you need to take a seat to take in the work. Entrance was included with the Paris Museum Pass which minimises delays in entering

Jaw droppingly beautiful - a must for Monet lovers. I visited the museum with a friend one Friday afternoon, and had to queue for less than 5mins for tickets to get in. As EU citizens under 26 it was free admission (great for a budget holiday). I have loved Monet for as long as I can remember and was amazed by the scale and beauty of his work. An absolute must see, and can easily be appreciated in just half an hour if your struggling for time and don't mind missing out on the downstairs part of the museum.

Monet's waterlily paintings...an oasis of serenity in the heart of a busy city.. This is a must-see museum. It is a small museum, but its displays of Monet's incredible waterlily paintings are stunniing. They request silence to respect Monet's desire for peace, and with the natural lighting coming in the skylight, the effect is calming. In the lower level, they have a relatively small but lovely collection of impressionist paintings. When you have finished your viewing, you can sit outside in the lovely park and watch Paris bustle by.

Awesome Monet Paintings. Monet's Water Lilly paintings are displayed under natural light in rooms designed especially for them. It's hard to describe how beautiful these paintings are in such a setting. L'Orangerie would be worth the visit for those paintings alone, however it boasts a collection of late 19th and 20th century art that would warrant a visit on their own.

Peaceful. Having seen the unbelievable queues at the Musee d'Orsay we went to the l'Orangerie to buy a combined ticket for both. We were able to spend time sitting and contemplating the vast paintings of the waterlilies at Giverny before returning the next day to the Orsay, early.
2 museums. Can get a 4 day pass for both d'Orsay and l'Orangerie. d'Orsay closed on a Monday and l'Orangerie on a Tuesday. Will take about 4 hours to do d'Orsay and 1 for l'Orangerie.

Often overlooked next to its big brothers. Mostly exhibiting from the private collection of a prescient art collector named Paul Gillaume, it also features Claude Monet's Nymphae (water lilies). The paintings cover 4 long walls, and were stitched together from multiple canvases - one is 55 feet long!. In typical Monet style, it depicts scenes of lilles at different times of the day. Downstairs is an impressive collection of Renoir, Cezanne, Modigliani, Picasso, Matisse, Utrillo, Derain, and others from that era.
Interesting. The museum is not great but if you have time do not miss the Monet paintings.

Beautiful museum for Monet lovers!. This museum mainly houses Monet's water lilies, the HUGE versions that Monet worked on in the later years of his life at his house in Giverny. They are beautiful and definitely worth checking out. The rest of the museum houses other impressionist artists as well, so it's a nice intro before you go to the Orsay museum.
A small but intensely packed museum. Definitely worth a visit and it's really got a great location.
Mad for Monet. It was a quiet sanctuary to ponder the lilypads. Very tranquil and beautiful.
Worth it if you have extra time. Monet's mural water lily rooms upstairs were impressive as was the collection of Renoir works in the basement. I wouldn't go out of my way to see this one.
Wonderful compact museum. Just the right size for a couple of hours visit. Not too large. Great impressionist paintings.

Mindboggling importance in a most unexpected location. The largest 360 mural of Monets waterlily up close and personal. Mindboggling scale, all to yourself. There is never a big crowd. By far the most concentrated Monet experience in Paris. Unlike any other gallery experience, this will be integrated into your artistic imperative forever.

If you like Monet. Small, very charming museum but with the astonishingly large "Water Lillies" collection, completed towards the end of Monet's life. The rooms were clearly designed to specifically showcase this collection, so the setting is nothing short of perfect.
Amazing Art. If you're interested in Art you should visit here on your trip to Paris. Under 26 are free with ID which is great!

Breathtaking. It is a lovely collection, most notable of which is Monet's Nymphs. There was no queue (unlike the 2 hour wait at the Louvre) and was a fabulous way to escape the summer heat. Despite the collection being relatively small, each piece is exquisite so it took me nearly 2 hours to view. A must see!

Monet, Renoir and Sisley at their best. This museum is often overlooked as it is located near the entrance to the Jardin des Tuileries [ the one facing the Place de la Concorde] and most tourists head to the other end as fast as possible to visit the Louvre. The collection is impressive. The large Monet Water Lillies are in two rooms. On the lower level the finest collection of Renoir and Sisley in France [ and possibly the world] line the walls. We were there on a Sunday afternoon and it was so pleasant. We had time to enjoy the paintings and just explore the gallery.I would definitely recommend this museum to anyone interested in Impressionism.
Try to Fit It In. It is much smaller than the more famous Musee d'Orsay so it can be dome in about 2-3 hours. You can see Monet, Picasso and Cezanne paintings.

Not to be missed. Small and perfectly formed. Paintings are stunning as is the building they are housed in. Whether you are interested in art or not, I believe most people will take away something positive from a visit to this museum. I know I loved it.
Water Lillies and then some. Monet's Water Lillies dominate this museum and their display is amazing.
1~1.5 hours is good enough for you. It's very compact so just stop by, and feel and enjoy the art. Good size for everyone.

Monet and beyond. While this museum is famous for its huge Monet lilly pond paintings downstairs is a collection of delights that will keep the art lover enthralled for a few hours. When we were there a ticket was available for entry for here and the Musee D'Orsay which is a deal an art lover would be mad to pass up.
Always inspiring.. The 20th Century's Sistine Chapel - I go everytime I visit Paris and it never disappoints.
Amazing. Small easy to do in1 hour. Need I d to rent headphone tour. Beautiful experience. Vs others it was enjoyable as crowds were not packed to bring
Well worth a visit. Stunning exhibit. Wonderful location. Do nott allow children's strollers which is not ideal with a sleeping baby!

Meditate in front of Monet's immersive waterlily canvasses. Just brilliant. A bite-size piece of impressionist genius without the crowds. There are two waterlily rooms with 4 canvasses each. They curve round the room so you can sit and imagine you are in Monet's garden on a warm summer day. There is a further gallery downstairs with a good selection of impressionist and post impressionist paintings. You could spend hours just admiring the water lillies, or if you are on a busy schedule then you could whizz round in under an hour, although that would be a shame!

Beautiful Collection. In all our trips to Paris we had never before visited Musee de l'Orangrie and I am so glad that we saved it for this visit. Monet's waterlillies are divine as are the rest of the impressionists' collection. We were able to spend a very happy couple of hours without feeling too overwhelmed by too much art. A lovely visit!
Monet in the Round. Good small museum. nice quick one. easy locatin by the Concorde and across from Dorsay on the Seine and on the end of the Tuleries

Monet's Waterlilies Breathtaking!. A small but beautiful gallery of impressionist art. Quiet, white, oval rooms hold Monet's mural masterpieces. The basement holds many more wonderful works of art. As a lover of Monet's work, this was a must-see and was my favourite gallery of the trip!

AVOID AT ALL COST !!!. I m a 45 years old woman living in paris for a bit as an expat for an international firm !!! All my friend coming to see me talk about this museum so far better than the famous "Louvre". After 2 years, i finally found the time to give a try with some huge expectations! We ve waited more than 45 mn before getting in !! and I was actually a bit disapointed about the painting! The staff is exactly the typical parisian bad example considering the tourists like animals ! Avoid and go to le louvre instead!

Fabulous for Monet Fans. If you are a fan of Monet, do not miss this museum. There is an atmosphere that is a close to a temple as you will find in non-sacred space. I loved it. My favorite spot in Paris!

Monet Waterlilies. Quiet place to sit and gaze at Monet's gift to Parisiennes. Very large impressionist paintings of waterlilies. Quite pricey if only doing the museum but worth the admission if bought as part of the Paris Museum Pass. A nice place to rest your legs and mind for a while when walking from site to site.
Surrounded by waterlilies.. If you like Monet, a must see. Guided English tour was fantastic addition. Buy passport for combined ticket with Musee D'Orsay.

Lovely Museum with the right amount of art to really enjoy !. We really enjoyed our visit to this museum as part of the Paris Museum pass. Wonderful setting for Monet's water lilies, and a good amount of art to make the museum worthwhile visiting, yet not too much to cause total overload ! Lovely visit and helpful staff.
Don't miss this museum. Great little museum --- wonderful exhibit of Monet's water lillies --- stretched on the walls of a white oval shaped room. Quiet, peaceful spot. Great for children.

Interesting. You have to use your imagination as to what these paintings looked like when freshly done and the rooms furnished.
Few paintings down stairs including Renoir and Picasso.
However I enjoyed my visit
Very nice collection. Small museum with great chefs-d'oeuvre! You will see famous paintings by Monet Renoir, Picasso and more.
Breath taking. I greatly enjoyed these larger than life displays and the ability to soak in these enormous pieces designed into the cool architecture of the building.

Not for those on a schedule. This was one of several museums we visited in a single day, and we may not have been able to do it justice. Leave plenty of contemplative time for this spot; it has many beautiful sights.
it's Monet. If you like Monet, you will be overwhelmed. Otherwise, it's a long painting.

Amazing museum - more than just "waterlillies"!. While I am not a big fan of very modern buildings in general, this streamlined museum (very accessible thru the Tuilleries gardens) is perfect and showcases the collections within in unique and beautiful ways.Not only the famous "waterlily" panels are here - although sitting and contemplating these amazing paintings is an experience that I treasure - the sunlight seems to move thru the trees and the light shifts and makes the huge paintings come alive.I really enjoyed the Picassos and Modiglianis that were exhibited as well - it was my first "sighting" of a Modigliani and I can't wait to see more paintings this year on our next visit to Paris.Beautiful museum, amazing exhibits in a wonderful location that is very easy to access! I highly recommend it!

Great little museum. L'Orangerie is great because of the beautiful oval rooms with the large Monets. There are some other great works in this museum, but probably the most practical reason to go is that it is not as crowded as some of the other big museums, and you can be in and out in a short time. My suggestion is to start at Chatelet metro, walk down the shops on Rue de Rivoli, walk through the Tuileries until you get to L'Orangerie, pop into the museum, and then walk the Champs until the Arc. A perfect day of sightseeing, museums, and shopping. Plenty of great places to stop and eat or get a coffee along the way.
compact. 2 circular rooms adorned with Monet's wonderful water lilies. Exhibition on lower floor worth viewing. Compact museum, so not too tiring to see everything.

Excellent museum. We recently returned to the Musee de lOrangerie. It's always a pleasure to see the collection and of course Monet's water lillies. The museum has the perfect size -- it's not so vast and daunting as the Louvre.Our previous visit was last Easter vacation and there were sizeable lines outside the museum. We had to wait for well over an hour in Paris's springtime drizzle. To avoid waiting in winter cold and snow, we booked tickets on-line. It turned out to be unecessary, however; we could walk right in! So the booking fee of 1½ euros per person was wasted this time -- but it's good to know that one can avoid the lines!
Fascinating. This was an overwhelming presentation of Monet, but mostly limited to that
Incredible exhibit of Monet's Waterlilies. The waterlily paintings are great as well as the exhibit in the lower level. Go early before the tours arrive.
Absolutely stunning. This was my favorite part of my visit to Paris in December. It is a lovely little museum.

Surreal. Monet's Water Lilly Pond was THE painting for me.Having tried to cram in as many museum visits on our short holiday & getting an overload of art, this "spoke" to me. Despite being a philistine when it comes to art.
Nice impression(ist)!. Beautiful Monet waterlilies walls are not to be missed.
Worth the visit. Not overly expensive to visit, and worth it to see Monet's most known pieces.

Small and more personal. After walking from the Lourve to this museum, I can honestly say I enjoyed this one more. The crowds were good (Feb) and doing the huge paintings on the top floor first, then descend down to other lovely works.
A Jewel Box Museum. Important art in a setting that allows one to digest everything because it is not so huge that each piece cannot be appreciated. I liked the opportunity to sit and appreciate.
Very Pleasant. Well worth a visit. Buy the Museum Pass and make time for this one.

More Monet please. I love Monet so was a little disappointed by the number of pieces by this artist on display at this Museum. The water lily pieces are well known I know but he did hundreds of other masterpieces that in my opinion deserve recognition and should be on show.
lovely. Newly refurbished, this holds Monet's waterlilly series. It's fabulous. It also has a collection of interesting works by a famous bunch downstairs
calm and collected. good selection of paintings and sculptures from reknowned impressionists
If you have time.... not much there, except a great collection of murals by Monet.

Monet. Monet's murals! a must to see, as well as the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collection. Lovely walk from Lourve through the Tuileries Gardens and the musee de l'Orangerie is located at the other end.

must see before going to giverny. If you are in Paris and plan to visit Monet's House in Giverny, this is a must see attraction. It is best to see it before heading out to Giverny as it will provide you with a preview of how to fully appreciate his Water Garden and water lilies. The light reflections in each of the water lily water color panels are so realistic with the different times of the day. You need to just stay focused on the panels and see the change in the lighting. Up front it appears as just a blob but at a distance it is a definite unique piece of picture.Take your time in the viewing rooms to appreciate them. Sit down, contemplate and just imagine yourself at the Water Garden in Giverny. It will definitely prepare your visit to Giverny. Monet was definitely an unique impressionist artist of his time.Get a Paris Museum pass to avoid the long line to get in the Musee de l'Oragerie. There is a separate line (quicker) for Museum pass holders.

Monet Must See. Spare, tranquil and focused environment in which to be immersed in Monet's lilly ponds. Especially good museum for those who are museum-averse. Plus it's on the grounds of the Tullieries so the walk around the museum is especially nice.

Monet Monet Monet. Monet planned the Orangerie to be a place of peace and reflection, he wanted his life work , his Lilies, to be exhibited in this place. It is fab - the halls and the paintings.There is more to see downstairs , but after enjoying the main course the rest is just a side dish.Do not miss the statue of Rodin 's -The Kiss - at the front door.

Alway amazing!. The main attraction - 2 oval rooms with the visual equivalent of surround sound Monet's waterlilies never cease to take your breath away - stunning! Even my teenage son had to admit they were "alright!". The rest of the collection is also a great introduction to the impressionists and other art of that period - and just the right number of paintings for a couple of teen age children.

My favourite museum in the World. I can never get tired of visiting here.There is something special about Monet's colours and yet my favourite works were done later in his life when he was close to blindness.A couple of hours here makes you absolutely awestruck of the creativity and talent of this man - I could often walk the streets for hours and feel the tension of the modern world but a revisit to this museum is far better than taking a valium to relax you.
Monet. Take time to sit and enjoy Monet's fabulous waterlilies. Beautiful....

Not only water lily. I paid attention to Marie Laurencin, who was Guillaume Apollinaire's muse and first of all a unique female painter. She developed her own distinctive aesthetic world. The pastel tones of rose, purple, blue and gray evince a glimmer of unmistakable intelligence and the existence of a cautiously hinted sensuality that create a soft and serene atmosphere, as if the entire scene were covered with a veil of mystery.

Shh, Shh, Best Kept Secret In Paris.. I have lived in France for quite a while and have visited the best Art museums a number of times. I have to say that l'Orangerie is my favourite. It is situated in an exquisite part of Paris near the Tuillerie Gardens and the Place de la Concorde. It has a wonderful history, where at one time, it narrowly escaped being condemned. But pleased to say it avoided the guillotine , it has survived, and has gone on to become a jewel in the crown. When you arrive at l'Orangerie, the first thing you will notice from the outside is that it is much smaller than many other museums. In fact, once inside you only have to negotiate a couple of floors. This is a great advantage as, unlike the Louvre, you do not get lost and spend hours walking the length and breadth of the building. I love the simplicity of The L'orangerie. Near the ticket office are a series of photographic tableaux which explain the life of Monet and the Water Lilies...How Monet was going blind when he painted the Water-Lilies and how his hands were almost paralysed with arthritis. There is also an audio-visual show about Monet. Be sure to see it. All this history is very helpful before you are swept off your feet by the beauty and the sheer size of Monet's masterpiece, "The Water-Lilies". I was able to view the Water Lilies for over two hours as there is comfortable circular seating there. Once you are done with Monet's "Nymphaes", visit the Impressionist floor as this is an absolute must. As you walk along the corridor, you are in for an absolute treat. You will see a fine collection of Renoir's, Van Gogh's and Gauguin works and many others. Many of them are their most celebrated works. Again, I mention how great it is to see these master pieces and not have to walk miles within the museum looking for them. I can well understand why the French love this museum so much, and to think that only a few year's ago , this museum was the best kept secret in Paris. In conclusion, the staff are friendly, the decor is bright and modern, and the tariff is very reasonable. Tips: 1. Get there early for pole position in the Water-Lilies Room. 2. Don't forget to view the Impressionist Paintings on lower floor. 3. L'Orangerie is closed Tuesdays. 4. See the Real" Water-lilies" that Monet painted at Monet's Gardens at Giverny. (Only a short trip from Paris).

Excellent small museum, no queues!. I thought this little museum between the Jardins Tuileries and Place de la Concorde was great. Some excellent works, including a full cycle of Monet's Waterlillies in a setting designed by Monet himself. Best of all, no queues (I'm looking at you Louvre and Musee d'Orsay), and no being herded around!

Beautiful, curving Monets. This wonderful museum at the west end of the Tuilleries is a must-see for Monet fans. The eight Water Lily canvasses are displayed in two naturally-lit rooms, the way Monet wanted them to be viewed. The paintings are impressive in both size and beauty, and the setting is serene. The basement galleries display some other fine paintings, including numerous Renoirs and some Modiglianis. Usually much less crowded than the Musee d'Orsay. Use Museum Pass and don't miss it.

The museum no American goes to. All Americans run to the Louvre and it is truly a special place on planet Earth. But in the tourist season it is beastly crowded. As a fan of French impressionists, this is a must-see stop. Musee de l'Orangerie is almost never crowded. The museum was designed by Monet as a gift to the French people near WWI time frame. It is quiet, peaceful, contemplative, sublime. You can do it in 30 minutes, or in 5 hours. Wonderful stop. And far from the maddening crowds.

Those who love Monet dont miss it !. Those huge paintings of Monet's water lillies are stunning and absolutely relaxing to sit and watch. Not crowded as other museums and no vast collection. If you adore Monet paintings then you cannot afford to miss it. The best Monet collection I have seen.This is a very relaxing place. It is about 300M walk from Concorde station across the park. The souvenir boutique has unique gift items of Monet paintings. Make sure you buy one to mark your visit to Paris. Free entrance with Museum Pass.
If you love Monet, you have to go!. Give yourself time just to sit and enjoy the beautiful water lily paintings. Incredible!
Monet. Just sit in the room with the water lilies! This is so close to the louvre and a cafe in the park. Do the l'orangerie first, then lunch, then louvre
Beautyful and Cosy. My favourite museum in Paris. The impressionist art is beautiful, the crew is the nicest and the size is perfect!
great for Monet fans. get museum pass!!! loved the great HUGE!! paintings of the water lilies by Monet
Monet. Well laid out and has a great display as well as the Monet Water Lilies there is a great selection of paintings. there are also good AV presentations, some with English subtitles.
Must see!. Exceptional Monets and also a wonderful gallery of impressionists downstairs which I was not aware of.
If you like Monet, you'll love this!. Fabulous Monet Nympheas panels. Fascinating collection of Renoir, Cezanne, and early Picasso downstairs. A charming gallery.
Monet. The oval rooms with Monet....breathtaking. Wonderful surprise!

Do Not Miss the Musee de l'Orangerie. We liked everything about the Musee de l'Orangerie. It's location is only the start- beautiful surroundings - a lovely walk. Be blown away by the presentation of Monet's Waterlilies! This is a gallery that feels comfortable rather than overwhelming- filled with a wonderful variety of art works. The giftshop offers many interesting things, too.
Close to the Louvre.. Monet's Water Lilies are housed in grand fashion here. This is a Paris Museum Pass site.

Jaw-dropping...a must-see.... We visited L'Orangerie the day after Musee d'Orsay across the Seine. M d'O was really overwhelming - but L'Orangerie is simpler with a magnificent collection but small enough not to exhaust. Though both are must-dos in Paris.Paul Guillame's collection downstairs is an eclectic mix of Impressionism and Post-Impressionism plus, with Modigliani, Monet, Renoir, Utrillo, Rousseau, Verain and Picasso etc. Stunning.However the highlight are the 2 oval rooms on the top floor devoted to Monet's massive lily canvases. Great to be here on a winter's day with few people to obscure the view but sunny so the filtered light warmed these rooms.Beautiful...And the building itself, ain't half bad!

A wonderful museum experience - perfect way to spend part of a day in Paris. This is a gem of a museum. It has excellent audioguides for several pieces of art, and an array of stunning works on the lower floor. I spent all my time exploring these wonderful works, and actually forgot to go visit the famed wall murals portion with the water lilies! I would not leave Paris without visiting L'Orangerie. Next time I am in Paris, I will make a visit to l'Orangerie a high priority.
Something to see. My only wish is that it had been sunny. The grey skies did not provide enough light to truely see the beauty of Monet's works. I have been here on a sunny day and was awe struck.
Looking for a peaceful place to sit and rethink your life?:).... ...at this beautiful old building full of natural light and..water lilies..

Have the Museum to Yourself at Opening!. I arrived at the Museum just as it was opening on a Sunday morning and had the place almost entirely to myself. I couldn't imagine a more delightful way to be surrounded by Monet's murals than sitting in solitude on the bench in the middle of the room absorbing the beauty of the panoramas! The paintings on the lower level and gift shop take an additional hour or two to view, so plan on at least a couple hours at l'Orangerie.
Water lillies plus more. Beautiful modern museum with large open area for murals of water lillies .
don't miss. Great collection. A Parisian Frick. Many Soutines, a great Derain, and many more. Right in the Tuleries.

Highlights Monet beautifully. Loved the Museum.. This was a small museum, with the whole first floor highlighting the amazing works of Monet – eight mammoth curved panels showing his gardens at Giverny at different times of day with different lighting. The first room is water lilies and the second includes willows near the pond. The underground gallery had works by Cezanne, Rouseau, Renoir, Picasso and others. It is easy to cover this museum in the same afternoon with the Orsay – buy a combo ticket here and save line-wait time at the Orsay.

A Hidden Gem!. I would never have known that the Musee de l'Orangerie existed had it not been suggested to me by a family member. It was worth going just to admire Monet's exquisite water lilies, "Les Nympheas" . Well worth the trip. A must see on any trip to Paris!
Worth a visit.. A tranquil haven to the hustle and bustle outside. Worth a look inside.
Don't miss downstairs!. The waterlilies are beyond amazing. Fabulous to see them not cropped. Loved loved the downstairs exhibit so don't skip it! Utrillo is a new favorite!

An absolute must see. A simply fabulous gallery designed especially for Monet's large paintings. It is heaven to sit and gaze at Les Nympheas. And then stroll through the Tuileries, along the Seine, and into the lively St Germain des Pres neighbourhood.
An absolute must see if you ever go to Paris. You get to see the masters in an absolutely wonderful museum. This will take your breath away.

Unforgettable!. The two Monet Rooms are great. The pictures in the internet don't make justice to the works, you have to see it live! And the gallery in the underground it's perfect. It's not so huge, so you will remember everything. It's one of the best experiences you can have in Art Museums.
Great collection. Loved the size of this museum and the collection. It's not overwhelming and is an enjoyable place to spend a couple of hours enjoying a fine collection of art.
Lovely. Being under 25, got in for free (bonus) and was lovely to look around.

Breath Taking. We bought the Paris Museum Pass - the best benefit, we didn't need to wait in the very looooooong queue. You need to leave everything at the reception area except valuables. I was surprised to see traveler's photo's on TA as we weren't allowed to take any pics. The two oval rooms with the Monet's paintings was just astonishing. We've sat in the rooms and just drank in the beauty of the liliies - absolutely worth the visit. Don't forget to go downstairs, a huge surprise is waiting. The paintings of very well known artists e.g Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir & more is just awesome!!

15 years on - charming, but improved. I visited this gallery last in 1996. To come back was great. It has been considerably remodelled. They have done a great job, with Monet's great works hung beautifully together.The only down side was the brusque entry clerk and the fact that this once quiet gallery is now heaving with people.
Great. Kind of crowded because of Monet's works on the main floor, but still amazing and worth it. Lots of interesting pieces by artists that I was not familiar with at all.

a must for Monet fans. This is an unmissable experience for anyone who likes/loves Monet's waterlillies. The museum is a perfect size, particularly if you are accompanied by someone who isn't really into art or the sheer scale of the Louvre is a little off-putting. The main attractions in this museum are the huge panels of the Waterlillies, for which the museum was purpose built, but there are also other impressionist paintings in the gallery below ground. Well worth the 8 euro entry fee.

Fun for Monet Lovers, but the collection downstairs is even better. 8 Spectacularly large works from Monet's later years are the 'selling point' for this spot, but my favorite is the fantastic collection downstairs. Great works by artists from cezanne to picasso, well worth the trip. A few hints: get there early as the line gets long quickly. I've recommended to several friends that they start their day with an early morning walk through the tuileries, then head here, then visit Angelina across the street for hot chocolate, then head on to another museum or location for the afternoon. Also, it's not the best place for rowdy kids as they ask for near absolute silence in the main rooms upstairs.
most beautiful museum. the one museum not to miss if you like to loose yourself in Impressionist paintings. The rooms with water lilies by Monet are simply stunning

I can hear the frogs croaking. The Monet panels are shocking at first, due to their sheer size and the two oval-shaped rooms that display them. It takes awhile to "get focused"--translating the impressionist's medium, not into "what it looks like" but into our own impressions of serene ponds, reeds, water lilies, glints of color and sparkly light on rivulets from a whisper of wind.After losing ourselves in just walking around the rooms, we started to talk about what kind of a patient genius it would take to capture and convey these extraordinary scenes and his compelling need and artistic capability to do so. I love the Louvre and d'Orsay for their variety of great art; the physical space of both museums is beyond description. But, it is the panels that bring me that rush of emotion even as I think of them now. Don't miss this place, until after you reluctantly walk out the door of the museum.

Just have to go there. This was the second time in one year. The collection of Rodin, Cezanne and Picasso is beautiful, but the two rooms with the paintings "water lillies" of Claude Monet. A perfect place to wind down and enjoy some extraordinarie contribution to art

Monet and More. Everyone goes here to see the Monet Waterlillies. And that pretty much is worth the price of admission. But there is also some classic turn of the century art on the bottom floor from Picasso, Modigliani, and others.

amazing Monet water lilies!. i have never seen such an amazing display of Monet's water lilies. The 2 white rooms on the ground floor each had 4 huge paintings of water lilies, they just took my breath away! the rest of the collection at the gallery are also worth checking out.
Monet. heavenly Monet waterlilies in a huge light space - it's a must see museum......

Excellent and not overwhelming. The collection at L'Orangerie is excellent but to me one of the best things about it is that the collection isn't so large that it overwhelms. You can take the time to see and study the work and really understand the story of the collection.
marvelous impressionist colection. this medium museum is special .Excellent exposition with the best of impressionits and a special Monet big paintings .
Monet. Breathtaking! The two oval shaped room with panoramic Monet paintings.

A roomful of Monet's Nympheas, just for us!. This museum, recently restored, is on the Place de la Concorde end of the Jardin des Tuileries, and contains wonderful Impressionist and Modern Art works, including paintings by Claude Monet (his Nympheas or Water Lilies are on huge panels in an oval room, so one is surrounded by their beauty), Picasso, Matisse, Renoir and many others. The building itself is pleasant, with huge skylights brightening what used to be a rather dreary interior, and it is a short, agreeable walk through the Tuileries Gardens from the Louvre Museum.
A real surprise!. Monet's paintings encompass two entire rooms. I was expecting small paintings. Many pther artists featured as well, but Monet is the star

Staggering. My wife and I went to the Orangerie after getting back from a day at Versailles, after which you would think anything else would pale, and found it as awesome in its own way as Louis XIV's country home, not just for the truly staggering water lilies, but also for the marvelous collection of smaller works. It should be on your must-see list just like the Louvre and d'Orsay, and it is certainly more manageable than those two.
Small museum with the best Claude Monet work. The museum is very small and it has the Les Nympheas exhibition. If you like impressionism this is the place to go to be surprised.

One of the most amazing sites ever. The Musee de l'Orangerie was awesome. I almost wanted to go a second time before leaving Paris just to absorb it once more but ran out of time. I would definitely go again.

A must for anybody who likes Impressionist works. Recommended by a friend and was totally surprised at the Water Lilies - a truly remarkable work. Not just a painting but two whole rooms! Excellent other works on display.

A Gem Near the Concorde!. Just when you think it couldn't get better than seeing Monet's gorgeous Waterlilies paintings in 380 degrees in a large, oval-shaped room built just for these pieces, step through the door in the back (which most people seem to overlook) and there is another oval room with 360 degrees of Monet's Nympheas works - simply breathtaking and well-worth the admission! I also was able to see the Spanish art exhibition which helped me become a fan of many new talented artisits. Get there early to avoid the long lines that form!

Go early. Le Musee de l'Orangerie is a very small museum but it's well worth a visit if you can get there early when they're opening like I did. The main attraction of this museum are the two oval rooms with four Monet paintings in each one. The idea was for the museum to be a place of tranquility that people can come to to get away from the hectic city. If you get there early it is nice to sit and look at the waterlilies and contemplate. By the time I was leaving - about 10:30 - it was starting to get very busy and the effect wouldn't have been the same.

If you could only do one, this is it!. The Musee de l' Orangerie was originally a green house for the kings orange trees and was later turned into a mueseum to be dedicated to Monet's works (les nympheas). It also holds a small collection of Picasso, Renoir, Dali, and other famous names. The facility is well lit, and can be seen in entirety in 4 hrs or less.

Monet - up close and personal. So nice to skip the crowds and the overwhelming deluge of art available at the Louvre and simply sit down, relax and drink in the subtle joys of this museum. The 'white room' you move through before you enter was created to separate you from the busy world and your normal museum expectations, and it works. You move into the first oval gallery and just sigh with relief and pure enjoyment. You can sit for as long as you want and absorb from different angles. A delightful and different experience. And be sure to enjoy the garadens afterwards.
A Must for Monet fans. Overwhelming in scale and grandeur, the recently refurbished l'Orangerie is a must for all serious Monet fans. Be surrounded by his genius. Serene and inspiring...

D'orsay 2.0 + waterlillies. Most people go to l'Orangeries solely for the waterlilles. They're pretty amazing, but all the other impressionist stuff in the basement is really cool as well. If you like impressionism this is definitely the place to go, right after you've been to the Musee d'Orsay.

Haven of light and lilies. We visited this Museum on 1 January 2012. As it was the first Sunday of the month, we enjoyed free admission. Thank you Paris for such a lovely New Year's gift! Inside this museum, the display of Monet's paintings in panoramic form allowed us to immerse ourselves in his world of light and water lilies. The Spanish paintings in the visiting exhibition area were also stunningly beautiful. I especially loved the white period of the Spanish painters.Bravo!

Favourite place in Paris. This museum is not widely known (as say, the Louvre), but it's one not to miss. Viewing the Monets is an amazing experience. After that, there's a superb collection to see with works from Renoir to Picasso to Gauguin.

interesting exhibitions. L'Orangerie has an excelent program of exhibition and it is one of the place to check when you are visiting Paris as it is beautifully situated in the middle of the Tuileries gardens and most of the time the artists presented there are surprising or unexpecterd.

Take the tour! Also good to come with time to sit. Wonderful art. We got a tour in English. So well organized! The woman who took us was amazing. Loved the art, wove stories of Monet's (and the other artists) lives into the talk - very interesting and they have a personal microphone system so you don't have to crowd up to hear it.
A must see.... Water lily's... and extensive collection and small crowds..

Personal view of Monet up close. This museum has three rooms. the first is pure white and gives you time to shed the noise of the outside. The next two contain a total of eight giant Money water lilies paintings. That is it. Plan to come in a sit and absorb the beauty.

From Giverny to Musee de l'Orangerie. My daughter and I visited Giverny in the morning and then went right to Musee de l'Orangerie to see Monet's waterlily paintings. It was a day to remember. First seeing the bridge and waterlilies in person adn then seeing with breathtaking awe how Monet transferred this reality to a canvass. I highly recommend doing this- it really blends reality and art and makes you understand how you can keep those memories of Giverny in yoru heart for the rest of your life.
beautiful. If you love Monet you must go here...it was built to house his art...magnifique!

Monet at his best. Monet's gift to Paris, this lovely and quiet museum house 8 water lily panels in room specially crafted for their viewing. the museum also has a nice collection as well as fun special exhibits.
Quiet & Relaxing. Very peaceful in the Monet rooms and an interesting selection of other paintings
waterlily heaven. the two oval rooms with Monet's Nympheas (Waterlilies) paintings were a quiet respite from the hustle and bustle outside...beautiful!

Is this Paris' best kept secret?. The Musee D'Orsay had a queue winding into the next street - even at lunch time. We walked on. Someone had suggested Musee de l'Orangerie so we followed the road towards the Tuilleries and found it very easily although little is mentioned of it in guide books and it is not often sign-posted. Is it Paris' best kept secret? Best of all, no queue! A short wait to go through the ubiquitous security screen, the usual fee to enter and we were in. Previous readers are right about the lovely Monet screens but there is much more to this museum than Monet. Downstairs there is some amazing art and I fast became an admirer of Tissot and his portraiture. We stayed a long time in l'Orangerie and it was worth every penny. On the way out you will be directed through the obligatory shop but this time you might just be surprised at the modest price of the souvenirs.

Great museum - a must visit for Monet fans. If you are a Monet fan, the l'Orangerie is a must-do - the two rooms featuring the huge waterlily paintings by Monet are absolutely stunning, and truly achieve Monet's vision of providing people with a quiet, beautiful and peaceful space in the city.The rest of the l'Orangerie's permanent collection is also quite impressive (the Walter-Guillame collection), featuring a number of works by Cezanne, Renoir, Picasso (though there aren't any of his Cubist works) and Modigliano. The audio guide is worth getting if you are interested in the background to paintings, as it was quite informative and there is little information on the panels next to the paintings.The l'Orangerie was my favourite museum in Paris - the collection, whilst much smaller than that of the d'Orsay and Louvre, is of high quality and well put-together.

Stunning. My daughter and I visited L'Orangerie one afternoon in December. We walked through rain, puddles and mud to get there from Le Louvre but it was worth. It was beautiful and so peaceful after the masses in Le Louvre. Together with the Musee D'Orsay it was a highlight of our family's visit to Paris.

Finally l'Orangerie is open. After having walked all over Paris, we went to the hotel so my other sister could go and rest. Every time my sister and I had been to Paris this museum was closed. So this time we hopped the Metro and went to see the museum. My favorite is the paintings of Monet. I could sit staring at them for hours. There are 2 rooms of his huge paintings of the water lillies. We walked around some more but the highlight was Monet.

Monet is incredible. There is no other museum like this. You are literally surrounded by a series of waterlily paintings in each of the 2 galleries. It is an unbelievable experience, because each painting is so wide that it engulfs you. Utterly unlike looking at ordinary paintings in rectangular frames.
hard to understand. this museum is very understated and requires time for quiet reflection. The history of the murals in extremely insteresting and worth learning about prior to visiting
One word, Monet. Two rooms of Monet, painted on site. Very do-able and enjoyable museum, used to be free admission with Teacher ID. You can easily miss this.
Stunning. This museum is pretty small, and is definitely worth a visit. It won't take up your whole day, and the Monet Water Lilies installation is stunning.

Don't miss!. If you love Monet's "Waterlilies" you'll want to see his very large works installed in specially constructed galleries to show them off. Many more works by Impressionists are also beautifully displayed. Nice shop!

Impressive Impressionists. We loved the Musee de l'Orangerie which has wonderful views of the Tuileries Gardens. It was amazing to see such a fabulous concentration of masterpieces from the Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume Collection, Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Rousseau, Matisse, Derain, Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo and Laurencin. We had just been to Giverny which made the experience of seeing Monet's work all the more special. What a privilege it was to see these works. We highly recommend buying advance tickets online.
tranquillity and magnificence. This attraction cannot be described as it would not do it justice this is a must see for yourself attraction

My favorite Paris museum. The Louvre is standard and necessary, of course. The Orsay was crowded and felt like a train station with art. But l'Orangerie is light and quiet and easy and flowing. You can sit in peace before massive Monets glowing in the filtered light or you can stand as long as you like in front of any number of other amazing artists' work without having to fight a crowd to get a glimpse. I cannot believe more people are not at this museum! Tucked away just a stroll through the gardens outside the louvre, it is a must-see in Paris.
Great Water Lillies. Nice surprise. Monet, Renoir, Cezanne. Go early.

If you like Monet.... High class, very good exhibition. And most of the important impreshionists represented. Nice and friendly staff if you speak french, and some staff who speak good english too. All in all, interesting and well worth a visit.

Beautiful Walls. If you are coming to this museum, you are really just coming to see Monet's Water Lilies right? Yes, I know I'm right. But if you asked me why I came? You would be surprised at my answer. I came because I wanted to see if I can get in for free--yes i did 26 and under EU is free... I had no clue his water lilies were here..But boy oh boy..was it beautiful. It was a room with water lilies painted on the walls...with benches in the middle and everyone just enjoying the artwork. There's two rooms, and both were drastically different but beautiful all at the same time. It's a SMALL museum but his work is beautiful so you should definitely come if you like his work. No Photos allowed :( Downstairs are some of other artists works...you can take photos at some portions downstairs. I think I finished within an hour because it's tiny. So I went back for a second look at the lilies :PThe sinks in the restrooms are a bit..different..you have to step on the handle thing on the floor to start the water! FYI :)

Limp compared to Musee D'Orsay but what is NOT?. There are extensive water lilly canvasses here that demand some visual meditation. The exhibits downstairs are fine but don't rate compared to those across the river at M D'Orsay. We would have bought a combined Museum ticket here to save queueing if we had our time over again.

Above Average. I know this museum gets super high ratings here so I was curious to check it out. I'm not that into art so I am speaking from the average joe point of view and am probably missing something. I know Monet's paintings are famous but I wasn't as amazed by the artwork here like I was in the Louvre and the Musee D'Orsay. I still liked it though.

a great little gem. So glad we wen there to see the monet water lilly's.... it was beautiful. We had a incredible time just sitting there taking in the water lillys... There is also a lot of other modern artists like matisse, and picasso... A small museum but definitely worth it, and in a beautiful area by the palace de concord.

Amazing that one man owned most of this. We were told about this by a friend and it is a unique museum even in this city. I can't believe that one man owned so much of this. Some great impressionists and art that you read about. Not a big museum so it's easy to go through and add to your list.
Worth it for Water Lilies alone. Really liked this little gallery. The presentation of Monet's Water Lilies is amazing.
Monet's Water Lilies The originals. They are exhibited as originally intended with light from above. You can study the brush strokes in this lovely museum
Amazing. Outstanding museum, a must in your visit. Purchase the Parius museum card

Musee de l'Orangerie is not to be missed.. Do yourself a favor when in Paris and visit the l'Orangerie. The art in these collections is fabulous and totally accessible. One can see everything, every work, linger at will and still see it all in 3 hours. It is not a museum where one has to pick and choose which works to find and see, because it is not so huge. However, this collection has Monet's famous Water Lillies, lots of Picasso, Cezanne, Renoir, Modigliani, Rousseau, Soutine and many, many more artists working in the early part of the 20th century. If time is an issue, forget the D'Orsay and the Louvre and visit l'Orangerie instead! If visiting solo, I recommend renting the informative headset. It is quite well done, full of interesting information and gives one the sense of being alone with the artwork.
monet's museum. take time to visit these murals..the wait is worth it...monet at his best.....
perfect size, great art!. perfect size with some amazing pieces. perfect size, great art! arrived late but had museum pass so we got right in. beautiful building too.
gorgeous!. Wonderful works of art. Very beautiful building and not crowded at opening.

The Art is lovely, but their rules suck.. In the good old days you could take (non-flash) photography of the artwork and be able to enjoy the art work that inspired you later. Now - much to my astonishment - you cannot even do drawings on your iPad. I brought my nine year old daughter to the museum and have found that it is CRITICAL to get her to participate - by drawing and re-creating the art work on my iPad. They came and told us it was forbidden. The art is lovely, but their rules suck.
Worth a visit. If you enjoy the Impressionists this is a place you will not want to miss. It is much smaller and more manageable than the Musee D'orsay (which is also wonderful, but takes more time.)
Excellent water lilies by Monét. Excellent water lilies by Monét. Worth the visit but take your time to sit and view them

Love the waterlillies. Getting to see Monet's room size paintings of his water lilly garden was amazing. It is definitely worth it, but it is too bad it is so crowded with people in the rooms.
However, the rest of the museum is just ok and doesn't deserve to be the number one attraction in Paris.
Monet's Waterlillies are breathtaking.. Amazing to see Monet's Waterlillies...totally worth it.

one of the great museums. Many great paintings have moved to Orsay, but it still has the Walter-Guillaume collections of Impressionists and early Twentieth century painters, with some of the most beautiful early Picassos and amazing Soutines and Modiglianis. It also has temporary exhibits of great interest and quality. Also, Monet's Water Lilies, which I almost forgot because I don't like them.

I was expecting more. There is long queue waiting outside the museum, we have to stand outside facing the cold weather with gusty wind and drizzle, no mercy. Should allow to queue inside the building.

What is the real story on Domenica Guillaume - Walter. The Musee de l'Orangerie is an absolute must-see in Paris: Monet's waterlilies in the perfect gallery setting and a truly amazing collection of French modern masters. But behind the facade of this most sophisticated of museums, what is the real story about Domenica Guillaume - Walter: the widow of the two men after whom the collection is named. There is an interesting panel inside the first room that alludes to a scandal .....
Don't Miss It. Monet's Murals and the other impressionist paintings. They often have special exhibits too.
A must for all travellers. A must for all travellers to Paris, a wonderful and interesting getaway from the crowds and the cafe is excellent, eibhlinn

Stunning!. This is one of the smaller museums we went to but my absolute favorite. The two Monet rooms were stunning as you are surrounded by Monet's most famous paintings. We almost didn't go - I am glad we did!

Great Art in a Peaceful Relaxing Envrionment. Almost forget to go to the Musee de l'Orangerie, so glad we made it. In comparison to the Louvre the museum is small and will take you far less time to enjoy. Give yourself about 2-3 hours. The Impressionist art displayed here is some of the best and most significant in the world. Of course Monet's Water Lllies is the highlight of the visit. See it last . It is calming and beautiful. Take a moment to destress while you look at the work. You will be revitalized and ready to return to hustle and bustle of Paris. The museum is on the Paris Museum Pass, which I strongly suggest getting. We bypassed several, lllooonngg admission lines. I don't rememeber there being a cafe of restaurant in the museum, but you're in Paris there is a multitude of eateries steps away. One big drawback, no photos, with or without flash, allowed here. Put Musee de l'Orangerie on your must see list..

A Spiritual Experience. There is nothing quite like walking into the oval rooms in the Orangerie and experiencing Les Nymphéas for the first, third or tenth time. I am always left breathless and serene. Then there is the added bonus of the Guillaume collection - some of the wonderful Impressionists in a small intimate setting. Go first thing in the morning before the crowds come.
Wonderful Museum. If you love Monet's waterlillies - this place is for you. What beautiful paintings!
Its a lot more beautiful after the restauration.. The museum is clear, full of natural light, easy to visit and with excellent permanent works of art.

Wonderfully Beautiful!. What a huge bit of heaven wrapped up in a small building. The Monet murals will take your breath away! There are benches in the two rooms to sit and admire them - and you'll want to do exactly that. Simply wonderful! You'll not want to leave Paris without visiting it. You can either stop in for a quick ten minute visit, or sit and admire for 40 minutes.NOTE: This is covered under the musuem pass. Also, their multi-stalled bathroom is shared by men and women. Men: Use the stalls if you don't want any "surprises" by having a woman walk in...OR use another bathroom facility prior to your visit.

If you really like impressionism, it's a must go. The museum is very small (and a little expensive for the size), but it has the most important paintings of Monet in a two dedicated rooms.It's really interesting the 360 degree perspective you have in the rooms and it's definitively a jewel of impressionism. Apart of the Monet's work, there is just a small collection. It's also very beautiful, but I think it worth if you really like art and impressionism.
Beautiful and tranquil. The size of the art works were huge and amazing and the location was easy to get to.

Really great museum, good collection away from the crowds. Really great collection of work, particularly for those who enjoy the Impressionists. Surprisingly not that crowded in comparison to Musee d'Orsay which is unpleasantly packed. Only complaint is coat check in where they would not take our coats.

A delight since it's restoration. You may remember this as a dingy museum, not at all fitting for the massive waterlillies paintings it houses. No more - it has been stunningly restored bringing back the delightful architecture of the original orangerie (I liked the architects models showing it through the years) - as well as re-siting the artworks in a fitting and well lit setting.Be prepared to queue - and plan for the opening hours - as it closes for lunch (Vive la France!) - worth every penny.

Impressionists, Oh My. Really enjoyed this little gem of a museum. The huge Monet canvases upstairs are the draw, but the real payoff is the collection downstairs of Cezanne and contemporaries. Plus the grounds outside the museum are beautiful.

excellent museum one of the better ones we have been to. it was very contemporary we had been meaning to go on the last 3 trips but were unable too due to time restrictions but we made the effort this time and we are glad we did
great arts. Many collections of Renoir, Picasso, and Monets. Amazing.

Not Monet's best work.. It was certainly interesting to see wall sized paintings of Monet's water lilies, but they are not his best work. What we liked best was the hallway gallery that had several Renoirs not usually seen. It was definitely worth the trip.
Delightful museum.. It was very hot whe I was in Paris and it was pleasant to get into this delightful museum.
Very relaxing. Loved the main exhibit, so relaxing! A good mix of more modern art, after a visit to the Louvre.
Drowning in waterlillies. I was taken aback by the scope of Monet's work, carried away!

Monet's Nympheas - swoon!. If you are at all interested in the work of Claude Monet you must go to the Orangerie to see the suite of waterlily (nympheas) murals. It's not a rush in, have a look, rush out experience - I recommend you take the time to wallow in the colour. The Orangerie also has a wonderful collection of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. I'd seen many of them when they were exhibited in Australia a few years ago while the Orangerie was being renovated, and it was good to see them again in their "home". Make sure you go for a stroll in the Tuileries afterwards!

Best museum we went to in Paris. We absolutely loved everything about this museum. The artwork is stunning, the experience alone of seeing Monet's "Water Lillies" first hand was incredible. Outside the museum is a beautiful fountain and a great place to sit. This was the most relaxing and enjoyable museum we went to in our entire stay in Paris. And we went a lot of places.
Bravo Monet!. Extraordinary museum. The Monet paintings -- what can be said that hasn't already been said. Don't miss this!

Pop in to see the Water Lilies with a Museum Pass. This one is worth the stop for Monet's water lilies if you have the Museum Pass, they have a fast line to let you in. If I didn't have the pass, I probably would've skipped this museum. The collection wasn't worth the wait in my opinion.
Space designed by Money for his paintings. A nice alternative to the more crowded museums nearby.

Awesome museum. I would suggest visiting only if you are a huge fan of Monet as this is the focus of the museum. My other half was bored as I wondered around taking in Monet's paintings. The beautifully designed rooms are breath-taking and are perfect for these special art works.

A surprising gem. A must-see for art fans and history lovers -- "Water Lilies" is stunning to behold, but the modern art collection on the lower level is what makes this museum worth it.Get the museum pass -- you'll go to the head of the line and get through at least part of the crowds (which can be incredibly annoying in Paris during the holidays).

Wonderful museum. Try to get advance tickets to avoid queues. Sit down and relax in the restaurant a real treat. Dish of the day good value at 15 euros but the room is the star, no booking just turn up and queue.

A GREAT FREE TREAT ON NEW YEAR'S DAY. A " Must See" for any Paris visitor and entry is free of charge on Public Holidays. Much less crowded than Le Louvre and full of interesting works by lots of famous artists and with plenty of room to admire the works properly
A small gem of a museum. The Orangerie is near the Musée d'Orsay and is certainly worth the short walk across the Seine!

A Wonderful Collection of Monet and Other Impressionist. The museum contains the large work of Monet, the Water Lillies. It also has the collection of major art collectors that contain some of the Impressionists. And they let you photograph without flash!
Beautiful. Loved the Monet rooms. Also loved their traveling exhibitions of Spanish painters down stairs. Something a little extra and kind of a continuation of Musee d'Orsay.
monet. giverney and lilly paintings but crowdyhis most masterpieces all the circle of the giverny paintings are arranged in a hormonious way

Color, energy and genius. Don't miss this museum. It is full of surprises with one masterpiece after another. L'Orangerie doesn't make you hunt to find the gems either. They put Monet's Water Lillies right up front, and viewing them is an experience in itself. Then the flow takes you down a level where the galleries are packed with many other masters: Picasso, Renoir, Matisse and Cezanne to name a few. The Musee de l'Orangerie is a very manageable size. If you only have one day to see Paris museums, come here. And if you can choose from any Paris sight and you want to soak up the masterpieces of color and style, make sure you visit l'Orangerie. Note that there is a security checkpoint at the door, and cameras are prohibited - even without a flash - in the Water Lillies viewing rooms.
For Monet Lovers. The water lilies was amazing - but I would only recommend going there if it is free or a reduced price. Less touristy than other museums and great art to be seen.

Love Monet's paintings. I loved all the paintings Monet made for these museum. I could stay here all day and just look at his artwork. I was only sad we couldnt take pictures of it, without flash, to sh are with friends and family back home.
Worth a visit. Nice size of building and good layout for a smaller exhibition

A soothing museum experience - but get a reservation or dual ticket if you can. The queue for those without reservations was not long but it moves very slowly - particularly as those with reservations or the dual museum pass are continually jumping to the front. We started at the top corner of the grass triangle and it took a good 30 minutes to get in (and then another 5-10 inside to actually buy the tickets). So nothing compared to the bigger attractions but unpleasant standing out exposed for that time on a cold, windy, rainy day. So why not bypass it? Easiest way to do this is with the combination "passport" with the musee d'orsay - or via an online reservation. For the latter I believe you will need to be able to print the reservation - a practical challenge for travellers.

Calm and Beautiful Museum. We ran over at 4:25, just before it closed at 5:00, and completely avoided the long lines that we'd seen previous days. The security guards at the front hurried us in and were worried that we only had 35 minutes to visit the museum, but it was lovely to sit and see the Water Lillies without giant crowds or having to wait in line for hours.
Tiny!. Beautiful Monets.I knew the museum was small, but it was so small that we were in and out within 20 minutes, haha.

Great smaller museum to see in Paris. I'd already been to Orsay and the Louvre and we wanted to see a smaller museum. You have to line up outside for about 30 minutes if you don't have a reservation, but it is worth it. The giant water lilly paintings (maybe you've seen Midnight in Paris?) were stunning and the collection on the lower floor is really big and beautiful as well. Definitely recommend!

If you only visit one museum..... If you are only there for one day, or have a busy agenda and can only visit one museum then I suggest that you visit this museum.It has no rooms./areas that you go into and think "that was a waste" everything is really great to look at, and the pinnacle, the waterlilies, are displayed in such a fantastic way (they are displayed much better than the MoMA in New York).

Worth your time. Especially due to it's prime location next to the Louvre, it's not hard to drop by L'orangerie. It's not a large museum, but what it contains is definitely worth your time. Every piece the museum contains, in particular the water lilies, is breathtaking; there is no filler.
Worth queuing for. Loved the Monets! Also a Spanish impressionist exhibition was on whilst we were there which was fantastic!
Don't miss this place!. Less crowds, and the artworks were beautifully displayed and well-lit.

Hidden gem in paris. A must see if you want to see Monet's water lily paintings in their full glory. Really breathtaking artwork... Great impressionist paintings downstairs by Remoir and others. Really loved it!

Queue!. Fabulous art, hideous queues to get to see it. I'm no sporing chicken, so this means I'm tired before I even get into the museum. We were regularly updated on how long our wait would be by a friendly attendant.
Brilliant. The Water Lillies....... say no more! we were lucky to also see an exhibition on Spanish painting which was very interesting. Combined ticket with the D'Orsay. Perfect.

great small museum. What a treat - we accidentally came across the museum and were so glad we did. It was a delightful experience - and if you enjoy a museum that does not make you feel like you need to sprint to see everything - this is it! Small so you can savor and enjoy everything in the museum.

Don't miss this one.. Wonderful temporary exhibit of Spanish painting. Don't miss it! Permanent collection is also excellent. But see that first; save Monet's water lilies till the end, as a quiet time for reflection, or do it first thing and again at the end.
Not my favorite museum. I should have known better but I wanted to experience as much as possible in Paris. I prefer modern art, and this wasn't the best place to experience that!
Great selection of art. The museum downstairs is fab - very concise, some great Spanish art. The big pictures by Monet are OK, nothing special. Some I wouldn't even put on my wall, very dull.

Beautiful.. Beautiful museum where on the first floor you will find only works of C.Monet, but if you go downstairs there is lot of interesting works of different artists of the period of time. Also they have videoteque room and schedule of art or documentary films they show. if you art lover it's a great place to visit to wide your intellectual horizons.
Super Art Gallery. Loved the selection of paintings and the special exhibition of Spanish art was great as I was unfamiliar with many of the artists featured.

A true hidden gem in Paris!. A friend told me about this museum and he was absolutely right! It is a wonderful museum displaying the works of Monet and other artists. I've visited this museum many time now and love going back and taking new friends or family here. Definitely worth a visit. Plan 2 to 3 hrs at a minimum.
Monet Water Lilies!. What else is there to say? It's a must see for anyone who loves impressionist art!

As always enchanting paintings.... Scope and scale is just right - great collection but it is possible to get around it in a reasonable time and without exhaustion. We like the way it is lit and its location is attractive and convenient. A Paris must for those interested in art?

Spectacular impressionist paintings. If you have already been to the Musee d'Orsay and liked it, then you should also visit this gallery. It has similarly-styled works. It also has two purpose-built *huge* room-sized Monet paintings, which have to be seen to be believed.
A must see when visiting Paris. You have to see Monet's enormous lily ponds. This is a smaller museum with a great collection of impressionist paintings.

unreal place. I could hardly imagine such museum – I like Mone and it was very interesting for me to see his panoramic pictures. I know his works from Pushkin museum in Moscow and from exhibitions, but Orangery Museum is some special place.
Wonderful Museum. Not crowded, lovely collection of art and interesting architecture
Waterlillies are amazing. Monet's Waterlillies are amazing, but all of the artwork downstairs is spectacular as well.

nice museum experience for lazy people!. This museum is perfect for people who do not want to spend a whole day in a museum! Not only of course, as you could spend ours just sitting staring at the Waterlilies!
monet paintings. Amazing to see the massive Monet waterlilly paintings on walls specially built to house these treasures
An amazing haven.... Simply to go in and visit the section dedicated to the Claude Monet murals is enough to make anyone"s day......

favorite museum in Paris. Small, but extraordinarily beautiful museum primarily houses Monet's Water Lilies. A collection of other works on the lower level is also worth a look. Much easier to take in (and get into) than D'Orsay or the Louvre.

Beautiful museum.. After 5 visits to Paris, the Musee de l'Orangerie had finally undergone its renovation and was open for visitors. It did not disappoint. The Monet paintings were exquisite and allowed one a restful, thoughtful experience in the large oval room in which they were displayed. The paintings by the great impressionists were not in the large numbers as in D'Orsay but were very approachable. All in all, worth the trip to the south west corner of Jardin des Tuileries.

An Oasis in a City. We visited the Musee de l'Orangerie late in the afternoon - it turned out to be the perfect way to end a hectic day. After the entry formalities, there is a little vestibule before entering the rooms where Claude Monet's Nymphaea are displayed. The Museum guide explains that the empty vestibule decorated with nothing but white paint was conceived as a place to "decompress" - a zone between the frenetic pace outside and the peaceful calm within. And peaceful it was - the two large oval rooms housing Monet's monumental paintings are places for inner reflection. The water lilies themselves are merely a backdrop to reflections of the sky, clouds and gardenscape of Monet's garden at different times of day and season. Float away the stresses of the day like the water lilies! After decompression, you will be in the right frame of mind to contemplate the other artworks in the collection.

It's very nice and small. I thought there would be more to the exhibits, so I was surprised at how small the museum was - it's not a bad thing, and I enjoyed walking through (took about 1 1/2 hours of looking and reading the descriptions). However, unless you want to specifically see these works, you might enjoy the D'Orsay with more options.
Loved this museum. I love Monet, but the display of his work here is something you need to see. Do not miss this museum. You will remember it for a long time.
Fantastic exhibition of Spanish art. Two centuries of Spanish Art was a real surprise. Fantastic paintings by Spanish artists both well known and others I'd never heard of. Just amazing

Monet murals are a must see. Entry fee is only 8 euros. There's more to see than just the Monet murals in the upper level oval rooms, but they are by far the most spectacular.
