If I lived in Paris, I would go sit and stare at the Waterlillies murals at least every couple weeks over a lunch break. The photos do not do these murals justice!
Musee de l'Orangerie. Fabulous! Takes off where the Louvre ends...it's the works from about 1900 on.

Spanish impressionism. At the moment there is a wonderful exhibition of spanish artists which are not generally as well known as their french counterparts but in my opinion they deserve to be more widely seen and enjoyed.
Perfect museum. Monet lilies are gorgeous, impressionist collection is quit interesting surely worse to visit
Breath taking!. Well worth the visit, the Monet lilies were divine :)

Monet's water lilly murals. This is a must see and you can do it in an hour. This museum has been undergoing recontruction for a very long time but it is now open for both the Monet murals and exhibitions of other impressionist artest. It is a small D'Orsey.

Small but a unique must see.. It is easy to overlook this attraction, it is smaller and less advertised but it is a must see. You only need an hour and it is easy to get to. The Monet rooms are amazing and they also have a nice collection downstairs.
Monet. It`s breathless to see Monet frames named Nympheas.
Beautiful Monet. You will be surrounded by Monet's water lillies in many seasons and in different light from various times of day. Floor to ceiling paintings! Don't skip this museum!!

Small and peaceful. Just got back from Paris. The permanent exhibit on the main floor is small but very peaceful. People either walked quietly or sat in the middle to take in the artwork. It was a welcome respite in my day. Downstairs, there was a bit more of a crowd for the special exhibit of Spanish art. There were also works of Renoir, Cezanne and others on the other side of the downstairs level. The approach is also from the lovely Jardin Tuilleries. Perfect for taking a nice stroll through the park and then capping it off with this museum. Overall it was a wonderful experience.
Great waterlillies. Monet, renoir, and all the others, and a stroll in the park afterwards!
excellent. a wide variety of paintings from the impressionist period well laid out and anust for art lovers
Amazing. Surround yourself in Monet. Small museum but worth a look if you have bought a Museum Pass just to sit in the room with floor to ceiling Monet Waterlillies
You like Impressionists?. then you should go there. You need to see Monet's big paintings in the oval room.
A Nice small museum, a quick visit was great. first, I bought a combined ticket to this and the Musee d'Orsay and saved a few bucks, second the large Monets were astounding!

Great gallery away from the crowds of the Lourve. I thought it just had the Monet's Water Lillies but there is more to it than that, downstairs is a wealth of familiar work by Cezanne, Picasso and Renuit.
Well worth a trip. Plus the Water Lillies themselves are breathtaking, you will spend a while staring at them!

Beautiful paintings. This museum containes a lot of paintings by Monet, Renoir, Sezanne, and they are really beautiful. Though I'm not a regular art-museum goer, I was impressed. You can even take pictures there. And then we visited Giverny and saw the famous water-lilies in the flesh)
Favorite Museum in Paris.. It's all about the waterlilies... Thank you Monet.
Yum!. Great chocolate eclairs! Very good coffee and great atmosphere. We didn't eat much here, but it was very good. And great for a small break while viewing the beautiful artwork!

Musee de l'Orangerie - impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. If you like impressionist and post-impressionist paintings the the Orangerie is a great place to vist. Eight huge Water Lilies murals by Claude Monet is the centerpiece of the museum on the ground floor. The lower level contains a variety of paintings as well as special exihibits. The price was reasonable (about 8 euro each if I recall)

Awesome. If you study the Monet pictures of water lilies long enough you get the effect he must have been seeking ... the reflections on the surface of the water, the depths of the lake and the lily pads and flowers on the top. Awesome scale and ambition. Fabulous to visit. The rest of the mused is brilliant too ... But for me really only the Renoirs.
impressionism. if you like the impressionist era this is the museum for you. i enjoyed waterlillies and the museum on a whole
Monet's waterlillies. Everyone rushes to see the Musee d'Orsay (which is a wonderful museum). But to round out your impressionist art education, you must see Monet's paintings here.
Beautiful museum. Smal museum , good experience , easy to walk and see all the paintings .

Do the Double. I wanted to visit her because of the Monets, but found a fabulous exhibition of Spanish art as well (ends in January 2012, so hurry)We made this our first port of call on a wet Saturday morning - a good idea is to buy a 13 Euro ticket that also gets you into the Musee D'Orsay. When we went there later, we only took 10 minutes to get in whereas the main queue would have had us in the rain for over an hour!Back to the Orangerie - take time to pause in the white vestibule before going into the 2 rooms of Nympheas. The size of these pictures is overwhelming. Take time, sit and just look for as long as you want.On the down side - watch out outside. A 'nice' young lady pointed out a wedding ring on the floor, which couldn't possibly be hers and would have loved us to have it - for a finder's fee! My husband doesn't have a wedding ring & her face fell when we said she should hand it in as lost property!
Great little museum. Downstairs, their are oval rooms of Monets' "Waterlillies" that cover the walls of the rooms in it's entirety

Make some time for this one. Well worth the stop, I got a lot out of this small museum. I had heard a lot about the water lilies, but it was really a magical experience to see them in this museum that was specifically designed to house them. We had the paris museum pass, so it didn't cost us any extra and we skipped the line.
A knockout. This lovely museum was one of the highlights of our brief stay in Paris. No where near the crowds of the Louvre, the museum is beautifully designed to display the artwork on display.
Fabulous. My new favorite. The Monet's are worth the trip alone, but the rest of the museum is jam-packed with every major impressionist. It is a feast that should not be missed.
Serene. With all the big museums it can be tiring (especially if trying to fit them all in in 2 days to use a museum pass). This was a nice respite. Loved the Monets.

One of the most calming places in Paris. Just like Monet wanted, this museum's water lily exhibit is one of Paris' treasures. It's amazing to see these huge masterpieces as well as the collection downstairs. The water lilies are some of the most beautiful artwork I've ever seen, so it's worth making a quick trip there just to see it.

Highlight. Don't just look at the water lilies--and actually, when you visit this museum, save them for last to really enjoy them. The entire collection is truly fabulous, so allow an hour and a half to two hours to take it all in. it's not a big collection but everything is worth stopping to see. if you happen to go while the Spanish impressionist special exhibition is on, it is not to be missed. My favorite museum in Paris!

Small, but fabulous. Very small, but worth seeing the waterlilies in this setting. It is also covered by the Paris museum pass, so you can skip any line that might be there. It was very easy to get to, and the building itself was very nice. If you like Monet, it's a must.

Panoramic Beauty!. Not only do they have great paintings on the lower level, but the panoramic Waterlillies are absolutely amazing to see! You can use the Museum Pass or combo ticket from the Orsay, but whatever money you pay for admission is well worth it if you love Impressionists being appreciated in small spaces, quietly.

If you visit one art museum in Paris.... This one is great! Neat presentation of Monet's Water Lilies, and a small but impressive collection of works from other modern painters downstairs (Renoir, Picasso, etc.). I'm not the kind of person who could spend all day in the Louvre or d'Orsay, but this museum was less intimidating, took about an hour and a half to stroll through in its entirety (and that was taking it slow, with an audio-guide), and was a fair price for an impressive collection. There is also a combo ticket for this museum and d'Orsay, so keep that in mind when you purchase tickets if you're thinking of visiting both (which are right across the river from one another, so doing both on the same day would seem to make a lot of sense).
Monet and more. Wonderfully displayed Monet's gift to the nation........together with collection of Derain, Matisse and other modern masters. Well displayed and not overcrowdeded on Sunday morning.

Rooms of Monet Water lillies-unbelievable. There was other fantastic artwork from the famous french, spanish and other masters. But the way they have the Monets displayed are in rooms where you can even sit and meditate or just stare at them and feel like you are in the Giverny gardens.

Nice...but...... This museum houses Monet's water lilies in circular room, and it is really nice to see. The lower level has more art by different artists and is also quite nice. We only had three short days though, and I wish I would have spent more time at the Louvre instead of coming here.

A hidden gem!. This museum was not overly hyped in my books and we almost over looked it. But because it stood between the Louvre and the Eiffel tower we stopped in to have a look. I'm so glad we did! It is one of my favorite places in Paris now! A wonderful collection of art that I had never seen before and by several artists that I had not heard of. Very educational and because it's a little off the beaten path you aren't bombarded by hoards of annoying tourists who don't appreciate art. It seemed like more of a local museum where "the locals" go.

Impressive!. Those huge Monet canvases are really a sight to see! I love Monet and this was worth it. No lines and not crowded and right off place de la Concorde. There are also some other wonderful paintings there, as well. Covered with Paris Museum Pass. We are glad we went.

More than just Monet's waterlilies. Excellent impressionist paintings in the museum's permanent collection downstairs. The temporary exhibition (From Zuloaga to Picasso, finishing 9th January 2012) was well worth the visit. The Waterlilies are the highlight of the display, but the experience suffered from low light levels.
A great alternative to the Louvre. You see Monet's Waterlilies and a number of other wonderful works of art in a smaller setting.

Outstanding. Possibly my favorite museum visited. Monet's waterlilies were just breathtaking and the collection of art downstairs was very well put together and contained a lot of stunning pieces I had never seen before. I would actually rate l'Orangerie and Orsay better than the Louvre which just goes to show how excellent they are.

Simply stunning!. Pictures of Monet's water lillys in art books do not do justice to the originals, which are HUGE, occupying the entire wallspace of one of the rooms. We sat for nearly an hour, just absorbing their incredible beauty. Many other Impressionist paintings are also displayed, but "les Hyacinthes" were the highlight.

A perfect little and yet quite extensive museum. The waterlillies are just stunning, and even if had great expectation, they were filled. These painting are still major masterpieces in the world art. An additional surprise were the exhibitions downstairs, of which at least one was temporary (and a very interesting one on early 1900-century Spanish paintings).If you are busy, and without seeing any other museum this time, I would recommed a visit here!

Water lillies all around. You can visit it either before or after a stroll in the Jardin des Tuileries- the museum is situated on the right of the entrance to the gardens. If you buy a double ticket Orsay/Orangerie you save some ! The 2 halls displaying the waterlillies by Monet are bewildering....just sit and adjust your view point to take in the colours, the beauty of it all. After you've had enough of these, check out the rest-I highly recommend the paintings by Marie Laurencin-whom I discovered on this occasion.

If you love Monet's Water Lillies, then this musee is a must.. I sat for an hour in the room where the enormous Water Lilly paintings are housed and gazed in awe at the beauty that we are all familiar with. The originals are not to be missed - the size alone is awe-inspiring. As with most musee's in Paris during September there was a long queue but I am very glad that I persevered as it was well worth the wait.

Not to be missed!. If you like Monet's waterlily series - this is a must for your Paris list. And even if you don't - you will be a believer after viewing these magnificent impressionistic specimens, bathing in perfect light. This museum is a gem! Small and very manageable. A great place to relax and soak in some color for a few hours!

Great to see Impressionist Paintings. Great place to visit for a lot of famous Impressionist paintings. Many paintings were out on loan but overall it was great to see the "originals' of many paintings.
Loved Musee de l'Orangerie. What a wonderful treat - I wanted to go back a second time.

I love this little museum! (and I'm not really into art!). I'm really not in to art - I cannot tell a lie! However, one must view the Monet's on display at the l'Orangerie...I could wax poetic for the next several hours but will restrain myself only in saying, I have a deep, abiding and true respect for the work of Monet - for the first time I truly get why a painting is deemed a masterpiece...they truly are a must see.And while you're there...definitely check out the downstairs exhibit - wonderful works of art by masters...I loved turning corners and recognizing pieces I had seen pictures...
Ok museum. I am not a fan of this museum. Waste of my time when there are far more extensive collections throughout the city.

Stunning. Monet's eight great paintings of waterlillies are on display here. To sit in the room and view them is realy inspring. Try to go there when the crowds are less as you will not have people waliking past you all of the time
worth it!. very impressive collection, not as crowded as other museums, perfect for anyone who loves impressionist art
Didn't know what to expect.... Didn't know what to expect but absolutely loved this museum. The downstairs is worth a quick walkthru, but the room sized paintings on the main floor are incredible.
Wonderful. I didn't know what to expect. I'd been to Paris on several occasions, but hadn't been here. It took my breath away, the paintings were absolutely beautiful.

Bitesize Culture. This was such a great gallery. I couldn't believe the waterlilies (Les Nympheas). The best bit was, by the end of the gallery I wasn't exhausted by all the art, which is usually the case. Also, it wasn't too busy.

Very interesting. This museum is known mainly for its Monet collection. I had not known much about Monet and initially viewed his murals with some interest but it wasn't until I saw a video about his life and work that I came to fully appreciate the art; in part his theme was to help people avoid the turmoil of modern life, and in his time to get people away from thinking about World War I.
One of my top 5 museums in the world. Superb museum. You must must must go. That's all I will say so I don't spoil the surprise of it.

Mini Vacation Within a Vacation. What took me so long to get to this museum?? What an experience! Monet's Waterlilies are certainly stunning and this museum is unique in that you get to sit in the middle of the room have a 365 degree view. I was a little surprised security wasn't tighter but the crowd seemed lulled into a deeply calm state by the artwork. The other floors contained pieces of art I've only ever dreamed about seeing in person. What was fantastic is that one can stand in front of a Renior for as long as one wants and not get sucked along with the flow of the masses. I've never had such time to admire the art at the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay. I've never enjoyed a museum more than this one. Go! You won't be disappointed!

Good for Monet fans.. The water lillies are the main attraction. Some other nice pieces and full of tourists waitng to have their picture taken! Tourists are not necessarily art experts nor do they always appreciate what they are seeing. However they do fill the museums up!

Amazing waterlillies. Even if you aren't convinced by the Impressionists, Monet's giant canvasses of waterlillies are worth seeing. The entire atmosphere of the two rooms lends to their calming feeling. The collections in the downstairs space are wonderful - especially the temporary exhibitions.

this museum and all of the others below are wonderful.. I disliked nothing except or the french - late october/early november is considered quite cold - so the heat was turned up to roast in all of the museums - too too warm.that is it.
my favorite in paris. wow @ the spanish art on the lower levels. I also very discovered the intriguing work of Marie Laurencin here!!!
For amateurs of impressionist art. Don't go on week end, otherwise you have to wait hours to get in the Orangerie.
Beautiful location. Uncluttered views of Monet water lilies, displayed as he intended.

Wondrous!. This is a great little museum, the highlight being the full sized panoramic Waterlily canvases that Monet created especially for this building. It's also a small enough museum that if you want to see some highlights of Parisian Impressionism but tire easily, are ill, infirm, elderly or with small children, you can spend a pleasant but short trip to see some masterpieces.

A nice place to while away an hour. Quite expensive at 7.5euros, considering the louvre is 10euros. But a relaxing place to enjoy two circular rooms with monet's waterlillies. Some interesting modern paintings on the floor below, including matisse and picasso.

Don't wait in the long line.. This museum is pretty small, but the line was crazy long (probably since the museum is small they don't allow that many people in at one time). We had a Paris Pass, which allowed us to breeze into other museums, but we had to wait for about 15 minutes to get into Musee de l'Orangerie. Once we got in, we were out in 15 minutes because there weren't that many exhibitions. It's worth checking out if you have a lot of time, but if you don't I would recommend choosing the Louvre and Musee de Orsay over this Musee de l'Orangerie.

Don't miss this museum. Five minutes from the Louvre so don't miss this museum. The collection here is worth going is only for the Monet lillies that surround you in the special gallery. The crowd is small so you get to enjoy 'just taking' in the art.

Beautiful way to spend a few hours. Great collection of art. The two rooms of Monet are a great way to start your tour as they get you in a relaxed and reflective state of mind. The size of the museum is just perfect - not overwhelming but you see many great artists in a manageable amount of time. Highly recommend.
We Loved It!. Monet's water lilies and so much more - take your time there is so much to see and appreciate.

Monet's Waterlillies!. Do not miss this museum! The waterlillies are spectacular! They are eight very large pieces well presented in two rooms. We went just an hour before closing and it was a quiet time to view the pictures.After you enjoy them, you can go downstairs to see an interesting collection of modern art.
a quiet, airy museum. a quiet, airy museum - a big departure from the JAMMED Louvre

calm exhibition. Lacking the crowds of the other museum, this place has the space to exhibit its pieces without being rudely pushed out of the way by the tourbus organized commentated 20 man tour groups.

So glad that I found out about this museum!. With only 3 days in Paris, we had very little time to see everything. But I am so glad that the last morning there we hired a shuttle to take us around to the last few places, and this was one of them. I love Monet's water lilies, so once I learned about this museum and the incredible displays in the round rooms, I knew that we had to go here. It is a not-to-be-missed museum especially if you are a Monet fan. I had never even heard about it until I did the research for this trip. Don't miss it! It's on the Museum Pass, so free if you have that.

A little gem of a museum. There are the extensive collections and big crowds at the Louvre and D'Orsay, then there is this gem. Monets rooms are worth the price of admission alone, but in addition you also see works by Picasso,Dali, Degas, Modigliani to name but a few. Lovely Museum if you are into impressionist art.
Monet lilies!. Not as famous as maybe Louvre, but it is phenomenal. Monet's lilies on walls! Not to be missed!N.B.: Very close to Louvre, by the way
Perfect Treasures. The size was just right to be seen in a couple of hours, I love it

Tranquility in Paris. This is the place I go for some peace and quiet. Unlike most of the other Parisian museums, with people buzzing all over the place to try to see everything, L'Orangerie is an oasis of calm. The oval design of the rooms housing Monet's Water lilies is minimalistic and beautiful.

Make it a day of Art!. Started the day at the Louvre, walked through the Tuilleries and admired those gorgeous sculptures, had a coffee, then onto L'Orangerie. I absolutely loved the tranquility of the water lilies and the other art on the floor below was also worthwhile. We then walked across the bridge and onto Musee D'Orsay and saw so may pictures I'd only ever seen in a book...a magnificent day of Art, all so close and so accessible.
monet magic. a visit to the waterlillies is a serene experience in the hustle and bustle of paris
they took everything to the Orsay!!. Monet's murals are still here, and well worth the visit, but everything else of real interest is in the Orsay.

Good, but not great. Monet's waterlilies are amazing, but you cant take pictures and staff are watching you all the time to make sure no-one does - kinda ruins the tranquil mood! Nice collection of Renoir etc downstairs and a special Spanish exhibition was on when we visited with Picasso's, Dali's etc. Worth a visit, but wouldn't be top of my list.
One of the Best in Paris. Downstairs in the main gallery is among the most amazing spectrum of historic paintings imaginable. A total surprise - we cam for the Manet but liked the gallery MUCH better
Get here early. Nice to see the paintings first hand and not on a postcard. Get to the Orangerie early to avoid the queues and give yourself some space.

Impressionists galore...loved it!. We had just traveled to Monet's house and Japanese gardens the day before, so it was nice to see his artwork in the museum the next day. I was also thrilled to see a few VanGoghs and Klimt. We ate at the cafe on the top floor and loved the huge clock window. We only wish that more

Great small museum to see Monet's waterlilies. Had to wait years before this museum was renovated,...well worth the wait. Beautiful display of Monet's waterlilies in two oval shaped rooms with rotating exhibits on the ground floor.

Refreshing and Calming. The Musee de l'Orangerie was a highlight of a recent trip to Paris. Monet's "white" room that transitions you into a calm place after being in the hustle and bustle of the Paris streets is genius. I was able to reflect peacefully in both of the rooms that are devoted to Monet's Water Lilies and The Willows. The museum was chock full of works from Monet's contemporaries. It was more intimate then the Musee D'Orsay and less crowded. I did enjoy both museum's but if you haven't been and are a fan of the D'Orsay then this should be a must visit for your next trip to Paris.

Terrific renovation. We saw the current exhibit Spain between the two centuries Loved it.. Lovely (also super accessible) renovation of the building. Truly enjoyed the current show of Spanish painters entering the 20th century, and of course a total delight to see Monet's water lily murals.

My absolute favorite museum in Paris!. Think 60 foot Monet paintings against curved stark white walls. It was like nothing I had ever seen before! It takes about 2-3 hours to get through this spectacular museum. Definitely worth or morning or afternoon in Paris! Buy a pass with Musee de Orsay, you can walk between the 2...they are about 3 blocks from each other!
i liked. i came here to see the matiss paintings but there is also many other masters works
Stunning. the manner of display of these wonderful Monets really adds to their beauty

Best in class. We have gone to the Orangerie since it was reopened after a hugely delayed completion of the renovation. The settings in the oval room displays makes the "Waterlillies" seem like you are looking at them in real time. The permanent exhibit of two dealers personal collection is also fantastic. There is usually a line but it moves pretty quickly since the museum is not that large. At time FNAC sells timed tickets, there's one on Champs Elysee.
Must see Monet. The Monet painings are a must see. Try to go on a quiet day and juist sit on the bench in the middle.Sometimes interesting temporary exposistions.
Ultimate Monet. Seeing the waterlilies, simply amazing a perfect display. Plus other exhibits our visit included a comprehensive exhibit of photographer Diane Arbus' career.

An overlooked gem. Excellent, free to get in if you're under 25. House Monet's Water Lillies in two large, circular rooms with multitudes other impressionist paintings. Not too crowded, definitely worth a visit.
A wonderful place to view art. The Monet's are great. The room where Monet's murals are is very tranquil and soothing. The whole place was great

Hidden gem. This gallery has two beautiful waterlily rooms, a gift from Monet to the people of Paris. I found it very relaxing and would highly recommend a visit to the gallery. Try and go before it gets busy later in the morning.

A must visit. We went on a guided tour in English led by a Curator and it was worth every cent. We got an in depth guide to the building and it's artwork which she made extremely interesting. It should have lasted 1 & a half hours but continued for nearly 2 hours.
Finally open again.. This museum was closed on my previous visits to Paris. Upstairs is great but downstairs is fantastic. What a collection of impressionistic art!

Oval rooms showcase Monet's waterlilies wonderfully. If you are a fan of Monet's waterlilies then you must visit the Orangerie. This museum does not have too many other great paintings - some but not lots. The guided tour in English using the headphones is very worthwhile.
Must see. Beautiful huge water lilly paintings , not as overwhelming as other museums

The Orange Trees Are Gone... But Not the Nymphs.... A small museum on the corner of the Louvre's grounds. The first two rooms upstairs hold the work of Monet's work in a wonderful way that makes you feel like you are sitting in the centre and looking out at the swamps around you.Downstairs concentrates on Jean Walter and Paul Guillaume collections which include works by Monet, Picasso, Modigliani and others and concentrates mostly on the impressionist period of these artists. Certainly not as great a collection as that in the Musee d'Orsay, but a nice and interesting collection.

Impressionist lover's dream!. We visited the Musee de l'Orangerie on a whim (we had the Paris Museum Pass, which covers the museum). It was amazing! The Monet works are incredible, and the museum houses a number of other paintings by well known impressionists. During our trip, we also went to the Orsay, but their Impressionist galleries were closed, which made me especially glad we visited the Orangerie!

Great Museum. The Building is amazing
Great formal restaurant
easy to get to and navigate

Best Kept Secret in Paris. Since "Midnight in Paris", I can only imagine that this petite bijou of a museum will be having crowds come this spring. And why not, it hosts a lovely collection and boasts spectacular Monets.

Special Gallery - Spectacular Works of Monet. Not overly crowded, but with a beautiful collection. The oval rooms with the series of Monet lilies is as spectacular now as it was when I first saw it 30+ years ago. Buy a ticket good for admission at both the L'Orangerie and the Musee D'Orsay.

waiting in the queu for nothing. We needed to wait about 30 minutes before we could enter the museum, however, the paintings shown are not comparable with the ones you can see in the Musee D'Orsay, which is close by. So, skip this queu and go directly to D'Orsay to see the most impressive paintings from Manet, Monet, Cezanne, Renoir etc.

Nice, intimate museum. After spending time at the Louvre, this was a nice break from the chaos of that museum. This is much smaller, but that does not mean its not as good. The waterlilies are beautiful, and the exhibit downstairs also has great work by Renoir and Picasso, just to name a few. Find the time in your busy Parisian schedule and visit this place.
lovely but limited. nice place , but not much to see there, basically 2 rooms. peaceful

Enjoyable experience. We enjoyed walking through this museum on our last day in Paris. We happened to be in Paris during fashion week and were treated to seeing several of the designers and models right out in front of the museum after their runway show. It definitely added a touch of excitement to our experience. The museum is small but has beautiful impressionist and post-impressionist art. It is located in the Place de la Concorde. Monet's Water Lilies were stunning to see and possibly one of the best collections we saw.

Amazing impressionist collection!. I studied art history in college and I am a great fan of French impressionist painting. Monet once said that impressionist artists don't see the world the way it looks with pain or problems but the way they would like the world to be. That being said this place carries a vast amount of beautiful Impressionism. I took my mother who is in a wheelchair and the staff here was very kind and helpful with guiding us around. We had such a lovely time here. I recommend getting the museum pass to save time and avoid lines in the museums it's money well spent. Everyone who appreciates French art should come to this place while in Paris.

Great Museum, it's a definite plus for Paris!. When people go to Paris, they immediately think about the Louvre museum. But this L'Orangerie museum is one which you should NOT miss! Most people know this museum due to the Monet water lilies display on the first floor BUT, please do go to the basement where the Paul Guillaume collection is. You will find hundreds of paintings from Renoir, Cezanne, Manet, Monet, Picasso, Dali, etc which you will thoroughly enjoy,
Monet experience. We went to the Orangerie Oct 7 and there was no line. A lovely experience and very tranquil.

So - so. Went here because the Musee d'Orsay was closed due to a strike. It was okay, but didn't have near the number of works of art that the Orsay has. The space is small and it is hard to move around in as well.
Charming Paris. I love Paris for its beauty of architecture. There is so much History connected with the city. Its streets are so enjoyable to wander. I did not find anything I disliked.
best musee. i am not an art major,but this is a must see.there was more here to see than in the d arcy as that has some construction going on.a must see.

Water Lilies to Time to Relax. We went on a free Sunday about 11:00. Short half hour wait to enter. This small museum is wonderful. The rooms that display Monet's water lilies are unique, designed to have you relax and walk around the wall panel size paitings. . The second floor are various selections of the Walter Gullaume Collection. This can easily be done in the morning and then another attraction in the afternoon.
More than Monet. The huge scale Monet's are worth the trip alone, but downstairs the Matisses, Renoirs, and some Picasso's were mindblowing.
More than expected. Set aside many hours to spend checking this out. There are signs asking not to take photos but does not deter others.

Monet ... Monet... beautiful Monet paintings and a great collection of Spanish painters. Just visit it.. It does not take long. The queue outside looks scary but it moves fast and the museum makes sure the employees managing this unpleasantness are friendly to the visitors. The basement has an exhibit of Spanish artists at the beginning of the 20th century. This collection is phenomenal... a must see in my opinion.

Monet full sized. the 360 degree lily pads were the largest attraction among many. This museum seemed not very crowded considering the attractions there. We went here first and bought our museum pass so we wouldn't have to wait in line at any of the others.

Water Lilies and more!. The opportunity to study the works of the "Masters" makes this wonderful museum a must see. There is no other place to really understand the beauty of Claude Monet's series from his Giverny gardens.

If you like Monet, you have to see this. I have never seen a galery that comes close to this. two oval rooms with huge Monet paintings left me speechless. The rest of the gallery ia nice. Being relativell small, one can really enjoy avery painting without feeling the urge to see more. If you like impressionasts, you have to see this gallery.
Monet at its best. fantastic little museum which does not get too crowded.
360 degrees of Monet. Water lillies surround you in 2 different rooms. Wow!

Excellent small dose of popular modern artists. I love this museum for its impressionist and post-impressionist art and Monet's Water Lilies paintings. It is a small museum so it need not take more than two hours but the artists are first-rate and some of the most popular--Renoir, Monet, Cezanne, Picasso--so they deserve more time if you want to spend it there. It is located inside the Tuillerie Gardens and near the Place de le Concorde, and the Eglise Madeleine so I like to combine a visit to four places in a morning or afternoon. Very accessible to the metro. Closed Tuesdays.
Surprising exhibit in a small museum. Contains a large amount of Spanish and other lesser known contemporaries of Picasso and other well know painters.

So much for so little. The Monet Waterlillies are the show upstairs. Monet himself designed these rooms to showcase his paintings. But downstairs is almost as awesome: Renoirs, Cezannes, Picassos. It's a wow!
A must for Monet fans... A lovely gallery which displays the glorious waterlillies which stretch across the walls in two rooms as well as many other works by other artists.

Beautiful Building-Fantastic Art. The exhibition of Spanish art was fantastic and introduced me to many wonderful works I had never seen. The presentation of the Monet waterlilies was exceptional. I would definitely recommend this as a museum not to miss.
Water Lilly Heaven. This museum was a treat. We were awed by the four huge water lilly cavasses displayed in the two infinity shaped oval rooms!

Can't make it to Giverny? See Monet's Water Lilies here. The museum is tiny compared to the Louvre, however if you can't make it to Giverny, you can see Monet's water lilies here. It's a quick stop and takes less than an hour to get through. Great to do if you have the Paris Museum pass.

Little known gem. If you like Monet's works, look here! There are 2 vast oval rooms which house the giant 'water lillies' canvases and an underground gallery with some excellent work by artists of the same period. Whilst we were there there was a Spanish temporary exhibition with pictures from Picasso, Miro, Dali etc. Superb! You see paintings from Picasso that show him in a completely different light.The only downside to the visit is the queue for the ladies toilets, be prepared for at least a 5 minute wait!

Excellent little museum. After walking round the huge museums of Paris, this one was much easier on the feet! Great collection of paintings - Monet, obviously - but also some excellent Spanish works as well.
Monet's lillies worth it. Not as much "painting for your buck" but the round room with the waterlillies paintings is something special

Waterlilies as they are ment to be seen.. Wow, this is a fantastic museum with a fantastic collection. We had to come back a second day because we did not know it was closed on Tuesday’s. It was worth it, this museum like any other place in Paris is best viewed early. We got there as the doors opened and it was almost as if we had a private tour of the place but by the time we left, there was a line waiting to get in. The paintings are amazing; you are able to stand very close and to see such wonderful works of art. This is a must for anyone who loves impressionism

Nice snapshot of impressionism. Unfortunately Orsay was closed due to a strike so we went to Orangerie as an afterthought. But it was a very unexpected treasure. You will see some great art there and from the noted masters Renoir, Monet, Cezanne and Picasso. Both my wife and I left the museum feeling very satisfied and happy.

My favorite art museum in Paris. Wow - this museum is a gem. It is small enough to digest in a relatively short visit and to see Monet's water lilies makes a visit mandatory when you are in Paris. Silly me, I so wanted to visit this museum I arrived just as they opened to avoid any lines but apparently that wasn't necessary. This museum doesn't attract the crowds of the Louvre or D'Orsay. If you can only see one museum while in Paris - definitely go to the Orangerie and skip the rest. Wonderful!
Stunning collection. Monet's Water lilies were inspiring, and the rest of the collection was excellent, arranged by artist. Also, after the Louvre the size felt much more do-able.
What can I say?. The 8 enormous Monet's left me speechless. I was transported back to my visit to Giverny.

monet's water lillies and willows are the star of the show here. On our recent trip to Paris we were frustrated by the strike which closed the Musee d'Orsay and searched for an alternative to get our impressionist "fix". The l'Orangerie just across the Seine from the Orsay was a delight. The two most impressive rooms are on the first floor where huge panels of Monet's waterlillies and willow tree paintings circle the rooms.
Wow.... Stayed in Giverny for two days. This provided closure. Magnificent

Impressive building and a good visit. We saw the waterlilies panels on the same day we saw Monet's Giverny. Highly recommended!We went later in the day (3PM) and walked right in...not crowded at all. It is not an overwhelming museum to visit...nice size.
our favorite museum. Beautiful art nicely displayed with room to view despite the crowds.
Classic Waterlilies. If you like the Waterlilies and impressionists this is a dream museum.
Amazing Little Art Gallery. Most people go for the amazing Monet gallery, but the tiny hall of Renoirs was my favourite.

A lovely respite from the bigger museums. We had not been to the Orangerie on our last trip and the renovations made the museum so full of light that the Monets were truly shown to their best advantage. The collection of other works by impressionists etc. is also exemplary. Get there early and enjoy !

Follow up your visit here to Giverny, France. we had visited the L'Orangerie during our 2010 trip to Paris, so this year we used ParisVision minibus to soujourn over to the west side of town (75km) to the quaint village of Giverny. If you like the Monet Waterlillies, you owe it to yourself to pay a visit here. It only costs you a half day.
Breathtaking. The images of water lilies will stay in my mind for a long time. Simply marvellous.

Great collection of impressionists. Close to other Museums, great part of the city.
We had a great day, and saw a lifetime of memories!

Very pleasant surprise, Monet gorgeous, but other amazing art, as well!. After a day of shopping and walking down St. Honore, my husband and I headed through the Tuileries Gardens. First, before heading the Musee, spend some time sitting in the chairs around the fountain in the garden! It was warm and we were in heavenly bliss, so relaxed! We then headed through the gardens to the Musee de l'Orangerie after a long day of walking, and what a lovely way to end our day! The gardens themselves are very beautiful, romantic, and help you imagine what life was like in 1800's Paris.We went straight into Les Nympheas, the two oval round rooms dedicated to Monet's exquisite and serene paintings of his gardens. I found the history fascinating, that the exhibit was created during his lifetime, but he died shortly before it opened. The beauty of his work mirrored our restful and romantic walk through the Tuileries, and now I can't wait to visit Giverny. We then headed downstairs to a special exhibit of Paul Guillaume's collection of outstanding artists of his time -- Cezanne, Renoir, Matisse, Picasso...no way! Wow! This museum was small and easy to see in an hour, a great "pow" in a small space. Excellent experience overall.

amazing Monet exhibition. The most important Monet exhibition with large scale waterlily panels around two oval rooms. Sit and indulge ! Downstairs best cross section of impressionists and lead in to modern day painters (like Picasso, Dali, Soutine etc). Don't miss.

Only took about an hour...maybe less...just ok, but if you love Monet..... Nice, but not great in my book. I love Monet and all, but the huge lilies panorama was just so so.....the rest was good, but not eye popping. It was also at the end of our trip after I cant count how many museums.....plus I know they rotate the works, but the Monet is the draw here for most.

Surprise gem. A great experience to view Monet and other impressionists in a relaxed and calm environment, there were little crowds and all the artwork is well presented to view, the round room with Monets water views from his garden was a tranquil restfull room to sit and take in the beauty of his painting

How could you not love it?. This is an absolute must-see if you are in Paris. Not only a lovely gallery, but a great location: walk through the Tuileries, stop for coffeee or lunch among the trees, watch the children palying with boats on the pond ...(sigh) ...heaven! Note however that this gallery has no cafe (but you can go out for coffee in the Tuileries and come back in again on the same ticket so long as it is the same day. you will however have to queue again!)
Small museum-worth a visit. Take a few minutes and sit in the room where you are surrounded by Monet's waterlilies-it's very relaxing
Fantastic Art Museum. The Claude Monet exhibit is amazing it fills two rooms, I thought it was beautiful. They also have some Renoirs and you can take pictures in this museum which is really nice.

Amazing. I went to this museum with no idea of the size and shape of the paintings, so I truly was in awe when I saw the paintings running the entire lengths of the curved walls. They were truly beautiful. Amazingly the museum is not very crowded, so you have an opportunity to really enjoy at your leisure.
Loved it. Beautiful. Enjoyed it thoroughly. Quick to get through which is nice after the other huge museums.
one of the nicer museums. very nice, beautiful artwork. art is well arranged. easy to enjoy. audiotape was very informative. arrived at opening time. became more crowed as the day wore on.

This was our favorite museum in Paris. We love the small galleries. There was not a room we didn't love. Renoir, Modigliani,Monet. We did the whole museum in about 2 hours. It was perfect. I suggest getting a museum pass so that you can go to multiple museums and not feel rushed. This is also a better value.

My favorite two paintings in Paris are here. If you only go here to see Monet's two water lily in the round paintings, it's well worth the price of admission. These masterpieces are so well displayed, you feel like you are sitting on the ground being surrounded by the beauty of Monet's backyard. Excellent painting, excellent presentation. Do not miss. And it is not necessary to dedicate a lot of time to this museum. There are many more very good paintings on the lower level of L'Orangerie. but the water lilies are awesome.
worth going for "The Nympheas". Beautifully displayed Monet's waterlilys are worth the entrance fee alone, but the rest of the museum is very good too

One of the secret highlights of Paris. Mon dieu! we were so lucky to accidentally venture into this little jewel of a museum we wanted to share the news - for me this was a don't miss museum. Unlike the Pompidu (which is magnificent) it's small, intimate and manageable. ENJOY!
Great Museum, Especially If You're a Monet Fan. You have to see the huge Monet paintings of his water lillies at this museum.

An unsusal setting of impressionists and modern masterpieces. The huge attraction here are the 8 giant Monet murals displayed in two rooms, representing the water lilies at certain times of the day on Monet's property in Giverny . ( You must combine going to this museum and a day trip to the real garden in Giverny, an hour outside Paris). It is a very peaceful collection with seating in the center so the viewer can study these panoramic scenes. Audio guides are available for further explanation of the art. There is also a wonderful collection of Paul Guillaume , an art collector and dealer of modern and impressionist painters . Here you can view exhibits of Renoir, Picasso, Matisse . There is a boutique and bookstore where you can purchase replicas of almost everything you have seen. There is a lift for the handicapped, and an auditorium which shows documentary films in French , some with English titles about Picasso , Matisse and others.. There is no cafe on the premises, which is a shame because you do work up an appetite and thrist. The museum is closed on Tuesdays. I found this museum bright and airy with attractive rampways to walk. If you watch the documentary in the auditorium, the time spent here will be about 2 hours.

Awesome. We were unprepared for the beauty of the Monet water lilies exhibition. It is exquisite. Go early so you can enjoy the peaceful setting the Monet envisaged. I would have liked to visit Monet's home and garden where he painted the water lilies but we didn't have time to do both.

Could sit in Monet Lilypad Rooms All Day!. Monet's Lilypads are so awesome! Thanks, Monet, for giving these painting to Paris! Downstair painting were also wonderful! Don't miss downstairs or Monet Lilypads!

An underrated gem in Paris.. Visited this place during a recent stay in Paris. Its a nice little museum full of great impressionist art, the main highlight being two rooms full of Monet's, including Water Lilies. Its not a very big museum, a visit of under two hours is good enough. Plus its not very far from the Louvre, in fact I managed to visit both on the same day that I was there.
Nice, but not 1st choice. Only go to this museum if you really like Monet or if you have gone many times to Paris and want something different.

Stunning, a must see. A relatively small museum, laid out exquisitely. Monet's iconic water lilies are a must see, but there are loads more paintings exhibited that are also worthwhile. A good selection for everyone, I'm not a Picasso fan but there is a small but diverse range on display. Matisse's works are divine! The Renoirs and Cezannes are also gorgeous.

If you like Monet - You'll Love this..!!. Not one of the biggest museums, but for lovers of Monet a must. We went with our "Paris Pass" which enabled us to miss the queuing. The impact of the large paintings was awesome.

Monet's Water Lilies in a Fabulous Setting!. I took my ten-year-old grandson to Paris with Monet, his gardens and his paintings at the top of our must-see list. We included the Orangerie in our museum day with the Paris museum pass...well worth the price! A chance to see his water lilies in the setting that he had planned for their display made for a life-long memory for us! There are eight large panels displayed in two oval rooms with sky lights above, giving the feeling of actually being at Monet's water garden in Giverny. We had been to Giverny to see it in person just the day before, so that helped to make the paintings even more meaningful. The museum was not crowded at all, giving us a chance to see the paintings at our leisure. My grandson enjoyed comparing the view of the paintings from the center of the room and then up close to study Monet's technique. He found it interesting that some random-looking brush strokes can turn into water lilies when viewed from a distance! We did not spend any time visiting the rest of the museum since we also had the nearby Louvre and Musée d'Orsay on our list for the day. The water lilies were certainly one of the highlights of our visit! If you are there with children, be sure to allow time for sailing a little boat in the fountain at the Tuileries gardens...right beside the Orangerie. It was a nice little chance for some down time between museum visits.

Go for the water lillies. Two rooms display Monet's water lillies in natural day light. This is the best way to see them. The rest of the museum is refreshingly small. It is easy to see this museum without wearing yourself out.

A must see for lovers of Monet or Renoir. If you appreciate the work of Monet and Renoir don't miss this museum! Monet's vast water lilly paintings engulf the visitor and the 24 Renoir paintings downstairs make for a special treat. Cezanne and other's works are icing on the cake! My impressionist loving daughter wanted to return to this museum for a second time during our stay in Paris. I was prepared to buy another ticket but amazingly the person checking tickets allowed us to return on our same ticket!
One of our two favorite museums.. The Monet exhibit of his water lillies is astounding!

Better than I expected especially if you love impressionist paintings. I was very lucky as I arrived just before the museum opened and since I had Museum Pass, I was first to enter the museum. So I had Monet's Nymphéas room all to myself for pictures until the other tourist came in. Do not miss the impressionist paintings in the basement level.Note: You can take photos in this museum
Must see if you love Monet. Small museum, easily accessible. If you've never seen Monet's Waterlillies it's a must visit. Beautifully displayed, quiet and peaceful. No lines at all when we visited.

My favorite..,Monet. Ii's not the first time I've visited these works, but the first i've dared to touch lightly on his strokes. I'd never do anything to damage his work, but to have it so closely available, it's magnificence is amazining and life-changing for me as an artist. I was in tears to be in those oval rooms where his lily paintings were so prevailed!
perfect. if you love Monet you cannot miss this . Lovely and peaceful chance to see Waterlillies as they should be seen . Then head to Giverny if you can to see the gardens that inspired him .

Visit with an inclusive discounted Musee D'Orsay ticket as well. Great place to go to sit relax and immerse yourself in the wonderful murals, but not with 500 other people around you.Visit spoiled purely by numbers. Must be lovely out of the tourist season.

Only spoiled by the photographers. Water lily paintings are amazing - it needs a few minutes of sitting to take in each one of the 8 paintings, and to allow the filtered light to change, so allow sufficient time. Sadly, people are allowed to photograph, not just the paintings but one another in front of them, which spoils the view somewhat. Immediate access with a museum pass (queue can build up quickly for those without). There are also galleries below the water lily galleries - worth allowing time for these too.

Stunning murals!. This museum is a gem! There is a lovely art gallery downstairs but the two rooms on the main floor housing Monet's waterlily murals steal the show! It's very close to the Louvre. If you're planning your itinerary, you can make Place de la Concorde your first stop, visit L'Orangerie, and then wander through the gardens as you head towards the Louvre.

Simply Beautiful. This is a small museum and easy to miss but so worth going. It was built to house Monet's waterlily paintings and is the perfect gallery for them. It was not crowded like the Louvre can be and so much more manageable. The staff were very informative.

My daughter's favorite gallery. We arrived in mid-afternoon after a morning or so in the Lourve - special to walk in the Jardin des Tuileries and find it. We had purchased Paris Museum Passes and waited in a short line a few minutes at best. It is amazing to experience Claude Monet's Nympheas or Water Lily paintings in person. The eight paintings, approx. 6 1/2 ft. high X 42 ft. long are displayed in two oval rooms all along the walls under direct diffused daylight as was originally intended by Monet. You are enveloped by the colors, and the movement, and the mood. There is seating in the middle of each room, so one can absorb and contemplate. The museum also houses other great impressionist works by Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso and many more that were in the Paul Guillaume collection - there are small models of his apartment circa the 20's, 30's with many famous paintings.. Go.
Breathtaking waterlilies.... This Museum is the best. Small, but not too small, with beautiful filtered light on Monet's waterlilies. A lovely building and wonderful to visit.

Upstairs is amazing, downstairs is just ok.. The upstairs of this small museum is amazing. 2 big oval rooms lined with long Monet paintings. The downstairs features art by other artists, but after the amazingness of the first floor, it seemed a bit dull.We had quite a long line to get in. People who had some sort of museum passport seemed to be getting in quicker. Also, we purchased a joint ticket for a bit more money, which got us into Musee d'Orsay without having to wait in line there.

My absolute favorite Museum in Paris!. If you are a fan of Monet - this is a place you must visit. This is where his huge Waterlily paintings reside. There are benches in the middle with 360 degrees of Monet to be viewed in natural light. This place moves me to tears every time I go.
beautiful. beautiful museum, do not miss it. it is not big, it is only very interesting. Outside you can relax on armchairs looking at Paris on your foot.

Do not miss it!. This museum is a perfect experience to get in touch with impressionist painting specially the Monet´s.It has a great collection and the building offers natural light that changes all they long ,giving various and different colors and shades on the works of art.When you live walk through Jardin du Tulleries!Amazing day!

Wonderful. THe upstairs rooms house the Water Lilies by Monet, a great experience to see these large canvases all in one venue. The gallery itself well thought out for the display of these paintings. One problem we had was too many people constantly clicking photos, we found this so upsetting where ever we went in Paris galleries except the D'Orsay where they do not allow it.Downstairs collection was magnificent, a very comprehensive collection of paintings strongly supported by impressionists and post impressionists. I particularly loved the collection of Renoirs, Well worth the visit and you get to go on that ticket to the D'Orsay for free. 2 Galleries for one price.

Surprisingly fresh and open. When we visited the Musée de l'Orangerie in Paris, we were lucky because it was quite calm. You'll be surprised by the amount of light that shines through the museum. I just loved the gigantic works of Monet en you can admire them from different angles too! If you plan to visit this museum, try to go as early as possible so you can escape the big crowd.
Take a breath, take your time. Monet's water lilies are amazing. Truly an oasis of calm, a meditative experience. For art fans, as much (more?) of a must-see than the Sistine Chapel at the Vatican.

A small gem of a museum. This is not a large museum and it was a little crowded but we really enjoyed it.The water lillies are in their own room and everyone is encouraged to be quiet. There are places to sit and just enjoy. A friend that was with us put on her ipod and just enjoyed the lovely scene. Not far away in the gardens is an outdoor ice cream stand where they make the best ice cream cones with the ice cream shaped like roses. There are beautiful statues and bences to sit on. A perfect way to end a trip to Musee de l' Orangerie. We used the museum pass but there were no lines so that wasn't something you need to make entrance easier.
This place is a hidden gem. I really loved this gallery, a fantastic small collection of some amazing (I don't use this word often or lightly) art. Better than the Musee d'Orsay, which I also love.

the place worth seeing. A big relief after Louvre: small quiet place without crowds. Apart of Nenufars we liked very much a Paul Guillamme collection downstairs, really great one. We admired mostly big collection of Renoirs, also we discovered there a great expressionist: Chaim Soutine. All in all: the place worth seeing.
Lovely time for the entire family. My tween girls loved the art. Great 2 hours spent.

Certainly a highlight of my trip. This is well worth a visit. If you are a lover of the impressionists, in particular Monet, go see this. There are some amazing pieces of his work, large canvases line the walls. Tip - check out the museum passes available - not only can they save you money but they provide you with prepaid entry so you can effectively cut the cues as most places provide a separate entry or cue for those with the museum passhttp://en.parismuseumpass.com/ - these can be bought at most of the venues

Don't miss this gallery - it's superb.. This gallery was the highlight of our gallery visits in Paris this weekend (we also went to Musee D'Orsay and The Louvre). As it was less busy than the other two galleries we were able to view the fabulous Monet murals and the incredible private collection on the floor below in peace and quiet. The Monet murals were stunning and worth spending time with to appreciate the effect of the passing clouds/ bright sun through the glass roof. So glad we didn't miss this. (Do buy a 2 day Pass - we got straight to the front of each gallery queue. )

Good to see Monets Water Lillies. This gallery is conveniently situated near the Place de ConcordIts not a massive gallery and the queues aren't bad.If you like 19th century art and have an hour or two to kill give it a go

Great Gem of a Museum--Don't Pass This By. One of the great things about Paris is that you can keep going back, and never run out of places to go. This, being my fifth trip to Paris, still left plenty to see. I had never been to L'Orangie. My fiance had been there years ago, but never mentioned it on our past trips. This time around, it was on my priority list because I wanted to see the Monets. Nestled in the Jardins des Tuileries not too far from a beautiful lavender patch, are the steps leading to this great little museum. We were lucky, as the line was extremely small. The Monets did not dissappoint. However, the gallery in which his water lilly painting and the other Giverny paintings. The paintings are spectacular. The colors are so soothing and just pretty. Sitting on a bench to soak it in, you really can get the feeling of being in water. I swear it is almost like being in a painting acquarium. My only "ugh" moment was that there were too many people at this exhibit. I know, I know, I sound like a hypocrite because we didn't have a long line to wait on, but most of the people at the museum were crowded into this exhibit. Naturally, in all my selfishness--and the fact that I'm becoming French by osmosis, I grouchily wished everyone would have gone away and just left us with the paintings. Now THAT would have been a totally tranquil few moments! The paintings truly were a magnificant site and now going to Giverny is high on the priority list for the next trip. That being said, (sorry I rambled) the remainder of the museum's galleries were a fantastic surprise. We had no idea that L'Orangie housed so many beautiful Renoirs!! And ohhh..how beautiful they were. Renior's nudes are just breathtaking! Picasso, Soutine, and Cezanne were among the other artist's whose paintings graced the gallerie's walls. You don't need more than an hour to enjoy this small museum. It isn't overwhelming. It is observing art at a very nice pace.After your exit, you will still be in the mood for a nice stroll in the Jardins...stop at a cafe for a nice coffee or citron presse...do some serious people watching...sit back, close your eyes, and daydream about beautiful works of art that you just saw!Please don't pass this gem by...had I known about it a few years ago, I would have made this a "must see" on my first visit to Paris!Thank you for reading and enjoy the sights of Paris!

Delightful museum, small and exquisite. We've been to Paris about 6 times and for the first few times we did not know about the Musee l"Orangerie. Better late than never. The museum is small and you can see most everything in an hour or so. Terrific collection of Picassos, Monets and other great French artists. It is just across the Tuilleries from the Louvre and should not be missed. En route from the Louvre to the museum, pause to enjoy a gelato, sit on a bench, admire the outdoor statues and reflect on the countless millions of people who have done the same for centuries.

Take your time, put the camera to one side for a little while. Thoroughly enjoyed this experience. The only thing marring the tranquility and the beauty on Monet's gift was so so many camera clicks and so so many people not realising the "no flash" meant them. I sound grumpy...not at all. Worth just moving sowly through and looking close up and far away. And then going back through again with the camera!

Orangerie is worth a visit to Paris.. The museum, located in a garden in the heart of Paris, was built primarily to display Claude Monet's magnificent paintings, Nympheas, or water lilies and the structure was approved by him. The museum has recently been renovated. It has on display several other paintings of great masters, such as Renoir, Picasso, Mogliani, Van Gogh and others, but the experience of looking at the Lilies is a lifetime experience. Unforgettable.

Exceptional and unexpected.. We have been to Paris several times in the last several years, but only based on TA's reviews that we visited Musee de l'Orangerie this month, which is directly across the street from our hotel. Exceptional to say the least. A relative smaller museum compared to its next door neighbors, the Louvre and the Orsay, but totally serene and not crowded in the late afternoon, where we can observe the room sized Monet without obstructed view. We felt like it was a private exhibit. Definitely worth visiting.

Next time in Paris I'll go to Giverny for the day. You don' t have to be an art aficionado to thoroughly enjoy your visit to this museum. Be sure to purchase the audio guide and your reward will be greater! When you enter the two rooms of Monet's water lilies you will feel the awe and magnitude of this collection. After walking the circular path, sit down, rest, and continue to drink it all in. My reaction was, "Darn, wish we had done the Fat Tire Bike Tour of Giverny (where Monet painted The Nympheas) instead of the trip to Versailles" (the day before). Next time in Paris we'll do that! Also, came home and got out a very old art history book from college days!We bought the 2 day Museum Pass so we would be sure to have some cultural experiences while in Paris. It "makes" you see places you might not have visited.

One of the Finest. The museum is beautiful. Went on a Friday morning when they just opened and it was nice and peaceful. One would go for the rooms of Monet only but then their are renoirs, Cezanne etc. downstairs. The guidebook makes a lovely momento - they were very rude in the gift shop though. Go early and marvel at the Monet.

Oasis of beauty. To sit in such a peaceful setting and watch Monet's pantings is a really moving experience. It is very touching, soulful, meaningful.The museum's architecture is beautiful. The collection downstairs is also worth seeing. very good.

Beautiful display of Monet's Waterlilies. We went for free on the first Sunday of the month - the first floor display of Monet's was beautiful! The natural light and whiteness of walls emphasizes the painter's giftedness. There are benches in the middle of the room to sit and take it all in. Overall, the museum is small - we went through in an hour or less. Downstairs there are more impressionist /post impressionist paintings - Even though there were some paintings I enjoyed here, I don't think I would have appreciated paying full price to get in so am glad we went when it was free. Museum Pass is a good deal.

takes your breath away to sit in the oval rooms to view monet's water lilies. Such a pleasure to see the oval room monet paintings again after being away from them for 20 years!Buy a combined ticket with musee d'orsay to save yourslves waiting in line.

Don't miss the Monets!. Very few people visit the L'Orangerie museum even though it is covered by the Paris museum pass. They don't know about the 2 large oval rooms that are covered by 8 huge Monet paintings. My teenage niece who is an artist said, "I wish that I could spend the whole day here painting."

Amazing Museum. Wow. The trip might have been worth seeing those alone. I’m on the fence on that statement… but suffice it to say, I really enjoyed them. Magical. Two rooms of these pictures. They asked that you be quite in the rooms, which honestly felt like peoples natural reaction. They were very spell binding.Would recommend buying tickets before hand to any attraction you can in Paris. A place called FNAC (like a US Best Buy) sells them (at least the one near my hotel did) or most attractions have a website you can purchase thru.

A gem. L'Orangerie museum in Paris is a gem. It is small and has a room full of Monet's water lilies, a superb permanent collection of impressionist art donated by Jean Walter and Paul Guillimaume. Their current special exhibit of works by Gino Severini is well worth a visit and is on until July 25, 2011. Open everyday except Tuesday and certain holidays.

A must for Monet lovers. I used to think that Museum d'Orsay is the best place in Paris to see Monet's paintings. Now I realize that the Marmottan Monet Museum and the Orangerie are as good as, if not better than d'Orsay, to enjoy Monet's works. The Orangerie houses the masterpiece of Monet, the Nympheas, in two oval-shaped rooms. The Nympheas comprise eight hugh paintings, with 'Sunset', 'Clouds', 'Morning' and 'Green Reflections' in the first room, and 'Morning Willows', 'Willows on a Clear Morning', 'Reflection of Trees' and 'The Two Willows' in the second room. When I entered the first room, my immediate reaction was 'wow'! These masterpieces are just stunning and mesmerizing. Other works by Monet, and those by Renoir, Cezanne, Mattise and Picasso are also exhibited in the museum. Moreover, photography (without flash) is allowed in the museum. Orangerie is truly a gem not to be missed by Monet lovers. Orangerie is about 600 meters from d'Orsay. So one can visit both museums in one day. However, photography is not allowed in d'Orsay.

Loved the Orangerie!. So happy that I went, great museum, fabulous display of art, great shop to buy beautiful things.The Monet are so beautiful, the museum is very well appointed, located in a great setting A dream come true for me

If you love Monet- this is a must see!. If you love Monet- this is a must see! It might not hold as many of the famous artists/ paintings as Orsay does, but worth a visit. The line is often much shorter then Orsay (maybe 5 or ten people), and so it is easy to enter. There are a few rooms of water lilies and these alone are worth the visit. The paintings are the size of the entire room- breathtaking! Also, some of the other art featured is very impressive. There is some Picasso- all stages of his art- that is very fun to witness. It is a relatively small museum, but worth a visit. There are restrooms- very clean- and a great gift shop. Also, you can skip the lines and the admission with a museum pass. If we had more time I also would have stayed and watched the film on Monet’s water lilies- it looked very interesting!

Possibly the favorite museum we went to in Paris. I was really surprised with this museum.I knew what to expect with the water lilies - they were amazing and in 2 rooms! that was a surprise! Beautiful!But the collection of other paintings downstairs really surprised me. They were superb and some famous works you'll surely recognize by Picasso and other big names.Use the Paris Museum Pass - it is totally worth it!

Musee de l'Orangerie. If you have limited time in Paris and need a quick shot of culture this exquisite, romantic little gallery, in it's glorious setting by the Seine and Tuilieries Gardens, should be right at the top of your list. Monet's Water Lilies fill two stunning light filled rooms, and downstairs some truy iconic paintings by Renoir, Sisely, Cezanne, Picasso, Gaugin, Derain, Matisse and Modigliani...and right outside the front door, Rodin's 'The Kiss'.

Breath of Fresh Air. This was on our "maybe if we have time" list, when we stumbled upon it as we walked through Tuileries Gardens. We were hot and tired, and this was a perfect respite from a day of touring. Unfortunately, we did not have enough time to really appreciate this place. Monet's water lilies are there in a lovely, quiet room where one can sit, rest, reflect, meditate. Beautiful presentation of the water lilies and numerous other artworks. Very nice gift shop. In the lower level we discovered more pieces by some of the greats....Picasso, Renoir, Matisse and others. Just a wonderful place to visit and one we will always return to when in Paris. Put it on your "don't miss" list.

A sweet surprise. Monet's lilies are gorgeously displayed across two oval rooms designed specifically for them. Then we were thrilled to discover the museum had outstanding modern work that we had not seen -- Matisse, Renoir, Derain, Picasso and more. Do make this trip.

Simply Perfect.. I will never go to Paris without visiting The Orangerie.It is small, you only need an hour or so. But it is simply beautiful. The Monet's on view are simply stunning. Go there in the morning and then take a late train out to his gardens (Giverney) in the afternoon and you can walk round and picture where he sat to create such masterpieces.It is quite delightful.

What an Unexpected Treat !. This was was my favorite museum while visiting in Paris last week. Not only for the magical walls covered with Monet's water lily paintings, but also for it's wonderful collection of other Impressionist artwork on the lower level. As suggested here on TA, I went to this museum before the d'Orsay and bought the combination ticket. Doing this allowed to me to go to the shorter line at the d'Orsay however I still has an hr. wait there. Musee de l'Orangerie is a underappreciated gem in a city of museum options.

Amazing. This is a must see museum. Small and easy to navigate with one of the most beautiful collections of impressionist paintings I have ever seen. Better to go here than the Louvre if you have limited time.

really nice little museum. I enjoyed this little museum, even though I wasn't really sure what I was looking at because there are no English captions inside and there's very little information about it in English on the internet! Monet's huge waterlilly paintings were spectacular, and the little collection of other impressionist paintings was nice too. I wouldn't say this is a must-see if you've only got a day in Paris, but it's certainly worth seeing if you have a little more time, esp. since you can get a joint ticket for the Orsay while you're here, allowing you to skip the line there.

Truly a hidden gem that people seem to miss!. When I started asking friends or family what we should see when in Paris, not one person mentioned this museum. How is that possible?! I would say this was one of our favorite museums in the city. It's small and modest, but to see Monet's waterlilies in such a beautiful arrangement was worth the trip. It's not as expensive as some of the attractions, and you won't spend a whole day here, but you will leave feeling like the experience was worth it. Along with Monet, you'll see some of the work from Cezanne, Renoire, Matisse, Picasso, Rousseau, and many others. I would recommend this stop for any art lover.

Monet's Infinity Paintings are breathtaking...but bring your Museum Pass!!. Musee de l'Orangerie is centrally located on the bank of the Seine River in the old orangery of the Tuileries Palace on the Place de la Concorde in Paris, near the Concorde metro station. I feel that this gallery is the ideal museum to introduce art to children while in Paris. Unlike the Louvre, which is quite overwhelming and overcrowded, the Musee de l"Orangerie offers a smaller setting, seating and an overall pleasant and engaging environment. However, don't let the size fool ya! This museum offers a impressive collection of impressionist and post-impressionist paintings. It contains works by artists such as Paul Cézanne, Henri Matisse, Claude Monet, Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Rousseau and many others.In an Infinity style on the ground floor, there are circular rooms displaying beautiful cycles of Monet's water-lily paintings. These series of paintings are known as the Nympheas, and are simply amazing...a must do.Before you go, I would STRONGLY recommend investing in the Paris Museum Pass, the website is as follows;http://en.parismuseumpass.com/There are options of 2, 4 or 6 days. With this pass, one has access to over 60 Museums and most importantly...no waiting in lines which can be very, very long. Museums include the Oragerie, Louvre and Orsay museums...among many others.

Worth the trip by itself. L'Orangerie's presentation of Monet's lilies is the most emotional display of art I can imagine. The first room in round, took my breath away. Finding the second, brought tears to my eyes. Then, the small collection downstairs was grand, wonderful Cezanne, Matisse, Picasso, Rousseau...I might suggest taking in the downstairs first, and finishing upstairs. Not crowded, but might be the best thing to see in Paris. Don't miss this gem.

Worth a visit. Usually the orangerie is one of the museums that is left out if you stay in paris for a short time, but it's worth the visit because the museum is small and it doesn't take much to visit it.)Ou can go straight to the oval rooms to admire .onet's waterlilies _amazing_you'll never forget the emotion that these masterpieces emanate!it seems that the lilies move and the colours are outstandig! In less than two hours you can visit it at ease.

Early morning beauty. One of the most beautiful places to be in Paris. If you have to pick on museum to see choose this one. We went early in the morning and were one of the first people in and it was as tranquil and beautiful as sitting in Monet gardens. There aren't a lot of pieces in this Museum and that's a good thing. You aren't overwhelmed with masters and styles, oils and sculpture. Please go and if you have time pair this with a trip to Giverny, Monet's home. This two experiences together make them all the richer. When I have kids and my husband and I take them to Paris for the first time we will skip the Louvre and go straight to the L'Orangerie. It's just the right amount of exposure as to not overwhelm and the visit to his home will show them what a true master he was and will always be.

Good collection, but not exhaustive. As an impressionist art lover, this gallery was a must for me. I had the Paris Museum Pass (or what ever it's called) so can't comment on value for entry fee, but I'd be surprised if anyone felt cheated. As with most galleries and museums in Paris, captions for the works are in French and there is little literature available, so get an audio guide if you can. We visited on a weekday afternoon and were pleasantly surprised not to find excessive queues or groups of tourists. The gallery is comparatively small, and combined with the reasonable flow of visitors, it made quite a nice change to the usual throng of the Louver or D'Orsay, etc. My understanding is that the gallery is purpose built for Monet's Water Lilly collection, and as such they are quite moving, although I felt the D'Orsay actually held a better collection of Monet's early work.Although I did enjoy the collection and will certainly visit again, I did not leave feeling awed, inspired or particularly enlightened. In some ways, this felt more like an exhibition, rather than permanent collection, perhaps partially because of the lack information (purely my own fault for not speaking ONE word of French) and partially because the collections (mostly Renoir, Gauguin and Cezanne) felt like the left-overs after the bigger and more prestigious galleries had their pick. Having said that, these paintings are still invaluable and worth a visit, but perhaps only for the more eager art enthusiasts than as a top tourist necessity.

If you only have time for one art gallery, this is the one.. Immerse yourself in Monet's water lillies then go to the floor below and complete the experience with examples of the best of impressionist and post-impressionist art. A delight for all art lovers.Tip; visit this art gallery in the morning and buy the joint ticket with the Musee D'Orsay then bypass the afternoon queues for the Musee D'Orsay.

Gorgeous collection. This was a tick off my bucket list as I have always wanted to see Monet's water lillies in the flesh so to speak. When I recall my trip to others it is surprising to see how many people do not know that they are painted onto the walls. I enjoyed trying to figure out which one was my favourite.The permanent collection downstairs was a great example of impressionist work and be sure not to miss Rodin's sculpture 'The Kss' just outside the front of the building!

A great 2 museums for the price of 1 start here. Some people really like art - and now you can say you have seen itThis was specifically built for Monet's lilies You've seen them on postcards, in books, and on a million prints at Wal-Mart.But you've never seen them life size and in living colour.If you are into art you will lose yourself here for the day. If not you will be on your way across the Seine to the Musee D'Orsay where you can bypass the crowds and go in your own express entrance.Buy the 2 for 1 ticket here and you get entrance to the other without waiting in line.

I love coming here, every time.. Every time I visit l'Orangerie, it confirms that this is by and large my favourite museum in Paris. I've always come early in the morning, which means that the museum is quasi-deserted. As I hold a student card, entrance is free, which is another nice touch. The moment I get my ticket, I go straight for Monet's "Nympheas", which are displayed in two large rooms under soft light, as the artist had intended them to be seen.
