The space they are kept in is large and peaceful, which allows you to be immersed in the splendor of the paintings. I usually spend (and encourage you to do the same) around forty-five minutes in the Nympheas area, because it is worth it!Afterwards, you can head downstairs to see some more great artwork, from Cézanne to Picasso. It is downstairs that I can think of the only negative aspect of the museum, as the Cézanne/Renoir works are displayed in a fairly narrow corridor, which means that one cannot stand back and appreciate the works in their fullest. Nevertheless, the collection downstairs is impressive, to say the least. Moreover, the temporary exhibitions are always of an excellent standard and definitely worth your while.What more can I say? I can only suggest that you come to l'Orangerie and discover this great museum for yourself!

Find the time to see this museum!. The Water Lillies rooms were breathtaking. I could have stayed there all day; it was such a calm and beautiful place. The museum was not as crowded as the larger museums, and has a terriffic collection of works. I'm so glad we set time aside to see this museum!
wonderful. UAU. monet has done a great and beautiful paintings. it worth the visit. peace and silence are rare to find in museums these days.

Wonderful museum. This was my favorite museum in Paris. It is in a lovely location and has a wonderful collection. The rooms housing Monet's Nympheas were incredible. This is a smaller facility that a lot of people miss, but it is a "do not miss," in my opinion.

Why haven't I been there before?. Having already visited the Musee D'Orsay and the Louvre (several times), we were looking for something a little different and the Musee de l'Orangerie appeared to fit the bill.It was fabulous! The Monet’s Nympheaus was absolutely stunning – and displayed in such a unique and original way. The original building was renovated to house the large, beautiful panels and they are displayed in direct, but diffused light, as intended by Monet. They truly do take your breath away.On the lower floor, there is a delightful collection of impressionist and post-impressionst paintings – some Cezanne, Renoir, Monet, Picasso, Gauguin and others - a really impressive collection actually. There is even a Sisley (or two).This is a really very lovely museum and well worth a visit – can’t rate it highly enough.

Wonderful experience - recommend highly. This is my favorite museum in Paris. Small enough to tour completely in 90 minutes or so but packed to the roof with Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and a smattering of later works. The Monet water lillies are just as great as you would expect and the fact that they were one of his final works makes them even more special. If you love Impressionist art and have limited time in Paris I would actually choose this over the Musee Orsay. It is a much smaller collection but top quality and a great experience.

Beautiful small museum. We ended up here somewhat by accident when we had more time in our schedule than we thought. Thank goodness! Musee d'Orsay is a bit of a disappointment because of the renovation work. This is wonderful, small museum. While people go for the water lillies, please stay and check out the rest of the works. Fewer crowds and a smaller (but terrific) collection made this a very enjoyable visit for my 11-year-old who was put off by the crowds in the bigger museums. It's location in the Tuileries Gardens is great also. What a delightful walk to the Metro stop!

A wonderful way to enjoy Impressionism. Nothing could have prepared me for Musée de l'Orangerie. We were tired when we went, but it's so absolutely stunning that we both felt sad when we thought we'd seen it all (we hadn't, the downstairs is amazing). For me, it was the perfect short introduction to Impressionism and made all the difference in how I approached the D'Orsay. We had been in the Louvre all day, and I thought I was arted out, truthfully, then the joy that is Monet's Waterlilies...what an amazing place.There were children and old people, and lots of French people. People treated it as a sacred space. We tried to take pictures (no way to capture it). It's soothing, has plenty of seating for we weary older travelers, and is a not to be missed part of the Paris experience. Afterwards, we just sat outside in the Gardens and marveled - of course at Monet and his vision, but also at the other Impressionists collected in the basement. It helped me realize why the Louvre had to have a cut-off point timewise or...it would be just stuffed too full of art. Some of the earliest known paintings are found in France, of course, and there's something about Monet and the presentation in the L'Orangerie (I don't want to say too much - it's just best to go and see it yourself) that provides a look back into the reasons why people paint, and how art is universal and why we love art.It is on the Paris Museum Pass. It does not take hours to see and is a perfect museum for children. There's lots of great curators' remarks (although I believe they may have been in French) and an English guided tour twice a week (Mondays and Thursdays at 2:30 pm) if you're the tour-wanting kind of person (although I believe the museum totally reveals itself to all who visit).Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Rousseau, Matisse, Derain, Modigliani, Soutine, Utrillo and Laurencin as well as others are all represented there. Before our trips to Paris, I think I was only marginally an art lover - and L'Orangerie may be the place where I really saw the light. It's so hard to compare museums, though - but this is one of Paris's must-sees.

Brilliant presentation for Monet's "Water Lilies". We found our way to this museum after walking through the Tuileries Gardens. The bottom floor has a nice collection of impressionist paintings by different artists. The real attraction is the top floor where several of Monet's "Water Lilies" can be found presented in two oval rooms. They have benches in the middle so one can sit with the paintings surrounding you. This is perhaps the most effective presentation of artwork I've seen.

A must see for Monet lovers. This museum is simply wonderful. The collection is small enough to take in and enjoy slowly without the exhaustion of the Louvre, but it includes an ample range of Impressionist artists' works. You can also take pictures (no flash!), which is not permitted at the Musee d'Orsay. The pinnacle of the museum, though, is the two room Monet exhibit of "Surround-Art," two oval rooms with Monet's huge water lily paintings surrounding you. This museum also opens a bit earlier than most of the others. We got there at opening time, and walked right in.

Have to pay extra with museum pass. This museum was nice. Lots of Monet and Renoir, which I was pleased with as I am a fan of both. Unfortunately however, despite paying 64€ for a museum pass, I had to pay an additional 1,50€. No, 1,50€ is not a lot, but it is a bit annoying after paying a ton of money for a museum pass. Also, despite the museum pass website stating that you wouldn't have to wait in any queues/lines, I had to wait in a line outside (there were two lines - one was for people with a pass and one was for people without a pass) and inside (to pay the additional 1,50€).Museum is quite small, but it was nice as I had already been to the Louvre and Musee d'orsay that day.Hard to get a nice view of water lillies as many people are sitting/standing around.Rodin's "The Kiss" is outside.

Loved...loved...loved this museum.. Spent ten days in Paris in May and got an extra day due to a cancelled flight, and thank goodness, because I was able to spend my last day in this museum. Monet's waterlillies alone are worth the trip - mesmerizing!!!

Don't miss this gem of a museum. Monet's water lillies are amazing. Sitting in the middle of the room, totally surrounded by his art, feeling as if you are in his gardens at Giverny, it's a totally awesome and reinvigorating experience. We went there the day after we visited his house/garden at Giverny (only a short train ride away) making this museum the perfect conclusion to our two-day outing. The Orangerie houses wonderful artwork on the bottom floor too, but I'll never forget the oval rooms with the Lillies.

Must see in Paris if you love Monet. We absolutely loved this Museum and the magnificent waterlily paintings encircling the floors of this musuem. Exquisite! Do make the the effort to see this - it is just at the end of the Tuillerie Gardens, so easy to add to your schedule - it does not take a long time.

Beautiful art, but not so great service... We loved the art at the Orangerie. It was absolutely beautiful and we could not ask for better. However, we found the staff there to be a bit cold and un-friendly. We really wanted to know about the art there, and asked one or two questions that were completely ignored by the people working there. We loved the location right by the water, and the tranquility of the building. With a bit more friendliness, it would have been perfect!

breathtaking and informative. Just spent the day at the museum. I came away with a real feeling of insight into Monet and a better appreciation of his work. The museum is beautiful and I loved the special exhibit about the artist's children and how they felt about having to pose for their parents . Monet"s work was lush, beautiful and his story is inspiring.

Very charmy small museum : ). This is a small but lovely museum. Of course the high-light is Monet's Nympheas, worthing the visit their selves. But there is a collection with paintings of Cézanne, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse, Modigliani, Utrillo and other important artists too.I used my Paris Museum Pass to enter, but if I remember correct, entrance fee is 7.50 euros (adult ticket). I visited end of November 2009. Unfortunately an audioguide costs 5 euros, I think it shouldn't cost extra, or been something like 2-3 euros would be more reasonable . But anyway, I don't regrett going in this place. At least when I visited, it wasn't very busy,so I had time to enjoy the paintings without feeling rushed to move on, as it often happens to larger Paris museums. Location is very handy to combin a visit in Orangerie with a walk on lovely Jardin des Tuileries, or a walk to Champs Elysees. or a visit to the Louvres. Place Concorde is literary a step away,as a metro station is. Very handy! I would recommend this museum to anyone with the slightest interest on paintings!

A little gem of a museum, not to be missed!. After fighting through the crowds of the Louvre, the Orangerie was a welcome sight (and a relaxing stroll through the Tuileries Garden). Positively tranquil in comparison, this museum boasts giant panels of Monet's "Water Lilies." Downstairs is a beautiful collection from other artists, including Renoir, Matisse and Picasso. If you're in Paris, you must spend an hour or two at the Orangerie!

The waterlily collection of Monet is quite stunningly beautiful.. Almost spiritual and very calming if you want to get away from the frenetic tourism of Paris.Tucked away in the Jardin des Tuileries an hour or two will take you around this attraction.Well worth a visit.

Do-able museum w lots of famous artists. This is a very nice museum because it is on the smaller size, but still has many famous artists, including Monet, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse. It is in the Tuilleres Gardens and covered by a museum pass so it is worth a stop if you are there anyways.

Excellent Museum of Monet, Renoir & Picasso to name a few.... My wife and I really enjoyed this museum, the display of Monet's Water Lilies is worth the price of admission. This main exhibit in within two large ellipliptical shaped rooms on the first floor and here you are literally surrounded by his work. Sitting on the bench in the middle of the room is a great way to enjoy the water lilies.The rest of the museum is on the floor below and very good although not large in size. You can spend an hour and half to see the entire museum. The audio guide is 5 euros and tells you quite a bit of background on key paintings. The gift shop is very well stocked wtih a large selection of poster prints.

Worth a trip. This museum is worth a stop. It was walking distance from my hotel so I was able to squeeze it in the morning before check-out. Bonus feature is Rodin sculpture in front. The advertised attraction is Monet's waterlilies and they are amazing, but the draw for me was the collection downstairs. Such a mixture! Renoir, Cezanne, Picasso, Matisse and Modigliani. This is one of the many museums on the Museum Pass list.
Well worth a little time. Great little museum for impressionist lovers that can be done in an hour and is in great location.

Must see for Monet lovers!!!. I stumbled upon this museum accidentally. It is at the end of the Jardin Tulleries near where the massive pool is just in front of the Obelisque de Louxor. Go up the ramp on the south side and make a left. They make you check in your backpack/bag (free). It is absolutely fantastic for monet lovers. His massive water lilies were hung along the walls of two large rooms. There were some impressive works downstairs too. It's a small quiet, museum and gives you just the right amount of things to see. Depending on how long you end up gazing at the Monet's for.... you can probably allocate 1 to 1.5 hrs for this musuem... but it will be one of the best museums in Paris that you can visit.

Overlooked gem for those who like impressionism. This art museum is a great, quick escape for those visiting the Tuileries/Louvre/Place de Concorde area and is a must-see for those who appreciate Impressionist art. The whole museum can easily be explored in about an hour, unless you decide to linger in the spacious, tranquil, rounded rooms that house Monet's amazing Nymphéas paintings. The Nymphéas collection consists of his famous, panoramic water lily scenes. Sitting on the benches in the middle of the naturally lit galleries, it's easy to get lost in the abstract, emotive brushstrokes that make up the massive, yet serene landscapes. The lower level of the museum has more interesting impressionist and post-impressionist works on display that's worth exploring.

It was OK. I would agree with Idra. We visited this past April and it was rather uninspiring. I am a museum professional and unfortunately they take a rather mundane art museum approach to labeling the collection. It is not very creative. The way finding is awful and we completely missed the video. In fact, we did not know it existed until I read the review and we went through the whole place. I am a huge Monet fan so the paintings were awesome, but I would have liked more information about who, what, when and why. The guidebooks gave me more information than the museum did about why the work was there. This was our 4th trip to Paris and we thought it was about time to see those museums that are not the usual one. I am glad we did, just wish I had been more enlightened and inspired by the interpretation. The staff did nothing to help in making sure that we knew there were other interpretive materials (i.e. the video or audio guide) available when we bought our tickets or entered the gallery spaces. We did not experience any crowds and we did not get there until 3:00ish on a beautiful, sunny spring day in Paris. I would recommend it, but don't go out of your way.

Interesting but let down by a lack of direction for visitors... I shall explain.. Whilst I am not mad on Monet I am interested in his work so I purchased a joint passport ticket for the Orangerie along with the d'Orsay. This had the advantage of skipping the line at the Orangerie. Bonus.I went in and headed straight for the Monets along with everyone else. What do you see? Really big Monets. Large. Massively so. Beautiful, yes... but as someone not very familiar with the 'point' of these particular works I meandered around and then went on.And here's the thing. I am an obsessive map reader, folloer of signs and so on and I had missed this entirely when I arrived. There is a movie available. It's on downstairs. Look for a door into a dark room. Please do look for it as it's a very, *very* good documentary with English subtitles about these particular works. Why they were painted. The stage of Monet's life and mind at the time. What they represent. Why they are laid out as they are. How they came to be in that particular building. What they meant to Monet and to post-war France.Fascinating and it completely contextualised the paintings themselves. I immediately rushed back upstairs to look at them with my new found knowledge! What do I find? It's 5.50pm so the lights are being turned off. *le sigh* I persisted in going into the darkened room regardless because now they *meant* so much more.Please, please... if you don't know their story make sure you see the video. It helped me so much.I did not see much of the rest of the collection as I was attempting to get back to the Monets, however the portrate of Chanel was a favourite find of my trip.Shop: Stuffed with Monet tat. Monet heaven for shoppers.Facilities: Great cloakroom, poor leaflets/interpretation, super toilets.
I do not care for Monet. I was bored. Do this on your 10th visit to Paris.

Excellent Museum for Monet Lovers!!. I was very excited to see Monet's Water Lilies exhibit, once there I was not disappointed. The other exhibits were also excellent. This museum is a MUST on your trip to Paris. Get there early, as soon as it opens, less people.Rent the Audio Guide as well, it gives good information on what you are viewing.

My favourite museum in Paris. We went to all the big name museums in Paris, but this small museum tucked away next to the Place de la Concorde was my favourite. It is small, and the crowds that we encountered in all the other museums were non existent. The impressionist art here is amazing and you don't feel overwhelmed by the amount of it. The water lillies are beautifully displayed, in round and oval rooms flooded with natural light and the atmosphere is so serene. It took us less than an hour to appreciate the whole gallery.I highly recommend this gallerey - especially to those people who are not necessarily art experts.

a small . beautiful museum inside the tulleries jardin. i read about it in new york times-journal-an exellent review-also my collegues advised me to visit- in fact this small,, beautiful museum of impressionistes-easy to visit-i absorbed everything and really liked to learn about other less known painters- my tip- buy tickets before -by internet- you spend a little more but you save time..

Must see. This is a must see --- for the Waterlilies alone. You can get through this entire museum in about an hour. You may need more time if you want to linger in the Waterlilies rooms as I did. These are absolutely captivating. Read Rick Steve's Paris book about this museum beforem, during, and after your tour for the fullest understanding of what the musuem is all about.
Short on time?. Come here. Has top impressionist names and it won't take you hours to see them.

Beautiful little museum just re-opened. In relation to all the huge museums here, you can easily walk through and enjoy this one. Especially if you are a fan of Impressionists. The main floor is large watercolor murals and the downstairs has other smaller and regular paintings. You can purchase an audio tour if you like. Very nice-don't miss!

Jaw dropping. I recently returned from 10 days in London and Paris and although my son and I saw many amazing sites this smaller yet fantastic museum with the panorama of Monets Water Lillies was jaw dropping. I literally gasped at the magnificence and sheer size of these paintings. Not to be missed -

A Real Gem. We used our museum passes to check out this wonderful, little museum. The setting for the "Waterlillies" was perfect. It was not too crowded on a Wednesday afternoon in May 2007. The art displayed downstairs was also a treat to see. It was a great experience and should be right up there with Musee d'Orsay as a must see.

A Must See. We visited this museum on New Years Day - as it was one of the few museum open that day and on our 'must see' list this trip. Opening after and extensive remodel - the museum is breathtaking. The Monet water lillies are simply a must to see in the spaces new design using natural lighting. The remaining collection from Picasso, Cezzane, Renior, and Modligiani (to name a few) is very pleasant - though some controversay in the news over the 'starkness' of the rooms with their concrete walls. We did not find it distracting or too cold of a space. I would recommend the audio guide - at 5 Euros - it did enhance the experience for us. You can easily spend 2 hours viewing the collections. The current temporary exhibit - a recreation of the a 1934 Paris exhibit at the Orangerie -bringing together for the first time these pieces of art - was impressive. It included works by Georges de la Tour - wonderful! Tip: Musee Pass helps you skip the line and quickly enter this museum. Otherwise, expect long lines since its reopening.

had to queue. Arrived at about 1pm on a Monday afternoon in late October and waited outside for twenty or so minutes. Visitors who had pre-booked tickets on the internet did not have to queue at all. It was worth the wait as the waterlilies were stunning.
It is open again. The Orangerie is now open. Waterlilies panaroma were awesome! Great setting to see this work of art. The rest of the museum is great too.

Still Closed. When I visited in May 2005 the opening date had been amended to 2006. They keep pasting a new opening date over the old one. But there are signs of work being carried out. We just have to be patient.
